I passed at Greenleaf six happy, quiet years. I never saw in any face there, thank heaven, on my birthday, that it would have been better if I had never been born. When the day came round, it brought me so many tokens of affectionate remembrance that my room was beautiful with them from New Year’s Day to Christmas.
我在绿叶度过了快乐、平静的六年。感谢上帝，在我生日那天，我从没有从任何人的脸上看到，如果我从未出生过会更好。当这一天到来时，它给我带来了许多深情的回忆，从元旦到圣诞节，我的房间里都充满了它们。

In those six years I had never been away except on visits at holiday time in the neighbourhood. After the first six months or so I had taken Miss Donny’s advice in reference to the propriety of writing to Mr. Kenge to say that I was happy and grateful, and with her approval I had written such a letter. I had received a formal answer acknowledging its receipt and saying, ‘We note the contents thereof, which shall be duly communicated to our client.’ After that I sometimes heard Miss Donny and her sister mention how regular my accounts were paid, and about twice a year I ventured to write a similar letter. I always received by return of post exactly the same answer in the same round hand, with the signature of Kenge and Carboy in another writing, which I supposed to be Mr. Kenge’s.
在那六年里，除了节假日去附近拜访外，我从未离开过。大约头六个月后，我采纳了唐尼小姐的建议，即写信给肯格先生表达我的高兴和感激之情是恰当的，在她的同意下，我写了这样一封信。我收到了一份正式的答复，确认收到了它，并说：“我们记下其中的内容，并将及时传达给我们的客户。”此后，我有时听到唐尼小姐和她的妹妹提到我的帐户付款是如何定期的，大约两次有一年我冒险写了一封类似的信。我收到的回信总是用同一笔圆字写着完全相同的答案，上面有肯格和卡博伊的签名，我认为那是肯格先生的。

It seems so curious to me to be obliged to write all this about myself! As if this narrative were the narrative of MY life! But my little body will soon fall into the background now.
对我来说，不得不写下所有关于我自己的事情真是太奇怪了！仿佛这个故事就是我一生的故事！但我小小的身体很快就会退到幕后。

Six quiet years (I find I am saying it for the second time) I had passed at Greenleaf, seeing in those around me, as it might be in a looking-glass, every stage of my own growth and change there, when, one November morning, I received this letter. I omit the date.
我在格林利夫度过了安静的六年（我发现我是第二次这么说），在我周围的人身上，就像在镜子里一样，看到我自己成长和变化的每一个阶段，当，十一月的早晨，我收到了这封信。我省略了日期。

Old Square, Lincoln’s Inn
老广场，林肯旅馆

Madam,
女士，

Jarndyce and Jarndyce
贾迪斯和贾迪斯

Our clt Mr. Jarndyce being abt to rece into his house, under an Order of the Ct of Chy, a Ward of the Ct in this cause, for whom he wishes to secure an elgble compn, directs us to inform you that he will be glad of your serces in the afsd capacity.
我们的 CLT Jarndyce 先生根据 Chy 区的命令，即将回到他的家中，他希望为他获得一份 elgble compn，指示我们通知您，他将很高兴您以 afsd 的身份提供服务。

We have arrngd for your being forded, carriage free, pr eight o’clock coach from Reading, on Monday morning next, to White Horse Cellar, Piccadilly, London, where one of our clks will be in waiting to convey you to our offe as above.
我们已经为您安排了下周一早上八点钟从雷丁出发的无马车涉渡巴士，前往伦敦皮卡迪利大街的白马酒窖，我们的一名乘客将在那里等候，将您送至我们的工作地点。多于。

We are, Madam, Your obedt Servts,
女士，我们是您的忠实仆人，

Kenge and Carboy
肯格和卡博伊

Miss Esther Summerson
埃丝特·萨默森小姐

Oh, never, never, never shall I forget the emotion this letter caused in the house! It was so tender in them to care so much for me, it was so gracious in that father who had not forgotten me to have made my orphan way so smooth and easy and to have inclined so many youthful natures towards me, that I could hardly bear it. Not that I would have had them less sorry—I am afraid not; but the pleasure of it, and the pain of it, and the pride and joy of it, and the humble regret of it were so blended that my heart seemed almost breaking while it was full of rapture.
哦，我永远、永远、永远不会忘记这封信在家里引起的激动！他们如此温柔地关心我，父亲如此仁慈，他没有忘记我，使我的孤儿之路如此顺利和轻松，并让许多年轻的天性向我倾斜，我几乎不能忍受。这并不是说我会让他们少些遗憾——恐怕不会；但它的快乐、它的痛苦、它的骄傲和喜悦、它的谦卑的遗憾是如此地混合在一起，我的心在狂喜之中几乎要破碎了。

The letter gave me only five days’ notice of my removal. When every minute added to the proofs of love and kindness that were given me in those five days, and when at last the morning came and when they took me through all the rooms that I might see them for the last time, and when some cried, ‘Esther, dear, say good-bye to me here at my bedside, where you first spoke so kindly to me!’ and when others asked me only to write their names, ‘With Esther’s love,’ and when they all surrounded me with their parting presents and clung to me weeping and cried, ‘What shall we do when dear, dear Esther’s gone!’ and when I tried to tell them how forbearing and how good they had all been to me and how I blessed and thanked them every one, what a heart I had!
这封信只提前五天通知我我将被解雇。当每一分钟都增加了那五天里给予我的爱和善意的证据时，当早晨终于到来时，当他们带我穿过所有房间以便我最后一次见到他们时，当有些人哭泣时“埃丝特，亲爱的，在我的床边向我告别，你第一次对我如此友善地说话！”当其他人只要求我写下他们的名字时，“以埃丝特的爱”，当他们都围着我时带着他们的离别礼物，紧紧地抱住我，哭泣着喊道：“亲爱的、亲爱的埃丝特走了，我们该怎么办！”当我试图告诉他们他们对我是多么宽容和多么好，以及我如何祝福和感谢他们时每个人，我都有一颗多么大的心啊！

And when the two Miss Donnys grieved as much to part with me as the least among them, and when the maids said, ‘Bless you, miss, wherever you go!’ and when the ugly lame old gardener, who I thought had hardly noticed me in all those years, came panting after the coach to give me a little nosegay of geraniums and told me I had been the light of his eyes—indeed the old man said so!— what a heart I had then!
当两个唐尼斯小姐像她们中最小的一个一样悲伤地与我分离时，当女仆们说：“祝福你，小姐，无论你去哪里！”当那个丑陋的跛脚老园丁（我以为他几乎没有注意到）时那些年，我气喘吁吁地跟在教练后面，给了我一束天竺葵，并告诉我，我一直是他眼中的光——老人确实这么说！——那时我的心是多么的好啊！

And could I help it if with all this, and the coming to the little school, and the unexpected sight of the poor children outside waving their hats and bonnets to me, and of a grey-haired gentleman and lady whose daughter I had helped to teach and at whose house I had visited (who were said to be the proudest people in all that country), caring for nothing but calling out, ‘Good-bye, Esther. May you be very happy!’—could I help it if I was quite bowed down in the coach by myself and said ‘Oh, I am so thankful, I am so thankful!’ many times over!
面对这一切，来到这所小学校，意外地看到外面可怜的孩子们向我挥舞着帽子和软帽，还有一位白发的绅士和女士，我曾帮助他们的女儿我在他的家里教书，拜访过他们（据说他们是这个国家最骄傲的人），除了大声喊道“再见，埃丝特”之外，什么都不关心。祝你幸福！”——如果我一个人在车厢里跪下，多次说“哦，我太感谢了，我太感谢了！”，我能不能控制住呢！

But of course I soon considered that I must not take tears where I was going after all that had been done for me. Therefore, of course, I made myself sob less and persuaded myself to be quiet by saying very often, ‘Esther, now you really must! This WILL NOT do!’ I cheered myself up pretty well at last, though I am afraid I was longer about it than I ought to have been; and when I had cooled my eyes with lavender water, it was time to watch for London.
但当然，我很快就考虑到，在为我所做的一切之后，我不能在我要去的地方流泪。因此，当然，我经常说：‘以斯帖，现在你真的必须这么做了，以此来让自己少抽泣，并说服自己保持安静。这不行！”我终于给自己打气了，尽管我担心我说得比我应该说的要长。当我用薰衣草水冷却眼睛后，就到了眺望伦敦的时候了。

I was quite persuaded that we were there when we were ten miles off, and when we really were there, that we should never get there. However, when we began to jolt upon a stone pavement, and particularly when every other conveyance seemed to be running into us, and we seemed to be running into every other conveyance, I began to believe that we really were approaching the end of our journey. Very soon afterwards we stopped.
我坚信，当我们距离十英里远时，我们就在那里，而当我们真正在那里时，我们永远不应该到达那里。然而，当我们开始在石头路面上颠簸时，特别是当其他所有交通工具似乎都在撞上我们时，而我们似乎也正在撞上所有其他交通工具时，我开始相信我们真的正在接近旅程的终点。很快我们就停了下来。

A young gentleman who had inked himself by accident addressed me from the pavement and said, ‘I am from Kenge and Carboy’s, miss, of Lincoln’s Inn.’
一位年轻的绅士不小心在身上沾了墨水，他在人行道上对我说道：“我来自林肯律师学院的肯格和卡博伊小姐。”

‘If you please, sir,’ said I.
“如果您愿意的话，先生，”我说道。

He was very obliging, and as he handed me into a fly after superintending the removal of my boxes, I asked him whether there was a great fire anywhere? For the streets were so full of dense brown smoke that scarcely anything was to be seen.
他非常乐于助人，当他监督我搬走箱子后把我交给苍蝇时，我问他是否有地方发生大火？因为街道上充满了浓浓的棕色烟雾，几乎什么也看不见。

‘Oh, dear no, miss,’ he said. ‘This is a London particular.’
“哦，亲爱的，不，小姐，”他说。 “这是伦敦的特色。”

I had never heard of such a thing.
我从来没有听说过这样的事情。

‘A fog, miss,’ said the young gentleman.
“有雾，小姐，”年轻的绅士说道。

‘Oh, indeed!’ said I.
“哦，确实如此！”我说道。

We drove slowly through the dirtiest and darkest streets that ever were seen in the world (I thought) and in such a distracting state of confusion that I wondered how the people kept their senses, until we passed into sudden quietude under an old gateway and drove on through a silent square until we came to an odd nook in a corner, where there was an entrance up a steep, broad flight of stairs, like an entrance to a church. And there really was a churchyard outside under some cloisters, for I saw the gravestones from the staircase window.
我们缓慢地驶过世界上最肮脏、最黑暗的街道（我想），在一种令人分心的混乱状态中，我想知道人们是如何保持理智的，直到我们在一个古老的大门下突然陷入安静，开车穿过一个寂静的广场，直到我们来到一个角落里的一个奇怪的角落，那里有一个入口，通往陡峭而宽阔的楼梯，就像教堂的入口一样。外面的一些回廊下面确实有一个教堂墓地，因为我从楼梯的窗户看到了墓碑。

This was Kenge and Carboy’s. The young gentleman showed me through an outer office into Mr. Kenge’s room—there was no one in it—and politely put an arm-chair for me by the fire. He then called my attention to a little looking-glass hanging from a nail on one side of the chimney-piece.
这是 Kenge 和 Carboy 的。这位年轻的绅士带我穿过外面的办公室，进入肯格先生的房间——里面没有人——并礼貌地在火边为我放了一张扶手椅。然后他让我注意烟囱一侧的钉子上挂着的一个小镜子。

‘In case you should wish to look at yourself, miss, after the journey, as you’re going before the Chancellor. Not that it’s requisite, I am sure,’ said the young gentleman civilly.
“如果您想看看自己，小姐，在旅途结束后，您将前往总理府。我确信这并不是必需的。”年轻的绅士礼貌地说。

‘Going before the Chancellor?’ I said, startled for a moment.
“去见财政大臣？”我惊讶地说。

‘Only a matter of form, miss,’ returned the young gentleman. ‘Mr. Kenge is in court now. He left his compliments, and would you partake of some refreshment’—there were biscuits and a decanter of wine on a small table—‘and look over the paper,’ which the young gentleman gave me as he spoke. He then stirred the fire and left me.
“只是形式问题，小姐，”年轻绅士回答道。 '先生。肯格现在出庭。他留下了他的致意，你能吃点点心吗？”——小桌子上有饼干和一瓶酒——“看看报纸，”年轻的绅士一边说话，一边递给我。然后他搅动了火，就离开了我。

Everything was so strange—the stranger from its being night in the day-time, the candles burning with a white flame, and looking raw and cold—that I read the words in the newspaper without knowing what they meant and found myself reading the same words repeatedly. As it was of no use going on in that way, I put the paper down, took a peep at my bonnet in the glass to see if it was neat, and looked at the room, which was not half lighted, and at the shabby, dusty tables, and at the piles of writings, and at a bookcase full of the most inexpressive-looking books that ever had anything to say for themselves. Then I went on, thinking, thinking, thinking; and the fire went on, burning, burning, burning; and the candles went on flickering and guttering, and there were no snuffers—until the young gentleman by and by brought a very dirty pair—for two hours.
一切都是那么陌生——白天是夜晚，蜡烛燃烧着白色的火焰，看起来又冷又冷——我读着报纸上的文字，却不知道它们的意思，发现自己读着同样的内容反复的话。这样下去是没有用的，我把报纸放下，从玻璃里看了一眼我的帽子是否整洁，又看了看房间里没有半点光亮，又看了看破旧的房间。布满灰尘的桌子，成堆的著作，还有一个书柜，里面装满了看起来最缺乏表达力的书籍，但它们本身却没什么可说的。然后我继续思考，思考，思考；火继续燃烧，燃烧，燃烧；蜡烛继续闪烁、熄灭，也没有蜡烛——直到那位年轻的绅士不久带来了一把非常脏的蜡烛——持续了两个小时。

At last Mr. Kenge came. HE was not altered, but he was surprised to see how altered I was and appeared quite pleased. ‘As you are going to be the companion of the young lady who is now in the Chancellor’s private room, Miss Summerson,’ he said, ‘we thought it well that you should be in attendance also. You will not be discomposed by the Lord Chancellor, I dare say?’
肯格先生终于来了。他没有改变，但他很惊讶地看到我的改变如此之大，并且显得很高兴。 “由于您将成为现在在财政大臣私人房间里的萨默森小姐的伴侣，”他说，“我们认为您也应该出席。”我敢说，大法官不会让你感到不安吧？

‘No, sir,’ I said, ‘I don’t think I shall,’ really not seeing on consideration why I should be.
“不，先生，”我说，“我想我不会。”我真的没有考虑过为什么我应该这样做。

So Mr. Kenge gave me his arm and we went round the corner, under a colonnade, and in at a side door. And so we came, along a passage, into a comfortable sort of room where a young lady and a young gentleman were standing near a great, loud-roaring fire. A screen was interposed between them and it, and they were leaning on the screen, talking.
于是肯格先生伸出了手臂，我们绕过拐角，从柱廊下，从侧门进去。于是我们沿着一条通道来到一间舒适的房间，一位年轻的女士和一位年轻的绅士站在熊熊燃烧的大火旁边。他们和它之间有一个屏幕，他们靠在屏幕上说话。

They both looked up when I came in, and I saw in the young lady, with the fire shining upon her, such a beautiful girl! With such rich golden hair, such soft blue eyes, and such a bright, innocent, trusting face!
当我进来的时候，他们都抬起头来，我看到那位年轻的女士，火光照射在她身上，是一个多么美丽的女孩啊！有着如此浓密的金色头发，如此柔和的蓝眼睛，以及如此明亮、天真、信任的脸！

‘Miss Ada,’ said Mr. Kenge, ‘this is Miss Summerson.’
“艾达小姐，”肯吉先生说，“这是萨默森小姐。”

She came to meet me with a smile of welcome and her hand extended, but seemed to change her mind in a moment and kissed me. In short, she had such a natural, captivating, winning manner that in a few minutes we were sitting in the window-seat, with the light of the fire upon us, talking together as free and happy as could be.
她带着欢迎的微笑来迎接我，并伸出了手，但似乎很快就改变了主意，吻了我。简而言之，她有一种自然、迷人、迷人的态度，几分钟后我们就坐在靠窗的座位上，在火光的照耀下，尽可能地自由而快乐地交谈。

What a load off my mind! It was so delightful to know that she could confide in me and like me! It was so good of her, and so encouraging to me!
我心里的负担多么减轻啊！很高兴知道她可以向我倾诉并喜欢我！她真是太好了，对我来说太鼓舞了！

The young gentleman was her distant cousin, she told me, and his name Richard Carstone. He was a handsome youth with an ingenuous face and a most engaging laugh; and after she had called him up to where we sat, he stood by us, in the light of the fire, talking gaily, like a light-hearted boy. He was very young, not more than nineteen then, if quite so much, but nearly two years older than she was. They were both orphans and (what was very unexpected and curious to me) had never met before that day. Our all three coming together for the first time in such an unusual place was a thing to talk about, and we talked about it; and the fire, which had left off roaring, winked its red eyes at us—as Richard said—like a drowsy old Chancery lion.
她告诉我，这位年轻的绅士是她的远房表弟，他的名字叫理查德·卡斯顿。他是一位英俊的青年，有着一张天真无邪的脸，笑起来十分迷人。她把他叫到我们坐的地方后，他站在我们旁边，在火光下，愉快地说话，就像一个无忧无虑的男孩。他很年轻，当时还不到十九岁，如果说还不少的话，但比她大了将近两岁。他们都是孤儿，而且（这让我非常意外和好奇）在那之前从未见过面。我们三个人第一次在这样一个不寻常的地方聚在一起是一件值得谈论的事情，我们也谈论了它;火焰停止了咆哮，像理查德所说的那样，向我们眨着红眼睛，就像一头昏昏欲睡的大法官狮子。

We conversed in a low tone because a full-dressed gentleman in a bag wig frequenfly came in and out, and when he did so, we could hear a drawling sound in the distance, which he said was one of the counsel in our case addressing the Lord Chancellor. He told Mr. Kenge that the Chancellor would be up in five minutes; and presently we heard a bustle and a tread of feet, and Mr. Kenge said that the Court had risen and his lordship was in the next room.
我们低声交谈，因为一位穿着全套、戴着假发的绅士经常进出，当他这样做时，我们可以听到远处有拖长声音，他说这是我们案件中的律师之一大法官。他告诉肯格先生，财政大臣将在五分钟内起床。不久，我们听到一阵喧闹声和一阵脚步声，肯格先生说法庭已经起立，勋爵阁下就在隔壁房间。

The gentleman in the bag wig opened the door almost directly and requested Mr. Kenge to come in. Upon that, we all went into the next room, Mr. Kenge first, with my darling—it is so natural to me now that I can’t help writing it; and there, plainly dressed in black and sitting in an arm-chair at a table near the fire, was his lordship, whose robe, trimmed with beautiful gold lace, was thrown upon another chair. He gave us a searching look as we entered, but his manner was both courtly and kind.
戴着假发袋的绅士几乎直接打开门，请肯格先生进来。然后，我们都走进隔壁房间，肯格先生先和我的宝贝——现在对我来说这是很自然的，我可以忍不住写下来；在那里，他的勋爵穿着朴素的黑色衣服，坐在靠近火炉的一张桌子旁的扶手椅上，他的长袍上镶着美丽的金色蕾丝，被扔在另一张椅子上。当我们进去时，他用审视的眼神看着我们，但他的举止既彬彬有礼又友善。

The gentleman in the bag wig laid bundles of papers on his lordship’s table, and his lordship silently selected one and turned over the leaves.
戴着假发袋的绅士把一捆捆文件放在大人的桌子上，大人默默地挑选了一张，翻了起来。

‘Miss Clare,’ said the Lord Chancellor. ‘Miss Ada Clare?’
“克莱尔小姐，”大法官说道。 “艾达·克莱尔小姐？”

Mr. Kenge presented her, and his lordship begged her to sit down near him. That he admired her and was interested by her even I could see in a moment. It touched me that the home of such a beautiful young creature should be represented by that dry, official place. The Lord High Chancellor, at his best, appeared so poor a substitute for the love and pride of parents.
肯格先生介绍了她，勋爵大人请她坐在他旁边。我立刻就看出他很欣赏她，对她感兴趣。让我感动的是，这样一个美丽的年轻生物的家应该由那个干燥、官方的地方来代表。大法官在他最好的状态下，显得如此可怜，无法替代父母的爱和骄傲。

‘The Jarndyce in question,’ said the Lord Chancellor, still turning over leaves, ‘is Jarndyce of Bleak House.’
“我们所说的贾迪斯，”大法官一边翻着书页一边说，“是《荒凉山庄》里的贾迪斯。”

‘Jarndyce of Bleak House, my lord,’ said Mr. Kenge.
“大人，荒凉山庄的贾迪斯，”肯吉先生说道。

‘A dreary name,’ said the Lord Chancellor.
“一个沉闷的名字，”大法官说。

‘But not a dreary place at present, my lord,’ said Mr. Kenge.
“但大人，目前这个地方并不沉闷。”肯格先生说道。

‘And Bleak House,’ said his lordship, ‘is in—‘
“荒凉山庄，”大人说道，“是在——”

‘Hertfordshire, my lord.’
“赫特福德郡，陛下。”

‘Mr. Jarndyce of Bleak House is not married?’ said his lordship.
'先生。荒凉山庄的贾迪斯还没结婚吧？”大人说道。

‘He is not, my lord,’ said Mr. Kenge.
“大人，他不是，”肯吉先生说。

A pause.
停顿一下。

‘Young Mr. Richard Carstone is present?’ said the Lord Chancellor, glancing towards him.
“年轻的理查德·卡斯通先生在吗？”大法官看了他一眼说道。

Richard bowed and stepped forward.
理查德鞠了一躬，向前走去。

‘Hum!’ said the Lord Chancellor, turning over more leaves.
“嗯！”大法官一边说，一边翻动更多的叶子。

‘Mr. Jarndyce of Bleak House, my lord,’ Mr. Kenge observed in a low voice, ‘if I may venture to remind your lordship, provides a suitable companion for—‘
'先生。荒凉山庄的贾迪斯，大人，”肯吉先生低声说道，“请允许我冒昧地提醒一下大人，他为——提供了一个合适的同伴——”

‘For Mr. Richard Carstone?’ I thought (but I am not quite sure) I heard his lordship say in an equally low voice and with a smile.
“理查德·卡斯通先生？”我想（但我不太确定）我听到勋爵大人微笑着用同样低沉的声音说道。

‘For Miss Ada Clare. This is the young lady. Miss Summerson.’
“献给艾达·克莱尔小姐。”这就是那位年轻女士。萨默森小姐。”

His lordship gave me an indulgent look and acknowledged my curtsy very graciously.
勋爵大人宽容地看了我一眼，非常客气地接受了我的屈膝礼。

‘Miss Summerson is not related to any party in the cause, I think?’
“我想萨默森小姐与这项事业中的任何一方都没有关系？”

‘No, my lord.’
“不，大人。”

Mr. Kenge leant over before it was quite said and whispered. His lordship, with his eyes upon his papers, listened, nodded twice or thrice, turned over more leaves, and did not look towards me again until we were going away.
话还没说完，肯格先生就靠过来低声说道。勋爵大人眼睛盯着文件，听着，点了两三次头，翻了更多的书页，直到我们离开时才再看我一眼。

Mr. Kenge now retired, and Richard with him, to where I was, near the door, leaving my pet (it is so natural to me that again I can’t help it!) sitting near the Lord Chancellor, with whom his lordship spoke a little part, asking her, as she told me afterwards, whether she had well reflected on the proposed arrangement, and if she thought she would be happy under the roof of Mr. Jarndyce of Bleak House, and why she thought so? Presently he rose courteously and released her, and then he spoke for a minute or two with Richard Carstone, not seated, but standing, and altogether with more ease and less ceremony, as if he still knew, though he WAS Lord Chancellor, how to go straight to the candour of a boy.
肯格先生现在退休了，理查德也跟着他，来到我所在的地方，靠近门，留下我的宠物（这对我来说太自然了，我又忍不住了！）坐在大法官旁边，大法官和他在一起她后来告诉我，她说了一小段话，问她是否对拟议的安排进行了充分的反思，是否认为自己在《荒凉山庄》的贾迪斯先生的屋檐下会感到幸福，为什么会这么想？不久，他礼貌地站起来，放开了她，然后他和理查德·卡斯通谈了一两分钟，不是坐着，而是站着，更加轻松，更少仪式，仿佛他仍然知道，尽管他是大法官，如何直奔男孩的坦白。

‘Very well!’ said his lordship aloud. ‘I shall make the order. Mr. Jarndyce of Bleak House has chosen, so far as I may judge,’ and this was when he looked at me, ‘a very good companion for the young lady, and the arrangement altogether seems the best of which the circumstances admit.’
“很好！”大人大声说道。 ‘我来下命令。据我判断，《荒凉山庄》的贾迪斯先生已经为这位年轻女士选择了一个非常好的伴侣，就我而言，”这是他看着我的时候，而且这种安排似乎是目前情况下最好的安排。”

He dismissed us pleasantly, and we all went out, very much obliged to him for being so affable and polite, by which he had certainly lost no dignity but seemed to us to have gained some.
他愉快地送我们出去，我们都出去了，非常感谢他如此和蔼可亲、彬彬有礼，他当然没有失去尊严，但在我们看来却赢得了一些尊严。

When we got under the colonnade, Mr. Kenge remembered that he must go back for a moment to ask a question and left us in the fog, with the Lord Chancellor’s carriage and servants waiting for him to come out.
当我们走到柱廊下时，肯格先生想起他必须回去问一个问题，就把我们留在了迷雾中，大法官的马车和仆人正在等待他出来。

‘Well!’ said Richard Carstone. ‘THAT’S over! And where do we go next, Miss Summerson?’
“好吧！”理查德·卡斯顿说。 '已经过去了！萨默森小姐，我们下一步该去哪里？

‘Don’t you know?’ I said.
“你不知道吗？”我说。

‘Not in the least,’ said he.
“一点也不，”他说。

‘And don’t YOU know, my love?’ I asked Ada.
“亲爱的，你难道不知道吗？”我问艾达。

‘No!’ said she. ‘Don’t you?’
“不！”她说。 “你不这么认为吗？”

‘Not at all!’ said I.
“一点也不！”我说。

We looked at one another, half laughing at our being like the children in the wood, when a curious little old woman in a squeezed bonnet and carrying a reticule came curtsying and smiling up to us with an air of great ceremony.
我们面面相觑，半笑半笑，因为我们就像树林里的孩子一样。 这时，一位好奇的小老妇人戴着帽子，手里拿着手提包，带着一种庄重的仪式向我们行屈膝礼，微笑着。

‘Oh!’ said she. ‘The wards in Jarndyce! Ve-ry happy, I am sure, to have the honour! It is a good omen for youth, and hope, and beauty when they find themselves in this place, and don’t know what’s to come of it.’
“哦！”她说。 “贾迪斯的病房！我确信，能有此荣幸，我感到非常高兴！当他们发现自己身处这个地方，却不知道会发生什么时，这对青春、希望和美丽来说是一个好兆头。

‘Mad!’ whispered Richard, not thinking she could hear him.
“疯了！”理查德低声说道，没想到她能听到他的声音。

‘Right! Mad, young gentleman,’ she returned so quickly that he was quite abashed. ‘I was a ward myself. I was not mad at that time,’ curtsying low and smiling between every little sentence. ‘I had youth and hope. I believe, beauty. It matters very little now. Neither of the three served or saved me. I have the honour to attend court regularly. With my documents. I expect a judgment. Shortly. On the Day of Judgment. I have discovered that the sixth seal mentioned in the Revelations is the Great Seal. It has been open a long time! Pray accept my blessing.’
'正确的！疯了，年轻的绅士。”她很快就回了话，让他感到非常尴尬。 “我自己也是一名受监护人。我当时并没有生气，”每句话之间都低下屈膝礼，微笑着。 “我曾经拥有青春和希望。我相信，美丽。现在这已经不重要了。这三个人都没有帮助或拯救我。我有幸定期出庭。和我的文件。我期待一个判决。不久。在审判日。我发现启示录中提到的第六印就是大印。已经开业好久了！请接受我的祝福。

As Ada was a little frightened, I said, to humour the poor old lady, that we were much obliged to her.
由于艾达有点害怕，为了迁就这位可怜的老太太，我说我们非常感谢她。

‘Ye-es!’ she said mincingly. ‘I imagine so. And here is Conversation Kenge. With HIS documents! How does your honourable worship do?’
“是的，是的！”她装腔作势地说。 ” “我想是这样。这是肯格对话。与他的文件！你的尊贵崇拜怎么样？

‘Quite well, quite well! Now don’t be troublesome, that’s a good soul!’ said Mr. Kenge, leading the way back.
‘很好，很好！现在别麻烦了，这是一个好灵魂！”肯格先生一边说着，一边带路回去。

‘By no means,’ said the poor old lady, keeping up with Ada and me. ‘Anything but troublesome. I shall confer estates on both—which is not being troublesome, I trust? I expect a judgment. Shortly. On the Day of Judgment. This is a good omen for you. Accept my blessing!’
“决不，”可怜的老太太一边说，一边跟上艾达和我。 ‘除了麻烦之外什么都可以。我将授予两人遗产——我相信这不会很麻烦吧？我期待一个判决。不久。在审判日。这对你来说是个好兆头。接受我的祝福吧！

She stopped at the bottom of the steep, broad flight of stairs; but we looked back as we went up, and she was still there, saying, still with a curtsy and a smile between every little sentence, ‘Youth. And hope. And beauty. And Chancery. And Conversation Kenge! Ha! Pray accept my blessing!’
她在陡峭、宽阔的楼梯底部停了下来。但我们上楼时回头一看，她还在那儿，每句话之间仍然带着微笑，行屈膝礼，说道：“青春。”和希望。和美丽。还有大法官办公室。和对话肯格！哈！请接受我的祝福！

CHAPTER IV
第四章


Telescopic Philanthropy
伸缩式慈善事业

We were to pass the night, Mr. Kenge told us when we arrived in his room, at Mrs. Jellyby’s; and then he turned to me and said he took it for granted I knew who Mrs. Jellyby was.
当我们到达杰利比夫人家时，肯吉先生告诉我们，我们要过夜。然后他转向我说他理所当然地认为我知道杰利比夫人是谁。

‘I really don’t, sir,’ I returned. ‘Perhaps Mr. Carstone—or Miss Clare—‘
“我真的不知道，先生，”我回答道。 “也许卡斯通先生——或者克莱尔小姐——”

But no, they knew nothing whatever about Mrs. Jellyby. ‘In-deed! Mrs. Jellyby,’ said Mr. Kenge, standing with his back to the fire and casting his eyes over the dusty hearth-rug as if it were Mrs. Jellyby’s biography, ‘is a lady of very remarkable strength of character who devotes herself entirely to the public. She has devoted herself to an extensive variety of public subjects at various times and is at present (until something else attracts her) devoted to the subject of Africa, with a view to the general cultivation of the coffee berry—AND the natives—and the happy settlement, on the banks of the African rivers, of our superabundant home population. Mr. Jarndyce, who is desirous to aid any work that is considered likely to be a good work and who is much sought after by philanthropists, has, I believe, a very high opinion of Mrs. Jellyby.’
但不，他们对杰利比夫人一无所知。 '的确！杰利比夫人，”肯吉先生说，他背对着火站着，目光投向布满灰尘的壁炉地毯，仿佛这是杰利比夫人的传记，“是一位性格非常坚强的女士，她全身心地奉献自己的事业。对公众。她在不同时期致力于广泛的公共主题，目前（直到有其他事情吸引她）致力于非洲主题，着眼于咖啡浆果和当地人的一般种植以及咖啡豆的种植。我们过剩的家乡人口在非洲河岸上幸福地定居。贾迪斯先生愿意帮助任何被认为可能是好作品的工作，并且受到慈善家的追捧，我相信他对杰利比夫人的评价非常高。

Mr. Kenge, adjusting his cravat, then looked at us.
肯格先生整理了一下领带，然后看着我们。

‘And Mr. Jellyby, sir?’ suggested Richard.
“那么杰利比先生呢，先生？”理查德建议道。

‘Ah! Mr. Jellyby,’ said Mr. Kenge, ‘is—a—I don’t know that I can describe him to you better than by saying that he is the husband of Mrs. Jellyby.’
'啊！杰利比先生，”肯吉先生说，“我不知道向您描述他比说他是杰利比太太的丈夫更好。”

‘A nonentity, sir?’ said Richard with a droll look.
“无足轻重，先生？”理查德一脸滑稽地说。

‘I don’t say that,’ returned Mr. Kenge gravely. ‘I can’t say that, indeed, for I know nothing whatever OF Mr. Jellyby. I never, to my knowledge, had the pleasure of seeing Mr. Jellyby. He may be a very superior man, but he is, so to speak, merged—merged—in the more shining qualities of his wife.’ Mr. Kenge proceeded to tell us that as the road to Bleak House would have been very long, dark, and tedious on such an evening, and as we had been travelling already, Mr. Jarndyce had himself proposed this arrangement. A carriage would be at Mrs. Jellyby’s to convey us out of town early in the forenoon of to-morrow.
“我没这么说。”肯吉先生严肃地回答道。 “事实上，我不能这么说，因为我对杰利比先生一无所知。据我所知，我从未有幸见到杰利比先生。他可能是一个非常优秀的男人，但可以说，他融合了——融合了——他妻子更闪亮的品质。这样的一个夜晚又黑又乏味，而且由于我们已经出发了，贾迪斯先生亲自提出了这样的安排。明天一早，杰利比太太家就会有一辆马车送我们出城。

He then rang a little bell, and the young gentleman came in. Addressing him by the name of Guppy, Mr. Kenge inquired whether Miss Summerson’s boxes and the rest of the baggage had been ‘sent round.’ Mr. Guppy said yes, they had been sent round, and a coach was waiting to take us round too as soon as we pleased.
然后他按响了小门铃，那位年轻的绅士进来了。肯吉先生称呼他为古比，询问萨默森小姐的箱子和其他行李是否已经“送去”。古比先生说是的，他们已经被派去参观了，只要我们愿意，教练就等着带我们参观。

‘Then it only remains,’ said Mr. Kenge, shaking hands with us, ‘for me to express my lively satisfaction in (good day, Miss Clare!) the arrangement this day concluded and my (GOOD-bye to you, Miss Summerson!) lively hope that it will conduce to the happiness, the (glad to have had the honour of making your acquaintance, Mr. Carstone!) welfare, the advantage in all points of view, of all concerned! Guppy, see the party safely there.’
“那么，”肯吉先生与我们握手时说道，“我对（美好的一天，克莱尔小姐！）今天的安排表示非常满意，我的（再见，萨默森小姐） ！） 热切地希望这将有助于幸福、（很高兴有幸认识您，卡斯通先生！） 福利、所有观点、所有有关方面的优势！孔雀鱼，祝大家安全。”

‘Where IS ‘there,’ Mr. Guppy?’ said Richard as we went downstairs.
“‘那里’在哪里，古皮先生？”我们下楼时理查德问道。

‘No distance,’ said Mr. Guppy; ‘round in Thavies Inn, you know.’
“没有距离，”孔雀先生说。 “你知道，在 Thavies Inn 转转。”

‘I can’t say I know where it is, for I come from Winchester and am strange in London.’
“我不能说我知道它在哪里，因为我来自温彻斯特，对伦敦很陌生。”

‘Only round the corner,’ said Mr. Guppy. ‘We just twist up Chancery Lane, and cut along Holborn, and there we are in four minutes’ time, as near as a toucher. This is about a London particular NOW, ain’t it, miss?’ He seemed quite delighted with it on my account.
“就在拐角处，”古比先生说。 “我们只要沿着大法官巷（Chancery Lane）转弯，沿着霍尔本（Holborn）行驶，四分钟后我们就到了，几乎就在咫尺之遥。”这是关于伦敦现在的一个特别事件，不是吗，小姐？”他似乎对我的说法很满意。

‘The fog is very dense indeed!’ said I.
“雾确实很浓！”我说道。

‘Not that it affects you, though, I’m sure,’ said Mr. Guppy, putting up the steps. ‘On the contrary, it seems to do you good, miss, judging from your appearance.’
“不过，我确信这不会影响你，”古皮先生一边说，一边搭起台阶。 “恰恰相反，从你的外表来看，这似乎对你有好处，小姐。”

I knew he meant well in paying me this compliment, so I laughed at myself for blushing at it when he had shut the door and got upon the box; and we all three laughed and chatted about our inexperience and the strangeness of London until we turned up under an archway to our destination—a narrow street of high houses like an oblong cistern to hold the fog. There was a confused little crowd of people, principally children, gathered about the house at which we stopped, which had a tarnished brass plate on the door with the inscription JELLYBY.
我知道他向我表示这种恭维是善意的，所以当他关上门，登上箱子时，我嘲笑自己脸红了。我们三个人笑着聊起了我们的经验不足和伦敦的陌生，直到我们出现在通往目的地的拱门下——一条狭窄的街道上，高高的房屋就像一个长方形的蓄水池，可以容纳雾气。一小群困惑的人，主要是孩子，聚集在我们停下来的房子周围，门上挂着一块失去光泽的黄铜牌，上面写着“杰利比”。

‘Don’t be frightened!’ said Mr. Guppy, looking in at the coachwindow. ‘One of the young Jellybys been and got his head through the area railings!’
“别害怕！”孔雀先生看着车窗说道。 “其中一个年轻的杰利比人的头穿过了区域栏杆！”

‘Oh, poor child,’ said I; ‘let me out, if you please!’
“哦，可怜的孩子，”我说。 “请让我出去吧！”

‘Pray be careful of yourself, miss. The young Jellybys are always up to something,’ said Mr. Guppy.
“请小心一点，小姐。年轻的杰利比一家总是在搞事情，”古皮先生说。

I made my way to the poor child, who was one of the dirtiest little unfortunates I ever saw, and found him very hot and frightened and crying loudly, fixed by the neck between two iron railings, while a milkman and a beadle, with the kindest intentions possible, were endeavouring to drag him back by the legs, under a general impression that his skull was compressible by those means. As I found (after pacifying him) that he was a little boy with a naturally large head, I thought that perhaps where his head could go, his body could follow, and mentioned that the best mode of extrication might be to push him forward. This was so favourably received by the milkman and beadle that he would immediately have been pushed into the area if I had not held his pinafore while Richard and Mr. Guppy ran down through the kitchen to catch him when he should be released. At last he was happily got down without any accident, and then he began to beat Mr. Guppy with a hoop-stick in quite a frantic manner.
我走向那个可怜的孩子，他是我见过的最肮脏的小不幸之一，发现他很热，很害怕，大声哭泣，脖子被固定在两根铁栏杆之间，而一个送牛奶的人和一个执事，带着出于最善意的意图，我们试图抓住他的腿把他拖回来，因为人们普遍认为他的头骨可以用这种方法压缩。当我（安抚他后）发现他是一个小男孩，头天生就很大，我想也许他的头能走到哪里，他的身体就能跟着走，并提到最好的解救方式可能是推动他前进。这受到了送奶工和执事的欢迎，如果我没有抓住他的围裙，他会立即被推到该地区，而理查德和孔雀鱼先生则跑到厨房去抓住他，当他应该被释放时。最后，他高兴地平安无事地下来了，然后他开始用箍棒疯狂地殴打孔雀鱼先生。

Nobody had appeared belonging to the house except a person in pattens, who had been poking at the child from below with a broom; I don’t know with what object, and I don’t think she did. I therefore supposed that Mrs. Jellyby was not at home, and was quite surprised when the person appeared in the passage without the pattens, and going up to the back room on the first floor before Ada and me, announced us as, ‘Them two young ladies, Missis Jellyby!’ We passed several more children on the way up, whom it was difficult to avoid treading on in the dark; and as we came into Mrs. Jellyby’s presence, one of the poor little things fell downstairs—down a whole flight (as it sounded to me), with a great noise.
除了一个穿着帕丁斯衣服的人之外，没有任何人属于这所房子，他一直在用扫帚从下面戳孩子。我不知道她用的是什么东西，我想她也没有这么做。因此，我猜想杰利比夫人不在家，当那个人出现在过道里时，没有帕滕斯，我感到非常惊讶，并在艾达和我之前上到一楼的后面的房间，宣布我们是，“他们两个” “年轻的女士们，杰利比小姐！”我们在上山的路上又经过了几个孩子，在黑暗中很难避免踩到他们。当我们来到杰利比太太面前时，一个可怜的小东西从楼上掉了下来——掉了一整段楼梯（对我来说是这样），发出很大的响声。

Mrs. Jellyby, whose face reflected none of the uneasiness which we could not help showing in our own faces as the dear child’s head recorded its passage with a bump on every stair—Richard afterwards said he counted seven, besides one for the landing—received us with perfect equanimity. She was a pretty, very diminutive, plump woman of from forty to fifty, with handsome eyes, though they had a curious habit of seeming to look a long way off. As if—I am quoting Richard again—they could see nothing nearer than Africa!
杰利比太太的脸上没有反映出我们在自己脸上忍不住流露出的不安，因为亲爱的孩子的头在每一个楼梯上都会有一个凸起，记录着它的通过——理查德后来说，除了楼梯平台的一个之外，他数到了七——收到了。我们完全平静。她是一位漂亮、娇小、丰满的女人，年龄在四十岁到五十岁之间，有着一双英俊的眼睛，尽管它们有一种奇怪的习惯，看起来看起来很遥远。就好像——我再次引用理查德的话——他们看不到比非洲更近的东西了！

‘I am very glad indeed,’ said Mrs. Jellyby in an agreeable voice, ‘to have the pleasure of receiving you. I have a great respect for Mr. Jarndyce, and no one in whom he is interested can be an object of indifference to me.’
“我确实很高兴，”杰利比太太用一种愉快的声音说道，“很高兴接待您。我非常尊重贾迪斯先生，他感兴趣的任何人都不能成为我冷漠的对象。

We expressed our acknowledgments and sat down behind the door, where there was a lame invalid of a sofa. Mrs. Jellyby had very good hair but was too much occupied with her African duties to brush it. The shawl in which she had been loosely muffled dropped onto her chair when she advanced to us; and as she turned to resume her seat, we could not help noticing that her dress didn’t nearly meet up the back and that the open space was railed across with a lattice-work of stay-lace—like a summer-house.
我们表达了谢意，然后在门后坐下，那里有一张跛脚的沙发。杰利比夫人的头发非常好，但她忙于非洲事务，没有时间梳理头发。当她向我们走来时，她身上松松垮垮的围巾掉到了椅子上。当她转身回到座位上时，我们不禁注意到她的衣服几乎没有与后背相连，而开放的空间则用蕾丝花边的格子围起来——就像一座避暑别墅。

The room, which was strewn with papers and nearly filled by a great writing-table covered with similar litter, was, I must say, not only very untidy but very dirty. We were obliged to take notice of that with our sense of sight, even while, with our sense of hearing, we followed the poor child who had tumbled downstairs: I think into the back kitchen, where somebody seemed to stifle him.
房间里堆满了文件，一张大写字台几乎堆满了类似的垃圾，我必须说，房间不仅非常不整洁，而且非常肮脏。我们不得不用我们的视觉来注意到这一点，即使我们用我们的听觉来跟踪那个从楼上摔下来的可怜的孩子：我想到了后厨房，那里似乎有人掐死了他。

But what principally struck us was a jaded and unhealthy-looking though by no means plain girl at the writing-table, who sat biting the feather of her pen and staring at us. I suppose nobody ever was in such a state of ink. And from her tumbled hair to her pretty feet, which were disfigured with frayed and broken satin slippers trodden down at heel, she really seemed to have no article of dress upon her, from a pin upwards, that was in its proper condition or its right place.
但最让我们印象深刻的是写字台前一个疲惫不堪、面容不健康但绝不平凡的女孩，她坐在那里咬着笔毛，盯着我们看。我想没有人曾经处于这样的墨水状态。从她凌乱的头发到她那双漂亮的脚，脚后跟都被磨损、破损的缎面拖鞋踩坏了，她身上似乎真的没有一件衣服，从别针向上，是在其适当的状态或正确的状态。地方。

‘You find me, my dears,’ said Mrs. Jellyby, snuffing the two great office candles in tin candlesticks, which made the room taste strongly of hot tallow (the fire had gone out, and there was nothing in the grate but ashes, a bundle of wood, and a poker), ‘you find me, my dears, as usual, very busy; but that you will excuse. The African project at present employs my whole time. It involves me in correspondence with public bodies and with private individuals anxious for the welfare of their species all over the country. I am happy to say it is advancing. We hope by this time next year to have from a hundred and fifty to two hundred healthy families cultivating coffee and educating the natives of Borrioboola-Gha, on the left bank of the Niger.’
“你们找到我了，亲爱的，”杰利比太太说着，掐灭了锡烛台上的两支办公室大蜡烛，这让房间里弥漫着浓烈的热牛脂味道（火已经灭了，炉排里除了灰烬什么也没有，一捆木头和一根拨火棍），“亲爱的，你发现我和往常一样非常忙碌；但你会原谅的。目前非洲项目占用了我全部时间。它让我与全国各地的公共机构和渴望人类福祉的私人进行通信。我很高兴地说它正在进步。我们希望明年这个时候，有一百五十到两百个健康的家庭种植咖啡并教育尼日尔左岸博里奥布拉加哈的当地人。

As Ada said nothing, but looked at me, I said it must be very gratifying.
艾达什么也没说，只是看着我，我说这一定很欣慰。

‘It IS gratifying,’ said Mrs. Jellyby. ‘It involves the devotion of all my energies, such as they are; but that is nothing, so that it succeeds; and I am more confident of success every day. Do you know, Miss Summerson, I almost wonder that YOU never turned your thoughts to Africa.’
“这真是令人高兴，”杰利比夫人说。 “它涉及我所有的精力的奉献；但这没什么，所以它成功了；我每天都对成功更有信心。你知道吗，萨默森小姐，我几乎想知道你从来没有把心思转向非洲。

This application of the subject was really so unexpected to me that I was quite at a loss how to receive it. I hinted that the climate—
这个题目的应用真是出乎我的意料，让我不知如何接受。我暗示过气候——

‘The finest climate in the world!’ said Mrs. Jellyby.
“世界上最好的气候！”杰利比夫人说。

‘Indeed, ma’am?’
“真的吗，女士？”

‘Certainly. With precaution,’ said Mrs. Jellyby. ‘You may go into Holborn, without precaution, and be run over. You may go into Holborn, with precaution, and never be run over. Just so with Africa.’
'当然。小心谨慎，”杰利比夫人说。 “如果不采取任何预防措施，你可能会进入霍尔本，然后被碾过。你可以进入霍尔本，但要小心谨慎，永远不会被碾过。非洲也是如此。

I said, ‘No doubt.’ I meant as to Holborn.
我说：“毫无疑问。”我指的是霍尔本。

‘If you would like,’ said Mrs. Jellyby, putting a number of papers towards us, ‘to look over some remarks on that head, and on the general subject, which have been extensively circulated, while I finish a letter I am now dictating to my eldest daughter, who is my amanuensis—‘
“如果您愿意的话，”杰利比夫人将几份文件递给我们，“在我写完一封信的同时，请您看一下关于这个问题和一般主题的一些评论，这些评论已被广泛流传。”向我的大女儿，即我的抄写员口授——”

The girl at the table left off biting her pen and made a return to our recognition, which was half bashful and half sulky.
桌边的女孩停止了咬笔的动作，半是害羞半是生气地认出了我们。

‘—I shall then have finished for the present,’ proceeded Mrs. Jellyby with a sweet smile, ‘though my work is never done. Where are you, Caddy?’
“——那么我现在就完成了，”杰利比太太带着甜美的微笑继续说道，“尽管我的工作还没有完成。”你在哪里，凯迪？

‘‘Presents her compliments to Mr. Swallow, and begs—‘’ said Caddy.
“向燕子先生致意，并恳求——”凯迪说。

‘‘And begs,’’ said Mrs. Jellyby, dictating, ‘‘to inform him, in reference to his letter of inquiry on the African project—‘ No, Peepy! Not on my account!’
“并且恳求，”杰利比夫人口授道，“就他关于非洲项目的询问信而言，通知他——‘不，皮皮！不在我的账户上！

Peepy (so self-named) was the unfortunate child who had fallen downstairs, who now interrupted the correspondence by presenting himself, with a strip of plaster on his forehead, to exhibit his wounded knees, in which Ada and I did not know which to pity most— the bruises or the dirt. Mrs. Jellyby merely added, with the serene composure with which she said everything, ‘Go along, you naughty Peepy!’ and fixed her fine eyes on Africa again.
皮比（Peepy）（如此自名）是那个从楼上摔下来的不幸的孩子，他现在打断了信件，他在额头上贴了一块石膏，展示了他受伤的膝盖，艾达和我不知道该用哪个膝盖。最可惜的是——瘀伤或污垢。杰利比夫人只是用她说一切时平静的镇静补充道：“走吧，你这个顽皮的皮皮！”然后她的漂亮眼睛又盯着非洲。

However, as she at once proceeded with her dictation, and as I interrupted nothing by doing it, I ventured quietly to stop poor Peepy as he was going out and to take him up to nurse. He looked very much astonished at it and at Ada’s kissing him, but soon fell fast asleep in my arms, sobbing at longer and longer intervals, until he was quiet. I was so occupied with Peepy that I lost the letter in detail, though I derived such a general impression from it of the momentous importance of Africa, and the utter insignificance of all other places and things, that I felt quite ashamed to have thought so little about it.
然而，当她立即开始听写，而我没有打扰他时，我冒险悄悄地阻止了可怜的皮皮，因为他正要出去，并带他去吃奶。他看起来非常惊讶，也看到艾达亲吻他，但很快就在我怀里睡着了，抽泣的时间越来越长，直到他安静下来。我太专注于《皮皮》了，以至于我把这封信的细节都弄丢了，尽管我从信中得到了这样一个总体印象：非洲的重要性，以及所有其他地方和事物的微不足道，以至于我为自己这么想而感到非常羞愧。对此知之甚少。

‘Six o’clock!’ said Mrs. Jellyby. ‘And our dinner hour is nominally (for we dine at all hours) five! Caddy, show Miss Clare and Miss Summerson their rooms. You will like to make some change, perhaps? You will excuse me, I know, being so much occupied. Oh, that very bad child! Pray put him down, Miss Summerson!’
“六点钟！”杰利比太太说。 “我们的晚餐时间名义上是（因为我们随时都在用餐）五点！”凯蒂，带克莱尔小姐和萨默森小姐看看他们的房间。也许你想做出一些改变？我知道，请原谅我太忙了。唉，真是个坏孩子啊！请把他放下来，萨默森小姐！”

I begged permission to retain him, truly saying that he was not at all troublesome, and carried him upstairs and laid him on my bed. Ada and I had two upper rooms with a door of communication between. They were excessively bare and disorderly, and the curtain to my window was fastened up with a fork.
我请求允许保留他，真心实意地说他一点也不麻烦，然后把他抱到楼上，放在我的床上。艾达和我有两个楼上的房间，中间有一扇门可以沟通。它们过于光秃秃的，杂乱无章，我窗户上的窗帘是用叉子固定的。

‘You would like some hot water, wouldn’t you?’ said Miss Jellyby, looking round for a jug with a handle to it, but looking in vain.
“你想要一些热水，不是吗？”杰利比小姐说，她环顾四周寻找一个有把手的水壶，但没有找到。

‘If it is not being troublesome,’ said we.
“如果不麻烦的话。”我们说道。

‘Oh, it’s not the trouble,’ returned Miss Jellyby; ‘the question is, if there IS any.’
“哦，这不是问题，”杰利比小姐回答道。 “问题是，是否有。”

The evening was so very cold and the rooms had such a marshy smell that I must confess it was a little miserable, and Ada was half crying. We soon laughed, however, and were busily unpacking when Miss Jellyby came back to say that she was sorry there was no hot water, but they couldn’t find the kettle, and the boiler was out of order.
晚上非常寒冷，房间里充满了沼泽的气味，我必须承认这有点痛苦，艾达快要哭了。然而，我们很快就笑了，正忙着打开行李，杰利比小姐回来说她很抱歉没有热水，但他们找不到水壶，锅炉也坏了。

We begged her not to mention it and made all the haste we could to get down to the fire again. But all the little children had come up to the landing outside to look at the phenomenon of Peepy lying on my bed, and our attention was distracted by the constant apparition of noses and fingers in situations of danger between the hinges of the doors. It was impossible to shut the door of either room, for my lock, with no knob to it, looked as if it wanted to be wound up; and though the handle of Ada’s went round and round with the greatest smoothness, it was attended with no effect whatever on the door. Therefore I proposed to the children that they should come in and be very good at my table, and I would tell them the story of Little Red Riding Hood while I dressed; which they did, and were as quiet as mice, including Peepy, who awoke opportunely before the appearance of the wolf.
我们恳求她不要提起这件事，并尽快再次来到火边。但是所有的小孩子都来到外面的楼梯平台上观看皮比躺在我床上的现象，我们的注意力被不断出现在门铰链之间的危险情况下的鼻子和手指所分散。两个房间的门都关不上，因为我的锁没有把手，看上去就像是要上发条一样。尽管艾达的把手转动起来非常顺畅，但它对门没有任何影响。因此，我建议孩子们进来，在我的餐桌上表现得很好，我会一边穿衣服，一边给他们讲小红帽的故事；他们照做了，安静得像老鼠一样，包括皮比，他在狼出现之前适时地醒了过来。

When we went downstairs we found a mug with ‘A Present from Tunbridge Wells’ on it lighted up in the staircase window with a floating wick, and a young woman, with a swelled face bound up in a flannel bandage blowing the fire of the drawing-room (now connected by an open door with Mrs. Jellyby’s room) and choking dreadfully. It smoked to that degree, in short, that we all sat coughing and crying with the windows open for half an hour, during which Mrs. Jellyby, with the same sweetness of temper, directed letters about Africa. Her being so employed was, I must say, a great relief to me, for Richard told us that he had washed his hands in a pie-dish and that they had found the kettle on his dressing-table, and he made Ada laugh so that they made me laugh in the most ridiculous manner.
当我们下楼时，我们发现楼梯窗户上有一个写着“来自坦布里奇韦尔斯的礼物”的杯子，上面有一根漂浮的灯芯，还有一个年轻女子，她肿胀的脸缠着法兰绒绷带，正在吹着画上的火。 -房间（现在通过一扇开着的门与杰利比夫人的房间相连）并且窒息得可怕。简而言之，烟雾达到了这样的程度，我们都开着窗户坐在那里咳嗽和哭泣了半个小时，在此期间，杰利比夫人以同样的温和脾气，写了一些关于非洲的信。我必须说，她如此忙碌对我来说是一个很大的安慰，因为理查德告诉我们，他已经在馅饼盘里洗手了，他们在他的梳妆台上找到了水壶，他让艾达笑得很开心。他们以最可笑的方式让我发笑。

Soon after seven o’clock we went down to dinner, carefully, by Mrs. Jellyby’s advice, for the stair-carpets, besides being very deficient in stair-wires, were so torn as to be absolute traps. We had a fine cod-fish, a piece of roast beef, a dish of cutlets, and a pudding; an excellent dinner, if it had had any cooking to speak of, but it was almost raw. The young woman with the flannel bandage waited, and dropped everything on the table wherever it happened to go, and never moved it again until she put it on the stairs. The person I had seen in pattens, who I suppose to have been the cook, frequently came and skirmished with her at the door, and there appeared to be ill will between them.
七点钟过后不久，我们按照杰利比太太的建议，小心翼翼地下楼去吃晚饭，因为楼梯地毯除了没有楼梯钢丝外，还被撕破了，简直就是陷阱。我们吃了一条上等的鳕鱼、一块烤牛肉、一盘炸肉排和一份布丁。一顿丰盛的晚餐，如果有什么烹饪可言的话，但它几乎是生的。缠着法兰绒绷带的年轻女子等待着，把所有东西都扔到了桌子上，不管它去了哪里，再也没有动过，直到她把它放在楼梯上。我在彭定康见过的那个人，我猜是厨师，经常来和她在门口发生冲突，他们之间似乎有不和。

All through dinner—which was long, in consequence of such accidents as the dish of potatoes being mislaid in the coal skuttle and the handle of the corkscrew coming off and striking the young woman in the chin—Mrs. Jellyby preserved the evenness of her disposition. She told us a great deal that was interesting about Borrioboola-Gha and the natives, and received so many letters that Richard, who sat by her, saw four envelopes in the gravy at once. Some of the letters were proceedings of ladies’ committees or resolutions of ladies’ meetings, which she read to us; others were applications from people excited in various ways about the cultivation of coffee, and natives; others required answers, and these she sent her eldest daughter from the table three or four times to write. She was full of business and undoubtedly was, as she had told us, devoted to the cause.
整个晚餐时间——由于土豆盘被误放在煤斗里、开瓶器的手柄脱落并击中年轻女子的下巴等意外事件，整个晚餐时间很长——夫人。杰利比保持着平稳的性格。她告诉我们很多关于博里奥布拉-加和当地人的有趣事情，并收到了如此多的信件，以至于坐在她旁边的理查德一下子就看到了肉汁里的四个信封。有些信件是妇女委员会的议事录或妇女会议的决议，她读给我们听；有些是妇女委员会的会议记录或妇女会议的决议。其他的是对咖啡种植充满热情的人们和当地人的申请；其他人需要答案，而这些她三四次让她的大女儿从桌子上写下来。她忙于事业，而且正如她告诉我们的那样，她无疑致力于这项事业。

I was a little curious to know who a mild bald gentleman in spectacles was, who dropped into a vacant chair (there was no top or bottom in particular) after the fish was taken away and seemed passively to submit himself to Borriohoola-Gha but not to be actively interested in that settlement. As he never spoke a word, he might have been a native but for his complexion. It was not until we left the table and he remained alone with Richard that the possibility of his being Mr. Jellyby ever entered my head. But he WAS Mr. Jellyby; and a loquacious young man called Mr. Quale, with large shining knobs for temples and his hair all brushed to the back of his head, who came in the evening, and told Ada he was a philanthropist, also informed her that he called the matrimonial alliance of Mrs. Jellyby with Mr. Jellyby the union of mind and matter.
我有点好奇，一位戴眼镜的温和秃头绅士是谁，鱼被拿走后，他跌坐在一张空椅子上（特别没有顶部或底部），似乎被动地屈服于博里奥胡拉-加（Borriohoola-Gha），但不是对该和解积极感兴趣。由于他从不说话，如果不是他的肤色，他可能是当地人。直到我们离开餐桌，他单独和理查德在一起时，我才想到他是杰利比先生的可能性。但他是杰利比先生；一位名叫奎尔先生的健谈年轻人，太阳穴上戴着闪闪发亮的大旋钮，头发全部梳到脑后，他晚上来了，告诉艾达他是一位慈善家，还告诉她他称这桩婚姻为婚姻。杰利比夫人与杰利比先生的联盟——精神与物质的结合。

This young man, besides having a great deal to say for himself about Africa and a project of his for teaching the coffee colonists to teach the natives to turn piano-forte legs and establish an export trade, delighted in drawing Mrs. Jellyby out by saving, ‘I believe now, Mrs. Jellyby, you have received as many as from one hundred and fifty to two hundred letters respecting Africa in a single day, have you not?’ or, ‘If my memory does not deceive me, Mrs. Jellyby, you once mentioned that you had sent off five thousand circulars from one post-office at one time?’—always repeating Mrs. Jellyby’s answer to us like an interpreter. During the whole evening, Mr. Jellyby sat in a corner with his head against the wall as if he were subject to low spirits. It seemed that he had several times opened his mouth when alone with Richard after dinner, as if he had something on his mind, but had always shut it again, to Richard’s extreme confusion, without saying anything.
这个年轻人除了对非洲有很多话要说，还有他的一个项目——教咖啡殖民者、教当地人学会弹钢琴的双腿并建立出口贸易，他还很高兴通过储蓄来吸引杰利比夫人。 ”我相信现在，杰利比夫人，您一天之内就收到了一百五十到两百封有关非洲的信件，不是吗？”或者，“如果我的记忆没有欺骗我，杰利比夫人。杰利比，你曾经提到过你曾经从一个邮局一次发出了五千份通知？”——总是像翻译一样重复杰利比夫人的回答。整个晚上，杰利比先生坐在角落里，头靠在墙上，显得情绪低落。似乎有好几次，当他和理查德一起吃完晚饭后，他曾好几次张开嘴，好像有什么心事，但总是又闭上嘴，令理查德极为困惑，什么也没说。

Mrs. Jellyby, sitting in quite a nest of waste paper, drank coffee all the evening and dictated at intervals to her eldest daughter. She also held a discussion with Mr. Quale, of which the subject seemed to be—if I understood it—the brotherhood of humanity, and gave utterance to some beautiful sentiments. I was not so attentive an auditor as I might have wished to be, however, for Peepy and the other children came flocking about Ada and me in a corner of the drawing-room to ask for another story; so we sat down among them and told them in whispers ‘Puss in Boots’ and I don’t know what else until Mrs. Jellyby, accidentally remembering them, sent them to bed. As Peepy cried for me to take him to bed, I carried him upstairs, where the young woman with the flannel bandage charged into the midst of the little family like a dragon and overturned them into cribs.
杰利比太太坐在一堆废纸里，整个晚上都在喝咖啡，时不时地向她的大女儿口授。她还与奎尔先生进行了一次讨论，如果我理解的话，讨论的主题似乎是人类的兄弟情谊，并表达了一些美好的情感。然而，我并没有像我希望的那样专心聆听，因为皮皮和其他孩子在客厅的角落里围着艾达和我，要求听另一个故事；他们的故事很有趣。于是我们坐在他们中间，低声告诉他们“穿靴子的猫”，我不知道还能说什么，直到杰利比太太无意中想起了他们，把他们送上床睡觉。当皮比哭着要我带他上床睡觉时，我把他抱上了楼，那个缠着法兰绒绷带的年轻女人像一条龙一样冲进了这个小家庭，把他们掀成了婴儿床。

After that I occupied myself in making our room a little tidy and in coaxing a very cross fire that had been lighted to burn, which at last it did, quite brightly. On my return downstairs, I felt that Mrs. Jellyby looked down upon me rather for being so frivolous, and I was sorry for it, though at the same time I knew that I had no higher pretensions.
此后，我忙着把我们的房间收拾得整洁一点，并哄着已经点燃的交叉火苗燃烧起来，最后它确实燃烧起来了，而且非常明亮。回到楼下，我觉得杰利比太太因为我如此轻浮而瞧不起我，我为此感到抱歉，但同时我也知道我没有更高的要求。

It was nearly midnight before we found an opportunity of going to bed, and even then we left Mrs. Jellyby among her papers drinking coffee and Miss Jellyby biting the feather of her pen.
快到半夜了，我们才找到上床睡觉的机会，即便如此，我们还是把杰利比太太留在她的报纸上喝着咖啡，而杰利比小姐则咬着钢笔的羽毛。

‘What a strange house!’ said Ada when we got upstairs. ‘How curious of my cousin Jarndyce to send us here!’
“多么奇怪的房子啊！”我们上楼时艾达说道。 “我的表弟贾迪斯多么好奇把我们送到这里！”

‘My love,’ said I, ‘it quite confuses me. I want to understand it, and I can’t understand it at all.’
“亲爱的，”我说，“这让我很困惑。”我想了解它，但我根本无法了解它。

‘What?’ asked Ada with her pretty smile.
“什么？”艾达带着美丽的微笑问道。

‘All this, my dear,’ said I. ‘It MUST be very good of Mrs. Jellyby to take such pains about a scheme for the benefit of natives—and yet—Peepy and the housekeeping!’
“这一切，亲爱的，”我说，“杰利比太太为了当地人的利益而煞费苦心地制定了一个计划，这一定是非常好的——然而——皮皮和家政！”

Ada laughed and put her arm about my neck as I stood looking at the fire, and told me I was a quiet, dear, good creature and had won her heart. ‘You are so thoughtful, Esther,’ she said, ‘and yet so cheerful! And you do so much, so unpretendingly! You would make a home out of even this house.’
当我站着看着炉火时，艾达笑着用手臂搂住我的脖子，告诉我我是一个安静、可爱的好人，赢得了她的心。 “你真是太体贴了，埃丝特，”她说，“而且还那么高兴！”而你却做得如此之多，如此毫不做作！即使是这所房子，你也会成为一个家。

My simple darling! She was quite unconscious that she only praised herself and that it was in the goodness of her own heart that she made so much of me!
我单纯的亲爱的！她完全没有意识到，她只是在夸奖自己，她是出于内心的善良，才这么看重我！

‘May I ask you a question?’ said I when we had sat before the fire a little while.
“我可以问你一个问题吗？”当我们在火炉前坐了一会儿后，我说道。

‘Five hundred,’ said Ada.
“五百，”艾达说。

‘Your cousin, Mr. Jarndyce. I owe so much to him. Would you mind describing him to me?’
“你的表弟，贾迪斯先生。我欠他太多了。你介意向我描述一下他吗？

Shaking her golden hair, Ada turned her eyes upon me with such laughing wonder that I was full of wonder too, partly at her beauty, partly at her surprise.
艾达摇晃着金色的头发，用充满惊奇的笑声看着我，我也充满了惊奇，部分是因为她的美丽，部分是因为她的惊讶。

‘Esther!’ she cried.
“以斯帖！”她喊道。

‘My dear!’
'亲爱的！'

‘You want a description of my cousin Jarndyce?’
“你想了解一下我的表弟贾迪斯吗？”

‘My dear, I never saw him.’
“亲爱的，我从来没有见过他。”

‘And I never saw him!’ returned Ada.
“我从来没有见过他！”艾达回答道。

Well, to be sure!
嗯，可以肯定的是！

No, she had never seen him. Young as she was when her mama died, she remembered how the tears would come into her eyes when she spoke of him and of the noble generosity of his character, which she had said was to be trusted above all earthly things; and Ada trusted it. Her cousin Jarndyce had written to her a few months ago—‘a plain, honest letter,’ Ada said—proposing the arrangement we were now to enter on and telling her that ‘in time it might heal some of the wounds made by the miserable Chancery suit.’ She had replied, gratefully accepting his proposal. Richard had received a similar letter and had made a similar response. He HAD seen Mr. Jarndyce once, but only once, five years ago, at Winchester school. He had told Ada, when they were leaning on the screen before the fire where I found them, that he recollected him as ‘a bluff, rosy fellow.’ This was the utmost description Ada could give me.
不，她从来没有见过他。她妈妈去世时，她还很年轻，但她记得，当她谈到他和他高贵慷慨的品格时，她的眼里会流下泪水，她说他的品格比世间的一切都更值得信赖；艾达相信这一点。她的表弟贾迪斯几个月前给她写了一封信——“一封平淡而诚实的信，”艾达说——提出了我们现在要进行的安排，并告诉她“及时地它可能会治愈一些由悲惨的人造成的伤口”。 “大法官诉讼。”她回答道，感激地接受了他的提议。理查德收到过类似的信并做出了类似的回应。他曾见过贾迪斯先生一次，但只见过一次，那是五年前，在温彻斯特学校。当他们靠在我发现他们的火炉前的屏风上时，他告诉艾达，他记得他是“一个虚张声势、面色红润的家伙。”这是艾达能给我的最详尽的描述。

It set me thinking so that when Ada was asleep, I still remained before the fire, wondering and wondering about Bleak House, and wondering and wondering that yesterday morning should seem so long ago. I don’t know where my thoughts had wandered when they were recalled by a tap at the door.
这让我开始思考，当艾达睡着的时候，我仍然留在火炉前，不断地思考《荒凉山庄》，不断地思考昨天早上似乎已经是很久以前的事了。当敲门声唤起我的思绪时，我不知道我的思绪飘到了哪里。

I opened it softly and found Miss Jellyby shivering there with a broken candle in a broken candlestick in one hand and an egg-cup in the other.
我轻轻地打开门，发现杰利比小姐在那里瑟瑟发抖，一只手拿着一根破碎的烛台，另一只手拿着一个鸡蛋杯。

‘Good night!’ she said very sulkily.
“晚安！”她闷闷不乐地说。

‘Good night!’ said I.
“晚安！”我说。

‘May I come in?’ she shortly and unexpectedly asked me in the same sulky way.
“我可以进来吗？”她出乎意料地简短地用同样阴沉的方式问我。

‘Certainly,’ said I. ‘Don’t wake Miss Clare.’
“当然可以，”我说，“别吵醒克莱尔小姐。”

She would not sit down, but stood by the fire dipping her inky middle finger in the egg-cup, which contained vinegar, and smearing it over the ink stains on her face, frowning the whole time and looking very gloomy.
她不肯坐下，而是站在火边，用漆黑的中指蘸着盛着醋的鸡蛋杯，抹在脸上的墨渍上，一直皱着眉头，脸色阴沉得很。

‘I wish Africa was dead!’ she said on a sudden.
“我希望非洲死掉！”她突然说道。

I was going to remonstrate.
我正想抗议。

‘I do!’ she said ‘Don’t talk to me, Miss Summerson. I hate it and detest it. It’s a beast!’
“我愿意！”她说，“别跟我说话，萨默森小姐。我讨厌它并且厌恶它。这是一头野兽！

I told her she was tired, and I was sorry. I put my hand upon her head, and touched her forehead, and said it was hot now but would be cool tomorrow. She still stood pouting and frowning at me, but presently put down her egg-cup and turned softly towards the bed where Ada lay.
我告诉她她很累，我很抱歉。我把手放在她的头上，摸了摸她的额头，说现在很热，明天就会凉了。她仍然站在那里，撅着嘴，皱着眉头看着我，但很快就放下了鸡蛋杯，轻轻地转向艾达躺着的床。

‘She is very pretty!’ she said with the same knitted brow and in the same uncivil manner.
“她很漂亮！”她同样皱着眉头，同样不文明地说道。

I assented with a smile.
我微笑着答应了。

‘An orphan. Ain’t she?’
'一个孤儿。她不是吗？

‘Yes.’
'是的。'

‘But knows a quantity, I suppose? Can dance, and play music, and sing? She can talk French, I suppose, and do geography, and globes, and needlework, and everything?’
“但我想知道一个数量吧？可以跳舞、演奏音乐、唱歌吗？我想她会说法语，还会做地理、地球仪、针线活等等？

‘No doubt,’ said I.
“毫无疑问，”我说。

‘I can’t,’ she returned. ‘I can’t do anything hardly, except write. I’m always writing for Ma. I wonder you two were not ashamed of yourselves to come in this afternoon and see me able to do nothing else. It was like your ill nature. Yet you think yourselves very fine, I dare say!’
“我不能，”她回答道。 “除了写作，我什么都做不了。我总是为妈妈写作。我想知道你们两个今天下午过来看到我无事可做，不感到羞耻吗？这就像你的坏本性。但我敢说，你认为自己很好！”

I could see that the poor girl was near crying, and I resumed my chair without speaking and looked at her (I hope) as mildly as I felt towards her.
我可以看到那个可怜的女孩快要哭了，我一言不发地坐回椅子上，看着她（我希望如此），就像我对她的感觉一样温和。

‘It’s disgraceful,’ she said. ‘You know it is. The whole house is disgraceful. The children are disgraceful. I’M disgraceful. Pa’s miserable, and no wonder! Priscilla drinks—she’s always drinking. It’s a great shame and a great story of you if you say you didn’t smell her today. It was as bad as a public-house, waiting at dinner; you know it was!’
“这是可耻的，”她说。 ‘你知道是这样。整个房子都丢脸了。孩子们是可耻的。我很丢脸。爸爸很痛苦，这也不足为奇！普里西拉喝酒——她总是喝酒。如果你说你今天没有闻到她的味道，那对你来说是一个巨大的耻辱，也是一个伟大的故事。这就像在一家酒馆里等待晚餐一样糟糕。你知道是这样！

‘My dear, I don’t know it,’ said I.
“亲爱的，我不知道，”我说。

‘You do,’ she said very shortly. ‘You shan’t say you don’t. You do!’
“你知道，”她简短地说。 ‘你不能说你不知道。你做！'

‘Oh, my dear!’ said I. ‘If you won’t let me speak—‘
“噢，亲爱的！”我说道，“如果你不让我说话——”

‘You’re speaking now. You know you are. Don’t tell stories, Miss Summerson.’
‘你现在说话了。你知道你是。别讲故事，萨默森小姐。”

‘My dear,’ said I, ‘as long as you won’t hear me out—‘
“亲爱的，”我说，“只要你不听我说完——”

‘I don’t want to hear you out.’
“我不想听你说完。”

‘Oh, yes, I think you do,’ said I, ‘because that would be so very unreasonable. I did not know what you tell me because the servant did not come near me at dinner; but I don’t doubt what you tell me, and I am sorry to hear it.’
“哦，是的，我想你会的，”我说，“因为那太不合理了。”我不知道你告诉我什么，因为晚餐时仆人没有靠近我；但我并不怀疑你告诉我的话，我很遗憾听到这个消息。

‘You needn’t make a merit of that,’ said she.
“你不必为此做出贡献，”她说。

‘No, my dear,’ said I. ‘That would be very foolish.’
“不，亲爱的，”我说，“那是非常愚蠢的。”

She was still standing by the bed, and now stooped down (but still with the same discontented face) and kissed Ada. That done, she came softly back and stood by the side of my chair. Her bosom was heaving in a distressful manner that I greatly pitied, but I thought it better not to speak.
她仍然站在床边，弯下腰（但仍然带着同样不满的表情）吻了艾达。说完，她轻轻地回来，站在我的椅子旁边。她的胸膛痛苦地起伏着，我非常同情，但我认为最好还是不要说话。

‘I wish I was dead!’ she broke out. ‘I wish we were all dead. It would be a great deal better for us.
“我希望我死了！”她大声说道。 ‘我希望我们都死了。这对我们来说会好很多。

In a moment afterwards, she knelt on the ground at my side, hid her face in my dress, passionately begged my pardon, and wept. I comforted her and would have raised her, but she cried no, no; she wanted to stay there!
过了一会儿，她跪在我身边的地上，把脸埋在我的衣服里，热情地请求我原谅，哭了。我安慰她并想抚养她，但她哭着不，不；她想留在那里！

‘You used to teach girls,’ she said, ‘If you could only have taught me, I could have learnt from you! I am so very miserable, and I like you so much!’
“你过去常常教女孩子，”她说，“如果你能教我，我就可以向你学习！”我好难过，我又好喜欢你！”

I could not persuade her to sit by me or to do anything but move a ragged stool to where she was kneeling, and take that, and still hold my dress in the same manner. By degrees the poor tired girl fell asleep, and then I contrived to raise her head so that it should rest on my lap, and to cover us both with shawls. The fire went out, and all night long she slumbered thus before the ashy grate. At first I was painfully awake and vainly tried to lose myself, with my eyes closed, among the scenes of the day. At length, by slow degrees, they became indistinct and mingled. I began to lose the identity of the sleeper resting on me. Now it was Ada, now one of my old Reading friends from whom I could not believe I had so recently parted. Now it was the little mad woman worn out with curtsying and smiling, now some one in authority at Bleak House. Lastly, it was no one, and I was no one.
我无法说服她坐在我身边或做任何事情，只能把一张破烂的凳子搬到她跪着的地方，拿着它，仍然以同样的方式握住我的衣服。渐渐地，可怜的疲惫的女孩睡着了，然后我设法抬起她的头，让她的头靠在我的腿上，并用披肩盖住我们俩。火灭了，她就这样在灰蒙蒙的炉栅前睡了一夜。起初，我痛苦地醒着，闭着眼睛，试图在白天的场景中迷失自己，但徒劳无功。最后，慢慢地，它们变得模糊并混在一起。我开始失去躺在我身上的睡眠者的身份。现在是艾达，现在是我的老雷丁朋友之一，我不敢相信我最近才和她分开。现在是那个因行屈膝礼和微笑而疲惫不堪的小疯女人，现在是荒凉山庄的某个权威人物。最后，没有人，我也没有人。

The purblind day was feebly struggling with the fog when I opened my eyes to encounter those of a dirty-faced little spectre fixed upon me. Peepy had scaled his crib, and crept down in his bed-gown and cap, and was so cold that his teeth were chattering as if he had cut them all.
当我睁开眼睛时，那昏暗的日子正在与雾气作斗争，我睁开眼睛，看到一个脏兮兮的小幽灵正盯着我。皮皮爬上了婴儿床，穿上睡衣，戴上帽子，爬了下来，他的牙齿格格作响，好像他把牙齿全部割掉了。

CHAPTER V
第五章


A Morning Adventure
早晨的冒险

Although the morning was raw, and although the fog still seemed heavy—I say seemed, for the windows were so encrusted with dirt that they would have made midsummer sunshine dim—I was sufficiently forewarned of the discomfort within doors at that early hour and sufficiently curious about London to think it a good idea on the part of Miss Jellyby when she proposed that we should go out for a walk.
虽然早晨天气还很冷，尽管雾气似乎仍然很重——我说是看起来，因为窗户上结满了污垢，它们会使仲夏的阳光变得暗淡——我已经充分地预先警告了在这么早的时候门内的不适，并且充分地警告了我。当杰利比小姐提议我们出去散步时，她对伦敦感到好奇，认为这是个好主意。

‘Ma won’t be down for ever so long,’ she said, ‘and then it’s a chance if breakfast’s ready for an hour afterwards, they dawdle so. As to Pa, he gets what he can and goes to the office. He never has what you would call a regular breakfast. Priscilla leaves him out the loaf and some milk, when there is any, overnight. Sometimes there isn’t any milk, and sometimes the cat drinks it. But I’m afraid you must be tired, Miss Summerson, and perhaps you would rather go to bed.’
“妈妈不会沮丧这么久，”她说，“如果一小时后早餐准备好了，那就有机会了，他们就这么磨磨蹭蹭。”至于爸爸，他尽其所能地去办公室。他从来不吃所谓的普通早餐。普里西拉把面包和牛奶（如果有的话）留给他过夜。有时没有牛奶，有时猫喝。但恐怕你一定很累了，萨默森小姐，也许你宁愿去睡觉。”

‘I am not at all tired, my dear,’ said I, ‘and would much prefer to go out.’
“我一点也不累，亲爱的，”我说，“我更愿意出去。”

‘If you’re sure you would,’ returned Miss Jellyby, ‘I’ll get my things on.’
“如果你确定愿意的话，”杰利比小姐回答道，“我就穿上衣服了。”

Ada said she would go too, and was soon astir. I made a proposal to Peepy, in default of being able to do anything better for him, that he should let me wash him and afterwards lay him down on my bed again. To this he submitted with the best grace possible, staring at me during the whole operation as if he never had been, and never could again be, so astonished in his life—looking very miserable also, certainly, but making no complaint, and going snugly to sleep as soon as it was over. At first I was in two minds about taking such a liberty, but I soon reflected that nobody in the house was likely to notice it.
艾达说她也要去，很快就动了起来。由于无法为他做更好的事情，我向皮皮提议，让我给他洗澡，然后再让他躺在我的床上。对此，他尽可能地优雅地服从了，在整个手术过程中他一直盯着我看，仿佛他一生中从来没有、也不可能再如此惊讶过——当然，看起来也很痛苦，但没有抱怨，然后就走了。结束后就舒舒服服地睡觉了。起初，我对如此随意的做法犹豫不决，但很快我就意识到，家里可能没有人注意到这一点。

What with the bustle of dispatching Peepy and the bustle of getting myself ready and helping Ada, I was soon quite in a glow. We found Miss Jellyby trying to warm herself at the fire in the writingroom, which Priscilla was then lighting with a smutty parlour candlestick, throwing the candle in to make it burn better. Everything was just as we had left it last night and was evidently intended to remain so. Below-stairs the dinner-cloth had not been taken away, but had been left ready for breakfast. Crumbs, dust, and waste-paper were all over the house. Some pewter pots and a milk-can hung on the area railings; the door stood open; and we met the cook round the corner coming out of a public-house, wiping her mouth. She mentioned, as she passed us, that she had been to see what o’clock it was.
忙着赶走皮皮，忙着做好准备并帮助艾达，我很快就变得神采飞扬。我们发现杰利比小姐正试图在写作室的火旁取暖，普里西拉当时用一个肮脏的客厅烛台点燃了火，把蜡烛扔进去，让它燃烧得更好。一切都和我们昨晚离开时一样，而且显然打算保持这样。楼下的餐巾并没有被拿走，而是留着准备吃早餐。房子里到处都是面包屑、灰尘和废纸。栏杆上挂着一些锡锅和一个牛奶罐；门开着。我们在拐角处遇见了从一家酒馆出来的厨师，她正在擦嘴。当她经过我们时，她提到她是来看看现在几点了。

But before we met the cook, we met Richard, who was dancing up and down Thavies Inn to warm his feet. He was agreeably surprised to see us stirring so soon and said he would gladly share our walk. So he took care of Ada, and Miss Jellyby and I went first. I may mention that Miss Jellyby had relapsed into her sulky manner and that I really should not have thought she liked me much unless she had told me so.
但在我们见到厨师之前，我们遇到了理查德，他正在塔维斯旅馆里跳舞来暖脚。看到我们这么快就动起来，他感到非常惊讶，并说他很乐意和我们一起散步。所以他照顾艾达，杰利比小姐和我先走。我可以提一下，杰利比小姐又恢复了她那种闷闷不乐的态度，除非她告诉我，否则我真的不应该认为她很喜欢我。

‘Where would you wish to go?’ she asked.
“你想去哪里？”她问道。

‘Anywhere, my dear,’ I replied.
“无论在哪里，亲爱的，”我回答道。

‘Anywhere’s nowhere,’ said Miss Jellyby, stopping perversely.
“无处可去，”杰利比小姐乖乖地停下来说道。

‘Let us go somewhere at any rate,’ said I.
“无论如何，我们去某个地方吧，”我说。

She then walked me on very fast.
然后她很快就带着我走了。

‘I don’t care!’ she said. ‘Now, you are my witness, Miss Summerson, I say I don’t care-but if he was to come to our house with his great, shining, lumpy forehead night after night till he was as old as Methuselah, I wouldn’t have anything to say to him. Such ASSES as he and Ma make of themselves!’
“我不在乎！”她说。 “现在，你是我的证人，萨默森小姐，我说我不在乎——但如果他夜复一夜地带着他那巨大、闪亮、凹凸不平的额头来到我们家，直到他像玛士撒拉一样老，我也不会”没什么可对他说的。他和妈妈都把自己当成蠢货了！

‘My dear!’ I remonstrated, in allusion to the epithet and the vigorous emphasis Miss Jellyby set upon it. ‘Your duty as a child—‘
“亲爱的！”我抗议道，暗指这个绰号以及杰利比小姐对它的大力强调。 “你作为一个孩子的责任——”

‘Oh! Don’t talk of duty as a child, Miss Summerson; where’s Ma’s duty as a parent? All made over to the public and Africa, I suppose! Then let the public and Africa show duty as a child; it’s much more their affair than mine. You are shocked, I dare say! Very well, so am I shocked too; so we are both shocked, and there’s an end of it!’
'哦！萨默森小姐，不要谈论小时候的责任；马云作为父母的责任在哪里？我想，一切都交给了公众和非洲！然后让公众和非洲像孩子一样履行义务；这更多是他们的事而不是我的事。我敢说你很震惊！很好，我也很震惊；所以我们都感到震惊，事情就这样结束了！”

She walked me on faster yet.
她带我走得更快了。

‘But for all that, I say again, he may come, and come, and come, and I won’t have anything to say to him. I can’t bear him. If there’s any stuff in the world that I hate and detest, it’s the stuff he and Ma talk. I wonder the very paving-stones opposite our house can have the patience to stay there and be a witness of such inconsistencies and contradictions as all that sounding nonsense, and Ma’s management!’
“但尽管如此，我再说一遍，他可能会来，来，来，而我不会对他说什么。”我受不了他。如果说世界上有什么是我讨厌和厌恶的，那就是他和妈妈谈论的事情。我不知道我们家对面的铺路石能有耐心留在那里，见证这些看似无稽之谈的不一致和矛盾，以及马云的管理！

I could not but understand her to refer to Mr. Quale, the young gentleman who had appeared after dinner yesterday. I was saved the disagreeable necessity of pursuing the subject by Richard and Ada coming up at a round pace, laughing and asking us if we meant to run a race. Thus interrupted, Miss Jellyby became silent and walked moodily on at my side while I admired the long successions and varieties of streets, the quantity of people already going to and fro, the number of vehicles passing and repassing, the busy preparations in the setting forth of shop windows and the sweeping out of shops, and the extraordinary creatures in rags secretly groping among the swept-out rubbish for pins and other refuse.
我不能不理解她指的是奎尔先生，昨天晚饭后出现的那位年轻绅士。理查德和艾达齐步走来，笑着问我们是否要参加一场比赛，这让我省去了继续讨论这个话题的麻烦。就这样被打断了，杰利比小姐沉默了，心情郁闷地走在我身边，而我则欣赏着那绵长、各异的街道、来来往往的人流、来来往往的车辆、出发前忙碌的准备工作。商店橱窗和商店的清扫，以及衣衫褴褛的非凡生物在清扫出来的垃圾中偷偷摸索，寻找别针和其他垃圾。

‘So, cousin,’ said the cheerful voice of Richard to Ada behind me. ‘We are never to get out of Chancery! We have come by another way to our place of meeting yesterday, and—by the Great Seal, here’s the old lady again!’
“那么，表弟，”理查德用欢快的声音对我身后的艾达说道。 “我们永远不能离开法庭！”我们昨天从另一条路来到了聚会地点，而且——以国玺的名义，老太太又来了！”

Truly, there she was, immediately in front of us, curtsying, and smiling, and saying with her yesterday’s air of patronage, ‘The wards in Jarndyce! Ve-ry happy, I am sure!’
确实，她就在那儿，就在我们面前，行屈膝礼，微笑着，用她昨天的庇护神态说道：“詹迪斯的病房！”非常高兴，我确信！

‘You are out early, ma’am,’ said I as she curtsied to me.
“你出去得很早，女士。”当她向我行屈膝礼时，我说道。

‘Ye-es! I usually walk here early. Before the court sits. It’s retired. I collect my thoughts here for the business of the day,’ said the old lady mincingly. ‘The business of the day requires a great deal of thought. Chancery justice is so ve-ry difficult to follow.’
‘是啊！我通常很早就步行到这里。开庭前。它已经退休了。 “我在这里收集我的想法是为了今天的事情。”老太太装腔作势地说。 “当今的事务需要大量的思考。衡平法院的司法是如此难以遵循。

‘Who’s this, Miss Summerson?’ whispered Miss Jellyby, drawing my arm tighter through her own.
“萨默森小姐，这是谁？”杰利比小姐低声问道，同时把我的手臂拉得更紧。

The little old lady’s hearing was remarkably quick. She answered for herself directly.
小老太太的听力出奇的快。她直接回答了自己。

‘A suitor, my child. At your service. I have the honour to attend court regularly. With my documents. Have I the pleasure of addressing another of the youthful parties in Jarndyce?’ said the old lady, recovering herself, with her head on one side, from a very low curtsy.
“一个追求者，我的孩子。乐意效劳。我有幸定期出庭。和我的文件。 “我有幸在加迪斯的另一场年轻聚会上发表讲话吗？”老妇人从一个非常低的屈膝礼中恢复过来，头偏向一侧，说道。

Richard, anxious to atone for his thoughtlessness of yesterday, good-naturedly explained that Miss Jellyby was not connected with the suit.
理查德急于弥补昨天的粗心，善意地解释说杰利比小姐与这起诉讼无关。

‘Ha!’ said the old lady. ‘She does not expect a judgment? She will still grow old. But not so old. Oh, dear, no! This is the garden of Lincoln’s Inn. I call it my garden. It is quite a bower in the summer-time. Where the birds sing melodiously. I pass the greater part of the long vacation here. In contemplation. You find the long vacation exceedingly long, don’t you?’
“哈！”老太太说。 ‘她不期待审判吗？她还是会变老。但没那么老。哦，亲爱的，不！这是林肯旅馆的花园。我称它为我的花园。夏天的时候，这里真是一个凉亭。那里，鸟儿悠扬地歌唱。我的长假的大部分时间都是在这里度过的。沉思中。你觉得这个长假太长了，不是吗？

We said yes, as she seemed to expect us to say so.
我们答应了，因为她似乎希望我们这么说。

‘When the leaves are falling from the trees and there are no more flowers in bloom to make up into nosegays for the Lord Chancellor’s court,’ said the old lady, ‘the vacation is fulfilled and the sixth seal, mentioned in the Revelations, again prevails. Pray come and see my lodging. It will be a good omen for me. Youth, and hope, and beauty are very seldom there. It is a long, long time since I had a visit from either.’
“当树叶从树上落下，不再有鲜花盛开，为大法官的宫廷装饰花束时，”老太太说，“假期就结束了，《启示录》中提到的第六印再次出现。占上风。请来看看我的住处。这对我来说将是一个好兆头。青春、希望、美丽都很少见。我已经很久很久没有来过他们了。”

She had taken my hand, and leading me and Miss Jellyby away, beckoned Richard and Ada to come too. I did not know how to excuse myself and looked to Richard for aid. As he was half amused and half curious and all in doubt how to get rid of the old lady without offence, she continued to lead us away, and he and Ada continued to follow, our strange conductress informing us all the time, with much smiling condescension, that she lived close by.
她拉着我的手，领着我和杰利比小姐离开，示意理查德和艾达也来。我不知道如何为自己辩解，只好向理查德寻求帮助。他半是觉得好笑，半是好奇，心里疑惑着怎样才能不冒犯到老太太，她继续领着我们离开，他和艾达继续跟在后面，我们奇怪的售票员一直面带微笑地告诉我们。居高临下，她住在附近。

It was quite true, as it soon appeared. She lived so close by that we had not time to have done humouring her for a few moments before she was at home. Slipping us out at a little side gate, the old lady stopped most unexpectedly in a narrow back street, part of some courts and lanes immediately outside the wall of the inn, and said, ‘This is my lodging. Pray walk up!’
这是千真万确的，很快就显现出来了。她住得很近，以至于我们在她回家之前都没有时间逗她玩。老太太带我们从一个小侧门出去，出人意料地在一条狭窄的后街停下来，那里是旅馆墙外的一些庭院和小巷的一部分，她说：“这是我的住处。”祈祷走起来！

She had stopped at a shop over which was written KROOK, RAG AND BOTTLE WAREHOUSE. Also, in long thin letters, KROOK, DEALER IN MARINE STORES. In one part of the window was a picture of a red paper mill at which a cart was unloading a quantity of sacks of old rags. In another was the inscription BONES BOUGHT. In another, KITCHEN-STUFF BOUGHT. In another, OLD IRON BOUGHT. In another, WASTE-PAPER BOUGHT. In another, LADIES’ AND GENTLEMEN’S WARDROBES BOUGHT. Everything seemed to be bought and nothing to be sold there. In all parts of the window were quantities of dirty bottles—blacking bottles, medicine bottles, ginger-beer and sodawater bottles, pickle bottles, wine bottles, ink bottles; I am reminded by mentioning the latter that the shop had in several little particulars the air of being in a legal neighbourhood and of being, as it were, a dirty hanger-on and disowned relation of the law. There were a great many ink bottles. There was a little tottering bench of shabby old volumes outside the door, labelled ‘Law Books, all at 9d.’ Some of the inscriptions I have enumerated were written in law-hand, like the papers I had seen in Kenge and Carboy’s office and the letters I had so long received from the firm. Among them was one, in the same writing, having nothing to do with the business of the shop, but announcing that a respectable man aged forty-five wanted engrossing or copying to execute with neatness and dispatch: Address to Nemo, care of Mr. Krook, within. There were several second-hand bags, blue and red, hanging up. A little way within the shop-door lay heaps of old crackled parchment scrolls and discoloured and dog’s-eared law-papers. I could have fancied that all the rusty keys, of which there must have been hundreds huddled together as old iron, had once belonged to doors of rooms or strong chests in lawyers’ offices. The litter of rags tumbled partly into and partly out of a one-legged wooden scale, hanging without any counterpoise from a beam, might have been counsellors’ bands and gowns torn up. One had only to fancy, as Richard whispered to Ada and me while we all stood looking in, that yonder bones in a corner, piled together and picked very clean, were the bones of clients, to make the picture complete.
她在一家商店前停了下来，上面写着“克鲁克、抹布和瓶子仓库”。另外，用又长又细的字母写着“KROOK，海事商店经销商”。窗户的一部分是一张红色造纸厂的照片，那里一辆推车正在卸下一袋袋旧破布。另一张纸上刻着“骨头买了”的字样。在另一个地方，买了厨房用品。在另一个地方，买了旧铁。在另一个地方，买了废纸。另一个是女士和男士的衣柜。那里似乎什么都买了，什么都卖不了。橱窗里到处都是脏瓶子——黑醋瓶、药瓶、姜汁汽水瓶、泡菜瓶、酒瓶、墨水瓶；提到后者让我想起，这家商店在几个小细节上给人一种合法邻居的感觉，而且可以说是一个肮脏的依附者和不承认的法律关系。有很多墨水瓶。门外有一张摇摇欲坠的小长凳，上面放着破旧的旧书，上面写着“法律书籍，全部是 9d。”我列举的一些铭文是用法律手写的，就像我在 Kenge 和 Carboy 的办公室看到的文件一样。我很久以来就收到了这家公司的来信。其中有一篇文章，在同一篇文章中，与商店的业务无关，但宣布一位四十五岁的受人尊敬的男人想要全神贯注或复制，以整齐而迅速地执行：给尼莫的地址，由尼莫先生照顾。克鲁克，在里面。挂着几个二手包，有蓝色的，有红色的。店门口不远的地方堆放着一堆堆破旧的、有裂纹的羊皮纸卷轴和褪色、折角的法律文件。 我本可以想象所有生锈的钥匙（其中肯定有数百把像旧铁一样挤在一起）曾经属于房间的门或律师办公室的坚固的箱子。这堆破布部分掉进了一块单腿木秤上，一部分掉了出来，木秤悬挂在横梁上，没有任何平衡，可能是辅导员的带子和撕碎的长袍。当理查德对艾达和我小声说话时，我们都站着往里看，人们只需想象一下，角落里的骨头堆在一起，捡得非常干净，是客户的骨头，使这幅画变得完整。

As it was still foggy and dark, and as the shop was blinded besides by the wall of Lincoln’s Inn, intercepting the light within a couple of yards, we should not have seen so much but for a lighted lantern that an old man in spectacles and a hairy cap was carrying about in the shop. Turning towards the door, he now caught sight of us. He was short, cadaverous, and withered, with his head sunk sideways between his shoulders and the breath issuing in visible smoke from his mouth as if he were on fire within. His throat, chin, and eyebrows were so frosted with white hairs and so gnarled with veins and puckered skin that he looked from his breast upward like some old root in a fall of snow.
由于天色还很暗，雾蒙蒙的，而且商店被林肯旅馆的墙挡住了，几码之内的光线被挡住了，如果不是一个戴着眼镜的老人和一个点燃的灯笼，我们本不应该看到这么多。店里随身带着一顶毛茸茸的帽子。他转向门口，看到了我们。他身材矮小，面色苍白，面容枯槁，头侧向两肩之间，呼吸时从嘴里冒出明显的烟雾，仿佛体内着火。他的喉咙、下巴和眉毛都长满了白毛，静脉曲张，皮肤皱起，从胸口往上看，就像雪中的老树根。

‘Hi, hi!’ said the old man, coming to the door. ‘Have you anything to sell?’
“嗨，嗨！”老人走到门口说道。 “你有什么东西要卖吗？”

We naturally drew back and glanced at our conductress, who had been trying to open the house-door with a key she had taken from her pocket, and to whom Richard now said that as we had had the pleasure of seeing where she lived, we would leave her, being pressed for time. But she was not to be so easily left. She became so fantastically and pressingly earnest in her entreaties that we would walk up and see her apartment for an instant, and was so bent, in her harmless way, on leading me in, as part of the good omen she desired, that I (whatever the others might do) saw nothing for it but to comply. I suppose we were all more or less curious; at any rate, when the old man added his persuasions to hers and said, ‘Aye, aye! Please her! It won’t take a minute! Come in, come in! Come in through the shop if t’other door’s out of order!’ we all went in, stimulated by Richard’s laughing encouragement and relying on his protection.
我们自然地退后一步，看了看我们的女售票员，她一直试图用从口袋里掏出的钥匙打开房门，理查德现在对她说，因为我们很高兴看到她住的地方，所以我们由于时间紧迫，他会离开她。但她不会这么轻易就被抛弃。她的恳求变得如此奇特而迫切，以至于我们会走上去看看她的公寓，她一心一意地以她无害的方式带我进去，作为她所希望的好兆头的一部分，我（无论其他人可能做什么）除了遵守之外别无他法。我想我们或多或少都感到好奇；无论如何，当老人把他的劝说加入到她的观点中并说道：“是的，是的！”请她吧！不会花一分钟的时间！进来吧，进来吧！如果‘另一扇门坏了，就从商店进来！’我们都进去了，理查德的笑声鼓励激励着我们，并依靠他的保护。

‘My landlord, Krook,’ said the little old lady, condescending to him from her lofty station as she presented him to us. ‘He is called among the neighbours the Lord Chancellor. His shop is called the Court of Chancery. He is a very eccentric person. He is very odd. Oh, I assure you he is very odd!’
“我的房东，克鲁克，”小老太太在将他介绍给我们时，站在崇高的地位上居高临下地向他说道。 “邻居们称他为大法官。他的店名叫大法官法庭。他是一个非常古怪的人。他很奇怪。哦，我向你保证他很奇怪！

She shook her head a great many times and tapped her forehead with her finger to express to us that we must have the goodness to excuse him, ‘For he is a little—you know—M!’ said the old lady with great stateliness. The old man overheard, and laughed.
她多次摇头，并用手指敲着额头，向我们表示我们必须善意地原谅他，“因为他是个小——你知道——M！”老太太非常庄严地说。老者听了，哈哈大笑。

‘It’s true enough,’ he said, going before us with the lantern, ‘that they call me the lord chancellor and call my shop Chancery. And why do you think they call me the Lord Chancellor and my shop Chancery?’
“确实如此，”他提着灯笼走到我们面前，说道，“他们称我为大法官，称我的商店为大法官办公室。”你认为他们为什么称我为大法官和我的办公室？

‘I don’t know, I am sure!’ said Richard rather carelessly.
“我不知道，但我确定！”理查德漫不经心地说。

‘You see,’ said the old man, stopping and turning round, ‘they—Hi! Here’s lovely hair! I have got three sacks of ladies’ hair below, but none so beautiful and fine as this. What colour, and what texture!’
“你看，”老人停下来转过身来说道，“他们——嗨！这是可爱的头发！我下面有三袋女士的头发，但没有一个像这一样美丽和精致。什么颜色，什么质地！

‘That’ll do, my good friend!’ said Richard, strongly disapproving of his having drawn one of Ada’s tresses through his yellow hand. ‘You can admire as the rest of us do without taking that liberty.’
“那就行了，我的好朋友！”理查德说，强烈反对他用黄色的手画出艾达的一缕头发。 “你可以像我们其他人一样欣赏，但不必冒昧。”

The old man darted at him a sudden look which even called my attention from Ada, who, startled and blushing, was so remarkably beautiful that she seemed to fix the wandering attention of the little old lady herself. But as Ada interposed and laughingly said she could only feel proud of such genuine admiration, Mr. Krook shrunk into his former self as suddenly as he had leaped out of it.
老人突然朝他看了一眼，甚至把我的注意力从艾达身上吸引了过来，艾达吓了一跳，脸红了，她是如此美丽，似乎自己也吸引了这位小老太太的注意力。但当艾达插话并笑着说她只能为这种真诚的钦佩感到自豪时，克鲁克先生突然又缩回了以前的自己，就像他跳出来一样。

‘You see, I have so many things here,’ he resumed, holding up the lantern, ‘of so many kinds, and all as the neighbours think (but THEY know nothing), wasting away and going to rack and ruin, that that’s why they have given me and my place a christening. And I have so many old parchmentses and papers in my stock. And I have a liking for rust and must and cobwebs. And all’s fish that comes to my net. And I can’t abear to part with anything I once lay hold of (or so my neighbours think, but what do THEY know?) or to alter anything, or to have any sweeping, nor scouring, nor cleaning, nor repairing going on about me. That’s the way I’ve got the ill name of Chancery. I don’t mind. I go to see my noble and learned brother pretty well every day, when he sits in the Inn. He don’t notice me, but I notice him. There’s no great odds betwixt us. We both grub on in a muddle. Hi, Lady Jane!’
“你看，我这里有很多东西，”他举起灯笼继续说道，“种类繁多，全都像邻居们所想的那样（但他们一无所知），都在浪费，即将被架子毁坏，那就是为什么他们给我和我的地方举行洗礼。我的库存里还有很多旧羊皮纸和纸张。我喜欢铁锈、葡萄汁和蜘蛛网。所有的鱼都来到我的网里。我无法忍受放弃我曾经拥有的任何东西（至少我的邻居是这么想的，但他们知道什么？）或改变任何东西，或进行任何清扫、擦洗、清洁或修理工作。关于我。这就是我得到大法官办公室这个恶名的原因。我不介意。当我的高贵而博学的​​兄弟坐在客栈里时，我每天都会去拜访他。他没有注意到我，但我注意到了他。我们之间的胜算并不大。我们俩都糊里糊涂地吃着。嗨，简女士！’

A large grey cat leaped from some neighbouring shelf on his shoulder and startled us all.
一只大灰猫从邻近的架子上跳到他的肩膀上，吓了我们一跳。

‘Hi! Show ‘em how you scratch. Hi! Tear, my lady!’ said her master.
'你好！向他们展示你是如何抓挠的。你好！泪水，我的女士！”她的主人说道。

The cat leaped down and ripped at a bundle of rags with her tigerish claws, with a sound that it set my teeth on edge to hear.
猫跳下来，用虎爪撕扯一捆破布，发出的声音让我牙痒痒。

‘She’d do as much for any one I was to set her on,’ said the old man. ‘I deal in cat-skins among other general matters, and hers was offered to me. It’s a very fine skin, as you may see, but I didn’t have it stripped off! THAT warn’t like Chancery practice though, says you!’
“我让她对任何一个人，她都会做同样多的事，”老人说。 “我经营猫皮和其他一般物品，而她的则提供给了我。正如你所看到的，这是一个非常好的皮肤，但我没有把它剥掉！你说，这不像大法官办公室的做法！

He had by this time led us across the shop, and now opened a door in the back part of it, leading to the house-entry. As he stood with his hand upon the lock, the little old lady graciously observed to him before passing out, ‘That will do, Krook. You mean well, but are tiresome. My young friends are pressed for time. I have none to spare myself, having to attend court very soon. My young friends are the wards in Jarndyce.’
这时他已经带我们穿过商店，现在打开了商店后面的一扇门，通向房屋入口。当他把手放在锁上时，小老太太在昏倒前亲切地对他说：“就这样吧，克鲁克。”你的本意是好的，但是很累人。我的年轻朋友们时间紧迫。我已经无暇顾及自己了，很快就要出庭了。我的年轻朋友们是加迪斯的受监护人。”

‘Jarndyce!’ said the old man with a start.
“贾迪斯！”老人吃了一惊。

‘Jarndyce and Jarndyce. The great suit, Krook,’ returned his lodger.
‘加迪斯和加迪斯。克鲁克，这套衣服很棒。”他的房客回答道。

‘Hi!’ exclaimed the old man in a tone of thoughtful amazement and with a wider stare than before. ‘Think of it!’
“嗨！”老人用一种深思熟虑的惊讶语气喊道，目光比以前更加开阔。 “想想看！”

He seemed so rapt all in a moment and looked so curiously at us that Richard said, ‘Why, you appear to trouble yourself a good deal about the causes before your noble and learned brother, the other Chancellor!’
他似乎一下子全神贯注，好奇地看着我们，理查德说：“为什么，你似乎在你高贵而博学的​​兄弟，另一位总理面前为这些事情烦恼了很多！”

‘Yes,’ said the old man abstractedly. ‘Sure! YOUR name now will be—‘
“是的。”老人心不在焉地说。 '当然！现在你的名字将是——‘

‘Richard Carstone.’
“理查德·卡斯顿。”

‘Carstone,’ he repeated, slowly checking off that name upon his forefinger; and each of the others he went on to mention upon a separate finger. ‘Yes. There was the name of Barbary, and the name of Clare, and the name of Dedlock, too, I think.’
“卡斯通，”他重复道，慢慢地用食指勾掉这个名字。他接着用一根单独的手指提到了其他每一个。 '是的。我想，其中有巴巴里（Barbary）的名字，克莱尔（Clare）的名字，还有戴德洛克（Dedlock）的名字。

‘He knows as much of the cause as the real salaried Chancellor!’ said Richard, quite astonished, to Ada and me.
“他对这个事业的了解和真正的拿薪水的财政大臣一样多！”理查德非常惊讶地对艾达和我说道。

‘Aye!’ said the old man, coming slowly out of his abstraction. ‘Yes! Tom Jarndyce—you’ll excuse me, being related; but he was never known about court by any other name, and was as well known there as—she is now,’ nodding slightly at his lodger. ‘Tom Jarndyce was often in here.
