I found the academy established in a sufficiently dingy house at the corner of an archway, with busts in all the staircase windows. In the same house there were also established, as I gathered from the plates on the door, a drawing-master, a coal-merchant (there was, certainly, no room for his coals), and a lithographic artist. On the plate which, in size and situation, took precedence of all the rest, I read, MR. TURVEYDROP. The door was open, and the hall was blocked up by a grand piano, a harp, and several other musical instruments in cases, all in progress of removal, and all looking rakish in the daylight. Miss Jellyby informed me that the academy had been lent, last night, for a concert.
我发现学院建在一座拱门拐角处的一栋相当肮脏的房子里，所有楼梯的窗户上都有半身像。据我从门上的铭牌得知，同一所房子里还有一位绘画大师、一位煤炭商人（当然，没有地方放他的煤炭）和一位平版艺术家。在尺寸和位置都优先于其他所有的盘子上，我读到，先生。特维德罗普。门开着，大厅里堆满了一架大钢琴、一架竖琴和其他几件乐器，都装在箱子里，都在搬走，在白天看起来很潇洒。杰利比小姐告诉我，昨晚学院已被借用举办一场音乐会。

We went upstairs—it had been quite a fine house once, when it was anybody’s business to keep it clean and fresh, and nobody’s business to smoke in it all day—and into Mr. Turveydrop’s great room, which was built out into a mews at the back and was lighted by a skylight. It was a bare, resounding room smelling of stables, with cane forms along the walls, and the walls ornamented at regular intervals with painted lyres and little cut-glass branches for candles, which seemed to be shedding their old-fashioned drops as other branches might shed autumn leaves. Several young lady pupils, ranging from thirteen or fourteen years of age to two or three and twenty, were assembled; and I was looking among them for their instructor when Caddy, pinching my arm, repeated the ceremony of introduction. ‘Miss Summerson, Mr. Prince Turveydrop!’
我们上楼——它曾经是一栋相当不错的房子，当时任何人都有权保持它干净整洁，没有人有权整天在里面抽烟——走进特维德罗普先生的大房间，它被改造成马厩。在后面，被天窗照亮。这是一间光秃秃的、响亮的房间，散发着马厩的气味，墙壁上挂满了藤条，墙壁上每隔一段距离就装饰着彩绘七弦琴和插蜡烛的小刻花玻璃树枝，这些树枝似乎正在像其他树枝一样掉落着老式的水滴。可能会落下秋天的落叶。聚集了几个年轻的女学生，年龄从十三岁、十四岁到二三岁、二十岁不等。当我在他们中间寻找他们的教练时，卡迪捏着我的手臂，重复了介绍的仪式。 “萨默森小姐，特维德罗普王子先生！”

I curtsied to a little blue-eyed fair man of youthful appearance with flaxen hair parted in the middle and curling at the ends all round his head. He had a little fiddle, which we used to call at school a kit, under his left arm, and its little bow in the same hand. His little dancing-shoes were particularly diminutive, and he had a little innocent, feminine manner which not only appealed to me in an amiable way, but made this singular effect upon me, that I received the impression that he was like his mother and that his mother had not been much considered or well used.
我向一位身材矮小、蓝眼睛的金发男子行了屈膝礼，他看上去很年轻，亚麻色的头发中分，发尾卷曲在头上。他的左腋下夹着一把小小提琴，我们在学校里把它称为工具包，同一只手里拿着它的小弓。他的小舞鞋特别小，他有一种天真的、女性化的举止，这不仅以一种和蔼可亲的方式吸引了我，而且给我带来了一种奇特的效果，我觉得他就像他的母亲，而且他的母亲没有得到太多考虑或充分利用。

‘I am very happy to see Miss Jellyby’s friend,’ he said, bowing low to me. ‘I began to fear,’ with timid tenderness, ‘as it was past the usual time, that Miss Jellyby was not coming.’
“我很高兴见到杰利比小姐的朋友，”他说道，向我深深鞠了一躬。 “我开始担心，”带着胆怯的温柔，“因为已经过了通常的时间，杰利比小姐不会来了。”

‘I beg you will have the goodness to attribute that to me, who have detained her, and to receive my excuses, sir,’ said I.
“先生，请您将此事归咎于我，是我拘留了她，并接受我的借口，”我说道。

‘Oh, dear!’ said he.
“哦，亲爱的！”他说。

‘And pray,’ I entreated, ‘do not allow me to be the cause of any more delay.’
“请祈祷，”我恳求道，“不要让我再造成任何延误。”

With that apology I withdrew to a seat between Peepy (who, being well used to it, had already climbed into a corner place) and an old lady of a censorious countenance whose two nieces were in the class and who was very indignant with Peepy’s boots. Prince Turveydrop then tinkled the strings of his kit with his fingers, and the young ladies stood up to dance. Just then there appeared from a side-door old Mr. Turveydrop, in the full lustre of his deportment.
带着歉意，我退到了皮皮（皮皮已经习惯了，已经爬到角落里了）和一位面容挑剔的老太太之间的座位上，她的两个侄女也在班上，她对皮皮的靴子非常愤慨。 。特维德罗普王子随后用手指敲响了他的乐器的琴弦，年轻的女士们站起来跳舞。就在这时，一位老特维德罗普先生从侧门出现了，他的举止十分光彩照人。

He was a fat old gentleman with a false complexion, false teeth, false whiskers, and a wig. He had a fur collar, and he had a padded breast to his coat, which only wanted a star or a broad blue ribbon to be complete. He was pinched in, and swelled out, and got up, and strapped down, as much as he could possibly bear. He had such a neckcloth on (puffing his very eyes out of their natural shape), and his chin and even his ears so sunk into it, that it seemed as though be must inevitably double up if it were cast loose. He had under his arm a hat of great size and weight, shelving downward from the crown to the brim, and in his hand a pair of white gloves with which he flapped it as he stood poised on one leg in a high-shouldered, round-elbowed state of elegance not to be surpassed. He had a cane, he had an eye-glass, he had a snuff-box, he had rings, he had wristbands, he had everything but any touch of nature; he was not like youth, he was not like age, he was not like anything in the world but a model of deportment.
他是一位肥胖的老绅士，有着假肤色、假牙齿、假胡须、戴着假发。他有一个毛领，他的外套上有一个垫胸，只需要一颗星星或一条宽阔的蓝色丝带就可以完成。他被捏住，又膨胀，然后站起来，又被绑起来，尽他所能承受。他戴着一条领巾（把他的眼睛都撑得变形了），他的下巴，甚至他的耳朵都深深地陷进了领巾里，如果它松了，似乎必然会卷起来。他腋下夹着一顶又大又重的帽子，从帽顶一直垂到帽檐，手里拿着一双白手套，当他单腿站立、穿着高肩圆帽时，他挥舞着手套。 - 无与伦比的优雅状态。他有拐杖，他有眼镜，他有鼻烟盒，他有戒指，他有腕带，他什么都有，就是没有一丝自然的触感；他不像年轻人，不像年龄，他不像世界上的任何东西，而是举止的典范。

‘Father! A visitor. Miss Jellyby’s friend, Miss Summerson.’
'父亲！一位访客。杰利比小姐的朋友萨默森小姐。

‘Distinguished,’ said Mr. Turveydrop, ‘by Miss Summerson’s presence.’ As he bowed to me in that tight state, I almost believe I saw creases come into the whites of his eyes.
“尊敬的，”特维德罗普先生说道，“萨默森小姐的光临。”当他在那种紧张的状态下向我鞠躬时，我几乎相信我看到了他眼白中的皱纹。

‘My father,’ said the son, aside, to me with quite an affecting belief in him, ‘is a celebrated character. My father is greatly admired.’
“我的父亲，”一旁的儿子对我说，对他充满信心，“是一位著名的人物。”我的父亲非常受人钦佩。

‘Go on, Prince! Go on!’ said Mr. Turveydrop, standing with his back to the fire and waving his gloves condescendingly. ‘Go on, my son!’
‘继续吧，王子！继续！”特维德罗普先生背对着火站着，居高临下地挥舞着手套。 “继续吧，我的儿子！”

At this command, or by this gracious permission, the lesson went on. Prince Turveydrop sometimes played the kit, dancing; sometimes played the piano, standing; sometimes hummed the tune with what little breath he could spare, while he set a pupil right; always conscientiously moved with the least proficient through every step and every part of the figure; and never rested for an instant. His distinguished father did nothing whatever but stand before the fire, a model of deportment.
在这个命令下，或者在这个仁慈的许可下，课程继续进行。特维德罗普王子有时会演奏该套件并跳舞。有时站着弹钢琴；有时，他会一边哼着曲子一边纠正学生。总是认真地以最不熟练的方式完成人物的每一步和每一个部分；一刻也没有休息过。他尊贵的父亲什么也没做，只是站在火堆前，堪称举止的典范。

‘And he never does anything else,’ said the old lady of the censorious countenance. ‘Yet would you believe that it’s HIS name on the door-plate?’
“而且他从来不做别的事，”老太太满脸挑剔地说。 “但是你相信门牌上写的是他的名字吗？”

‘His son’s name is the same, you know,’ said I.
“你知道，他儿子的名字是一样的，”我说。

‘He wouldn’t let his son have any name if he could take it from him,’ returned the old lady. ‘Look at the son’s dress!’ It certainly was plain—threadbare—almost shabby. ‘Yet the father must be garnished and tricked out,’ said the old lady, ‘because of his deportment. I’d deport him! Transport him would be better!’
“如果他能夺走他儿子的名字，他就不会让他有任何名字。”老太太回答道。 “看看儿子的衣服！”它确实很朴素——破旧——几乎破旧。 “然而，父亲必须受到装饰和欺骗，”老太太说，“因为他的举止。”我会驱逐他！运送他会更好！

I felt curious to know more concerning this person. I asked, ‘Does he give lessons in deportment now?’
我很想了解更多关于这个人的信息。我问：“他现在教礼仪课吗？”

‘Now!’ returned the old lady shortly. ‘Never did.’
“现在！”老太太很快回答道。 '从不做。'

After a moment’s consideration, I suggested that perhaps fencing had been his accomplishment.
经过片刻的考虑，我提出也许击剑是他的成就。

‘I don’t believe he can fence at all, ma’am,’ said the old lady.
“我不相信他根本不会击剑，女士，”老太太说。

I looked surprised and inquisitive. The old lady, becoming more and more incensed against the master of deportment as she dwelt upon the subject, gave me some particulars of his career, with strong assurances that they were mildly stated.
我看上去既惊讶又好奇。老太太在谈论这个话题时，对这位举止大师越来越恼火，她向我讲述了他职业生涯的一些细节，并强烈保证这些内容是温和叙述的。

He had married a meek little dancing-mistress, with a tolerable connexion (having never in his life before done anything but deport himself), and had worked her to death, or had, at the best, suffered her to work herself to death, to maintain him in those expenses which were indispensable to his position. At once to exhibit his deportment to the best models and to keep the best models constantly before himself, he had found it necessary to frequent all public places of fashionable and lounging resort, to be seen at Brighton and elsewhere at fashionable times, and to lead an idle life in the very best clothes. To enable him to do this, the affectionate little dancing-mistress had toiled and laboured and would have toiled and laboured to that hour if her strength had lasted so long. For the mainspring of the story was that in spite of the man’s absorbing selfishness, his wife (overpowered by his deportment) had, to the last, believed in him and had, on her death-bed, in the most moving terms, confided him to their son as one who had an inextinguishable claim upon him and whom he could never regard with too much pride and deference. The son, inheriting his mother’s belief, and having the deportment always before him, had lived and grown in the same faith, and now, at thirty years of age, worked for his father twelve hours a day and looked up to him with veneration on the old imaginary pinnacle.
他娶了一位温顺的小舞女，关系还算可以（他这辈子除了放逐自己之外，从来没有做过任何事），并且把她干活到死，或者充其量也让她把自己干死，维持他的职位所必需的开支。为了立即向最好的模特展示自己的举止，并让最好的模特不断出现在自己面前，他发现有必要经常光顾时尚休闲胜地的所有公共场所，在时尚时期出现在布莱顿和其他地方，并领导穿着最好的衣服过着闲散的生活。为了让他做到这一点，这位深情的小舞女已经辛苦了，如果她的力量能持续这么久的话，她一定会一直辛苦到那个时刻。因为这个故事的主旨是，尽管这个男人极其自私，但他的妻子（被他的举止压倒了）直到最后仍然相信他，并在临终前用最感人的语言向他吐露了心声。对他们的儿子来说，他对他有着不可磨灭的权利，他永远不会对他抱有太多的骄傲和尊重。儿子继承了母亲的信仰，始终以同样的信仰生活和成长，现在已经三十岁了，每天为父亲工作十二个小时，并以崇敬的目光仰望着他。旧的想象的顶峰。

‘The airs the fellow gives himself!’ said my informant, shaking her head at old Mr. Turveydrop with speechless indignation as he drew on his tight gloves, of course unconscious of the homage she was rendering. ‘He fully believes he is one of the aristocracy! And he is so condescending to the son he so egregiously deludes that you might suppose him the most virtuous of parents. Oh!’ said the old lady, apostrophizing him with infinite vehemence. ‘I could bite you!’
“这家伙摆出一副架子！”我的线人说道，当特维德罗普老先生戴上他的紧身手套时，她气愤地摇着头，当然没有意识到她正在表达敬意。 ‘他完全相信自己是贵族之一！他对儿子如此居高临下，他如此令人震惊地欺骗，以至于你可能会认为他是最有德行的父母。噢！”老太太说道，语气极其激烈地撇撇嘴。 “我可以咬你！”

I could not help being amused, though I heard the old lady out with feelings of real concern. It was difficult to doubt her with the father and son before me. What I might have thought of them without the old lady’s account, or what I might have thought of the old lady’s account without them, I cannot say. There was a fitness of things in the whole that carried conviction with it.
我不禁觉得好笑，虽然我听老太太说完的时候心里还是很关心的。和眼前这对父子一起，很难怀疑她。如果没有老太太的叙述，我可能会对他们有什么想法，或者如果没有他们，我可能会对老太太的叙述有什么想法，我不能说。整体上事物的契合度令人信服。

My eyes were yet wandering, from young Mr. Turveydrop working so hard, to old Mr. Turveydrop deporting himself so beautifully, when the latter came ambling up to me and entered into conversation.
我的目光一直在徘徊，从年轻的特维德罗普先生如此努力地工作，到老特维德罗普先生表现得如此美丽，当后者慢悠悠地走到我面前并开始交谈时。

He asked me, first of all, whether I conferred a charm and a distinction on London by residing in it? I did not think it necessary to reply that I was perfectly aware I should not do that, in any case, but merely told him where I did reside.
他首先问我，居住在伦敦是否给伦敦带来了魅力和区别？我认为没有必要回答说我完全知道无论如何我不应该这样做，而只是告诉他我住在哪里。

‘A lady so graceful and accomplished,’ he said, kissing his right glove and afterwards extending it towards the pupils, ‘will look leniently on the deficiencies here. We do our best to polish— polish—polish!’
“一位如此优雅和多才多艺的女士，”他一边说，一边亲吻他的右手手套，然后将其伸向学生，“她会宽容地看待这里的缺陷。”我们尽最大努力打磨——打磨——打磨！”

He sat down beside me, taking some pains to sit on the form. I thought, in imitation of the print of his illustrious model on the sofa. And really he did look very like it.
他在我旁边坐下，费了一番功夫才坐在表格上。我想，是在模仿他沙发上著名模特的印花。事实上，他看起来确实很像。

‘To polish—polish—polish!’ he repeated, taking a pinch of snuff and gently fluttering his fingers. ‘But we are not, if I may say so to one formed to be graceful both by Nature and Art—‘ with the high-shouldered bow, which it seemed impossible for him to make without lifting up his eyebrows and shutting his eyes ‘—we are not what we used to be in point of deportment.’
“擦亮——擦亮——擦亮！”他重复道，吸了一口鼻烟，轻轻地晃动着手指。 “但我们不是，如果我可以这样说，对一个天生优雅的人来说——”高肩鞠躬，他似乎不可能不扬起眉毛并闭上眼睛”——从行为举止来看，我们已经不再是以前的我们了。

‘Are we not, sir?’ said I.
“我们不是吗，先生？”我说。

‘We have degenerated,’ he returned, shaking his head, which he could do to a very limited extent in his cravat. ‘A levelling age is not favourable to deportment. It develops vulgarity. Perhaps I speak with some little partiality. It may not be for me to say that I have been called, for some years now, Gentleman Turveydrop, or that his Royal Highness the Prince Regent did me the honour to inquire, on my removing my hat as he drove out of the Pavilion at Brighton (that fine building), ‘Who is he? Who the devil is he? Why don’t I know him? Why hasn’t he thirty thousand a year?’ But these are little matters of anecdote—the general property, ma’am— still repeated occasionally among the upper classes.’
“我们已经堕落了，”他摇着头回答道，但他在领带中所能做到的程度非常有限。 ‘平衡年龄不利于行为举止。它发展粗俗。也许我说话有些偏颇。我可能不会说，多年来我一直被称为特维德罗普先生，或者摄政王殿下有幸在他开车离开展馆时摘下帽子时向我询问。布莱顿（那栋精美的建筑），“他是谁？他到底是谁啊？我为什么不认识他？为什么他每年没有三万块钱呢？”但是，这些都是轶事——一般财产，女士——仍然偶尔在上层阶级中重述。”

‘Indeed?’ said I.
“真的吗？”我说。

He replied with the high-shouldered bow. ‘Where what is left among us of deportment,’ he added, ‘still lingers. England—alas, my country!—has degenerated very much, and is degenerating every day. She has not many gentlemen left. We are few. I see nothing to succeed us but a race of weavers.’
他以高肩鞠躬作为回应。他补充道，“我们身上残留的风度仍然存在。”英国——唉，我的国家！——已经堕落得很厉害，而且每天都在堕落。她身边的绅士已经不多了。我们人少。我认为除了织布工种族之外，没有什么可以取代我们。”

‘One might hope that the race of gentlemen would be perpetuated here,’ said I.
“人们可能希望绅士种族能够在这里延续下去，”我说。

‘You are very good.’ He smiled with a high-shouldered bow again. ‘You flatter me. But, no—no! I have never been able to imbue my poor boy with that part of his art. Heaven forbid that I should disparage my dear child, but he has—no deportment.’
“你很好。”他再次微笑，高肩鞠躬。 ‘你太奉承我了。但是，不——不！我从来没能向我可怜的孩子灌输他那部分艺术。老天爷不允许我贬低我亲爱的孩子，但他却——没有任何举止。”

‘He appears to be an excellent master,’ I observed.
“他看起来是一位出色的大师，”我评论道。

‘Understand me, my dear madam, he IS an excellent master. All that can be acquired, he has acquired. All that can be imparted, he can impart. But there ARE things—‘ He took another pinch of snuff and made the bow again, as if to add, ‘This kind of thing, for instance.’
“理解我，亲爱的女士，他是一位出色的主人。能得到的，他都得到了。一切能传授的，他都能传授。但确实有一些东西——”他又吸了一口鼻烟，再次鞠了一躬，好像是在补充，“比如这种东西。”

I glanced towards the centre of the room, where Miss Jellyby’s lover, now engaged with single pupils, was undergoing greater drudgery than ever.
我朝房间中央看了一眼，杰利比小姐的情人现在正在那里，正在忙着比以往任何时候都更加苦差事。

‘My amiable child,’ murmured Mr. Turveydrop, adjusting his cravat.
“我可爱的孩子，”特维德罗普先生一边低声说道，一边整理着领带。

‘Your son is indefatigable,’ said I.
“你的儿子不知疲倦，”我说。

‘It is my reward,’ said Mr. Turveydrop, ‘to hear you say so. In some respects, he treads in the footsteps of his sainted mother. She was a devoted creature. But wooman, lovely wooman,’ said Mr. Turveydrop with very disagreeable gallantry, ‘what a sex you are!’
“听到你这么说，”特维德罗普先生说，“这是我的奖励。”在某些方面，他追随了他神圣母亲的脚步。她是一个忠诚的人。但是，女人，可爱的女人，”特维德罗普先生用令人不快的殷勤说道，“你真是个性别啊！”

I rose and joined Miss Jellyby, who was by this time putting on her bonnet. The time allotted to a lesson having fully elapsed, there was a general putting on of bonnets. When Miss Jellyby and the unfortunate Prince found an opportunity to become betrothed I don’t know, but they certainly found none on this occasion to exchange a dozen words.
我站起来，走到杰利比小姐身边，她此时已经戴上了帽子。一节课的时间已经过去了，大家都戴上了帽子。我不知道杰利比小姐和不幸的王子什么时候找到了订婚的机会，但这次他们肯定没有找到机会交换十几句话。

‘My dear,’ said Mr. Turveydrop benignly to his son, ‘do you know the hour?’
“亲爱的，”特维德罗普先生和蔼地对儿子说，“你知道时间吗？”

‘No, father.’ The son had no watch. The father had a handsome gold one, which he pulled out with an air that was an example to mankind.
“没有，父亲。”儿子没有手表。父亲有一把漂亮的金钥匙，他拿出它的时候神气十足，堪称人类的榜样。

‘My son,’ said he, ‘it’s two o’clock. Recollect your school at Kensington at three.’
“我的儿子，”他说，“现在是两点了。”三点钟回想一下你在肯辛顿的学校。

‘That’s time enough for me, father,’ said Prince. ‘I can take a morsel of dinner standing and be off.’
“这对我来说已经足够了，父亲，”普林斯说。 “我可以站着吃一点晚餐然后离开。”

‘My dear boy,’ returned his father, ‘you must be very quick. You will find the cold mutton on the table.’
“我亲爱的孩子，”他的父亲回答道，“你一定要快点。”你会发现桌子上有冷羊肉。

‘Thank you, father. Are YOU off now, father?’
‘谢谢你，父亲。你现在走了吗，父亲？

‘Yes, my dear. I suppose,’ said Mr. Turveydrop, shutting his eyes and lifting up his shoulders with modest consciousness, ‘that I must show myself, as usual, about town.’
'是的亲爱的。我想，”特维德罗普先生闭上眼睛，谦虚地抬起肩膀说道，“我必须像往常一样，去看看这座城市。”

‘You had better dine out comfortably somewhere,’ said his son.
“你最好找个舒服的地方吃饭，”他的儿子说。

‘My dear child, I intend to. I shall take my little meal, I think, at the French house, in the Opera Colonnade.’
‘我亲爱的孩子，我打算这么做。我想，我应该在法国房子的歌剧院柱廊里吃一顿小饭。

‘That’s right. Good-bye, father!’ said Prince, shaking hands.
'这是正确的。再见，父亲！”普林斯握手说道。

‘Good-bye, my son. Bless you!’
‘再见，我的儿子。祝福你！'

Mr. Turveydrop said this in quite a pious manner, and it seemed to do his son good, who, in parting from him, was so pleased with him, so dutiful to him, and so proud of him that I almost felt as if it were an unkindness to the younger man not to be able to believe implicitly in the elder. The few moments that were occupied by Prince in taking leave of us (and particularly of one of us, as I saw, being in the secret), enhanced my favourable impression of his almost childish character. I felt a liking for him and a compassion for him as he put his little kit in his pocket—and with it his desire to stay a little while with Caddy—and went away good-humouredly to his cold mutton and his school at Kensington, that made me scarcely less irate with his father than the censorious old lady.
特维德罗普先生以相当虔诚的方式说这句话，这似乎对他的儿子有好处，在与他告别时，他对他非常满意，对他非常尽职，为他感到骄傲，我几乎觉得好像不能完全相信长者，对年轻人来说是一种不仁慈。普林斯离开我们（尤其是我们中的一个人，正如我所看到的，处于秘密之中）的那几分钟，增强了我对他近乎幼稚的性格的好感。当他把他的小工具包放进口袋时，我对他产生了喜欢和同情——带着它他想和凯迪呆一会儿的愿望——然后幽默地离开他的冷羊肉和他在肯辛顿的学校，这使我对他父亲的愤怒丝毫不亚于那位挑剔的老太太。

The father opened the room door for us and bowed us out in a manner, I must acknowledge, worthy of his shining original. In the same style he presently passed us on the other side of the street, on his way to the aristocratic part of the town, where he was going to show himself among the few other gentlemen left. For some moments, I was so lost in reconsidering what I had heard and seen in Newman Street that I was quite unable to talk to Caddy or even to fix my attention on what she said to me, especially when I began to inquire in my mind whether there were, or ever had been, any other gentlemen, not in the dancing profession, who lived and founded a reputation entirely on their deportment. This became so bewildering and suggested the possibility of so many Mr. Turveydrops that I said, ‘Esther, you must make up your mind to abandon this subject altogether and attend to Caddy.’ I accordingly did so, and we chatted all the rest of the way to Lincoln’s Inn.
我必须承认，父亲为我们打开房门，并以一种符合他闪亮原创的方式向我们鞠躬。他以同样的方式在街道的另一边从我们身边经过，正在前往镇上的贵族区的路上，在那里他将在剩下的几位绅士中露面。有那么一会儿，我陷入了重新思考我在纽曼街听到和看到的事情，以至于我完全无法与凯迪交谈，甚至无法集中注意力在她对我说的话上，尤其是当我开始在心里询问时是否有或曾经有过任何非舞蹈界的绅士，他们的生活和声誉完全取决于他们的举止。这变得如此令人困惑，并暗示了如此多的特维德罗先生的可能性，以至于我说，“埃丝特，你必须下定决心完全放弃这个话题并照顾凯迪。”我因此这样做了，我们聊了剩下的所有事情。去林肯旅馆的路。

Caddy told me that her lover’s education had been so neglected that it was not always easy to read his notes. She said if he were not so anxious about his spelling and took less pains to make it clear, he would do better; but he put so many unnecessary letters into short words that they sometimes quite lost their English appearance. ‘He does it with the best intention,’ observed Caddy, ‘but it hasn’t the effect he means, poor fellow!’ Caddy then went on to reason, how could he be expected to be a scholar when he had passed his whole life in the dancing-school and had done nothing but teach and fag, fag and teach, morning, noon, and night! And what did it matter? She could write letters enough for both, as she knew to her cost, and it was far better for him to be amiable than learned. ‘Besides, it’s not as if I was an accomplished girl who had any right to give herself airs,’ said Caddy. ‘I know little enough, I am sure, thanks to Ma!
凯迪告诉我，她爱人的教育被严重忽视，以至于阅读他的笔记并不总是那么容易。她说，如果他不那么担心自己的拼写，并且不那么费力地把它说清楚，他会做得更好；但他把太多不必要的字母放入简短的单词中，以至于有时它们完全失去了英语的外观。 “他这样做是出于最好的意图，”卡迪观察到，“但这并没有达到他想要的效果，可怜的家伙！”卡迪接着继续推理，当他通过了全部考试后，怎么能指望他成为一名学者呢？在舞蹈学校的生活里，除了教课、教课、教课、教书，早上、中午、晚上什么也没做！这有什么关系呢？她可以为两人写足够的信，因为她知道自己付出了代价，而且对他来说，和蔼可亲比博学多才要好得多。 “此外，我并不是一个有成就的女孩，有权利摆架子，”凯迪说。 “我确信我知道的还不够多，谢谢妈妈！”

‘There’s another thing I want to tell you, now we are alone,’ continued Caddy, ‘which I should not have liked to mention unless you had seen Prince, Miss Summerson. You know what a house ours is. It’s of no use my trying to learn anything that it would be useful for Prince’s wife to know in OUR house. We live in such a state of muddle that it’s impossible, and I have only been more disheartened whenever I have tried. So I get a little practice with—who do you think? Poor Miss Flite! Early in the morning I help her to tidy her room and clean her birds, and I make her cup of coffee for her (of course she taught me), and I have learnt to make it so well that Prince says it’s the very best coffee he ever tasted, and would quite delight old Mr. Turveydrop, who is very particular indeed about his coffee. I can make little puddings too; and I know how to buy neck of mutton, and tea, and sugar, and butter, and a good many housekeeping things. I am not clever at my needle, yet,’ said Caddy, glancing at the repairs on Peepy’s frock, ‘but perhaps I shall improve, and since I have been engaged to Prince and have been doing all this, I have felt better-tempered, I hope, and more forgiving to Ma. It rather put me out at first this morning to see you and Miss Clare looking so neat and pretty and to feel ashamed of Peepy and myself too, but on the whole I hope I am better-tempered than I was and more forgiving to Ma.’
“还有一件事我想告诉你，现在我们只剩下我们了，”卡迪继续说道，“萨默森小姐，除非你见过普林斯，否则我不想提这件事。你知道我们的房子是什么样的。我试图学习任何对普林斯的妻子在我们家里有用的知识是没有用的。我们生活在如此混乱的状态中，这是不可能的，每当我尝试时，我只会更加沮丧。所以我和你觉得是谁进行了一些练习？可怜的弗利特小姐！一大早我帮她收拾房间，打扫鸟儿，还给她泡了一杯咖啡（当然是她教我的），而且我已经学会了煮得很好，普林斯说这是最好的咖啡他曾经尝过老特维德罗普先生的味道，并且非常高兴，因为他对咖啡确实非常挑剔。我也会做小布丁；我知道如何购买羊颈肉、茶、糖、黄油以及许多家务用品。不过，我的针线技术还不高明，”卡迪一边说，一边看了一眼皮比连衣裙上的修补处，“但也许我会进步，而且自从我和普林斯订婚并做了这一切之后，我感觉脾气好多了。 ，希望，对马云更加宽容。今天早上一开始我看到你和克莱尔小姐看起来如此整洁漂亮，并且为皮比和我自己感到羞耻，这让我很不高兴，但总的来说，我希望我的脾气比以前更好，对妈妈更宽容。 '

The poor girl, trying so hard, said it from her heart, and touched mine. ‘Caddy, my love,’ I replied, ‘I begin to have a great affection for you, and I hope we shall become friends.’
这个可怜的女孩如此努力，说出了她的心声，触动了我的心。 “球童，我的爱人，”我回答道，“我开始对你产生了深厚的感情，我希望我们能成为朋友。”

‘Oh, do you?’ cried Caddy. ‘How happy that would make me!’
“噢，是吗？”凯迪喊道。 “那会让我多么高兴啊！”

‘My dear Caddy,’ said I, ‘let us be friends from this time, and let us often have a chat about these matters and try to find the right way through them.’ Caddy was overjoyed. I said everything I could in my old-fashioned way to comfort and encourage her, and I would not have objected to old Mr. Turveydrop that day for any smaller consideration than a settlement on his daughter-in-law.
“亲爱的凯迪，”我说，“让我们从这次开始成为朋友吧，让我们经常谈论这些事情，并尝试找到正确的解决办法。”凯迪欣喜若狂。我用老派的方式尽我所能地安慰和鼓励她，那天我不会因为任何比解决他儿媳妇问题更小的考虑而反对特维德罗普老先生。

By this time we were come to Mr. Krook’s, whose private door stood open. There was a bill, pasted on the door-post, announcing a room to let on the second floor. It reminded Caddy to tell me as we proceeded upstairs that there had been a sudden death there and an inquest and that our little friend had been ill of the fright. The door and window of the vacant room being open, we looked in. It was the room with the dark door to which Miss Flite had secretly directed my attention when I was last in the house. A sad and desolate place it was, a gloomy, sorrowful place that gave me a strange sensation of mournfulness and even dread. ‘You look pale,’ said Caddy when we came out, ‘and cold!’ I felt as if the room had chilled me.
这时我们来到了克鲁克先生家，他的私人门开着。门柱上贴着一张账单，上面写着二楼出租一个房间。它提醒凯迪在我们上楼时告诉我，那里发生了一起猝死事件，并进行了调查，我们的小朋友被吓坏了。空房间的门窗都开着，我们往里看。这是我最后一次进屋时弗利特小姐偷偷让我注意的那个门黑的房间。那是一个悲伤、荒凉的地方，一个阴暗、悲伤的地方，给我一种奇怪的悲伤甚至恐惧的感觉。 “你看上去脸色苍白，”我们出来时凯迪说，“而且很冷！”我感觉房间里仿佛让我感到寒冷。

We had walked slowly while we were talking, and my guardian and Ada were here before us. We found them in Miss Flite’s garret. They were looking at the birds, while a medical gentleman who was so good as to attend Miss Flite with much solicitude and compassion spoke with her cheerfully by the fire.
我们一边说话，一边慢慢地走着，我的监护人和艾达就在我们前面。我们在弗利特小姐的阁楼里找到了它们。他们正在观察鸟儿，一位医术高尚的绅士非常关心和同情地照顾弗利特小姐，在火边愉快地与她交谈。

‘I have finished my professional visit,’ he said, coming forward. ‘Miss Flite is much better and may appear in court (as her mind is set upon it) to-morrow. She has been greatly missed there, I understand.’
“我已经结束了我的专业访问，”他走上前来说道。 “弗利特小姐好多了，明天可能会出庭（因为她已经下定决心了）。我理解，那里非常想念她。

Miss Flite received the compliment with complacency and dropped a general curtsy to us.
弗利特小姐沾沾自喜地接受了我们的称赞，并向我们行了个屈膝礼。

‘Honoured, indeed,’ said she, ‘by another visit from the wards in Jarndyce! Ve-ry happy to receive Jarndyce of Bleak House beneath my humble roof!’ with a special curtsy. ‘Fitz-Jarndyce, my dear’— she had bestowed that name on Caddy, it appeared, and always called her by it—‘a double welcome!’
“确实很荣幸，”她说，“贾迪斯的病房再次来访！非常高兴能在我简陋的屋檐下接待《荒凉山庄》的贾迪斯！’并行了特别的屈膝礼。 “菲茨·贾迪斯，亲爱的”——看来她给凯迪起了这个名字，并且总是这样称呼她——“双重欢迎！”

‘Has she been very ill?’ asked Mr. Jarndyce of the gentleman whom we had found in attendance on her. She answered for herself directly, though he had put the question in a whisper.
“她病得很重吗？”贾迪斯先生向我们发现照顾她的那位绅士问道。她直接回答了自己，尽管他是小声问的。

‘Oh, decidedly unwell! Oh, very unwell indeed,’ she said confidentially. ‘Not pain, you know—trouble. Not bodily so much as nervous, nervous! The truth is,’ in a subdued voice and trembling, ‘we have had death here. There was poison in the house. I am very susceptible to such horrid things. It frightened me. Only Mr. Woodcourt knows how much. My physician, Mr, Woodcourt!’ with great stateliness. ‘The wards in Jarndyce—Jarndyce of Bleak House—Fitz-Jarndyce!’
‘哦，肯定不舒服了！哦，确实很不舒服，”她偷偷地说。 “你知道，不是痛苦，而是麻烦。与其说是身体上的紧张，不如说是紧张！事实是，”声音低沉而颤抖，“我们在这里经历过死亡。屋里有毒。我对这种可怕的事情很敏感。这让我害怕。只有伍德考特先生知道有多少。我的医生，伍德考特先生！”语气十分庄严。 “贾迪斯的病房——荒凉山庄的贾迪斯——菲茨-贾迪斯！”

‘Miss Flite,’ said Mr. Woodcourt in a grave kind of voice, as if he were appealing to her while speaking to us, and laying his hand gently on her arm, ‘Miss Flite describes her illness with her usual accuracy. She was alarmed by an occurrence in the house which might have alarmed a stronger person, and was made ill by the distress and agitation. She brought me here in the first hurry of the discovery, though too late for me to be of any use to the unfortunate man. I have compensated myself for that disappointment by coming here since and being of some small use to her.’
“弗利特小姐，”伍德考特先生用一种严肃的声音说道，就像他在对我们说话时向她发出呼吁一样，他把手轻轻地放在她的手臂上，“弗利特小姐以她一贯的准确描述了她的病情。她对家里发生的事情感到震惊，这可能会惊动一个更坚强的人，并因痛苦和激动而生病。她在发现这一情况后第一时间就把我带到了这里，尽管为时已晚，我对这个不幸的人没有任何用处。从那以后我来到这里并为她提供了一些小帮助，以此来补偿自己的失望。

‘The kindest physician in the college,’ whispered Miss Flite to me. ‘I expect a judgment. On the day of judgment. And shall then confer estates.’
“学院里最和蔼的医生。”弗利特小姐低声对我说道。 “我期待一个判决。在审判日。然后将授予遗产。

‘She will be as well in a day or two,’ said Mr. Woodcourt, looking at her with an observant smile, ‘as she ever will be. In other words, quite well of course. Have you heard of her good fortune?’
“一两天后，她就会恢复正常了，”伍德考特先生说，脸上带着敏锐的微笑，看着她，“就像以前一样。”换句话说，当然很好。你听说过她的好运气吗？

‘Most extraordinary!’ said Miss Flite, smiling brightly. ‘You never heard of such a thing, my dear! Every Saturday, Conversation Kenge or Guppy (clerk to Conversation K.) places in my hand a paper of shillings. Shillings. I assure you! Always the same number in the paper. Always one for every day in the week. Now you know, really! So well-timed, is it not? Ye-es! From whence do these papers come, you say? That is the great question. Naturally. Shall I tell you what I think? I think,’ said Miss Flite, drawing herself back with a very shrewd look and shaking her right forefinger in a most significant manner, ‘that the Lord Chancellor, aware of the length of time during which the Great Seal has been open (for it has been open a long time!), forwards them. Until the judgment I expect is given. Now that’s very creditable, you know. To confess in that way that he IS a little slow for human life. So delicate! Attending court the other day—I attend it regularly, with my documents—I taxed him with it, and he almost confessed. That is, I smiled at him from my bench, and HE smiled at me from his bench. But it’s great good fortune, is it not? And FitzJarndyce lays the money out for me to great advantage. Oh, I assure you to the greatest advantage!’
“太不寻常了！”弗利特小姐灿烂地笑着说。 “你从来没有听说过这样的事，亲爱的！每个星期六，对话肯吉或古皮（对话K的职员）都会把一张先令纸放在我手里。先令。我向你们保证！报纸上的数字始终相同。一周中的每一天总是一个。现在你知道了，真的！这么及时，不是吗？是的！你说这些论文从哪里来？这是一个很好的问题。自然。我要告诉你我的想法吗？我认为，”弗利特小姐说，她以一种非常精明的表情向后退了一步，并以一种非常重要的方式摇动了她的右手食指，“大法官知道国玺被打开的时间长度（因为它已经开放很久了！），转发它们。直到给出我所期望的判断。你知道，这是非常值得信赖的。以这种方式承认他对人类生活有点迟钝。好精致啊！前几天出庭——我经常带着我的文件出庭——我用它向他征税，他几乎认罪了。也就是说，我在我的板凳上对他微笑，他也在他的板凳上对我微笑。但这也是天大的福气，不是吗？菲茨贾迪斯（FitzJarndyce）为我提供了巨大的优势。哦，我向你保证最大的好处！

I congratulated her (as she addressed herself to me) upon this fortunate addition to her income and wished her a long continuance of it. I did not speculate upon the source from which it came or wonder whose humanity was so considerate. My guardian stood before me, contemplating the birds, and I had no need to look beyond him.
我祝贺她（当她对我讲话时）她的收入有了如此幸运的增加，并祝愿她能长久地继续下去。我没有猜测它的来源，也没有想知道是谁的人性如此体贴。我的监护人站在我面前，凝视着这些鸟儿，我不需要把目光移向他以外的地方。

‘And what do you call these little fellows, ma’am?’ said he in his pleasant voice. ‘Have they any names?’
“女士，您怎么称呼这些小家伙呢？”他用愉快的声音问道。 “他们有名字吗？”

‘I can answer for Miss Elite that they have,’ said I, ‘for she promised to tell us what they were. Ada remembers?’
“我可以代表精英小姐回答他们的问题，”我说，“因为她答应告诉我们他们是什么。”艾达还记得吗？

Ada remembered very well.
艾达记得很清楚。

‘Did I?’ said Miss Elite. ‘Who’s that at my door? What are you listening at my door for, Krook?’
“是吗？”精英小姐说。 ‘我家门口是谁？你在我门口偷听干什么，克鲁克？

The old man of the house, pushing it open before him, appeared there with his fur cap in his hand and his cat at his heels.
屋里的老人在他面前推开门，出现了，手里拿着毛皮帽子，脚后跟着他的猫。

‘I warn’t listening, Miss Flite,’ he said, ‘I was going to give a rap with my knuckles, only you’re so quick!’
“我没在听，弗利特小姐，”他说，“我正想用指关节敲击，只是你太快了！”

‘Make your cat go down. Drive her away!’ the old lady angrily exclaimed.
‘让你的猫下去。把她赶走！”老太太愤怒地叫道。

‘Bah, bah! There ain’t no danger, gentlefolks,’ said Mr. Krook, looking slowly and sharply from one to another until he had looked at all of us; ‘she’d never offer at the birds when I was here unless I told her to it.’
‘呸，呸！先生们，没有危险。”克鲁克先生说，他慢慢地、锐利地从一个人看向另一个人，直到他看遍了我们所有人。 “当我在这里的时候，除非我告诉她，否则她永远不会向鸟儿献祭。”

‘You will excuse my landlord,’ said the old lady with a dignified air. ‘M, quite M! What do you want, Krook, when I have company?’
“请原谅我的房东。”老太太神情凝重地说。 ‘M，相当M！当我有伴时，克鲁克，你想要什么？

‘Hi!’ said the old man. ‘You know I am the Chancellor.’
“嗨！”老人说。 “你知道我是财政大臣。”

‘Well?’ returned Miss Elite. ‘What of that?’
“嗯？”精英小姐回答道。 “那又怎样？”

‘For the Chancellor,’ said the old man with a chuckle, ‘not to be acquainted with a Jarndyce is queer, ain’t it, Miss Flite? Mightn’t I take the liberty? Your servant, sir. I know Jarndyce and Jarndyce a’most as well as you do, sir. I knowed old Squire Tom, sir. I never to my knowledge see you afore though, not even in court. Yet, I go there a mortal sight of times in the course of the year, taking one day with another.’
“对大法官来说，”老人笑着说，“不认识詹迪斯是很奇怪的，不是吗，弗利特小姐？难道我就不能冒昧吗？您的仆人，先生。我和你一样了解贾迪斯和贾迪斯，先生。我认识老乡绅汤姆，先生。但据我所知，我以前从未见过你，甚至在法庭上也没有见过。然而，在这一年中，我曾多次去那里参观，一天又一天。

‘I never go there,’ said Mr. Jarndyce (which he never did on any consideration). ‘I would sooner go—somewhere else.’
“我从来没有去过那里，”贾迪斯先生说（他出于任何考虑都没有去过那里）。 “我宁愿去别的地方。”

‘Would you though?’ returned Krook, grinning. ‘You’re bearing hard upon my noble and learned brother in your meaning, sir, though perhaps it is but nat’ral in a Jarndyce. The burnt child, sir! What, you’re looking at my lodger’s birds, Mr. Jarndyce?’ The old man had come by little and little into the room until he now touched my guardian with his elbow and looked close up into his face with his spectacled eyes. ‘It’s one of her strange ways that she’ll never tell the names of these birds if she can help it, though she named ‘em all.’ This was in a whisper. ‘Shall I run ‘em over, Flite?’ he asked aloud, winking at us and pointing at her as she turned away, affecting to sweep the grate.
“你愿意吗？”克鲁克笑着回答。 “按照你的意思，你对我高贵而博学的​​兄弟很严厉，先生，尽管这也许只是加迪斯酒中的自然现象。”被烧伤的孩子，先生！什么，贾迪斯先生，你在看我房客的鸟吗？”老人一步一步地走进房间，直到他用肘部碰触了我的监护人，并用戴着眼镜的眼睛仔细地看着他的脸。 “这是她奇怪的方式之一，如果可以的话，她永远不会告诉这些鸟的名字，尽管她给‘它们全部命名’。这是低声说的。 “要我把他们撞过去吗，弗利特？”他大声问道，向我们眨了眨眼，在她转身走开时指着她，假装要扫炉栅。

‘If you like,’ she answered hurriedly.
“如果你愿意的话。”她急忙回答。

The old man, looking up at the cages after another look at us, went through the list.
老人抬头看了看笼子，又看了我们一眼，浏览了一遍清单。

‘Hope, Joy, Youth, Peace, Rest, Life, Dust, Ashes, Waste, Want, Ruin, Despair, Madness, Death, Cunning, Folly, Words, Wigs, Rags, Sheepskin, Plunder, Precedent, Jargon, Gammon, and Spinach. That’s the whole collection,’ said the old man, ‘all cooped up together, by my noble and learned brother.’
“希望、欢乐、青春、和平、休息、生命、尘土、灰烬、浪费、匮乏、废墟、绝望、疯狂、死亡、狡猾、愚蠢、言语、假发、破布、羊皮、掠夺、先例、行话、火腿和菠菜。这就是全部藏品，”老人说，“都是由我高贵而博学的​​兄弟收藏在一起的。”

‘This is a bitter wind!’ muttered my guardian.
“这风真刺骨！”我的监护人低声说道。

‘When my noble and learned brother gives his judgment, they’re to be let go free,’ said Krook, winking at us again. ‘And then,’ he added, whispering and grinning, ‘if that ever was to happen—which it won’t—the birds that have never been caged would kill ‘em.’
“当我高贵而博学的​​兄弟做出判断时，他们就会被释放，”克鲁克说道，再次对我们眨了眨眼。 “然后，”他微笑着低声补充道，“如果这种情况真的发生了——但它不会发生——那些从未被关在笼子里的鸟会杀死它们。”

‘If ever the wind was in the east,’ said my guardian, pretending to look out of the window for a weathercock, ‘I think it’s there today!’
“如果风向是东风的话，”我的监护人假装向窗外寻找风向标说道，“我想今天就在那里！”

We found it very difficult to get away from the house. It was not Miss Flite who detained us; she was as reasonable a little creature in consulting the convenience of others as there possibly could be. It was Mr. Krook. He seemed unable to detach himself from Mr. Jarndyce. If he had been linked to him, he could hardly have attended him more closely. He proposed to show us his Court of Chancery and all the strange medley it contained; during the whole of our inspection (prolonged by himself) he kept close to Mr. Jarndyce and sometimes detained him under one pretence or other until we had passed on, as if he were tormented by an inclination to enter upon some secret subject which he could not make up his mind to approach. I cannot imagine a countenance and manner more singularly expressive of caution and indecision, and a perpetual impulse to do something he could not resolve to venture on, than Mr. Krook’s was that day. His watchfulness of my guardian was incessant. He rarely removed his eyes from his face. If he went on beside him, he observed him with the slyness of an old white fox. If he went before, he looked back. When we stood still, he got opposite to him, and drawing his hand across and across his open mouth with a curious expression of a sense of power, and turning up his eyes, and lowering his grey eyebrows until they appeared to be shut, seemed to scan every lineament of his face.
我们发现很难离开房子。拦住我们的不是弗利特小姐，而是弗利特小姐。她是个很通情达理的小人，会尽可能地考虑别人的方便。是克鲁克先生。他似乎无法脱离贾迪斯先生。如果他和他有联系，他几乎不可能更密切地关注他。他提议向我们展示他的大法官法庭以及其中包含的所有奇怪的混合体。在我们视察的整个过程中（他自己延长了时间），他一直和贾迪斯先生保持着密切的关系，有时会以这样或那样的借口拘留他，直到我们离开为止，仿佛他被一种想要进入某个他可以谈论的秘密话题的倾向所折磨。没有下定决心去接近。我想象不出有什么表情和举止比克鲁克先生那天的表情和举止更能表现出谨慎和优柔寡断，以及做一些他无法下定决心冒险做的事情的永恒冲动。他对我的监护人始终保持警惕。他的目光很少从脸上移开。如果他走在他身边，他就会像一只老白狐一样狡猾地观察他。如果他以前去过，他就会回头看。当我们站着不动时，他走到他对面，用一只手抚过他张开的嘴，脸上带着一种充满力量感的好奇表情，他抬起眼睛，垂下灰色的眉毛，直到它们似乎闭上了，似乎扫描他脸上的每一个线条。

At last, having been (always attended by the cat) all over the house and having seen the whole stock of miscellaneous lumber, which was certainly curious, we came into the back part of the shop. Here on the head of an empty barrel stood on end were an ink-bottle, some old stumps of pens, and some dirty playbills; and against the wall were pasted several large printed alphabets in several plain hands.
最后，我们（总是有猫陪伴）走遍了整个房子，看到了所有的杂项木材，这当然很好奇，我们来到了商店的后面。一个空桶的头上竖立着一个墨水瓶、一些旧笔桩和一些脏兮兮的节目单；墙上贴着几个大大的印刷字母，是由几位朴素的手写的。

‘What are you doing here?’ asked my guardian.
“你来这里做什么？”我的监护人问。

‘Trying to learn myself to read and write,’ said Krook.
“努力学习阅读和写作，”克鲁克说。

‘And how do you get on?’
“你过得怎么样？”

‘Slow. Bad,’ returned the old man impatiently. ‘It’s hard at my time of life.’
'慢的。不好。”老人不耐烦地回答道。 “我这一生很艰难。”

‘It would be easier to be taught by some one,’ said my guardian.
“由某人来教导会更容易，”我的监护人说。

‘Aye, but they might teach me wrong!’ returned the old man with a wonderfully suspicious flash of his eye. ‘I don’t know what I may have lost by not being learned afore. I wouldn’t like to lose anything by being learned wrong now.’
“是的，但他们可能教错了我！”老人回答道，眼中闪过一丝奇妙的怀疑。 “我不知道如果之前没有学到东西，我可能会失去什么。我不想因为现在学错了而失去任何东西。”

‘Wrong?’ said my guardian with his good-humoured smile. ‘Who do you suppose would teach you wrong?’
“错了？”我的监护人带着幽默的微笑说道。 “你觉得谁会教你错呢？”

‘I don’t know, Mr. Jarndyce of Bleak House!’ replied the old man, turning up his spectacles on his forehead and rubbing his hands. ‘I don’t suppose as anybody would, but I’d rather trust my own self than another!’
“我不知道，荒凉山庄的贾迪斯先生！”老人答道，转动额头上的眼镜，揉搓双手。 “我不这么认为，但我宁愿相信自己，也不愿相信别人！”

These answers and his manner were strange enough to cause my guardian to inquire of Mr. Woodcourt, as we all walked across Lincoln’s Inn together, whether Mr. Krook were really, as his lodger represented him, deranged. The young surgeon replied, no, he had seen no reason to think so. He was exceedingly distrustful, as ignorance usually was, and he was always more or less under the influence of raw gin, of which he drank great quantities and of which he and his back-shop, as we might have observed, smelt strongly; but he did not think him mad as yet.
当我们一起穿过林肯旅馆时，这些答案和他的态度很奇怪，以至于我的监护人询问伍德考特先生，克鲁克先生是否真的像他的房客所代表的那样精神错乱。年轻的外科医生回答说，不，他认为没有理由这么想。他非常不信任别人，无知者通常都会这样，他总是或多或少地受到生杜松子酒的影响，他喝了大量的杜松子酒，正如我们可能已经观察到的那样，他和他的后店闻起来很浓烈。但他还不认为他疯了。

On our way home, I so conciliated Peepy’s affections by buying him a windmill and two flour-sacks that he would suffer nobody else to take off his hat and gloves and would sit nowhere at dinner but at my side. Caddy sat upon the other side of me, next to Ada, to whom we imparted the whole history of the engagement as soon as we got back. We made much of Caddy, and Peepy too; and Caddy brightened exceedingly; and my guardian was as merry as we were; and we were all very happy indeed until Caddy went home at night in a hackneycoach, with Peepy fast asleep, but holding tight to the windmill.
在回家的路上，我为了安抚皮比的感情，给他买了一个风车和两个面粉袋，以至于他不允许其他人脱下帽子和手套，而且在晚餐时除了我之外不会坐在任何地方。球童坐在我的另一边，挨着艾达，我们一回来就向她讲述了订婚的全部历史。我们很重视凯迪，还有皮皮。凯迪的神情格外明亮。我的监护人和我们一样快乐；我们真的都很高兴，直到晚上凯迪乘坐出租马车回家，皮皮睡得很熟，但紧紧抓住风车。

I have forgotten to mention—at least I have not mentioned—that Mr. Woodcourt was the same dark young surgeon whom we had met at Mr. Badger’s. Or that Mr. Jarndyce invited him to dinner that day. Or that he came. Or that when they were all gone and I said to Ada, ‘Now, my darling, let us have a little talk about Richard!’ Ada laughed and said—
我忘了提及——至少我没有提及——伍德考特先生就是我们在巴杰先生诊所遇到的那位皮肤黝黑的年轻外科医生。或者那天贾迪斯先生邀请他共进晚餐。或者说他来了。或者当他们都走了之后，我对艾达说：“现在，亲爱的，让我们来谈谈理查德吧！”艾达笑着说——

But I don’t think it matters what my darling said. She was always merry.
但我认为我亲爱的说的话并不重要。她总是很快乐。

CHAPTER XV
第十五章


Bell Yard
贝尔院

While we were in London Mr. Jarndyce was constantly beset by the crowd of excitable ladies and gentlemen whose proceedings had so much astonished us. Mr. Quale, who presented himself soon after our arrival, was in all such excitements. He seemed to project those two shining knobs of temples of his into everything that went on and to brush his hair farther and farther back, until the very roots were almost ready to fly out of his head in inappeasable philanthropy. All objects were alike to him, but he was always particularly ready for anything in the way of a testimonial to any one. His great power seemed to be his power of indiscriminate admiration. He would sit for any length of time, with the utmost enjoyment, bathing his temples in the light of any order of luminary. Having first seen him perfectly swallowed up in admiration of Mrs. Jellyby, I had supposed her to be the absorbing object of his devotion. I soon discovered my mistake and found him to be train-bearer and organ-blower to a whole procession of people.
当我们在伦敦时，贾迪斯先生经常被一群兴奋的女士和先生围观，他们的行为让我们大吃一惊。我们到达后不久，奎尔先生就出现了，他非常兴奋。他似乎把他那两个闪亮的太阳穴投射到了正在发生的一切中，并把他的头发向后梳得越来越远，直到头发根几乎准备好从他的头上飞出，无法平息的慈善事业。所有物体对他来说都是相似的，但他总是特别准备好以向任何人证明的方式对待任何事情。他的伟大力量，似乎就是他无差别的崇拜之力。他会以最大的享受坐上任何时间，让太阳穴沐浴在任何圣体的光芒中。第一次看到他完全沉浸在对杰利比夫人的崇拜中时，我以为她是他倾心的对象。我很快就发现了自己的错误，发现他是一大群人的火车夫和风琴吹奏者。

Mrs. Pardiggle came one day for a subscription to something, and with her, Mr. Quale. Whatever Mrs. Pardiggle said, Mr. Quale repeated to us; and just as he had drawn Mrs. Jellyby out, he drew Mrs. Pardiggle out. Mrs. Pardiggle wrote a letter of introduction to my guardian in behalf of her eloquent friend Mr. Gusher. With Mr. Gusher appeared Mr. Quale again. Mr. Gusher, being a flabby gentleman with a moist surface and eyes so much too small for his moon of a face that they seemed to have been originally made for somebody else, was not at first sight prepossessing; yet he was scarcely seated before Mr. Quale asked Ada and me, not inaudibly, whether he was not a great creature—which he certainly was, flabbily speaking, though Mr. Quale meant in intellectual beauty— and whether we were not struck by his massive configuration of brow. In short, we heard of a great many missions of various sorts among this set of people, but nothing respecting them was half so clear to us as that it was Mr. Quale’s mission to be in ecstasies with everybody else’s mission and that it was the most popular mission of all.
有一天，帕迪格太太来订阅一件东西，和她一起的还有奎尔先生。无论帕迪格夫人说什么，奎尔先生都会向我们重复一遍。就在他把杰利比夫人拉出来的同时，他也把帕迪格夫人拉了出来。帕迪格夫人代表她能言善辩的朋友古舍先生给我的监护人写了一封介绍信。与古舍先生一起出现的是奎尔先生。古舍先生是一位身材松弛的绅士，皮肤湿润，眼睛与月亮般的脸相比显得太小，似乎是为别人而生的，乍一看并不讨人喜欢。然而，他刚坐到奎尔先生面前，就小声地问艾达和我，他是否不是一个伟大的人物——他确实是，软弱地说，尽管奎尔先生指的是知性之美——以及我们是否没有被他的行为所震惊。眉毛的大量配置。简而言之，我们听说过这群人中有很多各种各样的使命，但对我们来说，没有什么比奎尔先生的使命更清楚的是，他的使命是与其他人的使命一起欣喜若狂，而这正是奎尔先生的使命。最受欢迎的任务。

Mr. Jarndyce had fallen into this company in the tenderness of his heart and his earnest desire to do all the good in his power; but that he felt it to be too often an unsatisfactory company, where benevolence took spasmodic forms, where charity was assumed as a regular uniform by loud professors and speculators in cheap notoriety, vehement in profession, restless and vain in action, servile in the last degree of meanness to the great, adulatory of one another, and intolerable to those who were anxious quietly to help the weak from failing rather than with a great deal of bluster and self-laudation to raise them up a little way when they were down, he plainly told us. When a testimonial was originated to Mr. Quale by Mr. Gusher (who had already got one, originated by Mr. Quale), and when Mr. Gusher spoke for an hour and a half on the subject to a meeting, including two charity schools of small boys and girls, who were specially reminded of the widow’s mite, and requested to come forward with halfpence and be acceptable sacrifices, I think the wind was in the east for three whole weeks.
贾迪斯先生是出于内心的温柔和尽其所能做好一切善事的热切愿望而加入这群人的。但他觉得这往往是一个令人不满意的公司，那里的仁慈采取了间歇性的形式，那里的慈善事业被那些声名狼藉的大声教授和投机者认为是一种常规制服，他们在职业上热情洋溢，在行动上焦躁不安，徒劳无功，最后卑躬屈膝。对伟人的卑鄙，对彼此的奉承，对那些默默地渴望帮助弱者免于失败的人来说是无法容忍的，而不是在他们失意时用大量的咆哮和自我吹捧来使他们稍微提高一点，他清楚地告诉我们。当 Gusher 先生向 Quale 先生发起一份感言时（他已经得到了一份由 Quale 先生发起的感言），以及当 Gusher 先生在一次会议上就该主题发表了一个半小时的演讲，其中包括两所慈善学校那些小男孩和女孩，特别提醒了寡妇的小费，并要求拿出半便士作为可以接受的牺牲，我认为风在东方持续了整整三个星期。

I mention this because I am coming to Mr. Skimpole again. It seemed to me that his off-hand professions of childishness and carelessness were a great relief to my guardian, by contrast with such things, and were the more readily believed in since to find one perfectly undesigning and candid man among many opposites could not fail to give him pleasure. I should be sorry to imply that Mr. Skimpole divined this and was politic; I really never understood him well enough to know. What he was to my guardian, he certainly was to the rest of the world.
我提到这一点是因为我又要去找斯金波尔先生了。在我看来，与这些事情相比，他即兴表白的幼稚和粗心对我的监护人来说是一种极大的安慰，而且更容易被相信，因为在众多相反的人中找到一个完全没有设计和坦率的人是不可能失败的。给他快乐。我很抱歉地暗示，斯金波尔先生已经预见到了这一点，并且很谨慎。我真的从来没有足够了解他。他对于我的监护人来说就像是对于世界其他地方一样。

He had not been very well; and thus, though he lived in London, we had seen nothing of him until now. He appeared one morning in his usual agreeable way and as full of pleasant spirits as ever.
他身体不太好。因此，虽然他住在伦敦，但我们直到现在才见到他。一天早上，他以一贯的和蔼可亲的方式出现，并且一如既往地充满愉快的精神。

Well, he said, here he was! He had been bilious, but rich men were often bilious, and therefore he had been persuading himself that he was a man of property. So he was, in a certain point of view—in his expansive intentions. He had been enriching his medical attendant in the most lavish manner. He had always doubled, and sometimes quadrupled, his fees. He had said to the doctor, ‘Now, my dear doctor, it is quite a delusion on your part to suppose that you attend me for nothing. I am overwhelming you with money—in my expansive intentions—if you only knew it!’ And really (he said) he meant it to that degree that he thought it much the same as doing it. If he had had those bits of metal or thin paper to which mankind attached so much importance to put in the doctor’s hand, he would have put them in the doctor’s hand. Not having them, he substituted the will for the deed. Very well! If he really meant it—if his will were genuine and real, which it was—it appeared to him that it was the same as coin, and cancelled the obligation.
好吧，他说，他来了！他脾气暴躁，但有钱人往往脾气暴躁，因此他一直说服自己，他是一个有钱人。从某种角度来看，他的意图也是如此。他一直在以最奢侈的方式丰富他的医疗侍从。他的费用总是加倍，有时甚至是四倍。他对医生说：“现在，我亲爱的医生，如果你以为你免费为我看病，那就太自欺欺人了。我用金钱压倒了你——在我广阔的意图中——如果你知道的话！’事实上（他说）他的意思是，他认为这与做这件事几乎是一样的。如果他把人类如此重视的那些金属碎片或薄纸放在医生手里，他就会把它们放在医生手里。由于没有这些，他用意志代替了行动。很好！如果他真的是这么想的——如果他的遗嘱是真实的、真实的——事实确实如此——在他看来，这就像硬币一样，并且取消了这项义务。

‘It may be, partly, because I know nothing of the value of money,’ said Mr. Skimpole, ‘but I often feel this. It seems so reasonable! My butcher says to me he wants that little bill. It’s a part of the pleasant unconscious poetry of the man’s nature that he always calls it a ‘little’ bill—to make the payment appear easy to both of us. I reply to the butcher, ‘My good friend, if you knew it, you are paid. You haven’t had the trouble of coming to ask for the little bill. You are paid. I mean it.’’
“这可能部分是因为我对金钱的价值一无所知，”斯金波尔先生说，“但我经常有这种感觉。”看起来很有道理啊！我的屠夫对我说他想要那张小钞票。他总是称其为“小”账单，这是这个人天性中令人愉快的无意识诗意的一部分——让付款对我们俩来说都显得很容易。我回答屠夫：‘我的好朋友，如果你知道的话，你就得到了报酬。你还没有麻烦来索要那张小帐单。你得到了报酬。我是认真的。''

‘But, suppose,’ said my guardian, laughing, ‘he had meant the meat in the bill, instead of providing it?’
“但是，假设，”我的监护人笑着说，“他指的是账单上的肉，而不是提供它？”

‘My dear Jarndyce,’ he returned, ‘you surprise me. You take the butcher’s position. A butcher I once dealt with occupied that very ground. Says he, ‘Sir, why did you eat spring lamb at eighteen pence a pound?’ ‘Why did I eat spring lamb at eighteen-pence a pound, my honest friend?’ said I, naturally amazed by the question. ‘I like spring lamb!’ This was so far convincing. ‘Well, sir,’ says he, ‘I wish I had meant the lamb as you mean the money!’ ‘My good fellow,’ said I, ‘pray let us reason like intellectual beings. How could that be? It was impossible. You HAD got the lamb, and I have NOT got the money. You couldn’t really mean the lamb without sending it in, whereas I can, and do, really mean the money without paying it!’ He had not a word. There was an end of the subject.’
“我亲爱的贾迪斯，”他回答道，“你让我很惊讶。”你占据了屠夫的位置。我曾经打过交道的一个屠夫就占据了那块地。他说：“先生，你为什么要以十八便士一磅的价格吃春羊肉？”“我诚实的朋友，为什么我要以十八便士一磅的价格吃春羊肉？”我自然而然地对这个问题感到惊讶。 “我喜欢春天的羊肉！”到目前为止，这很有说服力。 “好吧，先生，”他说，“我希望我指的是羔羊，就像您指的是金钱一样！”“我的好朋友，”我说，“请让我们像知识分子一样推理。”怎么可能呢？这是不可能的。你得到了羔羊，而我却没有得到钱。你不可能真的想要那只羔羊而不把它送进来，而我可以，而且确实，真正想要钱而不付钱！”他一言不发。话题就到此结束了。

‘Did he take no legal proceedings?’ inquired my guardian.
“他没有采取任何法律诉讼吗？”我的监护人问道。

‘Yes, he took legal proceedings,’ said Mr. Skimpole. ‘But in that he was influenced by passion, not by reason. Passion reminds me of Boythorn. He writes me that you and the ladies have promised him a short visit at his bachelor-house in Lincolnshire.’
“是的，他采取了法律诉讼，”斯金波尔先生说。 “但他是受到激情的影响，而不是理性的影响。激情让我想起博伊索恩。他写信给我说，你和女士们答应他在林肯郡的单身汉家里短暂拜访一下。

‘He is a great favourite with my girls,’ said Mr. Jarndyce, ‘and I have promised for them.’
“他是我女儿们的最爱，”贾迪斯先生说，“我已经向她们做出了承诺。”

‘Nature forgot to shade him off, I think,’ observed Mr. Skimpole to Ada and me. ‘A little too boisterous—like the sea. A little too vehement—like a bull who has made up his mind to consider every colour scarlet. But I grant a sledge-hammering sort of merit in him!’
“我想，大自然忘了把他遮蔽起来，”斯金波尔先生对艾达和我说道。 “有点太喧闹了——就像大海一样。有点太激烈了——就像一头公牛下定决心要把每种颜色都考虑为猩红色。但我承认他有大锤式的优点！

I should have been surprised if those two could have thought very highly of one another, Mr. Boythorn attaching so much importance to many things and Mr. Skimpole caring so little for anything. Besides which, I had noticed Mr. Boythorn more than once on the point of breaking out into some strong opinion when Mr. Skimpole was referred to. Of course I merely joined Ada in saying that we had been greatly pleased with him.
博伊索恩先生对许多事情如此重视，而斯金波尔先生对任何事情都漠不关心，如果这两个人能够互相评价很高的话，我会感到惊讶。除此之外，我不止一次地注意到博伊索恩先生在提到斯金波尔先生时即将发表强烈的意见。当然，我只是和艾达一起说我们对他非常满意。

‘He has invited me,’ said Mr. Skimpole; ‘and if a child may trust himself in such hands—which the present child is encouraged to do, with the united tenderness of two angels to guard him—I shall go. He proposes to frank me down and back again. I suppose it will cost money? Shillings perhaps? Or pounds? Or something of that sort? By the by, Coavinses. You remember our friend Coavinses, Miss Summerson?’
“他邀请了我，”斯金波尔先生说。 “如果一个孩子可以相信自己在这样的手中——现在的孩子被鼓励这样做，有两个天使联合的温柔来保护他——我就会去。他建议我先坦白再坦白。我想这会花钱吗？也许先令？还是磅？或者类似的东西？顺便说一句，科文斯。你还记得我们的朋友科文斯，萨默森小姐吗？

He asked me as the subject arose in his mind, in his graceful, light-hearted manner and without the least embarrassment.
当这个话题在他脑海中浮现时，他以优雅、轻松的态度问我，没有丝毫尴尬。

‘Oh, yes!’ said I.
“哦，是的！”我说。

‘Coavinses has been arrested by the Great Bailiff,’ said Mr. Skimpole. ‘He will never do violence to the sunshine any more.’
“科文斯已被大法警逮捕，”斯金波尔先生说。 “他再也不会对阳光施暴了。”

It quite shocked me to hear it, for I had already recalled with anything but a serious association the image of the man sitting on the sofa that night wiping his head.
听到这个消息，我感到非常震惊，因为那天晚上那个男人坐在沙发上擦头的画面已经让我产生了严肃的联想。

‘His successor informed me of it yesterday,’ said Mr. Skimpole. ‘His successor is in my house now—in possession, I think he calls it. He came yesterday, on my blue-eyed daughter’s birthday. I put it to him, ‘This is unreasonable and inconvenient. If you had a blue-eyed daughter you wouldn’t like ME to come, uninvited, on HER birthday?’ But he stayed.’
“他的继任者昨天告诉我这件事，”斯金波尔先生说。 “他的继任者现在在我家里——我想他称之为‘占有’。他昨天来了，那天是我蓝眼睛女儿的生日。我对他说：‘这不合理，也不方便。如果你有一个蓝眼睛的女儿，你不会希望我不请自来地在她生日那天来吗？”但他留下了。”

Mr. Skimpole laughed at the pleasant absurdity and lightly touched the piano by which he was seated.
斯金波尔先生对这令人愉快的荒唐事大笑起来，并轻轻碰了碰他坐的钢琴。

‘And he told me,’ he said, playing little chords where I shall put full stops, ‘The Coavinses had left. Three children. No mother. And that Coavinses’ profession. Being unpopular. The rising Coavinses. Were at a considerable disadvantage.’
“他告诉我，”他弹奏着小和弦，我将在此处画上句号，“科文斯一家已经离开了。”三个孩子。没有母亲。还有科文斯的职业。不受欢迎。正在崛起的科文斯。我们处于相当不利的地位。

Mr. Jarndyce got up, rubbing his head, and began to walk about. Mr. Skimpole played the melody of one of Ada’s favourite songs. Ada and I both looked at Mr. Jarndyce, thinking that we knew what was passing in his mind.
贾迪斯先生站起来，揉着头，开始走动。斯金波尔先生演奏了艾达最喜欢的一首歌曲的旋律。艾达和我都看着贾迪斯先生，以为我们知道他脑子里在想什么。

After walking and stopping, and several times leaving off rubbing his head, and beginning again, my guardian put his hand upon the keys and stopped Mr. Skimpole’s playing. ‘I don’t like this, Skimpole,’ he said thoughtfully.
我的监护人走来走去，停下来，好几次不再揉揉他的头，又重新开始，然后把手放在琴键上，停止了斯金波尔先生的演奏。 “我不喜欢这样，斯金波尔，”他若有所思地说。

Mr. Skimpole, who had quite forgotten the subject, looked up surprised.
斯金波尔先生已经完全忘记了这个话题，他惊讶地抬起头来。

‘The man was necessary,’ pursued my guardian, walking backward and forward in the very short space between the piano and the end of the room and rubbing his hair up from the back of his head as if a high east wind had blown it into that form. ‘If we make such men necessary by our faults and follies, or by our want of worldly knowledge, or by our misfortunes, we must not revenge ourselves upon them. There was no harm in his trade. He maintained his children. One would like to know more about this.’
“这个人是必要的，”我的监护人追着他说，他在钢琴和房间尽头之间的很短的空间里来回走动，揉着后脑勺的头发，仿佛一阵东风吹进了头发。那种形式。 “如果我们因为自己的错误和愚蠢、或者因为缺乏世俗知识、或者因为我们的不幸而需要这样的人，那么我们绝不能向他们报复。他的生意没有坏处。他抚养着他的孩子们。人们想更多地了解这一点。

‘Oh! Coavinses?’ cried Mr. Skimpole, at length perceiving what he meant. ‘Nothing easier. A walk to Coavinses’ headquarters, and you can know what you will.’
'哦！ “科文斯？”斯金波尔先生喊道，他终于明白了他的意思。 '没有什么比这更容易的了。步行到科文斯总部，你就知道你会做什么。

Mr. Jarndyce nodded to us, who were only waiting for the signal. ‘Come! We will walk that way, my dears. Why not that way as soon as another!’ We were quickly ready and went out. Mr. Skimpole went with us and quite enjoyed the expedition. It was so new and so refreshing, he said, for him to want Coavinses instead of Coavinses wanting him!
贾迪斯先生向我们点点头，我们只是在等待信号。 '来！我们会走那条路，亲爱的。为什么不尽快这样呢！’我们很快就准备好了，就出去了。斯金波尔先生和我们一起去了，他非常享受这次探险。他说，这太新鲜了，太令人耳目一新了，他想要科文斯，而不是科文斯想要他！

He took us, first, to Cursitor Street, Chancery Lane, where there was a house with barred windows, which he called Coavinses’ Castle. On our going into the entry and ringing a bell, a very hideous boy came out of a sort of office and looked at us over a spiked wicket.
他首先带我们去了大法官巷的库西托街，那里有一座窗户装有铁栅栏的房子，他称之为科文斯城堡。当我们走进入口并按响门铃时，一个非常丑陋的男孩从某种办公室里走出来，透过带刺的检票门看着我们。

‘Who did you want?’ said the boy, fitting two of the spikes into his chin.
“你想要谁？”男孩一边说，一边将两根尖刺钉在下巴上。

‘There was a follower, or an officer, or something, here,’ said Mr. Jarndyce, ‘who is dead.’
“这里有一个追随者，或者一个军官，或者什么东西，”贾迪斯先生说，“他已经死了。”

‘Yes?’ said the boy. ‘Well?’
“是吗？”男孩说。 '出色地？'

‘I want to know his name, if you please?’
“我想知道他的名字，可以吗？”

‘Name of Neckett,’ said the boy.
“内克特的名字。”男孩说道。

‘And his address?’
“他的地址呢？”

‘Bell Yard,’ said the boy. ‘Chandler’s shop, left hand side, name of Blinder.’
“钟院，”男孩说。 “钱德勒的商店，左手边，布林德的名字。”

‘Was he—I don’t know how to shape the question—‘ murmured my guardian, ‘industrious?’
“他——我不知道如何提出这个问题——”我的监护人低声说道，“勤奋吗？”

‘Was Neckett?’ said the boy. ‘Yes, wery much so. He was never tired of watching. He’d set upon a post at a street corner eight or ten hours at a stretch if he undertook to do it.’
“是内克特吗？”男孩问道。是的，非常如此。他总是看不厌烦。如果他愿意的话，他会连续八到十个小时在街角设立一个柱子。

‘He might have done worse,’ I heard my guardian soliloquize. ‘He might have undertaken to do it and not done it. Thank you. That’s all I want.’
“他可能做得更糟，”我听到我的监护人自言自语。 “他可能已经承诺要做这件事，但没有做到。谢谢。这就是我想要的。

We left the boy, with his head on one side and his arms on the gate, fondling and sucking the spikes, and went back to Lincoln’s Inn, where Mr. Skimpole, who had not cared to remain nearer Coavinses, awaited us. Then we all went to Bell Yard, a narrow alley at a very short distance. We soon found the chandler’s shop. In it was a good-natured-looking old woman with a dropsy, or an asthma, or perhaps both.
我们留下那个男孩，他的头偏在一侧，双臂放在门上，抚摸着并吮吸着钉子，然后回到林肯旅馆，不愿意靠近科文斯的斯金波尔先生在那里等着我们。然后我们就去了贝尔院，一条距离很近的窄巷。我们很快就找到了杂货店。里面有一位看上去和蔼可亲的老妇人，她患有浮肿病，或者哮喘病，或者两者兼而有之。

‘Neckett’s children?’ said she in reply to my inquiry. ‘Yes, Surely, miss. Three pair, if you please. Door right opposite the stairs.’ And she handed me the key across the counter.
“内克特的孩子们？”她回答我的问题时说道。 “是的，当然，小姐。如果可以的话，三对。门就在楼梯对面。”然后她把钥匙穿过柜台递给了我。

I glanced at the key and glanced at her, but she took it for granted that I knew what to do with it. As it could only be intended for the children’s door, I came out without askmg any more questions and led the way up the dark stairs. We went as quietly as we could, but four of us made some noise on the aged boards, and when we came to the second story we found we had disturbed a man who was standing there looking out of his room.
我看了一眼钥匙，又看了她一眼，但她理所当然地认为我知道该怎么处理它。由于它只能用于儿童门，所以我没有再问任何问题就出来了，带路走上黑暗的楼梯。我们尽可能安静地走着，但我们四个人在老化的木板上发出了一些噪音，当我们来到二楼时，我们发现我们打扰了一个站在那里向房间外望去的男人。

‘Is it Gridley that’s wanted?’ he said, fixing his eyes on me with an angry stare.
“是要找格里德利吗？”他说，用愤怒的目光盯着我。

‘No, sir,’ said I; ‘I am going higher up.’
“不，先生，”我说。 “我要去更高的地方。”

He looked at Ada, and at Mr. Jarndyce, and at Mr. Skimpole, fixing the same angry stare on each in succession as they passed and followed me. Mr. Jarndyce gave him good day. ‘Good day!’ he said abruptly and fiercely. He was a tall, sallow man with a careworn head on which but little hair remained, a deeply lined face, and prominent eyes. He had a combative look and a chafing, irritable manner which, associated with his figure—still large and powerful, though evidently in its decline—rather alarmed me. He had a pen in his hand, and in the glimpse I caught of his room in passing, I saw that it was covered with a litter of papers.
他看看艾达，看看贾迪斯先生，又看看斯金波尔先生，当他们走过并跟着我时，他连续用同样愤怒的目光盯着每个人。贾迪斯先生祝他度过了美好的一天。 “美好的一天！”他突然而激烈地说。他身材高大，脸色蜡黄，满头愁容，头发所剩无几，脸上布满深深的皱纹，眼睛突出。他的表情好斗，态度焦躁易怒，这与他的身材相联系——尽管明显在衰落，但身材仍然高大有力——让我感到相当震惊。他手里拿着一支笔，当我路过他的房间时，我看到里面堆满了一堆文件。

Leaving him standing there, we went up to the top room. I tapped at the door, and a little shrill voice inside said, ‘We are locked in. Mrs. Blinder’s got the key!’
留下他站在那里，我们上了顶层的房间。我敲了敲门，里面传来一个尖细的声音：“我们被锁在里面了。布林德太太拿到了钥匙！”

I applied the key on hearing this and opened the door. In a poor room with a sloping ceiling and containing very little furniture was a mite of a boy, some five or six years old, nursing and hushing a heavy child of eighteen months. There was no fire, though the weather was cold; both children were wrapped in some poor shawls and tippets as a substitute. Their clothing was not so warm, however, but that their noses looked red and pinched and their small figures shrunken as the boy walked up and down nursing and hushing the child with its head on his shoulder.
我一听这话就用钥匙打开了门。在一间天花板倾斜、家具很少的简陋房间里，有一个五六岁左右的小男孩，正在照顾和安抚一个十八个月大的大孩子。尽管天气寒冷，但没有生火。两个孩子都裹着一些破烂的披肩和披肩作为替代品。然而，他们的衣服并不那么暖和，但当男孩走来走去，把孩子的头靠在他的肩上时，他们的鼻子看起来又红又紧，他们的小身材也缩小了。

‘Who has locked you up here alone?’ we naturally asked.
“谁把你一个人关在这里？”我们自然地问道。

‘Charley,’ said the boy, standing still to gaze at us.
“查理，”男孩说，一动不动地站着看着我们。

‘Is Charley your brother?’
“查理是你哥哥吗？”

‘No. She’s my sister, Charlotte. Father called her Charley.’
'不。她是我的妹妹夏洛特。父亲叫她查理。

‘Are there any more of you besides Charley?’
“除了查理之外，你们还有其他人吗？”

‘Me,’ said the boy, ‘and Emma,’ patting the limp bonnet of the child he was nursing. ‘And Charley.’
“我，”男孩说，“还有艾玛，”拍拍他正在哺乳的孩子软软的帽子。 “还有查理。”

‘Where is Charley now?’
“查理现在在哪里？”

‘Out a-washing,’ said the boy, beginning to walk up and down again and taking the nankeen bonnet much too near the bedstead by trying to gaze at us at the same time.
“出去洗衣服了。”男孩说着，又开始走来走去，同时把那顶南京帽子离床架太近了，试图同时注视着我们。

We were looking at one another and at these two children when there came into the room a very little girl, childish in figure but shrewd and older-looking in the face—pretty-faced too—wearing a womanly sort of bonnet much too large for her and drying her bare arms on a womanly sort of apron. Her fingers were white and wrinkled with washing, and the soap-suds were yet smoking which she wiped off her arms. But for this, she might have been a child playing at washing and imitating a poor working-woman with a quick observation of the truth.
我们互相看着对方，看着这两个孩子，这时一个小女孩走进了房间，她身材稚气，但面容精明、苍老——脸蛋也很漂亮——戴着一顶女人味的帽子，帽子太大了。并用女性化的围裙擦干她裸露的手臂。她的手指因洗涤而变得苍白、皱巴巴的，她擦掉手臂上的肥皂沫，还在冒烟。如果不是这样，她可能只是一个玩洗衣的孩子，模仿一个快速观察真相的贫穷女工。

She had come running from some place in the neighbourhood and had made all the haste she could. Consequently, though she was very light, she was out of breath and could not speak at first, as she stood panting, and wiping her arms, and looking quietly at us.
她是从附近的某个地方跑来的，并且已经尽了最大的努力。结果，她虽然很轻，但一开始却气喘吁吁，说不出话来，只是气喘吁吁地站着，擦着胳膊，静静地看着我们。

‘Oh, here’s Charley!’ said the boy.
“哦，查理来了！”男孩说。

The child he was nursing stretched forth its arms and cried out to be taken by Charley. The little girl took it, in a womanly sort of manner belonging to the apron and the bonnet, and stood looking at us over the burden that clung to her most affectionately.
他正在哺乳的孩子张开双臂，哭喊着要查理抱走。小女孩接过它，以一种属于围裙和帽子的女人味，站在那儿，越过她最深情的负担，看着我们。

‘Is it possible,’ whispered my guardian as we put a chair for the little creature and got her to sit down with her load, the boy keeping close to her, holding to her apron, ‘that this child works for the rest? Look at this! For God’s sake, look at this!’
“有没有可能，”我的监护人低声说道，我们给这个小生物放了一把椅子，让她带着她的货物坐下，男孩紧紧地贴着她，抓着她的围裙，“这个孩子为其余的人工作吗？”看这个！看在上帝的份上，看看这个！”

It was a thing to look at. The three children close together, and two of them relying solely on the third, and the third so young and yet with an air of age and steadiness that sat so strangely on the childish figure.
这是一件值得一看的事情。三个孩子靠得很近，其中两个完全依赖第三个，而第三个则如此年轻，却带着一种上了年纪、稳重的神情，坐在这个孩子气的身影上显得如此奇怪。

‘Charley, Charley!’ said my guardian. ‘How old are you?’
“查理，查理！”我的监护人说。 '你今年多大？'

‘Over thirteen, sir,’ replied the child.
“先生，已经超过十三岁了，”孩子回答道。

‘Oh! What a great age,’ said my guardian. ‘What a great age, Charley!’
'哦！多么美好的年纪啊，”我的监护人说。 “多么美好的年纪啊，查理！”

I cannot describe the tenderness with which he spoke to her, half playfully yet all the more compassionately and mournfully.
我无法形容他对她说话时的温柔，一半是开玩笑，但更多的是同情和悲伤。

‘And do you live alone here with these babies, Charley?’ said my guardian.
“查理，你一个人和这些婴儿住在这里吗？”我的监护人说。

‘Yes, sir,’ returned the child, looking up into his face with perfect confidence, ‘since father died.’
“是的，先生，”孩子回答道，充满信心地抬头看着他的脸，“自从父亲去世以来。”

‘And how do you live, Charley? Oh! Charley,’ said my guardian, turning his face away for a moment, ‘how do you live?’
‘查理，你过着怎样的生活？哦！查理，”我的监护人把脸转过一会儿，说道，“你过着怎样的生活？

‘Since father died, sir, I’ve gone out to work. I’m out washing to-day.’
“先生，自从父亲去世后，我就出去工作了。我今天出去洗衣服了。”

‘God help you, Charley!’ said my guardian. ‘You’re not tall enough to reach the tub!’
“上帝保佑你，查理！”我的监护人说。 “你还不够高，够不到浴缸！”

‘In pattens I am, sir,’ she said quickly. ‘I’ve got a high pair as belonged to mother.’
“我是帕滕斯，先生，”她很快说道。 “我有一双属于母亲的高帮鞋。”

‘And when did mother die? Poor mother!’
‘妈妈什么时候死的？可怜的妈妈！

‘Mother died just after Emma was born,’ said the child, glancing at the face upon her bosom. ‘Then father said I was to be as good a mother to her as I could. And so I tried. And so I worked at home and did cleaning and nursing and washing for a long time before I began to go out. And that’s how I know how; don’t you see, sir?’
“艾玛出生后，母亲就去世了。”孩子看着她胸前的脸说道。 “然后父亲说我要尽我所能成为她的好母亲。所以我尝试了。所以我在家里干了很长一段时间的清洁、护理和洗衣工作，然后才开始出去。这就是我所知道的；你没看到吗，先生？

‘And do you often go out?’
“你经常出去吗？”

‘As often as I can,’ said Charley, opening her eyes and smiling, ‘because of earning sixpences and shillings!’
“只要有机会，”查莉睁开眼睛微笑着说，“因为能赚六便士和先令！”

‘And do you always lock the babies up when you go out?’
“你外出时总是把婴儿锁起来吗？”

‘To keep ‘em safe, sir, don’t you see?’ said Charley. ‘Mrs. Blinder comes up now and then, and Mr. Gridley comes up sometimes, and perhaps I can run in sometimes, and they can play you know, and Tom an’t afraid of being locked up, are you, Tom?’
“为了保证他们的安全，先生，你明白吗？”查理说。 '太太。布林德时不时地出现，格里德利先生有时也会出现，也许我有时可以跑进去，他们可以玩，你知道，汤姆不怕被关起来，是吗，汤姆？

‘’No-o!’ said Tom stoutly.
“不——哦！”汤姆坚决地说。

‘When it comes on dark, the lamps are lighted down in the court, and they show up here quite bright—almost quite bright. Don’t they, Tom?’
“天黑的时候，庭院里的灯都亮了，这里显得非常明亮——几乎非常明亮。不是吗，汤姆？

‘Yes, Charley,’ said Tom, ‘almost quite bright.’
“是的，查理，”汤姆说，“几乎很聪明。”

‘Then he’s as good as gold,’ said the little creature—Oh, in such a motherly, womanly way! ‘And when Emma’s tired, he puts her to bed. And when he’s tired he goes to bed himself. And when I come home and light the candle and has a bit of supper, he sits up again and has it with me. Don’t you, Tom?’
“那么他就和金子一样好，”这个小动物说——哦，以如此慈母般、女性般的方式！ “当艾玛累了的时候，他就会让她上床睡觉。当他累了的时候，他就会自己上床睡觉。当我回到家点燃蜡烛并吃点晚饭时，他又坐起来和我一起吃。你不是吗，汤姆？

‘Oh, yes, Charley!’ said Tom. ‘That I do!’ And either in this glimpse of the great pleasure of his life or in gratitude and love for Charley, who was all in all to him, he laid his face among the scanty folds of her frock and passed from laughing into crying.
“哦，是的，查理！”汤姆说。 “我愿意！”无论是瞥见了他生命中的巨大乐趣，还是出于对查理的感激和爱，查理是他的一切，他把脸埋在她连衣裙的稀疏褶皱中，从笑声变成了笑声。哭了。

It was the first time since our entry that a tear had been shed among these children. The little orphan girl had spoken of their father and their mother as if all that sorrow were subdued by the necessity of taking courage, and by her childish importance in being able to work, and by her bustling busy way. But now, when Tom cried, although she sat quite tranquil, looking quietly at us, and did not by any movement disturb a hair of the head of either of her little charges, I saw two silent tears fall down her face.
自从我们进来以来，这是这些孩子们第一次流泪。小孤女谈到他们的父亲和母亲，仿佛所有的悲伤都被鼓起勇气的必要性、她孩子气的工作能力和她忙碌的生活方式所抑制。但现在，当汤姆哭泣时，尽管她安静地坐着，静静地看着我们，没有任何动作惊动她的两个小孩子的一根头发，我看到两滴泪水无声地从她的脸上滑落。

I stood at the window with Ada, pretending to look at the housetops, and the blackened stack of chimneys, and the poor plants, and the birds in little cages belonging to the neighbours, when I found that Mrs. Blinder, from the shop below, had come in (perhaps it had taken her all this time to get upstairs) and was talking to my guardian.
我和艾达站在窗前，假装看着房顶、熏黑的烟囱、可怜的植物，还有邻居家小笼子里的鸟儿，这时我发现楼下商店里的布林德太太，进来了（也许她花了很长时间才上楼），正在和我的监护人说话。

‘It’s not much to forgive ‘em the rent, sir,’ she said; ‘who could take it from them!’
“先生，免除他们的房租并不算什么，”她说。 “谁能从他们手中夺走它！”

‘’Well, well!’ said my guardian to us two. ‘It is enough that the time will come when this good woman will find that it WAS much, and that forasmuch as she did it unto the least of these—This child,’ he added after a few moments, ‘could she possibly continue this?’
“好吧，好吧！”我的监护人对我们两个说道。 “到了这个时候，这个好女人就会发现，这已经足够了，因为她对这些人中最小的一个做了这件事——这个孩子，”过了一会儿，他补充道，“她能继续这个吗？” ？

‘Really, sir, I think she might,’ said Mrs. Blinder, getting her heavy breath by painful degrees. ‘She’s as handy as it’s possible to be. Bless you, sir, the way she tended them two children after the mother died was the talk of the yard! And it was a wonder to see her with him after he was took ill, it really was! ‘Mrs. Blinder,’ he said to me the very last he spoke—he was lying there —‘Mrs. Blinder, whatever my calling may have been, I see a angel sitting in this room last night along with my child, and I trust her to Our Father!’’
“真的，先生，我想她可能会这样，”布林德太太说，她的呼吸越来越沉重，感到痛苦。 “她真是太方便了。”上帝保佑您，先生，母亲去世后她照顾两个孩子的方式成了院子里的话题！他生病后看到她和他在一起真是一个奇迹，确实如此！ '太太。布林德，”他躺在那儿的最后一刻对我说，“布林德太太。布林德，无论我的使命是什么，昨晚我看到一位天使和我的孩子一起坐在这个房间里，我将她托付给我们的父亲！”

‘He had no other calling?’ said my guardian.
“他没有别的职业吗？”我的监护人说。

‘No, sir,’ returned Mrs. Blinder, ‘he was nothing but a follerers. When he first came to lodge here, I didn’t know what he was, and I confess that when I found out I gave him notice. It wasn’t liked in the yard. It wasn’t approved by the other lodgers. It is NOT a genteel calling,’ said Mrs. Blinder, ‘and most people do object to it. Mr. Gridley objected to it very strong, and he is a good lodger, though his temper has been hard tried.’
“不，先生，”布林德太太回答道，“他只不过是一个追随者。”当他第一次来这里住宿时，我不知道他是什么人，我承认当我发现时我就通知了他。院子里不受欢迎。它没有得到其他房客的批准。这不是一个优雅的召唤，”布林德夫人说，“而且大多数人确实反对它。格里德利先生非常强烈地反对，他是一个很好的房客，尽管他的脾气已经受到了考验。

‘So you gave him notice?’ said my guardian.
“所以你通知了他？”我的监护人说。

‘So I gave him notice,’ said Mrs. Blinder. ‘But really when the time came, and I knew no other ill of him, I was in doubts. He was punctual and diligent; he did what he had to do, sir,’ said Mrs. Blinder, unconsciously fixing Mr. Skimpole with her eye, ‘and it’s something in this world even to do that.’
“所以我通知了他，”布林德夫人说。 “但真正到了那个时候，我又不知道他有什么坏处，我就产生了怀疑。他准时、勤奋； “他做了他必须做的事，先生，”布林德夫人说，她的眼睛无意识地盯着斯金波尔先生，“即使这样做，这也是这个世界上的事情。”

‘So you kept him after all?’
“所以你还是留住了他？”

‘Why, I said that if he could arrange with Mr. Gridley, I could arrange it with the other lodgers and should not so much mind its being liked or disliked in the yard. Mr. Gridley gave his consent gruff—but gave it. He was always gruff with him, but he has been kind to the children since. A person is never known till a person is proved.’
“哎呀，我说过，如果他能和格里德利先生安排好，我就能和其他房客安排好，而且不应该太介意院子里的人喜欢或不喜欢它。格里德利先生粗声粗气地表示同意——但还是同意了。他总是对他很粗暴，但从那以后他对孩子们就很好了。在一个人被证明之前，一个人永远不会被认识。

‘Have many people been kind to the children?’ asked Mr. Jarndyce.
“很多人都善待孩子们吗？”贾迪斯先生问道。

‘Upon the whole, not so bad, sir,’ said Mrs. Blinder; ‘but certainly not so many as would have been if their father’s calling had been different. Mr. Coavins gave a guinea, and the follerers made up a little purse. Some neighbours in the yard that had always joked and tapped their shoulders when he went by came forward with a little subscription, and—in general—not so bad. Similarly with Charlotte. Some people won’t employ her because she was a follerer’s child; some people that do employ her cast it at her; some make a merit of having her to work for them, with that and all her draw-backs upon her, and perhaps pay her less and put upon her more. But she’s patienter than others would be, and is clever too, and always willing, up to the full mark of her strength and over. So I should say, in general, not so bad, sir, but might be better.’
“总的来说，还不错，先生，”布林德太太说。 “但如果他们父亲的使命不同的话，人数肯定不会那么多。”科文斯先生捐了一个几尼，追随者们凑了一个小钱包。院子里的一些邻居总是在他经过时开玩笑并拍拍肩膀，他们主动捐了一点钱，而且——总的来说——还不错。夏洛特也是如此。有些人不会雇用她，因为她是追随者的孩子。一些雇用她的人也对她持批评态度。有些人认为让她为他们工作是有好处的，尽管她的缺点和缺点都加在她身上，也许他们付给她的钱更少，但给她的负担却更多。但她比其他人更有耐心，也很聪明，而且总是愿意，充分发挥自己的力量。所以我应该说，总的来说，还不错，先生，但可能会更好。”

Mrs. Blinder sat down to give herself a more favourable opportunity of recovering her breath, exhausted anew by so much talking before it was fully restored. Mr. Jarndyce was turning to speak to us when his attention was attracted by the abrupt entrance into the room of the Mr. Gridley who had been mentioned and whom we had seen on our way up.
布林德夫人坐下来，给自己一个更有利的恢复呼吸的机会，在完全恢复呼吸之前，她因说话太多而再次疲惫不堪。贾迪斯先生正转身和我们说话，这时他的注意力被突然闯入房间的格里德利先生吸引了，我们在上楼的路上曾提到过他。

‘I don’t know what you may be doing here, ladies and gentlemen,’ he said, as if he resented our presence, ‘but you’ll excuse my coming in. I don’t come in to stare about me. Well, Charley! Well, Tom! Well, little one! How is it with us all to-day?’
“我不知道你们在这里做什么，女士们先生们，”他说道，好像他对我们的存在感到不满，“但是你们请原谅我进来。我进来不是为了盯着我看。”好吧，查理！好吧，汤姆！嗯，小家伙！今天我们大家怎么样？

He bent over the group in a caressing way and clearly was regarded as a friend by the children, though his face retained its stern character and his manner to us was as rude as it could be. My guardian noticed it and respected it.
他以一种爱抚的方式俯身在这群人身上，显然被孩子们视为朋友，尽管他的表情仍然保持着严肃的性格，而且他对我们的态度也非常粗鲁。我的监护人注意到了这一点并尊重它。

‘No one, surely, would come here to stare about him,’ he said mildly.
“当然，没有人会来这里盯着他看，”他温和地说。

‘May be so, sir, may be so,’ returned the other, taking Tom upon his knee and waving him off impatiently. ‘I don’t want to argue with ladies and gentlemen. I have had enough of arguing to last one man his life.’
“也许是这样，先生，也许是这样。”另一个人回答道，把汤姆抱在膝上，不耐烦地挥手让他走开。 “我不想与女士们先生们争论。我已经受够了争论，足以维持一个人的生命。

‘You have sufficient reason, I dare say,’ said Mr. Jarndyce, ‘for being chafed and irritated—‘
“我敢说，”贾迪斯先生说，“你有充分的理由感到恼火和恼怒——”

‘There again!’ exclaimed the man, becoming violently angry. ‘I am of a quarrelsome temper. I am irascible. I am not polite!’
“又来了！”那人大声说道，变得非常愤怒。 ‘我的脾气很暴躁。我脾气暴躁。我没有礼貌！

‘Not very, I think.’
“我认为不太好。”

‘Sir,’ said Gridley, putting down the child and going up to him as if he meant to strike him, ‘do you know anything of Courts of Equity?’
“先生，”格里德利放下孩子，走到他面前，好像要打他，“您了解衡平法院吗？”

‘Perhaps I do, to my sorrow.’
“也许我会这么做，但令我悲伤的是。”

‘To your sorrow?’ said the man, pausing in his wrath. ‘if so, I beg your pardon. I am not polite, I know. I beg your pardon! Sir,’ with renewed violence, ‘I have been dragged for five and twenty years over burning iron, and I have lost the habit of treading upon velvet. Go into the Court of Chancery yonder and ask what is one of the standing jokes that brighten up their business sometimes, and they will tell you that the best joke they have is the man from Shropshire. I,’ he said, beating one hand on the other passionately, ‘am the man from Shropshire.’
“让你伤心吗？”男人怒气冲冲地说道。 ‘如果是这样，请原谅。我没有礼貌，我知道。请再说一遍！先生，”再次暴怒道，“我已经在烧铁上拖了五年、二十年了，我已经失去了踩天鹅绒的习惯。走进那边的大法官法庭，询问有时可以让他们的生意变得有趣的笑话之一，他们会告诉你，他们最好的笑话是那个来自什罗普郡的人。 “我，”他热情地用一只手拍打着另一只手说道，“我是来自什罗普郡的人。”

‘I believe I and my family have also had the honour of furnishing some entertainment in the same grave place,’ said my guardian composedly. ‘You may have heard my name—Jarndyce.’
“我相信我和我的家人也有幸在同一个坟墓里提供了一些娱乐活动，”我的监护人平静地说。 “你可能听说过我的名字——贾迪斯。”

‘Mr. Jarndyce,’ said Gridley with a rough sort of salutation, ‘you bear your wrongs more quietly than I can bear mine. More than that, I tell you—and I tell this gentleman, and these young ladies, if they are friends of yours—that if I took my wrongs in any other way, I should be driven mad! It is only by resenting them, and by revenging them in my mind, and by angrily demanding the justice I never get, that I am able to keep my wits together. It is only that!’ he said, speaking in a homely, rustic way and with great vehemence. ‘You may tell me that I over-excite myself. I answer that it’s in my nature to do it, under wrong, and I must do it. There’s nothing between doing it, and sinking into the smiling state of the poor little mad woman that haunts the court. If I was once to sit down under it, I should become imbecile.’
'先生。贾迪斯，”格里德利粗暴地行礼道，“你承受自己的错误比我承受自己的错误更安静。不仅如此，我告诉你——我告诉这位先生和这些年轻女士，如果他们是你的朋友的话——如果我以任何其他方式接受我的错误，我就会发疯！只有怨恨他们，在心里报复他们，愤怒地要求我从未得到的正义，我才能保持理智。仅此而已！”他说，语气平淡、质朴，语气十分激烈。 “你可能会告诉我，我自己太兴奋了。我回答说，这样做是我的本性，即使是错误的，我也必须这样做。这样做和陷入法庭上那个出没的可怜的小疯女人的微笑状态之间没有什么关系。如果我曾经坐在它下面，我就会变得愚蠢。

The passion and heat in which he was, and the manner in which his face worked, and the violent gestures with which he accompanied what he said, were most painful to see.
他的热情和热情，他脸上的表情，以及他说话时的暴力手势，都是最令人痛苦的。

‘Mr. Jarndyce,’ he said, ‘consider my case. As true as there is a heaven above us, this is my case. I am one of two brothers. My father (a farmer) made a will and left his farm and stock and so forth to my mother for her life. After my mother’s death, all was to come to me except a legacy of three hundred pounds that I was then to pay my brother. My mother died. My brother some time afterwards claimed his legacy. I and some of my relations said that he had had a part of it already in board and lodging and some other things. Now mind! That was the question, and nothing else. No one disputed the will; no one disputed anything but whether part of that three hundred pounds had been already paid or not. To settle that question, my brother filing a bill, I was obliged to go into this accursed Chancery; I was forced there because the law forced me and would let me go nowhere else. Seventeen people were made defendants to that simple suit! It first came on after two years. It was then stopped for another two years while the master (may his head rot off!) inquired whether I was my father’s son, about which there was no dispute at all with any mortal creature. He then found out that there were not defendants enough—remember, there were only seventeen as yet!—but that we must have another who had been left out and must begin all over again. The costs at that time—before the thing was begun!—were three times the legacy. My brother would have given up the legacy, and joyful, to escape more costs. My whole estate, left to me in that will of my father’s, has gone in costs. The suit, still undecided, has fallen into rack, and ruin, and despair, with everything else—and here I stand, this day! Now, Mr. Jarndyce, in your suit there are thousands and thousands involved, where in mine there are hundreds. Is mine less hard to bear or is it harder to bear, when my whole living was in it and has been thus shamefully sucked away?’
'先生。贾迪斯，”他说，“考虑一下我的情况。正如我们头顶上有一个天堂一样，这就是我的情况。我是两个兄弟之一。我父亲（农民）立了遗嘱，把他的农场和牲畜等留给了我母亲生活。我母亲去世后，一切都归我所有，除了我当时要付给我哥哥的三百英镑遗产。我母亲去世了。一段时间后，我的兄弟领取了他的遗产。我和我的一些亲戚说，他已经把一部分钱放在了食宿和其他一些东西上。现在介意！这就是问题，除此之外没有别的。没有人对遗嘱提出异议；除了这三百英镑中的一部分是否已经支付之外，没有人对任何事情提出异议。为了解决这个问题，我的兄弟提出了一项法案，我不得不走进这个该死的大法官办公室；我被迫去那里是因为法律强迫我，不让我去其他地方。就这件简单的诉讼，有十七个人成为被告！它是在两年后首次出现的。然后又停了两年，而主人（愿他的头烂掉！）询问我是否是我父亲的儿子，对此与任何凡人都没有任何争议。然后他发现被告人数不够——记住，目前只有十七人！——但我们必须有另一个被排除在外的人，必须重新开始。当时的成本——在事情开始之前！——是遗产的三倍。我的兄弟会很高兴地放弃遗产，以逃避更多的费用。我父亲遗嘱中留给我的全部财产都已投入成本。这套诉讼，仍未决定，已经和其他一切一样陷入了困境、毁灭和绝望——而今天我站在这里！现在，先生。 贾迪斯，你的诉讼涉及成千上万的人，而我的诉讼有数百人。当我的全部生命都在其中并被可耻地吸走时，我的生活是更难忍受还是更难忍受？’

Mr. Jarndyce said that he condoled with him with all his heart and that he set up no monopoly himself in being unjustly treated by this monstrous system.
贾迪斯先生表示，他对他表示全心全意的哀悼，并表示他自己受到这个可怕制度的不公正对待并不意味着他有任何垄断行为。

‘There again!’ said Mr. Gridley with no diminution of his rage. ‘The system! I am told on all hands, it’s the system. I mustn’t look to individuals. It’s the system. I mustn’t go into court and say, ‘My Lord, I beg to know this from you—is this right or wrong? Have you the face to tell me I have received justice and therefore am dismissed?’ My Lord knows nothing of it. He sits there to administer the system. I mustn’t go to Mr. Tulkinghorn, the solicitor in Lincoln’s Inn Fields, and say to him when he makes me furious by being so cool and satisfied—as they all do, for I know they gain by it while I lose, don’t I?—I mustn’t say to him, ‘I will have something out of some one for my ruin, by fair means or foul!’ HE is not responsible. It’s the system. But, if I do no violence to any of them, here—I may! I don’t know what may happen if I am carried beyond myself at last! I will accuse the individual workers of that system against me, face to face, before the great eternal bar!’
“又来了！”格里德利先生说道，他的愤怒丝毫没有减弱。 '系统！大家都告诉我，这是系统。我不能把目光投向个人。这是系统。我不能走进法庭说：‘法官大人，我恳求您知道这一点——这是对还是错？你有脸告诉我，我已经得到了正义，因此被解雇了？’我的主对此一无所知。他坐在那里管理系统。当塔尔金霍恩先生（林肯律师学院的律师）表现得如此冷静和满足而让我大发雷霆时，我不能去找他，对他说——正如他们所有人所做的那样，因为我知道他们从中受益，而我却输了，不要我不是吗？——我不能对他说，“我会为了我的毁灭而从某人那里得到一些东西，不管是通过公平还是不正当的手段！”他不负有责任。这是系统。但是，如果我不对他们中的任何一个人实施暴力，在这里——我可以！我不知道如果我最终超越自我会发生什么！我将在伟大的永恒酒吧面前，面对面地指控该系统的个别工人反对我！

His passion was fearful. I could not have believed in such rage without seeing it.
他的热情令人恐惧。如果没有亲眼目睹，我简直不敢相信会有这样的愤怒。

‘I have done!’ he said, sitting down and wiping his face. ‘Mr. Jarndyce, I have done! I am violent, I know. I ought to know it. I have been in prison for contempt of court. I have been in prison for threatening the solicitor. I have been in this trouble, and that trouble, and shall be again. I am the man from Shropshire, and I sometimes go beyond amusing them, though they have found it amusing, too, to see me committed into custody and brought up in custody and all that. It would be better for me, they tell me, if I restrained myself. I tell them that if I did restrain myself I should become imbecile. I was a good-enough-tempered man once, I believe. People in my part of the country say they remember me so, but now I must have this vent under my sense of injury or nothing could hold my wits together. It would be far better for you, Mr. Gridley,’ the Lord Chancellor told me last week, ‘not to waste your time here, and to stay, usefully employed, down in Shropshire.’ ‘My Lord, my Lord, I know it would,’ said I to him, ‘and it would have been far better for me never to have heard the name of your high office, but unhappily for me, I can’t undo the past, and the past drives me here!’ Besides,’ he added, breaking fiercely out, ‘I’ll shame them.
