To the last, I’ll show myself in that court to its shame. If I knew when I was going to die, and could be carried there, and had a voice to speak with, I would die there, saying, ‘You have brought me here and sent me from here many and many a time. Now send me out feet foremost!’’
“我已经做到了！”他一边说，一边坐下来擦脸。 '先生。贾迪斯，我做到了！我很暴力，我知道。我应该知道的。我因藐视法庭而入狱。我因威胁律师而入狱。我曾经遇到过这样的麻烦，那样的麻烦，以后还会再遇到。我是来自什罗普郡的人，有时我不仅让他们感到好笑，尽管他们也觉得看到我被拘留、被拘留以及诸如此类的事情很有趣。他们告诉我，如果我克制自己，对我来说会更好。我告诉他们，如果我真的克制自己，我就会变得低能。我相信，我曾经是一个脾气很好的人。我所在地区的人们说他们记得我，但现在我必须在受伤的感觉下发泄，否则没有什么可以让我保持理智。格里德利先生，大法官上周对我说，“不要在这里浪费时间，留在什罗普郡，做有用的工作，对你来说会好得多。”“大人，大人，我知道”我对他说，“对我来说，如果我从来没有听说过你的高级职位的名字，那就好得多，但对我来说不幸的是，我无法挽回过去，而过去却把我赶到了这里！ ”此外，他猛烈地说道，“我会让他们感到羞耻。最后，我将在法庭上让自己蒙羞。如果我知道我什么时候会死，并且可以被带到那里，并且有一个声音可以说话，我会死在那里，说：‘你多次把我带到这里，又把我从这里送走。现在让我先出去！”

His countenance had, perhaps for years, become so set in its contentious expression that it did not soften, even now when he was quiet.
也许多年来，他的脸上一直充满争议性的表情，即使现在他安静下来，也没有软化。

‘I came to take these babies down to my room for an hour,’ he said, going to them again, ‘and let them play about. I didn’t mean to say all this, but it don’t much signify. You’re not afraid of me, Tom, are you?’
“我来是为了带这些婴儿到我的房间待一个小时，”他说着又走到他们身边，“让他们玩耍。”我本来不想说这些，但意义不大。汤姆，你不怕我，是吗？

‘No!’ said Tom. ‘You ain’t angry with ME.’
“不！”汤姆说。 “你没有生我的气。”

‘You are right, my child. You’re going back, Charley? Aye? Come then, little one!’ He took the youngest child on his arm, where she was willing enough to be carried. ‘I shouldn’t wonder if we found a ginger-bread soldier downstairs. Let’s go and look for him!’
‘你是对的，我的孩子。你要回去吗，查理？是吗？来吧，小家伙！”他把最小的孩子抱在怀里，她很乐意抱着。 “我不应该怀疑我们是否在楼下发现了姜饼士兵。我们去找他吧！

He made his former rough salutation, which was not deficient in a certain respect, to Mr. Jarndyce, and bowing slightly to us, went downstairs to his room.
他向贾迪斯先生行了以前粗暴的行礼，这在某种程度上并不缺乏，然后向我们微微鞠了一躬，然后下楼回到了他的房间。

Upon that, Mr. Skimpole began to talk, for the first time since our arrival, in his usual gay strain. He said, Well, it was really very pleasant to see how things lazily adapted themselves to purposes. Here was this Mr. Gridley, a man of a robust will and surprising energy—intellectually speaking, a sort of inharmonious blacksmith—and he could easily imagine that there Gridley was, years ago, wandering about in life for something to expend his superfluous combativeness upon—a sort of Young Love among the thorns—when the Court of Chancery came in his way and accommodated him with the exact thing he wanted. There they were, matched, ever afterwards! Otherwise he might have been a great general, blowing up all sorts of towns, or he might have been a great politician, dealing in all sorts of parliamentary rhetoric; but as it was, he and the Court of Chancery had fallen upon each other in the pleasantest way, and nobody was much the worse, and Gridley was, so to speak, from that hour provided for. Then look at Coavinses! How delightfully poor Coavinses (father of these charming children) illustrated the same principle! He, Mr. Skimpole, himself, had sometimes repined at the existence of Coavinses. He had found Coavinses in his way. He could had dispensed with Coavinses. There had been times when, if he had been a sultan, and his grand vizier had said one morning, ‘What does the Commander of the Faithful require at the hands of his slave?’ he might have even gone so far as to reply, ‘The head of Coavinses!’ But what turned out to be the case? That, all that time, he had been giving employment to a most deserving man, that he had been a benefactor to Coavinses, that he had actually been enabling Coavinses to bring up these charming children in this agreeable way, developing these social virtues! Insomuch that his heart had just now swelled and the tears had come into his eyes when he had looked round the room and thought, ‘I was the great patron of Coavinses, and his little comforts were MY work!’
就在这时，斯金波尔先生开始用他一贯的欢快语气说话，这是我们抵达以来的第一次。他说，嗯，看到事物如何懒洋洋地适应自己的目的，真的很令人愉快。这就是格里德利先生，一个有着坚强意志和惊人能量的人——从理智上来说，他是一个不和谐的铁匠——他很容易想象，几年前格里德利就在那里，在生活中徘徊，寻找一些东西来消耗他多余的好斗性。当大法官法院介入并为他提供了他想要的东西时，这就像一种荆棘中的年轻爱情。他们就在那里，相配，从此以后！否则他可能是一位伟大的将军，炸毁了各种城镇，或者他可能是一位伟大的政治家，处理各种议会言论；但事实上，他和大法官法院以最愉快的方式相互争斗，没有人比他更糟糕，可以说，从那时起，格里德利就得到了照顾。那就看看科文斯吧！可怜的科文斯（这些可爱的孩子的父亲）多么令人愉快地阐释了同样的原理！他，斯金波尔先生本人，有时也对科文斯的存在感到不满。他发现科文斯挡住了他的路。他本来可以不用科文斯。有时候，如果他是一位苏丹，他的大宰相有一天早上说：“忠诚者的指挥官对他的奴隶有什么要求？”他甚至可能会回答： “科文斯的头！”但结果是什么呢？ 一直以来，他一直在为一个最值得的人提供工作，他一直是科文斯的恩人，他实际上一直在帮助科文斯以这种令人愉快的方式抚养这些迷人的孩子，培养这些社会美德！当他环顾房间并想到：“我是科文斯的伟大赞助人，他的小小安慰是我的工作！’

There was something so captivating in his light way of touching these fantastic strings, and he was such a mirthful child by the side of the graver childhood we had seen, that he made my guardian smile even as he turned towards us from a little private talk with Mrs. Blinder. We kissed Charley, and took her downstairs with us, and stopped outside the house to see her run away to her work. I don’t know where she was going, but we saw her run, such a little, little creature in her womanly bonnet and apron, through a covered way at the bottom of the court and melt into the city’s strife and sound like a dewdrop in an ocean.
他以轻松的方式触动这些奇妙的琴弦，有一种令人着迷的感觉，在我们所见过的严肃的童年中，他是一个如此快乐的孩子，即使当他从私人谈话中转向我们时，他也让我的监护人微笑。和布林德夫人。我们吻了查理，带她下楼，在屋外停了下来，看着她跑去工作。我不知道她要去哪里，但我们看到她奔跑，一个戴着女性帽子和围裙的小生物，穿过球场底部的一条有遮盖的通道，融入城市的冲突中，声音像露珠一样在海洋中。

CHAPTER XVI
第十六章


Tom-all-Alone’s
汤姆独自一人

My Lady Dedlock is restless, very restless. The astonished fashionable intelligence hardly knows where to have her. To-day she is at Chesney Wold; yesterday she was at her house in town; tomorrow she may be abroad, for anything the fashionable intelligence can with confidence predict. Even Sir Leicester’s gallantry has some trouble to keep pace with her. It would have more but that his other faithful ally, for better and for worse—the gout—darts into the old oak bedchamber at Chesney Wold and grips him by both legs.
戴德洛克夫人焦躁不安，非常焦躁不安。令人惊讶的时尚智慧几乎不知道她在哪里。今天她在切斯尼沃尔德；昨天她在城里的家里；明天她可能会出国，时尚界人士可以自信地预测到这一点。即使是莱斯特爵士的英勇也难以跟上她的步伐。如果不是他的另一个忠实盟友——痛风——冲进切斯尼沃尔德的旧橡木卧室，抓住他的双腿，情况可能会更多。

Sir Leicester receives the gout as a troublesome demon, but still a demon of the patrician order. All the Dedlocks, in the direct male line, through a course of time during and beyond which the memory of man goeth not to the contrary, have had the gout. It can be proved, sir. Other men’s fathers may have died of the rheumatism or may have taken base contagion from the tainted blood of the sick vulgar, but the Dedlock family have communicated something exclusive even to the levelling process of dying by dying of their own family gout. It has come down through the illustrious line like the plate, or the pictures, or the place in Lincolnshire. It is among their dignities. Sir Leicester is perhaps not wholly without an impression, though he has never resolved it into words, that the angel of death in the discharge of his necessary duties may observe to the shades of the aristocracy, ‘My lords and gentlemen, I have the honour to present to you another Dedlock certified to have arrived per the family gout.’
莱斯特爵士将痛风视为麻烦的恶魔，但仍然是贵族阶层的恶魔。所有的戴德洛克家族，在男性直系血统中，在人类的记忆中和之后的一段时间内都患有痛风。这是可以证明的，先生。其他男人的父亲可能死于风湿病，或者可能是从普通病人的受污染的血液中感染了卑鄙的传染病，但戴德洛克家族却传达了一些独特的信息，甚至是死于他们自己的家族痛风的死亡过程。它就像盘子、图片或林肯郡的地方一样，是通过显赫的线条流传下来的。这是他们的尊严之一。莱斯特爵士也许并非完全没有这样的印象，尽管他从未将其化为言语，死亡天使在履行其必要职责时可能会观察贵族的阴影，“我的勋爵和先生们，我很荣幸向您展示另一个经过认证的 Dedlock，它是针对家庭痛风而到达的。

Hence Sir Leicester yields up his family legs to the family disorder as if he held his name and fortune on that feudal tenure. He feels that for a Dedlock to be laid upon his back and spasmodically twitched and stabbed in his extremities is a liberty taken somewhere, but he thinks, ‘We have all yielded to this; it belongs to us; it has for some hundreds of years been understood that we are not to make the vaults in the park interesting on more ignoble terms; and I submit myself to the compromise.
因此，莱斯特爵士将他的家庭腿交给了家庭混乱，就好像他在封建统治下保留了自己的名字和财产一样。他觉得，让戴德洛克仰面躺着，痉挛性地抽搐，刺伤他的四肢，这算是一种自由，但他想，‘我们都屈服了；我们都屈服了；我们都屈服了。它属于我们；数百年来人们一直明白，我们不应该以更卑鄙的方式使公园里的拱顶变得有趣；我屈服于妥协。

And a goodly show he makes, lying in a flush of crimson and gold in the midst of the great drawing-room before his favourite picture of my Lady, with broad strips of sunlight shining in, down the long perspective, through the long line of windows, and alternating with soft reliefs of shadow. Outside, the stately oaks, rooted for ages in the green ground which has never known ploughshare, but was still a chase when kings rode to battle with sword and shield and rode a-hunting with bow and arrow, bear witness to his greatness. Inside, his forefathers, looking on him from the walls, say, ‘Each of us was a passing reality here and left this coloured shadow of himself and melted into remembrance as dreamy as the distant voices of the rooks now lulling you to rest,’ and hear their testimony to his greatness too. And he is very great this day. And woe to Boythorn or other daring wight who shall presumptuously contest an inch with him!
他做了一场精彩的表演，躺在大客厅中央的深红色和金色的红晕中，面前是他最喜欢的夫人的照片，宽阔的阳光从长长的视野中穿过长长的线条照射进来。窗户，并与柔和的阴影浮雕交替。外面，庄严的橡树在绿色的土地上扎根了很多年，这里从未有过犁铧，但当国王们骑着剑和盾牌作战，骑着弓和箭狩猎时，它们仍然是追逐的对象，见证了他的伟大。在里面，他的祖先从墙上看着他，说：“我们每个人都是这里转瞬即逝的现实，留下了自己的彩色影子，融入了记忆，就像远处白嘴鸦的声音现在让你安息一样梦幻。”并聆听他们对他的伟大的见证。他这一天非常出色。博伊索恩或其他胆敢与他较量的恶棍有祸了！

My Lady is at present represented, near Sir Leicester, by her portrait. She has flitted away to town, with no intention of remaining there, and will soon flit hither again, to the confusion of the fashionable intelligence. The house in town is not prepared for her reception. It is muffled and dreary. Only one Mercury in powder gapes disconsolate at the hall-window; and he mentioned last night to another Mercury of his acquaintance, also accustomed to good society, that if that sort of thing was to last—which it couldn’t, for a man of his spirits couldn’t bear it, and a man of his figure couldn’t be expected to bear it—there would be no resource for him, upon his honour, but to cut his throat!
目前，莱斯特爵士附近有夫人的肖像。她已经飞到城里去了，无意留在那里，而且很快就会再次飞到这里，让时尚界的知识分子感到困惑。镇上的房子还没有准备好接待她。它是低沉而沉闷的。只有一颗裹着粉末的水星在大厅的窗户上张着嘴，忧郁地张着嘴；昨晚他向他的另一位熟人墨丘利提到，他也习惯了上流社会，如果这种事情能够持续下去的话——但这是不可能的，因为一个有精神的人无法忍受它，一个有道德的人也无法忍受。他的身材无法承受——以他的名誉来说，除了割断他的喉咙之外，他别无选择！

What connexion can there be between the place in Lincolnshire, the house in town, the Mercury in powder, and the whereabout of Jo the outlaw with the broom, who had that distant ray of light upon him when he swept the churchyard-step? What connexion can there have been between many people in the innumerable histories of this world who from opposite sides of great gulfs have, nevertheless, been very curiously brought together!
林肯郡的那个地方、镇上的房子、粉末中的水星号，以及拿着扫帚的亡命之徒乔的下落，当他扫墓地的台阶时，远处的光线照在他身上，这之间有什么联系呢？在这个世界无数的历史中，来自鸿沟对岸的许多人却非常奇怪地聚集在一起！

Jo sweeps his crossing all day long, unconscious of the link, if any link there be. He sums up his mental condition when asked a question by replying that he ‘don’t know nothink.’ He knows that it’s hard to keep the mud off the crossing in dirty weather, and harder still to live by doing it. Nobody taught him even that much; he found it out.
乔整天打扫十字路口，没有意识到其中的联系，如果有的话。当有人问他的问题时，他总结自己的精神状况，回答说“不知道。”他知道，在恶劣的天气里，很难让泥浆远离十字路口，而这样做更难维持生活。甚至没有人教过他那么多。他发现了。

Jo lives—that is to say, Jo has not yet died—in a ruinous place known to the like of him by the name of Tom-all-Alone’s. It is a black, dilapidated street, avoided by all decent people, where the crazy houses were seized upon, when their decay was far advanced, by some bold vagrants who after establishing their own possession took to letting them out in lodgings. Now, these tumbling tenements contain, by night, a swarm of misery. As on the ruined human wretch vermin parasites appear, so these ruined shelters have bred a crowd of foul existence that crawls in and out of gaps in walls and boards; and coils itself to sleep, in maggot numbers, where the rain drips in; and comes and goes, fetching and carrying fever and sowing more evil in its every footprint than Lord Coodle, and Sir Thomas Doodle, and the Duke of Foodle, and all the fine gentlemen in office, down to Zoodle, shall set right in five hundred years—though born expressly to do it.
乔生活在——也就是说，乔还没有死——一个像他这样的人都知道的破烂地方，名字叫“孤单汤姆”。这是一条黑色、破旧的街道，所有正派的人都避开这里，那里那些疯狂的房子，当它们腐烂得很厉害时，就被一些大胆的流浪者占领了，他们在建立了自己的财产后，开始把它们出租出去。现在，这些摇摇欲坠的房屋在夜间充满了痛苦。正如在被毁坏的人类可怜的寄生虫上出现一样，这些被毁坏的庇护所也滋生了一群肮脏的生物，它们在墙壁和木板的缝隙中爬进爬出；并在雨水滴落的地方盘绕着成群的蛆虫睡觉；来来去去，带着发烧，在每一个足迹中播下比库德尔勋爵、托马斯·杜德尔爵士、福德尔公爵以及所有在职的优秀绅士，直到佐德尔，都将在五百英里内集合起来的邪恶。岁月——尽管生来就是为了这样做。

Twice lately there has been a crash and a cloud of dust, like the springing of a mine, in Tom-all-Alone’s; and each time a house has fallen. These accidents have made a paragraph in the newspapers and have filled a bed or two in the nearest hospital. The gaps remain, and there are not unpopular lodgings among the rubbish. As several more houses are nearly ready to go, the next crash in Tomall-Alone’s may be expected to be a good one.
最近，汤姆独自屋里发生了两次撞击声，扬起一团灰尘，就像地雷弹出一样。每当有一座房子倒塌时。这些事故登上了报纸，并在最近的医院里填满了一两张床位。差距依然存在，垃圾之中也不乏不受欢迎的住所。随着另外几栋房屋即将竣工，托马尔-阿隆的下一次崩溃可能会是一场好事。

This desirable property is in Chancery, of course. It would be an insult to the discernment of any man with half an eye to tell him so. Whether ‘Tom’ is the popular representative of the original plaintiff or defendant in Jarndyce and Jarndyce, or whether Tom lived here when the suit had laid the street waste, all alone, until other settlers came to join him, or whether the traditional title is a comprehensive name for a retreat cut off from honest company and put out of the pale of hope, perhaps nobody knows. Certainly Jo don’t know.
当然，这个令人向往的房产位于 Chancery。告诉他这些，对任何一个有半只眼睛的人的洞察力来说都是一种侮辱。无论“汤姆”是加迪斯和加迪斯案中原告或被告的大众代表，还是当诉讼将街道变成废墟时，汤姆是否独自住在这里，直到其他定居者前来加入他的行列，或者传统的头衔是否是也许没有人知道，这是一个与诚实的公司隔绝、失去希望的撤退的综合名称。乔当然不知道。

‘For I don’t,’ says Jo, ‘I don’t know nothink.’
“因为我不知道，”乔说，“我什么也不知道。”

It must be a strange state to be like Jo! To shuffle through the streets, unfamiliar with the shapes, and in utter darkness as to the meaning, of those mysterious symbols, so abundant over the shops, and at the corners of streets, and on the doors, and in the windows! To see people read, and to see people write, and to see the postmen deliver letters, and not to have the least idea of all that language—to be, to every scrap of it, stone blind and dumb! It must be very puzzling to see the good company going to the churches on Sundays, with their books in their hands, and to think (for perhaps Jo DOES think at odd times) what does it all mean, and if it means anything to anybody, how comes it that it means nothing to me? To be hustled, and jostled, and moved on; and really to feel that it would appear to be perfectly true that I have no business here, or there, or anywhere; and yet to be perplexed by the consideration that I AM here somehow, too, and everybody overlooked me until I became the creature that I am! It must be a strange state, not merely to be told that I am scarcely human (as in the case of my offering myself for a witness), but to feel it of my own knowledge all my life! To see the horses, dogs, and cattle go by me and to know that in ignorance I belong to them and not to the superior beings in my shape, whose delicacy I offend! Jo’s ideas of a criminal trial, or a judge, or a bishop, or a govemment, or that inestimable jewel to him (if he only knew it) the Constitution, should be strange! His whole material and immaterial life is wonderfully strange; his death, the strangest thing of all.
像乔那样的状态一定很奇怪吧！拖着脚步穿过街道，那些神秘的符号在商店里、街角、门上、窗户上随处可见，它们的形状完全陌生，其意义也完全不可知！看到人们读书，看到人们写字，看到邮递员送信，却对所有这些语言一无所知——对它的每一个片段都是盲目和愚蠢的！看到一群好朋友在周日去教堂，手里拿着书，并思考（也许乔确实在奇怪的时候思考）这一切意味着什么，以及这对任何人是否意味着什么，一定是非常令人困惑的，怎么对我来说毫无意义呢？被推挤、推挤，然后继续前行；并真正感觉到我在这里、那里或任何地方都没有事，这似乎是完全正确的；然而，我却不知何故也在这里，而每个人都忽视了我，直到我成为我这样的生物，这让我感到困惑！这一定是一种奇怪的状态，不仅是被告知我几乎不是人类（就像我提供自己作为证人的情况一样），而且是我一生都用我自己的知识来感受它！看到马、狗和牛从我身边经过，我就知道，在无知中，我属于它们，而不是属于我形状的高级生物，我冒犯了它们的美味！乔关于刑事审判、法官、主教、政府、或者对他来说无价之宝（如果他只知道的话）宪法的想法应该是奇怪的！他的整个物质和非物质生活都非常奇怪。他的死是最奇怪的事情。

Jo comes out of Tom-all-Alone’s, meeting the tardy morning which is always late in getting down there, and munches his dirty bit of bread as he comes along. His way lying through many streets, and the houses not yet being open, he sits down to breakfast on the door-step of the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in Foreign Parts and gives it a brush when he has finished as an acknowledgment of the accommodation. He admires the size of the edifice and wonders what it’s all about. He has no idea, poor wretch, of the spiritual destitution of a coral reef in the Pacific or what it costs to look up the precious souls among the coco-nuts and bread-fruit.
乔从汤姆独自屋里出来，迎接迟到的早晨，总是很晚才下楼，他一边走一边嚼着脏面包。他穿过许多街道，房屋还没有开放，他在国外福音传播协会的门口坐下来吃早餐，吃完后，他用刷子刷了一下，以示对他的认可。住宿。他钦佩这座建筑的规模，并想知道它的全部内容。他不知道，可怜的家伙，太平洋珊瑚礁的精神匮乏，也不知道在椰子和面包果中寻找宝贵的灵魂需要付出什么代价。

He goes to his crossing and begins to lay it out for the day. The town awakes; the great tee-totum is set up for its daily spin and whirl; all that unaccountable reading and writing, which has been suspended for a few hours, recommences. Jo and the other lower animals get on in the unintelligible mess as they can. It is market-day. The blinded oxen, over-goaded, over-driven, never guided, run into wrong places and are beaten out, and plunge redeyed and foaming at stone walls, and often sorely hurt the innocent, and often sorely hurt themselves. Very like Jo and his order; very, very like!
他走到十字路口，开始安排当天的行程。小镇苏醒了；巨大的发球台是为了日常旋转而设置的；所有那些已经暂停了几个小时的不负责任的阅读和写作又重新开始。乔和其他低等动物尽其所能地在难以理解的混乱中相处。今天是集市日。盲目的牛，被过度刺激，过度驱赶，从未被引导，跑到错误的地方被殴打，然后跌倒在石墙上，眼睛红了，吐着泡沫，常常严重伤害无辜者，也常常严重伤害自己。非常喜欢乔和他的订单；非常非常喜欢！

A band of music comes and plays. Jo listens to it. So does a dog —a drover’s dog, waiting for his master outside a butcher’s shop, and evidently thinking about those sheep he has had upon his mind for some hours and is happily rid of. He seems perplexed respecting three or four, can’t remember where he left them, looks up and down the street as half expecting to see them astray, suddenly pricks up his ears and remembers all about it. A thoroughly vagabond dog, accustomed to low company and publichouses; a terrific dog to sheep, ready at a whistle to scamper over their backs and tear out mouthfuls of their wool; but an educated, improved, developed dog who has been taught his duties and knows how to discharge them. He and Jo listen to the music, probably with much the same amount of animal satisfaction; likewise as to awakened association, aspiration, or regret, melancholy or joyful reference to things beyond the senses, they are probably upon a par. But, otherwise, how far above the human listener is the brute!
一支乐队过来演奏。乔听着。一只狗也是如此——一只牧牛人的狗，在肉店外等待他的主人，显然在想着那些他已经在心里想了几个小时、很高兴摆脱的羊。他似乎对三四个人感到困惑，不记得自己把他们留在哪里了，他在街上上下打量着，似乎希望看到他们迷路，突然竖起耳朵，记起了这一切。一只彻头彻尾的流浪狗，习惯了低贱的陪伴和酒馆；对羊来说，它是一只了不起的狗，随时准备在它们的背上蹦蹦跳跳，撕下它们的羊毛。而是一只受过教育、进步、发展的狗，它已经学会了自己的职责，并且知道如何履行它们。他和乔听着音乐，可能带着同样程度的动物满足感；同样，对于超越感官的事物的唤醒联想、渴望或遗憾、忧郁或快乐，它们可能是同等的。但是，除此之外，人类听众的野蛮程度是多么的高啊！

Turn that dog’s descendants wild, like Jo, and in a very few years they will so degenerate that they will lose even their bark—but not their bite.
如果让那只狗的后代变得疯狂，就像乔一样，那么在短短几年内，他们就会变得如此堕落，甚至会失去吠叫，但不会失去咬力。

The day changes as it wears itself away and becomes dark and drizzly. Jo fights it out at his crossing among the mud and wheels, the horses, whips, and umbrellas, and gets but a scanty sum to pay for the unsavoury shelter of Tom-all-Alone’s. Twilight comes on; gas begins to start up in the shops; the lamplighter, with his ladder, runs along the margin of the pavement. A wretched evening is beginning to close in.
天色渐渐消逝，天色变暗，下着毛毛雨。乔在泥泞、车轮、马匹、鞭子和雨伞之间奋战，只得到了微薄的钱来支付汤姆孤身一人的令人讨厌的庇护所。暮色降临；商店里的煤气开始启动；点灯人带着梯子沿着人行道的边缘奔跑。一个悲惨的夜晚即将来临。

In his chambers Mr. Tulkinghorn sits meditating an application to the nearest magistrate to-morrow morning for a warrant. Gridley, a disappointed suitor, has been here to-day and has been alarming. We are not to be put in bodily fear, and that ill-conditioned fellow shall be held to bail again. From the ceiling, foreshortened Allegory, in the person of one impossible Roman upside down, points with the arm of Samson (out of joint, and an odd one) obtrusively toward the window. Why should Mr. Tulkinghorn, for such no reason, look out of window? Is the hand not always pointing there? So he does not look out of window.
图尔金霍恩先生坐在他的房间里，思考着明天早上向最近的地方法官申请逮捕令。格里德利是一位失望的求婚者，他今天来到了这里，并且一直令人震惊。我们不应该陷入肉体的恐惧，而那个状况不佳的家伙将再次被保释。天花板上，缩短的寓言以一个不可能的倒立的罗马人的形象，用参孙的手臂（关节脱节，而且很奇怪）引人注目地指向窗户。图金霍恩先生为什么要无缘无故地看着窗外呢？手不总是指向那里吗？所以他没有看窗外。

And if he did, what would it be to see a woman going by? There are women enough in the world, Mr. Tulkinghorn thinks—too many; they are at the bottom of all that goes wrong in it, though, for the matter of that, they create business for lawyers. What would it be to see a woman going by, even though she were going secretly? They are all secret. Mr. Tulkinghorn knows that very well.
如果他这样做了，看到一个女人走过会是什么感觉？图金霍恩先生认为，世界上的女性足够多——太多了；太多了。他们是所有问题的根源，尽管如此，他们为律师创造了生意。看到一个女人经过，尽管她是偷偷地走，那会是什么感觉？它们都是秘密的。图金霍恩先生非常清楚这一点。

But they are not all like the woman who now leaves him and his house behind, between whose plain dress and her refined manner there is something exceedingly inconsistent. She should be an upper servant by her attire, yet in her air and step, though both are hurried and assumed—as far as she can assume in the muddy streets, which she treads with an unaccustomed foot—she is a lady. Her face is veiled, and still she sufficiently betrays herself to make more than one of those who pass her look round sharply.
但他们并不全都像那个现在离开他和他的房子的女人，她朴素的衣着和优雅的举止之间存在着极其不一致的东西。从她的衣着来看，她应该是一个上层仆人，但从她的神态和步伐来看，尽管两者都显得匆忙和假装——就她在泥泞的街道上所能想象的，她用不习惯的脚踩着——她是一位女士。她的脸蒙着面纱，但她仍然充分暴露了自己，让不止一个经过她身边的人都猛地环顾四周。

She never turns her head. Lady or servant, she has a purpose in her and can follow it. She never turns her head until she comes to the crossing where Jo plies with his broom. He crosses with her and begs. Still, she does not turn her head until she has landed on the other side. Then she slightly beckons to him and says, ‘Come here!’
她从不回头。女士或仆人，她有自己的目标并且可以遵循它。她从来没有转过头，直到来到乔拿着扫帚的十字路口。他与她相遇并乞求。尽管如此，她还是没有转过头，直到降落到另一边。然后她轻轻地向他招了招手，说道：“过来！”

Jo follows her a pace or two into a quiet court.
乔跟着她走了一两步，走进了一个安静的庭院。

‘Are you the boy I’ve read of in the papers?’ she asked behind her veil.
“你就是我在报纸上读到的那个男孩吗？”她在面纱后面问道。

‘I don’t know,’ says Jo, staring moodily at the veil, ‘nothink about no papers. I don’t know nothink about nothink at all.’
“我不知道，”乔郁闷地盯着面纱说道，“别想没有证件。”我根本不知道nothink关于nothink的事。

‘Were you examined at an inquest?’
“你接受过审讯吗？”

‘I don’t know nothink about no—where I was took by the beadle, do you mean?’ says Jo. ‘Was the boy’s name at the inkwhich Jo?’
“我不知道，你是说，我被执事带到哪里去了？”乔说。 “墨水上那个男孩的名字是乔吗？”

‘Yes.’
'是的。'

‘That’s me!’ says Jo.
“那就是我！”乔说。

‘Come farther up.’
“再往上一点。”

‘You mean about the man?’ says Jo, following. ‘Him as wos dead?’
“你是说那个男人吗？”乔跟在后面问道。 “他死了吗？”

‘Hush! Speak in a whisper! Yes. Did he look, when he was living, so very ill and poor?’
‘嘘！小声说话！是的。他生前的样子是不是病得很重、很穷？

‘Oh, jist!’ says Jo.
“哦，天哪！”乔说。

‘Did he look like—not like YOU?’ says the woman with abhorrence.
“他看起来像——不像你吗？”女人厌恶地说。

‘Oh, not so bad as me,’ says Jo. ‘I’m a reg’lar one I am! You didn’t know him, did you?’
“哦，没我那么糟糕，”乔说。 “我是个正常人！”你不认识他，是吗？

‘How dare you ask me if I knew him?’
“你怎么敢问我是否认识他？”

‘No offence, my lady,’ says Jo with much humility, for even he has got at the suspicion of her being a lady.
“无意冒犯，我的女士，”乔非常谦虚地说，因为就连他也怀疑她是一位女士。

‘I am not a lady. I am a servant.’
‘我不是一位女士。我是一个仆人。

‘You are a jolly servant!’ says Jo without the least idea of saying anything offensive, merely as a tribute of admiration.
“你是一个快乐的仆人！”乔说道，丝毫没有冒犯别人的意思，只是表达钦佩之情。

‘Listen and be silent. Don’t talk to me, and stand farther from me! Can you show me all those places that were spoken of in the account I read? The place he wrote for, the place he died at, the place where you were taken to, and the place where he was buried? Do you know the place where he was buried?’
‘听着，保持沉默。别跟我说话，离我远点！你能告诉我我读到的帐户中提到的所有这些地方吗？他写作的地方，他去世的地方，你被带到的地方，以及他埋葬的地方？你知道他埋在哪里吗？

Jo answers with a nod, having also nodded as each other place was mentioned.
乔点点头回答，在提到彼此的地点时也点了点头。

‘Go before me and show me all those dreadful places. Stop opposite to each, and don’t speak to me unless I speak to you. Don’t look back. Do what I want, and I will pay you well.’
‘走在我面前，带我看看那些可怕的地方。在每个人对面停下来，除非我跟你说话，否则不要跟我说话。不要回头。做我想做的事，我会给你丰厚的报酬。

Jo attends closely while the words are being spoken; tells them off on his broom-handle, finding them rather hard; pauses to consider their meaning; considers it satisfactory; and nods his ragged head.
乔在说话时密切关注。发现他们很难受，就用扫帚柄斥责他们。停下来思考它们的含义；认为满意；并点点头。

‘I’m fly,’ says Jo. ‘But fen larks, you know. Stow hooking it!’
“我会飞，”乔说。 “但是你知道，百灵鸟。”把它钩起来！’

‘What does the horrible creature mean?’ exclaims the servant, recoiling from him.
“这个可怕的生物是什么意思？”仆人惊呼，从他身边退开。

‘Stow cutting away, you know!’ says Jo.
“斯托切开，你知道！”乔说。

‘I don’t understand you. Go on before! I will give you more money than you ever had in your life.’
‘我不明白你的意思。之前就继续吧！我会给你比你一生中拥有的更多的钱。”

Jo screws up his mouth into a whistle, gives his ragged head a rub, takes his broom under his arm, and leads the way, passing deftly with his bare feet over the hard stones and through the mud and mire.
乔把嘴吹成口哨，揉揉他那破烂的脑袋，把扫帚夹在腋下，在前面带路，光着脚灵巧地走过坚硬的石头，穿过泥泞。

Cook’s Court. Jo stops. A pause.
库克法庭。乔停了下来。停顿一下。

‘Who lives here?’
“谁住在这里？”

‘Him wot give him his writing and give me half a bull,’ says Jo in a whisper without looking over his shoulder.
“他不会把他的作品给他，也不会给我半头公牛。”乔头也不回地低声说道。

‘Go on to the next.’
“继续下一个。”

Krook’s house. Jo stops again. A longer pause.
克鲁克的房子。乔又停了下来。更长的停顿。

‘Who lives here?’
“谁住在这里？”

‘HE lived here,’ Jo answers as before.
“他住在这里，”乔像以前一样回答。

After a silence he is asked, ‘In which room?’
一阵沉默后，有人问他：“在哪个房间？”

‘In the back room up there. You can see the winder from this corner. Up there! That’s where I see him stritched out. This is the public-ouse where I was took to.’
“在后面的房间里。从这个角落你可以看到上链器。在上面！那就是我看到他伸展开来的地方。这是我被带到的公共场所。

‘Go on to the next!’
“继续下一个！”

It is a longer walk to the next, but Jo, relieved of his first suspicions, sticks to the forms imposed upon him and does not look round. By many devious ways, reeking with offence of many kinds, they come to the little tunnel of a court, and to the gas-lamp (lighted now), and to the iron gate.
到达下一个目标的路要走更长的路，但乔消除了最初的怀疑，坚持遵循强加给他的形式，没有环顾四周。他们通过许多迂回的途径，浑身散发着各种冒犯的味道，来到法庭的小隧道、煤气灯（现在亮着）和铁门前。

‘He was put there,’ says Jo, holding to the bars and looking in.
“他被放在那里，”乔一边说，一边抓着栏杆往里看。

‘Where? Oh, what a scene of horror!’
'在哪里？哦，多么恐怖的一幕啊！

‘There!’ says Jo, pointing. ‘Over yinder. Arnong them piles of bones, and close to that there kitchin winder! They put him wery nigh the top. They was obliged to stamp upon it to git it in. I could unkiver it for you with my broom if the gate was open. That’s why they locks it, I s’pose,’ giving it a shake. ‘It’s always locked. Look at the rat!’ cries Jo, excited. ‘Hi! Look! There he goes! Ho! Into the ground!’
“那里！”乔指着说。 ‘在阴德之上。阿农他们成堆的骨头，靠近那个厨房绕线机！他们把他放在了接近顶端的位置。他们不得不踩着它才能把它放进去。如果门开着，我可以用我的扫帚为你把它打开。我想，这就是为什么他们把它锁起来，摇晃它。 ‘它总是锁着的。看看那只老鼠！”乔兴奋地喊道。 '你好！看！他走了！嗬！进入地下！’

The servant shrinks into a corner, into a corner of that hideous archway, with its deadly stains contaminating her dress; and putting out her two hands and passionately telling him to keep away from her, for he is loathsome to her, so remains for some moments. Jo stands staring and is still staring when she recovers herself.
仆人缩到一个角落里，缩进那座丑陋拱门的角落里，致命的污渍沾染了她的衣服；她伸出两只手，热情地告诉他离她远点，因为他令她厌恶，所以持续了一会儿。乔站在那里盯着看，当她恢复过来时仍然盯着看。

‘Is this place of abomination consecrated ground?’
“这个可憎之地是圣地吗？”

‘I don’t know nothink of consequential ground,’ says Jo, still staring.
“我不知道有什么后果，”乔说道，仍然盯着看。

‘Is it blessed?’
“有福吗？”

‘Which?’ says Jo, in the last degree amazed.
“哪个？”乔说，最后程度的惊讶。

‘Is it blessed?’
“有福吗？”

‘I’m blest if I know,’ says Jo, staring more than ever; ‘but I shouldn’t think it warn’t. Blest?’ repeats Jo, something troubled in his mind. ‘It an’t done it much good if it is. Blest? I should think it was t’othered myself. But I don’t know nothink!’
“如果我知道那就太好了，”乔说道，目光比以往任何时候都更加凝视。 “但我不应该认为它不会。”天哪？”乔重复道，心里有些不安。 “如果是的话，那也没什么好处。”祝福？我应该认为这不是我自己的事。但我不知道！

The servant takes as little heed of what he says as she seems to take of what she has said herself. She draws off her glove to get some money from her purse. Jo silently notices how white and small her hand is and what a jolly servant she must be to wear such sparkling rings.
仆人对他所说的话毫不在意，就像她似乎对自己所说的话很在意一样。她脱下手套，从钱包里取出一些钱。乔默默地注意到她的手又白又小，她一定是一个多么快乐的仆人才能戴着这么闪闪发光的戒指。

She drops a piece of money in his hand without touching it, and shuddering as their hands approach. ‘Now,’ she adds, ‘show me the spot again!’
她把一张钱扔到他手里，但没有碰它，当他们的手靠近时，她颤抖着。 “现在，”她补充道，“再给我看看那个地方！”

Jo thrusts the handle of his broom between the bars of the gate, and with his utmost power of elaboration, points it out. At length, looking aside to see if he has made himself intelligible, he finds that he is alone.
乔把扫帚柄插在门闩之间，用尽全力的阐述指出了这一点。最后，他扭头看看自己是否已经明白了自己的意思，却发现只剩下他一个人了。

His first proceeding is to hold the piece of money to the gas-light and to be overpowered at finding that it is yellow—gold. His next is to give it a one-sided bite at the edge as a test of its quality. His next, to put it in his mouth for safety and to sweep the step and passage with great care. His job done, he sets off for Tom-all-Alone’s, stopping in the light of innumerable gas-lamps to produce the piece of gold and give it another one-sided bite as a reassurance of its being genuine.
他的第一步行动是将这块钱放在煤气灯下，当他发现它是黄金时，他感到震惊。他的下一步是在边缘上咬一口，以测试其质量。接下来，为了安全起见，他把它放在嘴里，并小心翼翼地清扫台阶和通道。工作完成后，他出发前往 Tom-all-Alone's，在无数煤气灯的照耀下停下来，取出那块金子，并又单面咬了一口，以确保它是真的。

The Mercury in powder is in no want of society to-night, for my Lady goes to a grand dinner and three or four balls. Sir Leicester is fidgety down at Chesney Wold, with no better company than the goat; he complains to Mrs. Rouncewell that the rain makes such a monotonous pattering on the terrace that he can’t read the paper even by the fireside in his own snug dressing-room.
粉状的水星今晚不需要社交，因为我的夫人要去参加一场盛大的晚宴和三四个舞会。莱斯特爵士在切斯尼沃尔德焦躁不安，没有比山羊更好的陪伴了。他向朗斯韦尔夫人抱怨说，雨水在露台上发出单调的淅淅沥沥的声音，以至于他甚至在自己舒适的更衣室里的炉边都无法阅读报纸。

‘Sir Leicester would have done better to try the other side of the house, my dear,’ says Mrs. Rouncewell to Rosa. ‘His dressing-room is on my Lady’s side. And in all these years I never heard the step upon the Ghost’s Walk more distinct than it is to-night!’
“亲爱的，莱斯特爵士最好尝试一下房子的另一边，”朗斯韦尔夫人对罗莎说。 “他的更衣室在夫人这边。这些年来，我从来没有听到过比今晚更清晰的鬼道脚步声！”

CHAPTER XVII
第十七章


Esther’s Narrative
以斯帖的叙述

Richard very often came to see us while we remained in London (though he soon failed in his letter-writing), and with his quick abilities, his good spirits, his good temper, his gaiety and freshness, was always delightful. But though I liked him more and more the better I knew him, I still felt more and more how much it was to be regretted that he had been educated in no habits of application and concentration. The system which had addressed him in exactly the same manner as it had addressed hundreds of other boys, all varying in character and capacity, had enabled him to dash through his tasks, always with fair credit and often with distinction, but in a fitful, dazzling way that had confirmed his reliance on those very qualities in himself which it had been most desirable to direct and train. They were good qualities, without which no high place can be meritoriously won, but like fire and water, though excellent servants, they were very bad masters. If they had been under Richard’s direction, they would have been his friends; but Richard being under their direction, they became his enemies.
当我们留在伦敦时，理查德经常来看我们（尽管他写信很快就失败了），他的敏捷能力，他的良好精神，他的好脾气，他的快乐和新鲜感，总是令人愉快。尽管我对他了解得越多，就越喜欢他，但我还是越来越感到遗憾，因为他没有受过专心致志的教育。这个制度对待他的方式与对待其他数百个男孩的方式完全相同，他们的性格和能力各不相同，使他能够冲刺完成自己的任务，总是获得公平的荣誉，并且常常表现出色，但时断时续，令人眼花缭乱的方式证实了他对自己最需要指导和训练的那些品质的依赖。他们具有良好的品质，没有这些品质就无法立功赢得高位，但就像火和水一样，虽然他们是优秀的仆人，但他们却是非常糟糕的主人。如果他们接受理查德的指导，他们就会成为他的朋友；如果他们接受理查德的指导，他们就会成为他的朋友。但理查德在他们的指导下，他们成了他的敌人。

I write down these opinions not because I believe that this or any other thing was so because I thought so, but only because I did think so and I want to be quite candid about all I thought and did. These were my thoughts about Richard. I thought I often observed besides how right my guardian was in what he had said, and that the uncertainties and delays of the Chancery suit had imparted to his nature something of the careless spirit of a gamester who felt that he was part of a great gaming system.
我写下这些观点并不是因为我相信这件事或任何其他事情是这样的，因为我是这么想的，而只是因为我确实是这样想的，并且我想对我的所想和所做的一切保持坦诚。这些是我对理查德的想法。我想我经常观察到，除了我的监护人所说的话是多么正确之外，大法官诉讼的不确定性和拖延也赋予了他一种游戏玩家的粗心精神，他觉得自己是一场伟大游戏的一部分。系统。

Mr. and Mrs. Bayham Badger coming one afternoon when my guardian was not at home, in the course of conversation I naturally inquired after Richard.
一天下午，我的监护人不在家，贝汉姆獾先生和夫人来了，谈话中我自然地询问了理查德的情况。

‘Why, Mr. Carstone,’ said Mrs. Badger, ‘is very well and is, I assure you, a great acquisition to our society. Captain Swosser used to say of me that I was always better than land a-head and a breeze a-starn to the midshipmen’s mess when the purser’s junk had become as tough as the fore-topsel weather earings. It was his naval way of mentioning generally that I was an acquisition to any society. I may render the same tribute, I am sure, to Mr. Carstone. But I—you won’t think me premature if I mention it?’
“为什么，卡斯通先生，”巴杰夫人说，“非常好，我向你保证，这对我们的社会来说是一项伟大的收获。斯沃瑟船长常常这样评价我，当事务长的垃圾变得像前顶板的气象耳环一样坚韧时，我总是比在船头着陆并微风吹过见习官的混乱要好。他以海军般的方式普遍地提到我是任何社会的收获。我相信，我也会向卡斯通先生致以同样的敬意。但我——如果我提起这件事，你不会认为我太早了？”

I said no, as Mrs. Badger’s insinuating tone seemed to require such an answer.
我拒绝了，因为獾夫人含沙射影的语气似乎需要这样的回答。

‘Nor Miss Clare?’ said Mrs. Bayham Badger sweetly.
“克莱尔小姐也没有吗？”贝汉姆獾夫人甜甜地说。

Ada said no, too, and looked uneasy.
艾达也拒绝了，看上去很不安。

‘Why, you see, my dears,’ said Mrs. Badger, ‘—you’ll excuse me calling you my dears?’
“为什么，你瞧，亲爱的，”獾夫人说，“——请原谅我称你们为亲爱的？”

We entreated Mrs. Badger not to mention it.
我们恳求獾夫人不要提这件事。

‘Because you really are, if I may take the liberty of saying so,’ pursued Mrs. Badger, ‘so perfectly charming. You see, my dears, that although I am still young—or Mr. Bayham Badger pays me the compliment of saying so—‘
“因为你真的是，如果我可以冒昧地说，”巴杰尔太太继续说道，“非常迷人。”你看，亲爱的，尽管我还年轻——或者贝汉姆獾先生这样夸奖我——”

‘No,’ Mr. Badger called out like some one contradicting at a public meeting. ‘Not at all!’
“不，”巴杰先生大声喊道，就像在公开会议上自相矛盾的人一样。 '一点也不！'

‘Very well,’ smiled Mrs. Badger, ‘we will say still young.’
“很好，”獾夫人微笑着，“我们可以说还年轻。”

‘Undoubtedly,’ said Mr. Badger.
“毫无疑问，”獾先生说。

‘My dears, though still young, I have had many opportunities of observing young men. There were many such on board the dear old Crippler, I assure you. After that, when I was with Captain Swosser in the Mediterranean, I embraced every opportunity of knowing and befriending the midshipmen under Captain Swosser’s command. YOU never heard them called the young gentlemen, my dears, and probably wonld not understand allusions to their pipeclaying their weekly accounts, but it is otherwise with me, for blue water has been a second home to me, and I have been quite a sailor. Again, with Professor Dingo.’
“亲爱的，虽然我还年轻，但我有很多机会观察年轻人。我向你保证，亲爱的老瘸子号上有很多这样的人。此后，当我在地中海与斯沃瑟船长一起工作时，我抓住了每一个认识斯沃瑟船长麾下的见习官并与他们交朋友的机会。你从来没有听过他们被称为年轻的绅士，亲爱的，并且可能不会理解他们用管道粘土制作每周账目的暗示，但对我来说却不然，因为蓝色的水一直是我的第二个家，而且我一直是一名不折不扣的水手。再次与丁戈教授一起。

‘A man of European reputation,’ murmured Mr. Badger.
“一个在欧洲享有盛誉的人。”巴杰尔先生低声说道。

‘When I lost my dear first and became the wife of my dear second,’ said Mrs. Badger, speaking of her former husbands as if they were parts of a charade, ‘I still enjoyed opportunities of observing youth. The class attendant on Professor Dingo’s lectures was a large one, and it became my pride, as the wife of an eminent scientific man seeking herself in science the utmost consolation it could impart, to throw our house open to the students as a kind of Scientific Exchange. Every Tuesday evening there was lemonade and a mixed biscuit for all who chose to partake of those refreshments. And there was science to an unlimited extent.’
“当我失去了我亲爱的第一个，成为我亲爱的第二个的妻子时，”巴杰尔太太说起她的前夫，仿佛他们是一个猜谜游戏的一部分，“我仍然享受观察青春的机会。丁戈教授讲课的班主任人数很多，作为一位杰出科学家的妻子，我感到自豪，她在科学中寻求科学所能给予的最大安慰，将我们的房子向学生开放，作为一种科学的方式。交换。每个星期二晚上，我们都会为所有选择享用这些茶点的人提供柠檬水和混合饼干。科学的范围是无限的。”

‘Remarkable assemblies those, Miss Summerson,’ said Mr. Badger reverentially. ‘There must have been great intellectual friction going on there under the auspices of such a man!’
“萨默森小姐，这真是了不起的集会，”巴杰先生恭敬地说。 “在这样一个人的主持下，那里肯定发生了巨大的智力摩擦！”

‘And now,’ pursued Mrs. Badger, ‘now that I am the wife of my dear third, Mr. Badger, I still pursue those habits of observation which were formed during the lifetime of Captain Swosser and adapted to new and unexpected purposes during the lifetime of Professor Dingo. I therefore have not come to the consideration of Mr. Carstone as a neophyte. And yet I am very much of the opinion, my dears, that he has not chosen his profession advisedly.’
“现在，”巴杰尔夫人继续说道，“既然我是我亲爱的第三任巴杰尔先生的妻子，我仍然追求那些在斯沃瑟船长在世时养成的观察习惯，并适应了新的和意想不到的目的。丁戈教授的一生。因此，我并没有将卡斯通先生视为新手。然而，亲爱的，我非常认为他没有经过深思熟虑地选择了自己的职业。

Ada looked so very anxious now that I asked Mrs. Badger on what she founded her supposition.
艾达现在看起来非常焦虑，我问獾夫人她的假设是根据什么成立的。

‘My dear Miss Summerson,’ she replied, ‘on Mr. Carstone’s character and conduct. He is of such a very easy disposition that probably he would never think it worthwhile to mention how he really feels, but he feels languid about the profession. He has not that positive interest in it which makes it his vocation. If he has any decided impression in reference to it, I should say it was that it is a tiresome pursuit. Now, this is not promising. Young men like Mr. Allan Woodcourt who take it from a strong interest in all that it can do will find some reward in it through a great deal of work for a very little money and through years of considerable endurance and disappointment. But I am quite convinced that this would never be the case with Mr. Carstone.’
“我亲爱的萨默森小姐，”她回答道，“关于卡斯顿先生的性格和行为。”他的性格非常随和，可能他永远不会认为值得提及他的真实感受，但他对这个职业感到无精打采。他对此没有那么积极的兴趣，这使得他成为他的职业。如果说他对此有什么明确的印象的话，我应该说这是一种令人厌烦的追求。现在看来，这并不乐观。像艾伦·伍德考特先生这样的年轻人，对它所能做的一切都抱有浓厚的兴趣，通过用很少的钱做大量的工作，并通过多年的相当大的忍耐和失望，他们会从中找到一些回报。但我坚信卡斯顿先生永远不会出现这种情况。

‘Does Mr. Badger think so too?’ asked Ada timidly.
“獾先生也这么认为吗？”艾达胆怯地问。

‘Why,’ said Mr. Badger, ‘to tell the truth, Miss Clare, this view of the matter had not occurred to me until Mrs. Badger mentioned it. But when Mrs. Badger put it in that light, I naturally gave great consideration to it, knowing that Mrs. Badger’s mind, in addition to its natural advantages, has had the rare advantage of being formed by two such very distinguished (I will even say illustrious) public men as Captain Swosser of the Royal Navy and Professor Dingo. The conclusion at which I have arrived is—in short, is Mrs. Badger’s conclusion.’
“哎呀，”巴杰尔先生说，“说实话，克莱尔小姐，直到巴杰尔太太提到这件事，我才想到了这个观点。但当獾夫人这么说时，我自然很重视，因为知道獾夫人的头脑除了天生的优势之外，还有难得的优势，是由两个如此杰出的人所形成的（我什至会比如说皇家海军斯沃瑟上尉和丁戈教授等杰出的公众人物。我得出的结论是——简而言之，就是巴杰尔夫人的结论。

‘It was a maxim of Captain Swosser’s,’ said Mrs. Badger, ‘speaking in his figurative naval manner, that when you make pitch hot, you cannot make it too hot; and that if you only have to swab a plank, you should swab it as if Davy Jones were after you. It appears to me that this maxim is applicable to the medical as well as to the nautical profession.
“这是斯沃瑟船长的格言，”巴杰夫人说，“用他象征性的海军风格来说，当你让沥青变得热时，你不能让它太热;如果你只需要擦拭一块木板，你应该像戴维·琼斯在追你一样擦拭它。在我看来，这条格言既适用于医学界，也适用于航海界。

‘To all professions,’ observed Mr. Badger. ‘It was admirably said by Captain Swosser. Beautifully said.’
“对所有职业来说，”巴杰尔先生评论道。 “斯沃瑟船长说得令人钦佩。说得漂亮。”

‘People objected to Professor Dingo when we were staying in the north of Devon after our marriage,’ said Mrs. Badger, ‘that he disfigured some of the houses and other buildings by chipping off fragments of those edifices with his little geological hammer. But the professor replied that he knew of no building save the Temple of Science. The principle is the same, I think?’
“当我们结婚后住在德文郡北部时，人们反对丁戈教授，”巴杰尔夫人说，“他用他的小地质锤敲碎了一些房屋和其他建筑物的碎片，从而毁坏了一些房屋和其他建筑物。但教授回答说，除了科学殿堂之外，他不知道有什么建筑。我想原理是一样的？

‘Precisely the same,’ said Mr. Badger. ‘Finely expressed! The professor made the same remark, Miss Summerson, in his last illness, when (his mind wandering) he insisted on keeping his little hammer under the pillow and chipping at the countenances of the attendants. The ruling passion!’
“一模一样，”獾先生说。 ‘表达得好！萨默森小姐，教授在他最后一次生病时也说过同样的话，当时（他的思绪飘忽不定）他坚持把他的小锤子放在枕头下，敲打服务员的脸。主导的激情！

Although we could have dispensed with the length at which Mr. and Mrs. Badger pursued the conversation, we both felt that it was disinterested in them to express the opinion they had communicated to us and that there was a great probability of its being sound. We agreed to say nothing to Mr. Jarndyce until we had spoken to Richard; and as he was coming next evening, we resolved to have a very serious talk with him.
虽然我们本可以省去獾先生和獾夫人继续谈话的时间，但我们都觉得他们没有兴趣表达他们向我们传达的观点，而且很有可能是正确的。我们同意在与理查德交谈之前不向贾迪斯先生透露任何信息。由于他第二天晚上就要来，我们决定与他进行一次非常严肃的谈话。

So after he had been a little while with Ada, I went in and found my darling (as I knew she would be) prepared to consider him thoroughly right in whatever he said.
因此，在他和艾达相处了一段时间后，我进去发现我亲爱的（我知道她会的）准备好认为他所说的一切都是完全正确的。

‘And how do you get on, Richard?’ said I. I always sat down on the other side of him. He made quite a sister of me.
“理查德，你过得怎么样？”我问道。我总是坐在他的另一边。他把我当成妹妹了。

‘Oh! Well enough!’ said Richard.
'哦！好吧！”理查德说。

‘He can’t say better than that, Esther, can he?’ cried my pet triumphantly.
“他不能说比这更好的了，埃丝特，不是吗？”我的宠物得意地喊道。

I tried to look at my pet in the wisest manner, but of course I couldn’t.
我试图以最明智的方式看待我的宠物，但我当然做不到。

‘Well enough?’ I repeated.
“够了吗？”我重复道。

‘Yes,’ said Richard, ‘well enough. It’s rather jog-trotty and humdrum. But it’ll do as well as anything else!’
“是的，”理查德说，“很好。”这是相当慢跑和单调的。但它的作用和其他任何东西一样好！

‘Oh! My dear Richard!’ I remonstrated.
'哦！我亲爱的理查德！”我抗议道。

‘What’s the matter?’ said Richard.
“怎么了？”理查德说。

‘Do as well as anything else!’
“做任何事都一样！”

‘I don’t think there’s any harm in that, Dame Durden,’ said Ada, looking so confidingly at me across him; ‘because if it will do as well as anything else, it will do very well, I hope.’
“我不认为这有什么坏处，德登夫人，”艾达说道，她的目光越过他，充满信心地看着我。 “因为如果它能像其他任何事情一样，它会做得很好，我希望。”

‘Oh, yes, I hope so,’ returned Richard, carelessly tossing his hair from his forehead. ‘After all, it may be only a kind of probation till our suit is—I forgot though. I am not to mention the suit. Forbidden ground! Oh, yes, it’s all right enough. Let us talk about something else.’
“哦，是的，我希望如此，”理查德回答道，漫不经心地甩开额前的头发。 “毕竟，这可能只是一种缓刑，直到我们的诉讼——不过我忘了。”我更不用说这套衣服了。禁地！哦，是的，没关系。让我们谈谈别的事情吧。

Ada would have done so willingly, and with a full persuasion that we had brought the question to a most satisfactory state. But I thought it would be useless to stop there, so I began again.
艾达会心甘情愿地这样做，并且完全相信我们已经把这个问题带到了最令人满意的状态。但我觉得停在这里是没有用的，所以我又开始了。

‘No, but Richard,’ said I, ‘and my dear Ada! Consider how important it is to you both, and what a point of honour it is towards your cousin, that you, Richard, should be quite in earnest without any reservation. I think we had better talk about this, really, Ada. It will be too late very soon.’
“不，但是理查德，”我说，“还有我亲爱的艾达！考虑一下，理查德，你应该毫无保留地认真对待这件事，这对你们俩来说是多么重要，对你的表弟来说是多么荣幸。我认为我们最好谈谈这个，真的，艾达。很快就太晚了。

‘Oh, yes! We must talk about it!’ said Ada. ‘But I think Richard is right.’
'哦是的！我们必须谈谈！”艾达说。 “但我认为理查德是对的。”

What was the use of my trying to look wise when she was so pretty, and so engaging, and so fond of him!
当她如此美丽、如此迷人、如此喜欢他时，我努力让自己看起来聪明又有什么用呢！

‘Mr. and Mrs. Badger were here yesterday, Richard,’ said I, ‘and they seemed disposed to think that you had no great liking for the profession.’
'先生。 “理查德，巴杰尔太太昨天也来过，”我说，“他们似乎认为你不太喜欢这个职业。”

‘Did they though?’ said Richard. ‘Oh! Well, that rather alters the case, because I had no idea that they thought so, and I should not have liked to disappoint or inconvenience them. The fact is, I don’t care much about it. But, oh, it don’t matter! It’ll do as well as anything else!’
“他们有吗？”理查德说。 '哦！好吧，这反而改变了情况，因为我不知道他们是这么想的，而且我也不应该让他们失望或给他们带来不便。事实是，我不太关心它。但是，哦，没关系！它会和其他任何事情一样好！

‘You hear him, Ada!’ said I.
“你听到了，艾达！”我说。

‘The fact is,’ Richard proceeded, half thoughtfully and half jocosely, ‘it is not quite in my way. I don’t take to it. And I get too much of Mrs. Bayham Badger’s first and second.’
“事实是，”理查德半若有所思半开玩笑地继续说道，“这不太妨碍我。”我不喜欢它。我对贝厄姆·獾夫人的第一和第二件事了解得太多了。

‘I am sure THAT’S very natural!’ cried Ada, quite delighted. ‘The very thing we both said yesterday, Esther!’
“我相信这很自然！”艾达非常高兴地喊道。 “这就是我们昨天说的，埃丝特！”

‘Then,’ pursued Richard, ‘it’s monotonous, and to-day is too like yesterday, and to-morrow is too like to-day.’
“那么，”理查德继续说道，“那就太单调了，今天太像昨天了，明天也太像今天了。”

‘But I am afraid,’ said I, ‘this is an objection to all kinds of application—to life itself, except under some very uncommon circumstances.’
“但我担心，”我说，“这是对各种应用的反对——对生命本身的反对，除非在一些非常不常见的情况下。”

‘Do you think so?’ returned Richard, still considering. ‘Perhaps! Ha! Why, then, you know,’ he added, suddenly becoming gay again, ‘we travel outside a circle to what I said just now. It’ll do as well as anything else. Oh, it’s all right enough! Let us talk about something else.’
“你这么认为吗？”理查德回答道，仍在思考。 '也许！哈！那么，你知道吗，”他补充道，突然又变得同性恋了，“我们走出了一个圈子，回到了我刚才所说的地方。它会和其他任何事情一样好。哦，没关系！让我们谈谈别的事情吧。

But even Ada, with her loving face—and if it had seemed innocent and trusting when I first saw it in that memorable November fog, how much more did it seem now when I knew her innocent and trusting heart—even Ada shook her head at this and looked serious. So I thought it a good opportunity to hint to Richard that if he were sometimes a little careless of himself, I was very sure he never meant to be careless of Ada, and that it was a part of his affectionate consideration for her not to slight the importance of a step that might influence both their lives. This made him almost grave.
但即使是艾达，她那张慈爱的脸庞——如果我第一次在令人难忘的十一月雾中看到它时，它看上去天真无邪、值得信赖，那么现在当我知道她天真无邪、值得信赖的心时，它看起来又是多么天真无邪——甚至艾达也摇了摇头。这看起来很严肃。所以我认为这是一个很好的机会向理查德暗示，如果他有时对自己有点粗心，我很确定他从来没有故意对艾达不小心，这是他深情考虑的一部分，让她不要轻视可能影响他们两人生活的一步的重要性。这让他几乎变得严肃起来。

‘My dear Mother Hubbard,’ he said, ‘that’s the very thing! I have thought of that several times and have been quite angry with myself for meaning to be so much in earnest and—somehow—not exactly being so. I don’t know how it is; I seem to want something or other to stand by. Even you have no idea how fond I am of Ada (my darling cousin, I love you, so much!), but I don’t settle down to constancy in other things. It’s such uphill work, and it takes such a time!’ said Richard with an air of vexation.
“我亲爱的哈伯德妈妈，”他说，“就是这样！”我曾多次想到这一点，并对自己感到非常生气，因为我本想如此认真，但不知为何，事实并非如此。我不知道是怎么回事；我似乎想要有什么东西站在旁边。即使你不知道我有多喜欢艾达（我亲爱的表弟，我非常爱你！），但我在其他事情上并没有安定下来。这是多么艰巨的工作，而且需要这么长时间！”理查德一脸烦恼地说道。

‘That may be,’ I suggested, ‘because you don’t like what you have chosen.’
“这可能是，”我建议道，“因为你不喜欢你所选择的。”

‘Poor fellow!’ said Ada. ‘I am sure I don’t wonder at it!’
“可怜的家伙！”艾达说。 “我确信我对此并不感到奇怪！”

No. It was not of the least use my trying to look wise. I tried again, but how could I do it, or how could it have any effect if I could, while Ada rested her clasped hands upon his shoulder and while he looked at her tender blue eyes, and while they looked at him!
不，我试图表现得明智一点也没有任何用处。我又试了一次，但是当艾达将双手紧握在他的肩膀上，当他看着她温柔的蓝眼睛，当他们看着他的时候，我该怎么办呢？

‘You see, my precious girl,’ said Richard, passing her golden curls through and through his hand, ‘I was a little hasty perhaps; or I misunderstood my own inclinations perhaps. They don’t seem to lie in that direction. I couldn’t tell till I tried. Now the question is whether it’s worth-while to undo all that has been done. It seems like making a great disturbance about nothing particular.’
“你看，我的宝贝女儿，”理查德一边说着，一边用手抚摸着她金色的卷发，“也许我有点草率了；但我还是有点急躁了。”或者我也许误解了自己的倾向。他们似乎并没有朝那个方向撒谎。在我尝试之前我无法判断。现在的问题是是否值得撤销已经完成的一切。好像没什么特别的事，就大闹了。”

‘My dear Richard,’ said I, ‘how CAN you say about nothing particular?’
“亲爱的理查德，”我说，“你怎么能说没什么特别的呢？”

‘I don’t mean absolutely that,’ he returned. ‘I mean that it MAY be nothing particular because I may never want it.’
“我绝对不是这个意思，”他回答道。 “我的意思是，它可能没什么特别的，因为我可能永远不想要它。”

Both Ada and I urged, in reply, not only that it was decidedly worth-while to undo what had been done, but that it must be undone. I then asked Richard whether he had thought of any more congenial pursuit.
艾达和我在答复中都敦促，不仅绝对值得撤销已经完成的事情，而且必须撤销它。然后我问理查德是否想过更合适的追求。

‘There, my dear Mrs. Shipton,’ said Richard, ‘you touch me home. Yes, I have. I have been thinking that the law is the boy for me.’
“好了，我亲爱的希普顿夫人，”理查德说，“你让我回家了。”是的，我有。我一直认为法律是我的最佳选择。

‘The law!’ repeated Ada as if she were afraid of the name.
“法律！”艾达重复道，仿佛她害怕这个名字。

‘If I went into Kenge’s office,’ said Richard, ‘and if I were placed under articles to Kenge, I should have my eye on the—hum!— the forbidden ground—and should be able to study it, and master it, and to satisfy myself that it was not neglected and was being properly conducted. I should be able to look after Ada’s interests and my own interests (the same thing!); and I should peg away at Blackstone and all those fellows with the most tremendous ardour.’
“如果我走进肯格的办公室，”理查德说，“如果我被安排在肯格的文章下，我应该会关注——嗯！——禁地——并且应该能够研究它，掌握它，并使我自己确信它没有被忽视并且正在正确地进行。我应该能够照顾艾达的利益和我自己的利益（同一件事！）；我应该以最大的热情锁定黑石和所有这些人。

I was not by any means so sure of that, and I saw how his hankering after the vague things yet to come of those long-deferred hopes cast a shade on Ada’s face. But I thought it best to encourage him in any project of continuous exertion, and only advised him to be quite sure that his mind was made up now.
我无论如何都不敢肯定这一点，我看到他对那些长期推迟的希望中尚未实现的模糊事物的渴望如何在艾达的脸上投下了阴影。但我认为最好在任何需要持续努力的项目上鼓励他，只是建议他确定自己现在已经下定决心了。

‘My dear Minerva,’ said Richard, ‘I am as steady as you are. I made a mistake; we are all liable to mistakes; I won’t do so any more, and I’ll become such a lawyer as is not often seen. That is, you know,’ said Richard, relapsing into doubt, ‘if it really is worth-while, after all, to make such a disturbance about nothing particular!’
“我亲爱的米勒娃，”理查德说，“我和你一样坚定。我犯了一个错误;我们都有可能犯错误；我不会再这样做了，我会成为一个不常见的律师。也就是说，你知道，”理查德说，再次陷入怀疑，“毕竟，为了没什么特别的事情而制造这样的麻烦是否真的值得！

This led to our saying again, with a great deal of gravity, all that we had said already and to our coming to much the same conclusion afterwards. But we so strongly advised Richard to be frank and open with Mr. Jarndyce, without a moment’s delay, and his disposition was naturally so opposed to concealment that he sought him out at once (taking us with him) and made a full avowal. ‘Rick,’ said my guardian, after hearing him attentively, ‘we can retreat with honour, and we will. But we must he careful—for our cousin s sake, Rick, for our cousin’s sake—that we make no more such mistakes. Therefore, in the matter of the law, we will have a good trial before we decide. We will look before we leap, and take plenty of time about it.’
这导致我们非常严肃地再次说出我们已经说过的一切，并导致我们后来得出了大致相同的结论。但我们强烈建议理查德对贾迪斯先生开诚布公，不要有片刻的拖延，而他的性情自然是反对隐瞒的，所以他立即找到了贾迪斯先生（带着我们）并完全坦白了。 “瑞克，”我的监护人仔细听完他的话后说道，“我们可以光荣地撤退，我们会的。”但我们必须小心——看在我们表弟的份上，瑞克，看在我们表弟的份上——不要再犯这样的错误。所以，在法律问题上，我们要好好审判一下再做决定。我们会三思而后行，并花大量时间。

Richard’s energy was of such an impatient and fitful kind that he would have liked nothing better than to have gone to Mr. Kenge’s office in that hour and to have entered into articles with him on the spot. Submitting, however, with a good grace to the caution that we had shown to be so necessary, he contented himself with sitting down among us in his lightest spirits and talking as if his one unvarying purpose in life from childhood had been that one which now held possession of him. My guardian was very kind and cordial with him, but rather grave, enough so to cause Ada, when he had departed and we were going upstairs to bed, to say, ‘Cousin John, I hope you don’t think the worse of Richard?’
理查德的精力如此不耐烦，断断续续，他最想在那个时间去肯格先生的办公室，当场与他签订文章。然而，他很高兴地接受了我们所表现出的必要的警告，心满意足地坐在我们中间，心情最轻松地聊天，仿佛他从童年起就一直坚持的人生目标就是现在的目标。占有了他。我的监护人对他非常友善和热情，但也很严肃，以至于当他离开、我们上楼睡觉时，艾达说：‘约翰表弟，我希望你不要把理查德想得更糟。 ？

‘No, my love,’ said he.
“不，亲爱的，”他说。

‘Because it was very natural that Richard should be mistaken in such a difficult case. It is not uncommon.’
“因为理查德在如此困难的案件中犯错是很自然的。这并不罕见。

‘No, no, my love,’ said he. ‘Don’t look unhappy.’
“不，不，我的爱人，”他说。 “别露出不高兴的样子。”

‘Oh, I am not unhappy, cousin John!’ said Ada, smiling cheerfully, with her hand upon his shoulder, where she had put it in bidding him good night. ‘But I should be a little so if you thought at all the worse of Richard.’
“噢，我并没有不高兴，约翰表弟！”艾达把手搭在约翰的肩膀上，高兴地微笑着说道，这是她向他道晚安时所放的。 “但如果你对理查德有更坏的看法，我也应该这么认为。”

‘My dear,’ said Mr. Jarndyce, ‘I should think the worse of him only if you were ever in the least unhappy through his means. I should be more disposed to quarrel with myself even then, than with poor Rick, for I brought you together. But, tut, all this is nothing! He has time before him, and the race to run. I think the worse of him? Not I, my loving cousin! And not you, I swear!’
“亲爱的，”贾迪斯先生说，“只有当你因他的手段而感到一丝不快时，我才会对他产生更坏的看法。”即使在那时，我也应该更愿意与自己争吵，而不是与可怜的里克争吵，因为是我把你们带到了一起。但是，啧，这一切都不算什么！他面前还有时间，还有赛跑要跑。我觉得他更坏？不是我，我亲爱的表弟！而不是你，我发誓！

‘No, indeed, cousin John,’ said Ada, ‘I am sure I could not—I am sure I would not—think any ill of Richard if the whole world did. I could, and I would, think better of him then than at any other time!’
“不，确实如此，约翰表弟，”艾达说，“如果全世界都这样想，我相信我也不会——我相信我不会——对理查德有任何不好的看法。那时我可以而且我会比任何其他时候都更想念他！

So quietly and honestly she said it, with her hands upon his shoulders—both hands now—and looking up into his face, like the picture of truth!
她如此平静而诚实地说道，双手搭在他的肩膀上——现在是双手——抬头看着他的脸，就像真实的画面一样！

‘I think,’ said my guardian, thoughtfully regarding her, ‘I think it must be somewhere written that the virtues of the mothers shall occasionally be visited on the children, as well as the sins of the father. Good night, my rosebud. Good night, little woman. Pleasant slumbers! Happy dreams!’
“我想，”我的监护人若有所思地看着她，说道，“我想一定有什么地方写着，母亲的美德有时会影响到孩子们，就像父亲的罪恶一样。”晚安，我的玫瑰花蕾。晚安，小女人。愉快的睡眠！高兴的梦！'

This was the first time I ever saw him follow Ada with his eyes with something of a shadow on their benevolent expression. I well remembered the look with which he had contemplated her and Richard when she was singing in the firelight; it was but a very little while since he had watched them passing down the room in which the sun was shining, and away into the shade; but his glance was changed, and even the silent look of confidence in me which now followed it once more was not quite so hopeful and untroubled as it had originally been.
这是我第一次看到他用慈祥的眼神带着一丝阴影追随艾达。我清楚地记得当她在火光下唱歌时，他注视着她和理查德的眼神。自从他看着他们穿过阳光明媚的房间，消失在阴凉处之后，这只是很短的一段时间。但他的眼神变了，甚至连那再次出现的对我充满信心的沉默​​表情也不再像原来那样充满希望和平静。

Ada praised Richard more to me that night than ever she had praised him yet. She went to sleep with a little bracelet he had given her clasped upon her arm. I fancied she was dreaming of him when I kissed her cheek after she had slept an hour and saw how tranquil and happy she looked.
那天晚上，艾达对我对理查德的赞扬比以往任何时候都多。她睡着了，手臂上戴着他送给她的小手镯。当我在她睡了一个小时后亲吻她的脸颊并看到她看起来多么平静和快乐时，我以为她正在梦见他。

For I was so little inclined to sleep myself that night that I sat up working. It would not be worth mentioning for its own sake, but I was wakeful and rather low-spirited. I don’t know why. At least I don’t think I know why. At least, perhaps I do, but I don’t think it matters.
因为那天晚上我根本不想睡觉，所以我就坐着工作。就其本身而言，这并不值得一提，但我很清醒，而且情绪低落。我不知道为什么。至少我认为我不知道为什么。至少，也许我这样做，但我认为这并不重要。

At any rate, I made up my mind to be so dreadfully industrious that I would leave myself not a moment’s leisure to be low-spirited. For I naturally said, ‘Esther! You to be low-spirited. YOU!’ And it really was time to say so, for I—yes, I really did see myself in the glass, almost crying. ‘As if you had anything to make you unhappy, instead of everything to make you happy, you ungrateful heart!’ said I.
无论如何，我下定决心要勤奋得要命，不给自己留下片刻的闲暇去消沉。因为我很自然地说：‘以斯帖！你要情绪低落。你！”确实是时候这么说了，因为我——是的，我确实在镜子里看到了自己，几乎哭了。 “你这忘恩负义的心，好像你有什么东西让你不快乐，而不是一切让你快乐的东西！”我说。

If I could have made myself go to sleep, I would have done it directly, but not being able to do that, I took out of my basket some ornamental work for our house (I mean Bleak House) that I was busy with at that time and sat down to it with great determination. It was necessary to count all the stitches in that work, and I resolved to go on with it until I couldn’t keep my eyes open, and then to go to bed.
如果我能让自己入睡，我会直接做，但做不到，我从篮子里拿出一些我当时正忙着的房子（我的意思是《荒凉山庄》）的装饰品时间到了，并以极大的决心坐下来。这项工作需要数清所有的针脚，我决定继续做下去，直到我睁不开眼睛，然后上床睡觉。

I soon found myself very busy. But I had left some silk downstairs in a work-table drawer in the temporary growlery, and coming to a stop for want of it, I took my candle and went softly down to get it. To my great surprise, on going in I found my guardian still there, and sitting looking at the ashes. He was lost in thought, his book lay unheeded by his side, his silvered iron-grey hair was scattered confusedly upon his forehead as though his hand had been wandering among it while his thoughts were elsewhere, and his face looked worn. Almost frightened by coming upon him so unexpectedly, I stood still for a moment and should have retired without speaking had he not, in again passing his hand abstractedly through his hair, seen me and started.
很快我就发现自己很忙。但我在楼下临时吵闹的工作台抽屉里留下了一些丝绸，我停下来拿了蜡烛，轻轻地下去拿。令我惊讶的是，进去后我发现我的监护人还在那里，坐着看着骨灰。他陷入了沉思，书放在身边无人理睬，铁灰色的银发凌乱地散落在额头上，仿佛他的手在其中游走，而他的思绪却在别处，他的脸色看上去憔悴不堪。我几乎被如此出人意料地撞到他身上吓坏了，我一动不动地站了一会儿，要不是他再次心不在焉地把手伸进头发里，看到我并吓了一跳，我本该一言不发地退出去。

‘Esther!’
“以斯帖！”

I told him what I had come for.
我告诉他我来这里的目的。

‘At work so late, my dear?’
“亲爱的，这么晚才上班吗？”

‘I am working late to-night,’ said I, ‘because I couldn’t sleep and wished to tire myself. But, dear guardian, you are late too, and look weary. You have no trouble, I hope, to keep you waking?’
“我今晚工作到很晚，”我说，“因为我睡不着，想让自己累了。”但是，亲爱的监护人，你也迟到了，而且看上去很疲惫。我希望你不会有什么麻烦让你保持清醒吧？

‘None, little woman, that YOU would readily understand,’ said he.
“没有，小女人，你很容易明白，”他说。

He spoke in a regretful tone so new to me that I inwardly repeated, as if that would help me to his meaning, ‘That I could readily understand!’
他用一种对我来说很陌生的遗憾语气说话，我在心里重复了一遍，好像这能帮助我理解他的意思，“我很容易理解！”

‘Remain a moment, Esther,’ said he, ‘You were in my thoughts.’
“等一下，埃丝特，”他说，“你在我的脑海里。”

‘I hope I was not the trouble, guardian?’
“我希望我不是麻烦，监护人？”

He slightly waved his hand and fell into his usual manner. The change was so remarkable, and he appeared to make it by dint of so much self-command, that I found myself again inwardly repeating, ‘None that I could understand!’
他轻轻一挥手，又恢复了平常的样子。这种变化是如此显着，而且他似乎是凭借如此多的自我控制才做到这一点的，我发现自己再次在内心重复：“我无法理解！”

‘Little woman,’ said my guardian, ‘I was thinking—that is, I have been thinking since I have been sitting here—that you ought to know of your own history all I know. It is very little. Next to nothing.’
“小女人，”我的监护人说，“我在想——也就是说，自从我坐在这里以来我一直在想——你应该知道我所知道的你自己的历史。数量非常少。几乎什么都没有。

‘Dear guardian,’ I replied, ‘when you spoke to me before on that subject—‘
“亲爱的监护人，”我回答道，“当你之前跟我谈过这个话题时——”

‘But since then,’ he gravely interposed, anticipating what I meant to say, ‘I have reflected that your having anything to ask me, and my having anything to tell you, are different considerations, Esther. It is perhaps my duty to impart to you the little I know.’
“但从那时起，”他严肃地插话，预料到了我的意思，“我已经意识到，你有什么要问我的，和我有什么要告诉你的，是不同的考虑，埃丝特。也许我有责任向你传授我所知道的一点点。

‘If you think so, guardian, it is right.’
“如果您这么认为，监护人，那就对了。”

‘I think so,’ he returned very gently, and kindly, and very distinctly. ‘My dear, I think so now. If any real disadvantage can attach to your position in the mind of any man or woman worth a thought, it is right that you at least of all the world should not magnify it to yourself by having vague impressions of its nature.’
“我想是的，”他非常温柔、友善、清晰地回答道。 ‘亲爱的，我现在也是这么想的。如果你在任何值得考虑的男人或女人心目中的地位有任何真正的劣势，那么你至少不应该因为对它的本质有模糊的印象而放大它，这是正确的。

I sat down and said after a little effort to be as calm as I ought to be, ‘One of my earliest remembrances, guardian, is of these words: ‘Your mother, Esther, is your disgrace, and you were hers. The time will come, and soon enough, when you will understand this better, and will feel it too, as no one save a woman can.’’ I had covered my face with my hands in repeating the words, but I took them away now with a better kind of shame, I hope, and told him that to him I owed the blessing that I had from my childhood to that hour never, never, never felt it. He put up his hand as if to stop me. I well knew that he was never to be thanked, and said no more.
我花了一点力气才让自己保持平静，然后坐下来说道：“监护人，我最早的记忆之一就是这样的话：‘你的母亲，埃丝特，是你的耻辱，而你是她的耻辱。总有一天，很快，你就会更好地理解这一点，也会感受到这一点，除了女人之外，没有人能做到。”我用双手捂住脸重复这句话，但我把它们拿走了我希望现在带着一种更好的羞耻感，并告诉他，我从童年到那一刻都得到了祝福，从未、从未、从未感受到过。他举起手，好像要阻止我。我深知永远不会感谢他，便不再多说什么。

‘Nine years, my dear,’ he said after thinking for a little while, ‘have passed since I received a letter from a lady living in seclusion, written with a stern passion and power that rendered it unlike all other letters I have ever read. It was written to me (as it told me in so many words), perhaps because it was the writer’s idiosyncrasy to put that trust in me, perhaps because it was mine to justify it. It told me of a child, an orphan girl then twelve years old, in some such cruel words as those which live in your remembrance. It told me that the writer had bred her in secrecy from her birth, had blotted out all trace of her existence, and that if the writer were to die before the child became a woman, she would be left entirely friendless, nameless, and unknown. It asked me to consider if I would, in that case, finish what the writer had begun.’
“亲爱的，”他想了一会儿说道，“自从我收到一封来自一位隐居女士的来信以来，已经过去了九年了，这封信充满了强烈的激情和力量，与我读过的所有其他信都不一样。 。它是写给我的（正如它用很多字告诉我的那样），也许是因为作者的特质是对我的信任，也许是因为我有理由证明它的合理性。它告诉我一个孩子，一个十二岁的孤女，用一些像你记忆中那样残酷的话语。它告诉我，作者从她出生起就秘密抚养她，抹去了她存在的所有痕迹，如果作者在孩子成为女人之前去世，她将完全没有朋友，无名，无人知晓。 。它要求我考虑在这种情况下我是否会完成作家已经开始的事情。

I listened in silence and looked attentively at him.
我默默地听着，也专注地看着他。

‘Your early recollection, my dear, will supply the gloomy medium through which all this was seen and expressed by the writer, and the distorted religion which clouded her mind with impressions of the need there was for the child to expiate an offence of which she was quite innocent. I felt concerned for the little creature, in her darkened life, and replied to the letter.’
“亲爱的，你早年的回忆将提供一种阴暗的媒介，通过它，作者看到并表达了这一切，而扭曲的宗教则笼罩了她的心灵，让她觉得孩子需要弥补她所犯下的过错。”很无辜。我对这个小生物感到担忧，在她黑暗的生活中，并回复了这封信。

I took his hand and kissed it.
我握住他的手并亲吻它。

‘It laid the injunction on me that I should never propose to see the writer, who had long been estranged from all intercourse with the world, but who would see a confidential agent if I would appoint one. I accredited Mr. Kenge. The lady said, of her own accord and not of his seeking, that her name was an assumed one. That she was, if there were any ties of blood in such a case, the child’s aunt. That more than this she would never (and he was well persuaded of the steadfastness of her resolution) for any human consideration disclose. My dear, I have told you all.’
“这对我下了禁令，我永远不应该提议去见这位作家，他早已与世隔绝，但如果我任命一名机密特工，他会见他。我认可肯格先生。这位女士说，她是自愿的，而不是他寻求的，她的名字是假的。如果在这种情况下有任何血缘关系的话，她就是孩子的姨妈。除此之外，出于人性的考虑，她绝不会透露更多的事情（他深信她的决心是坚定的）。亲爱的，我已经告诉你一切了。

I held his hand for a little while in mine.
我握着他的手一会儿。

‘I saw my ward oftener than she saw me,’ he added, cheerily making light of it, ‘and I always knew she was beloved, useful, and happy. She repays me twenty-thousandfold, and twenty more to that, every hour in every day!’
“我见到我的受监护人的次数比她见到我的次数还多，”他高兴地补充道，“我一直都知道她是受人爱戴的、有用的、快乐的。”她每天每时每刻都回报我两万倍，还有二十倍！”

‘And oftener still,’ said I, ‘“she blesses the guardian who is a father to her!’
“而且更常见的是，”我说，“她祝福作为她父亲的监护人！”

At the word father, I saw his former trouble come into his face. He subdued it as before, and it was gone in an instant; but it had been there and it had come so swiftly upon my words that I felt as if they had given him a shock. I again inwardly repeated, wondering, ‘That I could readily understand. None that I could readily understand!’ No, it was true. I did not understand it. Not for many and many a day.
听到父亲这个词，我看到他脸上浮现出他以前的烦恼。他照旧制服它，转眼间它就消失了；但它就在那里，而且随着我的话而来得如此之快，我觉得好像它们让他震惊了。我心里又重复了一遍，心里纳闷：“我很容易明白。”没有一个是我能轻易理解的！’不，这是真的。我不明白。不是很多很多一天。

‘Take a fatherly good night, my dear,’ said he, kissing me on the forehead, ‘and so to rest. These are late hours for working and thinking. You do that for all of us, all day long, little housekeeper!’
“亲爱的，祝您晚安，亲爱的，”他亲吻我的额头说道，“然后休息一下。”现在是工作和思考的较晚时间。你整天都在为我们所有人做这件事，小管家！”

I neither worked nor thought any more that night. I opened my grateful heart to heaven in thankfulness for its providence to me and its care of me, and fell asleep.
那天晚上我不再工作，也不再思考。我向天堂敞开了感恩的心，感谢它对我的眷顾和照顾，然后就睡着了。

We had a visitor next day. Mr. Allan Woodcourt came. He came to take leave of us; he had settled to do so beforehand. He was going to China and to India as a surgeon on board ship. He was to be away a long, long time.
第二天我们来了一位访客。艾伦·伍德考特先生来了。他来向我们告别；他事先就决定这么做了。他将作为一名船上外科医生前往中国和印度。他要离开很长很长一段时间。

I believe—at least I know—that he was not rich. All his widowed mother could spare had been spent in qualifying him for his profession. It was not lucrative to a young practitioner, with very little influence in London; and although he was, night and day, at the service of numbers of poor people and did wonders of gentleness and skill for them, he gained very little by it in money. He was seven years older than I. Not that I need mention it, for it hardly seems to belong to anything.
我相信——至少我知道——他并不富有。他丧偶的母亲把所有的积蓄都花在了他的职业资格上。对于一个在伦敦影响力很小的年轻从业者来说，这并不有利可图。尽管他夜以继日地为许多穷人服务，并为他们做出了温柔和技巧的奇迹，但他从中获得的金钱却很少。他比我大七岁。我不需要提及这一点，因为它似乎不属于任何东西。

I think—I mean, he told us—that he had been in practice three or four years and that if he could have hoped to contend through three or four more, he would not have made the voyage on which he was bound. But he had no fortune or private means, and so he was going away. He had been to see us several times altogether. We thought it a pity he should go away. Because he was distinguished in his art among those who knew it best, and some of the greatest men belonging to it had a high opinion of him.
我想——我的意思是，他告诉我们——他已经练习了三四年了，如果他还能希望再坚持三四年，他就不会完成他预定的航行了。但他没有财产，也没有私人财产，所以他要离开。他总共来看过我们好几次。我们认为他应该离开很遗憾。因为他的艺术在最了解该艺术的人中是杰出的，并且该艺术领域的一些最伟大的人物对他评价很高。

When he came to bid us good-bye, he brought his mother with him for the first time. She was a pretty old lady, with bright black eyes, but she seemed proud. She came from Wales and had had, a long time ago, an eminent person for an ancestor, of the name of Morgan apKerrig—of some place that sounded like Gimlet—who was the most illustrious person that ever was known and all of whose relations were a sort of royal family. He appeared to have passed his life in always getting up into mountains and fighting somebody; and a bard whose name sounded like Crumlinwallinwer had sung his praises in a piece which was called, as nearly as I could catch it, Mewlinnwillinwodd.
当他来向我们告别时，他第一次带着他的母亲一起来。她是一位漂亮的老太太，有着明亮的黑眼睛，但看上去很骄傲。她来自威尔士，很久以前，有一位杰出的人作为祖先，名叫摩根·阿普·凯里格（Morgan apKerrig）——在某个地方听起来像吉姆莱特——他是有史以来最杰出的人，他的所有亲戚是一种皇室家族。他的一生似乎都是在上山与人打斗中度过的。一位名字听起来像克鲁姆林沃林沃的吟游诗人曾在一首曲子中歌颂过他，据我所知，这首曲子的名字叫《Mewlinnwillinwodd》。

Mrs. Woodcourt, after expatiating to us on the fame of her great kinsman, said that no doubt wherever her son Allan went he would remember his pedigree and would on no account form an alliance below it. She told him that there were many handsome English ladies in India who went out on speculation, and that there were some to be picked up with property, but that neither charms nor wealth would suffice for the descendant from such a line without birth, which must ever be the first consideration. She talked so much about birth that for a moment I half fancied, and with pain— But what an idle fancy to suppose that she could think or care what MINE was!
伍德考特夫人向我们详细介绍了她的伟大亲戚的名声后说，毫无疑问，无论她的儿子艾伦走到哪里，他都会记住自己的血统，并且决不会在其血统之下结成联盟。她告诉他，印度有很多英俊的英国女士出去投机，其中一些可以用财产来获得，但魅力和财富都不足以满足这样一个没有出生的后代，这必须永远是首要考虑的因素。她谈论了太多关于出生的事情，有那么一刻，我半信半疑地、痛苦地想象着——但是假设她能思考或关心我的出生是什么，那是多么无聊的幻想啊！

Mr. Woodcourt seemed a little distressed by her prolixity, but he was too considerate to let her see it and contrived delicately to bring the conversation round to making his acknowledgments to my guardian for his hospitality and for the very happy hours—he called them the very happy hours—he had passed with us. The recollection of them, he said, would go with him wherever he went and would be always treasured. And so we gave him our hands, one after another—at least, they did—and I did; and so he put his lips to Ada’s hand—and to mine; and so he went away upon his long, long voyage!
伍德考特先生似乎对她的冗长感到有点苦恼，但他太体贴了，没有让她看到这一点，并巧妙地把谈话转入对我的监护人的热情款待和非常快乐的时光的感谢——他称他们为“非常快乐的时光——他和我们一起度过了。他说，无论他走到哪里，对他们的回忆都会伴随着他，并将永远被珍惜。于是我们一只又一只地向他伸出了双手——至少，他们这么做了——而我也这么做了。于是他把嘴唇放在艾达的手上——还有我的手。就这样，他踏上了漫长的旅程！

I was very busy indeed all day and wrote directions home to the servants, and wrote notes for my guardian, and dusted his books and papers, and jingled my housekeeping keys a good deal, one way and another. I was still busy between the lights, singing and working by the window, when who should come in but Caddy, whom I had no expectation of seeing!
我一整天确实很忙，给仆人写回家的指示，给我的监护人写便条，掸掉他的书本和文件，并用各种方式敲响我的家务钥匙。灯火通明时，我仍然忙着在窗边唱歌和工作，这时除了凯迪谁应该进来，我没想到会见到他！

‘Why, Caddy, my dear,’ said I, ‘what beautiful flowers!’
“哎呀，凯迪，亲爱的，”我说，“多么美丽的花啊！”

She had such an exquisite little nosegay in her hand.
她手里拿着一根如此精致的小花束。

‘Indeed, I think so, Esther,’ replied Caddy. ‘They are the loveliest I ever saw.’
“确实，我想是这样，埃丝特，”凯迪回答道。 “它们是我见过的最可爱的。”

‘Prince, my dear?’ said I in a whisper.
“王子，亲爱的？”我低声说道。

‘No,’ answered Caddy, shaking her head and holding them to me to smell. ‘Not Prince.’
“不，”凯蒂回答道，摇着头，把它们递给我闻。 “不是王子。”

‘Well, to be sure, Caddy!’ said I. ‘You must have two lovers!’
“好吧，当然，凯迪！”我说，“你一定有两个情人！”

‘What? Do they look like that sort of thing?’ said Caddy.
'什么？它们看起来像那种东西吗？”凯迪说。

‘Do they look like that sort of thing?’ I repeated, pinching her cheek.
“它们看起来像那种东西吗？”我重复道，捏了捏她的脸颊。

Caddy only laughed in return, and telling me that she had come for half an hour, at the expiration of which time Prince would be waiting for her at the corner, sat chatting with me and Ada in the window, every now and then handing me the flowers again or trying how they looked against my hair. At last, when she was going, she took me into my room and put them in my dress.
凯蒂只是笑笑，告诉我她已经来了半个小时，到了这段时间普林斯就会在拐角处等她，坐在窗边和我和艾达聊天，时不时地把我递给我。再次欣赏花朵，或者尝试它们与我的头发的搭配。最后，当她要走的时候，她把我带进了我的房间，把它们放进了我的衣服里。

‘For me?’ said I, surprised.
“给我的？”我惊讶地说。

‘For you,’ said Caddy with a kiss. ‘They were left behind by somebody.’
“为了你，”凯迪亲吻道。 “他们被某人留下了。”

‘Left behind?’
'被留下来？'

‘At poor Miss Flite’s,’ said Caddy. ‘Somebody who has been very good to her was hurrying away an hour ago to join a ship and left these flowers behind. No, no! Don’t take them out. Let the pretty little things lie here,’ said Caddy, adjusting them with a careful hand, ‘because I was present myself, and I shouldn’t wonder if somebody left them on purpose!’
“在可怜的弗利特小姐家，”凯迪说。 “一个对她很好的人一小时前匆匆离开去上船，留下了这些花。不，不！不要把它们拿出来。让这些漂亮的小东西放在这里吧，”凯迪一边说，一边小心翼翼地调整着它们，“因为我自己也在场，我不应该怀疑是不是有人故意把它们留下的！”

‘Do they look like that sort of thing?’ said Ada, coming laughingly behind me and clasping me merrily round the waist. ‘Oh, yes, indeed they do, Dame Durden! They look very, very like that sort of thing. Oh, very like it indeed, my dear!’
“它们看起来像那种东西吗？”艾达笑着走到我身后，高兴地搂住我的腰。 “哦，是的，确实如此，杜登夫人！它们看起来非常非常像那种东西。哦，确实很喜欢，亲爱的！

CHAPTER XVIII
第十八章


Lady Dedlock
德洛克夫人

It was not so easy as it had appeared at first to arrange for Richard’s making a trial of Mr. Kenge’s office. Richard himself was the chief impediment. As soon as he had it in his power to leave Mr. Badger at any moment, he began to doubt whether he wanted to leave him at all. He didn’t know, he said, really. It wasn’t a bad profession; he couldn’t assert that he disliked it; perhaps he liked it as well as he liked any other—suppose he gave it one more chance! Upon that, he shut himself up for a few weeks with some books and some bones and seemed to acquire a considerable fund of information with great rapidity. His fervour, after lasting about a month, began to cool, and when it was quite cooled, began to grow warm again. His vacillations between law and medicine lasted so long that midsummer arrived before he finally separated from Mr. Badger and entered on an experimental course of Messrs. Kenge and Carboy. For all his waywardness, he took great credit to himself as being determined to be in earnest ‘this time.’ And he was so good-natured throughout, and in such high spirits, and so fond of Ada, that it was very difficult indeed to be otherwise than pleased with him.
安排理查德参观肯吉先生的办公室并不像一开始看上去那么容易。理查德本人是主要障碍。一旦他有能力随时离开獾先生，他就开始怀疑自己是否真的想离开他。他说，他真的不知道。这并不是一个糟糕的职业。他不能断言他不喜欢它；也许他喜欢它就像喜欢其他任何东西一样——假设他再给它一次机会！此后，他用一些书和一些骨头把自己关了几个星期，似乎很快就获得了相当多的信息。他的热情持续了一个月左右，就开始冷却，等冷却到一定程度，又开始变得热烈起来。他在法律和医学之间犹豫不决，持续了很长时间，以至于仲夏到来，他最终与巴杰先生分开，并开始了肯格先生和卡博伊先生的实验课程。尽管他任性，他却自以为“这一次”是认真的。而且他自始至终都是那么好脾气，那么兴高采烈，又那么喜欢艾达，这确实是非常困难的。对他不满意。

‘As to Mr. Jarndyce,’ who, I may mention, found the wind much given, during this period, to stick in the east; ‘As to Mr. Jarndyce,’ Richard would say to me, ‘he is the finest fellow in the world, Esther! I must be particularly careful, if it were only for his satisfaction, to take myself well to task and have a regular wind-up of this business now.’
“至于贾迪斯先生，”我可以提一下，他发现这一时期的风向大多为东风； “至于贾迪斯先生，”理查德会对我说，“他是世界上最好的人，埃丝特！如果只是为了让他满意的话，我必须特别小心，认真对待自己的任务，并定期结束这件事。

The idea of his taking himself well to task, with that laughing face and heedless manner and with a fancy that everything could catch and nothing could hold, was ludicrously anomalous. However, he told us between-whiles that he was doing it to such an extent that he wondered his hair didn’t turn grey. His regular wind-up of the business was (as I have said) that he went to Mr. Kenge’s about midsummer to try how he liked it.
他带着那张笑脸和漫不经心的态度，带着一切都能抓住而没有任何东西能抓住的幻想，认真对待自己的任务，这种想法是荒谬的、反常的。然而，他偶尔告诉我们，他这样做的程度已经达到了他怀疑自己的头发没有变白的程度。他对这件事的常规结束是（正如我所说的），他在仲夏时节去肯格先生那里尝试一下他喜欢的方式。

All this time he was, in money affairs, what I have described him in a former illustration—generous, profuse, wildly careless, but fully persuaded that he was rather calculating and prudent. I happened to say to Ada, in his presence, half jestingly, half seriously, about the time of his going to Mr. Kenge’s, that he needed to have Fortunatus’ purse, he made so light of money, which he answered in this way, ‘My jewel of a dear cousin, you hear this old woman! Why does she say that? Because I gave eight pounds odd (or whatever it was) for a certain neat waistcoat and buttons a few days ago. Now, if I had stayed at Badger’s I should have been obliged to spend twelve pounds at a blow for some heart-breaking lecture-fees. So I make four pounds—in a lump—by the transaction!’
在金钱事务上，他一直都是我在前面的例子中所描述的那样——慷慨、慷慨、粗心大意，但完全相信他是相当精于算计和谨慎的。当艾达在场的时候，我碰巧半开玩笑半认真地对艾达说，关于他去肯格先生那儿的事，他需要福尔图纳图斯的钱包，他挣钱太轻了，他是这样回答的'我亲爱的表弟的宝贝，你听到这个老妇人的声音了！她为什么这么说？因为几天前我花了八英镑（或者不管是什么）买了一件整洁的背心和纽扣。现在，如果我留在獾学院，我就不得不一下子花掉十二英镑来支付一些令人心碎的讲座费。所以我通过这次交易一下子赚了四英镑！”

It was a question much discussed between him and my guardian what arrangements should be made for his living in London while he experimented on the law, for we had long since gone back to Bleak House, and it was too far off to admit of his coming there oftener than once a week. My guardian told me that if Richard were to settle down at Mr. Kenge’s he would take some apartments or chambers where we too could occasionally stay for a few days at a time; ‘but, little woman,’ he added, rubbing his head very significantly, ‘he hasn’t settled down there yet!’ The discussions ended in our hiring for him, by the month, a neat little furnished lodging in a quiet old house near Queen Square. He immediately began to spend all the money he had in buying the oddest little ornaments and luxuries for this lodging; and so often as Ada and I dissuaded him from making any purchase that he had in contemplation which was particularly unnecessary and expensive, he took credit for what it would have cost and made out that to spend anything less on something else was to save the difference.
这是他和我的监护人经常讨论的一个问题，当他尝试法律时，他在伦敦的生活应该如何安排，因为我们早已回到了荒凉山庄，距离承认他的到来还太遥远。每周不止一次。我的监护人告诉我，如果理查德要在肯吉先生家安顿下来，他会租一些公寓或房间，我们也可以偶尔在那里住上几天。 “但是，小女人，”他意味深长地揉了揉头，补充道，“他还没有在那儿安定下来！”讨论最终以我们按月为他租用了一栋安静的老房子里一间布置整洁的小住所而告终。皇后广场附近。他立即开始花光所有的钱，为这个住所购买最奇怪的小装饰品和奢侈品。当艾达和我经常劝阻他不要购买任何他认为特别不必要和昂贵的东西时，他就把这笔钱归功于自己，并认为在其他东西上少花点钱就是为了节省差额。 。

While these affairs were in abeyance, our visit to Mr. Boythorn’s was postponed. At length, Richard having taken possession of his lodging, there was nothing to prevent our departure. He could have gone with us at that time of the year very well, but he was in the full novelty of his new position and was making most energetic attempts to unravel the mysteries of the fatal suit. Consequently we went without him, and my darling was delighted to praise him for being so busy.
当这些事务暂时搁置时，我们对博伊索恩先生家的拜访也被推迟了。最后，理查德占领了他的住所，没有什么可以阻止我们离开。他本可以在一年中的那个时候很好地和我们一起去，但他对他的新职位充满了新鲜感，并且正在尽最大努力来揭开致命套装的神秘面纱。结果我们就没有他了，我亲爱的很高兴地称赞他这么忙。

We made a pleasant journey down into Lincolnshire by the coach and had an entertaining companion in Mr. Skimpole. His furniture had been all cleared off, it appeared, by the person who took possession of it on his blue-eyed daughter’s birthday, but he seemed quite relieved to think that it was gone. Chairs and table, he said, were wearisome objects; they were monotonous ideas, they had no variety of expression, they looked you out of countenance, and you looked them out of countenance. How pleasant, then, to be bound to no particular chairs and tables, but to sport like a butterfly among all the furniture on hire, and to flit from rosewood to mahogany, and from mahogany to walnut, and from this shape to that, as the humour took one!
我们乘坐长途汽车前往林肯郡，度过了一段愉快的旅程，并有一位有趣的同伴斯基姆波尔先生。他的家具似乎在他蓝眼睛女儿生日那天被占有它的人全部清理掉了，但想到家具不见了，他似乎松了口气。他说，椅子和桌子都是令人厌烦的东西；它们都是单调的想法，它们没有变化的表达方式，它们不高兴地看着你，而你也同样不高兴地看着他们。那么，不拘泥于特定的椅子和桌子，而是像蝴蝶一样在所有租用的家具中嬉戏，从红木飞到桃花心木，从桃花心木飞到胡桃木，从这种形状飞到那种形状，这是多么令人愉快的事情。幽默拿了一个！

‘The oddity of the thing is,’ said Mr. Skimpole with a quickened sense of the ludicrous, ‘that my chairs and tables were not paid for, and yet my landlord walks off with them as composedly as possible. Now, that seems droll! There is something grotesque in it. The chair and table merchant never engaged to pay my landlord my rent. Why should my landlord quarrel with HIM? If I have a pimple on my nose which is disagreeable to my landlord’s peculiar ideas of beauty, my landlord has no business to scratch my chair and table merchant’s nose, which has no pimple on it. His reasoning seems defective!’
“事情的奇怪之处在于，”斯金波尔先生说，他的语气里突然有一种荒唐的感觉，“我的椅子和桌子都没有付钱，但我的房东却尽可​​能泰然自若地把它们带走了。”现在，这看起来很滑稽！这里面有一些怪诞的东西。桌椅商人从未承诺向房东支付房租。为什么我的房东要和他争吵？如果我鼻子上长了一个疙瘩，不符合房东独特的审美观念，那么房东就没有权利去抓我桌椅商人的鼻子，因为鼻子上没有疙瘩。他的推理似乎有缺陷！

‘Well,’ said my guardian good-humouredly, ‘it’s pretty clear that whoever became security for those chairs and tables will have to pay for them.’
“好吧，”我的监护人幽默地说，“很明显，无论谁担任这些椅子和桌子的保安，都必须支付费用。”

‘Exactly!’ returned Mr. Skimpole. ‘That’s the crowning point of unreason in the business! I said to my landlord, ‘My good man, you are not aware that my excellent friend Jarndyce will have to pay for those things that you are sweeping off in that indelicate manner. Have you no consideration for HIS property?’ He hadn’t the least.’
“完全正确！”斯金波尔先生回答道。 ‘这就是这个行业最不合理的地方！我对房东说：‘我的好朋友，你不知道我的好朋友贾迪斯将不得不为你以这种不礼貌的方式扫走的东西付出代价。你不考虑他的财产吗？”他一点也没有。”

‘And refused all proposals,’ said my guardian.
“并拒绝了所有的提议，”我的监护人说。

‘Refused all proposals,’ returned Mr. Skimpole. ‘I made him business proposals. I had him into my room. I said, ‘You are a man of business, I believe?’ He replied, ‘I am,’ ‘Very well,’ said I, ‘now let us be business-like. Here is an inkstand, here are pens and paper, here are wafers. What do you want? I have occupied your house for a considerable period, I believe to our mutual satisfaction until this unpleasant misunderstanding arose; let us be at once friendly and business-like.
