What do you want?’ In reply to this, he made use of the figurative expression—which has something Eastern about it—that he had never seen the colour of my money. ‘My amiable friend,’ said I, ‘I never have any money. I never know anything about money.’ ‘Well, sir,’ said he, ‘what do you offer if I give you time?’ ‘My good fellow,’ said I, ‘I have no idea of time; but you say you are a man of business, and whatever you can suggest to be done in a business-like way with pen, and ink, and paper—and wafers—I am ready to do. Don’t pay yourself at another man’s expense (which is foolish), but be business-like!’ However, he wouldn’t be, and there was an end of it.’
“拒绝所有提议，”斯金波尔先生回答道。 “我向他提出了商业建议。我把他带进了我的房间。我说：“你是个生意人，我相信吗？”他回答说：“我是。”“很好，”我说，“现在让我们做生意吧。”这是墨水瓶，这是笔和纸，这是薄饼。你想要什么？我已经在你家住了相当长一段时间了，我相信我们双方都满意，直到发生了这种不愉快的误会；让我们既友好又务实。你想要什么？”作为回答，他用了一个带有东方意味的比喻表达：他从未见过我的钱的颜色。 “我亲爱的朋友，”我说，“我从来没有钱。” “好吧，先生，”他说，“如果我给你时间，你能提供什么？”但你说你是一个生意人，无论你建议用笔、墨水、纸张——还有威化饼——以一种商业化的方式完成任何事情，我都准备好了。不要以牺牲别人为代价来支付自己的工资（这是愚蠢的），而是要务实一点！”然而，他不会这样做，事情就这样结束了。”

If these were some of the inconveniences of Mr. Skimpole’s childhood, it assuredly possessed its advantages too. On the journey he had a very good appetite for such refreshment as came in our way (including a basket of choice hothouse peaches), but never thought of paying for anything. So when the coachman came round for his fee, he pleasantly asked him what he considered a very good fee indeed, now—a liberal one—and on his replying half a crown for a single passenger, said it was little enough too, all things considered, and left Mr. Jarndyce to give it him.
如果说这些是斯金波尔先生童年的一些不便之处，那么它肯定也有其优点。在旅途中，他对我们途中遇到的茶点非常感兴趣（包括一篮精选温室桃子），但从未想过要付钱。因此，当车夫来收取费用时，他愉快地问他现在认为什么是非常好的费用——一个自由的费用——当他回答一个乘客半克朗时，他说这也足够少了，所有的事情想了想，然后让贾迪斯先生把它交给他。

It was delightful weather. The green corn waved so beautifully, the larks sang so joyfully, the hedges were so full of wild flowers, the trees were so thickly out in leaf, the bean-fields, with a light wind blowing over them, filled the air with such a delicious fragrance! Late in the afternoon we came to the markettown where we were to alight from the coach—a dull little town with a church-spire, and a marketplace, and a market-cross, and one intensely sunny street, and a pond with an old horse cooling his legs in it, and a very few men sleepily lying and standing about in narrow little bits of shade. After the rustling of the leaves and the waving of the corn all along the road, it looked as still, as hot, as motionless a little town as England could produce.
天气宜人。绿色的玉米摇曳得多么美丽，百灵鸟的歌声多么欢快，树篱上开满了野花，树木长满了叶子，豆田里，微风吹过，空气中充满了这样的气息。美味的香味！下午晚些时候，我们来到了集镇，在那里我们下了车——一个沉闷的小镇，有一个教堂尖顶，一个市场，一个市场十字路口，一条阳光灿烂的街道，还有一个池塘，里面有一个古老的池塘。马在里面冷却双腿，几个人睡眼惺忪地躺在或站在狭窄的小树荫下。路边树叶沙沙作响，玉米随风摇曳，这里看起来像英格兰小镇一样寂静、炎热、一动不动。

At the inn we found Mr. Boythorn on horseback, waiting with an open carriage to take us to his house, which was a few miles off. He was over-joyed to see us and dismounted with great alacrity.
在旅馆里，我们发现博伊索恩先生骑在马背上，正用一辆敞篷马车等着带我们去几英里外的他家。他看到我们非常高兴，并迅速下了马。

‘By heaven!’ said he after giving us a courteous greeting. This a most infamous coach. It is the most flagrant example of an abominable public vehicle that ever encumbered the face of the earth. It is twenty-five minutes after its time this afternoon. The coachman ought to be put to death!’
“天哪！”他在礼貌地向我们打招呼后说道。这是一位最臭名昭著的教练。这是有史以来阻碍地球表面的令人厌恶的公共车辆的最明目张胆的例子。今天下午的时间已经过去二十五分钟了。车夫应该被处死！

‘IS he after his time?’ said Mr. Skimpole, to whom he happened to address himself. ‘You know my infirmity.’
“他是不是已经过时了？”斯基姆波尔先生问道，他碰巧对着自己说话。 “你知道我的软弱。”

‘Twenty-five minutes! Twenty-six minutes!’ replied Mr. Boythorn, referring to his watch. ‘With two ladies in the coach, this scoundrel has deliberately delayed his arrival six and twenty minutes. Deliberately! It is impossible that it can be accidental! But his father—and his uncle—were the most profligate coachmen that ever sat upon a box.’
‘二十五分钟！ “二十六分钟！”博伊索恩先生指着手表回答道。 “车厢里有两名女士，这个恶棍故意推迟了六到二十分钟的到达时间。故意地！不可能是偶然！但他的父亲和他的叔叔是有史以来最挥霍的车夫。

While he said this in tones of the greatest indignation, he handed us into the little phaeton with the utmost gentleness and was all smiles and pleasure.
当他以极其愤怒的语气说这句话的时候，他却极其温柔地把我们送进了那辆小马车，脸上满是微笑和愉快。

‘I am sorry, ladies,’ he said, standing bare-headed at the carriage-door when all was ready, ‘that I am obliged to conduct you nearly two miles out of the way. But our direct road lies through Sir Leicester Dedlock’s park, and in that fellow’s property I have sworn never to set foot of mine, or horse’s foot of mine, pending the present relations between us, while I breathe the breath of life!’ And here, catching my guardian’s eye, he broke into one of his tremendous laughs, which seemed to shake even the motionless little market-town.
“对不起，女士们，”一切准备就绪后，他光着头站在马车门边说道，“我不得不带你们走近两英里。但我们的直接道路是穿过莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士的公园，在那个家伙的财产中，我发誓，在我们之间目前的关系之前，当我呼吸着生命的气息时，我永远不会踏足我的脚，或我的马脚！当我的监护人注意到他的时候，他爆发出一阵大笑，似乎连一动不动的小集镇都震动了。

‘Are the Dedlocks down here, Lawrence?’ said my guardian as we drove along and Mr. Boythorn trotted on the green turf by the roadside.
“戴德洛克夫妇在这儿吗，劳伦斯？”我们开车前行时，我的监护人问道，博伊索恩先生在路边的绿色草坪上小跑。

‘Sir Arrogant Numskull is here,’ replied Mr. Boythorn. ‘Ha ha ha! Sir Arrogant is here, and I am glad to say, has been laid by the heels here. My Lady,’ in naming whom he always made a courtly gesture as if particularly to exclude her from any part in the quarrel, ‘is expected, I believe, daily. I am not in the least surprised that she postpones her appearance as long as possible. Whatever can have induced that transcendent woman to marry that effigy and figure-head of a baronet is one of the most impenetrable mysteries that ever baffled human inquiry. Ha ha ha ha!’
“傲慢的傻瓜先生在这里，”博伊索恩先生回答道。 ‘哈哈哈！傲慢先生就在这里，我很高兴地说，他已经在这里落败了。 “我的女士，”在提到她的名字时，他总是做出一种礼貌的姿态，仿佛是特意将她排除在争吵之外，“我相信，每天都在期待着她。”对于她尽可能推迟露面，我一点也不感到惊讶。无论是什么原因促使这位超凡脱俗的女人嫁给了那个从男爵的肖像和头像，都是人类探究中最难解的谜团之一。哈哈哈哈！’

‘I suppose, said my guardian, laughing, ‘WE may set foot in the park while we are here? The prohibition does not extend to us, does it?’
“我想，”我的监护人笑着说，“我们在这里的时候可以踏足公园吗？”这项禁令并不适用于我们，不是吗？

‘I can lay no prohibition on my guests,’ he said, bending his head to Ada and me with the smiling politeness which sat so gracefully upon him, ‘except in the matter of their departure. I am only sorry that I cannot have the happiness of being their escort about Chesney Wold, which is a very fine place! But by the light of this summer day, Jarndyce, if you call upon the owner while you stay with me, you are likely to have but a cool reception. He carries himself like an eight-day clock at all times, like one of a race of eight-day clocks in gorgeous cases that never go and never went—Ha ha ha!—but he will have some extra stiffness, I can promise you, for the friends of his friend and neighbour Boythorn!’
“我不能禁止我的客人，”他一边说，一边向艾达和我低下头，脸上带着优雅的微笑和礼貌，“除了他们离开的事情。”我只是很遗憾我不能有幸成为他们护送切斯尼沃尔德的快乐，那是一个非常好的地方！但在这个夏日的阳光下，贾迪斯，如果你在和我住在一起的时候拜访主人，你很可能会受到冷遇。他始终表现得像一个八天时钟，就像一场八天时钟竞赛中的一场比赛，在华丽的盒子里，从来没有走过，也从来没有走过——哈哈哈！——但他会有一些额外的僵硬，我可以向你保证，为了他的朋友和邻居博伊索恩的朋友们！”

‘I shall not put him to the proof,’ said my guardian. ‘He is as indifferent to the honour of knowing me, I dare say, as I am to the honour of knowing him. The air of the grounds and perhaps such a view of the house as any other sightseer might get are quite enough for me.’
“我不会让他接受证据，”我的监护人说。 “我敢说，他对认识我的荣誉漠不关心，就像我对认识他的荣誉漠不关心一样。”庭院里的空气，也许还有其他观光者可能看到的房子的景色对我来说已经足够了。

‘Well!’ said Mr. Boythorn. ‘I am glad of it on the whole. It’s in better keeping. I am looked upon about here as a second Ajax defying the lightning. Ha ha ha ha! When I go into our little church on a Sunday, a considerable part of the inconsiderable congregation expect to see me drop, scorched and withered, on the pavement under the Dedlock displeasure. Ha ha ha ha! I have no doubt he is surprised that I don’t. For he is, by heaven, the most self-satisfied, and the shallowest, and the most coxcombical and utterly brainless ass!’
“好吧！”博伊索恩先生说。 “总的来说，我对此感到高兴。它保存得更好。我在这里被视为第二个反抗闪电的阿贾克斯。哈哈哈哈！当我周日走进我们的小教堂时，相当一部分微不足道的会众都希望看到我在戴德洛克的不悦之下倒在人行道上，被烧焦和枯萎。哈哈哈哈！我毫不怀疑他会因为我不这样做而感到惊讶。因为他是天哪，最自鸣得意、最浅薄、最浮夸、最无脑的混蛋！

Our coming to the ridge of a hill we had been ascending enabled our friend to point out Chesney Wold itself to us and diverted his attention from its master.
当我们来到我们一直在攀登的山脊时，我们的朋友能够向我们指出切斯尼森林本身，并转移他对主人的注意力。

It was a picturesque old house in a fine park richly wooded. Among the trees and not far from the residence he pointed out the spire of the little church of which he had spoken. Oh, the solemn woods over which the light and shadow travelled swiftly, as if heavenly wings were sweeping on benignant errands through the summer air; the smooth green slopes, the glittering water, the garden where the flowers were so symmetrically arranged in clusters of the richest colours, how beautiful they looked! The house, with gable and chimney, and tower, and turret, and dark doorway, and broad terrace-walk, twining among the balustrades of which, and lying heaped upon the vases, there was one great flush of roses, seemed scarcely real in its light solidity and in the serene and peaceful hush that rested on all around it. To Ada and to me, that above all appeared the pervading influence. On everything, house, garden, terrace, green slopes, water, old oaks, fern, moss, woods again, and far away across the openings in the prospect to the distance lying wide before us with a purple bloom upon it, there seemed to be such undisturbed repose.
那是一座风景如画的老房子，坐落在一个树木繁茂的美丽公园里。他指着树林中离住所不远的地方，指着他所说的那座小教堂的尖顶。哦，庄严的树林，光影在其上飞快地掠过，仿佛天堂的翅膀在夏日的空气中扫过，执行着仁慈的使命；光滑的绿色山坡，波光粼粼的水面，花园里的花朵对称地排列成簇，色彩最丰富，看起来多么美丽啊！这座房子，有山墙、烟囱、塔楼、塔楼、黑暗的门口，还有宽阔的露台走道，栏杆缠绕在栏杆之间，花瓶上堆放着一大朵玫瑰花，看起来几乎不真实。其轻盈的坚固性以及周围宁静祥和的寂静。对艾达和我来说，最重要的是无处不在的影响力。在一切事物上，房子、花园、露台、绿色的山坡、水、老橡树、蕨类植物、苔藓、树林，还有远处的视野中的开口，远方就在我们面前，上面开着紫色的花朵，似乎有如此不受打扰的休息。

When we came into the little village and passed a small inn with the sign of the Dedlock Arms swinging over the road in front, Mr. Boythorn interchanged greetings with a young gentleman sitting on a bench outside the inn-door who had some fishing-tackle lying beside him.
当我们走进小村庄，经过一家小客栈时，前面的路上挂着戴德洛克手臂的招牌，博伊索恩先生和一位坐在客栈门外长凳上的年轻绅士寒暄了一番，这位年轻绅士拿着一些渔具。躺在他身边。

‘That’s the housekeeper’s grandson, Mr. Rouncewell by name,’ said, he, ‘and he is in love with a pretty girl up at the house. Lady Dedlock has taken a fancy to the pretty girl and is going to keep her about her own fair person—an honour which my young friend himself does not at all appreciate. However, he can’t marry just yet, even if his Rosebud were willing; so he is fain to make the best of it. In the meanwhile, he comes here pretty often for a day or two at a time to—fish. Ha ha ha ha!’
“那是管家的孙子，名叫朗斯韦尔先生，”他说，“他爱上了家里的一个漂亮女孩。戴德洛克夫人看上了这个漂亮的女孩，并打算让她成为自己美丽的人——我年轻的朋友本人根本不欣赏这种荣幸。然而，即使他的玫瑰花蕾愿意，他现在还不能结婚；所以他很想充分利用它。与此同时，他经常来这里钓鱼一两天。哈哈哈哈！’

‘Are he and the pretty girl engaged, Mr. Boythorn?’ asked Ada.
“博伊索恩先生，他和那个漂亮女孩订婚了吗？”艾达问。

‘Why, my dear Miss Clare,’ he returned, ‘I think they may perhaps understand each other; but you will see them soon, I dare say, and I must learn from you on such a point—not you from me.’
“哎呀，我亲爱的克莱尔小姐，”他回答道，“我想他们或许可以互相理解；但是，我想他们可能会互相理解。”但我敢说，你很快就会看到它们，在这一点上我必须向你学习，而不是你向我学习。

Ada blushed, and Mr. Boythorn, trotting forward on his comely grey horse, dismounted at his own door and stood ready with extended arm and uncovered head to welcome us when we arrived.
艾达脸红了，博伊索恩先生骑着他那匹漂亮的灰马小跑着，在自家门口下马，伸出手臂，不戴帽子，准备迎接我们的到来。

He lived in a pretty house, formerly the parsonage house, with a lawn in front, a bright flower-garden at the side, and a wellstocked orchard and kitchen-garden in the rear, enclosed with a venerable wall that had of itself a ripened ruddy look. But, indeed, everything about the place wore an aspect of maturity and abundance. The old lime-tree walk was like green cloisters, the very shadows of the cherry-trees and apple-trees were heavy with fruit, the gooseberry-bushes were so laden that their branches arched and rested on the earth, the strawberries and raspberries grew in like profusion, and the peaches basked by the hundred on the wall. Tumbled about among the spread nets and the glass frames sparkling and winking in the sun there were such heaps of drooping pods, and marrows, and cucumbers, that every foot of ground appeared a vegetable treasury, while the smell of sweet herbs and all kinds of wholesome growth (to say nothing of the neighbouring meadows where the hay was carrying) made the whole air a great nosegay. Such stillness and composure reigned within the orderly precincts of the old red wall that even the feathers hung in garlands to scare the birds hardly stirred; and the wall had such a ripening influence that where, here and there high up, a disused nail and scrap of list still clung to it, it was easy to fancy that they had mellowed with the changing seasons and that they had rusted and decayed according to the common fate.
他住在一栋漂亮的房子里，以前是牧师住宅，前面有草坪，旁边有一个明亮的花园，后面有一个资源丰富的果园和菜园，围着一堵古老的墙，墙本身就成熟了。面色红润。但事实上，这个地方的一切都显得成熟而丰富。古老的椴树步道就像绿色的回廊，樱桃树和苹果树的树荫下结满了果实，醋栗丛结满了果实，树枝拱成拱形，落在地上，草莓和覆盆子生长大量的桃子，还有数百个挂在墙上的桃子。铺开的网和在阳光下闪闪发光的玻璃框之间翻滚着，有一堆堆下垂的豆荚、骨髓和黄瓜，每一英尺的土地都像一个蔬菜宝库，甜香草和各种蔬菜的气味扑鼻而来。健康的生长（更不用说附近的草地上有干草了）使整个空气成为一个伟大的花束。古老的红墙秩序井然，一片寂静和平静，就连挂在花环上吓鸟的羽毛也几乎没有动静。这堵墙有一种成熟的影响力，以至于高处到处都还粘着废弃的钉子和碎木片，很容易让人认为它们已经随着季节的变化而变得成熟，并且根据季节的变化它们已经生锈和腐烂了。为了共同的命运。

The house, though a little disorderly in comparison with the garden, was a real old house with settles in the chimney of the brick-floored kitchen and great beams across the ceilings. On one side of it was the terrible piece of ground in dispute, where Mr. Boythorn maintained a sentry in a smock-frock day and night, whose duty was supposed to be, in cases of aggression, immediately to ring a large bell hung up there for the purpose, to unchain a great bull-dog established in a kennel as his ally, and generally to deal destruction on the enemy. Not content with these precautions, Mr. Boythorn had himself composed and posted there, on painted boards to which his name was attached in large letters, the following solemn warnings: ‘Beware of the bull-dog. He is most ferocious. Lawrence Boythorn.’ ‘The blunderbus is loaded with slugs. Lawrence Boythorn.’ ‘Man-traps and spring-guns are set here at all times of the day and night. Lawrence Boythorn.’ ‘Take notice. That any person or persons audaciously presuming to trespass on this property will be punished with the utmost severity of private chastisement and prosecuted with the utmost rigour of the law. Lawrence Boythorn.’ These he showed us from the drawing-room window, while his bird was hopping about his head, and he laughed, ‘Ha ha ha ha! Ha ha ha ha!’ to that extent as he pointed them out that I really thought he would have hurt himself.
这座房子虽然与花园相比有点杂乱，但却是一座真正的老房子，砖地板厨房的烟囱里有安乐窝，天花板上有大横梁。一侧是一片令人恐惧的有争议的土地，博伊索恩先生日日夜夜地派出一名穿着罩衫的哨兵，他的职责应该是，一旦发生侵略，立即敲响悬挂的大钟。其目的是解开狗舍里作为盟友的大斗牛犬，通常是为了对敌人造成毁灭性打击。博伊索恩先生对这些预防措施并不满足，他亲自撰写并张贴在画板上，上面用大写字母写着他的名字，如下严正警告：“小心斗牛犬。”他最为凶猛。劳伦斯·博伊索恩。”“火铳里装满了子弹。劳伦斯·博伊索恩。”“这里白天和晚上的任何时候都设置了捕人陷阱和弹簧枪。劳伦斯·博伊索恩。”“注意了。任何胆敢侵犯该财产的人都将受到最严厉的私人惩罚，并受到最严格的法律起诉。劳伦斯·博伊索恩。”他从客厅的窗户向我们展示了这些，而他的鸟儿在他的头上跳来跳去，他笑了，“哈哈哈哈！哈哈哈哈！”当他指出时，我真的以为他会伤害自己。

‘But this is taking a good deal of trouble,’ said Mr. Skimpole in his light way, ‘when you are not in earnest after all.’
“但是这会很麻烦，”斯金波尔先生轻松地说，“毕竟你不是认真的。”

‘Not in earnest!’ returned Mr. Boythorn with unspeakable warmth. ‘Not in earnest! If I could have hoped to train him, I would have bought a lion instead of that dog and would have turned him loose upon the first intolerable robber who should dare to make an encroachment on my rights. Let Sir Leicester Dedlock consent to come out and decide this question by single combat, and I will meet him with any weapon known to mankind in any age or country. I am that much in earnest. Not more!’
“不是认真的！”博伊索恩先生带着难以言表的热情回答道。 ‘不是认真的！如果我能希望训练他，我会买一头狮子而不是那条狗，并会把他释放到第一个敢于侵犯我权利的令人难以容忍的强盗身上。让莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士同意出来通过一场决斗来解决这个问题，我将用任何时代、任何国家的人类已知的任何武器来与他会面。我就是这么认真。不多！'

We arrived at his house on a Saturday. On the Sunday morning we all set forth to walk to the little church in the park. Entering the park, almost immediately by the disputed ground, we pursued a pleasant footpath winding among the verdant turf and the beautiful trees until it brought us to the church-porch.
我们在星期六到达了他家。周日早上，我们一起出发步行前往公园里的小教堂。进入公园，几乎立刻就到了有争议的地方，我们沿着一条令人愉快的小路蜿蜒在青翠的草坪和美丽的树木之间，直到它把我们带到了教堂门廊。

The congregation was extremely small and quite a rustic one with the exception of a large muster of servants from the house, some of whom were already in their seats, while others were yet dropping in. There were some stately footmen, and there was a perfect picture of an old coachman, who looked as if he were the official representative of all the pomps and vanities that had ever been put into his coach. There was a very pretty show of young women, and above them, the handsome old face and fine responsible portly figure of the housekeeper towered pre-eminent. The pretty girl of whom Mr. Boythorn had told us was close by her. She was so very pretty that I might have known her by her beauty even if I had not seen how blushingly conscious she was of the eyes of the young fisherman, whom I discovered not far off. One face, and not an agreeable one, though it was handsome, seemed maliciously watchful of this pretty girl, and indeed of every one and everything there. It was a Frenchwoman’s.
会众人数极少，气氛十分质朴，除了一大群从家里来的仆人，其中一些人已经就座，另一些人还没有进来。有一些威严的男仆，还有一个完美的仆人。一张老马车夫的照片，他看起来就像是他的马车上所有浮华和虚荣的官方代表。一群年轻女子非常漂亮，在她们的上方，女管家那张英俊的老脸和精致负责、肥胖的身材显得格外突出。博伊索恩先生告诉我们的那个漂亮女孩就在她身边。她非常漂亮，即使我没有看到她对我在不远处发现的年轻渔夫的眼睛有多么敏感，我也可能通过她的美貌认识她。一张脸，虽然很英俊，但并不讨人喜欢，但似乎在恶意地注视着这个漂亮的女孩，事实上，也注视着那里的每一个人和每件事。这是一位法国女人的。

As the bell was yet ringing and the great people were not yet come, I had leisure to glance over the church, which smelt as earthy as a grave, and to think what a shady, ancient, solemn little church it was. The windows, heavily shaded by trees, admitted a subdued light that made the faces around me pale, and darkened the old brasses in the pavement and the time and damp-worn monuments, and rendered the sunshine in the little porch, where a monotonous ringer was working at the bell, inestimably bright. But a stir in that direction, a gathering of reverential awe in the rustic faces, and a blandly ferocious assumption on the part of Mr. Boythorn of being resolutely unconscious of somebody’s existence forewarned me that the great people were come and that the service was going to begin.
钟声尚未敲响，伟人尚未到来，我才有闲暇扫视这座散发着坟墓般泥土味的教堂，心想这是一座多么阴凉、古老、庄严的小教堂。窗户被树木浓荫遮蔽，透进了柔和的光线，使我周围的脸变得苍白，使人行道上的旧黄铜、时间和潮湿磨损的纪念碑变暗，使阳光照在小门廊上，那里发出单调的铃声。正在敲钟，明亮得不可估量。但那个方向的一阵骚动，乡村面孔上聚集着崇敬的敬畏，以及博伊索恩先生温和凶猛的假设，他完全没有意识到某人的存在，这些都预先警告我，伟大的人们已经来了，服务即将开始开始。

‘‘Enter not into judgment with thy servant, O Lord, for in thy sight—‘’
“主啊，不要审判你的仆人，因为在你看来——”

Shall I ever forget the rapid beating at my heart, occasioned by the look I met as I stood up! Shall I ever forget the manner in which those handsome proud eyes seemed to spring out of their languor and to hold mine! It was only a moment before I cast mine down—released again, if I may say so—on my book; but I knew the beautiful face quite well in that short space of time.
我是否会忘记我站起来时所看到的目光所引起的心脏的快速跳动！我是否会忘记那些英俊而骄傲的眼睛似乎从他们的倦怠中跳出来并注视着我的方式！只过了一会儿，我就把我的心放下了——如果我可以这么说的话，我又放下了——在我的书上；但在那短短的时间里，我对那张美丽的脸庞了如指掌。

And, very strangely, there was something quickened within me, associated with the lonely days at my godmother’s; yes, away even to the days when I had stood on tiptoe to dress myself at my little glass after dressing my doll. And this, although I had never seen this lady’s face before in all my life—I was quite sure of it— absolutely certain.
而且，非常奇怪的是，我内心有一种东西在活跃起来，这与在教母家的孤独日子有关。是的，甚至到了我给洋娃娃穿好衣服后踮起脚尖站在小玻璃杯前给自己穿衣服的日子。而这一点，尽管我一生中从未见过这位女士的脸——我很确定——绝对确定。

It was easy to know that the ceremonious, gouty, grey-haired gentleman, the only other occupant of the great pew, was Sir Leicester Dedlock, and that the lady was Lady Dedlock. But why her face should be, in a confused way, like a broken glass to me, in which I saw scraps of old remembrances, and why I should be so fluttered and troubled (for I was still) by having casually met her eyes, I could not think.
很容易就知道，那位彬彬有礼、患有痛风、头发灰白的绅士，长椅上唯一的另一个占有者，是莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，而那位女士是戴德洛克夫人。但为什么她的脸对我来说应该像一块破碎的玻璃，在其中我看到了旧记忆的碎片，为什么我会因不经意地与她的目光相遇而感到如此颤抖和困扰（因为我仍然静止），我无法思考。

I felt it to be an unmeaning weakness in me and tried to overcome it by attending to the words I heard. Then, very strangely, I seemed to hear them, not in the reader’s voice, but in the wellremembered voice of my godmother. This made me think, did Lady Dedlock’s face accidentally resemble my godmother’s? It might be that it did, a little; but the expression was so different, and the stern decision which had worn into my godmother’s face, like weather into rocks, was so completely wanting in the face before me that it could not be that resemblance which had struck me. Neither did I know the loftiness and haughtiness of Lady Dedlock’s face, at all, in any one. And yet I—I, little Esther Summerson, the child who lived a life apart and on whose birthday there was no rejoicing—seemed to arise before my own eyes, evoked out of the past by some power in this fashionable lady, whom I not only entertained no fancy that I had ever seen, but whom I perfectly well knew I had never seen until that hour.
我觉得这是我内心的一个无意义的弱点，并试图通过关注我听到的话语来克服它。然后，非常奇怪的是，我似乎听到了他们的声音，不是读者的声音，而是我记忆深刻的教母的声音。这让我想到，戴德洛克夫人的脸是不是一不小心就长成了我教母的脸了？也许确实有那么一点点；但表情是如此不同，而我教母脸上的严厉决定，就像天气磨蚀岩石一样，在我面前的脸上完全消失了，不可能是我所震惊的那种相似之处。我也不知道戴德洛克夫人的脸上有多么高傲和傲慢。然而我——我，小埃丝特·萨默森，这个过着分离生活的孩子，在她的生日那天没有任何欢乐——似乎出现在我自己的眼前，被这位时尚女士的某种力量从过去唤起，而我并不认识她。只是对我从未见过的人没有任何幻想，但我非常清楚，直到那时我才见过他。

It made me tremble so to be thrown into this unaccountable agitation that I was conscious of being distressed even by the observation of the French maid, though I knew she had been looking watchfully here, and there, and everywhere, from the moment of her coming into the church. By degrees, though very slowly, I at last overcame my strange emotion. After a long time, I looked towards Lady Dedlock again. It was while they were preparing to sing, before the sermon. She took no heed of me, and the beating at my heart was gone. Neither did it revive for more than a few moments when she once or twice afterwards glanced at Ada or at me through her glass.
陷入这种莫名其妙的焦躁之中，我浑身发抖，甚至连那位法国女仆的观察都让我感到痛苦，尽管我知道，从她到来的那一刻起，她就一直在警惕地到处张望。进入教堂。我终于慢慢地克服了自己奇怪的情绪，虽然速度很慢。良久之后，我再次看向戴德洛克女士。那是在布道之前，他们准备唱歌的时候。她没有理会我，我的心跳也消失了。当她事后一两次透过镜片瞥见艾达或我时，这种感觉也没有持续多久。

The service being concluded, Sir Leicester gave his arm with much taste and gallantry to Lady Dedlock—though he was obliged to walk by the help of a thick stick—and escorted her out of church to the pony carriage in which they had come. The servants then dispersed, and so did the congregation, whom Sir Leicester had contemplated all along (Mr. Skimpole said to Mr. Boythorn’s infinite delight) as if he were a considerable landed proprietor in heaven.
仪式结束后，莱斯特爵士以极富品味和殷勤的态度向戴德洛克夫人伸出了手臂——尽管他不得不拄着一根粗棍子走路——然后护送她走出教堂，走向他们来时乘坐的小马车。仆人们随后散去，会众也散去，莱斯特爵士一直把他视为（斯金波尔先生对博伊索恩先生无限喜悦的说法），仿佛他是天堂里的一位大地主。

‘He believes he is!’ said Mr. Boythorn. ‘He firmly believes it. So did his father, and his grandfather, and his great-grandfather!’
“他相信他是！”博伊索恩先生说。 ’他坚信这一点。他的父亲、祖父和曾祖父也是如此！

‘Do you know,’ pursued Mr. Skimpole very unexpectedly to Mr. Boythorn, ‘it’s agreeable to me to see a man of that sort.’
“你知道吗，”斯金波尔先生非常意外地对博伊索恩先生追问，“见到这样的人我很高兴。”

‘IS it!’ said Mr. Boytborn.
“是这样！”博伊特伯恩先生说。

‘Say that he wants to patronize me,’ pursued Mr. Skimpole. ‘Very well! I don’t object.’
“说他想光顾我，”斯金波尔先生继续说道。 '很好！我不反对。

‘I do,’ said Mr. Boythorn with great vigour.
“我愿意，”博伊索恩先生精力充沛地说。

‘Do you really?’ returned Mr. Skimpole in his easy light vein. ‘But that’s taking trouble, surely. And why should you take trouble? Here am I, content to receive things childishly as they fall out, and I never take trouble! I come down here, for instance, and I find a mighty potentate exacting homage. Very well! I say ‘Mighty potentate, here IS my homage! It’s easier to give it than to withhold it. Here it is. If you have anything of an agreeable nature to show me, I shall be happy to see it; if you have anything of an agreeable nature to give me, I shall be happy to accept it.’ Mighty potentate replies in effect, ‘This is a sensible fellow. I find him accord with my digestion and my bilious system. He doesn’t impose upon me the necessity of rolling myself up like a hedgehog with my points outward. I expand, I open, I turn my silver lining outward like Milton’s cloud, and it’s more agreeable to both of us.’ That’s my view of such things, speaking as a child!’
“真的吗？”斯金波尔先生轻松地回答道。 “但这肯定会带来麻烦。”你为什么要自找麻烦呢？我就这样，幼稚地接受掉下来的东西，我从不惹麻烦！例如，我来到这里，发现一位强大的君主正在严格致敬。很好！我说‘伟大的君主，这是我的敬意！给予比拒绝更容易。这里是。如果你有任何令人愉快的东西要给我看，我会很高兴看到；如果你有什么好东西给我，我会很乐意接受。”强大的君主实际上回答道：“这是一个明智的人。我发现他符合我的消化和胆汁系统。他并没有强迫我像刺猬一样把自己卷起来，把观点向外。我扩展，我开放，我像弥尔顿的云一样将我的一线希望向外展开，这对我们俩来说都更愉快。“这就是我对这些事情的看法，作为一个孩子来说！”

‘But suppose you went down somewhere else to-morrow,’ said Mr. Boythorn, ‘where there was the opposite of that fellow—or of this fellow. How then?’
“但是假设你明天去别的地方，”博伊索恩先生说，“那里有与那个人相反的人——或者这个人。”那么如何？'

‘How then?’ said Mr. Skimpole with an appearance of the utmost simplicity and candour. ‘Just the same then! I should say, ‘My esteemed Boythorn’—to make you the personification of our imaginary friend—‘my esteemed Boythorn, you object to the mighty potentate? Very good. So do I. I take it that my business in the social system is to be agreeable; I take it that everybody’s business in the social system is to be agreeable. It’s a system of harmony, in short. Therefore if you object, I object. Now, excellent Boythorn, let us go to dinner!’’
“那怎么办？”斯金波尔先生说道，表情极其简单和坦率。 ‘那就一样了！我应该说，‘我尊敬的博伊索恩’——让你成为我们想象中的朋友的化身——‘我尊敬的博伊索恩，你反对强大的君主吗？非常好。我也是。我认为我在社会体系中的职责就是和睦相处；我认为社会体系中每个人的职责就是要和睦相处。简而言之，这是一个和谐的系统。因此，如果你反对，我也反对。现在，优秀的博伊索恩，我们去吃晚饭吧！”

‘But excellent Boythorn might say,’ returned our host, swelling and growing very red, ‘I’ll be—‘
“但是优秀的博伊索恩可能会说，”我们的主人回答道，他的脸肿得通红，“我会——”

‘I understand,’ said Mr. Skimpole. ‘Very likely he would.’
“我明白，”斯金波尔先生说。 “他很可能会的。”

‘—if I WILL go to dinner!’ cried Mr. Boythorn in a violent burst and stopping to strike his stick upon the ground. ‘And he would probably add, ‘Is there such a thing as principle, Mr. Harold Skimpole?’’
“——如果我愿意去吃晚饭就好了！”博伊索恩先生猛烈地喊道，并停下来用棍子敲打地面。 “他可能会补充说，‘哈罗德·斯基波尔先生，有原则这样的东西吗？’”

‘To which Harold Skimpole would reply, you know,’ he returned in his gayest manner and with his most ingenuous smile, ‘‘Upon my life I have not the least idea! I don’t know what it is you call by that name, or where it is, or who possesses it. If you possess it and find it comfortable, I am quite delighted and congratulate you heartily. But I know nothing about it, I assure you; for I am a mere child, and I lay no claim to it, and I don’t want it!’ So, you see, excellent Boythorn and I would go to dinner after all!’
“你知道，哈罗德·斯基波尔会回答这个问题，”他以最快乐的方式回答，带着最天真的微笑，“我对我的生活一无所知！”我不知道你叫它什么名字，也不知道它在哪里，也不知道它是谁拥有的。如果您拥有它并且觉得它很舒服，我会非常高兴并衷心祝贺您。但我向你保证，我对此一无所知；因为我只是个孩子，我没有权利要求它，我也不想要它！“所以，你看，优秀的博伊索恩和我终究会去吃晚饭！”

This was one of many little dialogues between them which I always expected to end, and which I dare say would have ended under other circumstances, in some violent explosion on the part of our host. But he had so high a sense of his hospitable and responsible position as our entertainer, and my guardian laughed so sincerely at and with Mr. Skimpole, as a child who blew bubbles and broke them all day long, that matters never went beyond this point. Mr. Skimpole, who always seemed quite unconscious of having been on delicate ground, then betook himself to beginning some sketch in the park which be never finished, or to playing fragments of airs on the piano, or to singing scraps of songs, or to lying down on his back under a tree and looking at the sky—which he couldn’t help thinking, he said, was what he was meant for; it suited him so exactly.
这是他们之间的许多小对话之一，我一直希望这些对话能够结束，而且我敢说，在其他情况下，在我们的东道主的一些猛烈爆炸中，这些对话也会结束。但他对自己作为我们的艺人的热情好客和负责任的地位有如此高的认识，而我的监护人对斯基姆波尔先生如此真诚地笑，并与他一起笑，就像一个整天吹泡泡并打破它们的孩子一样，事情从未超出这一点。斯金波尔先生似乎总是没有意识到自己身处微妙的境地，然后他开始在公园里开始一些从未完成的素描，或者在钢琴上弹奏一些片段，或者唱一些歌曲的片段，或者他仰面躺在树下，看着天空——他说，他不禁想，这就是他的使命；这非常适合他。

‘Enterprise and effort,’ he would say to us (on his back), are delightful to me. I believe I am truly cosmopolitan. I have the deepest sympathy with them. I lie in a shady place like this and think of adventurous spirits going to the North Pole or penetrating to the heart of the Torrid Zone with admiration. Mercenary creatures ask, ‘What is the use of a man’s going to the North Pole? What good does it do?’ I can’t say; but, for anything I CAN say, he may go for the purpose—though he don’t know it—of employing my thoughts as I lie here. Take an extreme case. Take the case of the slaves on American plantations. I dare say they are worked hard, I dare say they don’t altogether like it. I dare say theirs is an unpleasant experience on the whole; but they people the landscape for me, they give it a poetry for me, and perhaps that is one of the pleasanter objects of their existence. I am very sensible of it, if it be, and I shouldn’t wonder if it were!’
“进取心和努力，”他（背在背上）对我们说，这让我很高兴。我相信我是真正的世界主义者。我对他们表示最深切的同情。我躺在这样的阴凉处，怀着钦佩的心情想到前往北极或深入热带地区中心的冒险精神。佣兵们问：‘人去北极有什么用？它有什么好处？但是，无论我能说什么，他都可能是为了利用我躺在这里时的想法——尽管他自己并不知道。举一个极端的例子。以美国种植园里的奴隶为例。我敢说他们很努力，我敢说他们并不完全喜欢这样。我敢说他们的经历总的来说是一次不愉快的经历；但他们为我塑造了风景，为我赋予了诗意，也许这是他们存在中更令人愉快的目标之一。如果是的话，我对此非常敏感，而且我不应该怀疑它是否是这样！

I always wondered on these occasions whether he ever thought of Mrs. Skimpole and the children, and in what point of view they presented themselves to his cosmopolitan mind. So far as I could understand, they rarely presented themselves at all.
在这些场合，我总是想知道他是否想过斯金波尔夫人和孩子们，以及他们以什么观点呈现在他的国际视野中。据我所知，他们很少展示自己。

The week had gone round to the Saturday following that beating of my heart in the church; and every day had been so bright and blue that to ramble in the woods, and to see the light striking down among the transparent leaves and sparkling in the beautiful interlacings of the shadows of the trees, while the birds poured out their songs and the air was drowsy with the hum of insects, had been most delightful. We had one favourite spot, deep in moss and last year’s leaves, where there were some felled trees from which the bark was all stripped off. Seated among these, we looked through a green vista supported by thousands of natural columns, the whitened stems of trees, upon a distant prospect made so radiant by its contrast with the shade in which we sat and made so precious by the arched perspective through which we saw it that it was like a glimpse of the better land. Upon the Saturday we sat here, Mr. Jarndyce, Ada, and I, until we heard thunder muttering in the distance and felt the large raindrops rattle through the leaves.
在教堂里那次心跳之后，一周又到了星期六。每天都是如此明亮和蔚蓝，以至于可以在树林里漫步，看到阳光照在透明的树叶上，在树影的美丽交错中闪闪发光，而鸟儿则倾诉着它们的歌声和空气伴随着昆虫的嗡嗡声而昏昏欲睡，真是太令人愉快了。我们有一个最喜欢的地方，在苔藓和去年的树叶深处，那里有一些被砍倒的树，树皮都被剥掉了。坐在其中，我们透过数以千计的天然柱子和白色的树干支撑着绿色的远景，远处的景色与我们坐的树荫形成鲜明对比，显得如此光彩夺目，通过拱形的视角，景色变得如此珍贵。我们看到它就像瞥见了更美好的土地。星期六，我们、贾迪斯先生、艾达和我坐在这里，直到我们听到远处传来雷声，感觉到大雨滴穿过树叶发出嘎嘎声。

The weather had been all the week extremely sultry, but the storm broke so suddenly—upon us, at least, in that sheltered spot—that before we reached the outskirts of the wood the thunder and lightning were frequent and the rain came plunging through the leaves as if every drop were a great leaden bead. As it was not a time for standing among trees, we ran out of the wood, and up and down the moss-grown steps which crossed the plantation-fence like two broad-staved ladders placed back to back, and made for a keeper’s lodge which was close at hand. We had often noticed the dark beauty of this lodge standing in a deep twilight of trees, and how the ivy clustered over it, and how there was a steep hollow near, where we had once seen the keeper’s dog dive down into the fern as if it were water.
整个星期天气都非常闷热，但暴风雨来得太突然——至少在我们那个避风的地方——以至于在我们到达树林的郊区之前，雷电就频繁地袭来，大雨倾盆而下。叶子仿佛每一滴都是一颗巨大的铅珠。由于现在不适合站在树丛中，我们跑出了树林，在长满青苔的台阶上跑来跑去，这些台阶穿过种植园的栅栏，就像两架背靠背的宽梯子，通向看守人的小屋。就在眼前。我们经常注意到这座小屋矗立在树林深处的黑暗之美，常春藤如何聚集在它上面，以及附近如何有一个陡峭的洼地，我们曾经看到看门人的狗潜入蕨类植物中，仿佛那是水。

The lodge was so dark within, now the sky was overcast, that we only clearly saw the man who came to the door when we took shelter there and put two chairs for Ada and me. The lattice-windows were all thrown open, and we sat just within the doorway watching the storm. It was grand to see how the wind awoke, and bent the trees, and drove the rain before it like a cloud of smoke; and to hear the solemn thunder and to see the lightning; and while thinking with awe of the tremendous powers by which our little lives are encompassed, to consider how beneficent they are and how upon the smallest flower and leaf there was already a freshness poured from all this seeming rage which seemed to make creation new again.
小屋里很黑，现在天色阴沉，我们躲在那里，为我和艾达摆了两把椅子，才清楚地看到门口来的那个人。格子窗全部打开，我们就坐在门口观看暴风雨。看到风如何苏醒，吹弯了树木，驱散了前面的雨水，就像烟雾一样，真是太壮观了。听到庄严的雷声，看到闪电；当怀着敬畏之心思考我们小小的生命所蕴含的巨大力量时，想想它们是多么仁慈，以及如何在最小的花朵和叶子上已经从所有这些看似愤怒的事物中倾注出新鲜感，这似乎使造物再次焕然一新。

‘Is it not dangerous to sit in so exposed a place?’
“坐在这么暴露的地方难道不危险吗？”

‘Oh, no, Esther dear!’ said Ada quietly.
“哦，不，亲爱的艾丝特！”艾达轻声说道。

Ada said it to me, but I had not spoken.
艾达对我说过，但我没有说话。

The beating of my heart came back again. I had never heard the voice, as I had never seen the face, but it affected me in the same strange way. Again, in a moment, there arose before my mind innumerable pictures of myself.
我的心跳声又回来了。我从未听过那个声音，就像我从未见过那张脸一样，但它以同样奇怪的方式影响着我。刹那间，我的脑海中再次浮现出无数自己的画面。

Lady Dedlock had taken shelter in the lodge before our arrival there and had come out of the gloom within. She stood behind my chair with her hand upon it. I saw her with her hand close to my shoulder when I turned my head.
在我们到达之前，戴德洛克夫人已经在小屋里避难了，并从里面的阴暗中走了出来。她站在我的椅子后面，把手放在椅子上。当我转过头时，我看到她的手靠近我的肩膀。

‘I have frightened you?’ she said.
“我吓到你了吗？”她说。

No. It was not fright. Why should I be frightened!
不，这不是害怕。我为什么要害怕！

‘I believe,’ said Lady Dedlock to my guardian, ‘I have the pleasure of speaking to Mr. Jarndyce.’
“我相信，”戴德洛克夫人对我的监护人说，“我很高兴能与贾迪斯先生交谈。”

‘Your remembrance does me more honour than I had supposed it would, Lady Dedlock,’ he returned.
“戴德洛克女士，你的记忆给我带来的荣誉比我想象的还要多。”他回答道。

‘I recognized you in church on Sunday. I am sorry that any local disputes of Sir Leicester’s—they are not of his seeking, however, I believe—should render it a matter of some absurd difficulty to show you any attention here.’
“周日我在教堂里认出了你。我很抱歉，莱斯特爵士在当地的任何争议——然而，我相信这些争议并不是他所寻求的——应该会让你在这里引起任何关注变得有些荒谬的困难。

‘I am aware of the circumstances,’ returned my guardian with a smile, ‘and am sufficiently obliged.’
“我知道情况，”我的监护人微笑着回答，“我非常感激。”

She had given him her hand in an indifferent way that seemed habitual to her and spoke in a correspondingly indifferent manner, though in a very pleasant voice. She was as graceful as she was beautiful, perfectly self-possessed, and had the air, I thought, of being able to attract and interest any one if she had thought it worth her while. The keeper had brought her a chair on which she sat in the middle of the porch between us.
她以一种冷漠的方式向他伸出了手，这对她来说似乎是一种习惯，并且以一种相应的冷漠的方式说话，尽管声音非常好听。她既优雅又美丽，完全沉着，我想，她有一种能够吸引任何人的气质，只要她认为值得她花时间。看门人给她拿了一把椅子，她坐在我们之间的门廊中间。

‘Is the young gentleman disposed of whom you wrote to Sir Leicester about and whose wishes Sir Leicester was sorry not to have it in his power to advance in any way?’ she said over her shoulder to my guardian.
“你写信给莱斯特爵士提到的这位年轻绅士是否已经被处理掉了，莱斯特爵士很遗憾他的愿望不能以任何方式取得进展？”她转过头对我的监护人说道。

‘I hope so,’ said he.
“我希望如此，”他说。

She seemed to respect him and even to wish to conciliate him. There was something very winning in her haughty manner, and it became more familiar—I was going to say more easy, but that could hardly be—as she spoke to him over her shoulder.
她似乎很尊重他，甚至希望安抚他。她傲慢的态度中有一种非常吸引人的东西，当她回头对他说话时，这种态度变得更加熟悉——我想说更容易，但那几乎不可能。

‘I presume this is your other ward, Miss Clare?’
“我想这是你的另一个病房，克莱尔小姐？”

He presented Ada, in form.
他以形式呈现了艾达。

‘You will lose the disinterested part of your Don Quixote character,’ said Lady Dedlock to Mr. Jarndyce over her shoulder again, ‘if you only redress the wrongs of beauty like this. But present me,’ and she turned full upon me, ‘to this young lady too!’
“你就会失去堂吉诃德角色中无私的部分，”戴德洛克夫人再次回头对贾迪斯先生说道，“如果你只是像这样纠正美丽的错误。”但是请介绍我，”她转向我，“也介绍给这位年轻的女士！”

‘Miss Summerson really is my ward,’ said Mr. Jarndyce. ‘I am responsible to no Lord Chancellor in her case.’
“萨默森小姐确实是我的监护人，”贾迪斯先生说。 “在她的案件中，我不对大法官负责。”

‘Has Miss Summerson lost both her parents?’ said my Lady.
“萨默森小姐失去了双亲吗？”夫人问道。

‘Yes.’
'是的。'

‘She is very fortunate in her guardian.’
“她很幸运有她的监护人。”

Lady Dedlock looked at me, and I looked at her and said I was indeed. All at once she turned from me with a hasty air, almost expressive of displeasure or dislike, and spoke to him over her shoulder again.
戴德洛克夫人看着我，我也看着她说我确实是。突然，她神色急促地从我身边转过身来，几乎是在表达不满或厌恶，然后又回头对他说话。

‘Ages have passed since we were in the habit of meeting, Mr. Jarndyce.’
“自从我们习惯见面以来，已经过去很多年了，贾迪斯先生。”

‘A long time. At least I thought it was a long time, until I saw you last Sunday,’ he returned.
'很长时间。至少我觉得已经很久了，直到上周日见到你。”他回答道。

‘What! Even you are a courtier, or think it necessary to become one to me!’ she said with some disdain. ‘I have achieved that reputation, I suppose.’
'什么！即使你是朝臣，或者认为有必要成为我的朝臣！”她有些不屑地说道。 “我想我已经获得了这样的声誉。”

‘You have achieved so much, Lady Dedlock,’ said my guardian, ‘that you pay some little penalty, I dare say. But none to me.’
“你已经取得了如此大的成就，戴德洛克女士，”我的监护人说，“我敢说，你付出了一些小小的惩罚。但对我来说没有。

‘So much!’ she repeated, slightly laughing. ‘Yes!’
“这么多！”她重复道，微微笑着。 '是的！'

With her air of superiority, and power, and fascination, and I know not what, she seemed to regard Ada and me as little more than children. So, as she slightly laughed and afterwards sat looking at the rain, she was as self-possessed and as free to occupy herself with her own thoughts as if she had been alone.
她带着优越感、权力和魅力，我不知道是什么，她似乎把艾达和我当作孩子一样。所以，当她微微一笑，然后坐着看雨时，她泰然自若，自在地思考着自己的事情，就好像她是一个人一样。

‘I think you knew my sister when we were abroad together better than you know me?’ she said, looking at him again.
“我想，当我们一起出国时，你比我更了解我妹妹吧？”她再次看着他说道。

‘Yes, we happened to meet oftener,’ he returned.
“是的，我们碰巧见面比较频繁，”他回答道。

‘We went our several ways,’ said Lady Dedlock, ‘and had little in common even before we agreed to differ. It is to be regretted, I suppose, but it could not be helped.’
“我们各走各的路，”戴德洛克夫人说，“即使在我们同意不同之前，也没有什么共同点。我想这是令人遗憾的，但也是无可奈何的。

Lady Dedlock again sat looking at the rain. The storm soon began to pass upon its way. The shower greatly abated, the lightning ceased, the thunder rolled among the distant hills, and the sun began to glisten on the wet leaves and the falling rain. As we sat there, silently, we saw a little pony phaeton coming towards us at a merry pace.
戴德洛克夫人又坐在那里看着雨。暴风雨很快就开始袭来。阵雨大大减弱，闪电停止，雷声在远处的山间滚滚，阳光开始在湿漉漉的树叶和落下的雨中闪闪发光。当我们静静地坐在那里时，我们看到一辆小马驹快步朝我们驶来。

‘The messenger is coming back, my Lady,’ said the keeper, ‘with the carriage.’
“夫人，信使带着马车回来了，”看门人说道。

As it drove up, we saw that there were two people inside. There alighted from it, with some cloaks and wrappers, first the Frenchwoman whom I had seen in church, and secondly the pretty girl, the Frenchwoman with a defiant confidence, the pretty girl confused and hesitating.
车子开过来的时候，我们看到里面有两个人。从车上下来，带着一些斗篷和裹布，首先是我在教堂里见过的法国女人，其次是那个漂亮的女孩，那个法国女人带着挑衅的自信，那个漂亮的女孩困惑而犹豫。

‘What now?’ said Lady Dedlock. ‘Two!’
“现在怎么办？”德洛克夫人说。 '二！'

‘I am your maid, my Lady, at the present,’ said the Frenchwoman. ‘The message was for the attendant.’
“我的女士，现在我是您的女仆，”法国女人说道。 “这条信息是给服务员的。”

‘I was afraid you might mean me, my Lady,’ said the pretty girl.
“我担心您可能指的是我，我的女士，”漂亮的女孩说道。

‘I did mean you, child,’ replied her mistress calmly. ‘Put that shawl on me.’
“我说的是你，孩子。”她的女主人平静地回答道。 “把那条围巾披在我身上。”

She slightly stooped her shoulders to receive it, and the pretty girl lightly dropped it in its place. The Frenchwoman stood unnoticed, looking on with her lips very tightly set.
微微弯腰接过，漂亮少女轻轻将它放回原处。法国女人静静地站着，嘴唇紧闭，静静地看着。

‘I am sorry,’ said Lady Dedlock to Mr. Jarndyce, ‘that we are not likely to renew our former acquaintance. You will allow me to send the carriage back for your two wards. It shall be here directly.’
“很抱歉，”戴德洛克夫人对贾迪斯先生说，“我们不太可能再续前缘了。”你允许我把马车送回你们的两个病房。它应该直接在这里。

But as he would on no account accept this offer, she took a graceful leave of Ada—none of me—and put her hand upon his proffered arm, and got into the carriage, which was a little, low, park carriage with a hood.
但由于他无论如何都不会接受这个提议，所以她优雅地离开了艾达——不是我——然后把手搭在他伸出的手臂上，然后上了马车，那是一辆带引擎盖的小而低矮的公园马车。 。

‘Come in, child,’ she said to the pretty girl; ‘I shall want you. Go on!’
“进来吧，孩子，”她对漂亮女孩说。 ‘我会想要你。继续！'

The carriage rolled away, and the Frenchwoman, with the wrappers she had brought hanging over her arm, remained standing where she had alighted.
马车开走了，法国女人手臂上挂着她带来的包装纸，仍然站在她下车的地方。

I suppose there is nothing pride can so little bear with as pride itself, and that she was punished for her imperious manner. Her retaliation was the most singular I could have imagined. She remained perfectly still until the carriage had turned into the drive, and then, without the least discomposure of countenance, slipped off her shoes, left them on the ground, and walked deliberately in the same direction through the wettest of the wet grass.
我想没有什么比骄傲本身更能容忍骄傲了，而她却因为她专横的态度而受到了惩罚。她的报复是我能想象到的最奇特的。她一动不动，直到马车驶入车道，然后，脸上没有丝毫不安，脱下鞋子，把它们留在地上，故意沿着同一个方向穿过湿漉漉的草地。

‘Is that young woman mad?’ said my guardian.
“那个年轻女人疯了吗？”我的监护人问道。

‘Oh, no, sir!’ said the keeper, who, with his wife, was looking after her. ‘Hortense is not one of that sort. She has as good a head-piece as the best. But she’s mortal high and passionate— powerful high and passionate; and what with having notice to leave, and having others put above her, she don’t take kindly to it.’
“哦，不，先生！”守门员说道，他和他的妻子正在照顾她。 “霍滕斯不是那种人。她的头饰和最好的一样好。但她是凡人的高尚和热情——强大的高尚和热情；当她通知她离开，并让其他人凌驾于她之上时，她并不乐意。

‘But why should she walk shoeless through all that water?’ said my guardian.
“但是她为什么要光着鞋穿过那么多水呢？”我的监护人说。

‘Why, indeed, sir, unless it is to cool her down!’ said the man.
“确实是这样，先生，除非是为了让她冷静下来！”那人说道。

‘Or unless she fancies it’s blood,’ said the woman. ‘She’d as soon walk through that as anything else, I think, when her own’s up!’
“或者除非她认为那是血，”女人说。 “我想，当她自己的事情发生时，她会尽快经历这一切！”

We passed not far from the house a few minutes afterwards. Peaceful as it had looked when we first saw it, it looked even more so now, with a diamond spray glittering all about it, a light wind blowing, the birds no longer hushed but singing strongly, everything refreshed by the late rain, and the little carriage shining at the doorway like a fairy carriage made of silver. Still, very steadfastly and quietly walking towards it, a peaceful figure too in the landscape, went Mademoiselle Hortense, shoeless, through the wet grass.
几分钟后我们就经过了离房子不远的地方。初见时的宁静，现在更是如此，四周闪烁着钻石般的浪花，微风吹过，鸟儿不再安静，而是高声歌唱，一切都因晚雨而变得清新，小马车在门口闪闪发光，就像一辆银色的仙车。尽管如此，霍顿斯小姐赤着鞋，穿过湿漉漉的草地，坚定而安静地朝它走去，这也是风景中一个平静的身影。

CHAPTER XIX
第十九章


Moving On
继续

It is the long vacation in the regions of Chancery Lane. The good ships Law and Equity, those teak-built, copper-bottomed, ironfastened, brazen-faced, and not by any means fast-sailing clippers are laid up in ordinary. The Flying Dutchman, with a crew of ghostly clients imploring all whom they may encounter to peruse their papers, has drifted, for the time being, heaven knows where. The courts are all shut up; the public offices lie in a hot sleep. Westminster Hall itself is a shady solitude where nightingales might sing, and a tenderer class of suitors than is usually found there, walk.
现在是Chancery Lane地区的长假。好船“法律”号和“公平”号，那些柚木建造、铜底、铁系、黄铜面、绝不是快速航行的快船，都处于普通状态。飞翔的荷兰人号带着一群幽灵般的客户恳求所有可能遇到的人仔细阅读他们的文件，暂时已经漂流到了哪里，天知道在哪里。法庭全部关闭；公共办公室正在酣睡。威斯敏斯特大厅本身就是一处阴凉的僻静处，夜莺在这里歌唱，一群比通常在那里发现的更温柔的追求者在散步。

The Temple, Chancery Lane, Serjeants’ Inn, and Lincoln’s Inn even unto the Fields are like tidal harbours at low water, where stranded proceedings, offices at anchor, idle clerks lounging on lop-sided stools that will not recover their perpendicular until the current of Term sets in, lie high and dry upon the ooze of the long vacation. Outer doors of chambers are shut up by the score, messages and parcels are to be left at the Porter’s Lodge by the bushel. A crop of grass would grow in the chinks of the stone pavement outside Lincoln’s Inn Hall, but that the ticket-porters, who have nothing to do beyond sitting in the shade there, with their white aprons over their heads to keep the flies off, grub it up and eat it thoughtfully.
圣殿、大法官巷、军士酒馆和林肯酒馆，甚至一直到田野，都像低潮时的潮汐港，那里的程序搁浅，办公室抛锚，无所事事的职员懒洋洋地躺在倾斜的凳子上，直到水流完全恢复垂直。学期开始了，长假的泥浆上又高又干。房间的外门被门闩关闭，邮件和包裹必须按蒲式耳留在搬运工小屋。林肯旅馆大厅外石板路的缝隙里会长出一株草，但票务搬运工除了坐在阴凉处无事可做，头上还围着白色围裙，以防苍蝇，把它收拾起来，若有所思地吃掉。

There is only one judge in town. Even he only comes twice a week to sit in chambers. If the country folks of those assize towns on his circuit could see him now! No full-bottomed wig, no red petticoats, no fur, no javelin-men, no white wands. Merely a close-shaved gentleman in white trousers and a white hat, with seabronze on the judicial countenance, and a strip of bark peeled by the solar rays from the judicial nose, who calls in at the shellfish shop as he comes along and drinks iced ginger-beer!
镇上只有一名法官。甚至他每周也只来会议厅两次。如果他巡回演出的那些大小城镇的乡下人现在能看到他就好了！没有全底假发，没有红色衬裙，没有毛皮，没有标枪兵，没有白色魔杖。只不过是一位穿着白裤子、戴着白帽子、剃得光秃秃的绅士，法官的脸上有海古铜色，法官的鼻子上有一条被太阳光剥落的树皮，他一边过来一边在贝类店里拜访，喝着冰镇的饮料。姜汁啤酒！

The bar of England is scattered over the face of the earth. How England can get on through four long summer months without its bar —which is its acknowledged refuge in adversity and its only legitimate triumph in prosperity—is beside the question; assuredly that shield and buckler of Britannia are not in present wear. The learned gentleman who is always so tremendously indignant at the unprecedented outrage committed on the feelings of his client by the opposite party that he never seems likely to recover it is doing infinitely better than might be expected in Switzerland. The learned gentleman who does the withering business and who blights all opponents with his gloomy sarcasm is as merry as a grig at a French watering-place. The learned gentleman who weeps by the pint on the smallest provocation has not shed a tear these six weeks. The very learned gentleman who has cooled the natural heat of his gingery complexion in pools and fountains of law until he has become great in knotty arguments for term-time, when he poses the drowsy bench with legal ‘chaff,’ inexplicable to the uninitiated and to most of the initiated too, is roaming, with a characteristic delight in aridity and dust, about Constantinople. Other dispersed fragments of the same great palladium are to be found on the canals of Venice, at the second cataract of the Nile, in the baths of Germany, and sprinkled on the sea-sand all over the English coast. Scarcely one is to be encountered in the deserted region of Chancery Lane. If such a lonely member of the bar do flit across the waste and come upon a prowling suitor who is unable to leave off haunting the scenes of his anxiety, they frighten one another and retreat into opposite shades.
英格兰的酒吧遍布地球表面。英格兰如何在没有酒吧的情况下度过漫长的四个夏季月份——酒吧是英国在逆境中公认的避难所，也是其在繁荣时期唯一合法的胜利——这是一个问题。毫无疑问，不列颠尼亚的盾牌和圆盾目前并未佩戴。这位博学的绅士总是对对方对他的委托人的感情所犯下的前所未有的愤怒感到极其愤慨，以至于他似乎永远不可能恢复这种愤怒，但他在瑞士的表现比人们预期的要好得多。一位学识渊博的绅士，做着枯萎的生意，用阴郁的讽刺来折磨所有的对手，他的快乐就像法国水场里的一伙人一样。这位博学的绅士在最小的挑衅下就痛哭流涕，这六周以来他没有流过一滴眼泪。这位非常博学的绅士，在法律的池子和喷泉中冷却了他生姜般肤色的自然热量，直到他在学期时间的棘手争论中变得出色，当他在昏昏欲睡的长凳上摆出法律“谷壳”时，对于外行和外行来说是难以解释的。对于大多数入门者来说，这也是在君士坦丁堡周围漫游，带着对干旱和灰尘的特有的喜悦。在威尼斯的运河、尼罗河的第二瀑布、德国的浴场以及散布在英国海岸各地的海沙上，都可以找到同样伟大的钯金的其他分散碎片。在大法官巷的荒凉地区几乎看不到任何一只。如果酒吧里这样一个孤独的成员确实飞过荒野，遇到了一个徘徊的追求者，而他又无法摆脱焦虑的场景，他们就会互相吓到，并退回到相反的阴影中。

It is the hottest long vacation known for many years. All the young clerks are madly in love, and according to their various degrees, pine for bliss with the beloved object, at Margate, Ramsgate, or Gravesend. All the middle-aged clerks think their families too large. All the unowned dogs who stray into the Inns of Court and pant about staircases and other dry places seeking water give short howls of aggravation. All the blind men’s dogs in the streets draw their masters against pumps or trip them over buckets. A shop with a sun-blind, and a watered pavement, and a bowl of gold and silver fish in the window, is a sanctuary. Temple Bar gets so hot that it is, to the adjacent Strand and Fleet Street, what a heater is in an urn, and keeps them simmering all night.
这是多年来已知的最热长假。所有年轻的职员都疯狂地爱上了马盖特、拉姆斯盖特或格雷夫森德，根据他们的不同程度，渴望与心爱的对象幸福。所有的中年职员都认为他们的家庭太大了。所有误入法院旅馆的无主狗，在楼梯和其他干燥的地方气喘吁吁地寻找水源，都会发出短促的愤怒嚎叫。街上所有的盲人狗都把主人拖到水泵上，或者被水桶绊倒。一家有百叶窗、浇水的人行道、橱窗里摆着一碗金银鱼的商店，就是一个避难所。圣殿酒吧 (Temple Bar) 的天气非常炎热，与邻近的斯特兰德街 (Strand Street) 和舰队街 (Fleet Street) 相比，就像瓮中的加热器一样，让它们整晚都在沸腾。

There are offices about the Inns of Court in which a man might be cool, if any coolness were worth purchasing at such a price in dullness; but the little thoroughfares immediately outside those retirements seem to blaze. In Mr. Krook’s court, it is so hot that the people turn their houses inside out and sit in chairs upon the pavement—Mr. Krook included, who there pursues his studies, with his cat (who never is too hot) by his side. The Sol’s Arms has discontinued the Harmonic Meetings for the season, and Little Swills is engaged at the Pastoral Gardens down the river, where he comes out in quite an innocent manner and sings comic ditties of a juvenile complexion calculated (as the bill says) not to wound the feelings of the most fastidious mind.
法院附近有一些办公室，在那里，一个人可能很酷，如果有什么酷值得以如此沉闷的价格购买的话。但这些退休区外的小大道似乎正在燃烧。在克鲁克先生的宫廷里，天气太热了，人们把房子翻了个底朝天，坐在人行道上的椅子上——克鲁克先生。克鲁克也在其中，他在那里继续学业，他的猫（永远不会太热）在他身边。索尔之臂已经停止了本季的和声聚会，而小斯威尔斯正在河下游的田园花园订婚，在那里他以一种天真无邪的方式出现，唱着少年肤色的滑稽小调（正如法案所说）伤害最挑剔的心灵的感情。

Over all the legal neighbourhood there hangs, like some great veil of rust or gigantic cobweb, the idleness and pensiveness of the long vacation. Mr. Snagsby, law-stationer of Cook’s Court, Cursitor Street, is sensible of the influence not only in his mind as a sympathetic and contemplative man, but also in his business as a law-stationer aforesaid. He has more leisure for musing in Staple Inn and in the Rolls Yard during the long vacation than at other seasons, and he says to the two ‘prentices, what a thing it is in such hot weather to think that you live in an island with the sea a-rolling and a-bowling right round you.
在所有合法的社区里，都笼罩着长假的闲散和沉思，就像一层生锈的巨大面纱或巨大的蜘蛛网。斯纳格斯比先生是库西托街库克法院的法律文员，他作为一个富有同情心和沉思的人，不仅在他的思想中感受到了这种影响，而且在他作为上述法律文员的业务中也感受到了这种影响。长假期间，他在斯台普客栈和罗尔斯院子里比其他季节有更多的闲暇沉思，他对两个学徒说，在这么热的天气里，想到你住在一个岛上，有大海就在你周围翻滚、滚滚。

Guster is busy in the little drawing-room on this present afternoon in the long vacation, when Mr. and Mrs. Snagsby have it in contemplation to receive company. The expected guests are rather select than numerous, being Mr. and Mrs. Chadband and no more. From Mr. Chadband’s being much given to describe himself, both verbally and in writing, as a vessel, he is occasionally mistaken by strangers for a gentleman connected with navigation, but he is, as he expresses it, ‘in the ministry.’ Mr. Chadband is attached to no particular denomination and is considered by his persecutors to have nothing so very remarkable to say on the greatest of subjects as to render his volunteering, on his own account, at all incumbent on his conscience; but he has his followers, and Mrs. Snagsby is of the number. Mrs. Snagsby has but recently taken a passage upward by the vessel, Chadband; and her attention was attracted to that Bark A 1 when she was something flushed by the hot weather.
今天下午，在长假期间，古斯特在小客厅里忙碌着，斯纳格斯比先生和夫人正在考虑接待客人。预计的客人是经过精心挑选的，而不是众多，只有查德班德先生和夫人，仅此而已。查德班德先生经常在口头和书面上将自己描述为一艘船只，因此有时会被陌生人误认为是一位与航海有关的绅士，但正如他所说，他“在事奉中”。查德班德不属于任何特定教派，迫害他的人认为，他在最伟大的主题上没有什么值得说的，以至于使他为自己的志愿服务完全符合他的良心；但他也有自己的追随者，斯纳斯比夫人就是其中之一。斯纳格斯比夫人最近刚刚乘查德班号船向上航行；当她因天气炎热而脸红时，她的注意力就被那只树皮A 1吸引了。

‘My little woman,’ says Mr. Snagsby to the sparrows in Staple Inn, ‘likes to have her religion rather sharp, you see!’
“我的小女人，”斯纳斯比先生对斯台普客栈的麻雀说，“你看，她喜欢让她的宗教变得相当尖锐！”

So Guster, much impressed by regarding herself for the time as the handmaid of Chadband, whom she knows to be endowed with the gift of holding forth for four hours at a stretch, prepares the little drawing-room for tea. All the furniture is shaken and dusted, the portraits of Mr. and Mrs. Snagsby are touched up with a wet cloth, the best tea-service is set forth, and there is excellent provision made of dainty new bread, crusty twists, cool fresh butter, thin slices of ham, tongue, and German sausage, and delicate little rows of anchovies nestling in parsley, not to mention new-laid eggs, to be brought up warm in a napkin, and hot buttered toast. For Chadband is rather a consuming vessel—the persecutors say a gorging vessel—and can wield such weapons of the flesh as a knife and fork remarkably well.
因此，古斯特对自己当时作为查德班德的女仆印象深刻，她知道查德班德具有连续四个小时滔滔不绝的天赋，她准备在小客厅里喝茶。所有的家具都经过摇晃和除尘，斯纳斯比先生和夫人的肖像都用湿布擦拭过，提供了最好的茶具，还有精美的新面包、酥脆的面包、凉爽新鲜的美味佳肴。黄油、薄薄的火腿片、舌头和德国香肠，还有欧芹中精致的小排凤尾鱼，更不用说新产的鸡蛋，餐巾纸上温热，还有热黄油吐司。因为查德班德是一个消耗性的容器——迫害者说是一个狼吞虎咽的容器——并且可以非常熟练地使用刀叉等肉体武器。

Mr. Snagsby in his best coat, looking at all the preparations when they are completed and coughing his cough of deference behind his hand, says to Mrs. Snagsby, ‘At what time did you expect Mr. and Mrs. Chadband, my love?’
斯纳格斯比先生穿着他最好的外套，看着所有的准备工作都完成了，在手后面咳嗽一声表示敬意，对斯纳格斯比夫人说：“亲爱的，你什么时候在等查德班德先生和查德班德夫人？” '

‘At six,’ says Mrs. Snagsby.
“六点钟，”斯纳斯比太太说。

Mr. Snagsby observes in a mild and casual way that ‘it’s gone that.’
斯纳格斯比先生以一种温和而随意的方式评论道，“那已经过去了。”

‘Perhaps you’d like to begin without them,’ is Mrs. Snagsby’s reproachful remark.
“也许你想在没有它们的情况下开始，”斯纳斯比夫人责备地说。

Mr. Snagsby does look as if he would like it very much, but he says, with his cough of mildness, ‘No, my dear, no. I merely named the time.’
斯纳斯比先生看起来确实非常喜欢，但他轻咳一声说道：“不，亲爱的，不。”我只是说出了时间。

‘What’s time,’ says Mrs. Snagsby, ‘to eternity?’
“什么时候，”斯纳斯比夫人说，“到永恒？”

‘Very true, my dear,’ says Mr. Snagsby. ‘Only when a person lays in victuals for tea, a person does it with a view—perhaps—more to time. And when a time is named for having tea, it’s better to come up to it.’
“非常正确，亲爱的，”斯纳斯比先生说。 “只有当一个人准备茶点时，他才会带着一种观点——也许——更多的是时间。当指定喝茶的时间时，最好还是去喝茶。”

‘To come up to it!’ Mrs. Snagsby repeats with severity. ‘Up to it! As if Mr. Chadband was a fighter!’
“去完成它！”斯纳斯比夫人严厉地重复道。 ‘就这样吧！就好像查德班德先生是一名战士一样！

‘Not at all, my dear,’ says Mr. Snagsby.
“一点也不，亲爱的，”斯纳斯比先生说。

Here, Guster, who had been looking out of the bedroom window, comes rustling and scratching down the little staircase like a popular ghost, and falling flushed into the drawing-room, announces that Mr. and Mrs. Chadband have appeared in the court. The bell at the inner door in the passage immediately thereafter tinkling, she is admonished by Mrs. Snagsby, on pain of instant reconsignment to her patron saint, not to omit the ceremony of announcement. Much discomposed in her nerves (which were previously in the best order) by this threat, she so fearfully mutilates that point of state as to announce ‘Mr. and Mrs. Cheeseming, least which, Imeantersay, whatsername!’ and retires conscience-stricken from the presence.
在这里，一直在卧室窗户往外看的古斯特像一个受欢迎的鬼魂一样沙沙作响，抓着小楼梯走下来，满脸通红地跌进客厅，宣布查德班德夫妇已经出现在法庭上。通道内门的钟声随即响起，斯纳斯比夫人警告她不要忽略宣布仪式，否则将立即重新托付给她的守护神。这种威胁使她的神经（以前处于最佳状态）非常不安，她如此恐惧地破坏了这一点，以至于宣布“先生”。 “还有奇斯明太太，至少是那个，我是说，叫什么名字！”然后良心不安地从现场退了出去。

Mr. Chadband is a large yellow man with a fat smile and a general appearance of having a good deal of train oil in his system. Mrs. Chadband is a stern, severe-looking, silent woman. Mr. Chadband moves softly and cumbrously, not unlike a bear who has been taught to walk upright. He is very much embarrassed about the arms, as if they were inconvenient to him and he wanted to grovel, is very much in a perspiration about the head, and never speaks without first putting up his great hand, as delivering a token to his hearers that he is going to edify them.
查德班德先生是个身材高大的黄种人，笑容满面，看上去体内有大量火车油。查德班德夫人是一位严肃、严肃、沉默寡言的女人。查德班德的动作轻柔而笨重，就像一只被训练直立行走的熊。他对手臂感到非常尴尬，好像它们对他来说不方便，他想卑躬屈膝，头上冒汗，说话之前总是先举起他的大手，就像向听众传递令牌一样他要启发他们。

‘My friends,’ says Mr. Chadband, ‘peace be on this house! On the master thereof, on the mistress thereof, on the young maidens, and on the young men! My friends, why do I wish for peace? What is peace? Is it war? No. Is it strife? No. Is it lovely, and gentle, and beautiful, and pleasant, and serene, and joyful? Oh, yes! Therefore, my friends, I wish for peace, upon you and upon yours.’
“我的朋友们，”查德班德先生说，“愿这座房子平安！”在其主人身上，在其情妇身上，在少女身上，在少年男子身上！朋友们，我为什么祈求和平呢？什么是和平？是战争吗？不，是冲突吗？不，它是可爱的、温柔的、美丽的、愉快的、宁静的、快乐的吗？哦是的！因此，我的朋友们，我祝愿你们和你们的家人平安。”

In consequence of Mrs. Snagsby looking deeply edified, Mr. Snagsby thinks it expedient on the whole to say amen, which is well received.
由于斯纳格斯比夫人看起来深受启发，斯纳格斯比先生认为总的来说说“阿门”是有利的，这受到了好评。

‘Now, my friends,’ proceeds Mr. Chadband, ‘since I am upon this theme—‘
“现在，我的朋友们，”查德班德先生继续说道，“既然我要讨论这个主题——”

Guster presents herself. Mrs. Snagsby, in a spectral bass voice and without removing her eyes from Chadband, says with dreadful distinctness, ‘Go away!’
古斯特现身。斯纳斯比夫人用一种幽灵般的低音声音，眼睛始终没有离开查德班德，清晰得可怕地说：“走开！”

‘Now, my friends,’ says Chadband, ‘since I am upon this theme, and in my lowly path improving it—‘
“现在，我的朋友们，”查德班德说，“既然我正在研究这个主题，并且在我卑微的道路上改进它——”

Guster is heard unaccountably to murmur ‘one thousing seven hundred and eighty-two.’ The spectral voice repeats more solemnly, ‘Go away!’
古斯特莫名其妙地低声说道：“一千七百八十二。”幽灵般的声音更加严肃地重复道：“走开！”

‘Now, my friends,’ says Mr. Chadband, ‘we will inquire in a spirit of love—‘
“现在，我的朋友们，”查德班德先生说，“我们将本着爱的精神询问——”

Still Guster reiterates ‘one thousing seven hundred and eightytwo.’
古斯特仍然重申“一千七百八十二”。

Mr. Chadband, pausing with the resignation of a man accustomed to be persecuted and languidly folding up his chin into his fat smile, says, ‘Let us hear the maiden! Speak, maiden!’
查德班德先生停顿了一下，表现出一个习惯于受迫害的人的无奈，懒洋洋地抬起下巴，露出肥胖的笑容，说道：“让我们听听这位少女的声音！”说吧，少女！”

‘One thousing seven hundred and eighty-two, if you please, sir. Which he wish to know what the shilling ware for,’ says Guster, breathless.
“一千七百八十二，如果您愿意的话，先生。他想知道这些先令是做什么用的，”古斯特气喘吁吁地说。

‘For?’ returns Mrs. Chadband. ‘For his fare!’
“为了？”查德班德夫人回答道。 “为了他的车费！”

Guster replied that ‘he insistes on one and eightpence or on summonsizzing the party.’ Mrs. Snagsby and Mrs. Chadband are proceeding to grow shrill in indignation when Mr. Chadband quiets the tumult by lifting up his hand.
古斯特回答说，“他坚持要一先令八便士，或者要召集聚会。”当查德班德先生举起手来平息骚乱时，斯纳格斯比夫人和查德班德夫人的愤怒开始变得尖锐起来。

‘My friends,’ says he, ‘I remember a duty unfulfilled yesterday. It is right that I should be chastened in some penalty. I ought not to murmur. Rachael, pay the eightpence!’
“我的朋友们，”他说，“我记得昨天有一项任务没有完成。我应该受到一些惩罚，这是正确的。我不应该发怨言。瑞秋，付八便士！”

While Mrs. Snagsby, drawing her breath, looks hard at Mr. Snagsby, as who should say, ‘You hear this apostle!’ and while Mr. Chadband glows with humility and train oil, Mrs. Chadband pays the money. It is Mr. Chadband’s habit—it is the head and front of his pretensions indeed—to keep this sort of debtor and creditor account in the smallest items and to post it publicly on the most trivial occasions.
斯纳格斯比夫人屏住呼吸，狠狠地看着斯纳格斯比先生，谁该说：“你听到这位使徒的声音了！”查德班德先生脸上洋溢着谦卑和火车油，而查德班德夫人却付了钱。查德班德先生的习惯——这确实是他的自命不凡的核心——把这种债务人和债权人的账目记在最小的项目中，并在最琐碎的场合公开发布。

‘My friends,’ says Chadband, ‘eightpence is not much; it might justly have been one and fourpence; it might justly have been half a crown. O let us be joyful, joyful! O let us be joyful!’
“我的朋友们，”查德班德说，“八便士并不算多；”应该是一又四便士；可能是半克朗。噢，让我们喜乐、喜乐！噢，让我们快乐吧！

With which remark, which appears from its sound to be an extract in verse, Mr. Chadband stalks to the table, and before taking a chair, lifts up his admonitory hand.
查德班德先生说完这句话，听起来像是一首诗的摘录，他大步走向桌边，在坐下来之前，举起了他警告性的手。

‘My friends,’ says he, ‘what is this which we now behold as being spread before us? Refreshment. Do we need refreshment then, my friends? We do. And why do we need refreshment, my friends? Because we are but mortal, because we are but sinful, because we are but of the earth, because we are not of the air. Can we fly, my friends? We cannot. Why can we not fly, my friends?’
“我的朋友们，”他说道，“我们现在所看到的展现在我们面前的是什么？茶点。那么我们需要茶点吗，我的朋友们？我们的确是。我的朋友们，为什么我们需要茶点呢？因为我们只是凡人，因为我们只是有罪的，因为我们只是地球的，因为我们不属于空气。朋友们，我们可以飞吗？我们不可以。为什么我们不能飞，我的朋友们？

Mr. Snagsby, presuming on the success of his last point, ventures to observe in a cheerful and rather knowing tone, ‘No wings.’ But is immediately frowned down by Mrs. Snagsby.
斯纳斯比先生认为他的最后一点成功了，冒险用一种愉快且相当会意的语气观察道：“没有翅膀。”但立即被斯纳斯比太太皱起眉头。

‘I say, my friends,’ pursues Mr. Chadband, utterly rejecting and obliterating Mr. Snagsby’s suggestion, ‘why can we not fly? Is it because we are calculated to walk? It is. Could we walk, my friends, without strength? We could not. What should we do without strength, my friends? Our legs would refuse to bear us, our knees would double up, our ankles would turn over, and we should come to the ground. Then from whence, my friends, in a human point of view, do we derive the strength that is necessary to our limbs? Is it,’ says Chadband, glancing over the table, ‘from bread in various forms, from butter which is churned from the milk which is yielded unto us by the cow, from the eggs which are laid by the fowl, from ham, from tongue, from sausage, and from such like? It is. Then let us partake of the good things which are set before us!’
“我说，我的朋友们，”查德班德先生继续说道，完全拒绝并抹去了斯纳格斯比先生的建议，“为什么我们不能飞？是因为我们注定要走路吗？这是。我的朋友们，我们能在没有力气的情况下行走吗？我们不能。朋友们，没有力气怎么办？我们的双腿将无法支撑我们，我们的膝盖将弯起，我们的脚踝将翻转，我们应该落地。那么朋友们，从人的角度来看，我们的四肢所必需的力量是从哪里获得的呢？是不是，”查德班德扫了一眼桌子，说道，“是各种形式的面包，是用奶牛为我们生产的牛奶搅拌而成的黄油，是家禽下的蛋，是火腿，还是舌头，香肠，还有类似的东西？这是。那么让我们分享摆在我们面前的美好事物吧！

The persecutors denied that there was any particular gift in Mr. Chadband’s piling verbose flights of stairs, one upon another, after this fashion. But this can only be received as a proof of their determination to persecute, since it must be within everybody’s experience that the Chadband style of oratory is widely received and much admired.
迫害者否认查德班德先生以这种方式一层一层地堆积冗长的楼梯有任何特殊的天赋。但这只能被视为他们迫害决心的证据，因为查德班风格的演讲受到广泛接受和钦佩，这一定是每个人的经历。

Mr. Chadband, however, having concluded for the present, sits down at Mr. Snagsby’s table and lays about him prodigiously. The conversion of nutriment of any sort into oil of the quality already mentioned appears to be a process so inseparable from the constitution of this exemplary vessel that in beginning to eat and drink, he may be described as always becoming a kind of considerable oil mills or other large factory for the production of that article on a wholesale scale. On the present evening of the long vacation, in Cook’s Court, Cursitor Street, he does such a powerful stroke of business that the warehouse appears to be quite full when the works cease.
然而，查德班德先生暂时结束了谈话，他在斯纳格斯比先生的桌子旁坐下，在他身边躺了下来。将任何种类的营养物转化为已经提到的质量的油似乎是一个与这个示例性容器的构造密不可分的过程，以至于在开始吃喝时，他可以被描述为总是成为一种相当大的油磨坊或其他大规模生产该物品的大型工厂。长假的今天晚上，在库西托街的库克庭院里，他做了一件大事，以至于工作结束时仓库似乎已经满了。

At this period of the entertainment, Guster, who has never recovered her first failure, but has neglected no possible or impossible means of bringing the establishment and herself into contempt—among which may be briefly enumerated her unexpectedly performing clashing military music on Mr. Chadband’s head with plates, and afterwards crowning that gentleman with muffins—at which period of the entertainment, Guster whispers Mr. Snagsby that he is wanted.
在这个娱乐节目中，古斯特虽然还没有恢复第一次的失败，但她却忽略了任何可能或不可能的手段来蔑视当权者和她自己——其中可以简单地列举一下她在查德班德先生的舞台上出人意料地演奏了冲突的军乐。头顶着盘子，然后用松饼为这位绅士加冕——在娱乐活动的这个时候，古斯特低声对斯纳斯比先生说他被通缉了。

‘And being wanted in the—not to put too fine a point upon it—in the shop,’ says Mr. Snagsby, rising, ‘perhaps this good company will excuse me for half a minute.’
“在店里——不要说得太过分——在店里被通缉，”斯纳格斯比先生站起来说道，“也许这家好公司会原谅我半分钟。”

Mr. Snagsby descends and finds the two ‘prentices intently contemplating a police constable, who holds a ragged boy by the arm.
斯纳格斯比先生下楼，发现两个“学徒”正专注地注视着一名警员，警员挽着一名衣衫褴褛的男孩的手臂。

‘Why, bless my heart,’ says Mr. Snagsby, ‘what’s the matter!’
“哎呀，上帝保佑我的心，”斯纳斯比先生说，“这是怎么回事！”

‘This boy,’ says the constable, ‘although he’s repeatedly told to, won’t move on—‘
“这个男孩，”警官说，“尽管他一再被告知，但他不会继续前进——”

‘I’m always a-moving on, sar, cries the boy, wiping away his grimy tears with his arm. ‘I’ve always been a-moving and a-moving on, ever since I was born. Where can I possibly move to, sir, more nor I do move!’
“我一直在前进，萨尔，”男孩喊道，并用手臂擦去了肮脏的泪水。 “自从我出生以来，我一直在不断前进。我能搬到哪里去，先生，更何况我也不搬家！

‘He won’t move on,’ says the constable calmly, with a slight professional hitch of his neck involving its better settlement in his stiff stock, ‘although he has been repeatedly cautioned, and therefore I am obliged to take him into custody. He’s as obstinate a young gonoph as I know. He WON’T move on.’
“他不会继续前进，”警察平静地说，他的脖子上有轻微的职业障碍，这使得他僵硬的股票更好地固定，“尽管他已经被反复警告过，因此我不得不拘留他。据我所知，他是个固执的年轻地精。他不会继续前进。

‘Oh, my eye! Where can I move to!’ cries the boy, clutching quite desperately at his hair and beating his bare feet upon the floor of Mr. Snagsby’s passage.
‘哦，我的眼睛！ “我能搬到哪里去！”男孩喊道，拼命地抓着自己的头发，光着脚在斯纳斯比先生过道的地板上敲打。

‘Don’t you come none of that or I shall make blessed short work of you!’ says the constable, giving him a passionless shake. ‘My instructions are that you are to move on. I have told you so five hundred times.’
“你别来，否则我很快就会干掉你！”警察说道，冷漠地摇了摇他。 “我的指示是你要继续前进。我已经告诉过你五百次了。

‘But where?’ cries the boy.
“但是去哪儿呢？”男孩喊道。

‘Well! Really, constable, you know,’ says Mr. Snagsby wistfully, and coughing behind his hand his cough of great perplexity and doubt, ‘really, that does seem a question. Where, you know?’
'出色地！真的，警官，你知道，”斯纳格斯比先生若有所思地说，他在手后咳嗽了一声，带着极大的困惑和怀疑，“真的，这确实是一个问题。哪里，你知道吗？

‘My instructions don’t go to that,’ replies the constable. ‘My instructions are that this boy is to move on.’
“我的指示不是这样的，”警官回答道。 “我的指示是这个男孩要继续前进。”

Do you hear, Jo? It is nothing to you or to any one else that the great lights of the parliamentary sky have failed for some few years in this business to set you the example of moving on. The one grand recipe remains for you—the profound philosophical prescription—the be-all and the end-all of your strange existence upon earth. Move on! You are by no means to move off, Jo, for the great lights can’t at all agree about that. Move on!
你听到了吗，乔？几年来，议会天空中的伟大光芒未能为您树立继续前进的榜样，这对您或任何其他人来说都没什么关系。为你留下了一个伟大的秘诀——深刻的哲学处方——你在地球上奇怪的存在的全部和最终目的。继续前行！乔，你决不能离开，因为伟大的光明根本无法同意这一点。继续前行！

Mr. Snagsby says nothing to this effect, says nothing at all indeed, but coughs his forlornest cough, expressive of no thoroughfare in any direction. By this time Mr. and Mrs. Chadband and Mrs. Snagsby, hearing the altercation, have appeared upon the stairs. Guster having never left the end of the passage, the whole household are assembled.
斯纳斯比先生对此什么也没说，实际上什么也没说，只是咳嗽了一声，表示没有任何方向的通行。这时，查德班德夫妇和斯纳斯比夫人听到争吵声，已经出现在楼梯上。古斯特从未离开过通道的尽头，全家人都聚集在一起。

‘The simple question is, sir,’ says the constable, ‘whether you know this boy. He says you do.’
“简单的问题是，先生，”警察说，“你是否认识这个男孩。”他说你愿意。

Mrs. Snagsby, from her elevation, instantly cries out, ‘No he don’t!’
斯纳斯比夫人站在高处，立即喊道：“不，他不知道！”

‘My lit-tle woman!’ says Mr. Snagsby, looking up the staircase. ‘My love, permit me! Pray have a moment’s patience, my dear. I do know something of this lad, and in what I know of him, I can’t say that there’s any harm; perhaps on the contrary, constable.’ To whom the law-stationer relates his Joful and woful experience, suppressing the half-crown fact.
“我的小女人！”斯纳斯比先生看着楼梯说道。 ‘我的爱人，请允许我！请耐心等待，亲爱的。我确实对这个小伙子有所了解，就我对他的了解而言，我不能说这有什么坏处；也许恰恰相反，警察。”执法人员向他讲述了他快乐和悲惨的经历，隐瞒了半克朗的事实。

‘Well!’ says the constable, ‘so far, it seems, he had grounds for what he said. When I took him into custody up in Holborn, he said you knew him. Upon that, a young man who was in the crowd said he was acquainted with you, and you were a respectable housekeeper, and if I’d call and make the inquiry, he’d appear. The young man don’t seem inclined to keep his word, but— Oh! Here IS the young man!’
“好吧！”警察说道，“到目前为止，他所说的似乎都是有根据的。”当我在霍尔本拘留他时，他说你认识他。这时，人群中的一个年轻人说他认识你，你是一位令人尊敬的管家，如果我打电话询问，他就会出现。年轻人似乎不太愿意遵守诺言，但是——哦！这就是年轻人！

Enter Mr. Guppy, who nods to Mr. Snagsby and touches his hat with the chivalry of clerkship to the ladies on the stairs.
古皮先生上场，他向斯纳斯比先生点点头，并以职员的骑士精神向楼梯上的女士们碰了碰帽子。

‘I was strolling away from the office just now when I found this row going on,’ says Mr. Guppy to the law-stationer, ‘and as your name was mentioned, I thought it was right the thing should be looked into.’
“我刚刚走出办公室时，发现了这场争吵，”古皮先生对法律文员说，“当提到你的名字时，我认为应该对此事进行调查。”

‘It was very good-natured of you, sir,’ says Mr. Snagsby, ‘and I am obliged to you.’ And Mr. Snagsby again relates his experience, again suppressing the half-crown fact.
“您真是太好了，先生，”斯纳斯比先生说，“我很感激你。”斯纳斯比先生再次讲述了他的经历，再次隐瞒了半克朗的事实。

‘Now, I know where you live,’ says the constable, then, to Jo. ‘You live down in Tom-all-Alone’s. That’s a nice innocent place to live in, ain’t it?’
“现在，我知道你住在哪里了，”警察对乔说道。 “你住在汤姆孤儿家里。”那是一个美好而纯真的居住之地，不是吗？

‘I can’t go and live in no nicer place, sir,’ replies Jo. ‘They wouldn’t have nothink to say to me if I wos to go to a nice innocent place fur to live. Who ud go and let a nice innocent lodging to such a reg’lar one as me!’
“我不能去住在更好的地方了，先生，”乔回答道。 “如果我不想去一个美好而纯净的地方居住，他们不会想都不想告诉我。谁会去给我这样一个正经的人租一间漂亮的、无辜的住处呢！

‘You are very poor, ain’t you?’ says the constable.
“你很穷，不是吗？”警察说。

‘Yes, I am indeed, sir, wery poor in gin’ral,’ replies Jo. ‘I leave you to judge now! I shook these two half-crowns out of him,’ says the constable, producing them to the company, ‘in only putting my hand upon him!’
“是的，先生，我确实很穷金拉尔，”乔回答道。 ‘我现在就让你来判断吧！ “我从他身上甩掉了这两枚半克朗，”警官边说边把它们交给连队，“只是把手放在了他身上！”

‘They’re wot’s left, Mr. Snagsby,’ says Jo, ‘out of a sov-ring as wos give me by a lady in a wale as sed she wos a servant and as come to my crossin one night and asked to be showd this ‘ere ouse and the ouse wot him as you giv the writin to died at, and the berrin-ground wot he’s berrid in. She ses to me she ses ‘are you the boy at the inkwhich?’ she ses. I ses ‘yes’ I ses. She ses to me she ses ‘can you show me all them places?’ I ses ‘yes I can’ I ses. And she ses to me ‘do it’ and I dun it and she giv me a sov’ring and hooked it. And I an’t had much of the sov’ring neither,’ says Jo, with dirty tears, ‘fur I had to pay five bob, down in Tom-all-Alone’s, afore they’d square it fur to give me change, and then a young man he thieved another five while I was asleep and another boy he thieved ninepence and the landlord he stood drains round with a lot more on it.’
“斯纳格斯比先生，”乔说，“它们是一位威尔士女士送给我的戒指，她是一名仆人，有一天晚上来到我的十字路口，要求成为我的仆人。”向我展示了这一点，当你给他写下死亡的文字时，他的命运和他所陷入的柏林地面。她对我说，她是“你是那个墨水的男孩吗？”她说。我是‘是’我是。她对我说，“你能带我看看所有这些地方吗？”我对我说，“是的，我可以”。她对我说“做吧”，我催了款，她给了我一个索夫环并把它钩住了。我也没有太多的钱，”乔含着肮脏的泪水说，“但我得在汤姆孤身一人的店里付五个鲍勃，然后他们才会平价给我零钱。 ，然后他趁我睡着的时候又偷了一个年轻人五便士，又偷了另一个男孩九便士，他所在的房东在下水道周围还有更多东西。

‘You don’t expect anybody to believe this, about the lady and the sovereign, do you?’ says the constable, eyeing him aside with ineffable disdain.
“你不会指望有人会相信这位女士和君主的事吧？”警察说道，用难以形容的蔑视看着他。

‘I don’t know as I do, sir,’ replies Jo. ‘I don’t expect nothink at all, sir, much, but that’s the true hist’ry on it.’
“我不知道，先生，”乔回答道。 “先生，我根本没想到会发生什么，但这就是真实的历史。”

‘You see what he is!’ the constable observes to the audience. ‘Well, Mr. Snagsby, if I don’t lock him up this time, will you engage for his moving on?’
“你看他是什么人！”警员对观众说道。 “好吧，斯纳斯比先生，如果我这次不把他关起来，你会同意让他继续前进吗？”

‘No!’ cries Mrs. Snagsby from the stairs.
“不！”斯纳斯比夫人在楼梯上喊道。

‘My little woman!’ pleads her husband. ‘Constable, I have no doubt he’ll move on. You know you really must do it,’ says Mr. Snagsby.
“我的小女人！”她的丈夫恳求道。 “警员，我毫不怀疑他会继续前进。你知道你真的必须这样做，”斯纳斯比先生说。

‘I’m everyways agreeable, sir,’ says the hapless Jo.
“我总是很随和，先生，”倒霉的乔说道。

‘Do it, then,’ observes the constable. ‘You know what you have got to do. Do it! And recollect you won’t get off so easy next time. Catch hold of your money. Now, the sooner you’re five mile off, the better for all parties.’
“那就这么做吧，”警官说道。 ‘你知道你必须做什么。做吧！记住，下次你不会那么容易脱身了。抓住你的钱。现在，越早离开五英里，对各方都越好。

With this farewell hint and pointing generally to the setting sun as a likely place to move on to, the constable bids his auditors good afternoon and makes the echoes of Cook’s Court perform slow music for him as he walks away on the shady side, carrying his iron-bound hat in his hand for a little ventilation.
有了这个告别的暗示，并普遍指出夕阳下是一个可能继续前进的地方，警官向他的审计员道了下午好，并让库克法庭的回声为他演奏了缓慢的音乐，同时他背着他的书从阴凉的一边走开。手里拿着一顶铁帽子，稍微通风一下。

Now, Jo’s improbable story concerning the lady and the sovereign has awakened more or less the curiosity of all the company. Mr. Guppy, who has an inquiring mind in matters of evidence and who has been suffering severely from the lassitude of the long vacation, takes that interest in the case that he enters on a regular crossexamination of the witness, which is found so interesting by the ladies that Mrs. Snagsby politely invites him to step upstairs and drink a cup of tea, if he will excuse the disarranged state of the tea-table, consequent on their previous exertions. Mr. Guppy yielding his assent to this proposal, Jo is requested to follow into the drawing-room doorway, where Mr. Guppy takes him in hand as a witness, patting him into this shape, that shape, and the other shape like a butterman dealing with so much butter, and worrying him according to the best models. Nor is the examination unlike many such model displays, both in respect of its eliciting nothing and of its being lengthy, for Mr. Guppy is sensible of his talent, and Mrs. Snagsby feels not only that it gratifies her inquisitive disposition, but that it lifts her husband’s establishment higher up in the law. During the progress of this keen encounter, the vessel Chadband, being merely engaged in the oil trade, gets aground and waits to be floated off.
现在，乔讲述的贵妇与君主的匪夷所思的故事，或多或少地引起了所有人的好奇心。古比先生对证据问题有着好奇心，而且由于长假的倦怠而深受其害，他对案件产生了兴趣，因此他定期对证人进行盘问，这让他觉得很有趣。各位女士，斯纳斯比夫人礼貌地邀请他上楼喝杯茶，如果他能原谅她们之前劳累造成的茶桌凌乱的话。孔雀先生同意了这个提议，乔被要求跟着走进客厅门口，孔雀先生把他拉在手上作为见证人，把他拍成这个形状、那个形状、另一个形状，就像黄油小人一样处理这么多黄油，并根据最好的模型让他担心。这场考试也不像许多这样的模型展示，无论是在它没有引出什么内容还是在冗长方面，因为古皮先生对他的才华很敏感，斯纳斯比夫人觉得这不仅满足了她好奇的性格，而且在法律上提升了她丈夫的地位。在这次激烈的交锋过程中，仅从事石油贸易的查德邦号船搁浅并等待浮离。

‘Well!’ says Mr. Guppy. ‘Either this boy sticks to it like cobbler’s-wax or there is something out of the common here that beats anything that ever came into my way at Kenge and Carboy’s.’
“好吧！”古比先生说。 “要么是这个男孩像鞋匠的蜡一样坚持下去，要么是这里有一些不寻常的东西，打败了我在肯格和卡博伊店遇到的任何东西。”

Mrs. Chadband whispers Mrs. Snagsby, who exclaims, ‘You don’t say so!’
查德班德夫人低声对斯纳格斯比夫人耳语，斯纳格斯比夫人惊呼道：“你不是这么说的！”

‘For years!’ replied Mrs. Chadband.
“很多年了！”查德班德夫人回答道。

‘Has known Kenge and Carboy’s office for years,’ Mrs. Snagsby triumphantly explains to Mr. Guppy. ‘Mrs. Chadband—this gentleman’s wife—Reverend Mr. Chadband.’
“认识肯格和卡博伊的办公室很多年了，”斯纳格斯比夫人得意洋洋地向古比先生解释道。 '太太。查德班德——这位先生的妻子——查德班德牧师先生。

‘Oh, indeed!’ says Mr. Guppy.
“哦，确实如此！”古比先生说。

‘Before I married my present husband,’ says Mrs. Chadband.
“在我嫁给现在的丈夫之前，”查德班德夫人说。

‘Was you a party in anything, ma’am?’ says Mr. Guppy, transferring his cross-examination.
“女士，你参与过什么事情吗？”古皮先生一边说，一边转移他的盘问。

‘No.’
'不。'

‘NOT a party in anything, ma’am?’ says Mr. Guppy.
“女士，不参加任何聚会吗？”古比先生说。

Mrs. Chadband shakes her head.
查德班德夫人摇摇头。

‘Perhaps you were acquainted with somebody who was a party in something, ma’am?’ says Mr. Guppy, who likes nothing better than to model his conversation on forensic principles.
“也许您认识某个参与某件事的人，女士？”古皮先生说，他最喜欢按照法医原理来模拟他的谈话。

‘Not exactly that, either,’ replies Mrs. Chadband, humouring the joke with a hard-favoured smile.
“也不完全是这样，”查德班德夫人回答道，脸上带着勉强的微笑，幽默地调侃了这个笑话。

‘Not exactly that, either!’ repeats Mr. Guppy. ‘Very good. Pray, ma’am, was it a lady of your acquaintance who had some transactions (we will not at present say what transactions) with Kenge and Carboy’s office, or was it a gentleman of your acquaintance? Take time, ma’am. We shall come to it presently. Man or woman, ma’am?’
“也不完全是这样！”古比先生重复道。 '非常好。请问，女士，是您认识的一位女士与肯格和卡博伊的办公室进行了一些交易（我们目前不会透露什么交易），还是您认识的一位绅士？花点时间，女士。我们很快就会谈到这一点。女士，是男人还是女人？

‘Neither,’ says Mrs. Chadband as before.
“都不是，”查德班德夫人一如既往地说。

‘Oh! A child!’ says Mr. Guppy, throwing on the admiring Mrs. Snagsby the regular acute professional eye which is thrown on British jurymen. ‘Now, ma’am, perhaps you’ll have the kindness to tell us WHAT child.’
'哦！一个孩子！”古皮先生说道，同时用英国陪审员们惯用的敏锐专业眼光投向钦佩的斯纳斯比夫人。 “现在，女士，也许您能好心告诉我们，孩子是什么。”

‘You have got it at last, sir,’ says Mrs. Chadband with another hard-favoured smile. ‘Well, sir, it was before your time, most likely, judging from your appearance. I was left in charge of a child named Esther Summerson, who was put out in life by Messrs. Kenge and Carboy.’
“你终于得到了它，先生，”查德班德夫人说道，脸上又露出了一丝不易察觉的微笑。 “嗯，先生，从你的外表来看，很可能是在你之前。”我留下来照顾一个名叫埃丝特·萨默森的孩子，她被肯格和卡博伊先生赶走了。

‘Miss Summerson, ma’am!’ cries Mr. Guppy, excited.
“萨默森小姐，女士！”古皮先生兴奋地喊道。

‘I call her Esther Summerson,’ says Mrs. Chadband with austerity. ‘There was no Miss-ing of the girl in my time. It was Esther. ‘Esther, do this! Esther, do that!’ and she was made to do it.’
“我叫她艾丝特·萨默森，”查德班德夫人严肃地说。 “在我那个时代，从来没有失踪过这个女孩。”是埃丝特。 ‘艾丝特，这样做！以斯帖，就这么做！’她被迫这么做了。”

‘My dear ma’am,’ returns Mr. Guppy, moving across the small apartment, ‘the humble individual who now addresses you received that young lady in London when she first came here from the establishment to which you have alluded. Allow me to have the pleasure of taking you by the hand.’
“我亲爱的女士，”古比先生穿过小公寓回答道，“那位谦虚的人现在向您讲话，她在伦敦接待了那位年轻女士，当时她刚从您提到的机构来到这里。请允许我有幸牵着你的手。

Mr. Chadband, at last seeing his opportunity, makes his accustomed signal and rises with a smoking head, which he dabs with his pocket-handkerchief. Mrs. Snagsby whispers ‘Hush!’
查德班德先生终于看到了机会，他做出了惯常的手势，站起身来，头上冒着烟，他用口袋手帕擦了擦头。斯纳斯比夫人低声说：“嘘！”

‘My friends,’ says Chadband, ‘we have partaken in moderation’ (which was certainly not the case so far as he was concerned) ‘of the comforts which have been provided for us. May this house live upon the fatness of the land; may corn and wine be plentiful therein; may it grow, may it thrive, may it prosper, may it advance, may it proceed, may it press forward! But, my friends, have we partaken of any-hing else? We have. My friends, of what else have we partaken? Of spiritual profit? Yes. From whence have we derived that spiritual profit? My young friend, stand forth!’
“我的朋友们，”查德班德说，“我们适度地享受了”（就他而言，情况肯定不是这样）“为我们提供的舒适”。愿这座房子生活在肥沃的土地上；愿那里有充足的五谷和酒；愿它成长，愿它蓬勃发展，愿它繁荣，愿它前进，愿它前进，愿它前进！但是，我的朋友们，我们还参加过其他活动吗？我们有。我的朋友们，我们还参加了什么？精神利益？是的。我们从哪里获得这种精神利益呢？我的年轻朋友，站起来！

Jo, thus apostrophized, gives a slouch backward, and another slouch forward, and another slouch to each side, and confronts the eloquent Chadband with evident doubts of his intentions.
乔，如此撇号，向后一弯，向前一弯，再向两侧弯一弯，面对雄辩的查德班德，显然对他的意图表示怀疑。

‘My young friend,’ says Chadband, ‘you are to us a pearl, you are to us a diamond, you are to us a gem, you are to us a jewel. And why, my young friend?’
“我年轻的朋友，”查德班德说，“你对我们来说是一颗珍珠，对我们来说你是一颗钻石，你对我们来说是一颗宝石，你对我们来说是一颗宝石。为什么，我的年轻朋友？

‘I don’t know,’ replies Jo. ‘I don’t know nothink.’
“我不知道，”乔回答道。 “我不知道。”

‘My young friend,’ says Chadband, ‘it is because you know nothing that you are to us a gem and jewel. For what are you, my young friend? Are you a beast of the field? No. A bird of the air? No. A fish of the sea or river? No. You are a human boy, my young friend. A human boy. O glorious to be a human boy! And why glorious, my young friend? Because you are capable of receiving the lessons of wisdom, because you are capable of profiting by this discourse which I now deliver for your good, because you are not a stick, or a staff, or a stock, or a stone, or a post, or a pillar.
“我年轻的朋友，”查德班德说，“正是因为你一无所知，所以你对我们来说才是一颗宝石。”我年轻的朋友，你到底是为了什么？你是田野里的猛兽吗？不，空中的鸟？不，海里的鱼还是河里的鱼？不，你是一个人类男孩，我的年轻朋友。一个人类男孩。作为一个人类男孩多么光荣啊！为什么光荣呢，我年轻的朋友？因为你能够接受智慧的教训，因为你能够从我现在为你的利益而发表的这个演讲中受益，因为你不是一根棍子，或一根棍子，或一根股票，或一块石头，或一根柱子，或柱子。

O running stream of sparkling joy
哦，闪闪发光的欢乐之流

To be a soaring human boy!
做一个飞翔的人类少年！

And do you cool yourself in that stream now, my young friend? No. Why do you not cool yourself in that stream now? Because you are in a state of darkness, because you are in a state of obscurity, because you are in a state of sinfulness, because you are in a state of bondage. My young friend, what is bondage? Let us, in a spirit of love, inquire.’
我年轻的朋友，你现在在溪流中冷静下来了吗？不，你现在为什么不在溪流里冷静一下呢？因为你处于黑暗的状态，因为你处于默默无闻的状态，因为你处于罪恶的状态，因为你处于束缚的状态。我的年轻朋友，什么是束缚？让我们本着爱的精神来询问。
