At this threatening stage of the discourse, Jo, who seems to have been gradually going out of his mind, smears his right arm over his face and gives a terrible yawn. Mrs. Snagsby indignantly expresses her belief that he is a limb of the arch-fiend.
在谈话的这个威胁阶段，乔似乎已经逐渐失去了理智，他用右臂捂住了脸，打了一个可怕的哈欠。斯纳格斯比夫人愤怒地表示她相信他是大恶魔的一部分。

‘My friends,’ says Mr. Chadband with his persecuted chin folding itself into its fat smile again as he looks round, ‘it is right that I should be humbled, it is right that I should be tried, it is right that I should be mortified, it is right that I should be corrected. I stumbled, on Sabbath last, when I thought with pride of my three hours’ improving. The account is now favourably balanced: my creditor has accepted a composition. O let us be joyful, joyful! O let us be joyful!’
“我的朋友们，”查德班德先生环顾四周时，他那饱受折磨的下巴再次弯成胖胖的笑容，说道，“我应该感到谦卑，这是正确的，我应该受到审判，我应该接受审判，这是正确的。”感到羞愧，我应该被纠正是对的。上个安息日，当我自豪地想到我三个小时的进步时，我绊倒了。现在账户已经平衡：我的债权人已经接受了和解。噢，让我们喜乐、喜乐！噢，让我们快乐吧！

Great sensation on the part of Mrs. Snagsby.
斯纳斯比夫人引起了极大的轰动。

‘My friends,’ says Chadband, looking round him in conclusion, ‘I will not proceed with my young friend now. Will you come tomorrow, my young friend, and inquire of this good lady where I am to be found to deliver a discourse unto you, and will you come like the thirsty swallow upon the next day, and upon the day after that, and upon the day after that, and upon many pleasant days, to hear discourses?’ (This with a cow-like lightness.)
“我的朋友们，”查德班德环顾四周，最后说道，“我现在不会继续和我年轻的朋友在一起了。”我年轻的朋友，你明天会来询问这位善良的女士在哪里可以找到我给你演讲吗？你会像口渴的燕子一样在第二天、后天、最后一天来吗？在那之后的一天，以及许多愉快的日子里，来聆听开示？”（带着母牛般的轻松。）

Jo, whose immediate object seems to be to get away on any terms, gives a shuffling nod. Mr. Guppy then throws him a penny, and Mrs. Snagsby calls to Guster to see him safely out of the house. But before he goes downstairs, Mr. Snagsby loads him with some broken meats from the table, which he carries away, hugging in his arms.
乔的直接目标似乎是不惜一切代价逃脱，她拖着脚步点了点头。然后古比先生扔给他一分钱，斯纳斯比夫人打电话给古斯特，送他安全离开家。但在他下楼之前，斯纳斯比先生从桌子上拿了一些碎肉给他，他把它们抱在怀里带走了。

So, Mr. Chadband—of whom the persecutors say that it is no wonder he should go on for any length of time uttering such abominable nonsense, but that the wonder rather is that he should ever leave off, having once the audacity to begin—retires into private life until he invests a little capital of supper in the oil-trade. Jo moves on, through the long vacation, down to Blackfriars Bridge, where he finds a baking stony corner wherein to settle to his repast.
所以，查德班德先生——迫害者说，毫不奇怪他会继续说出如此令人憎恶的胡言乱语，但更奇怪的是，他曾经有过一次大胆的开始，竟然会停下来——退休后开始私人生活，直到他在石油贸易上投入了一点晚餐资金。乔继续前行，度过了漫长的假期，来到了布莱克法尔桥，在那里他找到了一个烘烤着石头的角落，在那里坐下来吃饭。

And there he sits, munching and gnawing, and looking up at the great cross on the summit of St. Paul’s Cathedral, glittering above a red-and-violet-tinted cloud of smoke. From the boy’s face one might suppose that sacred emblem to be, in his eyes, the crowning confusion of the great, confused city—so golden, so high up, so far out of his reach. There he sits, the sun going down, the river running fast, the crowd flowing by him in two streams—everything moving on to some purpose and to one end—until he is stirred up and told to ‘move on’ too.
他坐在那里，咀嚼着，抬头看着圣保罗大教堂顶上的巨大十字架，十字架在红紫色的烟雾中闪闪发光。从男孩的脸上，人们可能会认为，在他眼中，这个神圣的标志是这座伟大而混乱的城市的最高混乱——那么金色，那么高，那么遥不可及。他坐在那里，太阳落山，河水湍急，人群分两股从他身边流过——一切都在朝着某个目的和终点前进——直到他被激起并被告知也“继续前进”。

CHAPTER XX
第二十章


A New Lodger
新房客

The long vacation saunters on towards term-time like an idle river very leisurely strolling down a flat country to the sea. Mr. Guppy saunters along with it congenially. He has blunted the blade of his penknife and broken the point off by sticking that instrument into his desk in every direction. Not that he bears the desk any ill will, but he must do something, and it must be something of an unexciting nature, which will lay neither his physical nor his intellectual energies under too heavy contribution. He finds that nothing agrees with him so well as to make little gyrations on one leg of his stool, and stab his desk, and gape.
漫长的假期慢慢地临近学期，就像一条闲置的河流，悠闲地沿着平坦的乡村流向大海。孔雀鱼先生和蔼可亲地跟着它闲逛。他把小刀的刀刃弄钝了，并通过将小刀从各个方向插入办公桌来折断刀尖。并不是说他对办公桌怀有恶意，而是他必须做点什么，而且必须是一些平淡无奇的事情，这样既不会让他的体力和智力承担过重的负担。他发现没有什么比在凳子的一条腿上稍微旋转一下、刺伤桌子、目瞪口呆更适合他的了。

Kenge and Carboy are out of town, and the articled clerk has taken out a shooting license and gone down to his father’s, and Mr. Guppy’s two fellow-stipendiaries are away on leave. Mr. Guppy and Mr. Richard Carstone divide the dignity of the office. But Mr. Carstone is for the time being established in Kenge’s room, whereat Mr. Guppy chafes. So exceedingly that he with biting sarcasm informs his mother, in the confidential moments when he sups with her off a lobster and lettuce in the Old Street Road, that he is afraid the office is hardly good enough for swells, and that if he had known there was a swell coming, he would have got it painted.
肯格和卡博伊出城了，那位文章中的职员已经拿出了射击执照，去了他父亲的那儿，而古比先生的两位领取薪水的同事正在休假。古比先生和理查德·卡斯通先生瓜分了办公室的尊严。但卡斯通先生暂时住在肯吉的房间里，古比先生对此很恼火。如此极端，以至于当他与母亲在老街路一起吃龙虾和生菜时，他带着尖刻的讽刺告诉他的母亲，他担心办公室不足以容纳膨胀，如果他知道的话潮水即将来临，他会把它漆掉的。

Mr. Guppy suspects everybody who enters on the occupation of a stool in Kenge and Carboy’s office of entertaining, as a matter of course, sinister designs upon him. He is clear that every such person wants to depose him. If he be ever asked how, why, when, or wherefore, he shuts up one eye and shakes his head. On the strength of these profound views, he in the most ingenious manner takes infinite pains to counterplot when there is no plot, and plays the deepest games of chess without any adversary.
古比先生怀疑所有进入肯格和卡博伊办公室的人都是为了招待他，当然，他们对他怀有险恶的阴谋。他很清楚，每一个这样的人都想废黜他。如果有人问他如何、为什么、何时或为何，他就会闭上一只眼睛并摇摇头。凭借这些深刻的见解，他以最巧妙的方式在无情节时煞费苦心地进行反制，在没有对手的情况下下一盘最深的棋。

It is a source of much gratification to Mr. Guppy, therefore, to find the new-comer constantly poring over the papers in Jarndyce and Jarndyce, for he well knows that nothing but confusion and failure can come of that. His satisfaction communicates itself to a third saunterer through the long vacation in Kenge and Carboy’s office, to wit, Young Smallweed.
因此，让古比先生感到非常欣慰的是，新来的人不断地研读《加迪斯》和《加迪斯》的论文，因为他很清楚，这样做只会带来混乱和失败。他的满足感传达给了肯格和卡博伊办公室里的第三位闲逛者，即年轻的斯莫威德。

Whether Young Smallweed (metaphorically called Small and eke Chick Weed, as it were jocularly to express a fledgling) was ever a boy is much doubted in Lincoln’s Inn. He is now something under fifteen and an old limb of the law. He is facetiously understood to entertain a passion for a lady at a cigar-shop in the neighbourhood of Chancery Lane and for her sake to have broken off a contract with another lady, to whom he had been engaged some years. He is a town-made article, of small stature and weazen features, but may be perceived from a considerable distance by means of his very tall hat. To become a Guppy is the object of his ambition. He dresses at that gentleman (by whom he is patronized), talks at him, walks at him, founds himself entirely on him. He is honoured with Mr. Guppy’s particular confidence and occasionally advises him, from the deep wells of his experience, on difficult points in private life.
在林肯客栈，年轻的小草（被比喻为“小小”和“小鸡草”，因为它被戏谑地表达了雏鸟）是否曾经是一个男孩，人们非常怀疑。他现在还不到十五岁，已经是法律的老犯了。人们开玩笑地认为，他在大法官巷附近的一家雪茄店里对一位女士产生了热情，并为了她而与另一位已订婚多年的女士解除了合同。他是镇上的人物，身材矮小，面容苍白，但通过他很高的帽子，从很远的地方就可以看到他。成为孔雀鱼是他的野心目标。他对那位绅士（他受到他的庇护）着装，对他说话，对他行走，发现自己完全依赖于他。他对古比先生的特别信任感到荣幸，并偶尔根据他丰富的经验，就私人生活中的困难问题向他提出建议。

Mr. Guppy has been lolling out of window all the morning after trying all the stools in succession and finding none of them easy, and after several times putting his head into the iron safe with a notion of cooling it. Mr. Smallweed has been twice dispatched for effervescent drinks, and has twice mixed them in the two official tumblers and stirred them up with the ruler. Mr. Guppy propounds for Mr. Smallweed’s consideration the paradox that the more you drink the thirstier you are and reclines his head upon the windowsill in a state of hopeless languor.
古比先生一上午都懒洋洋地躺在窗外，他连续尝试了所有的凳子，发现没有一个容易做，并且几次把头伸进铁保险箱里，想给它降温。 Smallweed 先生曾两次被派去购买泡腾饮料，并两次将它们混合在两个官方玻璃杯中并用尺子搅拌。古皮先生向斯莫威德先生提出了一个悖论，即你喝得越多就越渴，他把头靠在窗台上，一副绝望的倦怠状态。

While thus looking out into the shade of Old Square, Lincoln’s Inn, surveying the intolerable bricks and mortar, Mr. Guppy becomes conscious of a manly whisker emerging from the cloistered walk below and turning itself up in the direction of his face. At the same time, a low whistle is wafted through the Inn and a suppressed voice cries, ‘Hip! Gup-py!’
当孔雀先生眺望林肯旅馆老广场的阴凉处，审视令人难以忍受的砖块和灰浆时，他意识到一根有男子气概的胡须从下面与世隔绝的小道上伸出，并朝他脸的方向翘起。与此同时，一声低沉的哨声在客栈中响起，一个压抑的声音喊道：“嗨！”孔雀鱼！’

‘Why, you don’t mean it!’ says Mr. Guppy, aroused. ‘Small! Here’s Jobling!’ Small’s head looks out of window too and nods to Jobling.
“哎呀，你不是这个意思！”古比先生兴奋地说。 '小的！这是乔布林！”斯莫尔也把头望向窗外，向乔布林点点头。

‘Where have you sprung up from?’ inquires Mr. Guppy.
“你从哪里冒出来的？”古比先生问道。

‘From the market-gardens down by Deptford. I can’t stand it any longer. I must enlist. I say! I wish you’d lend me half a crown. Upon my soul, I’m hungry.’
“从德普特福德下面的市场花园开始。”我再也受不了了。我必须入伍。我说！我希望你能借我半克朗。我的灵魂深处，我很饿。

Jobling looks hungry and also has the appearance of having run to seed in the market-gardens down by Deptford.
乔布林看起来很饿，而且还像是在德特福德附近的市场花园里撒种的样子。

‘I say! Just throw out half a crown if you have got one to spare. I want to get some dinner.’
'我说！如果你还有多余的，就扔掉半克朗吧。我想吃点晚饭。

‘Will you come and dine with me?’ says Mr. Guppy, throwing out the coin, which Mr. Jobling catches neatly.
“你愿意来和我一起吃饭吗？”古比先生说着，扔出了硬币，被乔布林先生巧妙地接住了。

‘How long should I have to hold out?’ says Jobling.
“我必须坚持多久？”乔布林说。

‘Not half an hour. I am only waiting here till the enemy goes, returns Mr. Guppy, butting inward with his head.
‘不到半小时。 “我只是在这里等敌人走，”孔雀鱼先生返回，用头向内撞。

‘What enemy?’
“什么敌人？”

‘A new one. Going to be articled. Will you wait?’
‘一个新的。即将发表文章。你会等吗？

‘Can you give a fellow anything to read in the meantime?’ says Mr Jobling.
乔布林先生说：“你能给一个人提供一些东西让他们同时阅读吗？”

Smallweed suggests the law list. But Mr. Jobling declares with much earnestness that he ‘can’t stand it.’
Smallweed 建议法律清单。但乔布林先生非常认真地宣称他“无法忍受”。

‘You shall have the paper,’ says Mr. Guppy. ‘He shall bring it down. But you had better not be seen about here. Sit on our staircase and read. It’s a quiet place.’
“你应该拿到那张纸，”古比先生说。 ‘他会把它打倒的。但你最好不要在这里被发现。坐在我们的楼梯上读书。这是一个安静的地方。

Jobling nods intelligence and acquiescence. The sagacious Smallweed supplies him with the newspaper and occasionally drops his eye upon him from the landing as a precaution against his becoming disgusted with waiting and making an untimely departure. At last the enemy retreats, and then Smallweed fetches Mr. Jobling up.
乔布林点头表示同意。聪明的斯莫威德给他提供了报纸，并偶尔在楼梯平台上注视着他，以防他因等待而感到厌恶并不合时宜地离开。最后敌人撤退了，然后斯莫威德把乔布林先生救了上来。

‘Well, and how are you?’ says Mr. Guppy, shaking hands with him.
“嗯，你好吗？”古比先生一边说，一边与他握手。

‘So, so. How are you?’
'一般般。你好吗？'

Mr. Guppy replying that he is not much to boast of, Mr. Jobling ventures on the question, ‘How is SHE?’ This Mr. Guppy resents as a liberty, retorting, ‘Jobling, there ARE chords in the human mind—‘ Jobling begs pardon.
古比先生回答说他没什么值得夸耀的，乔布林先生大胆地问了一个问题：“她怎么样？”古比先生厌恶这种自由，反驳道：“乔布林，人类的心灵里有和弦——”乔布林请求原谅。

‘Any subject but that!’ says Mr. Guppy with a gloomy enjoyment of his injury. ‘For there ARE chords, Jobling—‘
“除了这个以外，什么话题都可以！”古比先生说道，他对自己的受伤感到忧郁。 “因为有和弦，乔布林——”

Mr. Jobling begs pardon again.
乔布林先生再次请求原谅。

During this short colloquy, the active Smallweed, who is of the dinner party, has written in legal characters on a slip of paper, ‘Return immediately.’ This notification to all whom it may concern, he inserts in the letter-box, and then putting on the tall hat at the angle of inclination at which Mr. Guppy wears his, informs his patron that they may now make themselves scarce.
在这次简短的谈话中，参加晚宴的活跃分子斯莫尔韦德在一张纸条上用合法字符写下了“立即返回”。然后以孔雀先生所戴帽子的倾斜角度戴上高帽子，告诉他的赞助人，他们现在可以让自己变得稀缺。

Accordingly they betake themselves to a neighbouring dining-house, of the class known among its frequenters by the denomination slapbang, where the waitress, a bouncing young female of forty, is supposed to have made some impression on the susceptible Smallweed, of whom it may be remarked that he is a weird changeling to whom years are nothing. He stands precociously possessed of centuries of owlish wisdom. If he ever lay in a cradle, it seems as if he must have lain there in a tail-coat. He has an old, old eye, has Smallweed; and he drinks and smokes in a monkeyish way; and his neck is stiff in his collar; and he is never to be taken in; and he knows all about it, whatever it is. In short, in his bringing up he has been so nursed by Law and Equity that he has become a kind of fossil imp, to account for whose terrestrial existence it is reported at the public offices that his father was John Doe and his mother the only female member of the Roe family, also that his first long-clothes were made from a blue bag.
因此，他们去了附近的一家餐馆，这家餐馆的常客们都知道这家餐馆的名字叫“slapbang”，那里的女服务员是一位活泼的四十岁年轻女性，据说给易受影响的斯莫威德留下了一些印象，她可能值得注意的是，他是一个奇怪的换生灵，岁月对他来说不算什么。他早熟地拥有几个世纪的猫头鹰智慧。如果他曾经躺在摇篮里，那么他似乎一定是穿着燕尾服躺在那里。他有一双老眼睛，有小草；他像猴子一样喝酒、抽烟；他的脖子在衣领里僵硬；他永远不会被欺骗；他知道这一切，无论是什么。简而言之，在他的成长过程中，他一直受到法律和公平的养育，以至于他已经成为一种化石小恶魔，为了解释其在地球上的存在，据公共办公室报道，他的父亲是约翰·多伊，而他的母亲是唯一的母亲。罗伊家族的女性成员，还说他的第一件长衣服是用蓝色袋子制成的。

Into the dining-house, unaffected by the seductive show in the window of artificially whitened cauliflowers and poultry, verdant baskets of peas, coolly blooming cucumbers, and joints ready for the spit, Mr. Smallweed leads the way. They know him there and defer to him. He has his favourite box, he bespeaks all the papers, he is down upon bald patriarchs, who keep them more than ten minutes afterwards. It is of no use trying him with anything less than a full-sized ‘bread’ or proposing to him any joint in cut unless it is in the very best cut. In the matter of gravy he is adamant.
斯莫尔威德先生在前面带路，走进餐厅，橱窗里摆满了人工增白的花椰菜和家禽、一篮子翠绿的豌豆、凉爽绽放的黄瓜和准备上桌的大块大麻籽，丝毫没有受到这些诱惑的影响。他们在那里认识他并服从他。他有他最喜欢的盒子，他写了所有的文件，他对秃顶的族长很瞧不起，他们在十多分钟后就把它们保留了。尝试他用任何小于全尺寸“面包”的东西或向他建议任何切块都是没有用的，除非它是最好的切块。在肉汁问题上，他态度坚决。

Conscious of his elfin power and submitting to his dread experience, Mr. Guppy consults him in the choice of that day’s banquet, turning an appealing look towards him as the waitress repeats the catalogue of viands and saying ‘What do YOU take, Chick?’ Chick, out of the profundity of his artfulness, preferring ‘veal and ham and French beans—and don’t you forget the stuffing, Polly’ (with an unearthly cock of his venerable eye), Mr. Guppy and Mr. Jobling give the like order. Three pint pots of half-and-half are superadded. Quickly the waitress returns bearing what is apparently a model of the Tower of Babel but what is really a pile of plates and flat tin dish-covers. Mr. Smallweed, approving of what is set before him, conveys intelligent benignity into his ancient eye and winks upon her. Then, amid a constant coming in, and going out, and running about, and a clatter of crockery, and a rumbling up and down of the machine which brings the nice cuts from the kitchen, and a shrill crying for more nice cuts down the speaking-pipe, and a shrill reckoning of the cost of nice cuts that have been disposed of, and a general flush and steam of hot joints, cut and uncut, and a considerably heated atmosphere in which the soiled knives and tablecloths seem to break out spontaneously into eruptions of grease and blotches of beer, the legal triumvirate appease their appetites.
意识到自己的精灵力量并屈服于他可怕的经历，孔比先生在选择当天的宴会时向他咨询，当女服务员重复菜单上的食物并问道“你要吃什么，小鸡？”时，孔皮先生向他投来了恳求的目光。奇克出于他的狡猾之深，更喜欢“小牛肉、火腿和四季豆——还有你别忘了馅料，波利”（他那双令人尊敬的眼睛充满了神秘的公鸡），古皮先生和乔布林先生给了喜欢订单。添加了三品脱罐的各半。很快，女服务员回来了，手里拿着的东西显然是巴别塔的模型，但实际上是一堆盘子和扁平的锡盘盖。斯莫威德先生对眼前的一切表示赞同，他那双古老的眼睛里流露出聪明的仁慈，并对她眨了眨眼。然后，在不断地进出、跑来跑去的声音中，伴随着陶器的叮当声，机器的上下隆隆声，从厨房送来漂亮的切菜，还有尖叫声要求更多更好的切菜。说话管，对已处理掉的漂亮切口的成本进行尖锐的计算，对已切和未切的热接缝进行全面的冲洗和蒸汽，以及相当炎热的气氛，在这种气氛中，肮脏的刀具和桌布似乎要爆发出来合法的三巨头会自发地喷出油脂和啤酒，以满足他们的食欲。

Mr. Jobling is buttoned up closer than mere adornment might require. His hat presents at the rims a peculiar appearance of a glistening nature, as if it had been a favourite snail-promenade. The same phenomenon is visible on some parts of his coat, and particularly at the seams. He has the faded appearance of a gentleman in embarrassed circumstances; even his light whiskers droop with something of a shabby air.
乔布林先生的扣扣比单纯的装饰要求的要严密。他的帽子边缘呈现出一种闪闪发光的奇特外观，仿佛这是一条最喜欢的蜗牛散步。在他外套的某些部分，尤其是接缝处，也可以看到同样的现象。他有一种在尴尬的情况下褪色的绅士外表；就连浅色的胡须都耷拉着，显得有些破旧。

His appetite is so vigorous that it suggests spare living for some little time back. He makes such a speedy end of his plate of veal and ham, bringing it to a close while his companions are yet midway in theirs, that Mr. Guppy proposes another. ‘Thank you, Guppy,’ says Mr. Jobling, ‘I really don’t know but what I WILL take another.’
他的胃口如此旺盛，这表明他在不久的将来会过着悠闲的生活。他很快就把一盘小牛肉和火腿吃完了，而他的同伴们还没有吃到一半，孔雀鱼先生就提议再来一份。 “谢谢你，古比，”乔布林先生说，“我真的不知道我还要再拿什么。”

Another being brought, he falls to with great goodwill.
另一个人被带来，他怀着极大的善意。

Mr. Guppy takes silent notice of him at intervals until he is half way through this second plate and stops to take an enjoying pull at his pint pot of half-and-half (also renewed) and stretches out his legs and rubs his hands. Beholding him in which glow of contentment, Mr. Guppy says, ‘You are a man again, Tony!’
孔雀鱼先生时不时地默默地注意他，直到他吃完第二盘的一半，停下来享受他的一品脱壶对半的饮料（也更新了），然后伸出双腿，揉搓双手。看着他脸上洋溢着满足的光芒，古比先生说道：“托尼，你又是一个男人了！”

‘Well, not quite yet,’ says Mr. Jobling. ‘Say, just born.’
“嗯，还没有，”乔布林先生说。 “说吧，刚出生。”

‘Will you take any other vegetables? Grass? Peas? Summer cabbage?’
“你还要吃其他蔬菜吗？草？豌豆？夏天的卷心菜？

‘Thank you, Guppy,’ says Mr. Jobling. ‘I really don’t know but what I WILL take summer cabbage.’
“谢谢你，古比，”乔布林先生说。 “我真的不知道我会吃什么夏季卷心菜。”

Order given; with the sarcastic addition (from Mr. Smallweed) of ‘Without slugs, Polly!’ And cabbage produced.
已发出命令；加上讽刺的补充（来自斯莫威德先生）“没有蛞蝓，波莉！”然后卷心菜就生产出来了。

‘I am growing up, Guppy,’ says Mr. Jobling, plying his knife and fork with a relishing steadiness.
“我正在长大，孔雀鱼，”乔布林先生一边说，一边用他的刀叉以一种令人愉快的稳定状态使用着。

‘Glad to hear it.’
'听到那个消息很开心。'

‘In fact, I have just turned into my teens,’ says Mr. Jobling.
“事实上，我刚刚进入青少年时期，”乔布林先生说。

He says no more until he has performed his task, which he achieves as Messrs. Guppy and Smallweed finish theirs, thus getting over the ground in excellent style and beating those two gentlemen easily by a veal and ham and a cabbage.
他没有再说什么，直到他完成了他的任务，当孔雀鱼和斯莫威德先生完成了他们的任务时，他就完成了任务，从而以出色的风格取得了进展，并以小牛肉、火腿和卷心菜轻松击败了那两位先生。

‘Now, Small,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘what would you recommend about pastry?’
“现在，斯莫尔，”古比先生说，“你对糕点有何推荐？”

‘Marrow puddings,’ says Mr. Smallweed instantly.
“骨髓布丁，”斯莫威德先生立即说道。

‘Aye, aye!’ cries Mr. Jobling with an arch look. ‘You’re there, are you? Thank you, Mr. Guppy, I don’t know but what I WILL take a marrow pudding.’
“是啊，是啊！”乔布林先生一脸弓着脸喊道。 ‘你在那儿，是吗？谢谢你，古比先生，我不知道我要吃什么骨髓布丁。

Three marrow puddings being produced, Mr. Jobling adds in a pleasant humour that he is coming of age fast. To these succeed, by command of Mr. Smallweed, ‘three Cheshires,’ and to those ‘three small rums.’ This apex of the entertainment happily reached, Mr. Jobling puts up his legs on the carpeted seat (having his own side of the box to himself), leans against the wall, and says, ‘I am grown up now, Guppy. I have arrived at maturity.’
正在制作三块骨髓布丁，乔布林先生以愉快的幽默方式补充道，他很快就会成熟。为了使这些成功，在斯莫威德先生的指挥下，“三个柴郡”和“三个小朗姆酒”。娱乐活动愉快地达到了顶峰，乔布林先生把腿放在铺着地毯的座位上（他自己的一侧有盒子留给自己），靠在墙上说：“我现在长大了，孔雀鱼。”我已经成熟了。

‘What do you think, now,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘about—you don’t mind Smallweed?’
“现在，你觉得怎么样？”孔雀先生说，“你不介意斯莫威德吗？”

‘Not the least in the worid. I have the pleasure of drinking his good health.’
'这在世界上并不是最不重要的。我很高兴为他的健康干杯。

‘Sir, to you!’ says Mr. Smallweed.
“先生，您好！”斯莫威德先生说道。

‘I was saying, what do you think NOW,’ pursues Mr. Guppy, ‘of enlisting?’
“我是说，你现在觉得入伍怎么样？”古皮先生继续说道。

‘Why, what I may think after dinner,’ returns Mr. Jobling, ‘is one thing, my dear Guppy, and what I may think before dinner is another thing. Still, even after dinner, I ask myself the question, What am I to do? How am I to live? Ill fo manger, you know,’ says Mr. Jobling, pronouncing that word as if he meant a necessary fixture in an English stable. ‘Ill fo manger. That’s the French saying, and mangering is as necessary to me as it is to a Frenchman. Or more so.’
“哎呀，晚饭后我可能想的事情，”乔布林先生回答道，“是一回事，亲爱的孔雀鱼，而晚饭前我可能想的事情又是另一回事了。尽管如此，即使在晚饭后，我也会问自己这个问题：我该怎么办？我该如何生活？ “Ill fo manger，你知道的，”乔布林先生说，他的这个词的发音就好像他指的是英国马厩里的必备设施一样。 ‘马槽有病。这是法国人的俗话，管理对我和法国人来说都是必要的。或者更是如此。

Mr. Smallweed is decidedly of opinion ‘much more so.’
Smallweed 先生的观点显然“更是如此”。

‘If any man had told me,’ pursues Jobling, ‘even so lately as when you and I had the frisk down in Lincolnshire, Guppy, and drove over to see that house at Castle Wold—‘
“如果有人告诉我，”乔布林继续说道，“即使是最近，当你和我在林肯郡搜查孔雀鱼，然后开车去看沃尔德城堡的那所房子时——”

Mr. Smallweed corrects him—Chesney Wold.
斯莫威德先生纠正了他——切斯尼·沃尔德。

‘Chesney Wold. (I thank my honourable friend for that cheer.) If any man had told me then that I should be as hard up at the present time as I literally find myself, I should have—well, I should have pitched into him,’ says Mr. Jobling, taking a little rum-and-water with an air of desperate resignation; ‘I should have let fly at his head.’
‘切斯尼沃尔德。 （我感谢我尊敬的朋友的欢呼。）如果当时有人告诉我，我现在应该像我自己发现的那样困难，我应该——好吧，我应该向他投球，”说乔布林先生，带着绝望的无奈，喝了一点朗姆酒和水。 “我应该朝他的头放飞的。”

‘Still, Tony, you were on the wrong side of the post then,’ remonstrates Mr. Guppy. ‘You were talking about nothing else in the gig.’
“不过，托尼，你当时站在了错误的一边，”古皮先生抗议道。 “你在演出中没有谈论任何其他事情。”

‘Guppy,’ says Mr. Jobling, ‘I will not deny it. I was on the wrong side of the post. But I trusted to things coming round.’
“孔雀鱼，”乔布林先生说，“我不会否认这一点。我站在了帖子的错误一边。但我相信即将发生的事情。

That very popular trust in flat things coming round! Not in their being beaten round, or worked round, but in their ‘coming’ round! As though a lunatic should trust in the world’s ‘coming’ triangular!
人们对扁平事物的普遍信任即将到来！不是他们被打败，或者被工作，而是他们“来”了！就好像一个疯子应该相信世界‘即将到来’的三角形一样！

‘I had confident expectations that things would come round and be all square,’ says Mr. Jobling with some vagueness of expression and perhaps of meaning too. ‘But I was disappointed. They never did. And when it came to creditors making rows at the office and to people that the office dealt with making complaints about dirty trifles of borrowed money, why there was an end of that connexion. And of any new professional connexion too, for if I was to give a reference to-morrow, it would be mentioned and would sew me up. Then what’s a fellow to do? I have been keeping out of the way and living cheap down about the market-gardens, but what’s the use of living cheap when you have got no money? You might as well live dear.’
“我满怀信心地期望事情会好转，一切顺利。”乔布林先生说道，语气有些含糊，也许意思也含糊不清。 ‘但我很失望。他们从来没有这样做过。当债权人在办公室里争吵，以及与办公室打交道的人抱怨借钱的肮脏小事时，为什么这种联系会结束呢？还有任何新的专业联系，因为如果我明天要提供参考，它就会被提及，并且会把我缝合起来。那么，一个人该怎么办呢？我一直不碍事，在市场花园附近过着廉价的生活，但是当你没有钱的时候，过着廉价的生活有什么用呢？你还不如亲爱的生活。

‘Better,’ Mr. Smallweed thinks.
“更好了，”斯莫威德先生想。

‘Certainly. It’s the fashionable way; and fashion and whiskers have been my weaknesses, and I don’t care who knows it,’ says Mr. Jobling. ‘They are great weaknesses—Damme, sir, they are great. Well,’ proceeds Mr. Jobling after a defiant visit to his rum-andwater, ‘what can a fellow do, I ask you, BUT enlist?’
'当然。这是一种时尚的方式； “时尚和胡须一直是我的弱点，我不在乎谁知道这一点，”乔布林先生说。 “它们是巨大的弱点——达姆，先生，它们是伟大的。”好吧，”乔布林先生在喝完朗姆酒和水后继续说道，“我问你，一个人除了入伍还能做什么？

Mr. Guppy comes more fully into the conversation to state what, in his opinion, a fellow can do. His manner is the gravely impressive manner of a man who has not committed himself in life otherwise than as he has become the victim of a tender sorrow of the heart.
古比先生更全面地介入谈话，阐述他认为一个人可以做什么。他的举止是一种令人印象深刻的举止，一个人在生活中除了成为内心温柔悲伤的受害者之外，没有任何承诺。

‘Jobling,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘myself and our mutual friend Smallweed—‘
“工作，”古皮先生说，“我和我们共同的朋友斯莫威德——”

Mr. Smallweed modestly observes, ‘Gentlemen both!’ and drinks.
斯莫威德先生谦虚地说道：“两位先生！”然后喝了一杯。

‘—Have had a little conversation on this matter more than once since you—‘
“——自从你——以来，我们已经不止一次地就这件事进行过一些交谈了——”

‘Say, got the sack!’ cries Mr. Jobling bitterly. ‘Say it, Guppy. You mean it.’
“喂，被解雇了！”乔布林先生痛苦地喊道。 ‘说吧，古比。你是认真的。

‘No-o-o! Left the Inn,’ Mr. Smallweed delicately suggests.
‘不——哦——哦！离开旅馆，”斯莫威德先生微妙地建议道。

‘Since you left the Inn, Jobling,’ says Mr. Guppy; ‘and I have mentioned to our mutual friend Smallweed a plan I have lately thought of proposing. You know Snagsby the stationer?’
“乔布林，自从你离开旅馆以来，”古比先生说道。 “我向我们共同的朋友斯莫威德提到了我最近想提出的一个计划。你认识文具店斯纳斯比吗？

‘I know there is such a stationer,’ returns Mr. Jobling. ‘He was not ours, and I am not acquainted with him.’
“我知道有这样一个文具店，”乔布林先生回答道。 “他不是我们的，我也不认识他。”

‘He IS ours, Jobling, and I AM acquainted with him,’ Mr. Guppy retorts. ‘Well, sir! I have lately become better acquainted with him through some accidental circumstances that have made me a visitor of his in private life. Those circumstances it is not necessary to offer in argument. They may—or they may not—have some reference to a subject which may—or may not—have cast its shadow on my existence.’
“他是我们的，乔布林，我很熟悉他，”古皮先生反驳道。 ‘好吧，先生！最近，由于一些偶然的情况，我对他有了更多的了解，使我成为他私生活中的访客。这些情况没有必要在论证中提出。他们可能——也可能没有——提到了一个可能——也可能没有——给我的存在投下阴影的主题。

As it is Mr. Guppy’s perplexing way with boastful misery to tempt his particular friends into this subject, and the moment they touch it, to turn on them with that trenchant severity about the chords in the human mind, both Mr. Jobling and Mr. Smallweed decline the pitfall by remaining silent.
顾比先生用一种令人费解的方式，用自吹自擂的痛苦引诱他的特定朋友进入这个话题，而当他们触及这个话题时，他又以对人类心灵中的和弦的那种尖锐严厉的态度来攻击他们，乔布林先生和乔布林先生都如此。 Smallweed 通过保持沉默来避免陷入陷阱。

‘Such things may be,’ repeats Mr. Guppy, ‘or they may not be. They are no part of the case. It is enough to mention that both Mr. and Mrs. Snagsby are very willing to oblige me and that Snagsby has, in busy times, a good deal of copying work to give out. He has all Tulkinghorn’s, and an excellent business besides. I believe if our mutual friend Smallweed were put into the box, he could prove this?’
“这样的事情可能是，”古比先生重复道，“也可能不是。他们不属于此案。值得一提的是，斯纳格斯比先生和夫人都非常愿意帮助我，而且斯纳格斯比在繁忙的时候有大量的复印工作要做。他拥有图金霍恩的一切，此外还有一笔出色的生意。我相信如果我们共同的朋友 Smallweed 被放进盒子里，他可以证明这一点吗？

Mr. Smallweed nods and appears greedy to be sworn.
斯莫威德先生点点头，似乎很想宣誓。

‘Now, gentlemen of the jury,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘—I mean, now, Jobling—you may say this is a poor prospect of a living. Granted. But it’s better than nothing, and better than enlistment. You want time. There must be time for these late affairs to blow over. You might live through it on much worse terms than by writing for Snagsby.’
“现在，陪审团的先生们，”古皮先生说，“——我的意思是，现在，乔布林——你可能会说这是一种糟糕的生活前景。”的确。但这总比什么都没有好，也比入伍好。你想要时间。这些迟来的事情必须有时间平息。你可能会以比为 Snagsby 写作更糟糕的方式度过这一切。

Mr. Jobling is about to interrupt when the sagacious Smallweed checks him with a dry cough and the words, ‘Hem! Shakspeare!’
乔布林先生正要打断他的话，聪明的小威德干咳一声制止了他，并说道：“哼！”莎士比亚！’

‘There are two branches to this subject, Jobling,’ says Mr. Guppy. ‘That is the first. I come to the second. You know Krook, the Chancellor, across the lane. Come, Jobling,’ says Mr. Guppy in his encouraging cross-examination-tone, ‘I think you know Krook, the Chancellor, across the lane?’
“乔布林，这个主题有两个分支，”古比先生说。 ‘这是第一件事。我来谈谈第二个。你认识对面的财政大臣克鲁克。来吧，乔布林，”古皮先生用鼓励的盘问语气说道，“我想你认识对面巷子里的财政大臣克鲁克？”

‘I know him by sight,’ says Mr. Jobling.
“我一眼就认出了他，”乔布林先生说。

‘You know him by sight. Very well. And you know little Flite?’
‘你一眼就认识他了。很好。你认识小弗利特吗？

‘Everybody knows her,’ says Mr. Jobling.
“每个人都认识她，”乔布林先生说。

‘Everybody knows her. VERY well. Now it has been one of my duties of late to pay Flite a certain weekly allowance, deducting from it the amount of her weekly rent, which I have paid (in consequence of instructions I have received) to Krook himself, regularly in her presence. This has brought me into communication with Krook and into a knowledge of his house and his habits. I know he has a room to let. You may live there at a very low charge under any name you like, as quietly as if you were a hundred miles off. He’ll ask no questions and would accept you as a tenant at a word from me— before the clock strikes, if you chose. And I tell you another thing, Jobling,’ says Mr. Guppy, who has suddenly lowered his voice and become familiar again, ‘he’s an extraordinary old chap—always rummaging among a litter of papers and grubbing away at teaching himself to read and write, without getting on a bit, as it seems to me. He is a most extraordinary old chap, sir. I don’t know but what it might be worth a fellow’s while to look him up a bit.’
‘每个人都认识她。很好。现在，我最近的职责之一是向弗莱特支付一定的每周津贴，从中扣除她每周的租金，我已经（根据我收到的指示）向克鲁克本人支付了租金，定期当着她的面。这让我与克鲁克有了交流，了解了他的房子和他的习惯。我知道他有房间出租。您可以以非常低的费用以任何您喜欢的名字住在那里，就像您在一百英里外一样安静。他不会问任何问题，只要我一声令下，他就会接受你作为房客——如果你愿意的话，在时钟敲响之前。我告诉你另一件事，乔布林，”古比先生突然压低了声音，又变得熟悉起来，“他是个了不起的老家伙——总是在一堆文件中翻找，苦苦自学读书写字。 ，在我看来，没有一点进展。先生，他是一位非常了不起的老伙计。我不知道，但一个人花时间去查查他到底值不值得。”

‘You don’t mean—‘ Mr. Jobling begins.
“你的意思不是——”乔布林先生开始说道。

‘I mean,’ returns Mr. Guppy, shrugging his shoulders with becoming modesty, ‘that I can’t make him out. I appeal to our mutual friend Smallweed whether he has or has not heard me remark that I can’t make him out.’
“我的意思是，”古比先生回答道，他谦虚地耸了耸肩，“我认不出他来。”我向我们共同的朋友斯莫威德求助，无论他是否听到我说我听不清他。

Mr. Smallweed bears the concise testimony, ‘A few!’
斯莫威德先生作了简洁的证言：“有一些！”

‘I have seen something of the profession and something of life, Tony,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘and it’s seldom I can’t make a man out, more or less. But such an old card as this, so deep, so sly, and secret (though I don’t believe he is ever sober), I never came across. Now, he must be precious old, you know, and he has not a soul about him, and he is reported to be immensely rich; and whether he is a smuggler, or a receiver, or an unlicensed pawnbroker, or a money-lender—all of which I have thought likely at different times—it might pay you to knock up a sort of knowledge of him. I don’t see why you shouldn’t go in for it, when everything else suits.’
“托尼，我见识过职业生涯和生活，”古比先生说，“我很少能或多或少地辨认出一个人。”但像这张这么老的牌，这么深刻，这么狡猾，这么秘密（虽然我不相信他曾经清醒过），我从来没有遇到过。现在，你知道，他一定已经很老了，而且他身上没有灵魂，而且据说他非常富有；但是，他却是一个非常富有的人。无论他是走私犯、收货人、无照当铺还是放债人——我在不同时期都认为他可能是这样——你对他有一定的了解可能会有所帮助。我不明白为什么当其他一切都适合的时候你不应该参与其中。

Mr. Jobling, Mr. Guppy, and Mr. Smallweed all lean their elbows on the table and their chins upon their hands, and look at the ceiling. After a time, they all drink, slowly lean back, put their hands in their pockets, and look at one another.
乔布林先生、孔雀鱼先生和斯莫威德先生都把胳膊肘靠在桌子上，用手撑着下巴，看着天花板。过了一会儿，他们都喝了酒，慢慢靠在椅背上，双手插在口袋里，面面相觑。

‘If I had the energy I once possessed, Tony!’ says Mr. Guppy with a sigh. ‘But there are chords in the human mind—‘
“托尼，如果我能拥有曾经拥有的能量就好了！”古比先生叹了口气说道。 “但是人类的心灵中有和弦——”

Expressing the remainder of the desolate sentiment in rum-andwater, Mr. Guppy concludes by resigning the adventure to Tony Jobling and informing him that during the vacation and while things are slack, his purse, ‘as far as three or four or even five pound goes,’ will be at his disposal. ‘For never shall it be said,’ Mr. Guppy adds with emphasis, ‘that William Guppy turned his back upon his friend!’
古比先生用朗姆酒和水表达了剩余的荒凉情绪，最后将冒险任务交给了托尼·乔布林，并告诉他，在假期期间，当事情不景气时，他的钱包“最多三、四甚至五英镑”去”将由他支配。 “永远不能说，”顾比先生强调道，“威廉·顾比背弃了他的朋友！”

The latter part of the proposal is so directly to the purpose that Mr. Jobling says with emotion, ‘Guppy, my trump, your fist!’ Mr. Guppy presents it, saying, ‘Jobling, my boy, there it is!’ Mr. Jobling returns, ‘Guppy, we have been pals now for some years!’ Mr. Guppy replies, ‘Jobling, we have.’
提议的后半部分是如此直接地达到了目的，以至于乔布林先生激动地说：“古比，我的王牌，你的拳头！”古比先生展示了它，说：“乔布林，我的孩子，就是它！”乔布林回来了，“古比，我们已经成为好朋友好几年了！”古比先生回答道，“乔布林，我们已经是好朋友了。”

They then shake hands, and Mr. Jobling adds in a feeling manner, ‘Thank you, Guppy, I don’t know but what I WILL take another glass for old acquaintance sake.’
然后他们握手，乔布林先生感性地补充道：“谢谢你，古比，我不知道，但看在老相识的份上，我愿意再喝一杯。”

‘Krook’s last lodger died there,’ observes Mr. Guppy in an incidental way.
“克鲁克的最后一位房客死在那里，”古皮先生顺便说道。

‘Did he though!’ says Mr. Jobling.
“他确实这么做了！”乔布林先生说道。

‘There was a verdict. Accidental death. You don’t mind that?’
‘有一个判决。意外死亡。你不介意吗？

‘No,’ says Mr. Jobling, ‘I don’t mind it; but he might as well have died somewhere else. It’s devilish odd that he need go and die at MY place!’ Mr. Jobling quite resents this liberty, several times returning to it with such remarks as, ‘There are places enough to die in, I should think!’ or, ‘He wouldn’t have liked my dying at HIS place, I dare say!’
“不，”乔布林先生说，“我不介意；我不介意。”但他也可能死在别的地方了。他需要去我的地方死，这真是太奇怪了！”乔布林先生非常憎恨这种自由，他多次回到这种自由，并说了这样的话，“我认为，有足够的地方可以死！”或者，“他我敢说，他不会喜欢我死在他的地方！

However, the compact being virtually made, Mr. Guppy proposes to dispatch the trusty Smallweed to ascertain if Mr. Krook is at home, as in that case they may complete the negotiation without delay. Mr. Jobling approving, Smallweed puts himself under the tall hat and conveys it out of the dining-rooms in the Guppy manner. He soon returns with the intelligence that Mr. Krook is at home and that he has seen him through the shop-door, sitting in the back premises, sleeping ‘like one o’clock.’
然而，契约实际上已达成，古比先生建议派遣值得信赖的斯莫威德去查明克鲁克先生是否在家，这样他们就可以立即完成谈判。乔布林先生表示赞同，斯莫威德把自己戴在高高的帽子下面，并以孔雀鱼的方式把它带出了餐厅。很快他就回来了，并得知克鲁克先生在家，而且他从商店门口看到他坐在后面的房子里，睡得“好像凌晨一点”。

‘Then I’ll pay,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘and we’ll go and see him. Small, what will it be?’
“那我就付钱，”古比先生说，“然后我们就去看他。”小，会是什么？

Mr. Smallweed, compelling the attendance of the waitress with one hitch of his eyelash, instantly replies as follows: ‘Four veals and hams is three, and four potatoes is three and four, and one summer cabbage is three and six, and three marrows is four and six, and six breads is five, and three Cheshires is five and three, and four half-pints of half-and-half is six and three, and four small rums is eight and three, and three Pollys is eight and six. Eight and six in half a sovereign, Polly, and eighteenpence out!’
斯莫威德先生用睫毛一拉，强迫女服务员就座，立即回答如下：“四块小牛肉和火腿是三，四个土豆是三和四，一棵夏季卷心菜是三和六，三颗骨髓是四加六，六个面包是五，三个柴郡是五加三，四品脱半品脱半是六加三，四杯小朗姆酒是八加三，三个波利是八加三。六。八又六半英镑，波莉，十八便士！

Not at all excited by these stupendous calculations, Smallweed dismisses his friends with a cool nod and remains behind to take a little admiring notice of Polly, as opportunity may serve, and to read the daily papers, which are so very large in proportion to himself, shorn of his hat, that when he holds up the Times to run his eye over the columns, he seems to have retired for the night and to have disappeared under the bedclothes.
斯莫威德对这些惊人的计算一点也不兴奋，他冷静地点点头，打发他的朋友们离开，然后留下来，一有机会就对波莉稍加钦佩，并阅读日报，这些报纸与他的比例太大了摘下帽子后，当他举起《泰晤士报》，目光扫过柱子时，他似乎已经休息了一晚，消失在床单下。

Mr. Guppy and Mr. Jobling repair to the rag and bottle shop, where they find Krook still sleeping like one o’clock, that is to say, breathing stertorously with his chin upon his breast and quite insensible to any external sounds or even to gentle shaking. On the table beside him, among the usual lumber, stand an empty ginbottle and a glass. The unwholesome air is so stained with this liquor that even the green eyes of the cat upon her shelf, as they open and shut and glimmer on the visitors, look drunk.
古比先生和乔布林先生回到破布和瓶子店，在那里他们发现克鲁克仍然睡得像一点钟一样，也就是说，他的下巴靠在胸前，喘着粗气，对任何外部声音都没有感觉，甚至对任何声音都没有感觉。轻轻摇晃。他旁边的桌子上，在普通的木材中间，放着一个空杜松子酒瓶和一个玻璃杯。不健康的空气被这种酒污染得如此之深，甚至连架子上那只猫的绿眼睛，当它们打开、关闭并在访客身上闪烁时，看起来都醉了。

‘Hold up here!’ says Mr. Guppy, giving the relaxed figure of the old man another shake. ‘Mr. Krook! Halloa, sir!’
“站住！”古皮先生说，又摇晃了老人轻松的身躯。 '先生。骗子！你好，先生！

But it would seem as easy to wake a bundle of old clothes with a spirituous heat smouldering in it. ‘Did you ever see such a stupor as he falls into, between drink and sleep?’ says Mr. Guppy.
但唤醒一捆里面闷烧着精神热气的旧衣服似乎很容易。 “你见过他在喝酒和睡觉之间陷入这样的昏迷状态吗？”古皮先生说。

‘If this is his regular sleep,’ returns Jobling, rather alarmed, ‘it’ll last a long time one of these days, I am thinking.’
“如果这是他的常规睡眠，”乔布林相当惊慌地回答道，“我想，这些天它会持续很长时间。”

‘It’s always more like a fit than a nap,’ says Mr. Guppy, shaking him again. ‘Halloa, your lordship! Why, he might be robbed fifty times over! Open your eyes!’
“这总是更像是一阵痉挛，而不是小睡，”古皮先生说道，再次摇晃着他。 ‘哈喽，陛下！哎呀，他可能会被抢劫五十次！张开你的眼睛！'

After much ado, he opens them, but without appearing to see his visitors or any other objects. Though he crosses one leg on another, and folds his hands, and several times closes and opens his parched lips, he seems to all intents and purposes as insensible as before.
经过一番费力之后，他打开了它们，但似乎没有看到他的访客或任何其他物体。尽管他把一条腿交叉在另一条腿上，双手合十，干裂的嘴唇好几次合上又张开，但他似乎和以前一样麻木不仁。

‘He is alive, at any rate,’ says Mr. Guppy. ‘How are you, my Lord Chancellor. I have brought a friend of mine, sir, on a little matter of business.’
“无论如何，他还活着，”古比先生说。 ‘你好吗，大法官。先生，我带来了我的一位朋友，有一点生意上的事。

The old man still sits, often smacking his dry lips without the least consciousness. After some minutes he makes an attempt to rise. They help him up, and he staggers against the wall and stares at them.
老人依然坐着，时常无意识地咂着干燥的嘴唇。几分钟后，他尝试站起来。他们把他扶了起来，他摇摇晃晃地靠在墙上，盯着他们。

‘How do you do, Mr. Krook?’ says Mr. Guppy in some discomfiture. ‘How do you do, sir? You are looking charming, Mr. Krook. I hope you are pretty well?’
“克鲁克先生，你好吗？”古比先生有些不安地说道。 ‘你好吗，先生？你看起来很迷人，克鲁克先生。我希望你一切都好？

The old man, in aiming a purposeless blow at Mr. Guppy, or at nothing, feebly swings himself round and comes with his face against the wall. So he remains for a minute or two, heaped up against it, and then staggers down the shop to the front door. The air, the movement in the court, the lapse of time, or the combination of these things recovers him. He comes back pretty steadily, adjusting his fur cap on his head and looking keenly at them.
老人无意中向孔雀先生打了一拳，或者毫无目的，无力地转过身来，脸贴在墙上。于是他靠在门上停留了一两分钟，然后摇摇晃晃地沿着商店走到前门。空气、球场上的动静、时间的流逝，或者这些因素的结合让他恢复了过来。他稳稳地回来了，调整了一下头上的皮帽，目光敏锐地看着他们。

‘Your servant, gentlemen; I’ve been dozing. Hi! I am hard to wake, odd times.’
“你们的仆人，先生们；我一直在打瞌睡。你好！我很难醒来，奇怪的时候。

‘Rather so, indeed, sir,’ responds Mr. Guppy.
“确实如此，先生，”古比先生回答道。

‘What? You’ve been a-trying to do it, have you?’ says the suspicious Krook.
'什么？你一直在尝试这样做，是吗？”多疑的克鲁克说道。

‘Only a little,’ Mr. Guppy explains.
“只有一点点，”古比先生解释道。

The old man’s eye resting on the empty bottle, he takes it up, examines it, and slowly tilts it upside down.
老者的目光停留在空瓶子上，他拿起它看了看，然后慢慢地将它倒过来。

‘I say!’ he cries like the hobgoblin in the story. ‘Somebody’s been making free here!’
“我说！”他像故事中的妖精一样哭喊着。 “有人在这里释放了自由！”

‘I assure you we found it so,’ says Mr. Guppy. ‘Would you allow me to get it filled for you?’
“我向你保证，我们发现确实如此，”古皮先生说。 “你能允许我帮你把它填满吗？”

‘Yes, certainly I would!’ cries Krook in high glee. ‘Certainly I would! Don’t mention it! Get it filled next door—Sol’s Arms—the Lord Chancellor’s fourteenpenny. Bless you, they know ME!’
“是的，我当然愿意！”克鲁克高兴地喊道。 “我当然愿意！别提了！把隔壁——索尔的武器——大法官的十四便士装满。祝福你，他们认识我！

He so presses the empty bottle upon Mr. Guppy that that gentleman, with a nod to his friend, accepts the trust and hurries out and hurries in again with the bottle filled. The old man receives it in his arms like a beloved grandchild and pats it tenderly.
他把空瓶子按在孔雀先生身上，孔雀先生向他的朋友点了点头，接受了他的信任，带着装满了瓶子的瓶子匆匆出去又匆匆进来。老人像对待心爱的孙子一样将它抱在怀里，温柔地拍着。

‘But, I say,’ he whispers, with his eyes screwed up, after tasting it, ‘this ain’t the Lord Chancellor’s fourteenpenny. This is eighteenpenny!’
“但是，我说，”尝完之后，他眯起眼睛低声说道，“这不是大法官的十四便士。”这是十八便士！

‘I thought you might like that better,’ says Mr. Guppy.
“我想你可能会更喜欢这个，”古比先生说。

‘You’re a nobleman, sir,’ returns Krook with another taste, and his hot breath seems to come towards them like a flame. ‘You’re a baron of the land.’
“您是一位贵族，先生。”克鲁克带着另一种味道回答道，他炽热的呼吸似乎像火焰一样向他们袭来。 “你是这片土地的男爵。”

Taking advantage of this auspicious moment, Mr. Guppy presents his friend under the impromptu name of Mr. Weevle and states the object of their visit. Krook, with his bottle under his arm (he never gets beyond a certain point of either drunkenness or sobriety), takes time to survey his proposed lodger and seems to approve of him. ‘You’d like to see the room, young man?’ he says. ‘Ah! It’s a good room! Been whitewashed. Been cleaned down with soft soap and soda. Hi! It’s worth twice the rent, letting alone my company when you want it and such a cat to keep the mice away.’
趁着这个吉祥的时刻，古比先生以威弗勒先生的即兴名字介绍了他的朋友，并说明了他们来访的目的。克鲁克腋下夹着酒瓶（他从来没有超过醉酒或清醒的程度），花时间审视他提议的房客，似乎很认可他。 “年轻人，你想看看这个房间吗？”他说。 '啊！这是一个好房间！被洗白了用软肥皂和苏打水清洗干净。你好！它值双倍的租金，更不用说你想要的时候还有我的陪伴，还有这样一只可以驱赶老鼠的猫。”

Commending the room after this manner, the old man takes them upstairs, where indeed they do find it cleaner than it used to be and also containing some old articles of furniture which he has dug up from his inexhaustible stores. The terms are easily concluded— for the Lord Chancellor cannot be hard on Mr. Guppy, associated as he is with Kenge and Carboy, Jarndyce and Jarndyce, and other famous claims on his professional consideration—and it is agreed that Mr. Weevle shall take possession on the morrow. Mr. Weevle and Mr. Guppy then repair to Cook’s Court, Cursitor Street, where the personal introduction of the former to Mr. Snagsby is effected and (more important) the vote and interest of Mrs. Snagsby are secured. They then report progress to the eminent Smallweed, waiting at the office in his tall hat for that purpose, and separate, Mr. Guppy explaining that he would terminate his little entertainment by standing treat at the play but that there are chords in the human mind which would render it a hollow mockery.
老人这样称赞了这个房间，然后带他们上了楼，他们确实发现这里比以前干净了，而且还放着一些他从取之不尽用之不竭的商店里挖出来的旧家具。条款很容易就达成了——因为大法官不能对古比先生太严厉，因为他与肯格和卡博伊、贾迪斯和贾迪斯以及其他基于他的职业考虑的著名主张有联系——并且同意韦夫勒先生应接受明天占有。然后，韦夫勒先生和古皮先生前往库西特街的库克法院，在那里，韦夫勒先生向斯纳格斯比先生进行了个人介绍，并且（更重要的是）斯纳格斯比夫人的投票和利益得到了保障。然后，他们向著名的斯莫尔韦德报告进展情况，为此目的，他戴着高帽子在办公室等候，然后分开，古比先生解释说，他将通过在戏剧中站立招待来结束他的小娱乐活动，但人类的头脑中有和弦这将使它成为空洞的嘲弄。

On the morrow, in the dusk of evening, Mr. Weevle modestly appears at Krook’s, by no means incommoded with luggage, and establishes himself in his new lodging, where the two eyes in the shutters stare at him in his sleep, as if they were full of wonder. On the following day Mr. Weevle, who is a handy good-for-nothing kind of young fellow, borrows a needle and thread of Miss Flite and a hammer of his landlord and goes to work devising apologies for window-curtains, and knocking up apologies for shelves, and hanging up his two teacups, milkpot, and crockery sundries on a pennyworth of little hooks, like a shipwrecked sailor making the best of it.
第二天，黄昏时分，韦弗勒先生谦虚地出现在克鲁克家，行李一点也不多，并在他的新住所安顿下来，百叶窗里的两只眼睛在睡梦中盯着他，仿佛它们在注视着他。都充满了惊奇。第二天，威夫勒先生这个手巧的废物年轻人，向弗利特小姐借了一根针线，向房东借了一把锤子，去上班，为窗帘设计道歉，并敲门。为架子道歉，把他的两个茶杯、奶壶和陶器杂物挂在价值一便士的小挂钩上，就像一个遭遇海难的水手在充分利用它。

But what Mr. Weevle prizes most of all his few possessions (next after his light whiskers, for which he has an attachment that only whiskers can awaken in the breast of man) is a choice collection of copper-plate impressions from that truly national work The Divinities of Albion, or Galaxy Gallery of British Beauty, representing ladies of title and fashion in every variety of smirk that art, combined with capital, is capable of producing. With these magnificent portraits, unworthily confined in a band-box during his seclusion among the market-gardens, he decorates his apartment; and as the Galaxy Gallery of British Beauty wears every variety of fancy dress, plays every variety of musical instrument, fondles every variety of dog, ogles every variety of prospect, and is backed up by every variety of flower-pot and balustrade, the result is very imposing.
但韦夫勒先生最珍视的，是他为数不多的几件财产（其次是他的浅色胡须，因为他有一种只有胡须才能在人类胸中唤醒的依恋），是从这部真正的民族作品中精选出来的铜版印记。阿尔比恩的神灵，或英国美丽的银河画廊，代表了艺术与资本相结合能够产生的各种微笑中的名流和时尚女士。当他隐居在市场花园中时，他用这些宏伟的肖像画来装饰他的公寓，这些肖像画不合时宜地被限制在一个带盒里。英国美女银河画廊穿着各种各样的化装，演奏着各种各样的乐器，抚摸着各种各样的狗，注视着各种各样的景色，并有各种各样的花盆和栏杆作为支撑，结果非常有气势。

But fashion is Mr. Weevle’s, as it was Tony Jobling’s, weakness. To borrow yesterday’s paper from the Sol’s Arms of an evening and read about the brilliant and distinguished meteors that are shooting across the fashionable sky in every direction is unspeakable consolation to him. To know what member of what brilliant and distinguished circle accomplished the brilliant and distinguished feat of joining it yesterday or contemplates the no less brilliant and distinguished feat of leaving it to-morrow gives him a thrill of joy. To be informed what the Galaxy Gallery of British Beauty is about, and means to be about, and what Galaxy marriages are on the tapis, and what Galaxy rumours are in circulation, is to become acquainted with the most glorious destinies of mankind. Mr. Weevle reverts from this intelligence to the Galaxy portraits implicated, and seems to know the originals, and to be known of them.
但时尚是韦夫勒先生的弱点，正如托尼·乔布林的弱点一样。借用昨天晚上《索尔之臂》的报纸，读到从各个方向划过时尚天空的灿烂而杰出的流星，对他来说是难以言喻的安慰。知道哪个辉煌而杰出的圈子的成员昨天完成了加入该圈子的辉煌和杰出的壮举，或者考虑明天离开这个圈子的同样辉煌和杰出的壮举，这让他感到一阵喜悦。了解银河英国美人画廊的主题和意义、塔皮斯上的银河婚姻以及流传的银河谣言，就是了解人类最光荣的命运。韦夫勒先生从这一情报回到了所涉及的银河肖像，似乎知道原件，并且知道它们。

For the rest he is a quiet lodger, full of handy shifts and devices as before mentioned, able to cook and clean for himself as well as to carpenter, and developing social inclinations after the shades of evening have fallen on the court. At those times, when he is not visited by Mr. Guppy or by a small light in his likeness quenched in a dark hat, he comes out of his dull room—where he has inherited the deal wilderness of desk bespattered with a rain of ink—and talks to Krook or is ‘very free,’ as they call it in the court, commendingly, with any one disposed for conversation. Wherefore, Mrs. Piper, who leads the court, is impelled to offer two remarks to Mrs. Perkins: firstly, that if her Johnny was to have whiskers, she could wish ‘em to be identically like that young man’s; and secondly, ‘Mark my words, Mrs. Perkins, ma’am, and don’t you be surprised, Lord bless you, if that young man comes in at last for old Krook’s money!’
除此之外，他是一个安静的房客，像前面提到的那样，充满了方便的轮班和设备，能够为自己做饭和打扫，也能做木匠，并在夜幕降临球场后培养社交倾向。在那些时候，当孔雀先生没有来拜访他，或者没有他的肖像在黑帽子里熄灭的小光时，他就会从他沉闷的房间里走出来——在那里，他继承了沾满墨水雨的办公桌的荒野。 ——并与克鲁克交谈，或者正如他们在法庭上所说的那样，与任何愿意交谈的人都“非常自由”。因此，法庭庭长派珀夫人不得不向珀金斯夫人提出两点意见：第一，如果她的约翰尼有胡子，她希望它们和那个年轻人的胡子一模一样；其次，“记住我的话，帕金斯太太，女士，如果那个年轻人最终为了老克鲁克的钱而来，你不要感到惊讶，上帝保佑你！”

CHAPTER XXI
第二十一章


The Smallweed Family
小杂草家族

In a rather ill-favoured and ill-savoured neighbourhood, though one of its rising grounds bears the name of Mount Pleasant, the Elfin Smallweed, christened Bartholomew and known on the domestic hearth as Bart, passes that limited portion of his time on which the office and its contingencies have no claim. He dwells in a little narrow street, always solitary, shady, and sad, closely bricked in on all sides like a tomb, but where there yet lingers the stump of an old forest tree whose flavour is about as fresh and natural as the Smallweed smack of youth.
在一个相当不受欢迎和令人厌恶的社区里，尽管其中一处高地的名字叫芒特普莱森特，小精灵小草，被洗礼为巴塞洛缪，在家庭壁炉旁被称为巴特，他度过了他有限的一段时间，办公室及其意外事件没有索赔权。他住在一条狭窄的小街上，总是孤独、阴暗、悲伤，四面都用砖砌得严严实实，像一座坟墓，但那里还徘徊着一棵老树的树桩，它的味道就像小草的味道一样清新自然。的青春。

There has been only one child in the Smallweed family for several generations. Little old men and women there have been, but no child, until Mr. Smallweed’s grandmother, now living, became weak in her intellect and fell (for the first time) into a childish state. With such infantine graces as a total want of observation, memory, understanding, and interest, and an eternal disposition to fall asleep over the fire and into it, Mr. Smallweed’s grandmother has undoubtedly brightened the family.
Smallweed家族几代以来都只有一个孩子。那里有小老男人和小女人，但没有孩子，直到斯莫尔威德先生现在还活着的祖母变得智力低下，并（第一次）陷入幼稚的状态。斯莫威德先生的祖母有着婴儿般的优雅，完全缺乏观察力、记忆力、理解力和兴趣，而且总是喜欢在火边和火上睡着，毫无疑问，她给这个家庭带来了欢乐。

Mr. Smallweed’s grandfather is likewise of the party. He is in a helpless condition as to his lower, and nearly so as to his upper, limbs, but his mind is unimpaired. It holds, as well as it ever held, the first four rules of arithmetic and a certain small collection of the hardest facts. In respect of ideality, reverence, wonder, and other such phrenological attributes, it is no worse off than it used to be. Everything that Mr. Smallweed’s grandfather ever put away in his mind was a grub at first, and is a grub at last. In all his life he has never bred a single butterfly.
斯莫尔威德先生的祖父同样是该党的一员。他的下肢和上肢几乎都处于无助的状态，但他的精神没有受到损害。它一如既往地坚持着算术的前四个规则和一小部分最难的事实。在理想、敬畏、惊奇和其他颅相属性方面，它并不比以前更糟。斯莫尔威德先生的祖父在他的脑海中所存的一切，最初都是蛴螬，最后也是蛴螬。他一生中从未养育过一只蝴蝶。

The father of this pleasant grandfather, of the neighbourhood of Mount Pleasant, was a horny-skinned, two-legged, money-getting species of spider who spun webs to catch unwary flies and retired into holes until they were entrapped. The name of this old pagan’s god was Compound Interest. He lived for it, married it, died of it. Meeting with a heavy loss in an honest little enterprise in which all the loss was intended to have been on the other side, he broke something—something necessary to his existence, therefore it couldn’t have been his heart—and made an end of his career. As his character was not good, and he had been bred at a charity school in a complete course, according to question and answer, of those ancient people the Amorites and Hittites, he was frequently quoted as an example of the failure of education.
这位和蔼可亲的祖父住在芒特普莱森特附近，他的父亲是一种皮肤角质、两条腿、能赚钱的蜘蛛，它们会结网捕捉粗心的苍蝇，然后退回洞里，直到它们被困住。这位古老异教徒的神的名字是复利。他为此而生，与之结婚，并为此而死。一家诚实的小企业遭受了重大损失，所有的损失都应该在另一方，他打破了一些东西——一些对他的存在来说是必要的东西，因此它不可能是他的心——并结束了他的事业。由于他的性格不好，而且他是在一所慈善学校接受了古代亚摩利人和赫梯人的完整课程的教育，因此他经常被引用为教育失败的例子。

His spirit shone through his son, to whom he had always preached of ‘going out’ early in life and whom he made a clerk in a sharp scrivener’s office at twelve years old. There the young gentleman improved his mind, which was of a lean and anxious character, and developing the family gifts, gradually elevated himself into the discounting profession. Going out early in life and marrying late, as his father had done before him, he too begat a lean and anxiousminded son, who in his turn, going out early in life and marrying late, became the father of Bartholomew and Judith Smallweed, twins. During the whole time consumed in the slow growth of this family tree, the house of Smallweed, always early to go out and late to marry, has strengthened itself in its practical character, has discarded all amusements, discountenanced all story-books, fairytales, fictions, and fables, and banished all levities whatsoever. Hence the gratifying fact that it has had no child born to it and that the complete little men and women whom it has produced have been observed to bear a likeness to old monkeys with something depressing on their minds.
他的精神在他的儿子身上熠熠生辉，他从小就一直向他宣扬“走出去”，并在他十二岁时就让他在一家精明的书记员办公室当了一名职员。在那里，这位年轻的绅士改善了他原本瘦弱、焦虑的性格，并培养了家庭天赋，逐渐将自己提升到了折扣行业。正如他父亲在他之前所做的那样，他早出晚婚，也生了一个瘦弱而焦虑的儿子，而他的儿子也早出晚婚，成为双胞胎巴塞洛缪和朱迪思·斯莫威德的父亲。 。在这个家谱慢慢成长的整个过程中，总是早出晚婚的斯莫威德家族增强了自己的实用性，抛弃了一切娱乐，贬低了所有故事书、童话，小说和寓言，并消除了一切轻浮的内容。因此，令人欣慰的是，它没有生下任何孩子，而且人们观察到它所产下的完整的小男人和女人都像老猴子，心里有些压抑。

At the present time, in the dark little parlour certain feet below the level of the street—a grim, hard, uncouth parlour, only ornamented with the coarsest of baize table-covers, and the hardest of sheet-iron tea-trays, and offering in its decorative character no bad allegorical representation of Grandfather Smallweed’s mind— seated in two black horsehair porter’s chairs, one on each side of the fire-place, the superannuated Mr. and Mrs. Smallweed while away the rosy hours. On the stove are a couple of trivets for the pots and kettles which it is Grandfather Smallweed’s usual occupation to watch, and projecting from the chimney-piece between them is a sort of brass gallows for roasting, which he also superintends when it is in action. Under the venerable Mr. Smallweed’s seat and guarded by his spindle legs is a drawer in his chair, reported to contain property to a fabulous amount. Beside him is a spare cushion with which he is always provided in order that he may have something to throw at the venerable partner of his respected age whenever she makes an allusion to money—a subject on which he is particularly sensitive.
现在，在离街道几英尺远的黑暗小客厅里——一间阴森、坚硬、粗俗的客厅，只装饰着最粗糙的粗呢桌布和最坚硬的铁皮茶盘，它的装饰特征很好地寓言地表现了斯莫威德祖父的思想——年迈的斯莫威德先生和夫人坐在两张黑色马毛搬运工的椅子上，壁炉两侧各一张，消磨着美好的时光。炉子上有几个放锅和水壶的三脚架，斯莫威德祖父通常会负责观察，从三脚架之间的烟囱伸出来的是一种用于烘烤的黄铜绞架，在工作时他也会监督它。 。在受人尊敬的斯莫威德先生的座位下，椅子上有一个抽屉，由他的纺锤腿守护着，据说里面装着数量惊人的财产。他旁边有一个备用垫子，他总是拿着这个垫子，以便每当他尊敬的同龄人提到金钱时，他就可以向她扔一些东西——这是他特别敏感的话题。

‘And where’s Bart?’ Grandfather Smallweed inquires of Judy, Bart’s twin sister.
“巴特在哪里？”斯莫威德祖父询问巴特的双胞胎妹妹朱迪。

‘He an’t come in yet,’ says Judy.
“他还没进来，”朱迪说。

‘It’s his tea-time, isn’t it?’
“现在是他的下午茶时间，不是吗？”

‘No.’
'不。'

‘How much do you mean to say it wants then?’
“那么你的意思是说它想要多少钱？”

‘Ten minutes.’
'10分钟。'

‘Hey?’
'嘿？'

‘Ten minutes.’ (Loud on the part of Judy.)
“十分钟。”（朱迪大声说道。）

‘Ho!’ says Grandfather Smallweed. ‘Ten minutes.’
“嗬！”斯莫威德爷爷说道。 '10分钟。'

Grandmother Smallweed, who has been mumbling and shaking her head at the trivets, hearing figures mentioned, connects them with money and screeches like a horrible old parrot without any plumage, ‘Ten ten-pound notes!’
祖母斯莫威德一直对着三脚架咕哝着，在听到数字时摇着头，她把它们与金钱联系起来，像一只没有羽毛的可怕的老鹦鹉一样尖叫，“十张十英镑的钞票！”

Grandfather Smallweed immediately throws the cushion at her.
斯莫威德爷爷立即把垫子扔给她。

‘Drat you, be quiet!’ says the good old man.
“该死的，安静点！”好心的老人说道。

The effect of this act of jaculation is twofold. It not only doubles up Mrs. Smallweed’s head against the side of her porter’s chair and causes her to present, when extricated by her granddaughter, a highly unbecoming state of cap, but the necessary exertion recoils on Mr. Smallweed himself, whom it throws back into HIS porter’s chair like a broken puppet. The excellent old gentleman being at these times a mere clothes-bag with a black skull-cap on the top of it, does not present a very animated appearance until he has undergone the two operations at the hands of his granddaughter of being shaken up like a great bottle and poked and punched like a great bolster. Some indication of a neck being developed in him by these means, he and the sharer of his life’s evening again fronting one another in their two porter’s chairs, like a couple of sentinels long forgotten on their post by the Black Serjeant, Death.
这种射精行为的效果是双重的。这不仅使斯莫尔韦德太太的头靠在搬运工椅子的一侧，导致她在被孙女解救时呈现出一种非常不合适的帽子状态，而且必要的用力也会对斯莫尔韦德先生本人产生反作用力，从而使他向后退去。像一个破碎的木偶一样坐在他的搬运工的椅子上。这位优秀的老先生此时只是一个衣袋，上面戴着一顶黑色无边便帽，直到经历了孙女手中的两次手术后，才呈现出非常生动的样子。一个大瓶子，像一个大枕垫一样被戳和打。一些迹象表明，通过这些方式，他的脖子正在发育，他和他生命之夜的分享者再次坐在他们的两张门房椅子上，就像一对早已被黑色警官死亡遗忘在岗位上的哨兵。

Judy the twin is worthy company for these associates. She is so indubitably sister to Mr. Smallweed the younger that the two kneaded into one would hardly make a young person of average proportions, while she so happily exemplifies the before-mentioned family likeness to the monkey tribe that attired in a spangled robe and cap she might walk about the table-land on the top of a barrelorgan without exciting much remark as an unusual specimen. Under existing circumstances, however, she is dressed in a plain, spare gown of brown stuff.
双胞胎朱迪是这些同事值得陪伴的人。毫无疑问，她是小斯莫尔威德先生的妹妹，以至于两人揉合在一起很难成为一个中等身材的年轻人，而她则很高兴地体现了前面提到的穿着闪亮长袍和帽子的猴子部落的家族相似性。她可能会坐在桶风琴的顶部在高原上行走，而不会因为一个不寻常的标本而引起太多激动人心的评论。然而，在目前的情况下，她穿着一件朴素、备用的棕色长袍。

Judy never owned a doll, never heard of Cinderella, never played at any game. She once or twice fell into children’s company when she was about ten years old, but the children couldn’t get on with Judy, and Judy couldn’t get on with them. She seemed like an animal of another species, and there was instinctive repugnance on both sides. It is very doubtful whether Judy knows how to laugh. She has so rarely seen the thing done that the probabilities are strong the other way. Of anything like a youthful laugh, she certainly can have no conception. If she were to try one, she would find her teeth in her way, modelling that action of her face, as she has unconsciously modelled all its other expressions, on her pattern of sordid age. Such is Judy.
朱迪从未拥有过洋娃娃，从未听说过灰姑娘，也从未玩过任何游戏。她十岁左右的时候，曾有一两次陷入孩子们的陪伴，但孩子们与朱迪合不来，朱迪也与他们合不来。她看起来就像是另一个物种的动物，双方都有本能的厌恶。朱迪是否会笑很值得怀疑。她很少见过这种事，所以相反的可能性很大。对于青春的笑声这样的事情，她当然无法想象。如果她想尝试一下，她会发现她的牙齿挡住了她的路，模仿她脸上的动作，就像她无意识地模仿她肮脏的年龄模式的所有其他表情一样。朱迪就是这样。

And her twin brother couldn’t wind up a top for his life. He knows no more of Jack the Giant Killer or of Sinbad the Sailor than he knows of the people in the stars. He could as soon play at leapfrog or at cricket as change into a cricket or a frog himself. But he is so much the better off than his sister that on his narrow world of fact an opening has dawned into such broader regions as lie within the ken of Mr. Guppy. Hence his admiration and his emulation of that shining enchanter.
而她的双胞胎兄弟却未能达到人生巅峰。他对巨人杀手杰克和水手辛巴达的了解并不比他对星星中的人的了解更多。他既可以自己变成蟋蟀或青蛙，也可以玩蛙跳或板球。但他比他姐姐的境况要好得多，以至于在他狭隘的现实世界中，孔雀鱼先生的视野范围内的更广阔的领域已经出现了一个开口。因此他对那个闪耀的魔法师充满了钦佩和效仿。

Judy, with a gong-like clash and clatter, sets one of the sheetiron tea-trays on the table and arranges cups and saucers. The bread she puts on in an iron basket, and the butter (and not much of it) in a small pewter plate. Grandfather Smallweed looks hard after the tea as it is served out and asks Judy where the girl is.
朱迪发出锣声般的碰撞声，将一个铁皮茶盘放在桌子上，并摆好杯子和碟子。她把面包放在一个铁篮子里，把黄油（不多）放在一个小锡盘里。斯莫威德祖父认真地看着茶端上来，并问朱迪那个女孩在哪里。

‘Charley, do you mean?’ says Judy.
“查理，你是说吗？”朱迪说。

‘Hey?’ from Grandfather Smallweed.
“嘿？”来自斯莫威德祖父。

‘Charley, do you mean?’
“查理，你是说吗？”

This touches a spring in Grandmother Smallweed, who, chuckling as usual at the trivets, cries, ‘Over the water! Charley over the water, Charley over the water, over the water to Charley, Charley over the water, over the water to Charley!’ and becomes quite energetic about it. Grandfather looks at the cushion but has not sufficiently recovered his late exertion.
这触动了斯莫威德奶奶的心，她像往常一样对着三脚架咯咯笑，喊道：“在水面上！”查理在水面上，查理在水面上，在水面上到查理，查理在水面上，在水面上到查理！”并且变得非常有活力。祖父看着坐垫，但还没有完全恢复他迟来的体力。

‘Ha!’ he says when there is silence. ‘If that’s her name. She eats a deal. It would be better to allow her for her keep.’
“哈！”当一片寂静时他说道。 ‘如果那是她的名字的话。她吃了一笔交易。最好让她自己留下。

Judy, with her brother’s wink, shakes her head and purses up her mouth into no without saying it.
朱迪向她哥哥使了个眼色，摇摇头，抿起嘴，没有说出来。

‘No?’ returns the old man. ‘Why not?’
“没有？”老人回答道。 '为什么不？'

‘She’d want sixpence a day, and we can do it for less,’ says Judy.
“她每天想要六便士，我们可以花更少的钱，”朱迪说。

‘Sure?’
'当然？'

Judy answers with a nod of deepest meaning and calls, as she scrapes the butter on the loaf with every precaution against waste and cuts it into slices, ‘You, Charley, where are you?’ Timidly obedient to the summons, a little girl in a rough apron and a large bonnet, with her hands covered with soap and water and a scrubbing brush in one of them, appears, and curtsys.
朱迪意味深长地点了点头，边说边用一切预防措施把面包上的黄油刮掉，然后把它切成片，“你，查理，你在哪里？”一个小女孩胆怯地听从召唤，出现了一条粗糙的围裙和一顶大帽子，双手沾满了肥皂和水，其中一只手上拿着一把刷子，还行了屈膝礼。

‘What work are you about now?’ says Judy, making an ancient snap at her like a very sharp old beldame.
“你现在做什么工作？”朱迪问道，像一个非常尖刻的老贵妇一样对她发出古老的厉声。

‘I’m a-cleaning the upstairs back room, miss,’ replies Charley.
“我正在打扫楼上的后屋，小姐，”查理回答道。

‘Mind you do it thoroughly, and don’t loiter. Shirking won’t do for me. Make haste! Go along!’ cries Judy with a stamp upon the ground. ‘You girls are more trouble than you’re worth, by half.’
‘注意做事要彻底，不要闲逛。偷懒对我来说没有用。赶快！走吧！”朱迪大声喊道，并在地上踩了一个印记。 “你们这些女孩带来的麻烦比你们值得的还要多一半。”

On this severe matron, as she returns to her task of scraping the butter and cutting the bread, falls the shadow of her brother, looking in at the window. For whom, knife and loaf in hand, she opens the street-door.
当这位严厉的主妇继续刮黄油和切面包的任务时，她哥哥的影子落在了她的身上，她哥哥正朝窗户里看。她手里拿着刀和面包，为谁打开街门。

‘Aye, aye, Bart!’ says Grandfather Smallweed. ‘Here you are, hey?’
“是啊，是啊，巴特！”斯莫威德祖父说道。 “你在这儿，嘿？”

‘Here I am,’ says Bart.
“我在这里，”巴特说。

‘Been along with your friend again, Bart?’
“又和你的朋友在一起了吗，巴特？”

Small nods.
小小点头。

‘Dining at his expense, Bart?’
“巴特，吃饭要他出钱吗？”

Small nods again.
小小再次点头。

‘That’s right. Live at his expense as much as you can, and take warning by his foolish example. That’s the use of such a friend. The only use you can put him to,’ says the venerable sage.
'这是正确的。尽可能以他为代价生活，并以他愚蠢的榜样为戒。这就是有这样一个朋友的用处。这是你能利用他的唯一用途。”这位可敬的圣人说道。

His grandson, without receiving this good counsel as dutifully as he might, honours it with all such acceptance as may lie in a slight wink and a nod and takes a chair at the tea-table. The four old faces then hover over teacups like a company of ghastly cherubim, Mrs. Smallweed perpetually twitching her head and chattering at the trivets and Mr. Smallweed requiring to be repeatedly shaken up like a large black draught.
他的孙子虽然没有尽职尽责地接受这个好建议，但他只是轻轻地眨了眨眼，点了点头，就接受了它，然后在茶桌旁坐下来。然后，四张老面孔盘旋在茶杯上方，就像一群可怕的小天使一样，斯莫尔威德太太不断地抽搐着头，对着三脚架喋喋不休，而斯莫尔威德先生则需要像一股黑色的大风一样反复摇晃。

‘Yes, yes,’ says the good old gentleman, reverting to his lesson of wisdom. ‘That’s such advice as your father would have given you, Bart. You never saw your father. More’s the pity. He was my true son.’ Whether it is intended to be conveyed that he was particularly pleasant to look at, on that account, does not appear.
“是的，是的，”那位善良的老先生说道，又回到了他的智慧教训。 “这就是你父亲会给你的建议，巴特。你从未见过你的父亲。更多的是遗憾。他是我真正的儿子。”是否是为了表达他看起来特别讨人喜欢，因此，并没有出现。

‘He was my true son,’ repeats the old gentleman, folding his bread and butter on his knee, ‘a good accountant, and died fifteen years ago.’
“他是我真正的儿子，”老绅士重复道，把面包和黄油放在膝盖上，“一位优秀的会计师，十五年前去世了。”

Mrs. Smallweed, following her usual instinct, breaks out with ‘Fifteen hundred pound. Fifteen hundred pound in a black box, fifteen hundred pound locked up, fifteen hundred pound put away and hid!’ Her worthy husband, setting aside his bread and butter, immediately discharges the cushion at her, crushes her against the side of her chair, and falls back in his own, overpowered. His appearance, after visiting Mrs. Smallweed with one of these admonitions, is particularly impressive and not wholly prepossessing, firstly because the exertion generally twists his black skull-cap over one eye and gives him an air of goblin rakishness, secondly because he mutters violent imprecations against Mrs. Smallweed, and thirdly because the contrast between those powerful expressions and his powerless figure is suggestive of a baleful old malignant who would be very wicked if he could. All this, however, is so common in the Smallweed family circle that it produces no impression. The old gentleman is merely shaken and has his internal feathers beaten up, the cushion is restored to its usual place beside him, and the old lady, perhaps with her cap adjusted and perhaps not, is planted in her chair again, ready to be bowled down like a ninepin.
斯莫威德太太按照她一贯的本能，突然说出了“一千五百英镑”。一千五百英镑装在一个黑盒子里，一千五百英镑锁起来，一千五百英镑收起来藏起来！”她可敬的丈夫，把面包和黄油放在一边，立即把垫子扔给她，把她压在椅子的一边，然后又倒在自己的身上，被压倒了。在拜访斯莫威德夫人并提出其中一项警告后，他的外表特别令人印象深刻，但并不完全讨人喜欢，首先是因为这种努力通常会把他的黑色无边帽扭到一只眼睛上，给他一种妖精般的放荡气息，其次是因为他咕哝着暴力第三，因为那些强有力的表情和他无力的身材之间的对比让人想起一个恶毒的老恶棍，如果可以的话，他会非常邪恶。然而，这一切在 Smallweed 家族圈子里太常见了，以至于没有给人留下什么印象。老先生只是受到了震动，体内的羽毛被打碎了，坐垫又恢复到了他旁边原来的位置，而老太太，也许戴好了帽子，也许没有戴好，再次坐在椅子上，准备投球。像九柱球一样向下。

Some time elapses in the present instance before the old gentleman is sufficiently cool to resume his discourse, and even then he mixes it up with several edifying expletives addressed to the unconscious partner of his bosom, who holds communication with nothing on earth but the trivets. As thus: ‘If your father, Bart, had lived longer, he might have been worth a deal of money—you brimstone chatterer!—but just as he was beginning to build up the house that he had been making the foundations for, through many a year—you jade of a magpie, jackdaw, and poll-parrot, what do you mean!—he took ill and died of a low fever, always being a sparing and a spare man, fule been a good son, and I think I meant to have been one. But I wasn’t. I was a thundering bad son, that’s the long and the short of it, and never was a credit to anybody.’
在目前的情况下，过了一段时间，老绅士才冷静下来继续讲话，即便如此，他还是把它与几句对他怀里无意识的伴侣说的有启发性的脏话混在一起，后者除了三脚架之外与地球上没有任何东西进行交流。正如这样：“如果你的父亲巴特活得更久，他可能值很多钱——你这个硫磺喋喋不休的人！——但正当他开始建造他一直在打基础的房子时，通过多少年了——喜鹊、寒鸦、鹦鹉的玉石，你什么意思！——他得病了，发低烧死了，一向省吃俭用，真是个好儿子，而我我想我本来就是其中之一。但我不是。我是一个非常坏的儿子，总而言之，总而言之，我从来没有为任何人赢得荣誉。

‘Surprising!’ cries the old man.
“太惊讶了！”老人叫道。

‘However,’ Mr. George resumes, ‘the less said about it, the better now. Come! You know the agreement. Always a pipe out of the two months’ interest! (Bosh! It’s all correct. You needn’t be afraid to order the pipe. Here’s the new bill, and here’s the two months’ interest-money, and a devil-and-all of a scrape it is to get it together in my business.)’
“不过，”乔治先生继续说道，“现在越少说越好。”来！你知道这个协议。两个月的利息总是花光了！ （波什！都是对的。你不必害怕订购烟斗。这是新账单，这是两个月的利息，要在我的事。）'

Mr. George sits, with his arms folded, consuming the family and the parlour while Grandfather Smallweed is assisted by Judy to two black leathern cases out of a locked bureau, in one of which he secures the document he has just received, and from the other takes another similar document which hl of business care—I should like to throw a cat at you instead of a cushion, and I will too if you make such a confounded fool of yourself!—and your mother, who was a prudent woman as dry as a chip, just dwindled away like touchwood after you and Judy were born—you are an old pig. You are a brimstone pig. You’re a head of swine!’
乔治先生抱着双臂坐着，吃光了家人和客厅，而祖父斯莫威德则在朱迪的协助下，从锁着的办公桌里取出两个黑色皮箱，其中一个他把刚刚收到的文件放在其中，并且从其他人拿了另一份类似的文件，里面有商业关怀——我想向你扔一只猫而不是一个垫子，如果你做出如此愚蠢的傻事，我也会这么做！——还有你的母亲，她是一个谨慎的女人你和朱迪出生后，干得像木片一样，像触木一样逐渐消失——你是一头老猪。你是一头硫磺猪。你真是个猪头！

Judy, not interested in what she has often heard, begins to collect in a basin various tributary streams of tea, from the bottoms of cups and saucers and from the bottom of the teapot for the little charwoman’s evening meal. In like manner she gets together, in the iron bread-basket, as many outside fragments and worn-down heels of loaves as the rigid economy of the house has left in existence.
朱迪对她经常听到的东西不感兴趣，开始从茶杯、碟子的底部和茶壶的底部收集各种支流的茶流到盆里，作为小女佣的晚餐。她以同样的方式，把家里僵化的经济所留下的尽可能多的外部碎片和破旧的面包跟放在铁面包篮里。

‘But your father and me were partners, Bart,’ says the old gentleman, ‘and when I am gone, you and Judy will have all there is. It’s rare for you both that you went out early in life—Judy to the flower business, and you to the law. You won’t want to spend it. You’ll get your living without it, and put more to it. When I am gone, Judy will go back to the flower business and you’ll still stick to the law.’
“但是你的父亲和我是合伙人，巴特，”老绅士说道，“当我离开后，你和朱迪将拥有一切。”你们俩很早就出去了，这对你们来说是很少见的——朱迪从事花卉生意，而你则从事法律工作。你不会想花它的。没有它你也能过上好日子，而且还能投入更多。当我离开后，朱迪会回到花卉行业，而你仍然会遵守法律。

One might infer from Judy’s appearance that her business rather lay with the thorns than the flowers, but she has in her time been apprenticed to the art and mystery of artificial flower-making. A close observer might perhaps detect both in her eye and her brother’s, when their venerable grandsire anticipates his being gone, some little impatience to know when he may be going, and some resentful opinion that it is time he went.
人们可能会从朱迪的外表推断出，她的工作更多的是荆棘而不是鲜花，但她在她那个时代已经成为人造花制作艺术和神秘的学徒。当可敬的祖父预计他会离开时，细心的观察者也许会在她和她哥哥的眼中发现一些不耐烦，想知道他什么时候会离开，以及一些怨恨的意见，认为他是时候离开了。

‘Now, if everybody has done,’ says Judy, completing her preparations, ‘I’ll have that girl in to her tea. She would never leave off if she took it by herself in the kitchen.’
“现在，如果每个人都完成了，”朱迪说，完成她的准备工作，“我会让那个女孩去喝茶。”如果她一个人在厨房里拿着它，她就永远不会离开。

Charley is accordingly introduced, and under a heavy fire of eyes, sits down to her basin and a Druidical ruin of bread and butter. In the active superintendence of this young person, Judy Smallweed appears to attain a perfectly geological age and to date from the remotest periods. Her systematic manner of flying at her and pouncing on her, with or without pretence, whether or no, is wonderful, evincing an accomplishment in the art of girl-driving seldom reached by the oldest practitioners.
据此介绍了查理，在炽热的目光下，她坐在她的脸盆和德鲁伊面包和黄油的废墟旁。在这个年轻人的积极监督下，朱迪·斯莫威德似乎达到了完美的地质年龄，并且可以追溯到最遥远的时期。她系统地飞向她、扑向她，无论有没有伪装，无论是否有，都是精彩的，显示出最年长的从业者很少达到的女孩驾驶艺术的成就。

‘Now, don’t stare about you all the afternoon,’ cries Judy, shaking her head and stamping her foot as she happens to catch the glance which has been previously sounding the basin of tea, ‘but take your victuals and get back to your work.’
“现在，不要整个下午都盯着你看，”朱迪喊道，当她碰巧看到刚才敲响茶盆茶水声的目光时，她摇摇头，跺着脚，“带上你的食物，回去吧。”你的工作。'

‘Yes, miss,’ says Charley.
“是的，小姐，”查理说。

‘Don’t say yes,’ returns Miss Smallweed, ‘for I know what you girls are. Do it without saying it, and then I may begin to believe you.’
“别说‘是’，”斯莫威德小姐回答道，“因为我知道你们这些女孩是什么人。不说出来就去做，然后我就可以开始相信你了。

Charley swallows a great gulp of tea in token of submission and so disperses the Druidical ruins that Miss Smallweed charges her not to gormandize, which ‘in you girls,’ she observes, is disgusting. Charley might find some more difficulty in meeting her views on the general subject of girls but for a knock at the door.
查理喝了一大口茶以示屈服，并驱散了德鲁伊废墟，斯莫威德小姐要求她不要乱搞，她观察到，“你们这些女孩子们”的这种行为是令人作呕的。如果不是有人来敲门，查理可能会发现很难满足她对女孩这个普遍话题的看法。

‘See who it is, and don’t chew when you open it!’ cries Judy.
“看看是谁，打开它时不要咀嚼！”朱迪喊道。

The object of her attentions withdrawing for the purpose, Miss Smallweed takes that opportunity of jumbling the remainder of the bread and butter together and launching two or three dirty tea-cups into the ebb-tide of the basin of tea as a hint that she considers the eating and drinking terminated.
她的注意力集中在这个目的上，斯莫威德小姐趁这个机会把剩下的面包和黄油混在一起，然后把两三个脏茶杯扔进茶盆的退潮中，以此作为她认为的暗示。饮食停止了。

‘Now! Who is it, and what’s wanted?’ says the snappish Judy.
'现在！ “是谁？想要什么？”脾气暴躁的朱迪说道。

It is one Mr. George, it appears. Without other announcement or ceremony, Mr. George walks in.
看起来是一位乔治先生。没有其他公告或仪式，乔治先生就走了进来。

‘Whew!’ says Mr. George. ‘You are hot here. Always a fire, eh? Well! Perhaps you do right to get used to one.’ Mr. George makes the latter remark to himself as he nods to Grandfather Smallweed.
“哇！”乔治先生说。 ‘你这里很热。总是着火吧？出色地！也许你习惯了是对的。”乔治先生一边向斯莫威德爷爷点点头，一边自言自语道。

‘Ho! It’s you!’ cries the old gentleman. ‘How de do? How de do?’
‘嗬！是你！”老先生喊道。 ‘怎么办？怎么办？

‘Middling,’ replies Mr. George, taking a chair. ‘Your granddaughter I have had the honour of seeing before; my service to you, miss.’
“中等，”乔治先生回答道，坐到了椅子上。 “我以前有幸见过你的孙女；我为您服务，小姐。

‘This is my grandson,’ says Grandfather Smallweed. ‘You ha’n’t seen him before. He is in the law and not much at home.’
“这是我的孙子，”斯莫威德祖父说。 ‘你以前没见过他。他是在法律面前，不太在家里。”

‘My service to him, too! He is like his sister. He is very like his sister. He is devilish like his sister,’ says Mr. George, laying a great and not altogether complimentary stress on his last adjective.
“我也为他服务！他就像他的妹妹。他很像他的妹妹。他和他的妹妹一样邪恶。”乔治先生说道，他对最后一个形容词强调了很大的语气，但并不完全是恭维。

‘And how does the world use you, Mr. George?’ Grandfather Smallweed inquires, slowly rubbing his legs.
“乔治先生，这个世界是如何使用你的？”斯莫威德祖父问道，慢慢地揉着他的腿。

‘Pretty much as usual. Like a football.’
'和往常一样。就像足球一样。

He is a swarthy brown man of fifty, well made, and good looking, with crisp dark hair, bright eyes, and a broad chest. His sinewy and powerful hands, as sunburnt as his face, have evidently been used to a pretty rough life. What is curious about him is that he sits forward on his chair as if he were, from long habit, allowing space for some dress or accoutrements that he has altogether laid aside. His step too is measured and heavy and would go well with a weighty clash and jingle of spurs. He is close-shaved now, but his mouth is set as if his upper lip had been for years familiar with a great moustache; and his manner of occasionally laying the open palm of his broad brown hand upon it is to the same effect. Altogether one might guess Mr. George to have been a trooper once upon a time.
他是一个五十岁的黑皮肤男人，身材匀称，相貌英俊，有着清爽的黑发、明亮的眼睛和宽阔的胸膛。他那双有力而有力的双手，和他的脸一样被晒黑，显然已经习惯了相当艰苦的生活。令人好奇的是，他坐在椅子上，身体前倾，就好像他出于长期习惯，为一些他完全放在一边的衣服或装备留出空间。他的脚步也很稳重，很适合沉重的碰撞和马刺的叮当声。他现在胡子刮得很短，但他的嘴型就好像他的上唇已经长了很多年的大胡子一样。他偶尔将张开的棕色宽手放在上面的方式也达到了同样的效果。总而言之，人们可能会猜测乔治先生曾经是一名士兵。

A special contrast Mr. George makes to the Smallweed family. Trooper was never yet billeted upon a household more unlike him. It is a broadsword to an oyster-knife. His developed figure and their stunted forms, his large manner filling any amount of room and their little narrow pinched ways, his sounding voice and their sharp spare tones, are in the strongest and the strangest opposition. As he sits in the middle of the grim parlour, leaning a little forward, with his hands upon his thighs and his elbows squared, he looks as though, if he remained there long, he would absorb into himself the whole family and the whole four-roomed house, extra little back-kitchen and all.
乔治先生与斯莫威德家族形成了特殊的对比。特鲁珀从来没有住过一个与他如此不同的家庭。它是一把大刀和一把牡蛎刀。他发达的身材和他们发育不良的体形，他那充满任何空间的大举止和他们狭小的狭窄的方式，他响亮的声音和他们尖锐的闲适语调，都是最强烈和最奇怪的对立。当他坐在阴森的客厅中央时，身子稍微向前倾，双手放在大腿上，肘部呈方形，看上去，如果他在那里待得久一点，他就会把整个家庭和四个人都吸收进去。 -有房间的房子，额外的小后厨房等等。

‘Do you rub your legs to rub life into ‘em?’ he asks of Grandfather Smallweed after looking round the room.
“你会摩擦你的腿来给它们注入生命吗？”他环顾房间后问斯莫威德祖父。

‘Why, it’s partly a habit, Mr. George, and—yes—it partly helps the circulation,’ he replies.
“为什么，这部分是一种习惯，乔治先生，而且——是的——它部分有助于血液循环，”他回答道。

‘The cir-cu-la-tion!’ repeats Mr. George, folding his arms upon his chest and seeming to become two sizes larger. ‘Not much of that, I should think.’
“循环！”乔治先生重复道，双臂交叉在胸前，身体似乎变大了两号。 “我想，这并不多。”

‘Truly I’m old, Mr. George,’ says Grandfather Smallweed. ‘But I can carry my years. I’m older than HER,’ nodding at his wife, ‘and see what she is? You’re a brimstone chatterer!’ with a sudden revival of his late hostility.
“我确实老了，乔治先生，”斯莫威德祖父说。 “但我可以承受我的岁月。我比她大，”对他的妻子点点头，“看看她是什么样的人？你真是个喋喋不休的人！”他最近的敌意突然又回来了。

‘Unlucky old soul!’ says Mr. George, turning his head in that direction. ‘Don’t scold the old lady. Look at her here, with her poor cap half off her head and her poor hair all in a muddle. Hold up, ma’am. That’s better. There we are! Think of your mother, Mr. Smallweed,’ says Mr. George, coming back to his seat from assisting her, ‘if your wife an’t enough.’
“不幸的老灵魂！”乔治先生说着，把头转向那个方向。 ‘别骂老太太了。看看她，可怜的帽子半脱在头上，可怜的头发乱糟糟的。坚持住，女士。这样更好。我们到了！想想你的母亲，斯莫威德先生，”乔治先生帮完她回到座位上说道，“如果你的妻子还不够的话。

‘I suppose you were an excellent son, Mr. George?’ the old man hints with a leer.
“我想你是个出色的儿子，乔治先生？”老人斜视着暗示道。

The colour of Mr. George’s face rather deepens as he replies, ‘Why no. I wasn’t.’
乔治先生的脸色加深了，他回答道：“为什么不呢？”我不是。

‘I am astonished at it.’
“我对此感到惊讶。”

‘So am I. I ought to have hands to Mr. George, who twists it up for a pipelight. As the old man inspects, through his glasses, every up-stroke and down-stroke of both documents before he releases them from their leathern prison, and as he counts the money three times over and requires Judy to say every word she utters at least twice, and is as tremulously slow of speech and action as it is possible to be, this business is a long time in progress. When it is quite concluded, and not before, he disengages his ravenous eyes and fingers from it and answers Mr. George’s last remark by saying, ‘Afraid to order the pipe? We are not so mercenary as that, sir. Judy, see directly to the pipe and the glass of cold brandy-and-water for Mr. George.’
“我也是。我应该把手伸向乔治先生，他把它扭成一根烟斗。”当老人通过眼镜检查两份文件的每一个上下笔划时，他将它们从皮革监狱中释放出来，当他将钱数了三遍并要求朱迪至少说出她所说的每一个字时两次，并且言语和行动都尽可能缓慢，这项业务进行了很长时间。当它完全结束时，而不是之前，他将贪婪的眼睛和手指从烟斗上移开，并回答乔治先生的最后一句话：“害怕点烟斗？”先生，我们不是那么唯利是图。朱迪，直接看向乔治先生的管道和一杯冷白兰地和水。

The sportive twins, who have been looking straight before them all this time except when they have been engrossed by the black leathern cases, retire together, generally disdainful of the visitor, but leaving him to the old man as two young cubs might leave a traveller to the parental bear.
这对顽皮的双胞胎一直直视前方，除了全神贯注于黑色皮箱的时候，他们一起退了出去，通常对来访者不屑一顾，但把他留给了老人，就像两只幼崽可能会离开旅行者一样给熊爸爸。

‘And there you sit, I suppose, all the day long, eh?’ says Mr. George with folded arms.
“我想，你一整天都坐在那里，是吗？”乔治先生抱着双臂说道。

‘Just so, just so,’ the old man nods.
“正是如此，正是如此。”老人点头。

‘And don’t you occupy yourself at all?’
“你就一点也不忙吗？”

‘I watch the fire—and the boiling and the roasting—‘
“我看着火——还有沸腾和烘烤——”

‘When there is any,’ says Mr. George with great expression.
“如果有的话，”乔治先生神情激动地说。

‘Just so. When there is any.’
‘就是这样。当有的话。

‘Don’t you read or get read to?’
“你不读书，也不听别人读书吗？”

The old man shakes his head with sharp sly triumph. ‘No, no. We have never been readers in our family. It don’t pay. Stuff. Idleness. Folly. No, no!’
老人狡猾地胜利地摇摇头。 '不，不。我们家从来都不是读书人。它不付钱。东西。懒惰。蠢事。不，不！'

‘There’s not much to choose between your two states,’ says the visitor in a key too low for the old man’s dull hearing as he looks from him to the old woman and back again. ‘I say!’ in a louder voice.
“在你的两种状态之间没有太多选择，”来访者的声音对于老人迟钝的听力来说太低了，他的目光从他身上移到了老妇人身上，又转回来。 “我说！”声音更大了。

‘I hear you.’
“我听到了。”

‘You’ll sell me up at last, I suppose, when I am a day in arrear.’
“我想，当我拖欠一天的工资时，你最终会把我卖掉。”

‘My dear friend!’ cries Grandfather Smallweed, stretching out both hands to embrace him. ‘Never! Never, my dear friend! But my friend in the city that I got to lend you the money—HE might!’
“我亲爱的朋友！”斯莫威德爷爷喊道，伸出双手拥抱他。 '绝不！从来没有，我亲爱的朋友！但我在城里的朋友，我必须借钱给你——他可能会！”

‘Oh! You can’t answer for him?’ says Mr. George, finishing the inquiry in his lower key with the words ‘You lying old rascal!’
'哦！ “你不能替他回答吗？”乔治先生用低沉的语调结束了询问，“你这个撒谎的老流氓！”

‘My dear friend, he is not to be depended on. I wouldn’t trust him. He will have his bond, my dear friend.’
‘我亲爱的朋友，他不值得依赖。我不会相信他。他会得到他的保证，我亲爱的朋友。

‘Devil doubt him,’ says Mr. George. Charley appearing with a tray, on which are the pipe, a small paper of tobacco, and the brandyand-water, he asks her, ‘How do you come here! You haven’t got the family face.’
“魔鬼怀疑他，”乔治先生说。查理拿着一个托盘出现，上面有烟斗、一小张烟草纸和白兰地和水，他问她：“你怎么到这里来了！”你没有家人的面子。

‘I goes out to work, sir,’ returns Charley.
“我出去工作了，先生，”查理回答道。

The trooper (if trooper he be or have been) takes her bonnet off, with a light touch for so strong a hand, and pats her on the head. ‘You give the house almost a wholesome look. It wants a bit of youth as much as it wants fresh air.’ Then he dismisses her, lights his pipe, and drinks to Mr. Smallweed’s friend in the city— the one solitary flight of that esteemed old gentleman’s imagination.
警察（如果他是或曾经是警察的话）摘下她的帽子，用如此有力的手轻轻一碰，拍拍她的头。 “你给房子带来了几乎健康的外观。它需要一点青春，就像它需要新鲜空气一样。”然后他打发走了她，点燃烟斗，给斯莫威德先生在城里的朋友喝酒——这是那位受人尊敬的老绅士的一次孤独的想象力飞翔。

‘So you think he might be hard upon me, eh?’
“所以你认为他可能对我很严厉，是吗？”

‘I think he might—I am afraid he would. I have known him do it,’ says Grandfather Smallweed incautiously, ‘twenty times.’
“我认为他可能——我担心他会。我就知道他这么做过，”斯莫威德祖父漫不经心地说，“有二十次了。”

Incautiously, because his stricken better-half, who has been dozing over the fire for some time, is instantly aroused and jabbers ‘Twenty thousand pounds, twenty twenty-pound notes in a money-box, twenty guineas, twenty million twenty per cent, twenty—‘ and is then cut short by the flying cushion, which the visitor, to whom this singular experiment appears to be a novelty, snatches from her face as it crushes her in the usual manner.
不小心，因为他受伤的妻子已经在火上打瞌睡有一段时间了，他立刻就被惊醒了，叽叽喳喳地说：“两万英镑，钱箱里装着二十张二十英镑的钞票，二十几尼，两千万百分之二十，二十——”然后被飞垫打断了，对来访者来说，这个奇异的实验似乎很新奇，当它以通常的方式压碎她时，它从她的脸上夺走了。

‘You’re a brimstone idiot. You’re a scorpion—a brimstone scorpion! You’re a sweltering toad. You’re a chattering clattering broomstick witch that ought to be burnt!’ gasps the old man, prostrate in his chair. ‘My dear friend, will you shake me up a little?’
‘你是个硫磺白痴。你是一只蝎子——一只硫磺蝎子！你是一只闷热的蟾蜍。你是一个喋喋不休的扫帚女巫，应该被烧死！”老人倒在椅子上喘着气说道。 “我亲爱的朋友，你能让我摇晃一下吗？”

Mr. George, who has been looking first at one of them and then at the other, as if he were demented, takes his venerable acquaintance by the throat on receiving this request, and dragging him upright in his chalr as easily as if he were a doll, appears in two minds whether or no to shake all future power of cushioning out of him and shake him into his grave. Resisting the temptation, but agitating him violently enough to make his head roll like a harlequin’s, he puts him smartly down in his chair again and adjusts his skull-cap with such a rub that the old man winks with both eyes for a minute afterwards.
乔治先生先看看他们中的一个，然后又看看另一个，好像他疯了一样，一接到这个请求，就掐住了这位可敬的熟人的喉咙，把他从床上拉了起来，就像他是一个被人欺负的人一样。一个洋娃娃，出现在两个人的脑海中，是否要摆脱他未来所有的缓冲能力，并将他摇入坟墓。他抵制住了诱惑，但又猛烈地搅动了他，让他的头像丑角一样转动，他又巧妙地把他放到椅子上，揉了揉他的无边帽，结果老人眨了一会儿双眼。

‘O Lord!’ gasps Mr. Smallweed. ‘That’ll do. Thank you, my dear friend, that’ll do. Oh, dear me, I’m out of breath. O Lord!’ And Mr. Smallweed says it not without evident apprehensions of his dear friend, who still stands over him looming larger than ever.
“主啊！”斯莫威德先生喘着气说道。 ‘这样就可以了。谢谢你，我亲爱的朋友，就这样了。哦，天哪，我已经喘不过气来了。主啊！”斯莫尔韦德先生说这句话时，显然对他亲爱的朋友感到担忧，他仍然站在他的上方，比以往任何时候都显得更加高大。

The alarming presence, however, gradually subsides into its chair and falls to smoking in long puffs, consoling itself with the philosophical reflection, ‘The name of your friend in the city begins with a D, comrade, and you’re about right respecting the bond.’
然而，令人震惊的存在逐渐消退到椅子上，长长地吸着烟，用哲学反思来安慰自己，“同志，你在这座城市的朋友的名字以 D 开头，你尊重这个人是正确的”。纽带。'
