‘Did you speak, Mr. George?’ inquires the old man.
“乔治先生，你说话了吗？”老人问道。

The trooper shakes his head, and leaning forward with his right elbow on his right knee and his pipe supported in that hand, while his other hand, resting on his left leg, squares his left elbow in a martial manner, continues to smoke. Meanwhile he looks at Mr. Smallweed with grave attention and now and then fans the cloud of smoke away in order that he may see him the more clearly.
士兵摇摇头，身体前倾，右肘放在右膝上，一手托着烟斗，另一只手放在左腿上，以军事方式摆正左肘，继续抽烟。与此同时，他全神贯注地看着斯莫威德先生，时不时地扇开烟雾，以便能更清楚地看到他。

‘I take it,’ he says, making just as much and as little change in his position as will enable him to reach the glass to his lips with a round, full action, ‘that I am the only man alive (or dead either) that gets the value of a pipe out of YOU?’
“我认为，”他说，同时稍微改变自己的位置，以便能够以一个圆形、完整的动作将玻璃杯送到嘴唇上，“我是唯一活着的人（或者死了的人） ）这能让你获得烟斗的价值吗？

‘Well,’ returns the old man, ‘it’s true that I don’t see company, Mr. George, and that I don’t treat. I can’t afford to it. But as you, in your pleasant way, made your pipe a condition—‘
“嗯，”老人回答道，“确实，乔治先生，我没有见到同伴，也没有请客。”我负担不起。但当你以你愉快的方式把你的烟斗作为一个条件时——”

‘Why, it’s not for the value of it; that’s no great thing. It was a fancy to get it out of you. To have something in for my money.’
‘为什么，这不是为了它的价值；而是为了它的价值。这不是什么了不起的事。把它从你身上夺走真是一种幻想。用我的钱来得到一些东西。

‘Ha! You’re prudent, prudent, sir!’ cries Grandfather Smallweed, rubbing his legs.
'哈！你很谨慎，很谨慎，先生！”斯莫威德爷爷一边擦着腿一边喊道。

‘Very. I always was.’ Puff. ‘It’s a sure sign of my prudence that I ever found the way here.’ Puff. ‘Also, that I am what I am.’ Puff. ‘I am well known to be prudent,’ says Mr. George, composedly smoking. ‘I rose in life that way.’
'非常。我一直都是。’噗。 “我找到了来这里的路，这无疑表明了我的谨慎。”噗。 “而且，我就是我。”噗。 “众所周知，我是个谨慎的人，”乔治先生平静地抽着烟说道。 “我就是这样成长起来的。”

‘Don’t he down-hearted, sir. You may rise yet.’
“他别灰心丧气，先生。你还可以起来。

Mr. George laughs and drinks.
乔治先生笑着喝了酒。

‘Ha’n’t you no relations, now,’ asks Grandfather Smallweed with a twinkle in his eyes, ‘who would pay off this little principal or who would lend you a good name or two that I could persuade my friend in the city to make you a further advance upon? Two good names would be sufficient for my friend in the city. Ha’n’t you no such relations, Mr. George?’
“现在你没有亲戚了吗？”斯莫威德爷爷眼睛里闪烁着光芒，问道，“谁会还清这个小本金，或者谁会借给你一两个好名声，这样我就可以说服我在城里的朋友了。”使你更进一步？对于我在城里的朋友来说，两个好名字就足够了。乔治先生，你不是有这样的关系吗？

Mr. George, still composedly smoking, replies, ‘If I had, I shouldn’t trouble them. I have been trouble enough to my belongings in my day. It MAY be a very good sort of penitence in a vagabond, who has wasted the best time of his life, to go back then to decent people that he never was a credit to and live upon them, but it’s not my sort. The best kind of amends then for having gone away is to keep away, in my opinion.’
乔治先生仍然镇定地抽烟，回答说：“如果我抽了，我就不应该麻烦他们了。”我这一天对我的财物已经够麻烦的了。对于一个浪费了一生中最美好的时光的流浪汉来说，回到那些他从未信任过的正派人那里并依靠他们生活，这可能是一种很好的忏悔，但这不是我的类型。在我看来，对离开的最好补偿就是远离。

‘But natural affection, Mr. George,’ hints Grandfather Smallweed.
“但是自然的感情，乔治先生，”斯莫威德祖父暗示道。

‘For two good names, hey?’ says Mr. George, shaking his head and still composedly smoking. ‘No. That’s not my sort either.’
“给两个好名字，嘿？”乔治先生摇着头说道，仍然泰然自若地抽烟。 '不。那也不是我喜欢的类型。

Grandfather Smallweed has been gradually sliding down in his chair since his last adjustment and is now a bundle of clothes with a voice in it calling for Judy. That houri, appearing, shakes him up in the usual manner and is charged by the old gentleman to remain near him. For he seems chary of putting his visitor to the trouble of repeating his late attentions.
自从上次调整后，斯莫威德祖父在椅子上逐渐滑落，现在变成了一捆衣服，里面有一个声音在呼唤朱迪。那个小时出现了，以通常的方式摇晃了他，并被老绅士要求留在他身边。因为他似乎很小心，不想让他的访客重复他迟来的关注。

‘Ha!’ he observes when he is in trim again. ‘If you could have traced out the captain, Mr. George, it would have been the making of you. If when you first came here, in consequence of our advertisement in the newspapers—when I say ‘our,’ I’m alluding to the advertisements of my friend in the city, and one or two others who embark their capital in the same way, and are so friendly towards me as sometimes to give me a lift with my little pittance— if at that time you could have helped us, Mr. George, it would have been the making of you.’
“哈！”当他再次恢复状态时，他说道。 “如果你能找到船长，乔治先生，那就是你的功劳了。”如果当你第一次来到这里时，由于报纸上我们的广告——当我说“我们的”时，我指的是我在城里的朋友的广告，以及其他一两个以同样的方式踏上首都的广告，而且对我非常友好，有时甚至用我微薄的钱载我一程——如果当时你能帮助我们，乔治先生，那就是你的功劳了。

‘I was willing enough to be ‘made,’ as you call it,’ says Mr. George, smoking not quite so placidly as before, for since the entrance of Judy he has been in some measure disturbed by a fascination, not of the admiring kind, which obliges him to look at her as she stands by her grandfather’s chair, ‘but on the whole, I am glad I wasn’t now.’
“我很愿意被‘制造’，就像你所说的那样，”乔治先生说，他抽烟的样子不像以前那么平静了，因为自从朱迪进来后，他在某种程度上被一种迷恋所困扰，而不是被一种迷恋所困扰。当她站在她祖父的椅子旁时，他不得不看着她，“但总的来说，我很高兴我现在不是。”

‘Why, Mr. George? In the name of—of brimstone, why?’ says Grandfather Smallweed with a plain appearance of exasperation. (Brimstone apparently suggested by his eye lighting on Mrs. Smallweed in her slumber.)
“为什么，乔治先生？ “以硫磺的名义，为什么？”斯莫威德祖父说道，脸上显出明显的恼怒。 （硫磺石显然是通过他的目光照射在熟睡的斯莫威德夫人身上来暗示的。）

‘For two reasons, comrade.’
“有两个原因，同志。”

‘And what two reasons, Mr. George? In the name of the—‘
“乔治先生，哪两个原因？以——‘的名义

‘Of our friend in the city?’ suggests Mr. George, composedly drinking.
“我们在城里的朋友？”乔治先生沉着地喝着酒说道。

‘Aye, if you like. What two reasons?’
‘是的，如果你愿意的话。哪两个原因？

‘In the first place,’ returns Mr. George, but still looking at Judy as if she being so old and so like her grandfather it is indifferent which of the two he addresses, ‘you gentlemen took me in. You advertised that Mr. Hawdon (Captain Hawdon, if you hold to the saying ‘Once a captain, always a captain’) was to hear of something to his advantage.’
“首先，”乔治先生回答道，但仍然看着朱迪，就好像她那么老了，那么像她的祖父，他对这两个人中的哪一个说话并不重要，“你们先生们收留了我。你们宣传说，乔治先生收留了我。”霍顿（霍顿船长，如果你坚持‘一旦成为船长，永远是船长’这句话的话）听到了对他有利的事情。

‘Well?’ returns the old man shrilly and sharply.
“怎么样？”老人尖声尖锐地回答。

‘Well!’ says Mr. George, smoking on. ‘It wouldn’t have been much to his advantage to have been clapped into prison by the whole bill and judgment trade of London.’
“好吧！”乔治先生一边说，一边继续抽烟。 “如果伦敦的整个票据和判决交易把他关进监狱，那对他来说并没有多大好处。”

‘How do you know that? Some of his rich relations might have paid his debts or compounded for ‘em. Besides, he had taken US in. He owed us immense sums all round. I would sooner have strangled him than had no return. If I sit here thinking of him,’ snarls the old man, holding up his impotent ten fingers, ‘I want to strangle him now.’ And in a sudden access of fury, he throws the cushion at the unoffending Mrs. Smallweed, but it passes harmlessly on one side of her chair.
'你怎么知道？他的一些富有的亲戚可能已经偿还了他的债务或为他们提供了复利。此外，他已经接纳了美国。他欠我们巨额款项。我宁愿掐死他，也不愿不归路。如果我坐在这里想着他，”老人举起无力的十根手指咆哮道，“我现在就想掐死他。”他突然勃然大怒，把垫子扔向不冒犯的斯莫威德太太，但是它从她椅子的一侧无害地经过。

‘I don’t need to be told,’ returns the trooper, taking his pipe from his lips for a moment and carrying his eyes back from following the progress of the cushion to the pipe-bowl which is burning low, ‘that he carried on heavily and went to ruin. I have been at his right hand many a day when he was charging upon ruin full-gallop. I was with him when he was sick and well, rich and poor. I laid this hand upon him after he had run through everything and broken down everything beneath him—when he held a pistol to his head.’
“我不需要被告知，”士兵回答道，暂时把烟斗从嘴边拿开，然后把目光从沿着垫子移动到正在燃烧的烟斗碗上的过程中收回来，“他带着烟斗。”重重地走向毁灭。当他全速冲向废墟时，我已经在他的右手边很多天了。当他生病或健康、富有或贫穷时，我都陪伴在他身边。在他冲破一切并摧毁他身下的一切之后，我把手放在了他身上——当时他用手枪指着他的头。

‘I wish he had let it off,’ says the benevolent old man, ‘and blown his head into as many pieces as he owed pounds!’
“我希望他能放过这一切，”仁慈的老人说道，“把他的头炸成碎片，数量与他所欠的英镑一样多！”

‘That would have been a smash indeed,’ returns the trooper coolly; ‘any way, he had been young, hopeful, and handsome in the days gone by, and I am glad I never found him, when he was neither, to lead to a result so much to his advantage. That’s reason number one.’
“那确实是一次粉碎，”士兵冷静地回答道。 “无论如何，在过去的日子里，他一直年轻、充满希望、英俊，我很高兴我从来没有发现他，当他两者都不是时，导致了对他如此有利的结果。这是第一个原因。

‘I hope number two’s as good?’ snarls the old man.
“我希望第二个也一样好吗？”老人咆哮道。

‘Why, no. It’s more of a selfish reason. If I had found him, I must have gone to the other world to look. He was there.’
‘为什么，不。这更多是出于自私的原因。如果我找到了他，我一定是到另一个世界去寻找了。他在那。'

‘How do you know he was there?’
“你怎么知道他在那里？”

‘He wasn’t here.’
“他不在这里。”

‘How do you know he wasn’t here?’
“你怎么知道他不在这里？”

‘Don’t lose your temper as well as your money,’ says Mr. George, calmly knocking the ashes out of his pipe. ‘He was drowned long before. I am convinced of it. He went over a ship’s side. Whether intentionally or accidentally, I don’t know. Perhaps your friend in the city does. Do you know what that tune is, Mr. Smallweed?’ he adds after breaking off to whistle one, accompanied on the table with the empty pipe.
“不要发脾气，也不要发钱。”乔治先生一边说，一边平静地敲掉烟斗里的灰烬。 “他很久以前就被淹死了。我对此深信不疑。他越过船舷。是有意还是无意，我不知道。也许你在城里的朋友知道。你知道那首曲子是什么吗，斯莫威德先生？”他停下来吹了一支口哨，并用空烟斗放在桌子上伴奏。

‘Tune!’ replied the old man. ‘No. We never have tunes here.’
“调！”老人回答道。 '不。我们这里从来没有曲调。

‘That’s the Dead March in Saul. They bury soldiers to it, so it’s the natural end of the subject. Now, if your pretty granddaughter —excuse me, miss—will condescend to take care of this pipe for two months, we shall save the cost of one next time. Good evening, Mr. Smallweed!’
“这就是《扫罗》中的死亡进行曲。他们把士兵埋在里面，所以这就是这个话题的自然结局。现在，如果你漂亮的孙女——对不起，小姐——肯屈尊照顾这根烟斗两个月，我们下次就可以省下一根的费用了。晚上好，斯莫威德先生！

‘My dear friend!’ the old man gives him both his hands.
“我亲爱的朋友！”老人伸出双手。

‘So you think your friend in the city will be hard upon me if I fall in a payment?’ says the trooper, looking down upon him like a giant.
“那么你认为如果我拖欠付款，你在城里的朋友会对我很严厉吗？”士兵说道，他像巨人一样俯视着他。

‘My dear friend, I am afraid he will,’ returns the old man, looking up at him like a pygmy.
“我亲爱的朋友，恐怕他会的，”老人回答道，像侏儒一样抬头看着他。

Mr. George laughs, and with a glance at Mr. Smallweed and a parting salutation to the scornful Judy, strides out of the parlour, clashing imaginary sabres and other metallic appurtenances as he goes.
乔治先生笑了，看了一眼斯莫尔韦德先生，向轻蔑的朱迪行了临别致意，然后大步走出客厅，边走边碰撞着想象中的军刀和其他金属附属品。

‘You’re a damned rogue,’ says the old gentleman, making a hideous grimace at the door as he shuts it. ‘But I’ll lime you, you dog, I’ll lime you!’
“你真是个该死的流氓。”老先生关门时对着门做了个可怕的鬼脸，说道。 “但我会石灰你，你这狗，我会石灰你！”

After this amiable remark, his spirit soars into those enchanting regions of reflection which its education and pursuits have opened to it, and again he and Mrs. Smallweed while away the rosy hours, two unrelieved sentinels forgotten as aforesaid by the Black Serjeant.
在这句和蔼可亲的话之后，他的精神飞升到那些迷人的反思领域，这是他的教育和追求所打开的，他和斯莫尔威德夫人再次度过了美好的时光，就像黑警官所说的那样，两个无法释怀的哨兵被遗忘了。

While the twain are faithful to their post, Mr. George strides through the streets with a massive kind of swagger and a graveenough face. It is eight o’clock now, and the day is fast drawing in. He stops hard by Waterloo Bridge and reads a playbill, decides to go to Astley’s Theatre. Being there, is much delighted with the horses and the feats of strength; looks at the weapons with a critical eye; disapproves of the combats as giving evidences of unskilful swordsmanship; but is touched home by the sentiments. In the last scene, when the Emperor of Tartary gets up into a cart and condescends to bless the united lovers by hovering over them with the Union Jack, his eyelashes are moistened with emotion.
当两人忠于自己的岗位时，乔治先生大步穿过街道，神气十足，表情严肃。现在已经八点了，天色很快就过去了。他在滑铁卢桥前停下来，读了一份节目单，决定去阿斯特利剧院。在那里，人们对马匹和力量的壮举感到非常高兴。以批判的眼光审视武器；不赞成这些战斗，认为它们是剑术不熟练的证据；但被这些情感触动了。在最后一幕中，当鞑靼皇帝登上一辆马车，屈尊将英国国旗悬停在他们上方，祝福这对结合的恋人时，他的睫毛因情感而湿润。

The theatre over, Mr. George comes across the water again and makes his way to that curious region lying about the Haymarket and Leicester Square which is a centre of attraction to indifferent foreign hotels and indifferent foreigners, racket-courts, fightingmen, swordsmen, footguards, old china, gaming-houses, exhibitions, and a large medley of shabbiness and shrinking out of sight. Penetrating to the heart of this region, he arrives by a court and a long whitewashed passage at a great brick building composed of bare walls, floors, roof-rafters, and skylights, on the front of which, if it can be said to have any front, is painted GEORGE’S SHOOTING GALLERY, &c.
剧院结束了，乔治先生再次渡过水面，来到了干草市场和莱斯特广场附近那个令人好奇的地区，那里是一个吸引着冷漠的外国旅馆和冷漠的外国人、球场、战士、剑客、护卫的中心。 、旧瓷器、赌场、展览，还有一大堆破旧的东西和消失在视线之外的东西。深入到这个地区的中心，他经过一个庭院和一条长长的粉刷过的通道，到达了一座由光秃秃的墙壁、地板、屋顶椽子和天窗组成的巨大砖砌建筑，在它的前面，如果可以说有任何正面都涂有乔治射击馆等。

Into George’s Shooting Gallery, &c., he goes; and in it there are gaslights (partly turned off now), and two whitened targets for rifle-shooting, and archery accommodation, and fencing appliances, and all necessaries for the British art of boxing. None of these sports or exercises being pursued in George’s Shooting Gallery tonight, which is so devoid of company that a little grotesque man with a large head has it all to himself and lies asleep upon the floor.
他走进乔治的射击馆等；里面有煤气灯（现在部分关闭），两个用于步枪射击的白色靶子，射箭住宿，击剑用具，以及英国拳击艺术的所有必需品。今晚乔治的射击馆里没有进行这些运动或练习，那里如此缺乏同伴，以至于一个大脑袋的小怪人独自一人，躺在地板上睡着了。

The little man is dressed something like a gunsmith, in a greenbaize apron and cap; and his face and hands are dirty with gunpowder and begrimed with the loading of guns. As he lies in the light before a glaring white target, the black upon him shines again. Not far off is the strong, rough, primitive table with a vice upon it at which he has been working. He is a little man with a face all crushed together, who appears, from a certain blue and speckled appearance that one of his cheeks presents, to have been blown up, in the way of business, at some odd time or times.
这个小个子男人的打扮有点像枪匠，围着绿色围裙，戴着帽子。他的脸和手都被火药弄脏了，而且还因为装弹而弄脏了。当他躺在一个耀眼的白色目标前的光亮中时，他身上的黑色再次闪耀。不远处有一张坚固、粗糙、简陋的桌子，上面放着一个虎钳，他一直在上面工作。他是个小个子男人，一张脸都挤在一起了，从他的一侧脸颊呈现出的某种蓝色和斑点的外观来看，他似乎在某个奇怪的时间或时间里，在生意上被炸毁了。

‘Phil!’ says the trooper in a quiet voice.
“菲尔！”士兵轻声说道。

‘All right!’ cries Phil, scrambling to his feet.
“好吧！”菲尔喊道，爬了起来。

‘Anything been doing?’
“有什么事吗？”

‘Flat as ever so much swipes,’ says Phil. ‘Five dozen rifle and a dozen pistol. As to aim!’ Phil gives a howl at the recollection.
“滑动次数一如既往地平坦，”菲尔说。 “五打步枪和一打手枪。至于瞄准！”菲尔回忆起这件事，嚎啕大哭。

‘Shut up shop, Phil!’
“闭嘴吧，菲尔！”

As Phil moves about to execute this order, it appears that he is lame, though able to move very quickly. On the speckled side of his face he has no eyebrow, and on the other side he has a bushy black one, which want of uniformity gives him a very singular and rather sinister appearance. Everything seems to have happened to his hands that could possibly take place consistently with the retention of all the fingers, for they are notched, and seamed, and crumpled all over. He appears to be very strong and lifts heavy benches about as if he had no idea what weight was. He has a curious way of limping round the gallery with his shoulder against the wall and tacking off at objects he wants to lay hold of instead of going straight to them, which has left a smear all round the four walls, conventionally called ‘Phil’s mark.’
当菲尔准备执行这个命令时，虽然他能够移动得很快，但他看起来很跛。他脸上有斑点的一侧没有眉毛，另一侧则有浓密的黑色眉毛，这种不均匀的状态使他的外表显得非常奇特而阴险。一切似乎都发生在他的手上，而这些事情可能与所有手指的保留一致地发生，因为它们到处都是凹痕、接缝和皱巴巴的。他看起来很强壮，举着沉重的板凳，好像不知道什么是重量。他有一种奇怪的方式，用肩膀靠墙在画廊里一瘸一拐地走来走去，然后用钉子敲击他想要抓住的物体，而不是直接走向它们，这在四堵墙上留下了污点，通常被称为“菲尔的痕迹” .'

This custodian of George’s Gallery in George’s absence concludes his proceedings, when he has locked the great doors and turned out all the lights but one, which he leaves to glimmer, by dragging out from a wooden cabin in a corner two mattresses and bedding. These being drawn to opposite ends of the gallery, the trooper makes his own bed and Phil makes his.
这位乔治画廊的管理员在乔治不在的时候结束了他的工作，他锁上了大门，关掉了所有的灯，只留一盏灯在角落里微光，从角落里的木屋里拖出两张床垫和床上用品。这些人被吸引到画廊的两端，士兵自己铺床，菲尔铺他的床。

‘Phil!’ says the master, walking towards him without his coat and waistcoat, and looking more soldierly than ever in his braces. ‘You were found in a doorway, weren’t you?’
“菲尔！”大师说道，他没有穿外套和背心，朝他走来，戴着背带的样子比以往任何时候都更有军人气概。 “你是在门口被发现的，不是吗？”

‘Gutter,’ says Phil. ‘Watchman tumbled over me.’
“天沟，”菲尔说。 “看守人从我身上摔倒了。”

‘Then vagabondizing came natural to YOU from the beginning.’
“那么流浪对你来说从一开始就很自然。”

‘As nat’ral as possible,’ says Phil.
“尽可能自然，”菲尔说。

‘Good night!’
'晚安！'

‘Good night, guv’ner.’
“晚安，州长。”

Phil cannot even go straight to bed, but finds it necessary to shoulder round two sides of the gallery and then tack off at his mattress. The trooper, after taking a turn or two in the rifledistance and looking up at the moon now shining through the skylights, strides to his own mattress by a shorter route and goes to bed too.
菲尔甚至不能直接上床睡觉，但他发现有必要绕过画廊的两侧，然后钉上床垫。士兵在步枪距离转了一两圈，抬头看着天窗里的月亮，然后沿着一条较短的路大步走到自己的床垫上，也上床睡觉了。

CHAPTER XXII
第二十二章


Mr. Bucket
桶先生

Allegory looks pretty cool in Lincoln’s Inn Fields, though the evening is hot, for both Mr. Tulkinghorn’s windows are wide open, and the room is lofty, gusty, and gloomy. These may not be desirable characteristics when November comes with fog and sleet or January with ice and snow, but they have their merits in the sultry long vacation weather. They enable Allegory, though it has cheeks like peaches, and knees like bunches of blossoms, and rosy swellings for calves to its legs and muscles to its arms, to look tolerably cool to-night.
《寓言》在林肯客栈球场看起来很酷，尽管晚上很热，因为图金霍恩先生的窗户都大开着，房间很高，风很大，而且阴暗。当十一月有雾和雨夹雪或一月有冰雪时，这些特征可能并不理想，但在闷热的长假天气中它们有其优点。尽管《寓言》有着桃子般的脸颊、花朵般的膝盖、小腿至腿部的玫瑰色肿块以及手臂的肌肉，但它们使《寓言》今晚看起来相当凉爽。

Plenty of dust comes in at Mr. Tulkinghorn’s windows, and plenty more has generated among his furniture and papers. It lies thick everywhere. When a breeze from the country that has lost its way takes fright and makes a blind hurry to rush out again, it flings as much dust in the eyes of Allegory as the law-or Mr. Tulkinghorn, one of its trustiest representatives—may scatter, on occasion, in the eyes of the laity.
图尔金霍恩先生的窗户进了很多灰尘，他的家具和文件中也产生了更多灰尘。到处都是厚厚的。当一阵微风从迷失的国家吹来，带来恐惧，盲目地匆忙再次冲出时，它会在寓言的眼中扬起尽可能多的灰尘，就像法律——或者法律最值得信赖的代表之一图尔金霍恩先生——可能会驱散一样。 ，有时，在外行人看来。

In his lowering magazine of dust, the universal article into which his papers and himself, and all his clients, and all things of earth, animate and inanimate, are resolving, Mr. Tulkinghorn sits at one of the open windows enjoying a bottle of old port. Though a hard-grained man, close, dry, and silent, he can enjoy old wine with the best. He has a priceless bin of port in some artful cellar under the Fields, which is one of his many secrets. When he dines alone in chambers, as he has dined to-day, and has his bit of fish and his steak or chicken brought in from the coffee-house, he descends with a candle to the echoing regions below the deserted mansion, and heralded by a remote reverberation of thundering doors, comes gravely back encircled by an earthy atmosphere and carrying a bottle from which he pours a radiant nectar, two score and ten years old, that blushes in the glass to find itself so famous and fills the whole room with the fragrance of southern grapes.
图尔金霍恩先生坐在一扇开着的窗户前，坐在一扇开着的窗户旁，享受着一瓶陈旧的葡萄酒。港口。虽为人刚毅，亲近，干涩，沉默，却能与最好的老酒一起享用。他在田野下的某个巧妙的地窖里拥有一箱无价的波特酒，这是他的众多秘密之一。当他独自在房间里用餐时，就像他今天吃的那样，并从咖啡馆带来他的一点鱼和牛排或鸡肉时，他会拿着一支蜡烛下降到废弃宅邸下面回响的区域，并预示着远处传来雷鸣般的门声，他严肃地回来，被泥土的气氛包围着，手里拿着一个瓶子，从里面倒出了两瓶十岁的光芒四射的花蜜，它在玻璃杯里脸红了，发现自己如此出名，充满了整个房间带着南方葡萄的香气。

Mr. Tulkinghorn, sitting in the twilight by the open window, enjoys his wine. As if it whispered to him of its fifty years of silence and seclusion, it shuts him up the closer. More impenetrable than ever, he sits, and drinks, and mellows as it were in secrecy, pondering at that twilight hour on all the mysteries he knows, associated with darkening woods in the country, and vast blank shut-up houses in town, and perhaps sparing a thought or two for himself, and his family history, and his money, and his will—all a mystery to every one—and that one bachelor friend of his, a man of the same mould and a lawyer too, who lived the same kind of life until he was seventy-five years old, and then suddenly conceiving (as it is supposed) an impression that it was too monotonous, gave his gold watch to his hair-dresser one summer evening and walked leisurely home to the Temple and hanged himself.
图金霍恩先生在暮色中坐在开着的窗户旁，享用着他的葡萄酒。仿佛它在向他低声诉说五十年的沉默和隐居，却又让他闭得更近。他比以往任何时候都更加难以捉摸，他坐着，喝酒，慢慢成熟，就像在秘密中一样，在黄昏时分思考他所知道的所有奥秘，这些奥秘与乡间变暗的树林和城里大片空旷、封闭的房屋有关，也许会留心一两件事，想想他自己、他的家族史、他的金钱和他的遗嘱——对每个人来说，这一切都是一个谜——还有他的一个单身汉朋友，一个同样的人，也是一名律师，他生活在一直过着同样的生活，直到七十五岁，然后突然（正如人们所认为的）一种感觉太单调了，一个夏天的傍晚，他把金表交给了理发师，然后悠闲地走回家。寺庙上吊自杀了。

But Mr. Tulkinghorn is not alone to-night to ponder at his usual length. Seated at the same table, though with his chair modestly and uncomfortably drawn a little way from it, sits a bald, mild, shining man who coughs respectfully behind his hand when the lawyer bids him fill his glass.
但今晚，塔尔金霍恩先生并不是唯一一个像往常那样思考的人。同一张桌子上坐着一位秃顶的、温和的、光彩照人的男人，尽管他的椅子谦逊地、不舒服地离桌子有点远，当律师让他倒酒时，他在手后面恭敬地咳嗽了一声。

‘Now, Snagsby,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, ‘to go over this odd story again.’
“现在，斯纳格斯比，”塔尔金霍恩先生说，“再回顾一下这个奇怪的故事。”

‘If you please, sir.’
“如果您愿意的话，先生。”

‘You told me when you were so good as to step round here last night—‘
“你昨晚告诉我你很擅长到这里来——”

‘For which I must ask you to excuse me if it was a liberty, sir; but I remember that you had taken a sort of an interest in that person, and I thought it possible that you might—just—wish—to—‘
“如果这是一种自由的话，我必须请你原谅，先生；但我记得你对那个人有点兴趣，而且我认为你可能——只是——希望——”

Mr. Tulkinghorn is not the man to help him to any conclusion or to admit anything as to any possibility concerning himself. So Mr. Snagsby trails off into saying, with an awkward cough, ‘I must ask you to excuse the liberty, sir, I am sure.’
图金霍恩先生不会帮助他得出任何结论，也不会承认任何与他有关的可能性。于是，斯纳斯比先生尴尬地咳嗽了一声，最后说道：“我确信，先生，我必须请您原谅我的冒犯。”

‘Not at all,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn. ‘You told me, Snagsby, that you put on your hat and came round without mentioning your intention to your wife. That was prudent I think, because it’s not a matter of such importance that it requires to be mentioned.’
“一点也不，”图尔金霍恩先生说。 “斯纳斯比，你告诉我，你戴上帽子就过来了，但没有向你的妻子提及你的意图。我认为这是谨慎的做法，因为这并不是一个需要提及的重要问题。

‘Well, sir,’ returns Mr. Snagsby, ‘you see, my little woman is—not to put too fine a point upon it—inquisitive. She’s inquisitive. Poor little thing, she’s liable to spasms, and it’s good for her to have her mind employed. In consequence of which she employs it—I should say upon every individual thing she can lay hold of, whether it concerns her or not—especially not. My little woman has a very active mind, sir.’
“好吧，先生，”斯纳斯比先生回答道，“你看，我的小女人——不用说得太过分——好奇。她很好奇。可怜的小东西，她很容易痉挛，多动动脑子对她有好处。因此，她使用了它——我应该说的是她能掌握的每一件事情，无论它是否与她有关——尤其是与她无关。我的小女人头脑非常活跃，先生。”

Mr. Snagsby drinks and murmurs with an admiring cough behind his hand, ‘Dear me, very fine wine indeed!’
斯纳斯比先生一边喝着酒，一边在手背后发出钦佩的咳嗽声，低声说道：“天哪，确实是非常好的酒！”

‘Therefore you kept your visit to yourself last night?’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn. ‘And to-night too?’
“所以你昨晚才亲自拜访？”图尔金霍恩先生说道。 “今晚也是吗？”

‘Yes, sir, and to-night, too. My little woman is at present in— not to put too fine a point on it—in a pious state, or in what she considers such, and attends the Evening Exertions (which is the name they go by) of a reverend party of the name of Chadband. He has a great deal of eloquence at his command, undoubtedly, but I am not quite favourable to his style myself. That’s neither here nor there. My little woman being engaged in that way made it easier for me to step round in a quiet manner.’
“是的，先生，今晚也是。”我的小女人目前处于——不用说得太过分——处于一种虔诚的状态，或者说处于她认为的虔诚状态，并且参加了一个令人尊敬的聚会的晚间活动（这是他们的名字）。查德班德的名字。毫无疑问，他很有口才，但我自己不太喜欢他的风格。那既不在这里也不在那里。我的小女人以这种方式订婚，让我更容易安静地走来走去。

Mr. Tulkinghorn assents. ‘Fill your glass, Snagsby.’
图金霍恩先生表示同意。 “倒满你的杯子，斯纳斯比。”

‘Thank you, sir, I am sure,’ returns the stationer with his cough of deference. ‘This is wonderfully fine wine, sir!’
“谢谢您，先生，我相信，”文具店员咳嗽一声回答道。 “这是极好的美酒，先生！”

‘It is a rare wine now,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn. ‘It is fifty years old.’
“现在这是一种稀有的葡萄酒，”图金霍恩先生说。 “已经五十岁了。”

‘Is it indeed, sir? But I am not surprised to hear it, I am sure. It might be—any age almost.’ After rendering this general tribute to the port, Mr. Snagsby in his modesty coughs an apology behind his hand for drinking anything so precious.
“真的是这样吗，先生？但我确信，听到这个消息我并不感到惊讶。可能是——几乎任何年龄。”在向港口表达了普遍的敬意后，斯纳斯比先生谦虚地在手后咳嗽一声，为自己喝了如此珍贵的东西而道歉。

‘Will you run over, once again, what the boy said?’ asks Mr. Tulkinghorn, putting his hands into the pockets of his rusty smallclothes and leaning quietly back in his chair.
“你愿意再听一遍那个男孩说的话吗？”图金霍恩先生问道，他把手伸进生锈的内衣口袋里，静静地靠在椅子上。

‘With pleasure, sir.’
“很高兴，先生。”

Then, with fidelity, though with some prolixity, the law-stationer repeats Jo’s statement made to the assembled guests at his house. On coming to the end of his narrative, he gives a great start and breaks off with, ‘Dear me, sir, I wasn’t aware there was any other gentleman present!’
然后，法律文具员忠实地（尽管有些冗长）重复了乔对他家里聚集的客人所做的声明。在叙述结束时，他大吃一惊，接着说道：“天哪，先生，我不知道还有其他绅士在场！”

Mr. Snagsby is dismayed to see, standing with an attentive face between himself and the lawyer at a little distance from the table, a person with a hat and stick in his hand who was not there when he himself came in and has not since entered by the door or by either of the windows. There is a press in the room, but its hinges have not creaked, nor has a step been audible upon the floor. Yet this third person stands there with his attentive face, and his hat and stick in his hands, and his hands behind him, a composed and quiet listener. He is a stoutly built, steady-looking, sharp-eyed man in black, of about the middle-age. Except that he looks at Mr. Snagsby as if he were going to take his portrait, there is nothing remarkable about him at first sight but his ghostly manner of appearing.
斯纳格斯比先生沮丧地看到，在离桌子不远的地方，他和律师之间神情专注地站着一个人，手里拿着帽子，手里拿着棍子，他自己进来时并不在场，而且后来也没有进去过。靠近门或任一窗户。房间里有一台压力机，但铰链没有吱吱作响，地板上也没有脚步声。而第三个人站在那里，一脸专注，手里拿着帽子和手杖，双手放在身后，是一个镇定而安静的倾听者。他是一个身材魁梧、表情稳重、目光锐利的黑衣男子，大约中年。除了他看着斯纳斯比先生的样子，好像他要给他拍肖像一样，乍一看，除了他幽灵​​般的外表之外，他并没有什么特别之处。

‘Don’t mind this gentleman,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn in his quiet way. ‘This is only Mr. Bucket.’
“别介意这位先生，”图金霍恩先生平静地说。 “这只是巴克特先生。”

‘Oh, indeed, sir?’ returns the stationer, expressing by a cough that he is quite in the dark as to who Mr. Bucket may be.
“哦，确实如此，先生？”文具店老板咳嗽一声，表示他完全不知道巴克特先生是谁。

‘I wanted him to hear this story,’ says the lawyer, ‘because I have half a mind (for a reason) to know more of it, and he is very intelligent in such things. What do you say to this, Bucket?’
“我想让他听听这个故事，”律师说，“因为我（出于某种原因）有点想了解更多，而他在这些事情上非常聪明。”你对此有何看法，巴克？

‘It’s very plain, sir. Since our people have moved this boy on, and he’s not to be found on his old lay, if Mr. Snagsby don’t object to go down with me to Tom-all-Alone’s and point him out, we can have him here in less than a couple of hours’ time. I can do it without Mr. Snagsby, of course, but this is the shortest way.’
“这很简单，先生。既然我们的人已经把这个男孩转移了，而且在他的老地方已经找不到他了，如果斯纳格斯比先生不反对和我一起去汤姆孤儿店并指出他，我们可以让他在这儿不到几个小时的时间。当然，没有斯纳斯比先生我也可以做到，但这是最短的方法。

‘Mr. Bucket is a detective officer, Snagsby,’ says the lawyer in explanation.
'先生。巴克特是一名侦探，斯纳格斯比，”律师解释说。

‘Is he indeed, sir?’ says Mr. Snagsby with a strong tendency in his clump of hair to stand on end.
“他真的是吗，先生？”斯纳斯比先生说道，他的一簇头发都快要竖起来了。

‘And if you have no real objection to accompany Mr. Bucket to the place in question,’ pursues the lawyer, ‘I shall feel obliged to you if you will do so.’
“如果你确实不反对陪巴克特先生去那个地方，”律师继续说道，“如果你愿意的话，我将不胜感激。”

In a moment’s hesitation on the part of Mr. Snagsby, Bucket dips down to the bottom of his mind.
斯纳斯比先生犹豫了片刻，巴克特陷入了沉思。

‘Don’t you be afraid of hurting the boy,’ he says. ‘You won’t do that. It’s all right as far as the boy’s concerned. We shall only bring him here to ask him a question or so I want to put to him, and he’ll be paid for his trouble and sent away again. It’ll be a good job for him. I promise you, as a man, that you shall see the boy sent away all right. Don’t you be afraid of hurting him; you an’t going to do that.’
“你不用害怕伤害这个男孩，”他说。 ‘你不会那样做的。就男孩而言，这没什么问题。我们把他带到这里只是为了问他一个问题或者我想问他的问题，然后他会因为他的麻烦而得到报酬并再次被送走。这对他来说将是一份好工作。作为一个男人，我向你保证，你会看到这个男孩被顺利送走。你不怕伤害他吗？你不会那样做的。

‘Very well, Mr. Tulkinghorn!’ cries Mr. Snagsby cheerfully. And reassured, ‘Since that’s the case—‘
“很好，图金霍恩先生！”斯纳斯比先生高兴地喊道。并安慰道：“既然如此——”

‘Yes! And lookee here, Mr. Snagsby,’ resumes Bucket, taking him aside by the arm, tapping him familiarly on the breast, and speaking in a confidential tone. ‘You’re a man of the world, you know, and a man of business, and a man of sense. That’s what YOU are.’
'是的！瞧，斯纳斯比先生，”巴克特继续说道，抓住他的手臂，亲切地拍着他的胸口，用一种保密的语气说道。 “你知道，你是一个见多识广的人，一个有生意经的人，一个有理智的人。这就是你。

‘I am sure I am much obliged to you for your good opinion,’ returns the stationer with his cough of modesty, ‘but—‘
“我相信我非常感谢你的好意见，”文具店老板谦虚地咳嗽了一声，回答道，“但是——”

‘That’s what YOU are, you know,’ says Bucket. ‘Now, it an’t necessary to say to a man like you, engaged in your business, which is a business of trust and requires a person to be wide awake and have his senses about him and his head screwed on tight (I had an uncle in your business once)—it an’t necessary to say to a man like you that it’s the best and wisest way to keep little matters like this quiet. Don’t you see? Quiet!’
“你知道，这就是你，”巴克特说。 “现在，没有必要对像你这样的人说，从事你的生意，这是一项信任的生意，需要一个人保持清醒，对自己有清醒的认识，并且把头脑拧紧（我有曾经是你生意上的叔叔）——没有必要对像你这样的人说，像这样的小事保持安静是最好、最明智的方法。你没看到吗？安静的！'

‘Certainly, certainly,’ returns the other.
“当然，当然，”对方回答道。

‘I don’t mind telling YOU,’ says Bucket with an engaging appearance of frankness, ‘that as far as I can understand it, there seems to be a doubt whether this dead person wasn’t entitled to a little property, and whether this female hasn’t been up to some games respecting that property, don’t you see?’
“我不介意告诉你，”巴克特带着迷人的坦率说道，“据我所知，似乎有人怀疑这个死者是否没有资格获得一点财产，以及是否这位女性还没有参加过一些尊重该财产的游戏，你明白吗？

‘Oh!’ says Mr. Snagsby, but not appearing to see quite distinctly.
“哦！”斯纳斯比先生说道，但看上去并没有看得很清楚。

‘Now, what YOU want,’ pursues Bucket, again tapping Mr. Snagsby on the breast in a comfortable and soothing manner, ‘is that every person should have their rights according to justice. That’s what YOU want.’
“现在，你想要的，”巴克特继续说道，再次以一种舒适而安抚的方式拍拍斯纳斯比先生的胸口，“每个人都应该享有正义的权利。”那就是你想要的。'

‘To be sure,’ returns Mr. Snagsby with a nod.
“当然，”斯纳斯比先生点头回应。

‘On account of which, and at the same time to oblige a—do you call it, in your business, customer or client? I forget how my uncle used to call it.’
“因此，同时还要承担一个——在你的业务中，你称之为顾客还是客户？”我忘了我叔叔以前怎么称呼它。

‘Why, I generally say customer myself,’ replies Mr. Snagsby.
“为什么，我通常会说我自己是客户，”斯纳斯比先生回答道。

‘You’re right!’ returns Mr. Bucket, shaking hands with him quite affectionately. ‘—On account of which, and at the same time to oblige a real good customer, you mean to go down with me, in confidence, to Tom-all-Alone’s and to keep the whole thing quiet ever afterwards and never mention it to any one. That’s about your intentions, if I understand you?’
“你说得对！”巴克特先生回答道，并非常亲切地与他握手。 “——正因为如此，同时为了满足一位真正的好顾客的要求，你打算私下和我一起去汤姆孤儿店，从此以后将整件事保密，永远不要向别人提起这件事。”任何人。这就是你的意图，如果我理解的话？

‘You are right, sir. You are right,’ says Mr. Snagsby.
“你是对的，先生。你是对的，”斯纳斯比先生说。

‘Then here’s your hat,’ returns his new friend, quite as intimate with it as if he had made it; ‘and if you’re ready, I am.’
“那么这是你的帽子，”他的新朋友回答道，他对它的态度非常亲密，就好像它是他做的一样。 “如果你准备好了，我也准备好了。”

They leave Mr. Tulkinghorn, without a ruffle on the surface of his unfathomable depths, drinking his old wine, and go down into the streets.
他们离开了深不可测的图金霍恩先生，喝着他的老酒，表面上没有任何皱纹，然后走到街上。

‘You don’t happen to know a very good sort of person of the name of Gridley, do you?’ says Bucket in friendly converse as they descend the stairs.
“你碰巧不认识一个叫格里德利的好人，是吗？”他们走下楼梯时，巴克特友好地交谈道。

‘No,’ says Mr. Snagsby, considering, ‘I don’t know anybody of that name. Why?’
“不，”斯纳斯比先生考虑道，“我不认识叫这个名字的人。”为什么？'

‘Nothing particular,’ says Bucket; ‘only having allowed his temper to get a little the better of him and having been threatening some respectable people, he is keeping out of the way of a warrant I have got against him—which it’s a pity that a man of sense should do.’
“没什么特别的，”巴克特说。 “他只是任由自己的脾气变得好一点，并威胁了一些值得尊敬的人，他却回避了我对他的逮捕令——这是一个有理智的人应该做的事情，真是可惜。” '

As they walk along, Mr. Snagsby observes, as a novelty, that however quick their pace may be, his companion still seems in some undefinable manner to lurk and lounge; also, that whenever he is going to turn to the right or left, he pretends to have a fixed purpose in his mind of going straight ahead, and wheels off, sharply, at the very last moment. Now and then, when they pass a police-constable on his beat, Mr. Snagsby notices that both the constable and his guide fall into a deep abstraction as they come towards each other, and appear entirely to overlook each other, and to gaze into space. In a few instances, Mr. Bucket, coming behind some under-sized young man with a shining hat on, and his sleek hair twisted into one flat curl on each side of his head, almost without glancing at him touches him with his stick, upon which the young man, looking round, instantly evaporates. For the most part Mr. Bucket notices things in general, with a face as unchanging as the great mourning ring on his little finger or the brooch, composed of not much diamond and a good deal of setting, which he wears in his shirt.
当他们走着的时候，斯纳斯比先生观察到，不管他们的步伐有多快，他的同伴似乎仍然以某种难以定义的方式潜伏和休息，这是一种新奇的现象；而且，每当他要向右或向左转弯时，他都会假装心里有一个要一直向前走的固定目标，然后在最后一刻猛地转身离开。时不时地，当他们经过巡逻的警察时，斯纳斯比先生注意到，当警察和他的向导走向对方时，他们都陷入了深深的心不在焉，似乎完全忽视了对方，凝视着对方。空间。有几次，巴克特先生来到一个身材矮小的年轻人身后，戴着一顶闪亮的帽子，光滑的头发在头的两侧盘成一团平卷，几乎没有看他一眼，就用棍子碰了碰他，年轻人环顾四周，立刻就消失了。大多数情况下，巴克特先生注意到的是一般事物，他的脸就像他小指上的巨大哀悼戒指或胸针一样一成不变，由不多的钻石和大量的镶嵌组成，他把它们戴在衬衫上。

When they come at last to Tom-all-Alone’s, Mr. Bucket stops for a moment at the corner and takes a lighted bull’s-eye from the constable on duty there, who then accompanies him with his own particular bull’s-eye at his waist. Between his two conductors, Mr. Snagsby passes along the middle of a villainous street, undrained, unventilated, deep in black mud and corrupt water— though the roads are dry elsewhere—and reeking with such smells and sights that he, who has lived in London all his life, can scarce believe his senses. Branching from this street and its heaps of ruins are other streets and courts so infamous that Mr. Snagsby sickens in body and mind and feels as if he were going every moment deeper down into the infernal gulf.
当他们最终来到汤姆孤身之家时，巴克特先生在拐角处停了一会儿，从那里值班的警察那里看到了一个点燃的靶心，然后警察在他的腰间也带着他自己独特的靶心。斯纳格斯比先生在他的两名售票员之间穿过一条肮脏的街道中间，街道不排水、不通风，深陷黑泥和腐败的水里——尽管其他地方的道路是干的——而且散发着恶臭和景象，让他这个曾经生活在其中的人感到不舒服。他一生都在伦敦度过，几乎无法相信自己的感觉。从这条街道及其成堆的废墟中延伸出来的是其他臭名昭著的街道和法院，斯纳格斯比先生身心都感到恶心，感觉自己每时每刻都在深入地狱的深渊。

‘Draw off a bit here, Mr. Snagsby,’ says Bucket as a kind of shabby palanquin is borne towards them, surrounded by a noisy crowd. ‘Here’s the fever coming up the street!’
“斯纳格斯比先生，在这里稍微开一点。”巴克特说道，一辆破旧的轿子被抬向他们，周围是喧闹的人群。 “街上发烧了！”

As the unseen wretch goes by, the crowd, leaving that object of attraction, hovers round the three visitors like a dream of horrible faces and fades away up alleys and into ruins and behind walls, and with occasional cries and shrill whistles of warning, thenceforth flits about them until they leave the place.
当那个看不见的可怜虫经过时，人群离开了那个吸引人的物体，在三个游客周围盘旋，就像一场可怕的面孔的梦，然后消失在小巷、废墟和墙后，偶尔会发出警告的叫喊声和尖锐的口哨声，从那时起在他们周围飞翔，直到他们离开这个地方。

‘Are those the fever-houses, Darby?’ Mr. Bucket coolly asks as he turns his bull’s-eye on a line of stinking ruins.
“那些是发烧屋吗，达比？”巴克特先生将靶心转向一排散发着恶臭的废墟，冷静地问道。

Darby replies that ‘all them are,’ and further that in all, for months and months, the people ‘have been down by dozens’ and have been carried out dead and dying ‘like sheep with the rot.’ Bucket observing to Mr. Snagsby as they go on again that he looks a little poorly, Mr. Snagsby answers that he feels as if he couldn’t breathe the dreadful air.
达比回答说，“他们都是”，并且进一步说，几个月来，人们“已经有数十人倒下”，并且“像腐烂的羊一样”被抬出去死去活来。当他们继续说他看起来有点糟糕时，斯纳斯比先生回答说，他感觉好像无法呼吸这可怕的空气。

There is inquiry made at various houses for a boy named Jo. As few people are known in Tom-all-Alone’s by any Christian sign, there is much reference to Mr. Snagsby whether he means Carrots, or the Colonel, or Gallows, or Young Chisel, or Terrier Tip, or Lanky, or the Brick. Mr. Snagsby describes over and over again. There are conflicting opinions respecting the original of his picture. Some think it must be Carrots, some say the Brick. The Colonel is produced, but is not at all near the thing. Whenever Mr. Snagsby and his conductors are stationary, the crowd flows round, and from its squalid depths obsequious advice heaves up to Mr. Bucket. Whenever they move, and the angry bull’s-eyes glare, it fades away and flits about them up the alleys, and in the ruins, and behind the walls, as before.
人们在各个房屋中询问了一个名叫乔的男孩的情况。由于《汤姆孤身一人》中很少有人以任何基督教标志为人所知，所以很多地方都提到了斯纳斯比先生，无论他指的是胡萝卜、上校、绞刑架、小凿子、小梗犬尖、瘦长的还是砖头。 。斯纳斯比先生一遍又一遍地描述。对于他的照片的原作，存在着相互矛盾的意见。有人认为一定是胡萝卜，有人说是砖头。上校已出现，但根本不在那个东西附近。每当斯纳斯比先生和他的指挥静止不动时，人群就会围过来，从肮脏的深处向巴克特先生提出谄媚的建议。每当他们移动时，愤怒的靶心眩光就会消失，并像以前一样在小巷、废墟和墙后掠过他们。

At last there is a lair found out where Toughy, or the Tough Subject, lays him down at night; and it is thought that the Tough Subject may be Jo. Comparison of notes between Mr. Snagsby and the proprietress of the house—a drunken face tied up in a black bundle, and flaring out of a heap of rags on the floor of a doghutch which is her private apartment—leads to the establishment of this conclusion. Toughy has gone to the doctor’s to get a bottle of stuff for a sick woman but will be here anon.
最后，人们发现了一个巢穴，强悍的人，或者强悍的受试者，晚上把他放下来。据认为，棘手的主题可能是乔。斯纳格斯比先生和这所房子的女主人之间的笔记比较——一张醉酒的脸被绑在一个黑色的包裹里，从她私人公寓的狗笼地板上的一堆破布上闪闪发光——导致建立了这个结论。 Toughy 已经去医生那儿给生病的女人买了一瓶东西，但很快就会过来。

‘And who have we got here to-night?’ says Mr. Bucket, opening another door and glaring in with his bull’s-eye. ‘Two drunken men, eh? And two women? The men are sound enough,’ turning back each sleeper’s arm from his face to look at him. ‘Are these your good men, my dears?’
“今晚我们来的是谁？”巴克特先生一边说，一边打开另一扇门，用靶心怒视着里面。 “两个醉汉，是吗？还有两个女人？这些人都很健康，”每个睡觉的人都把手臂从他脸上转回来看着他。 “亲爱的，这些是你的好人吗？”

‘Yes, sir,’ returns one of the women. ‘They are our husbands.’
“是的，先生，”其中一位女士回答道。 “他们是我们的丈夫。”

‘Brickmakers, eh?’
“制砖工，嗯？”

‘Yes, sir.’
'是的先生。'

‘What are you doing here? You don’t belong to London.’
'你在这里做什么？你不属于伦敦。

‘No, sir. We belong to Hertfordshire.’
'不，先生。我们属于赫特福德郡。

‘Whereabouts in Hertfordshire?’
“赫特福德郡在哪里？”

‘Saint Albans.’
“圣奥尔本斯。”

‘Come up on the tramp?’
“跟流浪汉一起上来吗？”

‘We walked up yesterday. There’s no work down with us at present, but we have done no good by coming here, and shall do none, I expect.’
‘我们昨天是步行上去的。目前我们没有什么工作要做，但我们来这里并没有做任何好事，我想也不会做任何事。

‘That’s not the way to do much good,’ says Mr. Bucket, turning his head in the direction of the unconscious figures on the ground.
“这不是做多好事的方法，”巴克特先生说，他把头转向地面上失去知觉的人影。

‘It an’t indeed,’ replies the woman with a sigh. ‘Jenny and me knows it full well.’
“确实不是，”女人叹了口气回答道。 “珍妮和我非常清楚这一点。”

The room, though two or three feet higher than the door, is so low that the head of the tallest of the visitors would touch the blackened ceiling if he stood upright. It is offensive to every sense; even the gross candle burns pale and sickly in the polluted air. There are a couple of benches and a higher bench by way of table. The men lie asleep where they stumbled down, but the women sit by the candle. Lying in the arms of the woman who has spoken is a very young child.
房间虽然比门高两三英尺，但非常低，最高的访客如果站直的话，头会碰到黑色的天花板。从任何意义上来说，它都是令人反感的；就连粗俗的蜡烛在污染的空气中燃烧起来也显得苍白而病态。有几张长凳和一张靠近桌子的更高的长凳。男人们躺在他们跌倒的地方睡着了，而女人们则坐在蜡烛旁边。说话的女人怀里躺着一个很小的孩子。

‘Why, what age do you call that little creature?’ says Bucket. ‘It looks as if it was born yesterday.’ He is not at all rough about it; and as he turns his light gently on the infant, Mr. Snagsby is strangely reminded of another infant, encircled with light, that he has seen in pictures.
“为什么，你管那个小动物多大年纪了？”巴克特说。 “它看起来就像是昨天出生的。”他对此一点也不粗暴；当斯纳斯比先生轻轻地将灯转向婴儿时，他奇怪地想起了他在照片中看到的另一个被光包围的婴儿。

‘He is not three weeks old yet, sir,’ says the woman.
“先生，他还不到三周大，”女人说。

‘Is he your child?’
“他是你的孩子吗？”

‘Mine.’
'矿。'

The other woman, who was bending over it when they came in, stoops down again and kisses it as it lies asleep.
当他们进来时，另一个女人正弯腰在它身上，当它睡着时，她再次弯下腰亲吻它。

‘You seem as fond of it as if you were the mother yourself,’ says Mr. Bucket.
“你看起来就像你自己是母亲一样喜欢它，”巴克特先生说。

‘I was the mother of one like it, master, and it died.’
“我是一个这样的孩子的母亲，主人，但它死了。”

‘Ah, Jenny, Jenny!’ says the other woman to her. ‘Better so. Much better to think of dead than alive, Jenny! Much better!’
“啊，珍妮，珍妮！”另一个女人对她说道。 '这样更好。珍妮，想想死了比活着好得多！好多了！'

‘Why, you an’t such an unnatural woman, I hope,’ returns Bucket sternly, ‘as to wish your own child dead?’
“为什么，我希望你不是一个如此不自然的女人，”巴克特严厉地回答道，“以至于希望你自己的孩子死掉？”

‘God knows you are right, master,’ she returns. ‘I am not. I’d stand between it and death with my own life if I could, as true as any pretty lady.’
“上帝知道你是对的，主人，”她回答道。 '我不是。如果可以的话，我愿意用自己的生命来阻止它和死亡，就像任何漂亮的女士一样。

‘Then don’t talk in that wrong manner,’ says Mr. Bucket, mollified again. ‘Why do you do it?’
“那就别用那种错误的方式说话，”巴克特先生再次平静下来说道。 '你为什么要这么做？'

‘It’s brought into my head, master,’ returns the woman, her eyes filling with tears, ‘when I look down at the child lying so. If it was never to wake no more, you’d think me mad, I should take on so. I know that very well. I was with Jenny when she lost hers—warn’t I, Jenny?—and I know how she grieved. But look around you at this place. Look at them,’ glancing at the sleepers on the ground. ‘Look at the boy you’re waiting for, who’s gone out to do me a good turn. Think of the children that your business lays with often and often, and that YOU see grow up!’
“主人，当我低头看着孩子这样躺着的时候，我的脑海里就浮现出了这个想法，”女人回答道，她的眼睛里充满了泪水。如果它不再醒来，你会认为我疯了，我应该这样做。我很清楚这一点。当珍妮失去她的时候，我就在她身边——我不是吗，珍妮？——我知道她有多悲伤。但看看你周围的这个地方。看看他们，”瞥了一眼地上的睡眠者。 “看看你在等的那个男孩，他出去为我做了好事。想想那些经常和你的生意打交道的孩子们，你看着他们长大！

‘Well, well,’ says Mr. Bucket, ‘you train him respectable, and he’ll be a comfort to you, and look after you in your old age, you know.’
“好吧，好吧，”巴克特先生说，“你训练他受人尊敬，他会给你带来安慰，并在你晚年照顾你，你知道。”

‘I mean to try hard,’ she answers, wiping her eyes. ‘But I have been a-thinking, being over-tired to-night and not well with the ague, of all the many things that’ll come in his way. My master will be against it, and he’ll be beat, and see me beat, and made to fear his home, and perhaps to stray wild. If I work for him ever so much, and ever so hard, there’s no one to help me; and if he should be turned bad ‘spite of all I could do, and the time should come when I should sit by him in his sleep, made hard and changed, an’t it likely I should think of him as he lies in my lap now and wish he had died as Jenny’s child died!’
“我的意思是要努力，”她一边回答，一边擦着眼睛。 “但我一直在想，今晚我太累了，而且疟疾也不太好，很多事情都会妨碍他。”我的主人会反对，他会被打败，看到我被打败，他会害怕他的家，也许还会流浪。如果我为他工作如此多、如此努力，却没有人帮助我；如果尽管我竭尽全力，他还是变坏了，到了我应该在他睡梦中坐在他身边、变得坚硬、改变的时候，我是不是应该在他躺在我的床上时想起他？现在就跑一圈，希望他也能像珍妮的孩子一样死掉！”

‘There, there!’ says Jenny. ‘Liz, you’re tired and ill. Let me take him.’
“那儿，那儿！”珍妮说。 ‘莉兹，你又累又病了。让我带他走吧。

In doing so, she displaces the mother’s dress, but quickly readjusts it over the wounded and bruised bosom where the baby has been lying.
在这样做时，她把母亲的衣服移开，但很快又将其重新调整到婴儿躺着的受伤和瘀伤的胸部上。

‘It’s my dead child,’ says Jenny, walking up and down as she nurses, ‘that makes me love this child so dear, and it’s my dead child that makes her love it so dear too, as even to think of its being taken away from her now. While she thinks that, I think what fortune would I give to have my darling back. But we mean the same thing, if we knew how to say it, us two mothers does in our poor hearts!’
“是我死去的孩子，”珍妮边吃奶边走来走去，说道，“这让我如此爱这个孩子，也是我死去的孩子让她如此爱它，甚至一想到它被带走了。”现在远离她。当她这么想的时候，我想我该付出多大的运气才能让我的宝贝回来。但我们的意思是一样的，如果我们知道怎么说，我们两个母亲在我们可怜的心里就是这么做的！

As Mr. Snagsby blows his nose and coughs his cough of sympathy, a step is heard without. Mr. Bucket throws his light into the doorway and says to Mr. Snagsby, ‘Now, what do you say to Toughy? Will HE do?’
当斯纳斯比先生擤鼻涕并同情地咳嗽时，外面传来了脚步声。巴克特先生将手电筒投向门口，对斯纳斯比先生说：“现在，你对坚强有什么看法？”他会做吗？

‘That’s Jo,’ says Mr. Snagsby.
“那是乔，”斯纳斯比先生说。

Jo stands amazed in the disk of light, like a ragged figure in a magic-lantern, trembling to think that he has offended against the law in not having moved on far enough. Mr. Snagsby, however, giving him the consolatory assurance, ‘It’s only a job you will be paid for, Jo,’ he recovers; and on being taken outside by Mr. Bucket for a little private confabulation, tells his tale satisfactorily, though out of breath.
乔惊讶地站在光盘中，就像魔法灯笼里一个衣衫褴褛的人，想到自己因为没有走得足够远而触犯了法律，他浑身发抖。然而，斯纳格斯比先生给了他安慰性的保证，“这只是一份你会得到报酬的工作，乔，”他恢复道。在被巴克特先生带到外面进行一次私人谈话后，他满意地讲述了他的故事，尽管上气不接下气。

‘I have squared it with the lad,’ says Mr. Bucket, returning, ‘and it’s all right. Now, Mr. Snagsby, we’re ready for you.’
“我已经和那小伙子算好了，”巴克特先生回来后说道，“没问题。”现在，斯纳格斯比先生，我们已经为您做好了准备。

First, Jo has to complete his errand of good nature by handing over the physic he has been to get, which he delivers with the laconic verbal direction that ‘it’s to be all took d’rectly.’ Secondly, Mr. Snagsby has to lay upon the table half a crown, his usual panacea for an immense variety of afflictions. Thirdly, Mr. Bucket has to take Jo by the arm a little above the elbow and walk him on before him, without which observance neither the Tough Subject nor any other Subject could be professionally conducted to Lincoln’s Inn Fields. These arrangements completed, they give the women good night and come out once more into black and foul Tom-all-Alone’s.
首先，乔必须交出他要去的体检，以完成他的善意任务，他用简洁的口头指示传达了这一信息：“一切都应该直接采取。”其次，斯纳格斯比先生必须放下桌子上放着半个克朗，这是他常用的治疗各种痛苦的灵丹妙药。第三，巴克特先生必须抓住乔的手臂，让他在肘部上方一点点的地方走，否则，无论是艰难的主题还是任何其他主题都无法专业地引导到林肯客栈球场。这些安排完成后，他们向女人们道晚安，然后再次穿着黑色肮脏的汤姆独自走出来。

By the noisome ways through which they descended into that pit, they gradually emerge from it, the crowd flitting, and whistling, and skulking about them until they come to the verge, where restoration of the bull’s-eyes is made to Darby. Here the crowd, like a concourse of imprisoned demons, turns back, yelling, and is seen no more. Through the clearer and fresher streets, never so clear and fresh to Mr. Snagsby’s mind as now, they walk and ride until they come to Mr. Tulkinghorn’s gate.
他们通过令人讨厌的方式掉进那个坑里，然后逐渐从坑里出来，人群在他们身边飞快地走动、吹口哨、鬼鬼祟祟，直到他们来到边缘，在那里达比恢复了靶心。这里的人群就像一群被囚禁的恶魔，一边叫喊一边转身，然后就再也看不见了。穿过更加清晰、清新的街道，斯纳斯比先生的头脑从未像现在这样清晰和新鲜，他们步行、骑行，直到来到图尔金霍恩先生的大门前。

As they ascend the dim stairs (Mr. Tulkinghorn’s chambers being on the first floor), Mr. Bucket mentions that he has the key of the outer door in his pocket and that there is no need to ring. For a man so expert in most things of that kind, Bucket takes time to open the door and makes some noise too. It may be that he sounds a note of preparation.
当他们登上昏暗的楼梯时（图金霍恩先生的房间在一楼），巴克特先生提到他的口袋里有外门的钥匙，不需要按门铃。对于一个在大多数此类事情上都如此精通的人来说，巴克特需要花一些时间来打开门，并且还发出一些声音。他听起来可能有一种准备的意味。

Howbeit, they come at last into the hall, where a lamp is burning, and so into Mr. Tulkinghorn’s usual room—the room where he drank his old wine to-night. He is not there, but his two old-fashioned candlesticks are, and the room is tolerably light.
然而，他们最终还是走进了亮着灯的大厅，然后进入了图尔金霍恩先生常住的房间——他今晚喝陈酒的房间。他不在那儿，但他的两个老式烛台还在，而且房间里还算明亮。

Mr. Bucket, still having his professional hold of Jo and appearing to Mr. Snagsby to possess an unlimited number of eyes, makes a little way into this room, when Jo starts and stops.
巴克特先生仍然以他专业的方式控制着乔，并且在斯纳斯比先生看来拥有无限多的眼睛，当乔开始和停止时，巴克特先生向这个房间走了一小段路。

‘What’s the matter?’ says Bucket in a whisper.
“怎么了？”巴克特低声问道。

‘There she is!’ cries Jo.
“她在那儿！”乔喊道。

‘Who!’
'WHO！'

‘The lady!’
'这位女士！'

A female figure, closely veiled, stands in the middle of the room, where the light falls upon it. It is quite still and silent. The front of the figure is towards them, but it takes no notice of their entrance and remains like a statue.
一个女性身影，蒙着面纱，站在房间中央，光线照射在房间中央。周围十分安静。那人影的正面正对着他们，但它并没有注意到他们的到来，仍然像一尊雕像一样。

‘Now, tell me,’ says Bucket aloud, ‘how you know that to be the lady.’
“现在，告诉我，”巴克特大声说道，“你怎么知道那是那位女士。”

‘I know the wale,’ replies Jo, staring, ‘and the bonnet, and the gownd.’
“我了解威尔士的情况，”乔凝视着回答，“还有帽子和长袍。”

‘Be quite sure of what you say, Tough,’ returns Bucket, narrowly observant of him. ‘Look again.’
“要十分肯定你所说的话，强悍，”巴克特回答道，仔细地观察着他。 “再看看。”

‘I am a-looking as hard as ever I can look,’ says Jo with starting eyes, ‘and that there’s the wale, the bonnet, and the gownd.’
“我尽我最大的努力去寻找，”乔惊讶地说道，“还有那条条纹、那顶帽子和那件长袍。”

‘What about those rings you told me of?’ asks Bucket.
“你告诉我的那些戒指呢？”巴克特问道。

‘A-sparkling all over here,’ says Jo, rubbing the fingers of his left hand on the knuckles of his right without taking his eyes from the figure.
“这里到处都是闪闪发光的，”乔一边说，一边用左手的手指摩擦着右手的指关节，眼睛的目光始终没有离开这个人影。

The figure removes the right-hand glove and shows the hand.
该图摘掉了右手的手套并展示了手。

‘Now, what do you say to that?’ asks Bucket.
“现在，你对此有何看法？”巴克特问道。

Jo shakes his head. ‘Not rings a bit like them. Not a hand like that.’
乔摇摇头。 ‘听起来一点也不像他们。不是这样的手。

‘What are you talking of?’ says Bucket, evidently pleased though, and well pleased too.
“你在说什么？”巴克特说道，他显然很高兴，而且也很高兴。

‘Hand was a deal whiter, a deal delicater, and a deal smaller,’ returns Jo.
“手变得更白、更细腻、更小，”乔回答道。

‘Why, you’ll tell me I’m my own mother next,’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘Do you recollect the lady’s voice?’
“嘿，你接下来会告诉我我是我自己的母亲，”巴克特先生说。 “你还记得那位女士的声音吗？”

‘I think I does,’ says Jo.
“我想我知道，”乔说。

The figure speaks. ‘Was it at all like this? I will speak as long as you like if you are not sure. Was it this voice, or at all like this voice?’
人物会说话。 ‘原来是这样吗？如果你不确定的话，我会讲多久。是这个声音吗？或者根本就是这个声音？

Jo looks aghast at Mr. Bucket. ‘Not a bit!’
乔惊愕地看着巴克特先生。 “一点也不！”

‘Then, what,’ retorts that worthy, pointing to the figure, ‘did you say it was the lady for?’
“那么，什么？”那个值得尊敬的人指着那个人影反驳道，“你说这是那位女士的用途吗？”

‘Cos,’ says Jo with a perplexed stare but without being at all shaken in his certainty, ‘cos that there’s the wale, the bonnet, and the gownd. It is her and it an’t her. It an’t her hand, nor yet her rings, nor yet her woice. But that there’s the wale, the bonnet, and the gownd, and they’re wore the same way wot she wore ‘em, and it’s her height wot she wos, and she giv me a sov’ring and hooked it.’
“因为，”乔用困惑的眼神说道，但他的确定丝毫没有动摇，“因为那里有条纹、帽子和长袍。”这是她，又不是她。这不是她的手，也不是她的戒指，也不是她的声音。但那儿有条纹、帽子和长袍，它们的穿着方式和她穿的一样，而且她的身高是她的，她给了我一个索夫戒指并把它钩住了。

‘Well!’ says Mr. Bucket slightly, ‘we haven’t got much good out of YOU. But, however, here’s five shillings for you. Take care how you spend it, and don’t get yourself into trouble.’ Bucket stealthily tells the coins from one hand into the other like counters—which is a way he has, his principal use of them being in these games of skill—and then puts them, in a little pile, into the boy’s hand and takes him out to the door, leaving Mr. Snagsby, not by any means comfortable under these mysterious circumstances, alone with the veiled figure. But on Mr. Tulkinghorn’s coming into the room, the veil is raised and a sufficiently good-looking Frenchwoman is revealed, though her expression is something of the intensest.
“好吧！”巴克特先生淡淡地说，“我们从你那里得到的好处并不多。”不过，这里有五先令给你。小心你如何花掉它，不要给自己惹上麻烦。”巴克特像计数器一样偷偷地把硬币从一只手传到另一只手——这是他的一种方式，他主要用它们在这些技巧游戏中——然后把它们堆成一小堆，塞到男孩手里，带他到门口，留下斯纳斯比先生，在这种神秘的环境下，独自和那个蒙着面纱的人在一起，无论如何都感到不舒服。但当图金霍恩先生走进房间时，面纱被掀起，露出了一位相当漂亮的法国女人，尽管她的表情是最紧张的。

‘Thank you, Mademoiselle Hortense,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn with his usual equanimity. ‘I will give you no further trouble about this little wager.’
“谢谢您，霍滕斯小姐，”图金霍恩先生一如既往地平静地说。 “我不会再为这个小赌注给你添麻烦了。”

‘You will do me the kindness to remember, sir, that I am not at present placed?’ says mademoiselle.
“请您帮我记住，先生，我目前没有被安排？”小姐说道。

‘Certainly, certainly!’
“当然，当然！”

‘And to confer upon me the favour of your distinguished recommendation?’
“您杰出的推荐使我受益匪浅？”

‘By all means, Mademoiselle Hortense.’
“无论如何，霍滕斯小姐。”

‘A word from Mr. Tulkinghorn is so powerful.’
“图金霍恩先生的一句话是如此有力。”

‘It shall not be wanting, mademoiselle.’
“不会缺少的，小姐。”

‘Receive the assurance of my devoted gratitude, dear sir.’
“亲爱的先生，请接受我衷心的感激之情。”

‘Good night.’
'晚安。'

Mademoiselle goes out with an air of native gentility; and Mr. Bucket, to whom it is, on an emergency, as natural to be groom of the ceremonies as it is to be anything else, shows her downstairs, not without gallantry.
小姐出门时带着一种天生的绅士风度；巴克特先生，在紧急情况下，担任仪式的新郎就像担任其他任何事情一样自然，他带着她下楼，不无殷勤。

‘Well, Bucket?’ quoth Mr. Tulkinghorn on his return.
“怎么样，巴克特？”图金霍恩先生回来时问道。

‘It’s all squared, you see, as I squared it myself, sir. There an’t a doubt that it was the other one with this one’s dress on. The boy was exact respecting colours and everything. Mr. Snagsby, I promised you as a man that he should be sent away all right. Don’t say it wasn’t done!’
“你看，这都是平方的，就像我自己平方的一样，先生。毫无疑问，穿着这件衣服的是另一件。这个男孩非常尊重颜色和一切。斯纳斯比先生，我作为一个男人向你保证，他应该被送走。别说还没有完成！

‘You have kept your word, sir,’ returns the stationer; ‘and if I can be of no further use, Mr. Tulkinghorn, I think, as my little woman will be getting anxious—‘
“你遵守了诺言，先生。”文具店老板回答道。 “如果我不再有用，图尔金霍恩先生，我想，因为我的小女人会变得焦虑——”

‘Thank you, Snagsby, no further use,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn. ‘I am quite indebted to you for the trouble you have taken already.’
“谢谢你，斯纳格斯比，不再有用了，”图金霍恩先生说。 “我非常感谢你已经给我带来的麻烦。”

‘Not at all, sir. I wish you good night.’
“一点也不，先生。祝你晚安。'

‘You see, Mr. Snagsby,’ says Mr. Bucket, accompanying him to the door and shaking hands with him over and over again, ‘what I like in you is that you’re a man it’s of no use pumping; that’s what YOU are. When you know you have done a right thing, you put it away, and it’s done with and gone, and there’s an end of it. That’s what YOU do.’
“你看，斯纳斯比先生，”巴克特先生一边说着，一边陪着他走到门口，一遍又一遍地与他握手，“我喜欢你的一点是，你是一个男人，抽奶是没有用的；这就是你。当你知道你做了一件正确的事时，你就把它收起来，它就结束了，消失了，一切就结束了。这就是你所做的。

‘That is certainly what I endeavour to do, sir,’ returns Mr. Snagsby.
“这当然是我努力做的事情，先生，”斯纳斯比先生回答道。

‘No, you don’t do yourself justice. It an’t what you endeavour to do,’ says Mr. Bucket, shaking hands with him and blessing him in the tenderest manner, ‘it’s what you DO. That’s what I estimate in a man in your way of business.’
‘不，你没有公正地对待自己。 “这不是你努力做的事，”巴克特先生一边说，一边与他握手，并以最温柔的方式祝福他，“这就是你所做的事。”这就是我对从事你们生意的人的评价。

Mr. Snagsby makes a suitable response and goes homeward so confused by the events of the evening that he is doubtful of his being awake and out—doubtful of the reality of the streets through which he goes—doubtful of the reality of the moon that shines above him. He is presently reassured on these subjects by the unchallengeable reality of Mrs. Snagsby, sitting up with her head in a perfect beehive of curl-papers and night-cap, who has dispatched Guster to the police-station with official intelligence of her husband’s being made away with, and who within the last two hours has passed through every stage of swooning with the greatest decorum. But as the little woman feelingly says, many thanks she gets for it!
斯纳斯比先生做出了适当的回应，然后回家了，他对晚上发生的事情感到非常困惑，以至于他怀疑自己是否醒着并出去了——怀疑他所经过的街道的真实性——怀疑月亮照耀的真实性在他上方。目前，斯纳格斯比夫人的无可争议的现实让他对这些问题感到放心，她坐在一个由卷发纸和睡帽组成的完美蜂巢里，她已将古斯特派往警察局，并提供了有关她丈夫失踪的官方情报。被带走了，在过去的两个小时内，他以最大的礼节度过了昏迷的每个阶段。但正如小女人感慨地说，她为此得到了很多感谢！

CHAPTER XXIII
第二十三章


Esther’s Narrative
以斯帖的叙述

We came home from Mr. Boythorn’s after six pleasant weeks. We were often in the park and in the woods and seldom passed the lodge where we had taken shelter without looking in to speak to the keeper’s wife; but we saw no more of Lady Dedlock, except at church on Sundays. There was company at Chesney Wold; and although several beautiful faces surrounded her, her face retained the same influence on me as at first. I do not quite know even now whether it was painful or pleasurable, whether it drew me towards her or made me shrink from her. I think I admired her with a kind of fear, and I know that in her presence my thoughts always wandered back, as they had done at first, to that old time of my life.
愉快的六个星期后，我们从博伊索恩先生家回到家。我们经常在公园里和树林里，每次经过我们避难的小屋时，我们都会向看门人的妻子询问。但除了周日去教堂外，我们再也没有见到戴德洛克夫人。切斯尼沃尔德有同伴；虽然她周围有几张美丽的面孔，但她的脸对我的影响仍然和最初一样。即使现在我也不太清楚那是痛苦还是快乐，是把我吸引到她身边还是让我远离她。我想我怀着一种恐惧的心情仰慕她，而且我知道，在她面前，我的思绪总是会像最初一样，回到我生命中的旧时光。

I had a fancy, on more than one of these Sundays, that what this lady so curiously was to me, I was to her—I mean that I disturbed her thoughts as she influenced mine, though in some different way. But when I stole a glance at her and saw her so composed and distant and unapproachable, I felt this to be a foolish weakness. Indeed, I felt the whole state of my mind in reference to her to be weak and unreasonable, and I remonstrated with myself about it as much as I could.
在这些周日中，我不止一次地幻想过，这位女士对我来说如此奇怪，我对她来说也是如此——我的意思是，当她影响我的想法时，我扰乱了她的想法，尽管以某种不同的方式。但当我偷偷瞥了她一眼，看到她如此平静、疏远、难以接近时，我觉得这是一个愚蠢的弱点。确实，我觉得自己对她的整个心态是软弱和不合理的，我尽我所能地告诫自己。

One incident that occurred before we quitted Mr. Boythorn’s house, I had better mention in this place.
在我们离开博伊索恩先生家之前发生的一件事，我最好在这里提一下。

I was walking in the garden with Ada and when I was told that some one wished to see me. Going into the breakfast-room where this person was waiting, I found it to be the French maid who had cast off her shoes and walked through the wet grass on the day when it thundered and lightened.
我和艾达在花园里散步，有人告诉我有人想见我。走进早餐厅，这个人正在等候，我发现是那位法国女佣，在雷鸣闪电的那天，脱掉鞋子，走过湿漉漉的草地。

‘Mademoiselle,’ she began, looking fixedly at me with her too-eager eyes, though otherwise presenting an agreeable appearance and speaking neither with boldness nor servility, ‘I have taken a great liberty in coming here, but you know how to excuse it, being so amiable, mademoiselle.’
“小姐，”她开始用她过于热切的眼睛盯着我，尽管她的外表很讨人喜欢，说话既不大胆也不卑鄙，“我来这里是冒昧的，但你知道如何原谅它。” ，真是和蔼可亲，小姐。”

‘No excuse is necessary,’ I returned, ‘if you wish to speak to me.’
“如果你想跟我说话，”我回答道，“没有必要找借口。”

‘That is my desire, mademoiselle. A thousand thanks for the permission. I have your leave to speak. Is it not?’ she said in a quick, natural way.
“这就是我的愿望，小姐。一千次感谢您的许可。请允许我发言。不是吗？”她快速而自然地说道。

‘Certainly,’ said I.
“当然，”我说。

‘Mademoiselle, you are so amiable! Listen then, if you please. I have left my Lady. We could not agree. My Lady is so high, so very high. Pardon! Mademoiselle, you are right!’ Her quickness anticipated what I might have said presently but as yet had only thought. ‘It is not for me to come here to complain of my Lady. But I say she is so high, so very high. I will not say a word more. All the world knows that.’
‘小姐，你真是太和蔼可亲了！那就听听吧，如果你愿意的话。我已经离开了我的夫人。我们无法同意。我的夫人是如此之高，如此之高。赦免！小姐，你是对的！”她的敏捷预见到了我现在可能会说的话，但目前还只是想到。 “我来这里不是为了抱怨夫人。但我说她太高了，太高了。我不再多说一个字。全世界都知道这一点。

‘Go on, if you please,’ said I.
“请继续吧，”我说。

‘Assuredly; mademoiselle, I am thankful for your politeness. Mademoiselle, I have an inexpressible desire to find service with a young lady who is good, accomplished, beautiful. You are good, accomplished, and beautiful as an angel. Ah, could I have the honour of being your domestic!’
‘当然；小姐，我很感谢你的礼貌。小姐，我有一种难以言表的渴望，想要找到一位善良、多才多艺、美丽的年轻女士为我服务。你善良、多才多艺、美丽如天使。啊，我能有幸成为您的仆人吗！

‘I am sorry—‘ I began.
“对不起——”我开始说道。

‘Do not dismiss me so soon, mademoiselle!’ she said with an involuntary contraction of her fine black eyebrows. ‘Let me hope a moment! Mademoiselle, I know this service would be more retired than that which I have quitted. Well! I wish that. I know this service would be less distinguished than that which I have quitted. Well! I wish that, I know that I should win less, as to wages here. Good. I am content.’
“别这么快就打发我走，小姐！”她说道，黑色的细眉毛不由自主地收缩起来。 ‘让我希望一下吧！小姐，我知道这项服务会比我退出的服务更退休。出色地！我希望。我知道这项服务不如我已经退出的服务那么出色。出色地！我希望，我知道我应该少赢一点，就像这里的工资一样。好的。我满足了。'

‘I assure you,’ said I, quite embarrassed by the mere idea of having such an attendant, ‘that I keep no maid—‘
“我向你保证，”我说，一想到有这样一个侍从，我就感到很尴尬，“我没有留女仆——”

‘Ah, mademoiselle, but why not? Why not, when you can have one so devoted to you! Who would be enchanted to serve you; who would be so true, so zealous, and so faithful every day! Mademoiselle, I wish with all my heart to serve you. Do not speak of money at present. Take me as I am. For nothing!’
“啊，小姐，但为什么不呢？为什么不呢，当你能拥有一个如此忠诚于你的人时！谁会乐意为您服务；谁会每天都如此真实、如此热心、如此忠诚！小姐，我竭诚为您服务。目前不谈钱。拿我当我是。不求回报！'

She was so singularly earnest that I drew back, almost afraid of her. Without appearing to notice it, in her ardour she still pressed herself upon me, speaking in a rapid subdued voice, though always with a certain grace and propriety.
她是如此的认真，以至于我退缩了，几乎害怕她。她似乎没有注意到这一点，她仍然热情地把自己压在我身上，用一种快速而柔和的声音说话，尽管总是带着某种优雅和得体。

‘Mademoiselle, I come from the South country where we are quick and where we like and dislike very strong. My Lady was too high for me; I was too high for her. It is done—past—finlshed! Receive me as your domestic, and I will serve you well. I will do more for you than you figure to yourself now. Chut! Mademoiselle, I will— no matter, I will do my utmost possible in all things. If you accept my service, you will not repent it. Mademoiselle, you will not repent it, and I will serve you well. You don’t know how well!’
“小姐，我来自南方国家，那里的人行动敏捷，喜欢和不喜欢的东西都非常强烈。夫人对我来说太高了；我对她来说太高了。已经完成了——过去了——完成了！接待我作为你的家眷，我会好好为你服务的。我会为你做的比你现在想象的还要多。呸！小姐，我会——无论如何，我会尽力而为。如果你接受我的服务，你就不会后悔。小姐，您不会反悔的，我会好好为您服务的。你不知道有多好！

There was a lowering energy in her face as she stood looking at me while I explained the impossibility of my engagmg her (without thinking it necessary to say how very little I desired to do so), which seemed to bring visibly before me some woman from the streets of Paris in the reign of terror.
当我解释我不可能与她交往时，她的脸上有一种低沉的能量（我不认为有必要说我多么不愿意这样做），这似乎让我明显地看到了来自某个国家的女人。恐怖统治下的巴黎街头。

She heard me out without interruption and then said with her pretty accent and in her mildest voice, ‘Hey, mademoiselle, I have received my answer! I am sorry of it. But I must go elsewhere and seek what I have not found here. Will you graciously let me kiss your hand?’
她没有打断地听我说完，然后用她漂亮的口音和最温和的声音说：“嘿，小姐，我收到了答复！”我对此感到抱歉。但我必须去别处寻找我在这里没有找到的东西。你能慷慨地让我亲吻你的手吗？

She looked at me more intently as she took it, and seemed to take note, with her momentary touch, of every vein in it. ‘I fear I surprised you, mademoiselle, on the day of the storm?’ she said with a parting curtsy.
当她接过它时，她更加专注地看着我，似乎通过她短暂的触摸，注意到了它的每一根静脉。 “暴风雨那天，小姐，我恐怕让你吃了一惊吧？”她临别时行了一个屈膝礼。

I confessed that she had surprised us all.
我承认她让我们所有人都感到惊讶。

‘I took an oath, mademoiselle,’ she said, smiling, ‘and I wanted to stamp it on my mind so that I might keep it faithfully. And I will! Adieu, mademoiselle!’
“我发过誓，小姐，”她微笑着说，“我想把它铭记在心，这样我就可以忠实地遵守它。我会的！再见，小姐！”

So ended our conference, which I was very glad to bring to a close. I supposed she went away from the village, for I saw her no more; and nothing else occurred to disturb our tranquil summer pleasures until six weeks were out and we returned home as I began just now by saying.
我们的会议就这样结束了，我很高兴结束了这次会议。我猜想她已经离开了村子，因为我再也见不到她了。没有发生任何其他事情来打扰我们宁静的夏日乐趣，直到六个星期结束，我们回到家，就像我刚才开始说的那样。

At that time, and for a good many weeks after that time, Richard was constant in his visits. Besides coming every Saturday or Sunday and remaining with us until Monday morning, he sometimes rode out on horseback unexpectedly and passed the evening with us and rode back again early next day. He was as vivacious as ever and told us he was very industrious, but I was not easy in my mind about him. It appeared to me that his industry was all misdirected. I could not find that it led to anything but the formation of delusive hopes in connexion with the suit already the pernicious cause of so much sorrow and ruin. He had got at the core of that mystery now, he told us, and nothing could be plainer than that the will under which he and Ada were to take I don’t know how many thousands of pounds must be finally established if there were any sense or justice in the Court of Chancery—but oh, what a great IF that sounded in my ears—and that this happy conclusion could not be much longer delayed. He proved this to himself by all the weary arguments on that side he had read, and every one of them sunk him deeper in the infatuation. He had even begun to haunt the court. He told us how he saw Miss Flite there daily, how they talked together, and how he did her little kindnesses, and how, while he laughed at her, he pitied her from his heart. But he never thought—never, my poor, dear, sanguine Richard, capable of so much happiness then, and with such better things before him— what a fatal link was riveting between his fresh youth and her faded age, between his free hopes and her caged birds, and her hungry garret, and her wandering mind.
那时，以及此后的好几个星期，理查德不断地来访。除了每周六、周日来，和我们待到周一早上外，他有时会出人意料地骑马出去，和我们一起度过一个晚上，第二天一早又骑马回来。他一如既往的活泼，告诉我们他很勤奋，但我对他的心里并不轻松。在我看来，他的行业都被误导了。我发现它不会导致任何结果，除了与诉讼有关的虚幻希望的形成之外，诉讼已经成为如此多的悲伤和毁灭的有害原因。他告诉我们，他现在已经掌握了这个谜团的核心，没有什么比他和艾达将承担的遗嘱更清楚的了。我不知道如果有的话，最终必须建立多少数千英镑衡平法院的理智或正义——但是，哦，这在我耳中听起来是多么伟大的如果——而且这个幸福的结论不能再拖延太久了。他通过读过的所有令人厌烦的论点向自己证明了这一点，每一个论点都让他陷入了更深的迷恋。他甚至开始在法庭上出没。他告诉我们他每天如何在那里见到弗利特小姐，他们如何在一起交谈，以及他如何对她做点小善事，以及如何在嘲笑她的同时，如何从内心怜悯她。但他从来没有想过——我可怜的、亲爱的、乐观的理查德，当时能够享受如此多的幸福，面前有如此美好的事情——他的新鲜青春和她褪色的年龄之间，他自由的希望和她的自由之间有多么致命的联系。她关在笼子里的鸟儿，她饥饿的阁楼，还有她游荡的思绪。

Ada loved him too well to mistrust him much in anything he said or did, and my guardian, though he frequently complained of the east wind and read more than usual in the growlery, preserved a strict silence on the subject. So I thought one day when I went to London to meet Caddy Jellyby, at her solicitation, I would ask Richard to be in waiting for me at the coach-office, that we might have a little talk together. I found him there when I arrived, and we walked away arm in arm.
艾达太爱他了，不会对他所说或所做的任何事情抱有太多的不信任，而我的监护人，尽管他经常抱怨东风，并且在咆哮声中读得比平时更多，但在这个问题上却保持着严格的沉默。所以我想有一天，当我去伦敦见球童杰利比时，在她的恳求下，我会请理查德在教练办公室等我，我们可以一起聊聊。当我到达时，我发现了他，我们手挽着手走开了。

‘Well, Richard,’ said I as soon as I could begin to be grave with him, ‘are you beginning to feel more settled now?’
“好吧，理查德，”当我开始对他严肃起来时，我说道，“你现在开始感觉更安定了吗？”

‘Oh, yes, my dear!’ returned Richard. ‘I’m all right enough.’
“噢，是的，亲爱的！”理查德回答道。 “我没事。”

‘But settled?’ said I.
“但是已经解决了吗？”我说。

‘How do you mean, settled?’ returned Richard with his gay laugh.
“你的意思是，解决了？”理查德带着欢快的笑声回答道。

‘Settled in the law,’ said I.
“按照法律解决，”我说。

‘Oh, aye,’ replied Richard, ‘I’m all right enough.’
“哦，是的，”理查德回答道，“我很好。”

‘You said that before, my dear Richard.’
“你以前说过，我亲爱的理查德。”

‘And you don’t think it’s an answer, eh? Well! Perhaps it’s not. Settled? You mean, do I feel as if I were settling down?’
“你不认为这是一个答案，是吗？出色地！也许不是。解决了吗？你的意思是，我感觉自己好像安定下来了吗？

‘Yes.’
'是的。'

‘Why, no, I can’t say I am settling down,’ said Richard, strongly emphasizing ‘down,’ as if that expressed the difficulty, ‘because one can’t settle down while this business remains in such an unsettled state. When I say this business, of course I mean the— forbidden subject.’
“为什么，不，我不能说我正在安定下来，”理查德说，他强烈强调了“下来”，仿佛这表达了困难，“因为当这项业务仍处于如此不稳定的状态时，人们无法安定下来。”当我说这件事时，我当然指的是——禁止的话题。

‘Do you think it will ever be in a settled state?’ said I.
“你认为它会处于稳定状态吗？”我说。

‘Not the least doubt of it,’ answered Richard.
“毫无疑问，”理查德回答道。

We walked a little way without speaking, and presently Richard addressed me in his frankest and most feeling manner, thus: ‘My dear Esther, I understand you, and I wish to heaven I were a more constant sort of fellow. I don’t mean constant to Ada, for I love her dearly—better and better every day—but constant to myself. (Somehow, I mean something that I can’t very well express, but you’ll make it out.) If I were a more constant sort of fellow, I should have held on either to Badger or to Kenge and Carboy like grim death, and should have begun to be steady and systematic by this time, and shouldn’t be in debt, and—‘
我们走了一段路，没有说话，不久理查德就以他最坦率、最感人的方式对我说道：“亲爱的埃丝特，我理解你，但愿我是一个更加坚定的人。”我并不是说对艾达始终如一，因为我深爱着她——每天都越来越好——而是对我自己始终如一。 （不知何故，我的意思是一些我无法很好表达的东西，但你会明白的。）如果我是一个更坚定的人，我应该像死神一样紧紧抓住獾或肯吉和卡博伊，此时应该已经开始稳定和系统化，不应该负债累累，而且——”

‘ARE you in debt, Richard?’
“理查德，你欠债了吗？”

‘Yes,’ said Richard, ‘I am a little so, my dear. Also, I have taken rather too much to billiards and that sort of thing. Now the murder’s out; you despise me, Esther, don’t you?’
“是的，”理查德说，“我有点这样，亲爱的。另外，我对台球之类的事情也玩得太多了。现在谋杀案已经结束了；你鄙视我，埃丝特，不是吗？

‘You know I don’t,’ said I.
“你知道我不知道，”我说。

‘You are kinder to me than I often am to myself,’ he returned. ‘My dear Esther, I am a very unfortunate dog not to be more settled, but how CAN I be more settled? If you lived in an unfinished house, you couldn’t settle down in it; if you were condemned to leave everything you undertook unfinished, you would find it hard to apply yourself to anything; and yet that’s my unhappy case. I was born into this unfinished contention with all its chances and changes, and it began to unsettle me before I quite knew the difference between a suit at law and a suit of clothes; and it has gone on unsettling me ever since; and here I am now, conscious sometimes that I am but a worthless fellow to love my confiding cousin Ada.’
“你对我比我平时对自己更好，”他回答道。 “我亲爱的艾丝特，我是一只非常不幸的狗，无法安定下来，但我怎样才能安定下来呢？”如果你住在未完工的房子里，你就无法在里面安定下来；如果你注定要放弃你所从事的一切未完成的事情，你会发现很难全身心投入到任何事情中；但这就是我不幸的例子。我出生在这场未完成的争论中，伴随着它的各种机会和变化，在我完全了解法律诉讼和一套衣服之间的区别之前，它开始让我感到不安；从那时起，它就一直让我感到不安；现在我就在这里，有时意识到我只是一个毫无价值的人来爱我信任的表弟艾达。

We were in a solitary place, and he put his hands before his eyes and sobbed as he said the words.
我们在一个僻静的地方，他把手放在眼前，一边抽泣一边说着这句话。

‘Oh, Richard!’ said I. ‘Do not be so moved. You have a noble nature, and Ada’s love may make you worthier every day.’
“哦，理查德！”我说，“别这么感动。”你有高尚的本性，艾达的爱可能会让你每天都变得更有价值。

‘I know, my dear,’ he replied, pressing my arm, ‘I know all that. You mustn’t mind my being a little soft now, for I have had all this upon my mind for a long time, and have often meant to speak to you, and have sometimes wanted opportunity and sometimes courage. I know what the thought of Ada ought to do for me, but it doesn’t do it. I am too unsettled even for that. I love her most devotedly, and yet I do her wrong, in doing myself wrong, every day and hour. But it can’t last for ever. We shall come on for a final hearing and get judgment in our favour, and then you and Ada shall see what I can really be!’
“我知道，亲爱的，”他按着我的手臂回答，“我都知道。”你不要介意我现在有点软弱，因为这一切我已经想了很长时间了，并且经常想和你说话，有时需要机会，有时需要勇气。我知道艾达的想法应该为我做什么，但它没有这么做。即使这样我也感到不安。我全心全意地爱着她，但我日复一日、时时刻刻都做错了她，也做错了自己。但它不可能永远持续下去。我们将参加最后的听证会并获得对我们有利的判决，然后你和艾达就会看到我到底能成为什么样的人！

It had given me a pang to hear him sob and see the tears start out between his fingers, but that was infinitely less affecting to me than the hopeful animation with which he said these words.
听到他抽泣，看到他手指间流下泪水，我感到很痛苦，但这对我的影响远不如他说这些话时充满希望的活力。

‘I have looked well into the papers, Esther. I have been deep in them for months,’ he continued, recovering his cheerfulness in a moment, ‘and you may rely upon it that we shall come out triumphant. As to years of delay, there has been no want of them, heaven knows! And there is the greater probability of our bringing the matter to a speedy close; in fact, it’s on the paper now. It will be all right at last, and then you shall see!’
“我已经仔细研究过报纸了，埃丝特。我已经深陷其中几个月了，”他继续说道，一会儿又恢复了快乐，“你可以相信我们会取得胜利。至于这么多年的耽搁，根本就不需要，天知道！我们更有可能迅​​速结束这件事；事实上，现在已经写在纸上了。一切都会好起来的，然后你就会看到了！

Recalling how he had just now placed Messrs. Kenge and Carboy in the same category with Mr. Badger, I asked him when he intended to be articled in Lincoln’s Inn.
回想起他刚刚将肯格先生和卡博伊先生与巴杰先生归为同一类，我问他打算什么时候在《林肯律师学院》上发表文章。

‘There again! I think not at all, Esther,’ he returned with an effort. ‘I fancy I have had enough of it. Having worked at Jarndyce and Jarndyce like a galley slave, I have slaked my thirst for the law and satisfied myself that I shouldn’t like it. Besides, I find it unsettles me more and more to be so constantly upon the scene of action. So what,’ continued Richard, confident again by this time, ‘do I naturally turn my thoughts to?’
‘又来了！我想一点也不，埃丝特，”他努力回答道。 “我想我已经受够了。在加迪斯和加迪斯像厨房奴隶一样工作后，我满足了自己对法律的渴望，并满足了自己，我不应该喜欢它。此外，我发现不断地出现在行动现场让我越来越不安。那又怎么样，”理查德继续说道，此时他又恢复了自信，“我自然而然地把我的想法转向什么？”

‘I can’t imagine,’ said I.
“我无法想象，”我说。

‘Don’t look so serious,’ returned Richard, ‘because it’s the best thing I can do, my dear Esther, I am certain. It’s not as if I wanted a profession for life. These proceedings will come to a termination, and then I am provided for. No. I look upon it as a pursuit which is in its nature more or less unsettled, and therefore suited to my temporary condition—I may say, precisely suited. What is it that I naturally turn my thoughts to?’
“别显得那么严肃，”理查德回答道，“因为这是我能做的最好的事情，我亲爱的埃丝特，我确信。这并不是说我想要终生从事一个职业。这些程序将会结束，然后我就会得到照顾。不，我把它看作是一种本质上或多或少不稳定的追求，因此适合我暂时的状况——我可以说，完全适合。我自然会想到什么？

I looked at him and shook my head.
我看着他，摇了摇头。

‘What,’ said Richard, in a tone of perfect conviction, ‘but the army!’
“什么，”理查德用一种绝对确信的语气说道，“但是军队！”

‘The army?’ said I.
“军队？”我说。

‘The army, of course. What I have to do is to get a commission; and—there I am, you know!’ said Richard.
“当然是军队。我要做的就是拿到佣金；而且——我就在那里，你知道！”理查德说。

And then he showed me, proved by elaborate calculations in his pocket-book, that supposing he had contracted, say, two hundred pounds of debt in six months out of the army; and that he contracted no debt at all within a corresponding period in the army—as to which he had quite made up his mind; this step must involve a saving of four hundred pounds in a year, or two thousand pounds in five years, which was a considerable sum. And then he spoke so ingenuously and sincerely of the sacrifice he made in withdrawing himself for a time from Ada, and of the earnestness with which he aspired—as in thought he always did, I know full well—to repay her love, and to ensure her happiness, and to conquer what was amiss in himself, and to acquire the very soul of decision, that he made my heart ache keenly, sorely. For, I thought, how would this end, how could this end, when so soon and so surely all his manly qualities were touched by the fatal blight that ruined everything it rested on!
然后他向我展示，他的钱包里的详细计算证明了，假设他在六个月内从军队中欠下了两百英镑的债务；他在军队的相应时期内没有欠过任何债务——对此他已经下定决心了；这一步骤必须在一年内节省四百英镑，或者在五年内节省两千英镑，这是一笔相当大的数目。然后他如此天真而真诚地谈到他暂时离开艾达而做出的牺牲，以及他渴望的真诚——就像他一直在想的那样，我很清楚——报答她的爱，并确保她的幸福，并克服自己的毛病，并获得决定的灵魂，他让我的心剧烈地疼痛。因为，我想，这将如何结束，这怎么可能结束，当他所有的男子气概都如此迅速且肯定地被致命的枯萎病所触动时，毁灭了它所赖以生存的一切！

I spoke to Richard with all the earnestness I felt, and all the hope I could not quite feel then, and implored him for Ada’s sake not to put any trust in Chancery. To all I said, Richard readily assented, riding over the court and everything else in his easy way and drawing the brightest pictures of the character he was to settle into—alas, when the grievous suit should loose its hold upon him! We had a long talk, but it always came back to that, in substance.
我带着我当时无法感受到的全部真诚和所有希望与理查德交谈，并恳求他看在艾达的份上不要相信大法官办公室。对于我所说的一切，理查德欣然同意，以他轻松的方式驰骋在法庭和其他一切事物上，为他将要融入的角色画出最明亮的图画——唉，当那场严重的诉讼失去对他的控制时！我们聊了很长一段时间，但最终还是回到了实质内容。

At last we came to Soho Square, where Caddy Jellyby had appointed to wait for me, as a quiet place in the neighbourhood of Newman Street. Caddy was in the garden in the centre and hurried out as soon as I appeared. After a few cheerful words, Richard left us together.
最后我们来到了苏荷广场，球童杰利比约定在那里等我，那是纽曼街附近的一个安静的地方。球童在中央的花园里，我一出现就急忙跑了出去。理查德说了几句欢快的话后，就和我们一起离开了。

‘Prince has a pupil over the way, Esther,’ said Caddy, ‘and got the key for us. So if you will walk round and round here with me, we can lock ourselves in and I can tell you comfortably what I wanted to see your dear good face about.’
“王子在那边有一个学生，艾丝特，”凯迪说，“他帮我们拿了钥匙。”所以，如果你愿意和我一起在这里走来走去，我们就可以把自己锁在里面，我可以轻松地告诉你我想看到你亲爱的好脸孔。

‘Very well, my dear,’ said I. ‘Nothing could be better.’ So Caddy, after affectionately squeezing the dear good face as she called it, locked the gate, and took my arm, and we began to walk round the garden very cosily.
“很好，亲爱的，”我说，“没有比这更好的了。”于是卡迪深情地捏了捏她所说的亲爱的好脸蛋，然后锁上了门，挽起了我的手臂，我们开始绕着花园散步。非常舒适。

‘You see, Esther,’ said Caddy, who thoroughly enjoyed a little confidence, ‘after you spoke to me about its being wrong to marry without Ma’s knowledge, or even to keep Ma long in the dark respecting our engagement—though I don’t believe Ma cares much for me, I must say—I thought it right to mention your opinions to Prince. In the first place because I want to profit by everything you tell me, and in the second place because I have no secrets from Prince.’
“你看，埃丝特，”凯迪说，她完全享受到了一点自信，“在你告诉我在妈妈不知情的情况下结婚是错误的，甚至让妈妈长期蒙在鼓里尊重我们的订婚是错误的——尽管我不这么认为。”我不相信妈妈很关心我，我必须说——我认为向普林斯提及你的意见是正确的。首先是因为我想从你告诉我的一切中获益，其次是因为我对普林斯没有秘密。

‘I hope he approved, Caddy?’
“我希望他批准了，凯迪？”

‘Oh, my dear! I assure you he would approve of anything you could say. You have no idea what an opimon he has of you!’
'哦，我亲爱的！我向你保证他会赞同你所说的任何话。你不知道他对你有什么看法！

‘Indeed!’
'的确！'

‘Esther, it’s enough to make anybody but me jealous,’ said Caddy, laughing and shaking her head; ‘but it only makes me joyful, for you are the first friend I ever had, and the best friend I ever can have, and nobody can respect and love you too much to please me.’
“埃丝特，这足以让除了我以外的任何人嫉妒，”凯蒂笑着摇摇头说道。 “但这只会让我感到高兴，因为你是我第一个朋友，也是我能拥有的最好的朋友，没有人会因为太尊重和爱你而让我高兴。”

‘Upon my word, Caddy,’ said I, ‘you are in the general conspiracy to keep me in a good humour. Well, my dear?’
“老实说，凯迪，”我说，“你是在密谋让我保持良好的心情。怎么样，亲爱的？

‘Well! I am going to tell you,’ replied Caddy, crossing her hands confidentially upon my arm. ‘So we talked a good deal about it, and so I said to Prince, ‘Prince, as Miss Summerson—‘
'出色地！我要告诉你，”凯蒂回答道，她的双手秘密地交叉在我的手臂上。 “所以我们对此谈了很多，所以我对普林斯说，‘普林斯，作为萨默森小姐——’

‘I hope you didn’t say ‘Miss Summerson’?’
“我希望你没有说‘萨默森小姐’？”

‘No. I didn’t!’ cried Caddy, greatly pleased and with the brightest of faces. ‘I said, ‘Esther.’ I said to Prince, ‘As Esther is decidedly of that opinion, Prince, and has expressed it to me, and always hints it when she writes those kind notes, which you are so fond of hearing me read to you, I am prepared to disclose the truth to Ma whenever you think proper. And I think, Prince,’ said I, ‘that Esther thinks that I should be in a better, and truer, and more honourable position altogether if you did the same to your papa.’’
'不。我没有！”凯迪大声喊道，他非常高兴，脸上的表情最明亮。 “我说，‘以斯帖。’我对普林斯说，‘因为埃丝特绝对同意这个观点，普林斯，她已经向我表达了这一点，并且当她写下那些善意的便条时，她总是暗示这一点，你很喜欢听我说这些。读给你听，我准备在你认为合适的时候向马云透露真相。我认为，王子，”我说，“埃斯特认为，如果你对你的爸爸做同样的事情，我应该处于一个更好、更真实、更光荣的地位。”

‘Yes, my dear,’ said I. ‘Esther certainly does think so.’
“是的，亲爱的，”我说，“埃丝特确实这么认为。”

‘So I was right, you see!’ exclaimed Caddy. ‘Well! This troubled Prince a good deal, not because he had the least doubt about it, but because he is so considerate of the feelings of old Mr. Turveydrop; and he had his apprehensions that old Mr. Turveydrop might break his heart, or faint away, or be very much overcome in some affecting manner or other if he made such an announcement. He feared old Mr. Turveydrop might consider it undutiful and might receive too great a shock. For old Mr. Turveydrop’s deportment is very beautiful, you know, Esther,’ said Caddy, ‘and his feelings are extremely sensitive.’
“所以我是对的，你看！”凯迪喊道。 '出色地！这让普林斯很烦恼，不是因为他对此有丝毫怀疑，而是因为他太考虑老特维德罗普先生的感受了；他担心老特维德罗普先生如果宣布了这样的消息，可能会心碎，或者晕倒，或者以某种感人的方式被极大地克服。他担心老特维德罗普先生可能会认为这是不负责任的行为，并可能会受到太大的打击。因为老特维德罗普先生的举止非常漂亮，你知道，艾丝特，”卡迪说，“而且他的感情极其敏感。”

‘Are they, my dear?’
“是吗，亲爱的？”

‘Oh, extremely sensitive. Prince says so. Now, this has caused my darling child—I didn’t mean to use the expression to you, Esther,’ Caddy apologized, her face suffused with blushes, ‘but I generally call Prince my darling child.’
‘哦，非常敏感。王子如此说道。现在，这引起了我亲爱的孩子——我不是故意对你用这个表达方式的，埃丝特，”卡迪道歉，她的脸泛着红晕，“但我通常称普林斯为我亲爱的孩子。

I laughed; and Caddy laughed and blushed, and went on’
我笑了;凯蒂笑了，脸红了，然后继续说。

‘This has caused him, Esther—‘
“这导致他，埃斯特——”

‘Caused whom, my dear?’
“因为谁，亲爱的？”

‘Oh, you tiresome thing!’ said Caddy, laughing, with her pretty face on fire. ‘My darling child, if you insist upon it! This has caused him weeks of uneasiness and has made him delay, from day to day, in a very anxious manner. At last he said to me, ‘Caddy, if Miss Summerson, who is a great favourite with my father, could be prevailed upon to be present when I broke the subject, I think I could do it.’ So I promised I would ask you. And I made up my mind, besides,’ said Caddy, looking at me hopefully but timidly, ‘that if you consented, I would ask you afterwards to come with me to Ma. This is what I meant when I said in my note that I had a great favour and a great assistance to beg of you. And if you thought you could grant it, Esther, we should both be very grateful.’
“噢，你这个令人厌烦的东西！”凯迪笑着说道，她漂亮的脸庞着火了。 “我亲爱的孩子，如果你坚持的话！这给他带来了数周的不安，并让他日复一日地拖延，非常焦虑。最后他对我说：“凯迪，如果我能说服我父亲最喜欢的萨默森小姐在我打破这个话题时在场，我想我可以做到。”所以我答应我会问。你。此外，我还决定，”凯迪满怀希望但胆怯地看着我，说道，“如果你同意，我会请你随后跟我一起去妈妈那里。这就是我在便条中说我向您请求一个大恩惠和大帮助时的意思。如果你认为你可以同意，埃丝特，我们都应该非常感激。

‘Let me see, Caddy,’ said I, pretending to consider. ‘Really, I think I could do a greater thing than that if the need were pressing. I am at your service and the darling child’s, my dear, whenever you like.’
“让我想想，凯迪，”我假装思考着说道。 “真的，我认为如果需求紧迫的话，我可以做比这更伟大的事情。亲爱的，只要您愿意，我随时为您和亲爱的孩子服务。
