Caddy was quite transported by this reply of mine, being, I believe, as susceptible to the least kindness or encouragement as any tender heart that ever beat in this world; and after another turn or two round the garden, during which she put on an entirely new pair of gloves and made herself as resplendent as possible that she might do no avoidable discredit to the Master of Deportment, we went to Newman Street direct.
凯迪对我的回答感到非常感动，我相信，他就像这个世界上任何一颗温柔的心一样，容易受到哪怕是最起码的善意或鼓励。又绕着花园转了一两圈，期间她戴上了一副全新的手套，把自己打扮得尽可能光鲜亮丽，以免对仪态大师造成不可避免的损害，我们直接去了纽曼街。

Prince was teaching, of course. We found him engaged with a not very hopeful pupil—a stubborn little girl with a sulky forehead, a deep voice, and an inanimate, dissatisfied mama—whose case was certainly not rendered more hopeful by the confusion into which we threw her preceptor. The lesson at last came to an end, after proceeding as discordantly as possible; and when the little girl had changed her shoes and had had her white muslin extinguished in shawls, she was taken away. After a few words of preparation, we then went in search of Mr. Turveydrop, whom we found, grouped with his hat and gloves, as a model of deportment, on the sofa in his private apartment—the only comfortable room in the house. He appeared to have dressed at his leisure in the intervals of a light collation, and his dressing-case, brushes, and so forth, all of quite an elegant kind, lay about.
当然，普林斯正在教学。我们发现他和一个不太有希望的学生交往——一个顽固的小女孩，额头阴沉，声音低沉，还有一个毫无生气、不满的妈妈——我们让她的老师陷入混乱，她的情况当然没有变得更有希望。在尽可能不和谐地进行之后，这堂课终于结束了。当小女孩换了鞋子，并用围巾擦干她的白色平纹细布后，她就被带走了。经过几句话的准备，我们就去寻找特维德罗普先生，我们发现他戴着帽子和手套，坐在他私人公寓的沙发上——这栋房子里唯一舒适的房间。他似乎在闲暇时穿得很轻松，他的化妆盒、刷子等等，全都相当优雅，散落在各处。

‘Father, Miss Summerson; Miss Jellyby.’
“父亲，萨默森小姐；杰利比小姐。

‘Charmed! Enchanted!’ said Mr. Turveydrop, rising with his highshouldered bow. ‘Permit me!’ Handing chairs. ‘Be seated!’ Kissing the tips of his left fingers. ‘Overjoyed!’ Shutting his eyes and rolling. ‘My little retreat is made a paradise.’ Recomposing himself on the sofa like the second gentleman in Europe.
'迷住了！着迷了！”特维德罗普先生一边说，一边高举着他的高肩弓。 “请允许我！”把椅子递过来。 “坐下！”亲吻他左手的指尖。 “太高兴了！”闭上眼睛翻滚。 “我的小隐居处变成了天堂。”像欧洲第二位绅士一样在沙发上重新调整自己的心情。

‘Again you find us, Miss Summerson,’ said he, ‘using our little arts to polish, polish! Again the sex stimulates us and rewards us by the condescension of its lovely presence. It is much in these times (and we have made an awfully degenerating business of it since the days of his Royal Highness the Prince Regent—my patron, if I may presume to say so) to experience that deportment is not wholly trodden under foot by mechanics. That it can yet bask in the smile of beauty, my dear madam.’
“你又发现我们了，萨默森小姐，”他说，“用我们的小技巧来打磨，打磨！性再次通过它可爱的存在的屈尊来刺激我们并奖励我们。在这个时代（如果我可以这么说的话，我的赞助人摄政王殿下以来，我们已经做了一件非常堕落的事情），我们可以体会到，行为举止并没有完全被践踏在脚下。机械师。它仍然可以沐浴在美丽的微笑中，我亲爱的女士。

I said nothing, which I thought a suitable reply; and he took a pinch of snuff.
我什么也没说，我认为这是一个合适的回答；他吸了一口鼻烟。

‘My dear son,’ said Mr. Turveydrop, ‘you have four schools this afternoon. I would recommend a hasty sandwich.’
“我亲爱的儿子，”特维德罗普先生说，“今天下午你有四所学校。”我会推荐一份速食三明治。

‘Thank you, father,’ returned Prince, ‘I will be sure to be punctual. My dear father, may I beg you to prepare your mind for what I am going to say?’
“谢谢你，父亲，”普林斯回答道，“我一定会准时的。”我亲爱的父亲，我可以请求你为我要说的话做好准备吗？

‘Good heaven!’ exclaimed the model, pale and aghast as Prince and Caddy, hand in hand, bent down before him. ‘What is this? Is this lunacy! Or what is this?’
“天哪！”当王子和凯迪手拉着手在他面前弯下身子时，模特脸色苍白、惊愕不已，惊呼道。 '这是什么？这是疯子吗！或者这是什么？

‘Father,’ returned Prince with great submission, ‘I love this young lady, and we are engaged.’
“父亲，”普林斯非常顺从地回答道，“我爱这位年轻的女士，我们订婚了。”

‘Engaged!’ cried Mr. Turveydrop, reclining on the sofa and shutting out the sight with his hand. ‘An arrow launched at my brain by my own child!’
“订婚了！”特维德罗普先生靠在沙发上喊道，用手挡住了视线。 “我自己的孩子向我的大脑射出了一支箭！”

‘We have been engaged for some time, father,’ faltered Prince, ‘and Miss Summerson, hearing of it, advised that we should declare the fact to you and was so very kind as to attend on the present occasion. Miss Jellyby is a young lady who deeply respects you, father.’
“我们订婚已经有一段时间了，父亲，”普林斯结结巴巴地说，“萨默森小姐听说了这件事，建议我们向您宣布这个事实，并且非常友善地出席了这次活动。杰利比小姐是一位年轻的女士，她非常尊敬您，父亲。”

Mr. Turveydrop uttered a groan.
特维德罗普先生发出一声呻吟。

‘No, pray don’t! Pray don’t, father,’ urged his son. ‘Miss Jellyby is a young lady who deeply respects you, and our first desire is to consider your comfort.’
‘不，祈祷不要这样！请不要这样做，父亲。”他的儿子催促道。 “杰利比小姐是一位非常尊敬您的年轻女士，我们的首要愿望是考虑您的舒适度。”

Mr. Turveydrop sobbed.
特维德罗普先生抽泣着。

‘No, pray don’t, father!’ cried his son.
“不，请不要这样做，父亲！”他的儿子喊道。

‘Boy,’ said Mr. Turveydrop, ‘it is well that your sainted mother is spared this pang. Strike deep, and spare not. Strike home, sir, strike home!’
“孩子，”特维德罗普先生说，“你神圣的母亲幸免于难。”深入打击，不遗余力。直击目标，先生，直击目标！

‘Pray don’t say so, father,’ implored Prince, in tears. ‘It goes to my heart. I do assure you, father, that our first wish and intention is to consider your comfort. Caroline and I do not forget our duty—what is my duty is Caroline’s, as we have often said together—and with your approval and consent, father, we will devote ourselves to making your life agreeable.’
“请不要这么说，父亲，”普林斯流着泪恳求道。 ‘它触动了我的心。父亲，我向您保证，我们的首要愿望和意图是考虑您的舒适度。卡罗琳和我没有忘记我们的责任——正如我们经常在一起说的那样，我的责任就是卡罗琳的责任——在您的认可和同意下，父亲，我们将致力于让您的生活变得愉快。

‘Strike home,’ murmured Mr. Turveydrop. ‘Strike home!’ But he seemed to listen, I thought, too.
“打回家，”特维德罗普先生低声说道。 “攻击正中！”但我想，他似乎也在听。

‘My dear father,’ returned Prince, ‘we well know what little comforts you are accustomed to and have a right to, and it will always be our study and our pride to provide those before anything. If you will bless us with your approval and consent, father, we shall not think of being married until it is quite agreeable to you; and when we ARE married, we shall always make you—of course— our first consideration. You must ever be the head and master here, father; and we feel how truly unnatural it would be in us if we failed to know it or if we failed to exert ourselves in every possible way to please you.’
“我亲爱的父亲，”普林斯回答道，“我们很清楚您习惯并有权享受哪些小小的安慰，我们将永远致力于为您提供这些，我们也为此感到自豪。”父亲，如果您能以您的认可和同意来祝福我们，那么在您完全同意之前我们不会考虑结婚；当我们结婚时，当然，我们将永远把你作为我们的首要考虑。父亲，您必须永远是这里的头儿和主人；我们感到，如果我们不知道这一点，或者如果我们不竭尽全力取悦您，那么我们的内心就会多么不自然。

Mr. Turveydrop underwent a severe internal struggle and came upright on the sofa again with his cheeks puffing over his stiff cravat, a perfect model of parental deportment.
特维德罗普先生经历了一场剧烈的内心挣扎，再次从沙发上站了起来，脸颊鼓起，遮住了僵硬的领带，这是父母举止的完美典范。

‘My son!’ said Mr. Turveydrop. ‘My children! I cannot resist your prayer. Be happy!’
“我的儿子！”特维德罗普先生说。 '我的孩子们！我无法抗拒你的祈祷。要开心！'

His benignity as he raised his future daughter-in-law and stretched out his hand to his son (who kissed it with affectionate respect and gratitude) was the most confusing sight I ever saw.
当他抚养他未来的儿媳并向他的儿子伸出手（儿子带着深情的尊重和感激亲吻他的手）时，他的仁慈是我见过的最令人困惑的景象。

‘My children,’ said Mr. Turveydrop, paternally encircling Caddy with his left arm as she sat beside him, and putting his right hand gracefully on his hip. ‘My son and daughter, your happiness shall be my care. I will watch over you. You shall always live with me’—meaning, of course, I will always live with you—‘this house is henceforth as much yours as mine; consider it your home. May you long live to share it with me!’
“我的孩子们，”特维德罗普先生说道，当凯蒂坐在他身边时，他用左臂慈父般地搂住她，右手优雅地放在自己的臀部上。 ‘我的儿子和女儿，你们的幸福将由我来照顾。我会守护你。你将永远和我住在一起”——当然，我的意思是，我将永远和你住在一起——“从今以后，这所房子既是我的，也是你的；把它当作你的家。祝你长寿并与我分享！

The power of his deportment was such that they really were as much overcome with thankfulness as if, instead of quartering himself upon them for the rest of his life, he were making some munificent sacrifice in their favour.
他的举止如此有力，以至于他们真的充满了感激之情，仿佛他不是在余生中将自己奉献给他们，而是为他们做出了一些慷慨的牺牲。

‘For myself, my children,’ said Mr. Turveydrop, ‘I am falling into the sear and yellow leaf, and it is impossible to say how long the last feeble traces of gentlemanly deportment may linger in this weaving and spinning age. But, so long, I will do my duty to society and will show myself, as usual, about town. My wants are few and simple. My little apartment here, my few essentials for the toilet, my frugal morning meal, and my little dinner will suffice. I charge your dutiful affection with the supply of these requirements, and I charge myself with all the rest.’
“对我自己来说，我的孩子们，”特维德罗普先生说，“我正陷入灼热和黄叶之中，无法预测最后一丝绅士风度会在这个纺织和纺纱的时代持续多久。”但是，长期以来，我将尽我对社会的责任，并像往常一样展示自己关于城镇的情况。我的愿望很少而且很简单。我在这里的小公寓，我的一些厕所必需品，我节俭的早餐和我的小晚餐就足够了。我负责满足这些要求，并负责所有其余的事情。

They were overpowered afresh by his uncommon generosity.
他们再次被他不同寻常的慷慨所征服。

‘My son,’ said Mr. Turveydrop, ‘for those little points in which you are deficient—points of deportment, which are born with a man, which may be improved by cultivation, but can never be originated— you may still rely on me. I have been faithful to my post since the days of his Royal Highness the Prince Regent, and I will not desert it now. No, my son. If you have ever contemplated your father’s poor position with a feeling of pride, you may rest assured that he will do nothing to tarnish it. For yourself, Prince, whose character is different (we cannot be all alike, nor is it advisable that we should), work, be industrious, earn money, and extend the connexion as much as possible.’
“我的孩子，”特维德罗普先生说，“对于那些你所欠缺的小点——举止上的点，这些点是与生俱来的，可以通过培养来提高，但永远不可能是天生的——你仍然可以依靠我。我从摄政王殿下时代起就忠于职守，现在也不会放弃。不，我的儿子。如果你曾经怀着自豪的心情考虑过你父亲的可怜地位，你可以放心，他不会做任何事情来玷污它。对于你自己来说，普林斯，性格各异（我们不可能都一样，也不建议我们应该一样），工作，勤奋，赚钱，并尽可能扩大联系。

‘That you may depend I will do, dear father, with all my heart,’ replied Prince.
“亲爱的父亲，我会全心全意地为您服务，”王子回答道。

‘I have no doubt of it,’ said Mr. Turveydrop. ‘Your qualities are not shining, my dear child, but they are steady and useful. And to both of you, my children, I would merely observe, in the spirit of a sainted wooman on whose path I had the happiness of casting, I believe, SOME ray of light, take care of the establishment, take care of my simple wants, and bless you both!’
“我对此毫不怀疑，”特维德罗普先生说。 ‘我亲爱的孩子，你的品质并不耀眼，但却是稳定而有用的。对于你们俩，我的孩子们，我只是本着一位圣女的精神，我有幸在他们的道路上投射出一些光芒，我相信，照顾好机构，照顾好我简单的生活。想要，并祝福你们俩！

Old Mr. Turveydrop then became so very gallant, in honour of the occasion, that I told Caddy we must really go to Thavies Inn at once if we were to go at all that day. So we took our departure after a very loving farewell between Caddy and her betrothed, and during our walk she was so happy and so full of old Mr. Turveydrop’s praises that I would not have said a word in his disparagement for any consideration.
为了纪念这个场合，老特维德罗普先生变得非常殷勤，我告诉凯蒂，如果我们那天要走的话，我们必须立即去萨维斯旅馆。因此，凯迪和她的未婚夫深情地告别后，我们就出发了。在我们散步的过程中，她非常高兴，充满了老特维德罗普先生的赞美，以至于我不会出于任何考虑而对他说任何贬低的话。

The house in Thavies Inn had bills in the windows annoucing that it was to let, and it looked dirtier and gloomier and ghastlier than ever. The name of poor Mr. Jellyby had appeared in the list of bankrupts but a day or two before, and he was shut up in the dining-room with two gentlemen and a heap of blue bags, accountbooks, and papers, making the most desperate endeavours to understand his affairs. They appeared to me to be quite beyond his comprehension, for when Caddy took me into the dining-room by mistake and we came upon Mr. Jellyby in his spectacles, forlornly fenced into a corner by the great dining-table and the two gentlemen, he seemed to have given up the whole thing and to be speechless and insensible.
塔维斯旅馆的房子窗户上挂着账单，宣布要出租，而且它看起来比以前更脏、更阴暗、更可怕。可怜的杰利比先生的名字在一两天前就出现在破产者名单上，他和两位先生以及一堆蓝色的袋子、账簿和文件被关在餐厅里，让最绝望的人努力了解他的事务。在我看来，他们完全超出了他的理解范围，因为当卡迪错误地把我带进餐厅时，我们遇到了戴眼镜的杰利比先生，他被大餐桌和两位绅士凄凉地围在角落里，他似乎已经放弃了一切，无言以对，毫无知觉。

Going upstairs to Mrs. Jellyby’s room (the children were all screaming in the kitchen, and there was no servant to be seen), we found that lady in the midst of a voluminous correspondence, opening, reading, and sorting letters, with a great accumulation of torn covers on the floor. She was so preoccupied that at first she did not know me, though she sat looking at me with that curious, bright-eyed, far-off look of hers.
上楼来到杰利比太太的房间（厨房里孩子们都在尖叫，也看不到仆人），我们发现那位女士正在处理大量的信件，打开、阅读、分类信件，神情非常严肃。地板上堆积着撕破的盖子。她全神贯注，一开始并不认识我，尽管她坐在那儿，用那种好奇、明亮、遥远的神情看着我。

‘Ah! Miss Summerson!’ she said at last. ‘I was thinking of something so different! I hope you are well. I am happy to see you. Mr. Jarndyce and Miss Clare quite well?’
'啊！萨默森小姐！”她最后说道。 “我在想一些非常不同的事情！我希望你一切都好。我很高兴见到你。贾迪斯先生和克莱尔小姐关系很好吗？

I hoped in return that Mr. Jellyby was quite well.
作为回报，我希望杰利比先生一切都好。

‘Why, not quite, my dear,’ said Mrs. Jellyby in the calmest manner. ‘He has been unfortunate in his affairs and is a little out of spirits. Happily for me, I am so much engaged that I have no time to think about it. We have, at the present moment, one hundred and seventy families, Miss Summerson, averaging five persons in each, either gone or going to the left bank of the Niger.’
“哦，不完全是，亲爱的，”杰利比太太以最平静的方式说道。 ‘他的事情有些不幸，精神有些萎靡。令我高兴的是，我太忙了，没有时间去想它。萨默森小姐，目前我们有一百七十个家庭，平均每个家庭有五人，要么离开了，要么前往尼日尔左岸。

I thought of the one family so near us who were neither gone nor going to the left bank of the Niger, and wondered how she could be so placid.
我想起离我们那么近的一家人，他们既没有离开，也没有去尼日尔河左岸，我想知道她怎么能如此平静。

‘You have brought Caddy back, I see,’ observed Mrs. Jellyby with a glance at her daughter. ‘It has become quite a novelty to see her here. She has almost deserted her old employment and in fact obliges me to employ a boy.’
“我明白了，你把凯迪带回来了，”杰利比太太看了一眼她的女儿说道。 “在这里见到她已经变得很新奇了。她几乎放弃了原来的工作，实际上迫使我雇用了一个男孩。

‘I am sure, Ma—‘ began Caddy.
“我确信，妈妈——”凯迪开始说道。

‘Now you know, Caddy,’ her mother mildly interposed, ‘that I DO employ a boy, who is now at his dinner. What is the use of your contradicting?’
“现在你知道了，凯迪，”她母亲温和地插话道，“我确实雇佣了一个男孩，他现在正在吃晚饭。”你反驳有什么用？

‘I was not going to contradict, Ma,’ returned Caddy. ‘I was only going to say that surely you wouldn’t have me be a mere drudge all my life.’
“我不会反驳，妈妈，”凯迪回答道。 “我只是想说，你肯定不会让我一辈子当苦工。”

‘I believe, my dear,’ said Mrs. Jellyby, still opening her letters, casting her bright eyes smilingly over them, and sorting them as she spoke, ‘that you have a business example before you in your mother. Besides. A mere drudge? If you had any sympathy with the destinies of the human race, it would raise you high above any such idea. But you have none. I have often told you, Caddy, you have no such sympathy.’
“我相信，亲爱的，”杰利比太太一边说，一边继续打开信，用明亮的眼睛微笑着看着信，边说边把它们分类，“在你面前有一个商业榜样，那就是你的母亲。”除了。一个单纯的苦工？如果你对人类的命运有任何同情，你就会超越任何此类想法。但你没有。我经常告诉你，凯迪，你没有这样的同情心。

‘Not if it’s Africa, Ma, I have not.’
“如果是非洲就不会，妈，我没有。”

‘Of course you have not. Now, if I were not happily so much engaged, Miss Summerson,’ said Mrs. Jellyby, sweetly casting her eyes for a moment on me and considering where to put the particular letter she had just opened, ‘this would distress and disappoint me. But I have so much to think of, in connexion with Borrioboola-Gha and it is so necessary I should concentrate myself that there is my remedy, you see.’
“你当然没有。”现在，萨默森小姐，如果我不是很高兴地如此忙碌，”杰利比夫人说道，她甜蜜地在我身上看了一会儿，考虑着把她刚刚打开的那封信放在哪里，“这会让我感到痛苦和失望。但我有很多事情要考虑，与博里奥博拉-加有关，我非常有必要集中精力，这就是我的补救办法，你看。

As Caddy gave me a glance of entreaty, and as Mrs. Jellyby was looking far away into Africa straight through my bonnet and head, I thought it a good opportunity to come to the subject of my visit and to attract Mrs. Jellyby’s attention.
当卡迪恳求地看了我一眼，当杰利比夫人透过我的帽子和头直视远方的非洲时，我认为这是一个很好的机会来谈谈我访问的主题并吸引杰利比夫人的注意。

‘Perhaps,’ I began, ‘you will wonder what has brought me here to interrupt you.’
“也许，”我开始说道，“你会想知道是什么让我来这里打断你的。”

‘I am always delighted to see Miss Summerson,’ said Mrs. Jellyby, pursuing her employment with a placid smile. ‘Though I wish,’ and she shook her head, ‘she was more interested in the Borrioboolan project.’
“我总是很高兴见到萨默森小姐，”杰利比夫人说，带着平静的微笑寻求工作。 “虽然我希望如此，”她摇了摇头，“她对博里奥布尔兰项目更感兴趣。”

‘I have come with Caddy,’ said I, ‘because Caddy justly thinks she ought not to have a secret from her mother and fancies I shall encourage and aid her (though I am sure I don’t know how) in imparting one.’
“我和凯蒂一起来，”我说，“因为凯蒂认为她不应该对她母亲保守秘密，并且幻想我应该鼓励和帮助她（尽管我确信我不知道如何）透露一个秘密。 '

‘Caddy,’ said Mrs. Jellyby, pausing for a moment in her occupation and then serenely pursuing it after shaking her head, ‘you are going to tell me some nonsense.’
“球童，”杰利比太太在她的工作中停顿了一会儿，摇摇头后平静地继续说，“你要告诉我一些废话。”

Caddy untied the strings of her bonnet, took her bonnet off, and letting it dangle on the floor by the strings, and crying heartily, said, ‘Ma, I am engaged.’
球童解开帽子的带子，把帽子脱下来，用绳子把帽子挂在地板上，大声哭着说：“妈妈，我订婚了。”

‘Oh, you ridiculous child!’ observed Mrs. Jellyby with an abstracted air as she looked over the dispatch last opened; ‘what a goose you are!’
“哦，你这个可笑的孩子！”杰利比太太看着最后打开的那封信，心不在焉地说道。 “你真是一只鹅啊！”

‘I am engaged, Ma,’ sobbed Caddy, ‘to young Mr. Turveydrop, at the academy; and old Mr. Turveydrop (who is a very gentlemanly man indeed) has given his consent, and I beg and pray you’ll give us yours, Ma, because I never could be happy without it. I never, never could!’ sobbed Caddy, quite forgetful of her general complainings and of everything but her natural affection.
“妈妈，我在学院和年轻的特维德罗普先生订婚了，”卡迪抽泣道。老特维德罗普先生（他确实是一位非常有绅士风度的人）已经同意了，我恳求并祈祷您也能同意，妈妈，因为没有它我永远不会幸福。我永远、永远不能！”凯迪抽泣着，完全忘记了她一般的抱怨和一切，除了她自然的感情。

‘You see again, Miss Summerson,’ observed Mrs. Jellyby serenely, ‘what a happiness it is to be so much occupied as I am and to have this necessity for self-concentration that I have. Here is Caddy engaged to a dancing-master’s son—mixed up with people who have no more sympathy with the destinies of the human race than she has herself! This, too, when Mr. Quale, one of the first philanthropists of our time, has mentioned to me that he was really disposed to be interested in her!’
“你再看一遍，萨默森小姐，”杰利比夫人平静地说道，“像我这样忙得不可开交，而且有这种自我集中的必要性，这是多么幸福啊。”凯蒂与一位舞蹈大师的儿子订婚了——她和那些对人类命运并不比她自己更有同情心的人混在一起！当我们这个时代最早的慈善家之一奎尔先生向我提到他真的很想对她感兴趣时，也是如此！

‘Ma, I always hated and detested Mr. Quale!’ sobbed Caddy.
“妈妈，我一直讨厌奎尔先生！”凯迪抽泣着说道。

‘Caddy, Caddy!’ returned Mrs. Jellyby, opening another letter with the greatest complacency. ‘I have no doubt you did. How could you do otherwise, being totally destitute of the sympathies with which he overflows! Now, if my public duties were not a favourite child to me, if I were not occupied with large measures on a vast scale, these petty details might grieve me very much, Miss Summerson. But can I permit the film of a silly proceeding on the part of Caddy (from whom I expect nothing else) to interpose between me and the great African continent? No. No,’ repeated Mrs. Jellyby in a calm clear voice, and with an agreeable smile, as she opened more letters and sorted them. ‘No, indeed.’
“球童，球童！”杰利比太太回答道，带着极大的满足感打开了另一封信。 “我毫不怀疑你做到了。你怎么能不这样做呢，因为你完全没有他所充满的同情心！现在，如果我不喜欢我的公共职责，如果我没有忙于大规模的重大措施，这些琐碎的细节可能会让我非常悲伤，萨默森小姐。但我可以允许一部关于凯迪（我对他没有别的期望）的愚蠢行为的电影插在我和伟大的非洲大陆之间吗？不，不，”杰利比太太一边打开更多的信，一边对它们进行分类，用平静而清晰的声音重复道，脸上带着愉快的微笑。 “不，确实如此。”

I was so unprepared for the perfect coolness of this reception, though I might have expected it, that I did not know what to say. Caddy seemed equally at a loss. Mrs. Jellyby continued to open and sort letters and to repeat occasionally in quite a charming tone of voice and with a smile of perfect composure, ‘No, indeed.’
尽管我可能已经预料到了这样的接待，但我对这种完全冷静的接待感到非常措手不及，以至于我不知道该说什么。凯迪看上去同样不知所措。杰利比夫人继续打开和分类信件，偶尔以一种迷人的语气和完全镇静的微笑重复说：“不，确实如此。”

‘I hope, Ma,’ sobbed poor Caddy at last, ‘you are not angry?’
“我希望，妈妈，”可怜的凯迪最后抽泣着，“你不生气吗？”

‘Oh, Caddy, you really are an absurd girl,’ returned Mrs. Jellyby, ‘to ask such questions after what I have said of the preoccupation of my mind.’
“哦，凯迪，你真是个荒唐的女孩，”杰利比太太回答道，“在我说了我全神贯注的事情之后，你还问这样的问题。”

‘And I hope, Ma, you give us your consent and wish us well?’ said Caddy.
“妈妈，我希望您同意我们并祝我们一切顺利？”凯迪说。

‘You are a nonsensical child to have done anything of this kind,’ said Mrs. Jellyby; ‘and a degenerate child, when you might have devoted yourself to the great public measure. But the step is taken, and I have engaged a boy, and there is no more to be said. Now, pray, Caddy,’ said Mrs. Jellyby, for Caddy was kissing her, ‘don’t delay me in my work, but let me clear off this heavy batch of papers before the afternoon post comes in!’
“你真是个愚蠢的孩子，居然做出了这种事。”杰利比太太说。 ‘当你本可以致力于伟大的公共措施时，还是一个堕落的孩子。但步已迈出，又订了一个童子，也就没什么可说的了。现在，祈祷吧，凯蒂，”杰利比太太一边亲吻她，一边说道，“别耽误我的工作，但让我在下午的邮件送达之前把这堆厚重的文件处理掉！”

I thought I could not do better than take my leave; I was detained for a moment by Caddy’s saying, ‘You won’t object to my bringing him to see you, Ma?’
我想我最好的办法就是离开。凯迪的一句话让我愣住了：“妈妈，你不会反对我带他来见你吧？”

‘Oh, dear me, Caddy,’ cried Mrs. Jellyby, who had relapsed into that distant contemplation, ‘have you begun again? Bring whom?’
“哦，天哪，凯蒂，”杰利比太太喊道，她又陷入了那种遥远的沉思，“你又开始了吗？”带谁来？

‘Him, Ma.’
“他，妈妈。”

‘Caddy, Caddy!’ said Mrs. Jellyby, quite weary of such little matters. ‘Then you must bring him some evening which is not a Parent Society night, or a Branch night, or a Ramification night. You must accommodate the visit to the demands upon my time. My dear Miss Summerson, it was very kind of you to come here to help out this silly chit. Good-bye! When I tell you that I have fiftyeight new letters from manufacturing families anxious to understand the details of the native and coffee-cultivation question this morning, I need not apologize for having very little leisure.’
“球童，球童！”杰利比太太对这些小事感到厌烦了。 “那么你必须在某个晚上带他来，这个晚上不是家长协会之夜，也不是分支机构之夜，也不是分支之夜。您必须满足这次访问对我时间的要求。我亲爱的萨默森小姐，您能来这里帮助解决这个愚蠢的问题真是太好了。再见！当我告诉你，今天早上我收到了 58 封来自制造业家庭的新来信，他们急切地想了解本土和咖啡种植问题的细节时，我不需要为没有多少空闲而道歉。

I was not surprised by Caddy’s being in low spirits when we went downstairs, or by her sobbing afresh on my neck, or by her saying she would far rather have been scolded than treated with such indifference, or by her confiding to me that she was so poor in clothes that how she was ever to be married creditably she didn’t know. I gradually cheered her up by dwelling on the many things she would do for her unfortunate father and for Peepy when she had a home of her own; and finally we went downstairs into the damp dark kitchen, where Peepy and his little brothers and sisters were grovelling on the stone floor and where we had such a game of play with them that to prevent myself from being quite torn to pieces I was obliged to fall back on my fairy-tales. From time to time I heard loud voices in the parlour overhead, and occasionally a violent tumbling about of the furniture. The last effect I am afraid was caused by poor Mr. Jellyby’s breaking away from the dining-table and making rushes at the window with the intention of throwing himself into the area whenever he made any new attempt to understand his affairs.
当我们下楼时，凯迪情绪低落，或者她在我脖子上重新抽泣，或者她说她宁愿被责骂也不愿受到如此冷漠的对待，或者她向我吐露她她的衣服如此简陋，以至于她不知道如何才能体面地结婚。我逐渐让她高兴起来，想着当她有了自己的家后，她会为她不幸的父亲和皮皮做很多事情；最后我们下楼进入潮湿黑暗的厨房，皮皮和他的弟弟妹妹们正趴在石头地板上，我们和他们玩游戏，为了防止自己被撕成碎片，我不得不回到我的童话故事中。我不时听到头顶客厅里传来大声的说话声，偶尔还听到家具猛烈翻滚的声音。我担心最后一个影响是由于可怜的杰利比先生每当他试图了解自己的事务时，就会从餐桌上挣脱出来，冲向窗户，意图冲入该地区。

As I rode quietly home at night after the day’s bustle, I thought a good deal of Caddy’s engagement and felt confirmed in my hopes (in spite of the elder Mr. Turveydrop) that she would be the happier and better for it. And if there seemed to be but a slender chance of her and her husband ever finding out what the model of deportment really was, why that was all for the best too, and who would wish them to be wiser? I did not wish them to be any wiser and indeed was half ashamed of not entirely believing in him myself. And I looked up at the stars, and thought about travellers in distant countries and the stars THEY saw, and hoped I might always be so blest and happy as to be useful to some one in my small way.
经过一天的忙碌，晚上我安静地骑车回家时，我想了很多关于凯蒂订婚的事，并确信我的希望（尽管年长的特维德罗普先生）希望她会因此而更快乐、更好。如果她和她的丈夫似乎只有微乎其微的机会发现真正的行为模式是什么，那为什么这也是最好的呢？谁会希望他们变得更聪明呢？我不希望他们变得更聪明，事实上，我也为自己不完全相信他而感到羞愧。我抬头仰望星空，想着远方的旅行者和他们看到的星星，希望我能永远幸福快乐，以自己的微薄之力为某人做点贡献。

They were so glad to see me when I got home, as they always were, that I could have sat down and cried for joy if that had not been a method of making myself disagreeable. Everybody in the house, from the lowest to the highest, showed me such a bright face of welcome, and spoke so cheerily, and was so happy to do anything for me, that I suppose there never was such a fortunate little creature in the world.
当我回到家时，他们很高兴见到我，就像他们一贯的那样，如果这不是让自己变得不愉快的话，我可以坐下来高兴地哭泣。房子里的每个人，从最低层到最高层，都向我露出了如此灿烂的欢迎表情，说话如此愉快，很乐意为我做任何事，我想世界上从来没有过如此幸运的小动物。 。

We got into such a chatty state that night, through Ada and my guardian drawing me out to tell them all about Caddy, that I went on prose, prose, prosing for a length of time. At last I got up to my own room, quite red to think how I had been holding forth, and then I heard a soft tap at my door. So I said, ‘Come in!’ and there came in a pretty little girl, neatly dressed in mourning, who dropped a curtsy.
那天晚上，我们聊得很投机，艾达和我的监护人把我拉出来告诉他们关于凯迪的一切，以至于我写了很长一段时间的散文、散文、散文。最后，我回到了自己的房间，一想到自己一直在喋喋不休，脸就红了，然后我听到有人轻轻地敲门。于是我说：“请进！”然后进来了一个漂亮的小女孩，她穿着整齐的丧服，行了屈膝礼。

‘If you please, miss,’ said the little girl in a soft voice, ‘I am Charley.’
“请问，小姐，”小女孩轻声说道，“我是查理。”

‘Why, so you are,’ said I, stooping down in astonishment and giving her a kiss. ‘How glad am I to see you, Charley!’
“哎呀，原来你是这样啊。”我惊讶地弯下腰，吻了她一下。 “我很高兴见到你，查理！”

‘If you please, miss,’ pursued Charley in the same soft voice, ‘I’m your maid.’
“如果您愿意，小姐，”查利用同样柔和的声音追问，“我是您的女仆。”

‘Charley?’
“查理？”

‘If you please, miss, I’m a present to you, with Mr. Jarndyce’s love.’
“小姐，如果您愿意的话，我是送给您的一份礼物，带着贾迪斯先生的爱。”

I sat down with my hand on Charley’s neck and looked at Charley.
我坐下来，把手放在查理的脖子上，看着查理。

‘And oh, miss,’ says Charley, clapping her hands, with the tears starting down her dimpled cheeks, ‘Tom’s at school, if you please, and learning so good! And little Emma, she’s with Mrs. Blinder, miss, a-being took such care of! And Tom, he would have been at school—and Emma, she would have been left with Mrs. Blinder—and me, I should have been here—all a deal sooner, miss; only Mr. Jarndyce thought that Tom and Emma and me had better get a little used to parting first, we was so small. Don’t cry, if you please, miss!’
“哦，小姐，”查莉拍着手说道，泪水从她那双有酒窝的脸颊上流下来，“汤姆在学校，如果你愿意的话，他学得真好！还有小艾玛，她和布林德太太在一起，小姐，一个人受到了如此照顾！汤姆，他本来应该去学校的——艾玛，她本来应该和布林德太太在一起的——而我，我本应该到这里的——一切都早点了，小姐；只有贾迪斯先生认为汤姆、艾玛和我最好先习惯分开，我们太小了。小姐，请别哭！”

‘I can’t help it, Charley.’
“我没办法，查理。”

‘No, miss, nor I can’t help it,’ says Charley. ‘And if you please, miss, Mr. Jarndyce’s love, and he thinks you’ll like to teach me now and then. And if you please, Tom and Emma and me is to see each other once a month. And I’m so happy and so thankful, miss,’ cried Charley with a heaving heart, ‘and I’ll try to be such a good maid!’
“不，小姐，我也无能为力，”查理说。 “如果您愿意的话，小姐，贾迪斯先生的爱人，他认为您会时不时地教我。如果你愿意的话，汤姆、艾玛和我每月见一次面。我很高兴，也很感激，小姐，”查理心潮澎湃地喊道，“我会努力成为一名好女仆的！”

‘Oh, Charley dear, never forget who did all this!’
“噢，亲爱的查理，永远不要忘记这一切是谁干的！”

‘No, miss, I never will. Nor Tom won’t. Nor yet Emma. It was all you, miss.’
“不，小姐，我永远不会。汤姆也不会。艾玛也没有。都是你，小姐。”

‘I have known nothing of it. It was Mr. Jarndyce, Charley.’
“我对此一无所知。这是贾迪斯先生，查理。

‘Yes, miss, but it was all done for the love of you and that you might be my mistress. If you please, miss, I am a little present with his love, and it was all done for the love of you. Me and Tom was to be sure to remember it.’
“是的，小姐，但这一切都是为了爱你，为了让你成为我的情妇。如果您愿意的话，小姐，我送了一份小礼物给他的爱，这一切都是为了对您的爱。我和汤姆一定要记住这一点。

Charley dried her eyes and entered on her functions, going in her matronly little way about and about the room and folding up everything she could lay her hands upon. Presently Charley came creeping back to my side and said, ‘Oh, don’t cry, if you please, miss.’
查理擦干眼睛，开始她的工作，以她主妇的小方式在房间里走来走去，折叠她能拿到的所有东西。不久查理又爬到我身边说：“哦，请不要哭，小姐。”

And I said again, ‘I can’t help it, Charley.’
我又说了一遍：“我无能为力，查理。”

And Charley said again, ‘No, miss, nor I can’t help it.’ And so, after all, I did cry for joy indeed, and so did she.
查理又说：“不，小姐，我也无能为力。”所以，毕竟，我确实高兴得哭了，她也是。

CHAPTER XXIV
第二十四章


An Appeal Case
上诉案件

As soon as Richard and I had held the conversation of which I have given an account, Richard communicated the state of his mind to Mr. Jarndyce. I doubt if my guardian were altogether taken by surprise when he received the representation, though it caused him much uneasiness and disappointment. He and Richard were often closeted together, late at night and early in the morning, and passed whole days in London, and had innumerable appointments with Mr. Kenge, and laboured through a quantity of disagreeable business. While they were thus employed, my guardian, though he underwent considerable inconvenience from the state of the wind and rubbed his head so constantly that not a single hair upon it ever rested in its right place, was as genial with Ada and me as at any other time, but maintained a steady reserve on these matters. And as our utmost endeavours could only elicit from Richard himself sweeping assurances that everything was going on capitally and that it really was all right at last, our anxiety was not much relieved by him.
理查德和我进行了我已记述的谈话后，理查德就向贾迪斯先生传达了他的想法。我怀疑我的监护人在收到陈述时是否完全感到惊讶，尽管这让他感到非常不安和失望。他和理查德经常在深夜和清晨一起密室，在伦敦度过一整天，与肯吉先生进行了无数次约会，并处理了大量令人不快的事务。当他们这样工作时，我的监护人虽然因风势而感到相当不便，而且不断地揉着他的头，以至于头上一根头发都没有放在正确的位置，但他对艾达和我还是一如既往地和蔼可亲。其他时间，但对这些问题保持稳定的保留。由于我们竭尽全力只能从理查德本人那里得到全面的保证，一切都在顺利进行，最终真的没事了，所以他并没有减轻我们的焦虑。

We learnt, however, as the time went on, that a new application was made to the Lord Chancellor on Richard’s behalf as an infant and a ward, and I don’t know what, and that there was a quantity of talking, and that the Lord Chancellor described him in open court as a vexatious and capricious infant, and that the matter was adjourned and readjourned, and referred, and reported on, and petitioned about until Richard began to doubt (as he told us) whether, if he entered the army at all, it would not be as a veteran of seventy or eighty years of age. At last an appointment was made for him to see the Lord Chancellor again in his private room, and there the Lord Chancellor very seriously reproved him for trifling with time and not knowing his mind—‘a pretty good joke, I think,’ said Richard, ‘from that quarter!’—and at last it was settled that his application should be granted. His name was entered at the Horse Guards as an applicant for an ensign’s commission; the purchase-money was deposited at an agent’s; and Richard, in his usual characteristic way, plunged into a violent course of military study and got up at five o’clock every morning to practise the broadsword exercise.
然而，随着时间的推移，我们了解到，有人代表理查德作为婴儿和受监护人向大法官提出了新的申请，我不知道是什么，而且有很多谈话，而且大法官在公开法庭上将他形容为一个无理取闹、反复无常的婴儿，案件一再休会、提交、报告、请愿，直到理查德开始怀疑（正如他告诉我们的那样）是否，如果他进入根本就不是军队，也不会是七十、八十岁的老兵。最后，他被安排在大法官的私人房间里再次见到大法官，大法官非常严肃地责备他浪费时间，不了解自己的想法——“我认为这是一个很好的笑话，”理查德说。 ，“从那个季度开始！”——最后决定批准他的申请。他的名字被登记在皇家骑兵卫队，作为少尉委任的申请人。货款存入代理人处；理查德则以他一贯的方式，投入到激烈的军事学习中，每天早上五点起床练习大刀练习。

Thus, vacation succeeded term, and term succeeded vacation. We sometimes heard of Jarndyce and Jarndyce as being in the paper or out of the paper, or as being to be mentioned, or as being to be spoken to; and it came on, and it went off. Richard, who was now in a professor’s house in London, was able to be with us less frequently than before; my guardian still maintained the same reserve; and so time passed until the commission was obtained and Richard received directions with it to join a regiment in Ireland.
因此，假期继学期，学期又继假期。我们有时听说贾迪斯和贾迪斯出现在报纸上或报纸外，或者被提及，或者被谈论；它出现了，又消失了。理查德现在住在伦敦一位教授的家里，与我们在一起的次数比以前少了。我的监护人仍然保持同样的保留；就这样过了一段时间，理查德获得了委任状，并收到了前往爱尔兰加入一个军团的指示。

He arrived post-haste with the intelligence one evening, and had a long conference with my guardian. Upwards of an hour elapsed before my guardian put his head into the room where Ada and I were sitting and said, ‘Come in, my dears!’ We went in and found Richard, whom we had last seen in high spirits, leaning on the chimney-piece looking mortified and angry.
一天晚上，他带着情报匆匆赶到，并与我的监护人进行了一次长时间的会议。一个多小时过去了，我的监护人把头伸进艾达和我坐的房间说：“进来吧，亲爱的！”我们走进去，发现理查德靠在桌子上，我们最后一次看到他兴高采烈。烟囱看起来既羞愧又愤怒。

‘Rick and I, Ada,’ said Mr. Jarndyce, ‘are not quite of one mind. Come, come, Rick, put a brighter face upon it!’
“里克和我，艾达，”贾迪斯先生说，“意见不一。来吧，来吧，瑞克，把脸变得更明亮！”

‘You are very hard with me, sir,’ said Richard. ‘The harder because you have been so considerate to me in all other respects and have done me kindnesses that I can never acknowledge. I never could have been set right without you, sir.’
“你对我太严厉了，先生，”理查德说。 ‘更难的是因为你在其他方面都对我如此体贴，并且对我做出了我永远无法承认的善意。先生，如果没有你，我永远不可能康复。

‘Well, well!’ said Mr. Jarndyce. ‘I want to set you more right yet. I want to set you more right with yourself.’
“好吧，好吧！”贾迪斯先生说。 “我想让你更加正确。”我想让你更正确地对待自己。

‘I hope you will excuse my saying, sir,’ returned Richard in a fiery way, but yet respectfully, ‘that I think I am the best judge about myself.’
“我希望您能原谅我的话，先生，”理查德以一种火热但又充满敬意的方式回答道，“我认为我是对自己最好的判断。”

‘I hope you will excuse my saying, my dear Rick,’ observed Mr. Jarndyce with the sweetest cheerfulness and good humour, ‘that’s it’s quite natural in you to think so, but I don’t think so. I must do my duty, Rick, or you could never care for me in cool blood; and I hope you will always care for me, cool and hot.’
“亲爱的里克，我希望你能原谅我的话，”贾迪斯先生带着最甜蜜的快乐和幽默说道，“你这么想是很自然的，但我不这么认为。”我必须履行我的职责，瑞克，否则你永远无法冷静地关心我；我希望你永远关心我，无论冷酷还是热情。

Ada had turned so pale that he made her sit down in his readingchair and sat beside her.
艾达脸色苍白，他让她坐在阅读椅上，坐在她旁边。

‘It’s nothing, my dear,’ he said, ‘it’s nothing. Rick and I have only had a friendly difference, which we must state to you, for you are the theme. Now you are afraid of what’s coming.’
“没什么，亲爱的，”他说，“没什么。”里克和我只是有一些友好的分歧，我们必须向你说明这一点，因为你就是主题。现在你害怕即将发生的事情。

‘I am not indeed, cousin John,’ replied Ada with a smile, ‘if it is to come from you.’
“我确实不是，约翰表弟，”艾达微笑着回答，“如果这是你说的。”

‘Thank you, my dear. Do you give me a minute’s calm attention, without looking at Rick. And, little woman, do you likewise. My dear girl,’ putting his hand on hers as it lay on the side of the easy-chair, ‘you recollect the talk we had, we four when the little woman told me of a little love affair?’
'谢了亲爱的。你能冷静地关注我一分钟吗，不要看里克。小女人，你也这样做吧。我亲爱的女孩，”他把手放在安乐椅边上的她的手上，“你还记得我们四个人的谈话吗？那个小女人告诉我一段小小的恋情？”

‘It is not likely that either Richard or I can ever forget your kindness that day, cousin John.’
“无论是理查德还是我都不太可能忘记你那天的好意，约翰表弟。”

‘I can never forget it,’ said Richard.
“我永远不会忘记它，”理查德说。

‘And I can never forget it,’ said Ada.
“我永远不会忘记它，”艾达说。

‘So much the easier what I have to say, and so much the easier for us to agree,’ returned my guardian, his face irradiated by the gentleness and honour of his heart. ‘Ada, my bird, you should know that Rick has now chosen his profession for the last time. All that he has of certainty will be expended when he is fully equipped. He has exhausted his resources and is bound henceforward to the tree he has planted.’
“我要说的话就更容易了，我们也更容易达成一致。”我的监护人回答道，他的脸因他内心的温柔和荣誉而焕发光芒。 ‘艾达，我的小鸟，你应该知道，瑞克现在已经最后一次选择了他的职业。当他装备齐全时，他所拥有的一切确定性都会被消耗掉。他已经用尽了自己的资源，从此以后就只能和他种下的树绑在一起了。

‘Quite true that I have exhausted my present resources, and I am quite content to know it. But what I have of certainty, sir,’ said Richard, ‘is not all I have.’
“确实，我已经用尽了我目前的资源，而且我很高兴知道这一点。但是，先生，”理查德说，“我所拥有的还不是我所拥有的全部。”

‘Rick, Rick!’ cried my guardian with a sudden terror in his manner, and in an altered voice, and putting up his hands as if he would have stopped his ears. ‘For the love of God, don’t found a hope or expectation on the family curse! Whatever you do on this side the grave, never give one lingering glance towards the horrible phantom that has haunted us so many years. Better to borrow, better to beg, better to die!’
“瑞克，瑞克！”我的监护人喊道，他的态度突然变得恐惧，声音也变了，举起双手，好像要堵住耳朵一样。 ‘看在上帝的份上，不要对家族的诅咒抱有希望或期待！无论你在坟墓的这一边做什么，永远不要对这个困扰我们多年的可怕幽灵多看一眼。最好借，最好乞讨，最好死！”

We were all startled by the fervour of this warning. Richard bit his lip and held his breath, and glanced at me as if he felt, and knew that I felt too, how much he needed it.
我们都被这个警告的激烈程度吓了一跳。理查德咬住嘴唇，屏住呼吸，看了我一眼，好像他感觉到了，并且知道我也感觉到了，他是多么需要它。

‘Ada, my dear,’ said Mr. Jarndyce, recovering his cheerfulness, ‘these are strong words of advice, but I live in Bleak House and have seen a sight here. Enough of that. All Richard had to start him in the race of life is ventured. I recommend to him and you, for his sake and your own, that he should depart from us with the understanding that there is no sort of contract between you. I must go further. 1 will be plain with you both. You were to confide freely in me, and I will confide freely in you. I ask you wholly to relinquish, for the present, any tie but your relationship.’
“艾达，亲爱的，”贾迪斯先生恢复了愉快的心情，说道，“这些都是强烈的建议，但我住在荒凉山庄，也见过这里的景象。够了。理查德在人生的赛跑中必须要冒险。我建议他和你，为了他和你自己的利益，他应该离开我们，并理解你们之间不存在任何合同。我必须走得更远。 1 会向你们俩坦白。你应该自由地向我倾诉，我也会自由地向你倾诉。我要求你暂时放弃除你们的关系之外的任何联系。

‘Better to say at once, sir,’ returned Richard, ‘that you renounce all confidence in me and that you advise Ada to do the same.’
“最好立即说，先生，”理查德回答道，“您放弃对我的所有信任，并建议艾达也这样做。”

‘Better to say nothing of the sort, Rick, because I don’t mean it.’
“最好什么也不说，里克，因为我不是这个意思。”

‘You think I have begun ill, sir,’ retorted Richard. ‘I HAVE, I know.’
“你认为我已经开始生病了，先生，”理查德反驳道。 “我有，我知道。”

‘How I hoped you would begin, and how go on, I told you when we spoke of these things last,’ said Mr. Jarndyce in a cordial and encouraging manner. ‘You have not made that beginning yet, but there is a time for all things, and yours is not gone by; rather, it is just now fully come. Make a clear beginning altogether. You two (very young, my dears) are cousins. As yet, you are nothing more. What more may come must come of being worked out, Rick, and no sooner.’
“我多么希望你开始，以及如何继续，当我们上次谈到这些事情时，我已经告诉过你了，”贾迪斯先生以亲切和鼓励的方式说道。 ‘你还没有开始，但是万事都有一个时间，而你的时间还没有过去；相反，它现在才完全到来。完全有一个清晰的开始。你们两个（非常年轻，亲爱的）是表兄弟。到目前为止，你什么都不是。瑞克，接下来可能发生的事情必须得到解决，而且不会很快。

‘You are very hard with me, sir,’ said Richard. ‘Harder than I could have supposed you would be.’
“你对我太严厉了，先生，”理查德说。 “比我想象的还要难。”

‘My dear boy,’ said Mr. Jarndyce, ‘I am harder with myself when I do anything that gives you pain. You have your remedy in your own hands. Ada, it is better for him that he should be free and that there should be no youthful engagement between you. Rick, it is better for her, much better; you owe it to her. Come! Each of you will do what is best for the other, if not what is best for yourselves.’
“我亲爱的孩子，”贾迪斯先生说，“当我做任何让你痛苦的事情时，我会对自己更加严厉。”你有你自己的补救办法。艾达，他应该自由，对他来说更好，你们之间不应该有年轻时的订婚。瑞克，这对她来说更好，好多了；你欠她的。来！你们每个人都会做对对方最好的事情，即使不是对自己最好的事情。”

‘Why is it best, sir?’ returned Richard hastily. ‘It was not when we opened our hearts to you. You did not say so then.’
“为什么这是最好的，先生？”理查德急忙回答道。 ‘那不是我们向你敞开心扉的时候。那时你没有这么说。

‘I have had experience since. I don’t blame you, Rick, but I have had experience since.’
‘从那以后我就有了经验。我不怪你，里克，但从那以后我就有了经验。

‘You mean of me, sir.’
“你是在说我，先生。”

‘Well! Yes, of both of you,’ said Mr. Jarndyce kindly. ‘The time is not come for your standing pledged to one another. It is not right, and I must not recognize it. Come, come, my young cousins, begin afresh! Bygones shall be bygones, and a new page turned for you to write your lives in.’
'出色地！是的，你们俩，”贾迪斯先生和蔼地说。 ‘你们相互宣誓的时候还没有到。这是不对的，我一定不能承认。来吧，来吧，我年轻的表弟们，重新开​​始吧！过去的就过去了，新的一页已经翻开，供你书写自己的人生。”

Richard gave an anxious glance at Ada but said nothing.
理查德焦急地看了艾达一眼，但什么也没说。

‘I have avoided saying one word to either of you or to Esther,’ said Mr. Jarndyce, ‘until now, in order that we might be open as the day, and all on equal terms. I now affectionately advise, I now most earnestly entreat, you two to part as you came here. Leave all else to time, truth, and steadfastness. If you do otherwise, you will do wrong, and you will have made me do wrong in ever bringing you together.’
“直到现在，我都避免对你们或埃丝特说一句话，”贾迪斯先生说，“为了让我们能够像白天一样开放，并且一切都平等。”我现在亲切地劝告，现在恳切地恳求你们二人既然来到这里就分手吧。其他一切都交给时间、真理和坚定。如果你不这样做，你就会做错事，你也会让我在把你们聚集在一起时做错事。

A long silence succeeded.
长久的沉默成功了。

‘Cousin Richard,’ said Ada then, raising her blue eyes tenderly to his face, ‘after what our cousin John has said, I think no choice is left us. Your mind may he quite at ease about me, for you will leave me here under his care and will be sure that I can have nothing to wish for—quite sure if I guide myself by his advice. I—I don’t doubt, cousin Richard,’ said Ada, a little confused, ‘that you are very fond of me, and I—I don’t think you will fall in love with anybody else. But I should like you to consider well about it too, as I should like you to be in all things very happy. You may trust in me, cousin Richard. I am not at all changeable; but I am not unreasonable, and should never blame you. Even cousins may be sorry to part; and in truth I am very, very sorry, Richard, though I know it’s for your welfare. I shall always think of you affectionately, and often talk of you with Esther, and—and perhaps you will sometimes think a little of me, cousin Richard. So now,’ said Ada, going up to him and giving him her trembling hand, ‘we are only cousins again, Richard—for the time perhaps— and I pray for a blessing on my dear cousin, wherever he goes!’
“理查德表弟，”艾达说道，温柔地抬起蓝眼睛看着他的脸，“听了我们的表弟约翰的话，我想我们已经别无选择了。愿你的心对我很放心，因为你会把我留在这里，由他照顾，并确保我不会有任何愿望——如果我按照他的建议指导自己，那就很确定了。我——我毫不怀疑，理查德表弟，”艾达有点困惑地说，“你非常喜欢我，而且我——我认为你不会爱上任何人。但我希望你也能好好考虑一下，因为我希望你在所有事情上都非常快乐。你可以相信我，理查德表弟。我一点也不善变；但我也不是无理取闹，也不应该责怪你。即使是堂兄弟姐妹也可能会因分离而感到遗憾。事实上，我非常非常抱歉，理查德，尽管我知道这是为了你的福祉。我将永远深情地想起你，经常和埃丝特谈论你，而且——也许你有时会想起我，理查德表弟。所以现在，”艾达走到他面前，伸出颤抖的手，“我们又只是表兄弟了，理查德——也许只是暂时——无论我亲爱的表弟走到哪里，我都祈祷他能得到祝福！”

It was strange to me that Richard should not be able to forgive my guardian for entertaining the very same opinion of him which he himself had expressed of himself in much stronger terms to me. But it was certainly the case. I observed with great regret that from this hour he never was as free and open with Mr. Jarndyce as he had been before. He had every reason given him to be so, but he was not; and solely on his side, an estrangement began to arise between them.
让我感到奇怪的是，理查德不能原谅我的监护人对他的看法，而他本人也曾以更强烈的措辞向我表达过自己的看法。但事实确实如此。我非常遗憾地发现，从这一刻起，他对詹迪斯先生再也没有像以前那样自由和开放了。他有充分的理由这样做，但他没有。仅就他而言，他们之间开始产生隔阂。

In the business of preparation and equipment he soon lost himself, and even his grief at parting from Ada, who remained in Hertfordshire while he, Mr. Jarndyce, and I went up to London for a week. He remembered her by fits and starts, even with bursts of tears, and at such times would confide to me the heaviest selfreproaches. But in a few minutes he would recklessly conjure up some undefinable means by which they were both to be made rich and happy for ever, and would become as gay as possible.
在准备和装备的工作中，他很快就失去了自我，甚至失去了与艾达分手时的悲伤，艾达留在赫特福德郡，而他、贾迪斯先生和我去了伦敦一周。他时断时续地想起她，甚至泪流满面，在这种时候，他会向我吐露最沉重的自责。但几分钟之内，他就会鲁莽地想出一些无法定义的方法，让他们俩永远变得富有和幸福，并尽可能变得快乐。

It was a busy time, and I trotted about with him all day long, buying a variety of things of which he stood in need. Of the things he would have bought if he had been left to his own ways I say nothing. He was perfectly confidential with me, and often talked so sensibly and feelingly about his faults and his vigorous resolutions, and dwelt so much upon the encouragement he derived from these conversations that I could never have been tired if I had tried.
那段时间很忙，我整天跟着他跑来跑去，买了各种各样他需要的东西。如果让他按照自己的方式行事，他会买什么东西，我什么也没说。他对我完全保密，经常如此明智而深情地谈论他的缺点和他坚定的决心，并详细阐述了他从这些谈话中获得的鼓励，如果我尝试过，我永远不会感到疲倦。

There used, in that week, to come backward and forward to our lodging to fence with Richard a person who had formerly been a cavalry soldier; he was a fine bluff-looking man, of a frank free bearing, with whom Richard had practised for some months. I heard so much about him, not only from Richard, but from my guardian too, that I was purposely in the room with my work one morning after breakfast when he came.
那个星期，我们经常来来回回地到我们的住处和理查德围堵一个以前是骑兵的人。他是一个看上去很直率的人，举止坦率，自由自在，理查德已经和他练习了几个月了。我不仅从理查德那里听说了很多关于他的事情，而且还从我的监护人那里听说了很多关于他的事情，以至于有一天早上早餐后，当他来的时候，我特意在房间里工作。

‘Good morning, Mr. George,’ said my guardian, who happened to be alone with me. ‘Mr. Carstone will be here directly. Meanwhile, Miss Summerson is very happy to see you, I know. Sit down.’
“早上好，乔治先生，”我的监护人说，他恰好和我单独在一起。 '先生。卡斯通将直接赶到。与此同时，我知道，萨默森小姐很高兴见到你。坐下。'

He sat down, a little disconcerted by my presence, I thought, and without looking at me, drew his heavy sunburnt hand across and across his upper lip.
我想，他坐下来，对我的存在感到有点不安，没有看我，用他那被晒伤的厚重的手抚过他的上唇。

‘You are as punctual as the sun,’ said Mr. Jarndyce.
“你像太阳一样准时，”贾迪斯先生说。

‘Military time, sir,’ he replied. ‘Force of habit. A mere habit in me, sir. I am not at all business-like.’
“军事时间，长官，”他回答道。 ‘习惯的力量。先生，这只是我的习惯。我一点也不务实。

‘Yet you have a large establishment, too, I am told?’ said Mr. Jarndyce.
“然而，有人告诉我，你们也有一个很大的机构吗？”贾迪斯先生说。

‘Not much of a one, sir. I keep a shooting gallery, but not much of a one.’
“不是什么大不了的事，先生。我有一个射击场，但规模不大。

‘And what kind of a shot and what kind of a swordsman do you make of Mr. Carstone?’ said my guardian.
“你认为卡斯通先生是怎样的一击、怎样的剑客？”我的监护人问道。

‘Pretty good, sir,’ he replied, folding his arms upon his broad chest and looking very large. ‘If Mr. Carstone was to give his full mind to it, he would come out very good.’
“很好，先生。”他回答道，双臂交叉放在宽阔的胸前，看起来非常高大。 “如果卡斯通先生全身心投入，他会取得很好的成绩。”

‘But he don’t, I suppose?’ said my guardian.
“但我想他不会吧？”我的监护人说。

‘He did at first, sir, but not afterwards. Not his full mind. Perhaps he has something else upon it—some young lady, perhaps.’ His bright dark eyes glanced at me for the first time.
“他一开始这么做了，先生，但后来就不再这么做了。不是他的全部心思。也许他上面还有别的东西——也许是某个年轻女士。”他明亮的黑眼睛第一次扫了我一眼。

‘He has not me upon his mind, I assure you, Mr. George,’ said I, laughing, ‘though you seem to suspect me.’
“他心里没有我，我向你保证，乔治先生，”我笑着说，“尽管你似乎怀疑我。”

He reddened a little through his brown and made me a trooper’s bow. ‘No offence, I hope, miss. I am one of the roughs.’
他的棕色皮肤变红了一点，给我做了一把士兵的弓。 “我希望无意冒犯，小姐。我是粗暴的人之一。

‘Not at all,’ said I. ‘I take it as a compliment.’
“一点也不，”我说，“我认为这是一种恭维。”

If he had not looked at me before, he looked at me now in three or four quick successive glances. ‘I beg your pardon, sir,’ he said to my guardian with a manly kind of diffidence, ‘but you did me the honour to mention the young lady’s name—‘
如果他以前没有看过我，现在他会连续快速地看了我三四眼。 “请您原谅，先生，”他带着一种男子气概的自信对我的监护人说道，“但是您让我荣幸地提到了这位年轻女士的名字——”

‘Miss Summerson.’
“萨默森小姐。”

‘Miss Summerson,’ he repeated, and looked at me again.
“萨默森小姐，”他重复道，然后再次看着我。

‘Do you know the name?’ I asked.
“你知道名字吗？”我问。

‘No, miss. To my knowledge I never heard it. I thought I had seen you somewhere.’
‘不，小姐。据我所知，我从未听说过。我以为我在什么地方见过你。

‘I think not,’ I returned, raising my head from my work to look at him; and there was something so genuine in his speech and manner that I was glad of the opportunity. ‘I remember faces very well.’
“我想不是，”我回答道，从工作中抬起头来看着他。他的言语和态度都非常真诚，我很高兴有这个机会。 “我对面孔记得很清楚。”

‘So do I, miss!’ he returned, meeting my look with the fullness of his dark eyes and broad forehead. ‘Humph! What set me off, now, upon that!’
“我也是，小姐！”他回答道，用他饱满的黑眼睛和宽阔的额头迎着我的目光。 '哼！是什么让我如此激动，现在，就这个！

His once more reddening through his brown and being disconcerted by his efforts to remember the association brought my guardian to his relief.
他的棕色脸色再次变得通红，并因努力记住这一联想而感到不安，这让我的监护人松了口气。

‘Have you many pupils, Mr. George?’
“乔治先生，你有很多学生吗？”

‘They vary in their number, sir. Mostly they’re but a small lot to live by.’
“它们的数量各不相同，长官。大多数情况下，它们只是一小部分赖以生存的土地。

‘And what classes of chance people come to practise at your gallery?’
“人们来你的画廊练习的机会是什么？”

‘All sorts, sir. Natives and foreigners. From gentlemen to ‘prentices. I have had Frenchwomen come, before now, and show themselves dabs at pistol-shooting. Mad people out of number, of course, but THEY go everywhere where the doors stand open.’
“各种各样，先生。本地人和外国人。从绅士到“学徒”。在此之前，我曾邀请法国女性来展示自己手枪射击的技巧。当然，疯狂的人数量不计其数，但只要有门，他们就会去任何地方。

‘People don’t come with grudges and schemes of finishing their practice with live targets, I hope?’ said my guardian, smiling.
“我希望人们不会怀着怨恨和计划来完成他们的练习，我希望如此？”我的监护人微笑着说道。

‘Not much of that, sir, though that HAS happened. Mostly they come for skill—or idleness. Six of one, and half-a-dozen of the other. I beg your pardon,’ said Mr. George, sitting stiffly upright and squaring an elbow on each knee, ‘but I believe you’re a Chancery suitor, if I have heard correct?’
“虽然那件事已经发生了，但先生，那件事并不多。”他们大多是为了技能而来——或者是为了闲散。一个是六个，另一个是六个。请您原谅，”乔治先生说，他笔直地坐着，双肘撑在膝盖上，“但我相信您是大法官法庭的追求者，如果我没听错的话？

‘I am sorry to say I am.’
“我很遗憾地说我是。”

‘I have had one of YOUR compatriots in my time, sir.’
“我曾经有过一位你的同胞，先生。”

‘A Chancery suitor?’ returned my guardian. ‘How was that?’
“大法官法庭的求婚者？”我的监护人回答道。 '怎么样？'

‘Why, the man was so badgered and worried and tortured by being knocked about from post to pillar, and from pillar to post,’ said Mr. George, ‘that he got out of sorts. I don’t believe he had any idea of taking aim at anybody, but he was in that condition of resentment and violence that he would come and pay for fifty shots and fire away till he was red hot. One day I said to him when there was nobody by and he had been talking to me angrily about his wrongs, ‘If this practice is a safety-valve, comrade, well and good; but I don’t altogether like your being so bent upon it in your present state of mind; I’d rather you took to something else.’ I was on my guard for a blow, he was that passionate; but he received it in very good part and left off directly. We shook hands and struck up a sort of friendship.’
“哎呀，这个人被从一个柱子撞到另一个柱子，从一个柱子撞到另一个柱子，如此困扰、担心和折磨，”乔治先生说，“他变得不舒服了。”我不相信他有任何瞄准任何人的想法，但他处于一种怨恨和暴力的状态，他会来付五十枪的费用，然后开枪直到他变得红热。有一天，我对他说，当时旁边没有人，而他一直在愤怒地跟我谈论他的错误，“如果这种做法是一个安全阀，同志，那就太好了；”但我完全不喜欢你现在的心态如此执着于这件事；我宁愿你去做别的事。”我很警惕，以防受到打击，他是如此热情；但他收到了很好的部分，然后就直接离开了。我们握手并建立了某种友谊。

‘What was that man?’ asked my guardian in a new tone of interest.
“那个人是什么人？”我的监护人用一种新的感兴趣的语气问道。

‘Why, he began by being a small Shropshire farmer before they made a baited bull of him,’ said Mr. George.
“哎呀，他一开始只是什罗普郡的一个小农民，后来他们把他变成了一头诱饵公牛，”乔治先生说。

‘Was his name Gridley?’
“他叫格里德利吗？”

‘It was, sir.’
“是的，先生。”

Mr. George directed another succession of quick bright glances at me as my guardian and I exchanged a word or two of surprise at the coincidence, and I therefore explained to him how we knew the name. He made me another of his soldierly bows in acknowledgment of what he called my condescension.
乔治先生又一连串地快速明亮地看了我一眼，作为我的监护人，我对这个巧合交换了一两句话，表示惊讶，因此我向他解释了我们是如何知道这个名字的。他又向我鞠了一躬，以表示我的屈尊俯就。

‘I don’t know,’ he said as he looked at me, ‘what it is that sets me off again—but—bosh! What’s my head running against!’ He passed one of his heavy hands over his crisp dark hair as if to sweep the broken thoughts out of his mind and sat a little forward, with one arm akimbo and the other resting on his leg, looking in a brown study at the ground.
“我不知道，”他看着我说道，“是什么让我再次兴奋起来——但是——波什！”我的头在撞什么！”他用一只沉重的手抚摸着他挺括的黑发，仿佛要把脑海中那些支离破碎的思绪一扫而空，然后坐得稍微靠前，一只手叉腰，另一只手搭在腿上，向里看去。地面上的棕色研究。

‘I am sorry to learn that the same state of mind has got this Gridley into new troubles and that he is in hiding,’ said my guardian.
我的监护人说：“我很遗憾地得知，同样的心态让这个格里德利陷入了新的麻烦，而且他现在躲藏起来了。”

‘So I am told, sir,’ returned Mr. George, still musing and looking on the ground. ‘So I am told.’
“有人告诉我的，先生，”乔治先生回答道，他仍然沉思着，看着地面。 “别人是这么告诉我的。”

‘You don’t know where?’
“你不知道在哪里？”

‘No, sir,’ returned the trooper, lifting up his eyes and coming out of his reverie. ‘I can’t say anything about him. He will be worn out soon, I expect. You may file a strong man’s heart away for a good many years, but it will tell all of a sudden at last.’
“不，长官，”士兵回答道，抬起眼睛，从沉思中回过神来。 ‘关于他我无话可说。我预计他很快就会疲惫不堪。你可能会把一颗坚强的人的心锉掉很多年，但最后它会突然告诉你答案。

Richard’s entrance stopped the conversation. Mr. George rose, made me another of his soldierly bows, wished my guardian a good day, and strode heavily out of the room.
理查德的到来打断了谈话。乔治先生站起身来，再次向我鞠了一躬，祝我的监护人有美好的一天，然后大步走出房间。

This was the morning of the day appointed for Richard’s departure. We had no more purchases to make now; I had completed all his packing early in the afternoon; and our time was disengaged until night, when he was to go to Liverpool for Holyhead. Jarndyce and Jarndyce being again expected to come on that day, Richard proposed to me that we should go down to the court and hear what passed. As it was his last day, and he was eager to go, and I had never been there, I gave my consent and we walked down to Westminster, where the court was then sitting. We beguiled the way with arrangements concerning the letters that Richard was to write to me and the letters that I was to write to him and with a great many hopeful projects. My guardian knew where we were going and therefore was not with us.
这是理查德预定出发的那天早上。我们现在没有再买东西了；下午早些时候我就帮他收拾好了所有的行李。我们的时间一直闲置到晚上，那时他要去利物浦去霍利黑德。贾迪斯和贾迪斯那天再次预计会来，理查德向我提议我们应该去法庭听听发生了什么。因为这是他的最后一天，他很想去，而我从来没有去过那里，所以我同意了，我们步行到威斯敏斯特，当时法庭就在那里。我们用有关理查德要写给我的信和我要写给他的信的安排以及许多充满希望的计划来迷惑我们。我的监护人知道我们要去哪里，因此没有和我们在一起。

When we came to the court, there was the Lord Chancellor—the same whom I had seen in his private room in Lincoln’s Inn—sitting in great state and gravity on the bench, with the mace and seals on a red table below him and an immense flat nosegay, like a little garden, which scented the whole court. Below the table, again, was a long row of solicitors, with bundles of papers on the matting at their feet; and then there were the gentlemen of the bar in wigs and gowns—some awake and some asleep, and one talking, and nobody paying much attention to what he said. The Lord Chancellor leaned back in his very easy chair with his elbow on the cushioned arm and his forehead resting on his hand; some of those who were present dozed; some read the newspapers; some walked about or whispered in groups: all seemed perfectly at their ease, by no means in a hurry, very unconcerned, and extremely comfortable.
当我们来到法庭时，大法官——就是我在林肯律师学院的私人房间里见过的那个人——神情严肃地坐在长凳上，狼牙棒和印章放在他下面的一张红色桌子上，还有一张桌子。巨大而平坦的花束，像一座小花园，让整个庭院充满了香气。桌子下面又是一长排律师，脚边的垫子上放着一捆捆文件。然后是酒吧里戴着假发、穿着长袍的绅士们——有的醒着，有的睡着了，还有一个在说话，但没有人太注意他所说的话。大法官靠在他那张非常安乐的椅子上，肘部放在有软垫的扶手上，额头靠在手上。在场的一些人打瞌睡；有些人看报纸；有的人三五成群地走来走去，窃窃私语，一切都显得非常自在，一点也不匆忙，很不关心，非常舒服。

To see everything going on so smoothly and to think of the roughness of the suitors’ lives and deaths; to see all that full dress and ceremony and to think of the waste, and want, and beggared misery it represented; to consider that while the sickness of hope deferred was raging in so many hearts this polite show went calmly on from day to day, and year to year, in such good order and composure; to behold the Lord Chancellor and the whole array of practitioners under him looking at one another and at the spectators as if nobody had ever heard that all over England the name in which they were assembled was a bitter jest, was held in universal horror, contempt, and indignation, was known for something so flagrant and bad that little short of a miracle could bring any good out of it to any one—this was so curious and selfcontradictory to me, who had no experience of it, that it was at first incredible, and I could not comprehend it. I sat where Richard put me, and tried to listen, and looked about me; but there seemed to be no reality in the whole scene except poor little Miss Flite, the madwoman, standing on a bench and nodding at it.
看着一切如此顺利，想到追求者的生死坎坷；看到所有盛装和仪式，想到它所代表的浪费、匮乏和乞讨的痛苦；想想看，虽然希望被推迟的病态在许多人心中肆虐，但这场礼貌的表演却日复一日、年复一年地平静地进行着，秩序井然、镇定自若；看到大法官和他手下的一大批实践者互相看着对方，看着观众，仿佛没有人听说过，在整个英格兰，他们聚集在一起的名字是一个苦涩的笑话，受到普遍的恐惧和蔑视和愤慨，因如此明目张胆和恶劣而闻名，以至于几乎没有奇迹可以给任何人带来任何好处——这对我来说是如此好奇和自相矛盾，因为我没有经历过它，所以一开始它是难以置信，我无法理解。我坐在理查德安排我的地方，努力倾听，环顾四周。但整个场景似乎没有任何真实性，除了可怜的小弗利特小姐，那个疯女人，站在长凳上对它点点头。

Miss Flite soon espied us and came to where we sat. She gave me a gracious welcome to her domain and indicated, with much gratification and pride, its principal attractions. Mr. Kenge also came to speak to us and did the honours of the place in much the same way, with the bland modesty of a proprietor. It was not a very good day for a visit, he said; he would have preferred the first day of term; but it was imposing, it was imposing.
弗利特小姐很快就发现了我们，来到我们坐的地方。她热情地欢迎我来到她的领地，并非常满意和自豪地指出了它的主要景点。肯格先生也来与我们交谈，并以几乎相同的方式为这个地方带来了荣誉，带着业主的温和谦虚。他说，今天不太适合出访。他更喜欢开学第一天；但这是令人印象深刻的，它是令人印象深刻的。

When we had been there half an hour or so, the case in progress—if I may use a phrase so ridiculous in such a connexion—seemed to die out of its own vapidity, without coming, or being by anybody expected to come, to any resuIt. The Lord Chancellor then threw down a bundle of papers from his desk to the gentlemen below him, and somebody said, ‘Jarndyce and Jarndyce.’ Upon this there was a buzz, and a laugh, and a general withdrawal of the bystanders, and a bringing in of great heaps, and piles, and bags and bags full of papers.
当我们在那里呆了半个小时左右时，正在进行的案件——如果我可以在这种联系中使用一个如此荒谬的短语——似乎因其自身的乏味而消亡，没有到来，也没有任何人预计会来，任何结果。然后，大法官从他的办公桌上把一叠文件扔给下面的先生们，有人说：“加迪斯和加迪斯。”这句话引起了一阵嗡嗡声和笑声，旁观者普遍退却了，然后带来一大堆、一大堆、一袋又一袋装满的文件。

I think it came on ‘for further directions’—about some bill of costs, to the best of my understanding, which was confused enough. But I counted twenty-three gentlemen in wigs who said they were ‘in it,’ and none of them appeared to understand it much better than I. They chatted about it with the Lord Chancellor, and contradicted and explained among themselves, and some of them said it was this way, and some of them said it was that way, and some of them jocosely proposed to read huge volumes of affidavits, and there was more buzzing and laughing, and everybody concerned was in a state of idle entertainment, and nothing could be made of it by anybody. After an hour or so of this, and a good many speeches being begun and cut short, it was ‘referred back for the present,’ as Mr. Kenge said, and the papers were bundled up again before the clerks had finished bringing them in.
我认为这是“为了进一步的指示”——据我所知，关于一些成本清单，这已经够混乱的了。但我数了数，有二十三位戴假发的绅士说他们“参与其中”，但他们似乎没有一个比我更了解这件事。他们与大法官谈论这件事，互相矛盾和解释，其中一些他们说是这样，有的说是这样，有的还开玩笑地提出要读大卷的宣誓书，议论纷纷，笑声多了，大家都处于闲暇娱乐的状态，任何人都无法利用它。经过一个小时左右的时间，许多演讲开始后又被打断，正如肯格先生所说，会议被“暂时退回”，文件在办事员把它们送进来之前又被重新捆扎起来。 。

I glanced at Richard on the termination of these hopeless proceedings and was shocked to see the worn look of his handsome young face. ‘It can’t last for ever, Dame Durden. Better luck next time!’ was all he said.
在这些绝望的诉讼结束时，我看了一眼理查德，惊讶地看到他年轻英俊的脸上憔悴的表情。 “这不可能永远持续下去，德登夫人。下次祝你好运！”他只说了这么一句话。

I had seen Mr. Guppy bringing in papers and arranging them for Mr. Kenge; and he had seen me and made me a forlorn bow, which rendered me desirous to get out of the court. Richard had given me his arm and was taking me away when Mr. Guppy came up.
我看到古皮先生把文件带来并为肯吉先生整理。他看到了我，向我鞠了一躬，这让我很想离开法庭。当古比先生走过来时，理查德已经把他的手臂给了我，正要带我离开。

‘I beg your pardon, Mr. Carstone,’ said he in a whisper, ‘and Miss Summerson’s also, but there’s a lady here, a friend of mine, who knows her and wishes to have the pleasure of shaking hands.’ As he spoke, I saw before me, as if she had started into bodily shape from my remembrance, Mrs. Rachael of my godmother’s house.
“请原谅，卡斯通先生，”他低声说道，“还有萨默森小姐，但是这里有一位女士，我的一个朋友，她认识她，希望有幸与她握手。”说话时，我看到我的教母家的雷切尔夫人，她的身体仿佛在我的记忆中开始成形。

‘How do you do, Esther?’ said she. ‘Do you recollect me?’
“你好吗，埃丝特？”她说。 “你还记得我吗？”

I gave her my hand and told her yes and that she was very little altered.
我向她伸出了手，告诉她是的，而且她几乎没有改变。

‘I wonder you remember those times, Esther,’ she returned with her old asperity. ‘They are changed now. Well! I am glad to see you, and glad you are not too proud to know me.’ But indeed she seemed disappointed that I was not.
“我不知道你还记得那些时候吗，艾丝特，”她带着一如既往的严厉回答道。 ‘他们现在变了。出色地！我很高兴见到你，也很高兴你并没有因为认识我而感到骄傲。”但事实上，她似乎对我没有感到失望。

‘Proud, Mrs. Rachael!’ I remonstrated.
“骄傲，雷切尔夫人！”我抗议道。

‘I am married, Esther,’ she returned, coldly correcting me, ‘and am Mrs. Chadband. Well! I wish you good day, and I hope you’ll do well.’
“我已经结婚了，埃丝特，”她冷冷地纠正我，“我是查德班德夫人。”出色地！祝你有美好的一天，希望你一切顺利。

Mr. Guppy, who had been attentive to this short dialogue, heaved a sigh in my ear and elbowed his own and Mrs. Rachael’s way through the confused little crowd of people coming in and going out, which we were in the midst of and which the change in the business had brought together. Richard and I were making our way through it, and I was yet in the first chill of the late unexpected recognition when I saw, coming towards us, but not seeing us, no less a person than Mr. George. He made nothing of the people about him as he tramped on, staring over their heads into the body of the court.
顾比先生一直在注意这段简短的对话，他在我耳边叹了口气，然后用肘部挤开自己和雷切尔夫人，穿过进进出出的一小群混乱的人群，我们就在这群人中间。业务的变化已经汇集在一起​​。理查德和我正在穿过它，当我看到他朝我们走来，但没有看到我们时，我还处于最后的意外认出的第一场寒意中，这个人不亚于乔治先生。当他继续前行时，他对周围的人毫不在意，目光越过他们的头顶，凝视着法庭的主体。

‘George!’ said Richard as I called his attention to him.
“乔治！”当我把理查德的注意力吸引到他身上时，他说道。

‘You are well met, sir,’ he returned. ‘And you, miss. Could you point a person out for me, I want? I don’t understand these places.’
“很高兴见到您，先生。”他回答道。 ‘还有你，小姐。我想要你能帮我指一个人吗？我不明白这些地方。

Turning as he spoke and making an easy way for us, he stopped when we were out of the press in a corner behind a great red curtain.
他一边说话一边转身给我们让路，当我们走出新闻界，在红色大窗帘后面的一个角落里时，他停了下来。

‘There’s a little cracked old woman,’ he began, ‘that—‘
“有一个有点精神崩溃的老妇人，”他开始说道，“那个——”

I put up my finger, for Miss Flite was close by me, having kept beside me all the time and having called the attention of several of her legal acquaintance to me (as I had overheard to my confusion) by whispering in their ears, ‘Hush! Fitz Jarndyce on my left!’
我竖起手指，因为弗利特小姐就在我身边，她一直陪在我身边，并在她的几个法律熟人耳边低语，引起了我的注意（我无意中听到了这一点，这让我很困惑），“嘘！菲茨·贾迪斯在我左边！”

‘Hem!’ said Mr. George. ‘You remember, miss, that we passed some conversation on a certain man this morning? Gridley,’ in a low whisper behind his hand.
“哼！”乔治先生说。 “小姐，您还记得今天早上我们谈过一个关于某个人的事吗？”格里德利，”他在手后低声说道。

‘Yes,’ said I.
“是的，”我说。

‘He is hiding at my place. I couldn’t mention it. Hadn’t his authority. He is on his last march, miss, and has a whim to see her. He says they can feel for one another, and she has been almost as good as a friend to him here. I came down to look for her, for when I sat by Gridley this afternoon, I seemed to hear the roll of the muffled drums.’
‘他躲在我家。我无法提及。没有他的权力。小姐，他正在最后一次行军，突发奇想想见见她。他说他们可以互相感觉，而她在这里几乎就像他的朋友一样。我下来找她，因为今天下午我坐在格里德利旁边时，我似乎听到了低沉的鼓声。

‘Shall I tell her?’ said I.
“我要告诉她吗？”我说。

‘Would you be so good?’ he returned with a glance of something like apprehension at Miss Flite. ‘It’s a providence I met you, miss; I doubt if I should have known how to get on with that lady.’ And he put one hand in his breast and stood upright in a martial attitude as I informed little Miss Flite, in her ear, of the purport of his kind errand.
“你能这么乖吗？”他回了话，脸上带着某种忧虑的眼神看着弗利特小姐。 “我遇见你真是天意，小姐；我怀疑我是否应该知道如何与那位女士相处。”当我在小弗利特小姐耳边告诉她他的善意差事的目的时，他把一只手放在胸前，以一种军事态度笔直地站着。

‘My angry friend from Shropshire! Almost as celebrated as myself!’ she exclaimed. ‘Now really! My dear, I will wait upon him with the greatest pleasure.’
“我来自什罗普郡的愤怒的朋友！几乎和我一样出名！”她惊呼道。 ‘现在真的！亲爱的，我会非常高兴地侍候他。

‘He is living concealed at Mr. George’s,’ said I. ‘Hush! This is Mr. George.’
“他隐秘地住在乔治先生家里，”我说。“嘘！嘘！”这是乔治先生。

‘In—deed!’ returned Miss Flite. ‘Very proud to have the honour! A military man, my dear. You know, a perfect general!’ she whispered to me.
“确实如此！”弗利特小姐回答道。 ‘非常荣幸能获得此殊荣！亲爱的，一个军人。你知道，一位完美的将军！”她低声对我说。

Poor Miss Flite deemed it necessary to be so courtly and polite, as a mark of her respect for the army, and to curtsy so very often that it was no easy matter to get her out of the court. When this was at last done, and addressing Mr. George as ‘General,’ she gave him her arm, to the great entertainment of some idlers who were looking on, he was so discomposed and begged me so respectfully ‘not to desert him’ that I could not make up my mind to do it, especially as Miss Flite was always tractable with me and as she too said, ‘Fitz Jarndyce, my dear, you will accompany us, of course.’ As Richard seemed quite willing, and even anxious, that we should see them safely to their destination, we agreed to do so. And as Mr. George informed us that Gridley’s mind had run on Mr. Jarndyce all the afternoon after hearing of their interview in the morning, I wrote a hasty note in pencil to my guardian to say where we were gone and why. Mr. George sealed it at a coffee-house, that it might lead to no discovery, and we sent it off by a ticketporter.
可怜的弗利特小姐认为有必要如此彬彬有礼和礼貌，以表达她对军队的尊重，并且经常行屈膝礼，以至于要让她离开法庭并不容易。当这一切终于完成后，她称呼乔治先生为“将军”，她把手臂伸给了他，这让一些在场的闲人感到很开心，他非常不安，并恭敬地恳求我“不要抛弃他”我无法下定决心这样做，尤其是弗利特小姐总是对我很温顺，而且她也说：“菲茨·贾迪斯，亲爱的，当然，你会陪我们一起去。”理查德似乎很愿意，并且尽管担心我们应该送他们安全到达目的地，我们还是同意这样做。乔治先生告诉我们，格里德利在早上听到他们的采访后整个下午都在想着贾迪斯先生，我用铅笔匆忙地给我的监护人写了一张纸条，说明我们去了哪里以及为什么。乔治先生把它封在一家咖啡馆里，以免被人发现，然后我们就由票务搬运工把它寄走了。

We then took a hackney-coach and drove away to the neighbourhood of Leicester Square. We walked through some narrow courts, for which Mr. George apologized, and soon came to the shooting gallery, the door of which was closed. As he pulled a bell-handle which hung by a chain to the door-post, a very respectable old gentleman with grey hair, wearing spectacles, and dressed in a black spencer and gaiters and a broad-brimmed hat, and carrying a large gold-beaded cane, addressed him.
然后我们乘坐一辆出租客车前往莱斯特广场附近。我们穿过一些狭窄的球场，乔治先生对此表示歉意，很快就来到了射击场，射击场的门是关着的。当他拉动用链子挂在门柱上的钟把手时，一位非常受人尊敬的老绅士，头发花白，戴着眼镜，穿着黑色斯宾塞和绑腿，戴着宽边帽，手里拿着一个大金币。 ——串珠手杖，对他说道。

‘I ask your pardon, my good friend,’ said he, ‘but is this George’s Shooting Gallery?’
“请原谅，我的好朋友，”他说，“这是乔治射击场吗？”

‘It is, sir,’ returned Mr. George, glancing up at the great letters in which that inscription was painted on the whitewashed wall.
“是的，先生，”乔治先生回答道，他抬头看了一眼粉刷过的墙上刻着的大字。

‘Oh! To be sure!’ said the old gentleman, following his eyes. ‘Thank you. Have you rung the bell?’
'哦！当然！”老先生顺着他的目光说道。 '谢谢。你按过门铃吗？

‘My name is George, sir, and I have rung the bell.’
“我叫乔治，先生，我已经按响了门铃。”

‘Oh, indeed?’ said the old gentleman. ‘Your name is George? Then I am here as soon as you, you see. You came for me, no doubt?’
“哦，确实如此？”老先生说道。 ‘你叫乔治？然后你一看到我就来了。毫无疑问，你是来找我的？

‘No, sir. You have the advantage of me.’
'不，先生。你比我有优势。

‘Oh, indeed?’ said the old gentleman. ‘Then it was your young man who came for me. I am a physician and was requested—five minutes ago—to come and visit a sick man at George’s Shooting Gallery.’
“哦，确实如此？”老先生说道。 ‘然后就是你的年轻人来找我了。我是一名医生，五分钟前有人要求我去乔治射击馆看望一名病人。

‘The muffled drums,’ said Mr. George, turning to Richard and me and gravely shaking his head. ‘It’s quite correct, sir. Will you please to walk in.’
“低沉的鼓声，”乔治先生转向理查德和我，严肃地摇着头说道。 ‘这是非常正确的，先生。请您走进去好吗？

The door being at that moment opened by a very singular-looking little man in a green-baize cap and apron, whose face and hands and dress were blackened all over, we passed along a dreary passage into a large building with bare brick walls where there were targets, and guns, and swords, and other things of that kind. When we had all arrived here, the physician stopped, and taking off his hat, appeared to vanish by magic and to leave another and quite a different man in his place.
就在这时，门被一个长相奇特的小个子男人打开了，他戴着绿色毛呢帽，穿着围裙，脸、手和衣服都被熏黑了。我们穿过一条沉闷的通道，走进一座砖墙裸露的大建筑，有靶子、枪、剑和其他类似的东西。当我们都到达这里时，医生停了下来，摘下帽子，似乎神奇地消失了，留下了另一个完全不同的人代替他。

‘Now lookee here, George,’ said the man, turning quickly round upon him and tapping him on the breast with a large forefinger. ‘You know me, and I know you. You’re a man of the world, and I’m a man of the world. My name’s Bucket, as you are aware, and I have got a peace-warrant against Gridley. You have kept him out of the way a long time, and you have been artful in it, and it does you credit.’
“现在看这里，乔治，”那人说着，迅速转过身来，用一根大食指敲击他的胸口。 ‘你认识我，我也认识你。你是一个世界的人，我也是一个世界的人。如你所知，我叫巴克特，我收到了针对格里德利的和平令。你已经让他远离了很长一段时间，而且你做得很巧妙，这值得你赞扬。

Mr. George, looking hard at him, bit his lip and shook his head.
乔治先生认真地看着他，咬着嘴唇摇了摇头。

‘Now, George,’ said the other, keeping close to him, ‘you’re a sensible man and a well-conducted man; that’s what YOU are, beyond a doubt. And mind you, I don’t talk to you as a common character, because you have served your country and you know that when duty calls we must obey. Consequently you’re very far from wanting to give trouble. If I required assistance, you’d assist me; that’s what YOU’D do. Phil Squod, don’t you go a-sidling round the gallery like that’—the dirty little man was shuffling about with his shoulder against the wall, and his eyes on the intruder, in a manner that looked threatening—‘because I know you and won’t have it.’
“现在，乔治，”另一个人靠近他说道，“你是一个明智的人，也是一个品行良好的人；毫无疑问，这就是你。请注意，我不会把你当作一个普通人来说话，因为你为你的国家服务过，你知道当责任召唤时我们必须服从。因此，你根本就不想惹麻烦。如果我需要帮助，你会帮助我；这就是你要做的。菲尔·斯阔德，你不要像那样在画廊里侧行吗？”——那个肮脏的小个子男人肩膀靠在墙上，拖着脚走来走去，他的眼睛盯着入侵者，眼神里充满了威胁——“因为我知道你不会拥有它。

‘Phil!’ said Mr. George.
“菲尔！”乔治先生说。

‘Yes, guv’ner.’
“是的，州长。”

‘Be quiet.’
'安静。'

The little man, with a low growl, stood still.
小个子低吼一声，站在原地不动。

‘Ladies and gentlemen,’ said Mr. Bucket, ‘you’ll excuse anything that may appear to be disagreeable in this, for my name’s Inspector Bucket of the Detective, and I have a duty to perform. George, I know where my man is because I was on the roof last night and saw him through the skylight, and you along with him. He is in there, you know,’ pointing; ‘that’s where HE is—on a sofy. Now I must see my man, and I must tell my man to consider himself in custody; but you know me, and you know I don’t want to take any uncomfortable measures. You give me your word, as from one man to another (and an old soldier, mind you, likewise), that it’s honourable between us two, and I’ll accommodate you to the utmost of my power.’
“女士们，先生们，”巴克特先生说，“如果有任何不愉快的地方，请原谅，因为我是侦探督察巴克特，我有责任履行。”乔治，我知道我的人在哪里，因为昨晚我在屋顶上，透过天窗看到了他，还有你和他。他就在那里，你知道，”他指着； “这就是他所在的地方——坐在沙发上。”现在我必须见我的人，我必须告诉我的人考虑自己被拘留；但你了解我，你知道我不想采取任何不舒服的措施。你向我保证，就像从一个人到另一个人一样（还有一位老士兵，请注意，同样），我们两个之间是光荣的，我将尽我最大的能力容纳你。

‘I give it,’ was the reply. ‘“But it wasn’t handsome in you, Mr. Bucket.’
“我给了，”他回答道。 “但你并不英俊，巴克特先生。”

‘Gammon, George! Not handsome?’ said Mr. Bucket, tapping him on his broad breast again and shaking hands with him. ‘I don’t say it wasn’t handsome in you to keep my man so close, do I? Be equally good-tempered to me, old boy! Old William Tell, Old Shaw, the Life Guardsman! Why, he’s a model of the whole British army in himself, ladies and gentlemen. I’d give a fifty-pun’ note to be such a figure of a man!’
“金门，乔治！不帅吗？”巴克特先生说，再次拍拍他宽阔的胸膛，并与他握手。 “我并不是说你和我的男人如此亲近，这对你来说是不英俊的，不是吗？”老家伙，对我也同样客气一点吧！老威廉泰尔，老肖，救生员！嘿，女士们先生们，他本人就是整个英国军队的典范。我愿意付出五十个双关语才能成为这样一个男人！

The affair being brought to this head, Mr. George, after a little consideration, proposed to go in first to his comrade (as he called him), taking Miss Flite with him. Mr. Bucket agreeing, they went away to the further end of the gallery, leaving us sitting and standing by a table covered with guns. Mr. Bucket took this opportunity of entering into a little light conversation, asking me if I were afraid of fire-arms, as most young ladies were; asking Richard if he were a good shot; asking Phil Squod which he considered the best of those rifles and what it might be worth first-hand, telling him in return that it was a pity he ever gave way to his temper, for he was naturally so amiable that he might have been a young woman, and making himself generally agreeable.
事已至此，乔治先生考虑了一下，提议先带弗利特小姐去见他的同志（他这样称呼他）。巴克特先生同意了，他们走到画廊的另一端，留下我们在摆满枪的桌子旁坐着或站着。巴克特先生借此机会进行了一次轻松的谈话，问我是否像大多数年轻女士一样害怕枪支；问理查德是否是个好枪手；询问菲尔·斯夸德，他认为这些步枪中哪一款最好，以及它的第一手价值，并告诉他，遗憾的是他曾经发脾气，因为他生性如此和蔼可亲，以至于他可能会成为一名年轻女子，并且表现得总体上和蔼可亲。

After a time he followed us to the further end of the gallery, and Richard and I were going quietly away when Mr. George came after us. He said that if we had no objection to see his comrade, he would take a visit from us very kindly. The words had hardly passed his lips when the bell was rung and my guardian appeared, ‘on the chance,’ he slightly observed, ‘of being able to do any little thing for a poor fellow involved in the same misfortune as himself.’ We all four went back together and went into the place where Gridley was.
过了一会儿，他跟着我们到了画廊的尽头，当乔治先生追上我们时，理查德和我正悄悄地走开。他说如果我们不反对见见他的同志，他会非常热情地接待我们。话音刚落，铃声就响了，我的监护人出现了，“有机会，”他淡淡地说道，“能够为一个和他遭遇同样不幸的可怜人做点小事。”我们四个人一起回到格里德利所在的地方。

It was a bare room, partitioned off from the gallery with unpainted wood. As the screening was not more than eight or ten feet high and only enclosed the sides, not the top, the rafters of the high gallery roof were overhead, and the skylight through which Mr. Bucket had looked down. The sun was low—near setting—and its light came redly in above, without descending to the ground. Upon a plain canvas-covered sofa lay the man from Shropshire, dressed much as we had seen him last, but so changed that at first I recognized no likeness in his colourless face to what I recollected.
这是一间空荡荡的房间，用未上漆的木头与画廊隔开。由于屏风不超过八英尺或十英尺高，而且只围住了侧面，而不是顶部，所以画廊屋顶高高的椽子就在头顶上，而巴克特先生则透过天窗往下看。太阳很低——快要落山了——它的光芒从上方射入红色，但没有落到地面上。一张朴素的帆布沙发上躺着那个来自什罗普郡的男人，他的穿着与我们上次见到他时的样子很相似，但变化太大，以至于起初我认不出他那张毫无血色的脸与我记忆中的样子有什么相似之处。

He had been still writing in his hiding-place, and still dwelling on his grievances, hour after hour. A table and some shelves were covered with manuscript papers and with worn pens and a medley of such tokens. Touchingly and awfully drawn together, he and the little mad woman were side by side and, as it were, alone. She sat on a chair holding his hand, and none of us went close to them.
他仍然在藏身之处写作，仍然一小时又一小时地沉浸在他的委屈之中。一张桌子和一些架子上堆满了手稿纸、破旧的钢笔和各种类似的代币。他和那个小疯女人肩并肩，而且可以说是孤独一人，令人感动又可怕地被吸引在一起。她坐在椅子上，握着他的手，我们谁也没有靠近他们。

His voice had faded, with the old expression of his face, with his strength, with his anger, with his resistance to the wrongs that had at last subdued him. The faintest shadow of an object full of form and colour is such a picture of it as he was of the man from Shropshire whom we had spoken with before.
他的声音已经消失，他脸上的表情、他的力量、他的愤怒、他对最终征服他的错误的抵抗都消失了。一个充满形状和色彩的物体的最微弱的影子就是这样一幅图画，就像我们之前交谈过的那个来自什罗普郡的人一样。

He inclined his head to Richard and me and spoke to my guardian.
他向理查德和我倾斜了头，并对我的监护人说话。

‘Mr. Jarndyce, it is very kind of you to come to see me. I am not long to be seen, I think. I am very glad to take your hand, sir. You are a good man, superior to injustice, and God knows I honour you.’
'先生。贾迪斯，你来看我真是太好了。我想，我的出现时间不长了。先生，我很高兴握住您的手。你是一个好人，优于不公正，上帝知道我尊重你。

They shook hands earnestly, and my guardian said some words of comfort to him.
他们认真地握手，我的监护人对他说了一些安慰的话。

‘It may seem strange to you, sir,’ returned Gridley; ‘I should not have liked to see you if this had been the flrst time of our meeting. But you know I made a fight for it, you know I stood up with my single hand against them all, you know I told them the truth to the last, and told them what they were, and what they had done to me; so I don’t mind your seeing me, this wreck.’
“您可能觉得这很奇怪，先生，”格里德利回答道。 “如果这是我们第一次见面，我就不喜欢见到你。但你知道我为此进行了斗争，你知道我用我的一只手站起来反对他们所有人，你知道我直到最后都告诉了他们真相，告诉他们他们是什么，以及他们对我做了什么;所以我不介意你看到我这个残骸。”

‘You have been courageous with them many and many a time,’ returned my guardian.
我的监护人回答说：“你多次对他们表现得很勇敢。”

‘Sir, I have been,’ with a faint smile. ‘I told you what would come of it when I ceased to be so, and see here! Look at us—look at us!’ He drew the hand Miss Flite held through her arm and brought her something nearer to him.
“先生，我去过。”淡淡一笑。 ‘我告诉过你当我不再这样时会发生什么，看这里！看看我们——看看我们！”他拉过弗利特小姐挽着手臂的手，把一个东西拉近了一点。

‘This ends it. Of all my old associations, of all my old pursuits and hopes, of all the living and the dead world, this one poor soul alone comes natural to me, and I am fit for. There is a tie of many suffering years between us two, and it is the only tie I ever had on earth that Chancery has not broken.’
‘这就结束了。在我所有旧的交往中，在我所有旧的追求和希望中，在所有生者和死者的世界中，只有这个可怜的灵魂对我来说是自然的，我适合。我们两个之间有着多年痛苦的纽带，这是我在地球上唯一没有被大法官打破的纽带。

‘Accept my blessing, Gridley,’ said Miss Flite in tears. ‘Accept my blessing!’
“接受我的祝福，格里德利，”弗利特小姐泪流满面地说。 “接受我的祝福！”

‘I thought, boastfully, that they never could break my heart, Mr. Jarndyce. I was resolved that they should not. I did believe that I could, and would, charge them with being the mockery they were until I died of some bodily disorder. But I am worn out. How long I have been wearing out, I don’t know; I seemed to break down in an hour. I hope they may never come to hear of it. I hope everybody here will lead them to believe that I died defying them, consistently and perseveringly, as I did through so many years.’
“我自豪地认为，他们永远不会让我心碎，贾迪斯先生。我决定他们不应该这样做。我确实相信我可以而且会指责他们是对他们的嘲笑，直到我因某种身体疾病而去世。但我已经筋疲力尽了。我不知道我已经疲惫了多久；一个小时后我似乎崩溃了。我希望他们永远不会听到这个消息。我希望这里的每个人都能让他们相信，我是在反抗他们的过程中死去的，始终如一、坚持不懈，就像我多年来所做的那样。”

Here Mr. Bucket, who was sitting in a corner by the door, goodnaturedly offered such consolation as he could administer.
坐在门边角落里的巴克特先生和蔼地提供了他力所能及的安慰。

‘Come, come!’ he said from his corner. ‘Don’t go on in that way, Mr. Gridley. You are only a little low. We are all of us a little low sometimes. I am. Hold up, hold up! You’ll lose your temper with the whole round of ‘em, again and again; and I shall take you on a score of warrants yet, if I have luck.’
“来吧，来吧！”他在角落里说道。 “别再这样下去了，格里德利先生。你只是有点低。我们所有人有时都有点低落。我是。坚持住，坚持住！你会一次又一次地对他们发脾气；如果运气好的话，我还会带你去拿二十份搜查令。”

He only shook his head.
他只是摇了摇头。

‘Don’t shake your head,’ said Mr. Bucket. ‘Nod it; that’s what I want to see you do. Why, Lord bless your soul, what times we have had together! Haven’t I seen you in the Fleet over and over again for contempt? Haven’t I come into court, twenty afternoons for no other purpose than to see you pin the Chancellor like a bull-dog? Don’t you remember when you first began to threaten the lawyers, and the peace was sworn against you two or three times a week? Ask the little old lady there; she has been always present. Hold up, Mr. Gridley, hold up, sir!’
“别摇头，”巴克特先生说。 ‘点头吧；这就是我希望看到你做的。哎呀，上帝保佑你的灵魂，我们在一起度过了多么美好的时光啊！我不是在舰队里见过你一次又一次的蔑视吗？难道我二十个下午来到法庭不就是为了看你像斗牛犬一样钉住大法官吗？你不记得你第一次开始威胁律师的时候，每周都会有两三次向你宣誓和解吗？问问那里的小老太太；她一直都在。等一下，格里德利先生，等一下，先生！”

‘What are you going to do about him?’ asked George in a low voice.
“你打算对他做什么？”乔治低声问道。

‘I don’t know yet,’ said Bucket in the same tone. Then resuming his encouragement, he pursued aloud: ‘Worn out, Mr. Gridley? After dodging me for all these weeks and forcing me to climb the roof here like a tom cat and to come to see you as a doctor? That ain’t like being worn out. I should think not! Now I tell you what you want. You want excitement, you know, to keep YOU up; that’s what YOU want. You’re used to it, and you can’t do without it. I couldn’t myself. Very well, then; here’s this warrant got by Mr. Tulkinghorn of Lincoln’s Inn Fields, and backed into half-a-dozen counties since. What do you say to coming along with me, upon this warrant, and having a good angry argument before the magistrates? It’ll do you good; it’ll freshen you up and get you into training for another turn at the Chancellor. Give in? Why, I am surprised to hear a man of your energy talk of giving in. You mustn’t do that. You’re half the fun of the fair in the Court of Chancery. George, you lend Mr. Gridley a hand, and let’s see now whether he won’t be better up than down.’
“我还不知道，”巴克特用同样的语气说道。然后他继续鼓励，大声追问：“累了吗，格里德利先生？”躲了我好几个星期，还逼我像只公猫一样爬上屋顶，来给你看医生？这不像是疲惫不堪。我应该认为不会！现在我告诉你你想要什么。你知道，你需要兴奋来让你保持活力；那就是你想要的。你已经习惯了，而且你离不开它。我自己却做不到。那好吧;这是林肯因菲尔兹的图尔金霍恩先生获得的逮捕令，此后又支持了六个县。你觉得根据这个逮捕令跟我一起去，在地方法官面前进行一次激烈的愤怒争论怎么样？这对你有好处；它会让你精神焕发，并让你接受培训，为再次担任校长做好准备。让步？为什么，我很惊讶听到像你这样精力充沛的人谈论屈服。你不应该这样做。您是衡平法院展会的一半乐趣。乔治，你帮格里德利先生一把，现在让我们看看他的处境是否会比处境更好。”

‘He is very weak,’ said the trooper in a low voice.
“他很虚弱。”士兵低声说道。

‘Is he?’ returned Bucket anxiously. ‘I only want to rouse him. I don’t like to see an old acquaintance giving in like this. It would cheer him up more than anything if I could make him a little waxy with me. He’s welcome to drop into me, right and left, if he likes. I shall never take advantage of it.’
“是吗？”巴克特焦急地回答。 ‘我只是想唤醒他。我不喜欢看到一个老熟人就这样屈服。如果我能让他和我在一起变得有点蜡，这比什么都让他高兴。如果他愿意的话，欢迎他从左到右地撞到我身上。我永远不会利用它。

The roof rang with a scream from Miss Flite, which still rings in my ears.
屋顶上传来弗利特小姐的尖叫声，至今仍回响在我耳边。

‘Oh, no, Gridley!’ she cried as he fell heavily and calmly back from before her. ‘Not without my blessing. After so many years!’
“哦，不，格里德利！”当他从她面前重重而平静地倒下时，她喊道。 ‘没有我的祝福就不行。这么多年过去了！’

The sun was down, the light had gradually stolen from the roof, and the shadow had crept upward. But to me the shadow of that pair, one living and one dead, fell heavier on Richard’s departure than the darkness of the darkest night. And through Richard’s farewell words I heard it echoed: ‘Of all my old associations, of all my old pursuits and hopes, of all the living and the dead world, this one poor soul alone comes natural to me, and I am fit for. There is a tie of many suffering years between us two, and it is the only tie I ever had on earth that Chancery has not broken!’
太阳落山了，屋顶上的光渐渐偷走了，影子也向上爬了。但对我来说，理查德离开后，那一对生者和死者的阴影比最黑暗的夜晚还要沉重。在理查德的告别词中，我听到它的回声：“在我所有的旧联想中，在我所有旧的追求和希望中，在所有生与死的世界中，只有这个可怜的灵魂对我来说是自然的，我适合。”我们两个之间有着多年痛苦的纽带，这是我在地球上唯一没有被大法官打破的纽带！

CHAPTER XXV
第二十五章


Mrs. Snagsby Sees It All
斯纳斯比夫人目睹了这一切
