There is disquietude in Cook’s Court, Cursitor Street. Black suspicion hides in that peaceful region. The mass of Cook’s Courtiers are in their usual state of mind, no better and no worse; but Mr. Snagsby is changed, and his little woman knows it.
库西托街的库克法院里一片不安。黑色的怀疑隐藏在那个和平的地区。库克的朝臣们都处于平常的心态，没有好坏之分。但斯纳斯比先生变了，他的小女人知道这一点。

For Tom-all-Alone’s and Lincoln’s Inn Fields persist in harnessing themselves, a pair of ungovernable coursers, to the chariot of Mr. Snagsby’s imagination; and Mr. Bucket drives; and the passengers are Jo and Mr. Tulkinghorn; and the complete equipage whirls though the law-stationery business at wild speed all round the clock. Even in the little front kitchen where the family meals are taken, it rattles away at a smoking pace from the dinner-table, when Mr. Snagsby pauses in carving the first slice of the leg of mutton baked with potatoes and stares at the kitchen wall.
因为《汤姆孤身》和《林肯客栈》菲尔兹坚持把自己这对难以驾驭的骏马驾驭在斯纳斯比先生想象的战车上。和桶先生开车；乘客是乔和图金霍恩先生；整套设备全天候地以疯狂的速度在法律文具行业中运转。即使是在一家人吃饭的小前厨房里，当斯纳格斯比先生停下来切第一片烤土豆羊腿并盯着厨房墙壁时，餐桌上的声音也以冒着烟的速度嘎嘎作响。 。

Mr. Snagsby cannot make out what it is that he has had to do with. Something is wrong somewhere, but what something, what may come of it, to whom, when, and from which unthought of and unheard of quarter is the puzzle of his life. His remote impressions of the robes and coronets, the stars and garters, that sparkle through the surface-dust of Mr. Tulkinghorn’s chambers; his veneration for the mysteries presided over by that best and closest of his customers, whom all the Inns of Court, all Chancery Lane, and all the legal neighbourhood agree to hold in awe; his remembrance of Detective Mr. Bucket with his forefinger and his confidential manner, impossible to be evaded or declined, persuade him that he is a party to some dangerous secret without knowing what it is. And it is the fearful peculiarity of this condition that, at any hour of his daily life, at any opening of the shop-door, at any pull of the bell, at any entrance of a messenger, or any delivery of a letter, the secret may take air and fire, explode, and blow up—Mr. Bucket only knows whom.
斯纳斯比先生不明白这与他有什么关系。某处出了问题，但到底是什么问题，可能会发生什么，对谁、何时、从何而来，是他一生的困惑。他对长袍和冠冕、星星和吊袜带的遥远印象，在塔尔金霍恩先生房间的表面灰尘中闪闪发光；他对最优秀、最亲密的顾客所主持的神秘事物的崇敬，所有法院、大法官巷和所有法律界都一致对他们感到敬畏；他用食指回忆起警探巴克特先生，以及他无法回避或拒绝的保密态度，使他相信他是某个危险秘密的参与者，但他不知道那是什么。这种情况的可怕之处在于，在他日常生活的任何时刻，在商店门打开的任何时候，在门铃被拉动的任何时候，在信使的任何进入的时候，或者在任何一封信的交付时，秘密可能会吸收空气和火焰，爆炸并炸毁——先生。只有桶知道是谁。

For which reason, whenever a man unknown comes into the shop (as many men unknown do) and says, ‘Is Mr. Snagsby in?’ or words to that innocent effect, Mr. Snagsby’s heart knocks hard at his guilty breast. He undergoes so much from such inquiries that when they are made by boys he revenges himself by flipping at their ears over the counter and asking the young dogs what they mean by it and why they can’t speak out at once? More impracticable men and boys persist in walking into Mr. Snagsby’s sleep and terrifying him with unaccountable questions, so that often when the cock at the little dairy in Cursitor Street breaks out in his usual absurd way about the morning, Mr. Snagsby finds himself in a crisis of nightmare, with his little woman shaking him and saying ‘What’s the matter with the man!’
因此，每当一个不知名的人走进店里（正如许多不知名的人所做的那样）并问道：“斯纳格斯比先生在吗？”或者说一些无辜的话语时，斯纳格斯比先生的心就会剧烈地撞击着他内疚的胸膛。他从这些询问中经历了太多，以至于当男孩们向他询问时，他通过在柜台上翻动他们的耳朵来报复自己，并询问年轻的狗这是什么意思以及为什么他们不能立即说出来？更多不切实际的男人和男孩坚持走进斯纳格斯比先生的睡梦中，用一些无法解释的问题来吓唬他，因此，当库西特街的小奶牛场的公鸡在早晨以他惯常的荒谬方式爆发时，斯纳格斯比先生发现自己陷入了困境。一场噩梦般的危机，他的小女人摇晃着他，说“这个男人怎么了！”

The little woman herself is not the least item in his difficulty. To know that he is always keeping a secret from her, that he has under all circumstances to conceal and hold fast a tender double tooth, which her sharpness is ever ready to twist out of his head, gives Mr. Snagsby, in her dentistical presence, much of the air of a dog who has a reservation from his master and will look anywhere rather than meet his eye.
这个小女人本身并不是他遇到的困难中最重要的一个。斯纳斯比先生当着她的牙医在场，知道他总是对她保守秘密，在任何情况下他都必须隐藏并紧紧抓住一颗柔软的双牙，她的锐利随时准备将这颗牙齿从他的头上拧下来。 ，很像一只狗，它对主人有保留，会看向任何地方，而不是与主人目光相对。

These various signs and tokens, marked by the little woman, are not lost upon her. They impel her to say, ‘Snagsby has something on his mind!’ And thus suspicion gets into Cook’s Court, Cursitor Street. From suspicion to jealousy, Mrs. Snagsby finds the road as natural and short as from Cook’s Court to Chancery Lane. And thus jealousy gets into Cook’s Court, Cursitor Street. Once there (and it was always lurking thereabout), it is very active and nimble in Mrs. Snagsby’s breast, prompting her to nocturnal examinations of Mr. Snagsby’s pockets; to secret perusals of Mr. Snagsby’s letters; to private researches in the day book and ledger, till, cash-box, and iron safe; to watchings at windows, listenings behind doors, and a general putting of this and that together by the wrong end.
小女人所标记的这些不同的标志和象征，她并没有忘记。他们迫使她说：“斯纳格斯比有心事！”因此怀疑进入了库西托街的库克法院。从怀疑到嫉妒，斯纳斯比夫人发现这条路就像从库克法院到大法官巷一样自然而短。因此嫉妒就进入了库西特街的库克宫。一旦到达那里（它总是潜伏在那里），它就会在斯纳格斯比夫人的乳房中非常活跃和灵活，促使她在夜间检查斯纳格斯比先生的口袋；秘密审阅斯纳斯比先生的信件；对日记本和分类帐、收银台、钱箱和铁保险箱进行私人研究；窗外看，门后听，以及以错误的方式把这个和那个放在一起。

Mrs. Snagsby is so perpetually on the alert that the house becomes ghostly with creaking boards and rustling garments. The ‘prentices think somebody may have been murdered there in bygone times. Guster holds certain loose atoms of an idea (picked up at Tooting, where they were found floating among the orphans) that there is buried money underneath the cellar, guarded by an old man with a white beard, who cannot get out for seven thousand years because he said the Lord’s Prayer backwards.
斯纳斯比夫人时刻保持警惕，房子里变得阴森森的，木板嘎吱作响，衣服沙沙作响。 “学徒们认为过去可能有人被谋杀过。”古斯特持有某种想法的松散原子（在图廷发现的，在那里人们发现它们漂浮在孤儿中间），地窖下面埋着钱，由一位白胡子老人看守，他七千年都无法出去因为他把主祷文倒着念了。

‘Who was Nimrod?’ Mrs. Snagsby repeatedly inquires of herself. ‘Who was that lady—that creature? And who is that boy?’ Now, Nimrod being as dead as the mighty hunter whose name Mrs. Snagsby has appropriated, and the lady being unproducible, she directs her mental eye, for the present, with redoubled vigilance to the boy. ‘And who,’ quoth Mrs. Snagsby for the thousand and first time, ‘is that boy? Who is that—!’ And there Mrs. Snagsby is seized with an inspiration.
“宁罗德是谁？”斯纳斯比夫人反复问自己。 ‘那个女士——那个生物是谁？那个男孩是谁？现在，尼姆罗德已经死了，就像斯纳斯比夫人侵占了他的名字的强大猎人一样，而那位女士又无法生产，她目前将她的精神之眼引向那个男孩，加倍警惕。 “那么，”斯纳斯比夫人第一次问道，“那个男孩是谁？”那是谁——！”斯纳斯比夫人突然灵机一动。

He has no respect for Mr. Chadband. No, to be sure, and he wouldn’t have, of course. Naturally he wouldn’t, under those contagious circumstances. He was invited and appointed by Mr. Chadband—why, Mrs. Snagsby heard it herself with her own ears!—to come back, and be told where he was to go, to be addressed by Mr. Chadband; and he never came! Why did he never come? Because he was told not to come. Who told him not to come? Who? Ha, ha! Mrs. Snagsby sees it all.
他不尊重查德班德先生。不，可以肯定的是，他当然不会这么做。在这种具有传染性的情况下，他自然不会。查德班德先生邀请并任命他回来——为什么，斯纳斯比夫人亲耳所闻！——回来，并被告知他要去哪里，由查德班德先生接见；但他从来没有来过！他为什么不来？因为他被告知不要来。谁叫他不要来的？ WHO？哈哈！斯纳斯比夫人看到了这一切。

But happily (and Mrs. Snagsby tightly shakes her head and tightly smiles) that boy was met by Mr. Chadband yesterday in the streets; and that boy, as affording a subject which Mr. Chadband desires to improve for the spiritual delight of a select congregation, was seized by Mr. Chadband and threatened with being delivered over to the police unless he showed the reverend gentleman where he lived and unless he entered into, and fulfilled, an undertaking to appear in Cook’s Court to-morrow night, ‘‘to—mor—row—night,’ Mrs. Snagsby repeats for mere emphasis with another tight smile and another tight shake of her head; and to-morrow night that boy will be here, and to-morrow night Mrs. Snagsby will have her eye upon him and upon some one else; and oh, you may walk a long while in your secret ways (says Mrs. Snagsby with haughtiness and scorn), but you can’t blind ME!
但令人高兴的是（斯纳斯比夫人紧紧地摇着头，紧紧地微笑着）查德班德先生昨天在街上遇见了那个男孩；那个男孩，因为提供了查德班德先生希望改进的主题，以便为选定的会众的精神愉悦而改进，所以被查德班德先生抓住，并威胁说，除非他向这位可敬的绅士展示他住在哪里，否则就会被交给警察。他承诺并履行了明天晚上在库克法庭出庭的承诺，“明天——明天——晚上——”斯纳斯比夫人重复了一遍，只是为了强调，她又紧绷的微笑，又紧紧地摇了摇头。明天晚上那个男孩就会在这里，明天晚上斯纳斯比太太就会盯着他和其他人。哦，你可能会在你的秘密道路上走很长一段时间（斯纳斯比夫人傲慢而轻蔑地说道），但你不能蒙蔽我！

Mrs. Snagsby sounds no timbrel in anybody’s ears, but holds her purpose quietly, and keeps her counsel. To-morrow comes, the savoury preparations for the Oil Trade come, the evening comes. Comes Mr. Snagsby in his black coat; come the Chadbands; come (when the gorging vessel is replete) the ‘prentices and Guster, to be edified; comes at last, with his slouching head, and his shuflle backward, and his shuffle forward, and his shuffle to the right, and his shuffle to the left, and his bit of fur cap in his muddy hand, which he picks as if it were some mangy bird he had caught and was plucking before eating raw, Jo, the very, very tough subject Mr. Chadband is to improve.
斯纳斯比夫人没有在任何人耳边发出任何声音，但默默地坚持着她的目的，并坚持她的建议。明天到来，石油贸易的美味准备工作到来，夜晚来临。穿着黑色外套的斯纳斯比先生来了；乍得邦来了； （当狼吞虎咽的容器装满时）“学徒和古斯特”来接受启发；终于来了，他低垂着头，拖着脚步向后，拖着脚步向前，拖着脚步向右，拖着脚步向左，沾满泥的手上拿着一顶毛皮帽，他把它捡起来，好像它是它的样子。是他捉到的一只癞皮鸟，在生吃之前正在拔毛，乔，查德班德先生要改进的非常非常困难的科目。

Mrs. Snagsby screws a watchful glance on Jo as he is brought into the little drawing-room by Guster. He looks at Mr. Snagsby the moment he comes in. Aha! Why does he look at Mr. Snagsby? Mr. Snagsby looks at him. Why should he do that, but that Mrs. Snagsby sees it all? Why else should that look pass between them, why else should Mr. Snagsby be confused and cough a signal cough behind his hand? It is as clear as crystal that Mr. Snagsby is that boy’s father.
当乔被古斯特带进小客厅时，斯纳斯比夫人警惕地看了一眼乔。他一进来就看着斯纳斯比先生。啊哈！他为什么看着斯纳斯比先生？斯纳斯比先生看着他。他为什么要这么做，但斯纳斯比夫人看到了这一切？不然为什么他们之间会闪过那样的眼神，不然为什么斯纳斯比先生会感到困惑，并在手后示意性地咳了一声？很明显，斯纳斯比先生就是那个男孩的父亲。

‘’Peace, my friends,’ says Chadband, rising and wiping the oily exudations from his reverend visage. ‘Peace be with us! My friends, why with us? Because,’ with his fat smile, ‘it cannot be against us, because it must be for us; because it is not hardening, because it is softening; because it does not make war like the hawk, but comes home unto us like the dove. Therefore, my friends, peace be with us! My human boy, come forward!’
“请安静，我的朋友们，”查德班德说着，站了起来，擦掉了他那令人尊敬的脸上的油腻渗出物。 ‘愿平安与我们同在！我的朋友们，为什么和我们在一起？因为，”他脸上带着灿烂的笑容，“它不能反对我们，因为它一定是为了我们；因为它不是硬化，因为它是软化；因为它不像鹰那样发动战争，而是像鸽子一样回到我们身边。因此，我的朋友们，愿我们平安！我的人类男孩，挺身而出！

Stretching forth his flabby paw, Mr. Chadband lays the same on Jo’s arm and considers where to station him. Jo, very doubtful of his reverend friend’s intentions and not at all clear but that something practical and painful is going to be done to him, mutters, ‘You let me alone. I never said nothink to you. You let me alone.’
查德班德先生伸出松软的爪子，把它放在乔的手臂上，考虑把他放在哪里。乔对他可敬的朋友的意图非常怀疑，而且一点也不明白，但一些实际而痛苦的事情将会发生在他身上，他嘀咕道：“你让我一个人呆着。”我从来没有对你说过“nothink”。你让我一个人呆着。

‘No, my young friend,’ says Chadband smoothly, ‘I will not let you alone. And why? Because I am a harvest-labourer, because I am a toiler and a moiler, because you are delivered over unto me and are become as a precious instrument in my hands. My friends, may I so employ this instrument as to use it to your advantage, to your profit, to your gain, to your welfare, to your enrichment! My young friend, sit upon this stool.’
“不，我年轻的朋友，”查德班平静地说，“我不会让你孤单。”为什么？因为我是一个收割工人，因为我是一个辛劳者和劳作者，因为你被交付给我，成为我手中的宝贵工具。我的朋友们，愿我如此使用这个工具，以便利用它为您带来好处、为您带来利益、为您带来好处、为您带来福祉、为您致富！我的年轻朋友，请坐在这张凳子上。

Jo, apparently possessed by an impression that the reverend gentleman wants to cut his hair, shields his head with both arms and is got into the required position with great difficulty and every possible manifestation of reluctance.
乔显然以为这位尊贵的绅士想要剪掉他的头发，他用双臂护住他的头，费了很大的劲才达到了要求的位置，而且表现出了各种可能的不情愿。

When he is at last adjusted like a lay-figure, Mr. Chadband, retiring behind the table, holds up his bear’s-paw and says, ‘My friends!’ This is the signal for a general settlement of the audience. The ‘prentices giggle internally and nudge each other. Guster falls into a staring and vacant state, compounded of a stunned admiration of Mr. Chadband and pity for the friendless outcast whose condition touches her nearly. Mrs. Snagsby silently lays trains of gunpowder. Mrs. Chadband composes herself grimly by the fire and warms her knees, finding that sensation favourable to the reception of eloquence.
当他最终像外行人一样调整时，查德班德先生退到桌子后面，举起他的熊掌说：“我的朋友们！”这是观众们普遍就座的信号。学徒们在心里咯咯笑，互相推搡。古斯特陷入了一种凝视和茫然的状态，她对查德班德先生的钦佩和对这个没有朋友的被抛弃者的怜悯交织在一起，他的处境几乎触动了她。斯纳格斯比夫人默默地放置一列火药。查德班德夫人在火边让自己冷静下来，暖和膝盖，发现这种感觉有利于接受雄辩。

It happens that Mr. Chadband has a pulpit habit of fixing some member of his congregation with his eye and fatly arguing his points with that particular person, who is understood to be expected to be moved to an occasional grunt, groan, gasp, or other audible expression of inward working, which expression of inward working, being echoed by some elderly lady in the next pew and so communicated like a game of forfeits through a circle of the more fermentable sinners present, serves the purpose of parliamentary cheering and gets Mr. Chadband’s steam up. From mere force of habit, Mr. Chadband in saying ‘My friends!’ has rested his eye on Mr. Snagsby and proceeds to make that ill-starred stationer, already sufficiently confused, the immediate recipient of his discourse.
查德班德先生碰巧有一个讲坛习惯，他会用目光注视他的会众中的某个成员，并与那个特定的人激烈地争论他的观点，据了解，这个人会偶尔发出咕哝、呻吟、喘息或其他声音。内心工作的声音可以听到，这种内心工作的表达得到了旁边座位上的一些老太太的响应，并通过在场的一圈更容易发酵的罪人像一场输牌游戏一样进行交流，达到了议会欢呼的目的，并让先生感到高兴。查德班德气势汹汹。出于习惯的力量，查德班德先生在说“我的朋友们！”时，他的目光落在了斯纳斯比先生身上，然后让那个运气不好、已经很困惑的文具店员成为了他话语的直接接受者。

‘We have here among us, my friends,’ says Chadband, ‘a Gentile and a heathen, a dweller in the tents of Tom-all-Alone’s and a mover-on upon the surface of the earth. We have here among us, my friends,’ and Mr. Chadband, untwisting the point with his dirty thumb-nail, bestows an oily smile on Mr. Snagsby, signifying that he will throw him an argumentative back-fall presently if he be not already down, ‘a brother and a boy. Devoid of parents, devoid of relations, devoid of flocks and herds, devoid of gold and silver and of precious stones. Now, my friends, why do I say he is devoid of these possessions? Why? Why is he?’ Mr. Chadband states the question as if he were propoundlng an entirely new riddle of much ingenuity and merit to Mr. Snagsby and entreating him not to give it up.
“我的朋友们，我们中间有一个外邦人和一个异教徒，一个住在汤姆孤身帐篷里的居民，一个在地球表面上前进的人。查德班德先生用脏兮兮的大拇指指甲解开了这一点，对斯纳斯比先生露出了油腻的微笑，表示如果他不这样做，他很快就会给他一个争论性的倒退。已经下来了，‘一个兄弟和一个男孩。没有父母，没有亲人，没有牛羊，没有金银宝石。现在，我的朋友们，为什么我说他没有这些财产呢？为什么？为什么是他？”查德班德先生提出这个问题，就好像他在向斯纳斯比先生提出一个充满独创性和优点的全新谜语，并恳求他不要放弃。

Mr. Snagsby, greatly perplexed by the mysterious look he received just now from his little woman—at about the period when Mr. Chadband mentioned the word parents—is tempted into modestly remarking, ‘I don’t know, I’m sure, sir.’ On which interruption Mrs. Chadband glares and Mrs. Snagsby says, ‘For shame!’
斯纳斯比先生对他的小女人刚才看到的神秘目光感到非常困惑——大约是在查德班德先生提到“父母”这个词的时候——他忍不住谦虚地说：“我不知道，我确信，查德班德夫人怒视着这句话，斯纳斯比夫人说：“真丢脸！”

‘I hear a voice,’ says Chadband; ‘is it a still small voice, my friends? I fear not, though I fain would hope so—‘
“我听到一个声音，”查德班德说道。 ‘我的朋友们，声音还很小吗？我担心不会，尽管我很希望如此——”

‘Ah—h!’ from Mrs. Snagsby.
“啊——啊！”斯纳斯比夫人说道。

‘Which says, ‘I don’t know.’ Then I will tell you why. I say this brother present here among us is devoid of parents, devoid of relations, devoid of flocks and herds, devoid of gold, of silver, and of precious stones because he is devoid of the light that shines in upon some of us. What is that light? What is it? I ask you, what is that light?’
“这就是说，‘我不知道。’然后我会告诉你原因。”我说我们这里的这位弟兄，没有父母，没有亲人，没有牛羊，没有金银宝石，因为他没有照在我们一些人身上的光。那光是什么？它是什么？我问你，那光是什么？

Mr. Chadband draws back his head and pauses, but Mr. Snagsby is not to be lured on to his destruction again. Mr. Chadband, leaning forward over the table, pierces what he has got to follow directly into Mr. Snagsby with the thumb-nail already mentioned.
查德班德先生向后退了一步，停了下来，但斯纳斯比先生不会再被引诱走向毁灭。查德班德先生在桌子上倾身向前，用前面提到的拇指指甲将他必须遵循的东西直接刺入斯纳格斯比先生的体内。

‘It is,’ says Chadband, ‘the ray of rays, the sun of suns, the moon of moons, the star of stars. It is the light of Terewth.’
查德班德说：“它是光芒、太阳中的太阳、月亮中的月亮、星星中的星星。”这是特鲁斯之光。

Mr. Chadband draws himself up again and looks triumphantly at Mr. Snagsby as if he would be glad to know how he feels after that.
查德班德先生再次挺直身子，得意地看着斯纳斯比先生，仿佛他很高兴知道他之后的感受。

‘Of Terewth,’ says Mr. Chadband, hitting him again. ‘Say not to me that it is NOT the lamp of lamps. I say to you it is. I say to you, a million of times over, it is. It is! I say to you that I will proclaim it to you, whether you like it or not; nay, that the less you like it, the more I will proclaim it to you. With a speaking-trumpet! I say to you that if you rear yourself against it, you shall fall, you shall be bruised, you shall be battered, you shall be flawed, you shall be smashed.’
“特鲁斯的，”查德班德先生说，又打了他一下。 ‘别对我说这不是灯中之灯。我对你说是的。我对你说一百万次，确实如此。这是！我对你们说，无论你们喜欢与否，我都会向你们宣布这一点；不仅如此，你越不喜欢它，我就越向你宣告它。带着喇叭！我告诉你，如果你反抗它，你就会跌倒，你就会被打伤，你就会被殴打，你就会有缺陷，你就会被粉碎。

The present effect of this flight of oratory—much admired for its general power by Mr. Chadband’s followers—being not only to make Mr. Chadband unpleasantly warm, but to represent the innocent Mr. Snagsby in the light of a determined enemy to virtue, with a forehead of brass and a heart of adamant, that unfortunate tradesman becomes yet more disconcerted and is in a very advanced state of low spirits and false position when Mr. Chadband accidentally finishes him.
这种演讲的当前效果——查德班德先生的追随者因其普遍力量而备受推崇——不仅使查德班德先生变得令人不愉快的热情，而且从一个坚定的美德敌人的角度来代表无辜的斯纳格斯比先生，这位不幸的商人有着黄铜的额头和坚定的心，当查德班德先生意外地结束了他时，他变得更加不知所措，情绪低落，立场错误。

‘My friends,’ he resumes after dabbing his fat head for some time— and it smokes to such an extent that he seems to light his pockethandkerchief at it, which smokes, too, after every dab—‘to pursue the subject we are endeavouring with our lowly gifts to improve, let us in a spirit of love inquire what is that Terewth to which I have alluded. For, my young friends,’ suddenly addressing the ‘prentices and Guster, to their consternation, ‘if I am told by the doctor that calomel or castor-oil is good for me, I may naturally ask what is calomel, and what is castor-oil. I may wish to be informed of that before I dose myself with either or with both. Now, my young friends, what is this Terewth then? Firstly (in a spirit of love), what is the common sort of Terewth—the working clothes—the every-day wear, my young friends? Is it deception?’
“我的朋友们，”他在摸了摸他那胖胖的脑袋一段时间后继续说道——脑袋冒烟的程度如此之大，他似乎点燃了他的口袋手帕，每次擦拭后，口袋手帕也在冒烟——“去追求我们正在努力的主题让我们怀着爱的精神询问我所提到的特鲁斯是什么。因为，我的年轻朋友们，”突然对学徒们和古斯特说道，令他们惊愕的是，“如果医生告诉我甘汞或蓖麻油对我有好处，我自然会问什么是甘汞，什么是蓖麻油-油。在我选择其中一个或两者之前，我可能希望被告知这一点。现在，我的年轻朋友们，这个Terewth 是什么？首先（本着爱的精神），我的年轻朋友们，常见的Terewth是什么——工作服——日常穿着？这是欺骗吗？

‘Ah—h!’ from Mrs. Snagsby.
“啊——啊！”斯纳斯比夫人说道。

‘Is it suppression?’
“这是镇压吗？”

A shiver in the negative from Mrs. Snagsby.
斯纳格斯比夫人的否定让我不寒而栗。

‘Is it reservation?’
“是预订吗？”

A shake of the head from Mrs. Snagsby—very long and very tight.
斯纳斯比夫人摇了摇头——很长很紧。

‘No, my friends, it is neither of these. Neither of these names belongs to it. When this young heathen now among us—who is now, my friends, asleep, the seal of indifference and perdition being set upon his eyelids; but do not wake him, for it is right that I should have to wrestle, and to combat and to struggle, and to conquer, for his sake—when this young hardened heathen told us a story of a cock, and of a bull, and of a lady, and of a sovereign, was THAT the Terewth? No. Or if it was partly, was it wholly and entirely? No, my friends, no!’
‘不，我的朋友们，这两者都不是。这两个名字都不属于它。当这个年轻的异教徒现在在我们中间时——我的朋友们，他现在睡着了，冷漠和毁灭的印记贴在他的眼皮上；但不要叫醒他，因为为了他，我必须摔跤、战斗、奋斗、征服，这是正确的——当这个年轻的、冷酷的异教徒给我们讲了一个公鸡和公牛的故事时，那是一位女士和一位君主的特鲁斯吗？不。或者，如果是部分，那么是全部还是全部？不，我的朋友们，不！

If Mr. Snagsby could withstand his little woman’s look as it enters at his eyes, the windows of his soul, and searches the whole tenement, he were other than the man he is. He cowers and droops.
如果斯纳斯比先生能够承受他的小女人的目光进入他的眼睛，他的灵魂之窗，并搜索整个公寓，那么他就不是他这个人了。他畏缩并垂下身子。

‘Or, my juvenile friends,’ says Chadband, descending to the level of their comprehension with a very obtrusive demonstration in his greasily meek smile of coming a long way downstairs for the purpose, ‘if the master of this house was to go forth into the city and there see an eel, and was to come back, and was to call unto him the mistress of this house, and was to say, ‘Sarah, rejoice with me, for I have seen an elephant!’ would THAT be Terewth?’
“或者，我的少年朋友们，”查德班德说，他带着油腻温顺的微笑，带着非常唐突的表情，降到了他们的理解水平，为了这个目的，走了很长一段路，“如果这栋房子的主人要出去的话，”城里看到一只鳗鱼，他要回来，要叫这房子的女主人来，说：“莎拉，和我一起高兴吧，因为我看到了一头大象！”那是特鲁斯吗？ ？

Mrs. Snagsby in tears.
斯纳斯比夫人泪流满面。

‘Or put it, my juvenile friends, that he saw an elephant, and returning said ‘Lo, the city is barren, I have seen but an eel,’ would THAT be Terewth?’
“或者说，我的少年朋友们，他看到了一头大象，回来后说：‘瞧，这座城市很贫瘠，我只看到了一条鳗鱼，’那会是特鲁斯吗？”

Mrs. Snagsby sobbing loudly.
斯纳斯比夫人大声抽泣。

‘Or put it, my juvenile friends,’ said Chadband, stimulated by the sound, ‘that the unnatural parents of this slumbering heathen—for parents he had, my juvenile friends, beyond a doubt—after casting him forth to the wolves and the vultures, and the wild dogs and the young gazelles, and the serpents, went back to their dwellings and had their pipes, and their pots, and their flutings and their dancings, and their malt liquors, and their butcher’s meat and poultry, would THAT be Terewth?’
“或者说，我的少年朋友们，”查德班德被声音刺激着说道，“这个沉睡的异教徒的非自然父母——毫无疑问，我的少年朋友们，他的父母——在把他扔到狼群和秃鹰、野狗、小羚羊、蛇，回到自己的住所，拿走他们的笛子、他们的罐子、他们的笛子、他们的舞蹈、他们的麦芽酒、他们屠夫的肉和家禽，是特鲁斯吗？

Mrs. Snagsby replies by delivering herself a prey to spasms, not an unresisting prey, but a crying and a tearing one, so that Cook’s Court re-echoes with her shrieks. Finally, becoming cataleptic, she has to be carried up the narrow staircase like a grand piano. After unspeakable suffering, productive of the utmost consternation, she is pronounced, by expresses from the bedroom, free from pain, though much exhausted, in which state of affairs Mr. Snagsby, trampled and crushed in the piano-forte removal, and extremely timid and feeble, ventures to come out from behind the door in the drawing-room.
斯纳斯比夫人的回答是，把自己变成了一个痉挛的猎物，不是一个无法抵抗的猎物，而是一个哭泣和撕裂的猎物，以至于库克的法庭上回响着她的尖叫声。最后，她陷入了僵直状态，不得不像一架三角钢琴一样被抬着走上狭窄的楼梯。在经历了难以言喻的痛苦之后，她感到极度惊愕，从卧室里出来后，她被宣布，尽管已经精疲力竭，但没有任何痛苦，而斯纳格斯比先生在钢琴演奏中被践踏和压碎，而且非常胆怯。身体虚弱，大着胆子从客厅的门后走出来。

All this time Jo has been standing on the spot where he woke up, ever picking his cap and putting bits of fur in his mouth. He spits them out with a remorseful air, for he feels that it is in his nature to be an unimprovable reprobate and that it’s no good HIS trying to keep awake, for HE won’t never know nothink. Though it may be, Jo, that there is a history so interesting and affecting even to minds as near the brutes as thine, recording deeds done on this earth for common men, that if the Chadbands, removing their own persons from the light, would but show it thee in simple reverence, would but leave it unimproved, would but regard it as being eloquent enough without their modest aid—it might hold thee awake, and thou might learn from it yet!
乔一直站在他醒来的地方，摘下帽子，把一些毛皮放进嘴里。他带着悔恨的神情把这些话吐了出来，因为他觉得自己的天性就是一个不可改进的恶棍，他试图保持清醒是没有用的，因为他永远不会知道任何想法。乔，尽管有这样一段历史，它记录着普通人在地球上所做的事，甚至对那些像你一样近乎野蛮的人来说也是如此有趣和感人，如果查德班德家族把自己的人从光明中抹去，但以简单的敬意向你展示它，只会让它不加改进，只会在没有他们适度帮助的情况下认为它已经足够雄辩了——它可能会让你保持清醒，你还可以从中学习！

Jo never heard of any such book. Its compilers and the Reverend Chadband are all one to him, except that he knows the Reverend Chadband and would rather run away from him for an hour than hear him talk for five minutes. ‘It an’t no good my waiting here no longer,’ thinks Jo. ‘Mr. Snagsby an’t a-going to say nothink to me to-night.’ And downstairs he shuffles.
乔从未听说过任何这样的书。它的编译者和查德班德牧师对他来说都是一体的，只是他认识查德班德牧师，并且宁愿逃离他一个小时也不愿听他讲话五分钟。 “我不再在这里等待是没有用的，”乔想。 '先生。斯纳斯比今晚不会对我说“别想”。”然后他拖着脚步下了楼。

But downstairs is the charitable Guster, holding by the handrail of the kitchen stairs and warding off a fit, as yet doubtfully, the same having been induced by Mrs. Snagsby’s screaming. She has her own supper of bread and cheese to hand to Jo, with whom she ventures to interchange a word or so for the first time.
但楼下是仁慈的古斯特，他抓住厨房楼梯的扶手，避免痉挛，但目前还不确定，同样是由斯纳斯比太太的尖叫引起的。她准备了自己的面包和奶酪晚餐交给乔，她第一次冒险与乔交换了一个词。

‘Here’s something to eat, poor boy,’ says Guster.
“这是吃的东西，可怜的孩子，”古斯特说。

‘Thank’ee, mum,’ says Jo.
“谢谢，妈妈，”乔说。

‘Are you hungry?’
'你饿了吗？'

‘Jist!’ says Jo.
“就是这样！”乔说。

‘What’s gone of your father and your mother, eh?’
“你的父亲和母亲怎么了，嗯？”

Jo stops in the middle of a bite and looks petrified. For this orphan charge of the Christian saint whose shrine was at Tooting has patted him on the shoulder, and it is the first time in his life that any decent hand has been so laid upon him.
乔吃到一半就停了下来，看上去吓呆了。基督教圣人的神殿位于图廷，对这个孤儿的照顾拍了拍他的肩膀，这是他一生中第一次有像样的手如此按在他身上。

‘I never know’d nothink about ‘em,’ says Jo.
“我从来不知道会不会想到它们，”乔说。

‘No more didn’t I of mine,’ cries Guster. She is repressing symptoms favourable to the fit when she seems to take alarm at something and vanishes down the stairs.
“我不再是我的了，”古斯特喊道。当她似乎对某件事感到惊慌并消失在楼梯下时，她正在抑制有利于痉挛的症状。

‘Jo,’ whispers the law-stationer softly as the boy lingers on the step.
“乔，”当男孩在台阶上徘徊时，法律文员轻声说道。

‘Here I am, Mr. Snagsby!’
“我在这里，斯纳斯比先生！”

‘I didn’t know you were gone—there’s another half-crown, Jo. It was quite right of you to say nothing about the lady the other night when we were out together. It would breed trouble. You can’t be too quiet, Jo.’
“我不知道你走了——乔，还有半克朗。”那天晚上我们一起出去的时候，你对那位女士只字不提，这是非常正确的。这会滋生麻烦。你不能太安静，乔。”

‘I am fly, master!’
“我是苍蝇，主人！”

And so, good night.
那么，晚安。

A ghostly shade, frilled and night-capped, follows the lawstationer to the room he came from and glides higher up. And henceforth he begins, go where he will, to be attended by another shadow than his own, hardly less constant than his own, hardly less quiet than his own. And into whatsoever atmosphere of secrecy his own shadow may pass, let all concerned in the secrecy beware! For the watchful Mrs. Snagsby is there too—bone of his bone, flesh of his flesh, shadow of his shadow.
一个幽灵般的阴影，带着褶边和睡帽，跟随执法人员来到他来自的房间，然后滑向更高的地方。从那时起，他开始，去他想去的地方，有另一个影子陪伴着他，这个影子几乎不亚于他自己的稳定，不亚于他自己的安静。无论他自己的影子可能进入何种保密气氛，让所有与保密有关的人都要小心！因为警惕的斯纳斯比夫人也在那里——他的骨中的骨，他的肉中的肉，他的影子中的影子。

CHAPTER XXVI
第二十六章


Sharpshooters
神枪手

Wintry morning, looking with dull eyes and sallow face upon the neighbourhood of Leicester Square, finds its inhabitants unwilling to get out of bed. Many of them are not early risers at the brightest of times, being birds of night who roost when the sun is high and are wide awake and keen for prey when the stars shine out. Behind dingy blind and curtain, in upper story and garret, skulking more or less under false names, false hair, false titles, false jewellery, and false histories, a colony of brigands lie in their first sleep. Gentlemen of the green-baize road who could discourse from personal experience of foreign galleys and home treadmills; spies of strong governments that eternally quake with weakness and miserable fear, broken traitors, cowards, bullies, gamesters, shufflers, swindlers, and false witnesses; some not unmarked by the branding-iron beneath their dirty braid; all with more cruelty in them than was in Nero, and more crime than is in Newgate. For howsoever bad the devil can be in fustian or smock-frock (and he can be very bad in both), he is a more designing, callous, and intolerable devil when he sticks a pin in his shirt-front, calls himself a gentleman, backs a card or colour, plays a game or so of billiards, and knows a little about bills and promissory notes than in any other form he wears. And in such form Mr. Bucket shall find him, when he will, still pervading the tributary channels of Leicester Square.
寒冷的早晨，目光呆滞、面色蜡黄的莱斯特广场附近，居民们都不愿起床。它们中的许多人并不是在最明亮的时候起早起的动物，它们是夜鸟，它们在太阳升起时栖息，在星星闪耀时清醒并热衷于捕食。在肮脏的百叶窗和窗帘后面，在上层和阁楼里，一群强盗或多或少地以假名字、假头发、假头衔、假珠宝和假历史潜伏在他们的第一次睡眠中。绿毯路上的绅士们可以从国外厨房和家用跑步机的亲身经历来谈谈；强大政府的间谍，永远因软弱和悲惨的恐惧而颤抖，破碎的叛徒，懦夫，恶霸，赌徒，洗牌者，骗子和假证人；有些人肮脏的辫子下面有烙铁的痕迹；他们比尼禄时期更加残忍，比纽盖特时期更加犯罪。不管魔鬼穿粗布长袍或罩衫有多糟糕（而且他在这两方面都可能很糟糕），当他在衬衫前襟别上一根别针，称自己为绅士时，他就是一个更有计划、冷酷无情、令人难以忍受的魔鬼。 ，支持卡片或颜色，玩台球游戏左右，并且比他所穿的任何其他形式都了解一些钞票和期票。巴克特先生将以这种形式发现他，当他愿意时，仍然遍布莱斯特广场的支流渠道。

But the wintry morning wants him not and wakes him not. It wakes Mr. George of the shooting gallery and his familiar. They arise, roll up and stow away their mattresses. Mr. George, having shaved himself before a looking-glass of minute proportions, then marches out, bare-headed and bare-chested, to the pump in the little yard and anon comes back shining with yellow soap, friction, drifting rain, and exceedingly cold water. As he rubs himself upon a large jack-towel, blowing like a military sort of diver just come up, his hair curling tighter and tighter on his sunburnt temples the more he rubs it so that it looks as if it never could be loosened by any less coercive instrument than an iron rake or a curry-comb—as he rubs, and puffs, and polishes, and blows, turning his head from side to side the more conveniently to excoriate his throat, and standing with his body well bent forward to keep the wet from his martial legs, Phil, on his knees lighting a fire, looks round as if it were enough washing for him to see all that done, and sufficient renovation for one day to take in the superfluous health his master throws off.
但寒冷的早晨不想要他，也不叫醒他。它吵醒了射击场的乔治先生和他的魔宠。他们起身，卷起床垫并收起。乔治先生在镜子前刮了胡子，然后光着头、赤着上身，大步走向小院子里的水泵，不久就回来了，身上泛着黄色的肥皂，摩擦着，飘着雨，非常冷的水。他用一条大毛巾擦着自己，像刚上来的军事潜水员一样吹气，晒伤的太阳穴上的头发卷得越来越紧，越擦越紧，看起来好像任何人都无法松开。比铁耙子或咖喱梳子更具强制性的工具——当他摩擦、吹气、抛光、吹气时，他把头从一边转到另一边，以便更方便地刮擦喉咙，站着时身体向前弯曲为了防止他军事双腿上的湿气，菲尔跪在地上生火，环顾四周，仿佛这对他来说已经足够清洗，可以看到所有的事情都完成了，而且足够一天的翻新，以吸收他的主人抛弃的多余的健康。

When Mr. George is dry, he goes to work to brush his head with two hard brushes at once, to that unmerciful degree that Phil, shouldering his way round the gallery in the act of sweeping it, winks with sympathy. This chafing over, the ornamental part of Mr. George’s toilet is soon performed. He fills his pipe, lights it, and marches up and down smoking, as his custom is, while Phil, raising a powerful odour of hot rolls and coffee, prepares breakfast. He smokes gravely and marches in slow time. Perhaps this morning’s pipe is devoted to the memory of Gridley in his grave.
当乔治先生擦干的时候，他就会去上班，同时用两把硬刷子刷头，其残忍程度让菲尔在扫地时绕着画廊走，同情地眨着眼睛。等这一切都过去了，乔治先生厕所的装饰部分很快就完成了。他装满烟斗，点燃它，按照他的习惯来回抽烟，而菲尔则在准备早餐，散发着热面包卷和咖啡的浓烈气味。他严肃地抽烟，缓慢地行进。也许今天早上的烟斗是为了纪念格里德利在他的坟墓里。

‘And so, Phil,’ says George of the shooting gallery after several turns in silence, ‘you were dreaming of the country last night?’
“那么，菲尔，”射击场的乔治沉默了几圈后说道，“你昨晚梦见了这个国家吗？”

Phil, by the by, said as much in a tone of surprise as he scrambled out of bed.
顺便说一句，菲尔一边从床上爬起来，一边用惊讶的语气说道。

‘Yes, guv’ner.’
“是的，州长。”

‘What was it like?’
“那是什么样子？”

‘I hardly know what it was like, guv’ner,’ said Phil, considering.
“我几乎不知道那是什么感觉，领导，”菲尔思考着说道。

‘How did you know it was the country?’
“你怎么知道那是乡村？”

‘On account of the grass, I think. And the swans upon it,’ says Phil after further consideration.
“我想是因为草。”上面还有天鹅。”菲尔进一步考虑后说道。

‘What were the swans doing on the grass?’
“天鹅在草地上做什么？”

‘They was a-eating of it, I expect,’ says Phil.
“我想他们正在吃掉它，”菲尔说。

The master resumes his march, and the man resumes his preparation of breakfast. It is not necessarily a lengthened preparation, being limited to the setting forth of very simple breakfast requisites for two and the broiling of a rasher of bacon at the fire in the rusty grate; but as Phil has to sidle round a considerable part of the gallery for every object he wants, and never brings two objects at once, it takes time under the circumstances. At length the breakfast is ready. Phil announcing it, Mr. George knocks the ashes out of his pipe on the hob, stands his pipe itself in the chimney corner, and sits down to the meal. When he has helped himself, Phil follows suit, sitting at the extreme end of the little oblong table and taking his plate on his knees. Either in humility, or to hide his blackened hands, or because it is his natural manner of eating.
主人继续行军，男人继续准备早餐。这不一定是一个漫长的准备过程，仅限于为两个人提供非常简单的早餐必需品，并在生锈的炉排中烤一片培根；但由于菲尔必须在画廊的相当大一部分地方转来转去才能得到他想要的每一件物品，而且从来不会同时带来两件物品，因此在这种情况下这需要时间。终于，早餐准备好了。菲尔宣布这一消息后，乔治先生敲掉了炉灶上烟斗中的灰烬，将烟斗放在烟囱角落里，然后坐下来吃饭。当他吃完后，菲尔也跟着做了，坐在长方形小桌子的最末端，把盘子放在膝盖上。要么是出于谦卑，要么是为了隐藏他变黑的手，要么是因为这是他自然的饮食方式。

‘The country,’ says Mr. George, plying his knife and fork; ‘why, I suppose you never clapped your eyes on the country, Phil?’
“乡村，”乔治先生一边说，一边拿着刀叉。 “为什么，我想你从来没有关注过这个国家，菲尔？”

‘I see the marshes once,’ says Phil, contentedly eating his breakfast.
“我见过沼泽一次，”菲尔心满意足地吃着早餐说道。

‘What marshes?’
“什么沼泽？”

‘THE marshes, commander,’ returns Phil.
“是沼泽，指挥官，”菲尔回答道。

‘Where are they?’
'他们在哪里？'

‘I don’t know where they are,’ says Phil; ‘but I see ‘em, guv’ner. They was flat. And miste.’
“我不知道他们在哪里，”菲尔说。 “但我看到了他们，长官。”他们是平的。还有迷雾。’

Governor and commander are interchangeable terms with Phil, expressive of the same respect and deference and applicable to nobody but Mr. George.
总督和指挥官与菲尔是可以互换的术语，表达了同样的尊重和顺从，除了乔治先生之外，任何人都适用。

‘I was born in the country, Phil.’
“我出生在乡下，菲尔。”

‘Was you indeed, commander?’
“确实是你吗，指挥官？”

‘Yes. And bred there.’
'是的。并在那里长大。”

Phil elevates his one eyebrow, and after respectfully staring at his master to express interest, swallows a great gulp of coffee, still staring at him.
菲尔挑起一根眉毛，恭敬地盯着他的主人表达了兴趣后，喝了一大口咖啡，仍然盯着他。

‘There’s not a bird’s note that I don’t know,’ says Mr. George. ‘Not many an English leaf or berry that I couldn’t name. Not many a tree that I couldn’t climb yet if I was put to it. I was a real country boy, once. My good mother lived in the country.’
“没有一张鸟的音符是我不知道的，”乔治先生说。 “没有多少英国叶子或浆果是我叫不出名字的。如果让我爬上去的话，还没有多少棵树是我爬不上去的。我曾经是一个真正的乡下男孩。我的好母亲住在乡下。

‘She must have been a fine old lady, guv’ner,’ Phil observes.
“州长，她一定是一位漂亮的老太太，”菲尔评论道。

‘Aye! And not so old either, five and thirty years ago,’ says Mr. George. ‘But I’ll wager that at ninety she would be near as upright as me, and near as broad across the shoulders.’
‘是啊！而且也不那么老了，五三十年前，”乔治先生说。 “但我敢打赌，到了九十岁，她会和我一样直立，肩膀也一样宽阔。”

‘Did she die at ninety, guv’ner?’ inquires Phil.
“她九十岁就死了吗，州长？”菲尔问道。

‘No. Bosh! Let her rest in peace, God bless her!’ says the trooper. ‘What set me on about country boys, and runaways, and good-for-nothings? You, to be sure! So you never clapped your eyes upon the country—marshes and dreams excepted. Eh?’
'不。波什！让她安息吧，上帝保佑她！”士兵说道。 “是什么让我对乡村男孩、逃亡者和废物产生了兴趣？你，当然！所以你从来不会把目光投向这个国家——除了沼泽和梦想。嗯？’

Phil shakes his head.
菲尔摇摇头。

‘Do you want to see it?’
'你想看看吗？'

‘N-no, I don’t know as I do, particular,’ says Phil.
“不——不，我不知道，特别是，”菲尔说。

‘The town’s enough for you, eh?’
“这个小镇对你来说就足够了，嗯？”

‘Why, you see, commander,’ says Phil, ‘I ain’t acquainted with anythink else, and I doubt if I ain’t a-getting too old to take to novelties.’
“嘿，你看，指挥官，”菲尔说，“我对其他事情一无所知，而且我怀疑我是不是太老了，无法接受新鲜事物了。”

‘How old ARE you, Phil?’ asks the trooper, pausing as he conveys his smoking saucer to his lips.
“你多大了，菲尔？”士兵问道，将冒着烟的碟子放到唇边时停了下来。

‘I’m something with a eight in it,’ says Phil. ‘It can’t be eighty. Nor yet eighteen. It’s betwixt ‘em, somewheres.’
“我是一个带有八的东西，”菲尔说。 ‘不可能是八十。还没有十八岁。它就在“他们之间的某个地方”。

Mr. George, slowly putting down his saucer without tasting its contents, is laughingly beginning, ‘Why, what the deuce, Phil—‘ when he stops, seeing that Phil is counting on his dirty fingers.
乔治先生慢慢地放下碟子，没有品尝里面的东西，他笑着开始说：“嘿，到底是怎么回事，菲尔——”当他停下来时，看到菲尔正在用他肮脏的手指数数。

‘I was just eight,’ says Phil, ‘agreeable to the parish calculation, when I went with the tinker. I was sent on a errand, and I see him a-sittin under a old buildin with a fire all to himself wery comfortable, and he says, ‘Would you like to come along a me, my man?’ I says ‘Yes,’ and him and me and the fire goes home to Clerkenwell together. That was April Fool Day. I was able to count up to ten; and when April Fool Day come round again, I says to myself, ‘Now, old chap, you’re one and a eight in it.’ April Fool Day after that, I says, ‘Now, old chap, you’re two and a eight in it.’ In course of time, I come to ten and a eight in it; two tens and a eight in it. When it got so high, it got the upper hand of me, but this is how I always know there’s a eight in it.’
“当我和修补匠一起去时，我才八岁，”菲尔说，“同意教区的计算。”我被派去出差，我看到他坐在一座古老的建筑下，生着火，独自一人，非常舒服，他说，“你愿意和我一起去吗，我的朋友？”我说：“是的， ’然后他和我以及火一起回到克勒肯韦尔的家。那是愚人节。我能数到十；当愚人节再次到来时，我对自己说，“现在，老伙计，你是一加八。”在那之后的愚人节，我说，“现在，老伙计，你是二“里面有一个八。”随着时间的推移，我得到了十，里面有一个八。里面有两个十和一个八。当它变得如此高时，它占据了我的上风，但这就是我总是知道其中有一个八的方式。

‘Ah!’ says Mr. George, resuming his breakfast. ‘And where’s the tinker?’
“啊！”乔治先生一边说，一边继续吃早餐。 “补锅匠在哪里？”

‘Drink put him in the hospital, guv’ner, and the hospital put him— in a glass-case, I HAVE heerd,’ Phil replies mysteriously.
“领导，喝酒把他送进了医院，我听说，医院把他送进了玻璃柜里，”菲尔神秘地回答道。

‘By that means you got promotion? Took the business, Phil?’
‘这么说你就升职了？菲尔，接手这个生意了吗？

‘Yes, commander, I took the business. Such as it was. It wasn’t much of a beat—round Saffron Hill, Hatton Garden, Clerkenwell, Smiffeld, and there—poor neighbourhood, where they uses up the kettles till they’re past mending. Most of the tramping tinkers used to come and lodge at our place; that was the best part of my master’s earnings. But they didn’t come to me. I warn’t like him. He could sing ‘em a good song. I couldn’t! He could play ‘em a tune on any sort of pot you please, so as it was iron or block tin. I never could do nothing with a pot but mend it or bile it—never had a note of music in me. Besides, I was too ill-looking, and their wives complained of me.’
“是的，指挥官，我接手了这件事。就这样。在藏红花山、哈顿花园、克勒肯韦尔、斯米菲尔德以及那里的贫困社区周围，这并不是什么令人兴奋的事情，他们用完那里的水壶，直到它们无法修好为止。大多数流浪修补匠过去常来我们这里住宿。这是我主人收入中最好的部分。但他们没有来找我。我警告不喜欢他。他可以给他们唱一首好歌。我不能！他可以在任何你喜欢的锅上为他们演奏曲子，无论是铁锅还是锡块。除了修理它或给它胆汁之外，我对锅子什么也做不了——我身上从来没有任何音乐的音符。再说了，我长得也太难看了，他们的老婆都埋怨我。

‘They were mighty particular. You would pass muster in a crowd, Phil!’ says the trooper with a pleasant smile.
“他们非常特别。菲尔，你会在人群中通过检定的！”士兵带着愉快的微笑说道。

‘No, guv’ner,’ returns Phil, shaking his head. ‘No, I shouldn’t. I was passable enough when I went with the tinker, though nothing to boast of then; but what with blowing the fire with my mouth when I was young, and spileing my complexion, and singeing my hair off, and swallering the smoke, and what with being nat’rally unfort’nate in the way of running against hot metal and marking myself by sich means, and what with having turn-ups with the tinker as I got older, almost whenever he was too far gone in drink—which was almost always—my beauty was queer, wery queer, even at that time. As to since, what with a dozen years in a dark forge where the men was given to larking, and what with being scorched in a accident at a gas-works, and what with being blowed out of winder case-filling at the firework business, I am ugly enough to be made a show on!’
“不，领导，”菲尔摇着头回答道。 ‘不，我不应该。当我和补锅匠一起去的时候，我还过得去，虽然那时没什么值得夸耀的。但是年轻时用嘴吹火，弄脏了我的肤色，烧焦了我的头发，吞咽了烟雾，以及在与滚烫的金属碰撞和划痕方面自然不幸的事情随着年龄的增长，每当他喝得酩酊大醉时——这几乎总是——我的美就很奇怪，非常奇怪，即使在那个时候。自从那以后，人们在黑暗的锻造厂里度过了十几年，人们在那里嬉戏，在煤气厂的一次事故中被烧焦，在烟花生意中被从装满发条的盒子里吹出来。 ，我长得丑得让人作秀！

Resigning himself to which condition with a perfectly satisfied manner, Phil begs the favour of another cup of coffee. While drinking it, he says, ‘It was after the case-filling blow-up when I first see you, commander. You remember?’
菲尔以一种非常满意的方式接受了这种情况，请求再喝一杯咖啡。他边喝边说道：“我第一次见到你是在装箱爆炸之后，指挥官。”你记得？'

‘I remember, Phil. You were walking along in the sun.’
“我记得，菲尔。你在阳光下行走。

‘Crawling, guv’ner, again a wall—‘
“爬行，长官，又是一堵墙——”

‘True, Phil—shouldering your way on—‘
“没错，菲尔——你正在继续前进——”

‘In a night-cap!’ exclaims Phil, excited.
“戴着睡帽！”菲尔兴奋地喊道。

‘In a night-cap—‘
“戴着睡帽——”

‘And hobbling with a couple of sticks!’ cries Phil, still more excited.
“还有几根棍子，一瘸一拐的！”菲尔喊道，他更加兴奋了。

‘With a couple of sticks. When—‘
‘用几根棍子。什么时候-'

‘When you stops, you know,’ cries Phil, putting down his cup and saucer and hastily removing his plate from his knees, ‘and says to me, ‘What, comrade! You have been in the wars!’ I didn’t say much to you, commander, then, for I was took by surprise that a person so strong and healthy and bold as you was should stop to speak to such a limping bag of bones as I was. But you says to me, says you, delivering it out of your chest as hearty as possible, so that it was like a glass of something hot, ‘What accident have you met with? You have been badly hurt. What’s amiss, old boy? Cheer up, and tell us about it!’ Cheer up! I was cheered already! I says as much to you, you says more to me, I says more to you, you says more to me, and here I am, commander! Here I am, commander!’ cries Phil, who has started from his chair and unaccountably begun to sidle away. ‘If a mark’s wanted, or if it will improve the business, let the customers take aim at me. They can’t spoil MY beauty. I’M all right. Come on! If they want a man to box at, let ‘em box at me. Let ‘em knock me well about the head. I don’t mind. If they want a light-weight to be throwed for practice, Cornwall, Devonshire, or Lancashire, let ‘em throw me. They won’t hurt ME. I have been throwed, all sorts of styles, all my life!’
“当你停下来的时候，你知道，”菲尔喊道，放下杯子和碟子，急忙从膝盖上取下盘子，“对我说，‘什么，同志！你参加过战争！”我没有对你说太多，指挥官，因为我很惊讶像你这样强壮、健康、勇敢的人居然会停下来对这样一具跛行的骨头说话。像我以前一样。但你对我说，你说，尽可能地从你的胸口说出它，就像一杯热的东西一样，‘你遇到了什么意外？你受了重伤。老伙计，怎么了？振作起来，告诉我们这件事！’振作起来！我已经欢呼雀跃了！我对你说这么多，你对我说更多，我对你说更多，你对我说更多，我在这里，指挥官！我在这里，指挥官！”菲尔喊道，他从椅子上站起来，莫名其妙地开始侧身走开。 “如果想要一个商标，或者如果它能改善生意，就让顾客瞄准我吧。”他们不能破坏我的美丽。我很好。快点！如果他们想要一个人来拳击，那就让他们来拳击我吧。让他们狠狠地敲我的头吧。我不介意。如果他们想要扔一个轻量级的东西来练习，康沃尔郡、德文郡或兰开夏郡，就让他们扔我吧。他们不会伤害我。我一生都被抛弃过，各种各样的风格！

With this unexpected speech, energetically delivered and accompanied by action illustrative of the various exercises referred to, Phil Squod shoulders his way round three sides of the gallery, and abruptly tacking off at his commander, makes a butt at him with his head, intended to express devotion to his service. He then begins to clear away the breakfast.
菲尔·斯阔德在这段出人意料的演讲中，充满活力地发表了演讲，并伴随着所提到的各种练习的动作，他用肩膀绕过了观众席的三边，突然向他的指挥官发起进攻，用头撞了他，意图表达对他的服务的奉献精神。然后他开始收拾早餐。

Mr. George, after laughing cheerfully and clapping him on the shoulder, assists in these arrangements and helps to get the gallery into business order. That done, he takes a turn at the dumb-bells, and afterwards weighing himself and opining that he is getting ‘too fleshy,’ engages with great gravity in solitary broadsword practice. Meanwhile Phil has fallen to work at his usual table, where he screws and unscrews, and cleans, and files, and whistles into small apertures, and blackens himself more and more, and seems to do and undo everything that can be done and undone about a gun.
乔治先生高兴地大笑并拍拍他的肩膀后，协助进行这些安排，并帮助画廊恢复正常营业。完成后，他转动哑铃，然后称量自己，认为自己“太胖了”，然后以极大的重力进行单独的大刀练习。与此同时，菲尔在他惯用的桌子上开始工作，他在那里拧螺丝、拧螺丝、清洁、归档、吹口哨，把自己越来越黑，似乎可以做和撤消一切可以做和撤消的事情。一把枪。

Master and man are at length disturbed by footsteps in the passage, where they make an unusual sound, denoting the arrival of unusual company. These steps, advancing nearer and nearer to the gallery, bring into it a group at first sight scarcely reconcilable with any day in the year but the fifth of November.
主人和人终于被通道里的脚步声打扰了，他们发出了一种不寻常的声音，表明有不寻常的同伴到来。这些台阶离画廊越来越近，乍一看，除了十一月五日之外，这群人几乎与一年中的任何一天都格格不入。

It consists of a limp and ugly figure carried in a chair by two bearers and attended by a lean female with a face like a pinched mask, who might be expected immediately to recite the popular verses commemorative of the time when they did contrive to blow Old England up alive but for her keeping her lips tightly and defiantly closed as the chair is put down. At which point the figure in it gasping, ‘O Lord! Oh, dear me! I am shaken!’ adds, ‘How de do, my dear friend, how de do?’ Mr. George then descries, in the procession, the venerable Mr. Smallweed out for an airing, attended by his granddaughter Judy as body-guard.
它由两个轿夫抬在椅子上，由一个瘦弱的女性组成，她的脸像捏紧的面具，可能会立即背诵纪念他们确实设法吹旧的时代的流行诗句。英格兰队还活着，但在椅子放下时，她紧紧闭着嘴唇，挑衅地闭着嘴。就在这时，里面的人喘着气说：‘主啊！噢，亲爱的我！我震惊了！”补充道，“怎么办，我亲爱的朋友，怎么办？”乔治先生随后在游行队伍中描述了可敬的斯莫威德先生外出放风，他的孙女朱迪作为保镖陪同。

‘Mr. George, my dear friend,’ says Grandfather Smallweed, removing his right arm from the neck of one of his bearers, whom he has nearly throttled coming along, ‘how de do? You’re surprised to see me, my dear friend.’
'先生。乔治，我亲爱的朋友，”斯莫威德爷爷一边说着，一边从他的一名抬轿人的脖子上移开右臂，差点掐死了抬轿人的脚步，“你怎么样？你很惊讶地看到我，我亲爱的朋友。

‘I should hardly have been more surprised to have seen your friend in the city,’ returns Mr. George.
“在城里见到你的朋友，我简直不应该感到更惊讶，”乔治先生回答道。

‘I am very seldom out,’ pants Mr. Smallweed. ‘I haven’t been out for many months. It’s inconvenient—and it comes expensive. But I longed so much to see you, my dear Mr. George. How de do, sir?’
“我很少出去，”斯莫威德先生气喘吁吁地说。 ‘我已经好几个月没出去了。这很不方便，而且价格昂贵。但我非常渴望见到你，我亲爱的乔治先生。怎么样，先生？

‘I am well enough,’ says Mr. George. ‘I hope you are the same.’
“我很好，”乔治先生说。 “我希望你也一样。”

‘You can’t be too well, my dear friend.’ Mr. Smallweed takes him by both hands. ‘I have brought my granddaughter Judy. I couldn’t keep her away. She longed so much to see you.’
“你不太好，我亲爱的朋友。”斯莫威德先生握住他的双手。 “我带来了我的孙女朱迪。我无法让她远离我。她非常渴望见到你。

‘Hum! She hears it calmly!’ mutters Mr. George.
'哼！她平静地听着！”乔治先生嘀咕道。

‘So we got a hackney-cab, and put a chair in it, and just round the corner they lifted me out of the cab and into the chair, and carried me here that I might see my dear friend in his own establishment! This,’ says Grandfather Smallweed, alluding to the bearer, who has been in danger of strangulation and who withdraws adjusting his windpipe, ‘is the driver of the cab. He has nothing extra. It is by agreement included in his fare. This person,’ the other bearer, ‘we engaged in the street outside for a pint of beer. Which is twopence. Judy, give the person twopence. I was not sure you had a workman of your own here, my dear friend, or we needn’t have employed this person.’
“所以我们找了一辆出租马车，在里面放了一把椅子，就在拐角处，他们把我从出租车里抬到了椅子上，然后把我带到了这里，这样我就可以在他自己的住所里见到我亲爱的朋友了！”这位祖父斯莫威德说，他指的是那个有被勒死危险的人，他退出来调整气管，“是出租车司机。”他没有什么多余的。根据协议，它包含在他的票价中。这个人，”另一个搬运工，“我们在外面的街上喝了一品脱啤酒。这是两便士。朱迪，给那个人两便士。我不确定你这里有自己的工人，我亲爱的朋友，否则我们就不必雇用这个人了。

Grandfather Smallweed refers to Phil with a glance of considerable terror and a half-subdued ‘O Lord! Oh, dear me!’ Nor in his apprehension, on the surface of things, without some reason, for Phil, who has never beheld the apparition in the black-velvet cap before, has stopped short with a gun in his hand with much of the air of a dead shot intent on picking Mr. Smallweed off as an ugly old bird of the crow species.
斯莫威德爷爷用一种相当恐惧的眼神和半压抑的眼神提到菲尔：“主啊！哦，天哪！”他的忧虑也没有，从表面上看，没有任何原因，因为菲尔以前从未见过那个戴着黑天鹅绒帽子的幽灵，他突然停了下来，手里拿着一把枪，里面有很多东西。那种神情就像是一枪毙命，要把斯莫威德先生当作一只丑陋的乌鸦类老鸟来干掉。

‘Judy, my child,’ says Grandfather Smallweed, ‘give the person his twopence. It’s a great deal for what he has done.’
“朱迪，我的孩子，”斯莫威德爷爷说，“给这个人两便士。”对于他所做的事情来说，这是一件了不起的事情。

The person, who is one of those extraordinary specimens of human fungus that spring up spontaneously in the western streets of London, ready dressed in an old red jacket, with a ‘mission’ for holding horses and calling coaches, received his twopence with anything but transport, tosses the money into the air, catches it over-handed, and retires.
这个人是伦敦西部街道上自发出现的那些非凡的人类真菌标本之一，他穿着一件旧的红色夹克，肩负着牵马和叫马车的“使命”，他收到的两便士除了运输，将钱抛向空中，用力接住，然后退休。

‘My dear Mr. George,’ says Grandfather Smallweed, ‘would you be so kind as help to carry me to the fire? I am accustomed to a fire, and I am an old man, and I soon chill. Oh, dear me!’
“亲爱的乔治先生，”斯莫威德祖父说道，“您能帮我把我带到火场吗？”我习惯了火，而且我是个老人，很快就冷了。哦，天哪！’

His closing exclamation is jerked out of the venerable gentleman by the suddenness with which Mr. Squod, like a genie, catches him up, chair and all, and deposits him on the hearth-stone.
这位德高望重的绅士突然发出了最后的感叹，斯阔德先生像个精灵一样，突然抓住了他，连同椅子和所有东西，把他放在炉边的石头上。

‘O Lord!’ says Mr. Smallweed, panting. ‘Oh, dear me! Oh, my stars! My dear friend, your workman is very strong—and very prompt. O Lord, he is very prompt! Judy, draw me back a little. I’m being scorched in the legs,’ which indeed is testified to the noses of all present by the smell of his worsted stockings.
“主啊！”斯莫威德先生气喘吁吁地说。 ‘噢，亲爱的我！哦，我的星星！我亲爱的朋友，你的工人非常强大，而且非常迅速。主啊，他真是太及时了！朱迪，把我拉回来一点。我的腿被烧焦了，”他的精纺长袜的气味确实证明了在场所有人的鼻子。

The gentle Judy, having backed her grandfather a little way from the fire, and having shaken him up as usual, and having released his overshadowed eye from its black-velvet extinguisher, Mr. Smallweed again says, ‘Oh, dear me! O Lord!’ and looking about and meeting Mr. George’s glance, again stretches out both hands.
温柔的朱迪把她的祖父背到离火稍远的地方，像往常一样把他摇醒，然后从黑天鹅绒灭火器中松开被遮住的眼睛，斯莫威德先生再次说道：“哦，天哪！”主啊！”他环顾四周，迎上乔治先生的目光，再次伸出双手。

‘My dear friend! So happy in this meeting! And this is your establishment? It’s a delightful place. It’s a picture! You never find that anything goes off here accidentally, do you, my dear friend?’ adds Grandfather Smallweed, very ill at ease.
'我亲爱的朋友！这次聚会真开心！这是你的机构吗？这是一个令人愉快的地方。这是一张照片！你从来不会发现这里有任何事情会意外发生，不是吗，我亲爱的朋友？”斯莫威德祖父非常不安地补充道。

‘No, no. No fear of that.’
'不，不。不用担心这个。

‘And your workman. He—Oh, dear me!—he never lets anything off without meaning it, does he, my dear friend?’
‘还有你的工人。他——哦，天哪！——他从来不会无缘无故地放过任何事，不是吗，我亲爱的朋友？

‘He has never hurt anybody but himself,’ says Mr. George, smiling.
“除了他自己，他从来没有伤害过任何人，”乔治先生微笑着说道。

‘But he might, you know. He seems to have hurt himself a good deal, and he might hurt somebody else,’ the old gentleman returns. ‘He mightn’t mean it—or he even might. Mr. George, will you order him to leave his infernal firearms alone and go away?’
“但你知道，他可能会这么做。他似乎已经伤害了自己很多，而且他可能会伤害别人。”老先生回答道。 “他可能不是这个意思——或者他甚至可能是这个意思。乔治先生，你能命令他别管他那该死的枪并走开吗？

Obedient to a nod from the trooper, Phil retires, empty-handed, to the other end of the gallery. Mr. Smallweed, reassured, falls to rubbing his legs.
菲尔听从警察的点头，空手退到画廊的另一端。斯莫威德先生放心了，开始揉腿。

‘And you’re doing well, Mr. George?’ he says to the trooper, squarely standing faced about towards him with his broadsword in his hand. ‘You are prospering, please the Powers?’
“乔治先生，你做得很好吗？”他对士兵说道，手里拿着大刀，面朝他正对着他站着。 “请问列强们，你们很繁荣吗？”

Mr. George answers with a cool nod, adding, ‘Go on. You have not come to say that, I know.’
乔治先生冷静地点点头，补充道：“继续吧。”我知道你不是来这么说的。

‘You are so sprightly, Mr. George,’ returns the venerable grandfather. ‘You are such good company.’
“你真是太活泼了，乔治先生，”德高望重的祖父回答道。 “你们真是个好伙伴。”

‘Ha ha! Go on!’ says Mr. George.
'哈哈！继续吧！”乔治先生说。

‘My dear friend! But that sword looks awful gleaming and sharp. It might cut somebody, by accident. It makes me shiver, Mr. George. Curse him!’ says the excellent old gentleman apart to Judy as the trooper takes a step or two away to lay it aside. ‘He owes me money, and might think of paying off old scores in this murdering place. I wish your brimstone grandmother was here, and he’d shave her head off.’
'我亲爱的朋友！但这把剑看起来闪闪发亮，锋利无比。它可能会意外地割伤某人。这让我发抖，乔治先生。诅咒他！”那位优秀的老绅士对朱迪说道，而士兵则退开一两步，把它放在一边。 “他欠我钱，可能会想在这个杀人之地还清旧账。”我希望你的硫磺祖母在这里，他会把她的头剃掉。

Mr. George, returning, folds his arms, and looking down at the old man, sliding every moment lower and lower in his chair, says quietly, ‘Now for it!’
乔治先生回来了，抱起双臂，低头看着老人，在椅子上一步一步地滑下去，平静地说：“现在就开始吧！”

‘Ho!’ cries Mr. Smallweed, rubbing his hands with an artful chuckle. ‘Yes. Now for it. Now for what, my dear friend?’
“嗬！”斯莫尔韦德先生一边叫道，一边巧妙地笑着搓着手。 '是的。现在就开始吧。现在做什么，我亲爱的朋友？

‘For a pipe,’ says Mr. George, who with great composure sets his chair in the chimney-corner, takes his pipe from the grate, fills it and lights it, and falls to smoking peacefully.
“买烟斗，”乔治先生平静地说，他把椅子放在烟囱一角，从炉排上取下烟斗，装满烟斗，点燃，然后安静地抽烟。

This tends to the discomfiture of Mr. Smallweed, who finds it so difficult to resume his object, whatever it may be, that he becomes exasperated and secretly claws the air with an impotent vindictiveness expressive of an intense desire to tear and rend the visage of Mr. George. As the excellent old gentleman’s nails are long and leaden, and his hands lean and veinous, and his eyes green and watery; and, over and above this, as he continues, while he claws, to slide down in his chair and to collapse into a shapeless bundle, he becomes such a ghastly spectacle, even in the accustomed eyes of Judy, that that young virgin pounces at him with something more than the ardour of affection and so shakes him up and pats and pokes him in divers parts of his body, but particularly in that part which the science of self-defence would call his wind, that in his grievous distress he utters enforced sounds like a paviour’s rammer.
这往往会让斯莫尔威德先生感到沮丧，他发现无论它是什么，都很难恢复他的目标，以至于他变得恼怒并偷偷地用爪子抓着空气，带着一种无能为力的报复性，表达了一种强烈的欲望，想要撕裂和撕碎他的面容。乔治先生。这位优秀的老先生的指甲又长又铅，他的手又瘦又青，眼睛又绿又水汪汪；除此之外，当他继续用爪子滑落到椅子上并塌陷成一团无形的东西时，即使在朱迪习惯的眼中，他也变得如此可怕，以至于那个年轻的处女扑向了他。他怀着比热情更强烈的感情，摇晃着他，拍打着他身体的各个部位，特别是在自卫科学中称为“风”的部位，在他极度痛苦的情况下，他说出了这样的话：强制听起来就像铺路机的夯锤。

When Judy has by these means set him up again in his chair, with a white face and a frosty nose (but still clawing), she stretches out her weazen forefinger and gives Mr. George one poke in the back. The trooper raising his head, she makes another poke at her esteemed grandfather, and having thus brought them together, stares rigidly at the fire.
当朱迪用这些方法把他重新坐到椅子上时，他的脸色苍白，鼻子冰冷（但仍在抓挠），她伸出软弱的食指，在乔治先生的背上戳了一下。士兵抬起头，她又戳了戳她尊敬的祖父，这样就把他们聚集在一起，僵硬地盯着火。

‘Aye, aye! Ho, ho! U—u—u—ugh!’ chatters Grandfather Smallweed, swallowing his rage. ‘My dear friend!’ (still clawing).
'好的好的！嗬嗬！ “呃——呃——呃——呃！”斯莫威德祖父喋喋不休地说着，吞下了怒火。 “我亲爱的朋友！”（仍然抓着）。

‘I tell you what,’ says Mr. George. ‘If you want to converse with me, you must speak out. I am one of the roughs, and I can’t go about and about. I haven’t the art to do it. I am not clever enough. It don’t suit me. When you go winding round and round me,’ says the trooper, putting his pipe between his lips again, ‘damme, if I don’t feel as if I was being smothered!’
“我告诉你吧，”乔治先生说。 ‘如果你想和我说话，你就必须说出来。我是粗暴的人之一，我不能到处走走。我没有能力做到这一点。我不够聪明。它不适合我。当你绕着我转了一圈又一圈时，”士兵再次将烟斗放在嘴唇之间说道，“该死，如果我不觉得自己快要窒息了！”

And he inflates his broad chest to its utmost extent as if to assure himself that he is not smothered yet.
他将宽阔的胸膛膨胀到最大程度，仿佛在向自己保证自己还没有窒息。

‘If you have come to give me a friendly call,’ continues Mr. George, ‘I am obliged to you; how are you? If you have come to see whether there’s any property on the premises, look about you; you are welcome. If you want to out with something, out with it!’
“如果你来给我一个友好的拜访，”乔治先生继续说道，“我很感激你；你好吗？如果您来查看该处所是否有任何财产，请看看您的周围；不客气。如果你想出去做点什么，那就出去吧！

The blooming Judy, without removing her gaze from the fire, gives her grandfather one ghostly poke.
盛开的朱迪的目光没有从火上移开，幽灵般地戳了她祖父一记。

‘You see! It’s her opinion too. And why the devil that young woman won’t sit down like a Christian,’ says Mr. George with his eyes musingly fixed on Judy, ‘I can’t comprehend.’
'你看！这也是她的意见。为什么那个年轻女子不肯像基督徒那样坐下来，”乔治先生说道，他的眼睛若有所思地盯着朱迪，“我无法理解。”

‘She keeps at my side to attend to me, sir,’ says Grandfather Smallweed. ‘I am an old man, my dear Mr. George, and I need some attention. I can carry my years; I am not a brimstone poll-parrot’ (snarling and looking unconsciously for the cushion), ‘but I need attention, my dear friend.’
“她一直在我身边照顾我，先生，”斯莫威德祖父说道。 “我是个老人了，亲爱的乔治先生，我需要一些照顾。我可以承载我的岁月；我不是一只硫磺鹦鹉”（咆哮着，无意识地寻找垫子），“但我需要关注，我亲爱的朋友。”

‘Well!’ returns the trooper, wheeling his chair to face the old man. ‘Now then?’
“好吧！”士兵回答道，转动椅子面向老人。 '接着？'

‘My friend in the city, Mr. George, has done a little business with a pupil of yours.’
“我在城里的朋友乔治先生和你的一个学生做了一笔小生意。”

‘Has he?’ says Mr. George. ‘I am sorry to hear it.’
“他有吗？”乔治先生说。 “听到这个消息我很遗憾。”

‘Yes, sir.’ Grandfather Smallweed rubs his legs. ‘He is a fine young soldier now, Mr. George, by the name of Carstone. Friends came forward and paid it all up, honourable.’
“是的，先生。”斯莫威德爷爷揉着腿。 “乔治先生，他现在是一名优秀的年轻士兵，名叫卡斯通。朋友们挺身而出，付清了全部费用，很荣幸。”

‘Did they?’ returns Mr. George. ‘Do you think your friend in the city would like a piece of advice?’
“是吗？”乔治先生回答道。 “你认为你在城里的朋友愿意听听建议吗？”

‘I think he would, my dear friend. From you.’
“我想他会的，我亲爱的朋友。来自你。

‘I advise him, then, to do no more business in that quarter. There’s no more to be got by it. The young gentleman, to my knowledge, is brought to a dead halt.’
“那么，我建议他在那个季度不要再做生意了。”再也没有什么可得到的了。据我所知，这位年轻的绅士完全停了下来。

‘No, no, my dear friend. No, no, Mr. George. No, no, no, sir,’ remonstrates Grandfather Smallweed, cunningly rubbing his spare legs. ‘Not quite a dead halt, I think. He has good friends, and he is good for his pay, and he is good for the selling price of his commission, and he is good for his chance in a lawsuit, and he is good for his chance in a wife, and—oh, do you know, Mr. George, I think my friend would consider the young gentleman good for something yet?’ says Grandfather Smallweed, turning up his velvet cap and scratching his ear like a monkey.
‘不，不，我亲爱的朋友。不，不，乔治先生。不，不，不，先生。”斯莫威德祖父狡猾地揉着他多余的腿，抗议道。 “我认为，这还不算完全停止。他有好朋友，他对他的薪水有利，他对他的佣金的售价有利，他对他打官司的机会有利，他对他娶妻子的机会有利，而且——哦“乔治先生，你知道吗，我想我的朋友会认为这位年轻的绅士有什么用处吗？”斯莫威德祖父说道，他掀起天鹅绒帽子，像猴子一样抓耳朵。

Mr. George, who has put aside his pipe and sits with an arm on his chair-back, beats a tattoo on the ground with his right foot as if he were not particularly pleased with the turn the conversation has taken.
乔治先生把烟斗放在一边，一只手臂搭在椅背上，用右脚敲打着地上的纹身，似乎对谈话的转变不太满意。

‘But to pass from one subject to another,’ resumes Mr. Smallweed. ‘‘To promote the conversation, as a joker might say. To pass, Mr. George, from the ensign to the captain.’
“但是要从一个主题转到另一个主题，”斯莫威德先生继续说道。 “正如一个小丑可能会说的那样，为了促进对话。乔治先生，从少尉转到船长。”

‘What are you up to, now?’ asks Mr. George, pausing with a frown in stroking the recollection of his moustache. ‘What captain?’
“你现在在做什么？”乔治先生问道，他皱着眉头抚摸着自己的小胡子。 “什么队长？”

‘Our captain. The captain we know of. Captain Hawdon.’
‘我们的队长。我们认识的船长。霍顿船长。”

‘Oh! That’s it, is it?’ says Mr. George with a low whistle as he sees both grandfather and granddaughter looking hard at him. ‘You are there! Well? What about it? Come, I won’t be smothered any more. Speak!’
'哦！就是这样，是吗？”乔治先生低声吹着口哨说道，因为他看到祖父和孙女都在注视着他。 '你在那里！出色地？那又怎样呢？来吧，我不会再被闷闷不乐了。说话！'

‘My dear friend,’ returns the old man, ‘I was applied—Judy, shake me up a little!—I was applied to yesterday about the captain, and my opinion still is that the captain is not dead.’
“我亲爱的朋友，”老人回答道，“我被申请了——朱迪，让我振作一点！——我昨天被申请了关于船长的事情，而我的观点仍然是船长没有死。”

‘Bosh!’ observes Mr. George.
“波什！”乔治先生评论道。

‘What was your remark, my dear friend?’ inquires the old man with his hand to his ear.
“我亲爱的朋友，你说什么？”老人用手捂着耳朵问道。

‘Bosh!’
“波什！”

‘Ho!’ says Grandfather Smallweed. ‘Mr. George, of my opinion you can judge for yourself according to the questions asked of me and the reasons given for asking ‘em. Now, what do you think the lawyer making the inquiries wants?’
“嗬！”斯莫威德爷爷说道。 '先生。乔治，我认为你可以根据我提出的问题和提出问题的原因自行判断。现在，你认为进行调查的律师想要什么？

‘A job,’ says Mr. George.
“一份工作，”乔治先生说。

‘Nothing of the kind!’
“不是这样的！”

‘Can’t be a lawyer, then,’ says Mr. George, folding his arms with an air of confirmed resolution.
“那么，就不能当律师了，”乔治先生说，他抱着双臂，一副坚定的决心。

‘My dear friend, he is a lawyer, and a famous one. He wants to see some fragment in Captain Hawdon’s writing. He don’t want to keep it. He only wants to see it and compare it with a writing in his possession.’
“我亲爱的朋友，他是一名律师，而且是一位著名的律师。他想看看霍顿船长笔下的一些片段。他不想保留它。他只想看到它并与他拥有的文字进行比较。

‘Well?’
'出色地？'

‘Well, Mr. George. Happening to remember the advertisement concerning Captain Hawdon and any information that could be given respecting him, he looked it up and came to me—just as you did, my dear friend. WILL you shake hands? So glad you came that day! I should have missed forming such a friendship if you hadn’t come!’
“好吧，乔治先生。他碰巧想起了关于霍顿船长的广告以及任何可以提供的有关他的信息，他查了一下然后来找我——就像你一样，我亲爱的朋友。你愿意握手吗？很高兴你那天来了！如果你不来，我就错过了建立这样的友谊！

‘Well, Mr. Smallweed?’ says Mr. George again after going through the ceremony with some stiffness.
“怎么样，斯莫威德先生？”乔治先生在略显僵硬地完成了仪式后再次说道。

‘I had no such thing. I have nothing but his signature. Plague pestilence and famine, battle murder and sudden death upon him,’ says the old man, making a curse out of one of his few remembrances of a prayer and squeezing up his velvet cap between his angry hands, ‘I have half a million of his signatures, I think! But you,’ breathlessly recovering his mildness of speech as Judy readjusts the cap on his skittle-ball of a head, ‘you, my dear Mr. George, are likely to have some letter or paper that would suit the purpose. Anything would suit the purpose, written in the hand.’
‘我没有这样的事。我除了他的签名什么都没有。瘟疫、饥荒、战争、谋杀和突然死亡降临在他身上，”老人说着，从他为数不多的一次祈祷的记忆中咒骂了一句，并用愤怒的双手挤压了他的天鹅绒帽子，“我有五十万我想是他的签名！但是你，”当朱迪重新调整他的九柱球头上的帽子时，气喘吁吁地恢复了他温和的言语，“你，我亲爱的乔治先生，很可能有一些适合这个目的的信或纸。任何东西都会适合目的，用手写下来。”

‘Some writing in that hand,’ says the trooper, pondering; ‘may be, I have.’
“那只手上写着一些字，”士兵沉思着说道。 “也许是，我有。”

‘My dearest friend!’
“我最亲爱的朋友！”

‘May be, I have not.’
“也许是，但我没有。”

‘Ho!’ says Grandfather Smallweed, crest-fallen.
“嗬！”斯莫威德爷爷垂头丧气地说。

‘But if I had bushels of it, I would not show as much as would make a cartridge without knowing why.’
“但如果我有几蒲式耳的它，我就不会展示出像制作墨盒那样多的东西，而且不知道为什么。”

‘Sir, I have told you why. My dear Mr. George, I have told you why.’
‘先生，我已经告诉过你原因了。我亲爱的乔治先生，我已经告诉过你原因了。

‘Not enough,’ says the trooper, shaking his head. ‘I must know more, and approve it.’
“还不够，”士兵摇摇头说道。 “我必须了解更多，并批准它。”

‘Then, will you come to the lawyer? My dear friend, will you come and see the gentleman?’ urges Grandfather Smallweed, pulling out a lean old silver watch with hands like the leg of a skeleton. ‘I told him it was probable I might call upon him between ten and eleven this forenoon, and it’s now half after ten. Will you come and see the gentleman, Mr. George?’
‘那么，你会去找律师吗？我亲爱的朋友，你能来看看这位先生吗？”斯莫威德祖父催促道，他的手就像骷髅腿一样，拿出一块瘦长的旧银表。 “我告诉他，我可能会在今天上午十点到十一点之间拜访他，而现在已经是十点半了。乔治先生，您能来看望这位先生吗？

‘Hum!’ says he gravely. ‘I don’t mind that. Though why this should concern you so much, I don’t know.’
“哼！”他严肃地说。 “我不介意这个。虽然我不知道为什么这会让你如此担心。

‘Everything concerns me that has a chance in it of bringing anything to light about him. Didn’t he take us all in? Didn’t he owe us immense sums, all round? Concern me? Who can anything about him concern more than me? Not, my dear friend,’ says Grandfather Smallweed, lowering his tone, ‘that I want YOU to betray anything. Far from it. Are you ready to come, my dear friend?’
“一切与我有关的事情都有机会揭露关于他的一切。”他没有把我们都带进去吗？他不是欠我们一大笔钱吗？关心我吗？谁能比我更关心他的事呢？我亲爱的朋友，”斯莫威德祖父压低了语气说道，“我并不希望你背叛任何事情。离得很远。我亲爱的朋友，你准备好了吗？

‘Aye! I’ll come in a moment. I promise nothing, you know.’
‘是啊！我一会儿就来。我什么也不保证，你知道的。

‘No, my dear Mr. George; no.’
“不，我亲爱的乔治先生；不。'

‘And you mean to say you’re going to give me a lift to this place, wherever it is, without charging for it?’ Mr. George inquires, getting his hat and thick wash-leather gloves.
“你的意思是说，你要载我到这个地方，无论它在哪里，而且不收费？”乔治先生问道，拿起帽子和厚厚的水洗皮手套。

This pleasantry so tickles Mr. Smallweed that he laughs, long and low, before the fire. But ever while he laughs, he glances over his paralytic shoulder at Mr. George and eagerly watches him as he unlocks the padlock of a homely cupboard at the distant end of the gallery, looks here and there upon the higher shelves, and ultimately takes something out with a rustling of paper, folds it, and puts it in his breast. Then Judy pokes Mr. Smallweed once, and Mr. Smallweed pokes Judy once.
这种客套话让斯莫威德先生很高兴，他在火堆前低声长笑。但每当他笑的时候，他就会越过瘫痪的肩膀看向乔治先生，热切地看着他打开画廊远端一个普通橱柜的挂锁，在更高的架子上到处看看，最后拿了一些东西。沙沙作响，纸被拿出来，折叠起来，放进怀里。然后朱迪戳了斯莫尔韦德先生一次，斯莫尔韦德先生也戳了朱迪一次。

‘I am ready,’ says the trooper, coming back. ‘Phil, you can carry this old gentleman to his coach, and make nothing of him.’
“我准备好了，”士兵回来后说道。 “菲尔，你可以把这位老先生带到他的马车上，而不要把他当回事。”

‘Oh, dear me! O Lord! Stop a moment!’ says Mr. Smallweed. ‘He’s so very prompt! Are you sure you can do it carefully, my worthy man?’
‘噢，亲爱的我！主啊！ “等一下！”斯莫威德先生说道。 ‘他真是太及时了！你确定你能小心翼翼地做到这一点吗，我值得尊敬的人？

Phil makes no reply, but seizing the chair and its load, sidles away, tightly bugged by the now speechless Mr. Smallweed, and bolts along the passage as if he had an acceptable commission to carry the old gentleman to the nearest volcano. His shorter trust, however, terminating at the cab, he deposits him there; and the fair Judy takes her place beside him, and the chair embellishes the roof, and Mr. George takes the vacant place upon the box.
菲尔没有回答，但抓起椅子和上面的东西，侧身走开，被现在已经说不出话的斯莫威德先生牢牢堵住，沿着通道狂奔，仿佛他有一个可以接受的委托，要把这位老绅士带到最近的火山。然而，他的信托时间较短，最终在出租车处结束，他把他安置在那里。美丽的朱迪坐在他旁边，椅子装饰着屋顶，乔治先生则占据了包厢上的空位。

Mr. George is quite confounded by the spectacle he beholds from time to time as he peeps into the cab through the window behind him, where the grim Judy is always motionless, and the old gentleman with his cap over one eye is always sliding off the seat into the straw and looking upward at him out of his other eye with a helpless expression of being jolted in the back.
乔治先生时不时地从身后的窗户往驾驶室里看去，看到的景象让他感到很困惑，里面面容严峻的朱迪总是一动不动，而那个戴着帽子遮住一只眼睛的老绅士总是从车上滑下来。坐在稻草上，用另一只眼睛向上看着他，脸上露出一种背部被摇晃的无助表情。

CHAPTER XXVII
第二十七章


More Old Soldiers Than One
老兵多于一名

Mr. George has not far to ride with folded arms upon the box, for their destination is Lincoln’s Inn Fields. When the driver stops his horses, Mr. George alights, and looking in at the window, says, ‘What, Mr. Tulkinghorn’s your man, is he?’
乔治先生抱着双臂骑在箱子上已经不远了，因为他们的目的地是林肯因菲尔兹。当车夫停下马时，乔治先生下了车，看着窗外说道：“什么，塔尔金霍恩先生是你的人，是吗？”

‘Yes, my dear friend. Do you know him, Mr. George?’
‘是的，我亲爱的朋友。乔治先生，你认识他吗？

‘Why, I have heard of him—seen him too, I think. But I don’t know him, and he don’t know me.’
“哎呀，我听说过他——我想也见过他。但我不认识他，他也不认识我。”

There ensues the carrying of Mr. Smallweed upstairs, which is done to perfection with the trooper’s help. He is borne into Mr. Tulkinghorn’s great room and deposited on the Turkey rug before the fire. Mr. Tulkinghorn is not within at the present moment but will be back directly. The occupant of the pew in the hall, having said thus much, stirs the fire and leaves the triumvirate to warm themselves.
随后，斯莫尔韦德先生被抬上楼，在警察的帮助下，这件事做得非常完美。他被抬进图金霍恩先生的大房间，放在火前的土耳其地毯上。图金霍恩先生目前不在，但会直接回来。大厅里长椅上的人说了这么多，就搅动了火，让三人组去取暖。

Mr. George is mightily curious in respect of the room. He looks up at the painted ceiling, looks round at the old law-books, contemplates the portraits of the great clients, reads aloud the names on the boxes.
乔治先生对这个房间非常好奇。他抬头看着彩绘天花板，环顾四周古老的法律书籍，凝视着大客户的肖像，大声朗读盒子上的名字。

‘‘Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,’’ Mr. George reads thoughtfully. ‘Ha! ‘Manor of Chesney Wold.’ Humph!’ Mr. George stands looking at these boxes a long while—as if they were pictures—and comes back to the fire repeating, ‘Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, and Manor of Chesney Wold, hey?’
“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，”乔治先生若有所思地读道。 '哈！ “切斯尼沃尔德庄园。”哼！”乔治先生站在那里看着这些盒子好一会儿——就好像它们是图画一样——然后回到火边重复道：“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，还有切斯尼沃尔德庄园，嘿？

‘Worth a mint of money, Mr. George!’ whispers Grandfather Smallweed, rubbing his legs. ‘Powerfully rich!’
“值一毛钱，乔治先生！”斯莫威德祖父一边低声说道，一边揉着腿。 “非常富有！”

‘Who do you mean? This old gentleman, or the Baronet?’
‘你指的是谁？这位老先生，还是准男爵？

‘This gentleman, this gentleman.’
“这位先生，这位先生。”

‘So I have heard; and knows a thing or two, I’ll hold a wager. Not bad quarters, either,’ says Mr. George, looking round again. ‘See the strong-box yonder!’
‘我听说过；并且知道一两件事，我会打赌。乔治先生再次环顾四周说道。 “看那边的保险箱！”

This reply is cut short by Mr. Tulkinghorn’s arrival. There is no change in him, of course. Rustily drest, with his spectacles in his hand, and their very case worn threadbare. In manner, close and dry. In voice, husky and low. In face, watchful behind a blind; habitually not uncensorious and contemptuous perhaps. The peerage may have warmer worshippers and faithfuller believers than Mr. Tulkinghorn, after all, if everything were known.
图金霍恩先生的到来打断了我的答复。当然，他没有任何改变。他穿着生锈的衣服，手里拿着眼镜，眼镜盒也已经破旧不堪。在方式上，紧密且干燥。声音沙哑而低沉。面对面前，在百叶窗后面保持警惕；也许习惯性地不是不挑剔和轻蔑的。毕竟，如果一切都知道的话，贵族阶层可能比图尔金霍恩先生拥有更热情的崇拜者和更忠实的信徒。

‘Good morning, Mr. Smallweed, good morning!’ he says as he comes in. ‘You have brought the sergeant, I see. Sit down, sergeant.’
“早上好，斯莫威德先生，早上好！”他进来时说道。“我明白了，你带来了中士。”坐下，中士。”

As Mr. Tulkinghorn takes off his gloves and puts them in his hat, he looks with half-closed eyes across the room to where the trooper stands and says within himself perchance, ‘You’ll do, my friend!’
当图金霍恩先生脱下手套并将其戴在帽子上时，他半闭着眼睛看着房间另一边的士兵所站的地方，心里也许在说：“你会的，我的朋友！”

‘Sit down, sergeant,’ he repeats as he comes to his table, which is set on one side of the fire, and takes his easy-chair. ‘Cold and raw this morning, cold and raw!’ Mr. Tulkinghorn warms before the bars, alternately, the palms and knuckles of his hands and looks (from behind that blind which is always down) at the trio sitting in a little semicircle before him.
“坐下，中士，”他一边重复一边走到位于火炉一侧的桌子旁，坐上安乐椅。 “今天早上又冷又冷，又冷又冷！”图金霍恩先生在栏杆前暖和了一下手掌和指关节，然后看着（从总是垂下的百叶窗后面）坐在前面围成一个小半圆的三人组。他。

‘Now, I can feel what I am about’ (as perhaps he can in two senses), ‘Mr. Smallweed.’ The old gentleman is newly shaken up by Judy to bear his part in the conversation. ‘You have brought our good friend the sergeant, I see.’
“现在，我能感受到我的存在”（也许他可以在两种意义上感受到），“先生。”老先生刚刚被朱迪摇醒，开始参与谈话。 “我明白了，你把我们的好朋友中士带来了。”

‘Yes, sir,’ returns Mr. Smallweed, very servile to the lawyer’s wealth and influence.
“是的，先生。”斯莫威德先生回答道，他对律师的财富和影响力非常臣服。

‘And what does the sergeant say about this business?’
“中士对这件事怎么说？”

‘Mr. George,’ says Grandfather Smallweed with a tremulous wave of his shrivelled hand, ‘this is the gentleman, sir.’
'先生。乔治，”斯莫威德祖父颤抖着挥动枯萎的手说道，“这就是那位绅士，先生。”

Mr. George salutes the gentleman but otherwise sits bolt upright and profoundly silent—very forward in his chair, as if the full complement of regulation appendages for a field-day hung about him.
乔治先生向这位绅士行了个礼，但除此之外，他笔直地坐着，一言不发——他的椅子非常靠前，就好像他身上挂满了野外活动所需的全套规章制度。

Mr. Tulkinghorn proceeds, ‘Well, George—I believe your name is George?’
图金霍恩先生继续说道：“好吧，乔治——我相信你的名字是乔治？”

‘It is so, Sir.’
“是这样的，先生。”

‘What do you say, George?’
“乔治，你说什么？”

‘I ask your pardon, sir,’ returns the trooper, ‘but I should wish to know what YOU say?’
“请您原谅，先生，”士兵回答道，“但我想知道您说什么？”

‘Do you mean in point of reward?’
“你是指奖励吗？”

‘I mean in point of everything, sir.’
“我指的是一切方面，先生。”

This is so very trying to Mr. Smallweed’s temper that he suddenly breaks out with ‘You’re a brimstone beast!’ and as suddenly asks pardon of Mr. Tulkinghorn, excusing himself for this slip of the tongue by saying to Judy, ‘I was thinking of your grandmother, my dear.’
这对斯莫尔韦德先生的脾气来说太令人恼火了，他突然爆发出“你是一头硫磺野兽！”，并突然向图金霍恩先生请求原谅，他对朱迪说：“我为自己的失言道歉。”我在想你的祖母，亲爱的。”

‘I supposed, sergeant,’ Mr. Tulkinghorn resumes as he leans on one side of his chair and crosses his legs, ‘that Mr. Smallweed might have sufficiently explained the matter. It lies in the smallest compass, however. You served under Captain Hawdon at one time, and were his attendant in illness, and rendered him many little services, and were rather in his confidence, I am told. That is so, is it not?’
“我想，中士，”塔尔金霍恩先生靠在椅子的一侧，盘起双腿，继续说道，“斯莫威德先生可能已经充分解释了此事。然而，它位于最小的罗盘中。我听说，你曾在霍顿上尉麾下服役，在他生病时担任他的侍从，为他提供了许多小服务，并且相当信任他。是这样，不是吗？

‘Yes, sir, that is so,’ says Mr. George with military brevity.
“是的，先生，确实如此，”乔治先生用军事般的简洁语气说道。

‘Therefore you may happen to have in your possession something— anything, no matter what; accounts, instructions, orders, a letter, anything—in Captain Hawdon’s writing. I wish to compare his writing with some that I have. If you can give me the opportunity, you shall be rewarded for your trouble. Three, four, five, guineas, you would consider handsome, I dare say.’
‘因此，你可能碰巧拥有一些东西——任何东西，无论是什么；账目、指示、命令、一封信，任何东西——都是霍顿上尉写的。我想将他的作品与我的一些作品进行比较。如果你能给我这个机会，你的辛苦就会得到回报。三、四、五几尼，我敢说你会认为很帅。

‘Noble, my dear friend!’ cries Grandfather Smallweed, screwing up his eyes.
“高贵的，我亲爱的朋友！”斯莫威德祖父眯着眼睛喊道。

‘If not, say how much more, in your conscience as a soldier, you can demand. There is no need for you to part with the writing, against your inclination—though I should prefer to have it.’
“如果没有，请说一下，以你作为一名士兵的良心，你还可以要求多少。”你没有必要违背自己的意愿而放弃写作——尽管我更愿意拥有它。

Mr. George sits squared in exactly the same attitude, looks at the painted ceiling, and says never a word. The irascible Mr. Smallweed scratches the air.
乔治先生以完全相同的姿势端正地坐着，看着彩绘的天花板，一言不发。暴躁的斯莫威德先生在空中抓挠。

‘The question is,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn in his methodical, subdued, uninterested way, ‘first, whether you have any of Captain Hawdon’s writing?’
“问题是，”图金霍恩先生以他有条不紊、克制的、不感兴趣的方式说道，“首先，你有没有霍登船长的作品？”

‘First, whether I have any of Captain Hawdon’s writing, sir,’ repeats Mr. George.
“首先，先生，我是否有霍登船长的著作，”乔治先生重复道。

‘Secondly, what will satisfy you for the trouble of producing it?’
“第二，什么能让你在制作它时费尽心思？”

‘Secondly, what will satisfy me for the trouble of producing it, sir,’ repeats Mr. George.
“第二，先生，有什么能让我在制作它时感到满意，”乔治先生重复道。

‘Thirdly, you can judge for yourself whether it is at all like that,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, suddenly handing him some sheets of written paper tied together.
“第三，你可以自己判断是否真的如此，”图尔金霍恩先生说，突然递给他几张绑在一起的纸。

‘Whether it is at all like that, sir. Just so,’ repeats Mr. George.
“到底是不是这样，先生。正是如此，”乔治先生重复道。

All three repetitions Mr. George pronounces in a mechanical manner, looking straight at Mr. Tulkinghorn; nor does he so much as glance at the affidavit in Jarndyce and Jarndyce, that has been given to him for his inspection (though he still holds it in his hand), but continues to look at the lawyer with an air of troubled meditation.
乔治先生直视图尔金霍恩先生，以机械的方式重复了这三遍。他也没有看一眼交给他供他检查的《贾迪斯和贾迪斯》的宣誓书（尽管他手里还拿着它），而是继续带着一种困扰的沉思的神情看着律师。

‘Well?’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn. ‘What do you say?’
“怎么样？”图金霍恩先生说。 '你怎么说？'

‘Well, sir,’ replies Mr. George, rising erect and looking immense, ‘I would rather, if you’ll excuse me, have nothing to do with this.’
“好吧，先生，”乔治先生回答道，他站直了身子，看上去身材高大，“请原谅，我宁愿与这件事无关。”

Mr. Tulkinghorn, outwardly quite undisturbed, demands, ‘Why not?’
图金霍恩先生表面上很平静，问道：“为什么不呢？”

‘Why, sir,’ returns the trooper. ‘Except on military compulsion, I am not a man of business. Among civilians I am what they call in Scotland a ne’er-do-weel. I have no head for papers, sir. I can stand any fire better than a fire of cross questions. I mentioned to Mr. Smallweed, only an hour or so ago, that when I come into things of this kind I feel as if I was being smothered. And that is my sensation,’ says Mr. George, looking round upon the company, ‘at the present moment.’
“为什么，长官，”士兵回答道。 “除非出于军事强制，我不是一个商人。在苏格兰，我是平民中的“无赖”。先生，我没有心思去找文件。我能忍受任何火，而不是交叉问题的火。大约一个小时前，我向斯莫威德先生提到，当我遇到这类事情时，我感觉自己好像被窒息了。 “这就是我的感觉，”乔治先生环视着公司说道，“此时此刻。”

With that, he takes three strides forward to replace the papers on the lawyer’s table and three strides backward to resume his former station, where he stands perfectly upright, now looking at the ground and now at the painted ceillhg, with his hands behind him as if to prevent himself from accepting any other document whatever.
说完，他向前三步放回律师桌上的文件，又向后三步恢复原来的姿势，笔直地站着，时而看着地面，时而看着彩绘的天花板，双手放在身后，如果为了阻止自己接受任何其他文件。

Under this provocation, Mr. Smallweed’s favourite adjective of disparagement is so close to his tongue that he begins the words ‘my dear friend’ with the monosyllable ‘brim,’ thus converting the possessive pronoun into brimmy and appearing to have an impediment in his speech. Once past this difficulty, however, he exhorts his dear friend in the tenderest manner not to be rash, but to do what so eminent a gentleman requires, and to do it with a good grace, confident that it must be unobjectionable as well as profitable. Mr. Tulkinghorn merely utters an occasional sentence, as, ‘You are the best judge of your own interest, sergeant.’ ‘Take care you do no harm by this.’ ‘Please yourself, please yourself.’ ‘If you know what you mean, that’s quite enough.’ These he utters with an appearance of perfect indifference as he looks over the papers on his table and prepares to write a letter.
在这种挑衅下，斯莫尔威德先生最喜欢的贬义形容词离他的舌头如此之近，以至于他在“我亲爱的朋友”这个词的开头加上了单音节的“brim”，从而将所有格代词变成了“brimmy”，并且在他的讲话中显得有障碍。 。然而，一旦克服了这个困难，他就会以最温柔的方式劝告他亲爱的朋友不要鲁莽，而是要做一位杰出的绅士所要求的事情，并且要以一种优雅的态度去做，相信这一定不会令人反感，而且有利可图。 。图金霍恩先生只是偶尔说一句，“中士，你是自己利益的最佳判断者。”“小心，不要因此造成伤害。”“取悦你自己，取悦你自己。”“如果你知道你要做什么意思是，这就够了。”他一边说着，一边满不在乎地看着桌上的文件，准备写信。

Mr. George looks distrustfully from the painted ceiling to the ground, from the ground to Mr. Smallweed, from Mr. Smallweed to Mr. Tulkinghorn, and from Mr. Tulkinghorn to the painted ceiling again, often in his perplexity changing the leg on which he rests.
乔治先生怀疑地从彩绘天花板看向地面，从地面看向斯莫威德先生，从斯莫威德先生看向图尔金霍恩先生，然后又从图金霍恩先生看向彩绘天花板，常常在困惑中变换着腿。他休息了。

‘I do assure you, sir,’ says Mr. George, ‘not to say it offensively, that between you and Mr. Smallweed here, I really am being smothered fifty times over. I really am, sir. I am not a match for you gentlemen. Will you allow me to ask why you want to see the captain’s hand, in the case that I could find any specimen of it?’
“我向你保证，先生，”乔治先生说，“这并不是冒犯性的，在你和斯莫威德先生之间，我真的被窒息了五十次。我真的是，先生。我不是你们这些先生们的对手。你能允许我问一下，如果我能找到任何样本的话，你为什么想看船长的手呢？

Mr. Tulkinghorn quietly shakes his head. ‘No. If you were a man of business, sergeant, you would not need to be informed that there are confidential reasons, very harmless in themselves, for many such wants in the profession to which I belong. But if you are afraid of doing any injury to Captain Hawdon, you may set your mind at rest about that.’
图金霍恩先生静静地摇摇头。 '不。如果你是一个商人，中士，你就不需要被告知，在我所属的行业中，有许多这样的需求，其中有一些保密的原因，这些原因本身是无害的。但如果你害怕对霍顿船长造成任何伤害，你可以放心。

‘Aye! He is dead, sir.’
‘是啊！他死了，先生。”

‘IS he?’ Mr. Tulkinghorn quietly sits down to write.
“是他吗？”图金霍恩先生静静地坐下来写。

‘Well, sir,’ says the trooper, looking into his hat after another disconcerted pause, ‘I am sorry not to have given you more satisfaction. If it would be any satisfaction to any one that I should be confirmed in my judgment that I would rather have nothing to do with this by a friend of mine who has a better head for business than I have, and who is an old soldier, I am willing to consult with him. I—I really am so completely smothered myself at present,’ says Mr. George, passing his hand hopelessly across his brow, ‘that I don’t know but what it might be a satisfaction to me.’
“好吧，先生，”士兵又困惑地停顿了一下，然后看着自己的帽子说道，“很抱歉没有让您更加满意。如果我的一位朋友能够证实我的判断，即我宁愿与这件事无关，他对商业的头脑比我更好，而且是一名老兵，如果这能让任何人感到满意的话，我愿意与他协商。我——我现在真的完全窒息了，”乔治先生绝望地用手抚过额头，说道，“我不知道这对我来说可能是一种满足。”

Mr. Smallweed, hearing that this authority is an old soldier, so strongly inculcates the expediency of the trooper’s taking counsel with him, and particularly informing him of its being a question of five guineas or more, that Mr. George engages to go and see him. Mr. Tulkinghorn says nothing either way.
斯莫尔韦德先生听说这位权威是一位老兵，便极力劝说士兵与他商量是有利的，特别是告诉他这是一个五基尼或更多的问题，乔治先生答应去看看他。不管怎样，图金霍恩先生什么也没说。

‘I’ll consult my friend, then, by your leave, sir,’ says the trooper, ‘and I’ll take the liberty of looking in again with the final answer in the course of the day. Mr. Smallweed, if you wish to be carried downstairs—‘
“那么，请允许，先生，我会咨询我的朋友，”士兵说，“我会在当天再次查看最终答案。”斯莫威德先生，如果你想被抱下楼——”

‘In a moment, my dear friend, in a moment. Will you first let me speak half a word with this gentleman in private?’
‘一会儿，我亲爱的朋友，一会儿。你能先让我和这位先生私下说半句话吗？

‘Certainly, sir. Don’t hurry yourself on my account.’ The trooper retires to a distant part of the room and resumes his curious inspection of the boxes, strong and otherwise.
'当然，先生。别为了我而着急。”巡警退到房间的一个远处，继续好奇地检查盒子，无论是坚固的还是其他的。

‘If I wasn’t as weak as a brimstone baby, sir,’ whispers Grandfather Smallweed, drawing the lawyer down to his level by the lapel of his coat and flashing some half-quenched green fire out of his angry eyes, ‘I’d tear the writing away from him. He’s got it buttoned in his breast. I saw him put it there. Judy saw him put it there. Speak up, you crabbed image for the sign of a walkingstick shop, and say you saw him put it there!’
“如果我不像一个硫磺婴儿那么虚弱，先生，”斯莫威德祖父低声说道，拉着律师的外套翻领，将律师拉到与他同高的位置，愤怒的眼睛里闪出了半熄灭的绿色火焰，“我” d 把字从他身上撕下来。他把它扣在胸前。我看到他把它放在那里。朱迪看到他把它放在那里。大声说出来，你在拐杖店的招牌上抓了个图片，还说你看到他把它放在那里了！

This vehement conjuration the old gentleman accompanies with such a thrust at his granddaughter that it is too much for his strength, and he slips away out of his chair, drawing Mr. Tulkinghorn with him, until he is arrested by Judy, and well shaken.
老绅士在这种强烈的咒语中伴随着对孙女的猛烈一击，以至于他的力气太大了，他从椅子上滑了下来，拉着图金霍恩先生，直到他被朱迪逮捕，浑身发抖。

‘Violence will not do for me, my friend,’ Mr. Tulkinghorn then remarks coolly.
“我的朋友，暴力对我不起作用，”图尔金霍恩先生随后冷静地说道。

‘No, no, I know, I know, sir. But it’s chafing and galling—it’s— it’s worse than your smattering chattering magpie of a grandmother,’ to the imperturbable Judy, who only looks at the fire, ‘to know he has got what’s wanted and won’t give it up. He, not to give it up! HE! A vagabond! But never mind, sir, never mind. At the most, he has only his own way for a little while. I have him periodically in a vice. I’ll twist him, sir. I’ll screw him, sir. If he won’t do it with a good grace, I’ll make him do it with a bad one, sir! Now, my dear Mr. George,’ says Grandfather Smallweed, winking at the lawyer hideously as he releases him, ‘I am ready for your kind assistance, my excellent friend!’
