“不，不，我知道，我知道，先生。但这是令人恼火和恼怒的——这——比你那叽叽喳喳的祖母喜鹊更糟糕，”对于镇静的朱迪来说，她只看着火，“知道他已经得到了想要的东西，而且不会放弃。他，不放弃！他！一个流浪汉！但没关系，先生，没关系。至多，他也只能随心所欲地走一小会儿。我时常让他陷入恶习。我会扭转他，先生。我会操他的，先生。如果他不以善意的方式去做，我就让他以坏的方式去做，先生！现在，我亲爱的乔治先生，”斯莫威德祖父放开律师时，一边可怕地对他眨了眨眼睛，“我已经准备好接受你的帮助了，我的好朋友！”

Mr. Tulkinghorn, with some shadowy sign of amusement manifesting itself through his self-possession, stands on the hearth-rug with his back to the fire, watching the disappearance of Mr. Smallweed and acknowledging the trooper’s parting salute with one slight nod.
图金霍恩先生的镇静中流露出一丝隐隐的乐趣，他站在炉边地毯上，背对着炉火，看着斯莫威德先生消失，并轻轻点头向士兵告别敬礼。

It is more difficult to get rid of the old gentleman, Mr. George finds, than to bear a hand in carrying him downstairs, for when he is replaced in his conveyance, he is so loquacious on the subject of the guineas and retains such an affectionate hold of his button —having, in truth, a secret longing to rip his coat open and rob him—that some degree of force is necessary on the trooper’s part to effect a separation. It is accomplished at last, and he proceeds alone in quest of his adviser.
乔治先生发现，摆脱这位老绅士比扶着他下楼更困难，因为当他被替换上车时，他对基尼的话题是如此滔滔不绝，并且保留着这样的态度。深情地抓住他的纽扣——事实上，他暗自渴望撕开他的外套并抢劫他——士兵需要一定程度的力量才能实现分离。事情终于完成了，他独自一人前去寻找他的顾问。

By the cloisterly Temple, and by Whitefriars (there, not without a glance at Hanging-Sword Alley, which would seem to be something in his way), and by Blackfriars Bridge, and Blackfriars Road, Mr. George sedately marches to a street of little shops lying somewhere in that ganglion of roads from Kent and Surrey, and of streets from the bridges of London, centring in the far-famed elephant who has lost his castle formed of a thousand four-horse coaches to a stronger iron monster than he, ready to chop him into mince-meat any day he dares. To one of the little shops in this street, which is a musician’s shop, having a few fiddles in the window, and some Pan’s pipes and a tambourine, and a triangle, and certain elongated scraps of music, Mr. George directs his massive tread. And halting at a few paces from it, as he sees a soldierly looking woman, with her outer skirts tucked up, come forth with a small wooden tub, and in that tub commence a-whisking and a-splashing on the margin of the pavement, Mr. George says to himself, ‘She’s as usual, washing greens. I never saw her, except upon a baggage-waggon, when she wasn’t washing greens!’
穿过修道院般的圣殿，经过怀特修士（在那里，他不时瞥了一眼悬剑巷，这似乎是他的阻碍），经过黑衣修士桥和黑衣修士路，乔治先生平静地走向一条街道。小商店位于从肯特郡和萨里郡到伦敦桥梁的街道的某个地方，以著名的大象为中心，它已经把由一千辆四马车组成的城堡丢给了一个比他更强大的铁怪物。随时准备把他砍成肉末。乔治先生迈着大步，走向这条街上的一家小商店，那是一家音乐家商店，橱窗里有几把小提琴、一些潘氏管子、一个手鼓、一个三角钢琴和一些拉长的音乐片段。 。他在离它几步远的地方停下来，看到一个士兵般的女人，她的外裙卷起来，拿着一个小木桶走出来，在木桶里开始在人行道边缘上“拂尘”和“泼水”。 ”，乔治先生自言自语道，“她像往常一样，在洗蔬菜。我从来没有见过她，除了在行李车上，当她不洗蔬菜的时候！

The subject of this reflection is at all events so occupied in washing greens at present that she remains unsuspicious of Mr. George’s approach until, lifting up herself and her tub together when she has poured the water off into the gutter, she finds him standing near her. Her reception of him is not flattering.
无论如何，这次反思的主题目前正忙于清洗蔬菜，以至于她对乔治先生的到来仍然没有怀疑，直到她把水倒进排水沟后，一起抬起自己和浴缸，发现乔治先生站在附近她。她对他的接待并不讨人喜欢。

‘George, I never see you but I wish you was a hundred mile away!’
“乔治，我从来没有见过你，但我希望你在一百英里之外！”

The trooper, without remarking on this welcome, follows into the musical-instrument shop, where the lady places her tub of greens upon the counter, and having shaken hands with him, rests her arms upon it.
士兵没有对这种欢迎表示欢迎，跟着走进了乐器店，那位女士把她的一桶蔬菜放在柜台上，与他握手后，把手臂放在上面。

‘I never,’ she says, ‘George, consider Matthew Bagnet safe a minute when you’re near him. You are that resfless and that roving—‘
“我从来没有，”她说，“乔治，当你靠近马修·巴格尼特时，他会认为他是安全的。”你就是那么焦躁、那么游荡——”

‘Yes! I know I am, Mrs. Bagnet. I know I am.’
'是的！我知道我是，巴格内特夫人。我知道我是。'

‘You know you are!’ says Mrs. Bagnet. ‘What’s the use of that? WHY are you?’
“你知道你是！”巴格内特夫人说。 ‘那有什么用？你为什么？'

‘The nature of the animal, I suppose,’ returns the trooper goodhumouredly.
“我想，这就是动物的本性。”士兵幽默地回答道。

‘Ah!’ cries Mrs. Bagnet, something shrilly. ‘But what satisfaction will the nature of the animal be to me when the animal shall have tempted my Mat away from the musical business to New Zealand or Australey?’
“啊！”巴格内特太太尖声叫道。 “但是，当动物诱惑我的马特离开音乐事业去新西兰或澳大利亚时，动物的天性会给我带来什么满足呢？”

Mrs. Bagnet is not at all an ill-looking woman. Rather largeboned, a little coarse in the grain, and freckled by the sun and wind which have tanned her hair upon the forehead, but healthy, wholesome, and bright-eyed. A strong, busy, active, honest-faced woman of from forty-five to fifty. Clean, hardy, and so economically dressed (though substantially) that the only article of ornament of which she stands possessed appear’s to be her wedding-ring, around which her finger has grown to be so large since it was put on that it will never come off again until it shall mingle with Mrs. Bagnet’s dust.
巴格内特太太一点也不难看。她的骨骼相当粗大，纹理有些粗糙，额头上的头发被阳光和风晒黑了，脸上布满了雀斑，但她很健康，身体健康，眼睛明亮。一位坚强、忙碌、活跃、诚实的女性，年龄在四十五岁到五十岁之间。干净、耐操，穿着也很经济（虽然很简朴），她唯一拥有的装饰品似乎就是她的结婚戒指，自从戴上戒指以来，她的手指已经变得如此之大，以至于永远不会再戴上。再次脱落，直到它与巴格内特太太的灰尘混合在一起。

‘Mrs. Bagnet,’ says the trooper, ‘I am on my parole with you. Mat will get no harm from me. You may trust me so far.’
'太太。巴格内特，”士兵说，“我和你一起假释。马特不会受到我的伤害。到目前为止你可以相信我。

‘Well, I think I may. But the very looks of you are unsettling,’ Mrs. Bagnet rejoins. ‘Ah, George, George! If you had only settled down and married Joe Pouch’s widow when he died in North America, SHE’D have combed your hair for you.’
” “嗯，我想我可以。但你的样子就令人不安，”巴格内特夫人反驳道。 ‘啊，乔治，乔治！如果乔·普奇在北美去世时你才安定下来并娶了他的遗孀，她就会为你梳理头发。

‘It was a chance for me, certainly,’ returns the trooper half laughingly, half seriously, ‘but I shall never settle down into a respectable man now. Joe Pouch’s widow might have done me good— there was something in her, and something of her—but I couldn’t make up my mind to it. If I had had the luck to meet with such a wife as Mat found!’
“当然，这对我来说是一个机会，”士兵半笑半认真地回答道，“但我现在永远不会成为一个受人尊敬的人了。”乔·普奇的遗孀也许对我有好处——她身上有某种东西，她身上有某种东西——但我无法下定决心。如果我有幸遇到麦特这样的妻子就好了！

Mrs. Bagnet, who seems in a virtuous way to be under little reserve with a good sort of fellow, but to be another good sort of fellow herself for that matter, receives this compliment by flicking Mr. George in the face with a head of greens and taking her tub into the little room behind the shop.
巴格内特太太看上去很善良，对一个好人没有什么保留，但在这件事上她自己也是一个好人，她用头轻弹乔治先生的脸来接受这一赞美。蔬菜，然后把她的浴缸带到商店后面的小房间里。

‘Why, Quebec, my poppet,’ says George, following, on invitation, into that department. ‘And little Malta, too! Come and kiss your Bluffy!’
“为什么，魁北克，我的宝贝，”乔治应邀进入那个部门说道。 “还有小马耳他！”来亲吻你的Bluffy吧！

These young ladies—not supposed to have been actually christened by the names applied to them, though always so called in the family from the places of their birth in barracks—are respectively employed on three-legged stools, the younger (some five or six years old) in learning her letters out of a penny primer, the elder (eight or nine perhaps) in teaching her and sewing with great assiduity. Both hail Mr. George with acclamations as an old friend and after some kissing and romping plant their stools beside him.
这些年轻女士——实际上不应该按照她们的名字来命名，尽管在家里总是根据她们在军营中的出生地来称呼——分别坐在三足凳子上，年纪较小的（大约有五六岁）几岁）用便士入门书学习她的字母，年长者（也许八九岁）非常刻苦地教她缝纫。两人欢呼雀跃地向乔治先生致敬，称其为老朋友，在亲吻和嬉戏一番后，他们把凳子放在他旁边。

‘And how’s young Woolwich?’ says Mr. George.
“年轻的伍尔维奇怎么样？”乔治先生说。

‘Ah! There now!’ cries Mrs. Bagnet, turning about from her saucepans (for she is cooking dinner) with a bright flush on her face. ‘Would you believe it? Got an engagement at the theayter, with his father, to play the fife in a military piece.’
'啊！现在！”巴格内特太太喊道，她从平底锅里转过身来（因为她正在做晚饭），脸上泛着红晕。 ‘你相信吗？和他的父亲在剧院约好，在一部军事作品中吹奏横笛。

‘Well done, my godson!’ cries Mr. George, slapping his thigh.
“干得好，我的教子！”乔治先生拍着大腿喊道。

‘I believe you!’ says Mrs. Bagnet. ‘He’s a Briton. That’s what Woolwich is. A Briton!’
“我相信你！”巴格内特夫人说。 “他是英国人。这就是伍尔维奇。一个英国人！’

‘And Mat blows away at his bassoon, and you’re respectable civilians one and all,’ says Mr. George. ‘Family people. Children growing up. Mat’s old mother in Scotland, and your old father somewhere else, corresponded with, and helped a little, and—well, well! To be sure, I don’t know why I shouldn’t be wished a hundred mile away, for I have not much to do with all this!’
“马特吹着他的巴松管，你们都是受人尊敬的平民，”乔治先生说。 ‘家人。孩子们长大了。麦特在苏格兰的老母亲，和你在其他地方的老父亲，互相通信，也提供了一些帮助，而且——好吧，好吧！可以肯定的是，我不知道为什么我不应该在一百英里之外被祝福，因为我与这一切没有多大关系！

Mr. George is becoming thoughtful, sitting before the fire in the whitewashed room, which has a sanded floor and a barrack smell and contains nothing superfluous and has not a visible speck of dirt or dust in it, from the faces of Quebec and Malta to the bright tin pots and pannikins upon the dresser shelves—Mr. George is becoming thoughtful, sitting here while Mrs. Bagnet is busy, when Mr. Bagnet and young Woolwich opportunely come home. Mr. Bagnet is an exartilleryman, tall and upright, with shaggy eyebrows and whiskers like the fibres of a coco-nut, not a hair upon his head, and a torrid complexion. His voice, short, deep, and resonant, is not at all unlike the tones of the instrument to which he is devoted. Indeed there may be generally observed in him an unbending, unyielding, brass-bound air, as if he were himself the bassoon of the human orchestra. Young Woolwich is the type and model of a young drummer.
乔治先生坐在粉刷成白色的房间里的炉火前，陷入了沉思。房间里铺着沙子地板，散发着营房的味道，没有任何多余的东西，里面没有任何可见的污垢或灰尘，从魁北克和马耳他的脸上到梳妆台架上明亮的锡锅和煎锅——先生。当巴格尼特太太忙着的时候，乔治正变得若有所思，这时巴格尼特先生和年轻的伍尔维奇正好回家了。巴格内特先生是一名退伍军人，身材高大挺拔，眉毛浓密，胡须像椰子纤维一样，头上一根头发也没有，肤色火热。他的声音短促、低沉、洪亮，与他所钟爱的乐器的音色完全不同。事实上，在他身上通常可以看到一种不屈不挠、不屈不挠、铜管束缚的气质，就好像他自己就是人类管弦乐队的巴松管一样。 Young Woolwich 是年轻鼓手的类型和典范。

Both father and son salute the trooper heartily. He saying, in due season, that he has come to advise with Mr. Bagnet, Mr. Bagnet hospitably declares that he will hear of no business until after dinner and that his friend shall not partake of his counsel without first partaking of boiled pork and greens. The trooper yielding to this invitation, he and Mr. Bagnet, not to embarrass the domestic preparations, go forth to take a turn up and down the little street, which they promenade with measured tread and folded arms, as if it were a rampart.
父子俩都向战士们致以衷心的敬礼。他说，在适当的时候，他来向巴格内特先生提供建议，巴格内特先生热情地宣布，晚饭后他才会听到任何消息，并且他的朋友在没有先吃煮猪肉和青菜。士兵接受了这个邀请，他和巴格内特先生为了不让家里的准备工作难堪，出去在小街上来回转了一圈，他们以有节奏的步伐和交叉双臂漫步在这条街上，仿佛它是一个壁垒。

‘George,’ says Mr. Bagnet. ‘You know me. It’s my old girl that advises. She has the head. But I never own to it before her. Discipline must be maintained. Wait till the greens is off her mind. Then we’ll consult. Whatever the old girl says, do—do it!’
“乔治，”巴格内特先生说。 '你了解我。是我的老女儿给我建议的。她有头。但我从来没有在她面前承认过这一点。必须维持纪律。等到她不再关心果岭了。那我们就咨询一下。不管老姑娘说什么，就做——做！”

‘I intend to, Mat,’ replies the other. ‘I would sooner take her opinion than that of a college.’
“我打算这么做，马特，”另一个回答道。 “我更愿意接受她的意见，而不是大学的意见。”

‘College,’ returns Mr. Bagnet in short sentences, bassoon-like. ‘What college could you leave—in another quarter of the world— with nothing but a grey cloak and an umbrella—to make its way home to Europe? The old girl would do it to-morrow. Did it once!’
“学院，”巴格内特先生用巴松管般的简短句子回答道。 “在世界的另一个角落，你能离开哪一所大学，只身着一件灰色斗篷和一把雨伞，回到欧洲的家呢？”老姑娘明天就会做。做过一次！

‘You are right,’ says Mr. George.
“你是对的，”乔治先生说。

‘What college,’ pursues Bagnet, ‘could you set up in life—with two penn’orth of white lime—a penn’orth of fuller’s earth—a ha’porth of sand—and the rest of the change out of sixpence in money? That’s what the old girl started on. In the present business.’
“什么大学，”巴格内特追问，“你能用两便士的白石灰、一便士的漂白土、一哈波斯的沙子，以及剩下的六便士零钱，在生活中建立一所什么大学吗？”钱？老姑娘就是这么开始的。在目前的业务中。

‘I am rejoiced to hear it’s thriving, Mat.’
“我很高兴听到它正在蓬勃发展，马特。”

‘The old girl,’ says Mr. Bagnet, acquiescing, ‘saves. Has a stocking somewhere. With money in it. I never saw it. But I know she’s got it. Wait till the greens is off her mind. Then she’ll set you up.’
“老姑娘，”巴格内特先生默许道，“会救人。”某处有一只袜子。里面有钱。我从来没有见过它。但我知道她明白了。等到她不再关心果岭了。然后她就会给你安排。

‘She is a treasure!’ exclaims Mr. George.
“她真是个宝藏！”乔治先生惊叹道。

‘She’s more. But I never own to it before her. Discipline must be maintained. It was the old girl that brought out my musical abilities. I should have been in the artillery now but for the old girl. Six years I hammered at the fiddle. Ten at the flute. The old girl said it wouldn’t do; intention good, but want of flexibility; try the bassoon. The old girl borrowed a bassoon from the bandmaster of the Rifle Regiment. I practised in the trenches. Got on, got another, get a living by it!’
‘她更多了。但我从来没有在她面前承认过这一点。必须维持纪律。正是那个老女孩激发了我的音乐才能。如果没有那个老姑娘，我现在应该在炮兵营里了。我拉小提琴六年了。长笛十。老姑娘说不行，不行。意图良好，但缺乏灵活性；尝试巴松管。老姑娘向步枪团的乐队指挥借了一支巴松管。我在战壕里练习过。继续前进，再找一个，靠它谋生！

George remarks that she looks as fresh as a rose and as sound as an apple.
乔治说她看起来像玫瑰一样清新，像苹果一样健全。

‘The old girl,’ says Mr. Bagnet in reply, ‘is a thoroughly fine woman. Consequently she is like a thoroughly fine day. Gets finer as she gets on. I never saw the old girl’s equal. But I never own to it before her. Discipline must be maintained!’
“这个老姑娘，”巴格内特先生回答说，“是一个非常好的女人。”因此她就像是一个非常美好的日子。随着她的进步，她变得越来越好。我从来没有见过能与老女孩匹敌的人。但我从来没有在她面前承认过这一点。必须维持纪律！”

Proceeding to converse on indifferent matters, they walk up and down the little street, keeping step and time, until summoned by Quebec and Malta to do justice to the pork and greens, over which Mrs. Bagnet, like a military chaplain, says a short grace. In the distribution of these comestibles, as in every other household duty, Mrs. Bagnet developes an exact system, sitting with every dish before her, allotting to every portion of pork its own portion of pot-liquor, greens, potatoes, and even mustard, and serving it out complete. Having likewise served out the beer from a can and thus supplied the mess with all things necessary, Mrs. Bagnet proceeds to satisfy her own hunger, which is in a healthy state. The kit of the mess, if the table furniture may be so denominated, is chiefly composed of utensils of horn and tin that have done duty in several parts of the world. Young Woolwich’s knife, in particular, which is of the oyster kind, with the additional feature of a strong shutting-up movement which frequently balks the appetite of that young musician, is mentioned as having gone in various hands the complete round of foreign service.
他们继续谈论无关紧要的事情，在小街上走来走去，保持步伐和时间，直到魁北克和马耳他召唤来公正地对待猪肉和蔬菜，对此巴格尼特夫人像一位军事牧师一样简短地说了一句优雅。在分配这些食物时，就像处理其他家务一样，巴格内特夫人制定了一套精确的系统，她面前摆着每道菜，为每份猪肉分配自己的一份锅酒、蔬菜、土豆，甚至芥末。 ，并完成服务。同样，巴格尼特夫人也从罐头里倒出了啤酒，为餐厅提供了所有必需的东西，然后继续满足她自己的饥饿感，她的饥饿感是健康的。如果餐桌家具也可以这样命名的话，那么餐具的组成部分主要是用牛角和锡制成的器具，这些器具在世界多个地方都曾使用过。尤其是年轻的伍尔维奇的那把牡蛎刀，具有强烈的闭嘴动作的附加功能，经常阻碍这位年轻音乐家的胃口，据说在整个外交服务过程中，它都在不同的手中。

The dinner done, Mrs. Bagnet, assisted by the younger branches (who polish their own cups and platters, knives and forks), makes all the dinner garniture shine as brightly as before and puts it all away, first sweeping the hearth, to the end that Mr. Bagnet and the visitor may not be retarded in the smoking of their pipes. These household cares involve much pattening and counter-pattening in the backyard and considerable use of a pail, which is finally so happy as to assist in the ablutions of Mrs. Bagnet herself. That old girl reappearing by and by, quite fresh, and sitting down to her needlework, then and only then—the greens being only then to be considered as entirely off her mind—Mr. Bagnet requests the trooper to state his case.
晚饭做好了，巴格内特夫人，在年轻的枝干（他们擦亮自己的杯子和盘子、刀叉）的协助下，让所有的晚餐用具都像以前一样闪闪发光，然后把它们全部收起来，先把炉灶打扫干净，然后放到厨房里。最终巴格内特先生和来访者不会因抽烟斗而受到阻碍。这些家庭护理工作包括在后院进行大量的打理和反打理，并大量使用水桶，最后，水桶很乐意帮助巴格内特夫人自己洗澡。那个老姑娘渐渐地又出现了，神采奕奕，坐下来做针线活，直到那时——只有到了那时，她才被认为完全不关心绿色——先生。巴格内特要求士兵陈述他的情况。

This Mr. George does with great discretion, appearing to address himself to Mr. Bagnet, but having an eye solely on the old girl all the time, as Bagnet has himself. She, equally discreet, busies herself with her needlework. The case fully stated, Mr. Bagnet resorts to his standard artifice for the maintenance of discipline.
乔治先生这样做时非常谨慎，似乎是在向巴格内特先生讲话，但他的目光始终只集中在老女孩身上，就像巴格内特本人一样。她也同样谨慎，忙着做针线活。案件充分表明，巴格内特先生运用他的标准技巧来维持纪律。

‘That’s the whole of it, is it, George?’ says he.
“这就是全部，是吗，乔治？”他说。

‘That’s the whole of it.’
“这就是全部。”

‘You act according to my opinion?’
“你按照我的意见行事？”

‘I shall be guided,’ replies George, ‘entirely by it.’
“我将完全受到它的指导，”乔治回答道。

‘Old girl,’ says Mr. Bagnet, ‘give him my opinion. You know it. Tell him what it is.’
“老姑娘，”巴格内特先生说，“告诉他我的意见。”你知道的。告诉他那是什么。

It is that he cannot have too little to do with people who are too deep for him and cannot be too careful of interference with matters he does not understand—that the plain rule is to do nothing in the dark, to be a party to nothing underhanded or mysterious, and never to put his foot where he cannot see the ground. This, in effect, is Mr. Bagnet’s opinion, as delivered through the old girl, and it so relieves Mr. George’s mind by confirming his own opinion and banishing his doubts that he composes himself to smoke another pipe on that exceptional occasion and to have a talk over old times with the whole Bagnet family, according to their various ranges of experience.
就是对那些对他来说太深的人来往不能太少，对他不了解的事情干涉不能太小心——最简单的规则就是不做任何事，不参与任何事情。卑鄙或神秘，永远不会把脚放在他看不到地面的地方。事实上，这就是巴格内特先生的意见，是通过老姑娘传达的，乔治先生确认了自己的意见，消除了疑虑，这让他的心情大为放松，他在这个特殊的场合又吸了一根烟斗，然后根据巴格内特家族的不同经验，与他们一起谈论过去的时光。

Through these means it comes to pass that Mr. George does not again rise to his full height in that parlour until the time is drawing on when the bassoon and fife are expected by a British public at the theatre; and as it takes time even then for Mr. George, in his domestic character of Bluffy, to take leave of Quebec and Malta and insinuate a sponsorial shilling into the pocket of his godson with felicitations on his success in life, it is dark when Mr. George again turns his face towards Lincoln’s Inn Fields.
通过这些手段，乔治先生在客厅里再也没有站起来，直到时间临近，英国公众在剧院等待巴松管和横笛的演奏。即使在那时，乔治先生也需要时间，以他家庭中的布拉夫角色，告别魁北克和马耳他，并暗示将赞助先令塞进他教子的口袋，祝贺他人生的成功，当乔治先生离开时，天已经黑了。乔治再次把脸转向林肯客栈球场。

‘A family home,’ he ruminates as he marches along, ‘however small it is, makes a man like me look lonely. But it’s well I never made that evolution of matrimony. I shouldn’t have been fit for it. I am such a vagabond still, even at my present time of life, that I couldn’t hold to the gallery a month together if it was a regular pursuit or if I didn’t camp there, gipsy fashion. Come! I disgrace nobody and cumber nobody; that’s something. I have not done that for many a long year!’
“一个家庭住宅，”他边走边沉思着，“无论它多么小，都会让像我这样的人显得孤独。”但还好我从未经历过婚姻的演变。我不应该适合这个。即使在我现在的生活中，我仍然是一个流浪汉，如果这是一种常规追求，或者如果我不在那里扎营，吉普赛时尚，我就无法在画廊待一个月。来！我不辱没任何人，也不妨碍任何人；就是这样。我已经很多年没有这样做了！

So he whistles it off and marches on.
于是他吹口哨继续前进。

Arrived in Lincoln’s Inn Fields and mounting Mr. Tulkinghorn’s stair, he finds the outer door closed and the chambers shut, but the trooper not knowing much about outer doors, and the staircase being dark besides, he is yet fumbling and groping about, hoping to discover a bell-handle or to open the door for himself, when Mr. Tulkinghorn comes up the stairs (quietly, of course) and angrily asks, ‘Who is that? What are you doing there?’
到达林肯客栈场，登上图金霍恩先生的楼梯，他发现外门关着，房间也关着，但士兵对外门不太了解，而且楼梯又黑，他还在摸索和摸索，希望能当图金霍恩先生走上楼梯（当然是安静地）并愤怒地问道：“那是谁？”时，他发现了一个门铃把手，或者自己开门。你在那做什么？'

‘I ask your pardon, sir. It’s George. The sergeant.’
“请您原谅，先生。是乔治。中士。

‘And couldn’t George, the sergeant, see that my door was locked?’
“乔治中士难道没看到我的门锁着吗？”

‘Why, no, sir, I couldn’t. At any rate, I didn’t,’ says the trooper, rather nettled.
“为什么，不，先生，我不能。无论如何，我没有，”士兵相当恼火地说。

‘Have you changed your mind? Or are you in the same mind?’ Mr. Tulkinghorn demands. But he knows well enough at a glance.
‘你改变主意了吗？或者你也有同样的想法？”图金霍恩先生问道。但他一看就知道了。

‘In the same mind, sir.’
“同样的想法，先生。”

‘I thought so. That’s sufficient. You can go. So you are the man,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, opening his door with the key, ‘in whose hiding-place Mr. Gridley was found?’
'我是这么想的。这就足够了。你可以走了。 “这么说，你就是那个人，”塔尔金霍恩先生用钥匙打开门说道，“格里德利先生是在他的藏身之处被发现的？”

‘Yes, I AM the man,’ says the trooper, stopping two or three stairs down. ‘What then, sir?’
“是的，我就是那个人，”警察说着，停了下来，下了两三级楼梯。 “那怎么办，先生？”

‘What then? I don’t like your associates. You should not have seen the inside of my door this morning if I had thought of your being that man. Gridley? A threatening, murderous, dangerous fellow.’
'然后怎样呢？我不喜欢你的同事。如果我想到你就是那个人，你今天早上就不会看到我的门里面了。格里德利？一个具有威胁性、凶残、危险的家伙。”

With these words, spoken in an unusually high tone for him, the lawyer goes into his rooms and shuts the door with a thundering noise.
律师以对他而言异常高的语气说出这句话，然后走进自己的房间，并以雷鸣般的声音关上门。

Mr. George takes his dismissal in great dudgeon, the greater because a clerk coming up the stairs has heard the last words of all and evidently applies them to him. ‘A pretty character to bear,’ the trooper growls with a hasty oath as he strides downstairs. ‘A threatening, murderous, dangerous fellow!’ And looking up, he sees the clerk looking down at him and marking him as he passes a lamp. This so intensifies his dudgeon that for five minutes he is in an ill humour. But he whistles that off like the rest of it and marches home to the shooting gallery.
乔治先生对他的解雇感到非常愤怒，更严重的是，因为上楼的一名职员听到了所有人的最后一句话，并且显然将它们应用到了他身上。 “真是一个可爱的性格，”士兵一边大步走下楼，一边匆匆发誓，咆哮道。 “一个具有威胁性、凶残、危险的家伙！”他抬起头，看到店员低头看着他，并在他经过一盏灯时对他做了标记。这让他更加愤怒，有五分钟的时间他心情不好。但他像其他事情一样吹了口哨，然后大步走回射击场。

CHAPTER XXVIII
第二十八章


The Ironmaster
钢铁大师

Sir Leicester Dedlock has got the better, for the time being, of the family gout and is once more, in a literal no less than in a figurative point of view, upon his legs. He is at his place in Lincolnshire; but the waters are out again on the low-lying grounds, and the cold and damp steal into Chesney Wold, though well defended, and eke into Sir Leicester’s bones. The blazing fires of faggot and coal—Dedlock timber and antediluvian forest—that blaze upon the broad wide hearths and wink in the twilight on the frowning woods, sullen to see how trees are sacrificed, do not exclude the enemy. The hot-water pipes that trail themselves all over the house, the cushioned doors and windows, and the screens and curtains fail to supply the fires’ deficiencies and to satisfy Sir Leicester’s need. Hence the fashionable intelligence proclaims one morning to the listening earth that Lady Dedlock is expected shortly to return to town for a few weeks.
莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士的家族痛风暂时痊愈了，无论从字面上还是从比喻的角度来看，他再次站起来了。他在林肯郡他的住处；但低洼处的水又涨了，寒冷和潮湿的天气悄悄侵入了切斯尼沃尔德，尽管防御严密，并渗入莱斯特爵士的骨头里。柴草和煤的熊熊火焰——戴德洛克木材和古老的森林——在宽阔的壁炉上熊熊燃烧，在暮色中在皱着眉头的树林里闪烁，阴沉地看着树木如何被牺牲，并没有排除敌人。遍布整个房子的热水管、带软垫的门窗、屏风和窗帘都无法弥补火灾的不足，也无法满足莱斯特爵士的需要。因此，时尚情报界在一天早上向全世界的听众宣布，戴德洛克夫人预计很快将返回城里几周。

It is a melancholy truth that even great men have their poor relations. Indeed great men have often more than their fair share of poor relations, inasmuch as very red blood of the superior quality, like inferior blood unlawfully shed, WILL cry aloud and WILL be heard. Sir Leicester’s cousins, in the remotest degree, are so many murders in the respect that they ‘will out.’ Among whom there are cousins who are so poor that one might almost dare to think it would have been the happier for them never to have been plated links upon the Dedlock chain of gold, but to have been made of common iron at first and done base service.
即使是伟人也有穷亲戚，这是一个令人悲伤的事实。事实上，伟人往往拥有比他们应有的贫穷关系，因为高品质的红色血液，就像非法流淌的劣等血液一样，会大声哭泣，会被听到。莱斯特爵士的表兄弟，在最遥远的程度上，是如此多的谋杀者，以至于他们“会退出”。其中有一些表兄弟是如此贫穷，以至于人们几乎敢于认为他们永远不会更幸福。链节被镀在 Dedlock 金链上，但最初是用普通铁制成的，并完成了基础服务。

Service, however (with a few limited reservations, genteel but not profitable), they may not do, being of the Dedlock dignity. So they visit their richer cousins, and get into debt when they can, and live but shabbily when they can’t, and find—the women no husbands, and the men no wives—and ride in borrowed carriages, and sit at feasts that are never of their own making, and so go through high life. The rich family sum has been divided by so many figures, and they are the something over that nobody knows what to do with.
然而，服务（有一些有限的保留，礼貌但不盈利），他们可能不会这样做，因为戴德洛克的尊严。于是，他们拜访富有的表兄弟，有能力的时候就负债，无能力的时候就过着简陋的生活，发现——女人没有丈夫，男人没有妻子——乘坐借来的马车，参加盛宴。从来都不是他们自己创造的，所以他们会经历高尚的生活。富家的钱被分割了那么多数字，已经是无人知道如何处理的东西了。

Everybody on Sir Leicester Dedlock’s side of the question and of his way of thinking would appear to be his cousin more or less. From my Lord Boodle, through the Duke of Foodle, down to Noodle, Sir Leicester, like a glorious spider, stretches his threads of relationship. But while he is stately in the cousinship of the Everybodys, he is a kind and generous man, according to his dignified way, in the cousinship of the Nobodys; and at the present time, in despite of the damp, he stays out the visit of several such cousins at Chesney Wold with the constancy of a martyr.
在问题和思维方式上站在莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士一边的每个人似乎或多或少都是他的表弟。从布德尔勋爵，到福德尔公爵，再到面条，莱斯特爵士就像一只光荣的蜘蛛，伸展着他的关系之线。但是，虽然他在“大家”的表兄弟中表现得很庄严，但从他庄严的方式来看，在“无名之辈”的表兄弟中，他是一个善良而慷慨的人。目前，尽管天气潮湿，他仍以烈士般的毅力拒绝拜访切斯尼沃尔德的几位表兄弟。

Of these, foremost in the front rank stands Volumnia Dedlock, a young lady (of sixty) who is doubly highly related, having the honour to be a poor relation, by the mother’s side, to another great family. Miss Volumnia, displaying in early life a pretty talent for cutting ornaments out of coloured paper, and also for singing to the guitar in the Spanish tongue, and propounding French conundrums in country houses, passed the twenty years of her existence between twenty and forty in a sufficiently agreeable manner. Lapsing then out of date and being considered to bore mankind by her vocal performances in the Spanish language, she retired to Bath, where she lives slenderly on an annual present from Sir Leicester and whence she makes occasional resurrections in the country houses of her cousins. She has an extensive acquaintance at Bath among appalling old gentlemen with thin legs and nankeen trousers, and is of high standing in that dreary city. But she is a little dreaded elsewhere in consequence of an indiscreet profusion in the article of rouge and persistency in an obsolete pearl necklace like a rosary of little bird’s-eggs.
其中，排在最前面的是沃伦尼娅·戴德洛克（Volumnia Dedlock），一位年轻的女士（六十岁），她有双重血统，有幸成为另一个大家庭的穷亲戚。沃伦尼亚小姐早年就表现出了用彩纸剪出装饰品的天赋，还擅长用西班牙语弹吉他，在乡间别墅里提出法语难题，她在二十岁到四十岁之间度过了她存在的二十年。一种足够令人愉快的方式。当时她已经过时了，人们认为她的西班牙语表演让人类感到厌烦，她退休到巴斯，靠莱斯特爵士每年的礼物过着拮据的生活，从那里她偶尔会在她表兄弟的乡间别墅里复活。她在巴斯结识了很多腿细、裤子粗的可怕老绅士，在这座沉闷的城市里享有很高的地位。但她在其他地方有点令人畏惧，因为她不顾一切地大量使用胭脂，并且坚持佩戴一条像小鸟蛋念珠一样的过时珍珠项链。

In any country in a wholesome state, Volumnia would be a clear case for the pension list. Efforts have been made to get her on it, and when William Buffy came in, it was fully expected that her name would be put down for a couple of hundred a year. But William Buffy somehow discovered, contrary to all expectation, that these were not the times when it could be done, and this was the first clear indication Sir Leicester Dedlock had conveyed to him that the country was going to pieces.
在任何一个健康状况良好的国家，沃伦尼亚都是养老金名单上的一个明显例子。人们已经做出了努力让她加入，当威廉·巴菲进来时，人们完全预料到她的名字每年会被记下几百美元。但威廉·巴菲不知何故发现，与所有人的预期相反，现在不是可以做到这一点的时候，这是莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士向他传达的第一个明确的迹象，即国家正在分崩离析。

There is likewise the Honourable Bob Stables, who can make warm mashes with the skill of a veterinary surgeon and is a better shot than most gamekeepers. He has been for some time particularly desirous to serve his country in a post of good emoluments, unaccompanied by any trouble or responsibility. In a wellregulated body politic this natural desire on the part of a spirited young gentleman so highly connected would be speedily recognized, but somehow William Buffy found when he came in that these were not times in which he could manage that little matter either, and this was the second indication Sir Leicester Dedlock had conveyed to him that the country was going to pieces.
同样还有尊敬的鲍勃·斯泰布尔斯，他可以用兽医的技术制作热土豆泥，而且比大多数猎场看守人的射击技术都更好。一段时间以来，他一直特别渴望担任一个高薪职位为国家服务，不伴随任何麻烦或责任。在一个管理良好的政体中，一位精力充沛的年轻绅士如此高度的人脉关系，这种自然的愿望很快就会被认识到，但不知怎的，威廉·巴菲进来后发现，现在也不是他能处理那件小事的时候，而这个这是莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士向他传达的第二个迹象，表明这个国家正在分崩离析。

The rest of the cousins are ladies and gentlemen of various ages and capacities, the major part amiable and sensible and likely to have done well enough in life if they could have overcome their cousinship; as it is, they are almost all a little worsted by it, and lounge in purposeless and listless paths, and seem to be quite as much at a loss how to dispose of themselves as anybody else can be how to dispose of them.
其余的堂兄弟姐妹都是不同年龄和能力的女士和先生，其中大部分和蔼可亲、通情达理，如果他们能够克服表兄弟姐妹的关系，他们的生活可能会做得很好。事实上，他们几乎都被它打败了，在漫无目的和无精打采的道路上闲逛，似乎像其他人一样不知如何处置自己。

In this society, and where not, my Lady Dedlock reigns supreme. Beautiful, elegant, accomplished, and powerful in her little world (for the world of fashion does not stretch ALL the way from pole to pole), her influence in Sir Leicester’s house, however haughty and indifferent her manner, is greatly to improve it and refine it. The cousins, even those older cousins who were paralysed when Sir Leicester married her, do her feudal homage; and the Honourable Bob Stables daily repeats to some chosen person between breakfast and lunch his favourite original remark, that she is the best-groomed woman in the whole stud.
在这个社会中，无论在什么地方，戴德洛克夫人都是至高无上的。她在她的小世界里美丽、优雅、多才多艺、强大（因为时尚世界并没有从一个极地延伸到另一个极点），她对莱斯特爵士家族的影响力，无论她的举止如何傲慢和冷漠，都极大地改善了它，完善它。堂兄弟们，甚至是莱斯特爵士娶她时瘫痪的那些年长的堂兄弟们，都对她表示封建的敬意。尊敬的鲍勃·马厩每天在早餐和午餐之间向某个选定的人重复他最喜欢的原创言论，即她是整个种马中最漂亮的女人。

Such the guests in the long drawing-room at Chesney Wold this dismal night when the step on the Ghost’s Walk (inaudible here, however) might be the step of a deceased cousin shut out in the cold. It is near bed-time. Bedroom fires blaze brightly all over the house, raising ghosts of grim furniture on wall and ceiling. Bedroom candlesticks bristle on the distant table by the door, and cousins yawn on ottomans. Cousins at the piano, cousins at the soda-water tray, cousins rising from the card-table, cousins gathered round the fire. Standing on one side of his own peculiar fire (for there are two), Sir Leicester. On the opposite side of the broad hearth, my Lady at her table. Volumnia, as one of the more privileged cousins, in a luxurious chair between them. Sir Leicester glancing, with magnificent displeasure, at the rouge and the pearl necklace.
在这个凄凉的夜晚，切斯尼沃尔德长长的客厅里的客人就是这样，当时幽灵步道上的脚步声（不过这里听不见）可能是已故表弟在寒冷中被关起来的脚步声。快到睡觉时间了。卧室里的火在整个房子里熊熊燃烧，墙壁和天花板上的阴森家具的幽灵升起。卧室烛台竖立在门边远处的桌子上，表兄弟在脚凳上打哈欠。表兄弟在钢琴前，表兄弟在苏打水托盘前，表兄弟从牌桌上站起来，表兄弟聚集在火边。莱斯特爵士站在他自己独特的火焰的一侧（因为有两处）。在宽阔的壁炉的对面，夫人坐在她的餐桌旁。沃伦尼亚，作为更有特权的表兄弟之一，坐在他们之间的一张豪华椅子上。莱斯特爵士非常不悦地看了一眼胭脂和珍珠项链。

‘I occasionally meet on my staircase here,’ drawls Volumnia, whose thoughts perhaps are already hopping up it to bed, after a long evening of very desultory talk, ‘one of the prettiest girls, I think, that I ever saw in my life.’
“我偶尔会在我家的楼梯上碰面，”沃伦尼娅慢吞吞地说道，经过一整夜的漫无目的的谈话后，她的思绪也许已经跳上床了，“我想，她是我一生中见过的最漂亮的女孩之一” .'

‘A PROTEGEE of my Lady’s,’ observes Sir Leicester.
“我夫人的门徒，”莱斯特爵士评论道。

‘I thought so. I felt sure that some uncommon eye must have picked that girl out. She really is a marvel. A dolly sort of beauty perhaps,’ says Miss Volumnia, reserving her own sort, ‘but in its way, perfect; such bloom I never saw!’
'我是这么想的。我确信一定有一双不寻常的眼睛认出了那个女孩。她确实是一个奇迹。也许是一种可爱的美，”沃伦尼亚小姐保留着她自己的那种美，“但就其本身而言，是完美的；我从来没有见过这样的花！

Sir Leicester, with his magnificent glance of displeasure at the rouge, appears to say so too.
莱斯特爵士对胭脂投以不满的目光，似乎也是这么说的。

‘Indeed,’ remarks my Lady languidly, ‘if there is any uncommon eye in the case, it is Mrs. Rouncewell’s, and not mine. Rosa is her discovery.’
“确实，”夫人懒洋洋地说道，“如果说这件事情有什么不寻常的地方的话，那就是朗斯韦尔夫人的眼睛，而不是我的眼睛。”罗莎是她的发现。”

‘Your maid, I suppose?’
“我想是你的女仆吧？”

‘No. My anything; pet—secretary—messenger—I don’t know what.’
'不。我的一切；宠物——秘书——信使——我不知道是什么。

‘You like to have her about you, as you would like to have a flower, or a bird, or a picture, or a poodle—no, not a poodle, though—or anything else that was equally pretty?’ says Volumnia, sympathizing. ‘Yes, how charming now! And how well that delightful old soul Mrs. Rouncewell is looking. She must be an immense age, and yet she is as active and handsome! She is the dearest friend I have, positively!’
“你喜欢她在你身边，就像你想要一朵花、一只鸟、一幅画、一只贵宾犬——不，不是贵宾犬——或者任何其他同样漂亮的东西？”沃伦尼亚说，同情。 ‘是啊，现在多么迷人啊！朗斯韦尔夫人那个令人愉快的老灵魂看起来多么好啊。她年纪一定很大了，但还是那么活泼，那么帅气！她确实是我最亲爱的朋友！

Sir Leicester feels it to be right and fitting that the housekeeper of Chesney Wold should be a remarkable person. Apart from that, he has a real regard for Mrs. Rouncewell and likes to hear her praised. So he says, ‘You are right, Volumnia,’ which Volumnia is extremely glad to hear.
莱斯特爵士认为切斯尼·沃尔德的管家应该是一位了不起的人，这是正确且恰当的。除此之外，他非常尊重朗斯韦尔夫人，喜欢听到她受到赞扬。于是他说：“你是对的，沃伦尼亚。”沃伦尼亚听到这句话非常高兴。

‘She has no daughter of her own, has she?’
“她没有自己的女儿，不是吗？”

‘Mrs. Rouncewell? No, Volumnia. She has a son. Indeed, she had two.’
'太太。朗斯韦尔？不，沃伦尼亚。她有一个儿子。事实上，她有两个。

My Lady, whose chronic malady of boredom has been sadly aggravated by Volumnia this evening, glances wearily towards the candlesticks and heaves a noiseless sigh.
今晚，沃伦妮娅不幸地加剧了​​夫人的慢性无聊病，她疲倦地看了一眼烛台，无声地叹了口气。

‘And it is a remarkable example of the confusion into which the present age has fallen; of the obliteration of landmarks, the opening of floodgates, and the uprooting of distinctions,’ says Sir Leicester with stately gloom, ‘that I have been informed by Mr. Tulkinghorn that Mrs. Rouncewell’s son has been invited to go into Parliament.’
“这是当今时代陷入混乱的一个显着例子； “地标被毁，水闸被打开，各种区别被连根拔起，”莱斯特爵士庄严地忧郁地说，“塔尔金霍恩先生告诉我，朗斯韦尔夫人的儿子已被邀请进入议会。”

Miss Volumnia utters a little sharp scream.
沃伦尼亚小姐发出一声尖锐的尖叫。

‘Yes, indeed,’ repeats Sir Leicester. ‘Into Parliament.’
“是的，确实如此，”莱斯特爵士重复道。 “进入议会。”

‘I never heard of such a thing! Good gracious, what is the man?’ exclaims Volumnia.
‘我从来没有听说过这样的事！天哪，这个人是谁？”沃伦尼亚惊呼道。

‘He is called, I believe—an—ironmaster.’ Sir Leicester says it slowly and with gravity and doubt, as not being sure but that he is called a lead-mistress or that the right word may be some other word expressive of some other relationship to some other metal.
“我相信他被称为——一位——钢铁大师。”莱斯特爵士缓慢而严肃地说道，语气中带着怀疑，似乎不确定他被称为“首席情妇”，或者正确的词可能是表达某些事物的其他词。与其他金属的其他关系。

Volumnia utters another little scream.
沃伦尼亚又发出一声小尖叫。

‘He has declined the proposal, if my information from Mr. Tulkinghorn be correct, as I have no doubt it is. Mr. Tulkinghorn being always correct and exact; still that does not,’ says Sir Leicester, ‘that does not lessen the anomaly, which is fraught with strange considerations—startling considerations, as it appears to me.’
“如果我从图尔金霍恩先生那里得到的信息是正确的话，他已经拒绝了这个提议，对此我深信不疑。”图金霍恩先生总是正确而准确；尽管如此，”莱斯特爵士说道，“这并没有减轻这种异常现象，这种异常现象充满了奇怪的考虑——在我看来，这是令人震惊的考虑。”

Miss Volumnia rising with a look candlestick-wards, Sir Leicester politely performs the grand tour of the drawing-room, brings one, and lights it at my Lady’s shaded lamp.
沃伦尼亚小姐起身，目光凝视着烛台，莱斯特爵士礼貌地参观了客厅，拿来一盏，在夫人的灯罩下点燃。

‘I must beg you, my Lady,’ he says while doing so, ‘to remain a few moments, for this individual of whom I speak arrived this evening shortly before dinner and requested in a very becoming note’—Sir Leicester, with his habitual regard to truth, dwells upon it—‘I am bound to say, in a very becoming and well-expressed note, the favour of a short interview with yourself and MYself on the subject of this young girl. As it appeared that he wished to depart tonight, I replied that we would see him before retiring.’
“我必须恳求您，我的女士，”他边说边说道，“请稍等片刻，因为我所说的这个人今晚在晚饭前不久就到达了，并以非常恰当的方式提出了请求”——莱斯特爵士，带着他的习惯性地关注真理，详述它——“我必须以一种非常恰当和表达得当的方式说，赞成就这个年轻女孩的话题对你自己和我自己进行一次简短的采访。由于他似乎想今晚离开，我回答说我们会在退休前见他。

Miss Volumnia with a third little scream takes flight, wishing her hosts—O Lud!—well rid of the—what is it?—ironmaster!
沃伦尼亚小姐第三声尖叫着飞走了，祝愿她的主人——路德啊！——顺利摆脱——那是什么？——钢铁大师！

The other cousins soon disperse, to the last cousin there. Sir Leicester rings the bell, ‘Make my compliments to Mr. Rouncewell, in the housekeeper’s apartments, and say I can receive him now.’
其他表兄弟很快就散去，来到最后一个表兄弟那里。莱斯特爵士按响了门铃，“请向管家公寓里的朗斯韦尔先生致意，并说我现在可以接待他了。”

My Lady, who has beard all this with slight attention outwardly, looks towards Mr. Rouncewell as he comes in. He is a little over fifty perhaps, of a good figure, like his mother, and has a clear voice, a broad forehead from which his dark hair has retired, and a shrewd though open face. He is a responsible-looking gentleman dressed in black, portly enough, but strong and active. Has a perfectly natural and easy air and is not in the least embarrassed by the great presence into which he comes.
夫人，留着胡须，外表上略显引人注目，当朗斯韦尔先生进来时，她看着他。他大概五十多岁，身材很好，像他的母亲一样，声音清晰，额头宽阔。他的黑发已经退去，还有一张精明但开放的脸。他是一位看上去很负责任的绅士，身穿黑衣，身材肥胖，但强壮而活跃。有着一种完全自然和轻松的气质，并且不会因为他出现在伟大的场合而感到尴尬。

‘Sir Leicester and Lady Dedlock, as I have already apologized for intruding on you, I cannot do better than be very brief. I thank you, Sir Leicester.’
“莱斯特爵士和戴德洛克夫人，我已经为打扰你们道歉了，所以我只能说得非常简短。我谢谢你，莱斯特爵士。

The head of the Dedlocks has motioned towards a sofa between himself and my Lady. Mr. Rouncewell quietly takes his seat there.
戴德洛克夫妇的首领示意他和夫人之间的一张沙发。朗斯韦尔先生静静地坐在那儿。

‘In these busy times, when so many great undertakings are in progress, people like myself have so many workmen in so many places that we are always on the flight.’
“在这个忙碌的时代，当这么多伟大的事业正在进行时，像我这样的人在这么多地方有这么多工人，我们总是在飞行中。”

Sir Leicester is content enough that the ironmaster should feel that there is no hurry there; there, in that ancient house, rooted in that quiet park, where the ivy and the moss have had time to mature, and the gnarled and warted elms and the umbrageous oaks stand deep in the fern and leaves of a hundred years; and where the sun-dial on the terrace has dumbly recorded for centuries that time which was as much the property of every Dedlock—while he lasted— as the house and lands. Sir Leicester sits down in an easy-chair, opposing his repose and that of Chesney Wold to the restless flights of ironmasters.
莱斯特爵士对此很满意，铁匠应该觉得那里并不着急。在那里，在那座古老的房子里，扎根于那个安静的公园里，那里的常春藤和苔藓已经成熟了，粗糙和疣状的榆树和丑陋的橡树深深地矗立在一百年的蕨类植物和树叶中；露台上的日晷几个世纪以来一直默默地记录着那个时间，它是每个戴德洛克的财产——只要他还在世——就像房子和土地一样。莱斯特爵士坐在安乐椅上，将他和切斯尼·沃尔德的宁静与铁艺大师们焦躁不安的飞行相反。

‘Lady Dedlock has been so kind,’ proceeds Mr. Rouncewell with a respectful glance and a bow that way, ‘as to place near her a young beauty of the name of Rosa. Now, my son has fallen in love with Rosa and has asked my consent to his proposing marriage to her and to their becoming engaged if she will take him—which I suppose she will. I have never seen Rosa until to-day, but I have some confidence in my son’s good sense—even in love. I find her what he represents her, to the best of my judgment; and my mother speaks of her with great commendation.’
“戴德洛克夫人真是太仁慈了，”朗斯韦尔先生继续说道，他毕恭毕敬地看了一眼，然后鞠了个躬，“在她身边安置了一位名叫罗莎的年轻美人。”现在，我的儿子已经爱上了罗莎，并请求我同意他向她求婚，如果她愿意接受他，他们就订婚——我想她会的。直到今天我才见过罗莎，但我对儿子的良好判断力有一定的信心——即使是在爱情方面。根据我的判断，我发现她就是他所代表的她。我母亲谈到她时给予了极大的赞扬。

‘She in all respects deserves it,’ says my Lady.
“从各方面来说，她都是应得的，”我的女士说。

‘I am happy, Lady Dedlock, that you say so, and I need not comment on the value to me of your kind opinion of her.’
“我很高兴，戴德洛克夫人，你这么说，我不需要评论你对她的善意评价对我的价值。”

‘That,’ observes Sir Leicester with unspeakable grandeur, for he thinks the ironmaster a little too glib, ‘must be quite unnecessary.’
“那，”莱斯特爵士以难以形容的威严说道，因为他认为铁匠有点太油嘴滑舌了，“肯定是完全没有必要的。”

‘Quite unnecessary, Sir Leicester. Now, my son is a very young man, and Rosa is a very young woman. As I made my way, so my son must make his; and his being married at present is out of the question. But supposing I gave my consent to his engaging himself to this pretty girl, if this pretty girl will engage herself to him, I think it a piece of candour to say at once—I am sure, Sir Leicester and Lady Dedlock, you will understand and excuse me—I should make it a condition that she did not remain at Chesney Wold. Therefore, before communicating further with my son, I take the liberty of saying that if her removal would be in any way inconvenient or objectionable, I will hold the matter over with him for any reasonable time and leave it precisely where it is.’
“完全没有必要，莱斯特爵士。现在，我的儿子是一个非常年轻的男人，罗莎是一个非常年轻的女人。正如我走自己的路一样，我的儿子也必须走他的路；而他现在结婚是不可能的。但假设我同意他与这个漂亮的女孩订婚，如果这个漂亮的女孩愿意与他订婚，我认为这是一种坦率的说法，我相信，莱斯特爵士和戴德洛克夫人，你们会理解的对不起——我应该把她不留在切斯尼沃尔德作为一个条件。因此，在与我的儿子进一步沟通之前，我冒昧地说，如果她的离开会带来任何不便或令人反感，我将在任何合理的时间内与他一起处理这件事，并将其保留在原处。

Not remain at Chesney Wold! Make it a condition! All Sir Leicester’s old misgivings relative to Wat Tyler and the people in the iron districts who do nothing but turn out by torchlight come in a shower upon his head, the fine grey hair of which, as well as of his whiskers, actually stirs with indignation.
不要留在切斯尼沃尔德！就当做一个条件吧！莱斯特爵士对沃特·泰勒和铁矿区人们的所有疑虑都在他头上倾盆而下，细小的灰发和胡须实际上都因愤怒而颤动。 。

‘Am I to understand, sir,’ says Sir Leicester, ‘and is my Lady to understand’—he brings her in thus specially, first as a point of gallantry, and next as a point of prudence, having great reliance on her sense—‘am I to understand, Mr. Rouncewell, and is my Lady to understand, sir, that you consider this young woman too good for Chesney Wold or likely to be injured by remaining here?’
“我能理解吗，先生，”莱斯特爵士说，“我的夫人也能理解吗？”他特意把她带进来，首先是出于殷勤，其次是出于谨慎，非常依赖她的感觉——“我是否可以理解，朗斯韦尔先生，我的女士是否可以理解，先生，您认为这个年轻女子对切斯尼·沃尔德来说太好了，或者留在这里可能会受伤？”

‘Certainly not, Sir Leicester,’
“当然不是，莱斯特爵士。”

‘I am glad to hear it.’ Sir Leicester very lofty indeed.
“我很高兴听到这个消息。”莱斯特爵士确实非常崇高。

‘Pray, Mr. Rouncewell,’ says my Lady, warning Sir Leicester off with the slightest gesture of her pretty hand, as if he were a fly, ‘explain to me what you mean.’
“朗斯韦尔先生，请您向我夫人解释一下您的意思，”我的夫人用她那只漂亮的手轻轻地做了个手势，警告莱斯特爵士走开，就好像他是一只苍蝇一样。

‘Willingly, Lady Dedlock. There is nothing I could desire more.’
“愿意，戴德洛克夫人。我没有什么比这更渴望的了。

Addressing her composed face, whose intelligence, however, is too quick and active to be concealed by any studied impassiveness, however habitual, to the strong Saxon face of the visitor, a picture of resolution and perseverance, my Lady listens with attention, occasionally slightly bending her head.
她那张平静的脸庞，然而，她的智慧太敏捷、太活跃，无法被任何刻意的冷漠所掩盖，无论多么习惯，对来访者坚强的撒克逊面孔，这是一幅决心和毅力的图画，我的女士全神贯注地听着，偶尔轻微地她低下头。

‘I am the son of your housekeeper, Lady Dedlock, and passed my childhood about this house. My mother has lived here half a century and will die here I have no doubt. She is one of those examples—perhaps as good a one as there is—of love, and attachment, and fidelity in such a nation, which England may well be proud of, but of which no order can appropriate the whole pride or the whole merit, because such an instance bespeaks high worth on two sides—on the great side assuredly, on the small one no less assuredly.’
“我是你管家戴德洛克夫人的儿子，我的童年是在这所房子里度过的。我的母亲在这里生活了半个世纪，我毫不怀疑她也会死在这里。她是这样一个国家中的爱、依恋和忠诚的例子之一——也许是最好的例子之一，英格兰很可能为此感到自豪，但任何秩序都不能剥夺这个国家的全部骄傲或全部。优点，因为这样的例子表明了两方面的高价值——大方面肯定如此，小方面也同样肯定。

Sir Leicester snorts a little to hear the law laid down in this way, but in his honour and his love of truth, he freely, though silently, admits the justice of the ironmaster’s proposition.
莱斯特爵士听到这样制定的法律，不禁嗤之以鼻，但出于他的荣誉和对真理的热爱，他自由地、虽然沉默地承认了铁匠的主张的正义性。

‘Pardon me for saying what is so obvious, but I wouldn’t have it hastily supposed,’ with the least turn of his eyes towards Sir Leicester, ‘that I am ashamed of my mother’s position here, or wanting in all just respect for Chesney Wold and the family. I certainly may have desired—I certainly have desired, Lady Dedlock —that my mother should retire after so many years and end her days with me. But as I have found that to sever this strong bond would be to break her heart, I have long abandoned that idea.’
“请原谅我说得这么明显，但我不会仓促地认为，”他的眼睛至少转向莱斯特爵士，“我对我母亲在这里的地位感到羞耻，或者只是想要尊重切斯尼·沃尔德和家人。我当然可能希望——我当然希望，戴德洛克夫人——我的母亲应该在这么多年之后退休，和我一起结束她的日子。但我发现切断这种牢固的联系就会让她心碎，所以我早已放弃了这个想法。

Sir Leicester very magnificent again at the notion of Mrs. Rouncewell being spirited off from her natural home to end her days with an ironmaster.
莱斯特爵士再次对朗斯韦尔夫人被偷偷离开她的家乡、结束她与铁匠的日子的想法感到非常惊叹。

‘I have been,’ proceeds the visitor in a modest, clear way, ‘an apprentice and a workman. I have lived on workman’s wages, years and years, and beyond a certain point have had to educate myself. My wife was a foreman’s daughter, and plainly brought up. We have three daughters besides this son of whom I have spoken, and being fortunately able to give them greater advantages than we have had ourselves, we have educated them well, very well. It has been one of our great cares and pleasures to make them worthy of any station.’
“我曾经是，”来访者以谦虚、清晰的方式继续说道，“我是一名学徒和工人。”我年复一年地靠工人的工资生活，超过了一定程度就必须自我教育。我的妻子是工头的女儿，从小就很朴素。除了我刚才提到的这个儿子之外，我们还有三个女儿，幸运的是，我们能够给她们比我们自己更大的优势，我们把她们教育得很好，很好。让他们配得上任何职位是我们最大的关心和快乐之一。

A little boastfulness in his fatherly tone here, as if he added in his heart, ‘even of the Chesney Wold station.’ Not a little more magnificence, therefore, on the part of Sir Leicester.
他慈父般的语气里带着一丝自夸，仿佛他在心里补充道，“甚至是切斯尼沃尔德车站。”因此，莱斯特爵士的表现也毫不逊色。

‘All this is so frequent, Lady Dedlock, where I live, and among the class to which I belong, that what would be generally called unequal marriages are not of such rare occurrence with us as elsewhere. A son will sometimes make it known to his father that he has fallen in love, say, with a young woman in the factory. The father, who once worked in a factory himself, will be a little disappointed at first very possibly. It may be that he had other views for his son. However, the chances are that having ascertained the young woman to be of unblemished character, he will say to his son, ‘I must be quite sure you are in earnest here. This is a serious matter for both of you. Therefore I shall have this girl educated for two years,’ or it may be, ‘I shall place this girl at the same school with your sisters for such a time, during which you will give me your word and honour to see her only so often. If at the expiration of that time, when she has so far profited by her advantages as that you may be upon a fair equality, you are both in the same mind, I will do my part to make you happy.’ I know of several cases such as I describe, my Lady, and I think they indicate to me my own course now.’
“戴德洛克夫人，在我居住的地方以及我所属的阶级中，这一切都是如此频繁，以至于通常所说的不平等婚姻在我们这里并不像其他地方那样罕见。儿子有时会让父亲知道他爱上了工厂里的一位年轻女子。这位曾经在工厂工作过的父亲一开始很可能会有点失望。也许他对儿子有其他的看法。然而，当他确定这位年轻女子品格完美后，他很可能会对他的儿子说：“我必须非常确定你在这里是认真的。”这对你们俩来说都是一件严重的事情。因此，我将让这个女孩接受两年的教育，”或者可能是，“我将让这个女孩与你的姐妹们在同一所学校学习一段时间，在此期间，你将向我保证并荣幸地见到她，这样就可以了。”经常。如果到了这段时间，当她已经从她的优势中获益，你们可以处于公平的平等地位时，你们俩的想法是一样的，我会尽力让你们幸福。”我知道几个女士们，我所描述的例子，我认为它们向我表明了我现在的做法。

Sir Leicester’s magnificence explodes. Calmly, but terribly.
莱斯特爵士的辉煌爆发了。平静，但很可怕。

‘Mr. Rouncewell,’ says Sir Leicester with his right hand in the breast of his blue coat, the attitude of state in which he is painted in the gallery, ‘do you draw a parallel between Chesney Wold and a—‘ Here he resists a disposition to choke, ‘a factory?’
'先生。朗斯韦尔，”莱斯特爵士将右手放在蓝色外套的胸前说道，这就是他在画廊中所画的状态，“你是否将切斯尼·沃尔德与一个——”在这里，他抵制了一种倾向窒息，“工厂？”

‘I need not reply, Sir Leicester, that the two places are very different; but for the purposes of this case, I think a parallel may be justly drawn between them.’
“我不需要回答，莱斯特爵士，这两个地方非常不同；但就本案而言，我认为将它们进行类比是合理的。”

Sir Leicester directs his majestic glance down one side of the long drawing-room and up the other before he can believe that he is awake.
莱斯特爵士用他威严的目光扫过长客厅的一侧，又向上扫过另一侧，才相信自己已经醒了。

‘Are you aware, sir, that this young woman whom my Lady—my Lady— has placed near her person was brought up at the village school outside the gates?’
“您知道吗，先生，这位女士——女士——放在她身边的这位年轻女子是在门外的乡村学校长大的？”

‘Sir Leicester, I am quite aware of it. A very good school it is, and handsomely supported by this family.’
“莱斯特爵士，我很清楚这一点。这是一所非常好的学校，并得到了这个家庭的大力支持。”

‘Then, Mr. Rouncewell,’ returns Sir Leicester, ‘the application of what you have said is, to me, incomprehensible.’
“那么，朗斯韦尔先生，”莱斯特爵士回答道，“对我来说，你所说的话的应用是难以理解的。”

‘Will it be more comprehensible, Sir Leicester, if I say,’ the ironmaster is reddening a little, ‘that I do not regard the village school as teaching everything desirable to be known by my son’s wife?’
“莱斯特爵士，如果我说，”铁匠的脸有点红了，“我不认为乡村学校教授我儿媳妇所希望了解的一切，这样会更容易理解吗？”

From the village school of Chesney Wold, intact as it is this minute, to the whole framework of society; from the whole framework of society, to the aforesaid framework receiving tremendous cracks in consequence of people (iron-masters, lead-mistresses, and what not) not minding their catechism, and getting out of the station unto which they are called—necessarily and for ever, according to Sir Leicester’s rapid logic, the first station in which they happen to find themselves; and from that, to their educating other people out of THEIR stations, and so obliterating the landmarks, and opening the floodgates, and all the rest of it; this is the swift progress of the Dedlock mind.
从切斯尼沃尔德的乡村学校，到此刻完好无损的整个社会框架；从社会的整个框架，到上述框架由于人们（铁匠、首席情妇等等）不介意他们的教义问答而受到巨大的裂缝，并且离开了他们被召唤的地位——必然和按照莱斯特爵士的快速逻辑，永远是他们碰巧发现自己的第一站；从那以后，他们教育其他人离开自己的岗位，从而消除了地标，打开了闸门，以及所有其他的事情；这就是戴洛克思想的飞速进步。

‘My Lady, I beg your pardon. Permit me, for one moment!’ She has given a faint indication of intending to speak. ‘Mr. Rouncewell, our views of duty, and our views of station, and our views of education, and our views of—in short, ALL our views—are so diametrically opposed, that to prolong this discussion must be repellent to your feelings and repellent to my own. This young woman is honoured with my Lady’s notice and favour. If she wishes to withdraw herself from that notice and favour or if she chooses to place herself under the influence of any one who may in his peculiar opinions—you will allow me to say, in his peculiar opinions, though I readily admit that he is not accountable for them to me—who may, in his peculiar opinions, withdraw her from that notice and favour, she is at any time at liberty to do so. We are obliged to you for the plainness with which you have spoken. It will have no effect of itself, one way or other, on the young woman’s position here. Beyond this, we can make no terms; and here we beg—if you will be so good—to leave the subject.’
‘夫人，请您原谅。请允许我，一会儿！”她隐隐约约地表示要说话。 '先生。朗斯韦尔，我们对责任的看法，我们对地位的看法，我们对教育的看法，以及我们的观点——简而言之，我们所有的观点——都是截然相反的，以至于延长这场讨论必须让你感到厌恶，也让你厌恶我自己的。这位年轻女子很荣幸得到夫人的关注和青睐。如果她希望不再受到这种关注和青睐，或者如果她选择将自己置于任何可能持有其独特观点的人的影响之下——你会允许我说，以他的独特观点，尽管我欣然承认他是不对我负责——我可以根据他的独特意见，取消对她的关注和青睐，她可以随时这样做。我们很感谢你的直言不讳。无论以何种方式，它本身不会对这位年轻女子在这里的地位产生任何影响。除此之外，我们不能提出任何条件；在这里，我们恳求——如果你愿意的话——离开这个话题。

The visitor pauses a moment to give my Lady an opportunity, but she says nothing. He then rises and replies, ‘Sir Leicester and Lady Dedlock, allow me to thank you for your attention and only to observe that I shall very seriously recommend my son to conquer his present inclinations. Good night!’
来访者停顿了一下，给我的女士一个机会，但她什么也没说。然后他站起来回答道：“莱斯特爵士和戴德洛克夫人，请允许我感谢你们的关注，只是说我会非常认真地建议我的儿子克服他目前的倾向。”晚安！'

‘Mr. Rouncewell,’ says Sir Leicester with all the nature of a gentleman shining in him, ‘it is late, and the roads are dark. I hope your time is not so precious but that you will allow my Lady and myself to offer you the hospitality of Chesney Wold, for tonight at least.’
'先生。朗斯韦尔，”莱斯特爵士说道，他身上闪烁着绅士的气质，“时间已经很晚了，道路漆黑。我希望您的时间不那么宝贵，但您将允许我的女士和我本人为您提供切斯尼沃尔德的热情款待，至少今晚如此。

‘I hope so,’ adds my Lady.
“我希望如此，”夫人补充道。

‘I am much obliged to you, but I have to travel all night in order to reach a distant part of the country punctually at an appointed time in the morning.’
“我非常感谢你，但我必须整夜赶路，才能在早上指定的时间准时到达这个国家的一个遥远的地方。”

Therewith the ironmaster takes his departure, Sir Leicester ringing the bell and my Lady rising as he leaves the room.
随后，铁匠离开了，莱斯特爵士按响了门铃，夫人在他离开房间时起身。

When my Lady goes to her boudoir, she sits down thoughtfully by the fire, and inattentive to the Ghost’s Walk, looks at Rosa, writing in an inner room. Presently my Lady calls her.
当我的夫人去她的闺房时，她若有所思地坐在火边，不顾鬼步，看着正在内室写作的罗莎。不久，夫人就打电话给她。

‘Come to me, child. Tell me the truth. Are you in love?’
‘到我这里来吧，孩子。告诉我真相。你在恋爱吗？'

‘Oh! My Lady!’
'哦！我的女士！'

My Lady, looking at the downcast and blushing face, says smiling, ‘Who is it? Is it Mrs. Rouncewell’s grandson?’
夫人看着那脸色低沉、脸色通红的人，微笑道：“谁啊？”是朗斯韦尔夫人的孙子吗？

‘Yes, if you please, my Lady. But I don’t know that I am in love with him—yet.’
“是的，如果您愿意的话，夫人。但我还不知道我爱上了他。”

‘Yet, you silly little thing! Do you know that he loves YOU, yet?’
‘可是，你这个愚蠢的小东西！你知道他爱你吗？

‘I think he likes me a little, my Lady.’ And Rosa bursts into tears.
“我想他有点喜欢我，女士。”罗莎泪流满面。

Is this Lady Dedlock standing beside the village beauty, smoothing her dark hair with that motherly touch, and watching her with eyes so full of musing interest? Aye, indeed it is!
这位戴德洛克女士是站在乡村美女旁边，用慈母般的抚摸着她的黑发，用充满沉思兴趣的眼神看着她吗？是啊，确实是这样！

‘Listen to me, child. You are young and true, and I believe you are attached to me.’
‘听我说，孩子。你年轻而真实，我相信你对我很依恋。

‘Indeed I am, my Lady. Indeed there is nothing in the world I wouldn’t do to show how much.’
“确实如此，我的女士。事实上，世界上没有什么是我不愿意做的，来展示我的努力。”

‘And I don’t think you would wish to leave me just yet, Rosa, even for a lover?’
“罗莎，我想你现在还不想离开我，哪怕是为了一个情人？”

‘No, my Lady! Oh, no!’ Rosa looks up for the first time, quite frightened at the thought.
“不，夫人！哦，不！”罗莎第一次抬起头来，对这个想法感到非常害怕。

‘Confide in me, my child. Don’t fear me. I wish you to be happy, and will make you so—if I can make anybody happy on this earth.’
‘相信我，我的孩子。别怕我。我希望你快乐，并且会让你快乐——如果我能让这个地球上的任何人快乐的话。”

Rosa, with fresh tears, kneels at her feet and kisses her hand. My Lady takes the hand with which she has caught it, and standing with her eyes fixed on the fire, puts it about and about between her own two hands, and gradually lets it fall. Seeing her so absorbed, Rosa softly withdraws; but still my Lady’s eyes are on the fire.
罗莎满脸泪水，跪在她脚边，亲吻她的手。夫人握住她接住它的手，站在那里，眼睛盯着火，把它放在自己的两只手之间，然后慢慢地让它掉下来。罗莎见她如此全神贯注，轻轻地退了出去。但夫人的眼睛仍然盯着火。

In search of what? Of any hand that is no more, of any hand that never was, of any touch that might have magically changed her life? Or does she listen to the Ghost’s Walk and think what step does it most resemble? A man’s? A woman’s? The pattering of a little child’s feet, ever coming on—on—on? Some melancholy influence is upon her, or why should so proud a lady close the doors and sit alone upon the hearth so desolate?
寻找什么？任何已经不复存在的手，任何从未存在过的手，任何可能神奇地改变她生活的触碰？或者她会听鬼步并认为它最像哪一步？一个男人的？女人的？一个小孩子的脚步声，不断地——不断地——不断地传来？她身上有某种忧郁的影响，或者为什么如此骄傲的一位女士要关上门，独自坐在如此荒凉的炉边呢？

Volumnia is away next day, and all the cousins are scattered before dinner. Not a cousin of the batch but is amazed to hear from Sir Leicester at breakfast-time of the obliteration of landmarks, and opening of floodgates, and cracking of the framework of society, manifested through Mrs. Rouncewell’s son. Not a cousin of the batch but is really indignant, and connects it with the feebleness of William Buffy when in office, and really does feel deprived of a stake in the country—or the pension list—or something—by fraud and wrong. As to Volumnia, she is handed down the great staircase by Sir Leicester, as eloquent upon the theme as if there were a general rising in the north of England to obtain her rouge-pot and pearl necklace. And thus, with a clatter of maids and valets—for it is one appurtenance of their cousinship that however difficult they may find it to keep themselves, they MUST keep maids and valets—the cousins disperse to the four winds of heaven; and the one wintry wind that blows to-day shakes a shower from the trees near the deserted house, as if all the cousins had been changed into leaves.
沃伦尼亚第二天就离开了，所有的表兄弟姐妹在晚饭前都散了。虽然不是这批人的堂兄，但在早餐时间，莱斯特爵士惊讶地听到莱斯特爵士讲述了地标被毁、水闸打开、社会框架破裂的情况，这些都是通过朗斯韦尔夫人的儿子表现出来的。虽然不是这批人的表亲，但他确实感到愤怒，并将其与威廉·巴菲在任时的软弱联系起来，并且确实感到自己因欺诈和错误而被剥夺了国家的利益——或者养老金名单——或者其他什么东西。至于沃伦尼亚，莱斯特爵士将她从大楼梯上递了下来，雄辩地讲述了这个主题，就像英格兰北部发生了一场普遍的起义，以获取她的胭脂罐和珍珠项链。就这样，伴随着女仆和男仆的一阵喧哗声——因为这是他们表兄弟的附属物，无论他们发现自己如何难以维持，他们都必须保留女仆和男仆——表兄弟们四散而去；今天吹来的一阵寒风，把废弃房屋附近的树吹得阵阵雨，仿佛所有的表兄弟都变成了树叶。

CHAPTER XXIX
第二十九章


The Young Man
年轻人

Chesney Wold is shut up, carpets are rolled into great scrolls in corners of comfortless rooms, bright damask does penance in brown holland, carving and gilding puts on mortification, and the Dedlock ancestors retire from the light of day again. Around and around the house the leaves fall thick, but never fast, for they come circling down with a dead lightness that is sombre and slow. Let the gardener sweep and sweep the turf as he will, and press the leaves into full barrows, and wheel them off, still they lie ankledeep. Howls the shrill wind round Chesney Wold; the sharp rain beats, the windows rattle, and the chimneys growl. Mists hide in the avenues, veil the points of view, and move in funeral-wise across the rising grounds. On all the house there is a cold, blank smell like the smell of a little church, though something dryer, suggesting that the dead and buried Dedlocks walk there in the long nights and leave the flavour of their graves behind them.
切斯尼庄园被关起来，地毯在不舒适的房间的角落里卷成巨大的卷轴，明亮的锦缎在棕色荷兰色中进行忏悔，雕刻和镀金呈现出苦行，戴德洛克的祖先再次从阳光下消失。房子周围，树叶纷纷落下，但落得并不快，因为它们盘旋而下，带着一种死一般的轻盈，阴沉而缓慢。让园丁随心所欲地清扫草坪，把树叶压进装满的手推车里，然后用轮子把它们推开，它们仍然深埋在脚踝处。切斯尼森林周围呼啸着刺耳的风；暴雨倾盆而下，窗户嘎嘎作响，烟囱轰鸣。雾气隐藏在大街上，遮蔽了视野，并以葬礼的方式穿过高地。整个房子里都弥漫着一种冰冷、空洞的气味，就像一座小教堂的气味，尽管有些干燥，这表明死去和埋葬的德洛克人在漫长的夜晚走到那里，把坟墓的味道留在身后。

But the house in town, which is rarely in the same mind as Chesney Wold at the same time, seldom rejoicing when it rejoices or mourning when it mourns, expecting when a Dedlock dies—the house in town shines out awakened. As warm and bright as so much state may be, as delicately redolent of pleasant scents that bear no trace of winter as hothouse flowers can make it, soft and hushed so that the ticking of the clocks and the crisp burning of the fires alone disturb the stillness in the rooms, it seems to wrap those chilled bones of Sir Leicester’s in rainbow-coloured wool. And Sir Leicester is glad to repose in dignified contentment before the great fire in the library, condescendingly perusing the backs of his books or honouring the fine arts with a glance of approbation. For he has his pictures, ancient and modern. Some of the Fancy Ball School in which art occasionally condescends to become a master, which would be best catalogued like the miscellaneous articles in a sale. As ‘“Three high-backed chairs, a table and cover, long-necked bottle (containing wine), one flask, one Spanish female’s costume, three-quarter face portrait of Miss Jogg the model, and a suit of armour containing Don Quixote.’ Or ‘One stone terrace (cracked), one gondola in distance, one Venetian senator’s dress complete, richly embroidered white satin costume with profile portrait of Miss Jogg the model, one Scimitar superbly mounted in gold with jewelled handle, elaborate Moorish dress (very rare), and Othello.’
但城里的房子却很少和切斯尼·沃尔德同时有同样的想法，很少在欢乐时欢乐，在哀悼时也很少哀悼，期待着当戴德洛克去世时，城里的房子就会醒来。尽一切可能温暖而明亮，散发着令人愉悦的芬芳，就像温室里的花朵一样，没有冬天的痕迹，柔和而安静，以至于钟表的滴答声和炉火的清脆燃烧扰乱了周围的一切。房间里一片寂静，莱斯特爵士冰冷的骨头似乎被彩虹色的羊毛包裹着。莱斯特爵士很高兴在图书馆的篝火前端庄而满足地休息，居高临下地阅读他的书籍背面或以赞许的目光向美术致敬。因为他有他的照片，古代的和现代的。一些花式舞会学校，其中艺术偶尔屈尊成为大师，最好像拍卖中的杂货一样进行分类。如“三把高背椅、一张桌子和一个盖子、长颈瓶（装有酒）、一个烧瓶、一套西班牙女性服装、模特乔格小姐的四分之三脸部肖像、一套装有唐吉诃德的盔甲” ”或者“一个石头露台（有裂缝），远处有一艘贡多拉，一件完整的威尼斯参议员礼服，一件绣着华丽的白色缎子服装，上面有模特乔格小姐的侧面肖像，一把镶有宝石的黄金弯刀，精致的摩尔式连衣裙（非常罕见）和奥赛罗。

Mr. Tulkinghorn comes and goes pretty often, there being estate business to do, leases to be renewed, and so on. He sees my Lady pretty often, too; and he and she are as composed, and as indifferent, and take as little heed of one another, as ever. Yet it may be that my Lady fears this Mr. Tulkinghorn and that he knows it. It may be that he pursues her doggedly and steadily, with no touch of compunction, remorse, or pity. It may be that her beauty and all the state and brilliancy surrounding her only gives him the greater zest for what he is set upon and makes him the more inflexible in it. Whether he be cold and cruel, whether immovable in what he has made his duty, whether absorbed in love of power, whether determined to have nothing hidden from him in ground where he has burrowed among secrets all his life, whether he in his heart despises the splendour of which he is a distant beam, whether he is always treasuring up slights and offences in the affability of his gorgeous clients—whether he be any of this, or all of this, it may be that my Lady had better have five thousand pairs of fashionahle eyes upon her, in distrustful vigilance, than the two eyes of this rusty lawyer with his wisp of neckcloth and his dull black breeches tied with ribbons at the knees.
图金霍恩先生来来往往，有房地产生意要做，有续租等等。他也经常见到我的夫人；他和她一如既往地镇静、冷漠、不关心对方。然而，也许夫人害怕这位图尔金霍恩先生，而且他也知道这一点。也许他执着而坚定地追求着她，没有一丝内疚、悔恨或怜悯。也许她的美丽以及她周围的一切状态和光彩只会让他对自己所从事的事情更加热情，并使他更加顽固。他是否冷酷无情，是否坚定不移地履行自己的职责，是否热衷于权力，是否决心在他一生所挖掘的秘密中不向他隐瞒任何事情，是否内心鄙视他是远方的辉煌，无论他是否总是在他华丽的客户的和蔼可亲中珍视轻蔑和冒犯——无论他是其中任何一个，还是所有这一切，也许我的女士最好有五千一双双时尚的眼睛带着怀疑的警惕看着她，比这个生锈的律师的两只眼睛更重要，他戴着一缕领巾，穿着暗黑马裤，膝盖上系着丝带。

Sir Leicester sits in my Lady’s room—that room in which Mr. Tulkinghorn read the affidavit in Jarndyce and Jarndyce— particularly complacent. My Lady, as on that day, sits before the fire with her screen in her hand. Sir Leicester is particularly complacent because he has found in his newspaper some congenial remarks bearing directly on the floodgates and the framework of society. They apply so happily to the late case that Sir Leicester has come from the library to my Lady’s room expressly to read them aloud. ‘The man who wrote this article,’ he observes by way of preface, nodding at the fire as if he were nodding down at the man from a mount, ‘has a well-balanced mind.’
莱斯特爵士坐在夫人的房间里——塔尔金霍恩先生在房间里宣读了贾迪斯和贾迪斯的宣誓书——特别得意。夫人和那天一样，坐在火炉前，手里拿着屏风。莱斯特爵士尤其沾沾自喜，因为他在报纸上发现了一些直接针对闸门和社会框架的友善言论。他们如此高兴地申请了最新的案件，以至于莱斯特爵士从图书馆来到我夫人的房间特意大声朗读它们。 “写这篇文章的人，”他在序言中说道，他对着火点点头，就好像他在向山上的人点头一样，“他的头脑很平衡。”

The man’s mind is not so well balanced but that he bores my Lady, who, after a languid effort to listen, or rather a languid resignation of herself to a show of listening, becomes distraught and falls into a contemplation of the fire as if it were her fire at Chesney Wold, and she had never left it. Sir Leicester, quite unconscious, reads on through his double eye-glass, occasionally stopping to remove his glass and express approval, as ‘Very true indeed,’ ‘Very properly put,’ ‘I have frequently made the same remark myself,’ invariably losing his place after each observation, and going up and down the column to find it again.
这个男人的头脑不太平衡，但他让我的女士感到厌烦，她在懒洋洋地努力倾听之后，或者更确切地说，在懒洋洋地听天由命地倾听之后，变得心烦意乱，陷入了对火焰的沉思中，仿佛它是在燃烧。这是她对切斯尼沃尔德的热情，她从未离开过。莱斯特爵士完全没有意识，透过他的双眼眼镜继续阅读，偶尔停下来摘下眼镜并表示赞同，因为“确实非常正确”，“说得非常恰当”，“我自己也经常说过同样的话”，总是这样说。每次观察后都会失去自己的位置，然后在列中上下移动以再次找到它。

Sir Leicester is reading with infinite gravity and state when the door opens, and the Mercury in powder makes this strange announcement, ‘The young man, my Lady, of the name of Guppy.’
当门打开时，莱斯特爵士正在以无限的严肃和状态阅读，粉状的水星发出了这个奇怪的宣告：“这位年轻人，我的女士，名叫孔雀鱼。”

Sir Leicester pauses, stares, repeats in a killing voice, ‘The young man of the name of Guppy?’
莱斯特爵士停了下来，凝视着，用杀气腾腾的声音重复道：“那个叫孔比的年轻人？”

Looking round, he beholds the young man of the name of Guppy, much discomfited and not presenting a very impressive letter of introduction in his manner and appearance.
环顾四周，他看到了那个名叫孔比的年轻人，一脸狼狈，从举止和外表上看，都没有呈现出令人印象深刻的介绍信。

‘Pray,’ says Sir Leicester to Mercury, ‘what do you mean by announcing with this abruptness a young man of the name of Guppy?’
“请问，”莱斯特爵士对墨丘利说道，“您如此唐突地宣布一位名叫孔雀鱼的年轻人是什么意思？”

‘I beg your pardon, Sir Leicester, but my Lady said she would see the young man whenever he called. I was not aware that you were here, Sir Leicester.’
“请您原谅，莱斯特爵士，但我的夫人说只要他打电话来，她就会见到他。我不知道你在这里，莱斯特爵士。

With this apology, Mercury directs a scornful and indignant look at the young man of the name of Guppy which plainly says, ‘What do you come calling here for and getting ME into a row?’
说完这番道歉，墨丘利用轻蔑而愤慨的眼神看着那个名叫孔比的年轻人，他直白地说：“你打电话到这里来找我做什么？”

‘It’s quite right. I gave him those directions,’ says my Lady. ‘Let the young man wait.’
‘说得很对。我给了他这些指示，”我的夫人说道。 “让年轻人等一下。”

‘By no means, my Lady. Since he has your orders to come, I will not interrupt you.’ Sir Leicester in his gallantry retires, rather declining to accept a bow from the young man as he goes out and majestically supposing him to be some shoemaker of intrusive appearance.
“绝不是这样，我的女士。既然他有你的命令要来，我就不打扰你了。”莱斯特爵士殷勤地退了出去，在年轻人走出去时拒绝接受他的鞠躬，并威严地以为他是一个外表咄咄逼人的鞋匠。

Lady Dedlock looks imperiously at her visitor when the servant has left the room, casting her eyes over him from head to foot. She suffers him to stand by the door and asks him what he wants.
当仆人离开房间时，戴德洛克夫人专横地看着她的客人，从头到脚地打量着他。她让他站在门口，问他想要什么。

‘That your ladyship would have the kindness to oblige me with a little conversation,’ returns Mr. Guppy, embarrassed.
“尊敬的女士，请您和我聊聊。”古皮先生尴尬地回答道。

‘You are, of course, the person who has written me so many letters?’
“当然，你就是给我写了这么多信的人？”

‘Several, your ladyship. Several before your ladyship condescended to favour me with an answer.’
“有几个，夫人。夫人之前有几位屈尊给我一个答复。

‘And could you not take the same means of rendering a Conversation unnecessary? Can you not still?’
‘难道你不能采取同样的方式来使对话变得不必要吗？你能不能别这样？

Mr. Guppy screws his mouth into a silent ‘No!’ and shakes his head.
孔雀鱼先生抿着嘴，默默地说“不！”，然后摇摇头。

‘You have been strangely importunate. If it should appear, after all, that what you have to say does not concern me—and I don’t know how it can, and don’t expect that it will—you will allow me to cut you short with but little ceremony. Say what you have to say, if you please.’
‘你一直很奇怪地纠缠不休。毕竟，如果看起来你要说的话与我无关——而且我不知道怎么会这样，也不指望会这样——你就允许我打断你的话，但没有什么仪式。如果你愿意的话，请说你想说的话。

My Lady, with a careless toss of her screen, turns herself towards the fire again, sitting almost with her back to the young man of the name of Guppy.
夫人不经意地一甩屏风，又把自己转向火边，几乎背对着那个名叫孔雀鱼的年轻人。

‘With your ladyship’s permission, then,’ says the young man, ‘I will now enter on my business. Hem! I am, as I told your ladyship in my first letter, in the law. Being in the law, I have learnt the habit of not committing myself in writing, and therefore I did not mention to your ladyship the name of the firm with which I am connected and in which my standing—and I may add income—is tolerably good. I may now state to your ladyship, in confidence, that the name of that firm is Kenge and Carboy, of Lincoln’s Inn, which may not be altogether unknown to your ladyship in connexion with the case in Chancery of Jarndyce and Jarndyce.’
“那么，如果得到女士的许可，”年轻人说道，“我现在开始处理我的事情了。”哼！正如我在第一封信中告诉女士的那样，我是法律人士。在法律界，我养成了不以书面形式做出承诺的习惯，因此我没有向女士提及与我有联系的公司的名称，并且我在该公司的地位（并且我可能会增加收入）还算可以。好的。现在，我可以向您的女士私下声明，该公司的名称是林肯律师学院的 Kenge and Carboy，您可能并不完全不知道这家公司与贾迪斯和贾迪斯大法官法庭的案件有关。

My Lady’s figure begins to be expressive of some attention. She has ceased to toss the screen and holds it as if she were listening.
夫人的身影开始表现出某种关注。她不再扔屏幕，而是拿着它，仿佛在听。

‘Now, I may say to your ladyship at once,’ says Mr. Guppy, a little emboldened, ‘it is no matter arising out of Jarndyce and Jarndyce that made me so desirous to speak to your ladyship, which conduct I have no doubt did appear, and does appear, obtrusive—in fact, almost blackguardly.’
“现在，我可以立刻对夫人说，”顾比先生有点大胆地说，“无论是贾迪斯还是贾迪斯的事情，都让我如此渴望与夫人交谈，我对此毫不怀疑。”确实显得很唐突——事实上，几乎是无礼的。”

After waiting for a moment to receive some assurance to the contrary, and not receiving any, Mr. Guppy proceeds, ‘If it had been Jarndyce and Jarndyce, I should have gone at once to your ladyship’s solicitor, Mr. Tulkinghorn, of the Fields. I have the pleasure of being acquainted with Mr. Tulkinghorn—at least we move when we meet one another—and if it had been any business of that sort, I should have gone to him.’
等了一会儿，得到了一些相反的保证，但没有得到任何保证，顾比先生继续说道：“如果是贾迪斯和贾迪斯，我会立即去找您夫人的律师，菲尔兹的图金霍恩先生。” 。我很高兴认识图尔金霍恩先生——至少我们一见面就感动了——如果有这样的事情，我应该去找他。

My Lady turns a little round and says, ‘You had better sit down.’
夫人转过身来说道：“你最好坐下来。”

‘Thank your ladyship.’ Mr. Guppy does so. ‘Now, your ladyship’— Mr. Guppy refers to a little slip of paper on which he has made small notes of his line of argument and which seems to involve him in the densest obscurity whenever he looks at it—‘I—Oh, yes!—I place myself entirely in your ladyship’s hands. If your ladyship was to make any complaint to Kenge and Carboy or to Mr. Tulkinghorn of the present visit, I should be placed in a very disagreeable situation. That, I openly admit. Consequently, I rely upon your ladyship’s honour.’
“谢谢夫人。”古比先生照做了。 “现在，夫人，”古比先生指着一张小纸条，他在上面记下了他的论点，每当他看到这张纸条时，他似乎都陷入了最晦涩难懂的境地——“我——哦，是的！——我把自己完全交托在夫人的手中。如果您的女士要向肯格和卡博伊或图尔金霍恩先生对这次访问提出任何抱怨，我就会陷入非常不愉快的境地。对此，我公开承认。因此，我依靠夫人的名誉。

My Lady, with a disdainful gesture of the hand that holds the screen, assures him of his being worth no complaint from her.
夫人用握住屏风的手做出了一个轻蔑的姿势，向他保证他不值得她抱怨。

‘Thank your ladyship,’ says Mr. Guppy; ‘quite satisfactory. Now— I—dash it!—The fact is that I put down a head or two here of the order of the points I thought of touching upon, and they’re written short, and I can’t quite make out what they mean. If your ladyship will excuse me taking it to the window half a moment, I—‘
“谢谢您的女士，”古比先生说道。 ‘相当满意。现在——我——破烂吧！——事实是，我在这里按照我想触及的要点的顺序写下了一两个头，而且它们写得很短，我不太明白它们的意思。如果您的女士能原谅我把它拿到窗边半分钟，我——”

Mr. Guppy, going to the window, tumbles into a pair of love-birds, to whom he says in his confusion, ‘I beg your pardon, I am sure.’ This does not tend to the greater legibility of his notes. He murmurs, growing warm and red and holding the slip of paper now close to his eyes, now a long way off, ‘C.S. What’s C.S. for? Oh! C.S.! Oh, I know! Yes, to be sure!’ And comes back enlightened.
孔雀鱼先生走到窗前，撞见了一对爱情鸟，他困惑地对他们说：“我相信，请原谅。”这并不能提高他的笔记的可读性。他低声说道：“C.S. C.S.有什么用？哦！ CS。！哦，我知道！是的，当然！”回来后恍然大悟。

‘I am not aware,’ says Mr. Guppy, standing midway between my Lady and his chair, ‘whether your ladyship ever happened to hear of, or to see, a young lady of the name of Miss Esther Summerson.’
“我不知道，”顾比先生站在夫人和他的椅子中间，说道，“夫人是否曾经听说过或见过一位名叫埃丝特·萨默森小姐的年轻女士。”

My Lady’s eyes look at him full. ‘I saw a young lady of that name not long ago. This past autumn.’
夫人的眼睛全神贯注地看着他。 “不久前我见过一位叫这个名字的年轻女士。去年秋天。

‘Now, did it strike your ladyship that she was like anybody?’ asks Mr. Guppy, crossing his arms, holding his head on one side, and scratching the corner of his mouth with his memoranda.
“现在，夫人您有没有发现她和其他人一样？”古皮先生问道，他交叉着双臂，把头偏向一侧，用备忘录抓着嘴角。

My Lady removes her eyes from him no more.
夫人的目光不再从他身上移开。

‘No.’
'不。'

‘Not like your ladyship’s family?’
“不像贵夫人的家人吗？”

‘No.’
'不。'

‘I think your ladyship,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘can hardly remember Miss Summerson’s face?’
“我想您的女士，”古比先生说，“几乎不记得萨默森小姐的脸了？”

‘I remember the young lady very well. What has this to do with me?’
“我对这位年轻女士记得很清楚。这跟我有什么关系？

‘Your ladyship, I do assure you that having Miss Summerson’s image imprinted on my ‘eart—which I mention in confidence—I found, when I had the honour of going over your ladyship’s mansion of Chesney Wold while on a short out in the county of Lincolnshire with a friend, such a resemblance between Miss Esther Summerson and your ladyship’s own portrait that it completely knocked me over, so much so that I didn’t at the moment even know what it WAS that knocked me over. And now I have the honour of beholding your ladyship near (I have often, since that, taken the liberty of looking at your ladyship in your carriage in the park, when I dare say you was not aware of me, but I never saw your ladyship so near), it’s really more surprising than I thought it.’
“夫人，我向您保证，萨默森小姐的形象已深深印在我的心上——这是我私下提到的——当我在县里短暂外出时，有幸参观了夫人位于切斯尼沃尔德的宅邸时，我发现了这一点。”和朋友一起去林肯郡，埃丝特·萨默森小姐和您夫人本人的肖像如此相似，这让我彻底震惊了，以至于我当时甚至不知道是什么让我震惊了。现在我有幸在附近看到您的女士（从那时起，我经常冒昧地看着您在公园马车里的女士，当时我敢说您没有意识到我，但我从未见过您）女士这么近），这真的比我想象的更令人惊讶。

Young man of the name of Guppy! There have been times, when ladies lived in strongholds and had unscrupulous attendants within call, when that poor life of yours would NOT have been worth a minute’s purchase, with those beautiful eyes looking at you as they look at this moment.
名叫孔雀鱼的年轻人！有时候，当女士们住在要塞里，有不道德的随从随叫随到时，当你那可怜的生命一分钟都不值钱时，那双美丽的眼睛此刻正在看着你。

My Lady, slowly using her little hand-screen as a fan, asks him again what he supposes that his taste for likenesses has to do with her.
夫人慢慢地将她的小手屏当作扇子，再次问他认为他对相似的品味与她有什么关系。

‘Your ladyship,’ replies Mr. Guppy, again referring to his paper, ‘I am coming to that. Dash these notes! Oh! ‘Mrs. Chadband.’ Yes.’ Mr. Guppy draws his chair a little forward and seats himself again. My Lady reclines in her chair composedly, though with a trifle less of graceful ease than usual perhaps, and never falters in her steady gaze. ‘A—stop a minute, though!’ Mr. Guppy refers again. ‘E.S. twice? Oh, yes! Yes, I see my way now, right on.’
“尊敬的女士，”古比先生回答道，再次提到他的论文，“我正在讨论这个问题。”破折号这些笔记！哦！ '太太。查德班德。“是的。”古比先生把椅子向前拉了一点，然后又坐下了。夫人平静地靠在椅子上，尽管可能比平常少了一点优雅从容，但她坚定的目光从未动摇过。 “啊——不过，等一下！”古比先生再次说道。 ‘E.S.两次？哦是的！是的，我现在明白了，就在眼前。”

Rolling up the slip of paper as an instrument to point his speech with, Mr. Guppy proceeds.
古比先生卷起纸条作为演讲的工具，继续说道。

‘Your ladyship, there is a mystery about Miss Esther Summerson’s birth and bringing up. I am informed of that fact because—which I mention in confidence—I know it in the way of my profession at Kenge and Carboy’s. Now, as I have already mentioned to your ladyship, Miss Summerson’s image is imprinted on my ‘eart. If I could clear this mystery for her, or prove her to be well related, or find that having the honour to be a remote branch of your ladyship’s family she had a right to be made a party in Jarndyce and Jarndyce, why, I might make a sort of a claim upon Miss Summerson to look with an eye of more dedicated favour on my proposals than she has exactly done as yet. In fact, as yet she hasn’t favoured them at all.’
“夫人，埃丝特·萨默森小姐的出生和成长是一个谜。我被告知这一事实是因为——我私下提到过这一点——我以我在 Kenge 和 Carboy’s 的职业方式了解这一点。现在，正如我已经向阁下提到的那样，萨默森小姐的形象已经铭刻在我的“心上”。如果我能为她解开这个谜团，或者证明她有很好的血缘关系，或者发现有幸成为贵夫人家族的一个偏远分支，她有权在加迪斯和加迪斯参加派对，为什么，我可能向萨默森小姐提出某种要求，要求她以比她迄今为止所做的更专注的眼光看待我的建议。事实上，到目前为止，她根本就不喜欢他们。

A kind of angry smile just dawns upon my Lady’s face.
夫人的脸上浮现出一种愤怒的微笑。

‘Now, it’s a very singular circumstance, your ladyship,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘though one of those circumstances that do fall in the way of us professional men—which I may call myself, for though not admitted, yet I have had a present of my articles made to me by Kenge and Carboy, on my mother’s advancing from the principal of her little income the money for the stamp, which comes heavy—that I have encountered the person who lived as servant with the lady who brought Miss Summerson up before Mr. Jarndyce took charge of her. That lady was a Miss Barbary, your ladyship.’
“现在，这是一个非常奇特的情况，夫人，”古皮先生说，“尽管其中一个情况确实会妨碍我们职业人士——我可以称自己为自己，因为虽然没有承认，但我已经经历过肯格和卡博伊送给我的一份我的文章的礼物，是关于我母亲从她微薄的收入中垫付邮票的钱，这钱很重——我遇到了一个和那位带来小姐的女士一起作为仆人生活的人萨默森在贾迪斯先生接管她之前就上任了。那位女士是巴巴里小姐，您的女士。

Is the dead colour on my Lady’s face reflected from the screen which has a green silk ground and which she holds in her raised hand as if she had forgotten it, or is it a dreadful paleness that has fallen on her?
夫人脸上的死色是从她举起的手上举起的绿色丝质屏风上反射出来的，仿佛她已经忘记了它，还是落在她身上的一种可怕的苍白？

‘Did your ladyship,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘ever happen to hear of Miss Barbary?’
“夫人，”古比先生说，“有没有听说过巴巴里小姐？”

‘I don’t know. I think so. Yes.’
'我不知道。我想是这样。是的。'

‘Was Miss Barbary at all connected with your ladyship’s family?’
“巴巴里小姐和您夫人的家人有联系吗？”

My Lady’s lips move, but they utter nothing. She shakes her head.
夫人的嘴唇动了动，但什么也没说。她摇摇头。

‘NOT connected?’ says Mr. Guppy. ‘Oh! Not to your ladyship’s knowledge, perhaps? Ah! But might be? Yes.’ After each of these interrogatories, she has inclined her head. ‘Very good! Now, this Miss Barbary was extremely close—seems to have been extraordinarily close for a female, females being generally (in common life at least) rather given to conversation—and my witness never had an idea whether she possessed a single relative. On one occasion, and only one, she seems to have been confidential to my witness on a single point, and she then told her that the little girl’s real name was not Esther Summerson, but Esther Hawdon.’
“没有连接？”古比先生说。 '哦！也许您女士不知道？啊!但可能是吗？是的。’每次问完之后，她都会歪着头。 '非常好！现在，这位巴巴里小姐非常亲密——对于女性来说似乎非常亲密，女性通常（至少在日常生活中）更喜欢交谈——而我的证人从来不知道她是否有一个亲戚。有一次，而且只有一次，她似乎在某一点上对我的证人保密，然后她告诉她，这个小女孩的真名不是埃丝特·萨默森，而是埃丝特·霍顿。

‘My God!’
'我的上帝！'

Mr. Guppy stares. Lady Dedlock sits before him looking him through, with the same dark shade upon her face, in the same attitude even to the holding of the screen, with her lips a little apart, her brow a little contracted, but for the moment dead. He sees her consciousness return, sees a tremor pass across her frame like a ripple over water, sees her lips shake, sees her compose them by a great effort, sees her force herself back to the knowledge of his presence and of what he has said. All this, so quickly, that her exclamation and her dead condition seem to have passed away like the features of those long-preserved dead bodies sometimes opened up in tombs, which, struck by the air like lightning, vanish in a breath.
古比先生凝视着。戴德洛克夫人坐在他面前，审视着他，脸上带着同样的暗色，甚至拿着屏风的态度也一样，嘴唇微张，眉头微皱，但此刻却死了。他看到她的意识恢复了，看到她的身体像水面上的涟漪一样颤抖，看到她的嘴唇在颤抖，看到她努力地控制着嘴唇，看到她强迫自己重新认识到他的存在和他所说的话。 。这一切来得如此之快，以至于她的惊呼和她的死亡状态似乎都已经过去了，就像那些长期保存的尸体有时在坟墓中打开一样，被空气闪电般击中，转眼间就消失了。

‘Your ladyship is acquainted with the name of Hawdon?’
“夫人知道霍顿这个名字吗？”

‘I have heard it before.’
“我以前听说过。”

‘Name of any collateral or remote branch of your ladyship’s family?’
“您夫人家族的任何旁系或远支的名字？”

‘No.’
'不。'

‘Now, your ladyship,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘I come to the last point of the case, so far as I have got it up. It’s going on, and I shall gather it up closer and closer as it goes on. Your ladyship must know—if your ladyship don’t happen, by any chance, to know already—that there was found dead at the house of a person named Krook, near Chancery Lane, some time ago, a law-writer in great distress. Upon which law-writer there was an inquest, and which law-writer was an anonymous character, his name being unknown. But, your ladyship, I have discovered very lately that that lawwriter’s name was Hawdon.’
“现在，夫人，”古比先生说，“就我所掌握的情况而言，我现在要谈的是这个案子的最后一点。”它正在发生，随着它的发生，我将越来越仔细地收集它。女士们一定知道——如果女士们万一不知道的话——不久前，在大法官巷附近一个名叫克鲁克的人的家里被发现死了，他是一位处于极度痛苦中的法律作家。对哪位法律作家进行了调查，而哪一位法律作家是匿名人物，他的名字不详。但是，夫人，我最近发现那位律师的名字叫霍顿。”

‘And what is THAT to me?’
“那对我来说又算什么呢？”

‘Aye, your ladyship, that’s the question! Now, your ladyship, a queer thing happened after that man’s death. A lady started up, a disguised lady, your ladyship, who went to look at the scene of action and went to look at his grave. She hired a crossingsweeping boy to show it her. If your ladyship would wish to have the boy produced in corroboration of this statement, I can lay my hand upon him at any time.’
“是啊，夫人，这就是问题所在！女士们，在那个男人死后发生了一件奇怪的事情。一位女士站了起来，一位乔装打扮的女士，您的女士，她去看了行动现场，还去看了他的坟墓。她雇了一个清扫道路的男孩来给她看。如果夫人阁下希望生出这个男孩来证实这一说法，我可以随时把手放在他身上。

The wretched boy is nothing to my Lady, and she does NOT wish to have him produced.
这个可怜的男孩对我的女士来说毫无意义，她也不希望他出生。

‘Oh, I assure your ladyship it’s a very queer start indeed,’ says Mr. Guppy. ‘If you was to hear him tell about the rings that sparkled on her fingers when she took her glove off, you’d think it quite romantic.’
“哦，我向女士保证，这确实是一个非常奇怪的开始，”古皮先生说。 “如果你听他讲述当她脱下手套时，她手指上闪闪发光的戒指，你会觉得这很浪漫。”

There are diamonds glittering on the hand that holds the screen. My Lady trifles with the screen and makes them glitter more, again with that expression which in other times might have been so dangerous to the young man of the name of Guppy.
握住屏幕的手上有钻石闪闪发光。我的夫人摆弄着屏幕，让它们更加闪闪发光，同样的表情在其他时候可能对那个名叫孔雀鱼的年轻人来说是如此危险。

‘It was supposed, your ladyship, that he left no rag or scrap behind him by which he could be possibly identified. But he did. He left a bundle of old letters.’
“夫人，据推测，他身后没有留下任何可以辨认出他身份的破布或碎片。但他做到了。他留下了一叠旧信件。

The screen still goes, as before. All this time her eyes never once release him.
屏幕仍然像以前一样。一直以来，她的目光都没有离开过他。

‘They were taken and secreted. And to-morrow night, your ladyship, they will come into my possession.’
“它们被带走并被秘密保存。夫人，明天晚上，它们就会归我所有。”

‘Still I ask you, what is this to me?’
“我还是问你，这与我有什么关系？”

‘Your ladyship, I conclude with that.’ Mr. Guppy rises. ‘If you think there’s enough in this chain of circumstances put together— in the undoubted strong likeness of this young lady to your ladyship, which is a positive fact for a jury; in her having been brought up by Miss Barbary; in Miss Barbary stating Miss Summerson’s real name to be Hawdon; in your ladyship’s knowing both these names VERY WELL; and in Hawdon’s dying as he did—to give your ladyship a family interest in going further into the case, I will bring these papers here. I don’t know what they are, except that they are old letters: I have never had them in my posession yet. I will bring those papers here as soon as I get them and go over them for the first time with your ladyship. I have told your ladyship my object. I have told your ladyship that I should be placed in a very disagreeable situation if any complaint was made, and all is in strict confidence.’
