“夫人，我就这样结束吧。”古比先生站了起来。 “如果你认为这一系列的情况放在一起就足够了——这位年轻的女士无疑与您的夫人非常相似，这对陪审团来说是一个积极的事实；她是由巴巴里小姐抚养长大的；在巴巴里小姐中，萨默森小姐的真名是霍顿；夫人，您对这两个名字都很熟悉；在霍顿即将去世的情况下——为了让夫人阁下有兴趣进一步调查此案，我将把这些文件带到这里。我不知道它们是什么，只知道它们是旧信：我还从未拥有过它们。我一拿到这些文件就会把它们带到这里，并与夫人一起第一次检查。我已经告诉夫人我的目的了。我已经告诉夫人，如果有人提出任何投诉，我的处境就会非常不愉快，而且一切都严格保密。”

Is this the full purpose of the young man of the name of Guppy, or has he any other? Do his words disclose the length, breadth, depth, of his object and suspicion in coming here; or if not, what do they hide? He is a match for my Lady there. She may look at him, but he can look at the table and keep that witness-box face of his from telling anything.
这就是那个名叫孔雀鱼的年轻人的全部目的，还是另有目的？他的话是否透露了他来这里的目的和怀疑的长度、广度、深度？或者如果不是，他们隐藏了什么？他很适合我的女士。她可以看着他，但他可以看着桌子，让他那张证人席上的脸不说出任何事情。

‘You may bring the letters,’ says my Lady, ‘if you choose.’
“如果你愿意的话，你可以带上这些信，”夫人说道。

‘Your ladyship is not very encouraging, upon my word and honour,’ says Mr. Guppy, a little injured.
“我以我的名誉担保，您的女士不太鼓舞人心，”顾比先生说，他有点受伤。

‘You may bring the letters,’ she repeats in the same tone, ‘if you —please.’
“你可以把这些信带来，”她用同样的语气重复道，“如果你——请的话。”

‘It shall he done. I wish your ladyship good day.’
‘他一定会做到的。祝您女士有美好的一天。

On a table near her is a rich bauble of a casket, barred and clasped like an old strong-chest. She, looking at him still, takes it to her and unlocks it.
她旁边的桌子上放着一个精美的小盒子，上面有栅栏，扣得紧紧的，就像一个古老的坚固的箱子一样。她仍然看着他，把它拿过来并打开。

‘Oh! I assure your ladyship I am not actuated by any motives of that sort,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘and I couldn’t accept anything of the kind. I wish your ladyship good day, and am much obliged to you all the same.’
'哦！我向女士保证，我不会受到任何此类动机的驱使，”古皮先生说，“而且我不能接受任何此类行为。我祝您女士有美好的一天，但我仍然非常感谢您。

So the young man makes his bow and goes downstairs, where the supercilious Mercury does not consider himself called upon to leave his Olympus by the hall-fire to let the young man out.
于是年轻人鞠了一躬，下了楼，傲慢的墨丘利认为自己没有被要求离开他的奥林匹斯山，在大厅的火旁放年轻人出去。

As Sir Leicester basks in his library and dozes over his newspaper, is there no influence in the house to startle him, not to say to make the very trees at Chesney Wold fling up their knotted arms, the very portraits frown, the very armour stir?
当莱斯特爵士在他的图书馆里晒太阳，看着报纸打瞌睡时，房子里没有任何影响力让他吃惊，更不用说让切斯尼沃尔德的树木举起打结的手臂，让肖像皱眉，让盔甲搅拌？

No. Words, sobs, and cries are but air, and air is so shut in and shut out throughout the house in town that sounds need be uttered trumpet-tongued indeed by my Lady in her chamber to carry any faint vibration to Sir Leicester’s ears; and yet this cry is in the house, going upward from a wild figure on its knees.
不。言语、抽泣和哭声都不过是空气，镇上整栋房子里的空气都被封闭和隔绝，以至于我的女士在她的房间里确实需要用喇叭声发出声音，才能将任何微弱的振动传递到莱斯特爵士的耳朵里;然而，这呼喊却在屋子里响起，从一个跪着的狂野人物身上传出。

‘O my child, my child! Not dead in the first hours of her life, as my cruel sister told me, but sternly nurtured by her, after she had renounced me and my name! O my child, O my child!’
‘哦，我的孩子，我的孩子！正如我残忍的姐姐告诉我的那样，她并没有在生命的最初几个小时里就死了，而是在她放弃了我和我的名字之后，被她严格地养育了！哦，我的孩子，哦，我的孩子！

CHAPTER XXX
第三章


Esther’s Narrative
以斯帖的叙述

Richard had been gone away some time when a visitor came to pass a few days with us. It was an elderly lady. It was Mrs. Woodcourt, who, having come from Wales to stay with Mrs. Bayham Badger and having written to my guardian, ‘by her son Allan’s desire,’ to report that she had heard from him and that he was well ‘and sent his kind remembrances to all of us,’ had been invited by my guardian to make a visit to Bleak House. She stayed with us nearly three weeks. She took very kindly to me and was extremely confidential, so much so that sometimes she almost made me uncomfortable. I had no right, I knew very well, to be uncomfortable because she confided in me, and I felt it was unreasonable; still, with all I could do, I could not quite help it.
理查德已经离开一段时间了，这时一位访客来和我们一起住了几天。那是一位上了年纪的女士。那是伍德考特夫人，她从威尔士来到贝厄姆·獾夫人身边，“按照她儿子艾伦的意愿”，她写信给我的监护人，报告说她收到了他的消息，他的情况很好，“并被派去”。我的监护人邀请他去荒凉山庄参观。她和我们一起待了将近三个星期。她对我非常友善，而且非常保密，以至于有时她几乎让我感到不舒服。我很清楚，我没有权利因为她向我吐露心声而感到不舒服，而且我觉得这是不合理的。尽管如此，我尽了一切努力，还是无法控制自己。

She was such a sharp little lady and used to sit with her hands folded in each other looking so very watchful while she talked to me that perhaps I found that rather irksome. Or perhaps it was her being so upright and trim, though I don’t think it was that, because I thought that quaintly pleasant. Nor can it have been the general expression of her face, which was very sparkling and pretty for an old lady. I don’t know what it was. Or at least if I do now, I thought I did not then. Or at least—but it don’t matter.
她是一位非常敏锐的小女士，当她和我说话时，她总是双手交叉坐着，看起来非常警惕，也许我觉得这很令人厌烦。或者也许是因为她是如此的正直和整洁，虽然我不认为是那样，因为我觉得那是一种古怪的令人愉快的感觉。也不是她脸上的一般表情，对于一位老太太来说，这是非常闪亮和美丽的。我不知道那是什么。或者至少如果我现在这样做了，我想我当时没有这样做。或者至少——但这并不重要。

Of a night when I was going upstairs to bed, she would invite me into her room, where she sat before the fire in a great chair; and, dear me, she would tell me about Morgan ap-Kerrig until I was quite low-spirited! Sometimes she recited a few verses from Crumlinwallinwer and the Mewlinn-willinwodd (if those are the right names, which I dare say they are not), and would become quite fiery with the sentiments they expressed. Though I never knew what they were (being in Welsh), further than that they were highly eulogistic of the lineage of Morgan ap-Kerrig.
有一天晚上，当我上楼睡觉时，她会邀请我去她的房间，她坐在火炉前的一把大椅子上；而且，亲爱的我，她会告诉我有关摩根·阿普·克里格的事，直到我情绪低落为止！有时她会背诵一些《Crumlinwallinwer》和《Mewlinn-willinwodd》中的诗句（如果这些是正确的名字，我敢说它们不是），并且会因它们所表达的情感而变得非常激烈。虽然我从来不知道他们是什么（威尔士语），但除此之外，他们还高度赞扬摩根·阿普·克里格的血统。

‘So, Miss Summerson,’ she would say to me with stately triumph, ‘this, you see, is the fortune inherited by my son. Wherever my son goes, he can claim kindred with Ap-Kerrig. He may not have money, but he always has what is much better—family, my dear.’
“所以，萨默森小姐，”她会带着庄严的胜利对我说，“你看，这是我儿子继承的财产。”无论我的儿子走到哪里，他都可以声称与阿普-克里格有血缘关系。他可能没有钱，但他总是拥有更好的东西——家人，亲爱的。

I had my doubts of their caring so very much for Morgan ap-Kerrig in India and China, but of course I never expressed them. I used to say it was a great thing to be so highly connected.
我对他们对印度和中国的 Morgan ap-Kerrig 如此关心表示怀疑，但当然我从未表达过。我曾经说过，如此紧密的联系是一件很棒的事情。

‘It IS, my dear, a great thing,’ Mrs. Woodcourt would reply. ‘It has its disadvantages; my son’s choice of a wife, for instance, is limited by it, but the matrimonial choice of the royal family is limited in much the same manner.’
“亲爱的，这是一件伟大的事情，”伍德考特夫人会回答道。 “它有它的缺点；例如，我儿子对妻子的选择就受到它的限制，但王室的婚姻选择也受到同样的限制。

Then she would pat me on the arm and smooth my dress, as much as to assure me that she had a good opinion of me, the distance between us notwithstanding.
然后她会拍拍我的手臂，抚平我的衣服，尽可能地向我保证她对我有很好的评价，尽管我们之间的距离很远。

‘Poor Mr. Woodcourt, my dear,’ she would say, and always with some emotion, for with her lofty pedigree she had a very affectionate heart, ‘was descended from a great Highland family, the MacCoorts of MacCoort. He served his king and country as an officer in the Royal Highlanders, and he died on the field. My son is one of the last representatives of two old families. With the blessing of heaven he will set them up again and unite them with another old family.’
“可怜的伍德考特先生，亲爱的，”她总是带着某种情感说，因为她有着崇高的血统，她有一颗非常深情的心，“他是高地一个伟大家族麦考特家族的后裔。”他作为皇家高地军官，为国王和国家服务，最后战死沙场。我的儿子是两个古老家族最后的代表之一。在上天的祝福下，他将重新安置他们，并将他们与另一个古老的家庭团结起来。

It was in vain for me to try to change the subject, as I used to try, only for the sake of novelty or perhaps because—but I need not be so particular. Mrs. Woodcourt never would let me change it.
我试图改变话题是徒劳的，就像我以前那样，只是为了新奇，或者也许是因为——但我不需要那么挑剔。伍德考特夫人从来不让我改变它。

‘My dear,’ she said one night, ‘you have so much sense and you look at the world in a quiet manner so superior to your time of life that it is a comfort to me to talk to you about these family matters of mine. You don’t know much of my son, my dear; but you know enough of him, I dare say, to recollect him?’
“亲爱的，”一天晚上，她说道，“你很有理智，你看待世界的方式比你所处的时代更安静，所以能和你谈论我的这些家庭事务对我来说是一种安慰。” 。亲爱的，你对我儿子了解不多；但我敢说，你对他足够了解，能够回忆起他吗？

‘Yes, ma’am. I recollect him.’
'是的女士。我记得他。

‘Yes, my dear. Now, my dear, I think you are a judge of character, and I should like to have your opinion of him.’
'是的亲爱的。现在，亲爱的，我认为你是一个性格判断者，我想听听你对他的看法。

‘Oh, Mrs. Woodcourt,’ said I, ‘that is so difficult!’
“噢，伍德考特夫人，”我说，“这太难了！”

‘Why is it so difficult, my dear?’ she returned. ‘I don’t see it myself.’
“为什么这么难，亲爱的？”她回答道。 “我自己没看到。”

‘To give an opinion—‘
“提出意见——”

‘On so slight an acquaintance, my dear. THAT’S true.’
“就这么一点点认识，亲爱的。这是真的。'

I didn’t mean that, because Mr. Woodcourt had been at our house a good deal altogether and had become quite intimate with my guardian. I said so, and added that he seemed to be very clever in his profession—we thought—and that his kindness and gentleness to Miss Flite were above all praise.
我不是这个意思，因为伍德考特先生经常来我们家，并且与我的监护人变得非常亲密。我这么说，并补充说，他在自己的职业上似乎非常聪明——我们认为——而且他对弗利特小姐的善良和温柔首先值得赞扬。

‘You do him justice!’ said Mrs. Woodcourt, pressing my hand. ‘You define him exactly. Allan is a dear fellow, and in his profession faultless. I say it, though I am his mother. Still, I must confess he is not without faults, love.’
“你公正地对待他了！”伍德考特夫人握着我的手说道。 ‘你准确地定义了他。艾伦是一位可爱的小伙子，在他的职业中无可挑剔。我这么说，虽然我是他的母亲。尽管如此，我必须承认他并非没有缺点，亲爱的。

‘None of us are,’ said I.
“我们谁都不是，”我说。

‘Ah! But his really are faults that he might correct, and ought to correct,’ returned the sharp old lady, sharply shaking her head. ‘I am so much attached to you that I may confide in you, my dear, as a third party wholly disinterested, that he is fickleness itself.’
'啊！但他确实有一些缺点，他可以改正，也应该改正。”敏锐的老妇人猛地摇头，回答道。 “我是如此依恋你，亲爱的，作为一个完全无私的第三方，我可以向你倾诉，他本身就是善变的。”

I said I should have thought it hardly possible that he could have been otherwise than constant to his profession and zealous in the pursuit of it, judging from the reputation he had earned.
我说，从他所赢得的声誉来看，我本以为他不可能不忠于自己的职业并热忱地追求它。

‘You are right again, my dear,’ the old lady retorted, ‘but I don’t refer to his profession, look you.’
“你又说对了，亲爱的，”老太太反驳道，“但我指的不是他的职业，你看。”

‘Oh!’ said I.
“哦！”我说。

‘No,’ said she. ‘I refer, my dear, to his social conduct. He is always paying trivial attentions to young ladies, and always has been, ever since he was eighteen. Now, my dear, he has never really cared for any one of them and has never meant in doing this to do any harm or to express anything but politeness and good nature. Still, it’s not right, you know; is it?’
“不，”她说。 “亲爱的，我指的是他的社交行为。他总是对年轻女士给予琐碎的关注，从十八岁起就一直如此。现在，亲爱的，他从来没有真正关心过他们中的任何一个人，也从来没有想过这样做是为了造成任何伤害，或者表达除了礼貌和善良之外的任何东西。不过，你知道，这是不对的；是吗？'

‘No,’ said I, as she seemed to wait for me.
“不，”我说，因为她似乎在等我。

‘And it might lead to mistaken notions, you see, my dear.’
“这可能会导致错误的观念，你看，亲爱的。”

I supposed it might.
我以为可能是这样

‘Therefore, I have told him many times that he really should be more careful, both in justice to himself and in justice to others. And he has always said, ‘Mother, I will be; but you know me better than anybody else does, and you know I mean no harm—in short, mean nothing.’ All of which is very true, my dear, but is no justification. However, as he is now gone so far away and for an indefinite time, and as he will have good opportunities and introductions, we may consider this past and gone. And you, my dear,’ said the old lady, who was now all nods and smiles, ‘regarding your dear self, my love?’
因此，我多次告诉他，他真的应该更加小心，无论是对自己，还是对他人。他总是说：‘妈妈，我会的；但你比任何人都更了解我，你知道我没有恶意——简而言之，没有任何恶意。”所有这些都是真的，亲爱的，但没有任何理由。然而，由于他现在已经离开了很远的地方，并且无限期地离开了，而且他将有很好的机会和介绍，我们可以认为这已经过去了。那么你呢，亲爱的，”老妇人现在满脸点头微笑，“说到你亲爱的自己，我的爱人？”

‘Me, Mrs. Woodcourt?’
“我，伍德考特夫人？”

‘Not to be always selfish, talking of my son, who has gone to seek his fortune and to find a wife—when do you mean to seek YOUR fortune and to find a husband, Miss Summerson? Hey, look you! Now you blush!’
“不要总是自私，谈论我的儿子，他已经去寻找自己的财富并寻找妻子了——你打算什么时候寻找你的财富并找到一个丈夫，萨默森小姐？嘿，看你！现在你脸红了！

I don’t think I did blush—at all events, it was not important if I did—and I said my present fortune perfectly contented me and I had no wish to change it.
我不认为我脸红了——不管怎样，脸红了也不重要——而且我说我现在的财富让我很满足，我不想改变它。

‘Shall I tell you what I always think of you and the fortune yet to come for you, my love?’ said Mrs. Woodcourt.
“我要告诉你我一直以来对你的看法，以及未来的好运吗，我的爱人？”伍德考特夫人说道。

‘If you believe you are a good prophet,’ said I.
“如果你相信你是一个好先知，”我说。

‘Why, then, it is that you will marry some one very rich and very worthy, much older—five and twenty years, perhaps—than yourself. And you will be an excellent wife, and much beloved, and very happy.’
“那么，你会嫁给一个非常富有、非常有价值、比你年长很多——也许五岁到二十岁的人。”你将成为一位出色的妻子，深受爱戴，而且非常幸福。”

‘That is a good fortune,’ said I. ‘But why is it to be mine?’
“真是好运气，”我说，“但为什么它会是我的呢？”

‘My dear,’ she returned, ‘there’s suitability in it—you are so busy, and so neat, and so peculiarly situated altogether that there’s suitability in it, and it will come to pass. And nobody, my love, will congratulate you more sincerely on such a marriage than I shall.’
“亲爱的，”她回答道，“这很合适——你如此忙碌，如此整洁，而且位置如此奇特，所以这是合适的，它会实现的。”亲爱的，没有人会比我更真诚地祝贺你的婚姻。

It was curious that this should make me uncomfortable, but I think it did. I know it did. It made me for some part of that night uncomfortable. I was so ashamed of my folly that I did not like to confess it even to Ada, and that made me more uncomfortable still. I would have given anything not to have been so much in the bright old lady’s confidence if I could have possibly declined it. It gave me the most inconsistent opinions of her. At one time I thought she was a story-teller, and at another time that she was the pink of truth. Now I suspected that she was very cunning, next moment I believed her honest Welsh heart to be perfectly innocent and simple. And after all, what did it matter to me, and why did it matter to me? Why could not I, going up to bed with my basket of keys, stop to sit down by her fire and accommodate myself for a little while to her, at least as well as to anybody else, and not trouble myself about the harmless things she said to me? Impelled towards her, as I certainly was, for I was very anxious that she should like me and was very glad indeed that she did, why should I harp afterwards, with actual distress and pain, on every word she said and weigh it over and over again in twenty scales? Why was it so worrying to me to have her in our house, and confidential to me every night, when I yet felt that it was better and safer somehow that she should be there than anywhere else? These were perplexities and contradictions that I could not account for. At least, if I could—but I shall come to all that by and by, and it is mere idleness to go on about it now.
奇怪的是，这会让我感到不舒服，但我认为确实如此。我知道确实如此。那天晚上的某些时候，这让我感到不舒服。我为自己的愚蠢感到羞愧，甚至不愿意向艾达承认，这让我更加不舒服。如果我可以拒绝的话，我愿意付出任何代价来不让那位聪明的老太太如此信任我。这给了我对她最不一致的看法。有一段时间我认为她是一个讲故事的人，而另一次我认为她是真理的粉红色。现在我怀疑她很狡猾，下一刻我相信她那颗诚实的威尔士心是天真单纯的。毕竟，这对我来说重要什么，为什么对我重要？为什么我不能带着一篮子钥匙上床睡觉，停下来在她的火边坐下来，让自己适应她，至少也适应其他任何人，而不是为她那些无害的事情而烦恼。对我说？我确实是被逼着走向她的，因为我非常渴望她会喜欢我，而且确实很高兴她喜欢我，为什么我要在事后带着真正的痛苦和痛苦，对她说的每一个字喋喋不休，权衡利弊，再以二十个音阶重来一遍？当我觉得她呆在家里比在其他地方更好、更安全时，为什么让她住在我们家，每天晚上都对我保密，让我如此担心？这些都是我无法解释的困惑和矛盾。至少，如果我可以的话——但是我会慢慢地讲到这一切，现在再继续讨论这件事纯属无聊。

So when Mrs. Woodcourt went away, I was sorry to lose her but was relieved too. And then Caddy Jellyby came down, and Caddy brought such a packet of domestic news that it gave us abundant occupation.
因此，当伍德考特夫人离开时，我为失去她感到遗憾，但也松了口气。然后凯迪杰利比下来了，凯迪带来了这样一包国内新闻，这给我们带来了充足的工作。

First Caddy declared (and would at first declare nothing else) that I was the best adviser that ever was known. This, my pet said, was no news at all; and this, I said, of course, was nonsense. Then Caddy told us that she was going to be married in a month and that if Ada and I would be her bridesmaids, she was the happiest girl in the world. To be sure, this was news indeed; and I thought we never should have done talking about it, we had so much to say to Caddy, and Caddy had so much to say to us.
球童首先宣布（并且一开始不会宣布任何其他事情）我是有史以来最好的顾问。我的宠物说，这根本不是什么新闻；我说，这当然是无稽之谈。然后凯迪告诉我们，她一个月后就要结婚了，如果我和艾达做她的伴娘，她就是世界上最幸福的女孩。平心而论，这确实是新闻。我认为我们根本不应该谈论这件事，我们有很多话要对凯迪说，凯迪也有很多话要对我们说。

It seemed that Caddy’s unfortunate papa had got over his bankruptcy—‘gone through the Gazette,’ was the expression Caddy used, as if it were a tunnel—with the general clemency and commiseration of his creditors, and had got rid of his affairs in some blessed manner without succeeding in understanding them, and had given up everything he possessed (which was not worth much, I should think, to judge from the state of the furniture), and had satisfied every one concerned that he could do no more, poor man. So, he had been honourably dismissed to ‘the office’ to begin the world again. What he did at the office, I never knew; Caddy said he was a ‘custom-house and general agent,’ and the only thing I ever understood about that business was that when he wanted money more than usual he went to the docks to look for it, and hardly ever found it.
凯迪不幸的爸爸似乎已经从破产的阴影中走出来了——凯迪用“通过公报”这样的说法，仿佛这是一条隧道——带着债权人的普遍宽大和同情，并在某种受祝福的方式，但没有成功地理解它们，并放弃了他所拥有的一切（我想，从家具的状态来判断，这并没有多大价值），并且让所有有关的人都满意，他不能再做更多的事情，悲惨的人。于是，他被光荣地解雇到“办公室”，重新开始新的世界。我从来不知道他在办公室做什么；凯迪说他是一名“海关和总代理”，而我对这项业务唯一了解的是，当他比平时更需要钱时，他会去码头寻找，但几乎找不到。

As soon as her papa had tranquillized his mind by becoming this shorn lamb, and they had removed to a furnished lodging in Hatton Garden (where I found the children, when I afterwards went there, cutting the horse hair out of the seats of the chairs and choking themselves with it), Caddy had brought about a meeting between him and old Mr. Turveydrop; and poor Mr. Jellyby, being very humble and meek, had deferred to Mr. Turveydrop’s deportment so submissively that they had become excellent friends. By degrees, old Mr. Turveydrop, thus familiarized with the idea of his son’s marriage, had worked up his parental feelings to the height of contemplating that event as being near at hand and had given his gracious consent to the young couple commencing housekeeping at the academy in Newman Street when they would.
当她的爸爸通过变成这只剪了毛的羔羊来平静自己的心情后，他们就搬到了哈顿花园的一间带家具的住处（我在那里找到了孩子们，当我后来去那里时，剪掉了椅子座位上的马毛）卡迪促成了他和老特维德罗普先生的会面。可怜的杰利比先生非常谦虚、温顺，他对特维德罗普先生的举止非常顺从，以至于他们成了极好的朋友。渐渐地，特维德罗普老先生对儿子结婚的事了如指掌，他作为父母的感情已经达到了顶峰，认为这件事即将发生，并慷慨地同意这对年轻夫妇开始在家里做家务。当他们愿意时，他们会在纽曼街的学院。

‘And your papa, Caddy. What did he say?’
“还有你的爸爸，凯迪。他说什么？'

‘Oh! Poor Pa,’ said Caddy, ‘only cried and said he hoped we might get on better than he and Ma had got on. He didn’t say so before Prince, he only said so to me. And he said, ‘My poor girl, you have not been very well taught how to make a home for your husband, but unless you mean with all your heart to strive to do it, you bad better murder him than marry him—if you really love him.’’
'哦！可怜的爸爸，”凯迪说，“只是哭着说他希望我们能比他和妈妈相处得更好。他没有在Prince面前这么说过，他只对我这么说过。他说：“我可怜的女孩，你没有被很好地教导如何为你的丈夫建立一个家，但除非你全心全意地努力做到这一点，否则你最好杀了他，而不是嫁给他——如果你真的很爱他。”

‘And how did you reassure him, Caddy?’
“凯迪，你是怎么让他放心的？”

‘Why, it was very distressing, you know, to see poor Pa so low and hear him say such terrible things, and I couldn’t help crying myself. But I told him that I DID mean it with all my heart and that I hoped our house would be a place for him to come and find some comfort in of an evening and that I hoped and thought I could be a better daughter to him there than at home. Then I mentioned Peepy’s coming to stay with me, and then Pa began to cry again and said the children were Indians.’
“哎呀，你知道，看到可怜的爸爸如此沮丧，听他说这些可怕的话，我感到非常痛苦，我自己也忍不住哭了。但我告诉他，我确实是真心实意的，我希望我们的房子能成为他晚上来这里寻求安慰的地方，我希望并认为我可以在那里成为他更好的女儿比在家里。然后我提到皮皮要来和我住在一起，然后爸爸又开始哭，说孩子们是印第安人。

‘Indians, Caddy?’
“印第安人，凯迪？”

‘Yes,’ said Caddy, ‘wild Indians. And Pa said’—here she began to sob, poor girl, not at all like the happiest girl in the world— ‘that he was sensible the best thing that could happen to them was their being all tomahawked together.’
“是的，”凯迪说，“野生印第安人。”爸爸说——说到这里她开始抽泣，可怜的女孩，一点也不像世界上最幸福的女孩——“他很明白，发生在他们身上最好的事情就是他们一起被战斧砍死。”

Ada suggested that it was comfortable to know that Mr. Jellyby did not mean these destructive sentiments.
艾达表示，知道杰利比先生并不是故意表达这些破坏性的情绪，这让她感到很安心。

‘No, of course I know Pa wouldn’t like his family to be weltering in their blood,’ said Caddy, ‘but he means that they are very unfortunate in being Ma’s children and that he is very unfortunate in being Ma’s husband; and I am sure that’s true, though it seems unnatural to say so.’
“不，我当然知道爸爸不希望他的家人沾染上他们的血统，”凯迪说，“但他的意思是，他们是妈妈的孩子，他是非常不幸的，而他是妈妈的丈夫，是非常不幸的；我确信这是真的，尽管这么说似乎不自然。

I asked Caddy if Mrs. Jellyby knew that her wedding-day was fixed.
我问凯蒂杰利比夫人是否知道她的婚礼日期已经确定。

‘Oh! You know what Ma is, Esther,’ she returned. ‘It’s impossible to say whether she knows it or not. She has been told it often enough; and when she IS told it, she only gives me a placid look, as if I was I don’t know what—a steeple in the distance,’ said Caddy with a sudden idea; ‘and then she shakes her head and says ‘Oh, Caddy, Caddy, what a tease you are!’ and goes on with the Borrioboola letters.’
'哦！你知道妈妈是什么，艾丝特，”她回答道。 ‘很难说她是否知道。她已经听够了这句话了。当她告诉我这件事时，她只是平静地看了我一眼，就好像我是——我不知道是什么——远处的一座尖塔。”卡迪突然灵机一动说道。 “然后她摇摇头说‘哦，凯迪，凯迪，你真是个逗人的人！’然后继续写博里奥布拉的信。”

‘And about your wardrobe, Caddy?’ said I. For she was under no restraint with us.
“凯迪，你的衣柜呢？”我问道。因为她和我们在一起时不受任何约束。

‘Well, my dear Esther,’’ she returned, drying her eyes, ‘I must do the best I can and trust to my dear Prince never to have an unkind remembrance of my coming so shabbily to him. If the question concerned an outfit for Borrioboola, Ma would know all about it and would be quite excited. Being what it is, she neither knows nor cares.’
“好吧，我亲爱的艾丝特，”她擦干眼睛回答道，“我必须尽我所能，相信我亲爱的王子，我永远不会对我如此寒酸地来到他身边有不善的记忆。如果问题涉及博里奥布拉的服装，妈妈会知道一切，并且会非常兴奋。事实就是如此，她既不知道也不关心。

Caddy was not at all deficient in natural affection for her mother, but mentioned this with tears as an undeniable fact, which I am afraid it was. We were sorry for the poor dear girl and found so much to admire in the good disposition which had survived under such discouragement that we both at once (I mean Ada and I) proposed a little scheme that made her perfectly joyful. This was her staying with us for three weeks, my staying with her for one, and our all three contriving and cutting out, and repairing, and sewing, and saving, and doing the very best we could think of to make the most of her stock. My guardian being as pleased with the idea as Caddy was, we took her home next day to arrange the matter and brought her out again in triumph with her boxes and all the purchases that could be squeezed out of a ten-pound note, which Mr. Jellyby had found in the docks I suppose, but which he at all events gave her. What my guardian would not have given her if we had encouraged him, it would be difficult to say, but we thought it right to compound for no more than her wedding-dress and bonnet. He agreed to this compromise, and if Caddy had ever been happy in her life, she was happy when we sat down to work.
凯蒂对母亲的感情一点也不缺乏，只是含着泪提到这一点，这是无可否认的事实，恐怕确实如此。我们为这个可怜的亲爱的女孩感到难过，并发现她在如此沮丧的情况下幸存下来的良好性格非常值得钦佩，因此我们俩（我是指艾达和我）立即提出了一个让她非常高兴的小计划。这是她和我们一起住了三个星期，我和她一起住了一周，我们三个人一起设计、剪裁、修理、缝纫、节省，并尽我们所能想到的最好的方式来充分利用她库存。我的监护人和凯蒂一样对这个想法感到满意，第二天我们带她回家安排这件事，并带着她的盒子和所有可以从十英镑钞票中挤出来的东西凯旋地再次带她出去。我想杰利比是在码头找到的，但他无论如何都给了她。如果我们鼓励我的监护人，他不会给她什么，这很难说，但我们认为，只为她的婚纱和帽子而复合是正确的。他同意了这种妥协，如果凯迪一生幸福的话，当我们坐下来工作时她也会很高兴。

She was clumsy enough with her needle, poor girl, and pricked her fingers as much as she had been used to ink them. She could not help reddening a little now and then, partly with the smart and partly with vexation at being able to do no better, but she soon got over that and began to improve rapidly. So day after day she, and my darling, and my little maid Charley, and a milliner out of the town, and I, sat hard at work, as pleasantly as possible.
可怜的女孩，她用针的方式实在是太笨拙了，她的手指被刺破了，就像她以前在手指上涂墨水一样。她不时地忍不住脸红了一点，一半是聪明，一半是因为自己无法做得更好而烦恼，但她很快就克服了这一点，并开始迅速进步。就这样，日复一日，她、我的宝贝、我的小女仆查理、城外的一位女帽商，还有我，都尽可能愉快地埋头工作。

Over and above this, Caddy was very anxious ‘to learn housekeeping,’ as she said. Now, mercy upon us! The idea of her learning housekeeping of a person of my vast experience was such a joke that I laughed, and coloured up, and fell into a comical confusion when she proposed it. However, I said, ‘Caddy, I am sure you are very welcome to learn anything that you can learn of ME, my dear,’ and I showed her all my books and methods and all my fidgety ways. You would have supposed that I was showing her some wonderful inventions, by her study of them; and if you had seen her, whenever I jingled my housekeeping keys, get up and attend me, certainly you might have thought that there never was a greater imposter than I with a blinder follower than Caddy Jellyby.
除此之外，正如她所说，凯迪非常渴望“学习家务”。现在，怜悯我们吧！她让我这个经验丰富的人学习家务的想法简直是个笑话，当她提出这个想法时，我笑了，脸色红了，陷入了滑稽的困惑中。然而，我说，‘凯迪，我相信非常欢迎你向我学习任何你能学到的东西，亲爱的，’我向她展示了我所有的书和方法以及我所有烦躁的方式。你可能会认为我正在向她展示一些奇妙的发明，通过她对它们的研究；但事实并非如此。如果你见过她，每当我摇动我的家务钥匙，站起来照顾我时，你肯定会认为没有比我更大的冒名顶替者和比凯迪·杰利比更盲目的追随者了。

So what with working and housekeeping, and lessons to Charley, and backgammon in the evening with my guardian, and duets with Ada, the three weeks slipped fast away. Then I went home with Caddy to see what could be done there, and Ada and Charley remained behind to take care of my guardian.
那么，工作、家务、给查理上课、晚上和我的监护人玩双陆棋、和艾达二重唱，三个星期很快就过去了。然后我和凯迪一起回家看看能做些什么，艾达和查理留下来照顾我的监护人。

When I say I went home with Caddy, I mean to the furnished lodging in Hatton Garden. We went to Newman Street two or three times, where preparations were in progress too—a good many, I observed, for enhancing the comforts of old Mr. Turveydrop, and a few for putting the newly married couple away cheaply at the top of the house—but our great point was to make the furnished lodging decent for the wedding-breakfast and to imbue Mrs. Jellyby beforehand with some faint sense of the occasion.
当我说我和凯迪一起回家时，我指的是哈顿花园带家具的住所。我们去了纽曼街两三次，那里的准备工作也在进行中——据我观察，很多准备工作是为了让老特维德罗普先生更加舒适，还有一些准备工作是为了把这对新婚夫妇便宜地安置在顶层。房子——但我们的重点是让配备家具的住所适合举行婚礼早餐，并事先让杰利比太太对这个场合有一些隐约的了解。

The latter was the more difficult thing of the two because Mrs. Jellyby and an unwholesome boy occupied the front sitting-room (the back one was a mere closet), and it was littered down with wastepaper and Borrioboolan documents, as an untidy stable might be littered with straw. Mrs. Jellyby sat there all day drinking strong coffee, dictating, and holding Borrioboolan interviews by appointment. The unwholesome boy, who seemed to me to be going into a decline, took his meals out of the house. When Mr. Jellyby came home, he usually groaned and went down into the kitchen. There he got something to eat if the servant would give him anything, and then, feeling that he was in the way, went out and walked about Hatton Garden in the wet. The poor children scrambled up and tumbled down the house as they had always been accustomed to do.
后者是这两件事中更困难的事情，因为杰利比夫人和一个不健康的男孩占据了前面的起居室（后面的起居室只是一个壁橱），里面散落着废纸和博里奥布尔文件，就像一个不整洁的马厩可能会发生的那样。撒上稻草。杰利比夫人整天坐在那里，喝着浓咖啡，口授，并接受博里奥布尔兰预约的采访。在我看来，那个不健康的男孩似乎正在走向衰落，他把饭菜带出了屋子。当杰利比先生回家时，他通常会呻吟一声，然后走进厨房。在那里，如果仆人愿意给他任何东西，他就可以吃点东西，然后，他觉得自己妨碍了他，就出去在湿漉漉的哈顿花园里散步。可怜的孩子们像往常一样在房子里爬上爬下。

The production of these devoted little sacrifices in any presentable condition being quite out of the question at a week’s notice, I proposed to Caddy that we should make them as happy as we could on her marriage morning in the attic where they all slept, and should confine our greatest efforts to her mama and her mama’s room, and a clean breakfast. In truth Mrs. Jellyby required a good deal of attention, the lattice-work up her back having widened considerably since I first knew her and her hair looking like the mane of a dustman’s horse.
在一周的通知中，在任何像样的条件下制作这些奉献的小牺牲都是完全不可能的，我向凯蒂提议，我们应该在她结婚的早晨在他们都睡觉的阁楼上让他们尽可能高兴，并且应该我们最大的努力仅限于她妈妈和她妈妈的房间，以及干净的早餐。事实上，杰利比夫人需要大量的关注，自从我第一次认识她以来，她背部的格子结构已经大大加宽，她的头发看起来就像清洁工的马的鬃毛。

Thinking that the display of Caddy’s wardrobe would be the best means of approaching the subject, I invited Mrs. Jellyby to come and look at it spread out on Caddy’s bed in the evening after the unwholesome boy was gone.
我认为展示凯迪的衣柜是探讨这个主题的最佳方式，所以晚上那个不健康的男孩离开后，我邀请杰利比太太来看看凯迪床上铺着的衣服。

‘My dear Miss Summerson,’ said she, rising from her desk with her usual sweetness of temper, ‘these are really ridiculous preparations, though your assisting them is a proof of your kindness. There is something so inexpressibly absurd to me in the idea of Caddy being married! Oh, Caddy, you silly, silly, silly puss!’
“我亲爱的萨默森小姐，”她从办公桌上站起来，带着一贯的和善脾气，说道，“这些准备工作实在是可笑，尽管你对他们的帮助证明了你的善意。对我来说，凯蒂结婚的想法实在是太荒谬了！哦，凯迪，你这个傻、傻、傻的小猫！

She came upstairs with us notwithstanding and looked at the clothes in her customary far-off manner. They suggested one distinct idea to her, for she said with her placid smile, and shaking her head, ‘My good Miss Summerson, at half the cost, this weak child might have been equipped for Africa!’
尽管如此，她还是和我们一起上楼，用她惯常的冷漠态度打量着衣服。他们向她提出了一个独特的想法，因为她平静地微笑着，摇着头说道：“我的好萨默森小姐，只要花一半的费用，这个弱小的孩子就可以为非洲做好准备！”

On our going downstairs again, Mrs. Jellyby asked me whether this troublesome business was really to take place next Wednesday. And on my replying yes, she said, ‘Will my room be required, my dear Miss Summerson? For it’s quite impossible that I can put my papers away.’
当我们再次下楼时，杰利比太太问我这件麻烦事是否真的要在下周三进行。当我回答“是”时，她说：“我亲爱的萨默森小姐，需要我的房间吗？”因为我根本不可能把文件收起来。”

I took the liberty of saying that the room would certainly be wanted and that I thought we must put the papers away somewhere. ‘Well, my dear Miss Summerson,’ said Mrs. Jellyby, ‘you know best, I dare say. But by obliging me to employ a boy, Caddy has embarrassed me to that extent, overwhelmed as I am with public business, that I don’t know which way to turn. We have a Ramification meeting, too, on Wednesday afternoon, and the inconvenience is very serious.’
我冒昧地说，这个房间肯定会被需要，我认为我们必须把文件放在某个地方。 “好吧，我亲爱的萨默森小姐，”杰利比夫人说，“我敢说你最了解。”但是，凯迪强迫我雇用一个男孩，这让我很尴尬，因为我对公共事务不知所措，我不知道该走哪条路。我们周三下午也有一个 Ramification 会议，带来的不便非常严重。”

‘It is not likely to occur again,’ said I, smiling. ‘Caddy will be married but once, probably.’
“这种事不太可能再发生了。”我微笑着说道。 “球童可能会结婚，但一次。”

‘That’s true,’ Mrs. Jellyby replied; ‘that’s true, my dear. I suppose we must make the best of it!’
“确实如此，”杰利比夫人回答道。 ‘确实如此，亲爱的。我想我们必须充分利用它！

The next question was how Mrs. Jellyby should be dressed on the occasion. I thought it very curious to see her looking on serenely from her writing-table while Caddy and I discussed it, occasionally shaking her head at us with a half-reproachful smile like a superior spirit who could just bear with our trifling.
下一个问题是杰利比夫人在这个场合应该穿什么衣服。我觉得很奇怪的是，当凯迪和我讨论这件事时，她坐在写字台上平静地看着，偶尔带着半责备的微笑向我们摇摇头，就像一个高高在上的精灵，可以忍受我们的琐事。

The state in which her dresses were, and the extraordinary confusion in which she kept them, added not a little to our difficulty; but at length we devised something not very unlike what a common-place mother might wear on such an occasion. The abstracted manner in which Mrs. Jellyby would deliver herself up to having this attire tried on by the dressmaker, and the sweetness with which she would then observe to me how sorry she was that I had not turned my thoughts to Africa, were consistent with the rest of her behaviour.
她衣服的状况，以及她把它们存放得异常混乱，给我们增加了不少困难。但最终我们设计了一件与普通母亲在这种场合可能穿的衣服不太相似的衣服。杰利比夫人让裁缝试穿这件衣服时表现出的心不在焉的态度，以及随后她甜蜜地对我说她为我没有把注意力转向非洲而感到多么遗憾，这些都与她的其余行为。

The lodging was rather confined as to space, but I fancied that if Mrs. Jellyby’s household had been the only lodgers in Saint Paul’s or Saint Peter’s, the sole advantage they would have found in the size of the building would have been its affording a great deal of room to be dirty in. I believe that nothing belonging to the family which it had been possible to break was unbroken at the time of those preparations for Caddy’s marriage, that nothing which it had been possible to spoil in any way was unspoilt, and that no domestic object which was capable of collecting dirt, from a dear child’s knee to the door-plate, was without as much dirt as could well accumulate upon it.
住宿的空间相当有限，但我想，如果杰利比夫人一家是圣保罗或圣彼得的唯一房客，那么他们在这座建筑的规模上发现的唯一优势就是它能提供很大的住宿空间。我相信，在凯迪准备结婚的时候，属于这个家庭的一切可能被破坏的东西都没有被破坏，任何可能以任何方式破坏的东西都没有被破坏，凡是能够积聚污垢的家用物品，从可爱的孩子的膝盖到门板，都不会没有那么多的污垢积聚在上面。

Poor Mr. Jellyby, who very seldom spoke and almost always sat when he was at home with his head against the wall, became interested when he saw that Caddy and I were attempting to establish some order among all this waste and ruin and took off his coat to help. But such wonderful things came tumbling out of the closets when they were opened—bits of mouldy pie, sour bottles, Mrs. Jellyby’s caps, letters, tea, forks, odd boots and shoes of children, firewood, wafers, saucepan-lids, damp sugar in odds and ends of paper bags, footstools, blacklead brushes, bread, Mrs. Jellyby’s bonnets, books with butter sticking to the binding, guttered candle ends put out by being turned upside down in broken candlesticks, nutshells, heads and tails of shrimps, dinner-mats, gloves, coffeegrounds, umbrellas—that he looked frightened, and left off again. But he came regularly every evening and sat without his coat, with his head against the wall, as though he would have helped us if he had known how.
可怜的杰利比先生很少说话，在家时几乎总是把头靠在墙上坐着，当他看到凯迪和我试图在所有这些浪费和废墟中建立某种秩序时，他开始感兴趣，并脱下了他的衣服。外套来帮忙。但当壁橱打开时，这些奇妙的东西却从壁橱里滚了出来——发霉的馅饼、酸瓶子、杰利比夫人的帽子、信件、茶、叉子、奇怪的儿童靴子和鞋子、木柴、薄饼、锅盖、潮湿的东西。纸袋零碎的糖、脚凳、黑铅刷、面包、杰利比夫人的帽子、装订上粘着黄油的书、被倒置在破碎烛台、果壳、虾头和虾尾中的蜡烛头、餐垫、手套、咖啡渣、雨伞——他看起来很害怕，然后又离开了。但他每天晚上都会定期来，不穿外套，头靠在墙上坐着，好像如果他知道如何帮助我们一样。

‘Poor Pa!’ said Caddy to me on the night before the great day, when we really had got things a little to rights. ‘It seems unkind to leave him, Esther. But what could I do if I stayed! Since I first knew you, I have tidied and tidied over and over again, but it’s useless. Ma and Africa, together, upset the whole house directly. We never have a servant who don’t drink. Ma’s ruinous to everything.’
“可怜的爸爸！”在伟大的一天的前一天晚上，凯迪对我说，当时我们的情况确实有所改善。 “离开他似乎很不友善，埃丝特。但如果我留下来又能做什么呢！自从认识你以来，我整理了一遍又一遍，却毫无用处。马云和非洲一起，直接掀翻了整个房子。我们从来没有不喝酒的仆人。妈妈毁了一切。

Mr. Jellyby could not hear what she said, but he seemed very low indeed and shed tears, I thought.
杰利比先生听不见她说什么，但我想，他看起来确实很沮丧，还流着泪。

‘My heart aches for him; that it does!’ sobbed Caddy. ‘I can’t help thinking to-night, Esther, how dearly I hope to be happy with Prince, and how dearly Pa hoped, I dare say, to be happy with Ma. What a disappointed life!’
‘我的心为他而痛；确实如此！”凯迪抽泣着。 “今晚我情不自禁地想，埃丝特，我是多么希望能和普林斯在一起幸福，我敢说，爸爸是多么希望和妈妈在一起幸福。多么令人失望的生活啊！

‘My dear Caddy!’ said Mr. Jellyby, looking slowly round from the wail. It was the first time, I think, I ever heard him say three words together.
“我亲爱的球童！”杰利比先生说，他从哭声中慢慢地环顾四周。我想，这是我第一次听到他同时说出三个词。

‘Yes, Pa!’ cried Caddy, going to him and embracing him affectionately.
“是的，爸爸！”凯迪喊道，走到他身边，深情地拥抱了他。

‘My dear Caddy,’ said Mr. Jellyby. ‘Never have—‘
“我亲爱的球童，”杰利比先生说。 '从来没有-'

‘Not Prince, Pa?’ faltered Caddy. ‘Not have Prince?’
“爸爸，不是普林斯吗？”凯蒂​​结结巴巴地说。 “没有王子吗？”

‘Yes, my dear,’ said Mr. Jellyby. ‘Have him, certainly. But, never have—‘
“是的，亲爱的，”杰利比先生说。 ‘当然有他。但是，从来没有——”

I mentioned in my account of our first visit in Thavies Inn that Richard described Mr. Jellyby as frequently opening his mouth after dinner without saying anything. It was a habit of his. He opened his mouth now a great many times and shook his head in a melancholy manner.
我在第一次访问泰维斯旅馆时提到，理查德描述杰利比先生经常在晚饭后张开嘴，什么也没说。这是他的习惯。他多次张开嘴，忧郁地摇摇头。

‘What do you wish me not to have? Don’t have what, dear Pa?’ asked Caddy, coaxing him, with her arms round his neck.
‘你希望我不要什么？亲爱的爸爸，没有什么吗？”凯蒂​​问道，用双臂搂着他的脖子哄他。

‘Never have a mission, my dear child.’
“永远不要有使命，我亲爱的孩子。”

Mr. Jellyby groaned and laid his head against the wall again, and this was the only time I ever heard him make any approach to expressing his sentiments on the Borrioboolan question. I suppose he had been more talkative and lively once, but he seemed to have been completely exhausted long before I knew him.
杰利比先生呻吟着，再次把头靠在墙上，这是我唯一一次听到他对博里奥布尔兰问题表达自己的看法。我想他曾经比较健谈和活泼，但在我认识他之前，他似乎已经完全筋疲力尽了。

I thought Mrs. Jellyby never would have left off serenely looking over her papers and drinking coffee that night. It was twelve o’clock before we could obtain possession of the room, and the clearance it required then was so discouraging that Caddy, who was almost tired out, sat down in the middle of the dust and cried. But she soon cheered up, and we did wonders with it before we went to bed.
我想杰利比夫人那天晚上永远不会停止平静地检查她的文件和喝咖啡。到了十二点钟，我们才获得了房间的所有权，当时所要求的许可实在令人沮丧，以至于几乎精疲力尽的凯迪坐在灰尘中哭泣。但她很快就高兴起来，我们在睡觉前用它创造了奇迹。

In the morning it looked, by the aid of a few flowers and a quantity of soap and water and a little arrangement, quite gay. The plain breakfast made a cheerful show, and Caddy was perfectly charming. But when my darling came, I thought—and I think now— that I never had seen such a dear face as my beautiful pet’s.
早上，借助几朵花、大量肥皂和水以及一些小布置，它看起来非常愉快。简单的早餐呈现出欢乐的气氛，凯迪也非常迷人。但当我的爱人到来时，我想——现在我也这么想——我从来没有见过像我美丽的宠物那样可爱的脸。

We made a little feast for the children upstairs, and we put Peepy at the head of the table, and we showed them Caddy in her bridal dress, and they clapped their hands and hurrahed, and Caddy cried to think that she was going away from them and hugged them over and over again until we brought Prince up to fetch her away—when, I am sorry to say, Peepy bit him. Then there was old Mr. Turveydrop downstairs, in a state of deportment not to be expressed, benignly blessing Caddy and giving my guardian to understand that his son’s happiness was his own parental work and that he sacrificed personal considerations to ensure it. ‘My dear sir,’ said Mr. Turveydrop, ‘these young people will live with me; my house is large enough for their accommodation, and they shall not want the shelter of my roof. I could have wished—you will understand the allusion, Mr. Jarndyce, for you remember my illustrious patron the Prince Regent —I could have wished that my son had married into a family where there was more deportment, but the will of heaven be done!’
我们为楼上的孩子们做了一顿小盛宴，我们把皮皮放在桌子的一头，我们给他们看了穿着新娘礼服的凯蒂，他们拍手欢呼，凯蒂哭着想到她要离开他们一遍又一遍地拥抱他们，直到我们把普林斯带上来把她带走——我很遗憾地说，皮皮咬了他。然后楼下的老特维德罗普先生以一种难以言喻的举止，善意地祝福凯迪，让我的监护人明白，他儿子的幸福是他父母自己的努力，他牺牲了个人的考虑来确保这一点。 “亲爱的先生，”特维德罗普先生说，“这些年轻人将和我住在一起；我的房子足够大，足够他们住了，他们不会想要我屋顶的庇护。我本可以希望——贾迪斯先生，你会明白这个暗示的，因为你还记得我杰出的赞助人摄政王——我本可以希望我的儿子嫁入一个更有礼貌的家庭，但愿天意如此。 ！'

Mr. and Mrs. Pardiggle were of the party—Mr. Pardiggle, an obstinate-looking man with a large waistcoat and stubbly hair, who was always talking in a loud bass voice about his mite, or Mrs. Pardiggle’s mite, or their five boys’ mites. Mr. Quale, with his hair brushed back as usual and his knobs of temples shining very much, was also there, not in the character of a disappointed lover, but as the accepted of a young—at least, an unmarried—lady, a Miss Wisk, who was also there. Miss Wisk’s mission, my guardian said, was to show the world that woman’s mission was man’s mission and that the only genuine mission of both man and woman was to be always moving declaratory resolutions about things in general at public meetings. The guests were few, but were, as one might expect at Mrs. Jellyby’s, all devoted to public objects only. Besides those I have mentioned, there was an extremely dirty lady with her bonnet all awry and the ticketed price of her dress still sticking on it, whose neglected home, Caddy told me, was like a filthy wilderness, but whose church was like a fancy fair. A very contentious gentleman, who said it was his mission to be everybody’s brother but who appeared to be on terms of coolness with the whole of his large family, completed the party.
帕迪格先生和夫人是其中一员——帕迪格先生。帕迪格，一个看上去很固执的男人，穿着一件大背心，留着胡茬，他总是用大声的低音谈论他的小毛病，或者帕迪格太太的小毛病，或者他们五个男孩的小毛病。奎尔先生也在那里，他的头发像往常一样向后梳着，太阳穴闪闪发亮，他的形象并不是一个失望的情人，而是一位年轻——至少是一位未婚——女士的接受者，一位年轻的女士。威斯克小姐也在场。我的监护人说，威斯克小姐的使命是向世界表明，女人的使命就是男人的使命，而男人和女人唯一真正的使命就是始终在公开会议上就一般事务提出宣言性决议。客人虽少，但正如人们在杰利比夫人家所预料的那样，全都只专注于公共事务。除了我提到的那些之外，还有一位非常肮脏的女士，她的帽子歪了，衣服上还贴着她衣服的票价，凯迪告诉我，她的家被忽视了，就像一片肮脏的荒野，但她的教堂就像一座豪华的教堂。公平的。一位非常好争论的绅士，他说他的使命是成为每个人的兄弟，但他似乎对整个大家庭都很冷淡，他完成了聚会。

A party, having less in common with such an occasion, could hardly have been got together by any ingenuity. Such a mean mission as the domestic mission was the very last thing to be endured among them; indeed, Miss Wisk informed us, with great indignation, before we sat down to breakfast, that the idea of woman’s mission lying chiefly in the narrow sphere of home was an outrageous slander on the part of her tyrant, man. One other singularity was that nobody with a mission—except Mr. Quale, whose mission, as I think I have formerly said, was to be in ecstasies with everybody’s mission— cared at all for anybody’s mission. Mrs. Pardiggle being as clear that the only one infallible course was her course of pouncing upon the poor and applying benevolence to them like a strait-waistcoat; as Miss Wisk was that the only practical thing for the world was the emancipation of woman from the thraldom of her tyrant, man. Mrs. Jellyby, all the while, sat smiling at the limited vision that could see anything but Borrioboola-Gha.
与这种场合没有多少共同点的聚会几乎不可能靠任何聪明才智聚集在一起。像国内传教这样卑鄙的传教活动是他们最不能忍受的。事实上，在我们坐下来吃早餐之前，威斯克小姐非常愤慨地告诉我们，妇女的使命主要集中在家庭的狭小范围内的想法是对她的暴君男人的无耻诽谤。另一个奇特之处是，没有人有使命——除了奎尔先生，正如我之前所说，他的使命是对每个人的使命感到欣喜若狂——根本不关心任何人的使命。帕迪格夫人也很清楚，唯一正确的做法就是她像紧身马甲一样向穷人伸出援手，向他们施以仁慈。正如威斯克小姐所说，世界上唯一实际的事情就是将妇女从暴君男人的束缚中解放出来。杰利比夫人一直微笑着坐着，她的视力有限，除了博里奥布拉-加之外什么也看不到。

But I am anticipating now the purport of our conversation on the ride home instead of first marrying Caddy. We all went to church, and Mr. Jellyby gave her away. Of the air with which old Mr. Turveydrop, with his hat under his left arm (the inside presented at the clergyman like a cannon) and his eyes creasing themselves up into his wig, stood stiff and high-shouldered behind us bridesmaids during the ceremony, and afterwards saluted us, I could never say enough to do it justice. Miss Wisk, whom I cannot report as prepossessing in appearance, and whose manner was grim, listened to the proceedings, as part of woman’s wrongs, with a disdainful face. Mrs. Jellyby, with her calm smile and her bright eyes, looked the least concerned of all the company.
但我现在期待的是我们在回家的路上谈话的目的，而不是先嫁给凯迪。我们都去了教堂，杰利比先生把她送走了。老特维德罗普先生把帽子夹在左臂下（里面像大炮一样呈现在牧师面前），眼睛在假发上皱起，在仪式期间，他僵硬地高耸着肩膀站在我们伴娘身后，神态是那样的，然后向我们致敬，我永远无法说得足够公正。威斯克小姐，我不能说她的外表很讨人喜欢，而且她的举止很严肃，她带着轻蔑的表情听着整个过程，就像女人所受的委屈一样。杰利比夫人脸上带着平静的微笑和明亮的眼睛，看起来是全班人中最不关心的一个。

We duly came back to breakfast, and Mrs. Jellyby sat at the head of the table and Mr. Jellyby at the foot. Caddy had previously stolen upstairs to hug the children again and tell them that her name was Turveydrop. But this piece of information, instead of being an agreeable surprise to Peepy, threw him on his back in such transports of kicking grief that I could do nothing on being sent for but accede to the proposal that he should be admitted to the breakfast table. So he came down and sat in my lap; and Mrs. Jellyby, after saying, in reference to the state of his pinafore, ‘Oh, you naughty Peepy, what a shocking little pig you are!’ was not at all discomposed. He was very good except that he brought down Noah with him (out of an ark I had given him before we went to church) and WOULD dip him head first into the wine-glasses and then put him in his mouth.
我们按时回来吃早餐，杰利比太太坐在桌首，杰利比先生坐在桌脚。凯迪此前曾偷偷上楼再次拥抱孩子们，并告诉他们她的名字叫特维德罗普。但这条信息并没有让皮皮感到意外的惊喜，反而让他陷入极度悲伤的境地，以至于我在被叫去时无能为力，只能同意让他参加早餐桌的提议。于是他下来坐在我的腿上。杰利比夫人在谈到他围裙的状态时说道：“哦，你这个顽皮的皮比，你真是一只令人震惊的小猪！”一点也没有感到不安。他非常好，除了他把诺亚带下来（从我们去教堂之前我给他的方舟里），并把他的头先浸入酒杯中，然后把他放进嘴里。

My guardian, with his sweet temper and his quick perception and his amiable face, made something agreeable even out of the ungenial company. None of them seemed able to talk about anything but his, or her, own one subject, and none of them seemed able to talk about even that as part of a world in which there was anything else; but my guardian turned it all to the merry encouragement of Caddy and the honour of the occasion, and brought us through the breakfast nobly. What we should have done without him, I am afraid to think, for all the company despising the bride and bridegroom and old Mr. Turveydrop—and old Mr. Thrveydrop, in virtue of his deportment, considering himself vastly superior to all the company—it was a very unpromising case.
我的监护人脾气温和，反应敏捷，面容和蔼可亲，即使是在不友善的陪伴下，也能做出一些令人愉快的事情。除了他或她自己的一个主题之外，他们似乎都无法谈论任何事情，而且他们似乎都无法谈论这个世界的一部分，在这个世界里还有其他东西；但我的监护人把这一切都归功于凯迪的快乐鼓励和这个场合的荣誉，并带领我们高贵地度过了早餐。我恐怕想，如果没有他，我们应该做些什么，因为所有的人都鄙视新娘和新郎以及老特维德罗普先生——而老特维德罗普先生，由于他的举止，认为自己比所有的人都优越得多——这是一个非常没有希望的案例。

At last the time came when poor Caddy was to go and when all her property was packed on the hired coach and pair that was to take her and her husband to Gravesend. It affected us to see Caddy clinging, then, to her deplorable home and hanging on her mother’s neck with the greatest tenderness.
可怜的凯迪终于要走了，她所有的财产都装在了租来的马车和双人车上，载着她和她的丈夫去格雷夫森德。看到凯迪紧紧抓住她那可悲的家，并以最温柔的方式挂在她母亲的脖子上，我们感到很感动。

‘I am very sorry I couldn’t go on writing from dictation, Ma,’ sobbed Caddy. ‘I hope you forgive me now.’
“我很抱歉我不能继续听写写作，妈妈，”凯迪抽泣着说。 “我希望你现在原谅我。”

‘Oh, Caddy, Caddy!’ said Mrs. Jellyby. ‘I have told you over and over again that I have engaged a boy, and there’s an end of it.’
“哦，凯迪，凯迪！”杰利比太太说。 “我已经一遍又一遍地告诉你，我已经订婚了一个男孩，事情就这样结束了。”

‘You are sure you are not the least angry with me, Ma? Say you are sure before I go away, Ma?’
“你确定你一点也不生我的气吗，妈？在我走之前你说你确定吗，妈妈？

‘You foolish Caddy,’ returned Mrs. Jellyby, ‘do I look angry, or have I inclination to be angry, or time to be angry? How CAN you?’
“你这个愚蠢的球童，”杰利比太太回答道，“我看起来很生气吗？或者我有生气的倾向，或者是时候生气了？”你怎么？'

‘Take a little care of Pa while I am gone, Mama!’
“我不在的时候，请照顾一下爸爸，妈妈！”

Mrs. Jellyby positively laughed at the fancy. ‘You romantic child,’ said she, lightly patting Caddy’s back. ‘Go along. I am excellent friends with you. Now, good-bye, Caddy, and be very happy!’
杰利比夫人对这个幻想大笑起来。 “你这个浪漫的孩子，”她轻轻拍着凯迪的背说道。 '附和。我和你是很好的朋友。现在，再见，凯蒂，祝你幸福！”

Then Caddy hung upon her father and nursed his cheek against hers as if he were some poor dull child in pain. All this took place in the hall. Her father released her, took out his pocket handkerchief, and sat down on the stairs with his head against the wall. I hope he found some consolation in walls. I almost think he did.
然后凯迪依偎在她父亲身上，把他的脸颊贴在她的脸颊上，仿佛他是一个痛苦的可怜的迟钝的孩子。这一切都发生在大厅里。父亲松开了她，掏出口袋里的手帕，头抵着墙坐在了楼梯上。我希望他能在墙壁上找到一些安慰。我几乎认为他做到了。

And then Prince took her arm in his and turned with great emotion and respect to his father, whose deportment at that moment was overwhelming.
然后普林斯挽着她的手臂，怀着极大的情感和敬意转过身来面对他的父亲，他那一刻的举止令人难以抗拒。

‘Thank you over and over again, father!’ said Prince, kissing his hand. ‘I am very grateful for all your kindness and consideration regarding our marriage, and so, I can assure you, is Caddy.’
“再次感谢您，父亲！”王子亲吻着他的手说道。 “我非常感谢你对我们婚姻的善意和体贴，我可以向你保证，凯迪也是如此。”

‘Very,’ sobbed Caddy. ‘Ve-ry!’
“非常，”凯迪抽泣着。 '非常！'

‘My dear son,’ said Mr. Turveydrop, ‘and dear daughter, I have done my duty. If the spirit of a sainted wooman hovers above us and looks down on the occasion, that, and your constant affection, will be my recompense. You will not fail in YOUR duty, my son and daughter, I believe?’
“我亲爱的儿子，”特维德罗普先生说，“亲爱的女儿，我已经尽了我的职责。如果一位圣女的精神盘旋在我们之上并俯视这个场合，那么，以及您不断的爱，将是我的报答。我相信你们不会辜负你们的职责，我的儿子和女儿？

‘Dear father, never!’ cried Prince.
“亲爱的父亲，决不！”普林斯喊道。

‘Never, never, dear Mr. Turveydrop!’ said Caddy.
“永远，永远，亲爱的特维德罗普先生！”凯迪说。

‘This,’ returned Mr. Turveydrop, ‘is as it should be. My children, my home is yours, my heart is yours, my all is yours. I will never leave you; nothing but death shall part us. My dear son, you contemplate an absence of a week, I think?’
“这，”特维德罗普先生回答道，“这是应该的。”我的孩子们，我的家是你们的，我的心是你们的，我的一切都是你们的。我永远不会离开你;除了死亡，没有什么能将我们分开。我亲爱的儿子，我想你考虑缺席一周吧？

‘A week, dear father. We shall return home this day week.’
“一周了，亲爱的父亲。我们将在本周的这一天回家。

‘My dear child,’ said Mr. Turveydrop, ‘let me, even under the present exceptional circumstances, recommend strict punctuality. It is highly important to keep the connexion together; and schools, if at all neglected, are apt to take offence.’
“我亲爱的孩子，”特维德罗普先生说，“让我建议，即使在目前的特殊情况下，也要严格守时。”保持联系非常重要；学校如果被忽视，很容易被冒犯。

‘This day week, father, we shall be sure to be home to dinner.’
“这周的今天，父亲，我们一定会回家吃晚饭。”

‘Good!’ said Mr. Turveydrop. ‘You will find fires, my dear Caroline, in your own room, and dinner prepared in my apartment. Yes, yes, Prince!’ anticipating some self-denying objection on his son’s part with a great air. ‘You and our Caroline will be strange in the upper part of the premises and will, therefore, dine that day in my apartment. Now, bless ye!’
“好！”特维德罗普先生说。 “亲爱的卡罗琳，你会在你自己的房间里发现火，在我的公寓里准备好晚餐。是的，是的，王子！”他神情严肃地期待着儿子会做出一些克己的反对。 “你和我们的卡罗琳在房子的上层会很奇怪，因此那天会在我的公寓里吃饭。现在，祝福你们！

They drove away, and whether I wondered most at Mrs. Jellyby or at Mr. Turveydrop, I did not know. Ada and my guardian were in the same condition when we came to talk it over. But before we drove away too, I received a most unexpected and eloquent compliment from Mr. Jellyby. He came up to me in the hall, took both my hands, pressed them earnestly, and opened his mouth twice. I was so sure of his meaning that I said, quite flurried, ‘You are very welcome, sir. Pray don’t mention it!’
他们开车走了，我不知道我最想知道的是杰利比太太还是特维德罗普先生。当我们来讨论这件事时，艾达和我的监护人也处于同样的情况。但在我们也开车离开之前，我收到了杰利比先生最出乎意料且雄辩的赞美。他在大厅里走到我面前，握住我的双手，认真地握着，张了两次嘴。我非常确定他的意思，所以我非常慌乱地说：“不客气，先生。”请不要提及它！

‘I hope this marriage is for the best, guardian,’ said I when we three were on our road home.
“我希望这桩婚姻是最好的，监护人。”当我们三个走在回家的路上时，我说道。

‘I hope it is, little woman. Patience. We shall see.’
“我希望如此，小女人。耐心。我们将会看到。

‘Is the wind in the east to-day?’ I ventured to ask him.
“今天是东风吗？”我大胆地问他。

He laughed heartily and answered, ‘No.’
他哈哈大笑，回答说：“没有。”

‘But it must have been this morning, I think,’ said I.
“但我想一定是今天早上，”我说。

He answered ‘No’ again, and this time my dear girl confidently answered ‘No’ too and shook the lovely head which, with its blooming flowers against the golden hair, was like the very spring. ‘Much YOU know of east winds, my ugly darling,’ said I, kissing her in my admiration—I couldn’t help it.
他再次回答“不”，这一次我亲爱的女孩也自信地回答“不”，并摇了摇头，那朵盛开的花朵映衬着金色的头发，就像春天一样。 “你对东风了解得很多，我丑陋的亲爱的，”我说道，在钦佩中亲吻了她——我无法控制。

Well! It was only their love for me, I know very well, and it is a long time ago. I must write it even if I rub it out again, because it gives me so much pleasure. They said there could be no east wind where Somebody was; they said that wherever Dame Durden went, there was sunshine and summer air.
出色地！那只是他们对我的爱，我很清楚，而且是很久以前的事了。即使再擦掉我也必须写下来，因为它给我带来了很多乐趣。他们说有人在的地方不可能有东风；他们说杜登夫人所到之处，都有阳光和夏日的空气。

CHAPTER XXXI
第三十一章


Nurse and Patient
护士和病人

I had not been at home again many days when one evening I went upstairs into my own room to take a peep over Charley’s shoulder and see how she was getting on with her copy-book. Writing was a trying business to Charley, who seemed to have no natural power over a pen, but in whose hand every pen appeared to become perversely animated, and to go wrong and crooked, and to stop, and splash, and sidle into corners like a saddle-donkey. It was very odd to see what old letters Charley’s young hand had made, they so wrinkled, and shrivelled, and tottering, it so plump and round. Yet Charley was uncommonly expert at other things and had as nimble little fingers as I ever watched.
我已经很多天没有在家了，有一天晚上，我上楼走进自己的房间，从查理的肩膀上偷看，看看她抄作业的情况如何。对查理来说，写作是一件很艰难的事情，他似乎对钢笔没有天生的力量，但在他的手中，每支钢笔似乎都变得异常活跃，出错、弯曲、停下来、溅起水花、溜进角落，就像一头鞍驴。查利年轻的手写出的旧字母非常奇怪，它们如此皱巴巴、干瘪、摇摇欲坠，却又如此丰满和圆润。然而查理在其他事情上却是异常的专家，而且他的小手指是我见过的最灵活的。

‘Well, Charley,’ said I, looking over a copy of the letter O in which it was represented as square, triangular, pear-shaped, and collapsed in all kinds of ways, ‘we are improving. If we only get to make it round, we shall be perfect, Charley.’
“好吧，查理，”我看着字母 O 的副本说道，其中它被表示为正方形、三角形、梨形，并以各种方式折叠，“我们正在进步。”只要我们能顺利完成任务，我们就完美了，查理。”

Then I made one, and Charley made one, and the pen wouldn’t join Charley’s neatly, but twisted it up into a knot.
然后我做了一支，查理也做了一支，这支笔并没有和查理的笔整齐地连接在一起，而是把它扭成了一个结。

‘Never mind, Charley. We shall do it in time.’
‘没关系，查理。我们会及时做的。

Charley laid down her pen, the copy being finished, opened and shut her cramped little hand, looked gravely at the page, half in pride and half in doubt, and got up, and dropped me a curtsy.
查莉放下笔，抄完稿，张开又合上她那抽筋的小手，严肃地看着这一页，一半是骄傲，一半是怀疑，然后站起来，向我行了屈膝礼。

‘Thank you, miss. If you please, miss, did you know a poor person of the name of Jenny?’
「谢谢你，小姐。小姐，请问您认识一个叫珍妮的穷人吗？

‘A brickmaker’s wife, Charley? Yes.’
“查理，砖匠的妻子？是的。'

‘She came and spoke to me when I was out a little while ago, and said you knew her, miss. She asked me if I wasn’t the young lady’s little maid—meaning you for the young lady, miss—and I said yes, miss.’
“不久前我出去的时候，她过来跟我说话，说你认识她，小姐。她问我是不是小姐的小丫鬟——小姐，你就是小姐的意思——我说是的，小姐。

‘I thought she had left this neighbourhood altogether, Charley.’
“我以为她已经完全离开了这个社区，查理。”

‘So she had, miss, but she’s come back again to where she used to live—she and Liz. Did you know another poor person of the name of Liz, miss?’
“她确实这么做了，小姐，但她又回到了她以前住的地方——她和莉兹。小姐，你认识另一个叫莉兹的可怜人吗？

‘I think I do, Charley, though not by name.’
“我想我是这么做的，查理，虽然不是指名道姓。”

‘That’s what she said!’ returned Chariey. ‘They have both come back, miss, and have been tramping high and low.’
“她就是这么说的！”查理回答道。 “他们都回来了，小姐，并且一直在走来走去。”

‘Tramping high and low, have they, Charley?’
“他们走来走去，是吗，查理？”

‘Yes, miss.’ If Charley could only have made the letters in her copy as round as the eyes with which she looked into my face, they would have been excellent. ‘And this poor person came about the house three or four days, hoping to get a glimpse of you, miss—all she wanted, she said—but you were away. That was when she saw me. She saw me a-going about, miss,’ said Charley with a short laugh of the greatest delight and pride, ‘and she thought I looked like your maid!’
“是的，小姐。”如果查理能把她的副本中的字母写得像她看着我脸上的眼睛一样圆，那就太好了。 “这个可怜的人在房子里来了三四天，希望能看一眼你，小姐——她说这就是她想要的——但你不在。”就在那时她看到了我。她看到我到处走动，小姐，”查利带着极大的喜悦和自豪的短笑说道，“她认为我看起来像你的女仆！

‘Did she though, really, Charley?’
“查理，她真的这么想吗？”

‘Yes, miss!’ said Charley. ‘Really and truly.’ And Charley, with another short laugh of the purest glee, made her eyes very round again and looked as serious as became my maid. I was never tired of seeing Charley in the full enjoyment of that great dignity, standing before me with her youthful face and figure, and her steady manner, and her childish exultation breaking through it now and then in the pleasantest way.
“是的，小姐！”查理说。 “真的，真的。”查理又带着最纯粹的欢乐短促地笑了一声，她的眼睛又睁得大大的，看起来像我的女仆一样严肃。我乐此不疲地看到查理充分享受那种伟大的尊严，站在我面前，她年轻的脸庞和身材，她稳重的举止，以及她时不时以最令人愉快的方式突破的孩子气的狂喜。

‘And where did you see her, Charley?’ said I.
“查理，你在哪里看到她的？”我问道。

My little maid’s countenance fell as she replied, ‘By the doctor’s shop, miss.’ For Charley wore her black frock yet.
我的小女仆的脸色沉了下来，她回答道：“在医生的店里，小姐。”因为查理还穿着她的黑色连衣裙。

I asked if the brickmaker’s wife were ill, but Charley said no. It was some one else. Some one in her cottage who had tramped down to Saint Albans and was tramping he didn’t know where. A poor boy, Charley said. No father, no mother, no any one. ‘Like as Tom might have been, miss, if Emma and me had died after father,’ said Charley, her round eyes filling with tears.
我问砖匠的妻子是否病了，查理说没有。是别人的。她的小屋里有人徒步来到圣奥尔本斯，但他不知道徒步到了哪里。查理说，他是个可怜的孩子。没有父亲，没有母亲，没有任何人。 “就像汤姆一样，小姐，如果艾玛和我在父亲去世后就去世了，”查理说，她的圆眼睛里充满了泪水。

‘And she was getting medicine for him, Charley?’
“查理，她正在给他买药吗？”

‘She said, miss,’ returned Charley, ‘how that he had once done as much for her.’
“她说，小姐，”查利回答道，“他曾经为她做了这么多。”

My little maid’s face was so eager and her quiet hands were folded so closely in one another as she stood looking at me that I had no great difficulty in reading her thoughts. ‘Well, Charley,’ said I, ‘it appears to me that you and I can do no better than go round to Jenny’s and see what’s the matter.’
我的小女仆的脸是如此渴望，她安静的双手紧紧地握在一起，站在那里看着我，所以我不费吹灰之力就能读懂她的想法。 “好吧，查理，”我说，“在我看来，你和我最好的办法就是去珍妮家看看发生了什么事。”

The alacrity with which Charley brought my bonnet and veil, and having dressed me, quaintly pinned herself into her warm shawl and made herself look like a little old woman, sufficiently expressed her readiness. So Charley and I, without saying anything to any one, went out.
查莉敏捷地给我拿来帽子和面纱，给我穿好衣服，别致地把自己别在温暖的围巾里，让自己看起来像个小老太婆，这足以表明她已经做好了准备。于是查理和我，什么也没对任何人说，就出去了。

It was a cold, wild night, and the trees shuddered in the wind. The rain had been thick and heavy all day, and with little intermission for many days. None was falling just then, however. The sky had partly cleared, but was very gloomy—even above us, where a few stars were shining. In the north and north-west, where the sun had set three hours before, there was a pale dead light both beautiful and awful; and into it long sullen lines of cloud waved up like a sea stricken immovable as it was heaving. Towards London a lurid glare overhung the whole dark waste, and the contrast between these two lights, and the fancy which the redder light engendered of an unearthly fire, gleaming on all the unseen buildings of the city and on all the faces of its many thousands of wondering inhabitants, was as solemn as might be.
那是一个寒冷而狂野的夜晚，树木在风中颤抖。这场雨一整天都下得又大又大，而且好几天都没有间断过。然而，就在此时，没有任何东西掉落。天空已经部分放晴，但非常阴暗——即使在我们头顶上，也有几颗星星在闪烁。在北部和西北部，太阳在三小时前落下的地方，有一道苍白的死光，既美丽又可怕。天空中，长长的、阴沉的云线在波浪中飘扬，就像受海浪袭击的大海一样，在起伏时一动不动。伦敦的方向，一道可怕的光芒笼罩着整个黑暗的荒野，这两道光之间的对比，以及由超凡的火所产生的更红的光所产生的幻想，在这座城市所有看不见的建筑和成千上万的人的脸上闪闪发光好奇的居民，是尽可能的庄严。

I had no thought that night—none, I am quite sure—of what was soon to happen to me. But I have always remembered since that when we had stopped at the garden-gate to look up at the sky, and when we went upon our way, I had for a moment an undefinable impression of myself as being something different from what I then was. I know it was then and there that I had it. I have ever since connected the feeling with that spot and time and with everything associated with that spot and time, to the distant voices in the town, the barking of a dog, and the sound of wheels coming down the miry hill.
那天晚上我没有想到——我很确定，没有想到——很快就会发生在我身上的事情。但我一直记得，当我们在花园门口停下来仰望天空，当我们继续上路时，我有一瞬间有一种无法形容的感觉，觉得自己与当时的我不同了。 。我知道我就在那时就拥有了它。从那时起，我就将这种感觉与那个地点和时间以及与那个地点和时间相关的一切联系起来，与城镇中遥远的声音，狗的吠声，以及从泥泞的山上滚下的车轮声联系在一起。

It was Saturday night, and most of the people belonging to the place where we were going were drinking elsewhere. We found it quieter than I had previously seen it, though quite as miserable. The kilns were burning, and a stifling vapour set towards us with a pale-blue glare.
那是星期六晚上，我们要去的地方的大部分人都在别处喝酒。我们发现这里比我以前看到的要安静，尽管也同样悲惨。窑炉正在燃烧，令人窒息的蒸气带着淡蓝色的光芒向我们袭来。

We came to the cottage, where there was a feeble candle in the patched window. We tapped at the door and went in. The mother of the little child who had died was sitting in a chair on one side of the poor fire by the bed; and opposite to her, a wretched boy, supported by the chimney-piece, was cowering on the floor. He held under his arm, like a little bundle, a fragment of a fur cap; and as he tried to warm himself, he shook until the crazy door and window shook. The place was closer than before and had an unhealthy and a very peculiar smell.
我们来到了小屋，修补的窗户里点着微弱的蜡烛。我们敲了敲门，进去了。死去的小孩的母亲坐在床边可怜的火一侧的椅子上。在她对面，一个可怜的男孩靠着烟囱，蜷缩在地板上。他腋下夹着一块毛皮帽子的碎片，像一个小包一样。当他试图取暖时，他浑身颤抖，直到那扇疯狂的门窗摇晃起来。这个地方比以前更近了，而且有一种不健康的、很奇特的气味。

I had not lifted by veil when I first spoke to the woman, which was at the moment of our going in. The boy staggered up instantly and stared at me with a remarkable expression of surprise and terror.
当我第一次和那个女人说话时，也就是我们进去的那一刻，我并没有揭开面纱。男孩立刻摇摇晃晃地站起来，用一种明显的惊讶和恐惧的表情盯着我。

His action was so quick and my being the cause of it was so evident that I stood still instead of advancing nearer.
他的动作如此之快，而我的行动又是如此明显，以至于我没有走近，而是站在原地不动。

‘I won’t go no more to the berryin ground,’ muttered the boy; ‘I ain’t a-going there, so I tell you!’
“我不会再去浆果地了，”男孩嘀咕道。 “我不会去那里，所以我告诉你！”

I lifted my veil and spoke to the woman. She said to me in a low voice, ‘Don’t mind him, ma’am. He’ll soon come back to his head,’ and said to him, ‘Jo, Jo, what’s the matter?’
我掀起面纱，对那个女人说话。她低声对我说：‘女士，别理他。他很快就会清醒过来，”并对他说，“乔，乔，怎么了？

‘I know wot she’s come for!’ cried the boy.
“我知道她是来干什么的！”男孩喊道。

‘Who?’
'WHO？'

‘The lady there. She’s come to get me to go along with her to the berryin ground. I won’t go to the berryin ground. I don’t like the name on it. She might go a-berryin ME.’ His shivering came on again, and as he leaned against the wall, he shook the hovel.
‘那边的那位女士。她来接我和她一起去浆果园。我不会去浆果地。我不喜欢上面的名字。她可能会在我身上吃浆果。”他的颤抖又开始了，当他靠在墙上时，他摇晃着小屋。

‘He has been talking off and on about such like all day, ma’am,’ said Jenny softly. ‘Why, how you stare! This is MY lady, Jo.’
“他一整天都在断断续续地谈论这样的事情，女士，”珍妮轻声说道。 ‘哎呀，你的目光多么凝视啊！这是我的女士，乔。”

‘Is it?’ returned the boy doubtfully, and surveying me with his arm held out above his burning eyes. ‘She looks to me the t’other one. It ain’t the bonnet, nor yet it ain’t the gownd, but she looks to me the t’other one.’
“是吗？”男孩疑惑地回答，伸出手臂遮住灼热的眼睛，打量着我。 “她在我看来是另一个人。”这不是帽子，也不是长袍，但在我看来，她是另一个。

My little Charley, with her premature experience of illness and trouble, had pulled off her bonnet and shawl and now went quietly up to him with a chair and sat him down in it like an old sick nurse. Except that no such attendant could have shown him Charley’s youthful face, which seemed to engage his confidence.
我的小查理，由于过早地经历了疾病和麻烦，已经脱下了帽子和披肩，现在悄悄地拿着一把椅子走到他面前，让他坐在上面，就像一个生病的老护士一样。只是没有这样的服务员能够向他展示查理年轻的脸，这似乎激发了他的信心。

‘I say!’ said the boy. ‘YOU tell me. Ain’t the lady the t’other lady?’
“我说！”男孩说。 '你告诉我。这位女士不是另一位女士吗？

Charley shook her head as she methodically drew his rags about him and made him as warm as she could.
查利摇摇头，她有条不紊地把他的破布裹在身上，尽可能地让他暖和起来。

‘Oh!’ the boy muttered. ‘Then I s’pose she ain’t.’
“哦！”男孩嘟哝道。 “那我想她不是。”

‘I came to see if I could do you any good,’ said I. ‘What is the matter with you?’
“我来是想看看能不能帮到你什么忙，”我说道，“你怎么了？”

‘I’m a-being froze,’ returned the boy hoarsely, with his haggard gaze wandering about me, ‘and then burnt up, and then froze, and then burnt up, ever so many times in a hour. And my head’s all sleepy, and all a-going mad-like—and I’m so dry—and my bones isn’t half so much bones as pain.
“我被冻住了，”男孩沙哑地回答道，他那憔悴的目光在我周围徘徊，“然后被烧伤，然后被冻住，然后被烧伤，一小时内如此多次。我的头昏昏欲睡，快要发疯了——而且我太干了——我的骨头不是骨头的一半，而是疼痛。

‘When did he come here?’ I asked the woman.
“他什么时候来这里的？”我问那个女人。

‘This morning, ma’am, I found him at the corner of the town. I had known him up in London yonder. Hadn’t I, Jo?’
“今天早上，女士，我在小镇的拐角处找到了他。我在伦敦那边就认识他了。我不是吗，乔？

‘Tom-all-Alone’s,’ the boy replied.
“汤姆独自一人，”男孩回答道。

Whenever he fixed his attention or his eyes, it was only for a very little while. He soon began to droop his head again, and roll it heavily, and speak as if he were half awake.
每当他集中注意力或注视眼睛时，都只会持续很短的时间。很快他又开始低下头，重重地转动着，说话的样子就好像半梦半醒一样。

‘When did he come from London?’ I asked.
“他什么时候从伦敦来的？”我问。

‘I come from London yes’day,’ said the boy himself, now flushed and hot. ‘I’m a-going somewheres.’
“我昨天从伦敦来的。”男孩自己说道，他现在脸色通红，浑身发热。 “我要去某个地方。”

‘Where is he going?’ I asked.
“他要去哪里？”我问。

‘Somewheres,’ repeated the boy in a louder tone. ‘I have been moved on, and moved on, more nor ever I was afore, since the t’other one give me the sov’ring. Mrs. Snagsby, she’s always awatching, and a-driving of me—what have I done to her?—and they’re all a-watching and a-driving of me. Every one of ‘em’s doing of it, from the time when I don’t get up, to the time when I don’t go to bed. And I’m a-going somewheres. That’s where I’m agoing. She told me, down in Tom-all-Alone’s, as she came from Stolbuns, and so I took the Stolbuns Road. It’s as good as another.’
“在某个地方，”男孩大声重复道。 “自从另一个人给我主宰权以来，我一直在前进，一直前进，比以前更加前进。”斯纳斯比太太，她总是注视着我，驱使着我——我对她做了什么？——而他们都注视着我，驱使着我。他们每个人都在做这件事，从我不起床，到我不睡觉。我要去某个地方。这就是我要去的地方。她告诉我，她来自斯托尔本斯，就在汤姆孤儿店里，所以我就走斯托尔本斯路。它和另一个一样好。

He always concluded by addressing Charley.
最后他总是对查理说。

‘What is to be done with him?’ said I, taking the woman aside. ‘He could not travel in this state even if he had a purpose and knew where he was going!’
“该怎么办他呢？”我一边说，一边把女人拉到一边。 “即使他有目的并且知道他要去哪里，他也无法在这种状态下旅行！”

‘I know no more, ma’am, than the dead,’ she replied, glancing compassionately at him. ‘Perhaps the dead know better, if they could only tell us. I’ve kept him here all day for pity’s sake, and I’ve given him broth and physic, and Liz has gone to try if any one will take him in (here’s my pretty in the bed—her child, but I call it mine); but I can’t keep him long, for if my husband was to come home and find him here, he’d be rough in putting him out and might do him a hurt. Hark! Here comes Liz back!’
“我不知道更多，女士，就像死人一样，”她回答道，同情地看了他一眼。 “也许死者更清楚，如果他们能告诉我们的话。”出于怜悯，我把他留在这里一整天，我给了他肉汤和药，莉兹已经去尝试是否有人愿意收留他（这是我床上的漂亮女人——她的孩子，但我称之为矿）;但我不能把他留得太久，因为如果我丈夫回家发现他在这里，他会很粗暴地把他赶出去，可能会伤害他。听着！莉兹回来了！

The other woman came hurriedly in as she spoke, and the boy got up with a half-obscured sense that he was expected to be going. When the little child awoke, and when and how Charley got at it, took it out of bed, and began to walk about hushing it, I don’t know. There she was, doing all this in a quiet motherly manner as if she were living in Mrs. Blinder’s attic with Tom and Emma again.
说话间另一个女人匆匆走了进来，男孩起身，隐隐约约感觉到他要走了。当这个小孩子醒来时，查理什么时候、如何把它从床上抱起来，然后开始走来走去，让它安静下来，我不知道。她就在那里，以一种安静的母亲般的方式做着这一切，就好像她又和汤姆和艾玛一起住在布林德太太的阁楼里一样。

The friend had been here and there, and had been played about from hand to hand, and had come back as she went. At first it was too early for the boy to be received into the proper refuge, and at last it was too late. One official sent her to another, and the other sent her back again to the first, and so backward and forward, until it appeared to me as if both must have been appointed for their skill in evading their duties instead of performing them. And now, after all, she said, breathing quickly, for she had been running and was frightened too, ‘Jenny, your master’s on the road home, and mine’s not far behind, and the Lord help the boy, for we can do no more for him!’ They put a few halfpence together and hurried them into his hand, and so, in an oblivious, half-thankful, half-insensible way, he shuffled out of the house.
这位朋友曾来过这里那里，被人玩弄过，又一边走一边回来。起初，男孩被接纳到适当的避难所还为时过早，但最后为时已晚。一位官员将她送到另一位，另一位又将她送回第一个，如此反复，直到在我看来，两人的任命似乎都是因为他们擅长逃避职责而不是履行职责。现在，毕竟，她呼吸急促，因为她一直在奔跑，也很害怕，“珍妮，你的主人正在回家的路上，我的主人就在不远处，愿上帝帮助这个男孩，因为我们无能为力。”他们把几个半便士放在一起，匆匆塞到他手里，于是，他以一种健忘、半感激、半麻木的方式拖着脚步走出了屋子。

‘Give me the child, my dear,’ said its mother to Charley, ‘and thank you kindly too! Jenny, woman dear, good night!
“把孩子给我吧，亲爱的，”孩子的母亲对查理说，“也谢谢你！”珍妮，亲爱的女人，晚安！

Young lady, if my master don’t fall out with me, I’ll look down by the kiln by and by, where the boy will be most like, and again in the morning!’ She hurried off, and presenfty we passed her hushing and singing to her child at her own door and looking anxiously along the road for her drunken husband.
小姐，如果我的主人不跟我闹翻，我就到窑边去看看，那儿是男孩最喜欢的地方，明天早上再来一次！”她匆匆离去，我们就从她身边走过了。她在自家门口小声地给孩子唱歌，焦急地沿路寻找醉酒的丈夫。

I was afraid of staying then to speak to either woman, lest I should bring her into trouble. But I said to Charley that we must not leave the boy to die. Charley, who knew what to do much better than I did, and whose quickness equalled her presence of mind, glided on before me, and presently we came up with Jo, just short of the brick-kiln.
我不敢留下来和任何一个女人说话，以免给她带来麻烦。但我对查理说，我们不能让这个男孩死去。查理比我更清楚该做什么，她的敏捷与她的冷静相当，她在我前面滑行，不久我们就遇到了乔，就在砖窑附近。

I think he must have begun his journey with some small bundle under his arm and must have had it stolen or lost it. For he still carried his wretched fragment of fur cap like a bundle, though he went bareheaded through the rain, which now fell fast. He stopped when we called to him and again showed a dread of me when I came up, standing with his lustrous eyes fixed upon me, and even arrested in his shivering fit.
我想他一定是腋下夹着一些小包裹开始了他的旅程，并且一定被偷了或丢失了。因为他仍然像包裹一样带着那破旧的毛皮帽碎片，尽管他光着头穿过雨，现在雨下得很快。当我们叫他时，他停了下来，当我走上来时，他再次表现出对我的恐惧，站着，用他那双明亮的眼睛盯着我，甚至在颤抖中停下来。

I asked him to come with us, and we would take care that he had some shelter for the night.
我请他和我们一起去，我们会照顾他有地方过夜。

‘I don’t want no shelter,’ he said; ‘I can lay amongst the warm bricks.’
“我不想要任何庇护所，”他说； “我可以躺在温暖的砖块中间。”

‘But don’t you know that people die there?’ replied Charley.
“但是你不知道人们会死在那里吗？”查理回答道。

‘They dies everywheres,’ said the boy. ‘They dies in their lodgings—she knows where; I showed her—and they dies down in Tomall-Alone’s in heaps. They dies more than they lives, according to what I see.’ Then he hoarsely whispered Charley, ‘If she ain’t the t’other one, she ain’t the forrenner. Is there THREE of ‘em then?’
“他们到处都死了，”男孩说。 “他们死在自己的住处——她知道在哪里；我给她看了——它们在托莫尔孤独屋里成堆地消失了。根据我的观察，他们死的次数多于活的次数。”然后他沙哑地低声对查利说：“如果她不是另一个人，她就不是那个先行者。那么他们是三个吗？

Charley looked at me a little frightened. I felt half frightened at myself when the boy glared on me so.
查理有点害怕地看着我。当那个男孩如此瞪着我时，我对自己感到有些害怕。

But he turned and followed when I beckoned to him, and finding that he acknowledged that influence in me, I led the way straight home. It was not far, only at the summit of the hill. We passed but one man. I doubted if we should have got home without assistance, the boy’s steps were so uncertain and tremulous. He made no complaint, however, and was strangely unconcerned about himself, if I may say so strange a thing.
但当我向他招手时，他转身跟着我，发现他承认了我对我的影响，我就直接带路回家了。距离并不远，就到了山顶。我们只经过了一个人。我怀疑我们是否应该在没有帮助的情况下回家，男孩的脚步如此不确定和颤抖。然而，他没有抱怨，而且奇怪的是，他对自己毫不关心，如果我可以说这是一件奇怪的事情的话。

Leaving him in the hall for a moment, shrunk into the corner of the window-seat and staring with an indifference that scarcely could be called wonder at the comfort and brightness about him, I went into the drawing-room to speak to my guardian. There I found Mr. Skimpole, who had come down by the coach, as he frequently did without notice, and never bringing any clothes with him, but always borrowing everything he wanted.
我把他留在大厅里一会儿，缩在靠窗座位的角落里，冷漠地盯着他，对他周围的舒适和明亮几乎不能称之为惊讶，然后我走进客厅和我的监护人说话。在那里我找到了斯金波尔先生，他乘马车下来，就像他经常在没有通知的情况下一样，从不带任何衣服，但总是借用他想要的一切。

They came out with me directly to look at the boy. The servants had gathered in the hall too, and he shivered in the window-seat with Charley standing by him, like some wounded animal that had been found in a ditch.
他们直接和我一起出来看那个男孩。仆人们也聚集在大厅里，他在靠窗的座位上瑟瑟发抖，查理站在他身边，就像在沟渠里发现的一只受伤的动物。

‘This is a sorrowful case,’ said my guardian after asking him a question or two and touching him and examining his eyes. ‘What do you say, Harold?’
“这是一个令人悲伤的案例，”我的监护人在问了他一两个问题并抚摸他并检查了他的眼睛后说道。 “哈罗德，你说什么？”

‘You had better turn him out,’ said Mr. Skimpole.
“你最好把他赶出去，”斯金波尔先生说。

‘What do you mean?’ inquired my guardian, almost sternly.
“你这是什么意思？”我的监护人近乎严厉地问道。

‘My dear Jarndyce,’ said Mr. Skimpole, ‘you know what I am: I am a child. Be cross to me if I deserve it. But I have a constitutional objection to this sort of thing. I always had, when I was a medical man. He’s not safe, you know. There’s a very bad sort of fever about him.’
“我亲爱的贾迪斯，”斯金波尔先生说，“你知道我是什么：我是个孩子。”如果我罪有应得的话，就对我发脾气吧。但我从宪法上反对这种事情。当我还是一名医生时，我一直都有。你知道，他并不安全。他发烧得很严重。

Mr. Skimpole had retreated from the hall to the drawing-room again and said this in his airy way, seated on the music-stool as we stood by.
斯金波尔先生又从大厅退到客厅，坐在音乐凳上，我们站在旁边，用他轻快的语气说了这句话。

‘You’ll say it’s childish,’ observed Mr. Skimpole, looking gaily at us. ‘Well, I dare say it may be; but I AM a child, and I never pretend to be anything else. If you put him out in the road, you only put him where he was before. He will be no worse off than he was, you know. Even make him better off, if you like. Give him sixpence, or five shillings, or five pound ten—you are arithmeticians, and I am not—and get rid of him!’
“你会说这很幼稚，”斯金波尔先生高兴地看着我们说道。 “好吧，我敢说可能是这样；”但我是个孩子，我从不假装自己是其他人。如果你把他放在路上，你只是把他放在原来的地方。你知道，他的处境不会比以前更糟。如果你愿意的话，甚至可以让他过得更好。给他六便士，或者五先令，或者五先令——你们是算术家，而我不是——然后除掉他！

‘And what is he to do then?’ asked my guardian.
“那他该怎么办呢？”我的监护人问道。

‘Upon my life,’ said Mr. Skimpole, shrugging his shoulders with his engaging smile, ‘I have not the least idea what he is to do then. But I have no doubt he’ll do it.’
“我以我的生命起誓，”斯金波尔先生一边说，一边微笑着耸了耸肩，“我根本不知道他到时候要做什么。”但我毫不怀疑他会这么做。”

‘Now, is it not a horrible reflection,’ said my guardian, to whom I had hastily explained the unavailing efforts of the two women, ‘is it not a horrible reflection,’ walking up and down and rumpling his hair, ‘that if this wretched creature were a convicted prisoner, his hospital would be wide open to him, and he would be as well taken care of as any sick boy in the kingdom?’
“现在，这不是一个可怕的反映吗？”我的监护人说，我匆忙向他解释了这两个女人徒劳的努力，“这不是一个可怕的反映吗？”他走来走去，揉乱了他的头发，“如果这个可怜的家伙是一个被定罪的囚犯，他的医院会向他敞开大门，他会像王国里任何生病的男孩一样得到很好的照顾吗？

‘My dear Jarndyce,’ returned Mr. Skimpole, ‘you’ll pardon the simplicity of the question, coming as it does from a creature who is perfectly simple in worldly matters, but why ISN’T he a prisoner then?’
“我亲爱的贾迪斯，”斯金波尔先生回答道，“你会原谅这个问题的简单性，因为它来自一个对世俗事务非常简单的生物，但为什么他不是一个囚犯呢？”

My guardian stopped and looked at him with a whimsical mixture of amusement and indignation in his face.
我的监护人停下来看着他，脸上的表情既有趣又愤慨。

‘Our young friend is not to be suspected of any delicacy, I should imagine,’ said Mr. Skimpole, unabashed and candid. ‘It seems to me that it would be wiser, as well as in a certain kind of way more respectable, if he showed some misdirected energy that got him into prison. There would be more of an adventurous spirit in it, and consequently more of a certain sort of poetry.’
“我想，我们的年轻朋友不会有任何精致的嫌疑，”斯基姆波尔先生毫不掩饰而坦率地说。 “在我看来，如果他表现出一些导致他入狱的错误精力，那会更明智，而且在某种程度上更受人尊敬。”其中会有更多的冒险精神，因此更多的是某种诗歌。”

‘I believe,’ returned my guardian, resuming his uneasy walk, ‘that there is not such another child on earth as yourself.’
“我相信，”我的监护人回答道，继续他不安的步伐，“地球上再没有像你这样的孩子了。”

‘Do you really?’ said Mr. Skimpole. ‘I dare say! But I confess I don’t see why our young friend, in his degree, should not seek to invest himself with such poetry as is open to him. He is no doubt born with an appetite—probably, when he is in a safer state of health, he has an excellent appetite. Very well. At our young friend’s natural dinner hour, most likely about noon, our young friend says in effect to society, ‘I am hungry; will you have the goodness to produce your spoon and feed me?’ Society, which has taken upon itself the general arrangement of the whole system of spoons and professes to have a spoon for our young friend, does NOT produce that spoon; and our young friend, therefore, says ‘You really must excuse me if I seize it.’ Now, this appears to me a case of misdirected energy, which has a certain amount of reason in it and a certain amount of romance; and I don’t know but what I should be more interested in our young friend, as an illustration of such a case, than merely as a poor vagabond—which any one can be.’
“你真的吗？”斯金波尔先生说。 '我敢说！但我承认，我不明白为什么我们年轻的朋友，在他的学位上，不应该寻求向他自己开放的诗歌。毫无疑问，他生来就有胃口——也许，当他处于更安全的健康状态时，他的胃口就很好。很好。在我们年轻朋友自然的晚餐时间，很可能是中午，我们的年轻朋友实际上对社会说：“我饿了；我饿了；我饿了；我饿了；我饿了；我饿了。”你能拿出你的勺子来喂我吗？”社会，它已经承担了整个勺子系统的总体安排，并声称为我们的年轻朋友拥有一把勺子，但它并不生产那个勺子；它是一个勺子。因此，我们的年轻朋友说：“如果我抓住了它，你真的必须原谅我。” 现在，在我看来，这是一个能量被误导的例子，其中有一定的理由和一定的浪漫；我不知道我应该对我们的年轻朋友更感兴趣，作为这种情况的例证，而不是仅仅作为一个可怜的流浪汉——任何人都可以成为。

‘In the meantime,’ I ventured to observe, ‘he is getting worse.’
“与此同时，”我大胆地观察到，“他的情况越来越糟。”

‘In the meantime,’ said Mr. Skimpole cheerfully, ‘as Miss Summerson, with her practical good sense, observes, he is getting worse. Therefore I recommend your turning him out before he gets still worse.’
“与此同时，”斯金波尔先生高兴地说，“正如萨默森小姐凭着她实际敏锐的判断力所观察到的那样，他的情况越来越糟。因此我建议你在他变得更糟之前把他赶出去。

The amiable face with which he said it, I think I shall never forget.
他说这句话时的和蔼可亲的表情，我想我永远不会忘记。

‘Of course, little woman,’ observed my guardian, tuming to me, ‘I can ensure his admission into the proper place by merely going there to enforce it, though it’s a bad state of things when, in his condition, that is necessary. But it’s growing late, and is a very bad night, and the boy is worn out already. There is a bed in the wholesome loft-room by the stable; we had better keep him there till morning, when he can be wrapped up and removed. We’ll do that.’
“当然，小女人，”我的监护人转向我说道，“我只要去那里强制执行就可以确保他进入适当的地方，尽管在他的情况下，这是必要的，但情况很糟糕。” 。但天色已晚，这是一个非常糟糕的夜晚，男孩已经疲惫不堪了。马厩旁卫生的阁楼房间里有一张床；我们最好把他留在那里直到早上，那时他就可以被包裹起来并移走。我们会这么做的。

‘Oh!’ said Mr. Skimpole, with his hands upon the keys of the piano as we moved away. ‘Are you going back to our young friend?’
“哦！”我们走开时，斯金波尔先生双手放在钢琴键上说道。 “你要回到我们年轻朋友身边吗？”

‘Yes,’ said my guardian.
“是的，”我的监护人说。

‘How I envy you your constitution, Jarndyce!’ returned Mr. Skimpole with playful admiration. ‘You don’t mind these things; neither does Miss Summerson. You are ready at all times to go anywhere, and do anything. Such is will! I have no will at all—and no won’t—simply can’t.’
“我多么羡慕你的体格啊，贾迪斯！”斯金波尔先生带着俏皮的钦佩回答道。 ‘你不介意这些事情；萨默森小姐也没有。您随时准备好去任何地方、做任何事情。这就是意志！我根本没有意愿——也没有意愿——就是不能。

‘You can’t recommend anything for the boy, I suppose?’ said my guardian, looking back over his shoulder half angrily; only half angrily, for he never seemed to consider Mr. Skimpole an accountable being.
“我想你不能给这个男孩推荐任何东西吧？”我的监护人说道，半怒地回头看了一眼。只是半生气，因为他似乎从来不认为斯金波尔先生是一个负责任的人。

‘My dear Jarndyce, I observed a bottle of cooling medicine in his pocket, and it’s impossible for him to do better than take it. You can tell them to sprinkle a little vinegar about the place where he sleeps and to keep it moderately cool and him moderately warm. But it is mere impertinence in me to offer any recommendation. Miss Summerson has such a knowledge of detail and such a capacity for the administration of detail that she knows all about it.’
“我亲爱的贾迪斯，我发现他口袋里有一瓶退烧药，对他来说，除了服用它之外，别无他法。”你可以告诉他们在他睡觉的地方撒一点醋，保持适度凉爽和适度温暖。但我提出任何建议都是无礼的。萨默森小姐对细节的了解和管理细节的能力如此之高，以至于她对此了如指掌。

We went back into the hall and explained to Jo what we proposed to do, which Charley explained to him again and which he received with the languid unconcern I had already noticed, wearily looking on at what was done as if it were for somebody else. The servants compassionating his miserable state and being very anxious to help, we soon got the loft-room ready; and some of the men about the house carried him across the wet yard, well wrapped up. It was pleasant to observe how kind they were to him and how there appeared to be a general impression among them that frequently calling him ‘Old Chap’ was likely to revive his spirits. Charley directed the operations and went to and fro between the loft-room and the house with such little stimulants and comforts as we thought it safe to give him. My guardian himself saw him before he was left for the night and reported to me when he returned to the growlery to write a letter on the boy’s behalf, which a messenger was charged to deliver at day-light in the morning, that he seemed easier and inclined to sleep. They had fastened his door on the outside, he said, in case of his being delirious, but had so arranged that he could not make any noise without being heard.
我们回到大厅，向乔解释了我们打算做什么，查利又向他解释了一遍，他带着我已经注意到的慵懒的漠然态度接受了这一解释，疲倦地看着所做的事情，就好像这是为别人做的一样。仆人们同情他的悲惨处境，热心帮忙，很快我们就把阁楼房间准备好了。房子周围的一些人把他裹得严严实实，抬着穿过湿漉漉的院子。很高兴看到他们对他多么友善，而且他们之间似乎有一种普遍印象，经常叫他“老伙计”可能会让他精神振奋。查理指挥着行动，在阁楼房间和房子之间来回走动，带着我们认为安全的少量兴奋剂和舒适感。我的监护人在他离开过夜前亲自见到了他，并在他返回咆哮处为男孩写一封信时向我报告，这封信由一名信使在早上白天递送，他看起来更容易并倾向于睡觉。他说，他们把他的门锁在外面，以防他神志不清，但又安排得不能让他发出任何声音而不被人听到。

Ada being in our room with a cold, Mr. Skimpole was left alone all this time and entertained himself by playing snatches of pathetic airs and sometimes singing to them (as we heard at a distance) with great expression and feeling. When we rejoined him in the drawingroom he said he would give us a little ballad which had come into his head ‘apropos of our young friend,’ and he sang one about a peasant boy,
艾达因感冒而待在我们的房间里，斯金波尔先生一直独自一人，他通过演奏一些可怜的曲子来娱乐自己，有时还给他们唱歌（正如我们在远处听到的那样），表情丰富，感情丰富。当我们在客厅重新见到他时，他说他会给我们一首小歌谣，这首歌是他脑海中“关于我们年轻朋友的”，他唱了一首关于一个农民男孩的歌谣，

“Thrown on the wide world, doomed to wander and roam,
“被抛在广阔的世界上，注定要流浪和徜徉，

Bereft of his parents, bereft of a home.’
失去了父母，失去了家。”

quite exquisitely. It was a song that always made him cry, he told us.
相当精致。他告诉我们，这首歌总是让他哭泣。

He was extremely gay all the rest of the evening, for he absolutely chirped—those were his delighted words—when he thought by what a happy talent for business he was surrounded. He gave us, in his glass of negus, ‘Better health to our young friend!’ and supposed and gaily pursued the case of his being reserved like Whittington to become Lord Mayor of London. In that event, no doubt, he would establish the Jarndyce Institution and the Summerson Almshouses, and a little annual Corporation Pilgrimage to St. Albans. He had no doubt, he said, that our young friend was an excellent boy in his way, but his way was not the Harold Skimpole way; what Harold Skimpole was, Harold Skimpole had found himself, to his considerable surprise, when he first made his own acquaintance; he had accepted himself with all his failings and had thought it sound philosophy to make the best of the bargain; and he hoped we would do the same.
