整个晚上他都非常高兴，因为当他想到周围有一个多么快乐的商业天才时，他绝对叽叽喳喳地叫着——这是他高兴的话语。他在他的酒杯里对我们说：“祝我们年轻的朋友身体健康！”并愉快地设想自己会像惠廷顿一样被保留，成为伦敦市长。在这种情况下，毫无疑问，他将建立贾迪斯学院和萨默森救济院，以及每年一次的小型公司圣奥尔本斯朝圣活动。他说，他毫不怀疑我们的年轻朋友在他的方式上是一个优秀的男孩，但他的方式不是哈罗德·斯金波尔的方式；他的方式是他的方式。当哈罗德·斯金波尔第一次结识哈罗德·斯金波尔时，他大吃一惊地发现了自己的身份。他接受了自己的所有缺点，并认为充分利用这笔交易是明智的。他希望我们也这样做。

Charley’s last report was that the boy was quiet. I could see, from my window, the lantern they had left him burning quietly; and I went to bed very happy to think that he was sheltered.
查理的最后报告是这个男孩很安静。从窗户里我可以看到他们留给他的灯笼静静地燃烧着。想到他受到庇护，我很高兴地上床睡觉。

There was more movement and more talking than usual a little before daybreak, and it awoke me. As I was dressing, I looked out of my window and asked one of our men who had been among the active sympathizers last night whether there was anything wrong about the house. The lantern was still burning in the loft-window.
天亮之前，比平常有更多的动静和更多的谈话，这让我醒了。当我穿衣服的时候，我向窗外望去，问昨晚活跃的同情者中的一位男士，这栋房子是否有什么问题。阁楼窗户上的灯笼还亮着。

‘It’s the boy, miss,’ said he.
“是那个男孩，小姐，”他说。

‘Is he worse?’ I inquired.
“他的情况更糟吗？”我问道。

‘Gone, miss.
‘走了，小姐。

‘Dead!’
'死的！'

‘Dead, miss? No. Gone clean off.’
‘死了吗，小姐？不，彻底消失了。”

At what time of the night he had gone, or how, or why, it seemed hopeless ever to divine. The door remaining as it had been left, and the lantern standing in the window, it could only be supposed that he had got out by a trap in the floor which communicated with an empty cart-house below. But he had shut it down again, if that were so; and it looked as if it had not been raised. Nothing of any kind was missing. On this fact being clearly ascertained, we all yielded to the painful belief that delirium had come upon him in the night and that, allured by some imaginary object or pursued by some imaginary horror, he had strayed away in that worse than helpless state; all of us, that is to say, but Mr. Skimpole, who repeatedly suggested, in his usual easy light style, that it had occurred to our young friend that he was not a safe inmate, having a bad kind of fever upon him, and that he had with great natural politeness taken himself off.
他是在晚上什么时候离开的，或者是如何离开的，或者为什么离开的，似乎永远无法预测。门还是原来的样子，窗子上挂着灯笼，只能推测他是通过地板上的一个陷阱逃出来的，这个陷阱与下面一个空的马车房相通。但如果是这样的话，他又把它关掉了；看起来好像没有被抬起来。没有任何东西丢失。在清楚地确定这一事实后，我们都屈服于痛苦的信念，认为他在夜间出现了谵妄，受到某种想象中的物体的诱惑或某种想象中的恐怖的追捕，他在那种比无助更糟糕的状态中迷失了方向；也就是说，我们所有人，除了斯金波尔先生，他以他惯常的轻松轻松的风格反复暗示，我们的年轻朋友突然意识到他不是一个安全的囚犯，他正发着严重的发烧，他自然而然地彬彬有礼地把自己脱掉了。

Every possible inquiry was made, and every place was searched. The brick-kilns were examined, the cottages were visited, the two women were particularly questioned, but they knew nothing of him, and nobody could doubt that their wonder was genuine. The weather had for some time been too wet and the night itself had been too wet to admit of any tracing by footsteps. Hedge and ditch, and wall, and rick and stack, were examined by our men for a long distance round, lest the boy should be lying in such a place insensible or dead; but nothing was seen to indicate that he had ever been near. From the time when he was left in the loft-room, he vanished.
每一个可能的询问都被进行了，每一个地方都被搜查了。人们检查了砖窑，参观了小屋，特别询问了两个女人，但她们对他一无所知，没有人会怀疑她们的惊奇是真实的。一段时间以来，天气太潮湿，夜晚也太潮湿，无法留下任何足迹。我们的人对树篱、沟渠、墙壁、草垛和堆垛进行了很长一段距离的检查，以免男孩躺在这样的地方失去知觉或死亡。但没有看到任何迹象表明他曾经靠近过。从他被留在阁楼房间的那一刻起，他就消失了。

The search continued for five days. I do not mean that it ceased even then, but that my attention was then diverted into a current very memorable to me.
搜寻工作持续了五天。我并不是说它甚至在那时就停止了，而是说我的注意力随后转移到了令我非常难忘的电流上。

As Charley was at her writing again in my room in the evening, and as I sat opposite to her at work, I felt the table tremble. Looking up, I saw my little maid shivering from head to foot.
晚上，当查理再次在我的房间里写作时，当我坐在她对面工作时，我感到桌子在颤抖。抬头一看，只见我的小丫鬟从头到脚都在瑟瑟发抖。

‘Charley,’ said I, ‘are you so cold?’
“查理，”我说，“你这么冷吗？”

‘I think I am, miss,’ she replied. ‘I don’t know what it is. I can’t hold myself still. I felt so yesterday at about this same time, miss. Don’t be uneasy, I think I’m ill.’
“我想是的，小姐，”她回答道。 ‘我不知道那是什么。我无法保持静止。昨天大约在同一时间我也有这样的感觉，小姐。别担心，我想我病了。”

I heard Ada’s voice outside, and I hurried to the door of communication between my room and our pretty sitting-room, and locked it. Just in time, for she tapped at it while my hand was yet upon the key.
我听到外面艾达的声音，我赶紧跑到我的房间和我们漂亮的客厅之间的连通门前，把门锁上。来得正是时候，因为她敲击了钥匙，而我的手还放在钥匙上。

Ada called to me to let her in, but I said, ‘Not now, my dearest. Go away. There’s nothing the matter; I will come to you presently.’ Ah! It was a long, long time before my darling girl and I were companions again.
艾达叫我让她进来，但我说：“现在不行，我最亲爱的。”离开。没什么问题；我马上就来找你。’啊！过了很长很长一段时间，我和我亲爱的女儿才再次成为伴侣。

Charley fell ill. In twelve hours she was very ill. I moved her to my room, and laid her in my bed, and sat down quietly to nurse her. I told my guardian all about it, and why I felt it was necessary that I should seclude myself, and my reason for not seeing my darling above all. At first she came very often to the door, and called to me, and even reproached me with sobs and tears; but I wrote her a long letter saying that she made me anxious and unhappy and imploring her, as she loved me and wished my mind to be at peace, to come no nearer than the garden. After that she came beneath the window even oftener than she had come to the door, and if I had learnt to love her dear sweet voice before when we were hardly ever apart, how did I learn to love it then, when I stood behind the window-curtain listening and replying, but not so much as looking out! How did I learn to love it afterwards, when the harder time came!
查理病倒了。十二个小时后，她病得很重。我把她搬到我的房间，把她放在床上，安静地坐下来护理她。我告诉了我的监护人这一切，以及为什么我觉得有必要自我隔离，以及最重要的是我没有见到我亲爱的人的原因。起初，她经常到门口来叫我，甚至哭着、流着泪责备我。但我给她写了一封长信，说她让我感到焦虑和不快乐，并恳求她，因为她爱我，希望我的心灵平静，不要靠近花园。从那以后，她从窗下来的次数比到门口来的次数还要多，如果说以前我们几乎不分开的时候我就已经学会了爱她那可爱甜美的声音，那么当我站在窗子后面时，我又是如何学会爱她的呢？窗帘式的倾听和回应，但与其说是向外看！当困难时期来临时，我是如何学会爱它的！

They put a bed for me in our sitting-room; and by keeping the door wide open, I turned the two rooms into one, now that Ada had vacated that part of the house, and kept them always fresh and airy. There was not a servant in or about the house but was so good that they would all most gladly have come to me at any hour of the day or night without the least fear or unwillingness, but I thought it best to choose one worthy woman who was never to see Ada and whom I could trust to come and go with all precaution. Through her means I got out to take the air with my guardian when there was no fear of meeting Ada, and wanted for nothing in the way of attendance, any more than in any other respect.
他们在客厅里为我放了一张床。现在艾达已经腾出了房子的那一部分，我把门一直开着，把两个房间变成了一个房间，并保持它们总是新鲜通风。房子里或房子周围没有一个仆人，但他们非常好，他们都非常乐意在白天或晚上的任何时候来找我，没有丝毫的恐惧或不情愿，但我认为最好选择一个有价值的女人我从来没有见过艾达，我可以相信她会小心翼翼地来来去去。通过她的帮助，我和我的监护人一起出去散步，不再害怕见到艾达，也不需要任何出席，比任何其他方面都更重要。

And thus poor Charley sickened and grew worse, and fell into heavy danger of death, and lay severely ill for many a long round of day and night. So patient she was, so uncomplaining, and inspired by such a gentle fortitude that very often as I sat by Charley holding her head in my arms—repose would come to her, so, when it would come to her in no other attitude—I silently prayed to our Father in heaven that I might not forget the lesson which this little sister taught me.
就这样，可怜的查理病了，病情越来越重，陷入了死亡的重重危险，病重地躺了很多个日日夜夜。她是如此耐心，如此毫无怨言，并受到如此温柔的刚毅的启发，以至于当我坐在查理旁边，将她的头抱在怀里时，她就会平静下来，所以，当她以其他态度平静时，我默默地向天父祈祷，让我不要忘记这个小妹妹给我的教训。

I was very sorrowful to think that Charley’s pretty looks would change and be disfigured, even if she recovered—she was such a child with her dimpled face—but that thought was, for the greater part, lost in her greater peril. When she was at the worst, and her mind rambled again to the cares of her father’s sick bed and the little children, she still knew me so far as that she would be quiet in my arms when she could lie quiet nowhere else, and murmur out the wanderings of her mind less restlessly. At those times I used to think, how should I ever tell the two remaining babies that the baby who had learned of her faithful heart to be a mother to them in their need was dead!
一想到查理美丽的容貌会发生变化并被毁容，即使她康复了——她还是个脸上有酒窝的孩子——我感到非常悲伤，但这个想法在很大程度上已经消失在她更大的危险中。当她最难受的时候，她的思绪又开始牵扯到父亲的病床和孩子们的忧虑上，她仍然了解我，以至于当她无法安静地躺在其他地方时，她会安静地躺在我的怀里，喃喃自语。她的思绪不再那么焦躁不安。那时我常常想，我该如何告诉剩下的两个婴儿，那个得知她忠实的心成为他们需要的母亲的婴儿已经死了！

There were other times when Charley knew me well and talked to me, telling me that she sent her love to Tom and Emma and that she was sure Tom would grow up to be a good man. At those times Charley would speak to me of what she had read to her father as well as she could to comfort him, of that young man carried out to be buried who was the only son of his mother and she was a widow, of the ruler’s daughter raised up by the gracious hand upon her bed of death. And Charley told me that when her father died she had kneeled down and prayed in her first sorrow that he likewise might be raised up and given back to his poor children, and that if she should never get better and should die too, she thought it likely that it might come into Tom’s mind to offer the same prayer for her. Then would I show Tom how these people of old days had been brought back to life on earth, only that we might know our hope to be restored to heaven!
还有几次，查理很了解我，并与我交谈，告诉我她向汤姆和艾玛表达了她的爱，并且她确信汤姆长大后会成为一个好男人。那时查理会向我讲述她读给她父亲听的内容，以及她尽可能安慰他的内容，以及那个被抬去埋葬的年轻人的故事，他是他母亲唯一的儿子，而她是一个寡妇，统治者的女儿在临终前被仁慈的手扶起。查理告诉我，当她父亲去世时，她在第一次悲伤中跪下来祈祷，希望他也能复活并回到他可怜的孩子们身边，如果她永远不会好起来，也应该死，她想汤姆可能也会想到为她做同样的祈祷。然后我会向汤姆展示这些过去的人们是如何在地球上复活的，只是为了让我们知道我们恢复天堂的希望！

But of all the various times there were in Charley’s illness, there was not one when she lost the gentle qualities I have spoken of. And there were many, many when I thought in the night of the last high belief in the watching angel, and the last higher trust in God, on the part of her poor despised father.
但在查理生病的各个时期中，没有一次她失去了我所说的温柔品质。那天晚上，当我想到她那可怜的、被鄙视的父亲对守护天使的最后一次高度信仰，以及对上帝最后一次更高的信任时，我想到了很多很多。

And Charley did not die. She flutteringiy and slowly turned the dangerous point, after long lingering there, and then began to mend. The hope that never had been given, from the first, of Charley being in outward appearance Charley any more soon began to be encouraged; and even that prospered, and I saw her growing into her old childish likeness again.
查理并没有死。她轻飘飘地，慢慢地转过了那个危险点，在那儿徘徊了很久之后，才开始好转。从一开始就从未抱有的希望，即查理在外表上不再是查理的希望，很快就开始受到鼓舞。即便如此，我也看到她又恢复了原来的孩子气。

It was a great morning when I could tell Ada all this as she stood out in the garden; and it was a great evening when Charley and I at last took tea together in the next room. But on that same evening, I felt that I was stricken cold.
这是一个美好的早晨，当艾达站在花园里时，我可以告诉她这一切。这是一个美好的夜晚，查理和我终于在隔壁房间一起喝茶。但当天晚上，我就感觉浑身发冷。

Happily for both of us, it was not until Charley was safe in bed again and placidly asleep that I began to think the contagion of her illness was upon me. I had been able easily to hide what I felt at tea-time, but I was past that already now, and I knew that I was rapidly following in Charley’s steps.
让我们俩感到高兴的是，直到查理再次安全地躺在床上并平静地睡着时，我才开始认为她的病已经传染到了我身上。我很容易隐藏自己在喝茶时的感受，但现在我已经过去了，我知道我正在迅速追随查理的脚步。

I was well enough, however, to be up early in the morning, and to return my darling’s cheerful blessing from the garden, and to talk with her as long as usual. But I was not free from an impression that I had been walking about the two rooms in the night, a little beside myself, though knowing where I was; and I felt confused at times—with a curious sense of fullness, as if I were becoming too large altogether.
不过，我的身体状况还不错，可以一大早就起床，从花园里回报我亲爱的人的快乐祝福，并像平常一样与她交谈。但我还是没有摆脱这样的印象：夜里我一直在这两个房间里走来走去，有点疯狂，尽管我知道自己在哪里；有时我感到困惑——有一种奇怪的充实感，好像我变得太大了。

In the evening I was so much worse that I resolved to prepare Charley, with which view I said, ‘You’re getting quite strong, Charley, are you not?’
晚上，我的情况变得更糟，所以我决定让查理做好准备，我抱着这样的想法说：“查理，你已经变得很强壮了，不是吗？”

‘Oh, quite!’ said Charley.
“噢，完全可以！”查理说。

‘Strong enough to be told a secret, I think, Charley?’
“我想，查理，足够坚强，可以告诉别人一个秘密吗？”

‘Quite strong enough for that, miss!’ cried Charley. But Charley’s face fell in the height of her delight, for she saw the secret in MY face; and she came out of the great chair, and fell upon my bosom, and said ‘Oh, miss, it’s my doing! It’s my doing!’ and a great deal more out of the fullness of her grateful heart.
“足够强大了，小姐！”查理喊道。但查理的脸因喜悦而落下，因为她在我脸上看到了秘密；她从大椅子上走出来，倒在我怀里，说：“哦，小姐，这是我做的！”这是我做的！”而且更多的是出于她内心的感激之情。

‘Now, Charley,’ said I after letting her go on for a little while, ‘if I am to be ill, my great trust, humanly speaking, is in you. And unless you are as quiet and composed for me as you always were for yourself, you can never fulfil it, Charley.’
“现在，查理，”我让她继续说了一会儿后说道，“如果我生病了，从人的角度来说，我最大的信任就是你。除非你像对待自己一样对我保持安静和镇定，否则你永远无法实现它，查理。

‘If you’ll let me cry a little longer, miss,’ said Charley. ‘Oh, my dear, my dear! If you’ll only let me cry a little longer. Oh, my dear!’—how affectionately and devotedly she poured this out as she clung to my neck, I never can remember without tears—‘I’ll be good.’
“如果你能让我再哭一会儿，小姐，”查利说。 ‘哦，亲爱的，亲爱的！如果你能让我再哭一会儿就好了。哦，亲爱的！”——她搂着我的脖子，多么深情又虔诚地倾诉着这句话，我总是不禁热泪盈眶地回忆着——“我会很好的。”

So I let Charley cry a little longer, and it did us both good.
所以我让查理再哭一会儿，这对我们俩都有好处。

‘Trust in me now, if you please, miss,’ said Charley quietly. ‘I am listening to everything you say.’
“现在请相信我，小姐，”查理平静地说。 “我正在听你说的一切。”

‘It’s very little at present, Charley. I shall tell your doctor to-night that I don’t think I am well and that you are going to nurse me.’
“目前还很少，查理。”今晚我会告诉你的医生，我认为我不太好，你要照顾我。

For that the poor child thanked me with her whole heart. ‘And in the morning, when you hear Miss Ada in the garden, if I should not be quite able to go to the window-curtain as usual, do you go, Charley, and say I am asleep—that I have rather tired myself, and am asleep. At all times keep the room as I have kept it, Charley, and let no one come.’
为此，这个可怜的孩子全心全意地感谢我。 “早上，当你在花园里听到艾达小姐的声音时，如果我不能像往常一样走到窗帘那儿，你会去吗，查理，说我睡着了——我自己已经很累了。” ，然后我就睡着了。查理，请始终保持房间的整洁，不要让任何人进来。

Charley promised, and I lay down, for I was very heavy. I saw the doctor that night and asked the favour of him that I wished to ask relative to his saying nothing of my illness in the house as yet. I have a very indistinct remembrance of that night melting into day, and of day melting into night again; but I was just able on the first morning to get to the window and speak to my darling.
查理答应了，然后我躺了下来，因为我很重。那天晚上我去看了医生，向他求助，我想向他求助，但他在家里对我的病只字不提。我非常模糊地记得那天黑夜变成了白昼，白昼又变成了黑夜。但第一天早上我才能够走到窗前和我亲爱的说话。

On the second morning I heard her dear voice—Oh, how dear now!— outside; and I asked Charley, with some difficulty (speech being painful to me), to go and say I was asleep. I heard her answer softly, ‘Don’t disturb her, Charley, for the world!’
第二天早上，我在外面听到了她可爱的声音——哦，现在多么可爱啊！我有些困难地请查理（说话对我来说很痛苦），去告诉他我睡着了。我听到她轻声回答：“查理，别打扰她！”

‘How does my own Pride look, Charley?’ I inquired.
“我的骄傲看起来怎么样，查理？”我问道。

‘Disappointed, miss,’ said Charley, peeping through the curtain.
“很失望，小姐，”查理透过窗帘往外看。

‘But I know she is very beautiful this morning.’
“但我知道她今天早上非常漂亮。”

‘She is indeed, miss,’ answered Charley, peeping. ‘Still looking up at the window.’
“确实是，小姐，”查利偷偷地回答。 “仍然抬头看着窗户。”

With her blue clear eyes, God bless them, always loveliest when raised like that!
有着她蓝色清澈的眼睛，上帝保佑她们，这样长大的时候总是最可爱的！

I called Charley to me and gave her her last charge.
我把查理叫到身边，给了她最后的嘱托。

‘Now, Charley, when she knows I am ill, she will try to make her way into the room. Keep her out, Charley, if you love me truly, to the last! Charley, if you let her in but once, only to look upon me for one moment as I lie here, I shall die.’
“现在，查理，当她知道我病了时，她会试图走进房间。查理，如果你真的爱我，就别让她进来，直到最后！查理，如果你只让她进来一次，只是为了在我躺在这里的时候看我一会儿，我就会死。

‘I never will! I never will!’ she promised me.
‘我永远不会！我永远不会！”她向我保证。

‘I believe it, my dear Charley. And now come and sit beside me for a little while, and touch me with your hand. For I cannot see you, Charley; I am blind.’
“我相信，我亲爱的查理。现在过来在我身边坐一会儿，用手抚摸我。因为我看不见你，查理；我是盲人。

CHAPTER XXXII
第三十二章


The Appointed Time
指定时间

It is night in Lincoln’s Inn—perplexed and troublous valley of the shadow of the law, where suitors generally find but little day—and fat candles are snuffed out in offices, and clerks have rattled down the crazy wooden stairs and dispersed. The bell that rings at nine o’clock has ceased its doleful clangour about nothing; the gates are shut; and the night-porter, a solemn warder with a mighty power of sleep, keeps guard in his lodge. From tiers of staircase windows clogged lamps like the eyes of Equity, bleared Argus with a fathomless pocket for every eye and an eye upon it, dimly blink at the stars. In dirty upper casements, here and there, hazy little patches of candlelight reveal where some wise draughtsman and conveyancer yet toils for the entanglement of real estate in meshes of sheep-skin, in the average ratio of about a dozen of sheep to an acre of land. Over which bee-like industry these benefactors of their species linger yet, though office-hours be past, that they may give, for every day, some good account at last.
林肯律师学院是一个夜晚，法律阴影下的一个令人困惑和麻烦的山谷，求婚者通常在那里找到的时间很少。办公室里的粗蜡烛被熄灭，职员们嘎嘎地走下疯狂的木楼梯并散去。九点钟敲响的钟声已经停止了无缘无故的凄凉叮当声；城门关闭；夜间看门人是一位严肃的看守，具有强大的睡眠能力，在他的小屋里看守。楼梯间的窗户上布满了灯，就像公平的眼睛一样，昏暗的阿古斯每只眼睛都有一个深不可测的口袋，一只眼睛盯着它，朦胧地眨着眼睛看着星星。在脏兮兮的上层窗户里，到处都是朦胧的小片烛光，揭示了一些聪明的绘图员和产权转让师仍在辛勤地将房地产缠在羊皮网中，平均比例为一英亩土地大约有十几只羊。土地。尽管下班时间已经过去，但这些蜜蜂般的行业的恩人仍然在他们的物种中徘徊，以便他们最终可以每天做出一些好的贡献。

In the neighbouring court, where the Lord Chancellor of the rag and bottle shop dwells, there is a general tendency towards beer and supper. Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins, whose respective sons, engaged with a circle of acquaintance in the game of hide and seek, have been lying in ambush about the by-ways of Chancery Lane for some hours and scouring the plain of the same thoroughfare to the confusion of passengers—Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins have but now exchanged congratulations on the children being abed, and they still linger on a door-step over a few parting words. Mr. Krook and his lodger, and the fact of Mr. Krook’s being ‘continually in liquor,’ and the testamentary prospects of the young man are, as usual, the staple of their conversation. But they have something to say, likewise, of the Harmonic Meeting at the Sol’s Arms, where the sound of the piano through the partly opened windows jingles out into the court, and where Little Swills, after keeping the lovers of harmony in a roar like a very Yorick, may now be heard taking the gruff line in a concerted piece and sentimentally adjuring his friends and patrons to ‘Listen, listen, listen, tew the wa-ter fall!’ Mrs. Perkins and Mrs. Piper compare opinions on the subject of the young lady of professional celebrity who assists at the Harmonic Meetings and who has a space to herself in the manuscript announcement in the window, Mrs. Perkins possessing information that she has been married a year and a half, though announced as Miss M. Melvilleson, the noted siren, and that her baby is clandestinely conveyed to the Sol’s Arms every night to receive its natural nourishment during the entertainments. ‘Sooner than which, myself,’ says Mrs. Perkins, ‘I would get my living by selling lucifers.’ Mrs. Piper, as in duty bound, is of the same opinion, holding that a private station is better than public applause, and thanking heaven for her own (and, by implication, Mrs. Perkins’) respectability. By this time the pot-boy of the Sol’s Arms appearing with her supper-pint well frothed, Mrs. Piper accepts that tankard and retires indoors, first giving a fair good night to Mrs. Perkins, who has had her own pint in her hand ever since it was fetched from the same hostelry by young Perkins before he was sent to bed. Now there is a sound of putting up shopshutters in the court and a smell as of the smoking of pipes; and shooting stars are seen in upper windows, further indicating retirement to rest. Now, too, the policeman begins to push at doors; to try fastenings; to be suspicious of bundles; and to administer his beat, on the hypothesis that every one is either robbing or being robbed.
在附近的宫廷里，也就是破布和酒瓶店的大法官居住的地方，人们普遍喜欢喝啤酒和吃晚饭。派珀夫人和珀金斯夫人各自的儿子们在大法官巷的小道上埋伏了几个小时，并在同一条大道的平原上进行了搜查。令乘客感到困惑的是——派珀和珀金斯夫人现在已经就孩子们入睡交换了祝贺，他们仍然在门阶上徘徊，说了几句临别赠言。像往常一样，克鲁克先生和他的房客、克鲁克先生“不断酗酒”的事实以及年轻人的遗嘱前景是他们谈话的主要内容。但他们也有话要说，同样，关于在索尔之臂举行的和谐会议，钢琴的声音通过半开的窗户叮叮当当地传到庭院里，小斯威尔斯在让和谐爱好者们咆哮之后，像一个非常约里克的人，现在可能会听到在一首协奏曲中采取粗暴的路线，并感伤地恳求他的朋友和赞助人“听，听，听，拉瀑布！”帕金斯夫人和派珀夫人比较了对这个问题的看法。主题是在和谐会议上提供协助的职业名人年轻女士，她在窗口的手稿公告中拥有自己的空间，帕金斯夫人掌握着她已经结婚一年半的信息，尽管宣布为 M 小姐梅尔维尔森，著名的海妖，她的孩子每天晚上都会被秘密地送到索尔之臂，在娱乐活动期间接受它的天然营养。 “我自己，”帕金斯夫人说，“很快我就能靠卖路西法谋生了。” 出于义务，派珀也持同样的观点，认为私人地位比公众的掌声更好，并感谢上天赐予她自己（也暗指帕金斯夫人）的受人尊敬。这时，索尔阿姆斯的伙计出现了，她的晚餐品脱啤酒泡沫丰富，派珀夫人接受了酒杯，然后回到室内，首先向帕金斯夫人道了晚安，她手里拿着自己的品脱啤酒自从年轻的珀金斯在被送去睡觉之前从同一家旅馆取来它之后。现在院子里传来关门声和烟斗味。上方的窗户中出现流星，进一步表明退休休息。现在，警察也开始推门。尝试紧固；对捆绑持怀疑态度；并管理他的节奏，假设每个人要么在抢劫，要么被抢劫。

It is a close night, though the damp cold is searching too, and there is a laggard mist a little way up in the air. It is a fine steaming night to turn the slaughter-houses, the unwholesome trades, the sewerage, bad water, and burial-grounds to account, and give the registrar of deaths some extra business. It may be something in the air—there is plenty in it—or it may be something in himself that is in fault; but Mr. Weevle, otherwise Jobling, is very ill at ease. He comes and goes between his own room and the open street door twenty times an hour. He has been doing so ever since it fell dark. Since the Chancellor shut up his shop, which he did very early to-night, Mr. Weevle has been down and up, and down and up (with a cheap tight velvet skull-cap on his head, making his whiskers look out of all proportion), oftener than before.
这是一个寒冷的夜晚，但潮湿的寒冷也在逼近，空气中飘荡着一层迟缓的薄雾。这是一个天气热气腾腾的夜晚，可以对屠宰场、不健康的贸易、下水道、坏水和墓地进行调查，并给死亡登记员一些额外的工作。可能是空气中的某些东西——空气中有很多东西——或者可能是他自己的某些东西出了问题；但韦夫勒先生，除了乔布林之外，却非常不安。他每小时在自己的房间和敞开的门之间来回二十次。从天黑以后他就一直这样做。自从财政大臣今晚很早就关门了之后，韦夫勒先生就一直情绪低落、情绪高涨（他头上戴着一顶廉价的紧身天鹅绒无檐便帽，让他的胡须看起来很突兀）比例），比以前更频繁。

It is no phenomenon that Mr. Snagsby should be ill at ease too, for he always is so, more or less, under the oppressive influence of the secret that is upon him. Impelled by the mystery of which he is a partaker and yet in which he is not a sharer, Mr. Snagsby haunts what seems to be its fountain-head—the rag and bottle shop in the court. It has an irresistible attraction for him. Even now, coming round by the Sol’s Arms with the intention of passing down the court, and out at the Chancery Lane end, and so terminating his unpremeditated after-supper stroll of ten minutes’ long from his own door and back again, Mr. Snagsby approaches.
斯纳格斯比先生也难免感到不安，这并不是什么现象，因为他总是或多或少地受到这个秘密的压抑影响。斯纳格斯比先生受到他参与但又不参与其中的神秘感的驱使，经常出没于似乎是其源头的地方——宫廷里的破布和瓶子店。这对他来说有着不可抗拒的吸引力。即便是现在，他绕过索尔臂，打算穿过法庭，到大法官巷的尽头，结束了他在晚饭后从自家门口来来回走十分钟的漫无目的的散步。斯纳斯比走近。

‘What, Mr. Weevle?’ says the stationer, stopping to speak. ‘Are YOU there?’
“什么，威夫勒先生？”文具店员停下来说话。 '你在吗？'

‘Aye!’ says Weevle, ‘Here I am, Mr. Snagsby.’
“是的！”威夫勒说道，“我在这里，斯纳斯比先生。”

‘Airing yourself, as I am doing, before you go to bed?’ the stationer inquires.
“你睡觉前，像我一样，让自己通风一下吗？”文具店员问道。

‘Why, there’s not much air to be got here; and what there is, is not very freshening,’ Weevle answers, glancing up and down the court.
‘哎呀，这里没有多少空气了；威勒回答道，他环视球场上下。

‘Very true, sir. Don’t you observe,’ says Mr. Snagsby, pausing to sniff and taste the air a little, ‘don’t you observe, Mr. Weevle, that you’re—not to put too fine a point upon it—that you’re rather greasy here, sir?’
“非常正确，先生。 “你难道没有注意到吗？”斯纳格斯比先生说，他停下来闻了闻，尝了一下空气的味道，“你难道没有注意到吗，威夫勒先生，你——别说得太过分了——你“这里有点油腻，先生？”

‘Why, I have noticed myself that there is a queer kind of flavour in the place to-night,’ Mr. Weevle rejoins. ‘I suppose it’s chops at the Sol’s Arms.’
“哎呀，我自己注意到今晚这个地方有一种奇怪的味道，”韦夫勒先生回答道。 “我想是索尔之臂上的印章。”

‘Chops, do you think? Oh! Chops, eh?’ Mr. Snagsby sniffs and tastes again. ‘Well, sir, I suppose it is. But I should say their cook at the Sol wanted a little looking after. She has been burning ‘em, sir! And I don’t think’—Mr. Snagsby sniffs and tastes again and then spits and wipes his mouth—‘I don’t think— not to put too fine a point upon it—that they were quite fresh when they were shown the gridiron.’
‘乔普斯，你觉得呢？哦！排骨，嗯？”斯纳斯比先生闻了闻，又尝了尝。 “嗯，先生，我想是这样。但我应该说他们在索尔的厨师需要一点照顾。她一直在烧它们，先生！我不认为’——先生。斯纳斯比又闻了闻，尝了尝，然后吐了口唾沫，擦了擦嘴——“我不认为——不要过分强调——当它们被带到烤架上时，它们还很新鲜。”

‘That’s very likely. It’s a tainting sort of weather.’
‘这很有可能。这是一种有污染的天气。

‘It IS a tainting sort of weather,’ says Mr. Snagsby, ‘and I find it sinking to the spirits.’
“这是一种令人厌恶的天气，”斯纳斯比先生说，“我发现它让人心情低落。”

‘By George! I find it gives me the horrors,’ returns Mr. Weevle.
‘乔治！ “我发现它让我感到恐惧。”韦弗勒先生回答道。

‘Then, you see, you live in a lonesome way, and in a lonesome room, with a black circumstance hanging over it,’ says Mr. Snagsby, looking in past the other’s shoulder along the dark passage and then falling back a step to look up at the house. ‘I couldn’t live in that room alone, as you do, sir. I should get so fidgety and worried of an evening, sometimes, that I should be driven to come to the door and stand here sooner than sit there. But then it’s very true that you didn’t see, in your room, what I saw there. That makes a difference.’
“然后，你看，你生活在一个孤独的方式中，在一个孤独的房间里，上面笼罩着一层黑色的环境，”斯纳斯比先生说，沿着黑暗的通道越过对方的肩膀，然后向后退了一步，抬头看看房子。 “我不能像你一样独自住在那个房间里，先生。有时候，我会因为晚上而变得烦躁和担心，以至于我应该早点走到门口站在这里，而不是坐在那里。但确实，你在你的房间里没有看到我在那里看到的东西。这很重要。

‘I know quite enough about it,’ returns Tony.
“我对此了解得够多了，”托尼回答道。

‘It’s not agreeable, is it?’ pursues Mr. Snagsby, coughing his cough of mild persuasion behind his hand. ‘Mr. Krook ought to consider it in the rent. I hope he does, I am sure.’
“这不太舒服，是吗？”斯纳斯比先生问道，用手背后轻咳着咳嗽声。 '先生。克鲁克应该在租金中考虑这一点。我确信我希望他这么做。

‘I hope he does,’ says Tony. ‘But I doubt it.’
“我希望他这么做，”托尼说。 “但我对此表示怀疑。”

‘You find the rent too high, do you, sir?’ returns the stationer. ‘Rents ARE high about here. I don’t know how it is exactly, but the law seems to put things up in price. Not,’ adds Mr. Snagsby with his apologetic cough, ‘that I mean to say a word against the profession I get my living by.’
“您觉得房租太高了，先生，是吗？”文具店老板回答道。 “这里的租金很高。我不知道到底是怎么回事，但法律似乎规定了价格。斯纳格斯比先生带着歉意的咳嗽声补充道，“我并不是想对我赖以谋生的职业说一句话。”

Mr. Weevle again glances up and down the court and then looks at the stationer. Mr. Snagsby, blankly catching his eye, looks upward for a star or so and coughs a cough expressive of not exactly seeing his way out of this conversation.
韦弗勒先生再次环顾球场，然后看向文具店员。斯纳斯比先生茫然地与他的目光对视，向上寻找一颗星星左右，然后咳了一声，表示没有完全摆脱这场谈话。

‘It’s a curious fact, sir,’ he observes, slowly rubbing his hands, ‘that he should have been—‘
“这是一个奇怪的事实，先生，”他慢慢地搓着手，说道，“他本应该——”

‘Who’s he?’ interrupts Mr. Weevle.
“他是谁？”威弗尔先生打断道。

‘The deceased, you know,’ says Mr. Snagsby, twitching his head and right eyebrow towards the staircase and tapping his acquaintance on the button.
“死者，你知道的，”斯纳斯比先生说，他把头和右眉毛扭向楼梯，然后按下了他熟人的按钮。

‘Ah, to be sure!’ returns the other as if he were not over-fond of the subject. ‘I thought we had done with him.’
“啊，当然！”对方回答道，好像他并不太喜欢这个话题。 “我以为我们已经和他了结了。”

‘I was only going to say it’s a curious fact, sir, that he should have come and lived here, and been one of my writers, and then that you should come and live here, and be one of my writers too. Which there is nothing derogatory, but far from it in the appellation,’ says Mr. Snagsby, breaking off with a mistrust that he may have unpolitely asserted a kind of proprietorship in Mr. Weevle, ‘because I have known writers that have gone into brewers’ houses and done really very respectable indeed. Eminently respectable, sir,’ adds Mr. Snagsby with a misgiving that he has not improved the matter.
“我只想说，这是一个奇怪的事实，先生，他应该来这里住在这里，成为我的作家之一，然后你也应该来这里住在这里，也成为我的作家之一。斯纳格斯比先生说，这并没有什么贬义，但在这个称谓中却远非如此。”斯纳格斯比先生说，他不相信自己可能不礼貌地宣称自己对韦夫勒先生有某种所有权，“因为我认识一些作家，他们已经进入了韦夫勒先生的行列。啤酒厂的工作确实非常令人尊敬。非常值得尊敬，先生。”斯纳斯比先生补充道，他对自己没有改善这一问题感到疑虑。

‘It’s a curious coincidence, as you say,’ answers Weevle, once more glancing up and down the court.
“正如你所说，这是一个奇怪的巧合，”威勒回答道，再次环顾球场。

‘Seems a fate in it, don’t there?’ suggests the stationer.
“这似乎是一种命运，不是吗？”文具店老板建议道。

‘There does.’
“确实有。”

‘Just so,’ observes the stationer with his confirmatory cough. ‘Quite a fate in it. Quite a fate. Well, Mr. Weevle, I am afraid I must bid you good night’—Mr. Snagsby speaks as if it made him desolate to go, though he has been casting about for any means of escape ever since he stopped to speak—‘my little woman will be looking for me else. Good night, sir!’
“正是如此，”文具店员咳嗽着确认道。 ‘这真是一种命运。真是缘分啊。好吧，韦夫勒先生，恐怕我必须向您道晚安”——韦夫勒先生。斯纳斯比说得好像离开让他感到孤独，尽管自从他停下来说话以来，他一直在寻找任何逃跑的办法——“我的小女人会去找别的人。”晚安先生！'

If Mr. Snagsby hastens home to save his little woman the trouble of looking for him, he might set his mind at rest on that score. His little woman has had her eye upon him round the Sol’s Arms all this time and now glides after him with a pocket handkerchief wrapped over her head, honourmg Mr. Weevle and his doorway with a searching glance as she goes past.
如果斯纳斯比先生赶紧回家，免去他的小女人寻找他的麻烦，他可能会在这一点上放心。他的小女人一直在索尔之臂周围注视着他，现在她头上包着一块口袋手帕，跟在他后面，在经过时用审视的目光向韦弗勒先生和他的门口致敬。

‘You’ll know me again, ma’am, at all events,’ says Mr. Weevle to himself; ‘and I can’t compliment you on your appearance, whoever you are, with your head tied up in a bundle. Is this fellow NEVER coming!’
“无论如何，你会再次认识我的，女士，”威弗尔先生自言自语道。 “而且无论你是谁，你的头被绑起来，我都无法称赞你的外表。这家伙永远不会来吗？

This fellow approaches as he speaks. Mr. Weevle softly holds up his finger, and draws him into the passage, and closes the street door. Then they go upstairs, Mr. Weevle heavily, and Mr. Guppy (for it is he) very lightly indeed. When they are shut into the back room, they speak low.
这家伙一边说话一边走近。韦弗勒先生轻轻地举起手指，把他拉进过道，关上了临街的门。然后他们上楼，威夫勒先生很重，而古比先生（因为是他）确实很轻。当他们被关进里屋时，他们说话都很低声。

‘I thought you had gone to Jericho at least instead of coming here,’ says Tony.
“我以为你至少去了杰里科而不是来这里，”托尼说。

‘Why, I said about ten.’
“为什么，我说大约十个。”

‘You said about ten,’ Tony repeats. ‘Yes, so you did say about ten. But according to my count, it’s ten times ten—it’s a hundred o’clock. I never had such a night in my life!’
“你说大约十个，”托尼重复道。 “是的，所以你确实说了大约十个。但我数了数，十乘十——一百点了。我一生中从未经历过这样的夜晚！

‘What has been the matter?’
“出了什么事？”

‘That’s it!’ says Tony. ‘Nothing has been the matter. But here have I been stewing and fuming in this jolly old crib till I have had the horrors falling on me as thick as hail. THERE’S a blessedlooking candle!’ says Tony, pointing to the heavily burning taper on his table with a great cabbage head and a long winding-sheet.
“就是这样！”托尼说。 ‘没什么问题。但我一直在这个快乐的旧婴儿床上煎熬和冒烟，直到我的恐惧像冰雹一样厚重地降临在我身上。托尼指着桌子上燃烧着的蜡烛说道，蜡烛上有一个巨大的卷心菜头和一条长长的裹尸布。

‘That’s easily improved,’ Mr. Guppy observes as he takes the snuffers in hand.
“这很容易改进，”古比先生一边拿着剪子一边说道。

‘IS it?’ returns his friend. ‘Not so easily as you think. It has been smouldering like that ever since it was lighted.’
“是吗？”他的朋友回答道。 ‘并不像你想象的那么容易。自从点燃以来，它就一直这样闷烧着。”

‘Why, what’s the matter with you, Tony?’ inquires Mr. Guppy, looking at him, snuffers in hand, as he sits down with his elbow on the table.
“怎么了，你怎么了，托尼？”古皮先生问道，一边手肘撑在桌子上一边坐下来，手里拿着鼻烟。

‘William Guppy,’ replies the other, ‘I am in the downs. It’s this unbearably dull, suicidal room—and old Boguey downstairs, I suppose.’ Mr. Weevle moodily pushes the snuffers-tray from him with his elbow, leans his head on his hand, puts his feet on the fender, and looks at the fire. Mr. Guppy, observing him, slightly tosses his head and sits down on the other side of the table in an easy attitude.
“威廉·古比，”另一个回答道，“我正处于低谷。”就是这个令人难以忍受的沉闷、自杀式的房间——我想楼下还有老博吉。”韦夫勒先生情绪低落地用肘部把鼻烟盘推开，用手托着头，把脚放在挡泥板上，看着房间。火。顾比先生观察着他，微微摇头，态度轻松地在桌子的另一边坐下。

‘Wasn’t that Snagsby talking to you, Tony?’
“那不是斯纳斯比在跟你说话吗，托尼？”

‘Yes, and he—yes, it was Snagsby,’ said Mr. Weevle, altering the construction of his sentence.
“是的，他——是的，是斯纳格斯比，”威弗尔先生说，改变了句子的结构。

‘On business?’
“出差？”

‘No. No business. He was only sauntering by and stopped to prose.’
'不。没有生意。他只是闲逛，然后停下来写散文。

‘I thought it was Snagsby,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘and thought it as well that he shouldn’t see me, so I waited till he was gone.’
“我以为是斯纳斯比，”古比先生说，“而且我也认为他不应该看到我，所以我一直等到他走掉。”

‘There we go again, William G.!’ cried Tony, looking up for an instant. ‘So mysterious and secret! By George, if we were going to commit a murder, we couldn’t have more mystery about it!’
“又来了，威廉·G！”托尼突然抬起头喊道。 ‘如此神秘和秘密！乔治，如果我们要谋杀，我们就不能再有更多的神秘感了！

Mr. Guppy affects to smile, and with the view of changing the conversation, looks with an admiration, real or pretended, round the room at the Galaxy Gallery of British Beauty, terminating his survey with the portrait of Lady Dedlock over the mantelshelf, in which she is represented on a terrace, with a pedestal upon the terrace, and a vase upon the pedestal, and her shawl upon the vase, and a prodigious piece of fur upon the shawl, and her arm on the prodigious piece of fur, and a bracelet on her arm.
顾比先生假装微笑，为了改变谈话的目的，带着钦佩的目光，无论是真实的还是假装的，环视着银河英国美人画廊的房间，最后以壁炉架上德洛克夫人的肖像结束了他的调查。她被描绘在一个露台上，露台上有一个基座，基座上有一个花瓶，花瓶上有她的披肩，披巾上有一块巨大的毛皮，而她的手臂则放在那块巨大的毛皮上，并且她手臂上戴着一个手镯。

‘That’s very like Lady Dedlock,’ says Mr. Guppy. ‘It’s a speaking likeness.’
“这很像戴德洛克夫人，”古比先生说。 “这是一种说话的相似性。”

‘I wish it was,’ growls Tony, without changing his position. ‘I should have some fashionable conversation, here, then.’
“我希望如此，”托尼咆哮道，但没有改变立场。 “那我应该在这里聊点时髦的话题。”

Finding by this time that his friend is not to be wheedled into a more sociable humour, Mr. Guppy puts about upon the ill-used tack and remonstrates with him.
这时，古比先生发现他的朋友不能被哄骗而变得更友善，于是他采取了不恰当的策略并向他提出抗议。

‘Tony,’ says he, ‘I can make allowances for lowness of spirits, for no man knows what it is when it does come upon a man better than I do, and no man perhaps has a better right to know it than a man who has an unrequited image imprinted on his ‘eart. But there are bounds to these things when an unoffending party is in question, and I will acknowledge to you, Tony, that I don’t think your manner on the present occasion is hospitable or quite gentlemanly.’
“托尼，”他说，“我可以体谅情绪的低落，因为没有人比我更清楚当事情发生在一个人身上时是什么，也许没有人比一个人更有权利知道它。”他的“心”上印着一个单相思的形象。但是，当一个无冒犯的一方受到质疑时，这些事情是有界限的，我要向你承认，托尼，我认为你目前的态度并不热情好客或很有绅士风度。

‘This is strong language, William Guppy,’ returns Mr. Weevle.
“这是很重的语言，威廉·古比，”韦夫勒先生回答道。

‘Sir, it may be,’ retorts Mr. William Guppy, ‘but I feel strongly when I use it.’
“先生，可能是这样，”威廉·古比先生反驳道，“但当我使用它时，我的感觉很强烈。”

Mr. Weevle admits that he has been wrong and begs Mr. William Guppy to think no more about it. Mr. William Guppy, however, having got the advantage, cannot quite release it without a little more injured remonstrance.
韦夫勒先生承认自己错了，并恳求威廉·古比先生不要再想了。然而，威廉·古比先生虽然占据了优势，但在没有受到更多伤害的抗议的情况下，无法完全释放它。

‘No! Dash it, Tony,’ says that gentleman, ‘you really ought to be careful how you wound the feelings of a man who has an unrequited image imprinted on his ‘eart and who is NOT altogether happy in those chords which vibrate to the tenderest emotions. You, Tony, possess in yourself all that is calculated to charm the eye and allure the taste. It is not—happily for you, perhaps, and I may wish that I could say the same—it is not your character to hover around one flower. The ole garden is open to you, and your airy pinions carry you through it. Still, Tony, far be it from me, I am sure, to wound even your feelings without a cause!’
'不！去死吧，托尼，”这位绅士说道，“你真的应该小心，不要伤害一个男人的感情，他的心里已经烙印着单相思的形象，而且在那些振动着最温柔情感的和弦中并不完全快乐。 。托尼，你身上拥有一切吸引眼球和品味的东西。事实并非如此——也许对你来说很幸运，我可能希望我也能这么说——徘徊在一朵花周围不是你的性格。奥莱花园向您开放，您轻快的小齿轮将带您穿过它。不过，托尼，我确信我绝对不会无缘无故地伤害你的感情！

Tony again entreats that the subject may be no longer pursued, saying emphatically, ‘William Guppy, drop it!’ Mr. Guppy acquiesces, with the reply, ‘I never should have taken it up, Tony, of my own accord.’
托尼再次恳求不要再追究这个话题，他强调说：“威廉·古皮，放弃吧！”古皮先生默许了，并回答道：“托尼，我本来就不应该主动提起这个话题。”

‘And now,’ says Tony, stirring the fire, ‘touching this same bundle of letters. Isn’t it an extraordinary thing of Krook to have appointed twelve o’clock to-night to hand ‘em over to me?’
“现在，”托尼一边说，一边搅动火，“触摸同一堆信件。”克鲁克指定今晚十二点把它们交给我，这难道不是一件了不起的事吗？

‘Very. What did he do it for?’
'非常。他这样做是为了什么？

‘What does he do anything for? HE don’t know. Said to-day was his birthday and he’d hand ‘em over to-night at twelve o’clock. He’ll have drunk himself blind by that time. He has been at it all day.’
‘他做这些事是为了什么？他不知道。说今天是他的生日，他会在今晚十二点把它们交给我们。到时候他就已经喝醉了。他已经干了一整天了。

‘He hasn’t forgotten the appointment, I hope?’
“我希望他没有忘记约会吧？”

‘Forgotten? Trust him for that. He never forgets anything. I saw him to-night, about eight—helped him to shut up his shop—and he had got the letters then in his hairy cap. He pulled it off and showed ‘em me. When the shop was closed, he took them out of his cap, hung his cap on the chair-back, and stood turning them over before the fire. I heard him a little while afterwards, through the floor here, humming like the wind, the only song he knows— about Bibo, and old Charon, and Bibo being drunk when he died, or something or other. He has been as quiet since as an old rat asleep in his hole.’
'忘记了？相信他。他永远不会忘记任何事情。今晚八点左右我见到了他——帮助他关掉了他的店——当时他把信放在了他那顶毛茸茸的帽子里。他把它成功了并向我展示。商店关门后，他把帽子从帽子里拿出来，把帽子挂在椅背上，然后站在火边把它们翻过来。过了一会儿，我听到他穿过这里的地板，像风一样哼唱，这是他唯一知道的歌——关于比波和老卡戎，以及比波死时喝醉的歌，或者其他什么。从那以后他就一直安静得像一只在洞里睡觉的老老鼠。

‘And you are to go down at twelve?’
“你十二点钟就下去吗？”

‘At twelve. And as I tell you, when you came it seemed to me a hundred.’
‘十二点。正如我告诉你的，当你来的时候，我觉得已经一百了。

‘Tony,’ says Mr. Guppy after considering a little with his legs crossed, ‘he can’t read yet, can he?’
“托尼，”顾比先生盘着双腿想了想，说道，“他还不会读书，不是吗？”

‘Read! He’ll never read. He can make all the letters separately, and he knows most of them separately when he sees them; he has got on that much, under me; but he can’t put them together. He’s too old to acquire the knack of it now—and too drunk.’
'读！他永远不会读书。他能把所有的字母分开写出来，并且当他看到它们时，他能认出其中的大部分；在我的领导下，他已经取得了如此大的成就；但他无法将它们放在一起。他现在已经太老了，无法掌握这个技巧，而且也喝得太醉了。”

‘Tony,’ says Mr. Guppy, uncrossing and recrossing his legs, ‘how do you suppose he spelt out that name of Hawdon?’
“托尼，”古比先生说，双腿分开又交叉，“你猜他是怎么拼出霍顿这个名字的？”

‘He never spelt it out. You know what a curious power of eye he has and how he has been used to employ himself in copying things by eye alone. He imitated it, evidently from the direction of a letter, and asked me what it meant.’
‘他从来没有说清楚。你知道他的眼睛有多么奇妙的力量，也知道他如何习惯于仅凭眼睛来复制事物。他模仿了这句话，显然是按照一封信的方向模仿的，并问我这是什么意思。

‘Tony,’ says Mr. Guppy, uncrossing and recrossing his legs again, ‘should you say that the original was a man’s writing or a woman’s?’
“托尼，”古比先生说，双腿分开又重新交叉，“你应该说原作是男人的作品还是女人的作品？”

‘A woman’s. Fifty to one a lady’s—slopes a good deal, and the end of the letter ‘n,’ long and hasty.’
‘一个女人的。女士的五十比一——倾斜度很大，字母“n”的结尾又长又仓促。

Mr. Guppy has been biting his thumb-nail during this dialogue, generally changing the thumb when he has changed the cross leg. As he is going to do so again, he happens to look at his coat-sleeve. It takes his attention. He stares at it, aghast.
在这段对话中，孔雀鱼先生一直咬着拇指，通常在改变盘腿时也会改变拇指。当他准备再次这样做时，他碰巧看了一眼自己的衣袖。这需要他的注意力。他惊愕地盯着它。

‘Why, Tony, what on earth is going on in this house to-night? Is there a chimney on fire?’
“为什么，托尼，今晚这房子里到底发生了什么？烟囱着火了吗？

‘Chimney on fire!’
“烟囱着火了！”

‘Ah!’ returns Mr. Guppy. ‘See how the soot’s falling. See here, on my arm! See again, on the table here! Confound the stuff, it won’t blow off—smears like black fat!’
“啊！”古比先生回答道。 “看看烟灰是如何落下的。看这里，在我的手臂上！再看一遍，就在这儿的桌子上！把这些东西搞混了，它吹不掉——像黑色脂肪一样的污迹！”

They look at one another, and Tony goes listening to the door, and a little way upstairs, and a little way downstairs. Comes back and says it’s all right and all quiet, and quotes the remark he lately made to Mr. Snagsby about their cooking chops at the Sol’s Arms.
他们互相看着对方，托尼去听门声，上楼一点，下楼一点。回来后说一切都好，一切都很安静，并引用了他最近对斯纳斯比先生说的关于他们在索尔阿姆斯的烹饪排骨的言论。

‘And it was then,’ resumes Mr. Guppy, still glancing with remarkable aversion at the coat-sleeve, as they pursue their conversation before the fire, leaning on opposite sides of the table, with their heads very near together, ‘that he told you of his having taken the bundle of letters from his lodger’s portmanteau?’
“就在那时，”古皮先生继续说道，他仍然以一种明显厌恶的眼光扫视衣袖，他们在火炉前继续谈话，靠在桌子的两侧，头靠得很近，“他“告诉你他从房客的手提包里拿走了那捆信件吗？”

‘That was the time, sir,’ answers Tony, faintly adjusting his whiskers. ‘Whereupon I wrote a line to my dear boy, the Honourable William Guppy, informing him of the appointment for to-night and advising him not to call before, Boguey being a slyboots.’
“就是时候了，先生。”托尼回答道，微微整理了一下胡须。 “于是我给我亲爱的儿子威廉·古比阁下写了一封信，告诉他今晚的约会，并建议他之前不要打电话来，博吉是个狡猾的家伙。”

The light vivacious tone of fashionable life which is usually assumed by Mr. Weevle sits so ill upon him to-night that he abandons that and his whiskers together, and after looking over his shoulder, appears to yield himself up a prey to the horrors again.
韦弗勒先生通常所表现出的时尚生活的轻松活泼的基调今晚对他来说是如此不舒服，以至于他把胡须和胡须一起扔掉了，回头一看，似乎又让自己成为了恐怖的牺牲品。 。

‘You are to bring the letters to your room to read and compare, and to get yourself into a position to tell him all about them. That’s the arrangement, isn’t it, Tony?’ asks Mr. Guppy, anxiously biting his thumb-nail.
“你要把这些信带到你的房间里阅读和比较，并让自己能够告诉他所有的事情。 “就是这么安排的，不是吗，托尼？”古皮先生焦急地咬着拇指指甲问道。

‘You can’t speak too low. Yes. That’s what he and I agreed.’
‘你说话不能太低声。是的。这是他和我同意的。

‘I tell you what, Tony—‘
“我告诉你，托尼——”

‘You can’t speak too low,’ says Tony once more. Mr. Guppy nods his sagacious head, advances it yet closer, and drops into a whisper.
“你说话不能太低声。”托尼再次说道。孔雀鱼先生用他睿智的头点点头，将头靠得更近，然后低声说道。

‘I tell you what. The first thing to be done is to make another packet like the real one so that if he should ask to see the real one while it’s in my possession, you can show him the dummy.’
'让我告诉你。首先要做的就是再制作一个像真品一样的包，这样如果他要求看我手里的真品，你就可以给他看假品。

‘And suppose he detects the dummy as soon as he sees it, which with his biting screw of an eye is about five hundred times more likely than not,’ suggests Tony.
“假设他一看到假人就发现了它，用他那双尖利的眼睛，这种可能性大约是没有的五百倍，”托尼建议道。

‘Then we’ll face it out. They don’t belong to him, and they never did. You found that, and you placed them in my hands—a legal friend of yours—for security. If he forces us to it, they’ll be producible, won’t they?’
‘那么我们就去面对它吧。它们不属于他，也从来不属于他。你发现了这一点，为了安全起见，你把它们交给了我——你的合法朋友。如果他强迫我们这样做，它们就会被生产出来，不是吗？

‘Ye-es,’ is Mr. Weevle’s reluctant admission.
“是的，是的，”韦弗勒先生不情愿地承认。

‘Why, Tony,’ remonstrates his friend, ‘how you look! You don’t doubt William Guppy? You don’t suspect any harm?’
“为什么，托尼，”他的朋友抗议道，“你看起来怎么样！你不怀疑威廉·古比吗？你不怀疑有任何伤害吗？

‘I don’t suspect anything more than I know, William,’ returns the other gravely.
“威廉，我不会怀疑任何超出我所知的事情。”对方严肃地回答道。

‘And what do you know?’ urges Mr. Guppy, raising his voice a little; but on his friend’s once more warning him, ‘I tell you, you can’t speak too low,’ he repeats his question without any sound at all, forming with his lips only the words, ‘What do you know?’
“你知道什么？”古皮先生稍微提高了声音问道。但当他的朋友再次警告他“我告诉你，你不能说得太低”时，他毫无声音地重复了他的问题，只用嘴唇形成了这样的字：“你知道什么？”

‘I know three things. First, I know that here we are whispering in secrecy, a pair of conspirators.’
‘我知道三件事。首先，我知道我们在这里秘密窃窃私语，是一对同谋者。

‘Well!’ says Mr. Guppy. ‘And we had better be that than a pair of noodles, which we should be if we were doing anything else, for it’s the only way of doing what we want to do. Secondly?’
“好吧！”古比先生说。 “我们最好是这样，而不是一根面条，如果我们做其他任何事情，我们就应该这样做，因为这是做我们想做的事情的唯一方式。第二？'

‘Secondly, it’s not made out to me how it’s likely to be profitable, after all.’
“其次，我根本不知道它如何盈利。”

Mr. Guppy casts up his eyes at the portrait of Lady Dedlock over the mantelshelf and replies, ‘Tony, you are asked to leave that to the honour of your friend. Besides its being calculated to serve that friend in those chords of the human mind which—which need not be called into agonizing vibration on the present occasion—your friend is no fool. What’s that?’
古比先生抬头看着壁炉架上戴德洛克夫人的肖像，回答道：“托尼，请你把它留给你朋友的荣誉。”除了它的目的是为了在人类心灵的那些弦上服务那个朋友之外，你的朋友并不傻，而在目前的情况下，这不需要被召唤到痛苦的振动中。那是什么？'

‘It’s eleven o’clock striking by the bell of Saint Paul’s. Listen and you’ll hear all the bells in the city jangling.’
“圣保罗大教堂的钟声敲响了，已经十一点了。听着，你会听到城市里所有的钟声都在叮当作响。

Both sit silent, listening to the metal voices, near and distant, resounding from towers of various heights, in tones more various than their situations. When these at length cease, all seems more mysterious and quiet than before. One disagreeable result of whispering is that it seems to evoke an atmosphere of silence, haunted by the ghosts of sound—strange cracks and tickings, the rustling of garments that have no substance in them, and the tread of dreadful feet that would leave no mark on the sea-sand or the winter snow. So sensitive the two friends happen to be that the air is full of these phantoms, and the two look over their shoulders by one consent to see that the door is shut.
两人都静静地坐着，聆听金属的声音，或近或远，从不同高度的塔楼中回响，其音调比他们所处的情况更加不同。当这些最终停止时，一切似乎都比以前更加神秘和安静。窃窃私语的一个令人不快的结果是，它似乎会唤起一种寂静的气氛，被声音的幽灵所困扰——奇怪的裂纹和滴答声，毫无实质内容的衣服的沙沙声，以及不会留下任何痕迹的可怕脚步声。在海沙或冬雪上。这两个朋友非常敏感，空气中充满了这些幻影，两人不约而同地回头一看，发现门是关着的。

‘Yes, Tony?’ says Mr. Guppy, drawing nearer to the fire and biting his unsteady thumb-nail. ‘You were going to say, thirdly?’
“是吗，托尼？”古皮先生一边说，一边靠近火堆，咬着摇摇晃晃的拇指指甲。 “你想说的是，第三？”

‘It’s far from a pleasant thing to be plotting about a dead man in the room where he died, especially when you happen to live in it.’
“在一个死去的房间里策划一个死者的事件可不是一件令人愉快的事情，尤其是当你碰巧住在里面的时候。”

‘But we are plotting nothing against him, Tony.’
“但我们并没有图谋反对他，托尼。”

‘May be not, still I don’t like it. Live here by yourself and see how YOU like it.’
“也许不是，但我还是不喜欢它。你自己住在这里，看看你是否喜欢它。

‘As to dead men, Tony,’ proceeds Mr. Guppy, evading this proposal, ‘there have been dead men in most rooms.’
“至于死人，托尼，”古皮先生继续说道，回避了这个提议，“大多数房间里都有死人。”

‘I know there have, but in most rooms you let them alone, and—and they let you alone,’ Tony answers.
“我知道有，但在大多数房间里，你不会打扰他们，而且——他们也不会打扰你，”托尼回答道。

The two look at each other again. Mr. Guppy makes a hurried remark to the effect that they may be doing the deceased a service, that he hopes so. There is an oppressive blank until Mr. Weevle, by stirring the fire suddenly, makes Mr. Guppy start as if his heart had been stirred instead.
两人再次对视一眼。古比先生匆匆说了一句，大意是他们可能正在为死者提供服务，他希望如此。一阵压抑的空白，直到韦夫勒先生突然搅动了火，让孔雀鱼先生吃了一惊，仿佛他的心被搅动了。

‘Fah! Here’s more of this hateful soot hanging about,’ says he. ‘Let us open the window a bit and get a mouthful of air. It’s too close.’
‘呸！这里还有更多可恶的烟灰，”他说。 “让我们把窗户打开一点，呼吸一口空气。太近了。

He raises the sash, and they both rest on the window-sill, half in and half out of the room. The neighbouring houses are too near to admit of their seeing any sky without craning their necks and looking up, but lights in frowsy windows here and there, and the rolling of distant carriages, and the new expression that there is of the stir of men, they find to be comfortable. Mr. Guppy, noiselessly tapping on the window-sill, resumes his whisperirig in quite a light-comedy tone.
他拉起窗带，他们俩都靠在窗台上，一半在房间里，一半在房间外。邻近的房屋离得太近，如果不伸长脖子抬头仰望，他们就无法看到天空，但到处都是令人讨厌的窗户里的灯光，远处马车的滚动，以及人们骚动的新表情，他们觉得很舒服。孔雀先生无声地敲着窗台，以一种轻松喜剧的语气继续低语。

‘By the by, Tony, don’t forget old Smallweed,’ meaning the younger of that name. ‘I have not let him into this, you know. That grandfather of his is too keen by half. It runs in the family.’
“顺便说一句，托尼，别忘了老斯莫威德”，意思是这个名字中较年轻的一个。 “你知道，我没有让他参与其中。他那个爷爷太热心了一半。它在家庭中传承。

‘I remember,’ says Tony. ‘I am up to all that.’
“我记得，”托尼说。 “这一切我都能做到。”

‘And as to Krook,’ resumes Mr. Guppy. ‘Now, do you suppose he really has got hold of any other papers of importance, as he has boasted to you, since you have been such allies?’
“至于克鲁克，”古比先生继续说道。 “现在，既然你们一直是这样的盟友，你认为他真的像他向你吹嘘的那样，掌握了任何其他重要的文件吗？”

Tony shakes his head. ‘I don’t know. Can’t Imagine. If we get through this business without rousing his suspicions, I shall be better informed, no doubt. How can I know without seeing them, when he don’t know himself? He is always spelling out words from them, and chalking them over the table and the shop-wall, and asking what this is and what that is; but his whole stock from beginning to end may easily be the waste-paper he bought it as, for anything I can say. It’s a monomania with him to think he is possessed of documents. He has been going to learn to read them this last quarter of a century, I should judge, from what he tells me.’
托尼摇摇头。 '我不知道。无法想象。如果我们能顺利完成这件事而不引起他的怀疑，毫无疑问我会得到更好的消息。当他不认识他自己时，如果没有看到他们，我怎么能知道呢？他总是拼出其中的单词，然后用粉笔把它们写在桌子上和商店墙上，并询问这是什么、那是什么；但无论我怎么说，他的整个股票从头到尾很可能都是他买来的废纸。他认为自己拥有文件，这是一种偏执。从他告诉我的内容来看，我应该判断，在过去的四分之一个世纪里，他一直在学习阅读它们。

‘How did he first come by that idea, though? That’s the question,’ Mr. Guppy suggests with one eye shut, after a little forensic meditation. ‘He may have found papers in something he bought, where papers were not supposed to be, and may have got it into his shrewd head from the manner and place of their concealment that they are worth something.’
“那么他最初是怎么想到这个想法的呢？这就是问题所在。”经过一番法医沉思后，古比先生闭上一只眼睛说道。 “他可能在他买的东西中发现了纸张，而这些纸张本来不应该存在，并且他精明的头脑可能从它们隐藏的方式和地点中得知它们是有价值的。”

‘Or he may have been taken in, in some pretended bargain. Or he may have been muddled altogether by long staring at whatever he HAS got, and by drink, and by hanging about the Lord Chancellor’s Court and hearing of documents for ever,’ returns Mr. Weevle.
“或者他可能是在某种假装的讨价还价中被骗了。”或者，他可能已经完全糊涂了，因为长时间盯着他所拥有的一切，喝了酒，在大法官法庭上闲逛，永远听着文件，”韦夫勒先生回答道。

Mr. Guppy sitting on the window-sill, nodding his head and balancing all these possibilities in his mind, continues thoughtfully to tap it, and clasp it, and measure it with his hand, until he hastily draws his hand away.
孔雀先生坐在窗台上，点着头，在心里权衡着所有这些可能性，若有所思地继续敲着、握着、用手量着，直到匆忙把手抽开。

‘What, in the devil’s name,’ he says, ‘is this! Look at my fingers!’
“看在魔鬼的份上，”他说道，“这是什么！看看我的手指！

A thick, yellow liquor defiles them, which is offensive to the touch and sight and more offensive to the smell. A stagnant, sickening oil with some natural repulsion in it that makes them both shudder.
浓稠的黄色液体玷污了它们，触感和视觉都令人厌恶，气味更令人厌恶。一种停滞的、令人作呕的油，里面有一些自然的排斥力，让他们都颤抖起来。

‘What have you been doing here? What have you been pouring out of window?’
‘你来这里做什么？你从窗户里倒了什么？

‘I pouring out of window! Nothing, I swear! Never, since I have been here!’ cries the lodger.
‘我从窗户倾泻而出！没什么，我发誓！ “从来没有，自从我来过这里之后！”房客喊道。

And yet look here—and look here! When he brings the candle here, from the corner of the window-sill, it slowly drips and creeps away down the bricks, here lies in a little thick nauseous pool.
但看看这里——看看这里！当他把蜡烛从窗台的一角搬到这里时，它慢慢地滴下来，顺着砖块爬走，这里躺在一个又厚又恶心的水池里。

‘This is a horrible house,’ says Mr. Guppy, shutting down the window. ‘Give me some water or I shall cut my hand off.’
“这是一座可怕的房子，”古皮先生关上窗户说道。 “给我点水，不然我就砍掉我的手。”

He so washes, and rubs, and scrubs, and smells, and washes, that he has not long restored himself with a glass of brandy and stood silently before the fire when Saint Paul’s bell strikes twelve and all those other bells strike twelve from their towers of various heights in the dark air, and in their many tones. When all is quiet again, the lodger says, ‘It’s the appointed time at last. Shall I go?’
他如此洗、擦、擦、闻、洗，以至于当圣保罗的钟声敲响十二点，而所有其他钟声从塔楼上敲响十二点时，他很快就喝了一杯白兰地恢复了精神，静静地站在火前。在黑暗的空气中，它们的高度各异，音调各异。当一切再次安静下来时，房客说：“终于到了约定的时间了。”我可以去吗？

Mr. Guppy nods and gives him a ‘lucky touch’ on the back, but not with the washed hand, though it is his right hand.
孔雀鱼先生点点头，并在他的背上“幸运地碰了一下”，但不是用洗过的手，尽管那是他的右手。

He goes downstairs, and Mr. Guppy tries to compose himself before the fire for waiting a long time. But in no more than a minute or two the stairs creak and Tony comes swiftly back.
他下了楼，孔雀先生在炉火前等待了很长时间，试图让自己平静下来。但不到一两分钟，楼梯就吱吱作响，托尼迅速回来了。

‘Have you got them?’
“你拿到了吗？”

‘Got them! No. The old man’s not there.’
'抓到他们了！不，老人不在。”

He has been so horribly frightened in the short interval that his terror seizes the other, who makes a rush at him and asks loudly, ‘What’s the matter?’
在这短暂的时间里，他已经被吓得够呛，以至于他的恐惧抓住了另一个人，后者冲向他，大声问道：“怎么了？”

‘I couldn’t make him hear, and I softly opened the door and looked in. And the burning smell is there—and the soot is there, and the oil is there—and he is not there!’ Tony ends this with a groan.
“我无法让他听到，我轻轻地打开门往里看。那里有烧焦的气味——烟灰在那里，油在那里——而他却不在那儿！”托尼用一句结束语结束了这一切。呻吟。

Mr. Guppy takes the light. They go down, more dead than alive, and holding one another, push open the door of the back shop. The cat has retreated close to it and stands snarling, not at them, at something on the ground before the fire. There is a very little fire left in the grate, but there is a smouldering, suffocating vapour in the room and a dark, greasy coating on the walls and ceiling. The chairs and table, and the bottle so rarely absent from the table, all stand as usual. On one chair-back hang the old man’s hairy cap and coat.
孔雀鱼先生接过灯。他们下去了，死了也不活了，互相拥抱着，推开了后店的门。那只猫退到离它很近的地方，站在火边，不是对着他们，而是对着地上的某个东西咆哮。炉排里只剩下很少的火了，但房间里有闷烧的、令人窒息的蒸汽，墙壁和天花板上有一层深色的油腻的涂层。椅子和桌子，以及桌子上很少缺席的瓶子，都像往常一样站立着。一张椅背上挂着老人毛茸茸的帽子和外套。

‘Look!’ whispers the lodger, pointing his friend’s attention to these objects with a trembling finger. ‘I told you so. When I saw him last, he took his cap off, took out the little bundle of old letters, hung his cap on the back of the chair—his coat was there already, for he had pulled that off before he went to put the shutters up—and I left him turning the letters over in his hand, standing just where that crumbled black thing is upon the floor.’
“看！”房客低声说道，用颤抖的手指将他朋友的注意力引向这些物品。 '我已经告诉过你了。当我最后一次见到他时，他脱下了帽子，拿出那一小捆旧信件，把帽子挂在椅背上——他的外套已经在那里了，因为他在去关百叶窗之前就把它脱下来了。起来——我让他把信翻过来，站在地板上那个黑色碎块所在的地方。

Is he hanging somewhere? They look up. No.
他挂在什么地方吗？他们抬起头来。不。

‘See!’ whispers Tony. ‘At the foot of the same chair there lies a dirty bit of thin red cord that they tie up pens with. That went round the letters. He undid it slowly, leering and laughing at me, before he began to turn them over, and threw it there. I saw it fall.’
“看！”托尼低声说道。 “在同一张椅子的脚下，有一条肮脏的细红绳，他们用它来绑钢笔。这围绕着字母。他慢慢地解开了它，对我斜视着，笑着，然后他开始把它们翻过来，扔在那里。我看到它掉下来了。

‘What’s the matter with the cat?’ says Mr. Guppy. ‘Look at her!’
“那只猫怎么了？”孔雀先生说。 '看着她！'

‘Mad, I think. And no wonder in this evil place.’
“我想，是疯了。”难怪在这个邪恶的地方。

They advance slowly, looking at all these things. The cat remains where they found her, still snarling at the something on the ground before the fire and between the two chairs. What is it? Hold up the light.
他们缓慢地前进，看着这一切。那只猫仍然留在他们发现她的地方，仍然对着火前和两把椅子之间的地上的东西咆哮。它是什么？举起灯。

Here is a small burnt patch of flooring; here is the tinder from a little bundle of burnt paper, but not so light as usual, seeming to be steeped in something; and here is—is it the cinder of a small charred and broken log of wood sprinkled with white ashes, or is it coal? Oh, horror, he IS here! And this from which we run away, striking out the light and overturning one another into the street, is all that represents him.
这是一小块烧焦的地板；这是一小捆烧焦的纸制成的火绒，但不像平时那么轻，似乎浸透了某种东西；这是——这是一根烧焦的碎木头的灰烬，上面撒满了白色的灰烬，还是煤？哦，恐怖，他在这里！而我们逃离、熄灭灯光、互相推倒在街上的这一点，就是代表他的一切。

Help, help, help! Come into this house for heaven’s sake! Plenty will come in, but none can help. The Lord Chancellor of that court, true to his title in his last act, has died the death of all lord chancellors in all courts and of all authorities in all places under all names soever, where false pretences are made, and where injustice is done. Call the death by any name your Highness will, attribute it to whom you will, or say it might have been prevented how you will, it is the same death eternally—inborn, inbred, engendered in the corrupted humours of the vicious body itself, and that only—spontaneous combustion, and none other of all the deaths that can be died.
救命，救命，救命！看在上帝的份上，进入这所房子吧！很多人会进来，但没有人能提供帮助。该法院的大法官，在他最后的行动中忠实于他的头衔，已经与所有法院的所有大法官以及所有地方的所有当局一样死亡，无论在哪里，无论在哪里，在任何地方，都有虚假借口，也有不公正的行为。 。殿下可以用任何名字来称呼这种死亡，无论你想把它归属于谁，或者说它本可以按照你的意愿被阻止，这都是永恒的死亡——天生的，近亲繁殖的，在邪恶身体本身腐败的体液中产生的，唯一的死亡就是自燃，除此之外没有其他死亡方式。

CHAPTER XXXIII
第三十三章


Interlopers
闯入者

Now do those two gentlemen not very neat about the cuffs and buttons who attended the last coroner’s inquest at the Sol’s Arms reappear in the precincts with surprising swiftness (being, in fact, breathlessly fetched by the active and intelligent beadle), and institute perquisitions through the court, and dive into the Sol’s parlour, and write with ravenous little pens on tissue-paper. Now do they note down, in the watches of the night, how the neighbourhood of Chancery Lane was yesterday, at about midnight, thrown into a state of the most intense agitation and excitement by the following alarming and horrible discovery. Now do they set forth how it will doubtless be remembered that some time back a painful sensation was created in the public mind by a case of mysterious death from opium occurring in the first floor of the house occupied as a rag, bottle, and general marine store shop, by an eccentric individual of intemperate habits, far advanced in life, named Krook; and how, by a remarkable coincidence, Krook was examined at the inquest, which it may be recollected was held on that occasion at the Sol’s Arms, a well-conducted tavern immediately adjoining the premises in question on the west side and licensed to a highly respectable landlord, Mr. James George Bogsby. Now do they show (in as many words as possible) how during some hours of yesterday evening a very peculiar smell was observed by the inhabitants of the court, in which the tragical occurrence which forms the subject of that present account transpired; and which odour was at one time so powerful that Mr. Swills, a comic vocalist professionally engaged by Mr. J. G. Bogsby, has himself stated to our reporter that he mentioned to Miss M. Melvilleson, a lady of some pretensions to musical ability, likewise engaged by Mr. J. G. Bogsby to sing at a series of concerts called Harmonic Assemblies, or Meetings, which it would appear are held at the Sol’s Arms under Mr. Bogsby’s direction pursuant to the Act of George the Second, that he (Mr. Swills) found his voice seriously affected by the impure state of the atmosphere, his jocose expression at the time being that he was like an empty post-office, for he hadn’t a single note in him. How this account of Mr. Swills is entirely corroborated by two intelligent married females residing in the same court and known respectively by the names of Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins, both of whom observed the foetid effluvia and regarded them as being emitted from the premises in the occupation of Krook, the unfortunate deceased. All this and a great deal more the two gentlemen who have formed an amicable partnership in the melancholy catastrophe write down on the spot; and the boy population of the court (out of bed in a moment) swarm up the shutters of the Sol’s Arms parlour, to behold the tops of their heads while they are about it.
现在，参加索尔之臂最后一次验尸官审讯的那两位袖口和纽扣不太整洁的先生，以惊人的速度重新出现在辖区（事实上，被活跃而聪明的执事气喘吁吁地带走了），并通过走进法庭，潜入索尔的客厅，用贪婪的小笔在薄纸上写字。现在，他们在夜深人静时记下了昨天午夜时分，大法官巷一带是如何因以下令人震惊和可怕的发现而陷入最强烈的躁动和兴奋状态的。现在，他们是否阐述了人们将如何毫无疑问地记住，不久前，在一间被抹布、瓶子和海军陆战队占领的房子的一楼发生一起因鸦片神秘死亡的案件，在公众心目中引起了痛苦的感觉店里的店主是一个性格古怪、生活不节制、生活十分先进的人，名叫克鲁克。巧合的是，克鲁克是如何在审讯中接受审问的，人们可能记得审讯是在索尔阿姆斯酒店举行的，这是一家管理良好的酒馆，紧邻相关房屋的西侧，并获得了高级官员的许可。尊敬的房东，詹姆斯·乔治·博格斯比先生。现在，他们（用尽可能多的文字）表明，在昨天晚上的几个小时内，法庭上的居民如何观察到一种非常奇怪的气味，而正是在这种气味中发生了构成当前叙述主题的悲剧事件；这种气味一度如此强烈，以至于 J·G·博格斯比先生专业聘用的一位喜剧歌手斯威尔斯先生亲自向我们的记者表示，他曾向 M 小姐提到过。 梅尔维尔森（Melvilleson）是一位自命不凡的音乐才能女士，她同样受 J. G. Bogsby 先生的邀请，在一系列名为 Harmonic Assemblies 或 Meetings 的音乐会上演唱，这些音乐会似乎是在博格斯比先生的指导下在 Sol's Arms 举行的。乔治二世的行为，他（斯威尔斯先生）发现自己的声音受到了不纯净的气氛的严重影响，他当时的戏谑表情是他就像一个空荡荡的邮局，因为他没有一个请注意他。斯威尔斯先生的这种说法完全得到了居住在同一宫廷中的两位聪明的已婚女性的完全证实，她们的名字分别是派珀夫人和珀金斯夫人，她们都观察到了恶臭，并认为它们是从房间里散发出来的。不幸死者克鲁克被占领的房屋。所有这一切以及更多的事情，两位在这场悲伤的灾难中结成友好伙伴关系的先生当场写下了；法庭上的男孩们（一会儿就起床了）涌上索尔之臂客厅的百叶窗，在他们周围的时候看看他们的头顶。

The whole court, adult as well as boy, is sleepless for that night, and can do nothing but wrap up its many heads, and talk of the illfated house, and look at it. Miss Flite has been bravely rescued from her chamber, as if it were in flames, and accommodated with a bed at the Sol’s Arms. The Sol neither turns off its gas nor shuts its door all night, for any kind of public excitement makes good for the Sol and causes the court to stand in need of comfort. The house has not done so much in the stomachic article of cloves or in brandy-and-water warm since the inquest. The moment the pot-boy heard what had happened, he rolled up his shirt-sleeves tight to his shoulders and said, ‘There’ll be a run upon us!’ In the first outcry, young Piper dashed off for the fire-engines and returned in triumph at a jolting gallop perched up aloft on the Phoenix and holding on to that fabulous creature with all his might in the midst of helmets and torches. One helmet remains behind after careful investigation of all chinks and crannies and slowly paces up and down before the house in company with one of the two policemen who have likewise been left in charge thereof. To this trio everybody in the court possessed of sixpence has an insatiate desire to exhibit hospitality in a liquid form.
那天晚上，整个宫廷里的人，无论是大人还是小孩，都彻夜难眠，除了把脑袋包起来，谈论那座倒霉的房子，看看它之外，什么也做不了。弗利特小姐被勇敢地从她的房间里救了出来，就好像房间着火一样，并在索尔之臂酒店安置了一张床。索尔既不会关掉煤气，也不会整夜关门，因为任何形式的公众兴奋都会对索尔有利，并导致法庭需要安慰。自调查以来，这所房子还没有在丁香和白兰地加水的温水里做过那么多的事。伙计男孩听到发生的事情后，立即把衬衫袖子卷到肩膀上，说道：“有人跑过来追我们了！”在第一声叫喊中，年轻的派珀冲向消防车。他在凤凰号上高高地飞奔，凯旋而归，在头盔和火把中用尽全力抓住了这个神话般的生物。在仔细检查所有缝隙和缝隙后，留下了一顶头盔，并在两名同样负责此事的警察之一的陪伴下，在房子前缓慢地来回踱步。对于这三人来说，法庭上每个拥有六便士的人都渴望以流动的形式表现出热情好客。

Mr. Weevle and his friend Mr. Guppy are within the bar at the Sol and are worth anything to the Sol that the bar contains if they will only stay there. ‘This is not a time, says Mr. Bogsby, ‘to haggle about money,’ though he looks something sharply after it, over the counter; ‘give your orders, you two gentlemen, and you’re welcome to whatever you put a name to.’
Weevle 先生和他的朋友 Guppy 先生就在 Sol 的酒吧内，只要他们愿意呆在那里，他们对酒吧里的 Sol 来说都是有价值的。博格斯比先生说，“现在不是‘讨价还价’的时候”，尽管他在柜台后面敏锐地寻找着一些东西； “两位先生，下达命令，无论您指定什么名字，我们都欢迎您。”

Thus entreated, the two gentlemen (Mr. Weevle especially) put names to so many things that in course of time they find it difficult to put a name to anything quite distinctly, though they still relate to all new-comers some version of the night they have had of it, and of what they said, and what they thought, and what they saw. Meanwhile, one or other of the policemen often flits about the door, and pushing it open a little way at the full length of his arm, looks in from outer gloom. Not that he has any suspicions, but that he may as well know what they are up to in there.
经过如此恳求，两位先生（尤其是韦夫勒先生）给很多东西起了名字，随着时间的推移，他们发现很难给任何东西明确地命名，尽管他们仍然与所有新来者有关夜晚的某些版本他们已经经历过这一切，经历过他们所说的、他们所想的、以及他们所看到的。与此同时，一名或另一名警察经常在门上走来走去，用他的手臂将门推开一点，从外面的阴暗中向里看。并不是说他有任何怀疑，而是他或许知道他们在那里做什么。

Thus night pursues its leaden course, finding the court still out of bed through the unwonted hours, still treating and being treated, still conducting itself similarly to a court that has had a little money left it unexpectedly. Thus night at length with slow-retreating steps departs, and the lamp-lighter going his rounds, like an executioner to a despotic king, strikes off the little heads of fire that have aspired to lessen the darkness. Thus the day cometh, whether or no.
就这样，夜晚继续其沉闷的过程，发现法庭在不寻常的时间里仍然没有起床，仍然在治疗和接受治疗，仍然像一个意外地留下了一点钱的法庭一样行事。就这样，夜色慢慢地退去，点灯人四处走动，就像刽子手面对专制的国王，击落那些渴望减轻黑暗的小火头。因此，无论是否，这一天都会到来。

And the day may discern, even with its dim London eye, that the court has been up all night. Over and above the faces that have fallen drowsily on tables and the heels that lie prone on hard floors instead of beds, the brick and mortar physiognomy of the very court itself looks worn and jaded. And now the neighbourhood, waking up and beginning to hear of what has happened, comes streaming in, half dressed, to ask questions; and the two policemen and the helmet (who are far less impressible externally than the court) have enough to do to keep the door.
即使伦敦的眼睛昏暗，白天也能看出法庭已经彻夜未眠。除了昏昏欲睡地倒在桌子上的脸和趴在硬地板上而不是床上的脚后跟之外，法庭本身的砖瓦面貌看起来破旧而疲惫。现在，邻居们都醒了，开始听说发生了什么事，纷纷涌来，衣着不整，询问问题。两名警察和头盔（他们在外表上远不如法庭那么令人印象深刻）足以守住门。

‘Good gracious, gentlemen!’ says Mr. Snagsby, coming up. ‘What’s this I hear!’
“天哪，先生们！”斯纳斯比先生走过来说道。 “我听到这是什么！”

‘Why, it’s true,’ returns one of the policemen. ‘That’s what it is. Now move on here, come!’
“哦，这是真的，”一名警察回答道。 ‘就是这样。现在继续前进，来吧！

‘Why, good gracious, gentlemen,’ says Mr. Snagsby, somewhat promptly backed away, ‘I was at this door last night betwixt ten and eleven o’clock in conversation with the young man who lodges here.’
“哎呀，天哪，先生们，”斯纳斯比先生说着，立刻后退了一步，“昨晚十点到十一点之间，我在这扇门前与住在这里的年轻人谈话。”

‘Indeed?’ returns the policeman. ‘You will find the young man next door then. Now move on here, some of you,’
“真的吗？”警察回答道。 ‘那么你就会找到隔壁的那个年轻人。现在继续前进，你们中的一些人，”

‘Not hurt, I hope?’ says Mr. Snagsby.
“我希望没有受伤吧？”斯纳斯比先生说。

‘Hurt? No. What’s to hurt him!’
'伤害？不，有什么可以伤害他！

Mr. Snagsby, wholly unable to answer this or any question in his troubled mind, repairs to the Sol’s Arms and finds Mr. Weevle languishing over tea and toast with a considerable expression on him of exhausted excitement and exhausted tobacco-smoke.
斯纳格斯比先生完全无法回答这个问题，也无法在他混乱的头脑中回答任何问题，他回到索尔的手臂，发现韦夫勒先生正在喝着茶和烤面包，神情疲惫不堪，脸上带着疲惫的兴奋和疲惫的烟草烟雾。

‘And Mr. Guppy likewise!’ quoth Mr. Snagsby. ‘Dear, dear, dear! What a fate there seems in all this! And my lit—‘
“古比先生也是如此！”斯纳斯比先生说道。 ‘亲爱的，亲爱的，亲爱的！这一切似乎都是一种命运啊！还有我的灯——”

Mr. Snagsby’s power of speech deserts him in the formation of the words ‘my little woman.’ For to see that injured female walk into the Sol’s Arms at that hour of the morning and stand before the beer-engine, with her eyes fixed upon him like an accusing spirit, strikes him dumb.
斯纳斯比先生的语言能力在形成“我的小女人”这个词时就被抛弃了。因为看到那个受伤的女人在早上的那个时候走进索尔的怀抱，站在啤酒引擎前，眼睛盯着他就像一个控诉的精灵，让他哑口无言。

‘My dear,’ says Mr. Snagsby when his tongue is loosened, ‘will you take anything? A little—not to put too fine a point upon it—drop of shrub?’
“亲爱的，”斯纳斯比先生松开舌头说道，“你想要什么吗？一点点——不是说太细——一滴灌木？

‘No,’ says Mrs. Snagsby.
“不，”斯纳斯比夫人说。

‘My love, you know these two gentlemen?’
“亲爱的，你认识这两位先生吗？”

‘Yes!’ says Mrs. Snagsby, and in a rigid manner acknowledges their presence, still fixing Mr. Snagsby with her eye.
“是的！”斯纳斯比夫人说，并以一种僵硬的方式承认他们的存在，眼睛仍然盯着斯纳斯比先生。

The devoted Mr. Snagsby cannot bear this treatment. He takes Mrs. Snagsby by the hand and leads her aside to an adjacent cask.
忠诚的斯纳斯比先生无法忍受这种待遇。他拉着斯纳斯比夫人的手，把她带到旁边的一个木桶前。

‘My little woman, why do you look at me in that way? Pray don’t do it.’
“我的小女人，你为什么用这样的眼神看着我？祈祷不要这样做。

‘I can’t help my looks,’ says Mrs. Snagsby, ‘and if I could I wouldn’t.’
“我无法控制自己的外表，”斯纳斯比夫人说，“如果可以的话，我不会这么做。”

Mr. Snagsby, with his cough of meekness, rejoins, ‘Wouldn’t you really, my dear?’ and meditates. Then coughs his cough of trouble and says, ‘This is a dreadful mystery, my love!’ still fearfully disconcerted by Mrs. Snagsby’s eye.
斯纳斯比先生温顺地咳嗽了一声，问道：“亲爱的，你真的不愿意吗？”然后沉思起来。然后他咳嗽了一声，说道：“这是一个可怕的谜团，我的爱人！”仍然被斯纳斯比夫人的眼神吓得不知所措。

‘It IS,’ returns Mrs. Snagsby, shaking her head, ‘a dreadful mystery.’
“这确实是一个可怕的谜，”斯纳斯比夫人摇着头回答道。

‘My little woman,’ urges Mr. Snagsby in a piteous manner, ‘don’t for goodness’ sake speak to me with that bitter expression and look at me in that searching way! I beg and entreat of you not to do it. Good Lord, you don’t suppose that I would go spontaneously combusting any person, my dear?’
“我的小女人，”斯纳斯比先生可怜兮兮地劝道，“老天爷，别用那种苦涩的表情跟我说话，用那种探究的眼神看着我！”我恳求并恳求你不要这样做。天哪，你不认为我会自燃吗，亲爱的？

‘I can’t say,’ returns Mrs. Snagsby.
“我不能说，”斯纳斯比夫人回答道。

On a hasty review of his unfortunate position, Mr. Snagsby ‘can’t say’ either. He is not prepared positively to deny that he may have had something to do with it. He has had something—he don’t know what—to do with so much in this connexion that is mysterious that it is possible he may even be implicated, without knowing it, in the present transaction. He faintly wipes his forehead with his handkerchief and gasps.
斯纳斯比先生仓促地回顾了自己不幸的处境，他也“不能说”。他并不准备积极否认他可能与这件事有关。他在这方面做了很多事情——他不知道是什么——很神秘，以至于他甚至可能在不知情的情况下卷入了目前的交易。他用手帕轻轻地擦了擦额头，喘息着。

‘My life,’ says the unhappy stationer, ‘would you have any objections to mention why, being in general so delicately circumspect in your conduct, you come into a wine-vaults before breakfast?’
“我的生活，”那位不高兴的文具店员说道，“你会反对说一下为什么你的行为通常如此谨慎谨慎，早餐前进入了一个酒窖吗？”

‘Why do YOU come here?’ inquires Mrs. Snagsby.
“你为什么来这里？”斯纳斯比夫人问道。

‘My dear, merely to know the rights of the fatal accident which has happened to the venerable party who has been—combusted.’ Mr. Snagsby has made a pause to suppress a groan. ‘I should then have related them to you, my love, over your French roll.’
“亲爱的，只是想知道发生在受人尊敬的一方——被烧毁的致命事故上的权利。”斯纳格斯比先生停顿了一下，压制住一声呻吟。 “我应该把它们告诉你，我的爱人，而不是你的法式卷。”

‘I dare say you would! You relate everything to me, Mr. Snagsby.’
‘我敢说你会的！你把一切都和我联系起来了，斯纳斯比先生。

‘Every—my lit—‘
“每一个——我的点燃——”

‘I should be glad,’ says Mrs. Snagsby after contemplating his increased confusion with a severe and sinister smile, ‘if you would come home with me; I think you may be safer there, Mr. Snagsby, than anywhere else.’
“我会很高兴，”斯纳斯比太太在考虑了他日益混乱的情况后说道，脸上带着严肃而阴险的微笑，“如果你能和我一起回家；我会很高兴的。”我认为斯纳格斯比先生，你在那里可能比其他地方更安全。

‘My love, I don’t know but what I may be, I am sure. I am ready to go.’
“我的爱人，我不知道，但我确信我可能是什么。我准备走了。'

Mr. Snagsby casts his eye forlornly round the bar, gives Messrs. Weevle and Guppy good morning, assures them of the satisfaction with which he sees them uninjured, and accompanies Mrs. Snagsby from the Sol’s Arms. Before night his doubt whether he may not be responsible for some inconceivable part in the catastrophe which is the talk of the whole neighbourhood is almost resolved into certainty by Mrs. Snagsby’s pertinacity in that fixed gaze. His mental sufferings are so great that he entertains wandering ideas of delivering himself up to justice and requiring to be cleared if innocent and punished with the utmost rigour of the law if guilty.
斯纳斯比先生悲凉地环顾吧台，向韦弗勒先生和孔雀鱼先生道早安，并向他们保证看到他们没有受伤他感到很满意，然后从索尔之臂陪伴斯纳斯比夫人。到了晚上，他怀疑自己是否对这场全街坊都议论的这场灾难负有某种不可想象的责任，而斯纳斯比夫人那坚定的目光几乎让他确信无疑。他的精神痛苦如此之大，以至于他产生了一些飘忽不定的想法，要把自己送上法庭，如果无罪，就要求无罪释放；如果有罪，就要求受到最严厉的法律惩罚。

Mr. Weevle and Mr. Guppy, having taken their breakfast, step into Lincoln’s Inn to take a little walk about the square and clear as many of the dark cobwebs out of their brains as a little walk may.
威弗尔先生和孔雀鱼先生吃完早餐后，走进林肯旅馆，在广场上散步，尽可能地清除大脑中的黑色蜘蛛网。

‘There can be no more favourable time than the present, Tony,’ says Mr. Guppy after they have broodingly made out the four sides of the square, ‘for a word or two between us upon a point on which we must, with very little delay, come to an understanding.’
“没有比现在更有利的时机了，托尼，”在他们沉思地辨认出正方形的四个边后，古皮先生说道，“我们之间就一个问题说一两句话，我们必须非常认真地讨论这一点。”稍事拖延，达成谅解。

‘Now, I tell you what, William G.!’ returns the other, eyeing his companion with a bloodshot eye. ‘If it’s a point of conspiracy, you needn’t take the trouble to mention it. I have had enough of that, and I ain’t going to have any more. We shall have YOU taking fire next or blowing up with a bang.’
“现在，我告诉你，威廉·G！”另一个人回答道，用布满血丝的眼睛看着他的同伴。 “如果这是一个阴谋，你就不必费心提及。我已经受够了，我不会再受了。接下来我们会让你着火或者爆炸。

This supposititious phenomenon is so very disagreeable to Mr. Guppy that his voice quakes as he says in a moral way, ‘Tony, I should have thought that what we went through last night would have been a lesson to you never to be personal any more as long as you lived.’ To which Mr. Weevle returns, ‘William, I should have thought it would have been a lesson to YOU never to conspire any more as long as you lived.’ To which Mr. Guppy says, ‘Who’s conspiring?’ To which Mr. Jobling replies, ‘Why, YOU are!’ To which Mr. Guppy retorts, ‘No, I am not.’ To which Mr. Jobling retorts again, ‘Yes, you are!’ To which Mr. Guppy retorts, ‘Who says so?’ To which Mr. Jobling retorts, ‘I say so!’ To which Mr. Guppy retorts, ‘Oh, indeed?’ To which Mr. Jobling retorts, ‘Yes, indeed!’ And both being now in a heated state, they walk on silently for a while to cool down again.
这种虚构的现象让古比先生感到非常不舒服，他的声音颤抖着，以一种道德的方式说道：“托尼，我应该想到我们昨晚所经历的事情会给你一个教训，让你永远不要再把个人问题当回事了。”韦夫勒先生回答说：“威廉，我本以为这对你来说是一个教训，只要你还活着，就不要再密谋了。”对此，古皮先生说：“谁是对此，乔布林先生回答道：“为什么，你是！”对此，古皮先生反驳道：“不，我不是。”对此，乔布林先生再次反驳道：“是的，你是！”孔雀鱼反驳道，“谁这么说的？”乔布林先生反驳道，“我这么说！”孔雀鱼先生反驳道，“哦，确实如此？”乔布林先生反驳道，“是的，确实如此！”两人现在都处于热气腾腾的状态，默默地走了一会儿，才又冷静下来。

‘Tony,’ says Mr. Guppy then, ‘if you heard your friend out instead of flying at him, you wouldn’t fall into mistakes. But your temper is hasty and you are not considerate. Possessing in yourself, Tony, all that is calculated to charm the eye—‘
“托尼，”古比先生接着说，“如果你听你的朋友说完而不是冲向他，你就不会犯错误。但你脾气急躁，不善解人意。托尼，你身上所拥有的一切都是为了吸引眼球——”

‘Oh! Blow the eye!’ cries Mr. Weevle, cutting him short. ‘Say what you have got to say!’
'哦！打断他的眼睛！”威弗勒先生喊道，打断了他的话。 “说你要说的话！”

Finding his friend in this morose and material condition, Mr. Guppy only expresses the finer feelings of his soul through the tone of injury in which he recommences, ‘Tony, when I say there is a point on which we must come to an understanding pretty soon, I say so quite apart from any kind of conspiring, however innocent. You know it is professionally arranged beforehand in all cases that are tried what facts the witnesses are to prove. Is it or is it not desirable that we should know what facts we are to prove on the inquiry into the death of this unfortunate old mo—gentleman?’ (Mr. Guppy was going to say ‘mogul,’ but thinks ‘gentleman’ better suited to the circumstances.)
古比先生发现他的朋友处于这种忧郁和物质的状态，他只是通过受伤的语气表达了他灵魂的美好感受，他重新开始说：“托尼，当我说有一点我们必须很好地理解时”很快，我这样说，完全没有任何阴谋，无论多么无辜。你知道，在所有审理的案件中，证人要证明什么事实都是事先经过专业安排的。我们是否应该知道在调查这位不幸的老莫——绅士的死亡时我们要证明什么事实？适合具体情况。）

‘What facts? THE facts.’
‘什么事实？事实。'

‘The facts bearing on that inquiry. Those are’—Mr. Guppy tells them off on his fingers—‘what we knew of his habits, when you saw him last, what his condition was then, the discovery that we made, and how we made it.’
“与该调查有关的事实。那些是’——先生。孔比用手指告诉他们——“我们对他的习惯了解多少，你最后一次见到他是什么时候，他当时的状况如何，我们的发现，以及我们是如何发现的。”

‘Yes,’ says Mr. Weevle. ‘Those are about the facts.’
“是的，”韦夫勒先生说。 “这些都是事实。”

‘We made the discovery in consequence of his having, in his eccentric way, an appointment with you at twelve o’clock at night, when you were to explain some writing to him as you had often done before on account of his not being able to read. I, spending the evening with you, was called down—and so forth. The inquiry being only into the circumstances touching the death of the deceased, it’s not necessary to go beyond these facts, I suppose you’ll agree?’
“我们之所以有这个发现，是因为他以他古怪的方式在晚上十二点与你预约，当时你要向他解释一些写作，就像你以前经常做的那样，因为他不能读书。我和你一起度过了一个晚上，被叫下来——等等。调查只是涉及死者死亡的情况，没有必要超越这些事实，我想你会同意吗？

‘No!’ returns Mr. Weevle. ‘I suppose not.’
“不！”威弗尔先生回答道。 “我想不会。”

‘And this is not a conspiracy, perhaps?’ says the injured Guppy.
“这也许不是阴谋？”受伤的孔雀鱼说道。

‘No,’ returns his friend; ‘if it’s nothing worse than this, I withdraw the observation.’
“不，”他的朋友回答道。 “如果没有比这更糟糕的事情，我会撤回观察。”

‘Now, Tony,’ says Mr. Guppy, taking his arm again and walking him slowly on, ‘I should like to know, in a friendly way, whether you have yet thought over the many advantages of your continuing to live at that place?’
“现在，托尼，”古比先生再次挽起他的手臂，慢慢地走着，“我想以友好的方式知道，你是否考虑过继续住在那个地方的诸多好处。” ？

‘What do you mean?’ says Tony, stopping.
“你什么意思？”托尼停下来问道。

‘Whether you have yet thought over the many advantages of your continuing to live at that place?’ repeats Mr. Guppy, walking him on again.
“你有没有想过继续住在那个地方有很多好处？”古皮先生重复道，又带着他继续前行。

‘At what place? THAT place?’ pointing in the direction of the rag and bottle shop.
‘在什么地方？那个地方？”指着破布和瓶子店的方向。

Mr. Guppy nods.
古比先生点点头。

‘Why, I wouldn’t pass another night there for any consideration that you could offer me,’ says Mr. Weevle, haggardly staring.
“哎呀，如果你能为我提供任何考虑，我就不会再在那里过夜了，”威弗勒先生说道，目光憔悴地盯着。

‘Do you mean it though, Tony?’
“你是认真的吗，托尼？”

‘Mean it! Do I look as if I mean it? I feel as if I do; I know that,’ says Mr. Weevle with a very genuine shudder.
‘说真的！我看起来是认真的吗？我感觉好像我是这样做的；我知道这一点，”威夫勒先生说，他的内心非常颤抖。

‘Then the possibility or probability—for such it must be considered—of your never being disturbed in possession of those effects lately belonging to a lone old man who seemed to have no relation in the world, and the certainty of your being able to find out what he really had got stored up there, don’t weigh with you at all against last night, Tony, if I understand you?’ says Mr. Guppy, biting his thumb with the appetite of vexation.
“那么，有一种可能性或可​​能性——对此必须加以考虑——你最近拥有一个似乎与这个世界没有任何关系的孤独老人的那些物品，而你从未受到打扰，并且你能够确定你能够找到看看他到底在那里储存了什么，托尼，根本不用和你讨论昨晚的事，如果我理解你的话？”孔雀先生说，因为烦恼而咬着拇指。

‘Certainly not. Talk in that cool way of a fellow’s living there?’ cries Mr. Weevle indignantly. ‘Go and live there yourself.’
‘当然不是。 “用那种很酷的方式谈论一个人在那里的生活？”韦夫勒先生愤怒地喊道。 “你自己去那里住吧。”

‘Oh! I, Tony!’ says Mr. Guppy, soothing him. ‘I have never lived there and couldn’t get a lodging there now, whereas you have got one.’
'哦！我，托尼！”古比先生安抚他说道。 “我从来没有在那里住过，现在也找不到住处，而你却有。”

‘You are welcome to it,’ rejoins his friend, ‘and—ugh!—you may make yourself at home in it.’
“欢迎你来，”他的朋友回答道，“而且——呃！——你可以在里面感到宾至如归。”

‘Then you really and truly at this point,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘give up the whole thing, if I understand you, Tony?’
“那么，在这一点上，”古比先生说，“如果我理解你的话，你真的要放弃整件事吗，托尼？”

‘You never,’ returns Tony with a most convincing steadfastness, ‘said a truer word in all your life. I do!’
“你，”托尼以最令人信服的坚定态度回答道，“你这辈子从来没有说过更真实的话。”我愿意！'

While they are so conversing, a hackney-coach drives into the square, on the box of which vehicle a very tall hat makes itself manifest to the public. Inside the coach, and consequently not so manifest to the multitude, though sufficiently so to the two friends, for the coach stops almost at their feet, are the venerable Mr. Smallweed and Mrs. Smallweed, accompanied by their granddaughter Judy.
当他们正在交谈时，一辆出租马车驶入广场，车箱上有一顶很高的帽子显露出来。在马车里，受人尊敬的斯莫尔韦德先生和斯莫尔韦德夫人带着他们的孙女朱迪，虽然对这两个朋友来说足够明显，因为马车几乎就停在他们的脚边，但在马车里，对众人来说并不那么明显。

An air of haste and excitement pervades the party, and as the tall hat (surmounting Mr. Smallweed the younger) alights, Mr. Smallweed the elder pokes his head out of window and bawls to Mr. Guppy, ‘How de do, sir! How de do!’
聚会上弥漫着一种匆忙和兴奋的气氛，当高帽子（在小斯莫威德先生上方）落下时，老斯莫威德先生把头探出窗外，对孔雀鱼先生大声喊道：“你好，先生！”怎么办！’

‘What do Chick and his family want here at this time of the morning, I wonder!’ says Mr. Guppy, nodding to his familiar.
“我想知道，早上这个时候，奇克和他的家人来这里想做什么！”古皮先生一边说，一边向他的使魔点点头。

‘My dear sir,’ cries Grandfather Smallweed, ‘would you do me a favour? Would you and your friend be so very obleeging as to carry me into the public-house in the court, while Bart and his sister bring their grandmother along? Would you do an old man that good turn, sir?’
“亲爱的先生，”斯莫威德爷爷喊道，“你能帮我一个忙吗？你和你的朋友会热心地把我带进法院的酒馆，而巴特和他的妹妹则带着他们的祖母吗？先生，您愿意为一位老人做这样的好事吗？

Mr. Guppy looks at his friend, repeating inquiringly, ‘The publichouse in the court?’ And they prepare to bear the venerable burden to the Sol’s Arms.
古比先生看着他的朋友，询问地重复道：“宫廷里的酒馆？”然后他们准备将这一令人尊敬的负担扛到索尔的手臂上。

‘There’s your fare!’ says the patriarch to the coachman with a fierce grin and shaking his incapable fist at him. ‘Ask me for a penny more, and I’ll have my lawful revenge upon you. My dear young men, be easy with me, if you please. Allow me to catch you round the neck. I won’t squeeze you tighter than I can help. Oh, Lord! Oh, dear me! Oh, my bones!’
“这是你的车费！”族长对车夫说道，他咧嘴一笑，向他挥舞着无力的拳头。 “再向我要一分钱，我就会对你进行合法的报复。”我亲爱的年轻人，如果愿意的话，请对我轻松点。请允许我掐住你的脖子。我不会把你压得更紧。我的天！噢，亲爱的我！哦，我的骨头！

It is well that the Sol is not far off, for Mr. Weevle presents an apoplectic appearance before half the distance is accomplished. With no worse aggravation of his symptoms, however, than the utterance of divers croaking sounds expressive of obstructed respiration, he fulils his share of the porterage and the benevolent old gentleman is deposited by his own desire in the parlour of the Sol’s Arms.
幸亏太阳号离我们不远了，因为威弗勒先生还没走完一半的距离就露出了中风的表情。然而，他的症状并没有比呼吸受阻时发出的各种嘎嘎声更严重，他完成了自己的搬运工作，仁慈的老绅士按照自己的意愿被安置在索尔武器的客厅里。

‘Oh, Lord!’ gasps Mr. Smallweed, looking about him, breathless, from an arm-chair. ‘Oh, dear me! Oh, my bones and back! Oh, my aches and pains! Sit down, you dancing, prancing, shambling, scrambling poll-parrot! Sit down!’
“噢，上帝啊！”斯莫威德先生喘着气说道，他坐在扶手椅上，气喘吁吁地环顾四周。 ‘噢，亲爱的我！哦，我的骨头和背部！哦，我的疼痛！坐下吧，你这跳舞、腾跃、蹒跚、爬行的鹦鹉！坐下！'

This little apostrophe to Mrs. Smallweed is occasioned by a propensity on the part of that unlucky old lady whenever she finds herself on her feet to amble about and ‘set’ to inanimate objects, accompanying herself with a chattering noise, as in a witch dance. A nervous affection has probably as much to do with these demonstrations as any imbecile intention in the poor old woman, but on the present occasion they are so particularly lively in connexion with the Windsor arm-chair, fellow to that in which Mr. Smallweed is seated, that she only quite desists when her grandchildren have held her down in it, her lord in the meanwhile bestowing upon her, with great volubility, the endearing epithet of ‘a pig-headed jackdaw,’ repeated a surprising number of times.
