斯莫威德夫人的这个小撇号是由于那位不幸的老太太发现自己站起来漫步并“设置”到无生命的物体时的一种倾向而引起的，伴随着一种喋喋不休的声音，就像在巫婆舞蹈中一样。紧张的感情可能与这位可怜的老妇人的任何愚蠢的意图一样与这些示威有关，但在目前的情况下，它们与温莎扶手椅的联系是如此特别活跃，温莎扶手椅是斯莫威德先生坐在其中的同胞。坐着，只有当她的孙子们把她压在里面时，她才会完全停止，与此同时，她的主人滔滔不绝地授予她“猪头寒鸦”的可爱绰号，重复了令人惊讶的次数。

‘My dear sir,’ Grandfather Smallweed then proceeds, addressing Mr. Guppy, ‘there has been a calamity here. Have you heard of it, either of you?’
“亲爱的先生，”史莫威德祖父接着对孔雀鱼先生说道，“这里发生了一场灾难。你们听说过吗？

‘Heard of it, sir! Why, we discovered it.’
‘听说了，先生！为什么，我们发现了它。

‘You discovered it. You two discovered it! Bart, THEY discovered it!’
‘你发现了它。你们两个发现了！巴特，他们发现了！”

The two discoverers stare at the Smallweeds, who return the compliment.
两位发现者盯着小杂草，小杂草也回以恭维。

‘My dear friends,’ whines Grandfather Smallweed, putting out both his hands, ‘I owe you a thousand thanks for discharging the melancholy office of discovering the ashes of Mrs. Smallweed’s brother.’
“我亲爱的朋友们，”斯莫威德祖父伸出双手哀嚎道，“我欠你们一千个感谢，感谢你们履行了发现斯莫威德夫人弟弟骨灰的悲惨职责。”

‘Eh?’ says Mr. Guppy.
“呃？”古比先生说。

‘Mrs. Smallweed’s brother, my dear friend—her only relation. We were not on terms, which is to be deplored now, but he never WOULD be on terms. He was not fond of us. He was eccentric—he was very eccentric. Unless he has left a will (which is not at all likely) I shall take out letters of administration. I have come down to look after the property; it must be sealed up, it must be protected. I have come down,’ repeats Grandfather Smallweed, hooking the air towards him with all his ten fingers at once, ‘to look after the property.’
'太太。斯莫威德的兄弟，我亲爱的朋友——她唯一的亲戚。我们的关系不和，这现在令人遗憾，但他永远不会和好。他不喜欢我们。他很古怪——他非常古怪。除非他留下遗嘱（这根本不可能），否则我将拿出遗产管理书。我是来照看财产的；它必须被密封，它必须受到保护。我下来了，”斯莫威德祖父重复道，同时用十个手指将空气勾向他，“是为了看管这片土地。”

‘I think, Small,’ says the disconsolate Mr. Guppy, ‘you might have mentioned that the old man was your uncle.’
“我想，斯莫尔，”孔雀先生郁闷地说，“你可能提到过那个老人是你的叔叔。”

‘You two were so close about him that I thought you would like me to be the same,’ returns that old bird with a secretly glistening eye. ‘Besides, I wasn’t proud of him.’
“你们两个对他的关系如此亲密，我以为你们也会希望我也和他一样。”那只老鸟用一双暗自闪闪发光的眼睛回答道。 “此外，我并不为他感到骄傲。”

‘Besides which, it was nothing to you, you know, whether he was or not,’ says Judy. Also with a secretly glistening eye.
“除此之外，无论他是不是，这对你来说都无关紧要，你知道，”朱迪说。还带着一双隐秘的闪闪发光的眼睛。

‘He never saw me in his life to know me,’ observed Small; ‘I don’t know why I should introduce HIM, I am sure!’
“他一生中从未见过我，也从未认识过我，”斯莫尔说道。 “我不知道为什么要介绍他，但我确定！”

‘No, he never communicated with us, which is to be deplored,’ the old gentleman strikes in, ‘but I have come to look after the property—to look over the papers, and to look after the property. We shall make good our title. It is in the hands of my solicitor. Mr. Tulkinghorn, of Lincoln’s Inn Fields, over the way there, is so good as to act as my solicitor; and grass don’t grow under HIS feet, I can tell ye. Krook was Mrs. Smallweed’s only brother; she had no relation but Krook, and Krook had no relation but Mrs. Smallweed. I am speaking of your brother, you brimstone blackbeetle, that was seventy-six years of age.’
“不，他从来没有和我们联系过，这令人遗憾，”老绅士插嘴道，“但我是来照管财产的——检查文件，照管财产。”我们将兑现我们的称号。它在我的律师手中。林肯因菲尔兹的图金霍恩先生就在那边，他非常热心地担任我的律师。我可以告诉你们，他的脚下不长草。克鲁克是斯莫威德夫人唯一的兄弟。除了克鲁克之外，她没有任何亲属关系，而克鲁克除了斯莫威德夫人之外没有任何亲属关系。我说的是你的兄弟，你这个硫磺黑甲虫，已经七十六岁了。

Mrs. Smallweed instantly begins to shake her head and pipe up, ‘Seventy-six pound seven and sevenpence! Seventysix thousand bags of money! Seventy-six hundred thousand million of parcels of banknotes!’
斯莫尔威德太太立即开始摇头并尖声说道：“七十六英镑七又七便士！”七万六千袋钱！七百六十亿包钞票！

‘Will somebody give me a quart pot?’ exclaims her exasperated husband, looking helplessly about him and finding no missile within his reach. ‘Will somebody obleege me with a spittoon? Will somebody hand me anything hard and bruising to pelt at her? You hag, you cat, you dog, you brimstone barker!’ Here Mr. Smallweed, wrought up to the highest pitch by his own eloquence, actually throws Judy at her grandmother in default of anything else, by butting that young virgin at the old lady with such force as he can muster and then dropping into his chair in a heap.
“有人能给我一夸脱壶吗？”她愤怒的丈夫惊呼道，他无助地环顾四周，发现手边没有导弹。 “有人会用痰盂来求我吗？有人会递给我任何坚硬的、瘀伤的东西来攻击她吗？你这个老太婆，你这个猫，你这个狗，你这个硫磺狂吠者！”在这里，斯莫威德先生被自己的口才达到了最高的音调，实际上，他不顾一切地把朱迪扔到了她的祖母身上，把那个年轻的处女撞到了老处女身上。那位女士用尽了他所能集中的力量，然后瘫坐在椅子上。

‘Shake me up, somebody, if you’ll he so good,’ says the voice from within the faintly struggling bundle into which he has collapsed. ‘I have come to look after the property. Shake me up, and call in the police on duty at the next house to be explained to about the property. My solicitor will be here presently to protect the property. Transportation or the gallows for anybody who shall touch the property!’ As his dutiful grandchildren set him up, panting, and putting him through the usual restorative process of shaking and punching, he still repeats like an echo, ‘The—the property! The property! Property!’
“谁能摇醒我，如果你愿意的话，”他已经倒在了微弱挣扎的包裹里，声音说道。 ‘我是来照看财产的。把我摇醒，然后叫来隔壁的值班警察，向我解释财产的情况。我的律师很快就会来保护财产。交通或绞刑架，任何触及财产的人！”当他尽职的孙子把他扶起来，气喘吁吁，并让他经历通常的摇晃和拳打的恢复过程时，他仍然像回声一样重复，“财产！财产！财产！'

Mr. Weevle and Mr. Guppy look at each other, the former as having relinquished the whole affair, the latter with a discomfited countenance as having entertained some lingering expectations yet. But there is nothing to be done in opposition to the Smallweed interest. Mr. Tulkinghorn’s clerk comes down from his official pew in the chambers to mention to the police that Mr. Tulkinghorn is answerable for its being all correct about the next of kin and that the papers and effects will be formally taken possession of in due time and course. Mr. Smallweed is at once permitted so far to assert his supremacy as to be carried on a visit of sentiment into the next house and upstairs into Miss Flite’s deserted room, where he looks like a hideous bird of prey newly added to her aviary.
韦夫勒先生和古比先生互相看了一眼，前者似乎已经放弃了这一切，后者一脸窘迫，似乎还抱有一些挥之不去的期望。但我们无法采取任何措施来反对 Smallweed 的利益。图金霍恩先生的职员从会议厅的正式席位上下来，向警方提及，图金霍恩先生应对其关于近亲的一切正确性负责，文件和财物将在适当的时候被正式接管。课程。斯莫威德先生立刻被允许宣示他的至高无上的地位，并被带去隔壁的房子进行一次情感访问，然后上楼进入弗利特小姐的废弃房间，在那里他看起来就像一只新添加到她的鸟舍里的可怕的猛禽。

The arrival of this unexpected heir soon taking wind in the court still makes good for the Sol and keeps the court upon its mettle. Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins think it hard upon the young man if there really is no will, and consider that a handsome present ought to be made him out of the estate. Young Piper and young Perkins, as members of that restless juvenile circle which is the terror of the foot-passengers in Chancery Lane, crumble into ashes behind the pump and under the archway all day long, where wild yells and hootings take place over their remains. Little Swills and Miss M. Melvilleson enter into affable conversation with their patrons, feeling that these unusual occurrences level the barriers between professionals and non-professionals. Mr. Bogsby puts up ‘The popular song of King Death, with chorus by the whole strength of the company,’ as the great Harmonic feature of the week and announces in the bill that ‘J. G. B. is induced to do so at a considerable extra expense in consequence of a wish which has been very generally expressed at the bar by a large body of respectable individuals and in homage to a late melancholy event which has aroused so much sensation.’ There is one point connected with the deceased upon which the court is particularly anxious, namely, that the fiction of a full-sized coffin should be preserved, though there is so little to put in it. Upon the undertaker’s stating in the Sol’s bar in the course of the day that he has received orders to construct ‘a six-footer,’ the general solicitude is much relieved, and it is considered that Mr. Smallweed’s conduct does him great honour.
这位意想不到的继承人的到来很快就在宫廷中引起了轰动，这对索尔来说仍然是一件好事，并保持了宫廷的勇气。派珀夫人和珀金斯夫人认为，如果这个年轻人真的没有遗嘱，那就太难了，并认为应该从遗产中为他准备一份丰厚的礼物。年轻的派珀和年轻的珀金斯，作为令大法官巷的行人恐惧的不安分的青少年圈子的成员，整天在水泵后面和拱门下化为灰烬，在那里，他们的遗体上响起了疯狂的叫喊和叫喊声。 。 Little Swills 和 M. Melvilleson 小姐与顾客进行了亲切的交谈，他们认为这些不寻常的事件消除了专业人士和非专业人士之间的障碍。博格斯比先生将“死亡之王的流行歌曲，公司全体力量合唱”作为本周最精彩的 Harmonic 专题，并在法案中宣布“J. G. B. 被引诱这样做，花费了相当大的额外费用，这是因为酒吧里一大群受人尊敬的人士普遍表达了一个愿望，也是为了向最近引起如此大轰动的悲伤事件致敬。法院特别关注与死者有关的一点，即应该保留一具全尺寸棺材的虚构作品，尽管里面可放的东西很少。当天，殡葬承办人在索尔酒吧里宣布，他已收到建造“一座六英尺高的建筑”的命令，大家的忧虑都松了一口气，人们认为斯莫威德先生的行为给他带来了莫大的荣誉。

Out of the court, and a long way out of it, there is considerable excitement too, for men of science and philosophy come to look, and carriages set down doctors at the corner who arrive with the same intent, and there is more learned talk about inflammable gases and phosphuretted hydrogen than the court has ever imagined. Some of these authorities (of course the wisest) hold with indignation that the deceased had no business to die in the alleged manner; and being reminded by other authorities of a certain inquiry into the evidence for such deaths reprinted in the sixth volume of the Philosophical Transactions; and also of a book not quite unknown on English medical jurisprudence; and likewise of the Italian case of the Countess Cornelia Baudi as set forth in detail by one Bianchini, prebendary of Verona, who wrote a scholarly work or so and was occasionally heard of in his time as having gleams of reason in him; and also of the testimony of Messrs. Fodere and Mere, two pestilent Frenchmen who WOULD investigate the subject; and further, of the corroborative testimony of Monsieur Le Cat, a rather celebrated French surgeon once upon a time, who had the unpoliteness to live in a house where such a case occurred and even to write an account of it—still they regard the late Mr. Krook’s obstinacy in going out of the world by any such by-way as wholly unjustifiable and personally offensive. The less the court understands of all this, the more the court likes it, and the greater enjoyment it has in the stock in trade of the Sol’s Arms. Then there comes the artist of a picture newspaper, with a foreground and figures ready drawn for anything from a wreck on the Cornish coast to a review in Hyde Park or a meeting in Manchester, and in Mrs. Perkins’ own room, memorable evermore, he then and there throws in upon the block Mr. Krook’s house, as large as life; in fact, considerably larger, making a very temple of it. Similarly, being permitted to look in at the door of the fatal chamber, he depicts that apartment as three-quarters of a mile long by fifty yards high, at which the court is particularly charmed. All this time the two gentlemen before mentioned pop in and out of every house and assist at the philosophical disputations—go everywhere and listen to everybody—and yet are always diving into the Sol’s parlour and writing with the ravenous little pens on the tissue-paper.
走出法庭，走出法庭很远，也有相当大的兴奋，科学界和哲学界的人士前来观看，马车将怀着同样意图到达的医生停在拐角处，并且有更多有学问的谈话关于易燃气体和磷化氢的含量超出法院的想象。其中一些权威人士（当然是最明智的）愤怒地认为，死者没有理由以所谓的方式死去；并被其他当局提醒对《哲学汇刊》第六卷中重印的此类死亡证据进行某些调查；还有一本不太为人所知的关于英国医学法学的书；同样，意大利科妮莉亚·鲍迪伯爵夫人的案件也由维罗纳的准主教比安奇尼详细阐述，他写过一部左右的学术著作，在他那个时代偶尔会听说他身上闪烁着理性的光芒。还有 Fodere 和 Mere 先生的证词，这两个法国人将调查这个问题；此外，勒卡特先生的证词也证实了他的证词，勒卡特先生是一位颇有名气的法国外科医生，他无礼地住在发生过此类案件的房子里，甚至还写了一份报告——他们仍然认为已故的克鲁克先生固执地以任何这样的方式走出世界，这是完全不合理的，而且对个人来说是一种冒犯。宫廷对这一切了解得越少，宫廷就越喜欢它，并且对索尔之臂的库存交易也就越感兴趣。然后是图片报纸的艺术家，前景和人物已经准备好，从康沃尔海岸的沉船到海德公园的评论或曼彻斯特的会议，再到《夫人》。 帕金斯自己的房间，永远令人难忘，他当时就把克鲁克先生的房子扔到了街区上，像真人一样大；事实上，它要大得多，简直就是一座寺庙。同样，当他被允许查看致命房间的门时，他将那间公寓描绘成四分之三英里长、五十码高，宫廷对此特别着迷。一直以来，前面提到的两位先生在每所房子里进进出出，协助哲学辩论——到处走走，倾听每个人的意见——但总是潜入索尔的客厅，用贪婪的小笔在薄纸上写作。

At last come the coroner and his inquiry, like as before, except that the coroner cherishes this case as being out of the common way and tells the gentlemen of the jury, in his private capacity, that ‘that would seem to be an unlucky house next door, gentlemen, a destined house; but so we sometimes find it, and these are mysteries we can’t account for!’ After which the six-footer comes into action and is much admired.
最后，验尸官和他的调查一样，就像以前一样，只是验尸官认为这个案件不寻常，并以私人身份告诉陪审团先生们，“那似乎是一栋不吉利的房子”先生们，隔壁是一座命中注定的房子；但我们有时会发现它，而这些都是我们无法解释的奥秘！”之后，这位六英尺高的人开始行动并受到了极大的钦佩。

In all these proceedings Mr. Guppy has so slight a part, except when he gives his evidence, that he is moved on like a private individual and can only haunt the secret house on the outside, where he has the mortification of seeing Mr. Smallweed padlocking the door, and of bitterly knowing himself to be shut out. But before these proceedings draw to a close, that is to say, on the night next after the catastrophe, Mr. Guppy has a thing to say that must be said to Lady Dedlock.
在所有这些诉讼中，古比先生的作用是如此微不足道，除非他提供证据，否则他就像一个私人一样被移动，只能在外面的秘密房子里出没，在那里他羞于见到斯莫威德先生锁上门，痛苦地知道自己被关在门外。但在这些程序结束之前，也就是说，在灾难发生后的第二天晚上，古皮先生有话要说，必须对戴德洛克夫人说。

For which reason, with a sinking heart and with that hang-dog sense of guilt upon him which dread and watching enfolded in the Sol’s Arms have produced, the young man of the name of Guppy presents himself at the town mansion at about seven o’clock in the evening and requests to see her ladyship. Mercury replies that she is going out to dinner; don’t he see the carriage at the door? Yes, he does see the carriage at the door; but he wants to see my Lady too.
因此，带着一颗沉沉的心，带着被索尔的手臂包裹着的恐惧和监视所产生的那种悬而未决的负罪感，那个名叫孔雀鱼的年轻人在七点左右出现在镇上的宅邸。晚上的钟声要求见见她的女士。水星回答说她要出去吃晚饭；他没看到门口有马车吗？是的，他确实看到了门口的马车；但他也想见我的女士。

Mercury is disposed, as he will presently declare to a fellowgentleman in waiting, ‘to pitch into the young man”; but his instructions are positive. Therefore he sulkily supposes that the young man must come up into the library. There he leaves the young man in a large room, not over-light, while he makes report of him.
正如水星即将向一位等待中的绅士同胞宣布的那样，他准备“向年轻人投掷”；但他的指示是积极的。因此他闷闷不乐地认为年轻人一定是到图书馆来的。在那里，他把年轻人留在一个光线不太亮的大房间里，同时他向他汇报情况。

Mr. Guppy looks into the shade in all directions, discovering everywhere a certain charred and whitened little heap of coal or wood. Presently he hears a rustling. Is it—? No, it’s no ghost, but fair flesh and blood, most brilliantly dressed.
孔雀先生向各个方向的阴影里望去，发现到处都有一些烧焦、变白的小煤堆或木头。不久他听到一阵沙沙声。是吗-？不，这不是幽灵，而是有血有肉、衣着光鲜亮丽的人。

‘I have to beg your ladyship’s pardon,’ Mr. Guppy stammers, very downcast. ‘This is an inconvenient time—‘
“我必须请求夫人的原谅，”古皮先生结结巴巴地说，非常沮丧。 “现在是个不方便的时刻——”

‘I told you, you could come at any time.’ She takes a chair, looking straight at him as on the last occasion.
“我告诉过你，你随时都可以来。”她坐在椅子上，像上次一样直视着他。

‘Thank your ladyship. Your ladyship is very affable.’
‘谢谢夫人。夫人非常和蔼可亲。

‘You can sit down.’ There is not much affability in her tone.
“你可以坐下了。”她的语气中没有太多的和蔼可亲。

‘I don’t know, your ladyship, that it’s worth while my sitting down and detaining you, for I—I have not got the letters that I mentioned when I had the honour of waiting on your ladyship.’
“夫人，我不知道我是否值得坐下来拘留您，因为我——我没有收到我有幸侍候您的夫人时提到的那些信。”

‘Have you come merely to say so?’
“你来这里只是为了这么说吗？”

‘Merely to say so, your ladyship.’ Mr. Guppy besides being depressed, disappointed, and uneasy, is put at a further disadvantage by the splendour and beauty of her appearance.
“只是这么说，夫人。”孔比先生除了感到沮丧、失望和不安之外，还因为她容貌的辉煌和美丽而处于更加不利的地位。

She knows its influence perfectly, has studied it too well to miss a grain of its effect on any one. As she looks at him so steadily and coldly, he not only feels conscious that he has no guide in the least perception of what is really the complexion of her thoughts, but also that he is being every moment, as it were, removed further and further from her.
她完全了解它的影响，并且研究得非常透彻，不会错过它对任何人的影响。当她如此坚定而冷漠地看着他时，他不仅意识到自己对她的真实想法毫无了解，而且每时每刻都在进一步远离自己。离她更远。

She will not speak, it is plain. So he must.
她不会说话，很简单。所以他必须。

‘In short, your ladyship,’ says Mr. Guppy like a meanly penitent thief, ‘the person I was to have had the letters of, has come to a sudden end, and—‘ He stops. Lady Dedlock calmly finishes the sentence.
“简而言之，夫人，”古比先生像一个卑鄙的忏悔小偷一样说道，“我本该收到信件的那个人突然去世了，而且——”他停了下来。戴德洛克女士平静地说完这句话。

‘And the letters are destroyed with the person?’
“那么这些信件和这个人一起被毁掉了吗？”

Mr. Guppy would say no if he could—as he is unable to hide.
如果可以的话，古比先生会拒绝——因为他无法隐藏。

‘I believe so, your ladyship.’
“我相信是这样，夫人。”

If he could see the least sparkle of relief in her face now? No, he could see no such thing, even if that brave outside did not utterly put him away, and he were not looking beyond it and about it.
现在他是否能在她脸上看到一丝欣慰的光芒呢？不，他看不到这样的事情，即使那个勇敢的外表并没有完全把他拒之门外，而且他也没有超越它并关注它。

He falters an awkward excuse or two for his failure.
他为自己的失败找了一两个尴尬的借口。

‘Is this all you have to say?’ inquires Lady Dedlock, having heard him out—or as nearly out as he can stumble.
“这就是你要说的全部内容吗？”戴德洛克夫人在听完他的讲话后问道——或者说是尽可能地绊倒他。

Mr. Guppy thinks that’s all.
古比先生认为仅此而已。

‘You had better be sure that you wish to say nothing more to me, this being the last time you will have the opportunity.’
“你最好确定你不想再对我多说什么了，这是你最后一次有机会了。”

Mr. Guppy is quite sure. And indeed he has no such wish at present, by any means.
古比先生非常肯定。事实上，无论如何，他目前还没有这样的愿望。

‘That is enough. I will dispense with excuses. Good evening to you!’ And she rings for Mercury to show the young man of the name of Guppy out.
'足够了。我将不再找借口。晚上好！”她按响了水星的电话，让他​​带那个名叫孔雀鱼的年轻人出去。

But in that house, in that same moment, there happens to be an old man of the name of Tulkinghorn. And that old man, coming with his quiet footstep to the library, has his hand at that moment on the handle of the door—comes in—and comes face to face with the young man as he is leaving the room.
但就在同一时刻，在那所房子里，恰好有一位名叫图尔金霍恩的老人。那位老人迈着安静的脚步来到图书馆，此时他的手放在门把手上——进来了——在年轻人离开房间时，他与他面对面。

One glance between the old man and the lady, and for an instant the blind that is always down flies up. Suspicion, eager and sharp, looks out. Another instant, close again.
老人和女士一眼望去，一向垂下的百叶窗一瞬间飞了起来。怀疑，急切而尖锐，向外张望。又一瞬间，再次关闭。

‘I beg your pardon, Lady Dedlock. I beg your pardon a thousand times. It is so very unusual to find you here at this hour. I supposed the room was empty. I beg your pardon!’
“请您原谅，戴德洛克女士。我请你原谅一千次。这个时间在这里见到你真是太不寻常了。我以为房间是空的。请再说一遍！'

‘Stay!’ She negligently calls him back. ‘Remain here, I beg. I am going out to dinner. I have nothing more to say to this young man!’
“留下来！”她漫不经心地叫他回来。 “我恳求你，留在这里。”我要出去吃晚饭。我对这个年轻人没什么可说的了！

The disconcerted young man bows, as he goes out, and cringingly hopes that Mr. Tulkinghorn of the Fields is well.
那个惊慌失措的年轻人走出去时鞠了一躬，并满怀畏惧地希望田野的图尔金霍恩先生一切都好。

‘Aye, aye?’ says the lawyer, looking at him from under his bent brows, though he has no need to look again—not he. ‘From Kenge and Carboy’s, surely?’
“是吗？是吗？”律师弯着眉毛看着他，说道，尽管他不需要再看——他自己不需要。 “肯定是肯格和卡博伊的吗？”

‘Kenge and Carboy’s, Mr. Tulkinghorn. Name of Guppy, sir.’
“肯格和卡博伊的，图金霍恩先生。孔雀鱼的名字，先生。”

‘To be sure. Why, thank you, Mr. Guppy, I am very well!’
'为了确定。嗯，谢谢你，古比先生，我很好！

‘Happy to hear it, sir. You can’t be too well, sir, for the credit of the profession.’
“很高兴听到这个消息，先生。先生，为了这个职业的声誉，你不可能做得太好。”

‘Thank you, Mr. Guppy!’
“谢谢你，孔雀鱼先生！”

Mr. Guppy sneaks away. Mr. Tulkinghorn, such a foil in his oldfashioned rusty black to Lady Dedlock’s brightness, hands her down the staircase to her carriage. He returns rubbing his chin, and rubs it a good deal in the course of the evening.
孔雀鱼先生偷偷溜走了。图金霍恩先生用他老式的铁锈黑色衬托了戴德洛克夫人的光彩，他把她送下楼梯，送到了马车上。他回来揉着下巴，整个晚上都揉了很多次。

CHAPTER XXXIV
第三十四章


A Turn of the Screw
拧螺丝

‘Now, what,’ says Mr. George, ‘may this be? Is it blank cartridge or ball? A flash in the pan or a shot?’
“现在，”乔治先生说，“这可能是什么？是空白墨盒还是球？昙花一现还是一枪毙命？

An open letter is the subject of the trooper’s speculations, and it seems to perplex him mightily. He looks at it at arm’s length, brings it close to him, holds it in his right hand, holds it in his left hand, reads it with his head on this side, with his head on that side, contracts his eyebrows, elevates them, still cannot satisfy himself. He smooths it out upon the table with his heavy palm, and thoughtfully walking up and down the gallery, makes a halt before it every now and then to come upon it with a fresh eye. Even that won’t do. ‘Is it,’ Mr. George still muses, ‘blank cartridge or ball?’
一封公开信是这名士兵猜测的主题，这似乎让他非常困惑。他远远地看，靠近，右手拿，左手拿，头向这边读，头向那边读，皱眉，扬眉。 ，还是不能满足自己。他用沉重的手掌把它放在桌子上，若有所思地在画廊里走来走去，时不时地在它面前停下来，以新的眼光审视它。即使那样也行不通。 “是，”乔治先生仍在沉思，“是空弹还是球？”

Phil Squod, with the aid of a brush and paint-pot, is employed in the distance whitening the targets, softly whistling in quick-march time and in drum-and-fife manner that he must and will go back again to the girl he left behind him.
菲尔·斯夸德在画笔和油漆桶的帮助下，在远处将目标涂白，以快节奏的节奏和鼓与横笛的方式轻柔地吹着口哨，他必须并且将会再次回到他所认识的女孩身边。留在了他身后。

‘Phil!’ The trooper beckons as he calls him.
“菲尔！”士兵一边喊他，一边向他招手。

Phil approaches in his usual way, sidling off at first as if he were going anywhere else and then bearing down upon his commander like a bayonet-charge. Certain splashes of white show in high relief upon his dirty face, and he scrapes his one eyebrow with the handle of the brush.
菲尔以他惯常的方式接近，一开始侧身走开，好像他要去其他地方，然后像刺刀冲锋一样向他的指挥官冲来。他肮脏的脸上浮现出一些白色的浮雕，他用刷子的手柄刮擦一根眉毛。

‘Attention, Phil! Listen to this.’
‘注意，菲尔！听听这个。'

‘Steady, commander, steady.’
“稳住，指挥官，稳住。”

‘‘Sir. Allow me to remind you (though there is no legal necessity for my doing so, as you are aware) that the bill at two months’ date drawn on yourself by Mr. Matthew Bagnet, and by you accepted, for the sum of ninety-seven pounds four shillings and ninepence, will become due to-morrow, when you will please be prepared to take up the same on presentation. Yours, Joshua Smallweed.’ What do you make of that, Phil?’
''先生。请允许我提醒您（尽管如您所知，我这样做没有法律必要），马修·巴格内特先生在两个月后为您开出了账单，并由您接受，金额为九十-七英镑四先令九便士将于明天到期，届时请您准备好在演示中接受同样的金额。你的，约书亚·斯莫威德。“菲尔，你对此有何看法？”

‘Mischief, guv’ner.’
“恶作剧，长官。”

‘Why?’
'为什么？'

‘I think,’ replies Phil after pensively tracing out a cross-wrinkle in his forehead with the brush-handle, ‘that mischeevious consequences is always meant when money’s asked for.’
“我认为，”菲尔用刷柄若有所思地在额头上画出一条交叉皱纹后回答道，“当要钱的时候，总是意味着恶作剧的后果。”

‘Lookye, Phil,’ says the trooper, sitting on the table. ‘First and last, I have paid, I may say, half as much again as this principal in interest and one thing and another.’
“看，菲尔，”坐在桌子上的士兵说道。 “首先也是最后一点，我可以说，我已经支付了本金一半的利息，还有这样那样的东西。”

Phil intimates by sidling back a pace or two, with a very unaccountable wrench of his wry face, that he does not regard the transaction as being made more promising by this incident.
菲尔向后退了一两步，脸上莫名其妙地扭动了一下，暗示他并不认为这次事件让这笔交易变得更有希望。

‘And lookye further, Phil,’ says the trooper, staying his premature conclusions with a wave of his hand. ‘There has always been an understanding that this bill was to be what they call renewed. And it has been renewed no end of times. What do you say now?’
“再看看，菲尔，”士兵说道，挥了挥手，维持了他不成熟的结论。 “人们一直认为这项法案将被更新。”而且它已经被更新了无数次。你现在说什么？

‘I say that I think the times is come to a end at last.’
“我说我认为这个时代终于结束了。”

‘You do? Humph! I am much of the same mind myself.’
'你做？哼!我自己也有同样的想法。

‘Joshua Smallweed is him that was brought here in a chair?’
“约书亚·斯莫威德就是坐在椅子上被带到这里的人吗？”

‘The same.’
'相同。'

‘Guv’ner,’ says Phil with exceeding gravity, ‘he’s a leech in his dispositions, he’s a screw and a wice in his actions, a snake in his twistings, and a lobster in his claws.’
“古纳，”菲尔严肃地说，“他的性情是水蛭，他的行为是螺丝钉，他的扭曲是蛇，他的爪子是龙虾。”

Having thus expressively uttered his sentiments, Mr. Squod, after waiting a little to ascertain if any further remark be expected of him, gets back by his usual series of movements to the target he has in hand and vigorously signifies through his former musical medium that he must and he will return to that ideal young lady. George, having folded the letter, walks in that direction.
斯阔德先生如此表达地表达了他的感情，等了一会儿以确定是否需要他发表进一步的评论，然后通过他惯常的一系列动作回到了他手中的目标，并通过他以前的音乐媒介有力地表示：他必须而且他一定会回到那个理想的小姐身边。乔治把信折好，朝那个方向走去。

‘There IS a way, commander,’ says Phil, looking cunningly at him, ‘of settling this.’
“有一个办法，指挥官，”菲尔狡猾地看着他，“可以解决这个问题。”

‘Paying the money, I suppose? I wish I could.’
“我想是付钱吧？我希望我能。'

Phil shakes his head. ‘No, guv’ner, no; not so bad as that. There IS a way,’ says Phil with a highly artistic turn of his brush; ‘what I’m a-doing at present.’
菲尔摇摇头。 “不，长官，不；”还不错。 “有办法。”菲尔用极具艺术性的画笔说道。 “我现在正在做什么。”

‘Whitewashing.’
'粉刷。'

Phil nods.
菲尔点点头。

‘A pretty way that would be! Do you know what would become of the Bagnets in that case? Do you know they would be ruined to pay off my old scores? YOU’RE a moral character,’ says the trooper, eyeing him in his large way with no small indignation; ‘upon my life you are, Phil!’
‘那真是太好了！你知道如果那样的话 Bagnets 会变成什么样子吗？你知道他们会毁掉我的旧债吗？ “你是一个有道德的人。”士兵说道，眼睛里充满了不小的愤慨。 “菲尔，我以你的生命担保！”

Phil, on one knee at the target, is in course of protesting earnestly, though not without many allegorical scoops of his brush and smoothings of the white surface round the rim with his thumb, that he had forgotten the Bagnet responsibility and would not so much as injure a hair of the head of any member of that worthy family when steps are audible in the long passage without, and a cheerful voice is heard to wonder whether George is at home. Phil, with a look at his master, hobbles up, saying, ‘Here’s the guv’ner, Mrs. Bagnet! Here he is!’ and the old girl herself, accompanied by Mr. Bagnet, appears.
菲尔单膝跪在靶子前，正在诚恳地抗议，尽管他不无寓意地用画笔轻轻地舀了几下，用拇指抚平了边缘周围的白色表面，但他忘记了巴内特的责任，也不会那么强烈地抗议。当外面长长的过道里传来脚步声，并且听到一个欢快的声音询问乔治是否在家时，这就像伤害那个可敬的家庭成员的一根头发一样。菲尔看了一眼他的主人，一瘸一拐地站起来，说道：“这是州长，巴格尼特夫人！”他来了！”老女孩本人在巴格尼特先生的陪同下出现了。

The old girl never appears in walking trim, in any season of the year, without a grey cloth cloak, coarse and much worn but very clean, which is, undoubtedly, the identical garment rendered so interesting to Mr. Bagnet by having made its way home to Europe from another quarter of the globe in company with Mrs. Bagnet and an umbrella. The latter faithful appendage is also invariably a part of the old girl’s presence out of doors. It is of no colour known in this life and has a corrugated wooden crook for a handle, with a metallic object let into its prow, or beak, resembling a little model of a fanlight over a street door or one of the oval glasses out of a pair of spectacles, which ornamental object has not that tenacious capacity of sticking to its post that might be desired in an article long associated with the British army. The old girl’s umbrella is of a flabby habit of waist and seems to be in need of stays—an appearance that is possibly referable to its having served through a series of years at home as a cupboard and on journeys as a carpet bag. She never puts it up, having the greatest reliance on her well-proved cloak with its capacious hood, but generally uses the instrument as a wand with which to point out joints of meat or bunches of greens in marketing or to arrest the attention of tradesmen by a friendly poke. Without her marketbasket, which is a sort of wicker well with two flapping lids, she never stirs abroad. Attended by these her trusty companions, therefore, her honest sunburnt face looking cheerily out of a rough straw bonnet, Mrs. Bagnet now arrives, fresh-coloured and bright, in George’s Shooting Gallery.
老姑娘在一年中的任何季节里，走路时都不会穿着一件灰色的布斗篷，虽然粗糙、破旧，但非常干净，毫无疑问，这正是巴格尼特先生所穿的那件衣服，让他如此感兴趣。与巴格内特夫人和一把雨伞一起从地球的另一个角落回到欧洲。后者忠实的附属物也始终是老女孩户外活动的一部分。它没有现世已知的颜色，有一个波纹木钩作为把手，在它的船头或喙中插入一个金属物体，类似于街门上的扇形灯的小模型或椭圆形玻璃杯中的一个。一副眼镜，这种装饰物不具备长期与英国军队相关的物品中可能需要的顽强的坚守其位置的能力。老姑娘的伞腰部松垮，似乎需要撑住——这种外观可能与它多年来在家里当柜子、在旅途中当地毯包有关。她从不把它举起来，最大程度地依赖于她久经考验的斗篷和宽敞的兜帽，但通常使用该仪器作为魔杖，在营销中指出肉块或蔬菜串或吸引商人的注意力通过友好的戳。没有她的菜篮，那是一种带有两个扇动盖子的柳条井，她永远不会在国外活动。因此，在这些她值得信赖的同伴的陪伴下，巴格尼特夫人现在来到了乔治的射击馆，她那张诚实的晒黑的脸从一顶粗糙的草帽里露出来，看上去很高兴，她的肤色清新明亮。

‘Well, George, old fellow,’ says she, ‘and how do YOU do, this sunshiny morning?’
“好吧，乔治，老伙计，”她说，“这个阳光明媚的早晨，你好吗？”

Giving him a friendly shake of the hand, Mrs. Bagnet draws a long breath after her walk and sits down to enjoy a rest. Having a faculty, matured on the tops of baggage-waggons and in other such positions, of resting easily anywhere, she perches on a rough bench, unties her bonnet-strings, pushes back her bonnet, crosses her arms, and looks perfectly comfortable.
巴格内特夫人友好地与他握手，走完后长长地吸了一口气，然后坐下来休息。她有一种在行李车顶部和其他类似位置上成熟的能力，可以在任何地方轻松休息，她坐在一张粗糙的长凳上，解开帽子带子，推开帽子，交叉双臂，看起来非常舒服。

Mr. Bagnet in the meantime has shaken hands with his old comrade and with Phil, on whom Mrs. Bagnet likewise bestows a good-humoured nod and smile.
与此同时，巴格内特先生与他的老战友和菲尔握手，巴格内特夫人也同样幽默地点头并微笑。

‘Now, George,’ said Mrs. Bagnet briskly, ‘here we are, Lignum and myself’—she often speaks of her husband by this appellation, on account, as it is supposed, of Lignum Vitae having been his old regimental nickname when they first became acquainted, in compliment to the extreme hardness and toughness of his physiognomy—‘just looked in, we have, to make it all correct as usual about that security. Give him the new bill to sign, George, and he’ll sign it like a man.’
“现在，乔治，”巴格内特夫人轻快地说，“我们到了，利格努姆和我自己”——她经常用这个称呼来谈论她的丈夫，因为据推测，利格努姆维塔是他以前在团里的绰号。他们第一次认识，是为了称赞他外表的极端坚硬和坚韧——“我们只是进去看看，让保安的一切都像往常一样正确。”乔治，把新法案交给他签署，他会像个男人一样签署。

‘I was coming to you this morning,’ observes the trooper reluctantly.
“我今天早上就来找你，”士兵不情愿地说道。

‘Yes, we thought you’d come to us this morning, but we turned out early and left Woolwich, the best of boys, to mind his sisters and came to you instead—as you see! For Lignum, he’s tied so close now, and gets so little exercise, that a walk does him good. But what’s the matter, George?’ asks Mrs. Bagnet, stopping in her cheerful talk. ‘You don’t look yourself.’
“是的，我们以为你今天早上会来找我们，但我们很早就出发了，离开了伍尔维奇，最好的男孩，去照顾他的姐妹，而是来找你了——正如你所看到的！对于 Lignum 来说，他现在被绑得太紧了，几乎没有得到锻炼，所以散步对他有好处。 “乔治，怎么了？”巴格内特夫人停了下来，问道。 “你不看看自己。”

‘I am not quite myself,’ returns the trooper; ‘I have been a little put out, Mrs. Bagnet.’
“我不太像我自己，”士兵回答道。 “我有点不高兴，巴​​格内特太太。”

Her bright quick eye catches the truth directly. ‘George!’ holding up her forefinger. ‘Don’t tell me there’s anything wrong about that security of Lignum’s! Don’t do it, George, on account of the children!’
她明亮而敏捷的眼睛直接捕捉到了真相。 “乔治！”举起食指。 ‘别告诉我Lignum的安全措施有什么问题！乔治，为了孩子们，别这么做！”

The trooper looks at her with a troubled visage.
警察一脸困惑地看着她。

‘George,’ says Mrs. Bagnet, using both her arms for emphasis and occasionally bringing down her open hands upon her knees. ‘If you have allowed anything wrong to come to that security of Lignum’s, and if you have let him in for it, and if you have put us in danger of being sold up—and I see sold up in your face, George, as plain as print—you have done a shameful action and have deceived us cruelly. I tell you, cruelly, George. There!’
“乔治，”巴格内特太太用双臂强调，偶尔将张开的双手放在膝盖上。 “如果你允许任何错误发生在利格努姆的安全保障上，如果你让他参与进来，如果你让我们处于被出卖的危险之中——乔治，我在你的脸上看到了出卖的感觉，就像明明白白——你们做了可耻的事，残酷地欺骗了我们。我残酷地告诉你，乔治。那里！'

Mr. Bagnet, otherwise as immovable as a pump or a lamp-post, puts his large right hand on the top of his bald head as if to defend it from a shower-bath and looks with great uneasiness at Mrs. Bagnet.
巴格内特先生原本就像水泵或灯柱一样一动不动，但他却将右手大手放在光秃秃的头顶上，仿佛要保护自己的头免受淋浴，他不安地看着巴格内特太太。

‘George,’ says that old girl, ‘I wonder at you! George, I am ashamed of you! George, I couldn’t have believed you would have done it! I always knew you to be a rolling sone that gathered no moss, but I never thought you would have taken away what little moss there was for Bagnet and the children to lie upon. You know what a hard-working, steady-going chap he is. You know what Quebec and Malta and Woolwich are, and I never did think you would, or could, have had the heart to serve us so. Oh, George!’ Mrs. Bagnet gathers up her cloak to wipe her eyes on in a very genuine manner, ‘How could you do it?’
“乔治，”那个老女孩说，“我很奇怪你！乔治，我为你感到羞耻！乔治，我简直不敢相信你会做到这一点！我一直都知道你是一个不会长青苔的滚动之子，但我从未想过你会拿走巴格内特和孩子们躺在上面的那一点小青苔。你知道他是一个多么勤奋、踏实的小伙子。你知道魁北克、马耳他和伍尔维奇是什么，我从来没有想过你会，或者能够，有心为我们服务。哦，乔治！”巴格内特夫人卷起斗篷，真诚地擦了擦眼睛，“你怎么能这么做？”

Mrs. Bagnet ceasing, Mr. Bagnet removes his hand from his head as if the shower-bath were over and looks disconsolately at Mr. George, who has turned quite white and looks distressfully at the grey cloak and straw bonnet.
巴格尼特太太停下来，巴格尼特先生把手从头上移开，仿佛淋浴结束了，他沮丧地看着乔治先生，乔治先生的脸色变得煞白，痛苦地看着灰色斗篷和草帽。

‘Mat,’ says the trooper in a subdued voice, addressing him but still looking at his wife, ‘I am sorry you take it so much to heart, because I do hope it’s not so bad as that comes to. I certainly have, this morning, received this letter’—which he reads aloud—‘but I hope it may be set right yet. As to a rolling stone, why, what you say is true. I AM a rolling stone, and I never rolled in anybody’s way, I fully believe, that I rolled the least good to. But it’s impossible for an old vagabond comrade to like your wife and family better than I like ‘em, Mat, and I trust you’ll look upon me as forgivingly as you can. Don’t think I’ve kept anything from you. I haven’t had the letter more than a quarter of an hour.’
“马特，”士兵用低沉的声音说道，对他说话，但仍然看着他的妻子，“我很抱歉你把这件事放在心上，因为我确实希望事情没有那么糟糕。”今天早上我确实收到了这封信——”他大声读到了这封信——“但我希望它能得到纠正。至于滚石，为什么，你说的是真的。我是一块滚石，我从来没有以任何人的方式滚动，我完全相信，我滚动的方式是最糟糕的。但一个老流浪同志不可能比我更喜欢你的妻子和家人，马特，我相信你会尽可能宽容地看待我。别以为我对你隐瞒了什么。我收到这封信还不到一刻钟。”

‘Old girl,’ murmurs Mr. Bagnet after a short silence, ‘will you tell him my opinion?’
“老姑娘，”巴格内特先生沉默了一会儿，低声说道，“你能告诉他我的看法吗？”

‘Oh! Why didn’t he marry,’ Mrs. Bagnet answers, half laughing and half crying, ‘Joe Pouch’s widder in North America? Then he wouldn’t have got himself into these troubles.’
'哦！ “他为什么不结婚？”巴格内特夫人半笑半哭地回答道，“乔·普奇在北美走得更远了？”那么他就不会陷入这些麻烦之中。

‘The old girl,’ says Mr. Baguet, ‘puts it correct—why didn’t you?’
“老姑娘，”巴盖先生说，“说得对——为什么你不说呢？”

‘Well, she has a better husband by this time, I hope,’ returns the trooper. ‘Anyhow, here I stand, this present day, NOT married to Joe Pouch’s widder. What shall I do? You see all I have got about me. It’s not mine; it’s yours. Give the word, and I’ll sell off every morsel. If I could have hoped it would have brought in nearly the sum wanted, I’d have sold all long ago. Don’t believe that I’ll leave you or yours in the lurch, Mat. I’d sell myself first. I only wish,’ says the trooper, giving himself a disparaging blow in the chest, ‘that I knew of any one who’d buy such a second-hand piece of old stores.’
“好吧，我希望她现在有一个更好的丈夫，”士兵回答道。 “无论如何，今天我站在这里，没有嫁给乔·普奇的遗孀。我该怎么办？你看到了我所拥有的一切。不是我的;是你的。只要你一声令下，我就卖掉每一口。如果我能希望它能带来接近想要的金额，我早就卖掉了。别相信我会让你或你的家人陷入困境，马特。我会先把自己卖掉。 “我只希望，”警察轻蔑地在胸口上敲了一拳，“我只希望我知道有人会买这样一件旧商店的二手货。”

‘Old girl,’ murmurs Mr. Bagnet, ‘give him another bit of my mind.’
“老姑娘，”巴格内特先生低声说道，“再给他一点我的想法。”

‘George,’ says the old girl, ‘you are not so much to be blamed, on full consideration, except for ever taking this business without the means.’
“乔治，”老女孩说道，“考虑到你的全面考虑，你并没有什么过分的罪责，只是你在没有经济能力的情况下接手了这件事。”

‘And that was like me!’ observes the penitent trooper, shaking his head. ‘Like me, I know.’
“这就像我一样！”悔罪的士兵摇着头说道。 “就像我一样，我知道。”

‘Silence! The old girl,’ says Mr. Bagnet, ‘is correct—in her way of giving my opinions—hear me out!’
'安静！巴格内特先生说，“老姑娘是对的——她以她的方式表达了我的意见——听我说完！”

‘That was when you never ought to have asked for the security, George, and when you never ought to have got it, all things considered. But what’s done can’t be undone. You are always an honourable and straightforward fellow, as far as lays in your power, though a little flighty. On the other hand, you can’t admit but what it’s natural in us to be anxious with such a thing hanging over our heads. So forget and forgive all round, George. Come! Forget and forgive all round!’
“乔治，那时候你根本不应该要求安全，考虑到所有事情，你也不应该得到它。但已经发生的事是无法挽回的。在你力所能及的范围内，你总是一个诚实正直的人，尽管有点轻浮。另一方面，你也不能承认，我们对这样的事情感到焦虑是很自然的。所以，乔治，忘记并原谅一切。来！全面忘记并宽恕！

Mrs. Bagnet, giving him one of her honest hands and giving her husband the other, Mr. George gives each of them one of his and holds them while he speaks.
巴格内特夫人将她诚实的一只手递给他，另一只递给她的丈夫，乔治先生也向他们各伸出一只手，并在他说话时握着它们。

‘I do assure you both, there’s nothing I wouldn’t do to discharge this obligation. But whatever I have been able to scrape together has gone every two months in keeping it up. We have lived plainly enough here, Phil and I. But the gallery don’t quite do what was expected of it, and it’s not—in short, it’s not the mint. It was wrong in me to take it? Well, so it was. But I was in a manner drawn into that step, and I thought it might steady me, and set me up, and you’ll try to overlook my having such expectations, and upon my soul, I am very much obliged to you, and very much ashamed of myself.’ With these concluding words, Mr. George gives a shake to each of the hands he holds, and relinquishing them, backs a pace or two in a broad-chested, upright attitude, as if he had made a final confession and were immediately going to be shot with all military honours.
“我向你们俩保证，为了履行这一义务，我会尽一切努力。但我每两个月攒下的钱都会花掉。菲尔和我，我们在这里过着朴素的生活。但是画廊并没有完全达到人们的预期，它不是——简而言之，它不是造币厂。我接受它是错误的吗？嗯，确实如此。但我在某种程度上被吸引到了这一步，我想这可能会让我稳定下来，让我振作起来，而你会试图忽视我的这种期望，在我的灵魂上，我非常感谢你，并且说完这句话，乔治先生摇了摇他握住的每只手，然后松开它们，以宽阔的胸膛、挺直的态度向后退了一两步，仿佛他做了一个最后的坦白，并立即以所有军事荣誉被枪决。

‘George, hear me out!’ says Mr. Bagnet, glancing at his wife. ‘Old girl, go on!’
“乔治，听我说完！”巴格内特先生看了一眼他的妻子说道。 “老姑娘，继续吧！”

Mr. Bagnet, being in this singular manner heard out, has merely to observe that the letter must be attended to without any delay, that it is advisable that George and he should immediately wait on Mr. Smallweed in person, and that the primary object is to save and hold harmless Mr. Bagnet, who had none of the money. Mr. George, entirely assenting, puts on his hat and prepares to march with Mr. Bagnet to the enemy’s camp.
巴格内特先生以这种奇特的方式听取了他的意见，只需指出必须立即处理这封信，建议乔治和他立即亲自等候斯莫威德先生，并且主要目标是目的是拯救身无分文的巴格内特先生并使其免受伤害。乔治先生完全同意了，戴上帽子，准备与巴格内特先生一起前往敌人的营地。

‘Don’t you mind a woman’s hasty word, George,’ says Mrs. Bagnet, patting him on the shoulder. ‘I trust my old Lignum to you, and I am sure you’ll bring him through it.’
“乔治，你不介意女人的仓促一句话吗？”巴格内特夫人拍着他的肩膀说道。 “我把我的老Lignum托付给你，我相信你会带领他度过难关。”

The trooper returns that this is kindly said and that he WILL bring Lignum through it somehow. Upon which Mrs. Bagnet, with her cloak, basket, and umbrella, goes home, bright-eyed again, to the rest of her family, and the comrades sally forth on the hopeful errand of mollifying Mr. Smallweed.
士兵回复说这是善意的说法，他会以某种方式让利格纳姆度过难关。随后，巴格内特夫人带着斗篷、篮子和雨伞，回到家里，眼睛又明亮起来，回到家人身边，而同志们则出发去执行安抚斯莫威德先生的充满希望的任务。

Whether there are two people in England less likely to come satisfactorily out of any negotiation with Mr. Smallweed than Mr. George and Mr. Matthew Bagnet may be very reasonably questioned. Also, notwithstanding their martial appearance, broad square shoulders, and heavy tread, whether there are within the same limits two more simple and unaccustomed children in all the Smallweedy affairs of life. As they proceed with great gravity through the streets towards the region of Mount Pleasant, Mr. Bagnet, observing his companion to be thoughtful, considers it a friendly part to refer to Mrs. Bagnet’s late sally.
在英格兰，是否有两个人比乔治先生和马修·巴格尼特先生更不可能在与斯莫威德先生的谈判中取得令人满意的结果，这可能是一个非常合理的质疑。而且，尽管他们有着军人般的外表、宽阔的方肩和沉重的脚步，在小草生活的所有事务中是否还有两个更简单和不习惯的孩子。当他们严肃地穿过街道向芒特普莱森特地区前进时，巴格内特先生发现他的同伴若有所思，认为提及巴格内特夫人迟来的莎莉是一种友好的表现。

‘George, you know the old girl—she’s as sweet and as mild as milk. But touch her on the children—or myself—and she’s off like gunpowder.’
“乔治，你认识那个老女孩——她像牛奶一样甜美温和。但如果她碰触孩子们——或者我自己——她就会像火药一样消失。

‘It does her credit, Mat!’
“这是她的功劳，马特！”

‘George,’ says Mr. Bagnet, looking straight before him, ‘the old girl—can’t do anything—that don’t do her credit. More or less. I never say so. Discipline must he maintained.’
“乔治，”巴格内特先生直视前方说道，“这个老姑娘——什么也做不了——任何不值得她赞扬的事。”或多或少。我从来不这么说。他必须遵守纪律。

‘She’s worth her weight in gold,’ says the trooper.
“她的价值相当于她的黄金，”士兵说。

‘In gold?’ says Mr. Bagnet. ‘I’ll tell you what. The old girl’s weight—is twelve stone six. Would I take that weight—in any metal—for the old girl? No. Why not? Because the old girl’s metal is far more precious—-than the preciousest metal. And she’s ALL metal!’
“黄金？”巴格内特先生说。 ‘我会告诉你什么。老姑娘的体重——十二石六。我会为老女孩承受这个重量——任何金属吗？不，为什么不呢？因为老姑娘的金属比最珍贵的金属还要珍贵得多。她是全金属的！

‘You are right, Mat!’
“你是对的，马特！”

‘When she took me—and accepted of the ring—she ‘listed under me and the children—heart and head, for life. She’s that earnest,’ says Mr. Bagnet, ‘and true to her colours—that, touch us with a finger—and she turns out—and stands to her arms. If the old girl fires wide—once in a way—at the call of duty—look over it, George. For she’s loyal!’
“当她接受我并接受戒指时，她‘把我和孩子们的心和头脑都列在了我和孩子们的下面，一生一世。她是那么认真，”巴格内特先生说，“并且忠实于她的色彩——用手指触摸我们——结果她就站在她的怀里。如果那个老女孩在执行任务时偶尔开火的话，请注意，乔治。因为她很忠诚！

‘Why, bless her, Mat,’ returns the trooper, ‘I think the higher of her for it!’
“哎呀，上帝保佑她，马特，”士兵回答道，“我认为她做得更好！”

‘You are right!’ says Mr. Bagnet with the warmest enthusiasm, though without relaxing the rigidity of a single muscle. ‘Think as high of the old girl—as the rock of Gibraltar—and still you’ll be thinking low—of such merits. But I never own to it before her. Discipline must be maintained.’
“你是对的！”巴格内特先生热情地说，但没有放松任何一块肌肉的僵硬。 “对老女孩的评价就像直布罗陀的岩石一样高，但你仍然会对这些优点评价低。但我从来没有在她面前承认过这一点。必须维持纪律。”

These encomiums bring them to Mount Pleasant and to Grandfather Smallweed’s house. The door is opened by the perennial Judy, who, having surveyed them from top to toe with no particular favour, but indeed with a malignant sneer, leaves them standing there while she consults the oracle as to their admission. The oracle may be inferred to give consent from the circumstance of her returning with the words on her honey lips that they can come in if they want to it. Thus privileged, they come in and find Mr. Smallweed with his feet in the drawer of his chair as if it were a paper foot-bath and Mrs. Smallweed obscured with the cushion like a bird that is not to sing.
这些赞美把他们带到了普莱森特山和斯莫威德祖父的家里。门是常年不离不弃的朱迪打开的，她从头到脚打量了他们一眼，并没有什么特别的好意，但确实带着一种恶毒的冷笑，让他们站在那里，而她向神谕询问他们的入场情况。从她回来时嘴里甜言蜜语地说“如果他们愿意就可以进来”的情况，可以推断出神谕已经同意了。如此特权，他们走进来，发现斯莫威德先生的脚放在椅子的抽屉里，好像那是一个纸足浴，而斯莫威德太太则像一只不会唱歌的小鸟一样被垫子遮住了。

‘My dear friend,’ says Grandfather Smallweed with those two lean affectionate arms of his stretched forth. ‘How de do? How de do? Who is our friend, my dear friend?’
“我亲爱的朋友，”斯莫威德祖父伸出两只瘦长、充满感情的手臂说道。 ‘怎么办？怎么办？谁是我们的朋友，我亲爱的朋友？

‘Why this,’ returns George, not able to be very conciliatory at first, ‘is Matthew Bagnet, who has obliged me in that matter of ours, you know.’
“为什么会这样，”乔治回答道，一开始不太能和解，“是马修·巴格内特，你知道，他在我们的事情上帮了我的忙。”

‘Oh! Mr. Bagnet? Surely!’ The old man looks at him under his hand.
'哦！巴格内特先生？当然！”老人用手下看着他。

‘Hope you’re well, Mr. Bagnet? Fine man, Mr. George! Military air, sir!’
“希望你一切都好，巴格内特先生？”乔治先生，好人！军气，长官！”

No chairs being offered, Mr. George brings one forward for Bagnet and one for himself. They sit down, Mr. Bagnet as if he had no power of bending himself, except at the hips, for that purpose.
没有提供椅子，乔治先生为巴格内特带来了一把，为自己带来了一把。他们坐下来，巴格内特先生，好像他没有能力为此目的弯曲自己，除了臀部之外。

‘Judy,’ says Mr. Smallweed, ‘bring the pipe.’
“朱迪，”斯莫威德先生说，“把烟斗拿来。”

‘Why, I don’t know,’ Mr. George interposes, ‘that the young woman need give herself that trouble, for to tell you the truth, I am not inclined to smoke it to-day.’
“为什么，我不知道，”乔治先生插嘴道，“这位年轻女子是否需要给自己找麻烦，因为说实话，我今天不想抽烟。”

‘Ain’t you?’ returns the old man. ‘Judy, bring the pipe.’
“不是吗？”老人回答道。 “朱迪，把烟斗拿过来。”

‘The fact is, Mr. Smallweed,’ proceeds George, ‘that I find myself in rather an unpleasant state of mind. It appears to me, sir, that your friend in the city has been playing tricks.’
“事实是，斯莫威德先生，”乔治继续说道，“我发现自己的精神状态相当不愉快。先生，在我看来，你在城里的朋友一直在搞恶作剧。

‘Oh, dear no!’ says Grandfather Smallweed. ‘He never does that!’
“哦，天哪，不！”斯莫威德祖父说。 “他从来不这样做！”

‘Don’t he? Well, I am glad to hear it, because I thought it might be HIS doing. This, you know, I am speaking of. This letter.’
‘不是吗？嗯，我很高兴听到这个消息，因为我认为这可能是他做的。你知道，我正在谈论这个。这封信。'

Grandfather Smallweed smiles in a very ugly way in recognition of the letter.
斯莫威德祖父认出了这封信，露出非常难看的笑容。

‘What does it mean?’ asks Mr. George.
“这是什么意思？”乔治先生问道。

‘Judy,’ says the old man. ‘Have you got the pipe? Give it to me. Did you say what does it mean, my good friend?’
“朱迪，”老人说。 ‘你有管子吗？把它给我。你说这是什么意思吗，我的好朋友？

‘Aye! Now, come, come, you know, Mr. Smallweed,’ urges the trooper, constraining himself to speak as smoothly and confidentially as he can, holding the open letter in one hand and resting the broad knuckles of the other on his thigh, ‘a good lot of money has passed between us, and we are face to face at the present moment, and are both well aware of the understanding there has always been. I am prepared to do the usual thing which I have done regularly and to keep this matter going. I never got a letter like this from you before, and I have been a little put about by it this morning, because here’s my friend Matthew Bagnet, who, you know, had none of the money—‘
‘是啊！现在，来吧，来吧，你知道，斯莫威德先生，”士兵催促道，他一手拿着公开信，另一只手把宽指关节放在大腿上，尽量克制自己说话的流畅性和保密性，“我们之间已经度过了很多时光，此刻我们面对面，并且都清楚地意识到一直以来的理解。我准备做我经常做的平常事情，并让这件事继续下去。我以前从未收到过你写的这样的信，今天早上我对此感到有点不安，因为这是我的朋友马修·巴格内特，你知道，他没有钱——”

‘I DON’T know it, you know,’ says the old man quietly.
“你知道，我不知道，”老人平静地说。

‘Why, con-found you—it, I mean—I tell you so, don’t I?’
“为什么，让你感到困惑——我的意思是——我告诉过你了，不是吗？”

‘Oh, yes, you tell me so,’ returns Grandfather Smallweed. ‘But I don’t know it.’
“哦，是的，你是这么告诉我的，”斯莫威德祖父回答道。 “但我不知道。”

‘Well!’ says the trooper, swallowing his fire. ‘I know it.’
“好吧！”士兵吞下火说道。 '我知道这。'

Mr. Smallweed replies with excellent temper, ‘Ah! That’s quite another thing!’ And adds, ‘But it don’t matter. Mr. Bagnet’s situation is all one, whether or no.’
Smallweed先生脾气很好地回答道：“啊！那完全是另一回事！”并补充道，“但这并不重要。无论是否，巴格内特先生的情况都是如此。

The unfortunate George makes a great effort to arrange the affair comfortably and to propitiate Mr. Smallweed by taking him upon his own terms.
不幸的乔治竭尽全力把这件事安排得舒适，并按照自己的条件接受斯莫威德先生，以安抚他。

‘That’s just what I mean. As you say, Mr. Smallweed, here’s Matthew Bagnet liable to be fixed whether or no. Now, you see, that makes his good lady very uneasy in her mind, and me too, for whereas I’m a harurn-scarum sort of a good-for-nought that more kicks than halfpence come natural to, why he’s a steady family man, don’t you see? Now, Mr. Smallweed,’ says the trooper, gaining confidence as he proceeds in his soldierly mode of doing business, ‘although you and I are good friends enough in a certain sort of a way, I am well aware that I can’t ask you to let my friend Bagnet off entirely.’
‘这就是我的意思。正如你所说，斯莫尔韦德先生，马修·巴格内特无论是否能够得到修复。现在，你看，这让他的好夫人心里非常不安，我也是，因为虽然我是一个无用的人，自然而然地就会有比半便士更多的踢球，但为什么他是一个稳定的人顾家的男人，你看不出来吗？现在，斯莫尔韦德先生，”士兵说，在以军人的方式做事时获得了信心，“虽然你和我在某种程度上是足够好的朋友，但我很清楚我不能请你完全放过我的朋友巴格内特。”

‘Oh, dear, you are too modest. You can ASK me anything, Mr. George.’ (There is an ogreish kind of jocularity in Grandfather Smallweed to-day.)
‘哦，亲爱的，你太谦虚了。你可以问我任何事情，乔治先生。”（今天，斯莫威德祖父有一种食人魔般的幽默感。）

‘And you can refuse, you mean, eh? Or not you so much, perhaps, as your friend in the city? Ha ha ha!’
“你的意思是，你可以拒绝，是吗？或者，也许，你不像你在城里的朋友？哈哈哈！’

‘Ha ha ha!’ echoes Grandfather Smallweed. In such a very hard manner and with eyes so particularly green that Mr. Bagnet’s natural gravity is much deepened by the contemplation of that venerable man.
“哈哈哈！”斯莫威德爷爷附和道。巴格内特先生的态度如此严厉，眼睛特别绿，在这位可敬的人的沉思中，巴格内特先生的自然严肃感加深了很多。

‘Come!’ says the sanguine George. ‘I am glad to find we can be pleasant, because I want to arrange this pleasantly. Here’s my friend Bagnet, and here am I. We’ll settle the matter on the spot, if you please, Mr. Smallweed, in the usual way. And you’ll ease my friend Bagnet’s mind, and his family’s mind, a good deal if you’ll just mention to him what our understanding is.’
“来吧！”乐观的乔治说道。 “我很高兴发现我们可以愉快地相处，因为我想愉快地安排这一切。这是我的朋友巴格内特，我也在这里。如果您愿意，斯莫威德先生，我们会按照通常的方式当场解决问题。如果你向我的朋友巴格内特提及我们的理解，你就会让他和他的家人放心，这对他来说是一件好事。

Here some shrill spectre cries out in a mocking manner, ‘Oh, good gracious! Oh!’ Unless, indeed, it be the sportive Judy, who is found to be silent when the startled visitors look round, but whose chin has received a recent toss, expressive of derision and contempt. Mr. Bagnet’s gravity becomes yet more profound.
这时，有一个尖厉的幽灵以嘲讽的方式喊道：“哦，天哪！哦！”事实上，除非是活泼的朱迪，当惊愕的游客环顾四周时，她保持沉默，但她的下巴最近被甩动了，表现出嘲笑和蔑视。巴格内特先生的严肃性变得更加深刻。

‘But I think you asked me, Mr. George’—old Smallweed, who all this time has had the pipe in his hand, is the speaker now—‘I think you asked me, what did the letter mean?’
“但我想你问过我，乔治先生”——老斯莫威德一直拿着烟斗，现在是说话者——“我想你问过我，这封信是什么意思？”

‘Why, yes, I did,’ returns the trooper in his off-hand way, ‘but I don’t care to know particularly, if it’s all correct and pleasant.’
“嗯，是的，我做到了，”士兵随口答道，“但我并不想特别知道，这一切是否正确且令人愉快。”

Mr. Smallweed, purposely balking himself in an aim at the trooper’s head, throws the pipe on the ground and breaks it to pieces.
斯莫威德先生故意阻止自己瞄准士兵的头部，他把管子扔到地上，把它摔成了碎片。

‘That’s what it means, my dear friend. I’ll smash you. I’ll crumble you. I’ll powder you. Go to the devil!’
‘这就是它的意思，我亲爱的朋友。我会粉碎你。我会让你崩溃的。我给你粉。见鬼去吧！'

The two friends rise and look at one another. Mr. Bagnet’s gravity has now attained its profoundest point.
两个朋友站起来，互相看了一眼。巴格内特先生的严肃性现在已经达到了最深的地步。

‘Go to the devil!’ repeats the old man. ‘I’ll have no more of your pipe-smokings and swaggerings. What? You’re an independent dragoon, too! Go to my lawyer (you remember where; you have been there before) and show your independeuce now, will you? Come, my dear friend, there’s a chance for you. Open the street door, Judy; put these blusterers out! Call in help if they don’t go. Put ‘em out!’
“见鬼去吧！”老人重复道。 “我不会再受你的烟斗和大摇大摆的影响了。”什么？你也是独立的龙骑士！去见我的律师（你记得在哪里；你以前去过那里），现在就表现出你的独立性，好吗？来吧，我亲爱的朋友，你有机会。打开临街的门，朱迪；把这些咆哮者赶出去！如果他们不去，请寻求帮助。把他们赶出去！

He vociferates this so loudly that Mr. Bagnet, laying his hands on the shoulders of his comrade before the latter can recover from his amazement, gets him on the outside of the street door, which is instantly slammed by the triumphant Judy. Utterly confounded, Mr. George awhile stands looking at the knocker. Mr. Bagnet, in a perfect abyss of gravity, walks up and down before the little parlour window like a sentry and looks in every time he passes, apparently revolving something in his mind.
他喊得如此大声，以至于巴格内特先生在他的同伴从惊讶中恢复过来之前，把手放在了他的同伴的肩膀上，把他带到了街门的外面，得意洋洋的朱迪立刻把门关上了。乔治先生完全困惑了，他站在那里看着门环。巴格内特先生在一个完美的重力深渊中，像哨兵一样在客厅的小窗户前走来走去，每次经过时都会向里张望，显然他的脑子里在盘旋着什么。

‘Come, Mat,’ says Mr. George when he has recovered himself, ‘we must try the lawyer. Now, what do you think of this rascal?’
“来吧，马特，”乔治先生恢复过来后说道，“我们必须去找律师。”现在，你觉得这个无赖怎么样？

Mr. Bagnet, stopping to take a farewell look into the parlour, replies with one shake of his head directed at the interior, ‘If my old girl had been here—I’d have told him!’ Having so discharged himself of the subject of his cogitations, he falls into step and marches off with the trooper, shoulder to shoulder.
巴格内特先生停下来，向客厅里告别，朝室内摇了摇头，回答道：“如果我的老女儿在这里的话——我就会告诉他了！”说完就离开了这个话题。考虑到这一点，他迈出了步伐，与士兵并肩而行。

When they present themselves in Lincoln’s Inn Fields, Mr. Tulkinghorn is engaged and not to be seen. He is not at all willing to see them, for when they have waited a full hour, and the clerk, on his bell being rung, takes the opportunity of mentioning as much, he brings forth no more encouraging message than that Mr. Tulkinghorn has nothing to say to them and they had better not wait. They do wait, however, with the perseverance of military tactics, and at last the bell rings again and the client in possession comes out of Mr. Tulkinghorn’s room.
当他们出现在林肯因客栈时，图金霍恩先生正忙着，却不见踪影。他根本不愿意见他们，因为当他们等了整整一个小时，店员在铃响时，趁机提及了这些，他没有带来比图尔金霍恩先生更令人鼓舞的信息。无话可说，他们最好不要等待。然而，他们确实以军事策略的毅力等待着，最后铃声再次响起，拥有的客户从图金霍恩先生的房间里出来。

The client is a handsome old lady, no other than Mrs. Rouncewell, housekeeper at Chesney Wold. She comes out of the sanctuary with a fair old-fashioned curtsy and softly shuts the door. She is treated with some distinction there, for the clerk steps out of his pew to show her through the outer office and to let her out. The old lady is thanking him for his attention when she observes the comrades in waiting.
客户是一位英俊的老太太，正是切斯尼沃尔德的管家朗斯韦尔夫人。她走出圣所，行了一个老式的屈膝礼，轻轻地关上了门。她在那里受到了某种特殊的待遇，因为店员从座位上走出来，带她穿过外部办公室，然后让她出去。老太太一边观察等待的同志，一边感谢他的关注。

‘I beg your pardon, sir, but I think those gentlemen are military?’
“请您原谅，先生，但我认为那些先生们都是军人？”

The clerk referring the question to them with his eye, and Mr. George not turning round from the almanac over the fire-place. Mr. Bagnet takes upon himself to reply, ‘Yes, ma’am. Formerly.’
店员用眼睛向他们提出这个问题，而乔治先生则没有从壁炉上方的年鉴上转过身来。巴格内特先生亲自回答道：“是的，女士。”以前。'

‘I thought so. I was sure of it. My heart warms, gentlemen, at the sight of you. It always does at the sight of such. God bless you, gentlemen! You’ll excuse an old woman, but I had a son once who went for a soldier. A fine handsome youth he was, and good in his bold way, though some people did disparage him to his poor mother. I ask your pardon for troubling you, sir. God bless you, gentlemen!’
'我是这么想的。我确信这一点。先生们，一看到你们，我的心就暖暖的。看到这样的事情总是如此。上帝保佑你们，先生们！请原谅一位老妇人，但我有一个儿子曾经当过兵。他是个英俊的年轻人，性格大胆，尽管有些人确实在他可怜的母亲面前贬低他。先生，请您原谅，给您添麻烦了。上帝保佑你们，先生们！”

‘Same to you, ma’am!’ returns Mr. Bagnet with right good will.
“您也一样，女士！”巴格内特先生善意地回答道。

There is something very touching in the earnestness of the old lady’s voice and in the tremble that goes through her quaint old figure. But Mr. George is so occupied with the almanac over the fireplace (calculating the coming months by it perhaps) that he does not look round until she has gone away and the door is closed upon her.
老太太的语气诚恳，她那古雅的身躯颤抖不已，非常令人感动。但乔治先生正忙着看壁炉上的年鉴（也许是用它来计算未来几个月），直到她走开、门对她关上时，他才回头看一眼。

‘George,’ Mr. Bagnet gruffly whispers when he does turn from the almanac at last. ‘Don’t be cast down! ‘Why, soldiers, why—should we be melancholy, boys?’ Cheer up, my hearty!’
“乔治，”当巴格内特先生终于从年鉴上转过身来时，他粗声粗气地低声说道。 ‘别灰心丧气！ “为什么，士兵们，为什么——我们应该忧郁吗，孩子们？振作起来，我的心肝宝贝！”

The clerk having now again gone in to say that they are still there and Mr. Tulkinghorn being heard to return with some irascibility, ‘Let ‘em come in then!’ they pass into the great room with the painted ceiling and find him standing before the fire.
店员现在再次进去说他们还在那儿，有人听到图尔金霍恩先生带着一些愤怒回来了，“那就让他们进来吧！”他们走进了天花板漆成的大房间，发现他站在前面火。

‘Now, you men, what do you want? Sergeant, I told you the last time I saw you that I don’t desire your company here.’
‘现在，你们这些人，你们想要什么？中士，我上次见到你时就告诉过你，我不希望你在这里陪伴。

Sergeant replies—dashed within the last few minutes as to his usual manner of speech, and even as to his usual carriage—that he has received this letter, has been to Mr. Smallweed about it, and has been referred there.
警官在最后几分钟内回答说，他已经收到了这封信，已经向斯莫威德先生报告了此事，并且已被转介到那里。

‘I have nothing to say to you,’ rejoins Mr. Tulkinghorn. ‘If you get into debt, you must pay your debts or take the consequences. You have no occasion to come here to learn that, I suppose?’
“我没什么可对你说的，”图尔金霍恩先生回答道。 ‘如果你负债了，你必须偿还债务，否则后果自负。我想你没有机会来这里了解这一点吧？

Sergeant is sorry to say that he is not prepared with the money.
中士很遗憾地说他没有准备好这笔钱。

‘Very well! Then the other man—this man, if this is he—must pay it for you.’
'很好！然后另一个人——这个人，如果是他的话——必须替你付钱。

Sergeant is sorry to add that the other man is not prepared with the money either.
中士很抱歉地补充说，另一个人也没有准备好这笔钱。

‘Very well! Then you must pay it between you or you must both be sued for it and both suffer. You have had the money and must refund it. You are not to pocket other people’s pounds, shillings, and pence and escape scot-free.’
'很好！然后你们必须共同支付这笔费用，否则你们都必须因此被起诉并双双受苦。您已经收到了钱，必须退还。你不能把别人的英镑、先令和便士装进口袋然后逍遥法外。”

The lawyer sits down in his easy-chair and stirs the fire. Mr. George hopes he will have the goodness to—
律师坐在安乐椅上，搅动火。乔治先生希望他能够——

‘I tell you, sergeant, I have nothing to say to you. I don’t like your associates and don’t want you here. This matter is not at all in my course of practice and is not in my office. Mr. Smallweed is good enough to offer these affairs to me, but they are not in my way. You must go to Melchisedech’s in Clifford’s Inn.’
“我告诉你，中士，我没什么可对你说的。我不喜欢你的同事，也不希望你在这里。这件事根本不属于我的执业范围，也不属于我的办公室。斯莫威德先生足够好，可以向我提供这些事务，但它们并不妨碍我。你必须去克利福德旅馆的麦基洗德店。

‘I must make an apology to you, sir,’ says Mr. George, ‘for pressing myself upon you with so little encouragement—which is almost as unpleasant to me as it can be to you—but would you let me say a private word to you?’
“我必须向您道歉，先生，”乔治先生说，“因为我没有给您太多鼓励——这对我来说几乎和对您一样不愉快——但是您能允许我私下说一句吗？”给你的话？

Mr. Tulkinghorn rises with his hands in his pockets and walks into one of the window recesses. ‘Now! I have no time to waste.’ In the midst of his perfect assumption of indifference, he directs a sharp look at the trooper, taking care to stand with his own back to the light and to have the other with his face towards it.
图金霍恩先生站起身来，双手插在口袋里，走进窗户的一处凹处。 '现在！我没有时间可以浪费。”在他装出一副冷漠的样子时，他锐利地看了那个士兵一眼，小心翼翼地让自己背对着灯光，而另一个则面朝灯光。

‘Well, sir,’ says Mr. George, ‘this man with me is the other party implicated in this unfortunate affair—nominally, only nominally— and my sole object is to prevent his getting into trouble on my account. He is a most respectable man with a wife and family, formerly in the Royal Artillery—‘
“好吧，先生，”乔治先生说，“和我在一起的这个人就是这起不幸事件的另一方——名义上的，只是名义上的——而我唯一的目的就是防止他因为我的缘故而陷入麻烦。”他是一位最受尊敬的人，有妻子和家庭，以前在皇家炮兵部队服役——”

‘My friend, I don’t care a pinch of snuff for the whole Royal Artillery establishment—officers, men, tumbrils, waggons, horses, guns, and ammunition.’
“我的朋友，我对整个皇家炮兵部队一点鼻烟都不在乎——军官、士兵、战车、马车、马匹、枪支和弹药。”

‘‘Tis likely, sir. But I care a good deal for Bagnet and his wife and family being injured on my account. And if I could bring them through this matter, I should have no help for it but to give up without any other consideration what you wanted of me the other day.’
“这很可能，先生。但我非常关心巴格内特和他的妻子和家人因为我的原因而受伤。如果我能让他们解决这件事，我就别无选择，只能放弃，不考虑你那天对我的要求。

‘Have you got it here?’
“你拿到这里了吗？”

‘I have got it here, sir.’
“我已经拿到这里了，先生。”

‘Sergeant,’ the lawyer proceeds in his dry passionless manner, far more hopeless in the dealing with than any amount of vehemence, ‘make up your mind while I speak to you, for this is final. After I have finished speaking I have closed the subject, and I won’t reopen it. Understand that. You can leave here, for a few days, what you say you have brought here if you choose; you can take it away at once if you choose. In case you choose to leave it here, I can do this for you—I can replace this matter on its old footing, and I can go so far besides as to give you a written undertaking that this man Bagnet shall never be troubled in any way until you have been proceeded against to the utmost, that your means shall be exhausted before the creditor looks to his. This is in fact all but freeing him. Have you decided?’
“警官，”律师以他那冷漠无情的态度继续说道，在处理问题上比任何激烈的态度都更加绝望，“在我对你说话的时候你就下定决心吧，因为这是最终决定。”我说完我就结束了这个话题，我不会再展开了。明白。如果你愿意的话，你可以把你所说的带来的东西离开这里几天；如果您愿意，可以立即将其带走。如果你选择把它留在这里，我可以为你做这件事——我可以把这件事放在原来的基础上，而且我甚至可以给你一份书面保证，这个巴格内特永远不会遇到任何麻烦。直到你受到最大程度的打击，在债权人求助于他之前，你的钱财就已经耗尽了。事实上，这几乎让他获得了自由。你决定了吗？'

The trooper puts his hand into his breast and answers with a long breath, ‘I must do it, sir.’
士兵把手伸进胸前，长长地吸了一口气，回答道：“我必须这么做，长官。”

So Mr. Tulkinghorn, putting on his spectacles, sits down and writes the undertaking, which he slowly reads and explains to Bagnet, who has all this time been staring at the ceiling and who puts his hand on his bald head again, under this new verbal shower-bath, and seems exceedingly in need of the old girl through whom to express his sentiments. The trooper then takes from his breast-pocket a folded paper, which he lays with an unwilling hand at the lawyer’s elbow. ‘‘Tis ouly a letter of instructions, sir. The last I ever had from him.’
于是，图金霍恩先生戴上眼镜，坐下来写下承诺书，他慢慢地读完并向巴格内特解释。言语上的沐浴，似乎非常需要老姑娘通过她来表达自己的情感。然后，警察从胸前的口袋里拿出一张折叠好的纸，他不情愿地把手放在律师的肘部。 “这只是一封指示信，先生。这是我从他那里得到的最后一次。

Look at a millstone, Mr. George, for some change in its expression, and you will find it quite as soon as in the face of Mr. Tulkinghorn when he opens and reads the letter! He refolds it and lays it in his desk with a countenance as unperturbable as death.
乔治先生，看看磨石的表情是否有一些变化，你就会发现，当图尔金霍恩先生打开并阅读这封信时，他的脸上就会出现同样的变化！他把它重新折叠起来，放在办公桌上，脸上的表情平静得像死人一样。

Nor has he anything more to say or do but to nod once in the same frigid and discourteous manner and to say briefly, ‘You can go. Show these men out, there!’ Being shown out, they repair to Mr. Bagnet’s residence to dine.
他也没什么可说的或可做的，只是以同样冷漠无礼的方式点了点头，简短地说：“你可以走了。”把这些人带出去！” 被带出去后，他们回到巴格内特先生的住处去吃饭。

Boiled beef and greens constitute the day’s variety on the former repast of boiled pork and greens, and Mrs. Bagnet serves out the meal in the same way and seasons it with the best of temper, being that rare sort of old girl that she receives Good to her arms without a hint that it might be Better and catches light from any little spot of darkness near her. The spot on this occasion is the darkened brow of Mr. George; he is unusually thoughtful and depressed. At first Mrs. Bagnet trusts to the combined endearments of Quebec and Malta to restore him, but finding those young ladies sensible that their existing Bluffy is not the Bluffy of their usual frolicsome acquaintance, she winks off the light infantry and leaves him to deploy at leisure on the open ground of the domestic hearth.
煮牛肉和蔬菜构成了当天的菜品，之前的饭菜是煮猪肉和蔬菜，巴格尼特太太以同样的方式上菜，并以最好的脾气调味，她是那种罕见的老女孩，她受到了良好的对待。到她的怀里，没有任何暗示可能会更好，并从她附近的任何黑暗小点中捕捉到光。这次的亮点是乔治先生深色的眉毛。他异常深思熟虑且忧郁。起初，巴格内特夫人相信魁北克和马耳他的共同爱戴可以让他恢复健康，但发现那些年轻女士们意识到，她们现有的布拉夫不是他们平时嬉闹的熟人中的布拉夫，她对轻步兵眨了眨眼，让他部署在在家庭壁炉的空地上休闲。

But he does not. He remains in close order, clouded and depressed. During the lengthy cleaning up and pattening process, when he and Mr. Bagnet are supplied with their pipes, he is no better than he was at dinner. He forgets to smoke, looks at the fire and ponders, lets his pipe out, fills the breast of Mr. Bagnet with perturbation and dismay by showing that he has no enjoyment of tobacco.
但他没有。他仍然保持着紧密的秩序，阴沉而沮丧。在漫长的清理和拍打过程中，当他和巴格尼特先生拿到烟斗时，他的情况并不比晚餐时好多少。他忘记了抽烟，看着炉火沉思，拔出烟斗，表现出他不喜欢烟草，这让巴格尼特先生的胸膛充满了不安和沮丧。

Therefore when Mrs. Bagnet at last appears, rosy from the invigorating pail, and sits down to her work, Mr. Bagnet growls, ‘Old girl!’ and winks monitions to her to find out what’s the matter.
因此，当巴格尼特夫人终于出现，她因提神桶而脸色红润，坐下来工作时，巴格尼特先生咆哮道：“老姑娘！”并向她眨眼，示意她看看出了什么事。

‘Why, George!’ says Mrs. Bagnet, quietly threading her needle. ‘How low you are!’
“为什么，乔治！”巴格内特太太一边说，一边静静地穿针线。 ‘你多么低贱啊！’

‘Am I? Not good company? Well, I am afraid I am not.’
‘我是吗？不是好公司？好吧，恐怕我不是。

‘He ain’t at all like Blulfy, mother!’ cries little Malta.
“他一点也不像布拉菲，妈妈！”小马耳他喊道。

‘Because he ain’t well, I think, mother,’ adds Quebec.
“我想，因为他身体不太好，妈妈，”魁北克补充道。

‘Sure that’s a bad sign not to be like Bluffy, too!’ returns the trooper, kissing the young damsels. ‘But it’s true,’ with a sigh, ‘true, I am afraid. These little ones are always right!’
“当然，这也是一个不好的兆头，不能像布拉夫一样！”士兵回答道，亲吻了年轻的​​姑娘们。 “但这是真的，”叹了口气，“恐怕是真的。”这些小家伙总是对的！”

‘George,’ says Mrs. Bagnet, working busily, ‘if I thought you cross enough to think of anything that a shrill old soldier’s wife—who could have bitten her tongue off afterwards and ought to have done it almost—said this morning, I don’t know what I shouldn’t say to you now.’
“乔治，”巴格内特夫人忙着工作，“如果我认为你会生气，会想到今天早上一个尖刻的老士兵的妻子——她本可以咬掉自己的舌头，而且几乎应该这么做——说的话，我不知道现在我不应该对你说些什么。”

‘My kind soul of a darling,’ returns the trooper. ‘Not a morsel of it.’
“亲爱的，我善良的灵魂，”士兵回答道。 “一点也没有。”

‘Because really and truly, George, what I said and meant to say was that I trusted Lignum to you and was sure you’d bring him through it. And you HAVE brought him through it, noble!’
“因为，乔治，我说的和想说的是，我真的相信你，并且相信你会带领他度过难关。”你已经带领他度过了难关，高贵的！”

‘Thankee, my dear!’ says George. ‘I am glad of your good opinion.’
“谢谢，亲爱的！”乔治说。 “我很高兴你的好意见。”

In giving Mrs. Bagnet’s hand, with her work in it, a friendly shake—for she took her seat beside him—the trooper’s attention is attracted to her face. After looking at it for a little while as she plies her needle, he looks to young Woolwich, sitting on his stool in the corner, and beckons that fifer to him.
当巴格尼特夫人坐在他旁边时，他友好地握了握巴格尼特夫人的手，她的手上拿着她的工作，警察的注意力被她的脸吸引了。当她穿针的时候，他看了一会儿，然后看着坐在角落里凳子上的年轻伍尔维奇，向他招手示意。

‘See there, my boy,’ says George, very gently smoothing the mother’s hair with his hand, ‘there’s a good loving forehead for you! All bright with love of you, my boy. A little touched by the sun and the weather through following your father about and taking care of you, but as fresh and wholesome as a ripe apple on a tree.’
“看那儿，我的孩子，”乔治一边说，一边用手轻轻地抚平母亲的头发，“你的额头真可爱！”一切都充满了对你的爱，我的孩子。跟随你的父亲并照顾你，让阳光和天气有点感动，但就像树上熟透的苹果一样新鲜和健康。

Mr. Bagnet’s face expresses, so far as in its wooden material lies, the highest approbation and acquiescence.
就其木质材料而言，巴格内特先生的脸表达了最高的认可和默许。

‘The time will come, my boy,’ pursues the trooper, ‘when this hair of your mother’s will be grey, and this forehead all crossed and re-crossed with wrinkles, and a fine old lady she’ll be then. Take care, while you are young, that you can think in those days, ‘I never whitened a hair of her dear head—I never marked a sorrowful line in her face!’ For of all the many things that you can think of when you are a man, you had better have THAT by you, Woolwich!’
“总有一天，我的孩子，”士兵继续说道，“到那时，你母亲的头发就会变白，额头上布满皱纹，那时她就会成为一位美丽的老太太了。”当你还年轻的时候，要小心，在那些日子里你可以这样想：“我从来没有白过她亲爱的头上的一根头发——我从来没有在她脸上画过一条悲伤的皱纹！”因为在你能想到的所有事情中，你是一个男人，你最好随身携带这个，伍尔维奇！”

Mr. George concludes by rising from his chair, seating the boy beside his mother in it, and saying, with something of a hurry about him, that he’ll smoke his pipe in the street a bit.
最后，乔治先生从椅子上站起来，让男孩坐在他母亲旁边，语气匆忙地说，他要在街上抽一会儿烟斗。

CHAPTER XXXV
第三十五章


Esther’s Narrative
以斯帖的叙述

I lay ill through several weeks, and the usual tenor of my life became like an old remembrance. But this was not the effect of time so much as of the change in all my habits made by the helplessness and inaction of a sick-room. Before I had been confined to it many days, everything else seemed to have retired into a remote distance where there was little or no separation between the various stages of my life which had been really divided by years. In falling ill, I seemed to have crossed a dark lake and to have left all my experiences, mingled together by the great distance, on the healthy shore.
我病了好几个星期，平常的生活就像是一种古老的回忆。但这与其说是时间的影响，不如说是病房里的无助和无所事事改变了我的所有习惯。在我被限制在其中很多天之前，其他一切似乎都退到了遥远的距离，在那里，我生命的各个阶段之间几乎没有或根本没有分离，而这些阶段实际上是按岁月划分的。生病时，我仿佛跨过一片漆黑的湖水，把所有由遥远的距离交织在一起的经历留在了健康的岸边。

My housekeeping duties, though at first it caused me great anxiety to think that they were unperformed, were soon as far off as the oldest of the old duties at Greenleaf or the summer afternoons when I went home from school with my portfolio under my arm, and my childish shadow at my side, to my godmother’s house. I had never known before how short life really was and into how small a space the mind could put it.
我的家政职责，虽然一开始让我非常焦虑，认为它们没有得到履行，但很快就远离了格林利夫最古老的旧职责或夏天的下午，当我放学回家时，我的文件夹夹在腋下，和我幼稚的影子在我身边，去我教母的家。我以前从来不知道生命实际上是多么短暂，也不知道心灵能把它放在多么狭小的空间里。

While I was very ill, the way in which these divisions of time became confused with one another distressed my mind exceedingly. At once a child, an elder girl, and the little woman I had been so happy as, I was not only oppressed by cares and difficulties adapted to each station, but by the great perplexity of endlessly trying to reconcile them. I suppose that few who have not been in such a condition can quite understand what I mean or what painful unrest arose from this source.
当我病得很重时，这些时间的划分彼此混淆，让我感到非常痛苦。我既是一个孩子，一个年长的女孩，又是一个小女人，我曾经如此幸福，我不仅被适应每个处境的忧虑和困难所压迫，而且被无休止地试图调和它们的巨大困惑所压迫。我想，没有经历过这种情况的人很少能够完全理解我的意思，或者由此产生的痛苦的不安。

For the same reason I am almost afraid to hint at that time in my disorder—it seemed one long night, but I believe there were both nights and days in it—when I laboured up colossal staircases, ever striving to reach the top, and ever turned, as I have seen a worm in a garden path, by some obstruction, and labouring again. I knew perfectly at intervals, and I think vaguely at most times, that I was in my bed; and I talked with Charley, and felt her touch, and knew her very well; yet I would find myself complaining, ‘Oh, more of these never-ending stairs, Charley—more and more—piled up to the sky’, I think!’ and labouring on again.
出于同样的原因，我几乎不敢暗示当时我的混乱——那似乎是一个漫长的夜晚，但我相信其中既有黑夜，也有白天——当我费力地爬上巨大的楼梯，一直努力到达顶端，并且就像我在花园小路上看到的一条蠕虫一样，由于某些障碍，它会再次转动，然后再次劳动。我时不时地清楚地知道，而且大多数时候我也模模糊糊地想，我是在床上。我和查理交谈，感受到她的触摸，并且非常了解她。但我会发现自己在抱怨，“哦，更多这些永无休止的楼梯，查理——越来越多——堆积到天空，我想！”然后又继续努力。

Dare I hint at that worse time when, strung together somewhere in great black space, there was a flaming necklace, or ring, or starry circle of some kind, of which I was one of the beads! And when my only prayer was to be taken off from the rest and when it was such inexplicable agony and misery to be a part of the dreadful thing?
我敢暗示那个更糟糕的时刻，在巨大的黑色空间中的某个地方，有一条燃烧的项链、戒指或某种星星圈，而我就是其中的一颗珠子！当我唯一的祈祷是脱离其他祈祷时，当成为这可怕的事情的一部分是如此难以解释的痛苦和痛苦时？

Perhaps the less I say of these sick experiences, the less tedious and the more intelligible I shall be. I do not recall them to make others unhappy or because I am now the least unhappy in remembering them. It may be that if we knew more of such strange afflictions we might be the better able to alleviate their intensity.
也许我越少谈论这些病态的经历，我就会越不乏味，也越容易理解。我记起它们并不是为了让别人不高兴，也不是因为我现在想起它们最不高兴。如果我们更多地了解这些奇怪的痛苦，我们可能就能更好地减轻它们的强度。

The repose that succeeded, the long delicious sleep, the blissful rest, when in my weakness I was too calm to have any care for myself and could have heard (or so I think now) that I was dying, with no other emotion than with a pitying love for those I left behind—this state can be perhaps more widely understood. I was in this state when I first shrunk from the light as it twinkled on me once more, and knew with a boundless joy for which no words are rapturous enough that I should see again.
成功的休息，漫长而美味的睡眠，幸福的休息，当我在虚弱的时候，我太平静了，无法照顾自己，并且可以听到（或者我现在这么认为）我快要死了，除了与对我身后的人的怜悯之爱——这种状态也许可以被更广泛地理解。当我第一次在光再次闪烁时退缩时，我就处于这种状态，我带着无限的喜悦知道，没有任何言语可以描述我应该再次看到它。

I had heard my Ada crying at the door, day and night; I had heard her calling to me that I was cruel and did not love her; I had heard her praying and imploring to be let in to nurse and comfort me and to leave my bedside no more; but I had only said, when I could speak, ‘Never, my sweet girl, never!’ and I had over and over again reminded Charley that she was to keep my darling from the room whether I lived or died. Charley had been true to me in that time of need, and with her little hand and her great heart had kept the door fast.
我日日夜夜都听到我的艾达在门口哭泣；我听到她对我说我很残忍，不爱她；我听到她祈祷并恳求让她进来护理和安慰我，并且不要再离开我的床边。但当我能说话时，我才说：“永远不会，我可爱的女孩，永远不会！”我一遍又一遍地提醒查理，无论我是生是死，她都不能让我的宝贝进入房间。在我需要帮助的时候，查理对我很忠诚，用她的小手和伟大的心把门关得严严实实。

But now, my sight strengthening and the glorious light coming every day more fully and brightly on me, I could read the letters that my dear wrote to me every morning and evening and could put them to my lips and lay my cheek upon them with no fear of hurting her. I could see my little maid, so tender and so careful, going about the two rooms setting everything in order and speaking cheerfully to Ada from the open window again. I could understand the stillness in the house and the thoughtfulness it expressed on the part of all those who had always been so good to me. I could weep in the exquisite felicity of my heart and be as happy in my weakness as ever I had been in my strength.
但现在，我的视力增强了，灿烂的光芒每天都更加充分和明亮地照在我身上，我可以每天早上和晚上阅读我亲爱的写给我的信，并且可以将它们放在我的嘴唇上，将我的脸贴在它们上，而无需担心它们。害怕伤害她。我可以看到我的小女仆，那么温柔，那么细心，在两个房间里走来走去，把一切都安排妥当，并再次从开着的窗户里愉快地和艾达说话。我能理解房子里的寂静，以及那些一直对我那么好的人所表达的体贴。我可以在内心的美妙幸福中哭泣，在我的软弱中像在我的力量中一样快乐。

By and by my strength began to be restored. Instead of lying, with so strange a calmness, watching what was done for me, as if it were done for some one else whom I was quietly sorry for, I helped it a little, and so on to a little more and much more, until I became useful to myself, and interested, and attached to life again.
渐渐地，我的体力开始恢复。我没有撒谎，带着一种奇怪的平静，看着为我所做的一切，就好像这是为另一个我默默地感到抱歉的人所做的那样，我帮了一点忙，依此类推，越来越多，直到我对自己变得有用，变得有兴趣，并且再次热爱生活。

How well I remember the pleasant afternoon when I was raised in bed with pillows for the first time to enjoy a great tea-drinking with Charley! The little creature—sent into the world, surely, to minister to the weak and sick—was so happy, and so busy, and stopped so often in her preparations to lay her head upon my bosom, and fondle me, and cry with joyful tears she was so glad, she was so glad, that I was obliged to say, ‘Charley, if you go on in this way, I must lie down again, my darling, for I am weaker than I thought I was!’ So Charley became as quiet as a mouse and took her bright face here and there across and across the two rooms, out of the shade into the divine sunshine, and out of the sunshine into the shade, while I watched her peacefully. When all her preparations were concluded and the pretty tea-table with its little delicacies to tempt me, and its white cloth, and its flowers, and everything so lovingly and beautifully arranged for me by Ada downstairs, was ready at the bedside, I felt sure I was steady enough to say something to Charley that was not new to my thoughts.
我清楚地记得那个愉快的下午，我第一次在床上垫着枕头长大，和查理一起喝茶！这个小生物——当然是被派到这个世界上来照顾弱者和病人的——是如此快乐，如此忙碌，经常停下来准备把头靠在我怀里，抚摸我，高兴地哭泣。她流着泪，她太高兴了，她太高兴了，我不得不说：“查理，如果你继续这样下去，我必须再次躺下，亲爱的，因为我比我想象的还要虚弱！”查莉变得像老鼠一样安静，她那张明亮的脸在两个房间里来回走动，从阴凉处进入神圣的阳光，从阳光处进入阴凉处，而我则平静地看着她。当她所有的准备工作都完成后，漂亮的茶几、诱人的小菜、白桌布、鲜花，以及楼下艾达为我精心布置的一切，都准备在床边，我感到我确信我足够稳定，可以对查理说一些对我来说并不新鲜的事情。

First I complimented Charley on the room, and indeed it was so fresh and airy, so spotless and neat, that I could scarce believe I had been lying there so long. This delighted Charley, and her face was brighter than before.
首先，我称赞查理的房间，事实上，它是那么清新、通风、那么一尘不染、那么整洁，我简直不敢相信我已经在那里躺了这么久了。这让查理很高兴，她的脸色比以前更加明亮。

‘Yet, Charley,’ said I, looking round, ‘I miss something, surely, that I am accustomed to?’
“然而，查理，”我环顾四周说道，“我肯定想念一些我已经习惯的东西吗？”

Poor little Charley looked round too and pretended to shake her head as if there were nothing absent.
可怜的小查理也环顾四周，假装摇头，好像什么事都没有发生。

‘Are the pictures all as they used to be?’ I asked her.
“这些照片还和以前一样吗？”我问她。

‘Every one of them, miss,’ said Charley.
“他们每一个人，小姐，”查理说。

‘And the furniture, Charley?’
“查理，家具呢？”

‘Except where I have moved it about to make more room, miss.’
“除了我把它移到了哪里以腾出更多空间，小姐。”

‘And yet,’ said I, ‘I miss some familiar object. Ah, I know what it is, Charley! It’s the looking-glass.’
“然而，”我说，“我想念一些熟悉的东西。啊，我知道那是什么，查理！这是镜子。

Charley got up from the table, making as if she had forgotten something, and went into the next room; and I heard her sob there.
查理从桌子上站起来，好像她忘记了什么，走进了隔壁房间。我听到她在那里抽泣。

I had thought of this very often. I was now certain of it. I could thank God that it was not a shock to me now. I called Charley back, and when she came—at first pretending to smile, but as she drew nearer to me, looking grieved—I took her in my arms and said, ‘It matters very little, Charley. I hope I can do without my old face very well.’
我经常想到这一点。我现在可以肯定了。我感谢上帝，现在这对我来说并不感到震惊。我给查理回了电话，当她回来时——起初假装微笑，但当她靠近我时，她看起来很悲伤——我把她抱在怀里说：“这没什么关系，查理。”我希望我能在没有这张老脸的情况下过得很好。

I was presently so far advanced as to be able to sit up in a great chair and even giddily to walk into the adjoining room, leaning on Charley. The mirror was gone from its usual place in that room too, but what I had to bear was none the harder to bear for that.
我现在已经可以在一张大椅子上坐起来了，甚至可以靠在查理身上，头晕地走进隔壁的房间。房间里的镜子也从原来的位置消失了，但我所承受的却并不那么难以承受。

My guardian had throughout been earnest to visit me, and there was now no good reason why I should deny myself that happiness. He came one morning, and when he first came in, could only hold me in his embrace and say, ‘My dear, dear girl!’ I had long known—who could know better?—what a deep fountain of affection and generosity his heart was; and was it not worth my trivial suffering and change to fill such a place in it? ‘Oh, yes!’ I thought. ‘He has seen me, and he loves me better than he did; he has seen me and is even fonder of me than he was before; and what have I to mourn for!’
我的监护人一直很热心地来看望我，现在我没有充分的理由拒绝自己的幸福。一天早上他来了，当他第一次进来时，只能把我抱在怀里说：“我亲爱的，亲爱的女孩！”我早就知道——谁能知道得更清楚？——他的感情和慷慨是多么深厚的源泉。心是；为了填补其中的一个空缺，难道不值得我受些微不足道的痛苦和改变吗？ “哦，是的！”我想。 ‘他见过我，而且比以前更爱我；他见过我，甚至比以前更喜欢我了；我有什么可哀悼的！

He sat down by me on the sofa, supporting me with his arm. For a little while he sat with his hand over his face, but when he removed it, fell into his usual manner. There never can have been, there never can be, a pleasanter manner.
他坐在我旁边的沙发上，用手臂支撑着我。他用手捂着脸坐了一会儿，但当他把手拿开时，又恢复了平常的态度。从来没有、永远不可能有比这更令人愉快的方式了。

‘My little woman,’ said he, ‘what a sad time this has been. Such an inflexible little woman, too, through all!’
“我的小女人，”他说，“这是多么悲伤的时刻啊。”真是个不灵活的小女人啊！

‘Only for the best, guardian,’ said I.
“只为最好的，监护人，”我说。

‘For the best?’ he repeated tenderly. ‘Of course, for the best. But here have Ada and I been perfectly forlorn and miserable; here has your friend Caddy been coming and going late and early; here has every one about the house been utterly lost and dejected; here has even poor Rick been writing—to ME too—in his anxiety for you!’
“为了最好？”他温柔地重复道。 ‘当然，这是最好的。但艾达和我在这里感到非常孤独和痛苦；你的朋友凯迪来得迟、去得早；房子里的每个人都完全迷失和沮丧。就连可怜的里克也写信给我——因为他对你的焦虑！

I had read of Caddy in Ada’s letters, but not of Richard. I told him so.
我在艾达的信中读到过凯迪，但没有读过理查德。我告诉他了。

‘Why, no, my dear,’ he replied. ‘I have thought it better not to mention it to her.’
“为什么，不，亲爱的，”他回答道。 “我觉得最好不要向她提起这件事。”

‘And you speak of his writing to YOU,’ said I, repeating his emphasis. ‘As if it were not natural for him to do so, guardian; as if he could write to a better friend!’
“你谈到了他写给你的信，”我说，重复了他的强调。 “监护人，好像他这样做并不自然；就好像他可以写信给一个更好的朋友一样！

‘He thinks he could, my love,’ returned my guardian, ‘and to many a better. The truth is, he wrote to me under a sort of protest while unable to write to you with any hope of an answer—wrote coldly, haughtily, distantly, resentfully. Well, dearest little woman, we must look forbearingly on it. He is not to blame. Jarndyce and Jarndyce has warped him out of himself and perverted me in his eyes. I have known it do as bad deeds, and worse, many a time. If two angels could be concerned in it, I believe it would change their nature.’
“他认为他可以，我的爱人，”我的监护人回答道，“而且可以让很多人变得更好。”事实是，他写信给我是出于某种抗议，但却无法带着任何答复的希望写信给你——写得冷漠、傲慢、疏远、怨恨。好吧，最亲爱的小女人，我们必须耐心地看待它。他不应该受到责备。贾迪斯和贾迪斯扭曲了他，扭曲了他眼中的我。我知道很多时候这样做都是坏事，甚至更糟。如果两个天使能够参与其中，我相信这会改变他们的本性。

‘It has not changed yours, guardian.’
“它并没有改变你的，监护人。”

‘Oh, yes, it has, my dear,’ he said laughingly. ‘It has made the south wind easterly, I don’t know how often. Rick mistrusts and suspects me—goes to lawyers, and is taught to mistrust and suspect me. Hears I have conflicting interests, claims clashing against his and what not. Whereas, heaven knows that if I could get out of the mountains of wiglomeration on which my unfortunate name has been so long bestowed (which I can’t) or could level them by the extinction of my own original right (which I can’t either, and no human power ever can, anyhow, I believe, to such a pass have we got), I would do it this hour. I would rather restore to poor Rick his proper nature than be endowed with all the money that dead suitors, broken, heart and soul, upon the wheel of Chancery, have left unclaimed with the Accountant-General—and that’s money enough, my dear, to be cast into a pyramid, in memory of Chancery’s transcendent wickedness.’
“哦，是的，亲爱的，”他笑着说。 ‘它使南风转为东风，我不知道发生了多少次。里克不信任和怀疑我——去找了律师，并被教导要不信任和怀疑我。听说我有利益冲突，主张与他冲突等等。然而，天知道，如果我能够摆脱我不幸的名字长期以来被赋予的混乱山脉（我不能），或者可以通过消灭我自己的原始权利来平整它们（我不能）无论如何，我相信，人类的力量永远无法达到这样的境界），我这个小时就会这么做。我宁愿让可怜的里克恢复他应有的本性，也不愿意把那些死去的求婚者们在大法官法庭上心碎、心碎、在总会计师那里无人认领的所有钱财都赋予给我——而这些钱就足够了，亲爱的，被扔进金字塔，以纪念大法官办公室的超然邪恶。”

‘IS it possible, guardian,’ I asked, amazed, ‘that Richard can be suspicious of you?’
“监护人，理查德有可能对你产生怀疑吗？”我惊讶地问道。

‘Ah, my love, my love,’ he said, ‘it is in the subtle poison of such abuses to breed such diseases. His blood is infected, and objects lose their natural aspects in his sight. It is not HIS fault.’
“啊，我的爱人，我的爱人，”他说，“正是这种虐待行为的微妙毒害滋生了这种疾病。他的血液被感染，物体在他的视野中失去了自然的面貌。这不是他的错。

‘But it is a terrible misfortune, guardian.’
“但这是一个可怕的不幸，监护人。”

‘It is a terrible misfortune, little woman, to be ever drawn within the influences of Jarndyce and Jarndyce. I know none greater. By little and little he has been induced to trust in that rotten reed, and it communicates some portion of its rottenness to everything around him. But again I say with all my soul, we must be patient with poor Rick and not blame him. What a troop of fine fresh hearts like his have I seen in my time turned by the same means!’
“小女人，永远受到加迪斯和加迪斯的影响，这是一个可怕的不幸。我知道没有比这更伟大的了。渐渐地，他开始相信那根腐烂的芦苇，它把它的腐烂的一部分传达给了他周围的一切。但我再次全心全意地说，我们必须对可怜的瑞克保持耐心，而不是责备他。我在我的时代见过一群多么像他一样的新鲜的心啊！

I could not help expressing something of my wonder and regret that his benevolent, disinterested intentions had prospered so little.
我情不自禁地表达了我的惊讶和遗憾，因为他的仁慈、无私的意图却收效甚微。

‘We must not say so, Dame Durden,’ he cheerfully rephed; ‘Ada is the happier, I hope, and that is much. I did think that I and both these young creatures might be friends instead of distrustful foes and that we might so far counter-act the suit and prove too strong for it. But it was too much to expect. Jarndyce and Jarndyce was the curtain of Rick’s cradle.’
“我们不能这么说，德登夫人，”他高兴地反驳道。 “我希望艾达更快乐，仅此而已。我确实认为我和这两个年轻的生物可能是朋友而不是不信任的敌人，并且到目前为止我们可能会反击诉讼并证明我们太强大了。但这是太令人期待了。贾迪斯和贾迪斯是瑞克摇篮的帷幕。

‘But, guardian, may we not hope that a little experience will teach him what a false and wretched thing it is?’
