“但是，监护人，难道我们不希望一点点经验能让他明白这是多么虚假和可悲的事情吗？”

‘We WILL hope so, my Esther,’ said Mr. Jarndyce, ‘and that it may not teach him so too late. In any case we must not be hard on him. There are not many grown and matured men living while we speak, good men too, who if they were thrown into this same court as suitors would not be vitally changed and depreciated within three years—within two—within one. How can we stand amazed at poor Rick? A young man so unfortunate,’ here he fell into a lower tone, as if he were thinking aloud, ‘cannot at first believe (who could?) that Chancery is what it is. He looks to it, flushed and fitfully, to do something with his interests and bring them to some settlement. It procrastinates, disappoints, tries, tortures him; wears out his sanguine hopes and patience, thread by thread; but he still looks to it, and hankers after it, and finds his whole world treacherous and hollow. Well, well, well! Enough of this, my dear!’
“我们希望如此，我的埃丝特，”贾迪斯先生说，“这样他就不会受教得太晚了。”无论如何，我们不能对他太苛刻。在我们说话的时候，生活中没有多少成年和成熟的男人，也没有多少好男人，如果他们作为追求者被扔进同一个法庭，他们不会在三年内——两年内——一年内发生重大改变和贬值。我们怎能对可怜的瑞克感到惊讶呢？一个如此不幸的年轻人，”说到这里，他压低了语气，仿佛在自言自语，“一开始无法相信（谁能相信？） 大法官法庭就是这样的。他满脸通红、断断续续地期待着，为自己的利益做点什么，让他们达成某种解决方案。它拖延、失望、尝试、折磨他；一点一滴地耗尽了他乐观的希望和耐心；但他仍然仰望着它，渴望着它，却发现他的整个世界都是阴险而空洞的。好啦好啦！够了，亲爱的！

He had supported me, as at first, all this time, and his tenderness was so precious to me that I leaned my head upon his shoulder and loved him as if he had been my father. I resolved in my own mind in this little pause, by some means, to see Richard when I grew strong and try to set him right.
他一如既往地支持我，一直以来，他的温柔对我来说是如此珍贵，以至于我把头靠在他的肩膀上，爱他，就像他是我的父亲一样。在这短暂的停顿中，我暗下决心，当我变得坚强时，一定要设法去见理查德，并试图纠正他的错误。

‘There are better subjects than these,’ said my guardian, ‘for such a joyful time as the time of our dear girl’s recovery. And I had a commission to broach one of them as soon as I should begin to talk. When shall Ada come to see you, my love?’
“还有比这些更好的主题，”我的监护人说，“对于我们亲爱的女孩康复的时光来说，这是一个如此快乐的时光。”我接到委托，一开始讲话就立即提出其中的一个。艾达什么时候来看你，我的爱人？

I had been thinking of that too. A little in connexion with the absent mirrors, but not much, for I knew my loving girl would be changed by no change in my looks.
我也一直在想这个。与缺席的镜子有一点关系，但关系不大，因为我知道我心爱的女孩不会因我的外表改变而改变。

‘Dear guardian,’ said I, ‘as I have shut her out so long—though indeed, indeed, she is like the light to me—‘
“亲爱的监护人，”我说，“因为我已经把她拒之门外这么久了——尽管确实，确实，她对我来说就像光明——”

‘I know it well, Dame Durden, well.’
“我很清楚，德登夫人，嗯。”

He was so good, his touch expressed such endearing compassion and affection, and the tone of his voice carried such comfort into my heart that I stopped for a little while, quite unable to go on. ‘Yes, yes, you are tired,’ said he, ‘Rest a little.’
他太好了，他的触摸表达了那么可爱的同情和感情，他的语气给我的心里带来了那么大的安慰，让我停了下来，很无法继续说下去。 “是的，是的，你累了，”他说，“休息一下吧。”

‘As I have kept Ada out so long,’ I began afresh after a short while, ‘I think I should like to have my own way a little longer, guardian. It would be best to be away from here before I see her. If Charley and I were to go to some country lodging as soon as I can move, and if I had a week there in which to grow stronger and to be revived by the sweet air and to look forward to the happiness of having Ada with me again, I think it would be better for us.’
“因为我已经把艾达拒之门外这么久了，”过了一会儿我又开始说道，“我想我应该再按自己的方式行事，监护人。”在我见到她之前最好离开这里。如果我一可以搬家，查理和我就去乡间住处，如果我能在那里度过一周的时间，让自己变得更强壮，在甜美的空气中恢复活力，并期待着艾达和我在一起的幸福再说一遍，我认为这对我们来说会更好。”

I hope it was not a poor thing in me to wish to be a little more used to my altered self before I met the eyes of the dear girl I longed so ardently to see, but it is the truth. I did. He understood me, I was sure; but I was not afraid of that. If it were a poor thing, I knew he would pass it over.
我希望在见到我热切渴望见到的亲爱女孩的眼睛之前，希望能更习惯改变的自己，这对我来说并不是一件可怜的事情，但这是事实。我做到了。我确信他理解我；但我并不害怕。如果这是一件可怜的事情，我知道他会忽略它。

‘Our spoilt little woman,’ said my guardian, ‘shall have her own way even in her inflexibility, though at the price, I know, of tears downstairs. And see here! Here is Boythorn, heart of chivalry, breathing such ferocious vows as never were breathed on paper before, that if you don’t go and occupy his whole house, he having already turned out of it expressly for that purpose, by heaven and by earth he’ll pull it down and not leave one brick standing on another!’
“我们这个被宠坏的小女人，”我的监护人说，“即使她顽固不化，也应该按她自己的方式行事，尽管我知道，代价是在楼下流泪。”看到这里！这是博伊索恩，一颗骑士之心，他发出了前所未有的凶猛誓言，如果你不去占据他的整个房子，他已经为了这个目的而明确地从天上和地上离开了它他会把它推倒，而不是让一块砖立在另一块上！”

And my guardian put a letter in my hand, without any ordinary beginning such as ‘My dear Jarndyce,’ but rushing at once into the words, ‘I swear if Miss Summerson do not come down and take possession of my house, which I vacate for her this day at one o’clock, P.M.,’ and then with the utmost seriousness, and in the most emphatic terms, going on to make the extraordinary declaration he had quoted. We did not appreciate the writer the less for laughing heartily over it, and we settled that I should send him a letter of thanks on the morrow and accept his offer. It was a most agreeable one to me, for all the places I could have thought of, I should have liked to go to none so well as Chesney Wold.
我的监护人把一封信放在我手里，信的开头没有任何普通的开头，比如“我亲爱的贾迪斯”，而是立即插入这样的文字：“我发誓，如果萨默森小姐不下来占有我的房子，我就把它腾出来了。”今天下午一点，”然后以极其严肃的态度，以最有力的措辞，继续发表他所引用的非凡声明。我们对作者的开怀大笑并不感激，我们决定第二天给他写一封感谢信并接受他的提议。这对我来说是一个最令人愉快的地方，因为在我能想到的所有地方中，我最想去的地方就是切斯尼沃尔德。

‘Now, little housewife,’ said my guardian, looking at his watch, ‘I was strictly timed before I came upstairs, for you must not be tired too soon; and my time has waned away to the last minute. I have one other petition. Little Miss Flite, hearing a rumour that you were ill, made nothing of walking down here—twenty miles, poor soul, in a pair of dancing shoes—to inquire. It was heaven’s mercy we were at home, or she would have walked back again.’
“现在，小主妇，”我的监护人看了看手表，说道，“我在上楼之前已经严格计时了，因为你不能太早感到疲倦；我的时间已经到了最后一刻。我还有另一份请愿书。小弗利特小姐听说你病了，毫不犹豫地步行到这里来询问——可怜的灵魂，二十英里，穿着一双舞鞋。幸亏我们在家，不然她就又走回来了。”

The old conspiracy to make me happy! Everybody seemed to be in it!
老阴谋让我幸福！每个人似乎都身处其中！

‘Now, pet,’ said my guardian, ‘if it would not be irksome to you to admit the harmless little creature one afternoon before you save Boythorn’s otherwise devoted house from demolition, I believe you would make her prouder and better pleased with herself than I— though my eminent name is Jarndyce—could do in a lifetime.’
“现在，宠物，”我的监护人说，“如果在你拯救博伊索恩原本忠诚的房子免于拆除之前的一天下午承认这个无害的小生物对你来说不是令人厌烦的话，我相信你会让她比我更自豪和更满意自己我——尽管我的大名是贾迪斯——一生都可以做到。

I have no doubt he knew there would be something in the simple image of the poor afflicted creature that would fall like a gentle lesson on my mind at that time. I felt it as he spoke to me. I could not tell him heartily enough how ready I was to receive her. I had always pitied her, never so much as now. I had always been glad of my little power to soothe her under her calamity, but never, never, half so glad before.
我毫不怀疑他知道这个可怜的受苦生物的简单形象会像一个温柔的教训一样落在我的脑海里。当他对我说话时我感觉到了。我无法衷心地告诉他我已经准备好接待她了。我一直很可怜她，从来没有像现在这样。我一直很高兴自己能在她的灾难中安抚她的微薄之力，但以前从来没有，从来没有像现在这样高兴过。

We arranged a time for Miss Flite to come out by the coach and share my early dinner. When my guardian left me, I turned my face away upon my couch and prayed to be forgiven if I, surrounded by such blessings, had magnified to myself the little trial that I had to undergo. The childish prayer of that old birthday when I had aspired to be industrious, contented, and true-hearted and to do good to some one and win some love to myself if I could came back into my mind with a reproachful sense of all the happiness I had since enjoyed and all the affectionate hearts that had been turned towards me. If I were weak now, what had I profited by those mercies? I repeated the old childish prayer in its old childish words and found that its old peace had not departed from it.
我们安排了时间让弗利特小姐乘车出来和我一起吃早饭。当我的监护人离开我时，我把脸转向沙发上，祈祷如果我在这样的祝福包围下放大了自己必须经历的小考验，请得到宽恕。那个古老的生日的孩子气的祈祷，当时我渴望勤奋，满足，真诚，为某人做好事，为自己赢得一些爱，如果我能带着一种责备的幸福感回到我的脑海里从那时起，我就享受了所有转向我的深情之心。如果我现在软弱的话，那些怜悯对我有什么好处呢？我用幼稚的话语重复着古老的幼稚的祈祷，发现它古老的平静并没有离开它。

My guardian now came every day. In a week or so more I could walk about our rooms and hold long talks with Ada from behind the window-curtain. Yet I never saw her, for I had not as yet the courage to look at the dear face, though I could have done so easily without her seeing me.
我的监护人现在每天都来。大约一周后，我就可以在我们的房间里走来走去，并在窗帘后面与艾达进行长时间的交谈。然而我从来没有见过她，因为我还没有勇气去看那张可爱的脸，尽管我可以在没有她看到我的情况下轻松地做到这一点。

On the appointed day Miss Flite arrived. The poor little creature ran into my room quite forgetful of her usual dignity, and crying from her very heart of hearts, ‘My dear Fitz Jarndyce!’ fell upon my neck and kissed me twenty times.
弗利特小姐在约定的日子到来了。这个可怜的小东西完全忘记了她平时的尊严，跑进我的房间，从内心深处哭喊着：“我亲爱的菲茨·贾迪斯！”趴在我的脖子上，吻了我二十个。

‘Dear me!’ said she, putting her hand into her reticule, ‘I have nothing here but documents, my dear Fitz Jarndyce; I must borrow a pocket handkerchief.’
“天哪！”她把手伸进手提包里说道，“我这里除了文件什么也没有，亲爱的菲茨·贾迪斯；我必须借一块口袋手帕。

Charley gave her one, and the good creature certainly made use of it, for she held it to her eyes with both hands and sat so, shedding tears for the next ten minutes.
查理给了她一个，这个好心人当然利用了它，因为她用双手把它放在眼睛上，就这样坐着，在接下来的十分钟里流下了眼泪。

‘With pleasure, my dear Fitz Jarndyce,’ she was careful to explain. ‘Not the least pain. Pleasure to see you well again. Pleasure at having the honour of being admitted to see you. I am so much fonder of you, my love, than of the Chancellor. Though I DO attend court regularly. By the by, my dear, mentioning pocket handkerchiefs—‘
“很高兴，我亲爱的菲茨·贾迪斯，”她小心翼翼地解释道。 “一点也不痛苦。很高兴再次见到你一切安好。很高兴有幸获准与您会面。亲爱的，我比总理更喜欢你。尽管我确实定期出庭。顺便说一句，亲爱的，提到口袋手帕——”

Miss Flite here looked at Charley, who had been to meet her at the place where the coach stopped. Charley glanced at me and looked unwilling to pursue the suggestion.
弗利特小姐看着查理，后者本来是在马车停靠的地方迎接她的。查理看了我一眼，似乎不愿意采纳这个建议。

‘Ve-ry right!’ said Miss Flite, ‘Ve-ry correct. Truly! Highly indiscreet of me to mention it; but my dear Miss Fitz Jarndyce, I am afraid I am at times (between ourselves, you wouldn’t think it) a little—rambling you know,’ said Miss Flite, touching her forehead. ‘Nothing more,’
“非常正确！”弗利特小姐说，“非常正确。”真的！我提这件事真是太不检点了；但我亲爱的菲茨·贾迪斯小姐，恐怕我有时（我们之间，你不会这么想）有点——你知道，胡言乱语，”弗利特小姐摸着额头说道。 '而已，'

‘What were you going to tell me?’ said I, smiling, for I saw she wanted to go on. ‘You have roused my curiosity, and now you must gratify it.’
“你要告诉我什么？”我微笑着说道，因为我看出她还想继续说下去。 “你激起了我的好奇心，现在你必须满足它。”

Miss Flite looked at Charley for advice in this important crisis, who said, ‘If you please, ma’am, you had better tell then,’ and therein gratified Miss Flite beyond measure.
弗利特小姐在这场重要的危机中向查理寻求建议，后者说：“如果您愿意的话，女士，那么您最好告诉我。”弗利特小姐对此感到无比欣慰。

‘So sagacious, our young friend,’ said she to me in her mysterious way. ‘Diminutive. But ve-ry sagacious! Well, my dear, it’s a pretty anecdote. Nothing more. Still I think it charming. Who should follow us down the road from the coach, my dear, but a poor person in a very ungenteel bonnet—‘
“我们年轻的朋友，太聪明了。”她用她神秘的方式对我说。 ‘小个子。但非常睿智！嗯，亲爱的，这是一个非常有趣的轶事。而已。我仍然认为它很迷人。谁应该从马车上跟着我们走下去，亲爱的，但他是一个戴着非常不礼貌的帽子的穷人——”

‘Jenny, if you please, miss,’ said Charley.
“珍妮，请小姐，”查利说。

‘Just so!’ Miss Flite acquiesced with the greatest suavity. ‘Jenny. Ye-es! And what does she tell our young friend but that there has been a lady with a veil inquiring at her cottage after my dear Fitz Jarndyce’s health and taking a handkerchief away with her as a little keepsake merely because it was my amiable Fitz Jarndyce’s! Now, you know, so very prepossessing in the lady with the veil!’
“正是如此！”弗利特小姐极其和蔼地默许了。 ‘珍妮。是的！她告诉我们的年轻朋友，有一位戴着面纱的女士在她的小屋里询问我亲爱的菲茨·贾迪斯的健康状况，并带走了一块手帕作为小纪念品，仅仅因为那是我和蔼可亲的菲茨·贾迪斯的手帕！现在，你知道，戴面纱的女士非常迷人！”

‘If you please, miss,’ said Charley, to whom I looked in some astonishment, ‘Jenny says that when her baby died, you left a handkerchief there, and that she put it away and kept it with the baby’s little things. I think, if you please, partly because it was yours, miss, and partly because it had covered the baby.’
“请问，小姐，”查利说，我有些惊讶地看着他，“珍妮说，当她的孩子死后，你留下了一块手帕在那里，她把它收起来，和孩子的小东西放在一起。我想，如果你愿意的话，部分是因为它是你的，小姐，部分是因为它盖住了婴儿。

‘Diminutive,’ whispered Miss Flite, making a variety of motions about her own forehead to express intellect in Charley. ‘But exceedingly sagacious! And so dear! My love, she’s clearer than any counsel I ever heard!’
“个子很小。”弗利特小姐低声说道，一边在自己的前额上做了各种动作，以表达查理的聪明才智。 ‘但是非常有智慧！亲爱的！我的爱人，她比我听过的任何建议都清楚！

‘Yes, Charley,’ I returned. ‘I remember it. Well?’
“是的，查理，”我回答道。 '我记得。出色地？'

‘Well, miss,’ said Charley, ‘and that’s the handkerchief the lady took. And Jenny wants you to know that she wouldn’t have made away with it herself for a heap of money but that the lady took it and left some money instead. Jenny don’t know her at all, if you please, miss!’
“嗯，小姐，”查利说，“这就是那位女士拿的手帕。珍妮想让你知道，她自己不会为了一大笔钱而偷走它，而是那位女士拿走了它并留下了一些钱。珍妮根本不认识她，请问小姐！”

‘Why, who can she be?’ said I.
“为什么，她会是谁？”我问道。

‘My love,’ Miss Flite suggested, advancing her lips to my ear with her most mysterious look, ‘in MY opinion—don’t mention this to our diminutive friend—she’s the Lord Chancellor’s wife. He’s married, you know. And I understand she leads him a terrible life. Throws his lordship’s papers into the fire, my dear, if he won’t pay the jeweller!’
“我的爱人，”弗利特小姐建议道，用她最神秘的表情把嘴唇凑到我耳边，“在我看来——别向我们的小朋友提起这一点——她是大法官的妻子。他已经结婚了，你知道。我知道她让他过着糟糕的生活。亲爱的，如果他不付钱给珠宝商，就把勋爵的文件扔进火里！”

I did not think very much about this lady then, for I had an impression that it might be Caddy. Besides, my attention was diverted by my visitor, who was cold after her ride and looked hungry and who, our dinner being brought in, required some little assistance in arraying herself with great satisfaction in a pitiable old scarf and a much-worn and often-mended pair of gloves, which she had brought down in a paper parcel. I had to preside, too, over the entertainment, consisting of a dish of fish, a roast fowl, a sweetbread, vegetables, pudding, and Madeira; and it was so pleasant to see how she enjoyed it, and with what state and ceremony she did honour to it, that I was soon thinking of nothing else.
当时我并没有对这位女士想太多，因为我有一种印象，那就是凯迪。此外，我的注意力被我的访客转移了，她骑完车后很冷，看起来很饿，我们的晚餐送来后，她需要一些帮助才能非常满意地穿上一条可怜的旧围巾和一件经常磨损的衣服。 -修补了一双手套，她把它放在一个纸包裹里。我还必须主持娱乐活动，包括一盘鱼、一只烤鸡、一份牛杂碎、蔬菜、布丁和马德拉酒。看到她如此享受这一切，以及她以怎样的姿态和仪式来纪念这一切，我真是太高兴了，以至于我很快就不再考虑其他事情了。

When we had finished and had our little dessert before us, embellished by the hands of my dear, who would yield the superintendence of everything prepared for me to no one, Miss Flite was so very chatty and happy that I thought I would lead her to her own history, as she was always pleased to talk about herself. I began by saying ‘You have attended on the Lord Chancellor many years, Miss Flite?’
当我们吃完后，我们的小甜点摆在我们面前，由我亲爱的人亲手装饰，她不会把为我准备的一切交给任何人，弗利特小姐非常健谈和高兴，我想我会带她去她自己的历史，因为她总是很乐意谈论自己。我一开始就说：“弗利特小姐，你参加大法官会议已经很多年了？”

‘Oh, many, many, many years, my dear. But I expect a judgment. Shortly.’
‘噢，很多很多很多年了，亲爱的。但我期待一个判决。不久。'

There was an anxiety even in her hopefulness that made me doubtful if I had done right in approaching the subject. I thought I would say no more about it.
即使她的希望中也有一种焦虑，这让我怀疑我是否正确地处理了这个话题。我想我不会再多说了。

‘My father expected a judgment,’ said Miss Flite. ‘My brother. My sister. They all expected a judgment. The same that I expect.’
“我父亲期待着审判，”弗利特小姐说。 '我的兄弟。我的姐妹。他们都期待着审判。和我期望的一样。

‘They are all—‘
“他们都是——”

‘Ye-es. Dead of course, my dear,’ said she.
‘是的。当然死了，亲爱的，”她说。

As I saw she would go on, I thought it best to try to be serviceable to her by meeting the theme rather than avoiding it.
当我看到她会继续说下去时，我认为最好是通过满足主题而不是回避主题来尝试为她服务。

‘Would it not be wiser,’ said I, ‘to expect this judgment no more?’
“不再期待这样的审判，”我说，“不是更明智吗？”

‘Why, my dear,’ she answered promptly, ‘of course it would!’
“哎呀，亲爱的，”她立即回答，“当然会的！”

‘And to attend the court no more?’
“然后不再出庭吗？”

‘Equally of course,’ said she. ‘Very wearing to be always in expectation of what never comes, my dear Fitz Jarndyce! Wearing, I assure you, to the bone!’
“当然也一样，”她说。 “总是期待着永远不会发生的事情，真是太累人了，我亲爱的菲茨·贾迪斯！我向你保证，穿着到骨头里了！

She slightly showed me her arm, and it was fearfully thin indeed.
她轻轻地向我展示了她的手臂，它确实瘦得可怕。

‘But, my dear,’ she went on in her mysterious way, ‘there’s a dreadful attraction in the place. Hush! Don’t mention it to our diminutive friend when she comes in. Or it may frighten her. With good reason. There’s a cruel attraction in the place. You CAN’T leave it. And you MUST expect.’
“但是，亲爱的，”她以神秘的方式继续说道，“这个地方有一种可怕的吸引力。嘘！当我们的小朋友进来时，不要向她提起这件事。否则可能会吓到她。有充分的理由。这个地方有一种残酷的吸引力。你不能离开它。你必须期待。

I tried to assure her that this was not so. She heard me patiently and smilingly, but was ready with her own answer.
我试图向她保证事实并非如此。她耐心地微笑着听我说话，但也准备好了自己的答案。

‘Aye, aye, aye! You think so because I am a little rambling. Very absurd, to be a little rambling, is it not? Ve-ry confusing, too. To the head. I find it so. But, my dear, I have been there many years, and I have noticed. It’s the mace and seal upon the table.’
‘是啊，是啊，是啊！你这么认为是因为我有点胡言乱语。太荒唐了，有点胡言乱语，不是吗？也非常令人困惑。到头。我觉得是这样。但是，亲爱的，我已经在那里很多年了，我已经注意到了。这是桌子上的狼牙棒和印章。”

What could they do, did she think? I mildly asked her.
她想，他们能做什么呢？我温和地问她。

‘Draw,’ returned Miss Flite. ‘Draw people on, my dear. Draw peace out of them. Sense out of them. Good looks out of them. Good qualities out of them. I have felt them even drawing my rest away in the night. Cold and glittering devils!’
“画画，”弗利特小姐回答道。 “吸引人们，亲爱的。从他们身上汲取平安。从他们身上感觉到。他们看起来不错。他们身上都有良好的品质。我感觉到它们甚至在晚上剥夺了我的休息时间。冰冷而闪闪发光的魔鬼！

She tapped me several times upon the arm and nodded good-humouredly as if she were anxious I should understand that I had no cause to fear her, though she spoke so gloomily, and confided these awful secrets to me.
她在我的手臂上拍了几下，幽默地点点头，好像她很担心我会明白，我没有理由害怕她，尽管她说话的语气如此阴郁，并向我吐露了这些可怕的秘密。

‘Let me see,’ said she. ‘I’ll tell you my own case. Before they ever drew me—before I had ever seen them—what was it I used to do? Tambourine playing? No. Tambour work. I and my sister worked at tambour work. Our father and our brother had a builder’s business. We all lived together. Ve-ry respectably, my dear! First, our father was drawn—slowly. Home was drawn with him. In a few years he was a fierce, sour, angry bankrupt without a kind word or a kind look for any one. He had been so different, Fitz Jarndyce. He was drawn to a debtors’ prison. There he died. Then our brother was drawn—swiftly—to drunkenness. And rags. And death. Then my sister was drawn. Hush! Never ask to what! Then I was ill and in misery, and heard, as I had often heard before, that this was all the work of Chancery. When I got better, I went to look at the monster. And then I found out how it was, and I was drawn to stay there.’
“让我看看，”她说。 ‘我来告诉你我自己的例子。在他们吸引我之前——在我见到他们之前——我过去常常做什么？手鼓演奏？不，鼓手工作。我和姐姐从事手鼓工作。我们的父亲和兄弟经营一家建筑商生意。我们都住在一起。非常尊敬，亲爱的！首先，我们的父亲被吸引了——慢慢地。家被他吸引了。几年之内，他就变成了一个脾气暴躁、脾气暴躁、愤怒的破产者，对任何人都没有一句善意的话，也没有一个友善的眼神。菲茨·贾迪斯，他是如此与众不同。他被吸引到债务人监狱。他死在那里。然后我们的兄弟很快就醉了。还有破布。还有死亡。然后我妹妹就被吸引了。嘘！永远不要问什么！然后我病了，陷入了痛苦之中，并且正如我以前经常听到的那样，我听说这都是大法官办公室的工作。当我病情好转后，我去看怪物。然后我发现了它是怎么回事，我被吸引住在那里。

Having got over her own short narrative, in the delivery of which she had spoken in a low, strained voice, as if the shock were fresh upon her, she gradually resumed her usual air of amiable importance.
她用低沉、紧张的声音讲述了自己的简短叙述，仿佛刚刚受到了震惊，在克服了这一点后，她逐渐恢复了平常的和蔼可亲的态度。

‘You don’t quite credit me, my dear! Well, well! You will, some day. I am a little rambling. But I have noticed. I have seen many new faces come, unsuspicious, within the influence of the mace and seal in these many years. As my father’s came there. As my brother’s. As my sister’s. As my own. I hear Conversation Kenge and the rest of them say to the new faces, ‘Here’s little Miss Flite. Oh, you are new here; and you must come and be presented to little Miss Flite!’ Ve-ry good. Proud I am sure to have the honour! And we all laugh. But, Fitz Jarndyce, I know what will happen. I know, far better than they do, when the attraction has begun. I know the signs, my dear. I saw them begin in Gridley. And I saw them end. Fitz Jarndyce, my love,’ speaking low again, ‘I saw them beginning in our friend the ward in Jarndyce. Let some one hold him back. Or he’ll be drawn to ruin.
“你不太相信我，亲爱的！好吧！总有一天你会的。我有点胡言乱语。但我注意到了。这些年来，我看到许多新面孔在狼牙棒和海豹的影响下毫无疑心地出现。当我父亲来到那里时。就像我兄弟的一样。就像我姐姐的一样。作为我自己的。我听到对话肯格和其他人对新面孔说：‘这是小弗利特小姐。哦，你是新来的；你必须来并被介绍给小弗利特小姐！’很好。我很自豪，我一定有这个荣幸！我们都笑了。但是，菲茨·贾迪斯，我知道会发生什么。当吸引力开始时，我比他们更清楚。我知道这些迹象，亲爱的。我看到他们从格里德利开始。我看到他们结束了。菲茨·贾迪斯，我的爱人，”再次低声说道，“我看到他们从我们朋友贾迪斯的病房开始。让某人阻止他吧。否则他会被吸引走向毁灭。

She looked at me in silence for some moments, with her face gradually softening into a smile. Seeming to fear that she had been too gloomy, and seeming also to lose the connexion in her mind, she said politely as she sipped her glass of wine, ‘Yes, my dear, as I was saying, I expect a judgment shortly. Then I shall release my birds, you know, and confer estates.’
她沉默地看了我一会儿，脸上渐渐柔和了笑容。似乎是担心自己太过阴郁，也似乎失去了心灵的联系，她一边喝着酒，一边礼貌地说道：“是的，亲爱的，正如我所说，我很快就会得到审判。”然后我将释放我的鸟儿，你知道，并授予财产。

I was much impressed by her allusion to Richard and by the sad meaning, so sadly illustrated in her poor pinched form, that made its way through all her incoherence. But happily for her, she was quite complacent again now and beamed with nods and smiles.
她对理查德的暗示和悲伤的含义给我留下了深刻的印象，她可怜的捏着的身体如此悲伤地说明了这一点，这贯穿了她所有的语无伦次。但令她高兴的是，她现在又很自满了，微笑着点头。

‘But, my dear,’ she said, gaily, reaching another hand to put it upon mine. ‘You have not congratulated me on my physician. Positively not once, yet!’
“但是，亲爱的，”她高兴地说，伸出另一只手放在我的手上。 ‘你还没有祝贺我拥有我的医生。肯定还没有一次！

I was obliged to confess that I did not quite know what she meant.
我不得不承认我不太明白她的意思。

‘My physician, Mr. Woodcourt, my dear, who was so exceedingly attentive to me. Though his services were rendered quite gratuitously. Until the Day of Judgment. I mean THE judgment that will dissolve the spell upon me of the mace and seal.’
“亲爱的，我的医生伍德考特先生对我非常关心。尽管他的服务是无偿提供的。直到审判日。我指的是能够解除我身上的狼牙棒和封印咒语的审判。

‘Mr. Woodcourt is so far away, now,’ said I, ‘that I thought the time for such congratulation was past, Miss Flite.’
'先生。伍德考特现在离我们太远了，”我说，“我以为这样祝贺的时候已经过去了，弗利特小姐。”

‘But, my child,’ she returned, ‘is it possible that you don’t know what has happened?’
“但是，我的孩子，”她回答道，“你有可能不知道发生了什么事吗？”

‘No,’ said I.
“不，”我说。

‘Not what everybody has been talking of, my beloved Fitz Jarndyce!’
“不是每个人都在谈论的，我亲爱的菲茨·贾迪斯！”

‘No,’ said I. ‘You forget how long I have been here.’
“不，”我说，“你忘了我在这里呆了多久了。”

‘True! My dear, for the moment—true. I blame myself. But my memory has been drawn out of me, with everything else, by what I mentioned. Ve-ry strong influence, is it not? Well, my dear, there has been a terrible shipwreck over in those East Indian seas.’
'真的！亲爱的，目前来说——是的。我责怪自己。但我的记忆和其他一切都被我提到的事情带走了。影响力非常大，不是吗？好吧，亲爱的，东印度海域发生了一场可怕的沉船事故。

‘Mr. Woodcourt shipwrecked!’
'先生。伍德考特遭遇海难！”

‘Don’t be agitated, my dear. He is safe. An awful scene. Death in all shapes. Hundreds of dead and dying. Fire, storm, and darkness. Numbers of the drowning thrown upon a rock. There, and through it all, my dear physician was a hero. Calm and brave through everything. Saved many lives, never complained in hunger and thirst, wrapped naked people in his spare clothes, took the lead, showed them what to do, governed them, tended the sick, buried the dead, and brought the poor survivors safely off at last! My dear, the poor emaciated creatures all but worshipped him. They fell down at his feet when they got to the land and blessed him. The whole country rings with it. Stay! Where’s my bag of documents? I have got it there, and you shall read it, you shall read it!’
‘别激动，亲爱的。他很安全。可怕的一幕。死亡有各种形状。数百人死亡和垂死。火焰、风暴和黑暗。扔在岩石上溺水的人数。在那儿，经历了这一切，我亲爱的医生是一位英雄。冷静勇敢的面对一切。拯救了许多生命，从不抱怨饥饿和口渴，用他的备用衣服裹住赤身裸体的人，带头，告诉他们该做什么，统治他们，照顾病人，埋葬死者，最后把可怜的幸存者安全地带走！亲爱的，这些可怜的瘦弱生物几乎崇拜他。当他们到达那地时，他们就俯伏在他脚前祝福他。整个国家都随之响起。停留！我的文件袋在哪里？我已经拿到了，你应该读它，你应该读它！

And I DID read all the noble history, though very slowly and imperfectly then, for my eyes were so dimmed that I could not see the words, and I cried so much that I was many times obliged to lay down the long account she had cut out of the newspaper. I felt so triumphant ever to have known the man who had done such generous and gallant deeds, I felt such glowing exultation in his renown, I so admired and loved what he had done, that I envied the storm-worn people who had fallen at his feet and blessed him as their preserver. I could myself have kneeled down then, so far away, and blessed him in my rapture that he should be so truly good and brave. I felt that no one—mother, sister, wife—could honour him more than I. I did, indeed!
我确实读完了所有高贵的历史，尽管当时读得非常慢而且不完美，因为我的眼睛太暗了，看不清文字，而且我哭得很厉害，很多时候我不得不放下她剪下来的长篇大论。从报纸上出来。认识这个做出了如此慷慨和英勇事迹的人，我感到如此胜利，我对他的名声感到如此欣喜，我如此钦佩和热爱他的所作所为，以至于我羡慕那些在暴风雨中倒下的人们。并祝福他为他们的保护者。我当时真想在那么远的地方跪下来，欣喜若狂地祝福他，他真的是那么善良和勇敢。我觉得没有人——母亲、姐妹、妻子——能比我更尊敬他。我确实做到了！

My poor little visitor made me a present of the account, and when as the evening began to close in she rose to take her leave, lest she should miss the coach by which she was to return, she was still full of the shipwreck, which I had not yet sufflciently composed myself to understand in all its details.
我可怜的小客人把帐单送给了我一份礼物，当夜幕降临时，她起身告辞，以免错过返回的马车，她仍然满脑子都是沉船残骸，我还没有完全镇定下来，无法理解其中的所有细节。

‘My dear,’ said she as she carefully folded up her scarf and gloves, ‘my brave physician ought to have a title bestowed upon him. And no doubt he will. You are of that opinlon?’
“亲爱的，”她小心翼翼地折起围巾和手套，说道，“我勇敢的医生应该被授予一个称号。”毫无疑问他会的。你也这么认为吗？

That he well deserved one, yes. That he would ever have one, no.
他当之无愧，是的。他会拥有一个，不。

‘Why not, Fitz Jarndyce?’ she asked rather sharply.
“为什么不呢，菲茨·贾迪斯？”她尖锐地问道。

I said it was not the custom in England to confer titles on men distinguished by peaceful services, however good and great, unless occasionally when they consisted of the accumulation of some very large amount of money.
我说过，英国没有向因和平服务而杰出的人授予头衔的惯例，无论这些人多么优秀和伟大，除非偶尔积累了一些非常大的金钱。

‘Why, good gracious,’ said Miss Flite, ‘how can you say that? Surely you know, my dear, that all the greatest ornaments of England in knowledge, imagination, active humanity, and improvement of every sort are added to its nobility! Look round you, my dear, and consider. YOU must be rambling a little now, I think, if you don’t know that this is the great reason why titles will always last in the land!’
“哎呀，天哪，”弗利特小姐说，“你怎么能这么说呢？亲爱的，你当然知道，英国在知识、想象力、积极的人性和各种进步方面最伟大的装饰都增添了它的高贵！亲爱的，看看你的周围，并考虑一下。我想，如果你不知道这就是头衔在这片土地上永垂不朽的重要原因，你现在一定有点胡言乱语了！

I am afraid she believed what she said, for there were moments when she was very mad indeed.
我恐怕她相信自己所说的话，因为有时候她确实非常生气。

And now I must part with the little secret I have thus far tried to keep. I had thought, sometimes, that Mr. Woodcourt loved me and that if he had been richer he would perhaps have told me that he loved me before he went away. I had thought, sometimes, that if he had done so, I should have been glad of it. But how much better it was now that this had never happened! What should I have suffered if I had had to write to him and tell him that the poor face he had known as mine was quite gone from me and that I freely released him from his bondage to one whom he had never seen!
现在我必须放弃我迄今为止一直试图保守的小秘密了。有时我想，伍德考特先生爱我，如果他更富有的话，他也许会在离开之前告诉我他爱我。有时我想，如果他这么做了，我应该会感到高兴。但如果这件事从未发生过，那该多好啊！如果我不得不写信给他，告诉他，他所认识的那张可怜的脸已经从我身上消失了，而且我自由地把他从他从未见过的人的束缚中释放出来，我该承受多大的痛苦啊！

Oh, it was so much better as it was! With a great pang mercifully spared me, I could take back to my heart my childish prayer to be all he had so brightly shown himself; and there was nothing to be undone: no chain for me to break or for him to drag; and I could go, please God, my lowly way along the path of duty, and he could go his nobler way upon its broader road; and though we were apart upon the journey, I might aspire to meet him, unselfishly, innocently, better far than he had thought me when I found some favour in his eyes, at the journey’s end.
哦，原来这样好多了！仁慈地宽恕了我的巨大痛苦，我可以在心里收回我幼稚的祈祷，希望他能如此明亮地展示自己；没有什么是可以挽回的：没有锁链可以让我折断，也没有锁链可以让他拖拽；上帝啊，我可以沿着责任之路走我卑微的道路，而他可以在更宽阔的道路上走他更高尚的道路；尽管我们在旅途中分开，但我可能渴望无私、天真地见到他，比他想象的要好得多，当我在旅程结束时在他的眼中发现了一些青睐。

CHAPTER XXXVI
第三十六章


Chesney Wold
切斯尼沃尔德

Charley and I did not set off alone upon our expedition into Lincolnshire. My guardian had made up his mind not to lose sight of me until I was safe in Mr. Boythorn’s house, so he accompanied us, and we were two days upon the road. I found every breath of air, and every scent, and every flower and leaf and blade of grass, and every passing cloud, and everything in nature, more beautiful and wonderful to me than I had ever found it yet. This was my first gain from my illness. How little I had lost, when the wide world was so full of delight for me.
查理和我并不是独自出发去林肯郡探险的。我的监护人决定在我安全到达博伊索恩先生的房子之前不会失去我的视线，所以他陪着我们，我们在路上走了两天。我发现每一口空气、每一种气味、每一朵花、每一片叶子、每一片草叶、每一朵飘过的云彩，以及大自然中的一切，对我来说都比我以前发现的更加美丽和奇妙。这是我从病中得到的第一个收获。当广阔的世界对我来说如此充满欢乐时，我失去的却是多么少啊。

My guardian intending to go back immediately, we appointed, on our way down, a day when my dear girl should come. I wrote her a letter, of which he took charge, and he left us within half an hour of our arrival at our destination, on a delightful evening in the early summer-time.
我的监护人打算立即回去，我们在下山的路上指定了我亲爱的女儿应该回来的一天。我给她写了一封信，由他负责，在我们到达目的地后半小时内，他就离开了我们，那是初夏的一个愉快的夜晚。

If a good fairy had built the house for me with a wave of her wand, and I had been a princess and her favoured god-child, I could not have been more considered in it. So many preparations were made for me and such an endearing remembrance was shown of all my little tastes and likings that I could have sat down, overcome, a dozen times before I had revisited half the rooms. I did better than that, however, by showing them all to Charley instead. Charley’s delight calmed mine; and after we had had a walk in the garden, and Charley had exhausted her whole vocabulary of admiring expressions, I was as tranquilly happy as I ought to have been. It was a great comfort to be able to say to myself after tea, ‘Esther, my dear, I think you are quite sensible enough to sit down now and write a note of thanks to your host.’ He had left a note of welcome for me, as sunny as his own face, and had confided his bird to my care, which I knew to be his highest mark of confidence. Accordingly I wrote a little note to him in London, telling him how all his favourite plants and trees were looking, and how the most astonishing of birds had chirped the honours of the house to me in the most hospitable manner, and how, after singing on my shoulder, to the inconceivable rapture of my little maid, he was then at roost in the usual corner of his cage, but whether dreaming or no I could not report. My note finished and sent off to the post, I made myself very busy in unpacking and arranging; and I sent Charley to bed in good time and told her I should want her no more that night.
如果一位善良的仙女挥动魔杖为我建造了这座房子，而我是一位公主和她最宠爱的教子，那么我在其中就不会受到更多的考虑。为我做了那么多的准备，对我所有的小品味和喜好都表现出了如此可爱的记忆，以至于我可以坐下来克服，在我重新参观一半的房间之前十几次。然而，我做得更好，把它们全部展示给查理看。查理的喜悦让我平静下来。我们在花园里散步后，查理用尽了她所有的赞美表情，我就如我应有的那样平静地快乐了。喝茶后能够对自己说：“埃丝特，亲爱的，我认为你现在很明智，可以坐下来给你的主人写一封感谢信。”他留下了一张欢迎信，这是一种极大的安慰。对我来说，他就像他自己的脸一样阳光明媚，并将他的鸟​​托付给我照顾，我知道这是他信任的最高标志。因此，我在伦敦给他写了一张小纸条，告诉他所有他最喜欢的植物和树木的样子，最令人惊奇的鸟儿如何以最热情的方式向我鸣叫，以表示这座房子的荣誉，以及在歌唱之后如何令我的小女仆难以置信的是，它栖息在笼子的通常角落里，但无论是不是在做梦，我都无法报告。信写完了寄出去，我忙着拆包、整理；我及时送查理上床睡觉，并告诉她那天晚上我不再需要她了。

For I had not yet looked in the glass and had never asked to have my own restored to me. I knew this to be a weakness which must be overcome, but I had always said to myself that I would begin afresh when I got to where I now was. Therefore I had wanted to be alone, and therefore I said, now alone, in my own room, ‘Esther, if you are to be happy, if you are to have any right to pray to be truehearted, you must keep your word, my dear.’ I was quite resolved to keep it, but I sat down for a little while first to reflect upon all my blessings. And then I said my prayers and thought a little more.
因为我还没有看过镜子，也从未要求将自己的镜子归还给我。我知道这是一个必须克服的弱点，但我总是对自己说，当我到达现在的位置时，我会重新开始。因此我本来想一个人呆着，所以现在独自一人在我自己的房间里，我说：‘以斯帖，如果你想要幸福，如果你想要有权利真诚地祈祷，你就必须遵守诺言，我亲爱的。”我下定决心要保留它，但我先坐下来思考了一会儿我所有的祝福。然后我祈祷并想了一些。

My hair had not been cut off, though it had been in danger more than once. It was long and thick. I let it down, and shook it out, and went up to the glass upon the dressing-table. There was a little muslin curtain drawn across it. I drew it back and stood for a moment looking through such a veil of my own hair that I could see nothing else. Then I put my hair aside and looked at the reflection in the mirror, encouraged by seeing how placidly it looked at me. I was very much changed—oh, very, very much. At first my face was so strange to me that I think I should have put my hands before it and started back but for the encouragement I have mentioned. Very soon it became more familiar, and then I knew the extent of the alteration in it better than I had done at first. It was not like what I had expected, but I had expected nothing definite, and I dare say anything definite would have surprised me.
我的头发没有被剪掉，尽管它不止一次处于危险之中。它又长又粗。我把它放下来，抖了抖，然后走到梳妆台上的玻璃面前。上面拉着一块细布小窗帘。我把它拉回来，站了一会儿，透过我自己的头发看去，我什么也看不见。然后我把头发放在一边，看着镜子里的倒影，看到它如此平静地看着我，我深受鼓舞。我改变了很多——哦，非常非常。起初，我的脸对我来说是如此陌生，以至于我想如果没有我提到的鼓励，我应该把手放在它前面然后开始返回。很快它就变得更加熟悉了，然后我比一开始更了解它的改变程度。这与我的预期不同，但我没有预料到任何明确的事情，而且我敢说任何明确的事情都会让我感到惊讶。

I had never been a beauty and had never thought myself one, but I had been very different from this. It was all gone now. Heaven was so good to me that I could let it go with a few not bitter tears and could stand there arranging my hair for the night quite thankfully.
我从来都不是美女，也从来不认为自己是美女，但我与此截然不同。现在一切都消失了。上天对我太好了，我可以流下几滴不苦涩的泪水就让它过去，庆幸的是我可以站在那里整理我的头发过夜。

One thing troubled me, and I considered it for a long time before I went to sleep. I had kept Mr. Woodcourt’s flowers. When they were withered I had dried them and put them in a book that I was fond of. Nobody knew this, not even Ada. I was doubtful whether I had a right to preserve what he had sent to one so different—whether it was generous towards him to do it. I wished to be generous to him, even in the secret depths of my heart, which he would never know, because I could have loved him—could have been devoted to him. At last I came to the conclusion that I might keep them if I treasured them only as a remembrance of what was irrevocably past and gone, never to be looked back on any more, in any other light. I hope this may not seem trivial. I was very much in earnest.
有件事困扰着我，我想了很久才睡觉。我保留了伍德考特先生的花。当它们枯萎时，我把它们晒干，放在我喜欢的书里。没有人知道这一点，甚至艾达也不知道。我怀疑我是否有权保留他送给如此不同的人的东西——这样做对他是否慷慨。我希望对他慷慨，即使是在我内心深处，他永远不会知道，因为我本可以爱他，本可以为他奉献。最后我得出的结论是，如果我珍惜它们，只是为了纪念那些不可挽回的过去和逝去的事情，永远不再以任何其他角度回顾的话，我就可以保留它们。我希望这看起来不是微不足道的。我是非常认真的。

I took care to be up early in the morning and to be before the glass when Charley came in on tiptoe.
早上我小心翼翼地起得很早，当查理踮起脚尖进来时，我就站在玻璃前。

‘Dear, dear, miss!’ cried Charley, starting. ‘Is that you?’
“亲爱的，亲爱的，小姐！”查利惊叫道。 '那是你吗？'

‘Yes, Charley,’ said I, quietly putting up my hair. ‘And I am very well indeed, and very happy.’
“是的，查理，”我轻轻地盘起头发说道。 “我确实很好，也很高兴。”

I saw it was a weight off Charley’s mind, but it was a greater weight off mine. I knew the worst now and was composed to it. I shall not conceal, as I go on, the weaknesses I could not quite conquer, but they always passed from me soon and the happier frame of mind stayed by me faithfully.
我发现查理心里的负担减轻了，但我的负担更重了。我现在已经知道最坏的情况了，并且已经做好了应对的准备。在我继续前进的过程中，我不会隐瞒那些我无法完全克服的弱点，但它们总是很快就会从我身边消失，而快乐的心态会忠实地留在我身边。

Wishing to be fully re-established in my strength and my good spirits before Ada came, I now laid down a little series of plans with Charley for being in the fresh air all day long. We were to be out before breakfast, and were to dine early, and were to be out again before and after dinner, and were to talk in the garden after tea, and were to go to rest betimes, and were to climb every hill and explore every road, lane, and field in the neighbourhood. As to restoratives and strengthening delicacies, Mr. Boythorn’s good housekeeper was for ever trotting about with something to eat or drink in her hand; I could not even be heard of as resting in the park but she would come trotting after me with a basket, her cheerful face shining with a lecture on the importance of frequent nourishment. Then there was a pony expressly for my riding, a chubby pony with a short neck and a mane all over his eyes who could canter—when he would—so easily and quietly that he was a treasure. In a very few days he would come to me in the paddock when I called him, and eat out of my hand, and follow me about. We arrived at such a capital understanding that when he was jogging with me lazily, and rather obstinately, down some shady lane, if I patted his neck and said, ‘Stubbs, I am surprised you don’t canter when you know how much I like it; and I think you might oblige me, for you are only getting stupid and going to sleep,’ he would give his head a comical shake or two and set off directly, while Charley would stand still and laugh with such enjoyment that her laughter was like music. I don’t know who had given Stubbs his name, but it seemed to belong to him as naturally as his rough coat. Once we put him in a little chaise and drove him triumphantly through the green lanes for five miles; but all at once, as we were extolling him to the skies, he seemed to take it ill that he should have been accompanied so far by the circle of tantalizing little gnats that had been hovering round and round his ears the whole way without appearing to advance an inch, and stopped to think about it. I suppose he came to the decision that it was not to be borne, for he steadily refused to move until I gave the reins to Charley and got out and walked, when he followed me with a sturdy sort of good humour, putting his head under my arm and rubbing his ear against my sleeve. It was in vain for me to say, ‘Now, Stubbs, I feel quite sure from what I know of you that you will go on if I ride a little while,’ for the moment I left him, he stood stock still again. Consequently I was obliged to lead the way, as before; and in this order we returned home, to the great delight of the village.
我希望在艾达来之前能完全恢复体力和良好的精神状态，现在我和查理制定了一系列计划，以便整天呼吸新鲜空气。我们要在早餐前出去，要早点吃饭，要在晚饭前后再次出去，要喝完茶后在花园里聊天，要及时去休息，要爬上每座山丘，探索附近的每条道路、小巷和田野。至于恢复体力的美味佳肴，博伊索恩先生的好管家总是手里拿着吃的或喝的东西走来走去。我什至听不到我在公园里休息的消息，但她会提着篮子小跑着跟在我后面，她那张开朗的脸闪闪发光，讲述着经常补充营养的重要性。还有一匹专门供我骑乘的小马，一匹胖乎乎的小马，脖子很短，眼睛上长着鬃毛，它可以慢跑——当他愿意的时候——如此轻松、安静，以至于他是一个宝贝。几天之内，当我呼唤他时，他就会到围场来找我，从我手中接过食物，并跟着我走来走去。我们达成了如此重要的谅解，当他和我一起懒洋洋地、相当固执地沿着一条阴暗的小巷慢跑时，如果我拍拍他的脖子说：“斯塔布斯，我很惊讶你不慢跑，当你知道我有多少喜欢它;我想你可能会答应我，因为你只会变得愚蠢，然后去睡觉。”他会滑稽地摇一摇他的头，然后直接出发，而查理会一动不动地站着，开心地笑，她的笑声就像音乐。我不知道是谁给斯塔布斯起了这个名字，但这似乎就像他那件粗糙的外套一样自然地属于他。 有一次，我们把他放在一辆小马车上，胜利地开着他穿过绿色车道，行驶了五英里。但突然间，当我们把他捧到天上时，他似乎很不高兴，觉得自己竟然被一圈诱人的小蚊子陪伴着走这么远，这些小蚊子一直在他的耳朵周围盘旋，却没有表现出任何迹象。前进一寸，停下来思考。我猜想他已经决定不接受这件事了，因为他一直拒绝移动，直到我把缰绳交给查理，下车走路，他带着一种坚定的幽默感跟着我，把头埋在下面。我的手臂，他的耳朵在我的袖子上摩擦。我徒劳地说：“现在，斯塔布斯，根据我对你的了解，我很确定，如果我骑一会儿，你就会继续前进。”在我离开他的那一刻，他又一动不动地站着。因此，我不得不像以前一样带路。我们就这样按顺序回家了，全村人都高兴极了。

Charley and I had reason to call it the most friendly of villages, I am sure, for in a week’s time the people were so glad to see us go by, though ever so frequently in the course of a day, that there were faces of greeting in every cottage. I had known many of the grown people before and almost all the children, but now the very steeple began to wear a familiar and affectionate look. Among my new friends was an old old woman who lived in such a little thatched and whitewashed dwelling that when the outside shutter was turned up on its hinges, it shut up the whole house-front. This old lady had a grandson who was a sailor, and I wrote a letter to him for her and drew at the top of it the chimney-corner in which she had brought him up and where his old stool yet occupied its old place. This was considered by the whole village the most wonderful achievement in the world, but when an answer came back all the way from Plymouth, in which he mentioned that he was going to take the picture all the way to America, and from America would write again, I got all the credit that ought to have been given to the postoffice and was invested with the merit of the whole system.
我确信查理和我有理由称它为最友好的村庄，因为在一周的时间里，人们很高兴看到我们经过，尽管一天中如此频繁地出现，以至于有一些面孔每间小屋都问候。我以前认识很多成年人，也认识几乎所有的孩子，但现在这座尖塔开始呈现出熟悉而亲切的样子。我的新朋友中有一位老太太，她住在一间粉刷成白色的茅草小屋里，当外面的百叶窗在铰链上打开时，整个房子的正面都被关闭了。这位老太太有一个孙子，是一名水手，我替她给他写了一封信，并在信的顶部画了她抚养他长大的烟囱角，以及他的旧凳子还占据着原来的位置。这被全村人认为是世界上最了不起的成就，但是当从普利茅斯远道而来的答复中，他提到他要一路拍到美国，而从美国会写下我再次获得了应归于邮局的所有荣誉，并投入了整个系统的优点。

Thus, what with being so much in the air, playing with so many children, gossiping with so many people, sitting on invitation in so many cottages, going on with Charley’s education, and writing long letters to Ada every day, I had scarcely any time to think about that little loss of mine and was almost always cheerful. If I did think of it at odd moments now and then, I had only to be busy and forget it. I felt it more than I had hoped I should once when a child said, ‘Mother, why is the lady not a pretty lady now like she used to be?’ But when I found the child was not less fond of me, and drew its soft hand over my face with a kind of pitying protection in its touch, that soon set me up again. There were many little occurrences which suggested to me, with great consolation, how natural it is to gentle hearts to be considerate and delicate towards any inferiority. One of these particularly touched me. I happened to stroll into the little church when a marriage was just concluded, and the young couple had to sign the register.
因此，在这么多的空气中，和这么多的孩子一起玩耍，和这么多的人闲聊，应邀坐在这么多的小屋里，继续查理的教育，每天给艾达写长信，我几乎没有什么可做的。每当想起我所失去的那点小事时，我都会感到很高兴。如果我确实偶尔想起这件事，我也只能忙着忘记它。有一次，当一个孩子说：“妈妈，为什么这位女士现在不再像以前那样漂亮了？”时，我的感受比我希望的还要强烈。它柔软的手抚过我的脸，触摸中带着一种怜悯的保护，很快我又恢复了活力。有许多小事让我感到极大的安慰，这让我意识到，温柔的心对任何自卑感都表现得体贴和敏感是多么自然的事情。其中有一件特别让我感动。我偶然走进小教堂，当时正值一场婚礼刚刚结束，年轻夫妇要在登记册上签字。

The bridegroom, to whom the pen was handed first, made a rude cross for his mark; the bride, who came next, did the same. Now, I had known the bride when I was last there, not only as the prettiest girl in the place, but as having quite distinguished herself in the school, and I could not help looking at her with some surprise. She came aside and whispered to me, while tears of honest love and admiration stood in her bright eyes, ‘He’s a dear good fellow, miss; but he can’t write yet—he’s going to learn of me—and I wouldn’t shame him for the world!’ Why, what had I to fear, I thought, when there was this nobility in the soul of a labouring man’s daughter!
新郎是第一个收到笔的人，他粗鲁地画了一个十字，作为自己的记号。接下来的新娘也做了同样的事情。现在，我上次来的时候就认识新娘了，她不仅是当地最漂亮的女孩，而且在学校里也很出名，我不禁有些惊讶地看着她。她走到一旁，对我低声说道，她明亮的眼睛里充满了真诚的爱和钦佩的泪水，“他是一个亲爱的好人，小姐；他是个好人。”但他还不会写——他要向我学习——我不会让他蒙羞！”哎呀，我想，当一个劳动人民的灵魂里有这种高贵的时候，我还有什么好害怕的呢？女儿！

The air blew as freshly and revivingly upon me as it had ever blown, and the healthy colour came into my new face as it had come into my old one. Charley was wonderful to see, she was so radiant and so rosy; and we both enjoyed the whole day and slept soundly the whole night.
空气一如既往地清新、充满活力，健康的色彩出现在我的新脸上，就像它出现在我的旧脸上一样。看到查理真是太棒了，她容光焕发，脸色红润。我们都度过了愉快的一天，并且睡了一整夜。

There was a favourite spot of mine in the park-woods of Chesney Wold where a seat had been erected commanding a lovely view. The wood had been cleared and opened to improve this point of sight, and the bright sunny landscape beyond was so beautiful that I rested there at least once every day. A picturesque part of the Hall, called the Ghost’s Walk, was seen to advantage from this higher ground; and the startling name, and the old legend in the Dedlock family which I had heard from Mr. Boythorn accounting for it, mingled with the view and gave it something of a mysterious interest in addition to its real charms. There was a bank here, too, which was a famous one for violets; and as it was a daily delight of Charley’s to gather wild flowers, she took as much to the spot as I did.
在切斯尼沃尔德的公园树林里有一个我最喜欢的地方，那里竖起了一个座位，可以欣赏到美丽的景色。树林已被清理并打开，以改善视野，远处阳光明媚的风景是如此美丽，我每天至少在那里休息一次。大厅中有一个风景如画的部分，称为“幽灵步道”，地势较高，可以说是有利的。这个令人吃惊的名字，以及我从博伊索恩先生那里听来的戴德洛克家族的古老传说，与这景色融为一体，除了真正的魅力之外，还给它带来了一些神秘的趣味。这里还有一家银行，以紫罗兰闻名。由于采摘野花是查理每天的一大乐趣，所以她和我一样带了很多野花。

It would be idle to inquire now why I never went close to the house or never went inside it. The family were not there, I had heard on my arrival, and were not expected. I was far from being incurious or uninterested about the building; on the contrary, I often sat in this place wondering how the rooms ranged and whether any echo like a footstep really did resound at times, as the story said, upon the lonely Ghost’s Walk. The indefinable feeling with which Lady Dedlock had impressed me may have had some influence in keeping me from the house even when she was absent. I am not sure. Her face and figure were associated with it, naturally; but I cannot say that they repelled me from it, though something did. For whatever reason or no reason, I had never once gone near it, down to the day at which my story now arrives.
现在问我为什么从来没有走近那所房子，或者从来没有进去过，是毫无意义的。我到达时就听说他们的家人不在，这也是我预料之外的事情。我对这座建筑并非不感兴趣。相反，我经常坐在这个地方，想知道房间的分布情况，以及是否真的像故事中所说的那样，在孤独的鬼道上有时会响起像脚步声这样的回声。戴德洛克夫人给我留下的难以言表的感觉可能对我产生了某种影响，即使她不在，我也无法到家中去。我不知道。她的脸和身材自然与它联系在一起。但我不能说他们排斥我，尽管有些东西确实排斥了我。不管出于什么原因，或者没有任何原因，直到我的故事现在到来的那一天，我从来没有靠近过它。

I was resting at my favourite point after a long ramble, and Charley was gathering violets at a little distance from me. I had been looking at the Ghost’s Walk lying in a deep shade of masonry afar off and picturing to myself the female shape that was said to haunt it when I became aware of a figure approaching through the wood. The perspective was so long and so darkened by leaves, and the shadows of the branches on the ground made it so much more intricate to the eye, that at first I could not discern what figure it was. By little and little it revealed itself to be a woman’s—a lady’s—Lady Dedlock’s. She was alone and coming to where I sat with a much quicker step, I observed to my surprise, than was usual with her.
经过长时间的漫步后，我正在我最喜欢的地方休息，查理正在离我不远的地方采摘紫罗兰。我一直看着远处砖石深处的幽灵步道，想象着据说出没于其中的女性身影，这时我意识到一个人影穿过树林走近。视野太长，被树叶遮得又暗，加上地面上树枝的影子，显得更加错综复杂，一开始我看不出那是什么人影。渐渐地，它显露出来是一个女人的——一位女士的——戴德洛克夫人的。我惊讶地发现，她独自一人来到我坐的地方，脚步比平常快得多。

I was fluttered by her being unexpectedly so near (she was almost within speaking distance before I knew her) and would have risen to continue my walk. But I could not. I was rendered motionless. Not so much by her hurried gesture of entreaty, not so much by her quick advance and outstretched hands, not so much by the great change in her manner and the absence of her haughty self-restraint, as by a something in her face that I had pined for and dreamed of when I was a little child, something I had never seen in any face, something I had never seen in hers before.
她出乎意料地离我如此之近，让我心慌意乱（在我认识她之前，她几乎就在说话的距离之内），我想站起来继续散步。但我不能。我一动不动。与其说是因为她匆忙的恳求姿态，不如说是因为她迅速走上前并伸出了双手，与其说是因为她态度的巨大变化和她傲慢的自我克制的缺失，不如说是因为她脸上的某种东西让我无法理解。当我还是个小孩子的时候，我就曾渴望和梦想过，这是我从未在任何人的脸上看到过的东西，也是我以前从未在她的脸上看到过的东西。

A dread and faintness fell upon me, and I called to Charley. Lady Dedlock stopped upon the instant and changed back almost to what I had known her.
一种恐惧和晕眩袭上我的心头，我呼唤查理。戴德洛克夫人立刻停了下来，几乎变回了我所认识的样子。

‘Miss Summerson, I am afraid I have startled you,’ she said, now advancing slowly. ‘You can scarcely be strong yet. You have been very ill, I know. I have been much concerned to hear it.’
“萨默森小姐，恐怕我吓到了你，”她一边说，一边慢慢地向前走去。 ‘你还很难变得坚强。我知道你病得很重。听到这个消息我很担心。

I could no more have removed my eyes from her pale face than I could have stirred from the bench on which I sat. She gave me her hand, and its deadly coldness, so at variance with the enforced composure of her features, deepened the fascination that overpowered me. I cannot say what was in my whirling thoughts.
我无法将目光从她苍白的脸上移开，就像我无法从我所坐的长凳上站起来一样。她向我伸出了手，那手的冰冷与她强行镇定的神情格格不入，加深了我的迷恋。我无法说出我内心的想法。

‘You are recovering again?’ she asked kindly.
“你康复了吗？”她友善地问道。

‘I was quite well but a moment ago, Lady Dedlock.’
“刚才我还很好，戴德洛克夫人。”

‘Is this your young attendant?’
“这是你的小侍从吗？”

‘Yes.’
'是的。'

‘Will you send her on before and walk towards your house with me?’
“你可以先送她一起去你家吗？”

‘Charley,’ said I, ‘take your flowers home, and I will follow you directly.’
“查理，”我说，“把你的花带回家，我会直接跟着你。”

Charley, with her best curtsy, blushingly tied on her bonnet and went her way. When she was gone, Lady Dedlock sat down on the seat beside me.
查莉行了她最好的屈膝礼，红着脸戴上了帽子，走开了。她走后，戴德洛克夫人在我旁边的座位上坐下。

I cannot tell in any words what the state of my mind was when I saw in her hand my handkerchief with which I had covered the dead baby.
当我看到她手里拿着我用来盖死婴儿的手帕时，我无法用任何言语表达我的心情。

I looked at her, but I could not see her, I could not hear her, I could not draw my breath. The beating of my heart was so violent and wild that I felt as if my life were breaking from me. But when she caught me to her breast, kissed me, wept over me, compassionated me, and called me back to myself; when she fell down on her knees and cried to me, ‘Oh, my child, my child, I am your wicked and unhappy mother! Oh, try to forgive me!’—when I saw her at my feet on the bare earth in her great agony of mind, I felt, through all my tumult of emotion, a burst of gratitude to the providence of God that I was so changed as that I never could disgrace her by any trace of likeness, as that nobody could ever now look at me and look at her and remotely think of any near tie between us.
我看着她，但我看不到她，听不到她的声音，我无法呼吸。我的心脏跳动得如此剧烈和狂野，以至于我感觉我的生命正在与我分离。但当她把我抱在怀里，亲吻我，为我哭泣，同情我，让我清醒过来时；当她跪下向我哭喊时，‘哦，我的孩子，我的孩子，我是你邪恶而不幸的母亲！哦，试着原谅我吧！”——当我看到她在我的脚下，站在光秃秃的土地上，内心极度痛苦时，我在激动的情绪中，突然对上帝的眷顾感到一阵感激，因为上帝让我如此幸运。改变是因为我永远不会因为任何相似的痕迹而羞辱她，因为现在没有人会在看着我和她的时候远远地想到我们之间有任何密切的联系。

I raised my mother up, praying and beseeching her not to stoop before me in such affliction and humiliation. I did so in broken, incoherent words, for besides the trouble I was in, it frightened me to see her at MY feet. I told her—or I tried to tell her—that if it were for me, her child, under any circumstances to take upon me to forgive her, I did it, and had done it, many, many years. I told her that my heart overflowed with love for her, that it was natural love which nothing in the past had changed or could change. That it was not for me, then resting for the first time on my mother’s bosom, to take her to account for having given me life, but that my duty was to bless her and receive her, though the whole world turned from her, and that I only asked her leave to do it. I held my mother in my embrace, and she held me in hers, and among the still woods in the silence of the summer day there seemed to be nothing but our two troubled minds that was not at peace.
我把母亲扶了起来，祈祷并恳求她不要在我面前如此痛苦和屈辱。我用断断续续、语无伦次的语言这样做了，因为除了我遇到的麻烦之外，看到她站在我的脚下也让我感到害怕。我告诉她——或者我试图告诉她——如果我，她的孩子，在任何情况下都愿意原谅她，我就会这么做，而且已经做了很多很多年了。我告诉她，我的心里充满了对她的爱，这是自然的爱，过去没有任何事情可以改变，也无法改变。那时我第一次躺在母亲的怀抱里，并不是因为她赋予了我生命，而是我的责任是祝福她并接纳她，尽管整个世界都背弃了她，我只是请她允许这样做。我把母亲搂在怀里，她也把我搂在怀里，夏日寂静的树林里，除了我们两个不安的心，似乎什么也没有。

‘To bless and receive me,’ groaned my mother, ‘it is far too late. I must travel my dark road alone, and it will lead me where it will. From day to day, sometimes from hour to hour, I do not see the way before my guilty feet. This is the earthly punishment I have brought upon myself. I bear it, and I hide it.’
“祝福并接待我，”母亲呻吟道，“已经太晚了。”我必须独自走完我的黑暗之路，它会带我去往它想去的地方。日复一日，有时一小时又一小时，我都看不到我罪恶的脚前的路。这就是我给自己带来的尘世惩罚。我承受它，我隐藏它。

Even in the thinking of her endurance, she drew her habitual air of proud indifference about her like a veil, though she soon cast it off again.
即使想到她的忍耐力，她还是把惯常的傲慢冷漠的神态像一层面纱一样包裹在身上，尽管她很快又把它脱掉了。

‘I must keep this secret, if by any means it can be kept, not wholly for myself. I have a husband, wretched and dishonouring creature that I am!’
“如果可以以任何方式保守这个秘密，我必须保守这个秘密，但不能完全为我自己保守。”我有一个丈夫，而我就是一个可怜又丢人的家伙！

These words she uttered with a suppressed cry of despair, more terrible in its sound than any shriek. Covering her face with her hands, she shrank down in my embrace as if she were unwilling that I should touch her; nor could I, by my utmost persuasions or by any endearments I could use, prevail upon her to rise. She said, no, no, no, she could only speak to me so; she must be proud and disdainful everywhere else; she would be humbled and ashamed there, in the only natural moments of her life.
她说这句话时，带着压抑的绝望呼喊，声音比任何尖叫声都更可怕。她用手捂住脸，缩在我的怀里，似乎不愿意我碰她。我也无法用我最大的说服力或我能用的任何爱意说服她站起来。她说，不不不，她只能这样对我说话；她在其他地方一定是骄傲而轻蔑的；在她生命中唯一自然的时刻，她会在那里感到谦卑和羞愧。

My unhappy mother told me that in my illness she had been nearly frantic. She had but then known that her child was living. She could not have suspected me to be that child before. She had followed me down here to speak to me but once in all her life. We never could associate, never could communicate, never probably from that time forth could interchange another word on earth. She put into my hands a letter she had written for my reading only and said when I had read it and destroyed it—but not so much for her sake, since she asked nothing, as for her husband’s and my own—I must evermore consider her as dead. If I could believe that she loved me, in this agony in which I saw her, with a mother’s love, she asked me to do that, for then I might think of her with a greater pity, imagining what she suffered. She had put herself beyond all hope and beyond all help. Whether she preserved her secret until death or it came to be discovered and she brought dishonour and disgrace upon the name she had taken, it was her solitary struggle always; and no affection could come near her, and no human creature could render her any aid.
我不高兴的母亲告诉我，在我生病的时候，她几乎要发疯了。她当时才知道她的孩子还活着。她以前不可能怀疑我就是那个孩子。她跟着我到这里来跟我说话，但这辈子只有一次。我们永远无法交往，永远无法交流，从那时起，我们可能永远无法在地球上互换另一个词。她把一封她写的信交给我，仅供我阅读，并说当我读完这封信后，她就把它销毁了——但与其说是为了她，因为她什么也没问，不如说是为了她丈夫和我自己的——我必须永远考虑她就像死了一样。如果我能相信她爱我，在我看到她的痛苦中，带着母爱，她要求我这样做，因为那样我可能会更加怜悯地想到她，想象她所遭受的痛苦。她已经让自己失去了一切希望和帮助。无论她将自己的秘密保守到死，还是被发现，让她所取的名字蒙羞，这始终是她孤独的斗争；没有任何感情可以靠近她，也没有任何人类可以向她提供任何帮助。

‘But is the secret safe so far?’ I asked. ‘Is it safe now, dearest mother?’
“但是到目前为止这个秘密安全吗？”我问道。 “现在安全吗，最亲爱的妈妈？”

‘No,’ replied my mother. ‘It has been very near discovery. It was saved by an accident. It may be lost by another accident—tomorrow, any day.’
“不，”我母亲回答道。 ‘它已经非常接近被发现了。一次意外得救了。它可能会因另一次事故而丢失——明天，任何一天。

‘Do you dread a particular person?’
“你害怕某个特定的人吗？”

‘Hush! Do not tremble and cry so much for me. I am not worthy of these tears,’ said my mother, kissing my hands. ‘I dread one person very much.’
‘嘘！不要为我颤抖和哭泣。我不值得流这些眼泪。”母亲亲吻我的手说道。 “我非常害怕一个人。”

‘An enemy?’
“敌人？”

‘Not a friend. One who is too passionless to be either. He is Sir Leicester Dedlock’s lawyer, mechanically faithful without attachment, and very jealous of the profit, privilege, and reputation of being master of the mysteries of great houses.’
‘不是朋友。一个太冷漠的人，不可能是其中之一。他是莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士的律师，机械地忠诚而没有依恋，并且非常嫉妒成为大家族之谜主人的利润、特权和声誉。

‘Has he any suspicions?’
“他有什么怀疑吗？”

‘Many.’
'许多。'

‘Not of you?’ I said alarmed.
“不是你吗？”我惊恐地说。

‘Yes! He is always vigilant and always near me. I may keep him at a standstill, but I can never shake him off.’
'是的！他总是很警惕，总是靠近我。我可能会让他停滞不前，但我永远无法摆脱他。

‘Has he so little pity or compunction?’
“他就这么少有怜悯或内疚吗？”

‘He has none, and no anger. He is indifferent to everything but his calling. His calling is the acquisition of secrets and the holding possession of such power as they give him, with no sharer or opponent in it.’
‘他没有，也没有愤怒。除了他的使命之外，他对一切都漠不关心。他的使命是获取秘密并拥有秘密赋予他的权力，没有分享者或对手。

‘Could you trust in him?’
“你能相信他吗？”

‘I shall never try. The dark road I have trodden for so many years will end where it will. I follow it alone to the end, whatever the end be. It may be near, it may be distant; while the road lasts, nothing turns me.’
‘我永远不会尝试。我走了这么多年的黑暗路，也到了该结束的时候了。我独自追随它到底，无论结局如何。可能近，也可能远；当路还长的时候，没有什么能让我兴奋。”

‘Dear mother, are you so resolved?’
“亲爱的妈妈，你就这么决心吗？”

‘I AM resolved. I have long outbidden folly with folly, pride with pride, scorn with scorn, insolence with insolence, and have outlived many vanities with many more. I will outlive this danger, and outdie it, if I can. It has closed around me almost as awfully as if these woods of Chesney Wold had closed around the house, but my course through it is the same. I have but one; I can have but one.’
‘我已经下定决心了。长期以来，我一直在以愚昧战胜愚昧，以骄傲战胜骄傲，以蔑视战胜蔑视，以傲慢战胜傲慢，并以更多的方式战胜虚荣。如果可以的话，我会战胜这种危险，并战胜它。它几乎将我包围起来，就像切斯尼森林的树林包围了房子一样可怕，但我穿过它的路线是一样的。我只有一个；我只能拥有一个。

‘Mr. Jarndyce—‘ I was beginning when my mother hurriedly inquired, ‘Does HE suspect?’
'先生。贾迪斯——“我刚开始，我妈妈就急忙问道，‘他怀疑吗？’

‘No,’ said I. ‘No, indeed! Be assured that he does not!’ And I told her what he had related to me as his knowledge of my story. ‘But he is so good and sensible,’ said I, ‘that perhaps if he knew—‘
“不，”我说，“确实不！”请放心，他不会！”我告诉她他对我的了解，即他对我故事的了解。 “但他是如此善良和明智，”我说，“也许如果他知道——”

My mother, who until this time had made no change in her position, raised her hand up to my lips and stopped me.
母亲一直没有改变立场，她把手举到我的唇边，阻止了我。

‘Confide fully in him,’ she said after a little while. ‘You have my free consent—a small gift from such a mother to her injured child!but do not tell me of it. Some pride is left in me even yet.’
“完全相信他，”过了一会儿她说道。 “你得到了我的自由同意——这样一位母亲给她受伤的孩子的一份小礼物！但不要告诉我。我心里还残留着一些自豪感。

I explained, as nearly as I could then, or can recall now—for my agitation and distress throughout were so great that I scarcely understood myself, though every word that was uttered in the mother’s voice, so unfamiliar and so melancholy to me, which in my childhood I had never learned to love and recognize, had never been sung to sleep with, had never heard a blessing from, had never had a hope inspired by, made an enduring impression on my memory—I say I explained, or tried to do it, how I had only hoped that Mr. Jarndyce, who had been the best of fathers to me, might be able to afford some counsel and support to her. But my mother answered no, it was impossible; no one could help her. Through the desert that lay before her, she must go alone.
我尽我所能地解释，或者现在能回忆起来——因为我自始至终都如此激动和痛苦，以至于我几乎听不懂自己的意思，尽管母亲的声音中所说的每一个字对我来说都是如此陌生和如此忧郁，在我的童年里，我从未学会爱和认识，从未被唱歌入睡，从未听过祝福，从未激发过希望，在我的记忆中留下持久的印象——我说我解释过，或者尝试过为了做到这一点，我多么希望贾迪斯先生，他对我来说是最好的父亲，能够为她提供一些建议和支持。但妈妈的回答是不，不可能；没有人能帮助她。穿越面前的沙漠，她必须独自前行。

‘My child, my child!’ she said. ‘For the last time! These kisses for the last time! These arms upon my neck for the last time! We shall meet no more. To hope to do what I seek to do, I must be what I have been so long. Such is my reward and doom. If you hear of Lady Dedlock, brilliant, prosperous, and flattered, think of your wretched mother, conscience-stricken, underneath that mask! Think that the reality is in her suffering, in her useless remorse, in her murdering within her breast the only love and truth of which it is capable! And then forgive her if you can, and cry to heaven to forgive her, which it never can!’
“我的孩子，我的孩子！”她说。 '最后一次！这是最后一次吻了！这是最后一次用手臂搭在我的脖子上！我们不会再见面了。为了希望做我想做的事，我必须成为我长期以来的样子。这就是我的奖赏和厄运。如果你听说过戴德洛克夫人，她才华横溢，富有，受宠若惊，想想你可怜的母亲，在面具下，良心受到打击！想想现实就在她的痛苦中，在她无用的悔恨中，在她胸中谋杀了她所能拥有的唯一的爱和真理！然后如果可以的话就原谅她，向天堂哭诉以原谅她，但它永远做不到！

We held one another for a little space yet, but she was so firm that she took my hands away, and put them back against my breast, and with a last kiss as she held them there, released them, and went from me into the wood. I was alone, and calm and quiet below me in the sun and shade lay the old house, with its terraces and turrets, on which there had seemed to me to be such complete repose when I first saw it, but which now looked like the obdurate and unpitying watcher of my mother’s misery.
我们还互相拥抱了一会儿，但她太坚定了，她把我的手拿开，放回我的胸前，最后一个吻，她握着它们，松开它们，从我身边进入了我的世界。木头。我独自一人，在阳光和树荫下，我脚下那座老房子平静而安静，有露台和塔楼，当我第一次看到它时，我觉得它是如此完全的休息，但现在看起来就像顽固而无情地注视着我母亲的苦难。

Stunned as I was, as weak and helpless at first as I had ever been in my sick chamber, the necessity of guarding against the danger of discovery, or even of the remotest suspicion, did me service. I took such precautions as I could to hide from Charley that I had been crying, and I constrained myself to think of every sacred obligation that there was upon me to be careful and collected. It was not a little while before I could succeed or could even restrain bursts of grief, but after an hour or so I was better and felt that I might return. I went home very slowly and told Charley, whom I found at the gate looking for me, that I had been tempted to extend my walk after Lady Dedlock had left me and that I was over-tired and would lie down. Safe in my own room, I read the letter. I clearly derived from it—and that was much then—that I had not been abandoned by my mother. Her elder and only sister, the godmother of my childhood, discovering signs of life in me when I had been laid aside as dead, had in her stern sense of duty, with no desire or willingness that I should live, reared me in rigid secrecy and had never again beheld my mother’s face from within a few hours of my birth. So strangely did I hold my place in this world that until within a short time back I had never, to my own mother’s knowledge, breathed—had been buried—had never been endowed with life—had never borne a name. When she had first seen me in the church she had been startled and had thought of what would have been like me if it had ever lived, and had lived on, but that was all then.
尽管我很震惊，一开始就像我在病房里一样虚弱无助，但必须防范被发现的危险，甚至是最轻微的怀疑，这对我很有帮助。我采取了尽可能多的预防措施，向查理隐瞒我一直在哭，我强迫自己思考我所肩负的每一项神圣义务，要小心谨慎，镇定自若。没过多久我就成功了，甚至可以抑制住阵阵悲伤，但一个小时左右后，我就好了，觉得我可能会回来。我慢慢地回家，告诉查理，我发现他在门口找我，在戴德洛克夫人离开我之后，我一直想延长步行时间，而且我太累了，会躺下来。我在自己的房间里安全地读了这封信。我清楚地从中得出——当时就这样——我并没有被母亲抛弃。她唯一的姐姐，我童年的教母，当我被当作死人放在一边时，她发现了我的生命迹象，她以她严厉的责任感，没有欲望或意愿让我活下去，严格保密地抚养我长大。在我出生后的几个小时内，我再也没有见过我母亲的脸。奇怪的是，我在这个世界上占据着自己的位置，直到不久之前，据我母亲所知，我从未呼吸过——被埋葬过——从未被赋予生命——从未有过名字。当她第一次在教堂里看到我时，她吃了一惊，想到如果它曾经存在过，并且一直存在下去，会是什么样子，但仅此而已。

What more the letter told me needs not to be repeated here. It has its own times and places in my story.
信中所告诉我的更多内容无需在此重复。它在我的故事中有自己的时间和地点。

My first care was to burn what my mother had written and to consume even its ashes. I hope it may not appear very unnatural or bad in me that I then became heavily sorrowful to think I had ever been reared. That I felt as if I knew it would have been better and happier for many people if indeed I had never breathed. That I had a terror of myself as the danger and the possible disgrace of my own mother and of a proud family name. That I was so confused and shaken as to be possessed by a belief that it was right and had been intended that I should die in my birth, and that it was wrong and not intended that I should be then alive.
我首先关心的是烧掉母亲写下的东西，甚至烧掉它的灰烬。我希望，当我想到自己曾经被抚养长大时，我变得非常悲伤，这对我来说不会显得非常不自然或糟糕。我感觉好像我知道，如果我确实从未呼吸过，对许多人来说会更好、更快乐。我对自己感到恐惧，因为我害怕自己的母亲和我骄傲的姓氏面临危险和可能的耻辱。我感到如此困惑和动摇，以至于被一种信念所占据，即我出生时就应该死去，这是正确的，也是命中注定的，而我活着的时候是错误的，也是命中注定的。

These are the real feelings that I had. I fell asleep worn out, and when I awoke I cried afresh to think that I was back in the world with my load of trouble for others. I was more than ever frightened of myself, thinking anew of her against whom I was a witness, of the owner of Chesney Wold, of the new and terrible meaning of the old words now moaning in my ear like a surge upon the shore, ‘Your mother, Esther, was your disgrace, and you are hers. The time will come—and soon enough—when you will understand this better, and will feel it too, as no one save a woman can.’ With them, those other words returned, ‘Pray daily that the sins of others be not visited upon your head.’ I could not disentangle all that was about me, and I felt as if the blame and the shame were all in me, and the visitation had come down.
这些都是我的真实感受。我疲惫不堪地睡着了，当我醒来时，我又哭了，想到我又回到了这个世界，还给别人带来了很多麻烦。我比以往任何时候都更害怕自己，重新想到我所见证的她，想到切斯尼沃尔德的主人，想到现在像海岸上的浪潮一样在我耳边呻吟的旧词的新的和可怕的含义，“你的母亲埃丝特是你的耻辱，而你是她的耻辱。那个时刻将会到来——而且很快——那时你会更好地理解这一点，也会感受到这一点，除了女人之外，没有人能做到这一点。”他们又想起了那句话，“每天祈祷，不要让别人的罪孽受到追究。”我无法理清所有关于我的事情，我觉得责备和羞耻都在我身上，而拜访已经降临了。

The day waned into a gloomy evening, overcast and sad, and I still contended with the same distress. I went out alone, and after walking a little in the park, watching the dark shades falling on the trees and the fitful flight of the bats, which sometimes almost touched me, was attracted to the house for the first time. Perhaps I might not have gone near it if I had been in a stronger frame of mind. As it was, I took the path that led close by it.
天色渐暗，傍晚时分，阴云密布，悲伤不已，而我仍然在与同样的痛苦作斗争。我独自出去，在公园里走了一会儿，看着树上的黑影和断断续续的飞行的蝙蝠，有时几乎触动了我，第一次被这座房子所吸引。如果我当时的心态更坚强的话，也许我就不会接近它。事实上，我走的是它附近的那条路。

I did not dare to linger or to look up, but I passed before the terrace garden with its fragrant odours, and its broad walks, and its well-kept beds and smooth turf; and I saw how beautiful and grave it was, and how the old stone balustrades and parapets, and wide flights of shallow steps, were seamed by time and weather; and how the trained moss and ivy grew about them, and around the old stone pedestal of the sun-dial; and I heard the fountain falling. Then the way went by long lines of dark windows diversified by turreted towers and porches of eccentric shapes, where old stone lions and grotesque monsters bristled outside dens of shadow and snarled at the evening gloom over the escutcheons they held in their grip. Thence the path wound underneath a gateway, and through a court-yard where the principal entrance was (I hurried quickly on), and by the stables where none but deep voices seemed to be, whether in the murmuring of the wind through the strong mass of ivy holding to a high red wall, or in the low complaining of the weathercock, or in the barking of the dogs, or in the slow striking of a clock. So, encountering presently a sweet smell of limes, whose rustling I could hear, I turned with the turning of the path to the south front, and there above me were the balustrades of the Ghost’s Walk and one lighted window that might be my mother’s.
我不敢久留，也不敢抬头，但我经过了芳香四溢的露台花园，宽阔的步道，整洁的床铺和光滑的草坪；我看到它是多么美丽和庄严，古老的石栏杆和护栏，以及宽阔的浅台阶，是如何被时间和天气所缝合的。以及他们周围以及日晷的旧石座周围如何生长出经过训练的苔藓和常春藤；我听到喷泉落下的声音。然后，一路上经过一长排黑暗的窗户，其中有塔楼和形状怪异的门廊，古老的石狮子和怪诞的怪物在阴影的巢穴外竖立着，对着他们手中的盾牌上的夜色咆哮。从那儿，小路在大门下面蜿蜒而行，穿过主入口所在的庭院（我赶紧向前走），经过马厩，那里似乎只有低沉的声音，无论是风吹过人群的低语声。常春藤挂在高高的红墙上，或者在风向标的低声抱怨中，或者在狗的吠叫中，或者在时钟的缓慢敲击中。因此，不久我就闻到了一股酸橙的甜香，我能听到它的沙沙声，我随着小路的转弯转向南面，在我的上方是幽灵步道的栏杆和一扇可能是我母亲的灯火通明的窗户。

The way was paved here, like the terrace overhead, and my footsteps from being noiseless made an echoing sound upon the flags. Stopping to look at nothing, but seeing all I did see as I went, I was passing quickly on, and in a few moments should have passed the lighted window, when my echoing footsteps brought it suddenly into my mind that there was a dreadful truth in the legend of the Ghost’s Walk, that it was I who was to bring calamity upon the stately house and that my warning feet were haunting it even then. Seized with an augmented terror of myself which turned me cold, I ran from myself and everything, retraced the way by which I had come, and never paused until I had gained the lodge-gate, and the park lay sullen and black behind me.
这里的路是铺好的，就像头顶上的露台一样，我的脚步声无声无息，在旗帜上发出回响。停下来不看任何东西，但看到了我所看到的一切，我快速地向前走，过一会儿就应该经过那扇亮着灯的窗户，这时我回响的脚步声突然让我意识到有一个可怕的事实在鬼行的传说中，是我给这座庄严的房子带来了灾难，而我的警告脚甚至在那时就在它附近徘徊。我对自己产生了一种增强的恐惧，这种恐惧使我浑身发冷，我逃离了自己和一切，沿着来时的路走回了原路，一直没有停下来，直到我到达小屋大门，公园就在我身后阴沉而黑暗的地方。

Not before I was alone in my own room for the night and had again been dejected and unhappy there did I begin to know how wrong and thankless this state was. But from my darling who was coming on the morrow, I found a joyful letter, full of such loving anticipation that I must have been of marble if it had not moved me; from my guardian, too, I found another letter, asking me to tell Dame Durden, if I should see that little woman anywhere, that they had moped most pitiably without her, that the housekeeping was going to rack and ruin, that nobody else could manage the keys, and that everybody in and about the house declared it was not the same house and was becoming rebellious for her return. Two such letters together made me think how far beyond my deserts I was beloved and how happy I ought to be. That made me think of all my past life; and that brought me, as it ought to have done before, into a better condition.
直到我独自一人在自己的房间里过夜，再次感到沮丧和不高兴之前，我才开始知道这种状态是多么错误和吃力不讨好。但我从第二天就要来的亲爱的那里发现了一封令人高兴的信，充满了如此充满爱的期待，如果它没有感动我，我一定是大理石的；我还找到了我的监护人的另一封信，要求我告诉德登夫人，如果我应该在任何地方看到那个小女人，没有她，他们就闷闷不乐，家政服务将会崩溃，没有其他人可以管理钥匙，房子里和房子周围的每个人都宣称这不是同一所房子，并且对她的回归变得叛逆。两封这样的信放在一起，让我想到我所爱的人远远超出了我的应得，我应该感到多么幸福。这让我想起了我过去的生活；正如以前应该做的那样，这使我处于更好的状态。

For I saw very well that I could not have been intended to die, or I should never have lived; not to say should never have been reserved for such a happy life. I saw very well how many things had worked together for my welfare, and that if the sins of the fathers were sometimes visited upon the children, the phrase did not mean what I had in the morning feared it meant. I knew I was as innocent of my birth as a queen of hers and that before my Heavenly Father I should not be punished for birth nor a queen rewarded for it. I had had experience, in the shock of that very day, that I could, even thus soon, find comforting reconcilements to the change that had fallen on me. I renewed my resolutions and prayed to be strengthened in them, pouring out my heart for myself and for my unhappy mother and feeling that the darkness of the morning was passing away. It was not upon my sleep; and when the next day’s light awoke me, it was gone.
因为我很清楚，我不可能死，或者我根本不应该活下去。更不用说永远不应该保留这样幸福的生活。我清楚地看到有多少事情共同为我的福祉而努力，如果父亲的罪孽有时会降临在孩子们身上，那么这句话的意思并不像我早上担心的那样。我知道我的出生就像她的女王一样无辜，并且在我的天父面前，我不应该因为出生而受到惩罚，也不应该因此而得到女王的奖励。在那一天的震惊中，我有过这样的经验：即使这么快，我也能找到令人欣慰的和解来应对降临在我身上的变化。我重新制定了自己的决心，并祈祷自己的决心能够得到加强，为自己和不幸的母亲倾诉心声，并感到早晨的黑暗正在消失。这不是在我睡觉时发生的；而是在我睡觉时发生的。当第二天的光线唤醒我时，它已经消失了。

My dear girl was to arrive at five o’clock in the afternoon. How to help myself through the intermediate time better than by taking a long walk along the road by which she was to come, I did not know; so Charley and I and Stubbs—Stubbs saddled, for we never drove him after the one great occasion—made a long expedition along that road and back. On our return, we held a great review of the house and garden and saw that everything was in its prettiest condition, and had the bird out ready as an important part of the establishment.
我亲爱的女儿将于下午五点到达。我不知道如何才能更好地帮助自己度过这中间的时间，而不是沿着她要走的路走很长一段路。于是查理、我和斯塔布斯——斯塔布斯备好了马鞍，因为在这个伟大的场合之后我们再也没有开车送过他——沿着那条路来回进行了一次长途探险。回来后，我们对房子和花园进行了一次仔细的检查，发现一切都处于最漂亮的状态，并准备好了这只鸟，作为酒店的重要组成部分。

There were more than two full hours yet to elapse before she could come, and in that interval, which seemed a long one, I must confess I was nervously anxious about my altered looks. I loved my darling so well that I was more concerned for their effect on her than on any one. I was not in this slight distress because I at all repined—I am quite certain I did not, that day—but, I thought, would she be wholly prepared? When she first saw me, might she not be a little shocked and disappointed? Might it not prove a little worse than she expected? Might she not look for her old Esther and not find her? Might she not have to grow used to me and to begin all over again?
距离她来还有整整两个多小时，在那段看似漫长的间隔里，我必须承认，我对自己容貌的改变感到紧张焦虑。我非常爱我的宝贝，所以我比任何人都更关心它们对她的影响。我并没有陷入这种轻微的痛苦，因为我根本没有抱怨——我很确定那天我没有抱怨——但是，我想，她会做好充分的准备吗？当她第一次看到我的时候，会不会有些震惊和失望呢？会不会比她预想的还要糟糕一点？难道她不会去寻找她的老艾丝特却找不到她吗？难道她不必习惯我并重新开始吗？

I knew the various expressions of my sweet girl’s face so well, and it was such an honest face in its loveliness, that I was sure beforehand she could not hide that first look from me. And I considered whether, if it should signify any one of these meanings, which was so very likely, could I quite answer for myself?
我非常熟悉我可爱的女孩脸上的各种表情，这是一张如此诚实可爱的脸，我事先就确信她无法向我隐瞒第一眼的表情。我想，如果它代表这些含义中的任何一种（而且很有可能），我是否可以为自己做出回答？

Well, I thought I could. After last night, I thought I could. But to wait and wait, and expect and expect, and think and think, was such bad preparation that I resolved to go along the road again and meet her.
嗯，我想我可以。经过昨晚之后，我想我可以。但等啊等，期待啊期待，想啊想，准备得如此糟糕，我决定再次沿着这条路去见她。

So I said to Charley, ‘“Charley, I will go by myself and walk along the road until she comes.’ Charley highly approving of anything that pleased me, I went and left her at home.
于是我对查理说：“查理，我自己一个人去，沿着路走，直到她来。”查理对任何让我高兴的事情都非常满意，我就走了，把她留在家里。

But before I got to the second milestone, I had been in so many palpitations from seeing dust in the distance (though I knew it was not, and could not, be the coach yet) that I resolved to turn back and go home again. And when I had turned, I was in such fear of the coach coming up behind me (though I still knew that it neither would, nor could, do any such thing) that I ran the greater part of the way to avoid being overtaken.
但在到达第二个里程碑之前，我因看到远处的灰尘而感到心悸（尽管我知道我还不是，也不能成为教练），所以我决定折返并再次回家。当我转弯时，我非常害怕教练追上我（尽管我仍然知道它既不会也不可能做任何这样的事情），所以我跑了大部分路以避免被超越。

Then, I considered, when I had got safe back again, this was a nice thing to have done! Now I was hot and had made the worst of it instead of the best.
然后我想，当我再次安全回来时，这真是一件好事！现在我很热，并且做了最坏的事情，而不是最好的事情。

At last, when I believed there was at least a quarter of an hour more yet, Charley all at once cried out to me as I was trembling in the garden, ‘Here she comes, miss! Here she is!’
最后，当我相信至少还有一刻钟的时候，当我在花园里瑟瑟发抖时，查理突然向我喊道：“她来了，小姐！”她在这！'

I did not mean to do it, but I ran upstairs into my room and hid myself behind the door. There I stood trembling, even when I heard my darling calling as she came upstairs, ‘Esther, my dear, my love, where are you? Little woman, dear Dame Durden!’
我本来不是故意的，但我跑上楼进了自己的房间，躲到了门后面。我站在那儿，浑身发抖，甚至听到我亲爱的上楼时喊道：“艾丝特，亲爱的，我的爱人，你在哪里？”小女人，亲爱的德登夫人！

She ran in, and was running out again when she saw me. Ah, my angel girl! The old dear look, all love, all fondness, all affection. Nothing else in it—no, nothing, nothing!
她跑了进来，看到我时又跑了出去。啊，我的天使女孩！昔日亲爱的样子，全是爱，全是喜爱，全是感情。里面什么也没有——不，什么都没有，什么都没有！

Oh, how happy I was, down upon the floor, with my sweet beautiful girl down upon the floor too, holding my scarred face to her lovely cheek, bathing it with tears and kisses, rocking me to and fro like a child, calling me by every tender name that she could think of, and pressing me to her faithful heart.
哦，我多么高兴，趴在地板上，我可爱美丽的女孩也趴在地板上，把我伤痕累累的脸贴在她可爱的脸颊上，用泪水和亲吻沐浴它，像孩子一样摇晃我，呼唤我用她能想到的每一个温柔的名字，把我压在她忠实的心上。

CHAPTER XXXVII
第三十七章


Jarndyce and Jarndyce
贾迪斯和贾迪斯

If the secret I had to keep had been mine, I must have confided it to Ada before we had been long together. But it was not mine, and I did not feel that I had a right to tell it, even to my guardian, unless some great emergency arose. It was a weight to bear alone; still my present duty appeared to be plain, and blest in the attachment of my dear, I did not want an impulse and encouragement to do it. Though often when she was asleep and all was quiet, the remembrance of my mother kept me waking and made the night sorrowful, I did not yield to it at another time; and Ada found me what I used to be—except, of course, in that particular of which I have said enough and which I have no intention of mentioning any more just now, if I can help it.
如果我必须保守的秘密是我自己的，我一定在我们在一起很久之前就把它告诉了艾达。但这不是我的，而且我觉得我没有权利告诉它，即使是对我的监护人，除非出现重大紧急情况。这是一个需要独自承受的重量；不过，我目前的职责似乎很简单，而且有幸与我亲爱的人依恋，我不想因为冲动和鼓励而去做这件事。虽然常常当她睡着了，万籁俱寂的时候，我就会想起母亲，让我彻夜难眠，让我的夜晚变得悲伤，但在其他时候我并没有屈服。艾达发现了我以前的样子——当然，除了那个我已经说得够多了、如果可以的话我现在不想再提的具体情况。

The difficulty that I felt in being quite composed that first evening when Ada asked me, over our work, if the family were at the house, and when I was obliged to answer yes, I believed so, for Lady Dedlock had spoken to me in the woods the day before yesterday, was great. Greater still when Ada asked me what she had said, and when I replied that she had been kind and interested, and when Ada, while admitting her beauty and elegance, remarked upon her proud manner and her imperious chilling air. But Charley helped me through, unconsciously, by telling us that Lady Dedlock had only stayed at the house two nights on her way from London to visit at some other great house in the next county and that she had left early on the morning after we had seen her at our view, as we called it. Charley verified the adage about little pitchers, I am sure, for she heard of more sayings and doings in a day than would have come to my ears in a month.
第一天晚上，当艾达问我，关于我们的工作，家人是否在家里时，我感到很难保持镇定，当我不得不回答“是”时，我相信是的，因为戴德洛克夫人在前天的树林，很棒。更重要的是，当艾达问我她说了些什么，当我回答说她很友善且感兴趣时，当艾达承认她的美丽和优雅时，却评论了她傲慢的举止和专横的冷酷神情。但查理不知不觉地帮助我度过了难关，他告诉我们，戴德洛克夫人在从伦敦出发去参观下一个县的另一座大宅的途中，只在这所房子里住了两晚，而且在我们离开后的第二天一早，她就离开了。从我们的角度来看她，正如我们所说的那样。我确信查理证实了关于小水手的格言，因为她一天听到的说法和行为比我一个月听到的还多。

We were to stay a month at Mr. Boythorn’s. My pet had scarcely been there a bright week, as I recollect the time, when one evening after we had finished helping the gardener in watering his flowers, and just as the candles were lighted, Charley, appearing with a very important air behind Ada’s chair, beckoned me mysteriously out of the room.
我们要在博伊索恩先生家住一个月。我记得我的宠物在那儿呆了不到一个愉快的星期，有一天晚上，我们帮园丁浇完花后，蜡烛刚刚点燃，查理就以一种非常重要的神态出现在艾达的椅子后面。 ，神秘地招呼我走出房间。

‘Oh! If you please, miss,’ said Charley in a whisper, with her eyes at their roundest and largest. ‘You’re wanted at the Dedlock Arms.’
'哦！如果您愿意的话，小姐。”查理小声说道，她的眼睛睁得又圆又大。 “戴德洛克武器店正在通缉你。”

‘Why, Charley,’ said I, ‘who can possibly want me at the publichouse?’
“为什么，查理，”我说，“谁会想要我去酒店呢？”

‘I don’t know, miss,’ returned Charley, putting her head forward and folding her hands tight upon the band of her little apron, which she always did in the enjoyment of anything mysterious or confidential, ‘but it’s a gentleman, miss, and his compliments, and will you please to come without saying anything about it.’
“我不知道，小姐，”查理回答道，她把头向前倾，双手紧紧地扣在小围裙的带子上，她在享受任何神秘或机密的事情时总是这样做，“但这是一位绅士，小姐。” ，以及他的赞美，请您不要说什么就来吧。

‘Whose compliments, Charley?’
“查理，谁的赞美？”

‘His’n, miss,’ returned Charley, whose grammatical education was advancing, but not very rapidly.
“他的，小姐，”查利回答道，他的语法教育正在进步，但进展不是很快。

‘And how do you come to be the messenger, Charley?’
“查理，你是怎么成为信使的？”

‘I am not the messenger, if you please, miss,’ returned my little maid. ‘It was W. Grubble, miss.’
“我不是信使，请您原谅，小姐，”我的小女仆回答道。 “是W·格鲁布尔，小姐。”

‘And who is W. Grubble, Charley?’
“查理，W·格拉布尔是谁？”

‘Mister Grubble, miss,’ returned Charley. ‘Don’t you know, miss? The Dedlock Arms, by W. Grubble,’ which Charley delivered as if she were slowly spelling out the sign.
“格拉布尔先生，小姐，”查利回答道。 ‘小姐你不知道吗？ 《戴德洛克武器》（The Dedlock Arms），作者：W·格鲁布尔（W. Grubble），查理说道，就好像她在慢慢地拼出这个标志一样。

‘Aye? The landlord, Charley?’
‘是吗？房东，查理？

‘Yes, miss. If you please, miss, his wife is a beautiful woman, but she broke her ankle, and it never joined. And her brother’s the sawyer that was put in the cage, miss, and they expect he’ll drink himself to death entirely on beer,’ said Charley.
'是的，女士。麻烦您了，小姐，他的妻子是一位美丽的女人，但她扭断了脚踝，从此再也没有连上。她哥哥就是被关在笼子里的锯木工，小姐，他们预计他会喝啤酒喝死。”查理说。

Not knowing what might be the matter, and being easily apprehensive now, I thought it best to go to this place by myself. I bade Charley be quick with my bonnet and veil and my shawl, and having put them on, went away down the little hilly street, where I was as much at home as in Mr. Boythorn’s garden.
由于不知道发生了什么事，而且现在很容易担心，我认为最好自己去这个地方。我吩咐查理快点戴上我的帽子、面纱和披肩，然后戴上它们，沿着小山路走开，在那里我就像在博伊索恩先生的花园里一样自在。

Mr. Grubble was standing in his shirt-sleeves at the door of his very clean little tavern waiting for me. He lifted off his hat with both hands when he saw me coming, and carrying it so, as if it were an iron vessel (it looked as heavy), preceded me along the sanded passage to his best parlour, a neat carpeted room with more plants in it than were quite convenient, a coloured print of Queen Caroline, several shells, a good many tea-trays, two stuffed and dried fish in glass cases, and either a curious egg or a curious pumpkin (but I don’t know which, and I doubt if many people did) hanging from his ceiling. I knew Mr. Grubble very well by sight, from his often standing at his door. A pleasant-looking, stoutish, middle-aged man who never seemed to consider himself cozily dressed for his own fire-side without his hat and top-boots, but who never wore a coat except at church.
格鲁布尔先生穿着衬衫站在他那间非常干净的小酒馆门口等我。当他看到我走过来时，他用双手摘下帽子，拎着它，仿佛它是一个铁器皿（看起来很重），在我前面沿着铺着沙子的通道来到他最好的客厅，这是一个铺着地毯的整洁房间，里面有更多东西。里面的植物比以前相当方便，一张卡罗琳王后的彩色照片，几个贝壳，很多茶盘，玻璃柜里的两条填充鱼干，还有一个奇怪的鸡蛋或一个奇怪的南瓜（但我不知道我怀疑是否有很多人这样做）挂在天花板上。我对格鲁布尔先生很熟悉，因为他经常站在他家门口。一个相貌宜人、粗壮的中年男子，似乎从来不认为自己在不戴帽子和高筒靴的情况下在自己的炉边穿着舒适，但除了在教堂之外，他从不穿外套。

He snuffed the candle, and backing away a little to see how it looked, backed out of the room—unexpectedly to me, for I was going to ask him by whom he had been sent. The door of the opposite parlour being then opened, I heard some voices, familiar in my ears I thought, which stopped.
