It looks as if Symond were a sparing man in his way and constructed his inn of old building materials which took kindly to the dry rot and to dirt and all things decaying and dismal, and perpetuated Symond’s memory with congenial shabbiness. Quartered in this dingy hatchment commemorative of Symond are the legal bearings of Mr. Vholes.
弗霍尔斯先生的名字，前面加上传说中的“底层”，刻在大法官巷西蒙旅馆的门柱上——这是一家苍白、双眼斜视、悲惨的小旅馆，就像一个有两个隔间的大垃圾箱，一个筛子。看起来西蒙德在他的方式上是一个节约的人，他用旧的建筑材料建造了他的旅馆，这些建筑材料对干腐烂和污垢以及所有腐烂和阴暗的东西很友好，并以令人愉快的破旧永存了西蒙德的记忆。在这个肮脏的西蒙纪念馆里，有弗霍尔斯先生的合法身份。

Mr. Vholes’s office, in disposition retiring and in situation retired, is squeezed up in a corner and blinks at a dead wall. Three feet of knotty-floored dark passage bring the client to Mr. Vholes’s jet-black door, in an angle profoundly dark on the brightest midsummer morning and encumbered by a black bulk-head of cellarage staircase against which belated civilians generally strike their brows. Mr. Vholes’s chambers are on so small a scale that one clerk can open the door without getting off his stool, while the other who elbows him at the same desk has equal facilities for poking the fire. A smell as of unwholesome sheep blending with the smell of must and dust is referable to the nightly (and often daily) consumption of mutton fat in candles and to the fretting of parchment forms and skins in greasy drawers. The atmosphere is otherwise stale and close. The place was last painted or whitewashed beyond the memory of man, and the two chimneys smoke, and there is a loose outer surface of soot evervwhere, and the dull cracked windows in their heavy frames have but one piece of character in them, which is a determination to be always dirty and always shut unless coerced. This accounts for the phenomenon of the weaker of the two usually having a bundle of firewood thrust between its jaws in hot weather.
沃尔斯先生的办公室，正处于退休状态，也处于退休状态，挤在一个角落里，对着一堵死墙眨眼。三英尺长、地板上布满疙瘩的黑暗通道将客户带到了沃尔斯先生漆黑的门前，在最明亮的仲夏早晨，门的角度非常黑暗，并被地下室楼梯的黑色舱壁阻碍，迟到的平民通常会在楼梯上皱起眉头。沃尔斯先生的房间规模很小，一名职员不用离开凳子就可以打开门，而另一位在同一张桌子上用肘部推着他的职员也有同样的设施来戳火。不健康的羊的气味与芥末和灰尘的气味混合在一起，指的是每晚（通常是每天）在蜡烛中消耗的羊脂，以及油腻的抽屉里羊皮纸和羊皮的磨损。否则气氛就陈旧而封闭。这个地方最后一次被油漆或粉刷过，已经超出了人们的记忆，两个烟囱冒着烟，到处都是松散的煤灰外表面，厚重的框架上暗淡、开裂的窗户只有一个特征，那就是除非被迫，否则决心永远肮脏，永远封闭。这就是为什么在炎热的天气里，两者中较弱的一方通常会用嘴夹一捆木柴的现象。

Mr. Vholes is a very respectable man. He has not a large business, but he is a very respectable man. He is allowed by the greater attorneys who have made good fortunes or are making them to be a most respectable man. He never misses a chance in his practice, which is a mark of respectability. He never takes any pleasure, which is another mark of respectability. He is reserved and serious, which is another mark of respectability. His digestion is impaired, which is highly respectable. And he is making hay of the grass which is flesh, for his three daughters. And his father is dependent on him in the Vale of Taunton.
Vholes 先生是一位非常值得尊敬的人。他没有很大的生意，但他是一个非常值得尊敬的人。他得到了那些发了大财或正在使他们成为最受尊敬的人的伟大律师的允许。他在练习中从不错过任何一个机会，这是受人尊敬的标志。他从不享受任何快乐，这是受人尊敬的另一个标志。他内向而严肃，这是受人尊敬的另一个标志。他的消化功能受损，这是非常值得尊敬的。他正在用有肉的草为他的三个女儿做干草。他的父亲在汤顿谷依赖他。

The one great principle of the English law is to make business for itself. There is no other principle distinctly, certainly, and consistently maintained through all its narrow turnings. Viewed by this light it becomes a coherent scheme and not the monstrous maze the laity are apt to think it. Let them but once clearly perceive that its grand principle is to make business for itself at their expense, and surely they will cease to grumble.
英国法律的一项重要原则是为自己做生意。没有任何其他原则能够在其所有的狭窄转折中得到明确、确定和始终如一的维护。从这个角度来看，它变成了一个连贯的计划，而不是外行人容易认为的巨大迷宫。只要让他们清楚地认识到它的伟大原则就是以牺牲自己为代价为自己谋取利益，他们就一定不会再抱怨了。

But not perceiving this quite plainly—only seeing it by halves in a confused way—the laity sometimes suffer in peace and pocket, with a bad grace, and DO grumble very much. Then this respectability of Mr. Vholes is brought into powerful play against them. ‘Repeal this statute, my good sir?’ says Mr. Kenge to a smarting client. ‘Repeal it, my dear sir? Never, with my consent. Alter this law, sir, and what will be the effect of your rash proceeding on a class of practitioners very worthily represented, allow me to say to you, by the opposite attorney in the case, Mr. Vholes? Sir, that class of practitioners would be swept from the face of the earth. Now you cannot afford—I will say, the social system cannot afford—to lose an order of men like Mr. Vholes. Diligent, persevering, steady, acute in business. My dear sir, I understand your present feelings against the existing state of things, which I grant to be a little hard in your case; but I can never raise my voice for the demolition of a class of men like Mr. Vholes.’ The respectability of Mr. Vholes has even been cited with crushing effect before Parliamentary committees, as in the following blue minutes of a distinguished attorney’s evidence. ‘Question (number five hundred and seventeen thousand eight hundred and sixty-nine): If I understand you, these forms of practice indisputably occasion delay? Answer: Yes, some delay. Question: And great expense? Answer: Most assuredly they cannot be gone through for nothing. Question: And unspeakable vexation? Answer: I am not prepared to say that. They have never given ME any vexation; quite the contrary. Question: But you think that their abolition would damage a class of practitioners? Answer: I have no doubt of it. Question: Can you instance any type of that class? Answer: Yes. I would unhesitatingly mention Mr. Vholes. He would be ruined. Question: Mr. Vholes is considered, in the profession, a respectable man? Answer: ‘—which proved fatal to the inquiry for ten years—‘Mr. Vholes is considered, in the profession, a MOST respectable man.’
但他们并没有很清楚地认识到这一点——只是以一种混乱的方式半途而废地看待这一点——平信徒有时会在平静和口袋里受苦，带着一种不好的风度，而且确实会发牢骚。然后，沃尔斯先生的这种受人尊敬的态度在对抗他们时发挥了强大的作用。 “废除这条法规吧，我的好先生？”肯吉先生对一位聪明的客户说道。 ‘亲爱的先生，废除它吗？经我同意，绝对不会。先生，改变这条法律，你的鲁莽行动会对一类非常值得代表的从业者产生什么影响，请允许我对你说，由本案的另一位律师，弗霍尔斯先生？先生，这一班修行者将会从地球表面被扫除。现在你不能——我想说，社会制度不能——失去像沃尔斯先生这样的人。勤奋、坚忍、稳健、敏锐。亲爱的先生，我理解您目前对现状的感受，我承认这对您来说有点困难；沃尔斯先生的受人尊敬甚至在议会委员会中得到了压倒性的效果，正如一位杰出律师在接下来的蓝色会议记录中所提供的证据一样。 ‘问（第五十一万七千八百六十九）：如果我理解你的话，这些修行方式无疑会造成延误？答：是的，有一些延迟。问：费用大吗？回答：当然，这些事情不可能白费。问：还有说不出的烦恼？答：我不准备这么说。他们从来没有给我带来任何烦恼；恰恰相反。弟子：但是您认为废除会损害一个修炼者阶层吗？答：我对此毫不怀疑。问题：你能实例化该类的任何类型吗？ 答：是的。我会毫不犹豫地提到 Vholes 先生。他会被毁掉的。问：Vholes 先生在业内被认为是一位受人尊敬的人吗？回答：“——这对十年的调查来说是致命的——”先生。在这个行业中，Vholes 被认为是最受尊敬的人。’

So in familiar conversation, private authorities no less disinterested will remark that they don’t know what this age is coming to, that we are plunging down precipices, that now here is something else gone, that these changes are death to people like Vholes—a man of undoubted respectability, with a father in the Vale of Taunton, and three daughters at home. Take a few steps more in this direction, say they, and what is to become of Vholes’s father? Is he to perish? And of Vholes’s daughters? Are they to be shirt-makers, or governesses? As though, Mr. Vholes and his relations being minor cannibal chiefs and it being proposed to abolish cannibalism, indignant champions were to put the case thus: Make man-eating unlawful, and you starve the Vholeses!
因此，在熟悉的谈话中，同样公正的私人当局会说，他们不知道这个时代即将走向何方，我们正在跌入悬崖，现在这里已经有其他东西消失了，这些变化对像沃勒斯这样的人来说是死亡——毫无疑问，他是一位受人尊敬的人，父亲住在汤顿谷，家里有三个女儿。他们说，朝这个方向再迈出几步，沃尔斯的父亲会变成什么样子呢？他要灭亡吗？沃勒斯的女儿们呢？她们是衬衫制造商，还是家庭教师？就好像沃勒斯先生和他的亲戚是食人族的小酋长，而提议废除食人行为一样，愤怒的拥护者们会这样说：把吃人定为非法，你就会让沃勒斯人挨饿！

In a word, Mr. Vholes, with his three daughters and his father in the Vale of Taunton, is continually doing duty, like a piece of timber, to shore up some decayed foundation that has become a pitfall and a nuisance. And with a great many people in a great many instances, the question is never one of a change from wrong to right (which is quite an extraneous consideration), but is always one of injury or advantage to that eminently respectable legion, Vholes.
总之，沃尔斯先生带着他的三个女儿和他的父亲住在汤顿谷，他像一块木头一样，不断地履行职责，以加固一些已经成为陷阱和麻烦的腐烂的基础。对于很多人来说，在很多情况下，问题从来不是从错误到正确的转变（这是一个相当无关的考虑），而始终是对Vholes这一令人尊敬的军团的伤害或好处。

The Chancellor is, within these ten minutes, ‘up’ for the long vacation. Mr. Vholes, and his young client, and several blue bags hastily stuffed out of all regularity of form, as the larger sort of serpents are in their first gorged state, have returned to the official den. Mr. Vholes, quiet and unmoved, as a man of so much respectability ought to be, takes off his close black gloves as if he were skinning his hands, lifts off his tight hat as if he were scalping himself, and sits down at his desk. The client throws his hat and gloves upon the ground—tosses them anywhere, without looking after them or caring where they go; flings himself into a chair, half sighing and half groaning; rests his aching head upon his hand and looks the portrait of young despair.
在这十分钟内，财政大臣就准备开始放长假了。沃尔斯先生和他年轻的客户，以及几个被匆忙塞进的蓝色袋子，因为较大的蛇正处于第一次狼吞虎咽的状态，他们已经回到了官方巢穴。沃尔斯先生安静而无动于衷，就像一个受人尊敬的人应该有的那样，他脱下贴身的黑色手套，就像在剥手上的皮一样，摘下紧闭的帽子，就像在给自己剥头皮一样，然后在他的座位上坐下。桌子。客户把他的帽子和手套扔到地上——把它们扔到任何地方，不看管它们，也不关心它们去了哪里；他一屁股坐在椅子上，一半叹息一半呻吟。他用手托着疼痛的头，看上去就像年轻人绝望的写照。

‘Again nothing done!’ says Richard. ‘Nothing, nothing done!’
“又什么也没做！”理查德说。 “没什么，什么都没做！”

‘Don’t say nothing done, sir,’ returns the placid Vholes. ‘That is scarcely fair, sir, scarcely fair!’
“别说什么都没做，先生。”平静的沃尔斯回答道。 “这太不公平了，先生，太不公平了！”

‘Why, what IS done?’ says Richard, turning gloomily upon him.
“哎呀，到底发生了什么？”理查德阴郁地转向他说道。

‘That may not be the whole question,’ returns Vholes, ‘The question may branch off into what is doing, what is doing?’
“这可能不是问题的全部，”沃尔斯回答道，“问题可能会延伸到正在做什么，正在做什么？”

‘And what is doing?’ asks the moody client.
“那我们在做什么？”这位喜怒无常的客户问道。

Vholes, sitting with his arms on the desk, quietly bringing the tips of his five right fingers to meet the tips of his five left fingers, and quietly separating them again, and fixedly and slowly looking at his client, replies, ‘A good deal is doing, sir. We have put our shoulders to the wheel, Mr. Carstone, and the wheel is going round.’
沃尔斯坐在桌子上，双臂放在桌子上，静静地将右手五根手指的指尖与左手五根手指的指尖相碰，然后又静静地分开，固定地、缓慢地看着他的客户，回答道：“很划算。”正在做，先生。卡斯通先生，我们已经把我们的肩膀放在了方向盘上，方向盘正在转动。

‘Yes, with Ixion on it. How am I to get through the next four or five accursed months?’ exclaims the young man, rising from his chair and walking about the room.
“是的，上面有伊克西翁。我该如何度过接下来的四五个月呢？”年轻人惊呼道，从椅子上站起来，在房间里走来走去。

‘Mr. C.,’ returns Vholes, following him close with his eyes wherever he goes, ‘your spirits are hasty, and I am sorry for it on your account. Excuse me if I recommend you not to chafe so much, not to be so impetuous, not to wear yourself out so. You should have more patience. You should sustain yourself better.’
'先生。 “C.，”沃尔斯回答道，无论他走到哪里，他的眼睛都紧紧地跟着他，“你的情绪很急躁，我为你感到抱歉。对不起，我建议你不要那么生气，不要那么浮躁，不要那么疲惫。你应该有更多的耐心。你应该更好地维持自己。

‘I ought to imitate you, in fact, Mr. Vholes?’ says Richard, sitting down again with an impatient laugh and beating the devil’s tattoo with his boot on the patternless carpet.
“事实上，我应该效仿你，沃尔斯先生？”理查德说道，一边不耐烦地笑着重新坐下，用靴子在无图案的地毯上敲打着魔鬼的纹身。

‘Sir,’ returns Vholes, always looking at the client as if he were making a lingering meal of him with his eyes as well as with his professional appetite. ‘Sir,’ returns Vholes with his inward manner of speech and his bloodless quietude, ‘I should not have had the presumption to propose myself as a model for your imitation or any man’s. Let me but leave the good name to my three daughters, and that is enough for me; I am not a self-seeker. But since you mention me so pointedly, I will acknowledge that I should like to impart to you a little of my—come, sir, you are disposed to call it insensibility, and I am sure I have no objection—say insensibility—a little of my insensibility.’
“先生，”沃尔斯回答道，他总是看着客户，仿佛他正在用自己的眼睛和专业的胃口为他做一顿令人流连忘返的大餐。 “先生，”沃尔斯用他内心的说话方式和冷酷的平静回答说，“我不应该冒昧地把自己当作你或任何人模仿的榜样。让我把好名字留给我的三个女儿吧，这对我来说就足够了。我不是一个自私自利的人。但既然你如此尖锐地提到我，我承认我想向你透露一点我的——来吧，先生，你倾向于称其为麻木不仁，我确信我不反对——说麻木不仁——一点我的麻木不仁。

‘Mr. Vholes,’ explains the client, somewhat abashed, ‘I had no intention to accuse you of insensibility.’
'先生。 “Vholes，”这位客户有点尴尬地解释道，“我无意指责你麻木不仁。”

‘I think you had, sir, without knowing it,’ returns the equable Vholes. ‘Very naturally. It is my duty to attend to your interests with a cool head, and I can quite understand that to your excited feelings I may appear, at such times as the present, insensible. My daughters may know me better; my aged father may know me better. But they have known me much longer than you have, and the confiding eye of affection is not the distrustful eye of business. Not that I complain, sir, of the eye of business being distrustful; quite the contrary. In attending to your interests, I wish to have all possible checks upon me; it is right that I should have them; I court inquiry. But your interests demand that I should be cool and methodical, Mr. Carstone; and I cannot be otherwise—no, sir, not even to please you.’
“我想你已经这么做了，先生，但你自己并不知道。”平静的沃尔斯回答道。 ‘非常自然。我有责任冷静地关注您的利益，而且我完全可以理解，对于您激动的感情，在目前这样的时刻，我可能显得麻木不仁。我的女儿们可能更了解我；我年迈的父亲可能更了解我。但他们认识我的时间比你长得多，充满感情的信任之眼并不是商业上的怀疑之眼。先生，我并不是抱怨商业界的目光不信任；我只是抱怨。恰恰相反。为了照顾您的利益，我希望对我进行一切可能的检查；我应该拥有它们，这是正确的；我法庭调查。但你的利益要求我必须冷静、有条理，卡斯通先生；我不能这样做——不，先生，甚至不是为了取悦您。”

Mr. Vholes, after glancing at the official cat who is patiently watching a mouse’s hole, fixes his charmed gaze again on his young client and proceeds in his buttoned-up, half-audible voice as if there were an unclean spirit in him that will neither come out nor speak out, ‘What are you to do, sir, you inquire, during the vacation. I should hope you gentlemen of the army may find many means of amusing yourselves if you give your minds to it. If you had asked me what I was to do during the vacation, I could have answered you more readily. I am to attend to your interests. I am to be found here, day by day, attending to your interests. That is my duty, Mr. C., and term-time or vacation makes no difference to me. If you wish to consult me as to your interests, you will find me here at all times alike. Other professional men go out of town. I don’t. Not that I blame them for going; I merely say I don’t go. This desk is your rock, sir!’
沃尔斯先生看了一眼正在耐心观察老鼠洞的官方猫后，再次用他迷人的目光注视着他的年轻客户，并用他压抑的、几乎听不见的声音继续说道，仿佛他体内有一个不洁的灵魂，既不出来也不说话：‘先生，您问，假期期间您要做什么？我希望军中的先生们只要用心，就能找到许多娱乐的方式。如果你问我假期要做什么，我可以更轻松地回答你。我要照顾你的兴趣。我会在这里发现，日复一日，关注你的兴趣。这是我的职责，C. 先生，学期或假期对我来说没有区别。如果您想就您的兴趣向我咨询，您随时都会在这里找到我。其他职业人士则出城。我不。并不是我责怪他们去；而是我责备他们。我只是说我不去。这张桌子是你的基石，先生！”

Mr. Vholes gives it a rap, and it sounds as hollow as a coffin. Not to Richard, though. There is encouragement in the sound to him. Perhaps Mr. Vholes knows there is.
沃尔斯先生敲了敲，听起来就像棺材一样空洞。不过，对理查德来说不是。声音里带着对他的鼓励。也许沃尔斯先生知道有这样的事情。

‘I am perfectly aware, Mr. Vholes,’ says Richard, more familiarly and good-humouredly, ‘that you are the most reliable fellow in the world and that to have to do with you is to have to do with a man of business who is not to be hoodwinked. But put yourself in my case, dragging on this dislocated life, sinking deeper and deeper into difficulty every day, continually hoping and continually disappointed, conscious of change upon change for the worse in myself, and of no change for the better in anything else, and you will find it a dark-looking case sometimes, as I do.’
“我完全清楚，沃尔斯先生，”理查德语气更加亲切、幽默地说，“您是世界上最可靠的人，与您打交道就像与商人打交道谁不被蒙蔽。但把你自己放在我的情况下，拖着这种混乱的生活，每天在困难中越陷越深，不断地希望和不断地失望，意识到自己的变化越来越糟，而其他任何事情都没有变好，有时你会发现它看起来很黑，就像我一样。

‘You know,’ says Mr. Vholes, ‘that I never give hopes, sir. I told you from the first, Mr. C., that I never give hopes. Particularly in a case like this, where the greater part of the costs comes out of the estate, I should not be considerate of my good name if I gave hopes. It might seem as if costs were my object. Still, when you say there is no change for the better, I must, as a bare matter of fact, deny that.’
“你知道，”沃尔斯先生说，“我从不抱有希望，先生。 C.先生，我从一开始就告诉过你，我从不抱有希望。尤其是在这种情况下，大部分费用都来自遗产，如果我寄予希望，我就不应该考虑到我的名誉。看起来成本似乎是我的目标。不过，当你说没有任何改善时，我必须，事实上，我必须否认这一点。

‘Aye?’ returns Richard, brightening. ‘But how do you make it out?’
“嗯？”理查德回答道，脸上的表情焕然一新。 “但是你怎么知道呢？”

‘Mr. Carstone, you are represented by—‘
'先生。卡斯顿，你的代表是——‘

‘You said just now—a rock.’
“你刚才说——一块石头。”

‘Yes, sir,’ says Mr. Vholes, gently shaking his head and rapping the hollow desk, with a sound as if ashes were falling on ashes, and dust on dust, ‘a rock. That’s something. You are separately represented, and no longer hidden and lost in the interests of others. THAT’S something. The suit does not sleep; we wake it up, we air it, we walk it about. THAT’S something. It’s not all Jarndyce, in fact as well as in name. THAT’S something. Nobody has it all his own way now, sir. And THAT’S something, surely.’
“是的，先生，”沃尔斯先生轻轻摇着头，敲打着空荡荡的桌子，发出的声音就好像灰烬落在灰烬上，灰尘落在灰尘上，“一块石头。”就是这样。你们有独立的代表，不再隐藏和迷失于他人的利益中。就是这样。套装不睡觉；我们叫醒它，播出它，散步它。就是这样。事实上，从名字上看，这并不全是贾迪斯。就是这样。现在没有人可以完全按照自己的方式行事，先生。当然，这就是事情。

Richard, his face flushing suddenly, strikes the desk with his clenched hand.
理查德的脸突然涨得通红，握紧的手敲打着桌子。

‘Mr. Vholes! If any man had told me when I first went to John Jarndyce’s house that he was anything but the disinterested friend he seemed—that he was what he has gradually turned out to be—I could have found no words strong enough to repel the slander; I could not have defended him too ardently. So little did I know of the world! Whereas now I do declare to you that he becomes to me the embodiment of the suit; that in place of its being an abstraction, it is John Jarndyce; that the more I suffer, the more indignant I am with him; that every new delay and every new disappointment is only a new injury from John Jarndyce’s hand.’
'先生。沃勒斯！当我第一次去约翰·贾迪斯家时，如果有人告诉我，他根本不是一个表面上看起来无私的朋友——他就是他逐渐变成的样子——我找不到任何有力的言语来驳斥这种诽谤；我不能太热情地为他辩护。我对这个世界知之甚少！然而现在我确实向你们宣布，他对我来说就是这套衣服的化身；它不是一个抽象概念，而是约翰·贾迪斯（John Jardyce）；我越受苦，我就越对他感到愤怒；每一次新的延误和每一次新的失望都只是约翰·贾迪斯手上的新伤。

‘No, no,’ says vholes. ‘Don’t say so. We ought to have patience, all of us. Besides, I never disparage, sir. I never disparage.’
“不，不，”沃尔斯说。 ‘别这么说。我们所有人都应该有耐心。此外，我从不贬低，先生。我从不贬低。

‘Mr. Vholes,’ returns the angry client. ‘You know as well as I that he would have strangled the suit if he could.’
'先生。 Vholes，”愤怒的客户回答道。 “你和我一样清楚，如果可以的话，他会掐死这套衣服的。”

‘He was not active in it,’ Mr. Vholes admits with an appearance of reluctance. ‘He certainly was not active in it. But however, but however, he might have had amiable intentions. Who can read the heart, Mr. C.!’
“他在这件事上并不积极，”沃尔斯先生承认道，他的表情显得不情愿。 “他当然不积极参与其中。但是，但是，但是，他也许是有好意的。谁能读懂人心，C先生！”

‘You can,’ returns Richard.
“你可以，”理查德回答道。

‘I, Mr. C.?’
“我，C先生？”

‘Well enough to know what his intentions were. Are or are not our interests conflicting? Tell—me—that!’ says Richard, accompanying his last three words with three raps on his rock of trust.
‘足以知道他的意图是什么。我们的利益是否冲突？告诉我那个！”理查德说道，在他的最后三个字的同时，还敲击了他信任的磐石三声。

‘Mr. C.,’ returns Vholes, immovable in attitude and never winking his hungry eyes, ‘I should be wanting in my duty as your professional adviser, I should be departing from my fidelity to your interests, if I represented those interests as identical with the interests of Mr. Jarndyce. They are no such thing, sir. I never impute motives; I both have and am a father, and I never impute motives. But I must not shrink from a professional duty, even if it sows dissensions in families. I understand you to be now consulting me professionally as to your interests? You are so? I reply, then, they are not identical with those of Mr. Jarndyce.’
'先生。 C.，”弗霍尔斯回答道，态度坚定，从不眨动他那双饥渴的眼睛，“如果我将这些利益与你的利益等同起来，我就没有履行作为你的专业顾问的职责，我就应该背离对你的利益的忠诚。”贾迪斯先生的兴趣。他们不是这样的人，先生。我从不归咎于动机；我既是父亲，也是父亲，我从不归咎于动机。但我绝不能回避职业职责，即使这会在家庭中造成不和。据我所知，您现在正在就您的兴趣向我进行专业咨询？你太？那么我的回答是，它们与贾迪斯先生的并不相同。

‘Of course they are not!’ cries Richard. ‘You found that out long ago.’
“当然不是！”理查德喊道。 “你很久以前就发现了。”

‘Mr. C.,’ returns Vholes, ‘I wish to say no more of any third party than is necessary. I wish to leave my good name unsullied, together with any little property of which I may become possessed through industry and perseverance, to my daughters Emma, Jane, and Caroline. I also desire to live in amity with my professional brethren. When Mr. Skimpole did me the honour, sir—I will not say the very high honour, for I never stoop to flattery—of bringing us together in this room, I mentioned to you that I could offer no opinion or advice as to your interests while those interests were entrusted to another member of the profession. And I spoke in such terms as I was bound to speak of Kenge and Carboy’s office, which stands high. You, sir, thought fit to withdraw your interests from that keeping nevertheless and to offer them to me. You brought them with clean hands, sir, and I accepted them with clean hands. Those interests are now paramount in this office. My digestive functions, as you may have heard me mention, are not in a good state, and rest might improve them; but I shall not rest, sir, while I am your representative. Whenever you want me, you will find me here. Summon me anywhere, and I will come. During the long vacation, sir, I shall devote my leisure to studying your interests more and more closely and to making arrangements for moving heaven and earth (including, of course, the Chancellor) after Michaelmas term; and when I ultimately congratulate you, sir,’ says Mr. Vholes with the severity of a determined man, ‘when I ultimately congratulate you, sir, with all my heart, on your accession to fortune—which, but that I never give hopes, I might say something further about—you will owe me nothing beyond whatever little balance may be then outstanding of the costs as between solicitor and client not included in the taxed costs allowed out of the estate. I pretend to no claim upon you, Mr. C., but for the zealous and active discharge—not the languid and routine discharge, sir: that much credit I stipulate for—of my professional duty. My duty prosperously ended, all between us is ended.’
'先生。 C.，”Vholes 回答道，“我不想对任何第三方说任何不必要的话。我希望将我的好名声和我通过勤奋和毅力可能拥有的任何一点财产都完好无损地留给我的女儿艾玛、简和卡罗琳。我也希望与我的专业弟兄和睦相处。当斯金波尔先生让我荣幸地把我们聚集在这个房间里时，先生——我不会说非常高的荣誉，因为我从不屈尊奉承——我向你提到过，我无法就你的问题提供任何意见或建议。利益，而这些利益被委托给该专业的另一名成员。我所说的措辞就像我必然要谈到肯格和卡博伊的办公室一样，它很高。先生，您认为还是应该撤回您的利益并将其提供给我。先生，您干净地带来了它们，我也干净地接受了它们。这些利益现在在这个办公室中至关重要。我的消化功能，你可能听我说过，状态不太好，休息可能会改善；但先生，当我担任您的代表时，我不会休息。无论什么时候你需要我，你都会在这里找到我。到任何地方召唤我，我都会来。先生，在这个漫长的假期里，我将把我的闲暇时间用于更加仔细地研究您的兴趣，并为米迦勒节结束后的搬迁事宜（当然包括大法官）做出安排；当我最终祝贺你时，先生，”先生说。 沃尔斯以坚定的人的严厉态度说道：“先生，当我最终全心全意地祝贺您获得财富时——但我从不抱有希望，我可以进一步说——您将不欠我任何东西”除了律师和委托人之间的费用中可能存在的任何一点余额之外，不包括在允许从遗产中扣除的纳税费用中。 C. 先生，我假装对您没有什么要求，只是因为您热心而积极地履行了我的职业职责，而不是慵懒而例行公事的履行，先生：我规定了这一点。我的职责圆满结束，我们之间的一切都结束了。’

Vholes finally adds, by way of rider to this declaration of his principles, that as Mr. Carstone is about to rejoin his regiment, perhaps Mr. C. will favour him with an order on his agent for twenty pounds on account.
沃尔斯最后补充道，作为他的原则宣言的附加内容，当卡斯通先生即将重新加入他的团时，也许C.先生会向他的经纪人下达二十英镑的预付款命令。

‘For there have been many little consultations and attendances of late, sir,’ observes Vholes, turning over the leaves of his diary, ‘and these things mount up, and I don’t profess to be a man of capital. When we first entered on our present relations I stated to you openly—it is a principle of mine that there never can be too much openness between solicitor and client—that I was not a man of capital and that if capital was your object you had better leave your papers in Kenge’s office. No, Mr. C., you will find none of the advantages or disadvantages of capital here, sir. This,’ Vholes gives the desk one hollow blow again, ‘is your rock; it pretends to be nothing more.’
“因为最近有很多小咨询和出席，先生，”沃尔斯翻着日记本说道，“这些事情越来越多，我并不自称是一个有资本的人。当我们第一次建立目前的关系时，我公开地向你声明——律师和委托人之间永远不能有太多的开放性，这是我的原则——我不是一个资本家，如果资本是你的目标，你就拥有了资本。最好把你的文件留在肯格的办公室。不，C.先生，您在这里找不到资本的优点或缺点，先生。 “这个，”沃尔斯再次空洞地敲了一下桌子，“是你的石头；”它假装什么都没有。

The client, with his dejection insensibly relieved and his vague hopes rekindled, takes pen and ink and writes the draft, not without perplexed consideration and calculation of the date it may bear, implying scant effects in the agent’s hands. All the while, Vholes, buttoned up in body and mind, looks at him attentively. All the while, Vholes’s official cat watches the mouse’s hole.
委托人的沮丧不知不觉地缓解了，模糊的希望重新燃起，拿起笔和墨水写下了草稿，不无困惑地考虑和计算了它可能发生的日期，这意味着在代理人手中收效甚微。一直以来，沃尔斯都保持着身心的平静，聚精会神地看着他。沃勒斯的官方猫一直注视着老鼠的洞。

Lastly, the client, shaking hands, beseeches Mr. Vholes, for heaven’s sake and earth’s sake, to do his utmost to ‘pull him through’ the Court of Chancery. Mr. Vholes, who never gives hopes, lays his palm upon the client’s shoulder and answers with a smile, ‘Always here, sir. Personally, or by letter, you will always find me here, sir, with my shoulder to the wheel.’ Thus they part, and Vholes, left alone, employs himself in carrying sundry little matters out of his diary into his draft bill book for the ultimate behoof of his three daughters. So might an industrious fox or bear make up his account of chickens or stray travellers with an eye to his cubs, not to disparage by that word the three raw-visaged, lank, and buttoned-up maidens who dwell with the parent Vholes in an earthy cottage situated in a damp garden at Kennington.
最后，委托人握手，恳求沃尔斯先生，看在老天爷的份上，尽最大努力“拉他通过”大法官法庭。沃尔斯先生从不抱有希望，他将手掌放在客户的肩膀上，微笑着回答：“永远在这里，先生。”亲自或通过信件，您总是会在这里找到我，先生，我的肩膀靠在方向盘上。”就这样他们分开了，沃尔斯独自一人，忙着从日记中把各种各样的小事记入他的草案帐单簿中。他的三个女儿的最终利益。因此，一只勤劳的狐狸或熊可能会编造鸡或流浪旅行者的故事，以关注他的幼崽，而不是用这个词来贬低与父母Vholes住在一个房子里的三个面容粗糙、瘦长、扣着纽扣的少女。朴实的小屋坐落在肯宁顿潮湿的花园里。

Richard, emerging from the heavy shade of Symond’s Inn into the sunshine of Chancery Lane—for there happens to be sunshine there to-day—walks thoughtfully on, and turns into Lincoln’s Inn, and passes under the shadow of the Lincoln’s Inn trees. On many such loungers have the speckled shadows of those trees often fallen; on the like bent head, the bitten nail, the lowering eye, the lingering step, the purposeless and dreamy air, the good consuming and consumed, the life turned sour. This lounger is not shabby yet, but that may come. Chancery, which knows no wisdom but in precedent, is very rich in such precedents; and why should one be different from ten thousand?
理查德从西蒙律师学院的浓荫下走出来，来到大法官巷的阳光下——因为今天那里正好有阳光——若有所思地继续前行，拐进林肯律师学院，穿过林肯律师学院的树荫。许多这样的躺椅上都有那些树木经常落下的斑点阴影；低下的头，被咬过的指甲，低垂的目光，徘徊的脚步，漫无目的的梦幻空气，美好的消耗和消耗，生活变质了。这个躺椅还不算破旧，但那可能会到来。最高法院除了先例之外一无所知，这样的先例非常丰富。为什么一与万不同呢？

Yet the time is so short since his depreciation began that as he saunters away, reluctant to leave the spot for some long months together, though he hates it, Richard himself may feel his own case as if it were a startling one. While his heart is heavy with corroding care, suspense, distrust, and doubt, it may have room for some sorrowful wonder when he recalls how different his first visit there, how different he, how different all the colours of his mind. But injustice breeds injustice; the fighting with shadows and being defeated by them necessitates the setting up of substances to combat; from the impalpable suit which no man alive can understand, the time for that being long gone by, it has become a gloomy relief to turn to the palpable figure of the friend who would have saved him from this ruin and make HIM his enemy. Richard has told Vholes the truth. Is he in a hardened or a softened mood, he still lays his injuries equally at that door; he was thwarted, in that quarter, of a set purpose, and that purpose could only originate in the one subject that is resolving his existence into itself; besides, it is a justification to him in his own eyes to have an embodied antagonist and oppressor.
然而，自从他开始贬值以来，时间是如此之短，以至于当他漫步离开时，不愿意离开这个地方一起度过漫长的几个月，尽管他讨厌这样，理查德本人可能会觉得自己的情况似乎是一个令人震惊的情况。虽然他的内心充满了腐蚀的忧虑、悬念、不信任和怀疑，但当他回想起第一次访问那里时，他是多么不同，他的思想是多么不同，他可能有一些悲伤的奇迹的空间。但不公正会滋生不公正；与影子战斗，被影子打败，必须设置实体来战斗；从没有一个活着的人能够理解的难以捉摸的诉讼中，那已经过去了很久，转向朋友的明显身影已经成为一种令人沮丧的解脱，他本可以将他从废墟中拯救出来，并使他成为他的敌人。理查德告诉了沃尔斯真相。无论他的情绪是强硬还是软化，他仍然将自己的伤害都平等地归咎于那扇门；在那个方面，他受到了既定目标的阻碍，而这个目标只能源于将他的存在解决为自身的一个主体；此外，在他自己看来，拥有一个具体的对手和压迫者是合理的。

Is Richard a monster in all this, or would Chancery be found rich in such precedents too if they could be got for citation from the Recording Angel?
理查德在这一切中是否是一个怪物，或者如果可以从记录天使那里引用这些先例，大法官法庭是否也会发现丰富的此类先例？

Two pairs of eyes not unused to such people look after him, as, biting his nails and brooding, he crosses the square and is swallowed up by the shadow of the southern gateway. Mr. Guppy and Mr. Weevle are the possessors of those eyes, and they have been leaning in conversation against the low stone parapet under the trees. He passes close by them, seeing nothing but the ground.
两双不习惯这种人的眼睛注视着他，他咬着指甲，沉思着，穿过广场，被南门的影子吞没了。古皮先生和韦弗勒先生就是这双眼睛的拥有者，他们一直靠在树下低矮的石栏杆上交谈。他从他们身边走过，除了地面什么也看不见。

‘William,’ says Mr. Weevle, adjusting his whiskers, ‘there’s combustion going on there! It’s not a case of spontaneous, but it’s smouldering combustion it is.’
“威廉，”威弗勒先生一边说，一边整理着胡须，“那里正在燃烧！”这不是自燃，而是阴燃燃烧。”

‘Ah!’ says Mr. Guppy. ‘He wouldn’t keep out of Jarndyce, and I suppose he’s over head and ears in debt. I never knew much of him. He was as high as the monument when he was on trial at our place. A good riddance to me, whether as clerk or client! Well, Tony, that as I was mentioning is what they’re up to.’
“啊！”孔雀先生说。 “他不会避开贾迪斯，我想他已经负债累累了​​。我对他一向不太了解。当他在我们这里受审时，他的高度就像纪念碑一样高。无论是作为职员还是客户，这对我来说都是一个很好的摆脱！好吧，托尼，正如我提到的，这就是他们要做的。

Mr. Guppy, refolding his arms, resettles himself against the parapet, as resuming a conversation of interest.
古比先生重新抱起双臂，重新靠在栏杆上，继续进行一场有趣的谈话。

‘They are still up to it, sir,’ says Mr. Guppy, ‘still taking stock, still examining papers, still going over the heaps and heaps of rubbish. At this rate they’ll be at it these seven years.’
“他们仍然在做这件事，先生，”古皮先生说，“仍然在盘点，仍然在检查文件，仍然在检查成堆的垃圾。按照这个速度，他们将在这七年里做到这一点。

‘And Small is helping?’
“斯莫尔也在帮忙吗？”

‘Small left us at a week’s notice. Told Kenge his grandfather’s business was too much for the old gentleman and he could better himself by undertaking it. There had been a coolness between myself and Small on account of his being so close. But he said you and I began it, and as he had me there—for we did—I put our acquaintance on the old footing. That’s how I come to know what they’re up to.’
“斯莫尔提前一周就离开了我们。告诉肯格，他祖父的生意对这位老绅士来说太过分了，他可以通过承担这件事来改善自己。由于斯莫尔如此亲密，我和他之间一直很冷淡。但他说是你和我开始的，当他让我在那里时——因为我们确实这么做了——我让我们的相识重新回到了旧的基础上。这就是我如何知道他们在做什么。

‘You haven’t looked in at all?’
“你根本就没进去看过吗？”

‘Tony,’ says Mr. Guppy, a little disconcerted, ‘to be unreserved with you, I don’t greatly relish the house, except in your company, and therefore I have not; and therefore I proposed this little appointment for our fetching away your things. There goes the hour by the clock! Tony’—Mr. Guppy becomes mysteriously and tenderly eloquent—‘it is necessary that I should impress upon your mind once more that circumstances over which I have no control have made a melancholy alteration in my most cherished plans and in that unrequited image which I formerly mentioned to you as a friend. That image is shattered, and that idol is laid low. My only wish now in connexion with the objects which I had an idea of carrying out in the court with your aid as a friend is to let ‘em alone and bury ‘em in oblivion. Do you think it possible, do you think it at all likely (I put it to you, Tony, as a friend), from your knowledge of that capricious and deep old character who fell a prey to the—spontaneous element, do you, Tony, think it at all likely that on second thoughts he put those letters away anywhere, after you saw him alive, and that they were not destroyed that night?’
“托尼，”古比先生有点不知所措地说，“我不喜欢毫无保留地和你在一起，除非有你在身边，所以我不喜欢这栋房子。”因此我提出了这个小小的约会，让我们来取走你的东西。时间一分一秒地过去了！托尼——先生。孔雀变得神秘而温柔的雄辩——“我有必要再次让你记住，我无法控制的情况已经对我最珍视的计划和我之前向你提到的那个单相思的形象产生了令人忧郁的改变。一个朋友。那个形象被粉碎了，那个偶像被放下了。我现在唯一的愿望是，在你作为朋友的帮助下，我想在法庭上实现我的目标，那就是让他们独自一人，并将他们埋葬在遗忘中。从你对那个反复无常、深沉的老角色的了解来看，你认为这可能吗？你认为这有可能吗（托尼，我作为朋友），你认为，托尼，你想一想，在你看到他还活着之后，他是否有可能把那些信放在任何地方，并且那天晚上它们没有被销毁？

Mr. Weevle reflects for some time. Shakes his head. Decidedly thinks not.
韦夫勒先生沉思了一会儿。摇摇头。坚决认为不是。

‘Tony,’ says Mr. Guppy as they walk towards the court, ‘once again understand me, as a friend. Without entering into further explanations, I may repeat that the idol is down. I have no purpose to serve now but burial in oblivion. To that I have pledged myself. I owe it to myself, and I owe it to the shattered image, as also to the circumstances over which I have no control. If you was to express to me by a gesture, by a wink, that you saw lying anywhere in your late lodgings any papers that so much as looked like the papers in question, I would pitch them into the fire, sir, on my own responsibility.’
“托尼，”当他们走向球场时，古比先生说道，“再次理解我，作为一个朋友。”在不做进一步解释的情况下，我可以重复一下，偶像已经倒下了。我现在没有任何服务的目的，除了埋葬在遗忘中。我自己对此做出了保证。我对自己负有责任，对破碎的形象负有责任，也对我无法控制的环境负有责任。如果您通过一个手势、一个眨眼的方式向我表示您在您最近的住处发现了任何看起来像所讨论的文件的文件，我会亲自将它们扔进火里，先生，责任。'

Mr. Weevle nods. Mr. Guppy, much elevated in his own opinion by having delivered these observations, with an air in part forensic and in part romantic—this gentleman having a passion for conducting anything in the form of an examination, or delivering anything in the form of a summing up or a speech—accompanies his friend with dignity to the court.
韦夫勒先生点点头。古比先生，他自己认为，通过发表这些观察结果，他的态度得到了很大的提升，他的神情一半是法医，一半是浪漫——这位绅士热衷于以检查的形式进行任何事情，或者以检查的形式提供任何东西。总结或演讲——带着尊严陪同他的朋友出庭。

Never since it has been a court has it had such a Fortunatus’ purse of gossip as in the proceedings at the rag and bottle shop. Regularly, every morning at eight, is the elder Mr. Smallweed brought down to the corner and carried in, accompanied by Mrs. Smallweed, Judy, and Bart; and regularly, all day, do they all remain there until nine at night, solaced by gipsy dinners, not abundant in quantity, from the cook’s shop, rummaging and searching, digging, delving, and diving among the treasures of the late lamented. What those treasures are they keep so secret that the court is maddened. In its delirium it imagines guineas pouring out of tea-pots, crown-pieces overflowing punch-bowls, old chairs and mattresses stuffed with Bank of England notes. It possesses itself of the sixpenny history (with highly coloured folding frontispiece) of Mr. Daniel Dancer and his sister, and also of Mr. Elwes, of Suffolk, and transfers all the facts from those authentic narratives to Mr. Krook. Twice when the dustman is called in to carry off a cartload of old paper, ashes, and broken bottles, the whole court assembles and pries into the baskets as they come forth. Many times the two gentlemen who write with the ravenous little pens on the tissue-paper are seen prowling in the neighbourhood—shy of each other, their late partnership being dissolved. The Sol skilfully carries a vein of the prevailing interest through the Harmonic nights. Little Swills, in what are professionally known as ‘patter’ allusions to the subject, is received with loud applause; and the same vocalist ‘gags’ in the regular business like a man inspired. Even Miss M. Melvilleson, in the revived Caledonian melody of ‘We’re a-Nodding,’ points the sentiment that ‘the dogs love broo’ (whatever the nature of that refreshment may be) with such archness and such a turn of the head towards next door that she is immediately understood to mean Mr. Smallweed loves to find money, and is nightly honoured with a double encore. For all this, the court discovers nothing; and as Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins now communicate to the late lodger whose appearance is the signal for a general rally, it is in one continual ferment to discover everything, and more.
自从法庭成立以来，福图纳图斯的钱包里从来没有像破布和瓶子店的诉讼程序那样有如此多的流言蜚语。每天早上八点，老斯莫威德先生都会被带到角落里，由斯莫威德太太、朱迪和巴特陪同进来。他们经常整天呆在那里，直到晚上九点，从厨师店里吃着数量不多的吉卜赛晚餐来安慰自己，在那些已故的人们哀叹的宝藏中翻箱倒柜、寻找、挖掘、探索和潜入。这些宝藏到底是什么，他们保密得如此之高，以至于朝廷都抓狂了。在它的精神错乱中，它想象几尼从茶壶里倒出来，皇冠上的酒杯溢出来，旧椅子和床垫上塞满了英格兰银行的钞票。它拥有丹尼尔·丹瑟先生和他的妹妹以及萨福克郡埃尔维斯先生的六便士历史（带有色彩丰富的折叠卷首插画），并将这些真实叙述中的所有事实转移给克鲁克先生。有两次，当清洁工被叫来运走一车旧纸、灰烬和破瓶子时，整个法庭都会聚集起来，在篮子出来时撬进篮子。很多时候，人们会看到这两位用贪婪的小笔在薄纸上写字的绅士在附近徘徊——彼此害羞，他们最近的合作关系已经解散。 Sol 巧妙地在 Harmonic 之夜中体现了人们的普遍兴趣。 《Little Swills》，专业人士称之为“喋喋不休”的暗示，赢得了热烈的掌声。同样的歌手在日常活动中“搞笑”，就像一个受启发的人。就连M小姐 梅尔维尔森在《We're a-Nodding》中用复兴的喀里多尼亚旋律，指出了“狗爱兄弟”（无论茶点的性质是什么）的情感，并如此调皮地将头转向隔壁她立即​​被理解为斯莫尔韦德先生喜欢赚钱，并且每晚都会荣幸地获得双重安可表演。尽管如此，法庭却一无所获。派珀夫人和帕金斯夫人现在正在与已故房客沟通，后者的出现是一场全面集会的信号，在不断的发酵中，我们发现了一切，甚至更多。

Mr. Weevle and Mr. Guppy, with every eye in the court’s head upon them, knock at the closed door of the late lamented’s house, in a high state of popularity. But being contrary to the court’s expectation admitted, they immediately become unpopular and are considered to mean no good.
威夫勒先生和古比先生在法庭上的每一双眼睛都注视着他们，敲响了已故哀悼者紧闭的房子的门，人气很高。但与法庭承认的预期相反，它们立即变得不受欢迎，并被认为没有什么好处。

The shutters are more or less closed all over the house, and the ground-floor is sufficiently dark to require candles. Introduced into the back shop by Mr. Smallweed the younger, they, fresh from the sunlight, can at first see nothing save darkness and shadows; but they gradually discern the elder Mr. Smallweed seated in his chair upon the brink of a well or grave of waste-paper, the virtuous Judy groping therein like a female sexton, and Mrs. Smallweed on the level ground in the vicinity snowed up in a heap of paper fragments, print, and manuscript which would appear to be the accumulated compliments that have been sent flying at her in the course of the day. The whole party, Small included, are blackened with dust and dirt and present a fiendish appearance not relieved by the general aspect of the room. There is more litter and lumber in it than of old, and it is dirtier if possible; likewise, it is ghostly with traces of its dead inhabitant and even with his chalked writing on the wall.
整个房子的百叶窗或多或少都关着，底层很暗，需要蜡烛。小斯莫威德先生把他们引入后店，刚接触过阳光的他们，一开始除了黑暗和阴影什么也看不到；后来他们又被带到了后店。但他们逐渐看出年长的斯莫尔威德先生坐在一口井边或废纸堆的坟墓边上的椅子上，善良的朱迪像女教堂司事一样在里面摸索，而斯莫尔威德太太则坐在附近被雪覆盖的平地上。一堆纸片、印刷品和手稿，似乎是一天中向她飞来的累积的赞美之词。整个聚会，包括小聚会，都被灰尘和污垢熏黑，呈现出一种邪恶的外观，但房间的整体外观并没有缓解这一点。里面的垃圾和木材比以前更多了，而且如果可能的话也更脏。同样，它也显得幽灵般，有死去的居民的痕迹，甚至墙上还有他用粉笔写下的字迹。

On the entrance of visitors, Mr. Smallweed and Judy simultaneously fold their arms and stop in their researches.
当参观者进来时，斯莫尔韦德先生和朱迪同时抱起双臂，停下来研究。

‘Aha!’ croaks the old gentleman. ‘How de do, gentlemen, how de do! Come to fetch your property, Mr. Weevle? That’s well, that’s well. Ha! Ha! We should have been forced to sell you up, sir, to pay your warehouse room if you had left it here much longer. You feel quite at home here again, I dare say? Glad to see you, glad to see you!’
“啊哈！”老先生嘎嘎叫道。 ‘怎么样，先生们，怎么样！威弗勒先生，来取你的财产吗？那就好，那就好。哈！哈！先生，如果你把仓库留在这里的时间更长的话，我们就不得不卖掉你来支付你的仓库费用。我敢说你又在这里感到宾至如归了？很高兴见到你，很高兴见到你！”

Mr. Weevle, thanking him, casts an eye about. Mr. Guppy’s eye follows Mr. Weevle’s eye. Mr. Weevle’s eye comes back without any new intelligence in it. Mr. Guppy’s eye comes back and meets Mr. Smallweed’s eye. That engaging old gentleman is still murmuring, like some wound-up instrument running down, ‘How de do, sir—how de—how—‘ And then having run down, he lapses into grinning silence, as Mr. Guppy starts at seeing Mr. Tulkinghorn standing in the darkness opposite with his hands behind him.
韦夫勒先生向他表示感谢，并向四周看了看。古皮先生的目光追随威弗勒先生的目光。韦弗勒先生的眼睛恢复了，但里面没有任何新的智慧。孔雀鱼先生的目光又回来了，与斯莫威德先生的目光相遇。那位迷人的老绅士仍在低语，就像某种上紧发条的乐器跑下来，“怎么办，先生——怎么——怎么——”然后跑下来，当孔雀先生开始看到先生时，他陷入微笑的沉默。图金霍恩背负着双手站在对面的黑暗中。

‘Gentleman so kind as to act as my solicitor,’ says Grandfather Smallweed. ‘I am not the sort of client for a gentleman of such note, but he is so good!’
“这位先生非常好心，愿意担任我的律师。”斯莫威德祖父说道。 “我不是那种有名望的绅士的客户，但他太棒了！”

Mr. Guppy, slightly nudging his friend to take another look, makes a shuffling bow to Mr. Tulkinghorn, who returns it with an easy nod. Mr. Tulkinghorn is looking on as if he had nothing else to do and were rather amused by the novelty.
古比先生轻轻地推了他的朋友再看一眼，然后向图尔金霍恩先生鞠了一躬，图尔金霍恩先生也轻松地点了点头。图金霍恩先生在一旁看着，好像他没有别的事可做，并对这个新奇事物感到很有趣。

‘A good deal of property here, sir, I should say,’ Mr. Guppy observes to Mr. Smallweed.
“我应该说，这里有很多财产，先生，”古皮先生对斯莫威德先生说道。

‘Principally rags and rubbish, my dear friend! Rags and rubbish! Me and Bart and my granddaughter Judy are endeavouring to make out an inventory of what’s worth anything to sell. But we haven’t come to much as yet; we—haven’t—come—to—hah!’
“主要是破布和垃圾，我亲爱的朋友！破布和垃圾！我、巴特和我的孙女朱迪正在努力清点值得出售的物品的清单。但我们还没有取得太多进展。我们——还没——来——哈！”

Mr. Smallweed has run down again, while Mr. Weevle’s eye, attended by Mr. Guppy’s eye, has again gone round the room and come back.
小威德先生又跑下来了，而韦夫勒先生的眼睛，在孔雀先生的眼睛的陪伴下，又绕着房间转了一圈又回来了。

‘Well, sir,’ says Mr. Weevle. ‘We won’t intrude any longer if you’ll allow us to go upstairs.’
“好吧，先生，”威弗尔先生说。 “如果你允许我们上楼，我们就不会再打扰了。”

‘Anywhere, my dear sir, anywhere! You’re at home. Make yourself so, pray!’
“无论在哪里，亲爱的先生，无论在哪里！你在家。让自己成为这样，祈祷吧！

As they go upstairs, Mr. Guppy lifts his eyebrows inquiringly and looks at Tony. Tony shakes his head. They find the old room very dull and dismal, with the ashes of the fire that was burning on that memorable night yet in the discoloured grate. They have a great disinclination to touch any object, and carefully blow the dust from it first. Nor are they desirous to prolong their visit, packing the few movables with all possible speed and never speaking above a whisper.
当他们上楼时，古比先生询问地扬起眉毛，看着托尼。托尼摇摇头。他们发现旧房间非常沉闷和阴暗，在那个难忘的夜晚燃烧的火的灰烬仍在变色的炉排中。他们非常不愿意触摸任何物体，并且会先小心地吹掉上面的灰尘。他们也不想延长他们的访问时间，以尽可能快的速度收拾好少量的可移动物品，而且从来不低声说话。

‘Look here,’ says Tony, recoiling. ‘Here’s that horrible cat coming in!’
“看这里，”托尼说，后退了一步。 “那只可怕的猫进来了！”

Mr. Guppy retreats behind a chair. ‘Small told me of her. She went leaping and bounding and tearing about that night like a dragon, and got out on the house-top, and roamed about up there for a fortnight, and then came tumbling down the chimney very thin. Did you ever see such a brute? Looks as if she knew all about it, don’t she? Almost looks as if she was Krook. Shoohoo! Get out, you goblin!’
古比先生退到椅子后面。 “斯莫尔告诉我她的事。那天晚上，她像一条龙一样又蹦又跳，又撕又扯，然后爬到屋顶上，在那里徘徊了两周，然后从烟囱里滚了下来，身子瘦了。你见过这么野蛮的人吗？看起来她好像知道这一切，不是吗？看起来她几乎就是克鲁克。嘘！滚出去，你这个妖精！

Lady Jane, in the doorway, with her tiger snarl from ear to ear and her club of a tail, shows no intention of obeying; but Mr. Tulkinghorn stumbling over her, she spits at his rusty legs, and swearing wrathfully, takes her arched back upstairs. Possibly to roam the house-tops again and return by the chimney.
简女士站在门口，老虎般的咆哮声从耳边传到耳边，尾巴挥舞着，丝毫没有服从的意思。但图金霍恩先生被她绊倒了，她朝他生锈的腿吐口水，愤怒地咒骂着，把她弓着背带上楼。可能会再次在屋顶上漫步，然后从烟囱返回。

‘Mr. Guppy,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, ‘could I have a word with you?’
'先生。孔雀鱼，”图金霍恩先生说，“我能和你说句话吗？”

Mr. Guppy is engaged in collecting the Galaxy Gallery of British Beauty from the wall and depositing those works of art in their old ignoble band-box. ‘Sir,’ he returns, reddening, ‘I wish to act with courtesy towards every member of the profession, and especially, I am sure, towards a member of it so well known as yourself—I will truly add, sir, so distinguished as yourself. Still, Mr. Tulkinghorn, sir, I must stipulate that if you have any word with me, that word is spoken in the presence of my friend.’
古比先生正忙着从墙上收集英国美人银河画廊，并将这些艺术品存放在他们破旧的、不光彩的带盒里。 “先生，”他红着脸回答道，“我希望对这个行业的每一位成员都表现出礼貌，尤其是，我相信，对像你这样众所周知的人——我真的要补充一点，先生，如此杰出的人。”就像你自己一样。不过，图金霍恩先生，先生，我必须规定，如果您对我有任何话，必须当着我朋友的面说。

‘Oh, indeed?’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn.
“哦，确实如此？”图金霍恩先生说。

‘Yes, sir. My reasons are not of a personal nature at all, but they are amply sufficient for myself.’
'是的先生。我的理由根本不是个人性质的，但对我自己来说已经足够了。

‘No doubt, no doubt.’ Mr. Tulkinghorn is as imperturbable as the hearthstone to which he has quietly walked. ‘The matter is not of that consequence that I need put you to the trouble of making any conditions, Mr. Guppy.’ He pauses here to smile, and his smile is as dull and rusty as his pantaloons. ‘You are to be congratulated, Mr. Guppy; you are a fortunate young man, sir.’
“毫无疑问，毫无疑问。”图金霍恩先生就像他悄悄走到的炉边一样镇定自若。 “问题并不在于我需要麻烦你提出任何条件，古皮先生。”他停了下来，微笑着，他的微笑和他的马裤一样暗淡而生锈。 “值得恭喜你，古比先生；你是一个幸运的年轻人，先生。”

‘Pretty well so, Mr. Tulkinghorn; I don’t complain.’
“很好，图金霍恩先生；我不抱怨。

‘Complain? High friends, free admission to great houses, and access to elegant ladies! Why, Mr. Guppy, there are people in London who would give their ears to be you.’
'抱怨？高级朋友，免费进入豪宅，接触优雅女士！为什么，古比先生，伦敦有人愿意倾听你的声音。

Mr. Guppy, looking as if he would give his own reddening and still reddening ears to be one of those people at present instead of himself, replies, ‘Sir, if I attend to my profession and do what is right by Kenge and Carboy, my friends and acquaintances are of no consequence to them nor to any member of the profession, not excepting Mr. Tulkinghorn of the Fields. I am not under any obligation to explain myself further; and with all respect for you, sir, and without offence—I repeat, without offence—‘
顾比先生看上去似乎愿意献出自己那双正在泛红、仍在泛红的耳朵，代替他自己，成为目前这些人中的一员，他回答说：“先生，如果我专注于我的职业，做肯格和卡博伊认为正确的事情，我的朋友和熟人对他们或任何专业人士来说都没有影响，除了菲尔兹的图金霍恩先生。我没有义务进一步解释自己；先生，我谨向您致以崇高敬意，无意冒犯——我重复一遍，无意冒犯——”

‘Oh, certainly!’
“哦，当然！”

‘—I don’t intend to do it.’
“——我不想这么做。”

‘Quite so,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn with a calm nod. ‘Very good; I see by these portraits that you take a strong interest in the fashionable great, sir?’
“确实如此，”图尔金霍恩先生平静地点点头说道。 '非常好;我从这些肖像中看出您对时尚伟人很感兴趣，先生？

He addresses this to the astounded Tony, who admits the soft impeachment.
他向震惊的托尼说出了这句话，托尼承认了软弹劾。

‘A virtue in which few Englishmen are deficient,’ observes Mr. Tulkinghorn. He has been standing on the hearthstone with his back to the smoked chimney-piece, and now turns round with his glasses to his eyes. ‘Who is this? ‘Lady Dedlock.’ Ha! A very good likeness in its way, but it wants force of character. Good day to you, gentlemen; good day!’
图尔金霍恩先生评论说：“很少有英国人缺乏这种美德。”他一直站在炉石上，背对着冒着烟的烟囱，现在转过身来，把眼镜放在眼睛上。 '这是谁？ “戴德洛克女士。”哈！其方式非常相似，但它需要性格的力量。先生们，美好的一天！再会！'

When he has walked out, Mr. Guppy, in a great perspiration, nerves himself to the hasty completion of the taking down of the Galaxy Gallery, concluding with Lady Dedlock.
当他走出去时，古比先生满头大汗，他给自己鼓足了勇气，准备匆忙完成对银河画廊的拆除，最后以戴德洛克夫人为结束。

‘Tony,’ he says hurriedly to his astonished companion, ‘let us be quick in putting the things together and in getting out of this place. It were in vain longer to conceal from you, Tony, that between myself and one of the members of a swan-like aristocracy whom I now hold in my hand, there has been undivulged communication and association. The time might have been when I might have revealed it to you. It never will be more. It is due alike to the oath I have taken, alike to the shattered idol, and alike to circumstances over which I have no control, that the whole should be buried in oblivion. I charge you as a friend, by the interest you have ever testified in the fashionable intelligence, and by any little advances with which I may have been able to accommodate you, so to bury it without a word of inquiry!’
“托尼，”他急忙对他惊讶的同伴说道，“让我们快点把东西收拾好，然后离开这个地方。”托尼，我再向你隐瞒我和现在握在手中的一位天鹅般的贵族成员之间，一直存在着不为人知的交流和交往，这是徒劳的。也许是时候我可以向你透露它了。永远不会更多。由于我所发的誓言，由于破碎的偶像，由于我无法控制的情况，整个事情都应该被埋葬在遗忘中。我以朋友的身份责备你，因为你对时尚情报的兴趣，以及我可能为你提供的任何一点进步，所以不问任何一句话就将它埋葬！

This charge Mr. Guppy delivers in a state little short of forensic lunacy, while his friend shows a dazed mind in his whole head of hair and even in his cultivated whiskers.
古比先生提出的这一指控近乎法医精神错乱，而他的朋友则在他的整个头发甚至精心修剪的胡须中表现出一种茫然的精神。

CHAPTER XL
第二十章


National and Domestic
国内及国内

England has been in a dreadful state for some weeks. Lord Coodle would go out, Sir Thomas Doodle wouldn’t come in, and there being nobody in Great Britain (to speak of) except Coodle and Doodle, there has been no government. It is a mercy that the hostile meeting between those two great men, which at one time seemed inevitable, did not come off, because if both pistols had taken effect, and Coodle and Doodle had killed each other, it is to be presumed that England must have waited to be governed until young Coodle and young Doodle, now in frocks and long stockings, were grown up. This stupendous national calamity, however, was averted by Lord Coodle’s making the timely discovery that if in the heat of debate he had said that he scorned and despised the whole ignoble career of Sir Thomas Doodle, he had merely meant to say that party differences should never induce him to withhold from it the tribute of his warmest admiration; while it as opportunely turned out, on the other hand, that Sir Thomas Doodle had in his own bosom expressly booked Lord Coodle to go down to posterity as the mirror of virtue and honour. Still England has been some weeks in the dismal strait of having no pilot (as was well observed by Sir Leicester Dedlock) to weather the storm; and the marvellous part of the matter is that England has not appeared to care very much about it, but has gone on eating and drinking and marrying and giving in marriage as the old world did in the days before the flood. But Coodle knew the danger, and Doodle knew the danger, and all their followers and hangers-on had the clearest possible perception of the danger. At last Sir Thomas Doodle has not only condescended to come in, but has done it handsomely, bringing in with him all his nephews, all his male cousins, and all his brothers-in-law. So there is hope for the old ship yet.
几周以来，英格兰一直处于可怕的状态。库德尔勋爵会出去，托马斯·杜德尔爵士不会进来，而英国除了库德尔和杜德尔之外没有任何人（可以说），没有政府。幸运的是，这两位伟人之间一度看似不可避免的敌对会面并没有发生，因为如果两支手枪都发挥作用，并且库德和杜德互相杀死了对方，那么就可以认为英格兰一定要等到年轻的库德和年轻的杜德（现在穿着连衣裙和长袜）长大后才接受统治。然而，库德尔勋爵及时发现，如果他在激烈的辩论中表示蔑视和鄙视托马斯·杜德尔爵士的整个不光彩的职业生涯，那么他的意思只是说党派分歧应该被避免，从而避免了这场巨大的国家灾难。永远不要诱使他拒绝表达他最热烈的钦佩；另一方面，事实证明，托马斯·杜德尔爵士在自己的心中明确地指定库德尔勋爵作为美德和荣誉的镜子留传后世。尽管如此，英格兰已经有几个星期陷入了没有飞行员（莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士清楚地观察到）来度过这场风暴的悲惨困境；事情的奇妙之处在于，英国似乎并不太关心此事，而是继续像洪水前的旧世界那样吃喝嫁娶。但库德知道危险，涂鸦也知道危险，他们所有的追随者和追随者都对危险有最清晰的认识。 最后，托马斯·杜德尔爵士不仅屈尊进来，而且做得很漂亮，把他所有的侄子、所有的堂兄弟姐妹和所有的妹夫都带来了。所以这艘旧船还有希望。

Doodle has found that he must throw himself upon the country, chiefly in the form of sovereigns and beer. In this metamorphosed state he is available in a good many places simultaneously and can throw himself upon a considerable portion of the country at one time. Britannia being much occupied in pocketing Doodle in the form of sovereigns, and swallowing Doodle in the form of beer, and in swearing herself black in the face that she does neither— plainly to the advancement of her glory and morality—the London season comes to a sudden end, through all the Doodleites and Coodleites dispersing to assist Britannia in those religious exercises.
涂鸦发现他必须投身于这个国家，主要是以金币和啤酒的形式。在这种变形的状态下，他可以同时出现在很多地方，并且可以一次将自己投入到该国的相当大一部分地区。大不列颠全神贯注地把金币形式的涂鸦装进口袋，以啤酒的形式吞下涂鸦，并当着黑脸发誓她两者都不做——显然是为了提高她的荣耀和道德——伦敦季节到来了突然结束，所有的杜德派和库德派都分散开来协助不列颠尼亚进行这些宗教活动。

Hence Mrs. Rouncewell, housekeeper at Chesney Wold, foresees, though no instructions have yet come down, that the family may shortly be expected, together with a pretty large accession of cousins and others who can in any way assist the great Constitutional work. And hence the stately old dame, taking Time by the forelock, leads him up and down the staircases, and along the galleries and passages, and through the rooms, to witness before he grows any older that everything is ready, that floors are rubbed bright, carpets spread, curtains shaken out, beds puffed and patted, still-room and kitchen cleared for action—all things prepared as beseems the Dedlock dignity.
因此，切斯尼沃尔德的管家朗斯韦尔夫人预见到，虽然还没有下达指示，但很快就会迎来这个家庭，以及相当多的堂兄弟姐妹和其他能够以任何方式协助伟大宪法工作的人。于是这位庄严的老太太抓住了时间的前发，领着他上下楼梯，沿着画廊和通道，穿过房间，在他变老之前见证一切都准备好了，地板被擦得光亮。铺开地毯，抖开窗帘，把床铺得鼓鼓的，拍拍拍打，静室和厨房都清理干净，准备行动——一切准备工作都符合戴德洛克的尊严。

This present summer evening, as the sun goes down, the preparations are complete. Dreary and solemn the old house looks, with so many appliances of habitation and with no inhabitants except the pictured forms upon the walls. So did these come and go, a Dedlock in possession might have ruminated passing along; so did they see this gallery hushed and quiet, as I see it now; so think, as I think, of the gap that they would make in this domain when they were gone; so find it, as I find it, difficult to believe that it could be without them; so pass from my world, as I pass from theirs, now closing the reverberating door; so leave no blank to miss them, and so die.
今夏的傍晚，随着太阳落山，准备工作已经完成。老房子看起来沉闷而庄严，有那么多居住用具，除了墙上的图画外，没有任何人。就这样，这些东西来了又走，一个拥有球权的戴德洛克可能会思考如何传球；他们也看到这个画廊寂静无声，就像我现在看到的那样。因此，正如我所想的那样，想想当他们离开后，他们在这个领域会造成怎样的差距？因此，正如我所发现的那样，很难相信没有它们就可以实现。因此，离开我的世界，就像我离开他们的世界一样，现在关上回响的门；所以不要留下空白来错过他们，然后死去。

Through some of the fiery windows beautiful from without, and set, at this sunset hour, not in dull-grey stone but in a glorious house of gold, the light excluded at other windows pours in rich, lavish, overflowing like the summer plenty in the land. Then do the frozen Dedlocks thaw. Strange movements come upon their features as the shadows of leaves play there. A dense justice in a corner is beguiled into a wink. A staring baronet, with a truncheon, gets a dimple in his chin. Down into the bosom of a stony shepherdess there steals a fleck of light and warmth that would have done it good a hundred years ago. One ancestress of Volumnia, in highheeled shoes, very like her—casting the shadow of that virgin event before her full two centuries—shoots out into a halo and becomes a saint. A maid of honour of the court of Charles the Second, with large round eyes (and other charms to correspond), seems to bathe in glowing water, and it ripples as it glows.
透过一些火红的窗户，从外面看很美丽，在这个日落的时刻，不是在暗灰色的石头上，而是在一座辉煌的金屋子里，其他窗户所排除的光线倾泻而下，丰富、奢华，像夏天的充足一样溢出来。那片土地。然后将冷冻的 Dedlocks 解冻。当树叶的影子在他们脸上游动时，他们的脸上出现了奇怪的动作。角落里的浓密正义被眨眼所迷惑。一位拿着警棍、目光凝视的准男爵，下巴上有一个酒窝。在一个石质牧羊女的怀里，偷走了一丝光亮和温暖，这在一百年前是有用的。沃伦尼亚的一位女祖先，穿着高跟鞋，非常像她——在她整整两个世纪之前投下那场处女事件的阴影——射出光环，成为一名圣人。查理二世宫廷的一位伴娘，长着圆圆的大眼睛（还有其他相应的魅力），似乎沐浴在发光的水中，发光时水波荡漾。

But the fire of the sun is dying. Even now the floor is dusky, and shadow slowly mounts the walls, bringing the Dedlocks down like age and death. And now, upon my Lady’s picture over the great chimneypiece, a weird shade falls from some old tree, that turns it pale, and flutters it, and looks as if a great arm held a veil or hood, watching an opportunity to draw it over her. Higher and darker rises shadow on the wall—now a red gloom on the ceiling—now the fire is out.
但太阳之火正在熄灭。即使现在，地板还是昏暗的，阴影慢慢爬上墙壁，像衰老和死亡一样让戴洛克一家黯然失色。现在，在我夫人的大烟囱上方的照片上，一种奇怪的阴影从某棵老树上落下，使它变得苍白，并使其飘动，看起来好像一只巨大的手臂握住了面纱或兜帽，等待机会将其拉下来她。墙上的阴影越来越高、越来越暗——现在天花板上出现了红色的阴影——现在火已经熄灭了。

All that prospect, which from the terrace looked so near, has moved solemnly away and changed—not the first nor the last of beautiful things that look so near and will so change—into a distant phantom. Light mists arise, and the dew falls, and all the sweet scents in the garden are heavv in the air. Now the woods settle into great masses as if they were each one profound tree. And now the moon rises to separate them, and to glimmer here and there in horizontal lines behind their stems, and to make the avenue a pavement of light among high cathedral arches fantastically broken.
所有从露台上看去如此近的景象，都庄严地移开并改变了——不是第一个，也不是最后一个看起来如此近且将如此变化的美丽事物——变成了遥远的幻影。轻雾升起，露珠落下，花园里所有的甜香都弥漫在空气中。现在，树林聚集成一大片，仿佛每一棵都是一棵玄树。现在，月亮升起，将它们分开，并在它们的茎后面以水平线闪烁，使大道成为高高的大教堂拱门之间的光路，令人难以置信地破碎。

Now the moon is high; and the great house, needing habitation more than ever, is like a body without life. Now it is even awful, stealing through it, to think of the live people who have slept in the solitary bedrooms, to say nothing of the dead. Now is the time for shadow, when every corner is a cavern and every downward step a pit, when the stained glass is reflected in pale and faded hues upon the floors, when anything and everything can be made of the heavy staircase beams excepting their own proper shapes, when the armour has dull lights upon it not easily to be distinguished from stealthy movement, and when barred helmets are frightfully suggestive of heads inside. But of all the shadows in Chesney Wold, the shadow in the long drawing-room upon my Lady’s picture is the first to come, the last to be disturbed. At this hour and by this light it changes into threatening hands raised up and menacing the handsome face with every breath that stirs.
现在月亮高高挂起；这座大房子比以往任何时候都更需要居住，就像一具没有生命的身体。现在，偷偷地穿过它，想到那些睡在孤独的卧室里的活人，就更可怕了，更不用说死者了。现在是阴影的时候了，当每个角落都是一个洞穴，每一个向下的台阶都是一个坑，当彩色玻璃以苍白和褪色的色调反射在地板上时，当任何东西都可以由沉重的楼梯梁制成时，除了它们自己的梁之外正确的形状，当盔甲上有暗淡的灯光时，很难将其与隐秘的运动区分开来，当带栏的头盔可怕地暗示着头在里面时。但在切斯尼沃尔德的所有阴影中，长客厅里夫人画像上的阴影是最先出现的，也是最后一个受到干扰的。在这个时刻，在这样的光线下，它变成了举起的威胁性的双手，随着每一次呼吸的搅动，威胁着这张英俊的脸。

‘She is not well, ma’am,’ says a groom in Mrs. Rouncewell’s audience-chamber.
“她身体不太好，女士，”朗斯韦尔夫人的觐见厅里的一位新郎说道。

‘My Lady not well! What’s the matter?’
‘夫人身体不太好！怎么了？'

‘Why, my Lady has been but poorly, ma’am, since she was last here— I don’t mean with the family, ma’am, but when she was here as a bird of passage like. My Lady has not been out much for her and has kept her room a good deal.’
“为什么，自从她上次来到这里以来，我的女士一直很糟糕——我不是指与家人在一起，女士，而是当她作为候鸟来到这里时。夫人并没有为她外出太多，而且把她的房间保养得很好。

‘Chesney Wold, Thomas,’ rejoins the housekeeper with proud complacency, ‘will set my Lady up! There is no finer air and no healthier soil in the world!’
“切斯尼·沃尔德，托马斯，”管家自豪地自满地回答道，“会安排我的女士的！”世界上没有比这更好的空气和更健康的土壤了！”

Thomas may have his own personal opinions on this subject, probably hints them in his manner of smoothing his sleek head from the nape of his neck to his temples, but he forbears to express them further and retires to the servants’ hall to regale on cold meat-pie and ale.
托马斯可能对这个问题有他自己的个人看法，很可能通过他抚平光滑的头从颈背到太阳穴的方式暗示了这些看法，但他没有进一步表达这些看法，而是退到仆人大厅享用冷饮。肉馅饼和麦芽酒。

This groom is the pilot-fish before the nobler shark. Next evening, down come Sir Leicester and my Lady with their largest retinue, and down come the cousins and others from all the points of the compass. Thenceforth for some weeks backward and forward rush mysterious men with no names, who fly about all those particular parts of the country on which Doodle is at present throwing himself in an auriferous and malty shower, but who are merely persons of a restless disposition and never do anything anywhere.
这条新郎是高贵鲨鱼之前的领航鱼。第二天晚上，莱斯特爵士和夫人带着他们最大的随从下来，表兄弟姐妹和其他人从罗盘的各个角落下来。从那以后的几个星期里，来回奔波的没有名字的神秘人，他们在这个国家的所有特定地区飞来飞去，而嘟嘟目前正在其上沐浴着金色和麦芽味的阵雨，但他们只是性格焦躁不安的人，从不这样做。随时随地做任何事。

On these national occasions Sir Leicester finds the cousins useful. A better man than the Honourable Bob Stables to meet the Hunt at dinner, there could not possibly be. Better got up gentlemen than the other cousins to ride over to polling-booths and hustings here and there, and show themselves on the side of England, it would be hard to find. Volumnia is a little dim, but she is of the true descent; and there are many who appreciate her sprightly conversation, her French conundrums so old as to have become in the cycles of time almost new again, the honour of taking the fair Dedlock in to dinner, or even the privilege of her hand in the dance. On these national occasions dancing may be a patriotic service, and Volumnia is constantly seen hopping about for the good of an ungrateful and unpensioning country.
在这些全国性的场合，莱斯特爵士发现堂兄弟们很有用。不可能有比鲍勃·斯泰布尔斯阁下更好的人来与亨特共进晚餐。先生们，最好站起来，比其他堂兄妹骑车去各地的投票站和竞选集会，表明自己站在英格兰一边，否则很难找到。沃伦尼娅虽然有点暗淡，但她是真正的血统；有很多人欣赏她活泼的谈话，她的法国难题，这些古老的问题在时间的循环中几乎又变成了新的，她荣幸地邀请美丽的戴德洛克共进晚餐，甚至欣赏她在舞会上牵手的特权。在这些全国性的场合，跳舞可能是一种爱国服务，人们经常看到沃伦尼亚为了一个忘恩负义、没有养老金的国家而跳来跳去。

My Lady takes no great pains to entertain the numerous guests, and being still unwell, rarely appears until late in the day. But at all the dismal dinners, leaden lunches, basilisk balls, and other melancholy pageants, her mere appearance is a relief. As to Sir Leicester, he conceives it utterly impossible that anything can be wanting, in any direction, by any one who has the good fortune to be received under that roof; and in a state of sublime satisfaction, he moves among the company, a magnificent refrigerator.
夫人并不费心去招待众多的客人，而且身体仍然不舒服，很少到深夜才出现。但在所有令人沮丧的晚餐、沉闷的午餐、蛇怪舞会和其他忧郁的盛会中，她的出现本身就让人松了一口气。至于莱斯特爵士，他认为，对于任何有幸在那个屋檐下受到接待的人来说，在任何方面都不可能有任何欠缺。他怀着无比满足的心情，在公司里那台宏伟的冰箱里走来走去。

Daily the cousins trot through dust and canter over roadside turf, away to hustings and polling-booths (with leather gloves and hunting-whips for the counties and kid gloves and riding-canes for the boroughs), and daily bring back reports on which Sir Leicester holds forth after dinner. Daily the restless men who have no occupation in life present the appearance of being rather busy. Daily Volumnia has a little cousinly talk with Sir Leicester on the state of the nation, from which Sir Leicester is disposed to conclude that Volumnia is a more reflecting woman than he had thought her.
每天，堂兄弟们在尘土中小跑，在路边的草坪上慢跑，前往投票站和投票站（县戴着皮手套和猎鞭，行政区戴着羊皮手套和骑手杖），每天带回有关先生的报告莱斯特在晚餐后继续讨论。生活中没有职业、焦躁不安的人们每天都显得很忙碌。 《每日沃伦尼亚》与莱斯特爵士就国家状况进行了一次堂兄般的谈话，莱斯特爵士从谈话中得出结论，沃伦尼亚是一个比他想象的更善于思考的女人。

‘How are we getting on?’ says Miss Volumnia, clasping her hands. ‘ARE we safe?’
“我们相处得怎么样？”沃伦尼亚小姐紧握双手说道。 “我们安全吗？”

The mighty business is nearly over by this time, and Doodle will throw himself off the country in a few days more. Sir Leicester has just appeared in the long drawing-room after dinner, a bright particular star surrounded by clouds of cousins.
此时，伟大的事业已经接近尾声，几天后，涂鸦就会离开这个国家。晚饭后，莱斯特爵士刚刚出现在长长的客厅里，他就像一颗明亮的星星，被一群表兄弟包围着。

‘Volumnia,’ replies Sir Leicester, who has a list in his hand, ‘we are doing tolerably.’
“沃伦尼亚，”莱斯特爵士回答道，他手里拿着一份清单，“我们做得还算可以。”

‘Only tolerably!’
“只能忍受！”

Although it is summer weather, Sir Leicester always has his own particular fire in the evening. He takes his usual screened seat near it and repeats with much firmness and a little displeasure, as who should say, I am not a common man, and when I say tolerably, it must not be understood as a common expression, ‘Volumnia, we are doing tolerably.’
虽然是夏天的天气，但莱斯特爵士在晚上总是有自己独特的篝火。他坐在靠近它的通常的屏蔽座位上，以非常坚定和有点不高兴的态度重复，谁应该说，我不是一个普通人，当我说可以容忍时，它一定不能被理解为一个常见的表达，“Volumnia，我们表现还算可以。

‘At least there is no opposition to YOU,’ Volumnia asserts with confidence.
“至少没有人反对你，”沃伦尼亚自信地断言。

‘No, Volumnia. This distracted country has lost its senses in many respects, I grieve to say, but—‘
“不，沃伦尼亚。”我悲伤地说，这个心烦意乱的国家在很多方面都失去了理智，但是——”

‘It is not so mad as that. I am glad to hear it!’
‘事情没那么疯狂。我很高兴听到这个消息！

Volumnia’s finishing the sentence restores her to favour. Sir Leicester, with a gracious inclination of his head, seems to say to himself, ‘A sensible woman this, on the whole, though occasionally precipitate.’
沃伦尼亚的判决结束后，她重新获得了青睐。莱斯特爵士亲切地歪着头，似乎在对自己说：“总的来说，这是一个明智的女人，尽管偶尔会突然发生。”

In fact, as to this question of opposition, the fair Dedlock’s observation was superfluous, Sir Leicester on these occasions always delivering in his own candidateship, as a kind of handsome wholesale order to be promptly executed. Two other little seats that belong to him he treats as retail orders of less importance, merely sending down the men and signifying to the tradespeople, ‘You will have the goodness to make these materials into two members of Parliament and to send them home when done.’
事实上，对于这个反对的问题，公平的戴德洛克的观察是多余的，莱斯特爵士在这些场合总是以他自己的候选人身份交付，作为一种需要立即执行的漂亮的批发命令。属于他的另外两个小席位，他将其视为不太重要的零售订单，只是派出人员并向商人表示，“你们将有幸将这些材料制成两名国会议员，并在完成后将他们送回家” .'

‘I regret to say, Volumnia, that in many places the people have shown a bad spirit, and that this opposition to the government has been of a most determined and most implacable description.’
“我遗憾地说，沃伦尼亚，在许多地方，人民表现出了恶劣的精神，这种对政府的反对是最坚决、最无情的。”

‘W-r-retches!’ says Volumnia.
“干、干、干呕！”沃伦尼亚说道。

‘Even,’ proceeds Sir Leicester, glancing at the circumjacent cousins on sofas and ottomans, ‘even in many—in fact, in most—of those places in which the government has carried it against a faction—‘
“甚至，”莱斯特爵士继续说道，扫了一眼周围沙发和脚凳上的表兄弟，“甚至在许多——事实上，在大多数——政府对某个派系采取行动的地方——”

(Note, by the way, that the Coodleites are always a faction with the Doodleites, and that the Doodleites occupy exactly the same position towards the Coodleites.)
（顺便说一下，请注意，Coodleites 始终与 Doodleites 是一个派系，并且 Doodleites 对 Coodleites 占据完全相同的位置。）

‘—Even in them I am shocked, for the credit of Englishmen, to be constrained to inform you that the party has not triumphed without being put to an enormous expense. Hundreds,’ says Sir Leicester, eyeing the cousins with increasing dignity and swelling indignation, ‘hundreds of thousands of pounds!’
“——即使在这些文章中，我也感到震惊，为了英国人的信誉，我不得不告诉你们，该党在没有付出巨大代价的情况下就没有取得胜利。数百英镑，”莱斯特爵士说道，看着表兄弟俩，眼神中的尊严与日俱增，愤怒越来越高，“数十万英镑！”

If Volumnia have a fault, it is the fault of being a trifle too innocent, seeing that the innocence which would go extremely well with a sash and tucker is a little out of keeping with the rouge and pearl necklace. Howbeit, impelled by innocence, she asks, ‘What for?’
如果说沃伦尼娅有什么缺点的话，那就是有点太天真了，因为与腰带和褶皱搭配得天真无邪，与胭脂和珍珠项链却有点格格不入。然而，出于纯真，她问道：“为什么？”

‘Volumnia,’ remonstrates Sir Leicester with his utmost severity. ‘Volumnia!’
“沃伦尼亚，”莱斯特爵士极其严厉地抗议道。 “沃卢姆尼亚！”

‘No, no, I don’t mean what for,’ cries Volumnia with her favourite little scream. ‘How stupid I am! I mean what a pity!’
“不，不，我不是说为什么，”沃伦尼亚用她最喜欢的小尖叫声喊道。 ‘我多么愚蠢啊！我的意思是多么遗憾啊！

‘I am glad,’ returns Sir Leicester, ‘that you do mean what a pity.’
“我很高兴，”莱斯特爵士回答道，“你的意思确实很可惜。”

Volumnia hastens to express her opinion that the shocking people ought to be tried as traitors and made to support the party.
沃伦尼亚赶紧表达了她的观点，认为这些令人震惊的人应该被当作叛徒来审判，并让他们支持党。

‘I am glad, Volumnia,’ repeats Sir Leicester, unmindful of these mollifying sentiments, ‘that you do mean what a pity. It is disgraceful to the electors. But as you, though inadvertently and without intending so unreasonable a question, asked me ‘what for?’ let me reply to you. For necessary expenses. And I trust to your good sense, Volumnia, not to pursue the subject, here or elsewhere.’
“我很高兴，沃伦尼娅，”莱斯特爵士重复道，不顾这些安抚的情绪，“你的意思确实很可惜。”这是对选民的耻辱。但是，当你无意中问我“为什么？”时，让我回答你。用于必要的开支。我相信你的理智，沃伦尼亚，不要在这里或其他地方追究这个话题。

Sir Leicester feels it incumbent on him to observe a crushing aspect towards Volumnia because it is whispered abroad that these necessary expenses will, in some two hundred election petitions, be unpleasantly connected with the word bribery, and because some graceless jokers have consequently suggested the omission from the Church service of the ordinary supplication in behalf of the High Court of Parliament and have recommended instead that the prayers of the congregation be requested for six hundred and fifty-eight gentlemen in a very unhealthy state.
莱斯特爵士认为他有责任观察到对沃伦尼亚的压倒性的一面，因为国外有传言说，在大约两百份选举请愿书中，这些必要的开支将与贿赂这个词令人不愉快地联系在一起，而且因为一些无礼的玩笑者因此建议忽略这一点教会代表议会高等法院举行普通祈祷仪式，并建议为六百五十八位健康状况极差的绅士请求会众祈祷。

‘I suppose,’ observes Volumnia, having taken a little time to recover her spirits after her late castigation, ‘I suppose Mr. Tulkinghorn has been worked to death.’
“我想，”沃卢尼娅在她最近的严厉批评后花了一点时间恢复精神后说道，“我想图金霍恩先生已经被累死了。”

‘I don’t know,’ says Sir Leicester, opening his eyes, ‘why Mr. Tulkinghorn should be worked to death. I don’t know what Mr. Tulkinghorn’s engagements may be. He is not a candidate.’
“我不知道，”莱斯特爵士睁开眼睛说道，“为什么图尔金霍恩先生要被劳累致死。我不知道图尔金霍恩先生的任务是什么。他不是候选人。

Volumnia had thought he might have been employed. Sir Leicester could desire to know by whom, and what for. Volumnia, abashed again, suggests, by somebody—to advise and make arrangements. Sir Leicester is not aware that any client of Mr. Tulkinghorn has been in need of his assistance.
沃伦尼亚原以为他可能已经被雇用了。莱斯特爵士可能想知道是谁干的、为了什么目的。沃伦尼亚再次感到羞愧，有人建议——建议并做出安排。莱斯特爵士并不知道图尔金霍恩先生的任何客户需要他的帮助。

Lady Dedlock, seated at an open window with her arm upon its cushioned ledge and looking out at the evening shadows falling on the park, has seemed to attend since the lawyer’s name was mentioned.
自从提到律师的名字以来，戴德洛克夫人坐在一扇开着的窗户前，手臂搭在带软垫的窗台上，望着傍晚落在公园上的影子。

A languid cousin with a moustache in a state of extreme debility now observes from his couch that man told him ya’as’dy that Tulkinghorn had gone down t’ that iron place t’ give legal ‘pinion ‘bout something, and that contest being over t’ day, ‘twould be highly jawlly thing if Tulkinghorn should ‘pear with news that Coodle man was floored.
一个留着小胡子、处于极度虚弱状态的疲惫表弟现在在沙发上观察到，那个人告诉他，图金霍恩已经到了那个铁地方，对某件事给予法律“支持”，而那场比赛正在今天，如果图金霍恩听到库德曼被击倒的消息，那将是一件非常下巴的事情。

Mercury in attendance with coffee informs Sir Leicester, hereupon, that Mr. Tulkinghorn has arrived and is taking dinner. My Lady turns her head inward for the moment, then looks out again as before.
墨丘利带着咖啡出席，通知莱斯特爵士图尔金霍恩先生已经抵达并正在吃晚饭。夫人暂时将头向内转了一会儿，然后又像以前一样向外望去。

Volumnia is charmed to hear that her delight is come. He is so original, such a stolid creature, such an immense being for knowing all sorts of things and never telling them! Volumnia is persuaded that he must be a Freemason. Is sure he is at the head of a lodge, and wears short aprons, and is made a perfect idol of with candlesticks and trowels. These lively remarks the fair Dedlock delivers in her youthful manner, while making a purse.
沃伦尼娅听到她的喜悦即将到来，很高兴。他是如此原始，如此冷漠的生物，如此伟大的存在，知道各种各样的事情却从不告诉他们！沃伦尼亚确信他一定是共济会成员。确信他是一家旅馆的负责人，穿着短围裙，用烛台和抹子做成了完美的偶像。美丽的戴德洛克在制作钱包时，以她年轻的态度说出了这些生动的言论。

‘He has not been here once,’ she adds, ‘since I came. I really had some thoughts of breaking my heart for the inconstant creature. I had almost made up my mind that he was dead.’
“自从我来之后，他就没有来过这里一次，”她补充道。我真的有些想为这个反复无常的生物而伤透我的心。我几乎已经下定决心他已经死了。

It may be the gathering gloom of evening, or it may be the darker gloom within herself, but a shade is on my Lady’s face, as if she thought, ‘I would he were!’
也许是夜色渐浓，也许是她内心的阴郁，但我夫人的脸上却笼罩着阴影，仿佛她在想：“我希望他是这样！”

‘Mr. Tulkinghorn,’ says Sir Leicester, ‘is always welcome here and always discreet wheresoever he is. A very valuable person, and deservedly respected.’
'先生。莱斯特爵士说，图金霍恩在这里总是受到欢迎，而且无论他身在何处，他总是很谨慎。一个非常有价值的人，值得尊重。”

The debilitated cousin supposes he is ‘‘normously rich fler.’
这位虚弱的表弟认为他“非常富有”。

‘He has a stake in the country,’ says Sir Leicester, ‘I have no doubt. He is, of course, handsomely paid, and he associates almost on a footing of equality with the highest society.’
“他对这个国家有利害关系，”莱斯特爵士说，“我毫不怀疑。”当然，他的薪水很高，而且他几乎在平等的基础上与上流社会交往。

Everybody starts. For a gun is fired close by.
大家开始。因为有枪在附近开火。

‘Good gracious, what’s that?’ cries Volumnia with her little withered scream.
“天哪，那是什么？”沃伦妮娅用她微弱的尖叫声喊道。

‘A rat,’ says my Lady. ‘And they have shot him.’
“一只老鼠，”夫人说。 “他们开枪打死了他。”

Enter Mr. Tulkinghorn, followed by Mercuries with lamps and candles.
图金霍恩先生上，水星提着灯和蜡烛紧随其后。

‘No, no,’ says Sir Leicester, ‘I think not. My Lady, do you object to the twilight?’
“不，不，”莱斯特爵士说，“我想不是。”夫人，您反对黄昏吗？

On the contrary, my Lady prefers it.
相反，夫人更喜欢它。

‘Volumnia?’
“沃卢尼亚？”

Oh! Nothing is so delicious to Volumnia as to sit and talk in the dark.
哦！对于沃伦尼亚来说，没有什么比在黑暗中坐下来聊天更美妙的事情了。

‘Then take them away,’ says Sir Leicester. ‘Tulkinghorn, I beg your pardon. How do you do?’
“那就把它们带走，”莱斯特爵士说。 “图尔金霍恩，请原谅。你好吗？'

Mr. Tulkinghorn with his usual leisurely ease advances, renders his passing homage to my Lady, shakes Sir Leicester’s hand, and subsides into the chair proper to him when he has anything to communicate, on the opposite side of the Baronet’s little newspaper-table. Sir Leicester is apprehensive that my Lady, not being very well, will take cold at that open window. My Lady is obliged to him, but would rather sit there for the air. Sir Leicester rises, adjusts her scarf about her, and returns to his seat. Mr. Tulkinghorn in the meanwhile takes a pinch of snuff.
图金霍恩先生一如既往地从容不迫地走上前来，向我的夫人致以短暂的敬意，与莱斯特爵士握手，当他有什么话要交流时，就坐到男爵小报纸桌对面适合他的椅子上。莱斯特爵士担心夫人身体不太好，会在开着的窗户前着凉。夫人很感激他，但她宁愿坐在那儿透透气。莱斯特爵士站起身来，整理了一下围巾，然后回到座位上。与此同时，图金霍恩先生吸了一口鼻烟。

‘Now,’ says Sir Leicester. ‘How has that contest gone?’
“现在，”莱斯特爵士说。 “那场比赛进行得怎么样了？”

‘Oh, hollow from the beginning. Not a chance. They have brought in both their people. You are beaten out of all reason. Three to one.’
‘哦，从一开始就空洞。没有机会。他们把他们的人都带来了。你被无缘无​​故地打了。三对一。

It is a part of Mr. Tulkinghorn’s policy and mastery to have no political opinions; indeed, NO opinions. Therefore he says ‘you’ are beaten, and not ‘we.’
图尔金霍恩先生的政策和专长之一是不持有任何政治观点；确实，没有意见。因此他说‘你’被打败了，而不是‘我们’。

Sir Leicester is majestically wroth. Volumnia never heard of such a thing. ‘The debilitated cousin holds that it’s sort of thing that’s sure tapn slongs votes—giv’n—Mob.
莱斯特爵士勃然大怒。沃伦尼亚从来没有听说过这样的事情。 “这位虚弱的表弟认为，这是一种肯定会赢得选票的事情——给予——暴民。”

‘It’s the place, you know,’ Mr. Tulkinghorn goes on to say in the fast-increasing darkness when there is silence again, ‘where they wanted to put up Mrs. Rouncewell’s son.’
“你知道，这就是地方，”塔尔金霍恩先生在夜色快速加深、再次陷入寂静时继续说道，“他们想把朗斯韦尔夫人的儿子安置在那里。”

‘A proposal which, as you correctly informed me at the time, he had the becoming taste and perception,’ observes Sir Leicester, ‘to decline. I cannot say that I by any means approve of the sentiments expressed by Mr. Rouncewell when he was here for some half-hour in this room, but there was a sense of propriety in his decision which I am glad to acknowledge.’
“正如你当时正确告诉我的那样，他有适当的品味和洞察力，”莱斯特爵士说，“拒绝了这个提议。”我不能说我无论如何都赞同朗斯韦尔先生在这个房间里呆了半个小时时所表达的观点，但我很高兴承认他的决定有一种得体的感觉。

‘Ha!’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn. ‘It did not prevent him from being very active in this election, though.’
“哈！”图金霍恩先生说道。 “不过，这并没有阻止他在这次选举中非常活跃。”

Sir Leicester is distinctly heard to gasp before speaking. ‘Did I understand you? Did you say that Mr. Rouncewell had been very active in this election?’
明显可以听到莱斯特爵士在讲话前喘息着。 ‘我听懂你的话了吗？你是说朗斯韦尔先生在这次选举中非常积极吗？

‘Uncommonly active.’
“异常活跃。”

‘Against—‘
'反对-'

‘Oh, dear yes, against you. He is a very good speaker. Plain and emphatic. He made a damaging effect, and has great influence. In the business part of the proceedings he carried all before him.’
‘哦，亲爱的，是的，反对你。他是一位非常好的演讲家。平实而有力。他造成了破坏性的影响，影响很大。在诉讼程序的商业部分，他把一切都摆在了面前。

It is evident to the whole company, though nobody can see him, that Sir Leicester is staring majestically.
尽管没有人能看到莱斯特爵士，但整个公司的人都清楚地看到他正在凝视着他。

‘And he was much assisted,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn as a wind-up, ‘by his son.’
“他得到了他儿子的大力帮助，”图尔金霍恩先生总结道。

‘By his son, sir?’ repeats Sir Leicester with awful politeness.
“是他的儿子，先生？”莱斯特爵士极其礼貌地重复道。

‘By his son.’
“是他儿子的。”

‘The son who wished to marry the young woman in my Lady’s service?’
“那个想娶侍奉夫人的年轻女子的儿子？”

‘That son. He has but one.’
‘那个儿子。他只有一个。

‘Then upon my honour,’ says Sir Leicester after a terrific pause during which he has been heard to snort and felt to stare, ‘then upon my honour, upon my life, upon my reputation and principles, the floodgates of society are burst open, and the waters have—a— obliterated the landmarks of the framework of the cohesion by which things are held together!’
“那么，以我的名誉起誓，”莱斯特爵士在一阵可怕的停顿之后说道，在此期间，有人听到他在哼哼，并感觉到他在盯着我看，“那么，以我的名誉起誓，以我的生命起誓，以我的名誉和原则起誓，社会的大门突然打开了。” ，而水已经——a——抹去了事物结合在一起的凝聚力框架的地标！

General burst of cousinly indignation. Volumnia thinks it is really high time, you know, for somebody in power to step in and do something strong. Debilitated cousin thinks—country’s going— Dayvle—steeple-chase pace.
表弟一般爆发出愤怒。沃伦尼亚认为，现在正是有权力的人介入并采取强有力行动的时候了。虚弱的表弟认为——乡村正在前进——戴夫勒——障碍赛的步伐。

‘I beg,’ says Sir Leicester in a breathless condition, ‘that we may not comment further on this circumstance. Comment is superfluous. My Lady, let me suggest in reference to that young woman—‘
“我请求，”莱斯特爵士气喘吁吁地说，“我们不要对这种情况进一​​步发表评论。评论是多余的。夫人，让我就那位年轻女子提出建议——”

‘I have no intention,’ observes my Lady from her window in a low but decided tone, ‘of parting with her.’
“我无意与她分离，”我的夫人在窗外用低沉但坚定的语气说道。

‘That was not my meaning,’ returns Sir Leicester. ‘I am glad to hear you say so. I would suggest that as you think her worthy of your patronage, you should exert your influence to keep her from these dangerous hands. You might show her what violence would be done in such association to her duties and principles, and you might preserve her for a better fate. You might point out to her that she probably would, in good time, find a husband at Chesney Wold by whom she would not be—‘ Sir Leicester adds, after a moment’s consideration, ‘dragged from the altars of her forefathers.’
“那不是我的意思，”莱斯特爵士回答道。 ‘我很高兴听到你这么说。我建议，既然你认为她值得你的庇护，你就应该发挥你的影响力，让她远离这些危险的人。你可能会向她展示与她的职责和原则相关的暴力行为，并且你可能会保护她以获得更好的命运。你可能会向她指出，她很可能会在适当的时候在切斯尼沃尔德找到一个丈夫，而她不会被——”莱斯特爵士考虑了一下后补充道，“从她祖先的祭坛上拖下来。”

These remarks he offers with his unvarying politeness and deference when he addresses himself to his wife. She merely moves her head in reply. The moon is rising, and where she sits there is a little stream of cold pale light, in which her head is seen.
当他向妻子讲话时，他始终保持礼貌和尊重，说出这些话。她只是点头回应。月亮正在升起，她坐的地方有一小束冷淡的光，从中可以看到她的头。

‘It is worthy of remark,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, ‘however, that these people are, in their way, very proud.’
“值得注意的是，”图尔金霍恩先生说，“不过，这些人以他们的方式感到非常自豪。”

‘Proud?’ Sir Leicester doubts his hearing.
“骄傲？”莱斯特爵士怀疑自己的听力。

‘I should not be surprised if they all voluntarily abandoned the girl—yes, lover and all—instead of her abandoning them, supposing she remained at Chesney Wold under such circumstances.’
“如果他们都自愿抛弃了这个女孩——是的，她的爱人和所有人——而不是她抛弃了他们，假设她在这种情况下留在切斯尼沃尔德，我不会感到惊讶。”

‘Well!’ says Sir Leicester tremulously. ‘Well! You should know, Mr. Tulkinghorn. You have been among them.’
“好吧！”莱斯特爵士颤抖着说道。 '出色地！你应该知道，图金霍恩先生。你就是其中之一。

‘Really, Sir Leicester,’ returns the lawyer, ‘I state the fact. Why, I could tell you a story—with Lady Dedlock’s permission.’
“真的，莱斯特爵士，”律师回答道，“我陈述事实。”嘿，我可以给你讲一个故事——经过戴德洛克夫人的许可。

Her head concedes it, and Volumnia is enchanted. A story! Oh, he is going to tell something at last! A ghost in it, Volumnia hopes?
她的头脑承认了这一点，沃伦尼亚着迷了。一个故事！哦，他终于要说点什么了！沃伦尼亚希望里面有鬼魂？

‘No. Real flesh and blood.’ Mr. Tulkinghorn stops for an instant and repeats with some little emphasis grafted upon his usual monotony, ‘Real flesh and blood, Miss Dedlock. Sir Leicester, these particulars have only lately become known to me. They are very brief. They exemplify what I have said. I suppress names for the present. Lady Dedlock will not think me ill-bred, I hope?’
'不。真正的有血有肉的人。”图金霍恩先生停了下来，在他一贯的单调的基础上稍加强调地重复道：“真正的有血有肉的人，戴德洛克小姐。莱斯特爵士，我最近才知道这些细节。它们非常简短。他们举例说明了我所说的内容。我暂时隐瞒了名字。希望戴德洛克夫人不会认为我没有教养吧？

By the light of the fire, which is low, he can be seen looking towards the moonlight. By the light of the moon Lady Dedlock can be seen, perfecfly still.
借着微弱的火光，可以看到他正朝着月光看去。借着月光，可以看到戴德洛克夫人，一动不动。

‘A townsman of this Mrs. Rouncewell, a man in exactly parallel circumstances as I am told, had the good fortune to have a daughter who attracted the notice of a great lady. I speak of really a great lady, not merely great to him, but married to a gentleman of your condition, Sir Leicester.’
“朗斯韦尔夫人的一位同乡，据我所知，他的情况与我完全相似，他很幸运，有一个女儿，引起了一位伟大女士的注意。我说的是一位真正伟大的女士，不仅对他很伟大，而且嫁给了一位像您这样的绅士，莱斯特爵士。

Sir Leicester condescendingly says, ‘Yes, Mr. Tulkinghorn,’ implying that then she must have appeared of very considerable moral dimensions indeed in the eyes of an iron-master.
莱斯特爵士居高临下地说：“是的，图金霍恩先生。”这意味着，在一位钢铁大师的眼中，她一定具有非常高的道德标准。

‘The lady was wealthy and beautiful, and had a liking for the girl, and treated her with great kindness, and kept her always near her. Now this lady preserved a secret under all her greatness, which she had preserved for many years. In fact, she had in early life been engaged to marry a young rake—he was a captain in the army— nothing connected with whom came to any good. She never did marry him, but she gave birth to a child of which he was the father.’
这位女士富有又美丽，很喜欢这个女孩，对她非常友善，总是把她留在身边。现在，这位女士在她的伟大之下保守了一个秘密，这个秘密她已经保守了很多年。事实上，她早年曾与一个年轻的浪荡子订婚——他是一名陆军上尉——与谁没有任何关系。她从未嫁给他，但她生了一个孩子，他是孩子的父亲。

By the light of the fire he can be seen looking towards the moonlight. By the moonlight, Lady Dedlock can be seen in profile, perfectly still.
借着火光，可以看到他正朝着月光看去。月光下，可以看到戴德洛克夫人的侧影，一动不动。

‘The captain in the army being dead, she believed herself safe; but a train of circumstances with which I need not trouble you led to discovery. As I received the story, they began in an imprudence on her own part one day when she was taken by surprise, which shows how difficult it is for the firmest of us (she was very firm) to be always guarded. There was great domestic trouble and amazement, you may suppose; I leave you to imagine, Sir Leicester, the husband’s grief. But that is not the present point. When Mr. Rouncewell’s townsman heard of the disclosure, he no more allowed the girl to be patronized and honoured than he would have suffered her to be trodden underfoot before his eyes. Such was his pride, that he indignantly took her away, as if from reproach and disgrace. He had no sense of the honour done him and his daughter by the lady’s condescension; not the least. He resented the girl’s position, as if the lady had been the commonest of commoners. That is the story. I hope Lady Dedlock will excuse its painful nature.’
“军队的队长死了，她相信自己安全了；但我不必麻烦你，一系列的情况导致了你的发现。当我收到这个故事时，有一天，当她感到惊讶时，他们开始了她自己的轻率行为，这表明对于我们中最坚定的人（她非常坚定）来说，始终保持警惕是多么困难。你可能会认为，家里有很大的麻烦和惊奇；但事实却是这样。莱斯特爵士，我让你想象一下丈夫的悲伤。但这不是现在的重点。当朗斯韦尔先生的镇民听说此事后，他不允许这个女孩受到居高临下和尊敬，就像他不允许她在他眼前被践踏一样。他是如此的骄傲，以至于他愤怒地把她带走了，仿佛是出于责备和耻辱。他并没有意识到这位女士的居高临下给他和他的女儿带来了荣誉。并非最不重要的。他对这个女孩的地位很反感，就好像她是最普通的平民一样。这就是故事。我希望戴德洛克夫人能够原谅其痛苦的本质。

There are various opinions on the merits, more or less conflicting with Volumnia’s. That fair young creature cannot believe there ever was any such lady and rejects the whole history on the threshold.
