The majority incline to the debilitated cousin’s sentiment, which is in few words—‘no business—Rouncewell’s fernal townsman.’ Sir Leicester generally refers back in his mind to Wat Tyler and arranges a sequence of events on a plan of his own.
对于案情的是非曲直，存在着各种各样的观点，或多或少与沃伦尼亚的观点相冲突。那个美丽的年轻生物无法相信曾经有过这样的女士，并且拒绝接受整个历史。大多数人倾向于虚弱的表弟的情绪，简而言之——“没啥事——朗斯韦尔的热情镇民。”莱斯特爵士通常会在脑海中回想起瓦特·泰勒，并按照自己的计划安排一系列事件。

There is not much conversation in all, for late hours have been kept at Chesney Wold since the necessary expenses elsewhere began, and this is the first night in many on which the family have been alone. It is past ten when Sir Leicester begs Mr. Tulkinghorn to ring for candles. Then the stream of moonlight has swelled into a lake, and then Lady Dedlock for the first time moves, and rises, and comes forward to a table for a glass of water. Winking cousins, bat-like in the candle glare, crowd round to give it; Volumnia (always ready for something better if procurable) takes another, a very mild sip of which contents her; Lady Dedlock, graceful, self-possessed, looked after by admiring eyes, passes away slowly down the long perspective by the side of that nymph, not at all improving her as a question of contrast.
总的来说，没有太多的谈话，因为自从其他地方开始有必要的开支以来，切斯尼沃尔德就一直待到很晚，而这是许多人中家人独处的第一个晚上。十点多了，莱斯特爵士恳求图金霍恩先生按铃要蜡烛。然后月光的溪流涌入了一个湖，然后戴德洛克夫人第一次移动，站起来，走到一张桌子前喝了一杯水。堂兄弟们在烛光下像蝙蝠一样眨着眼睛，围过来送礼物；沃伦尼娅（如果可以的话，总是准备好喝点更好的东西）又喝了一口，非常温和地喝了一口，她感到很满足。戴德洛克夫人优雅、沉着，在众人羡慕的目光注视下，沿着长长的视角慢慢地在仙女身边逝去，与对比相比，她并没有得到任何改善。

CHAPTER XLI
第 XLI 章


In Mr. Tulkinghorn’s Room
在图金霍恩先生的房间里

Mr. Tulkinghorn arrives in his turret-room a little breathed by the journey up, though leisurely performed. There is an expression on his face as if he had discharged his mind of some grave matter and were, in his close way, satisfied. To say of a man so severely and strictly self-repressed that he is triumphant would be to do him as great an injustice as to suppose him troubled with love or sentiment or any romantic weakness. He is sedately satisfied. Perhaps there is a rather increased sense of power upon him as he loosely grasps one of his veinous wrists with his other hand and holding it behind his back walks noiselessly up and down.
图金霍恩先生抵达他的炮塔室时，尽管表现得很悠闲，但上山的旅程让他有点喘不过气来。他脸上的表情就好像他已经摆脱了一些严重的事情，并且以他近乎的方式感到满意。如果说一个如此严重、严格地自我压抑的人是胜利者，那就对他来说是一种极大的不公正，就像认为他受到爱情、情感或任何浪漫弱点的困扰一样。他心里很满足。也许当他用另一只手松松地抓住他青筋暴起的手腕，背在背后，无声地走来走去时，他身上的力量感反而增强了。

There is a capacious writing-table in the room on which is a pretty large accumulation of papers. The green lamp is lighted, his reading-glasses lie upon the desk, the easy-chair is wheeled up to it, and it would seem as though he had intended to bestow an hour or so upon these claims on his attention before going to bed. But he happens not to be in a business mind. After a glance at the documents awaiting his notice—with his head bent low over the table, the old man’s sight for print or writing being defective at night—he opens the French window and steps out upon the leads. There he again walks slowly up and down in the same attitude, subsiding, if a man so cool may have any need to subside, from the story he has related downstairs.
房间里有一张宽敞的写字台，上面堆放着相当多的文件。绿灯亮着，他的老花镜放在桌子上，安乐椅被推到桌前，看起来他打算在睡觉前花一个小时左右的时间来集中精力处理这些事情。 。但他恰好没有商业头脑。扫了一眼等待他注意的文件后——他把头低垂在桌子上，老人在晚上打印或书写的视力有缺陷——他打开落地窗，踏着线索走了出去。在那里，他又以同样的态度慢慢地走来走去，平静下来，如果一个如此冷静的人可能需要平静下来，从他在楼下讲述的故事来看。

The time was once when men as knowing as Mr. Tulkinghorn would walk on turret-tops in the starlight and look up into the sky to read their fortunes there. Hosts of stars are visible to-night, though their brilliancy is eclipsed by the splendour of the moon. If he be seeking his own star as he methodically turns and turns upon the leads, it should be but a pale one to be so rustily represented below. If he be tracing out his destiny, that may be written in other characters nearer to his hand.
曾经，像图尔金霍恩先生这样博学的人会在星光下走在塔顶上，仰望天空，在那里算命。今晚可以看到许多星星，尽管它们的光彩被月亮的光辉所掩盖。如果他在有条不紊地在导线上转来转去时正在寻找自己的星星，那么下面如此生锈地表现出来的那颗星星应该只是一颗苍白的星星。如果他要描绘自己的命运，那可能会写在离他更近的其他文字上。

As he paces the leads with his eyes most probably as high above his thoughts as they are high above the earth, he is suddenly stopped in passing the window by two eyes that meet his own. The ceiling of his room is rather low; and the upper part of the door, which is opposite the window, is of glass. There is an inner baize door, too, but the night being warm he did not close it when he came upstairs. These eyes that meet his own are looking in through the glass from the corridor outside. He knows them well. The blood has not flushed into his face so suddenly and redly for many a long year as when he recognizes Lady Dedlock.
当他在线索上踱步时，他的眼睛很可能高出他的思想，就像它们高出地球一样高，他在经过窗户时突然被两只与他自己相遇的眼睛拦住了。他房间的天花板相当低；与窗户相对的门的上部是玻璃的。里面也有一扇呢子门，但夜色暖和，他上楼时没有关门。这双眼睛与他的目光相遇，正从外面的走廊透过玻璃往里看。他很了解他们。多年来，他从未像认出戴德洛克夫人时那样突然、如此红润地冲上他的脸。

He steps into the room, and she comes in too, closing both the doors behind her. There is a wild disturbance—is it fear or anger?—in her eyes. In her carriage and all else she looks as she looked downstairs two hours ago.
他走进房间，她也进来，关上身后的门。她的眼中充满了疯狂的不安——是恐惧还是愤怒？她在马车里和其他所有东西上的样子都和两小时前楼下的样子一模一样。

Is it fear or is it anger now? He cannot be sure. Both might be as pale, both as intent.
现在是恐惧还是愤怒？他不能确定。两者可能都一样苍白，都一样专注。

‘Lady Dedlock?’
“德洛克女士？”

She does not speak at first, nor even when she has slowly dropped into the easy-chair by the table. They look at each other, like two pictures.
她一开始没有说话，甚至当她慢慢地坐到桌边的安乐椅上时也没有说话。他们四目相对，就像两张照片。

‘Why have you told my story to so many persons?’
“你为什么要向这么多人讲述我的故事？”

‘Lady Dedlock, it was necessary for me to inform you that I knew it.’
“戴德洛克女士，我有必要告诉你我知道这一点。”

‘How long have you known it?’
“你知道这件事多久了？”

‘I have suspected it a long while—fully known it a little while.’
“我怀疑它已经有一段时间了——完全了解它也有一段时间了。”

‘Months?’
“几个月？”

‘Days.’
'天。'

He stands before her with one hand on a chair-back and the other in his old-fashioned waistcoat and shirt-frill, exactly as he has stood before her at any time since her marriage. The same formal politeness, the same composed deference that might as well be defiance; the whole man the same dark, cold object, at the same distance, which nothing has ever diminished.
他站在她面前，一只手放在椅背上，另一只手穿着老式背心和衬衫褶边，就像她结婚以来他一直站在她面前一样。同样的正式礼貌，同样的沉着的尊重，也可能是蔑视；同样的礼貌。整个人都是同一个黑暗、冰冷的物体，在同样的距离上，没有任何东西可以减弱。

‘Is this true concerning the poor girl?’
“关于那个可怜的女孩，这是真的吗？”

He slightly inclines and advances his head as not quite understanding the question.
他微微侧过头，似乎不太明白这个问题。

‘You know what you related. Is it true? Do her friends know my story also? Is it the town-talk yet? Is it chalked upon the walls and cried in the streets?’
‘你知道你所涉及的是什么。这是真的吗？她的朋友们也知道我的故事吗？这是镇上的谈话吗？它是否用粉笔写在墙上并在街上哭泣？

So! Anger, and fear, and shame. All three contending. What power this woman has to keep these raging passions down! Mr. Tulkinghorn’s thoughts take such form as he looks at her, with his ragged grey eyebrows a hair’s breadth more contracted than usual under her gaze.
所以！愤怒、恐惧、羞耻。三者皆相争。这个女人到底有多大的力量才能压制住这些汹涌的激情！当图金霍恩先生看着她时，他的思绪就这样形成了，他那参差不齐的灰色眉毛在她的注视下比平时收缩了一根头发丝的宽度。

‘No, Lady Dedlock. That was a hypothetical case, arising out of Sir Leicester’s unconsciously carrying the matter with so high a hand. But it would be a real case if they knew—what we know.’
“不，德洛克夫人。这是一个假设的案例，源于莱斯特爵士无意识地对此事采取了如此高的态度。但如果他们知道——我们所知道的，这将是一个真实的案例。

‘Then they do not know it yet?’
“那么他们还不知道吗？”

‘No.’
'不。'

‘Can I save the poor girl from injury before they know it?’
“我能在他们意识到之前拯救这个可怜的女孩免遭伤害吗？”

‘Really, Lady Dedlock,’ Mr. Tulkinghorn replies, ‘I cannot give a satisfactory opinion on that point.’
“说实话，戴德洛克夫人，”图金霍恩先生回答道，“在这一点上我无法给出令人满意的意见。”

And he thinks, with the interest of attentive curiosity, as he watches the struggle in her breast, ‘The power and force of this woman are astonishing!’
当他注视着她胸中的挣扎时，他带着好奇心想，“这个女人的力量和力量是惊人的！”

‘Sir,’ she says, for the moment obliged to set her lips with all the energy she has, that she may speak distinctly, ‘I will make it plainer. I do not dispute your hypothetical case. I anticipated it, and felt its truth as strongly as you can do, when I saw Mr. Rouncewell here. I knew very well that if he could have had the power of seeing me as I was, he would consider the poor girl tarnished by having for a moment been, although most innocently, the subject of my great and distinguished patronage. But I have an interest in her, or I should rather say—no longer belonging to this place—I had, and if you can find so much consideration for the woman under your foot as to remember that, she will be very sensible of your mercy.’
“先生，”她说道，此时她不得不用尽全力抿紧嘴唇，以便能够清晰地说话，“我会把它说得更清楚。”我对你的假设案例没有异议。当我在这里看到朗斯韦尔先生时，我就预料到了这一点，并尽可能强烈地感受到了它的真实性。我非常清楚，如果他能够看到我本来的面目，他就会认为这个可怜的女孩曾一度受到我伟大而尊贵的赞助，虽然是天真无邪的，但却玷污了她的形象。但我对她有兴趣，或者我更应该说——不再属于这个地方——我有兴趣，如果你能对你脚下的女人如此体贴，记住这一点，她就会非常明白你的意思。怜悯。'

Mr. Tulkinghorn, profoundly attentive, throws this off with a shrug of self-depreciation and contracts his eyebrows a little more.
图金霍恩先生非常专注，他自嘲地耸耸肩，把这件事抛之脑后，眉毛又皱得更紧了。

‘You have prepared me for my exposure, and I thank you for that too. Is there anything that you require of me? Is there any claim that I can release or any charge or trouble that I can spare my husband in obtaining HIS release by certifying to the exactness of your discovery? I will write anything, here and now, that you will dictate. I am ready to do it.’
“你让我为曝光做好了准备，我也为此感谢你。你对我有什么要求吗？是否有任何我可以释放的主张，或者通过证明您的发现的准确性，我可以免除我丈夫在获得释放时受到的任何指控或麻烦？我会在此时此地写下您所指定的任何内容。我已经准备好这么做了。

And she would do it, thinks the lawver, watchful of the firm hand with which she takes the pen!
她会这么做的，律师想，并注意她握笔的坚定手！

‘I will not trouble you, Lady Dedlock. Pray spare yourself.’
“我不会麻烦你的，戴德洛克女士。祈祷饶命吧。

‘I have long expected this, as you know. I neither wish to spare myself nor to be spared. You can do nothing worse to me than you have done. Do what remains now.’
“正如你所知，我早就预料到了这一点。我既不想饶过自己，也不想被饶恕。你对我所做的事，没有比你所做的更糟糕的了。做现在剩下的事。

‘Lady Dedlock, there is nothing to be done. I will take leave to say a few words when you have finished.’
“戴德洛克女士，没有什么可做的。当你说完之后我就请假说几句话。

Their need for watching one another should be over now, but they do it all this time, and the stars watch them both through the opened window. Away in the moonlight lie the woodland fields at rest, and the wide house is as quiet as the narrow one. The narrow one! Where are the digger and the spade, this peaceful night, destined to add the last great secret to the many secrets of the Tulkinghorn existence? Is the man born yet, is the spade wrought yet? Curious questions to consider, more curious perhaps not to consider, under the watching stars upon a summer night.
他们互相注视的需要现在应该结束了，但他们一直这样做，星星透过打开的窗户注视着他们。月光下，远处的林地静静地躺着，宽阔的房子和狭窄的房子一样安静。窄的那种！在这个宁静的夜晚，注定要为图金霍恩存在的众多秘密增添最后一个伟大秘密的挖掘机和铁锹在哪里？人已经出生了吗，铁锹已经炼成了吗？在夏夜的星空下，需要考虑一些奇怪的问题，更奇怪的问题也许不应该考虑。

‘Of repentance or remorse or any feeling of mine,’ Lady Dedlock presently proceeds, ‘I say not a word. If I were not dumb, you would be deaf. Let that go by. It is not for your ears.’
“无论是悔恨、悔恨还是我的任何感觉，”戴德洛克夫人接着说道，“我什么也没说。如果我不傻，你就聋了。就这样过去吧。这不适合你的耳朵。

He makes a feint of offering a protest, but she sweeps it away with her disdainful hand.
他假装提出抗议，但她轻蔑地用一只手将其扫掉。

‘Of other and very different things I come to speak to you. My jewels are all in their proper places of keeping. They will be found there. So, my dresses. So, all the valuables I have. Some ready money I had with me, please to say, but no large amount. I did not wear my own dress, in order that I might avoid observation. I went to be henceforward lost. Make this known. I leave no other charge with you.’
“我来是要和你谈谈其他非常不同的事情。我的珠宝都在适当的地方。他们会在那里被发现。所以，我的衣服。所以，我拥有的所有贵重物品。请说一下，我身上有一些现钱，但数额不大。我没有穿自己的衣服，以免被人看见。我从此迷失了。让大家知道这一点。我没有给你留下任何其他费用。

‘Excuse me, Lady Dedlock,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, quite unmoved. ‘I am not sure that I understand you. You want—‘
“对不起，戴德洛克夫人，”图金霍恩先生说道，一动不动。 ‘我不确定我是否理解你。你要-'

‘To be lost to all here. I leave Chesney Wold to-night. I go this hour.’
‘这里的所有人都迷失了。我今晚离开切斯尼沃尔德。我这个时间就去。

Mr. Tulkinghorn shakes his head. She rises, but he, without moving hand from chair-back or from old-fashioned waistcoat and shirtfrill, shakes his head.
图金霍恩先生摇摇头。她站了起来，但他的手没有从椅背上或老式背心和衬衣褶边上移开，只是摇了摇头。

‘What? Not go as I have said?’
'什么？不按照我说的去吗？

‘No, Lady Dedlock,’ he very calmly replies.
“不，戴德洛克女士，”他非常平静地回答。

‘Do you know the relief that my disappearance will be? Have you forgotten the stain and blot upon this place, and where it is, and who it is?’
‘你知道我的失踪会让你松一口气吗？你忘记了这个地方的污点和污点、它在哪里、它是谁吗？

‘No, Lady Dedlock, not by any means.’
“不，戴德洛克女士，无论如何都不会。”

Without deigning to rejoin, she moves to the inner door and has it in her hand when he says to her, without himself stirring hand or foot or raising his voice, ‘Lady Dedlock, have the goodness to stop and hear me, or before you reach the staircase I shall ring the alarm-bell and rouse the house. And then I must speak out before every guest and servant, every man and woman, in it.’
她没有屈尊再加入，而是走到内门，把门拿在手里，当他对她说时，他自己没有动动手脚，也没有提高声音，“戴德洛克女士，请停下来听我说，或者在你面前”到达楼梯后，我将敲响警铃，唤醒全屋。然后我必须在里面的每一位客人和仆人、每一个男人和女人面前大声说话。

He has conquered her. She falters, trembles, and puts her hand confusedly to her head. Slight tokens these in any one else, but when so practised an eye as Mr. Tulkinghorn’s sees indecision for a moment in such a subject, he thoroughly knows its value.
他已经征服了她。她摇摇欲坠、颤抖着，困惑地把手放在头上。这些在任何其他人身上都微不足道，但当图尔金霍恩先生的眼睛如此熟练，在这样的主题上看到片刻的犹豫不决时，他就完全知道它的价值。

He promptly says again, ‘Have the goodness to hear me, Lady Dedlock,’ and motions to the chair from which she has risen. She hesitates, but he motions again, and she sits down.
他立即再次说道：“请听我说，戴德洛克女士，”然后指着她站起来的椅子。她犹豫了一下，但他再次示意，她坐下了。

‘The relations between us are of an unfortunate description, Lady Dedlock; but as they are not of my making, I will not apologize for them. The position I hold in reference to Sir Leicester is so well known to you that I can hardly imagine but that I must long have appeared in your eyes the natural person to make this discovery.’
“我们之间的关系很不幸，戴德洛克夫人；但由于它们不是我造成的，我不会为它们道歉。我对莱斯特爵士的立场对你来说是众所周知的，我几乎无法想象，但我一定很早就在你眼中成为了做出这一发现的自然人。

‘Sir,’ she returns without looking up from the ground on which her eyes are now fixed, ‘I had better have gone. It would have been far better not to have detained me. I have no more to say.’
“先生，”她头也不抬地回答道，“我最好还是走了。”如果不拘留我的话会好得多。我没什么可说的了。

‘Excuse me, Lady Dedlock, if I add a little more to hear.’
“对不起，戴德洛克女士，我想再补充一点。”

‘I wish to hear it at the window, then. I can’t breathe where I am.’
“那我希望在窗边听到它。”我在哪里无法呼吸。

His jealous glance as she walks that way betrays an instant’s misgiving that she may have it in her thoughts to leap over, and dashing against ledge and cornice, strike her life out upon the terrace below. But a moment’s observation of her figure as she stands in the window without any support, looking out at the stars —not up-gloomily out at those stars which are low in the heavens, reassures him. By facing round as she has moved, he stands a little behind her.
当她朝那条路走去时，他嫉妒的目光暴露了她一瞬间的疑虑，担心她可能会想跳过去，冲向窗台和檐口，在下面的露台上丧命。但是，当她没有任何支撑地站在窗前，看着外面的星星——而不是阴沉地看着那些低空的星星时，他观察了一会儿她的身影，这让他放心了。当她移动时，他转过身来，站在她身后不远的地方。

‘Lady Dedlock, I have not yet been able to come to a decision satisfactory to myself on the course before me. I am not clear what to do or how to act next. I must request you, in the meantime, to keep your secret as you have kept it so long and not to wonder that I keep it too.’
“戴德洛克女士，在我面前的课程中，我还没有能够做出令自己满意的决定。我不清楚下一步该做什么或如何行动。与此同时，我必须要求你保守你的秘密，就像你保守了这么久一样，不要奇怪我也保守了它。

He pauses, but she makes no reply.
他停顿了一下，但她没有回答。

‘Pardon me, Lady Dedlock. This is an important subject. You are honouring me with your attention?’
“请原谅，戴德洛克女士。这是一个重要的课题。你的关注是在尊重我吗？

‘I am.’
'我是。'

‘‘Thank you. I might have known it from what I have seen of your strength of character. I ought not to have asked the question, but I have the habit of making sure of my ground, step by step, as I go on. The sole consideration in this unhappy case is Sir Leicester.’
''谢谢。从我所看到的你的坚强性格中我可能已经知道了这一点。我不应该问这个问题，但我有一个习惯，就是在继续说下去时，一步一步地确定自己的立场。在这起不幸的案件中，唯一要考虑的是莱斯特爵士。

‘‘Then why,’ she asks in a low voice and without removing her gloomy look from those distant stars, ‘do you detain me in his house?’
“那你为什么把我困在他家里？”她低声问道，脸上的阴郁神色没有从那些遥远的星星上移开。

‘Because he IS the consideration. Lady Dedlock, I have no occasion to tell you that Sir Leicester is a very proud man, that his reliance upon you is implicit, that the fall of that moon out of the sky would not amaze him more than your fall from your high position as his wife.’
‘因为他就是考虑因素。戴德洛克夫人，我没有机会告诉你，莱斯特爵士是一个非常骄傲的人，他对你的依赖是含蓄的，那颗月亮从天上掉下来不会比你从高位上摔下来更令他惊讶。他的老婆。'

She breathes quickly and heavily, but she stands as unflinchingly as ever he has seen her in the midst of her grandest company.
她呼吸急促而粗重，但她一如既往地坚定地站在她最盛大的公司之中。

‘I declare to you, Lady Dedlock, that with anything short of this case that I have, I would as soon have hoped to root up by means of my own strength and my own hands the oldest tree on this estate as to shake your hold upon Sir Leicester and Sir Leicester’s trust and confidence in you. And even now, with this case, I hesitate. Not that he could doubt (that, even with him, is impossible), but that nothing can prepare him for the blow.’
“我向你声明，戴德洛克夫人，如果我没有这个案子，我真希望能够凭借自己的力量和双手连根拔起这座庄园里最古老的树，以摆脱你的控制。”基于莱斯特爵士和莱斯特爵士对你的信任和信心。即使现在，面对这个案子，我仍然犹豫不决。并不是说他可以怀疑（即使对他来说，这也是不可能的），而是说没有什么能让他为这一打击做好准备。

‘Not my flight?’ she returned. ‘Think of it again.’
“这不是我的航班？”她回答道。 “再想一想。”

‘Your flight, Lady Dedlock, would spread the whole truth, and a hundred times the whole truth, far and wide. It would be impossible to save the family credit for a day. It is not to be thought of.’
“戴德洛克夫人，你的逃亡将会把全部真相传播出去，而且是把全部真相传播一百倍。”家族信用想要挽回一天是不可能的。这是不应该考虑的。

There is a quiet decision in his reply which admits of no remonstrance.
他的答复中有一个平静的决定，没有任何异议。

‘When I speak of Sir Leicester being the sole consideration, he and the family credit are one. Sir Leicester and the baronetcy, Sir Leicester and Chesney Wold, Sir Leicester and his ancestors and his patrimony’—Mr. Tulkinghorn very dry here—‘are, I need not say to you, Lady Dedlock, inseparable.’
“当我说莱斯特爵士是唯一的考虑因素时，他和家族的功劳是其中之一。莱斯特爵士和男爵夫人，莱斯特爵士和切斯尼沃尔德，莱斯特爵士和他的祖先和他的遗产”——莱斯特先生。图金霍恩这里非常干燥——“戴德洛克夫人，我不用对你说，这里是密不可分的。”

‘Go on!’
'继续！'

‘Therefore,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, pursuing his case in his jogtrot style, ‘I have much to consider. This is to be hushed up if it can be. How can it be, if Sir Leicester is driven out of his wits or laid upon a death-bed? If I inflicted this shock upon him to-morrow morning, how could the immediate change in him be accounted for? What could have caused it? What could have divided you? Lady Dedlock, the wall-chalking and the street-crying would come on directly, and you are to remember that it would not affect you merely (whom I cannot at all consider in this business) but your husband, Lady Dedlock, your husband.’
“因此，”图尔金霍恩先生以慢跑的方式处理他的案件，“我有很多事情需要考虑。”如果可以的话，这件事应该保密。如果莱斯特爵士失去理智或躺在床上，那怎么可能呢？如果我明天早上对他造成这种震惊，如何解释他立即发生的变化？什么可能导致它？是什么让你们分裂了？戴德洛克夫人，粉笔画墙和街头哭泣会直接发生，你要记住，这不仅会影响你（在这件事上我完全不能考虑到你），还会影响你的丈夫，戴德洛克夫人，你的丈夫。 '

He gets plainer as he gets on, but not an atom more emphatic or animated.
随着讲的深入，他变得更加平淡，但并没有变得更加强调或活跃。

‘There is another point of view,’ he continues, ‘in which the case presents itself. Sir Leicester is devoted to you almost to infatuation. He might not be able to overcome that infatuation, even knowing what we know. I am putting an extreme case, but it might be so. If so, it were better that he knew nothing. Better for common sense, better for him, better for me. I must take all this into account, and it combines to render a decision very difficult.’
“还有另一种观点，”他继续说道，“这个案子本身就存在。”莱斯特爵士对你几乎近乎痴迷。即使他知道我们所知道的，他也可能无法克服这种迷恋。我举的是一个极端的例子，但也有可能是这样。如果是这样，他还不如什么都不知道。对常识更好，对他更好，对我更好。我必须考虑到所有这些因素，综合起来使做出决定变得非常困难。”

She stands looking out at the same stars without a word. They are beginning to pale, and she looks as if their coldness froze her.
她站着，望着同样的星星，一言不发。他们的脸色开始变得苍白，她看上去仿佛被他们的寒冷冻住了。

‘My experience teaches me,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, who has by this time got his hands in his pockets and is going on in his business consideration of the matter like a machine. ‘My experience teaches me, Lady Dedlock, that most of the people I know would do far better to leave marriage alone. It is at the bottom of three fourths of their troubles. So I thought when Sir Leicester married, and so I always have thought since. No more about that. I must now be guided by circumstances. In the meanwhile I must beg you to keep your own counsel, and I will keep mine.’
“我的经验告诉我，”图尔金霍恩先生说，此时他已经把手插在口袋里，像一台机器一样继续对此事进行商业考虑。 “戴德洛克夫人，我的经验告诉我，我认识的大多数人最好还是不要结婚。这是他们四分之三的麻烦的根源。当莱斯特爵士结婚时我就是这么想的，从那以后我一直这么想。不再谈论这个了。我现在必须以环境为指导。与此同时，我必须请求你保留自己的建议，我也会保留我的建议。

‘I am to drag my present life on, holding its pains at your pleasure, day by day?’ she asks, still looking at the distant sky.
“我要继续我现在的生活，日复一日地忍受痛苦吗？”她问道，仍然望着远方的天空。

‘Yes, I am afraid so, Lady Dedlock.’
“是的，恐怕是这样，戴德洛克夫人。”

‘It is necessary, you think, that I should be so tied to the stake?’
“你认为我有必要被绑在木桩上吗？”

‘I am sure that what I recommend is necessary.’
“我确信我的建议是必要的。”

‘I am to remain on this gaudy platforna on which my miserable deception has been so long acted, and it is to fall beneath me when you give the signal?’ she said slowly.
“我要留在这个华而不实的平台上，我的悲惨欺骗已经在这个平台上进行了这么长时间，当你发出信号时，它就会落在我的下面吗？”她慢慢地说。

‘Not without notice, Lady Dedlock. I shall take no step without forewarning you.’
“并非没有通知，戴德洛克夫人。没有事先警告你，我不会采取任何行动。

She asks all her questions as if she were repeating them from memory or calling them over in her sleep.
她问所有的问题就好像她凭记忆重复这些问题或在睡梦中呼唤它们一样。

‘We are to meet as usual?’
“我们要像往常一样见面吗？”

‘Precisely as usual, if you please.’
“如果你愿意的话，就和平常一样。”

‘And I am to hide my guilt, as I have done so many years?’
“我要隐藏我的罪孽，就像我多年来所做的那样？”

‘As you have done so many years. I should not have made that reference myself, Lady Dedlock, but I may now remind you that your secret can be no heavier to you than it was, and is no worse and no better than it was. I know it certainly, but I believe we have never wholly trusted each other.’
‘正如你多年来所做的那样。我自己不应该提到这一点，戴德洛克夫人，但我现在可以提醒你，你的秘密对你来说不会比以前更重，也不会比以前更糟，也不会更好。我当然知道，但我相信我们从未完全信任彼此。

She stands absorbed in the same frozen way for some little time before asking, ‘Is there anything more to be sald to-night?’
她以同样冰冷的方式全神贯注地站了一会儿，然后问道：“今晚还有什么可吃的吗？”

‘Why,’ Mr. Tulkinghorn returns methodically as he softly rubs his hands, ‘I should like to be assured of your acquiescence in my arrangements, Lady Dedlock.’
“为什么，”图尔金霍恩先生轻柔地搓着双手，有条不紊地回答道，“戴德洛克夫人，我想向您保证，您会默许我的安排。”

‘You may be assured of it.’
“你可以放心。”

‘Good. And I would wish in conclusion to remind you, as a business precaution, in case it should be necessary to recall the fact in any communication with Sir Leicester, that throughout our interview I have expressly stated my sole consideration to be Sir Leicester’s feelings and honour and the family reputation. I should have been happy to have made Lady Dedlock a prominent consideration, too, if the case had admitted of it; but unfortunately it does not.’
'好的。最后，我想提醒您，作为商业预防措施，以防有必要在与莱斯特爵士的任何沟通中回忆起这一事实，在我们的采访中，我已明确表示我唯一考虑的是莱斯特爵士的感情和荣誉以及家族的声誉。如果案件承认了这一点，我也会很高兴把戴德洛克夫人作为一个重要的考虑因素。但不幸的是事实并非如此。

‘I can attest your fidelity, sir.’
“我可以证明你的忠诚，先生。”

Both before and after saving it she remains absorbed, but at length moves, and turns, unshaken in her natural and acquired presence, towards the door. Mr. Tulkinghorn opens both the doors exactly as he would have done yesterday, or as he would have done ten years ago, and makes his old-fashioned bow as she passes out. It is not an ordinary look that he receives from the handsome face as it goes into the darkness, and it is not an ordinary movement, though a very slight one, that acknowledges his courtesy. But as he reflects when he is left alone, the woman has been putting no common constraint upon herself.
在保存它之前和之后，她仍然全神贯注，但最终移动并转身，在她自然和后天的存在中没有动摇，走向门口。图金霍恩先生打开了两扇门，就像他昨天或十年前会做的那样，并在她昏倒时以老式的方式鞠了一躬。当那张英俊的脸消失在黑暗中时，他所看到的不是一个普通的眼神，也不是一个普通的动作，虽然是一个非常轻微的动作，但它表明了他的礼貌。但当他独自一人时，他反思道，这个女人并没有对自己施加任何常见的约束。

He would know it all the better if he saw the woman pacing her own rooms with her hair wildly thrown from her flung-back face, her hands clasped behind her head, her figure twisted as if by pain. He would think so all the more if he saw the woman thus hurrying up and down for hours, without fatigue, without intermission, followed by the faithful step upon the Ghost’s Walk. But he shuts out the now chilled air, draws the window-curtain, goes to bed, and falls asleep. And truly when the stars go out and the wan day peeps into the turret-chamber, finding him at his oldest, he looks as if the digger and the spade were both commissioned and would soon be digging.
如果他看到那个女人在自己的房间里踱来踱去，头发从后仰的脸上乱糟糟地散开，双手抱在脑后，身体仿佛因疼痛而扭曲，他会更清楚这一点。如果他看到这个女人就这样匆忙地走来走去几个小时，没有疲劳，没有间断，然后忠实地踏上鬼道，他会更这么想。但他把寒冷的空气拒之门外，拉上窗帘，上床睡觉。确实，当星星熄灭，苍白的白天窥视炮塔室，发现他年纪最大时，他看起来好像挖掘机和铁锹都已投入使用，很快就会开始挖掘。

The same wan day peeps in at Sir Leicester pardoning the repentant country in a majestically condescending dream; and at the cousins entering on various public employments, principally receipt of salary; and at the chaste Volumnia, bestowing a dower of fifty thousand pounds upon a hideous old general with a mouth of false teeth like a pianoforte too full of keys, long the admiration of Bath and the terror of every other commuuity. Also into rooms high in the roof, and into offices in court-yards, and over stables, where humbler ambition dreams of bliss, in keepers’ lodges, and in holy matrimony with Will or Sally. Up comes the bright sun, drawing everything up with it—the Wills and Sallys, the latent vapour in the earth, the drooping leaves and flowers, the birds and beasts and creeping things, the gardeners to sweep the dewy turf and unfold emerald velvet where the roller passes, the smoke of the great kitchen fire wreathing itself straight and high into the lightsome air. Lastly, up comes the flag over Mr. Tulkinghorn’s unconscious head cheerfully proclaiming that Sir Leicester and Lady Dedlock are in their happy home and that there is hospitality at the place in Lincolnshire.
同一天，莱斯特爵士在一个庄严的居高临下的梦中赦免了这个悔改的国家。以及表兄弟姐妹从事各种公共工作，主要是领取工资；在贞洁的沃伦尼亚，向一位面目狰狞的老将军赠送了五万英镑的嫁妆，他的嘴里装满了假牙，就像一架装满琴键的钢琴，长期以来引起巴斯的钦佩和其他社区的恐惧。还可以进入屋顶高处的房间，进入庭院的办公室，进入马厩，在那里，卑微的野心梦想着幸福，在看守人的小屋，以及与威尔或莎莉的神圣婚姻。明媚的太阳升起，把一切都卷了起来——意志和莎莉，大地潜藏的水汽，下垂的树叶和花朵，鸟兽和爬行动物，园丁们清扫露水的草皮，展开翠绿的天鹅绒，滚轮经过，厨房大火的烟雾直直地盘旋在轻盈的空气中。最后，图金霍恩先生昏迷不醒的头上升起了旗帜，高兴地宣布莱斯特爵士和戴德洛克夫人在他们幸福的家中，林肯郡的这个地方热情好客。

CHAPTER XLII
第四十二章


In Mr. Tulkinghorn’s Chambers
在图金霍恩先生的房间里

From the verdant undulations and the spreading oaks of the Dedlock property, Mr. Tulkinghorn transfers himself to the stale heat and dust of London. His manner of coming and going between the two places is one of his impenetrabilities. He walks into Chesney Wold as if it were next door to his chambers and returns to his chambers as if he had never been out of Lincoln’s Inn Fields. He neither changes his dress before the journey nor talks of it afterwards. He melted out of his turret-room this morning, just as now, in the late twilight, he melts into his own square.
从戴德洛克庄园翠绿的起伏和蔓延的橡树，图金霍恩先生将自己转移到了伦敦的闷热和尘土中。他在两地之间来来往往的方式是他难以捉摸的地方之一。他走进切斯尼沃尔德，就好像它就在他的房间隔壁一样，然后回到他的房间，就好像他从未离开过林肯的客栈场一样。他在旅途前既不换衣服，也不在旅途后谈论这件事。今天早上，他从自己的炮塔房间里消失了，就像现在，在暮色中，他融入了自己的广场一样。

Like a dingy London bird among the birds at roost in these pleasant fields, where the sheep are all made into parchment, the goats into wigs, and the pasture into chaff, the lawyer, smoke-dried and faded, dwelling among mankind but not consorting with them, aged without experience of genial youth, and so long used to make his cramped nest in holes and corners of human nature that he has forgotten its broader and better range, comes sauntering home. In the oven made by the hot pavements and hot buildings, he has baked himself dryer than usual; and he has in his thirsty mind his mellowed port-wine half a century old.
就像一只肮脏的伦敦鸟栖息在这些宜人的田野里，那里的绵羊都被做成了羊皮纸，山羊被做成了假发，牧场变成了糠秕，律师，被烟熏干了，褪色了，住在人类中间，但不与人交往与他们一起，年老的人没有经历过和蔼的青年时代，长期习惯于在人性的洞穴和角落里筑巢，以至于忘记了人性的更广阔和更好的范围，漫步回家。在炎热的人行道和炎热的建筑物组成的烤箱里，他把自己烤得比平常更干燥；他口渴的脑海里还藏着半个世纪的醇厚波特酒。

The lamplighter is skipping up and down his ladder on Mr. Tulkinghorn’s side of the Fields when that high-priest of noble mysteries arrives at his own dull court-yard. He ascends the doorsteps and is gliding into the dusky hall when he encounters, on the top step, a bowing and propitiatory little man.
当这位高贵神秘的大祭司来到他自己沉闷的庭院时，点灯人正在田野里图金霍恩先生这边的梯子上跳来跳去。他走上门阶，滑进昏暗的大厅，这时他在最上面的台阶上遇到了一个鞠躬、表示和解的小个子男人。

‘Is that Snagsby?’
“那是斯纳斯比吗？”

‘Yes, sir. I hope you are well, sir. I was just giving you up, sir, and going home.’
'是的先生。我希望你一切都好，先生。我只是想放弃你，先生，然后回家。”

‘Aye? What is it? What do you want with me?’
‘是吗？它是什么？你想和我做什么？'

‘Well, sir,’ says Mr. Snagsby, holding his hat at the side of his head in his deference towards his best customer, ‘I was wishful to say a word to you, sir.’
“好吧，先生，”斯纳斯比先生将帽子举在头侧，以示对他最好的顾客的尊重，“我很想对您说句话，先生。”

‘Can you say it here?’
“你能在这里说吗？”

‘Perfectly, sir.’
“完美，先生。”

‘Say it then.’ The lawyer turns, leans his arms on the iron railing at the top of the steps, and looks at the lamplighter lighting the court-yard.
“那就说吧。”律师转过身来，双臂靠在台阶顶端的铁栏杆上，看着照亮庭院的点灯者。

‘It is relating,’ says Mr. Snagsby in a mysterious low voice, ‘it is relating—not to put too fine a point upon it—to the foreigner, sir!’
“这是有关联的，”斯纳斯比先生用一种神秘的低沉声音说道，“这是有关联的——不要说得太过分——与外国人有关，先生！”

Mr. Tulkinghorn eyes him with some surprise. ‘What foreigner?’
图金霍恩先生有些惊讶地看着他。 “什么外国人？”

‘The foreign female, sir. French, if I don’t mistake? I am not acquainted with that language myself, but I should judge from her manners and appearance that she was French; anyways, certainly foreign. Her that was upstairs, sir, when Mr. Bucket and me had the honour of waiting upon you with the sweeping-boy that night.’
“这位外国女性，先生。法语，如果我没记错的话？我自己并不熟悉那种语言，但从她的举止和外表来看，我应该判断她是法国人。无论如何，肯定是外国的。先生，那天晚上我和巴克特先生有幸和扫地工一起侍候您时，她就在楼上。”

‘Oh! Yes, yes. Mademoiselle Hortense.’
'哦！是的是的。霍滕斯小姐。”

‘Indeed, sir?’ Mr. Snagsby coughs his cough of submission behind his hat. ‘I am not acquainted myself with the names of foreigners in general, but I have no doubt it WOULD be that.’ Mr. Snagsby appears to have set out in this reply with some desperate design of repeating the name, but on reflection coughs again to excuse himself.
“真的吗，先生？”斯纳斯比先生在帽子后面咳嗽了一声，表示屈服。 “一般来说，我自己并不熟悉外国人的名字，但我毫不怀疑，一定会是这样的。”斯纳格斯比先生在这次答复中似乎是在绝望地重复这个名字，但转念一想，他又咳嗽了。为自己辩解。

‘And what can you have to say, Snagsby,’ demands Mr. Tulkinghorn, ‘about her?’
“斯纳斯比，”图尔金霍恩先生问道，“关于她，你有什么要说的吗？”

‘Well, sir,’ returns the stationer, shading his communication with his hat, ‘it falls a little hard upon me. My domestic happiness is very great—at least, it’s as great as can be expected, I’m sure— but my little woman is rather given to jealousy. Not to put too fine a point upon it, she is very much given to jealousy. And you see, a foreign female of that genteel appearance coming into the shop, and hovering—I should be the last to make use of a strong expression if I could avoid it, but hovering, sir—in the court— you know it is—now ain’t it? I only put it to yourself, sir.
“好吧，先生，”文具店员回答道，用帽子遮住了他的通讯，“这对我来说有点困难。”我的家庭幸福感非常好——至少，我确信这是可以期待的——但我的小女人却很容易嫉妒。不用说得太过分，她很容易嫉妒。你看，一位外表优雅的外国女性走进店里，徘徊——如果我能避免的话，我应该是最后一个使用强烈表达方式的人，但是徘徊，先生——在法庭上——你知道这是——现在不是吗？我只是对你自己说的，先生。

Mr. Snagsby, having said this in a very plaintive manner, throws in a cough of general application to fill up all the blanks.
斯纳格斯比先生以一种非常哀伤的方式说了这句话，然后用通用的咳嗽声来填补所有的空白。

‘Why, what do you mean?’ asks Mr. Tulkinghorn.
“为什么，你是什么意思？”图金霍恩先生问道。

‘Just so, sir,’ returns Mr. Snagsby; ‘I was sure you would feel it yourself and would excuse the reasonableness of MY feelings when coupled with the known excitableness of my little woman. You see, the foreign female—which you mentioned her name just now, with quite a native sound I am sure—caught up the word Snagsby that night, being uncommon quick, and made inquiry, and got the direction and come at dinner-time. Now Guster, our young woman, is timid and has fits, and she, taking fright at the foreigner’s looks—which are fierce—and at a grinding manner that she has of speaking—which is calculated to alarm a weak mind—gave way to it, instead of bearing up against it, and tumbled down the kitchen stairs out of one into another, such fits as I do sometimes think are never gone into, or come out of, in any house but ours. Consequently there was by good fortune ample occupation for my little woman, and only me to answer the shop. When she DID say that Mr. Tulkinghorn, being always denied to her by his employer (which I had no doubt at the time was a foreign mode of viewing a clerk), she would do herself the pleasure of continually calling at my place until she was let in here. Since then she has been, as I began by saying, hovering, hovering, sir’—Mr. Snagsby repeats the word with pathetic emphasis—‘in the court. The effects of which movement it is impossible to calculate. I shouldn’t wonder if it might have already given rise to the painfullest mistakes even in the neighbours’ minds, not mentioning (if such a thing was possible) my little woman. Whereas, goodness knows,’ says Mr. Snagsby, shaking his head, ‘I never had an idea of a foreign female, except as being formerly connected with a bunch of brooms and a baby, or at the present time with a tambourine and earrings. I never had, I do assure you, sir!’
“正是如此，先生，”斯纳斯比先生回答道。 “我确信你会亲自感受到这一点，并且会原谅我的感受的合理性，再加上我的小女人众所周知的兴奋。你看，那个外国女人——你刚才提到了她的名字，我确信她的声音相当地道——那天晚上，她不寻常地很快地听到了斯纳格斯比这个词，并询问了情况，并得到了方向，并在晚餐时间来了。 。现在，我们的年轻女子古斯特很胆怯，脾气暴躁，她被外国人的表情吓坏了——那是凶猛的——还有她说话时的粗暴态度——这是故意让脆弱的心惊慌——让位于它没有顶住它，而是从厨房的楼梯上滚下来，从一个楼梯滚到另一个楼梯上，我有时认为，除了我们的房子之外，在任何房子里都不会出现或出来这种情况。因此，幸运的是，我的小女人有足够的工作，只有我来负责商店。当她确实提到图金霍恩先生时，他的雇主总是拒绝与她见面（当时我毫不怀疑这是一种看待职员的外国方式），她会很高兴地不断地到我家打电话，直到她同意为止。被允许进入这里。从那时起，正如我一开始所说的，她一直在徘徊，徘徊，先生。”——先生。斯纳斯比可怜兮兮地强调了这个词——“在法庭上”。哪种运动的影响无法计算。我不应该怀疑它是否已经引起了最痛苦的错误，甚至在邻居的心中也是如此，更不用说（如果可能的话）我的小女人。然而，天知道，”斯纳斯比先生摇着头说，“我从来没有想过外国女性，除了以前与一堆扫帚和一个婴儿有关，或者现在与手鼓和耳环有关之外。 。 我向你保证，我从未有过，先生！’

Mr. Tulkinghorn had listened gravely to this complaint and inquires when the stationer has finished, ‘And that’s all, is it, Snagsby?’
图金霍恩先生严肃地听着这个抱怨，当文具店员写完后问道：“就这样吧，斯纳斯比？”

‘Why yes, sir, that’s all,’ says Mr. Snagsby, ending with a cough that plainly adds, ‘and it’s enough too—for me.’
“是的，先生，就这些了，”斯纳斯比先生咳嗽了一声，补充道，“对我来说，这也足够了。”

‘I don’t know what Mademoiselle Hortense may want or mean, unless she is mad,’ says the lawyer.
“我不知道霍滕斯小姐想要什么或意味着什么，除非她生气了，”律师说。

‘Even if she was, you know, sir,’ Mr. Snagsby pleads, ‘it wouldn’t be a consolation to have some weapon or another in the form of a foreign dagger planted in the family.’
“先生，你知道，即使她是，”斯纳斯比先生恳求道，“家里安放一把外国匕首这样的武器也不会让人感到安慰。”

‘No,’ says the other. ‘Well, well! This shall be stopped. I am sorry you have been inconvenienced. If she comes again, send her here.’
“不，”另一个说。 '好吧！这种行为应当停止。很抱歉给您带来不便。如果她再来的话，就送她来这里。”

Mr. Snagsby, with much bowing and short apologetic coughing, takes his leave, lightened in heart. Mr. Tulkinghorn goes upstairs, saying to himself, ‘These women were created to give trouble the whole earth over. The mistress not being enough to deal with, here’s the maid now! But I will be short with THIS jade at least!’
斯纳斯比先生深深地鞠了一躬，抱歉地咳嗽了一声，然后心情轻松地离开了。图金霍恩先生上楼，自言自语道：“这些女人生来就是为了给整个地球带来麻烦的。”女主人还不够对付，现在是女仆！但至少我会缺这块玉！”

So saying, he unlocks his door, gropes his way into his murky rooms, lights his candles, and looks about him. It is too dark to see much of the Allegory over-head there, but that importunate Roman, who is for ever toppling out of the clouds and pointing, is at his old work pretty distinctly. Not honouring him with much attention, Mr. Tulkinghorn takes a small key from his pocket, unlocks a drawer in which there is another key, which unlocks a chest in which there is another, and so comes to the cellar-key, with which he prepares to descend to the regions of old wine. He is going towards the door with a candle in his hand when a knock comes.
说着，他打开门锁，摸索着走进昏暗的房间，点燃蜡烛，环顾四周。天色太暗，头顶上看不清寓言的大部分内容，但那个纠缠不休的罗马人，总是从云层中跳出来指指点点，非常清楚地在看他的旧作。图金霍恩先生并没有给予太多的关注，他从口袋里拿出一把小钥匙，打开了一个抽屉，里面有另一把钥匙，又打开了一个箱子，里面有另一把钥匙，然后来到了地窖钥匙，他用这把钥匙准备下到老酒产区。当他手里拿着蜡烛朝门口走去时，有人敲门。

‘Who’s this? Aye, aye, mistress, it’s you, is it? You appear at a good time. I have just been hearing of you. Now! What do you want?’
'这是谁？是啊是啊，小姐，是你吧？你出现得正是时候。我刚刚听说过你。现在！你想要什么？'

He stands the candle on the chimney-piece in the clerk’s hall and taps his dry cheek with the key as he addresses these words of welcome to Mademoiselle Hortense. That feline personage, with her lips tightly shut and her eyes looking out at him sideways, softly closes the door before replying.
他把蜡烛放在职员大厅的烟囱上，一边用钥匙敲打干燥的脸颊，一边对霍滕斯小姐说欢迎的话。那猫一般的人物，双唇紧闭，目光斜视着他，轻轻关上门，然后回答道。

‘I have had great deal of trouble to find you, sir.’
“我费了很大的劲才找到您，先生。”

‘HAVE you!’
'你！'

‘I have been here very often, sir. It has always been said to me, he is not at home, he is engage, he is this and that, he is not for you.’
“我经常来这里，先生。人们总是对我说，他不在家，他订婚了，他这样那样，他不适合你。

‘Quite right, and quite true.’
“非常正确，而且非常正确。”

‘Not true. Lies!’
'不对。谎言！

At times there is a suddenness in the manner of Mademoiselle Hortense so like a bodily spring upon the subject of it that such subject involuntarily starts and fails back. It is Mr. Tulkinghorn’s case at present, though Mademoiselle Hortense, with her eyes almost shut up (but still looking out sideways), is only smiling contemptuously and shaking her head.
有时，霍滕斯小姐的态度会突然出现，就像身体突然跳到这个主题上一样，使这个主题不由自主地开始并失败。目前图金霍恩先生的情况就是如此，不过霍顿斯小姐几乎闭上了眼睛（但仍然斜视着外面），只是轻蔑地微笑着摇摇头。

‘Now, mistress,’ says the lawyer, tapping the key hastily upon the chimney-piece. ‘If you have anything to say, say it, say it.’
“现在，女主人，”律师一边说，一边急忙用钥匙敲击烟囱。 “如果你有什么话要说，就说吧。”

‘Sir, you have not use me well. You have been mean and shabby.’
‘先生，你没有好好利用我。你既卑鄙又卑鄙。

‘Mean and shabby, eh?’ returns the lawyer, rubbing his nose with the key.
“卑鄙又破旧，嗯？”律师回答道，用钥匙擦着鼻子。

‘Yes. What is it that I tell you? You know you have. You have attrapped me—catched me—to give you information; you have asked me to show you the dress of mine my Lady must have wore that night, you have prayed me to come in it here to meet that boy. Say! Is it not?’ Mademoiselle Hortense makes another spring.
'是的。我告诉你什么？你知道你有。你吸引了我——抓住了我——来给你提供信息；你让我给你看我的女士那天晚上一定穿的衣服，你祈求我穿着它来这里见那个男孩。说！不是吗？”霍滕斯小姐又迎来了春天。

‘You are a vixen, a vixen!’ Mr. Tulkinghorn seems to meditate as he looks distrustfully at her, then he replies, ‘Well, wench, well. I paid you.’
“你是个泼妇，泼妇！”图金霍恩先生怀疑地看着她，似乎在沉思，然后回答道：“好吧，丫头，好吧。”我付钱给你了。

‘You paid me!’ she repeats with fierce disdain. ‘Two sovereign! I have not change them, I re-fuse them, I des-pise them, I throw them from me!’ Which she literally does, taking them out of her bosom as she speaks and flinging them with such violence on the floor that they jerk up again into the light before they roll away into corners and slowly settle down there after spinning vehemently.
“你付钱给我！”她带着强烈的蔑视重复道。 ‘两位君主！我没有改变它们，我拒绝它们，我鄙视它们，我把它们从我身边扔掉！”她确实这么做了，一边说话一边把它们从怀里拿出来，用如此暴力的方式把它们扔到地板上，以至于它们都被扔到了地上。在它们滚到角落之前，它们会再次猛地升到光线中，并在剧烈旋转后慢慢地在那里安顿下来。

‘Now!’ says Mademoiselle Hortense, darkening her large eyes again. ‘You have paid me? Eh, my God, oh yes!’
“现在！”霍滕斯小姐说道，她的大眼睛又变黑了。 ‘你付钱给我了？呃，天啊，哦，是的！

Mr. Tulkinghorn rubs his head with the key while she entertains herself with a sarcastic laugh.
图金霍恩先生用钥匙擦着头，而她则自嘲地笑了起来。

‘You must be rich, my fair friend,’ he composedly observes, ‘to throw money about in that way!’
“我亲爱的朋友，你一定很富有，”他平静地说道，“才会这样乱花钱！”

‘I AM rich,’ she returns. ‘I am very rich in hate. I hate my Lady, of all my heart. You know that.’
“我很有钱，”她回答道。 ‘我充满仇恨。我从心底里恨我的夫人。你懂的。'

‘Know it? How should I know it?’
'知道？我怎么知道呢？

‘Because you have known it perfectly before you prayed me to give you that information. Because you have known perfectly that I was en-r-r-r-raged!’ It appears impossible for mademoiselle to roll the letter ‘r’ sufficiently in this word, notwithstanding that she assists her energetic delivery by clenching both her hands and setting all her teeth.
‘因为在你请求我向你提供这些信息之前，你已经完全了解了这一点。因为你完全知道我当时非常愤怒！”小姐似乎不可能在这个单词中充分滚动字母“r”，尽管她通过紧握双手和咬紧牙关来帮助她充满活力的表达。

‘Oh! I knew that, did I?’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, examining the wards of the key.
'哦！ “我知道这一点，不是吗？”图金霍恩先生一边说，一边检查钥匙的防护区。

‘Yes, without doubt. I am not blind. You have made sure of me because you knew that. You had reason! I det-est her.’ Mademoiselle folds her arms and throws this last remark at him over one of her shoulders.
‘是的，毫无疑问。我不是瞎子。你对我很确定，因为你知道这一点。你有道理！ “我讨厌她。”小姐抱起双臂，越过肩膀对他说了这最后一句话。

‘Having said this, have you anything else to say, mademoiselle?’
“说了这么多，小姐还有什么要说的吗？”

‘I am not yet placed. Place me well. Find me a good condition! If you cannot, or do not choose to do that, employ me to pursue her, to chase her, to disgrace and to dishonour her. I will help you well, and with a good will. It is what YOU do. Do I not know that?’
‘我还没有被安置。把我安置好。给我找个好条件！如果你不能，或者不选择这样做，就雇用我去追求她，追赶她，羞辱她，羞辱她。我会很好地帮助你，而且是善意的。这就是你所做的。难道我不知道吗？

‘You appear to know a good deal,’ Mr. Tulkinghorn retorts.
“你似乎知道很多，”图金霍恩先生反驳道。

‘Do I not? Is it that I am so weak as to believe, like a child, that I come here in that dress to rec-cive that boy only to decide a little bet, a wager? Eh, my God, oh yes!’ In this reply, down to the word ‘wager’ inclusive, mademoiselle has been ironically polite and tender, then as suddenly dashed into the bitterest and most defiant scorn, with her black eyes in one and the same moment very nearly shut and staringly wide open.
‘我不是吗？是不是我太软弱了，像个孩子一样相信我穿着那件衣服来到这里是为了接待那个男孩，只是为了决定一个小小的赌注，一个赌注？呃，我的上帝，哦，是的！”在这个回答中，一直到“赌注”这个词都包含在内，小姐一直表现出讽刺的礼貌和温柔，然后突然陷入了最痛苦和最挑衅的蔑视中，她的黑眼睛眯成一条缝，同一时刻几乎关闭又完全敞开。

‘Now, let us see,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, tapping his chin with the key and looking imperturbably at her, ‘how this matter stands.’
“现在，让我们看看，”图尔金霍恩先生用钥匙敲着下巴，平静地看着她，“这件事到底是怎么回事。”

‘Ah! Let us see,’ mademoiselle assents, with many angry and tight nods of her head.
'啊！让我们看看，”小姐表示同意，同时愤怒地多次点头。

‘You come here to make a remarkably modest demand, which you have just stated, and it not being conceded, you will come again.’
“你来这里是为了提出一个非常温和的要求，正如你刚才所说的，如果不被承认，你就会再来。”

‘And again,’ says mademoiselle with more tight and angry nods. ‘And yet again. And yet again. And many times again. In effect, for ever!’
“再来一次，”小姐说道，并更加紧张和愤怒地点头。 ‘还有一次。还有一次。又重复了很多次。实际上，永远！”

‘And not only here, but you will go to Mr, Snagsby’s too, perhaps? That visit not succeeding either, you will go again perhaps?’
“不仅是这里，也许你也会去斯纳斯比先生家？”那次访问也不成功，你也许会再去一次？

‘And again,’ repeats mademoiselle, cataleptic with determination. ‘And yet again. And yet again. And many times again. In effect, for ever!’
“再来一次，”小姐重复道，眼神坚定而坚定。 ‘还有一次。还有一次。又重复了很多次。实际上，永远！”

‘Very well. Now, Mademoiselle Hortense, let me recommend you to take the candle and pick up that money of yours. I think you will find it behind the clerk’s partition in the corner yonder.’
'很好。现在，霍滕斯小姐，让我建议你拿起蜡烛，拿起你的钱。我想你会在那边角落里店员的隔板后面找到它。

She merely throws a laugh over her shoulder and stands her ground with folded arms.
她只是笑了笑，双手抱胸坚守阵地。

‘You will not, eh?’
“你不会，嗯？”

‘No, I will not!’
'不我不会！'

‘So much the poorer you; so much the richer I! Look, mistress, this is the key of my wine-cellar. It is a large key, but the keys of prisons are larger. In this city there are houses of correction (where the treadmills are, for women), the gates of which are very strong and heavy, and no doubt the keys too. I am afraid a lady of your spirit and activity would find it an inconvenience to have one of those keys turned upon her for any length of time. What do you think?’
‘你就更穷了；我就更富有了！夫人，你看，这是我酒窖的钥匙。这是一把大钥匙，但监狱的钥匙更大。在这个城市里有一些惩戒所（那里有女性的跑步机），它们的大门非常坚固和沉重，毫无疑问也有钥匙。我担心像你这样精神和活跃的女士会发现其中一把钥匙长时间打开会给她带来不便。你怎么认为？'

‘I think,’ mademoiselle replies without any action and in a clear, obliging voice, ‘that you are a miserable wretch.’
“我认为，”小姐没有任何动作，用一种清晰、亲切的声音回答道，“你是一个可怜的可怜虫。”

‘Probably,’ returns Mr. Tulkinghorn, quietly blowing his nose. ‘But I don’t ask what you think of myself; I ask what you think of the prison.’
“可能吧，”图尔金霍恩先生回答道，轻轻地擤了擤鼻子。 “但我不会问你对我自己的看法；我会问你对我自己的看法。”我问你对监狱的看法。

‘Nothing. What does it matter to me?’
'没有什么。这对我有什么关系？

‘Why, it matters this much, mistress,’ says the lawyer, deliberately putting away his handkerchief and adjusting his frill; ‘the law is so despotic here that it interferes to prevent any of our good English citizens from being troubled, even by a lady’s visits against his desire. And on his complaining that he is so troubled, it takes hold of the troublesome lady and shuts her up in prison under hard discipline. Turns the key upon her, mistress.’ Illustrating with the cellar-key.
“哎呀，这事这么重要，情妇，”律师一边说，一边故意收起手帕，调整了一下褶边。 “这里的法律是如此专制，以至于它阻止我们任何一个善良的英国公民受到困扰，即使是一位女士违反他的意愿来访。当他抱怨自己太麻烦时，它抓住了这位麻烦的女士，把她关进监狱，接受严厉的管教。把钥匙转向她，女主人。’用地窖钥匙来说明。

‘Truly?’ returns mademoiselle in the same pleasant voice. ‘That is droll! But—my faith! —still what does it matter to me?’
“真的吗？”小姐用同样愉快的声音回答。 ‘真是滑稽！但是——我的信仰！ ——这对我来说还有什么关系呢？

‘My fair friend,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, ‘make another visit here, or at Mr. Snagsby’s, and you shall learn.’
“我的好朋友，”塔尔金霍恩先生说，“再来这里一次，或者去斯纳斯比先生家，你就会学到东西的。”

‘In that case you will send me to the prison, perhaps?’
“既然如此，你也许会把我送进监狱吧？”

‘Perhaps.’
'也许。'

It would be contradictory for one in mademoiselle’s state of agreeable jocularity to foam at the mouth, otherwise a tigerish expansion thereabouts might look as if a very little more would make her do it.
对于一个在小姐愉快的诙谐状态下口吐白沫的人来说，这是自相矛盾的，否则，周围的老虎般的扩张可能看起来好像多一点点就会让她这么做。

‘In a word, mistress,’ says Mr. Tulkinghorn, ‘I am sorry to be unpolite, but if you ever present yourself uninvited here—or there—again, I will give you over to the police. Their gallantry is great, but they carry troublesome people through the streets in an ignominious manner, strapped down on a board, my good wench.’
“总而言之，女主人，”图尔金霍恩先生说，“我很抱歉不礼貌，但如果你再次不请自来地出现在这里或那里，我会把你交给警察。”他们的英勇是伟大的，但他们以一种可耻的方式带着麻烦的人穿过街道，把他们绑在木板上，我的好姑娘。

‘I will prove you,’ whispers mademoiselle, stretching out her hand, ‘I will try if you dare to do it!’
“我会证明给你看，”小姐伸出手低声说道，“如果你敢的话，我就试试！”

‘And if,’ pursues the lawyer without minding her, ‘I place you in that good condition of being locked up in jail, it will be some time before you find yourself at liberty again.’
“如果，”律师不理睬她，继续说道，“我会让你处于被关进监狱的良好状态，那么你需要一段时间才能再次获得自由。”

‘I will prove you,’ repeats mademoiselle in her former whisper.
“我会证明给你看，”小姐用以前的低声重复道。

‘And now,’ proceeds the lawyer, still without minding her, ‘you had better go. Think twice before you come here again.’
“现在，”律师继续说道，仍然没有理会她，“你最好走吧。”在你再次来到这里之前请三思。

‘Think you,’ she answers, ‘twice two hundred times!’
“想想你，”她回答，“两次两百次！”

‘You were dismissed by your lady, you know,’ Mr. Tulkinghorn observes, following her out upon the staircase, ‘as the most implacable and unmanageable of women. Now turn over a new leaf and take warning by what I say to you. For what I say, I mean; and what I threaten, I will do, mistress.’
“你知道，你被你的女士抛弃了，”图尔金霍恩先生一边说，一边跟着她走上楼梯，“认为你是最难以平息、最难以驾驭的女人。”现在翻开新的一页，并接受我对你所说的话的警告。我所说的，我的意思是；我威胁什么，我就会做什么，夫人。”

She goes down without answering or looking behind her. When she is gone, he goes down too, and returning with his cobweb-covered bottle, devotes himself to a leisurely enjoyment of its contents, now and then, as he throws his head back in his chair, catching sight of the pertinacious Roman pointing from the ceiling.
她没有回答，也没有回头看，就下去了。当她走后，他也下去了，带着他那只布满蜘蛛网的瓶子回来了，全神贯注于悠闲地享受里面的东西，时不时地，他把头靠在椅子上，瞥见罗马人顽固的指点。从天花板上。

CHAPTER XLIII
第四十三章


Esther’s Narrative
以斯帖的叙述

It matters little now how much I thought of my living mother who had told me evermore to consider her dead. I could not venture to approach her or to communicate with her in writing, for my sense of the peril in which her life was passed was only to be equalled by my fears of increasing it. Knowing that my mere existence as a living creature was an unforeseen danger in her way, I could not always conquer that terror of myself which had seized me when I first knew the secret. At no time did I dare to utter her name. I felt as if I did not even dare to hear it. If the conversation anywhere, when I was present, took that direction, as it sometimes naturally did, I tried not to hear: I mentally counted, repeated something that I knew, or went out of the room. I am conscious now that I often did these things when there can have been no danger of her being spoken of, but I did them in the dread I had of hearing anything that might lead to her betrayal, and to her betrayal through me.
现在我有多想念我活着的母亲已经无关紧要了，她一直告诉我要考虑她已经死了。我无法冒险接近她或与她进行书面交流，因为我对她生命中所经历的危险的感觉与我对增加危险的恐惧相当。当我知道我作为一个生物的存在对她来说是一种不可预见的危险时，我总是无法克服当我第一次知道这个秘密时对我自己的恐惧。我始终不敢说出她的名字。我感觉自己连听都不敢听。如果任何地方的谈话，当我在场时，朝着那个方向发展，就像有时自然地那样，我尽量不去听：我在心里数着，重复我知道的事情，或者走出房间。我现在意识到，我经常在没有她被谈论的危险的情况下做这些事情，但我这样做是因为我害怕听到任何可能导致她背叛的事情，以及她通过我背叛的事情。

It matters little now how often I recalled the tones of my mother’s voice, wondered whether I should ever hear it again as I so longed to do, and thought how strange and desolate it was that it should be so new to me. It matters little that I watched for every public mention of my mother’s name; that I passed and repassed the door of her house in town, loving it, but afraid to look at it; that I once sat in the theatre when my mother was there and saw me, and when we were so wide asunder before the great company of all degrees that any link or confidence between us seemed a dream. It is all, all over. My lot has been so blest that I can relate little of myself which is not a story of goodness and generosity in others. I may well pass that little and go on.
现在，我多少次想起母亲的语气，想知道我是否还能像我渴望的那样再次听到它，并想它对我来说是如此陌生和荒凉，这已经无关紧要了。我关注每一次公开提及我母亲的名字并不重要；但我知道，这并不重要。我在镇上经过她家的门，又经过又经过，很喜欢它，但又不敢看它。有一次，我坐在剧院里，母亲也在场，看到了我，当时我们在各阶层的大朋友面前分歧如此之大，以至于我们之间的任何联系或信任都像是一场梦。一切都结束了。我的命运如此幸运，以至于我几乎无法讲述自己的故事，这不是一个关于他人善良和慷慨的故事。我很可能会略过这一点并继续下去。

When we were settled at home again, Ada and I had many conversations with my guardian of which Richard was the theme. My dear girl was deeply grieved that he should do their kind cousin so much wrong, but she was so faithful to Richard that she could not bear to blame him even for that. My guardian was assured of it, and never coupled his name with a word of reproof. ‘Rick is mistaken, my dear,’ he would say to her. ‘Well, well! We have all been mistaken over and over again. We must trust to you and time to set him right.’
当我们再次在家安顿下来时，艾达和我与我的监护人进行了多次对话，其中理查德是主题。我亲爱的女儿对他如此伤害了他们善良的表弟而深感悲痛，但她对理查德如此忠诚，以至于她甚至不忍心为此责备他。我的监护人对此深信不疑，并没有在他的名字上加上一句责备的话。 “瑞克错了，亲爱的，”他会对她说。 '好吧！我们都一次又一次地犯错。我们必须相信你和时间来纠正他的错误。

We knew afterwards what we suspected then, that he did not trust to time until he had often tried to open Richard’s eyes. That he had written to him, gone to him, talked with him, tried every gentle and persuasive art his kindness could devise. Our poor devoted Richard was deaf and blind to all. If he were wrong, he would make amends when the Chancery suit was over. If he were groping in the dark, he could not do better than do his utmost to clear away those clouds in which so much was confused and obscured. Suspicion and misunderstanding were the fault of the suit? Then let him work the suit out and come through it to his right mind. This was his unvarying reply. Jarndyce and Jarndyce had obtained such possession of his whole nature that it was impossible to place any consideration before him which he did not, with a distorted kind of reason, make a new argument in favour of his doing what he did. ‘So that it is even more mischievous,’ said my guardian once to me, ‘to remonstrate with the poor dear fellow than to leave him alone.’
后来我们才知道我们当时的怀疑，他不相信时间，直到他经常试图睁开理查德的眼睛。他曾写信给他，去找过他，与他交谈过，尝试过他仁慈能想到的每一种温柔而有说服力的技巧。我们可怜的虔诚的理查德对所有人都充耳不闻、视而不见。如果他错了，他会在大法官诉讼结束后做出弥补。如果他在黑暗中摸索，他最好的办法莫过于尽最大努力清除那些混乱和模糊的乌云。怀疑和误会都是诉讼惹的祸？然后让他把这套衣服设计出来，并通过它恢复正常的头脑。这是他不变的回答。贾迪斯和贾迪斯已经完全掌握了他的整个本性，以至于他不可能不以一种扭曲的理由提出新的论据来支持他所做的事情。 “因此，”我的监护人有一次对我说，“劝告这个可怜的亲爱的小伙子比让他独自一人更加恶作剧。”

I took one of these opportunities of mentioning my doubts of Mr. Skimpole as a good adviser for Richard.
我利用其中一个机会提到了我对斯基姆波尔先生作为理查德的好顾问的怀疑。

‘Adviser!’ returned my guardian, laughing, ‘My dear, who would advise with Skimpole?’
“顾问！”我的监护人笑着回答道，“亲爱的，谁会向斯基姆波尔提供建议呢？”

‘Encourager would perhaps have been a better word,’ said I.
“用‘鼓励’这个词或许更好。”我说。

‘Encourager!’ returned my guardian again. ‘Who could be encouraged by Skimpole?’
“鼓励者！”我的监护人再次回答道。 “斯金波尔可以鼓励谁？”

‘Not Richard?’ I asked.
“不是理查德吗？”我问。

‘No,’ he replied. ‘Such an unworldly, uncalculating, gossamer creature is a relief to him and an amusement. But as to advising or encouraging or occupying a serious station towards anybody or anything, it is simply not to be thought of in such a child as Skimpole.’
“不，”他回答道。 “这样一个超凡脱俗、不计较的、如丝般的生物对他来说是一种解脱，也是一种乐趣。但至于对任何人或任何事提供建议、鼓励或占据严肃的地位，对于像斯金波尔这样的孩子来说，根本就不可能被想到。

‘Pray, cousin John,’ said Ada, who had just joined us and now looked over my shoulder, ‘what made him such a child?’
“请问，约翰表弟，”刚加入我们的艾达说道，现在她回头看了看我的肩膀，“是什么让他变得如此孩子气？”

‘What made him such a child?’ inquired my guardian, rubbing his head, a little at a loss.
“是什么让他变成了这样一个孩子？”我的监护人摸着头问道，有点不知所措。

‘Yes, cousin John.’
“是的，约翰表弟。”

‘Why,’ he slowly replied, roughening his head more and more, ‘he is all sentiment, and—and susceptibility, and—and sensibility, and— and imagination. And these qualities are not regulated in him, somehow. I suppose the people who admired him for them in his youth attached too much importance to them and too little to any training that would have balanced and adjusted them, and so he became what he is. Hey?’ said my guardian, stopping short and looking at us hopefully. ‘What do you think, you two?’
“为什么，”他慢慢地回答，他的头越来越粗糙，“他充满了感性，而且——和易感性，和——和感性，和——和想象力。”不知何故，这些品质在他身上并没有受到调节。我想那些在他年轻时钦佩他的人过于重视这些，而太少关注任何平衡和调整它们的训练，所以他变成了现在的样子。嘿？”我的监护人突然停下来，充满希望地看着我们。 “你们两个觉得怎么样？”

Ada, glancing at me, said she thought it was a pity he should be an expense to Richard.
艾达看了我一眼，说她觉得他成了理查德的牺牲品，真是可惜。

‘So it is, so it is,’ returned my guardian hurriedly. ‘That must not be. We must arrange that. I must prevent it. That will never do.’
“原来如此，原来如此。”我的监护人急忙回答道。 ‘那一定不是这样的。我们必须安排一下。我必须阻止它。那是永远不行的。

And I said I thought it was to be regretted that he had ever introduced Richard to Mr. Vholes for a present of five pounds.
我说我认为他曾将理查德介绍给沃尔斯先生以换取五英镑的礼物，这令人遗憾。

‘Did he?’ said my guardian with a passing shade of vexation on his face. ‘But there you have the man. There you have the man! There is nothing mercenary in that with him. He has no idea of the value of money. He introduces Rick, and then he is good friends with Mr. Vholes and borrows five pounds of him. He means nothing by it and thinks nothing of it. He told you himself, I’ll be bound, my dear?’
“是吗？”我的监护人说道，脸上闪过一丝烦恼。 “但是你看到了这个人。”那就是你的男人！他身上没有任何唯利是图的成分。他不知道金钱的价值。他介绍了里克，然后与沃尔斯先生成了好朋友，并向他借了五英镑。他这样说毫无意义，也没有多想。他亲口告诉过你，我会被束缚的，亲爱的？

‘Oh, yes!’ said I.
“哦，是的！”我说。

‘Exactly!’ cried my guardian, quite triumphant. ‘There you have the man! If he had meant any harm by it or was conscious of any harm in it, he wouldn’t tell it. He tells it as he does it in mere simplicity. But you shall see him in his own home, and then you’ll understand him better. We must pay a visit to Harold Skimpole and caution him on these points. Lord bless you, my dears, an infant, an infant!’
“完全正确！”我的监护人得意洋洋地喊道。 ‘这就是那个男人！如果他有意这样做或意识到其中有任何危害，他就不会说出来。他说的和做的一样简单。但你会在他自己的家里见到他，然后你就会更好地了解他。我们必须拜访哈罗德·斯金波尔并就这些问题向他提出警告。上帝保佑你，亲爱的，一个婴儿，一个婴儿！

In pursuance of this plan, we went into London on an early day and presented ourselves at Mr. Skimpole’s door.
为了执行这个计划，我们一早就来到了伦敦，来到了斯金波尔先生的家门口。

He lived in a place called the Polygon, in Somers Town, where there were at that time a number of poor Spanish refugees walking about in cloaks, smoking little paper cigars. Whether he was a better tenant than one might have supposed, in consequence of his friend Somebody always paying his rent at last, or whether his inaptitude for business rendered it particularly difficult to turn him out, I don’t know; but he had occupied the same house some years. It was in a state of dilapidation quite equal to our expectation. Two or three of the area railings were gone, the water-butt was broken, the knocker was loose, the bell-handle had been pulled off a long time to judge from the rusty state of the wire, and dirty footprints on the steps were the only signs of its being inhabited.
他住在萨默斯镇一个叫“多边形”的地方，当时那里有一些贫穷的西班牙难民穿着斗篷走来走去，抽着小纸雪茄。我不知道他是否是一个比人们想象的更好的房客，因为他的朋友总有人最后支付他的房租，或者是否他的商业能力使他很难把他赶出去；但我不知道。但他已经在同一所房子里住了很多年了。它的破旧程度与我们的预期相当。小区栏杆不见了，水桶坏了，门环松了，从铁丝生锈的情况看，钟把手已经被拉掉很久了，台阶上有肮脏的脚印。这是它有人居住的唯一迹象。

A slatternly full-blown girl who seemed to be bursting out at the rents in her gown and the cracks in her shoes like an over-ripe berry answered our knock by opening the door a very little way and stopping up the gap with her figure. As she knew Mr. Jarndyce (indeed Ada and I both thought that she evidently associated him with the receipt of her wages), she immediately relented and allowed us to pass in. The lock of the door being in a disabled condition, she then applied herself to securing it with the chain, which was not in good action either, and said would we go upstairs?
一个邋遢成熟的女孩，她的礼服和鞋子上的裂缝就像一个熟透的浆果，她似乎因为她的礼服的撕裂和鞋子的裂缝而爆发，她回应我们的敲门，把门打开了一点点，用她的身材堵住了缝隙。由于她认识贾迪斯先生（事实上，艾达和我都认为她显然将他与她的工资收据联系在一起），她立即心软并允许我们进去。门锁处于失效状态，然后她申请了她自己用链子固定它，链子也不好用，并说我们要上楼吗？

We went upstairs to the first floor, still seeing no other furniture than the dirty footprints. Mr. Jarndyce without further ceremony entered a room there, and we followed. It was dingy enough and not at all clean, but furnished with an odd kind of shabby luxury, with a large footstool, a sofa, and plenty of cushions, an easy-chair, and plenty of pillows, a piano, books, drawing materials, music, newspapers, and a few sketches and pictures. A broken pane of glass in one of the dirty windows was papered and wafered over, but there was a little plate of hothouse nectarines on the table, and there was another of grapes, and another of sponge-cakes, and there was a bottle of light wine. Mr. Skimpole himself reclined upon the sofa in a dressing-gown, drinking some fragrant coffee from an old china cup—it was then about mid-day—and looking at a collection of wallflowers in the balcony.
我们上楼到了一楼，除了肮脏的脚印之外，仍然没有看到其他家具。贾迪斯先生没有进一步的仪式就进入了那里的一个房间，我们也跟着进去。房间已经够脏了，一点也不干净，但布置却有一种奇怪的破旧奢华，有一个大脚凳、一张沙发、很多垫子、一张安乐椅、很多枕头、一架钢琴、书籍、绘画材料、音乐、报纸以及一些草图和图片。一扇肮脏的窗户上有一块破碎的玻璃，上面贴满了纸和薄片，但桌子上有一小盘温室油桃，还有一颗葡萄，还有一块海绵蛋糕，还有一瓶啤酒。淡酒。斯金波尔先生本人穿着晨衣斜靠在沙发上，喝着旧瓷杯里的香浓咖啡——当时大约是中午——看着阳台上的一群壁花。

He was not in the least disconcerted by our appearance, but rose and received us in his usual airy manner.
他丝毫没有因为我们的出现而感到不安，而是站起来，以他一贯的轻松态度接待了我们。

‘Here I am, you see!’ he said when we were seated, not without some little difficulty, the greater part of the chairs being broken. ‘Here I am! This is my frugal breakfast. Some men want legs of beef and mutton for breakfast; I don’t. Give me my peach, my cup of coffee, and my claret; I am content. I don’t want them for themselves, but they remind me of the sun. There’s nothing solar about legs of beef and mutton. Mere animal satisfaction!’
“我在这里，你看！”当我们坐下时，他说道，但遇到了一些困难，椅子的大部分都坏了。 '我在这里！这就是我节俭的早餐。有些男人早餐想吃牛羊腿；有些男人想吃牛羊腿。我不。给我我的桃子、我的咖啡和我的红葡萄酒；我满足了。我并不想要它们本身，但它们让我想起了太阳。牛羊腿没有任何阳光。仅仅是动物的满足！’

‘This is our friend’s consulting-room (or would be, if he ever prescribed), his sanctum, his studio,’ said my guardian to us.
“这是我们朋友的咨询室（或者，如果他曾经开过处方的话），他的密室，他的工作室，”我的监护人对我们说。

‘Yes,’ said Mr. Skimpole, turning his bright face about, ‘this is the bird’s cage. This is where the bird lives and sings. They pluck his feathers now and then and clip his wings, but he sings, he sings!’
“是的，”斯金波尔先生转过他那张明亮的脸说道，“这就是鸟笼。”这是鸟儿生活和歌唱的地方。他们时不时地拔掉他的羽毛，剪掉他的翅膀，但他唱歌，他唱歌！”

He handed us the grapes, repeating in his radiant way, ‘He sings! Not an ambitious note, but still he sings.’
他把葡萄递给我们，用他光芒四射的方式重复道：“他唱歌了！”虽然不是一个雄心勃勃的音符，但他仍然唱歌。

‘These are very fine,’ said my guardian. ‘A present?’
“这些都很好，”我的监护人说。 '礼物？'

‘No,’ he answered. ‘No! Some amiable gardener sells them. His man wanted to know, when he brought them last evening, whether he should wait for the money. ‘Really, my friend,’ I said, ‘I think not—if your time is of any value to you.’ I suppose it was, for he went away.’
“不，”他回答道。 '不！一些和蔼可亲的园丁出售它们。他的人想知道，当他昨晚带来这些钱时，他是否应该等待钱。 “真的，我的朋友，”我说，“我想不会——如果你的时间对你有价值的话。”我想是的，因为他走了。

My guardian looked at us with a smile, as though he asked us, ‘Is it possible to be worldly with this baby?’
我的监护人微笑着看着我们，仿佛在问我们：“这个孩子还能世俗吗？”

‘This is a day,’ said Mr. Skimpole, gaily taking a little claret in a tumbler, ‘that will ever be remembered here. We shall call it Saint Clare and Saint Summerson day. You must see my daughters. I have a blue-eyed daughter who is my Beauty daughter, I have a Sentiment daughter, and I have a Comedy daughter. You must see them all. They’ll be enchanted.’
“这一天，”斯金波尔先生兴高采烈地在玻璃杯里盛了一杯红葡萄酒，说道，“这里将永远铭记这一天。”我们将其称为圣克莱尔和圣萨默森日。你一定要看看我的女儿们。我有一个蓝眼睛的女儿，她是我的美丽女儿，我有一个情感女儿，我有一个喜剧女儿。你必须看到它们全部。他们会着迷的。

He was going to summon them when my guardian interposed and asked him to pause a moment, as he wished to say a word to him first. ‘My dear Jarndyce,’ he cheerfully replied, going back to his sofa, ‘as many moments as you please. Time is no object here. We never know what o’clock it is, and we never care. Not the way to get on in life, you’ll tell me? Certainly. But we DON’T get on in life. We don’t pretend to do it.’
当他正要召唤他们时，我的监护人插嘴并要求他暂停一下，因为他想先对他说一句话。 “我亲爱的贾迪斯，”他高兴地回答，然后回到沙发上，“你想多久都可以。”时间在这里不再是问题。我们永远不知道现在几点了，我们也从不关心。你会告诉我，这不是生活的方式吗？当然。但我们的生活却过不下去。我们不会假装这样做。

My guardian looked at us again, plainly saying, ‘You hear him?’
我的监护人再次看着我们，淡淡地说：“你们听到了吗？”

‘Now, Harold,’ he began, ‘the word I have to say relates to Rick.’
“现在，哈罗德，”他开始说道，“我要说的这个词与里克有关。”

‘The dearest friend I have!’ returned Mr. Skimpole cordially. ‘I suppose he ought not to be my dearest friend, as he is not on terms with you. But he is, I can’t help it; he is full of youthful poetry, and I love him. If you don’t like it, I can’t help it. I love him.’
“我最亲爱的朋友！”斯金波尔先生亲切地回答道。 “我想他不应该成为我最亲密的朋友，因为他与你关系不和。但他就是这样，我无能为力；他充满了青春的诗意，我爱他。如果你不喜欢，我也无能为力。我爱他。'

The engaging frankness with which he made this declaration really had a disinterested appearance and captivated my guardian, if not, for the moment, Ada too.
他发表这一声明时所表现出的令人着迷的坦率确实具有一种无私的外表，并且吸引了我的监护人（如果不是的话），艾达也被吸引了。

‘You are welcome to love him as much as you like,’ returned Mr. Jarndyce, ‘but we must save his pocket, Harold.’
“欢迎你尽情地爱他，”贾迪斯先生回答道，“但我们必须拯救他的口袋，哈罗德。”

‘Oh!’ said Mr. Skimpole. ‘His pocket? Now you are coming to what I don’t understand.’ Taking a little more claret and dipping one of the cakes in it, he shook his head and smiled at Ada and me with an ingenuous foreboding that he never could be made to understand.
“哦！”斯金波尔先生说。 ‘他的口袋？现在你开始明白我不明白的事情了。”他又拿了一点红葡萄酒，把一块蛋糕浸在里面，然后摇摇头，对艾达和我微笑，带着一种他永远无法理解的天真不祥的预感。

‘If you go with him here or there,’ said my guardian plainly, ‘you must not let him pay for both.’
“如果你和他一起去这里或那里，”我的监护人明确地说，“你不能让他付钱。”

‘My dear Jarndyce,’ returned Mr. Skimpole, his genial face irradiated by the comicality of this idea, ‘what am I to do? If he takes me anywhere, I must go. And how can I pay? I never have any money. If I had any money, I don’t know anything about it. Suppose I say to a man, how much? Suppose the man says to me seven and sixpence? I know nothing about seven and sixpence. It is impossible for me to pursue the subject with any consideration for the man. I don’t go about asking busy people what seven and sixpence is in Moorish—which I don’t understand. Why should I go about asking them what seven and sixpence is in Money—which I don’t understand?’
“我亲爱的贾迪斯，”斯金波尔先生回答道，他和蔼可亲的脸因这个滑稽的想法而焕发光彩，“我该怎么办？如果他带我去任何地方，我就必须去。我该如何付款？我从来没有钱。如果我有钱，我对此一无所知。假设我对一个人说，多少钱？假设这个人对我说七又六便士呢？我对七便士一无所知。我不可能在不顾及这个人的情况下讨论这个话题。我不会去问忙碌的人摩尔语中的七又六便士是什么——我听不懂。我为什么要问他们“金钱”中的“七便士”和“六便士”是多少——我不明白？

‘Well,’ said my guardian, by no means displeased with this artless reply, ‘if you come to any kind of journeying with Rick, you must borrow the money of me (never breathing the least allusion to that circumstance), and leave the calculation to him.’
“好吧，”我的监护人对这个朴实的回答一点也不不满意，“如果你和瑞克一起去旅行，你必须借我的钱（绝对不要提及这种情况），然后离开给他算算。

‘My dear Jarndyce,’ returned Mr. Skimpole, ‘I will do anything to give you pleasure, but it seems an idle form—a superstition. Besides, I give you my word, Miss Clare and my dear Miss Summerson, I thought Mr. Carstone was immensely rich. I thought he had only to make over something, or to sign a bond, or a draft, or a cheque, or a bill, or to put something on a file somewhere, to bring down a shower of money.’
“我亲爱的贾迪斯，”斯金波尔先生回答道，“我愿意做任何事情来让你高兴，但这似乎是一种无聊的形式——一种迷信。”此外，我向你们保证，克莱尔小姐和我亲爱的萨默森小姐，我认为卡斯顿先生非常富有。我以为他只需改造一些东西，或者签署一份债券、一张汇票、一张支票、一张账单，或者把一些东西放在某个地方的档案中，就能带来一大笔钱。

‘Indeed it is not so, sir,’ said Ada. ‘He is poor.’
“事实上并非如此，先生，”艾达说。 “他很穷。”

‘No, really?’ returned Mr. Skimpole with his bright smile. ‘You surprise me.
“没有，真的吗？”斯金波尔先生带着灿烂的笑容回答道。 ‘你让我很惊讶。

‘And not being the richer for trusting in a rotten reed,’ said my guardian, laying his hand emphatically on the sleeve of Mr. Skimpole’s dressing-gown, ‘be you very careful not to encourage him in that reliance, Harold.’
“不要因为相信一根腐烂的芦苇而变得更富有，”我的监护人说，他把手放在斯基姆波尔先生晨衣的袖子上，“你要非常小心，不要鼓励他这种依赖，哈罗德。”

‘My dear good friend,’ returned Mr. Skimpole, ‘and my dear Miss Siunmerson, and my dear Miss Clare, how can I do that? It’s business, and I don’t know business. It is he who encourages me. He emerges from great feats of business, presents the brightest prospects before me as their result, and calls upon me to admire them. I do admire them—as bright prospects. But I know no more about them, and I tell him so.’
“我亲爱的好朋友，”斯金波尔先生回答道，“还有我亲爱的西恩默森小姐，还有我亲爱的克莱尔小姐，我该怎么办呢？这是生意，而我不懂生意。是他鼓励我。他从伟大的商业成就中脱颖而出，将最光明的前景作为其结果呈现在我面前，并呼吁我钦佩它们。我确实钦佩他们——因为他们有着光明的前景。但我对他们一无所知，所以我告诉了他。”

The helpless kind of candour with which he presented this before us, the light-hearted manner in which he was amused by his innocence, the fantastic way in which he took himself under his own protection and argued about that curious person, combined with the delightful ease of everything he said exactly to make out my guardian’s case. The more I saw of him, the more unlikely it seemed to me, when he was present, that he could design, conceal, or influence anything; and yet the less likely that appeared when he was not present, and the less agreeable it was to think of his having anything to do with any one for whom I cared.
他以一种无助的坦率向我们展示了这一点，他对自己的纯真感到好笑的轻松态度，他将自己置于自己的保护之下并与那个好奇的人争论的奇妙方式，再加上令人愉快的他所说的一切都是为了弄清楚我监护人的情况而轻松。我对他看得越多，当他在场时，我就越觉得他不可能设计、隐瞒或影响任何事情。然而，当他不在场时，这种情况就越不可能出现，一想到他与我所关心的任何人有任何关系，我就越不愉快。

Hearing that his examination (as he called it) was now over, Mr. Skimpole left the room with a radiant face to fetch his daughters (his sons had run away at various times), leaving my guardian quite delighted by the manner in which he had vindicated his childish character. He soon came back, bringing with him the three young ladies and Mrs. Skimpole, who had once been a beauty but was now a delicate high-nosed invalid suffering under a complication of disorders.
听说他的考试（他这样称呼考试）已经结束，斯金波尔先生满脸容光焕发地离开房间去接他的女儿们（他的儿子们曾多次逃跑），这让我的监护人对他的表现感到非常高兴。证明了他幼稚的性格。他很快就回来了，带来了三位年轻女士和斯金波尔夫人。斯金波尔夫人曾经是一位美人，但现在却是一位娇弱的高鼻子病人，患有并发症。

‘This,’ said Mr. Skimpole, ‘is my Beauty daughter, Arethusa—plays and sings odds and ends like her father. This is my Sentiment daughter, Laura—plays a little but don’t sing. This is my Comedy daughter, Kitty—sings a little but don’t play. We all draw a little and compose a little, and none of us have any idea of time or money.’
“这，”斯金波尔先生说，“是我美丽的女儿，阿瑞图莎——像她父亲一样演奏和唱歌。这是我的情感女儿劳拉——会玩一点，但不会唱歌。这是我的喜剧女儿基蒂——会唱歌，但不会玩耍。我们都画一点，作一点，我们都没有时间或金钱的概念。

Mrs. Skimpole sighed, I thought, as if she would have been glad to strike out this item in the family attainments. I also thought that she rather impressed her sigh upon my guardian and that she took every opportunity of throwing in another.
我想，斯金波尔夫人叹了口气，好像她很乐意在家庭成就中剔除这一项。我还认为她给我的监护人留下了深刻的印象，并且她抓住每一个机会又扔了一个。

‘It is pleasant,’ said Mr. Skimpole, turning his sprightly eyes from one to the other of us, ‘and it is whimsically interesting to trace peculiarities in families. In this family we are all children, and I am the youngest.’
“这很令人愉快，”斯金波尔先生说，用他那双明亮的眼睛从我们中的一个人转向另一个人，“追踪家庭的特殊性是一种异想天开的有趣。”在这个家里我们都是孩子，而我是最小的。”

The daughters, who appeared to be very fond of him, were amused by this droll fact, particularly the Comedy daughter.
女儿们似乎很喜欢他，被这个滑稽的事实逗乐了，尤其是喜剧女儿。

‘My dears, it is true,’ said Mr. Skimpole, ‘is it not? So it is, and so it must be, because like the dogs in the hymn, ‘it is our nature to.’ Now, here is Miss Summerson with a fine administrative capacity and a knowledge of details perfectly surprising. It will sound very strange in Miss Summerson’s ears, I dare say, that we know nothing about chops in this house. But we don’t, not the least. We can’t cook anything whatever. A needle and thread we don’t know how to use. We admire the people who possess the practical wisdom we want, but we don’t quarrel with them. Then why should they quarrel with us? Live and let live, we say to them. Live upon your practical wisdom, and let us live upon you!’
“亲爱的，这是真的，”斯金波尔先生说，“不是吗？确实如此，也必须如此，因为就像赞美诗中的狗一样，“这是我们的本性。”现在，萨默森小姐拥有出色的管理能力和对细节的了解，令人惊讶。我敢说，我们对这所房子里的排骨一无所知，这在萨默森小姐的耳中听起来会很奇怪。但我们不这样做，至少不这样做。我们什么都不能煮。我们不知道如何使用的针和线。我们钦佩那些拥有我们想要的实践智慧的人，但我们不会与他们争吵。那他们为什么要和我们吵架呢？我们对他们说，自己活，也让别人活。靠你的实践智慧生活，让我们靠你生活！

He laughed, but as usual seemed quite candid and really to mean what he said.
他笑了，但像往常一样显得很坦诚，而且是真心实意的。

‘We have sympathy, my roses,’ said Mr. Skimpole, ‘sympathy for everything. Have we not?’
“我们有同情心，我的玫瑰，”斯金波尔先生说，“对一切都有同情心。”我们没有吗？

‘Oh, yes, papa!’ cried the three daughters.
“噢，是的，爸爸！”三个女儿喊道。

‘In fact, that is our family department,’ said Mr. Skimpole, ‘in this hurly-burly of life. We are capable of looking on and of being interested, and we DO look on, and we ARE interested. What more can we do? Here is my Beauty daughter, married these three years. Now I dare say her marrying another child, and having two more, was all wrong in point of political economy, but it was very agreeable. We had our little festivities on those occasions and exchanged social ideas. She brought her young husband home one day, and they and their young fledglings have their nest upstairs. I dare say at some time or other Sentiment and Comedy will bring THEIR husbands home and have THEIR nests upstairs too. So we get on, we don’t know how, but somehow.’
“事实上，在这喧嚣的生活中，这就是我们的家庭部门，”斯金波尔先生说。我们有能力旁观并感兴趣，我们确实旁观，而且我们很感兴趣。我们还能做什么？这是我的美丽女儿，结婚三年了。现在我敢说她再娶一个孩子，又生两个孩子，从政治经济学的角度来看是完全错误的，但这是非常令人愉快的。我们在那些场合举行了小型庆祝活动并交换了社会想法。有一天，她把年轻的丈夫带回家，他们和雏鸟在楼上筑巢。我敢说，在某个时候或其他时候，情感和喜剧会把他们的丈夫带回家，并在楼上安家。所以我们继续前进，我们不知道如何，但不知何故。

She looked very young indeed to be the mother of two children, and I could not help pitying both her and them. It was evident that the three daughters had grown up as they could and had had just as little haphazard instruction as qualified them to be their father’s playthings in his idlest hours. His pictorial tastes were consulted, I observed, in their respective styles of wearing their hair, the Beauty daughter being in the classic manner, the Sentiment daughter luxuriant and flowing, and the Comedy daughter in the arch style, with a good deal of sprightly forehead, and vivacious little curls dotted about the corners of her eyes. They were dressed to correspond, though in a most untidy and negligent way.
作为两个孩子的母亲，她看起来确实很年轻，我不禁同情她和他们。显然，这三个女儿已经长大了，也没有受到过多少随意的教育，这使得她们成为了父亲最空闲时的玩物。我观察到，他们各自的发型风格都参考了他的绘画品味，美人女儿古典，情感女儿华丽飘逸，喜剧女儿拱门，额头明朗。 ，活泼的小卷发点缀在她的眼角。他们的着装符合相应的要求，尽管穿着非常邋遢和粗心。

Ada and I conversed with these young ladies and found them wonderfully like their father. In the meanwhile Mr. Jarndyce (who had been rubbing his head to a great extent, and hinted at a change in the wind) talked with Mrs. Skimpole in a corner, where we could not help hearing the chink of money. Mr. Skimpole had previously volunteered to go home with us and had withdrawn to dress himself for the purpose.
艾达和我与这些年轻女士交谈，发现她们非常像她们的父亲。与此同时，贾迪斯先生（他一直在用力地揉着头，暗示着风向的变化）在角落里与斯金波尔夫人交谈，我们不禁听到了钱的叮当声。斯金波尔先生此前曾自愿与我们一起回家，并特意退到一边穿衣服。

‘My roses,’ he said when he came back, ‘take care of mama. She is poorly to-day. By going home with Mr. Jarndyce for a day or two, I shall hear the larks sing and preserve my amiability. It has been tried, you know, and would be tried again if I remained at home.’
“我的玫瑰，”他回来后说道，“照顾妈妈。”她今天身体不太好。和贾迪斯先生回家一两天，我就能听到百灵鸟的歌声，保持我的和蔼可亲。你知道，这已经尝试过了，如果我留在家里，还会再尝试一次。”

‘That bad man!’ said the Comedy daughter.
“那个坏人！”喜剧女儿说道。

‘At the very time when he knew papa was lying ill by his wallflowers, looking at the blue sky,’ Laura complained.
“就在他知道爸爸病倒在壁花旁，看着蓝天的时候，”劳拉抱怨道。

‘And when the smell of hay was in the air!’ said Arethusa.
“当空气中弥漫着干草的味道时！”阿瑞图莎说道。

‘It showed a want of poetry in the man,’ Mr. Skimpole assented, but with perfect good humour. ‘It was coarse. There was an absence of the finer touches of humanity in it! My daughters have taken great offence,’ he explained to us, ‘at an honest man—‘
“这表明这个人缺乏诗意，”斯金波尔先生表示同意，但语气非常幽默。 '这很粗糙。里面缺乏人性的细腻触感！ “我的女儿们非常生气，”他向我们解释道，“一个诚实的人——”

‘Not honest, papa. Impossible!’ they all three protested.
“不诚实，爸爸。不可能！”三人都抗议道。

‘At a rough kind of fellow—a sort of human hedgehog rolled up,’ said Mr. Skimpole, ‘who is a baker in this neighbourhood and from whom we borrowed a couple of armchairs. We wanted a couple of armchairs, and we hadn’t got them, and therefore of course we looked to a man who HAD got them, to lend them. Well! This morose person lent them, and we wore them out. When they were worn out, he wanted them back. He had them back. He was contented, you will say. Not at all. He objected to their being worn. I reasoned with him, and pointed out his mistake. I said, ‘Can you, at your time of life, be so headstrong, my friend, as to persist that an arm-chair is a thing to put upon a shelf and look at? That it is an object to contemplate, to survey from a distance, to consider from a point of sight? Don’t you KNOW that these arm-chairs were borrowed to be sat upon?’ He was unreasonable and unpersuadable and used intemperate language. Being as patient as I am at this minute, I addressed another appeal to him. I said, ‘Now, my good man, however our business capacities may vary, we are all children of one great mother, Nature. On this blooming summer morning here you see me’ (I was on the sofa) ‘with flowers before me, fruit upon the table, the cloudless sky above me, the air full of fragrance, contemplating Nature. I entreat you, by our common brotherhood, not to interpose between me and a subject so sublime, the absurd figure of an angry baker!’ But he did,’ said Mr. Skimpole, raising his laughing eyes in playful astonishinent; ‘he did interpose that ridiculous figure, and he does, and he will again. And therefore I am very glad to get out of his way and to go home with my friend Jarndyce.’
“这是一个粗暴的家伙——一种卷起来的人类刺猬，”斯金波尔先生说，“他是附近的一名面包师，我们从他那里借了几把扶手椅。我们想要几把扶手椅，但我们没有，因此我们当然会向一个拥有它们的人借用它们。出色地！这个闷闷不乐的人把它们借给了我们，我们把它们穿坏了。当它们疲惫不堪时，他希望它们回来。他把它们拿回来了。你会说，他很满足。一点也不。他反对佩戴它们。我跟他讲道理，指出他的错误。我说：‘我的朋友，在你这个年纪，你能如此任性，坚持认为扶手椅是一个可以放在架子上看的东西吗？它是一个可以沉思、可以从远处观察、可以从一个视点考虑的对象吗？难道你不知道这些扶手椅是借来坐的吗？”他毫无道理，难以说服，而且言语过激。此刻，我像我一样耐心，向他发出了另一次呼吁。我说：‘现在，我的好人，无论我们的业务能力如何，我们都是一位伟大母亲——大自然的孩子。在这个盛夏的早晨，你看到我’（我在沙发上）‘面前鲜花，桌上水果，头顶万里无云，空气中充满芬芳，沉思着大自然。我恳求你，以我们共同的兄弟情谊，不要介入我和一个如此崇高的主题之间，一个愤怒的面包师的荒谬人物！“但他做到了，”斯金波尔先生说，抬起他笑着的眼睛，戏谑而惊讶； “他确实介入了这个荒谬的数字，他确实介入了，而且他还会再次介入。因此，我很高兴能够摆脱他的妨碍，和我的朋友贾迪斯一起回家。”

It seemed to escape his consideration that Mrs. Skimpole and the daughters remained behind to encounter the baker, but this was so old a story to all of them that it had become a matter of course. He took leave of his family with a tenderness as airy and graceful as any other aspect in which he showed himself and rode away with us in perfect harmony of mind. We had an opportunity of seeing through some open doors, as we went downstairs, that his own apartment was a palace to the rest of the house.
他似乎没有考虑到斯金波尔夫人和女儿们留下来迎接面包师，但这对她们所有人来说都是一个老故事了，所以这已经成为理所当然的事了。他以一种轻柔、优雅的态度告别了家人，就像他表现自己的其他方面一样，然后带着完美的心灵与我们一起骑马离开。当我们下楼时，我们有机会透过一些敞开的门看到，他自己的公寓对于房子的其他部分来说就像一座宫殿。

I could have no anticipation, and I had none, that something very startling to me at the moment, and ever memorable to me in what ensued from it, was to happen before this day was out. Our guest was in such spirits on the way home that I could do nothing but listen to him and wonder at him; nor was I alone in this, for Ada yielded to the same fascination. As to my guardian, the wind, which had threatened to become fixed in the east when we left Somers Town, veered completely round before we were a couple of miles from it.
我不可能预料到，我也没有预料到，在这一天结束之前，此刻会发生令我震惊的事情，并且随之而来的事情让我永远难忘。我们的客人在回家的路上兴高采烈，我无能为力，只能听他说话，对他感到惊讶。我并不孤单，因为艾达也同样着迷。至于我的监护人，当我们离开萨默斯镇时，风向有可能转为东风，但在我们离开几英里之前，风就完全转向了。

Whether of questionable childishness or not in any other matters, Mr. Skimpole had a child’s enjoyment of change and bright weather. In no way wearied by his sallies on the road, he was in the drawing-room before any of us; and I heard him at the piano while I was yet looking after my housekeeping, singing refrains of barcaroles and drinking songs, Italian and German, by the score.
不管在其他事情上是否有可疑的幼稚，斯金波尔先生对变化和明朗的天气有着孩子般的享受。他在路上的突袭丝毫没有让他感到厌倦，他比我们任何人都先到了客厅。当我还在打理家务时，我听见他弹奏钢琴，按乐谱唱着船歌和饮酒歌曲，意大利和德国的歌曲。

We were all assembled shortly before dinner, and he was still at the piano idly picking out in his luxurious way little strains of music, and talking between whiles of finishing some sketches of the ruined old Verulam wall to-morrow, which he had begun a year or two ago and had got tired of, when a card was brought in and my guardian read aloud in a surprised voice, ‘Sir Leicester Dedlock!’
晚餐前不久，我们都聚集在一起，他仍然在钢琴前闲着，以他奢华的方式弹奏小曲子，并在完成明天被毁的旧维鲁拉姆墙的一些草图的间隙中交谈，他已经开始了一项工作。一两年前，我已经厌倦了，当一张卡片被带进来时，我的监护人用惊讶的声音大声朗读：“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士！”

The visitor was in the room while it was yet turning round with me and before I had the power to stir. If I had had it, I should have hurried away. I had not even the presence of mind, in my giddiness, to retire to Ada in the window, or to see the window, or to know where it was. I heard my name and found that my guardian was presenting me before I could move to a chair.
当房间还没有和我一起转动时，在我有能力移动之前，访客就已经在房间里了。如果我有的话，我就应该赶紧走开。我什至没有头脑，在我的头晕中，退到窗外的艾达那里，或者看看窗户，或者知道它在哪里。我听到我的名字，发现我的监护人在我移动到椅子上之前就在引导我。

‘Pray be seated, Sir Leicester.’
“请坐下，莱斯特爵士。”

‘Mr. Jarndyce,’ said Sir Leicester in reply as he bowed and seated himself, ‘I do myself the honour of calling here—‘
'先生。詹迪斯，”莱斯特爵士一边鞠躬坐下，一边答道，“我很荣幸能来这里——”

‘You do ME the honour, Sir Leicester.’
“莱斯特爵士，您很荣幸。”

‘Thank you—of calling here on my road from Lincolnshire to express my regret that any cause of complaint, however strong, that I may have against a gentleman who—who is known to you and has been your host, and to whom therefore I will make no farther reference, should have prevented you, still more ladies under your escort and charge, from seeing whatever little there may be to gratify a polite and refined taste at my house, Chesney Wold.’
“谢谢您从林肯郡一路过来，表达我对一位绅士的任何投诉，无论多么强烈的不满，他是您所认识的，也是您的东道主，因此我向他表示遗憾。”不会再做进一步的提及，应该阻止你，还有更多在你的护送和负责下的女士，看到我家切斯尼沃尔德可能有的一点点可以满足礼貌和高雅品味的东西。

‘You are exceedingly obliging, Sir Leicester, and on behalf of those ladies (who are present) and for myself, I thank you very much.’
“莱斯特爵士，您非常乐于助人，我代表（在场的）女士们以及我自己，非常感谢您。”

‘It is possible, Mr. Jarndyce, that the gentleman to whom, for the reasons I have mentioned, I refrain from making further allusion— it is possible, Mr. Jarndyce, that that gentleman may have done me the honour so far to misapprehend my character as to induce you to believe that you would not have been received by my local establishment in Lincolnshire with that urbanity, that courtesy, which its members are instructed to show to all ladies and gentlemen who present themselves at that house. I merely beg to observe, sir, that the fact is the reverse.’
“贾迪斯先生，有可能的是，由于我已经提到的原因，我没有向这位先生作进一步的暗示——贾迪斯先生，有可能那位先生到目前为止已经让我荣幸地误解了他的意思。”我的性格是为了让你相信，我在林肯郡当地的机构不会以那种彬彬有礼、礼貌的态度接待你，而我的成员被要求向所有来到那所房子的女士们和先生们表现出这种礼貌。先生，我只是想指出，事实恰恰相反。

My guardian delicately dismissed this remark without making any verbal answer.
我的监护人巧妙地驳回了这一说法，没有做出任何口头答复。
