‘It has given me pain, Mr. Jarndyce,’ Sir Leicester weightily proceeded. ‘I assure you, sir, it has given—me—pain—to learn from the housekeeper at Chesney Wold that a gentleman who was in your company in that part of the county, and who would appear to possess a cultivated taste for the fine arts, was likewise deterred by some such cause from examining the family pictures with that leisure, that attention, that care, which he might have desired to bestow upon them and which some of them might possibly have repaid.’ Here he produced a card and read, with much gravity and a little trouble, through his eye-glass, ‘Mr. Hirrold—Herald— Harold—Skampling—Skumpling—I beg your pardon—Skimpole.’
“这让我很痛苦，贾迪斯先生，”莱斯特爵士沉重地继续说道。 “我向您保证，先生，从切斯尼沃尔德的管家那里得知，在县里的那个地方，有一位与您同行的绅士，而且他似乎对精致的事物有着高雅的品味，这让我感到痛苦。艺术界的人，同样也因为这样的原因而不敢以那种闲暇、那种关注、那种关怀来检查家庭照片，而他可能希望给予他们这些，而他们中的一些人可能已经回报了。”他在这里拿出一张卡片，然后透过他的眼镜，一本正经地读着，有点费劲，“先生”。希罗德——先驱——哈罗德——斯坎普林——斯坎普林——对不起——斯坎波尔。

‘This is Mr. Harold Skimpole,’ said my guardian, evidently surprised.
“这是哈罗德·斯基波尔先生，”我的监护人显然很惊讶地说。

‘Oh!’ exclaimed Sir Leicester, ‘I am happy to meet Mr. Skimpole and to have the opportunity of tendering my personal regrets. I hope, sir, that when you again find yourself in my part of the county, you will be under no similar sense of restraint.’
“哦！”莱斯特爵士惊呼道，“我很高兴见到斯金波尔先生，并有机会表达我个人的遗憾。先生，我希望当您再次来到我所在的县城时，您将不再受到类似的束缚。

‘You are very obliging, Sir Leicester Dedlock. So encouraged, I shall certainly give myself the pleasure and advantage of another visit to your beautiful house. The owners of such places as Chesney Wold,’ said Mr. Skimpole with his usual happy and easy air, ‘are public benefactors. They are good enough to maintain a number of delightful objects for the admiration and pleasure of us poor men; and not to reap all the admiration and pleasure that they yield is to be ungrateful to our benefactors.’
“你非常乐于助人，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士。如此鼓舞，我一定会给自己带来再次参观您美丽的房子的乐趣和优势。像切斯尼沃尔德这样的地方的主人，”斯金波尔先生用他一贯的快乐和轻松的神情说道，“都是公共捐助者。他们足以维持许多令人愉快的物品，让我们这些穷人钦佩和高兴。不获得他们所带来的所有钦佩和快乐就是对我们的恩人忘恩负义。

Sir Leicester seemed to approve of this sentiment highly. ‘An artist, sir?’
莱斯特爵士似乎非常赞同这种观点。 “一位艺术家，先生？”

‘No,’ returned Mr. Skimpole. ‘A perfectly idle man. A mere amateur.’
“不，”斯金波尔先生回答道。 “一个十足的闲人。”只是一个业余爱好者。

Sir Leicester seemed to approve of this even more. He hoped he might have the good fortune to be at Chesney Wold when Mr. Skimpole next came down into Lincolnshire. Mr. Skimpole professed himself much flattered and honoured.
莱斯特爵士似乎更加赞同这一点。他希望当斯金波尔先生下次来到林肯郡时，他能有幸来到切斯尼沃尔德。斯金波尔先生表示自己非常受宠若惊，也深感荣幸。

‘Mr. Skimpole mentioned,’ pursued Sir Leicester, addressing himself again to my guardian, ‘mentioned to the house-keeper, who, as he may have observed, is an old and attached retainer of the family—‘
'先生。斯金波尔提到，”莱斯特爵士继续说道，再次向我的监护人讲话，“向管家提到，正如他可能已经观察到的那样，她是这个家庭的一位年老的、依附的家臣——”

(“That is, when I walked through the house the other day, on the occasion of my going down to visit Miss Summerson and Miss Clare,’ Mr. Skimpole airily explained to us.)
（“也就是说，那天我在拜访萨默森小姐和克莱尔小姐时穿过这栋房子时，”斯金波尔先生轻描淡写地向我们解释道。）

‘—That the friend with whom he had formerly been staying there was Mr. Jarndyce.’ Sir Leicester bowed to the bearer of that name. ‘And hence I became aware of the circumstance for which I have professed my regret. That this should have occurred to any gentleman, Mr. Jarndyce, but especially a gentleman formerly known to Lady Dedlock, and indeed claiming some distant connexion with her, and for whom (as I learn from my Lady herself) she entertains a high respect, does, I assure you, give—me—pain.’
“——以前和他一起住在那里的朋友是贾迪斯先生。”莱斯特爵士向持有这个名字的人鞠了一躬。 ‘因此，我意识到了我所表示遗憾的情况。贾迪斯先生，任何一位绅士都会想到这一点，尤其是戴德洛克夫人以前认识的一位绅士，他确实声称与她有某种遥远的联系，而且（据我从夫人本人那里得知）她对他怀有崇高的敬意，我向你保证，确实会给——我——带来痛苦。”

‘Pray say no more about it, Sir Leicester,’ returned my guardian. ‘I am very sensible, as I am sure we all are, of your consideration. Indeed the mistake was mine, and I ought to apologize for it.’
“请不要再说这件事了，莱斯特爵士，”我的监护人回答道。 “我非常明智，我相信我们大家都是如此，很理解您的考虑。事实上，这个错误是我的，我应该为此道歉。

I had not once looked up. I had not seen the visitor and had not even appeared to myself to hear the conversation. It surprises me to find that I can recall it, for it seemed to make no impression on me as it passed. I heard them speaking, but my mind was so confused and my instinctive avoidance of this gentleman made his presence so distressing to me that I thought I understood nothing, through the rushing in my head and the beating of my heart.
我一次也没有抬头。我没有看到这位访客，甚至没有听到他们的谈话。我惊讶地发现我竟然能回忆起它，因为它过去时似乎没有给我留下任何印象。我听到他们在说话，但我的思绪如此混乱，我本能地回避这位先生，让他的存在让我感到如此痛苦，以至于我以为我什么也听不懂，因为我的头脑在奔腾，我的心脏在跳动。

‘I mentioned the subject to Lady Dedlock,’ said Sir Leicester, rising, ‘and my Lady informed me that she had had the pleasure of exchanging a few words with Mr. Jarndyce and his wards on the occasion of an accidental meeting during their sojourn in the vicinity. Permit me, Mr. Jarndyce, to repeat to yourself, and to these ladies, the assurance I have already tendered to Mr. Skimpole. Circumstances undoubtedly prevent my saying that it would afford me any gratification to hear that Mr. Boythorn had favoured my house with his presence, but those circumstances are confined to that gentleman himself and do not extend beyond him.’
“我向戴德洛克夫人提到了这个话题，”莱斯特爵士站了起来，“夫人告诉我，在贾迪斯先生和他的受监护人逗留期间的一次偶然会面中，她很高兴与他们交谈了几句话。”在附近。贾迪斯先生，请允许我向您本人和这些女士重复一遍我已经向斯金波尔先生作出的保证。毫无疑问，情况不允许我说，如果博伊索恩先生在场，我会感到很高兴，但这些情况仅限于这位先生本人，不会超出他的范围。

‘You know my old opinion of him,’ said Mr. Skimpole, lightly appealing to us. ‘An amiable bull who is detenined to make every colour scarlet!’
“你知道我以前对他的看法，”斯金波尔先生轻轻地向我们恳求道。 “一头和蔼可亲的公牛，注定会让每种颜色都变成猩红色！”

Sir Leicester Dedlock coughed as if he could not possibly hear another word in reference to such an individual and took his leave with great ceremony and politeness. I got to my own room with all possible speed and remained there until I had recovered my selfcommand. It had been very much disturbed, but I was thankful to find when I went downstairs again that they only rallied me for having been shy and mute before the great Lincolnshire baronet.
莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士咳嗽了一声，好像他再也听不到提到这样一个人的词了，然后以隆重的仪式和礼貌离开了。我以最快的速度回到了自己的房间，一直呆在那里，直到我恢复了自制力。我感到非常不安，但我很庆幸地发现，当我再次下楼时，他们只是因为我在伟大的林肯郡准男爵面前害羞和沉默而重新振作起来。

By that time I had made up my mind that the period was come when I must tell my guardian what I knew. The possibility of my being brought into contact with my mother, of my being taken to her house, even of Mr. Skimpole’s, however distantly associated with me, receiving kindnesses and obligations from her husband, was so painful that I felt I could no longer guide myself without his assistance.
那时我已经下定决心，是时候我必须告诉我的监护人我所知道的事情了。我可能会与我的母亲接触，我可能会被带到她的家里，甚至是斯金波尔先生的家，无论与我的关系有多么遥远，接受她丈夫的善意和义务，我感到如此痛苦，以至于我觉得我再也不能无需他的帮助即可引导自己。

When we had retired for the night, and Ada and I had had our usual talk in our pretty room, I went out at my door again and sought my guardian among his books. I knew he always read at that hour, and as I drew near I saw the light shining out into the passage from his reading-lamp.
当我们晚上休息时，艾达和我在我们漂亮的房间里进行了我们平常的谈话，我再次走出家门，在他的书中寻找我的监护人。我知道他总是在那个时间读书，当我走近时，我看到灯光从他的台灯照进走廊。

‘May I come in, guardian?’
“我可以进来吗，监护人？”

‘Surely, little woman. What’s the matter?’
“当然可以，小女人。怎么了？'

‘Nothing is the matter. I thought I would like to take this quiet time of saying a word to you about myself.’
‘没什么事。我想我想利用这个安静的时间向你介绍一下我自己。

He put a chair for me, shut his book, and put it by, and turned his kind attentive face towards me. I could not help observing that it wore that curious expression I had observed in it once before—on that night when he had said that he was in no trouble which I could readily understand.
他给我放了一张椅子，合上书，放在一边，然后把他那张慈祥专注的脸转向我。我情不自禁地发现，它脸上带着我以前曾经观察过的那种奇怪的表情——那天晚上，当他说他没有遇到麻烦时，我很容易理解这一点。

‘What concerns you, my dear Esther,’ said he, ‘concerns us all. You cannot be more ready to speak than I am to hear.’
“亲爱的埃丝特，你所关心的事情，”他说，“也关系到我们所有人。”你不可能比我更愿意倾听。

‘I know that, guardian. But I have such need of your advice and support. Oh! You don’t know how much need I have to-night.’
“我知道，监护人。但我非常需要你的建议和支持。哦！你不知道今晚我有多么需要。

He looked unprepared for my being so earnest, and even a little alarmed.
对于我如此认真，他显得有些措手不及，甚至还有点惊慌。

‘Or how anxious I have been to speak to you,’ said I, ‘ever since the visitor was here to-day.’
“或者说，自从客人今天来到这里以来，我就一直渴望和你说话，”我说。

‘The visitor, my dear! Sir Leicester Dedlock?’
‘亲爱的，有客人来了！莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士？

‘Yes.’
'是的。'

He folded his arms and sat looking at me with an air of the profoundest astonishment, awaiting what I should say next. I did not know how to prepare him.
他抱起双臂，坐着，带着极其惊讶的神情看着我，等待我接下来要说的话。我不知道如何让他做好准备。

‘Why, Esther,’ said he, breaking into a smile, ‘our visitor and you are the two last persons on earth I should have thought of connecting together!’
“哎呀，艾丝特，”他突然微笑起来，“我们的访客和你是地球上最后两个我最不想联系在一起的人！”

‘Oh, yes, guardian, I know it. And I too, but a little while ago.’
“哦，是的，监护人，我知道了。我也是，但不久前。

The smile passed from his face, and he became graver than before. He crossed to the door to see that it was shut (but I had seen to that) and resumed his seat before me.
笑容从他脸上消失，他的表情比之前更加严肃。他走到门口，看到门关着（但我已经看到了），然后又回到了我面前的座位上。

‘Guardian,’ said I, ‘do you remensher, when we were overtaken by the thunder-storm, Lady Dedlock’s speaking to you of her sister?’
“守护者，”我说，“你还记得，当我们被雷暴袭击时，戴德洛克夫人向你谈到了她的妹妹吗？”

‘Of course. Of course I do.’
'当然。我当然是了。'

‘And reminding you that she and her sister had differed, had gone their several ways?’
“并提醒你，她和她的妹妹是不同的，已经分道扬镳了？”

‘Of course.’
'当然。'

‘Why did they separate, guardian?’
“他们为什么分开，监护人？”

His face quite altered as he looked at me. ‘My child, what questions are these! I never knew. No one but themselves ever did know, I believe. Who could tell what the secrets of those two handsome and proud women were! You have seen Lady Dedlock. If you had ever seen her sister, you would know her to have been as resolute and haughty as she.’
当他看着我时，他的脸色发生了很大的变化。 ‘我的孩子，这都是什么问题啊！我一直都不知道。我相信，除了他们自己，没有人知道。谁能知道这两个俊美高傲的女人到底藏着什么秘密！你见过德洛克夫人。如果你见过她姐姐，你就会知道她和她一样刚毅和傲慢。

‘Oh, guardian, I have seen her many and many a time!’
“噢，守护者，我已经见过她很多很多次了！”

‘Seen her?’
“看到她了吗？”

He paused a little, biting his lip. ‘Then, Esther, when you spoke to me long ago of Boythorn, and when I told you that he was all but married once, and that the lady did not die, but died to him, and that that time had had its influence on his later life—did you know it all, and know who the lady was?’
他停顿了一下，咬着嘴唇。 “然后，埃丝特，当你很久以前对我谈到博伊索恩时，当我告诉你他几乎结过一次婚，那位女士并没有死，而是对他死了，那段时间对他产生了影响。他后来的生活——你知道这一切吗？知道那位女士是谁吗？

‘No, guardian,’ I returned, fearful of the light that dimly broke upon me. ‘Nor do I know yet.’
“不，监护人，”我回答道，害怕照在我身上的微光。 “我也不知道。”

‘Lady Dedlock’s sister.’
“戴德洛克夫人的妹妹。”

‘And why,’ I could scarcely ask him, ‘why, guardian, pray tell me why were THEY parted?’
“为什么，”我几乎无法问他，“为什么，监护人，请告诉我他们为什么分开？”

‘It was her act, and she kept its motives in her inflexible heart. He afterwards did conjecture (but it was mere conjecture) that some injury which her haughty spirit had received in her cause of quarrel with her sister had wounded her beyond all reason, but she wrote him that from the date of that letter she died to him—as in literal truth she did—and that the resolution was exacted from her by her knowledge of his proud temper and his strained sense of honour, which were both her nature too. In consideration for those master points in him, and even in consideration for them in herself, she made the sacrifice, she said, and would live in it and die in it. She did both, I fear; certainly he never saw her, never heard of her from that hour. Nor did any one.’
“这是她的行为，她将其动机藏在她顽固的心里。后来他确实推测（但这只是推测），她傲慢的精神因与姐姐争吵而受到了某种伤害，这种伤害已经无缘无故地伤害了她，但她写信给他，从那封信之日起，她对他来说已经死了——正如她确实所做的那样——她之所以做出这样的决定，是因为她了解他骄傲的脾气和紧张的荣誉感，而这也是她的本性。她说，考虑到他的那些大师点，甚至考虑到她自己的那些大师点，她做出了牺牲，并且将在其中生，在其中死。我担心她两者都做到了。当然，从那时起他就再也没有见过她，也没有听说过她。也没有人这样做。

‘Oh, guardian, what have I done!’ I cried, giving way to my grief; ‘what sorrow have I innocently caused!’
“哦，监护人，我做了什么！”我哭喊着，屈服于悲伤。 “我无意中造成了多么大的悲伤啊！”

‘You caused, Esther?’
“是你造成的，埃丝特？”

‘Yes, guardian. Innocently, but most surely. That secluded sister is my first remembrance.’
‘是的，监护人。无辜的，但最肯定的是。那个与世隔绝的姐姐是我的第一个记忆。

‘No, no!’ he cried, starting.
“不，不！”他惊叫道。

‘Yes, guardian, yes! And HER sister is my mother!’
‘是的，监护人，是的！她的妹妹是我的母亲！

I would have told him all my mother’s letter, but he would not hear it then. He spoke so tenderly and wisely to me, and he put so plainly before me all I had myself imperfectly thought and hoped in my better state of mind, that, penetrated as I had been with fervent gratitude towards him through so many years, I believed I had never loved him so dearly, never thanked him in my heart so fully, as I did that night. And when he had taken me to my room and kissed me at the door, and when at last I lay down to sleep, my thought was how could I ever be busy enough, how could I ever be good enough, how in my little way could I ever hope to be forgetful enough of myself, devoted enough to him, and useful enough to others, to show him how I blessed and honoured him.
我本想把我母亲的信全部告诉他，但他不会听。他对我说话如此温柔而明智，他如此清楚地将我自己不完美的想法和希望以更好的心态呈现在我面前，多年来我一直对他怀着热烈的感激之情，我相信我从来没有像那天晚上那样深深地爱过他，也从未在心里如此衷心地感谢过他。当他带我到我的房间并在门口亲吻我，当我最终躺下睡觉时，我的想法是我如何才能足够忙碌，我如何才能足够好，如何以我的小方式我是否希望能够忘记自己，对他足够忠诚，对他人足够有用，向他展示我是如何祝福和尊重他的。

CHAPTER XLIV
第四十四章


The Letter and the Answer
信与答复

My guardian called me into his room next morning, and then I told him what had been left untold on the previous night. There was nothing to be done, he said, but to keep the secret and to avoid another such encounter as that of yesterday. He understood my feeling and entirely shared it. He charged himself even with restraining Mr. Skimpole from improving his opportunity. One person whom he need not name to me, it was not now possible for him to advise or help. He wished it were, but no such thing could be. If her mistrust of the lawyer whom she had mentioned were wellfounded, which he scarcely doubted, he dreaded discovery. He knew something of him, both by sight and by reputation, and it was certain that he was a dangerous man. Whatever happened, he repeatedly impressed upon me with anxious affection and kindness, I was as innocent of as himself and as unable to influence.
第二天早上，我的监护人把我叫到他的房间，然后我告诉了他前一天晚上未说的事情。他说，除了保守秘密并避免再次发生像昨天那样的遭遇之外，别无他法。他理解我的感受并且完全同意我的感受。他甚至责备自己阻止斯金波尔先生改善自己的机会。他不需要向我透露一个人的名字，但他现在不可能提供建议或帮助。他希望如此，但这是不可能的。如果她对她提到的律师的不信任是有充分根据的（他几乎不怀疑这一点），那么他害怕被发现。他从外表和名声上都对他有所了解，并且可以肯定他是一个危险的人。无论发生什么事，他一再给我留下焦灼的感情和友善的印象，我和他一样天真无邪，无法影响。

‘Nor do I understand,’ said he, ‘that any doubts tend towards you, my dear. Much suspicion may exist without that connexion.’
“我也不明白，”他说，“任何怀疑都会针对你，亲爱的。如果没有这种联系，可能还会存在很多怀疑。

‘With the lawyer,’ I returned. ‘But two other persons have come into my mind since I have been anxious. Then I told him all about Mr. Guppy, who I feared might have had his vague surmises when I little understood his meaning, but in whose silence after our last interview I expressed perfect confidence.
“和律师一起。”我回答道。 “但是自从我一直焦虑以来，我的脑海里浮现出了另外两个人。然后我告诉他关于古比先生的一切，我担心当我不太理解他的意思时，他可能会做出模糊的猜测，但在我们上次采访后的沉默中，我表达了完全的信心。

‘Well,’ said my guardian. ‘Then we may dismiss him for the present. Who is the other?’
“好吧，”我的监护人说。 ‘那么我们可以暂时解雇他了。另一个是谁？

I called to his recollection the French maid and the eager offer of herself she had made to me.
我让他回忆起那个法国女仆，以及她向我提出的热切求婚。

‘Ha!’ he returned thoughtfully. ‘That is a more alarming person than the clerk. But after all, my dear, it was but seeking for a new service. She had seen you and Ada a little while before, and it was natural that you should come into her head. She merely proposed herself for your maid, you know. She did nothing more.’
“哈！”他若有所思地回答道。 ‘那是一个比店员更令人震惊的人。但毕竟，亲爱的，这只是在寻求新的服务。她不久前见过你和艾达，很自然地你就会出现在她的脑海里。你知道，她只是向你的女仆求婚而已。她什么也没做。

‘Her manner was strange,’ said I.
“她的态度很奇怪，”我说。

‘Yes, and her manner was strange when she took her shoes off and showed that cool relish for a walk that might have ended in her death-bed,’ said my guardian. ‘It would be useless self-distress and torment to reckon up such chances and possibilities. There are very few harmless circumstances that would not seem full of perilous meaning, so considered. Be hopeful, little woman. You can be nothing better than yourself; be that, through this knowledge, as you were before you had it. It is the best you can do for everybody’s sake. I, sharing the secret with you—‘
“是的，当她脱掉鞋子并表现出对散步的冷静兴趣时，她的态度很奇怪，而这可能会在她临死前结束。”我的监护人说。 “考虑这样的机会和可能性，自我苦恼和折磨是没有用的。”考虑到这一点，几乎没有什么无害的情况看起来不充满危险的意义。要有希望，小女人。你不可能比你自己更好；通过这种知识，就像你在拥有它之前一样。这是你为每个人都能做的最好的事情。我，与你分享这个秘密——”

‘And lightening it, guardian, so much,’ said I.
“守护者，减轻了它的负担，”我说道。

‘—will be attentive to what passes in that family, so far as I can observe it from my distance. And if the time should come when I can stretch out a hand to render the least service to one whom it is better not to name even here, I will not fail to do it for her dear daughter’s sake.’
“——只要我能从远处观察到，我就会留意那个家庭里发生的事情。如果有一天我能伸出援手，为一个最好不要在这里提到名字的人提供哪怕一点点的服务，我也不会不为了她亲爱的女儿而这样做。

I thanked him with my whole heart. What could I ever do but thank him! I was going out at the door when he asked me to stay a moment. Quickly turning round, I saw that same expression on his face again; and all at once, I don’t know how, it flashed upon me as a new and far-off possibility that I understood it.
我全心全意地感谢他。除了感谢他我还能做什么！我正要出门，他让我稍等一下。迅速转过身，我再次看到他脸上同样的表情；突然间，我不知道怎么的，我突然意识到一种新的、遥远的可能性，我明白了。

‘My dear Esther,’ said my guardian, ‘I have long had something in my thoughts that I have wished to say to you.’
“我亲爱的艾丝特，”我的监护人说，“我一直有一些话想对你说。”

‘Indeed?’
'的确？'

‘I have had some difficulty in approaching it, and I still have. I should wish it to be so deliberately said, and so deliberately considered. Would you object to my writing it?’
“我在接近这个目标时遇到了一些困难，现在仍然如此。我希望如此刻意地说出它，并如此刻意地考虑它。你会反对我写它吗？

‘Dear guardian, how could I object to your writing anything for ME to read?’
“亲爱的监护人，我怎么能反对你写任何东西给我读呢？”

‘Then see, my love,’ said he with his cheery smile, ‘am I at this moment quite as plain and easy—do I seem as open, as honest and old-fashioned—as I am at any time?’
“那么，亲爱的，”他带着愉快的微笑说道，“此时此刻的我是不是像任何时候一样坦率、随和——我看起来是不是那么开放、诚实和守旧？”

I answered in all earnestness, ‘Quite.’ With the strictest truth, for his momentary hesitation was gone (it had not lasted a minute), and his fine, sensible, cordial, sterling manner was restored.
我很认真地回答：“是的。”说的是最严格的事实，因为他一时的犹豫消失了（没有持续一分钟），恢复了他那优雅、明智、亲切、纯正的态度。

‘Do I look as if I suppressed anything, meant anything but what I said, had any reservation at all, no matter what?’ said he with his bright clear eyes on mine.
“我看起来好像压抑了什么，除了我所说的以外什么都没有，无论发生什么，我都没有任何保留吗？”他用明亮清澈的眼睛看着我说道。

I answered, most assuredly he did not.
我回答说，他肯定没有。

‘Can you fully trust me, and thoroughly rely on what I profess, Esther?’
“你能完全信任我，并完全依赖我所宣称的吗，埃丝特？”

‘Most thoroughly,’ said I with my whole heart.
“非常彻底。”我全心全意地说。

‘My dear girl,’ returned my guardian, ‘give me your hand.’
“我亲爱的女孩，”我的监护人回答道，“把你的手给我。”

He took it in his, holding me lightly with his arm, and looking down into my face with the same genuine freshness and faithfulness of manner—the old protecting manner which had made that house my home in a moment—said, ‘You have wrought changes in me, little woman, since the winter day in the stage-coach. First and last you have done me a world of good since that time.’
他接过它，用手臂轻轻地抱着我，低头看着我的脸，带着同样真诚的新鲜感和忠诚的态度——那种古老的保护态度，使那所房子立刻成为我的家——说，“你已经做了自从冬日在驿站马车里以来，我这个小女人就发生了变化。从那时起，你首先也是最后一次为我做了很多好事。

‘Ah, guardian, what have you done for me since that time!’
“啊，守护者，从那时起你为我做了什么！”

‘But,’ said he, ‘that is not to be remembered now.’
“但是，”他说，“现在已经不记得了。”

‘It never can be forgotten.’
“它永远不会被忘记。”

‘Yes, Esther,’ said he with a gentle seriousness, ‘it is to be forgotten now, to be forgotten for a while. You are only to remember now that nothing can change me as you know me. Can you feel quite assured of that, my dear?’
“是的，埃丝特，”他温和而严肃地说，“现在就应该忘记，暂时忘记。”你现在只需记住，正如你所了解的那样，没有什么可以改变我。亲爱的，你能对此感到十分放心吗？

‘I can, and I do,’ I said.
“我可以，而且我愿意，”我说。

‘That’s much,’ he answered. ‘That’s everything. But I must not take that at a word. I will not write this something in my thoughts until you have quite resolved within yourself that nothing can change me as you know me. If you doubt that in the least degree, I will never write it. If you are sure of that, on good consideration, send Charley to me this night week—‘for the letter.’ But if you are not quite certain, never send. Mind, I trust to your truth, in this thing as in everything. If you are not quite certain on that one point, never send!’
“就这么多了，”他回答道。 ‘就是这样。但我决不能只相信这一点。我不会在我的想法中写下这些，直到你内心下定决心，没有什么可以改变你所了解的我。如果你有哪怕一点点的怀疑，我就永远不会写它。如果你确定这一点，那么，经过深思熟虑，请在本周晚上将查理发送给我——“为了这封信”。但如果你不太确定，就不要发送。请注意，我相信你的真理，无论是在这件事上还是在所有事情上。如果您对这一点不太确定，请不要发送！

‘Guardian,’ said I, ‘I am already certain, I can no more be changed in that conviction than you can be changed towards me. I shall send Charley for the letter.’
“守护者，”我说，“我已经确定，我的信念无法改变，就像你对我的态度无法改变一样。”我会派查理去取信。

He shook my hand and said no more. Nor was any more said in reference to this conversation, either by him or me, through the whole week. When the appointed night came, I said to Charley as soon as I was alone, ‘Go and knock at Mr. Jarndyce’s door, Charley, and say you have come from me—‘for the letter.’’ Charley went up the stairs, and down the stairs, and along the passages—the zigzag way about the old-fashioned house seemed very long in my listening ears that night—and so came back, along the passages, and down the stairs, and up the stairs, and brought the letter. ‘Lay it on the table, Charley,’ said I. So Charley laid it on the table and went to bed, and I sat looking at it without taking it up, thinking of many things.
他握了握我的手，没有再说什么。整个星期，无论是他还是我，都没有再提及这次谈话。当约定的夜晚到来时，我一独自一人就对查理说：“查理，去敲一下贾迪斯先生的门，说你是我来的——‘为了这封信。’”查理走上楼梯，下了楼梯，沿着过道——那天晚上，在我听着的耳朵里，那条老式房子周围的曲折道路似乎很长——于是回来，沿着过道，下楼梯，上楼梯，带着这封信。 “把它放在桌子上，查理，”我说。于是查理把它放在桌子上，然后上床睡觉了，我坐在那儿看着它，没有拿起它，想着很多事情。

I began with my overshadowed childhood, and passed through those timid days to the heavy time when my aunt lay dead, with her resolute face so cold and set, and when I was more solitary with Mrs. Rachael than if I had had no one in the world to speak to or to look at. I passed to the altered days when I was so blest as to find friends in all around me, and to be beloved. I came to the time when I first saw my dear girl and was received into that sisterly affection which was the grace and beauty of my life. I recalled the first bright gleam of welcome which had shone out of those very windows upon our expectant faces on that cold bright night, and which had never paled. I lived my happy life there over again, I went through my illness and recovery, I thought of myself so altered and of those around me so unchanged; and all this happiness shone like a light from one central figure, represented before me by the letter on the table.
我从我阴暗的童年开始，经历了那些胆怯的日子，一直到我姨妈去世的那段沉重的时光，她那坚定的脸是如此冷漠而坚定，而我和雷切尔夫人在一起比没有人在我身边时更加孤独。可以交谈或观察的世界。我经历了改变的日子，那时我很幸运能在周围找到朋友，并被爱着。当我第一次见到我亲爱的女孩时，我就被那种姐妹般的感情所接纳，这是我生命中的优雅和美丽。我记得在那个寒冷而明亮的夜晚，第一道明亮的欢迎光芒从那些窗户射出，照在我们满怀期待的脸上，而且从未褪色。我在那里重新过上了幸福的生活，经历了生病和康复，我认为自己发生了很大的变化，而周围的人却没有改变；所有这些幸福就像来自一个中心人物的光芒一样闪耀，在我面前，桌上的信代表了这一点。

I opened it and read it. It was so impressive in its love for me, and in the unselfish caution it gave me, and the consideration it showed for me in every word, that my eyes were too often blinded to read much at a time. But I read it through three times before I laid it down. I had thought beforehand that I knew its purport, and I did. It asked me, would I be the mistress of Bleak House.
我打开它并阅读了它。它对我的爱是如此令人印象深刻，它给我的无私的谨慎，以及它在每句话中对我的关怀，使我的眼睛常常被蒙蔽，无法一次读太多书。但我还是把它读了三遍才放下。我事先以为我知道它的要旨，而且我确实知道。它问我，我会成为《荒凉山庄》的女主人吗？

It was not a love letter, though it expressed so much love, but was written just as he would at any time have spoken to me. I saw his face, and heard his voice, and felt the influence of his kind protecting manner in every line. It addressed me as if our places were reversed, as if all the good deeds had been mine and all the feelings they had awakened his. It dwelt on my being young, and he past the prime of life; on his having attained a ripe age, while I was a child; on his writing to me with a silvered head, and knowing all this so well as to set it in full before me for mature deliberation. It told me that I would gain nothing by such a marriage and lose nothing by rejecting it, for no new relation could enhance the tenderness in which he held me, and whatever my decision was, he was certain it would be right. But he had considered this step anew since our late confidence and had decided on taking it, if it only served to show me through one poor instance that the whole world would readily unite to falsify the stern prediction of my childhood. I was the last to know what happiness I could bestow upon him, but of that he said no more, for I was always to remember that I owed him nothing and that he was my debtor, and for very much. He had often thought of our future, and foreseeing that the time must come, and fearing that it might come soon, when Ada (now very nearly of age) would leave us, and when our present mode of life must be broken up, had become accustomed to reflect on this proposal. Thus he made it. If I felt that I could ever give him the best right he could have to be my protector, and if I felt that I could happily and justly become the dear companion of his remaining life, superior to all lighter chances and changes than death, even then he could not have me bind myself irrevocably while this letter was yet so new to me, but even then I must have ample time for reconsideration. In that case, or in the opposite case, let him be unchanged in his old relation, in his old manner, in the old name by which I called him. And as to his bright Dame Durden and little housekeeper, she would ever be the same, he knew.
这不是一封情书，尽管它表达了如此多的爱，但它的写作方式就像他随时对我说话一样。我看到了他的脸，听到了他的声音，感受到了他的每一行仁慈的保护态度的影响。它对我说，好像我们的位置颠倒了，好像所有的善行都是我的，而它们的所有感情都唤醒了他的。写的是我还年轻，而他已经过了壮年；当我还是个孩子的时候，他已经成年了；他用银头写信给我，他对这一切了如指掌，并把它完整地摆在我面前，供我成熟思考。它告诉我，这样的婚姻不会给我带来任何好处，拒绝它也不会失去什么，因为没有任何新的关系可以增强他对我的温柔，无论我的决定是什么，他都确信它是正确的。但自从我们迟来的信心之后，他重新考虑了这一步骤，并决定采取这一步骤，只要它能通过一个可怜的例子向我表明，整个世界将很容易联合起来，推翻我童年时的严厉预言。我是最后一个知道我能给他带来什么幸福的人，但对此他没有再说什么，因为我总是记得我不欠他什么，而他是我的债务人，而且欠我很多。他经常想到我们的未来，预见到这一时刻一定会到来，并担心它很快就会到来，那时艾达（现在已经快成年了）将离开我们，我们目前的生活方式必须被打破，习惯于思考这个建议。他就这样做到了。 如果我觉得我可以给他最好的权利，他就可以成为我的保护者，如果我觉得我可以快乐而公正地成为他余生的亲爱伴侣，胜过所有比死亡更轻的机会和变化，甚至那么，当这封信对我来说还很陌生时，他就不能让我不可撤销地约束自己，但即便如此，我也必须有足够的时间重新考虑。在这种情况下，或者在相反的情况下，让他保持旧的关系，保持他的旧方式，保持我称呼他的旧名字。至于他那聪明的杜登夫人和小管家，她也永远不会变，他知道。

This was the substance of the letter, written throughout with a justice and a dignity as if he were indeed my responsible guardian impartially representing the proposal of a friend against whom in his integrity he stated the full case.
这就是这封信的实质内容，写得充满正义和尊严，就好像他确实是我负责任的监护人，公正地代表了一位朋友的提议，他以自己的正直陈述了整个案情。

But he did not hint to me that when I had been better looking he had had this same proceeding in his thoughts and had refrained from it. That when my old face was gone from me, and I had no attractions, he could love me just as well as in my fairer days. That the discovery of my birth gave him no shock. That his generosity rose above my disfigurement and my inheritance of shame. That the more I stood in need of such fidelity, the more firmly I might trust in him to the last.
但他并没有向我暗示，当我看起来更好时，他也曾有过同样的想法，但没有这样做。当我的旧容貌消失，我不再有吸引力时，他可以像我年轻时一样爱我。我出生的消息并没有让他感到震惊。他的慷慨超越了我的毁容和我继承的耻辱。我越需要这种忠诚，我就越能坚定地信任他直到最后。

But I knew it, I knew it well now. It came upon me as the close of the benignant history I had been pursuing, and I felt that I had but one thing to do. To devote my life to his happiness was to thank him poorly, and what had I wished for the other night but some new means of thanking him?
但我知道，我现在很清楚了。当我一直追求的良性历史结束时，我觉得我只有一件事要做。把我的一生奉献给他的幸福就是对他的谢意，而那天晚上我除了想一些新的方式来感谢他之外，还希望什么？

Still I cried very much, not only in the fullness of my heart after reading the letter, not only in the strangeness of the prospect— for it was strange though I had expected the contents—but as if something for which there was no name or distinct idea were indefinitely lost to me. I was very happy, very thankful, very hopeful; but I cried very much.
尽管如此，我还是哭得很厉害，不仅是因为读完这封信后内心的充实，不仅因为前景的陌生——因为虽然我已经预料到了内容，但它很奇怪——而且好像有什么东西没有名字或没有名字。我无限期地失去了独特的想法。我很高兴，很感恩，很希望；但我哭得很厉害。

By and by I went to my old glass. My eyes were red and swollen, and I said, ‘Oh, Esther, Esther, can that be you!’ I am afraid the face in the glass was going to cry again at this reproach, but I held up my finger at it, and it stopped.
渐渐地，我走向我的旧玻璃。我的眼睛又红又肿，我说：“哦，艾丝特，艾丝特，那是你吗！”我担心镜子里的脸会因为这种责备而再次哭泣，但我举起了手指，然后它就停了。

‘That is more like the composed look you comforted me with, my dear, when you showed me such a change!’ said I, beginning to let down my hair. ‘When you are mistress of Bleak House, you are to be as cheerful as a bird. In fact, you are always to be cheerful; so let us begin for once and for all.’
“亲爱的，当你向我展示这样的变化时，这更像是你安慰我的镇定神情！”我说道，开始放下头发。 ‘当你是荒凉山庄的女主人时，你要像小鸟一样快乐。事实上，你应该永远保持快乐；所以让我们一劳永逸地开始吧。

I went on with my hair now, quite comfortably. I sobbed a little still, but that was because I had been crying, not because I was crying then.
我现在继续梳理头发，很舒服。我仍然抽泣着，但那是因为我一直在哭，而不是因为我当时就哭了。

‘And so Esther, my dear, you are happy for life. Happy with your best friends, happy in your old home, happy in the power of doing a great deal of good, and happy in the undeserved love of the best of men.’
“所以埃丝特，亲爱的，你一生幸福。”与你最好的朋友在一起快乐，在你的老家快乐，因有能力做很多善事而快乐，并因最好的人不值得的爱而快乐。

I thought, all at once, if my guardian had married some one else, how should I have felt, and what should I have done! That would have been a change indeed. It presented my life in such a new and blank form that I rang my housekeeping keys and gave them a kiss before I laid them down in their basket again.
我突然想到，如果我的监护人嫁给了别人，我会有什么感受，我应该做什么！这确实是一个改变。它以一种全新的、空白的形式呈现了我的生活，我按响了家务钥匙，吻了它们，然后又把它们放进了篮子里。

Then I went on to think, as I dressed my hair before the glass, how often had I considered within myself that the deep traces of my illness and the circumstances of my birth were only new reasons why I should be busy, busy, busy—useful, amiable, serviceable, in all honest, unpretending ways. This was a good time, to be sure, to sit down morbidly and cry! As to its seeming at all strange to me at first (if that were any excuse for crying, which it was not) that I was one day to be the mistress of Bleak House, why should it seem strange? Other people had thought of such things, if I had not. ‘Don’t you remember, my plain dear,’ I asked myself, looking at the glass, ‘what Mrs. Woodcourt said before those scars were there about your marrying—‘
然后，当我在镜子前梳理头发时，我继续想，我有多少次在内心深处想到，我的疾病的深刻痕迹和我出生的环境只是我应该忙碌、忙碌、忙碌的新理由——有用的、和蔼可亲的、有用的，以所有诚实、朴实的方式。确实，这是一个病态地坐下来哭泣的好时机！至于我有一天会成为荒凉山庄的女主人，一开始对我来说似乎很奇怪（如果这是哭泣的借口，但事实并非如此），为什么会显得奇怪呢？如果我没有的话，其他人也想到过这些事情。 “你不记得吗，我亲爱的，”我看着镜子问自己，“在那些伤疤出现之前，伍德考特夫人说过关于你结婚的话——”

Perhaps the name brought them to my remembrance. The dried remains of the flowers. It would be better not to keep them now. They had only been preserved in memory of something wholly past and gone, but it would be better not to keep them now.
也许这个名字让我想起了他们。花干后的残骸。现在最好不要保留它们。保留它们只是为了纪念一些完全过去和消失的事情，但现在最好不要保留它们。

They were in a book, and it happened to be in the next room—our sitting-room, dividing Ada’s chamber from mine. I took a candle and went softly in to fetch it from its shelf. After I had it in my hand, I saw my beautiful darling, through the open door, lying asleep, and I stole in to kiss her.
它们在一本书里，而它恰好在隔壁房间——我们的起居室，将艾达的房间和我的房间分开。我拿起一支蜡烛，轻轻走进去，从架子上取出它。当我把它拿在手里后，我透过敞开的门看到了我美丽的宝贝，躺在床上睡着了，我偷偷走进去吻她。

It was weak in me, I know, and I could have no reason for crying; but I dropped a tear upon her dear face, and another, and another. Weaker than that, I took the withered flowers out and put them for a moment to her lips. I thought about her love for Richard, though, indeed, the flowers had nothing to do with that. Then I took them into my own room and burned them at the candle, and they were dust in an instant.
我知道，我的内心很脆弱，我没有理由哭泣。但我在她亲爱的脸上滴下一滴泪，一滴，又一滴。比这更虚弱的是，我把枯萎的花拿出来，放在她的唇边一会儿。我想到了她对理查德的爱，尽管事实上，鲜花与此无关。然后我把它们拿到自己的房间里，用蜡烛把它们烧掉，它们瞬间就化成了灰尘。

On entering the breakfast-room next morning, I found my guardian just as usual, quite as frank, as open, and free. There being not the least constraint in his manner, there was none (or I think there was none) in mine. I was with him several times in the course of the morning, in and out, when there was no one there, and I thought it not unlikely that he might speak to me about the letter, but he did not say a word.
第二天早上走进早餐室时，我发现我的监护人和往常一样，一样坦率、一样开放、一样自由。他的举止没有丝毫约束，但我的举止却没有（或者我认为没有）。早上我和他在一起好几次，进进出出，当时那里没有人，我认为他不太可能跟我谈论这封信，但他什么也没说。

So, on the next morning, and the next, and for at least a week, over which time Mr. Skimpole prolonged his stay. I expected, every day, that my guardian might speak to me about the letter, but he never did.
就这样，第二天早上，然后是下一个早上，至少一个星期，斯金波尔先生延长了他的逗留时间。我每天都期待我的监护人会和我谈论这封信，但他从来没有这样做。

I thought then, growing uneasy, that I ought to write an answer. I tried over and over again in my own room at night, but I could not write an answer that at all began like a good answer, so I thought each night I would wait one more day. And I waited seven more days, and he never said a word.
我当时觉得我应该写一个答案，心里越来越不安。晚上我在自己的房间里一遍又一遍地尝试，但我写不出一个开头像个好答案的答案，所以我每天晚上都想再等一天。我又等了七天，他还是一句话也没说。

At last, Mr. Skimpole having departed, we three were one afternoon going out for a ride; and I, being dressed before Ada and going down, came upon my guardian, with his back towards me, standing at the drawing-room window looking out.
最后，斯金波尔先生离开了，我们三个下午出去兜风。我在艾达面前穿好衣服，下楼时，遇到了我的监护人，他背对着我，站在客厅的窗户边向外看。

He turned on my coming in and said, smiling, ‘Aye, it’s you, little woman, is it?’ and looked out again.
当我进来时，他转身微笑着说道：“是的，是你，小女人，是吗？”然后又向外望去。

I had made up my mind to speak to him now. In short, I had come down on purpose. ‘Guardian,’ I said, rather hesitating and trembling, ‘when would you like to have the answer to the letter Charley came for?’
我现在已经决定要跟他说话了。简而言之，我是故意下来的。 “监护人，”我有些犹豫和颤抖地说，“你想什么时候得到查理来取信的答复？”

‘When it’s ready, my dear,’ he replied.
“准备好了，亲爱的，”他回答道。

‘I think it is ready,’ said I.
“我想已经准备好了，”我说。

‘Is Charley to bring it?’ he asked pleasantly.
“查理会带来吗？”他愉快地问道。

‘No. I have brought it myself, guardian,’ I returned.
'不。我自己带来的，监护人。”我回答道。

I put my two arms round his neck and kissed him, and he said was this the mistress of Bleak House, and I said yes; and it made no difference presently, and we all went out together, and I said nothing to my precious pet about it.
我用两只手臂搂住他的脖子，吻了他，他说这就是荒凉山庄的女主人，我说是的；眼下这没什么区别了，我们一起出去了，我没有对我的宝贝宠物说这件事。

CHAPTER XLV
第四十五章


In Trust
信任

One morning when I had done jingling about with my baskets of keys, as my beauty and I were walking round and round the garden I happened to turn my eyes towards the house and saw a long thin shadow going in which looked like Mr. Vholes. Ada had been telling me only that morning of her hopes that Richard might exhaust his ardour in the Chancery suit by being so very earnest in it; and therefore, not to damp my dear girl’s spirits, I said nothing about Mr. Vholes’s shadow.
一天早上，当我把一篮子钥匙叮当作响后，当我和我的美人在花园里绕着一圈又一圈散步时，我碰巧把目光转向房子，看到一个细长的影子走进来，看起来像沃尔斯先生。那天早上，艾达才告诉我，她希望理查德能在大法官诉讼中表现得如此认真，从而耗尽他的热情。因此，为了不打击我亲爱的女儿的情绪，我没有提及沃尔斯先生的影子。

Presently came Charley, lightly winding among the bushes and tripping along the paths, as rosy and pretty as one of Flora’s attendants instead of my maid, saying, ‘Oh, if you please, miss, would you step and speak to Mr. Jarndyce!’
不久查理就来了，他轻轻地在灌木丛中蜿蜒，沿着小路绊倒，脸色红润而美丽，就像弗洛拉的侍从而不是我的女仆，他说：“哦，小姐，如果您愿意的话，请您走上前去和贾迪斯先生说话吧！” '

It was one of Charley’s peculiarities that whenever she was charged with a message she always began to deliver it as soon as she beheld, at any distance, the person for whom it was intended. Therefore I saw Charley asking me in her usual form of words to ‘step and speak’ to Mr. Jarndyce long before I heard her. And when I did hear her, she had said it so often that she was out of breath.
查莉的一个特点是，每当她接到消息时，只要她在远处看到消息的传达者，她总是会立即开始传递消息。因此，早在我听到查理的声音之前，我就看到查理以她惯常的方式要求我“上前与贾迪斯先生说话”。当我真正听到她的声音时，她说这句话的次数太多了，以至于她上气不接下气。

I told Ada I would make haste back and inquired of Charley as we went in whether there was not a gentleman with Mr. Jarndyce. To which Charley, whose grammar, I confess to my shame, never did any credit to my educational powers, replied, ‘Yes, miss. Him as come down in the country with Mr. Richard.’
我告诉艾达我会赶紧回来，并在我们进去时询问查利是否有一位绅士和贾迪斯先生在一起。对于查理的语法，我承认我的耻辱，从来没有为我的教育能力做出任何贡献，他​​回答说：“是的，小姐。他和理查德先生一起来到乡下。

A more complete contrast than my guardian and Mr. Vholes I suppose there could not be. I found them looking at one another across a table, the one so open and the other so close, the one so broad and upright and the other so narrow and stooping, the one giving out what he had to say in such a rich ringing voice and the other keeping it in in such a cold-blooded, gasping, fish-like manner that I thought I never had seen two people so unmatched.
我想不可能有比我的监护人和沃尔斯先生更鲜明的对比了。我发现他们隔着一张桌子互相看着对方，一个如此开放，另一个如此接近，一个如此宽阔和直立，另一个如此狭窄和弯腰，一个用如此丰富而响亮的声音说出了他要说的话另一个则以冷血、气喘吁吁、鱼般的方式保持沉默，我想我从来没有见过两个人如此无与伦比。

‘You know Mr. Vholes, my dear,’ said my guardian. Not with the greatest urbanity, I must say.
“你认识沃尔斯先生，亲爱的，”我的监护人说。我必须说，这并不是最有礼貌的。

Mr. Vholes rose, gloved and buttoned up as usual, and seated himself again, just as he had seated himself beside Richard in the gig. Not having Richard to look at, he looked straight before him.
沃尔斯先生站了起来，像往常一样戴上手套，扣好纽扣，然后又坐下来，就像他坐在平底艇里理查德旁边一样。他没有看理查德，而是直视前方。

‘Mr. Vholes,’ said my guardian, eyeing his black figure as if he were a bird of ill omen, ‘has brought an ugly report of our most unfortunate Rick.’ Laying a marked emphasis on ‘most unfortunate’ as if the words were rather descriptive of his connexion with Mr. Vholes.
'先生。 “沃尔斯，”我的监护人看着他的黑色身影，仿佛他是一只不祥之鸟，“带来了一份关于我们最不幸的瑞克的丑陋报告。”他与沃尔斯先生的关系

I sat down between them; Mr. Vholes remained immovable, except that he secretly picked at one of the red pimples on his yellow face with his black glove.
我坐在他们中间；沃尔斯先生一动不动，只是用黑色手套偷偷地抠了黄色脸上的一颗红疙瘩。

‘And as Rick and you are happily good friends, I should like to know,’ said my guardian, ‘what you think, my dear. Would you be so good as to—as to speak up, Mr. Vholes?’
“因为里克和你是幸福的好朋友，我想知道，”我的监护人说，“你的想法是什么，亲爱的。”沃尔斯先生，您愿意——敢于大声说出来吗？

Doing anything but that, Mr. Vholes observed, ‘I have been saying that I have reason to know, Miss Summerson, as Mr. C.’s professional adviser, that Mr. C.’s circumstances are at the present moment in an embarrassed state. Not so much in point of amount as owing to the peculiar and pressing nature of liabilities Mr. C. has incurred and the means he has of liquidating or meeting the same. I have staved off many little matters for Mr. C., but there is a limit to staving off, and we have reached it. I have made some advances out of pocket to accommodate these unpleasantnesses, but I necessarily look to being repaid, for I do not pretend to be a man of capital, and I have a father to support in the Vale of Taunton, besides striving to realize some little independence for three dear girls at home. My apprehension is, Mr. C.’s circumstances being such, lest it should end in his obtaining leave to part with his commission, which at all events is desirable to be made known to his connexions.’
除此以外，沃尔斯先生观察到，“我一直在说，萨默森小姐，作为 C. 先生的专业顾问，我有理由知道，C. 先生目前的情况正处于危险之中。”尴尬的状态。与其说是金额，不如说是由于 C. 先生所承担的债务的特殊性和紧迫性以及他拥有清算或偿还债务的手段。我为C.先生回避了很多小事，但是回避是有限度的，而我们已经达到了这个限度。我已经自掏腰包预支了一些费用来应对这些不愉快的事情，但我必然希望得到回报，因为我不会假装自己是一个有资本的人，而且我除了努力实现汤顿谷的生活之外，还有一个父亲要供养。家里三个亲爱的女孩有一点独立的能力。我担心的是，C. 先生的情况如此，以免最终导致他获得许可放弃他的佣金，无论如何，最好让他的亲戚知道这一点。

Mr. Vholes, who had looked at me while speaking, here emerged into the silence he could hardly be said to have broken, so stifled was his tone, and looked before him again.
沃尔斯先生在说话时一直看着我，现在他的语气如此压抑，现在出现在他几乎不能说打破的沉默中，再次看着他的面前。

‘Imagine the poor fellow without even his present resource,’ said my guardian to me. ‘Yet what can I do? You know him, Esther. He would never accept of help from me now. To offer it or hint at it would be to drive him to an extremity, if nothing else did.’
“想象一下这个可怜的家伙连他现在的资源都没有，”我的监护人对我说。 ‘可是我能做什么呢？你认识他，埃丝特。他现在绝对不会接受我的帮助了。如果没有其他办法的话，提供或暗示这一点就会把他逼到绝境。

Mr. Vholes hereupon addressed me again.
沃尔斯先生于是再次对我讲话。

‘What Mr. Jarndyce remarks, miss, is no doubt the case, and is the difficulty. I do not see that anything is to be done, I do not say that anything is to be done. Far from it. I merely come down here under the seal of confidence and mention it in order that everything may be openly carried on and that it may not be said afterwards that everything was not openly carried on. My wish is that everything should be openly carried on. I desire to leave a good name behind me. If I consulted merely my own interests with Mr. C., I should not be here. So insurmountable, as you must well know, would be his objections. This is not a professional attendance. This can he charged to nobody. I have no interest in it except as a member of society and a father—AND a son,’ said Mr. Vholes, who had nearly forgotten that point.
“小姐，贾迪斯先生所说的毫无疑问是事实，也是困难所在。我没有看到需要做任何事情，我也没有说需要做任何事情。离得很远。我只是带着信心来到这里，提一下，以便一切都可以公开进行，以免事后说一切都没有公开进行。我的愿望是一切都应该公开进行。我渴望在身后留下一个好名字。如果我只是向 C. 先生咨询我自己的利益，我就不应该在这里。你一定很清楚，他的反对意见是难以克服的。这不是专业出席。他可以向任何人收取这个费用。 “除了作为社会成员、父亲和儿子，我对此没有任何兴趣。”弗霍尔斯先生说，他几乎忘记了这一点。

It appeared to us that Mr. Vholes said neither more nor less than the truth in intimating that he sought to divide the responsibility, such as it was, of knowing Richard’s situation. I could only suggest that I should go down to Deal, where Richard was then stationed, and see him, and try if it were possible to avert the worst. Without consulting Mr. Vholes on this point, I took my guardian aside to propose it, while Mr. Vholes gauntly stalked to the fire and warmed his funeral gloves.
在我们看来，沃尔斯先生暗示他试图分担了解理查德处境的责任，这句话一点也不假。我只能建议我应该去迪尔（理查德当时驻扎的地方）见见他，并尝试是否可以避免最坏的情况发生。在这一点上，我没有咨询沃尔斯先生，而是把我的监护人拉到一边提出了这个建议，而沃尔斯先生则面容憔悴地走到火边，温暖了他的葬礼手套。

The fatigue of the journey formed an immediate objection on my guardian’s part, but as I saw he had no other, and as I was only too happy to go, I got his consent. We had then merely to dispose of Mr. Vholes.
旅途的疲劳立即引起了我监护人的反对，但我看到他没有别的办法，而且我也很乐意去，所以我得到了他的同意。那么我们只需处理掉沃尔斯先生就可以了。

‘Well, sir,’ said Mr. Jarndyce, ‘Miss Summerson will communicate with Mr. Carstone, and you can only hope that his position may be yet retrievable. You will allow me to order you lunch after your journey, sir.’
“好吧，先生，”贾迪斯先生说，“萨默森小姐将会与卡斯通先生沟通，你只能希望他的职位还能恢复。”先生，您可以允许我在您旅途结束后为您订午餐。”

‘I thank you, Mr. Jarndyce,’ said Mr. Vholes, putting out his long black sleeve to check the ringing of the bell, ‘not any. I thank you, no, not a morsel. My digestion is much impaired, and I am but a poor knife and fork at any time. If I was to partake of solid food at this period of the day, I don’t know what the consequences might be. Everything having been openly carried on, sir, I will now with your permission take my leave.’
“谢谢你，贾迪斯先生，”沃尔斯先生说着，伸出黑色长袖，检查铃声，“没有。”我谢谢你，不，一点也不。我的消化能力很差，任何时候我都只是一把可怜的刀叉。如果我在一天中的这个时候吃固体食物，我不知道会产生什么后果。一切都已公开进行，先生，在您的允许下，我现在要离开了。”

‘And I would that you could take your leave, and we could all take our leave, Mr. Vholes,’ returned my guardian bitterly, ‘of a cause you know of.’
“我希望你可以离开，我们都可以离开，沃尔斯先生，”我的监护人痛苦地回答道，“出于你知道的原因。”

Mr. Vholes, whose black dye was so deep from head to foot that it had quite steamed before the fire, diffusing a very unpleasant perfume, made a short one-sided inclination of his head from the neck and slowly shook it.
沃尔斯先生从头到脚的黑色染料很深，以至于在火前已经冒出蒸汽，散发出一种非常难闻的香水味，他从脖子上稍微偏了一下头，慢慢地摇了摇头。

‘We whose ambition it is to be looked upon in the light of respectable practitioners, sir, can but put our shoulders to the wheel. We do it, sir. At least, I do it myself; and I wish to think well of my professional brethren, one and all. You are sensible of an obligation not to refer to me, miss, in communicating with Mr. C.?’
‘先生，我们的志向是要以受人尊敬的实践者的眼光来看待，我们只能把我们的肩膀放在方向盘上。我们做到了，先生。至少，我自己是这么做的；我希望对我的职业弟兄们有好感。小姐，在与 C 先生交流时，您是否意识到自己有义务不提及我？

I said I would be careful not to do it.
我说我会小心不要这样做。

‘Just so, miss. Good morning. Mr. Jarndyce, good morning, sir.’ Mr. Vholes put his dead glove, which scarcely seemed to have any hand in it, on my fingers, and then on my guardian’s fingers, and took his long thin shadow away. I thought of it on the outside of the coach, passing over all the sunny landscape between us and London, chilling the seed in the ground as it glided along.
「正是如此，小姐。早上好。贾迪斯先生，早上好，先生。”沃尔斯先生把他那只几乎没有人手放进去的手套戴在我的手指上，然后戴在我监护人的手指上，然后把他又长又瘦的影子拿开。我在车外想到了这一点，掠过我们和伦敦之间所有阳光明媚的风景，当种子滑行时，让土地里的种子感到寒冷。

Of course it became necessary to tell Ada where I was going and why I was going, and of course she was anxious and distressed. But she was too true to Richard to say anything but words of pity and words of excuse, and in a more loving spirit still—my dear devoted girl!—she wrote him a long letter, of which I took charge.
当然有必要告诉艾达我要去哪里以及为什么要去，她当然感到焦虑和苦恼。但她对理查德太忠诚了，除了怜悯和借口之外，她不会说任何别的话，而且仍然以一种更加慈爱的精神——我亲爱的忠诚的女孩！——她给他写了一封长信，由我负责。

Charley was to be my travelling companion, though I am sure I wanted none and would willingly have left her at home. We all went to London that afternoon, and finding two places in the mail, secured them. At our usual bed-time, Charley and I were rolling away seaward with the Kentish letters.
查理将成为我的旅伴，尽管我确信我不想要任何人，并且愿意把她留在家里。那天下午我们都去了伦敦，在邮件中找到了两个地方，确保了它们。在我们平常的就寝时间，查理和我带着肯特郡的信件向大海驶去。

It was a night’s journey in those coach times, but we had the mail to ourselves and did not find the night very tedious. It passed with me as I suppose it would with most people under such circumstances. At one while my journey looked hopeful, and at another hopeless. Now I thought I should do some good, and now I wondered how I could ever have supposed so. Now it seemed one of the most reasonable things in the world that I should have come, and now one of the most unreasonable. In what state I should find Richard, what I should say to him, and what he would say to me occupied my mind by turns with these two states of feeling; and the wheels seemed to play one tune (to which the burden of my guardian’s letter set itself) over and over again all night.
在当时的长途汽车时代，这是一个晚上的旅程，但我们有自己的邮件，并不觉得这个夜晚很乏味。我想，在这种情况下，大多数人也会这样。我的旅程有时看起来充满希望，有时却又充满希望。现在我想我应该做点好事，现在我想知道我怎么会这么想。现在看来，我应该来的事情是世界上最合理的事情之一，但现在却是最不合理的事情之一。我应该在什么状态下找到理查德，我应该对他说什么，他会对我说什么，这两种感觉轮番占据我的脑海；整个晚上，轮子似乎一遍又一遍地演奏着一种曲调（我监护人的信的负担本身就是这样的）。

At last we came into the narrow streets of Deal, and very gloomy they were upon a raw misty morning. The long flat beach, with its little irregular houses, wooden and brick, and its litter of capstans, and great boats, and sheds, and bare upright poles with tackle and blocks, and loose gravelly waste places overgrown with grass and weeds, wore as dull an appearance as any place I ever saw. The sea was heaving under a thick white fog; and nothing else was moving but a few early ropemakers, who, with the yarn twisted round their bodies, looked as if, tired of their present state of existence, they were spinning themselves into cordage.
最后，我们来到了迪尔的狭窄街道，在一个薄雾弥漫的早晨，街道显得非常阴暗。长长平坦的海滩上，有一些不规则的小房子，木制和砖砌的，还有绞盘的垃​​圾，大船，棚屋，光秃秃的直立杆子，上面有滑车和木块，还有长满青草和杂草的松散的砾石荒地，外观和我见过的任何地方一样暗淡。大海在浓浓的白雾下波涛汹涌。除了一些早期的制绳工外，没有其他东西在移动，他们把纱线缠绕在身上，看起来好像厌倦了目前的存在状态，正在将自己纺成绳索。

But when we got into a warm room in an excellent hotel and sat down, comfortably washed and dressed, to an early breakfast (for it was too late to think of going to bed), Deal began to look more cheerful. Our little room was like a ship’s cabin, and that delighted Charley very much. Then the fog began to rise like a curtain, and numbers of ships that we had had no idea were near appeared. I don’t know how many sail the waiter told us were then lying in the downs. Some of these vessels were of grand size—one was a large Indiaman just come home; and when the sun shone through the clouds, maktng silvery pools in the dark sea, the way in which these ships brightened, and shadowed, and changed, amid a bustle of boats pulling off from the shore to them and from them to the shore, and a general life and motion in themselves and everything around them, was most beautiful.
但当我们走进一家很棒的酒店温暖的房间，舒服地洗漱、穿好衣服，坐下来吃早饭时（因为已经太晚了，想睡觉了），迪尔开始显得更加高兴了。我们的小房间就像一个船舱，这让查理非常高兴。然后雾开始像幕布一样升起，许多我们不知道的船只出现在附近。我不知道服务员告诉我们当时有多少帆躺在丘陵中。其中一些船只体型巨大——一艘是一艘刚刚回国的印度船；另一艘是一艘刚回国的印度船。当阳光透过云层照射进来，在黑暗的大海中形成银色的水潭时，这些船只的方式在熙熙攘攘的船只中从岸边驶向它们，又从它们驶向岸边，变得明亮、阴影和变化，他们自己以及周围的一切的总体生活和运动是最美丽的。

The large Indiaman was our great attraction because she had come into the downs in the night. She was surrounded by boats, and we said how glad the people on board of her must be to come ashore. Charley was curious, too, about the voyage, and about the heat in India, and the serpents and the tigers; and as she picked up such information much faster than grammar, I told her what I knew on those points. I told her, too, how people in such voyages were sometimes wrecked and cast on rocks, where they were saved by the intrepidity and humanity of one man. And Charley asking how that could be, I told her how we knew at home of such a case.
这位身材高大的印度人对我们来说非常有吸引力，因为她是在夜间进入丘陵的。她被小船包围着，我们说船上的人上岸一定很高兴。查理也对这次航行、印度的酷热、蛇和老虎感到好奇。由于她掌握这些信息的速度比语法快得多，我告诉她我在这些方面所知道的。我还告诉她，在这样的航行中，人们有时会遭遇失事并被抛在岩石上，但一个人的无畏和人性将他们救了出来。查理问这是怎么回事，我告诉她我们在家里是怎么知道这样的案子的。

I had thought of sending Richard a note saying I was there, but it seemed so much better to go to him without preparation. As he lived in barracks I was a little doubtful whether this was feasible, but we went out to reconnoitre. Peeping in at the gate of the barrack-yard, we found everything very quiet at that time in the morning, and I asked a sergeant standing on the guardhousesteps where he lived. He sent a man before to show me, who went up some bare stairs, and knocked with his knuckles at a door, and left us.
我本来想给理查德发一张便条，说我在那里，但似乎没有准备就去找他要好得多。由于他住在军营里，我有点怀疑这是否可行，但我们还是出去侦察了。早上，我们从军营门口往里看，发现一切都很安静，我就向站在门卫台阶上的一名中士打听他住的地方。他之前派了一个人来给我看，他爬上一些光秃秃的楼梯，用指关节敲了敲门，然后就离开了我们。

‘Now then!’ cried Richard from within. So I left Charley in the little passage, and going on to the half-open door, said, ‘Can I come in, Richard? It’s only Dame Durden.’
“那么现在！”理查德在里面喊道。于是我把查理留在了小过道里，然后走到半开的门前说道：“理查德，我可以进来吗？”这只是德登夫人。

He was writing at a table, with a great confusion of clothes, tin cases, books, boots, brushes, and portmanteaus strewn all about the floor. He was only half dressed—in plain clothes, I observed, not in uniform—and his hair was unbrushed, and he looked as wild as his room. All this I saw after he had heartily welcomed me and I was seated near him, for he started upon hearing my voice and caught me in his arms in a moment. Dear Richard! He was ever the same to me. Down to—ah, poor poor fellow!—to the end, he never received me but with something of his old merry boyish manner.
他正在一张桌子上写字，地板上乱七八糟地散落着衣服、锡盒、书籍、靴子、刷子和手提箱。他只穿了半身衣服——据我观察，他穿着便衣，没有穿制服——头发也没梳，看起来和他的房间一样狂野。当他热情地欢迎我，我坐在他旁边时，我看到了这一切，因为他听到我的声音，立刻把我抱在怀里。亲爱的理查德！他对我来说永远都是一样的。直到——啊，可怜的家伙！——到最后，他除了带着他那种快乐的孩子气的态度之外，从来没有接待过我。

‘Good heaven, my dear little woman,’ said he, ‘how do you come here? Who could have thought of seeing you! Nothing the matter? Ada is well?’
“天哪，我亲爱的小女人，”他说，“你怎么到这里来了？谁能想到见到你！没什么事吗？艾达还好吗？

‘Quite well. Lovelier than ever, Richard!’
'很好。比以前更可爱了，理查德！”

‘Ah!’ he said, lenning back in his chair. ‘My poor cousin! I was writing to you, Esther.’
“啊！”他说着，向后靠回椅子上。 ‘我可怜的表弟！我正在写信给你，埃斯特。

So worn and haggard as he looked, even in the fullness of his handsome youth, leaning back in his chair and crushing the closely written sheet of paper in his hand!
他靠在椅子上，手里捏碎了写得密密麻麻的纸，尽管他正值英俊的青春年华，但看上去还是那么憔悴憔悴！

‘Have you been at the trouble of writing all that, and am I not to read it after all?’ I asked.
“你费尽心思写下这些，难道我就不读了吗？”我问。

‘Oh, my dear,’ he returned with a hopeless gesture. ‘You may read it in the whole room. It is all over here.’
“哦，亲爱的，”他做出绝望的手势。 “你可以在整个房间里读它。一切都在这里。

I mildly entreated him not to be despondent. I told him that I had heard by chance of his being in difficulty and had come to consult with him what could best be done.
我温和地恳求他不要沮丧。我告诉他，我偶然听说他遇到了困难，所以来和他商量一下最好的办法。

‘Like you, Esther, but useless, and so NOT like you!’ said he with a melancholy smile. ‘I am away on leave this day—should have been gone in another hour—and that is to smooth it over, for my selling out. Well! Let bygones be bygones. So this calling follows the rest. I only want to have been in the church to have made the round of all the professions.’
“像你一样，埃丝特，但没用，所以不像你！”他忧郁地微笑着说道。 “我今天休假了——本来应该再过一个小时就走——这是为了平息事情，因为我的卖光了。出色地！过去的就让它过去吧。所以这个呼召紧接着其余的呼召。我只想在教堂里完成所有的职业。

‘Richard,’ I urged, ‘it is not so hopeless as that?’
“理查德，”我催促道，“事情没有那么绝望吧？”

‘Esther,’ he returned, ‘it is indeed. I am just so near disgrace as that those who are put in authority over me (as the catechism goes) would far rather be without me than with me. And they are right. Apart from debts and duns and all such drawbacks, I am not fit even for this employment. I have no care, no mind, no heart, no soul, but for one thing. Why, if this bubble hadn’t broken now,’ he said, tearing the letter he had written into fragments and moodily casting them away, by driblets, ‘how could I have gone abroad? I must have been ordered abroad, but how could I have gone? How could I, with my experience of that thing, trust even Vholes unless I was at his back!’
“以斯帖，”他回答道，“确实如此。”我简直就是耻辱，以至于那些对我拥有权威的人（正如教义问答所言）宁愿离开我，也不愿和我在一起。他们是对的。除了债务、催款和所有这些缺点之外，我什至不适合这份工作。我没有关心，没有头脑，没有心，没有灵魂，但只有一件事。为什么，如果这个泡沫现在没有破裂，”他说着，将自己写的信撕成碎片，心情郁闷地把它们一滴一滴地扔掉，“我怎么能出国呢？我一定是被命令出国了，但我怎么可能去呢？以我对那件事的经历，我怎么可能相信Vholes，除非我在他背后！”

I suppose he knew by my face what I was about to say, but he caught the hand I had laid upon his arm and touched my own lips with it to prevent me from going on.
我想他从我的脸上就知道我要说什么，但他抓住了我放在他手臂上的手，并用它碰了碰我的嘴唇，阻止我继续说下去。

‘No, Dame Durden! Two subjects I forbid—must forbid. The first is John Jarndyce. The second, you know what. Call it madness, and I tell you I can’t help it now, and can’t be sane. But it is no such thing; it is the one object I have to pursue. It is a pity I ever was prevailed upon to turn out of my road for any other. It would be wisdom to abandon it now, after all the time, anxiety, and pains I have bestowed upon it! Oh, yes, true wisdom. It would be very agreeable, too, to some people; but I never will.’
“不，德登夫人！有两个话题我禁止——必须禁止。第一个是约翰·贾迪斯。第二个，你知道是什么。称之为疯狂，我告诉你我现在无法控制，无法保持理智。但事实并非如此。这是我必须追求的唯一目标。遗憾的是，我曾经被说服离开我的道路而选择其他道路。在我为它付出了那么多的时间、焦虑和痛苦之后，现在就放弃它是明智的！哦，是的，真正的智慧。对于某些人来说，这也是非常令人愉快的。但我永远不会。

He was in that mood in which I thought it best not to increase his determination (if anything could increase it) by opposing him. I took out Ada’s letter and put it in his hand.
他当时的心情是，我认为最好不要通过反对他来增强他的决心（如果有什么可以增强的话）。我拿出艾达的信，放在他手里。

‘Am I to read it now?’ he asked.
“我现在可以读吗？”他问道。

As I told him yes, he laid it on the table, and resting his head upon his hand, began. He had not read far when he rested his head upon his two hands—to hide his face from me. In a little while he rose as if the light were bad and went to the window. He finished reading it there, with his back towards me, and after he had finished and had folded it up, stood there for some minutes with the letter in his hand. When he came back to his chair, I saw tears in his eyes.
当我告诉他是的时，他把它放在桌子上，然后把头靠在手上，开始了。他还没读多久，就把头枕在两只手上——以遮挡我的脸。过了一会儿，他起身，仿佛光线不好，走到窗前。他背对着我读完了这封信，读完后把它折好，手里拿着信，在那里站了几分钟。当他回到椅子上时，我看到他眼里含着泪水。

‘Of course, Esther, you know what she says here?’ He spoke in a softened voice and kissed the letter as he asked me.
“当然，埃丝特，你知道她在这里说什么吗？”他用柔和的声音问道，一边吻着那封信，一边问我。

‘Yes, Richard.’
“是的，理查德。”

‘Offers me,’ he went on, tapping his foot upon the floor, ‘the little inheritance she is certain of so soon—just as little and as much as I have wasted—and begs and prays me to take it, set myself right with it, and remain in the service.’
“向我提供，”他继续说，用脚轻拍地板，“她这么快就确定了一点遗产——就像我浪费的一样少和一样多——恳求并祈祷我接受它，让自己改正过来。”带着它，并继续服役。

‘I know your welfare to be the dearest wish of her heart,’ said I. ‘And, oh, my dear Richard, Ada’s is a noble heart.’
“我知道你的幸福是她内心最深切的愿望，”我说，“而且，哦，亲爱的理查德，艾达有一颗崇高的心。”

‘I am sure it is. I—I wish I was dead!’
“我确信是这样。我——我希望我死了！

He went back to the window, and laying his arm across it, leaned his head down on his arm. It greatly affected me to see him so, but I hoped he might become more yielding, and I remained silent. My experience was very limited; I was not at all prepared for his rousing himself out of this emotion to a new sense of injury.
他回到窗边，将手臂放在窗上，把头靠在手臂上。看到他这样，我心里很受触动，但我希望他能变得更顺从一些，所以我保持沉默。我的经验非常有限；我完全没有准备好让他从这种情绪中醒来，产生新的伤害感。

‘And this is the heart that the same John Jarndyce, who is not otherwise to be mentioned between us, stepped in to estrange from me,’ said he indignantly. ‘And the dear girl makes me this generous offer from under the same John Jarndyce’s roof, and with the same John Jarndyce’s gracious consent and connivance, I dare say, as a new means of buying me off.’
“这正是约翰·贾迪斯（John Jardyce）介入，与我疏远的原因，”他愤怒地说。 “亲爱的女孩在同一个约翰·贾迪斯的屋檐下向我提出了这个慷慨的提议，并且得到了约翰·贾迪斯的慷慨同意和纵容，我敢说，这是一种收买我的新手段。”

‘Richard!’ I cried out, rising hastily. ‘I will not hear you say such shameful words!’ I was very angry with him indeed, for the first time in my life, but it only lasted a moment. When I saw his worn young face looking at me as if he were sorry, I put my hand on his shoulder and said, ‘If you please, my dear Richard, do not speak in such a tone to me. Consider!’
“理查德！”我喊道，急忙站起来。 “我不会听你说这么丢人的话！”我确实对他很生气，这是我有生以来第一次，但这种愤怒只持续了一会儿。当我看到他疲惫的年轻脸庞看着我，仿佛很抱歉时，我把手放在他的肩膀上说：“亲爱的理查德，请不要用这样的语气对我说话。”考虑！'

He blamed himself exceedingly and told me in the most generous manner that he had been very wrong and that he begged my pardon a thousand times. At that I laughed, but trembled a little too, for I was rather fluttered after being so fiery.
他非常自责，并以最慷慨的方式告诉我，他错了，他恳求我原谅一千次。我听了笑了，但也有点颤抖，因为我在如此火热之后心慌意乱。

‘To accept this offer, my dear Esther,’ said he, sitting down beside me and resuming our conversation, ‘—once more, pray, pray forgive me; I am deeply grieved—to accept my dearest cousin’s offer is, I need not say, impossible. Besides, I have letters and papers that I could show you which would convince you it is all over here. I have done with the red coat, believe me. But it is some satisfaction, in the midst of my troubles and perplexities, to know that I am pressing Ada’s interests in pressing my own. Vholes has his shoulder to the wheel, and he cannot help urging it on as much for her as for me, thank God!’
“接受这个提议，我亲爱的埃丝特，”他在我旁边坐下，继续我们的谈话，“——再一次，祈祷，祈祷原谅我；我深感悲痛——不用说，接受我最亲爱的表弟的提议是不可能的。此外，我可以给你看一些信件和文件，让你相信一切都在这里。相信我，我已经不再穿那件红外套了。但在我的烦恼和困惑中，当我知道我在推动艾达的利益同时也在推动我自己的利益时，我感到有些满足。沃尔斯肩负着方向盘，他情不自禁地为她和我敦促它，感谢上帝！

His sanguine hopes were rising within him and lighting up his features, but they made his face more sad to me than it had been before.
他乐观的希望在他内心升起，照亮了他的面容，但在我看来，这让他的脸比以前更加悲伤。

‘No, no!’ cried Richard exultingly. ‘If every farthing of Ada’s little fortune were mine, no part of it should be spent in retaining me in what I am not fit for, can take no interest in, and am weary of. It should be devoted to what promises a better return, and should be used where she has a larger stake. Don’t be uneasy for me! I shall now have only one thing on my mind, and Vholes and I will work it. I shall not be without means. Free of my commission, I shall be able to compound with some small usurers who will hear of nothing but their bond now—Vholes says so. I should have a balance in my favour anyway, but that would swell it. Come, come! You shall carry a letter to Ada from me, Esther, and you must both of you be more hopeful of me and not believe that I am quite cast away just yet, my dear.’
“不，不！”理查德兴高采烈地喊道。 “如果艾达的小财产里的每一分钱都是我的，那么它的任何一部分都不应该用来让我做我不适合、不感兴趣、厌倦的事情。它应该致力于那些承诺更好的回报，并且应该用于她拥有更大股份的地方。别为我不安！我现在脑子里只有一件事，沃尔斯和我会努力去做。我不会没有手段。不用我的佣金，我将能够与一些小高利贷者复合，他们现在除了债券之外什么也听不到——沃尔斯是这么说的。无论如何，我应该保持对我有利的平衡，但这会加剧平衡。来来！你应该带着我写给艾达的一封信，埃丝特，你们一定要对我更有希望，不要相信我现在已经完全被抛弃了，亲爱的。

I will not repeat what I said to Richard. I know it was tiresome, and nobody is to suppose for a moment that it was at all wise. It only came from my heart. He heard it patiently and feelingly, but I saw that on the two subjects he had reserved it was at present hopeless to make any representation to him. I saw too, and had experienced in this very interview, the sense of my guardian’s remark that it was even more mischievous to use persuasion with him than to leave him as he was.
我不会重复我对理查德说过的话。我知道这很烦人，而且没有人会认为这是明智的。它只来自我的内心。他耐心而深情地听着，但我看到，在他保留的两个主题上，目前不可能向他做出任何陈述。我也看到，并且在这次采访中体验到了我的监护人所说的感觉，即对他进行说服比让他保持原样更加恶作剧。

Therefore I was driven at last to asking Richard if he would mind convincing me that it really was all over there, as he had said, and that it was not his mere impression. He showed me without hesitation a correspondence making it quite plain that his retirement was arranged. I found, from what he told me, that Mr. Vholes had copies of these papers and had been in consultation with him throughout. Beyond ascertaining this, and having been the bearer of Ada’s letter, and being (as I was going to be) Richard’s companion back to London, I had done no good by coming down. Admitting this to myself with a reluctant heart, I said I would return to the hotel and wait until he joined me there, so he threw a cloak over his shoulders and saw me to the gate, and Charley and I went back along the beach.
因此，我最后不得不问理查德是否介意让我相信，正如他所说，一切都在那里，而这不仅仅是他的印象。他毫不犹豫地给我看了一封信，清楚地表明他的退休生活已经安排好了。从他告诉我的情况来看，我发现沃尔斯先生拥有这些文件的副本，并且自始至终都在与他协商。除了确定这一点之外，作为艾达信的携带者，并且作为（正如我即将成为的）理查德回到伦敦的同伴，我下来并没有什么好处。我怀着不情愿的心情向自己承认了这一点，说我要回旅馆，等他和我一起去，于是他把一件斗篷披在肩上，送我到门口，查理和我沿着海滩回去。

There was a concourse of people in one spot, surrounding some naval officers who were landing from a boat, and pressing about them with unusual interest. I said to Charley this would be one of the great Indiaman’s boats now, and we stopped to look.
一个地方聚集了一群人，围住了一些从船上登陆的海军军官，并以不同寻常的兴趣围住了他们。我对查理说，这将是伟大的印度人的一艘船，我们停下来看看。

The gentlemen came slowly up from the waterside, speaking goodhumouredly to each other and to the people around and glancing about them as if they were glad to be in England again. ‘Charley, Charley,’ said I, ‘come away!’ And I hurried on so swiftly that my little maid was surprised.
先生们慢慢地从水边走上来，彼此之间以及周围的人都幽默地交谈着，环顾四周，仿佛很高兴再次来到英国。 “查理，查理，”我说，“走开！”我走得如此之快，让我的小女仆感到惊讶。

It was not until we were shut up in our cabin-room and I had had time to take breath that I began to think why I had made such haste. In one of the sunburnt faces I had recognized Mr. Allan Woodcourt, and I had been afraid of his recognizing me. I had been unwilling that he should see my altered looks. I had been taken by surprise, and my courage had quite failed me.
直到我们被关在我们的小屋里，我有时间喘口气时，我才开始思考为什么我这么着急。在一张晒黑的脸上我认出了艾伦·伍德考特先生，我一直害怕他认出我。我一直不愿意让他看到我改变的容貌。我大吃一惊，我的勇气彻底丧失了。

But I knew this would not do, and I now said to myself, ‘My dear, there is no reason—there is and there can be no reason at all—why it should be worse for you now than it ever has been. What you were last month, you are to-day; you are no worse, you are no better. This is not your resolution; call it up, Esther, call it up!’ I was in a great tremble—with running—and at first was quite unable to calm myself; but I got better, and I was very glad to know it.
但我知道这样做是不行的，我现在对自己说：‘亲爱的，没有理由——没有理由，也不可能有理由——为什么你现在的处境比以往任何时候都更糟。上个月的你，今天的你；你没有更差，也没有更好。这不是你的决定；而是你的决定。喊起来，艾丝特，喊起来！’我因为跑步而浑身发抖，一开始根本无法让自己平静下来。但我好多了，我很高兴知道这一点。

The party came to the hotel. I heard them speaking on the staircase. I was sure it was the same gentlemen because I knew their voices again—I mean I knew Mr. Woodcourt’s. It would still have been a great relief to me to have gone away without making myself known, but I was determined not to do so. ‘No, my dear, no. No, no, no!’
一行人来到酒店。我听到他们在楼梯上说话。我确信那是同一位先生，因为我又听出了他们的声音——我的意思是我听得见伍德考特先生的声音。如果我能在不让别人知道自己的情况下离开，对我来说仍然是一种极大的解脱，但我决心不这样做。 ‘不，亲爱的，不。不不不！'

I untied my bonnet and put my veil half up—I think I mean half down, but it matters very little—and wrote on one of my cards that I happened to be there with Mr. Richard Carstone, and I sent it in to Mr. Woodcourt. He came immediately. I told him I was rejoiced to be by chance among the first to welcome him home to England. And I saw that he was very sorry for me.
我解开帽子，把面纱半举起来——我想我的意思是半垂下来，但这并不重要——并在一张卡片上写下我碰巧和理查德·卡斯通先生在一起，然后我把它寄给了先生。 .伍德考特。他立刻就来了。我告诉他，我很高兴能够成为第一批欢迎他回到英国的人之一。我看到他很为我难过。

‘You have been in shipwreck and peril since you left us, Mr. Woodcourt,’ said I, ‘but we can hardly call that a misfortune which enabled you to be so useful and so brave. We read of it with the truest interest. It first came to my knowledge through your old patient, poor Miss Flite, when I was recovering from my severe illness.’
“伍德考特先生，自从你离开我们以来，你一直处于海难和危险之中，”我说，“但我们很难说这是一种不幸，它使你变得如此有用和如此勇敢。我们怀着最真实的兴趣阅读它。我第一次知道这件事是通过你的老病人可怜的弗利特小姐，当时我正从重病中恢复过来。

‘Ah! Little Miss Flite!’ he said. ‘She lives the same life yet?’
'啊！ “弗利特小小姐！”他说。 “她还过着同样的生活吗？”

‘Just the same.’
“一样。”

I was so comfortable with myself now as not to mind the veil and to be able to put it aside.
我现在对自己感到很舒服，不再介意面纱，并且能够把它放在一边。

‘Her gratitude to you, Mr. Woodcourt, is delightful. She is a most affectionate creature, as I have reason to say.’
“伍德考特先生，她对您的感激之情令人高兴。正如我有理由说的，她是一个最深情的人。

‘You—you have found her so?’ he returned. ‘I—I am glad of that.’ He was so very sorry for me that he could scarcely speak.
“你——你就这样找到她了？”他回答道。 “我——我很高兴。”他为我感到非常难过，几乎说不出话来。

‘I assure you,’ said I, ‘that I was deeply touched by her sympathy and pleasure at the time I have referred to.’
“我向你保证，”我说，“在我提到的那一刻，我被她的同情和快乐深深感动了。”

‘I was grieved to hear that you had been very ill.’
“听说你病得很重，我感到很难过。”

‘I was very ill.’
“我病得很重。”

‘But you have quite recovered?’
“但是你已经完全康复了吗？”

‘I have quite recovered my health and my cheerfulness,’ said I. ‘You know how good my guardian is and what a happy life we lead, and I have everything to be thankful for and nothing in the world to desire.’
“我已经完全恢复了健康和快乐，”我说，“你知道我的监护人是多么善良，我们过着多么幸福的生活，我拥有一切值得感恩的东西，世界上没有什么可渴望的。”

I felt as if he had greater commiseration for me than I had ever had for myself. It inspired me with new fortitude and new calmness to find that it was I who was under the necessity of reassuring him. I spoke to him of his voyage out and home, and of his future plans, and of his probable return to India. He said that was very doubtful. He had not found himself more favoured by fortune there than here. He had gone out a poor ship’s surgeon and had come home nothing better. While we were talking, and when I was glad to believe that I had alleviated (if I may use such a term) the shock he had had in seeing me, Richard came in. He had heard downstairs who was with me, and they met with cordial pleasure.
我觉得他对我的同情比我对自己的同情还要多。我发现正是我需要让他放心，这激发了我新的毅力和新的冷静。我向他讲述了他的出境和回家之旅、他未来的计划以及他可能返回印度的情况。他说这是非常值得怀疑的。他发现自己在那里没有比这里更受财富青睐的了。他离开了一位可怜的船上外科医生，回家后情况也没有好转。当我们谈话时，当我很高兴地相信我已经减轻了（如果我可以使用这样的术语）他看到我时的震惊时，理查德进来了。他听到楼下有谁和我在一起，他们见面了诚挚地高兴。

I saw that after their first greetings were over, and when they spoke of Richard’s career, Mr. Woodcourt had a perception that all was not going well with him. He frequently glanced at his face as if there were something in it that gave him pain, and more than once he looked towards me as though he sought to ascertain whether I knew what the truth was. Yet Richard was in one of his sanguine states and in good spirits and was thoroughly pleased to see Mr. Woodcourt again, whom he had always liked.
我发现，在他们第一次寒暄结束后，当他们谈到理查德的职业生涯时，伍德考特先生有一种感觉，他一切都不顺利。他经常扫视自己的脸，仿佛脸上有什么东西让他感到痛苦，他不止一次地看着我，好像想确定我是否知道真相是什么。然而理查德却处于一种乐观的状态，精神也很好，他非常高兴再次见到他一直喜欢的伍德考特先生。

Richard proposed that we all should go to London together; but Mr. Woodcourt, having to remain by his ship a little longer, could not join us. He dined with us, however, at an early hour, and became so much more like what he used to be that I was still more at peace to think I had been able to soften his regrets. Yet his mind was not relieved of Richard. When the coach was almost ready and Richard ran down to look after his luggage, he spoke to me about him.
理查德提议我们一起去伦敦；但伍德考特先生不得不在船上多待一会儿，所以无法加入我们。然而，他一大早就和我们一起吃饭，变得更像以前的样子，所以我更安心地认为我已经能够减轻他的遗憾了。然而他的心并没有摆脱理查德。当教练快准备好时，理查德跑下来看行李，他向我谈到了他。

I was not sure that I had a right to lay his whole story open, but I referred in a few words to his estrangement from Mr Jarndyce and to his being entangled in the ill-fated Chancery suit. Mr. Woodcourt listened with interest and expressed his regret.
我不确定我是否有权把他的整个故事公开，但我用几句话提到了他与詹迪斯先生的疏远以及他卷入了命运多舛的大法官诉讼。伍德考特先生饶有兴趣地听着，并表示遗憾。

‘I saw you observe him rather closely,’ said I, ‘Do you think him so changed?’
“我看到你观察得很仔细，”我说，“你认为他有这么大的变化吗？”

‘He is changed,’ he returned, shaking his head.
“他变了。”他摇着头回答道。

I felt the blood rush into my face for the first time, but it was only an instantaneous emotion. I turned my head aside, and it was gone.
我第一次感觉到血液涌上我的脸，但这只是瞬间的情绪。我把头扭到一边，它就消失了。

‘It is not,’ said Mr. Woodcourt, ‘his being so much younger or older, or thinner or fatter, or paler or ruddier, as there being upon his face such a singular expression. I never saw so remarkable a look in a young person. One cannot say that it is all anxiety or all weariness; yet it is both, and like ungrown despair.’
伍德考特先生说，“并不是因为他脸上有这样一种奇特的表情，而是他年轻或年长、瘦或胖、苍白或红润。”我从来没有见过一个年轻人有如此非凡的外表。不能说全是焦虑，全是疲倦；但两者兼而有之，就像未成熟的绝望一样。

‘You do not think he is ill?’ said I.
“你不认为他病了吗？”我说。

No. He looked robust in body.
不，他看起来身体很健壮。

‘That he cannot be at peace in mind, we have too much reason to know,’ I proceeded. ‘Mr. Woodcourt, you are going to London?’
“他内心无法平静，我们有太多理由知道，”我继续说道。 '先生。伍德考特，你要去伦敦吗？

‘To-morrow or the next day.’
“明天或者后天。”

‘There is nothing Richard wants so much as a friend. He always liked you. Pray see him when you get there. Pray help him sometimes with your companionship if you can. You do not know of what service it might be. You cannot think how Ada, and Mr. Jarndyce, and even I—how we should all thank you, Mr. Woodcourt!’
“理查德最想要的莫过于朋友了。他一直喜欢你。祈祷你到达那里后能见到他。如果可以的话，请有时用你的陪伴来帮助他。您不知道它可能是什么服务。你无法想象艾达、贾迪斯先生，甚至我——我们应该多么感谢你，伍德考特先生！

‘Miss Summerson,’ he said, more moved than he had been from the first, ‘before heaven, I will be a true friend to him! I will accept him as a trust, and it shall be a sacred one!’
“萨默森小姐，”他说道，比一开始更加感动，“在天堂面前，我将成为他真正的朋友！”我会接受他作为我的信任，这将是一个神圣的信任！

‘God bless you!’ said I, with my eyes filling fast; but I thought they might, when it was not for myself. ‘Ada loves him—we all love him, but Ada loves him as we cannot. I will tell her what you say. Thank you, and God bless you, in her name!’
“愿上帝保佑你！”我的眼睛里充满了泪水，说道。但我认为他们可能会这么做，但不是为了我自己。 “艾达爱他——我们都爱他，但艾达爱他，我们却不能。”我会告诉她你说的话。谢谢你，愿上帝以她的名义保佑你！”

Richard came back as we finished exchanging these hurried words and gave me his arm to take me to the coach.
当我们匆忙地交谈完后，理查德回来了，他伸出手臂带我去教练处。

‘Woodcourt,’ he said, unconscious with what application, ‘pray let us meet in London!’
“伍德考特，”他无意识地说道，“请让我们在伦敦见面吧！”

‘Meet?’ returned the other. ‘I have scarcely a friend there now but you. Where shall I find you?’
“见面？”另一个人回答道。 “除了你，我现在在那里几乎没有朋友了。”我到哪里去找你？

‘Why, I must get a lodging of some sort,’ said Richard, pondering. ‘Say at Vholes’s, Symond’s Inn.’
“为什么，我必须找个住处，”理查德沉思着说道。 “比如在沃尔斯的西蒙旅馆。”

‘Good! Without loss of time.’
'好的！不浪费时间。

They shook hands heartily. When I was seated in the coach and Richard was yet standing in the street, Mr. Woodcourt laid his friendly hand on Richard’s shoulder and looked at me. I understood him and waved mine in thanks.
他们热烈握手。当我坐在车厢里，理查德还站在街上时，伍德考特先生友好地将手放在理查德的肩膀上，看着我。我明白了他的意思，并挥手致谢。

And in his last look as we drove away, I saw that he was very sorry for me. I was glad to see it. I felt for my old self as the dead may feel if they ever revisit these scenes. I was glad to be tenderly remembered, to be gently pitied, not to be quite forgotten.
当我们开车离开时，从他最后的眼神中，我看到他对我感到非常抱歉。我很高兴看到它。我对过去的自己的感觉就像死者重温这些场景时可能会有的感觉一样。我很高兴被温柔地记住，被温柔地怜悯，而不是被完全遗忘。

CHAPTER XLVI
第四十六章


Stop Him!
阻止他！

Darkness rests upon Tom-All-Alone’s. Dilating and dilating since the sun went down last night, it has gradually swelled until it fills every void in the place. For a time there were some dungeon lights burning, as the lamp of life hums in Tom-all-Alone’s, heavily, heavily, in the nauseous air, and winking—as that lamp, too, winks in Tom-all-Alone’s—at many horrible things. But they are blotted out. The moon has eyed Tom with a dull cold stare, as admitting some puny emulation of herself in his desert region unfit for life and blasted by volcanic fires; but she has passed on and is gone. The blackest nightmare in the infernal stables grazes on Tom-all-Alone’s, and Tom is fast asleep.
黑暗降临在汤姆孤身一人的身上。自从昨晚太阳落山之后，它就一直膨胀啊膨胀，直到填满了这里的每一个空隙。有一段时间，地牢里的灯火在燃烧，生命之灯在令人作呕的空气中沉重地、沉重地嗡嗡作响，并且眨着眼睛——就像那盏灯在汤姆独自屋里眨着——许多可怕的事情。但它们被抹掉了。月亮用冷漠的眼神看着汤姆，承认自己在汤姆的沙漠地区做了一些微不足道的模仿，那里不适合生命，而且被火山大火烧毁了。但她已经去世了。地狱马厩中最黑暗的噩梦袭击了孤身一人的汤姆，而汤姆正在熟睡。

Much mighty speech-making there has been, both in and out of Parliament, concerning Tom, and much wrathful disputation how Tom shall be got right. Whether he shall be put into the main road by constables, or by beadles, or by bell-ringing, or by force of figures, or by correct principles of taste, or by high church, or by low church, or by no church; whether he shall be set to splitting trusses of polemical straws with the crooked knife of his mind or whether he shall be put to stone-breaking instead. In the midst of which dust and noise there is but one thing perfectly clear, to wit, that Tom only may and can, or shall and will, be reclaimed according to somebody’s theory but nobody’s practice. And in the hopeful meantime, Tom goes to perdition head foremost in his old determined spirit.
议会内外就汤姆进行了许多激烈的演讲，并就如何纠正汤姆的问题进行了激烈的争论。是否应该通过警察，或通过执事，或通过敲钟，或通过数字的力量，或通过正确的品味原则，或通过高级教会，或通过低级教会，或不通过教会，将他带入主干道；是用他头脑里的弯刀劈开好争论的稻草，还是用石头砸碎他。在尘土和噪音之中，只有一件事非常清楚，那就是，汤姆只能根据某人的理论而不是任何人的实践，可能并且能够，或者应该并且将会被回收。就在充满希望的同时，汤姆以他昔日坚定的精神走向灭亡。

But he has his revenge. Even the winds are his messengers, and they serve him in these hours of darkness. There is not a drop of Tom’s corrupted blood but propagates infection and contagion somewhere. It shall pollute, this very night, the choice stream (in which chemists on analysis would find the genuine nobility) of a Norman house, and his Grace shall not be able to say nay to the infamous alliance. There is not an atom of Tom’s slime, not a cubic inch of any pestilential gas in which he lives, not one obscenity or degradation about him, not an ignorance, not a wickedness, not a brutality of his committing, but shall work its retribution through every order of society up to the proudest of the proud and to the highest of the high. Verily, what with tainting, plundering, and spoiling, Tom has his revenge.
但他有他的复仇。甚至风也是他的使者，在黑暗的时刻为他服务。汤姆没有一滴腐败的血液，但却在某处传播感染和传染病。就在今晚，它将污染诺曼家族的精选流（化学家在分析中会发现真正的贵族），而陛下将无法拒绝这个臭名昭著的联盟。汤姆身上没有一粒粘液，他生活的地方没有一立方英寸的瘟疫气体，他身上没有任何淫秽或堕落，没有无知，没有邪恶，没有他的残忍行为，但都将受到报应贯穿社会的各个阶层，直到最骄傲的人以及最高层的人。确实，汤姆通过玷污、掠夺和破坏进行了报复。

It is a moot point whether Tom-all-Alone’s be uglier by day or by night, but on the argument that the more that is seen of it the more shocking it must be, and that no part of it left to the imagination is at all likely to be made so bad as the reality, day carries it. The day begins to break now; and in truth it might be better for the national glory even that the sun should sometimes set upon the British dominions than that it should ever rise upon so vile a wonder as Tom.
《汤姆孤身一人》是白天更丑还是晚上更丑，这是一个有争议的问题，但根据这样的论点，它看得越多，它一定越令人震惊，而且它的任何部分都没有留给想象的余地。一切都可能变得像现实一样糟糕，白天就会发生。天已经亮了；事实上，对于国家荣耀来说，即使太阳有时在英国的领土上落下，也比在汤姆这样卑鄙的奇迹上升起更好。

A brown sunburnt gentleman, who appears in some inaptitude for sleep to be wandering abroad rather than counting the hours on a restless pillow, strolls hitherward at this quiet time. Attracted by curiosity, he often pauses and looks about him, up and down the miserable by-ways. Nor is he merely curious, for in his bright dark eye there is compassionate interest; and as he looks here and there, he seems to understand such wretchedness and to have studied it before.
一位皮肤黝黑、皮肤晒黑的绅士，在这个安静的时刻向这里漫步，他似乎不太适合睡觉，而是在国外徘徊，而不是在不安的枕头上数着时间。受到好奇心的吸引，他经常停下来环顾四周，在悲惨的小路上来回走动。他不仅仅是好奇，因为他那双明亮的黑眼睛里流露出富有同情心的兴趣。当他四处张望时，他似乎了解这种不幸，并且以前就研究过它。

On the banks of the stagnant channel of mud which is the main street of Tom-all-Alone’s, nothing is to be seen but the crazy houses, shut up and silent. No waking creature save himself appears except in one direction, where he sees the solitary figure of a woman sitting on a door-step. He walks that way. Approaching, he observes that she has journeyed a long distance and is footsore and travel-stained. She sits on the door-step in the manner of one who is waiting, with her elbow on her knee and her head upon her hand. Beside her is a canvas bag, or bundle, she has carried. She is dozing probably, for she gives no heed to his steps as he comes toward her.
在汤姆独自的主街那条停滞的泥泞河道的岸边，除了那些疯狂的房子之外什么也看不见，它们紧闭而寂静。除了他自己之外，没有任何醒着的生物出现，除了在一个方向，他看到一个女人孤独的身影坐在门口的台阶上。他就那样走。走近一看，他发现她已经走了很长的路，脚痛，身上沾满了旅行的痕迹。她以等待的方式坐在门口台阶上，肘部放在膝盖上，头枕在手上。她旁边是她随身携带的一个帆布包或包裹。她可能正在打瞌睡，因为当他向她走来时，她没有注意到他的脚步。

The broken footway is so narrow that when Allan Woodcourt comes to where the woman sits, he has to turn into the road to pass her. Looking down at her face, his eye meets hers, and he stops.
破损的人行道非常狭窄，当艾伦·伍德考特来到那位女士坐的地方时，他必须拐进马路才能经过她。低头看着她的脸，他的目光与她的目光相遇，然后他停了下来。

‘What is the matter?’
'什么事？'

‘Nothing, sir.’
“没什么，先生。”

‘Can’t you make them hear? Do you want to be let in?’
‘你不能让他们听到吗？你想进去吗？

‘I’m walting till they get up at another house—a lodging-house— not here,’ the woman patiently returns. ‘I’m waiting here because there will be sun here presently to warm me.’
“我一直在走，直到他们在另一所房子——一间寄宿处——起床，而不是在这里，”女人耐心地回答道。 “我在这里等，因为这里很快就会有阳光来温暖我。”

‘I am afraid you are tired. I am sorry to see you sitting in the street.’
‘我担心你累了。我很遗憾看到你坐在街上。

‘Thank you, sir. It don’t matter.’
'谢谢你，先生。没关系。

A habit in him of speaking to the poor and of avoiding patronage or condescension or childishness (which is the favourite device, many people deeming it quite a subtlety to talk to them like little spelling books) has put him on good terms with the woman easily.
他习惯于与穷人交谈，避免居高临下、居高临下或幼稚（这是他最喜欢的手段，许多人认为像小拼写书一样与他们交谈是一种微妙的做法），这使他很容易与女人建立良好的关系。 。

‘Let me look at your forehead,’ he says, bending down. ‘I am a doctor. Don’t be afraid. I wouldn’t hurt you for the world.’
“让我看看你的额头，”他弯下腰说道。 '我是医生。不要害怕。我绝对不会伤害你。

He knows that by touching her with his skilful and accustomed hand he can soothe her yet more readily. She makes a slight objection, saying, ‘It’s nothing”; but he has scarcely laid his fingers on the wounded place when she lifts it up to the light.
他知道，用他熟练而习惯的手抚摸她，可以更轻松地安抚她。她略微反对说：“没什么”；但他的手指刚放在受伤的地方，她就把它举到了光亮处。

‘Aye! A bad bruise, and the skin sadly broken. This must be very sore.’
‘是啊！严重的瘀伤，皮肤也破碎了。这一定很痛。”

‘It do ache a little, sir,’ returns the woman with a started tear upon her cheek.
“确实有点疼，先生，”女人回答道，脸颊上流下了泪水。

‘Let me try to make it more comfortable. My handkerchief won’t hurt you.’
“让我试着让它变得更舒服。我的手帕不会伤害你。”

‘Oh, dear no, sir, I’m sure of that!’
“哦，亲爱的，不，先生，我确信这一点！”

He cleanses the injured place and dries it, and having carefully examined it and gently pressed it with the palm of his hand, takes a small case from his pocket, dresses it, and binds it up. While he is thus employed, he says, after laughing at his establishing a surgery in the street, ‘And so your husband is a brickmaker?’
他将受伤的地方清洗干净，擦干，仔细检查后，用手掌轻轻按了一下，从口袋里掏出一个小盒子，包扎起来。当他这样工作时，他嘲笑自己在街上开办了一家诊所后说道，“所以你的丈夫是一名砖匠？”

‘How do you know that, sir?’ asks the woman, astonished.
“先生，你怎么知道？”女人惊讶地问道。

‘Why, I suppose so from the colour of the clay upon your bag and on your dress. And I know brickmakers go about working at piecework in different places. And I am sorry to say I have known them cruel to their wives too.’
‘哎呀，从你包上和衣服上粘土的颜色来看，我猜是这样的。我知道制砖工人在不同的地方进行计件工作。我很遗憾地说，我也知道他们对自己的妻子也很残忍。

The woman hastily lifts up her eyes as if she would deny that her injury is referable to such a cause. But feeling the hand upon her forehead, and seeing his busy and composed face, she quietly drops them again.
女人急忙抬起眼睛，似乎要否认她的受伤是由这样的原因造成的。但感觉到放在她额头上的手，看到他忙碌而平静的脸，她又悄悄地放下了它们。

‘Where is he now?’ asks the surgeon.
“他现在在哪里？”外科医生问道。

‘He got into trouble last night, sir; but he’ll look for me at the lodging-house.’
“他昨晚遇到麻烦了，先生；但他会去寄宿处找我。”
