‘He will get into worse trouble if he often misuses his large and heavy hand as he has misused it here. But you forgive him, brutal as he is, and I say no more of him, except that I wish he deserved it. You have no young child?’
“如果他经常滥用他那只又大又重的手，他会遇到更严重的麻烦，就像他在这里滥用它一样。但你原谅了他，尽管他很残酷，我不再谈论他，只是我希望他罪有应得。你没有小孩吗？

The woman shakes her head. ‘One as I calls mine, sir, but it’s Liz’s.’
女人摇摇头。 “我称之为我的，先生，但它是莉兹的。”

‘Your own is dead. I see! Poor little thing!’
‘你自己的人已经死了。我懂了！可怜的小东西！'

By this time he has finished and is putting up his case. ‘I suppose you have some settled home. Is it far from here?’ he asks, good-humouredly making light of what he has done as she gets up and curtsys.
此时他已经完成并正在提出他的案子。 “我想你已经有一个安定的家了。离这里远吗？”他问道，当她起身行屈膝礼时，他幽默地对他所做的事情轻描淡写。

‘It’s a good two or three and twenty mile from here, sir. At Saint Albans. You know Saint Albans, sir? I thought you gave a start like, as if you did.’
“距离这里有两三二十英里，长官。在圣奥尔本斯。先生，你知道圣奥尔本斯吗？我以为你吓了一跳，就好像你确实那样。

‘Yes, I know something of it. And now I will ask you a question in return. Have you money for your lodging?’
“是的，我知道一些事情。现在我将问你一个问题作为回报。你有钱住吗？

‘Yes, sir,’ she says, ‘really and truly.’ And she shows it. He tells her, in acknowledgment of her many subdued thanks, that she is very welcome, gives her good day, and walks away. Tom-allAlone’s is still asleep, and nothing is astir.
“是的，先生，”她说，“真的，真的。”她也表现出了这一点。他向她表示非常欢迎，并向她道了一声美好的问候，然后就离开了。汤姆独自还在睡觉，没有任何动静。

Yes, something is! As he retraces his way to the point from which he descried the woman at a distance sitting on the step, he sees a ragged figure coming very cautiously along, crouching close to the soiled walls—which the wretchedest figure might as well avoid—and furtively thrusting a hand before it. It is the figure of a youth whose face is hollow and whose eyes have an emaciated glare. He is so intent on getting along unseen that even the apparition of a stranger in whole garments does not tempt him to look back. He shades his face with his ragged elbow as he passes on the other side of the way, and goes shrinking and creeping on with his anxious hand before him and his shapeless clothes hanging in shreds. Clothes made for what purpose, or of what material, it would be impossible to say. They look, in colour and in substance, like a bundle of rank leaves of swampy growth that rotted long ago.
是的，有东西！当他原路返回，看到远处坐在台阶上的那个女人时，他看到一个衣衫褴褛的人影非常小心地走过来，蹲在靠近肮脏的墙壁的地方——最可怜的人也最好避开——并偷偷地走来。将一只手伸到它面前。那是一个面容空洞，双目憔悴的青年身影。他如此热衷于在不被人看见的情况下相处，即使是一个穿着整件衣服的陌生人的出现也不会诱惑他回头。当他从路的另一边经过时，他用破烂的手肘遮住脸，然后畏缩着，蠕动着，焦急的手放在面前，不成形的衣服挂在了碎片上。衣服是为了什么目的而制作的，或者是由什么材料制成的，这是不可能说的。它们的颜色和实质看起来就像一束很久以前就腐烂的沼泽植物的叶子。

Allan Woodcourt pauses to look after him and note all this, with a shadowy belief that he has seen the boy before. He cannot recall how or where, but there is some association in his mind with such a form. He imagines that he must have seen it in some hospital or refuge, still, cannot make out why it comes with any special force on his remembrance.
艾伦·伍德考特停下来照顾他，记下这一切，隐约相信他以前见过这个男孩。他不记得如何或在哪里，但他的脑海中与这样的形式有某种联系。他想象他一定在某家医院或避难所见过它，但仍然无法弄清楚为什么它对他的记忆有任何特殊的影响力。

He is gradually emerging from Tom-all-Alone’s in the morning light, thinking about it, when he hears running feet behind him, and looking round, sees the boy scouring towards him at great speed, followed by the woman.
他在晨光中逐渐从汤姆独自的家中走出来，想着这件事，这时他听到身后有脚步声，他环顾四周，看到男孩以极快的速度向他冲来，女人紧随其后。

‘Stop him, stop him!’ cries the woman, almost breath less. ‘Stop him, sir!’
“阻止他，阻止他！”女人几乎喘不过气来喊道。 “阻止他，先生！”

He darts across the road into the boy’s path, but the boy is quicker than he, makes a curve, ducks, dives under his hands, comes up half-a-dozen yards beyond him, and scours away again. Still the woman follows, crying, ‘Stop him, sir, pray stop him!’ Allan, not knowing but that he has just robbed her of her money, follows in chase and runs so hard that he runs the boy down a dozen times, but each time he repeats the curve, the duck, the dive, and scours away again. To strike at him on any of these occasions would be to fell and disable him, but the pursuer cannot resolve to do that, and so the grimly ridiculous pursuit continues. At last the fugitive, hard-pressed, takes to a narrow passage and a court which has no thoroughfare. Here, against a hoarding of decaying timber, he is brought to bay and tumbles down, lying gasping at his pursuer, who stands and gasps at him until the woman comes up.
他冲过马路，进入男孩的道路，但男孩比他更快，拐了一个弯，躲过他的手，来到距离他六码远的地方，然后再次冲走。那个女人仍然跟在后面，哭喊着：“阻止他，先生，求你阻止他！”艾伦不知道他刚刚抢了她的钱，他紧随其后，拼命奔跑，结果把他撞倒了十几次。但每次他都会重复转弯、鸭子、俯冲，然后再次冲走。在任何这些情况下攻击他都会使他摔倒并致残，但追击者无法下定决心这样做，因此这种极其荒谬的追击仍在继续。最后，逃亡者在困境中逃到了一条狭窄的通道和一个没有大道的法庭。在这里，他靠着一堆腐烂的木材，被逼到了海湾，摔倒了，躺在地上，对着他的追捕者喘着粗气，后者站着，对着他喘着粗气，直到那个女人出现。

‘Oh, you, Jo!’ cries the woman. ‘What? I have found you at last!’
“哦，你，乔！”女人喊道。 '什么？我终于找到你了！

‘Jo,’ repeats Allan, looking at him with attention, ‘Jo! Stay. To be sure! I recollect this lad some time ago being brought before the coroner.’
“乔，”艾伦重复道，专注地看着他，“乔！停留。为了确定！我记得这个小伙子不久前被带到验尸官面前。

‘Yes, I see you once afore at the inkwhich,’ whimpers Jo. ‘What of that? Can’t you never let such an unfortnet as me alone? An’t I unfortnet enough for you yet? How unfortnet do you want me fur to be? I’ve been a-chivied and a-chivied, fust by one on you and nixt by another on you, till I’m worritted to skins and bones. The inkwhich warn’t MY fault. I done nothink. He wos wery good to me, he wos; he wos the only one I knowed to speak to, as ever come across my crossing. It ain’t wery likely I should want him to be inkwhiched. I only wish I wos, myself. I don’t know why I don’t go and make a hole in the water, I’m sure I don’t.’
“是的，我以前在墨水店见过你一次，”乔呜咽道。 ‘那又怎样？难道你就不能放过我这样一个不幸的人吗？我对你来说还不够不幸吗？你想让我变得多么不幸？我对你狠狠地狠狠地狠狠地狠狠地狠狠地狠狠地狠狠地攻击一次，然后又再一次地对你狠狠地攻击，直到我焦急万分。墨水这不是我的错。我什么也没做。他对我很好，他很好；他是我认识的唯一一个可以与之交谈的人，就像以前穿过我的路口时一样。我不太可能希望他被墨水污染。我只希望我自己。我不知道为什么我不去在水里打一个洞，我确信我不会。

He says it with such a pitiable air, and his grimy tears appear so real, and he lies in the corner up against the hoarding so like a growth of fungus or any unwholesome excrescence produced there in neglect and impurity, that Allan Woodcourt is softened towards him. He says to the woman, ‘Miserable creature, what has he done?’
他用一种可怜的神情说这句话，他肮脏的眼泪显得那么真实，他躺在角落里靠着围板，就像真菌的生长或任何不健康的赘生物在忽视和杂质中产生的，艾伦·伍德考特对艾伦·伍德考特的态度变得软化了。他。他对女人说：“可怜的家伙，他做了什么？”

To which she only replies, shaking her head at the prostrate figure more amazedly than angrily, ‘Oh, you Jo, you Jo. I have found you at last!’
她只是回答道，对着倒下的人摇摇头，与其说是愤怒，不如说是惊讶，“哦，你乔，你乔。”我终于找到你了！

‘What has he done?’ says Allan. ‘Has he robbed you?’
“他做了什么？”艾伦说。 “他抢劫了你吗？”

‘No, sir, no. Robbed me? He did nothing but what was kind-hearted by me, and that’s the wonder of it.’
‘不，先生，不。抢我的？他除了我的善意之外什么也没做，这就是奇迹。”

Allan looks from Jo to the woman, and from the woman to Jo, waiting for one of them to unravel the riddle.
艾伦看看乔，看看那个女人，又看看那个女人，又看看乔，等待他们中的一个人解开谜团。

‘But he was along with me, sir,’ says the woman. ‘Oh, you Jo! He was along with me, sir, down at Saint Albans, ill, and a young lady, Lord bless her for a good friend to me, took pity on him when I durstn’t, and took him home—‘
“但他和我在一起，先生，”女人说。 ‘哦，你乔！先生，他和我一起在圣奥尔本斯生病了，一位年轻的女士，上帝保佑她，她是我的好朋友，在我不敢的时候怜悯他，带他回家了——”

Allan shrinks back from him with a sudden horror.
艾伦突然感到恐惧，从他身边退缩了。

‘Yes, sir, yes. Took him home, and made him comfortable, and like a thankless monster he ran away in the night and never has been seen or heard of since till I set eyes on him just now. And that young lady that was such a pretty dear caught his illness, lost her beautiful looks, and wouldn’t hardly be known for the same young lady now if it wasn’t for her angel temper, and her pretty shape, and her sweet voice. Do you know it? You ungrateful wretch, do you know that this is all along of you and of her goodness to you?’ demands the woman, beginning to rage at him as she recalls it and breaking into passionate tears.
‘是的，先生，是的。带他回家，让他舒服点，然后他像一个忘恩负义的怪物一样连夜逃跑，从此再也没有人见过或听说过他，直到我刚才看到他。而那个那么可爱的小姐却得了病，失去了美丽的容颜，如果不是她天使般的脾气，漂亮的身材，还有她的甜美，现在也很难为同一个小姐所熟知。嗓音。你知道吗？你这个忘恩负义的坏蛋，你知道这都是你和她对你的好吗？”女人问道，回忆起这件事，她开始对他发怒，并热泪盈眶。

The boy, in rough sort stunned by what he hears, falls to smearing his dirty forehead with his dirty palm, and to staring at the ground, and to shaking from head to foot until the crazy hoarding against which he leans rattles.
男孩被他听到的内容惊呆了，用肮脏的手掌涂抹了肮脏的额头，盯着地面，从头到脚摇晃着，直到他靠着的疯狂的木板嘎嘎作响。

Allan restrains the woman, merely by a quiet gesture, but effectually.
艾伦只是用一个安静的姿势制止了那个女人，但很有效。

‘Richard told me—‘ He falters. ‘I mean, I have heard of this— don’t mind me for a moment, I will speak presently.’
“理查德告诉我——”他支吾着。 “我的意思是，我听说过这个——暂时别介意我，我马上就说。”

He turns away and stands for a while looking out at the covered passage. When he comes back, he has recovered his composure, except that he contends against an avoidance of the boy, which is so very remarkable that it absorbs the woman’s attention.
他转过身来，站了一会儿，看着外面有遮盖的通道。当他回来时，他已经恢复了平静，只是他竭力回避男孩，这一点非常引人注目，以至于吸引了女人的注意力。

‘You hear what she says. But get up, get up!’
‘你听她说的话。但是站起来，站起来！

Jo, shaking and chattering, slowly rises and stands, after the manner of his tribe in a difficulty, sideways against the hoarding, resting one of his high shoulders against it and covertly rubbing his right hand over his left and his left foot over his right.
乔颤抖着，喋喋不休，慢慢地站起来，按照他部落在困难中的方式，侧身靠着围板，用他的一个高肩膀靠在上面，偷偷地用右手在左手上摩擦，左脚在右脚上摩擦。 。

‘You hear what she says, and I know it’s true. Have you been here ever since?’
“你听到她说的话，我知道这是真的。从那以后你就一直在这里吗？

‘Wishermaydie if I seen Tom-all-Alone’s till this blessed morning,’ replies Jo hoarsely.
“要是我能在这个幸福的早晨看到汤姆孤身一人就好了，”乔沙哑地回答道。

‘Why have you come here now?’
“你为什么现在才来这里？”

Jo looks all round the confined court, looks at his questioner no higher than the knees, and finally answers, ‘I don’t know how to do nothink, and I can’t get nothink to do. I’m wery poor and ill, and I thought I’d come back here when there warn’t nobody about, and lay down and hide somewheres as I knows on till arter dark, and then go and beg a trifle of Mr. Snagsby. He wos allus willin fur to give me somethink he wos, though Mrs. Snagsby she was allus achivying on me—like everybody everywheres.’
乔环视了封闭的球场，看着发问者，目光高度不超过膝盖，最后回答道：“我不知道如何做nothink，我也无法让nothink做。”我又穷又病，我想我会在没人警告的时候回到这里，在我知道的地方躺下并躲起来，直到天黑，然后去向斯纳斯比先生乞讨一点东西。他愿意给我一些认为他愿意的东西，尽管斯纳格斯比夫人对我有所成就——就像世界各地的每个人一样。

‘Where have you come from?’
“你从哪里来？”

Jo looks all round the court again, looks at his questioner’s knees again, and concludes by laying his profile against the hoarding in a sort of resignation.
乔再次环视了球场，又看了看提问者的膝盖，最后以一种无奈的方式将自己的侧脸靠在了围板上。

‘Did you hear me ask you where you have come from?’
“你听到我问你从哪里来了吗？”

‘Tramp then,’ says Jo.
“那就流浪吧，”乔说。

‘Now tell me,’ proceeds Allan, making a strong effort to overcome his repugnance, going very near to him, and leaning over him with an expression of confidence, ‘tell me how it came about that you left that house when the good young lady had been so unfortunate as to pity you and take you home.’
“现在告诉我，”艾伦继续说道，他竭尽全力克服自己的反感，走近他，靠在他身上，脸上露出自信的表情，“告诉我，当那个好年轻人的时候，你是怎么离开那所房子的？”女士太不幸了，可怜你，把你带回家了。”

Jo suddenly comes out of his resignation and excitedly declares, addressing the woman, that he never known about the young lady, that he never heern about it, that he never went fur to hurt her, that he would sooner have hurt his own self, that he’d sooner have had his unfortnet ed chopped off than ever gone a-nigh her, and that she wos wery good to him, she wos. Conducting himself throughout as if in his poor fashion he really meant it, and winding up with some very miserable sobs.
乔突然从辞职中走出来，兴奋地对那个女人宣称，他从来不知道这位年轻女士的事，他从来没有听说过这件事，他从来没有去伤害她，他宁愿伤害自己，他宁愿把自己不幸的女儿砍掉，也不愿靠近她，而且她对他很好，她很好。他自始至终都表现得好像他是真心实意的，以他那糟糕的方式行事，最后却发出了一阵非常痛苦的抽泣。

Allan Woodcourt sees that this is not a sham. He constrains himself to touch him. ‘Come, Jo. Tell me.’
艾伦·伍德考特看出这不是骗局。他强迫自己去触碰他。来吧，乔。告诉我。'

‘No. I dustn’t,’ says Jo, relapsing into the profile state. ‘I dustn’t, or I would.’
'不。我没有除尘，”乔说道，又回到了个人资料状态。 “我不掸灰尘，否则我会的。”

‘But I must know,’ returns the other, ‘all the same. Come, Jo.’
“但我必须知道，”对方回答道，“无论如何。”来吧，乔。”

After two or three such adjurations, Jo lifts up his head again, looks round the court again, and says in a low voice, ‘Well, I’ll tell you something. I was took away. There!’
这样的嘱咐了两三遍之后，乔又抬起头来，环视了一下球场，低声说道：“好吧，我告诉你一件事。”我被带走了。那里！'

‘Took away? In the night?’
'拿走？晚上？

‘Ah!’ Very apprehensive of being overheard, Jo looks about him and even glances up some ten feet at the top of the hoarding and through the cracks in it lest the object of his distrust should be looking over or hidden on the other side.
“啊！”乔非常担心被人偷听，他环顾四周，甚至抬头看了看围板顶部大约十英尺的地方，透过围板的裂缝，以免他不信任的对象从另一边窥视或隐藏起来。

‘Who took you away?’
“谁把你带走了？”

‘I dustn’t name him,’ says Jo. ‘I dustn’t do it, sir.
“我没有提到他的名字，”乔说。 “我不会这么做，先生。

‘But I want, in the young lady’s name, to know. You may trust me. No one else shall hear.’
“但我想以这位年轻女士的名义知道。你可以相信我。没有其他人会听到。

‘Ah, but I don’t know,’ replies Jo, shaking his head fearfulty, ‘as he DON’T hear.’
“啊，但我不知道，”乔回答道，害怕地摇着头，“因为他没有听到。”

‘Why, he is not in this place.’
“为什么，他不在这个地方。”

‘Oh, ain’t he though?’ says Jo. ‘He’s in all manner of places, all at wanst.’
“哦，不是吗？”乔说。 “他在各个地方，都处于匮乏状态。”

Allan looks at him in perplexity, but discovers some real meaning and good faith at the bottom of this bewildering reply. He patiently awaits an explicit answer; and Jo, more baffled by his patience than by anything else, at last desperately whispers a name in his ear.
艾伦困惑地看着他，但在这个令人困惑的回答中发现了一些真正的含义和善意。他耐心地等待明确的答复；乔对他的耐心比其他任何事情都更感到困惑，最后绝望地在他耳边低声说出了一个名字。

‘Aye!’ says Allan. ‘Why, what had you been doing?’
“是的！”艾伦说。 “为什么，你刚才在做什么？”

‘Nothink, sir. Never done nothink to get myself into no trouble, ‘sept in not moving on and the inkwhich. But I’m a-moving on now. I’m a-moving on to the berryin ground—that’s the move as I’m up to.’
“不用想，先生。从来没有想过让自己陷入麻烦，只是不继续前进和墨水。但我现在要继续前进。我要搬到浆果地——这就是我要做的搬家。

‘No, no, we will try to prevent that. But what did he do with you?’
‘不，不，我们会尽力阻止这种情况发生。但他对你做了什么？

‘Put me in a horsepittle,’ replied Jo, whispering, ‘till I was discharged, then giv me a little money—four half-bulls, wot you may call half-crowns—and ses ‘Hook it! Nobody wants you here,’ he ses. ‘You hook it. You go and tramp,’ he ses. ‘You move on,’ he ses. ‘Don’t let me ever see you nowheres within forty mile of London, or you’ll repent it.’ So I shall, if ever he doos see me, and he’ll see me if I’m above ground,’ concludes Jo, nervously repeating all his former precautions and investigations.
“把我关进马坑，”乔低声回答，“直到我出院，然后给我一点钱——四个半公牛，你可以称之为半克朗——然后‘钩住它！没有人想要你在这里，”他说道。 ‘你钩住它。你去流浪吧，”他说道。 “你继续前进，”他说道。 “别让我在伦敦四十英里范围内的任何地方看到你，否则你会后悔的。”所以，如果他真的看到我，我会看到我，如果我在地面上，他也会看到我，“总结道乔紧张地重复着他之前的所有预防措施和调查。

Allan considers a little, then remarks, turning to the woman but keeping an encouraging eye on Jo, ‘He is not so ungrateful as you supposed. He had a reason for going away, though it was an insufficient one.’
艾伦想了一会儿，然后说道，转向那个女人，但仍用鼓励的目光看着乔，“他并不像你想象的那么忘恩负义。”他离开是有理由的，尽管这个理由还不够充分。”

‘Thankee, sir, thankee!’ exclaims Jo. ‘There now! See how hard you wos upon me. But ony you tell the young lady wot the genlmn ses, and it’s all right. For YOU wos wery good to me too, and I knows it.’
“谢谢，先生，谢谢！”乔喊道。 '就是现在！看你对我有多狠。但只要你告诉那位小姐我是将军，那就没问题了。因为你对我也很好，我知道这一点。

‘Now, Jo,’ says Allan, keeping his eye upon him, ‘come with me and I will find you a better place than this to lie down and hide in. If I take one side of the way and you the other to avoid observation, you will not run away, I know very well, if you make me a promise.’
“现在，乔，”艾伦注视着他，说道，“跟我来，我会给你找一个比这里更好的地方躺下藏身。如果我走一侧，你走另一侧，避开观察，如果你向我保证，你就不会逃跑，我很清楚。”

‘I won’t, not unless I wos to see HIM a-coming, sir.’
“我不会，除非我愿意看到他来，先生。”

‘Very well. I take your word. Half the town is getting up by this time, and the whole town will be broad awake in another hour. Come along. Good day again, my good woman.’
'很好。我相信你的话。这个时候一半的城镇已经起床了，再过一个小时整个城镇就会完全苏醒。一起来。又是美好的一天，我的好女人。

‘Good day again, sir, and I thank you kindly many times again.’
“再见，先生，我再次衷心感谢您。”

She has been sitting on her bag, deeply attentive, and now rises and takes it up. Jo, repeating, ‘Ony you tell the young lady as I never went fur to hurt her and wot the genlmn ses!’ nods and shambles and shivers, and smears and blinks, and half laughs and half cries, a farewell to her, and takes his creeping way along after Allan Woodcourt, close to the houses on the opposite side of the street. In this order, the two come up out of Tom-all-Alone’s into the broad rays of the sunlight and the purer air.
她一直坐在包上，全神贯注，现在站起来拿起包。乔重复道：“只有你告诉这位年轻女士，因为我从来没有伤害过她，也没有伤害过你们！”点点头，颤抖着，颤抖着，抹着脸，眨着眼睛，半笑半哭，向她告别，然后缓慢地跟在艾伦·伍德考特后面，靠近街对面的房子。按照这个顺序，两人走出汤姆独自屋，进入广阔的阳光和纯净的空气中。

CHAPTER XLVII
第四十七章


Jo’s Will
乔的遗嘱

As Allan Woodcourt and Jo proceed along the streets where the high church spires and the distances are so near and clear in the morning light that the city itself seems renewed by rest, Allan revolves in his mind how and where he shall bestow his companion. ‘It surely is a strange fact,’ he considers, ‘that in the heart of a civilized world this creature in human form should be more difficult to dispose of than an unowned dog.’ But it is none the less a fact because of its strangeness, and the difficulty remains.
当艾伦·伍德考特和乔沿着街道前进时，那里有高高的教堂尖顶，在晨光中，距离是如此的近和清晰，以至于这座城市本身似乎因休息而焕然一新，艾伦在他的脑海中盘旋着他将如何以及在哪里给予他的同伴。 “这确实是一个奇怪的事实，”他认为，“在一个文明世界的中心，这种人类形态的生物应该比一只无主的狗更难处理。”但这仍然是一个事实，因为它的陌生感，困难依然存在。

At first he looks behind him often to assure himself that Jo is still really following. But look where he will, he still beholds him close to the opposite houses, making his way with his wary hand from brick to brick and from door to door, and often, as he creeps along, glancing over at him watchfully. Soon satisfied that the last thing in his thoughts is to give him the slip, Allan goes on, considering with a less divided attention what he shall do.
起初，他经常向后看，以确保乔确实在跟着他。但无论他往哪里看，他仍然看到他靠近对面的房子，小心翼翼地用他的手从一块砖走到另一块砖，从一扇门走到另一扇门，当他爬行时，常常会警惕地瞥见他。艾伦很快就意识到自己最不想做的事情就是让他溜走，他继续说道，注意力不集中地考虑着他应该做什么。

A breakfast-stall at a street-corner suggests the first thing to be done. He stops there, looks round, and beckons Jo. Jo crosses and comes halting and shuffling up, slowly scooping the knuckles of his right hand round and round in the hollowed palm of his left, kneading dirt with a natural pestle and mortar. What is a dainty repast to Jo is then set before him, and he begins to gulp the coffee and to gnaw the bread and butter, looking anxiously about him in all directions as he eats and drinks, like a scared animal.
街角的早餐摊建议我们要做的第一件事。他停在那里，环顾四周，并向乔招手。乔走过来，停下来，拖着脚步，慢慢地用右手的指节在左手空心的手掌上转了一圈又一圈，用天然的杵和研钵揉捏泥土。对乔来说，一顿美味的晚餐就摆在他面前，他开始大口喝咖啡，啃面包和黄油，一边吃喝，一边焦急地环顾四周，就像一只受惊的动物。

But he is so sick and miserable that even hunger has abandoned him. ‘I thought I was amost a-starvin, sir,’ says Jo, soon putting down his food, ‘but I don’t know nothink—not even that. I don’t care for eating wittles nor yet for drinking on ‘em.’ And Jo stands shivering and looking at the breakfast wonderingly.
但他病得很重，痛苦不堪，连饥饿都抛弃了他。 “我以为我快要饿死了，先生，”乔说着，很快就放下了食物，“但我不知道——连这一点也不知道。”我不喜欢吃玉米粒，也不喜欢吃玉米粒喝饮料。乔浑身发抖地站着，惊奇地看着早餐。

Allan Woodcourt lays his hand upon his pulse and on his chest. ‘Draw breath, Jo!’ ‘It draws,’ says Jo, ‘as heavy as a cart.’ He might add, ‘And rattles like it,’ but he only mutters, ‘I’m amoving on, sir.’
艾伦·伍德考特把手放在脉搏上和胸口上。 “深吸一口气，乔！”“它深吸一口气，”乔说，“像一辆推车一样重。”他可能会补充说，“还有像它一样的嘎嘎声，”但他只是咕哝道，“我要继续前进了，先生。”

Allan looks about for an apothecary’s shop. There is none at hand, but a tavern does as well or better. He obtains a little measure of wine and gives the lad a portion of it very carefully. He begins to revive almost as soon as it passes his lips. ‘We may repeat that dose, Jo,’ observes Allan after watching him with his attentive face. ‘So! Now we will take five minutes’ rest, and then go on again.’
艾伦四处寻找一家药店。手边没有，但小酒馆也可以，甚至更好。他取了一点酒，小心翼翼地给了小伙子一份。几乎一经过他的嘴唇，他就开始苏醒。 “我们可以重复这个剂量，乔，”艾伦用专注的表情看着他后说道。 '所以！现在我们休息五分钟，然后再继续。”

Leaving the boy sitting on the bench of the breakfast-stall, with his back against an iron railing, Allan Woodcourt paces up and down in the early sunshine, casting an occasional look towards him without appearing to watch him. It requires no discernment to perceive that he is warmed and refreshed. If a face so shaded can brighten, his face brightens somewhat; and by little and little he eats the slice of bread he had so hopelessly laid down. Observant of these signs of improvement, Allan engages him in conversation and elicits to his no small wonder the adventure of the lady in the veil, with all its consequences. Jo slowly munches as he slowly tells it. When he has finished his story and his bread, they go on again.
艾伦·伍德考特把男孩留在早餐摊的长凳上，背靠着铁栏杆，在清晨的阳光下踱来踱去，时不时地看他一眼，但似乎没有看他。不需要任何洞察力就能察觉到他感到温暖和神清气爽。如果一张如此阴影的脸可以变亮，那么他的脸就会变亮一些；他一点点地吃掉了他绝望地放下的那片面包。艾伦观察到这些改善的迹象，便与他交谈，并让他对戴面纱的女士的冒险及其所有后果感到惊讶。乔一边慢慢咀嚼，一边慢慢讲述。当他讲完他的故事和他的面包后，他们又继续前进。

Intending to refer his difficulty in finding a temporary place of refuge for the boy to his old patient, zealous little Miss Flite, Allan leads the way to the court where he and Jo first foregathered. But all is changed at the rag and bottle shop; Miss Flite no longer lodges there; it is shut up; and a hard-featured female, much obscured by dust, whose age is a problem, but who is indeed no other than the interesting Judy, is tart and spare in her replies. These sufficing, however, to inform the visitor that Miss Flite and her birds are domiciled with a Mrs. Blinder, in Bell Yard, he repairs to that neighbouring place, where Miss Flite (who rises early that she may be punctual at the divan of justice held by her excellent friend the Chancellor) comes running downstairs with tears of welcome and with open arms.
艾伦打算向他的老病人、热心的小弗利特小姐诉说他为男孩寻找临时避难所所遇到的困难，于是他带路来到了他和乔第一次见面的法庭。但在破布和瓶子店里，一切都变了。弗利特小姐不再住在那里；它被关闭了；一位面容冷酷的女性，被灰尘遮住了，她的年龄是个问题，但她确实不是别人，正是有趣的朱迪，她的回答尖酸刻薄。然而，这些足以告诉来访者，弗利特小姐和她的鸟儿住在贝尔院的布林德夫人那里，他飞往邻近的地方，弗利特小姐（她起得很早，以便她可以准时在沙发上）她的好朋友总理主持的正义）带着欢迎的泪水和张开双臂跑下楼。

‘My dear physician!’ cries Miss Flite. ‘My meritorious, distinguished, honourable officer!’ She uses some odd expressions, but is as cordial and full of heart as sanity itself can be—more so than it often is. Allan, very patient with her, waits until she has no more raptures to express, then points out Jo, trembling in a doorway, and tells her how he comes there.
“我亲爱的医生！”弗利特小姐喊道。 “我的功勋卓著、尊敬的军官！”她用了一些奇怪的表达方式，但她的神智正常，充满热情，比平常更加真诚。艾伦对她非常耐心，等到她不再有任何喜悦可以表达，然后指着门口颤抖着的乔，告诉她他是怎么到那里的。

‘Where can I lodge him hereabouts for the present? Now, you have a fund of knowledge and good sense and can advise me.
“我现在可以把他安置在哪里？”现在，您拥有丰富的知识和良好的判断力，可以为我提供建议。

Miss Flite, mighty proud of the compliment, sets herself to consider; but it is long before a bright thought occurs to her. Mrs. Blinder is entirely let, and she herself occupies poor Gridley’s room. ‘Gridley!’ exclaims Miss Flite, clapping her hands after a twentieth repetition of this remark. ‘Gridley! To be sure! Of course! My dear physician! General George will help us out.’
弗利特小姐对这种恭维感到非常自豪，她开始考虑；但过了很久她才想到一个明智的想法。布林德太太完全被租了，她自己也住在可怜的格里德利的房间里。 “格里德利！”弗利特小姐喊道，这句话重复了二十遍后，她拍起了手。 ‘格里德利！为了确定！当然！我亲爱的医生！乔治将军会帮助我们。”

It is hopeless to ask for any information about General George, and would be, though Miss Flite had not akeady run upstairs to put on her pinched bonnet and her poor little shawl and to arm herself with her reticule of documents. But as she informs her physician in her disjointed manner on coming down in full array that General George, whom she often calls upon, knows her dear Fitz Jarndyce and takes a great interest in all connected with her, Allan is induced to think that they may be in the right way. So he tells Jo, for his encouragement, that this walking about will soon be over now; and they repair to the general’s. Fortunately it is not far.
询问有关乔治将军的任何信息是没有希望的，而且也确实会这样，尽管弗利特小姐还没有跑上楼戴上她那顶紧缩的帽子和她可怜的小披肩，并用她的文件袋武装自己。但是，当她全副武装地下来后，以杂乱无章的方式告诉医生，她经常拜访的乔治将军认识她亲爱的菲茨·贾迪斯，并对与她有关的一切都非常感兴趣，艾伦不禁认为他们可能以正确的方式。因此，为了鼓励乔，他告诉乔，这次散步很快就会结束。他们修复了将军的。幸好距离不远。

From the exterior of George’s Shooting Gallery, and the long entry, and the bare perspective beyond it, Allan Woodcourt augurs well. He also descries promise in the figure of Mr. George himself, striding towards them in his mornmg exercise with his pipe in his mouth, no stock on, and his muscular arms, developed by broadsword and dumbbell, weightily asserting themselves through his light shirt-sleeves.
从乔治射击馆的外观、长长的入口以及后面的裸露视角来看，艾伦·伍德考特预示着良好的前景。他还从乔治先生本人的形象中看到了希望，他在晨练中大步走向他们，嘴里叼着烟斗，没戴枪托，他肌肉发达的手臂，由大刀和哑铃锻炼而成，通过他的浅色衬衫有力地彰显自己的力量——袖子。

‘Your servant, sir,’ says Mr. George with a military salute. Goodhumouredly smiling all over his broad forehead up into his crisp hair, he then defers to Miss Flite, as, with great stateliness, and at some length, she performs the courtly ceremony of presentation. He winds it up with another ‘Your servant, sir!’ and another salute.
“您的仆人，先生，”乔治先生行了一个军礼说道。宽阔的前额上满是幽默的微笑，一直延伸到清爽的头发中，然后他向弗利特小姐致敬，因为她以极大的威严和一段较长的时间，执行了宫廷的介绍仪式。他又说了一句“您的仆人，先生！”并再次行了一个礼。

‘Excuse me, sir. A sailor, I believe?’ says Mr. George.
'对不起，先生。 “我相信是个水手吧？”乔治先生说。

‘I am proud to find I have the air of one,’ returns Allan; ‘but I am only a sea-going doctor.’
“我很自豪地发现我有一个人的气质，”艾伦回答道； “但我只是一名航海医生。”

‘Indeed, sir! I should have thought you was a regular blue-jacket myself.’
‘确实如此，先生！我本应该以为你自己就是一名普通的蓝夹克。

Allan hopes Mr. George will forgive his intrusion the more readily on that account, and particularly that he will not lay aside his pipe, which, in his politeness, he has testifled some intention of doing. ‘You are very good, sir,’ returns the trooper. ‘As I know by experience that it’s not disagreeable to Miss Flite, and since it’s equally agreeable to yourself—‘ and finishes the sentence by putting it between his lips again. Allan proceeds to tell him all he knows about Jo, unto which the trooper listens with a grave face.
艾伦希望乔治先生能因此而更容易地原谅他的闯入，特别是他不会放下烟斗，他出于礼貌已经证明了这样做的意图。 “你非常好，长官，”士兵回答道。 “根据我的经验，这对弗利特小姐来说并不令人不快，因为这对你来说也同样令人愉快——”他再次把它放在嘴唇之间，结束了这句话。艾伦继续告诉他他所知道的有关乔的一切，士兵面色严肃地听着。

‘And that’s the lad, sir, is it?’ he inquires, looking along the entry to where Jo stands staring up at the great letters on the whitewashed front, which have no meaning in his eyes.
“这就是那个小伙子，先生，是吗？”他问道，一边沿着入口望向乔站着的地方，盯着粉刷过的正面上的大字，这些字在他眼里毫无意义。

‘That’s he,’ says Allan. ‘And, Mr. George, I am in this difficulty about him. I am unwilling to place him in a hospital, even if I could procure him immediate admission, because I foresee that he would not stay there many hours if he could be so much as got there. The same objection applies to a workhouse, supposing I had the patience to be evaded and shirked, and handed about from post to pillar in trying to get him into one, which is a system that I don’t take kindly to.’
“就是他，”艾伦说。 “而且，乔治先生，我对他感到很为难。”即使我能让他立即入院，我也不愿意把他送进医院，因为我预见到，如果他能赶到那里，他也不会在那里待上几个小时。同样的反对意见也适用于济贫院，假设我有耐心被回避和推卸，并从一个岗位调到另一个岗位，试图让他进入济贫院，这是一个我不喜欢的制度。

‘No man does, sir,’ returns Mr. George.
“没有人这样做，先生，”乔治先生回答道。

‘I am convinced that he would not remain in either place, because he is possessed by an extraordinary terror of this person who ordered him to keep out of the way; in his ignorance, he believes this person to be everywhere, and cognizant of everything.’
“我确信他不会留在任何一个地方，因为他对这个命令他让开的人感到异常恐惧；由于他的无知，他相信这个人无处不在，并且了解一切。

‘I ask your pardon, sir,’ says Mr. George. ‘But you have not mentioned that party’s name. Is it a secret, sir?’
“请您原谅，先生，”乔治先生说。 “但你没有提到那个政党的名字。这是一个秘密吗，先生？

‘The boy makes it one. But his name is Bucket.’
“这男孩做到了。”但他的名字叫巴克特。”

‘Bucket the detective, sir?’
“把侦探扔进桶里吗，先生？”

‘The same man.’
“同一个人。”

‘The man is known to me, sir,’ returns the trooper after blowing out a cloud of smoke and squaring his chest, ‘and the boy is so far correct that he undoubtedly is a—rum customer.’ Mr. George smokes with a profound meaning after this and surveys Miss Flite in silence.
“我认识这个人，长官，”警察喷出一团烟，挺起胸膛，回答道，“到目前为止，这个男孩是正确的，他无疑是朗姆酒的顾客。”乔治先生抽烟时用的是此后意义深远，沉默地审视着弗利特小姐。

‘Now, I wish Mr. Jarndyce and Miss Summerson at least to know that this Jo, who tells so strange a story, has reappeared, and to have it in their power to speak with him if they should desire to do so. Therefore I want to get him, for the present moment, into any poor lodging kept by decent people where he would be admitted. Decent people and Jo, Mr. George,’ says Allan, following the direction of the trooper’s eyes along the entry, ‘have not been much acquainted, as you see. Hence the difficulty. Do you happen to know any one in this neighbourhood who would receive him for a while on my paying for him beforehand?’
“现在，我希望贾迪斯先生和萨默森小姐至少知道这个讲述了如此奇怪故事的乔已经重新出现，并且如果他们愿意的话，可以与他交谈。因此，我想暂时让他住进任何一个由正派人士开办的简陋住所，在那里他可以入住。正直的人们和乔，乔治先生，”艾伦顺着入口处的士兵目光方向说道，“如你所见，他们并不熟悉。因此困难就来了。你碰巧知道附近有谁会因为我预先付钱而接待他一段时间吗？

As he puts the question, he becomes aware of a dirty-faced little man standing at the trooper’s elbow and looking up, with an oddly twisted figure and countenance, into the trooper’s face. After a few more puffs at his pipe, the trooper looks down askant at the little man, and the little man winks up at the trooper.
当他提出问题时，他意识到一个满脸脏兮兮的小个子男人站在士兵的肘部，用一种奇怪的扭曲的身材和面容抬起头来看着士兵的脸。士兵又吸了几口烟斗后，低头斜视着小个子男人，小个子男人向士兵眨了眨眼睛。

‘Well, sir,’ says Mr. George, ‘I can assure you that I would willingiy be knocked on the head at any time if it would be at all agreeable to Miss Summerson, and consequently I esteem it a privilege to do that young lady any service, however small. We are naturally in the vagabond way here, sir, both myself and Phil. You see what the place is. You are welcome to a quiet corner of it for the boy if the same would meet your views. No charge made, except for rations. We are not in a flourishing state of circumstances here, sir. We are liable to be tumbled out neck and crop at a moment’s notice. However, sir, such as the place is, and so long as it lasts, here it is at your service.’
“好吧，先生，”乔治先生说，“我可以向您保证，如果萨默森小姐愿意的话，我随时愿意被人敲头，因此，我认为能做这个年轻人是我的荣幸。”女士提供任何服务，无论多么小。先生，我们在这里自然是流浪者，我和菲尔都是如此。一看就知道是什么地方了如果男孩也能满足您的意见，欢迎您来到男孩的安静角落。除口粮外，不收取任何费用。先生，我们这里的情况并不繁荣。我们很可能会立刻被摔倒。不过，先生，这个地方就是这样，只要它还存在，这里就为您服务。”

With a comprehensive wave of his pipe, Mr. George places the whole building at his visitor’s disposal.
乔治先生全面地挥舞着他的烟斗，将整座建筑交给他的来访者使用。

‘I take it for granted, sir,’ he adds, ‘you being one of the medical staff, that there is no present infection about this unfortunate subject?’
“我认为理所当然，先生，”他补充道，“作为医务人员之一，这个不幸的对象目前没有感染？”

Allan is quite sure of it.
艾伦对此十分确定。

‘Because, sir,’ says Mr. George, shaking his head sorrowfully, ‘we have had enough of that.’
“因为，先生，”乔治先生悲伤地摇摇头，“我们已经受够了。”

His tone is no less sorrowfully echoed by his new acquaintance. ‘Still I am bound to tell you,’ observes Allan after repeating his former assurance, ‘that the boy is deplorably low and reduced and that he may be—I do not say that he is—too far gone to recover.’
他的新朋友也同样悲伤地呼应着他的语气。 “但我还是必须告诉你，”艾伦在重复了他之前的保证后说道，“这孩子的地位低落得可怜，而且他可能——我不是说他——已经走得太远了，无法恢复。”

‘Do you consider him in present danger, sir?’ inquires the trooper.
“您认为他目前处于危险之中吗，长官？”士兵问道。

‘Yes, I fear so.’
“是的，我担心是这样。”

‘Then, sir,’ returns the trooper in a decisive manner, ‘it appears to me—being naturally in the vagabond way myself—that the sooner he comes out of the street, the better. You, Phil! Bring him in!’
“那么，先生，”士兵果断地回答道，“在我看来——我自己天生就是流浪者——他越早从街上出来越好。你，菲尔！带他进来！

Mr. Squod tacks out, all on one side, to execute the word of command; and the trooper, having smoked his pipe, lays it by. Jo is brought in. He is not one of Mrs. Pardiggle’s Tockahoopo Indians; he is not one of Mrs. Jellyby’s lambs, being wholly unconnected with Borrioboola-Gha; he is not softened by distance and unfamiliarity; he is not a genuine foreign-grown savage; he is the ordinary home-made article. Dirty, ugly, disagreeable to all the senses, in body a common creature of the common streets, only in soul a heathen. Homely filth begrimes him, homely parasites devour him, homely sores are in him, homely rags are on him; native ignorance, the growth of English soil and climate, sinks his immortal nature lower than the beasts that perish. Stand forth, Jo, in uncompromising colours! From the sole of thy foot to the crown of thy head, there is nothing interesting about thee.
斯阔德先生在一侧出海执行命令；士兵抽完烟斗，把它放在一边。乔被带进来了。他不是帕迪格夫人的托卡胡波印第安人之一；他是帕迪格夫人的托卡胡波印第安人。他不是杰利比夫人的羔羊之一，与博里奥布拉-加完全没有关系；他不会因距离和陌生而变得软弱；他不是真正的外国野蛮人；他就是普通的自制物品。肮脏、丑陋、令人厌恶，身体上是普通街道上的普通生物，但灵魂上却是异教徒。平凡的污秽玷污了他，平凡的寄生虫吞噬了他，平凡的疮在他身上，平凡的破布在他身上；与生俱来的无知、英国土壤和气候的生长，使他不朽的本性比那些灭亡的野兽还要低沉。乔，以不妥协的色彩站出来！从你的脚底到你的头顶，你没有什么有趣的地方。

He shuffles slowly into Mr. George’s gallery and stands huddled together in a bundle, looking all about the floor. He seems to know that they have an inclination to shrink from him, partly for what he is and partly for what he has caused. He, too, shrinks from them. He is not of the same order of things, not of the same place in creation. He is of no order and no place, neither of the beasts nor of humanity.
他慢慢地走进乔治先生的画廊，站成一团，环视地板。他似乎知道他们倾向于回避他，部分是因为他的身份，部分是因为他造成的后果。他也对他们退缩。他不属于同一秩序的事物，也不属于创造中的同一位置。他不属于任何秩序，也不属于任何地方，既不属于野兽，也不属于人类。

‘Look here, Jo!’ says Allan. ‘This is Mr. George.’
“看这里，乔！”艾伦说。 “这是乔治先生。”

Jo searches the floor for some time longer, then looks up for a moment, and then down again.
乔在地板上又搜索了一段时间，然后抬头看了一会儿，然后又低下头。

‘He is a kind friend to you, for he is going to give you lodging room here.’
“他是你的好朋友，因为他会在这里给你提供住宿。”

Jo makes a scoop with one hand, which is supposed to be a bow. After a little more consideration and some backing and changing of the foot on which he rests, he mutters that he is ‘wery thankful.’
乔用一只手做了一个勺子，这应该是一把弓。经过更多的考虑、一些支持和改变他所休息的脚之后，他低声说他“非常感激”。

‘You are quite safe here. All you have to do at present is to be obedient and to get strong. And mind you tell us the truth here, whatever you do, Jo.’
‘你在这里很安全。现在你要做的就是顺从，坚强起来。请注意，无论你做什么，请在这里告诉我们真相，乔。”

‘Wishermaydie if I don’t, sir,’ says Jo, reverting to his favourite declaration. ‘I never done nothink yit, but wot you knows on, to get myself into no trouble. I never was in no other trouble at all, sir, ‘sept not knowin’ nothink and starwation.’
“如果我不这样做的话，先生，”乔说道，又回到了他最喜欢的宣言。 “我从来没有做过任何事，但你知道吗，为了不让自己陷入麻烦。先生，我从来没有遇到过任何其他麻烦，‘不知道’没有思考和星际状态。”

‘I believe it, now attend to Mr. George. I see he is going to speak to you.’
“我相信，现在去听乔治先生吧。”我看他要跟你说话。

‘My intention merely was, sir,’ observes Mr. George, amazingly broad and upright, ‘to point out to him where he can lie down and get a thorough good dose of sleep. Now, look here.’ As the trooper speaks, he conducts them to the other end of the gallery and opens one of the little cabins. ‘There you are, you see! Here is a mattress, and here you may rest, on good behaviour, as long as Mr., I ask your pardon, sir’—he refers apologetically to the card Allan has given him—‘Mr. Woodcourt pleases. Don’t you be alarmed if you hear shots; they’ll be aimed at the target, and not you. Now, there’s another thing I would recommend, sir,’ says the trooper, turning to his visitor. ‘Phil, come here!’
“我的目​​的只是，先生，”乔治先生说，他的身体宽阔而挺拔，令人惊讶，“向他指出哪里可以躺下，让他睡个好觉。”现在，看这里。”士兵一边说话，一边把他们带到走廊的另一端，打开其中一间小木屋。 ‘你瞧，就在这儿！这是一张床垫，如果您表现良好，您可以在这里休息，只要先生，请您原谅，先生”——他带着歉意地指着艾伦给他的卡片——“先生。”伍德考特很高兴。如果听到枪声，请不要惊慌；他们会瞄准目标，而不是你。现在，我要推荐另一件事，长官，”士兵转向他的访客说道。 “菲尔，过来！”

Phil bears down upon them according to his usual tactics. ‘Here is a man, sir, who was found, when a baby, in the gutter. Consequently, it is to be expected that he takes a natural interest in this poor creature. You do, don’t you, Phil?’
菲尔按照他一贯的策略向他们发起进攻。 “先生，这是一个人，当他还是个婴儿时，就在阴沟里被发现了。因此，可以预料他会对这个可怜的生物产生天然的兴趣。你知道，不是吗，菲尔？

‘Certainly and surely I do, guv’ner,’ is Phil’s reply.
“我当然愿意，领导，”菲尔回答道。

‘Now I was thinking, sir,’ says Mr. George in a martial sort of confidence, as if he were giving his opinion in a council of war at a drum-head, ‘that if this man was to take him to a bath and was to lay out a few shillings in getting him one or two coarse articles—‘
“现在我在想，先生，”乔治先生以一种军事般的自信说道，就好像他在战争会议上大声发表自己的意见，“如果这个人带他去洗澡并要花几先令给他买一两件粗品——”

‘Mr. George, my considerate friend,’ returns Allan, taking out his purse, ‘it is the very favour I would have asked.’
'先生。乔治，我体贴的朋友，”艾伦拿出钱包回答道，“这正是我想要的。”

Phil Squod and Jo are sent out immediately on this work of improvement. Miss Flite, quite enraptured by her success, makes the best of her way to court, having great fears that otherwise her friend the Chancellor may be uneasy about her or may give the judgment she has so long expected in her absence, and observing ‘which you know, my dear physician, and general, after so many years, would be too absurdly unfortunate!’ Allan takes the opportunity of going out to procure some restorative medicines, and obtaining them near at hand, soon returns to find the trooper walking up and down the gallery, and to fall into step and walk with him.
Phil Squod 和 Jo 立即被派去进行这项改进工作。弗利特小姐对自己的成功感到非常欣喜，她尽最大努力去法庭，她非常担心，否则她的朋友大法官可能会对她感到不安，或者可能会在她缺席的情况下做出她期待已久的判断，并观察到“你知道吗，我亲爱的医生和将军，这么多年过去了，真是太不幸了！”艾伦趁着出去采购一些恢复性药物的机会，在手边拿到了它们，很快回来，发现士兵走了过来。沿着走廊，与他并肩同行。

‘I take it, sir,’ says Mr. George, ‘that you know Miss Summerson pretty well?’
“我想，先生，”乔治先生说，“您很了解萨默森小姐吧？”

Yes, it appears.
是的，看来是的。

‘Not related to her, sir?’
“先生，和她没有关系吗？”

No, it appears.
不，看来。

‘Excuse the apparent curiosity,’ says Mr. George. ‘It seemed to me probable that you might take more than a common interest in this poor creature because Miss Summerson had taken that unfortunate interest in him. ‘Tis MY case, sir, I assure you.’
“请原谅你明显的好奇心，”乔治先生说。 “在我看来，你对这个可怜的家伙的兴趣可能不仅仅是一般的兴趣，因为萨默森小姐对他产生了这种不幸的兴趣。 “这就是我的情况，先生，我向你保证。”

‘And mine, Mr. George.’
“还有我的，乔治先生。”

The trooper looks sideways at Allan’s sunburnt cheek and bright dark eye, rapidly measures his height and build, and seems to approve of him.
士兵侧身看着艾伦晒黑的脸颊和明亮的黑眼睛，迅速测量了他的身高和体格，似乎很认可他。

‘Since you have been out, sir, I have been thinking that I unquestionably know the rooms in Lincoln’s Inn Fields, where Bucket took the lad, according to his account. Though he is not acquainted with the name, I can help you to it. It’s Tulkinghorn. That’s what it is.’
“自从您出去之后，先生，我一直在想，毫无疑问，我知道林肯客栈场的房间，根据巴克特的说法，巴克特就是在那里带走了小伙子的。虽然他不熟悉这个名字，但我可以帮助你。这是图尔金霍恩。就是这样。

Allan looks at him inquiringly, repeating the name.
艾伦询问地看着他，重复着这个名字。

‘Tulkinghorn. That’s the name, sir. I know the man, and know him to have been in communication with Bucket before, respecting a deceased person who had given him offence. I know the man, sir. To my sorrow.’
“图尔金霍恩。就是这个名字，先生。我认识这个人，也知道他以前曾与巴克特有过交流，尊重一位冒犯了他的死者。我认识这个人，先生。令我悲伤的是。

Allan naturally asks what kind of man he is.
艾伦自然会问他是一个什么样的人。

‘What kind of man! Do you mean to look at?’
‘什么样的人啊！你想看吗？

‘I think I know that much of him. I mean to deal with. Generally, what kind of man?’
“我想我对他很了解。我的意思是处理。一般来说，什么样的人？

‘Why, then I’ll tell you, sir,’ returns the trooper, stopping short and folding his arms on his square chest so angrily that his face fires and flushes all over; ‘he is a confoundedly bad kind of man. He is a slow-torturing kind of man. He is no more like flesh and blood than a rusty old carbine is. He is a kind of man—by George!—that has caused me more restlessness, and more uneasiness, and more dissatisfaction with myself than all other men put together. That’s the kind of man Mr. Tulkinghorn is!’
“为什么，那我就告诉你，长官，”士兵回答道，他突然停了下来，双臂交叉放在方正的胸前，他的脸火红、通红。 ‘他是一个极其糟糕的人。他是一个慢慢折磨人的人。他不像一把生锈的旧卡宾枪那样有血有肉。他是这样一种人——乔治！——比所有其他人加起来更令我不安、不安和对自己更加不满。图金霍恩先生就是这样的人！

‘I am sorry,’ says Allan, ‘to have touched so sore a place.’
“我很抱歉，”艾伦说，“触动了如此疼痛的地方。”

‘Sore?’ The trooper plants his legs wider apart, wets the palm of his broad right hand, and lays it on the imaginary moustache. ‘It’s no fault of yours, sir; but you shall judge. He has got a power over me. He is the man I spoke of just now as being able to tumble me out of this place neck and crop. He keeps me on a constant see-saw. He won’t hold off, and he won’t come on. If I have a payment to make him, or time to ask him for, or anything to go to him about, he don’t see me, don’t hear me—passes me on to Melchisedech’s in Clifford’s Inn, Melchisedech’s in Clifford’s Inn passes me back again to him—he keeps me prowling and dangling about him as if I was made of the same stone as himself. Why, I spend half my life now, pretty well, loitering and dodging about his door. What does he care? Nothing. Just as much as the rusty old carbine I have compared him to. He chafes and goads me till— Bah! Nonsense! I am forgetting myself. Mr. Woodcourt,’ the trooper resumes his march, ‘all I say is, he is an old man; but I am glad I shall never have the chance of setting spurs to my horse and riding at him in a fair field. For if I had that chance, in one of the humours he drives me into—he’d go down, sir!’
“疼吗？”士兵把双腿分开，弄湿宽大的右手手掌，放在想象中的小胡子上。 “这不是你的错，先生；但你要判断。他对我有权力。他就是我刚才提到的那个能够把我从这个地方摔下来的人。他让我一直处于拉锯状态。他不会拖延，也不会继续前进。如果我要付钱给他，或者有时间向他要，或者有什么事情要去找他，他就看不到我，也听不到我——把我带到克利福德旅馆的麦基洗德店，克利福德店的麦基洗德店。又把我传回给他——他让我在他身边徘徊、晃来晃去，就好像我和他是同一块石头做的一样。哎呀，我现在的半辈子都在他的门口徘徊、躲闪，过得很好。他关心什么？没有什么。就像我把他比作生锈的旧卡宾枪一样。他不断地激怒我，直到——呸！废话！我快忘记我自己了。伍德考特先生，”士兵继续行军，“我只想说，他是个老人；他是个老人。但我很高兴我再也没有机会在公平的田野上策马驰骋了。因为如果我有这个机会，在他驱使我进入的一种幽默中——他就会倒下，先生！”

Mr. George has been so excited that he finds it necessary to wipe his forehead on his shirt-sleeve. Even while he whistles his impetuosity away with the national anthem, some involuntary shakings of his head and heavings of his chest still linger behind, not to mention an occasional hasty adjustment with both hands of his open shirt-collar, as if it were scarcely open enough to prevent his being troubled by a choking sensation. In short, Allan Woodcourt has not much doubt about the going down of Mr. Tulkinghorn on the field referred to.
乔治先生太兴奋了，他发现有必要用衬衫袖子擦擦额头。尽管他吹着国歌的口哨消除了自己的浮躁，但他的一些不自觉的摇头和胸口的起伏仍然在后面挥之不去，更不用说偶尔用两只敞开的衬衫领子匆匆调整了一下，好像它几乎没有打开一样。足以防止他被窒息的感觉所困扰。简而言之，艾伦·伍德考特对于图尔金霍恩先生在上述领域的倒下并没有太多怀疑。

Jo and his conductor presently return, and Jo is assisted to his mattress by the careful Phil, to whom, after due administration of medicine by his own hands, Allan confides all needful means and instructions. The morning is by this time getting on apace. He repairs to his lodgings to dress and breakfast, and then, without seeking rest, goes away to Mr. Jarndyce to communicate his discovery.
乔和他的售票员很快就回来了，乔在细心的菲尔的帮助下回到了床垫上，在亲手给予适当的药物后，艾伦向菲尔透露了所有必要的方法和指示。早晨的时间过得很快。他回到住处穿好衣服，吃完早餐，然后没有休息，就去找贾迪斯先生，告诉他他的发现。

With him Mr. Jarndyce returns alone, confidentially telling him that there are reasons for keeping this matter very quiet indeed and showing a serious interest in it. To Mr. Jarndyce, Jo repeats in substance what he said in the morning, without any material variation. Only that cart of his is heavier to draw, and draws with a hollower sound.
贾迪斯先生独自一人回来，并秘密地告诉他，确实有理由对这件事保持秘密，并对它表现出浓厚的兴趣。对于贾迪斯先生，乔实质上重复了他早上所说的话，没有任何实质性变化。只是他的那辆小车拉起来比较重，拉起来的声音也比较空洞。

‘Let me lay here quiet and not be chivied no more,’ falters Jo, ‘and be so kind any person as is a-passin nigh where I used fur to sleep, as jist to say to Mr. Sangsby that Jo, wot he known once, is a-moving on right forards with his duty, and I’ll be wery thankful. I’d be more thankful than I am aready if it wos any ways possible for an unfortnet to be it.’
“让我安静地躺在这里，不要再被人欺负了，”乔支支吾吾地说，“对我睡觉的地方附近的任何人都要友善，就像对桑斯比先生说的那样，乔，他在吗？”曾经知道，他正在履行自己的职责，我将非常感激。如果有任何可能成为不幸的网络，我会更加感激。

He makes so many of these references to the law-stationer in the course of a day or two that Allan, after conferring with Mr. Jarndyce, good-naturedly resolves to call in Cook’s Court, the rather, as the cart seems to be breaking down.
他在一两天内多次提到法律文具员，以至于艾伦在与贾迪斯先生商量后，善意地决定去库克法院，更确切地说，因为车似乎坏了向下。

To Cook’s Court, therefore, he repairs. Mr. Snagsby is behind his counter in his grey coat and sleeves, inspecting an indenture of several skins which has just come in from the engrosser’s, an immense desert of law-hand and parchment, with here and there a resting-place of a few large letters to break the awful monotony and save the traveller from despair. Mr Snagsby puts up at one of these inky wells and greets the stranger with his cough of general preparation for business.
因此，他前往库克宫进行修复。斯纳格斯比先生穿着灰色的外套和袖子，站在柜台后面，检查一张刚从吸纳者那里运来的几张兽皮的契约，这是一片巨大的法律手和羊皮纸沙漠，到处都有一些人的休息处。大字母打破了可怕的单调，让旅行者免于绝望。斯纳格斯比先生在其中一口漆黑的井旁驻足，用咳嗽声向陌生人打招呼，一副准备做生意的样子。

‘You don’t remember me, Mr. Snagsby?’
“你不记得我了，斯纳斯比先生？”

The stationer’s heart begins to thump heavily, for his old apprehensions have never abated. It is as much as he can do to answer, ‘No, sir, I can’t say I do. I should have considered—not to put too fine a point upon it—that I never saw you before, sir.’
文具店老板的心开始重重地跳动，因为他过去的忧虑从未减轻。他只能回答：‘不，先生，我不能说我愿意。我应该考虑到——不要过分强调——我以前从未见过你，先生。

‘Twice before,’ says Allan Woodcourt. ‘Once at a poor bedside, and once—‘
“以前两次，”艾伦·伍德考特说。 “有一次在一个贫穷的床边，还有一次——”

‘It’s come at last!’ thinks the afflicted stationer, as recollection breaks upon him. ‘It’s got to a head now and is going to burst!’ But he has sufficient presence of mind to conduct his visitor into the little counting-house and to shut the door.
“终于来了！”痛苦的文具店主回忆起来，心想。 “现在已经到了紧要关头，快要破裂了！”但他有足够的头脑，带着客人走进小会计室，并关上了门。

‘Are you a married man, sir?’
“您是已婚男人吗，先生？”

‘No, I am not.’
'不我不是。'

‘Would you make the attempt, though single,’ says Mr. Snagsby in a melancholy whisper, ‘to speak as low as you can? For my little woman is a-listening somewheres, or I’ll forfeit the business and five hundred pound!’
“尽管你单身，”斯纳斯比先生忧郁地低声说道，“你会尝试尽可能低声说话吗？”因为我的小女人在某个地方正在倾听，否则我将失去生意和五百英镑！

In deep dejection Mr. Snagsby sits down on his stool, with his back against his desk, protesting, ‘I never had a secret of my own, sir. I can’t charge my memory with ever having once attempted to deceive my little woman on my own account since she named the day. I wouldn’t have done it, sir. Not to put too fine a point upon it, I couldn’t have done it, I dursn’t have done it. Whereas, and nevertheless, I find myself wrapped round with secrecy and mystery, till my life is a burden to me.’
斯纳斯比先生非常沮丧地坐在凳子上，背靠着桌子，抗议道：“我从来没有自己的秘密，先生。”自从她命名这一天以来，我无法回忆起曾经试图以我自己的名义欺骗我的小女人。我不会这么做的，先生。不夸张地说，我做不到，我也不敢做。然而，尽管如此，我发现自己被秘密和神秘所包围，直到我的生活成为我的负担。

His visitor professes his regret to bear it and asks him does he remember Jo. Mr. Snagsby answers with a suppressed groan, oh, don’t he!
他的来访者承认自己很遗憾承受这一切，并问他还记得乔吗？斯纳斯比先生压抑着呻吟声回答道，哦，不是吗！

‘You couldn’t name an individual human being—except myself—that my little woman is more set and determined against than Jo,’ says Mr. Snagsby.
斯纳格斯比先生说，“除了我自己，你找不到一个人比乔更坚决地反对我的小女人。”

Allan asks why.
艾伦问为什么。

‘Why?’ repeats Mr. Snagsby, in his desperation clutching at the clump of hair at the back of his bald head. ‘How should 1 know why? But you are a single person, sir, and may you long be spared to ask a married person such a question!’
“为什么？”斯纳斯比先生重复道，他绝望地抓着光头后面的一缕头发。 ‘我怎么知道为什么呢？但先生，您是单身人士，愿您永远不用问已婚人士这样的问题！”

With this beneficent wish, Mr. Snagsby coughs a cough of dismal resignation and submits himself to hear what the visitor has to communicate.
带着这个善意的愿望，斯纳斯比先生沮丧地无奈地咳嗽了一声，然后听听来访者要传达的信息。

‘There again!’ says Mr. Snagsby, who, between the earnestness of his feelings and the suppressed tones of his voice is discoloured in the face. ‘At it again, in a new direction! A certain person charges me, in the solemnest way, not to talk of Jo to any one, even my little woman. Then comes another certain person, in the person of yourself, and charges me, in an equally solemn way, not to mention Jo to that other certain person above all other persons. Why, this is a private asylum! Why, not to put too fine a point upon it, this is Bedlam, sir!’ says Mr. Snagsby.
“又来了！”斯纳斯比先生说，由于他的感情真挚，声音压抑，他的脸色变得苍白。 ‘再次出发，朝着新的方向！有人郑重地嘱咐我不要向任何人谈论乔，即使是我的小女人。然后另一个特定的人以你的身份出现，以同样严肃的方式责备我，更不用说向那个特定的人提到乔了。为什么，这是私人庇护所！哎呀，别说得太过分了，这就是疯人院，先生！”斯纳斯比先生说道。

But it is better than he expected after all, being no explosion of the mine below him or deepening of the pit into which he has fallen. And being tender-hearted and affected by the account he hears of Jo’s condition, he readily engages to ‘look round’ as early in the evening as he can manage it quietly. He looks round very quietly when the evening comes, but it may turn out that Mrs. Snagsby is as quiet a manager as he.
但这毕竟比他预想的要好，因为他下面的地雷没有爆炸，他所掉的坑也没有加深。听到乔的病情后，他心地善良，深受感动，很乐意在晚上尽早“环顾四周”，只要他能安静地处理这件事。夜幕降临时，他非常安静地四处张望，但事实可能是，斯纳斯比夫人和他一样是一位安静的经理。

Jo is very glad to see his old friend and says, when they are left alone, that he takes it uncommon kind as Mr. Sangsby should come so far out of his way on accounts of sich as him. Mr. Snagsby, touched by the spectacle before him, immediately lays upon the table half a crown, that magic balsam of his for all kinds of wounds.
乔很高兴见到他的老朋友，并说，当他们独处时，他认为桑斯比先生为了像他这样的人而特意走这么远，这很不寻常。斯纳斯比先生被眼前的景象所感动，立即在桌子上放了半克朗，这是他治疗各种伤口的神奇香脂。

‘And how do you find yourself, my poor lad?’ inquires the stationer with his cough of sympathy.
“你觉得自己怎么样了，我可怜的小伙子？”文具店老板同情地咳嗽了一声问道。

‘I am in luck, Mr. Sangsby, I am,’ returns Jo, ‘and don’t want for nothink. I’m more cumfbler nor you can’t think. Mr. Sangsby! I’m wery sorry that I done it, but I didn’t go fur to do it, sir.’
“我很幸运，桑斯比先生，我很幸运，”乔回答道，“而且不想白费力气。”我比较笨，你也不能思考。桑斯比先生！我很抱歉我这么做了，但我并没有这么做，先生。”

The stationer softly lays down another half-crown and asks him what it is that he is sorry for having done.
文具店老板轻声地又放下了半克朗，问他为自己做了什么而感到抱歉。

‘Mr. Sangsby,’ says Jo, ‘I went and giv a illness to the lady as wos and yit as warn’t the t’other lady, and none of ‘em never says nothink to me for having done it, on accounts of their being ser good and my having been s’unfortnet. The lady come herself and see me yesday, and she ses, ‘Ah, Jo!’ she ses. ‘We thought we’d lost you, Jo!’ she ses. And she sits down a-smilin so quiet, and don’t pass a word nor yit a look upon me for having done it, she don’t, and I turns agin the wall, I doos, Mr. Sangsby. And Mr. Jarnders, I see him a-forced to turn away his own self. And Mr. Woodcot, he come fur to giv me somethink fur to ease me, wot he’s allus a-doin’ on day and night, and wen he come a-bending over me and a-speakin up so bold, I see his tears a-fallin, Mr. Sangsby.’
'先生。桑斯比，”乔说，“我去给这位女士带来了一场疾病，就像其他女士一样，他们中没有一个人从来没有对我做过这件事说不，因为他们是很好，我一直很不幸。昨天那位女士亲自来见我，她说：“啊，乔！”她说。 “我们以为我们失去了你，乔！”她说道。她安静地微笑着坐下来，没有说一句话，也没有看我一眼，因为我做了这件事，她没有，我转身靠墙，我愿意，桑斯比先生。还有贾恩德斯先生，我看到他被迫放弃自己。还有伍德科特先生，他来给我一些让我放松的东西，他日日夜夜都在做，当他弯下腰来，如此大胆地说话时，我看到他的眼泪摔倒了，桑斯比先生。

The softened stationer deposits another half-crown on the table. Nothing less than a repetition of that infallible remedy will relieve his feelings.
软化的文具又把半克朗放在桌子上。只有重复这种万无一失的疗法才能缓解他的情绪。

‘Wot I was a-thinkin on, Mr. Sangsby,’ proceeds Jo, ‘wos, as you wos able to write wery large, p’raps?’
“我在想什么，桑斯比先生，”乔继续说道，“你能写很大的字吗？”

‘Yes, Jo, please God,’ returns the stationer.
“是的，乔，上帝保佑，”文具店老板回答道。

‘Uncommon precious large, p’raps?’ says Jo with eagerness.
“难得一见的珍贵大号，好吗？”乔热切地说。

‘Yes, my poor boy.’
“是的，我可怜的孩子。”

Jo laughs with pleasure. ‘Wot I wos a-thinking on then, Mr. Sangsby, wos, that when I wos moved on as fur as ever I could go and couldn’t he moved no furder, whether you might be so good p’raps as to write out, wery large so that any one could see it anywheres, as that I wos wery truly hearty sorry that I done it and that I never went fur to do it, and that though I didn’t know nothink at all, I knowd as Mr. Woodcot once cried over it and wos allus grieved over it, and that I hoped as he’d be able to forgive me in his mind. If the writin could be made to say it wery large, he might.’
乔高兴地笑了。 “当时我在想，桑斯比先生，当我尽可能地继续前进时，他就不能再继续前进，无论你是否会写得这么好？”外面很大，任何人都可以在任何地方看到它，因为我真的很抱歉我做了这件事，而且我从来没有去做这件事，虽然我根本不知道任何想法，但我知道伍德科特先生曾经为此哭泣过，我们也为此感到悲伤，我希望他能够在心里原谅我。如果文字可以说它很大，他可能会。

‘It shall say it, Jo. Very large.’
“它会这么说的，乔。很大。'

Jo laughs again. ‘Thankee, Mr. Sangsby. It’s wery kind of you, sir, and it makes me more cumfbler nor I was afore.’
乔又笑了。 “谢谢，桑斯比先生。先生，您真是太好了，这让我变得比以前更笨拙了。

The meek little stationer, with a broken and unfinished cough, slips down his fourth half-crown—he has never been so close to a case requiring so many—and is fain to depart. And Jo and he, upon this little earth, shall meet no more. No more.
温顺的小文具店员咳嗽了一声，没说完，放下了他的第四枚半冠——他从来没有如此接近过一个需要这么多硬币的箱子——然后准备离开。乔和他，在这个小小的地球上，将不会再见面了。不再。

For the cart so hard to draw is near its journey’s end and drags over stony ground. All round the clock it labours up the broken steps, shattered and worn. Not many times can the sun rise and behold it still upon its weary road.
因为这辆很难拉的车快要到达终点了，拖着石头地面。它昼夜不停地在破碎、破旧的台阶上艰难前行。太阳升起并看到它仍然走在疲惫的道路上的次数并不多。

Phil Squod, with his smoky gunpowder visage, at once acts as nurse and works as armourer at his little table in a corner, often looking round and saying with a nod of his green-baize cap and an encouraging elevation of his one eyebrow, ‘Hold up, my boy! Hold up!’ There, too, is Mr. Jarndyce many a time, and Allan Woodcourt almost always, both thinking, much, how strangely fate has entangled this rough outcast in the web of very different lives. There, too, the trooper is a frequent visitor, filling the doorway with his athletic figure and, from his superfluity of life and strength, seeming to shed down temporary vigour upon Jo, who never fails to speak more robustly in answer to his cheerful words.
菲尔·斯阔德（Phil Squod）有着一张烟熏火药般的面容，他在角落里的小桌子上既担任护士，又担任军械师，他时常环顾四周，戴着绿色毛呢帽，点点头，鼓励性地扬起一根眉毛，说道：坚持住，我的孩子！站住！”贾迪斯先生也多次出现在场，艾伦·伍德考特几乎总是在想，命运是多么奇怪地将这个粗鲁的被遗弃者卷入了截然不同的生活的网络中。那里的士兵也是这里的常客，他的运动员般的身材占据了门口，由于他过剩的生命和力量，似乎给乔带来了暂时的活力，而乔总是用更强有力的语气来回答他欢快的话语。 。

Jo is in a sleep or in a stupor to-day, and Allan Woodcourt, newly arrived, stands by him, looking down upon his wasted form. After a while he softly seats himself upon the bedside with his face towards him—just as he sat in the law-writer’s room—and touches his chest and heart. The cart had very nearly given up, but labours on a little more.
乔今天正在睡觉或处于昏迷状态，新来的艾伦·伍德考特站在他身边，俯视着他虚弱的身体。过了一会儿，他轻轻地坐在床边，脸朝向他——就像他坐在法律作家的房间里一样——抚摸着他的胸口和心脏。推车几乎要放弃了，但还继续努力。

The trooper stands in the doorway, still and silent. Phil has stopped in a low clinking noise, with his little hammer in his hand. Mr. Woodcourt looks round with that grave professional interest and attention on his face, and glancing significantly at the trooper, signs to Phil to carry his table out. When the little hammer is next used, there will be a speck of rust upon it.
警察站在门口，一动不动，一言不发。菲尔手里拿着小锤子，发出一声低沉的叮当声停了下来。伍德考特先生环顾四周，脸上带着严肃的职业兴趣和专注，他意味深长地看了一眼警察，示意菲尔把他的桌子搬出去。当小锤下次使用时，上面会出现一粒锈迹。

‘Well, Jo! What is the matter? Don’t be frightened.’
‘好吧，乔！什么事？不要害怕。

‘I thought,’ says Jo, who has started and is looking round, ‘I thought I was in Tom-all-Alone’s agin. Ain’t there nobody here but you, Mr. Woodcot?’
“我想，”乔说，她开始环顾四周，“我以为我是在《汤姆孤身一人》中。”伍德科特先生，这里除了你之外没有人吗？

‘Nobody.’
'没有人。'

‘And I ain’t took back to Tom-all-Alone’s. Am I, sir?’
“而且我也没有回到汤姆孤身一人的地方。”我是吗，先生？

‘No.’ Jo closes his eyes, muttering, ‘I’m wery thankful.’
“不。”乔闭上眼睛，嘀咕道，“我非常感激。”

After watching him closely a little while, Allan puts his mouth very near his ear and says to him in a low, distinct voice, ‘Jo! Did you ever know a prayer?’
仔细观察了他一会儿，艾伦把嘴凑到他耳边，低沉而清晰地对他说：“乔！”你知道祈祷吗？

‘Never knowd nothink, sir.’
“从来不知道，先生。”

‘Not so much as one short prayer?’
“连一个简短的祈祷都没有吗？”

‘No, sir. Nothink at all. Mr. Chadbands he wos a-prayin wunst at Mr. Sangsby’s and I heerd him, but he sounded as if he wos aspeakin to hisself, and not to me. He prayed a lot, but I couldn’t make out nothink on it. Different times there was other genlmen come down Tom-all-Alone’s a-prayin, but they all mostly sed as the t’other ‘wuns prayed wrong, and all mostly sounded to be a-talking to theirselves, or a-passing blame on the t’others, and not atalkin to us. WE never knowd nothink. I never knowd what it wos all about.’
'不，先生。一点也不想。查德先生说他在桑斯比先生那里祈祷，我听到了他的声音，但他听起来好像是在自言自语，而不是对我说话。他祈祷了很多，但我却看不出有什么想法。不同的时候，还有其他绅士来到汤姆独自祈祷，但他们大多都是因为其他“巫师”祈祷错误而发出声音，而且所有这些听起来大多是在自言自语，或者将责任推卸给自己其他人，而不是对我们说话。我们从来不知道任何想法。我从来不知道这是怎么回事。

It takes him a long time to say this, and few but an experienced and attentive listener could hear, or, hearing, understand him. After a short relapse into sleep or stupor, he makes, of a sudden, a strong effort to get out of bed.
他花了很长时间才说出这句话，除了经验丰富、细心的听众之外，很少有人能听懂他的话，或者听懂他的话。在短暂地重新进入睡眠或昏迷状态后，他突然极力想要起床。

‘Stay, Jo! What now?’
“留下来，乔！现在怎么办？'

‘It’s time for me to go to that there berryin ground, sir,’ he returns with a wild look.
“先生，我该去那片浆果地了，”他带着狂野的表情回答道。

‘Lie down, and tell me. What burying ground, Jo?’
‘躺下，告诉我。什么墓地，乔？

‘Where they laid him as wos wery good to me, wery good to me indeed, he wos. It’s time fur me to go down to that there berryin ground, sir, and ask to be put along with him. I wants to go there and be berried. He used fur to say to me, ‘I am as poor as you today, Jo,’ he ses. I wants to tell him that I am as poor as him now and have come there to be laid along with him.’
“他们把他安置在对我很好的地方，确实对我很好，他真的很好。”先生，是时候让我去那片浆果地，请求和他一起住了。我想去那里采摘浆果。他用毛皮对我说：“乔，我今天和你一样穷。”他这样说道。我想告诉他，我现在和他一样穷，来到这里是为了和他一起安息。”

‘By and by, Jo. By and by.’
“慢慢来，乔。渐渐地。’

‘Ah! P’raps they wouldn’t do it if I wos to go myself. But will you promise to have me took there, sir, and laid along with him?’
'啊！如果我自己不去的话，他们可能不会这么做。但先生，您能答应把我带到那里，和他一起躺下吗？

‘I will, indeed.’
“我确实会的。”

‘Thankee, sir. Thankee, sir. They’ll have to get the key of the gate afore they can take me in, for it’s allus locked. And there’s a step there, as I used for to clean with my broom. It’s turned wery dark, sir. Is there any light a-comin?’
“谢谢，先生。谢谢，先生。他们必须先拿到大门的钥匙才能带我进去，因为门已经锁上了。那里有一个台阶，就像我以前用扫帚清洁一样。天已经黑了，先生。有光来吗？

‘It is coming fast, Jo.’
“来得很快，乔。”

Fast. The cart is shaken all to pieces, and the rugged road is very near its end.
快速地。大车被摇得粉碎，崎岖的道路已接近尽头。

‘Jo, my poor fellow!’
“乔，我可怜的家伙！”

‘I hear you, sir, in the dark, but I’m a-gropin—a-gropin—let me catch hold of your hand.’
“我在黑暗中听到了你的声音，先生，但我是一只小兔子——一只小兔子——让我抓住你的手。”

‘Jo, can you say what I say?’
“乔，你能说出我说的话吗？”

‘I’ll say anythink as you say, sir, for I knows it’s good.’
“我会按照你说的做任何事，先生，因为我知道这很好。”

‘Our Father.’
“我们的父亲。”

‘Our Father! Yes, that’s wery good, sir.’
‘我们的父亲！是的，那很好，先生。”

‘Which art in heaven.’
“天堂里的艺术。”

‘Art in heaven—is the light a-comin, sir?’
“天堂里的艺术——光来了吗，先生？”

‘It is close at hand. Hallowed by thy name!’
‘它就在眼前。愿人都尊你的名为圣！’

‘Hallowed be—thy—‘
“愿你的——”

The light is come upon the dark benighted way. Dead!
光明已经照耀在黑暗的道路上。死的！

Dead, your Majesty. Dead, my lords and gentlemen. Dead, right reverends and wrong reverends of every order. Dead, men and women, born with heavenly compassion in your hearts. And dying thus around us every day.
死了，陛下。死了，我的大人，先生们。死了，每个教派的正确牧师和错误牧师。死去的男人和女人，生来心中就怀有天堂般的慈悲。我们每天就这样死去。

CHAPTER XLVIII
第四十八章


Closing in
逼进

The place in Lincolnshire has shut its many eyes again, and the house in town is awake. In Lincolnshire the Dedlocks of the past doze in their picture-frames, and the low wind murmurs through the long drawing-room as if they were breathing pretty regularly. In town the Dedlocks of the present rattle in their fire-eyed carriages through the darkness of the night, and the Dedlock Mercuries, with ashes (or hair-powder) on their heads, symptomatic of their great humility, loll away the drowsy mornings in the little windows of the hall. The fashionable world—tremendous orb, nearly five miles round—is in full swing, and the solar system works respectfully at its appointed distances.
林肯郡的人们再次闭上了眼睛，镇上的房子也苏醒了。在林肯郡，过去的戴德洛克夫妇在相框里打瞌睡，低风在长长的客厅里低语，仿佛他们的呼吸很有规律。在城里，现在的戴德洛克人在他们火眼金睛的马车里嘎嘎作响地穿过夜晚的黑暗，而戴德洛克水星人则头上撒着骨灰（或发粉），表现出他们极大的谦卑，懒洋洋地度过了昏昏欲睡的早晨。大厅的小窗户。时尚世界——近五英里圆的巨大球体——正在如火如荼地进行，太阳系在其指定的距离上恭敬地运转。

Where the throng is thickest, where the lights are brightest, where all the senses are ministered to with the greatest delicacy and refinement, Lady Dedlock is. From the shining heights she has scaled and taken, she is never absent. Though the belief she of old reposed in herself as one able to reserve whatsoever she would under her mantle of pride is beaten down, though she has no assurance that what she is to those around her she will remain another day, it is not in her nature when envious eyes are looking on to yield or to droop. They say of her that she has lately grown more handsome and more haughty. The debilitated cousin says of her that she’s beauty nough—tsetup shopofwomen—but rather larming kind—remindingmanfact—inconvenient woman—who WILL getoutofbedandbawthstahlishment—Shakespeare.
人群最密集的地方，灯光最亮的地方，所有感官都得到最精致和精致的服务的地方，就是戴德洛克夫人。从她所攀登和取得的辉煌高度来看，她从未缺席。虽然她过去相信自己能够在骄傲的外衣下保留自己想要保留的一切，但这种信念已经被打倒了，虽然她不能保证自己对周围人来说会是什么样子，但那并不在她的内心。当嫉妒的眼睛看着屈服或垂下时，自然。他们说她最近变得更英俊、更傲慢了。虚弱的表弟谈到她时说，她足够美丽——女人的商店——但相当令人惊叹的善良——提醒男人事实——不方便的女人——她会起床并恢复健康——莎士比亚。

Mr. Tulkinghorn says nothing, looks nothing. Now, as heretofore, he is to be found in doorways of rooms, with his limp white cravat loosely twisted into its old-fashioned tie, receiving patronage from the peerage and making no sign. Of all men he is still the last who might be supposed to have any influence upon my Lady. Of all woman she is still the last who might be supposed to have any dread of him.
图金霍恩先生什么也没说，看上去也没什么表情。现在，和以前一样，他出现在房间的门口，柔软的白色领巾松散地扭成老式领带，接受贵族的惠顾，但没有任何迹象。在所有男人中，他仍然是最后一个可能对夫人产生影响的人。在所有女人中，她仍然是最不应该害怕他的人。

One thing has been much on her mind since their late interview in his turret-room at Chesney Wold. She is now decided, and prepared to throw it off.
自从他们在切斯尼沃尔德的塔楼房间里接受采访后，一件事一直萦绕在她的心头。她现在已经决定了，并准备抛弃它。

It is morning in the great world, afternoon according to the little sun. The Mercuries, exhausted by looking out of window, are reposing in the hall and hang their heavy heads, the gorgeous creatures, like overblown sunflowers. Like them, too, they seem to run to a deal of seed in their tags and trimmings. Sir Leicester, in the library, has fallen asleep for the good of the country over the report of a Parliamentary committee. My Lady sits in the room in which she gave audience to the young man of the name of Guppy. Rosa is with her and has been writing for her and reading to her. Rosa is now at work upon embroidery or some such pretty thing, and as she bends her head over it, my Lady watches her in silence. Not for the first time to-day.
大世界是早晨，小太阳是下午。水星们疲惫不堪地看着窗外，正在大厅里休息，垂着沉重的头，这些美丽的生物就像盛开的向日葵。和它们一样，它们似乎也喜欢在标签和装饰物上撒上大量种子。莱斯特爵士在图书馆里，为了国家的利益，听着议会委员会的报告睡着了。夫人坐在她觐见名叫孔雀鱼的年轻人的房间里。罗莎和她在一起，一直在为她写作、读书给她听。罗莎现在正在刺绣或类似的漂亮东西，当她低下头时，夫人静静地看着她。今天已经不是第一次了。

‘Rosa.’
“罗莎。”

The pretty village face looks brightly up. Then, seeing how serious my Lady is, looks puzzled and surprised.
村里漂亮的脸庞显得明亮起来。然后，见夫人一脸严肃，一脸的疑惑和惊讶。

‘See to the door. Is it shut?’
‘看门口。关门了吗？

Yes. She goes to it and returns, and looks yet more surprised.
是的。她走到那儿又回来了，看上去更加惊讶了。

‘I am about to place confidence in you, child, for I know I may trust your attachment, if not your judgment. In what I am going to do, I will not disguise myself to you at least. But I confide in you. Say nothing to any one of what passes between us.’
“我即将对你充满信心，孩子，因为我知道我可能会相信你的依恋，即使不是你的判断。我要做的事，至少不会在你面前伪装自己。但我信任你。对我们之间发生的任何一件事情都不要说。

The timid little beauty promises in all earnestness to be trustworthy.
胆怯的小美女郑重承诺，值得信赖。

‘Do you know,’ Lady Dedlock asks her, signing to her to bring her chair nearer, ‘do you know, Rosa, that I am different to you from what I am to any one?’
“你知道吗？”戴德洛克夫人一边示意她把椅子拉近一点，一边问她，“你知道吗，罗莎，我对你来说和对任何人都不同？”

‘Yes, my Lady. Much kinder. But then I often think I know you as you really are.’
'好的，夫人。友善多了。但后来我常常认为我了解你的真实面目。

‘You often think you know me as I really am? Poor child, poor child!’
‘你常常认为你了解我的真实身份吗？可怜的孩子，可怜的孩子！

She says it with a kind of scorn—though not of Rosa—and sits brooding, looking dreamily at her.
她带着一种轻蔑的语气说这句话——虽然不是对罗莎——然后坐在那里沉思，出神地看着她。

‘Do you think, Rosa, you are any relief or comfort to me? Do you suppose your being young and natural, and fond of me and grateful to me, makes it any pleasure to me to have you near me?’
‘罗莎，你认为你对我有任何缓解或安慰吗？你认为你年轻、自然、喜欢我、感激我，让你靠近我会让我感到高兴吗？

‘I don’t know, my Lady; I can scarcely hope so. But with all my heart, I wish it was so.’
“我不知道，夫人；我不知道。”我几乎不能希望如此。但我真心希望如此。”

‘It is so, little one.’
“是这样的，小家伙。”

The pretty face is checked in its flush of pleasure by the dark expression on the handsome face before it. It looks timidly for an explanation.
美丽的脸庞上泛起喜悦的红晕，被面前英俊的脸庞上的阴郁表情所掩盖。它看起来胆怯地寻求解释。

‘And if I were to say to-day, ‘Go! Leave me!’ I should say what would give me great pain and disquiet, child, and what would leave me very solitary.’
“如果我今天说，‘走吧！离开我！’我应该说那些会给我带来巨大痛苦和不安的事情，孩子，以及那些会让我感到非常孤独的事情。”

‘My Lady! Have I offended you?’
'我的女士！我冒犯你了吗？

‘In nothing. Come here.’
‘什么也没有。过来。'

Rosa bends down on the footstool at my Lady’s feet. My Lady, with that motherly touch of the famous ironmaster night, lays her hand upon her dark hair and gently keeps it there.
罗莎在夫人脚边的脚凳上弯下腰。夫人，带着著名的铁匠之夜的母爱，把手放在她的黑发上，轻轻地留在那里。

‘I told you, Rosa, that I wished you to be happy and that I would make you so if I could make anybody happy on this earth. I cannot. There are reasons now known to me, reasons in which you have no part, rendering it far better for you that you should not remain here. You must not remain here. I have determined that you shall not. I have written to the father of your lover, and he will be here to-day. All this I have done for your sake.’
“我告诉过你，罗莎，我希望你幸福，如果我能让这个地球上的任何人幸福，我会让你幸福。”我不能。我现在知道一些原因，你没有参与其中的原因，因此你不应该留在这里对你来说要好得多。你不能留在这里。我已经决定你不会。我已经写信给你爱人的父亲，他今天会来。我所做的这一切都是为了你。

The weeping girl covers her hand with kisses and says what shall she do, what shall she do, when they are separated! Her mistress kisses her on the cheek and makes no other answer.
哭泣的女孩亲吻着她的手，说当他们分开时她该怎么办，她该怎么办！她的女主人亲吻了她的脸颊，没有做出其他回答。

‘Now, be happy, child, under better circumstances. Be beloved and happy!’
‘现在，孩子，在更好的环境下要快乐。被爱并快乐！

‘Ah, my Lady, I have sometimes thought—forgive my being so free— that YOU are not happy.’
“啊，我的女士，我有时会想——请原谅我这么自由——你不快乐。”

‘I!’
'我！'

‘Will you be more so when you have sent me away? Pray, pray, think again. Let me stay a little while!’
‘当你把我送走后，你会更这样吗？祈祷，祈祷，再想一想。让我呆一会儿吧！

‘I have said, my child, that what I do, I do for your sake, not my own. It is done. What I am towards you, Rosa, is what I am now— not what I shall be a little while hence. Remember this, and keep my confidence. Do so much for my sake, and thus all ends between us!’
“我说过，我的孩子，我所做的一切都是为了你，而不是为了我自己。完成了。罗莎，我对你的态度是现在的我，而不是不久之后的我。请记住这一点，并保持信心。为了我做这么多，我们之间的一切就这样结束了！”

She detaches herself from her simple-hearted companion and leaves the room. Late in the afternoon, when she next appears upon the staircase, she is in her haughtiest and coldest state. As indifferent as if all passion, feeling, and interest had been worn out in the earlier ages of the world and had perished from its surface with its other departed monsters.
她与心地单纯的同伴分开，离开了房间。下午晚些时候，当她再次出现在楼梯上时，她处于最傲慢和最冷酷的状态。冷漠得仿佛所有的激情、感觉和兴趣都在这个世界的早期时代被磨灭了，并与其他死去的怪物一起从它的表面消失了。

Mercury has announced Mr. Rouncewell, which is the cause of her appearance. Mr. Rouncewell is not in the library, but she repairs to the library. Sir Leicester is there, and she wishes to speak to him first.
水星宣布了朗斯韦尔先生，这也是她出现的原因。朗斯韦尔先生不在图书馆，但她去了图书馆。莱斯特爵士在那里，她想先和他谈谈。

‘Sir Leicester, I am desirous—but you are engaged.’
“莱斯特爵士，我很渴望——但你已经订婚了。”

Oh, dear no! Not at all. Only Mr. Tulkinghorn.
哦，天哪，不！一点也不。只有图金霍恩先生。

Always at hand. Haunting every place. No relief or security from him for a moment.
随时可用。出没于每一个地方。他暂时没有得到任何缓解或安全感。

‘I beg your pardon, Lady Dedlock. Will you allow me to retire?’
“请您原谅，戴德洛克女士。你能让我退休吗？

With a look that plainly says, ‘You know you have the power to remain if you will,’ she tells him it is not necessary and moves towards a chair. Mr. Tulkinghorn brings it a little forward for her with his clumsy bow and retires into a window opposite. Interposed between her and the fading light of day in the now quiet street, his shadow falls upon her, and he darkens all before her. Even so does he darken her life.
她的表情清楚地表明：“你知道，如果你愿意，你有能力留下来。”她告诉他没有必要，然后走向一把椅子。图金霍恩先生用他笨拙的鞠躬为她稍稍前了一步，然后退到对面的窗户里。在现在安静的街道上，他的影子插在她和逐渐暗淡的日光之间，落在她身上，她面前的一切都变暗了。即便如此，他还是让她的生活变得黑暗。

It is a dull street under the best conditions, where the two long rows of houses stare at each other with that severity that half-adozen of its greatest mansions seem to have been slowly stared into stone rather than originally built in that material. It is a street of such dismal grandeur, so determined not to condescend to liveliness, that the doors and windows hold a gloomy state of their own in black paint and dust, and the echoing mews behind have a dry and massive appearance, as if they were reserved to stable the stone chargers of noble statues. Complicated garnish of iron-work entwines itself over the flights of steps in this awful street, and from these petrified bowers, extinguishers for obsolete flambeaux gasp at the upstart gas. Here and there a weak little iron hoop, through which bold boys aspire to throw their friends’ caps (its only present use), retains its place among the rusty foliage, sacred to the memory of departed oil. Nay, even oil itself, yet lingering at long intervals in a little absurd glass pot, with a knob in the bottom like an oyster, blinks and sulks at newer lights every night, like its high and dry master in the House of Lords.
在最好的条件下，这是一条沉闷的街道，两排长长的房屋相互凝视着，六座最大的豪宅似乎慢慢地凝视在石头上，而不是最初用石头建造的。这是一条如此凄凉而宏伟的街道，如此决意不屈尊于热闹，以至于门窗在黑漆和灰尘中保持着自己的阴暗状态，而后面回响的马厩看起来干燥而厚重，仿佛它们被保留来稳定高贵雕像的石马。在这条可怕的街道上，复杂的铁制品装饰缠绕在台阶上，从这些石化的凉亭里，过时的火炬的灭火器在暴发户的煤气中喘息着。到处都有一个脆弱的小铁箍，勇敢的男孩们渴望通过它扔朋友的帽子（它目前唯一的用途），在生锈的树叶中保留着它的位置，对逝去的石油的记忆是神圣的。不仅如此，甚至连油本身，也会在一个小而荒谬的玻璃罐里长时间地徘徊，底部有一个像牡蛎一样的旋钮，每天晚上都会在新的灯光下眨眼和生闷气，就像它在上议院的高调和干燥的主人一样。

Therefore there is not much that Lady Dedlock, seated in her chair, could wish to see through the window in which Mr. Tulkinghorn stands. And yet—and yet—she sends a look in that direction as if it were her heart’s desire to have that figure moved out of the way.
因此，坐在椅子上的戴德洛克女士希望透过图金霍恩先生所站的窗户看到的东西并不多。然而——然而——她朝那个方向看了一眼，仿佛她内心渴望让那个身影走开。

Sir Leicester begs his Lady’s pardon. She was about to say?
莱斯特爵士请求夫人原谅。她正想说什么？

‘Only that Mr. Rouncewell is here (he has called by my appointment) and that we had better make an end of the question of that girl. I am tired to death of the matter.’
“只是朗斯韦尔先生在这里（他是按照我的预约打来的），我们最好结束那个女孩的问题。我对这件事厌倦得要死。

‘What can I do—to—assist?’ demands Sir Leicester in some considerable doubt.
“我能做什么——帮助——吗？”莱斯特爵士带着相当大的疑问问道。

‘Let us see him here and have done with it. Will you tell them to send him up?’
“让我们在这里见见他，事情就结束了。你会告诉他们送他上去吗？

‘Mr. Tulkinghorn, be so good as to ring. Thank you. Request,’ says Sir Leicester to Mercury, not immediately remembering the business term, ‘request the iron gentleman to walk this way.’
'先生。图金霍恩，快来敲响吧。谢谢。 “请求，”莱斯特爵士对墨丘利说道，但他并没有立即想起这个商业术语，“请求铁绅士走这条路。”

Mercury departs in search of the iron gentleman, finds, and produces him. Sir Leicester receives that ferruginous person graciously.
水星出发寻找铁绅，找到并生下了他。莱斯特爵士亲切地接待了那个铁石心肠的人。

‘I hope you are well, Mr. Rouncewell. Be seated. (My solicitor, Mr. Tulkinghorn.) My Lady was desirous, Mr. Rouncewell,’ Sir Leicester skilfully transfers him with a solemn wave of his hand, ‘was desirous to speak with you. Hem!’
“我希望你一切都好，朗斯韦尔先生。就座。 （我的律师，图金霍恩先生。） 夫人很想，朗斯韦尔先生，”莱斯特爵士熟练地把他转移开，庄严地挥了挥手，“想和您谈谈。哼！’

‘I shall be very happy,’ returns the iron gentleman, ‘to give my best attention to anything Lady Dedlock does me the honour to say.’
“我会很高兴，”钢铁绅士回答道，“对戴德洛克女士有幸说的任何事情都给予我最大的关注。”

As he turns towards her, he finds that the impression she makes upon him is less agreeable than on the former occasion. A distant supercilious air makes a cold atmosphere about her, and there is nothing in her bearing, as there was before, to encourage openness.
当他转向她时，他发现她给他的印象不如上次那么令人愉快。一种疏远的傲慢态度使她周围气氛冷漠，而且她的举止不像以前那样有任何鼓励开放的地方。

‘Pray, sir,’ says Lady Dedlock listlessly, ‘may I be allowed to inquire whether anything has passed between you and your son respecting your son’s fancy?’
“请问，先生，”戴德洛克夫人无精打采地说，“我可以询问一下您和您儿子之间是否发生过任何尊重您儿子的幻想的事情吗？”

It is almost too troublesome to her languid eyes to bestow a look upon him as she asks this question.
当她问这个问题时，她那双无精打采的眼睛几乎无法看他一眼。

‘If my memory serves me, Lady Dedlock, I said, when I had the pleasure of seeing you before, that I should seriously advise my son to conquer that—fancy.’ The ironmaster repeats her expression with a little emphasis.
“如果我没记错的话，戴德洛克夫人，当我以前有幸见到你时，我说过，我应该认真地建议我的儿子克服这个幻想。”铁匠稍微强调了一遍她的表情。

‘And did you?’
“你呢？”

‘Oh! Of course I did.’
'哦！我当然做了。'

Sir Leicester gives a nod, approving and confirmatory. Very proper. The iron gentleman, having said that he would do it, was bound to do it. No difference in this respect between the base metals and the precious. Highly proper.
莱斯特爵士点点头，表示认可和确认。非常恰当。铁君子既然说到做到，那就一定要做到。在这方面，贱金属和贵金属之间没有区别。非常合适。

‘And pray has he done so?’
“请问他这样做了吗？”

‘Really, Lady Dedlock, I cannot make you a definite reply. I fear not. Probably not yet. In our condition of life, we sometimes couple an intention with our—our fancies which renders them not altogether easy to throw off. I think it is rather our way to be in earnest.’
“说实话，戴德洛克女士，我无法给你一个明确的答复。我担心不会。可能还没有。在我们的生活状况中，我们有时会将意图与我们的幻想结合起来，这使得它们不容易被抛弃。我认为这才是我们认真的方式。

Sir Leicester has a misgiving that there may be a hidden Wat Tylerish meaning in this expression, and fumes a little. Mr. Rouncewell is perfectly good-humoured and polite, but within such limits, evidently adapts his tone to his reception.
莱斯特爵士怀疑这句话中可能隐藏着瓦特·泰勒里什的意思，并有点生气。朗斯韦尔先生脾气很好，很有礼貌，但在这种限度内，他显然会根据接待情况调整自己的语气。

‘Because,’ proceeds my Lady, ‘I have been thinking of the subject, which is tiresome to me.’
“因为，”夫人继续说道，“我一直在思考这个话题，这让我感到厌烦。”

‘I am very sorry, I am sure.’
“我确信，我非常抱歉。”

‘And also of what Sir Leicester said upon it, in which I quite concur’—Sir Leicester flattered—‘and if you cannot give us the assurance that this fancy is at an end, I have come to the conclusion that the girl had better leave me.’
“还有莱斯特爵士对此的看法，我非常同意”——莱斯特爵士受宠若惊——“如果你不能向我们保证这种幻想已经结束，我得出的结论是，这个女孩最好离开我吧。

‘I can give no such assurance, Lady Dedlock. Nothing of the kind.’
“我不能给出这样的保证，戴德洛克女士。根本不是这样的。

‘Then she had better go.’
“那她最好走吧。”

‘Excuse me, my Lady,’ Sir Leicester considerately interposes, ‘but perhaps this may be doing an injury to the young woman which she has not merited. Here is a young woman,’ says Sir Leicester, magnificently laying out the matter with his right hand like a service of plate, ‘whose good fortune it is to have attracted the notice and favour of an eminent lady and to live, under the protection of that eminent lady, surrounded by the various advantages which such a position confers, and which are unquestionably very great—I believe unquestionably very great, sir—for a young woman in that station of life. The question then arises, should that young woman be deprived of these many advantages and that good fortune simply because she has’—Sir Leicester, with an apologetic but dignified inclination of his head towards the ironmaster, winds up his sentence—‘has attracted the notice of Mr Rouncewell’s son? Now, has she deserved this punishment? Is this just towards her? Is this our previous understanding?’
“对不起，夫人，”莱斯特爵士体贴地插话道，“但这也许对这位年轻女子造成了不应有的伤害。这是一位年轻女子，”莱斯特爵士说道，他用右手像盘子一样华丽地摆出了这件事，“她的幸运在于吸引了一位杰出女士的注意和青睐，并在她的保护下生活这位杰出的女士，周围环绕着这样一个职位所赋予的各种优势，这些优势对于处于这种生活地位的年轻女性来说无疑是非常伟大的——我相信毫无疑问是非常伟大的，先生。那么问题来了，这位年轻女子是否应该被剥夺这么多的优势和好运，仅仅因为她“——莱斯特爵士带着歉意但庄重的头向钢铁大师倾斜，结束了他的判决——”吸引了注意到朗斯韦尔先生的儿子了吗？现在，她该受这样的惩罚吗？这只是针对她吗？这是我们之前的理解吗？

‘I beg your pardon,’ interposes Mr. Rouncewell’s son’s father. ‘Sir Leicester, will you allow me? I think I may shorten the subject. Pray dismiss that from your consideration. If you remember anything so unimportant—which is not to be expected—you would recollect that my first thought in the affair was directly opposed to her remaining here.’
“请原谅，”朗斯韦尔先生儿子的父亲插话道。 “莱斯特爵士，你可以允许我吗？我想我可以缩短这个话题。请不要考虑这一点。如果你还记得如此不重要的事情——这是不可能的——你会记得我在这件事上的第一个想法是直接反对她留在这里。

Dismiss the Dedlock patronage from consideration? Oh! Sir Leicester is bound to believe a pair of ears that have been handed down to him through such a family, or he really might have mistrusted their report of the iron gentleman’s observations.
不考虑戴德洛克的赞助？哦！莱斯特爵士必然会相信这样一个家族传给他的一双耳朵，否则他可能真的不相信他们关于铁绅士观察的报告。

‘It is not necessary,’ observes my Lady in her coldest manner before he can do anything but breathe amazedly, ‘to enter into these matters on either side. The girl is a very good girl; I have nothing whatever to say against her, but she is so far insensible to her many advantages and her good fortune that she is in love—or supposes she is, poor little fool—and unable to appreciate them.’
“没有必要，”我的夫人以她最冷漠的态度说道，在他只能惊讶地呼吸之前，“没有必要从任何一方介入这些事情。”这个女孩是一个非常好的女孩；我对她没有什么可说的，但到目前为止，她对自己的许多优点和她的好运都麻木不仁，以至于她恋爱了——或者假设她恋爱了，可怜的小傻瓜——却无法欣赏它们。

Sir Leicester begs to observe that wholly alters the case. He might have been sure that my Lady had the best grounds and reasons in support of her view. He entirely agrees with my Lady. The young woman had better go.
莱斯特爵士请求观察，这完全改变了情况。他可能确信夫人有最好的理由和理由来支持她的观点。他完全同意夫人的观点。这位年轻女子最好还是走吧。

‘As Sir Leicester observed, Mr. Rouncewell, on the last occasion when we were fatigued by this business,’ Lady Dedlock languidly proceeds, ‘we cannot make conditions with you. Without conditions, and under present circumstances, the girl is quite misplaced here and had better go. I have told her so. Would you wish to have her sent back to the village, or would you like to take her with you, or what would you prefer?’
“正如莱斯特爵士所说，朗斯韦尔先生，上次我们对这件事感到厌倦时，”戴德洛克夫人懒洋洋地继续说道，“我们不能向你提出条件。没有条件，在现在的情况下，女孩子实在是太不合适了，还是走吧。我已经这样告诉她了。你想让她送回村子，还是带她一起走，或者你更喜欢什么？

‘Lady Dedlock, if I may speak plainly—‘
“戴德洛克女士，请让我直白地说——”

‘By all means.’
“无论如何。”

‘—I should prefer the course which will the soonest relieve you of the incumbrance and remove her from her present position.’
“——我更喜欢那种能尽快解除你的负担并让她离开目前职位的做法。”

‘And to speak as plainly,’ she returns with the same studied carelessness, ‘so should I. Do I understand that you will take her with you?’
“坦白地说，”她带着同样故意的漫不经心回答道，“我也应该这么做。我明白你会带她一起走吗？”

The iron gentleman makes an iron bow.
铁君子造铁弓。

‘Sir Leicester, will you ring?’ Mr. Tulkinghorn steps forward from his window and pulls the bell. ‘I had forgotten you. Thank you.’ He makes his usual bow and goes quietly back again. Mercury, swift-responsive, appears, receives instructions whom to produce, skims away, produces the aforesaid, and departs.
“莱斯特爵士，您愿意按铃吗？”图金霍恩先生从窗户向前走去，拉响了门铃。 ‘我已经忘记你了。谢谢你。”他像往常一样鞠了一躬，然后又悄悄地回去了。水星反应迅速，出现，接受指令，产生，掠过，产生上述内容，然后离开。

Rosa has been crying and is yet in distress. On her coming in, the ironmaster leaves his chair, takes her arm in his, and remains with her near the door ready to depart.
罗莎一直在哭泣，但仍然很痛苦。她一进来，铁匠就离开了椅子，挽着她的手臂，和她一起站在门口准备离开。

‘You are taken charge of, you see,’ says my Lady in her weary manner, ‘and are going away well protected. I have mentioned that you are a very good girl, and you have nothing to cry for.’
“你知道，你已经被接管了，”我的夫人疲惫地说道，“并且会受到很好的保护。”我说过你是一个非常好的女孩，你没有什么可哭的。

‘She seems after all,’ observes Mr. Tulkinghorn, loitering a little forward with his hands behind him, ‘as if she were crying at going away.’
“她毕竟看起来，”图尔金霍恩先生观察到，他双手放在身后，稍微向前走动，“好像她在离开时哭了。”

‘Why, she is not well-bred, you see,’ returns Mr. Rouncewell with some quickness in his manner, as if he were glad to have the lawyer to retort upon, ‘and she is an inexperienced little thing and knows no better. If she had remained here, sir, she would have improved, no doubt.’
“哎呀，你看，她没有受过良好的教养，”朗斯韦尔先生语气有些敏捷地回答道，仿佛他很高兴有律师来反驳，“而且她是个没有经验的小东西，一无所知。” 。先生，如果她留在这里，毫无疑问她会有所进步。”

‘No doubt,’ is Mr. Tulkinghorn’s composed reply.
“毫无疑问，”图尔金霍恩先生冷静地回答道。

Rosa sobs out that she is very sorry to leave my Lady, and that she was happy at Chesney Wold, and has been happy with my Lady, and that she thanks my Lady over and over again. ‘Out, you silly little puss!’ says the ironmaster, checking her in a low voice, though not angrily. ‘Have a spirit, if you’re fond of Watt!’ My Lady merely waves her off with indifference, saying, ‘There, there, child! You are a good girl. Go away!’ Sir Leicester has magnificently disengaged himself from the subject and retired into the sanctuary of his blue coat. Mr. Tulkinghorn, an indistinct form against the dark street now dotted with lamps, looms in my Lady’s view, bigger and blacker than before.
罗莎抽泣着说，她很遗憾离开我的夫人，她在切斯尼沃尔德过得很开心，和我的夫人在一起很开心，她一遍又一遍地感谢我的夫人。 “滚出去，你这个愚蠢的小猫！”钢铁大师低声检查着她，但并不生气。 “如果你喜欢瓦特，就打点精神吧！”夫人只是冷漠地挥手示意她走开，说道：“好了，好了，孩子！”你是个好女孩。走开！”莱斯特爵士华丽地摆脱了这个话题，退到了蓝色外套的避难所里。图金霍恩先生的身影在现在点缀着灯光的黑暗街道上隐约可见，在夫人的视野中若隐若现，比以前更大更黑。

‘Sir Leicester and Lady Dedlock,’ says Mr. Rouncewell after a pause of a few moments, ‘I beg to take my leave, with an apology for having again troubled you, though not of my own act, on this tiresome subject. I can very well understand, I assure you, how tiresome so small a matter must have become to Lady Dedlock.
