‘Nay, my dears,’ he would remonstrate; and when I saw Caddy’s thin arm about his fat neck as he said it, I would be melted too, though not by the same process. ‘Nay, nay! I have promised never to leave ye. Be dutiful and affectionate towards me, and I ask no other return. Now, bless ye! I am going to the Park.’
“不，亲爱的，”他会抗议道。当我看到凯迪说这句话时，他瘦弱的手臂搂着他肥胖的脖子，我也会被融化，尽管不是通过同样的过程。 ‘不，不！我已经答应永远不会离开你们。对我尽职尽责、充满感情，我不求其他回报。现在，祝福你们！我要去公园。'

He would take the air there presently and get an appetite for his hotel dinner. I hope I do old Mr. Turveydrop no wrong, but I never saw any better traits in him than these I faithfully record, except that he certainly conceived a liking for Peepy and would take the child out walking with great pomp, always on those occasions sending him home before he went to dinner himself, and occasionally with a halfpenny in his pocket. But even this disinterestedness was attended with no inconsiderable cost, to my knowledge, for before Peepy was sufficiently decorated to walk hand in hand with the professor of deportment, he had to be newly dressed, at the expense of Caddy and her husband, from top to toe.
他很快就会去那里呼吸空气，并有胃口地享用酒店的晚餐。我希望我没有做错特维德罗普老先生，但我在他身上从未见过比我忠实记录的这些更好的品质，除了他肯定喜欢皮皮，并且总是在那些场合带着孩子出去散步，总是很盛况在他自己去吃晚饭之前送他回家，有时口袋里还揣着半个便士。但据我所知，即使是这种无私的态度也付出了不小的代价，因为在皮比获得足够的装饰以与举止教授携手同行之前，他必须从上到下以凯迪和她丈夫为代价，换上新衣服。到脚趾。

Last of our visitors, there was Mr. Jellyby. Really when he used to come in of an evening, and ask Caddy in his meek voice how she was, and then sit down with his head against the wall, and make no attempt to say anything more, I liked him very much. If he found me bustling about doing any little thing, he sometimes half took his coat off, as if with an intention of helping by a great exertion; but he never got any further. His sole occupation was to sit with his head against the wall, looking hard at the thoughtful baby; and I could not quite divest my mind of a fancy that they understood one another.
最后一位访客是杰利比先生。真的，当他晚上进来，用温柔的声音问凯迪怎么样，然后头靠在墙上坐下来，不再试图再说什么时，我非常喜欢他。如果他发现我忙着做点小事，有时他会把外套脱掉一半，似乎是想尽力帮忙；但他再也没有进一步。他唯一的任务就是头靠墙坐着，凝视着若有所思的婴儿。我无法完全放弃他们彼此理解的幻想。

I have not counted Mr. Woodcourt among our visitors because he was now Caddy’s regular attendant. She soon began to improve under his care, but he was so gentle, so skilful, so unwearying in the pains he took that it is not to be wondered at, I am sure. I saw a good deal of Mr. Woodcourt during this time, though not so much as might be supposed, for knowing Caddy to be safe in his hands, I often slipped home at about the hours when he was expected. We frequently met, notwithstanding. I was quite reconciled to myself now, but I still felt glad to think that he was sorry for me, and he still WAS sorry for me I believed. He helped Mr. Badger in his professional engagements, which were numerous, and had as yet no settled projects for the future.
我没有把伍德考特先生算在我们的访客之列，因为他现在是凯迪的常客。在他的照顾下，她的病情很快开始好转，但他是如此温柔，如此熟练，如此不辞辛劳，我相信这并不奇怪。这段时间我经常见到伍德考特先生，尽管没有想象中那么多，因为我知道球童在他手里很安全，所以我经常在他预计的时间溜回家。尽管如此，我们还是经常见面。我现在对自己很和解，但我仍然很高兴想到他为我感到难过，而且我相信他仍然为我感到难过。他在巴杰尔先生的职业生涯中为他提供了很多帮助，但目前还没有确定的未来计划。

It was when Caddy began to recover that I began to notice a change in my dear girl. I cannot say how it first presented itself to me, because I observed it in many slight particulars which were nothing in themselves and only became something when they were pieced together. But I made it out, by putting them together, that Ada was not so frankly cheerful with me as she used to be. Her tenderness for me was as loving and true as ever; I did not for a moment doubt that; but there was a quiet sorrow about her which she did not confide to me, and in which I traced some hidden regret.
当凯迪开始康复时，我开始注意到我亲爱的女儿发生了变化。我无法说出它最初是如何呈现在我面前的，因为我在许多细微的细节中观察到了它，这些细节本身并无什么，只有当它们拼凑在一起时才成为某种东西。但通过将它们放在一起，我发现艾达对我并不像以前那样坦率地高兴。她对我的温柔一如既往地充满爱意和真诚。我对此毫不怀疑；但她身上有一种平静的悲伤，她没有向我吐露，我在其中找到了一些隐藏的遗憾。

Now, I could not understand this, and I was so anxious for the happiness of my own pet that it caused me some uneasiness and set me thinking often. At length, feeling sure that Ada suppressed this something from me lest it should make me unhappy too, it came into my head that she was a little grieved—for me—by what I had told her about Bleak House.
现在，我无法理解这一点，而且我对自己的宠物的幸福如此着急，这让我感到有些不安，并经常让我思考。最后，我确信艾达对我隐瞒了这件事，以免让我也不高兴，我的脑海里浮现出她对我告诉她《荒凉山庄》的事感到有点悲伤——为我而悲伤。

How I persuaded myself that this was likely, I don’t know. I had no idea that there was any selfish reference in my doing so. I was not grieved for myself: I was quite contented and quite happy. Still, that Ada might be thinking—for me, though I had abandoned all such thoughts—of what once was, but was now all changed, seemed so easy to believe that I believed it.
我不知道我是如何说服自己相信这是可能的。我不知道我这样做有什么自私的成分。我并不为自己悲伤：我很满足，也很快乐。尽管如此，艾达可能正在思考——对我来说，尽管我已经放弃了所有这些想法——曾经是但现在一切都改变了的事情，似乎很容易相信我相信它。

What could I do to reassure my darling (I considered then) and show her that I had no such feelings? Well! I could only be as brisk and busy as possible, and that I had tried to be all along. However, as Caddy’s illness had certainly interfered, more or less, with my home duties—though I had always been there in the morning to make my guardian’s breakfast, and he had a hundred times laughed and said there must be two little women, for his little woman was never missing—I resolved to be doubly diligent and gay. So I went about the house humming all the tunes I knew, and I sat working and working in a desperate manner, and I talked and talked, morning, noon, and night.
我该怎么做才能让我亲爱的（我当时考虑过）放心并向她表明我没有这种感觉？出色地！我只能尽可能地活跃和忙碌，而且我一直在努力做到这一点。然而，凯迪的病确实或多或少地干扰了我的家务——尽管我早上总是在那里为我的监护人做早餐，而他却笑了一百次，说肯定有两个小女人，因为他的小女人从来没有失踪过——我决心加倍勤奋、快乐。于是我在屋里走来走去，哼着所有我熟悉的曲子，绝望地坐着工作，不停地工作，从早上、中午到晚上，我一直在说啊说啊。

And still there was the same shade between me and my darling.
但我和我亲爱的之间仍然存在着同样的阴影。

‘So, Dame Trot,’ observed my guardian, shutting up his book one night when we were all three together, ‘so Woodcourt has restored Caddy Jellyby to the full enjoyment of life again?’
“那么，特洛特夫人，”一天晚上我们三人在一起时，我的监护人合上书，说道，“那么伍德考特已经让球童杰利比再次充分享受生活了？”

‘Yes,’ I said; ‘and to be repaid by such gratitude as hers is to be made rich, guardian.’
“是的，”我说。 “如果得到她这样的感激之情，你就会变得富有，监护人。”

‘I wish it was,’ he returned, ‘with all my heart.’
“我希望如此，”他回答道，“我全心全意地希望如此。”

So did I too, for that matter. I said so.
就此而言，我也是如此。我是这么说的。

‘Aye! We would make him as rich as a Jew if we knew how. Would we not, little woman?’
‘是啊！如果我们知道怎么做的话，我们会让他像犹太人一样富有。我们不会吗，小女人？

I laughed as I worked and replied that I was not sure about that, for it might spoil him, and he might not be so useful, and there might be many who could ill spare him. As Miss Flite, and Caddy herself, and many others.
我一边干活一边笑，回答说我对此并不确定，因为这可能会宠坏他，而且他可能不会那么有用，而且可能有很多人饶不了他。作为弗利特小姐、凯迪本人以及许多其他人。

‘True,’ said my guardian. ‘I had forgotten that. But we would agree to make him rich enough to live, I suppose? Rich enough to work with tolerable peace of mind? Rich enough to have his own happy home and his own household gods—and household goddess, too, perhaps?’
“是的，”我的监护人说。 ‘我已经忘记了。但我想我们会同意让他有足够的钱生活下去吧？足够富有，可以安心地工作吗？足够富有，拥有自己幸福的家和自己的家庭神——也许还有家庭女神？

That was quite another thing, I said. We must all agree in that.
我说，那是另一回事了。我们都必须同意这一点。

‘To be sure,’ said my guardian. ‘All of us. I have a great regard for Woodcourt, a high esteem for him; and I have been sounding him delicately about his plans. It is difficult to offer aid to an independent man with that just kind of pride which he possesses. And yet I would be glad to do it if I might or if I knew how. He seems half inclined for another voyage. But that appears like casting such a man away.’
“当然，”我的监护人说。 ‘我们所有人。我非常尊重伍德考特，非常尊敬他。我一直在小心翼翼地向他询问他的计划。很难向一个具有这种自豪感的独立人提供帮助。然而，如果可以的话或者如果我知道如何去做的话，我会很乐意这样做。他似乎有点想再次航行。但这似乎等于抛弃了这样一个人。”

‘It might open a new world to him,’ said I.
“这可能会为他打开一个新世界，”我说。

‘’So it might, little woman,’ my guardian assented. ‘’I doubt if he expects much of the old world. Do you know I have fancied that he sometimes feels some particular disappointment or misfortune encountered in it. You never heard of anything of that sort?’
“可能是这样，小女人，”我的监护人同意道。 “我怀疑他是否对旧世界抱有太多期望。你知道吗，我猜想他有时会感到某种特别的失望或不幸。你从来没有听说过这样的事情吗？

I shook my head.
我摇摇头。

‘Humph,’ said my guardian. ‘I am mistaken, I dare say.’ As there was a little pause here, which I thought, for my dear girl’s satisfaction, had better be filled up, I hummed an air as I worked which was a favourite with my guardian.
“哼，”我的监护人说。 “我敢说，我错了。”因为这里有一点停顿，我想，为了让我亲爱的女儿满意，最好把它填满，我一边工作一边哼着小调，这是我的监护人最喜欢的。

‘And do you think Mr. Woodcourt will make another voyage?’ I asked him when I had hummed it quietly all through.
“你认为伍德考特先生还会再次航行吗？”当我低声哼着这首歌时，我问他。

‘I don’t quite know what to think, my dear, but I should say it was likely at present that he will give a long trip to another country.’
“我不太知道该怎么想，亲爱的，但我应该说，目前他很可能会去另一个国家进行长途旅行。”

‘I am sure he will take the best wishes of all our hearts with him wherever he goes,’ said I; ‘and though they are not riches, he will never be the poorer for them, guardian, at least.’
“我相信，无论他走到哪里，他都会带着我们所有人衷心的最美好的祝愿，”我说。 “虽然它们不是财富，但至少，监护人，他永远不会因为它们而变得更穷。”

‘Never, little woman,’ he replied.
“从来没有，小女人，”他回答道。

I was sitting in my usual place, which was now beside my guardian’s chair. That had not been my usual place before the letter, but it was now. I looked up to Ada, who was sitting opposite, and I saw, as she looked at me, that her eyes were filled with tears and that tears were falling down her face. I felt that I had only to be placid and merry once for all to undeceive my dear and set her loving heart at rest. I really was so, and I had nothing to do but to be myself.
我坐在原来的位置，现在在我监护人的椅子旁边。在收到这封信之前，那不是我常去的地方，但现在是了。我抬头看向坐在对面的艾达，当她看着我时，我看到她的眼睛里充满了泪水，泪水从她的脸上滑落下来。我觉得我只要表现得平静、快乐一次，就能让我亲爱的人不再受骗，让她那颗慈爱的心得到安息。我确实就是这样，除了做我自己，我别无他法。

So I made my sweet girl lean upon my shoulder—how little thinking what was heavy on her mind!—and I said she was not quite well, and put my arm about her, and took her upstairs. When we were in our own room, and when she might perhaps have told me what I was so unprepared to hear, I gave her no encouragement to confide in me; I never thought she stood in need of it.
于是我让我可爱的女儿靠在我的肩膀上——她心里的重担是多么少啊！——我说她不太舒服，然后用胳膊搂住她，带她上楼。当我们在自己的房间里时，当她也许会告诉我我完全没有准备好听到的事情时，我没有鼓励她向我吐露心声。我从没想过她需要它。

‘Oh, my dear good Esther,’ said Ada, ‘if I could only make up my mind to speak to you and my cousin John when you are together!’
“哦，我亲爱的艾丝特，”艾达说，“要是我能下定决心，当你们和我的表弟约翰在一起的时候，能和你们说话就好了！”

‘Why, my love!’ I remonstrated. ‘Ada, why should you not speak to us!’
“为什么，亲爱的！”我抗议道。 “艾达，你为什么不跟我们说话！”

Ada only dropped her head and pressed me closer to her heart.
艾达只是低下头，把我贴近她的心。

‘You surely don’t forget, my beauty,’ said I, smiling, ‘what quiet, old-fashioned people we are and how I have settled down to be the discreetest of dames? You don’t forget how happily and peacefully my life is all marked out for me, and by whom? I am certain that you don’t forget by what a noble character, Ada. That can never be.’
“你一定不会忘记，我的美人，”我微笑着说，“我们是多么安静、守旧的人，而我是如何安定下来成为最谨慎的贵妇的？你不会忘记我的生活是多么幸福和平静，是由谁来规划的？我确信你不会忘记艾达的高尚品格。那永远不可能。

‘No, never, Esther.’
“不，从来没有，埃丝特。”

‘Why then, my dear,’ said I, ‘there can be nothing amiss—and why should you not speak to us?’
“那么，亲爱的，”我说，“不会有什么问题的——为什么你不跟我们说话呢？”

‘Nothing amiss, Esther?’ returned Ada. ‘Oh, when I think of all these years, and of his fatherly care and kindness, and of the old relations among us, and of you, what shall I do, what shall I do!’
“没有什么问题吗，埃丝特？”艾达回答道。 “哦，当我想起这些年来，想起他父亲般的关怀和仁慈，想起我们之间的旧关系，还有你，我该怎么办，我该怎么办！”

I looked at my child in some wonder, but I thought it better not to answer otherwise than by cheering her, and so I turned off into many little recollections of our life together and prevented her from saying more. When she lay down to sleep, and not before, I returned to my guardian to say good night, and then I came back to Ada and sat near her for a little while.
我有些惊奇地看着我的孩子，但我认为最好不要回答，而是为她欢呼，所以我开始回忆我们在一起的生活，不让她再说更多。当她躺下睡觉时，而不是之前，我回到我的监护人那里道晚安，然后我回到艾达身边，在她身边坐了一会儿。

She was asleep, and I thought as I looked at her that she was a little changed. I had thought so more than once lately. I could not decide, even looking at her while she was unconscious, how she was changed, but something in the familiar beauty of her face looked different to me. My guardian’s old hopes of her and Richard arose sorrowfully in my mind, and I said to myself, ‘She has been anxious about him,’ and I wondered how that love would end.
她睡着了，我看着她，觉得她有点变了。我最近不止一次这么想。即使在她失去知觉时看着她，我也无法确定她发生了怎样的变化，但她熟悉的美丽面孔中的某些东西对我来说似乎有所不同。我的脑海里悲伤地升起监护人对她和理查德的旧日希望，我对自己说：“她一直为他担心。”我想知道这段爱情将如何结束。

When I had come home from Caddy’s while she was ill, I had often found Ada at work, and she had always put her work away, and I had never known what it was. Some of it now lay in a drawer near her, which was not quite closed. I did not open the drawer, but I still rather wondered what the work could he, for it was evidently nothing for herself.
当我从凯迪生病时从她那里回家时，我经常发现艾达在工作，而她总是把工作收起来，而我从来不知道那是什么。其中一些现在放在她附近的抽屉里，抽屉没有完全关闭。我没有打开抽屉，但我还是很想知道他能做什么，因为这显然对她来说没什么意义。

And I noticed as I kissed my dear that she lay with one hand under her pillow so that it was hidden.
当我亲吻我亲爱的时，我注意到她把一只手放在枕头下面，这样它就被隐藏起来了。

How much less amiable I must have been than they thought me, how much less amiable than I thought myself, to be so preoccupied with my own cheerfulness and contentment as to think that it only rested with me to put my dear girl right and set her mind at peace!
我一定比他们想象的更不和蔼可亲，比我自己想象的更不和蔼可亲，我如此专注于自己的快乐和满足，以至于认为只有我才能纠正我亲爱的女儿并安顿她。心态平和！

But I lay down, self-deceived, in that belief. And I awoke in it next day to find that there was still the same shade between me and my darling.
但我自欺欺人地相信了这一点。第二天我在其中醒来，发现我和我亲爱的之间仍然有同样的阴影。

CHAPTER LI
第 6 章


Enlightened
开明

When Mr. Woodcourt arrived in London, he went, that very same day, to Mr. Vholes’s in Symond’s Inn. For he never once, from the moment when I entreated him to be a friend to Richard, neglected or forgot his promise. He had told me that he accepted the charge as a sacred trust, and he was ever true to it in that spirit.
伍德考特先生抵达伦敦后，当天就去了位于西蒙旅馆的沃尔斯先生家。因为从我恳求他成为理查德的朋友那一刻起，他从来没有忽视或忘记过他的诺言。他告诉我，他接受这项指控是一种神圣的委托，并且他始终本着这种精神忠实于这一点。

He found Mr. Vholes in his office and informed Mr. Vholes of his agreement with Richard that he should call there to learn his address.
他在沃尔斯先生的办公室里找到了他，并告诉沃尔斯先生他与理查德达成协议，他应该打电话到那里了解他的地址。

‘Just so, sir,’ said Mr. Vholes. ‘Mr. C.’s address is not a hundred miles from here, sir, Mr. C.’s address is not a hundred miles from here. Would you take a seat, sir?’
“就是这样，先生，”沃尔斯先生说。 '先生。 C. 的地址距离这里不到一百英里，先生，C. 先生的地址距离这里不到一百英里。先生，请坐吧？

Mr. Woodcourt thanked Mr. Vholes, but he had no business with him beyond what he had mentioned.
伍德考特先生感谢了沃尔斯先生，但除了他提到的以外，他与他没有任何关系。

‘Just so, sir. I believe, sir,’ said Mr. Vholes, still quietly insisting on the seat by not giving the address, ‘that you have influence with Mr. C. Indeed I am aware that you have.’
“就是这样，先生。 “我相信，先生，”沃尔斯先生说道，他仍然默默地坚持要座位，没有发表讲话，“您对 C 先生有影响力。事实上，我知道您有影响力。”

‘I was not aware of it myself,’ returned Mr. Woodcourt; ‘but I suppose you know best.’
“我自己也没意识到这一点，”伍德考特先生回答道。 “但我想你最了解。”

‘Sir,’ rejoined Mr. Vholes, self-contained as usual, voice and all, ‘it is a part of my professional duty to know best. It is a part of my professional duty to study and to understand a gentleman who confides his interests to me. In my professional duty I shall not be wanting, sir, if I know it. I may, with the best intentions, be wanting in it without knowing it; but not if I know it, sir.’
“先生，”弗霍尔斯先生回答道，他的声音和平常一样独立，“了解情况是我职业职责的一部分。”研究和了解一位向我吐露兴趣的绅士是我职业职责的一部分。先生，如果我知道的话，在我的职业职责中我不会有所欠缺。出于最好的意图，我可能在不知情的情况下想要它；但如果我知道的话就不会了，先生。”

Mr. Woodcourt again mentioned the address.
伍德考特先生再次提到了这个地址。

‘Give me leave, sir,’ said Mr. Vholes. ‘Bear with me for a moment. Sir, Mr. C. is playing for a considerable stake, and cannot play without—need I say what?’
“请让我离开，先生，”沃尔斯先生说道。 “请耐心听我说一会儿。先生，C. 先生正在玩相当大的赌注，没有它就不能玩——需要我说什么吗？

‘Money, I presume?’
“我想是钱吧？”

‘Sir,’ said Mr. Vholes, ‘to be honest with you (honesty being my golden rule, whether I gain by it or lose, and I find that I generally lose), money is the word. Now, sir, upon the chances of Mr. C.’s game I express to you no opinion, NO opinion. It might be highly impolitic in Mr. C., after playing so long and so high, to leave off; it might be the reverse; I say nothing. No, sir,’ said Mr. Vholes, bringing his hand flat down upon his desk in a positive manner, ‘nothing.’
“先生，”沃尔斯先生说，“说实话（诚实是我的黄金法则，无论我从中获利还是损失，而且我发现我通常会损失），金钱就是这个词。现在，先生，对于 C. 先生的比赛的机会，我不向您表达任何意见，不发表任何意见。对于 C 先生来说，在玩了这么长时间、这么高调之后，放弃可能是非常不明智的。可能恰恰相反；我无话可说。不，先生，”沃尔斯先生说，他以一种积极的态度把手平放在桌子上，“没什么。”

‘You seem to forget,’ returned Mr, Woodcourt, ‘that I ask you to say nothing and have no interest in anything you say.’
“你似乎忘记了，”伍德考特先生回答道，“我要求你什么也不说，而且对你所说的任何事情都没有兴趣。”

‘Pardon me, sir!’ retorted Mr. Vholes. ‘You do yourself an injustice. No, sir! Pardon me! You shall not—shall not in my office, if I know it—do yourself an injustice. You are interested in anything, and in everything, that relates to your friend. I know human nature much better, sir, than to admit for an instant that a gentleman of your appearance is not interested in whatever concerns his friend.’
“请原谅，先生！”沃尔斯先生反驳道。 ‘你对自己不公平。不，先生！对不起！如果我知道的话，你不应该——不应该在我的办公室里——对自己做不公正的事情。你对与你的朋友有关的任何事情都感兴趣。先生，我比承认像你这样的绅士对他朋友关心的事情不感兴趣更了解人性。”

‘Well,’ replied Mr. Woodcourt, ‘that may be. I am particularly interested in his address.’
“嗯，”伍德考特先生回答说，“也许是这样。”我对他的地址特别感兴趣。

‘The number, sir,’ said Mr. Vholes parenthetically, ‘I believe I have already mentioned. If Mr. C. is to continue to play for this considerable stake, sir, he must have funds. Understand me! There are funds in hand at present. I ask for nothing; there are funds in hand. But for the onward play, more funds must be provided, unless Mr. C. is to throw away what he has already ventured, which is wholly and solely a point for his consideration. This, sir, I take the opportunity of stating openly to you as the friend of Mr. C. Without funds I shall always be happy to appear and act for Mr. C. to the extent of all such costs as are safe to be allowed out of the estate, not beyond that. I could not go beyond that, sir, without wronging some one. I must either wrong my three dear girls or my venerable father, who is entirely dependent on me, in the Vale of Taunton; or some one. Whereas, sir, my resolution is (call it weakness or folly if you please) to wrong no one.’
“这个数字，先生，”沃尔斯先生插话道，“我相信我已经提到过了。”先生，如果 C. 先生要继续争夺这笔相当大的股份，他就必须有资金。明白我！目前手头还有资金。我什么也不求；手头有资金。但对于接下来的比赛，必须提供更多的资金，除非C.先生要放弃他已经冒险的东西，这完全是他考虑的一点。先生，我借此机会以 C 先生的朋友的身份向您公开声明。如果没有资金，我将始终乐意为 C 先生出庭并在安全允许的所有费用范围内行事。走出庄园，不超出这个范围。先生，我无法超越这一点，否则就会冤枉某人。我要么得罪了我亲爱的三个女儿，要么得罪了我在汤顿谷完全依赖我的可敬的父亲；或某个。然而，先生，我的决心是（如果你愿意的话，可以称之为软弱或愚蠢）不伤害任何人。

Mr. Woodcourt rather sternly rejoined that he was glad to hear it.
伍德考特先生相当严厉地回答说他很高兴听到这个消息。

‘I wish, sir,’ said Mr. Vholes, ‘to leave a good name behind me. Therefore I take every opportunity of openly stating to a friend of Mr. C. how Mr. C. is situated. As to myself, sir, the labourer is worthy of his hire. If I undertake to put my shoulder to the wheel, I do it, and I earn what I get. I am here for that purpose. My name is painted on the door outside, with that object.’
“我希望，先生，”沃尔斯先生说，“为我留下一个好名声。”因此，我利用一切机会向 C. 先生的朋友公开说明 C. 先生的处境。先生，就我而言，这个工人是值得雇用的。如果我承诺全力以赴，我就会这么做，并且我会赚到我所得到的。我就是为了这个目的而来的。我的名字和那个东西一起画在外面的门上。”

‘And Mr. Carstone’s address, Mr. Vholes?’
“卡斯通先生的地址呢，沃尔斯先生？”

‘Sir,’ returned Mr. Vholes, ‘as I believe I have already mentioned, it is next door. On the second story you will find Mr. C.’s apartments. Mr. C. desires to be near his professional adviser, and I am far from objecting, for I court inquiry.’
“先生，”沃尔斯先生回答道，“我相信我已经提到过，它就在隔壁。”在二楼，您会发现 C. 先生的公寓。 C.先生希望接近他的专业顾问，我一点也不反对，因为我会接受询问。

Upon this Mr. Woodcourt wished Mr. Vholes good day and went in search of Richard, the change in whose appearance he began to understand now but too well.
伍德考特先生向沃尔斯先生问好，然后去寻找理查德，他现在开始理解理查德外表的变化，但太清楚了。

He found him in a dull room, fadedly furnished, much as I had found him in his barrack-room but a little while before, except that he was not writing but was sitting with a book before him, from which his eyes and thoughts were far astray. As the door chanced to be standing open, Mr. Woodcourt was in his presence for some moments without being perceived, and he told me that he never could forget the haggardness of his face and the dejection of his manner before he was aroused from his dream.
他发现他在一间昏暗的房间里，家具已经褪色，就像我不久前在他的营房里发现他一样，只是他没有在写字，而是坐在他面前，面前有一本书，他的眼睛和思想都来自这本书。误入歧途很远。当门碰巧开着时，伍德考特先生在他面前待了一会儿，但没有被察觉，他告诉我，他永远无法忘记他从梦中醒来之前的憔悴表情和沮丧态度。 。

‘Woodcourt, my dear fellow,’ cried Richard, starting up with extended hands, ‘you come upon my vision like a ghost.’
“伍德考特，我亲爱的朋友，”理查德伸出双手喊道，“你像幽灵一样出现在我的视野中。”

‘A friendly one,’ he replied, ‘and only waiting, as they say ghosts do, to be addressed. How does the mortal world go?’ They were seated now, near together.
“一个友好的人，”他回答道，“就像人们所说的鬼魂一样，只是等待着被解决。”现在，他们坐在一起，离得很近。

‘Badly enough, and slowly enough,’ said Richard, ‘speaking at least for my part of it.’
“已经够糟糕了，也够慢了，”理查德说，“至少就我而言。”

‘What part is that?’
“那是什么部分？”

‘The Chancery part.’
“大法官办公室部分。”

‘I never heard,’ returned Mr. Woodcourt, shaking his head, ‘of its going well yet.’
“我从来没有听说过，”伍德考特先生摇着头回答道，“目前还进展顺利。”

‘Nor I,’ said Richard moodily. ‘Who ever did?’ He brightened again in a moment and said with his natural openness, ‘Woodcourt, I should be sorry to be misunderstood by you, even if I gained by it in your estimation. You must know that I have done no good this long time. I have not intended to do much harm, but I seem to have been capable of nothing else. It may be that I should have done better by keeping out of the net into which my destiny has worked me, but I think not, though I dare say you will soon hear, if you have not already heard, a very different opinion. To make short of a long story, I am afraid I have wanted an object; but I have an object now—or it has me—and it is too late to discuss it. Take me as I am, and make the best of me.’
“我也没有，”理查德郁闷地说。 “谁曾经这样做过？”他立刻又高兴起来，用他自然的开放态度说道，“伍德考特，我应该为被你误解而感到遗憾，即使在你看来我因此而获益。”你一定知道，我这么久没有做过任何好事。我并不想造成太大的伤害，但我似乎也无能为力。也许我应该做得更好，远离我的命运给我带来的罗网，但我认为不是，尽管我敢说，如果你还没有听说过，你很快就会听到一个非常不同的意见。长话短说，我恐怕想要一个东西；但我现在有一个物体——或者说它有我——而现在讨论它已经太晚了。接受我本来的样子，充分利用我。

‘A bargain,’ said Mr. Woodcourt. ‘Do as much by me in return.’
“很划算，”伍德考特先生说。 “我也做同样多的事作为回报。”

‘Oh! You,’ returned Richard, ‘you can pursue your art for its own sake, and can put your hand upon the plough and never turn, and can strike a purpose out of anything. You and I are very different creatures.’
'哦！你，”理查德回答道，“你可以为了艺术本身而追求你的艺术，你可以把手放在犁上而不转动，你可以从任何事情中找到一个目的。你和我是非常不同的生物。

He spoke regretfully and lapsed for a moment into his weary condition.
他遗憾地说着，一时间陷入了疲倦的状态。

‘Well, well!’ he cried, shaking it off. ‘Everything has an end. We shall see! So you will take me as I am, and make the best of me?’
“好吧，好吧！”他喊道，甩掉了它。 '所有事都会过去的。我们将会看到！那么你会接受我本来的样子，并充分利用我吗？

‘Aye! Indeed I will.’ They shook hands upon it laughingly, but in deep earnestness. I can answer for one of them with my heart of hearts.
‘是啊！我确实会的。”他们笑着与它握手，但语气十分诚恳。我可以真心实意地回答其中一个问题。

‘You come as a godsend,’ said Richard, ‘for I have seen nobody here yet but Vholes. Woodcourt, there is one subject I should like to mention, for once and for all, in the beginning of our treaty. You can hardly make the best of me if I don’t. You know, I dare say, that I have an attachment to my cousin Ada?’
“你的到来真是天赐之物，”理查德说，“因为除了沃尔斯之外，我还没见过这里的任何人。”伍德考特，在我们条约的开头，我想一劳永逸地提到一个主题。如果我不这样做，你就很难充分利用我。我敢说，你知道我对我的表弟艾达有一种依恋吗？

Mr. Woodcourt replied that I had hinted as much to him. ‘Now pray,’ returned Richard, ‘don’t think me a heap of selfishness. Don’t suppose that I am splitting my head and half breaking my heart over this miserable Chancery suit for my own rights and interests alone. Ada’s are bound up with mine; they can’t be separated; Vholes works for both of us. Do think of that!’
伍德考特先生回答说我已经向他暗示过这一点。 “现在祈祷，”理查德回答道，“不要认为我很自私。别以为我只是为了自己的权益而为了这桩悲惨的大法官诉讼而伤透了心。艾达的与我的紧密相连；他们无法分开； Vholes 为我们俩工作。请想一想！

He was so very solicitous on this head that Mr. Woodcourt gave him the strongest assurances that he did him no injustice.
他对这个问题非常关心，伍德考特先生向他做出了最有力的保证，保证他不会冤枉他。

‘You see,’ said Richard, with something pathetic in his manner of lingering on the point, though it was off-hand and unstudied, ‘to an upright fellow like you, bringing a friendly face like yours here, I cannot bear the thought of appearing selfish and mean. I want to see Ada righted, Woodcourt, as well as myself; I want to do my utmost to right her, as well as myself; I venture what I can scrape together to extricate her, as well as myself. Do, I beseech you, think of that!’
“你看，”理查德说道，他的语气中带着一种可悲的意味，尽管他的语气是即兴的、未经深思熟虑的，“对于像你这样正直的人，带着一张像你这样友善的面孔来到这里，我无法忍受这样的想法。”显得自私和卑鄙。我希望看到艾达得到伸张正义，伍德考特，还有我自己；我想尽我最大的努力纠正她，也纠正我自己；我冒险尽我所能来解救她，也解救我自己。我恳求你，想一想！

Afterwards, when Mr. Woodcourt came to reflect on what had passed, he was so very much impressed by the strength of Richard’s anxiety on this point that in telling me generally of his first visit to Symond’s Inn he particularly dwelt upon it. It revived a fear I had had before that my dear girl’s little property would be absorbed by Mr. Vholes and that Richard’s justification to himself would be sincerely this. It was just as I began to take care of Caddy that the interview took place, and I now return to the time when Caddy had recovered and the shade was still between me and my darling.
后来，当伍德考特先生开始反思所发生的事情时，理查德在这一点上的焦虑程度给他留下了深刻的印象，因此在向我讲述他第一次访问西蒙旅馆的大体情况时，他特别详细地讲述了这一点。这让我再次产生了一种恐惧，担心我亲爱的女儿的一点财产会被沃尔斯先生吸收，而理查德对自己的辩护也将是真诚的。就在我开始照顾凯迪的时候，采访发生了，我现在回到了凯迪康复的时候，阴影还在我和我的宝贝之间。

I proposed to Ada that morning that we should go and see Richard. It a little surprised me to find that she hesitated and was not so radiantly willing as I had expected.
那天早上我向艾达提议我们应该去见理查德。让我有点惊讶的是，她犹豫了，并没有我想象的那么乐意。

‘My dear,’ said I, ‘you have not had any difference with Richard since I have been so much away?’
“亲爱的，”我说，“自从我离开这么久以来，你和理查德没有什么不同吗？”

‘No, Esther.’
“不，埃丝特。”

‘Not heard of him, perhaps?’ said I.
“也许没有听说过他？”我说。

‘Yes, I have heard of him,’ said Ada.
“是的，我听说过他，”艾达说。

Such tears in her eyes, and such love in her face. I could not make my darling out. Should I go to Richard’s by myself? I said. No, Ada thought I had better not go by myself. Would she go with me? Yes, Ada thought she had better go with me. Should we go now? Yes, let us go now. Well, I could not understand my darling, with the tears in her eyes and the love in her face!
她的眼里充满了泪水，脸上充满了爱。我无法让我的宝贝出来。我应该自己去理查德家吗？我说。不，艾达认为我最好不要自己去。她愿意和我一起去吗？是的，艾达认为她最好和我一起去。我们现在该走了吗？是的，我们现在就走吧。好吧，我无法理解我亲爱的，她眼里含着泪水，脸上充满爱意！

We were soon equipped and went out. It was a sombre day, and drops of chill rain fell at intervals. It was one of those colourless days when everything looks heavy and harsh. The houses frowned at us, the dust rose at us, the smoke swooped at us, nothing made any compromise about itself or wore a softened aspect. I fancied my beautiful girl quite out of place in the rugged streets, and I thought there were more funerals passing along the dismal pavements than I had ever seen before.
很快我们就装备好了，就出去了。天阴沉的，时不时下着冰冷的雨点。那是那些毫无色彩的日子之一，一切都显得沉重而严酷。房屋向我们皱着眉头，尘土向我们扬起，烟雾向我们猛扑过来，没有任何东西对自己做出任何妥协，也没有表现出柔和的一面。我觉得我美丽的女儿在崎岖的街道上显得格格不入，而且我认为沿着阴暗的人行道举行的葬礼比我以前见过的还要多。

We had first to find out Symond’s Inn. We were going to inquire in a shop when Ada said she thought it was near Chancery Lane. ‘We are not likely to be far out, my love, if we go in that direction,’ said I. So to Chancery Lane we went, and there, sure enough, we saw it written up. Symond’s Inn.
我们首先要找到西蒙旅馆。我们正要去一家商店打听，艾达说她认为那家商店就在大法官巷附近。我说：“亲爱的，如果我们朝那个方向走，我们就不会走得太远。”于是我们去了大法官巷，果然，我们看到了上面写着的东西。西蒙德旅馆。

We had next to find out the number. ‘Or Mr. Vholes’s office will do,’ I recollected, ‘for Mr. Vholes’s office is next door.’ Upon which Ada said, perhaps that was Mr. Vholes’s office in the corner there. And it really was.
接下来我们要找出号码。 “或者沃尔斯先生的办公室也行，”我回忆道，“因为沃尔斯先生的办公室就在隔壁。”艾达说，也许那就是沃尔斯先生在角落里的办公室。确实如此。

Then came the question, which of the two next doors? I was going for the one, and my darling was going for the other; and my darling was right again. So up we went to the second story, when we came to Richard’s name in great white letters on a hearse-like panel.
那么问题来了，隔壁两个是哪一个？我想要一个，而我亲爱的想要另一个；我亲爱的又是对的。于是我们就到了第二层，看到理查德的名字，上面写着白色的大字，写在灵车一样的面板上。

I should have knocked, but Ada said perhaps we had better turn the handle and go in. Thus we came to Richard, poring over a table covered with dusty bundles of papers which seemed to me like dusty mirrors reflecting his own mind. Wherever I looked I saw the ominous words that ran in it repeated. Jarndyce and Jarndyce.
我本应该敲门的，但艾达说也许我们最好转动把手进去。就这样，我们来到了理查德身边，仔细地看着一张桌子，桌子上堆满了灰尘的一捆捆文件，在我看来，这些文件就像布满灰尘的镜子，反射着他自己的想法。无论我往哪里看，我都看到里面重复着不祥的话语。贾迪斯和贾迪斯。

He received us very affectionately, and we sat down. ‘If you had come a little earlier,’ he said, ‘you would have found Woodcourt here. There never was such a good fellow as Woodcourt is. He finds time to look in between-whiles, when anybody else with half his work to do would be thinking about not being able to come. And he is so cheery, so fresh, so sensible, so earnest, so—everything that I am not, that the place brightens whenever he comes, and darkens whenever he goes again.’
他非常热情地接待了我们，我们就坐了下来。 “如果你来得早一点，”他说，“你就会在这里找到伍德考特了。”从来没有像伍德考特这样的好人。当其他有一半工作要做的人会考虑不能来的时候，他会抽出时间去看看。他是那么快乐，那么新鲜，那么明智，那么认真，那么——一切都是我所不具备的，所以每当他到来时，这个地方就会变得明亮，而每当他再次离开时，这个地方就会变得黑暗。

‘God bless him,’ I thought, ‘for his truth to me!’
“上帝保佑他，”我想，“因为他对我很诚实！”

‘He is not so sanguine, Ada,’ continued Richard, casting his dejected look over the bundles of papers, ‘as Vholes and I are usually, but he is only an outsider and is not in the mysteries. We have gone into them, and he has not. He can’t be expected to know much of such a labyrinth.’
“他不像我和沃尔斯那样乐观，艾达，”理查德继续说道，沮丧地看着一叠文件，“但他只是一个局外人，并不处于神秘之中。我们已经深入研究过它们，而他还没有。不能指望他对这样的迷宫了解太多。

As his look wandered over the papers again and he passed his two hands over his head, I noticed how sunken and how large his eyes appeared, how dry his lips were, and how his finger-nails were all bitten away.
当他的目光再次在文件上徘徊，他用两只手举过头顶时，我注意到他的眼睛显得多么凹陷、多么大，他的嘴唇多么干燥，他的指甲都被咬掉了。

‘Is this a healthy place to live in, Richard, do you think?’ said I.
“理查德，你认为这里是一个健康的居住地吗？”我说。

‘Why, my dear Minerva,’ answered Richard with his old gay laugh, ‘it is neither a rural nor a cheerful place; and when the sun shines here, you may lay a pretty heavy wager that it is shining brightly in an open spot. But it’s well enough for the time. It’s near the offices and near Vholes.’
“哎呀，我亲爱的密涅瓦，”理查德用他一贯的欢快的笑声回答道，“那既不是一个乡村，也不是一个令人愉快的地方；它是一个充满活力的地方。”当阳光照耀这里时，你可以打赌，它在空旷的地方闪耀着明亮的光芒。但对于当时来说已经足够了。它靠近办公室，靠近 Vholes。”

‘Perhaps,’ I hinted, ‘a change from both—‘
“也许，”我暗示道，“两者都发生了变化——”

‘Might do me good?’ said Richard, forcing a laugh as he finished the sentence. ‘I shouldn’t wonder! But it can only come in one way now—in one of two ways, I should rather say. Either the suit must be ended, Esther, or the suitor. But it shall be the suit, my dear girl, the suit, my dear girl!’
“这对我有好处吗？”理查德说完，强颜欢笑。 ‘我不应该奇怪！但现在它只能以一种方式出现——我宁愿说，以两种方式之一。要么诉讼必须结束，埃丝特，要么求婚者。但它应该是西装，我亲爱的女孩，西装，我亲爱的女孩！

These latter words were addressed to Ada, who was sitting nearest to him. Her face being turned away from me and towards him, I could not see it.
后面这句话是对坐在离他最近的艾达说的。她的脸背对着我，转向了他，我看不到。

‘We are doing very well,’ pursued Richard. ‘Vholes will tell you so. We are really spinning along. Ask Vholes. We are giving them no rest. Vholes knows all their windings and turnings, and we are upon them everywhere. We have astonished them already. We shall rouse up that nest of sleepers, mark my words!’
“我们做得很好，”理查德继续说道。 ‘维霍尔斯会告诉你的。我们真的在旋转。问问维霍尔斯。我们不让他们休息。沃尔斯知道它们所有的蜿蜒曲折，我们无处不在。我们已经让他们感到惊讶了。我们将唤醒那一窝沉睡者，记住我的话！”

His hopefulness had long been more painful to me than his despondency; it was so unlike hopefulness, had something so fierce in its determination to be it, was so hungry and eager, and yet so conscious of being forced and unsustainable that it had long touched me to the heart. But the commentary upon it now indelibly written in his handsome face made it far more distressing than it used to be. I say indelibly, for I felt persuaded that if the fatal cause could have been for ever terminated, according to his brightest visions, in that same hour, the traces of the premature anxiety, self-reproach, and disappointment it had occasioned him would have remained upon his features to the hour of his death.
长期以来，他的希望比他的沮丧更令我痛苦。它与希望如此不同，它有一种如此强烈的决心，如此饥饿和渴望，但又如此意识到被迫和不可持续，以至于它早已触动了我的心。但现在他英俊的脸上写着不可磨灭的评论，却比以前更加令人痛苦。我说不可磨灭，因为我深信，如果致命的原因能够永远终止，根据他最明亮的愿景，在同一时刻，过早的焦虑、自责和失望的痕迹就会消失。直到他去世的那一刻，它仍然留在他的脸上。

‘The sight of our dear little woman,’ said Richard, Ada still remaining silent and quiet, ‘is so natural to me, and her compassionate face is so like the face of old days—‘
“看到我们亲爱的小女人，”理查德说，艾达仍然保持着沉默和安静，“对我来说是那么自然，她富有同情心的脸就像过去的脸一样——”

Ah! No, no. I smiled and shook my head.
啊!不，不。我微笑着摇了摇头。

‘—So exactly like the face of old days,’ said Richard in his cordial voice, and taking my hand with the brotherly regard which nothing ever changed, ‘that I can’t make pretences with her. I fluctuate a little; that’s the truth. Sometimes I hope, my dear, and sometimes I—don’t quite despair, but nearly. I get,’ said Richard, relinquishing my hand gently and walking across the room, ‘so tired!’
“——和过去的脸一模一样，”理查德用他亲切的声音说道，并以从未改变过的兄弟般的态度握住我的手，“我不能对她假装。”我有点波动；这是事实。有时我希望，亲爱的，有时我——并不完全绝望，但几乎绝望。 “我明白了，”理查德轻轻地放开我的手，穿过房间，“太累了！”

He took a few turns up and down and sunk upon the sofa. ‘I get,’ he repeated gloomily, ‘so tired. It is such weary, weary work!’
他上下翻了几圈，倒在沙发上。 “我明白，”他阴沉地重复道，“太累了。”这是多么令人厌倦、令人厌倦的工作啊！

He was leaning on his arm saying these words in a meditative voice and looking at the ground when my darling rose, put off her bonnet, kneeled down beside him with her golden hair falling like sunlight on his head, clasped her two arms round his neck, and turned her face to me. Oh, what a loving and devoted face I saw!
他靠在他的手臂上，用沉思的声音说着这些话，看着地面，这时我亲爱的站起来，摘下帽子，跪在他身边，金色的头发像阳光一样落在他的头上，用两只手臂搂住他的脖子。 ，然后把脸转向我。哦，我看到了一张多么慈爱和忠诚的脸啊！

‘Esther, dear,’ she said very quietly, ‘I am not going home again.’
“埃丝特，亲爱的，”她非常平静地说，“我不会再回家了。”

A light shone in upon me all at once.
一道光立刻照在我身上。

‘Never any more. I am going to stay with my dear husband. We have been married above two months. Go home without me, my own Esther; I shall never go home any more!’ With those words my darling drew his head down on her breast and held it there. And if ever in my life I saw a love that nothing but death could change, I saw it then before me.
'再也不会了。我要和我亲爱的丈夫住在一起。我们结婚两个多月了。回家吧，别带我，我自己的埃丝特；我再也不会回家了！”说完这句话，我亲爱的把头埋在她的胸口上。如果我一生中见过一种只有死亡才能改变的爱，那么我就看到了它就在我面前。

‘Speak to Esther, my dearest,’ said Richard, breaking the silence presently. ‘Tell her how it was.’
“跟我最亲爱的埃丝特谈谈，”理查德立刻打破了沉默。 “告诉她情况如何。”

I met her before she could come to me and folded her in my arms. We neither of us spoke, but with her cheek against my own I wanted to hear nothing. ‘My pet,’ said I. ‘My love. My poor, poor girl!’ I pitied her so much. I was very fond of Richard, but the impulse that I had upon me was to pity her so much.
在她来到我身边并将她抱在我怀里之前，我遇见了她。我们谁也没说话，但她的脸贴着我的脸，我什么也不想听。 “我的宠物，”我说，“我的爱人。”我可怜的、可怜的女孩！”我非常可怜她。我非常喜欢理查德，但我的冲动却是非常可怜她。

‘Esther, will you forgive me? Will my cousin John forgive me?’
‘艾丝特，你能原谅我吗？我的表弟约翰会原谅我吗？

‘My dear,’ said I, ‘to doubt it for a moment is to do him a great wrong. And as to me!’ Why, as to me, what had I to forgive!
“亲爱的，”我说，“哪怕有片刻的怀疑，就是对他大错特错。”至于我！’为什么，对于我来说，我有什么可以原谅的！

I dried my sobbing darling’s eyes and sat beside her on the sofa, and Richard sat on my other side; and while I was reminded of that so different night when they had first taken me into their confidence and had gone on in their own wild happy way, they told me between them how it was.
我擦干亲爱的哭泣的眼睛，坐在她旁边的沙发上，理查德坐在我的另一边。虽然我想起了那个截然不同的夜晚，当时他们第一次信任我，并以他们自己狂野快乐的方式继续生活，他们告诉我他们之间的情况。

‘All I had was Richard’s,’ Ada said; ‘and Richard would not take it, Esther, and what could I do but be his wife when I loved him dearly!’
“我的一切都是理查德的，”艾达说。 “而理查德不会接受，埃丝特，当我深爱着他时，我除了成为他的妻子还能做什么！”

‘And you were so fully and so kindly occupied, excellent Dame Durden,’ said Richard, ‘that how could we speak to you at such a time! And besides, it was not a long-considered step. We went out one morning and were married.’
“杰出的杜登夫人，您是如此忙碌，如此亲切，”理查德说，“我们怎么能在这种时候和您说话呢！而且，这并不是一个经过长期考虑的步骤。一天早上我们出去结婚了。”

‘And when it was done, Esther,’ said my darling, ‘I was always thinking how to tell you and what to do for the best. And sometimes I thought you ought to know it directly, and sometimes I thought you ought not to know it and keep it from my cousin John; and I could not tell what to do, and I fretted very much.’
“当事情完成后，埃丝特，”我亲爱的说，“我一直在想如何告诉你，以及怎样做才是最好的。”有时我认为你应该直接知道它，有时我认为你不应该知道它并瞒着我的表弟约翰；我不知道该怎么办，我非常烦恼。

How selfish I must have been not to have thought of this before! I don’t know what I said now. I was so sorry, and yet I was so fond of them and so glad that they were fond of me; I pitied them so much, and yet I felt a kind of pride in their loving one another. I never had experienced such painful and pleasurable emotion at one time, and in my own heart I did not know which predominated. But I was not there to darken their way; I did not do that.
我以前没有想到这一点，真是太自私了！我现在不知道我说了什么。我很抱歉，但我很喜欢他们，很高兴他们喜欢我；我非常同情他们，但我为他们彼此相爱感到一种自豪。我从来没有同时体验过如此痛苦和愉悦的情绪，而我自己心里也分不清到底是哪一种占主导地位。但我并不是为了遮蔽他们的道路；我没有那样做。

When I was less foolish and more composed, my darling took her wedding-ring from her bosom, and kissed it, and put it on. Then I remembered last night and told Richard that ever since her marriage she had worn it at night when there was no one to see. Then Ada blushingly asked me how did I know that, my dear. Then I told Ada how I had seen her hand concealed under her pillow and had little thought why, my dear. Then they began telling me how it was all over again, and I began to be sorry and glad again, and foolish again, and to hide my plain old face as much as I could lest I should put them out of heart.
当我不再那么愚蠢、变得更加镇定时，我的宝贝从怀里取出了结婚戒指，亲吻了它，然后戴上了它。然后我想起昨晚，告诉理查德，自从她结婚以来，她就在晚上没人见的时候戴着它。然后艾达红着脸问我怎么知道的，亲爱的。然后我告诉艾达我如何看到她的手藏在枕头下，但几乎没有想到为什么，亲爱的。然后他们开始告诉我这一切是如何重来的，我又开始感到遗憾和高兴，又开始愚蠢，并尽可能地隐藏我那张朴素的老脸，以免我让他们心烦意乱。

Thus the time went on until it became necessary for me to think of returning. When that time arrived it was the worst of all, for then my darling completely broke down. She clung round my neck, calling me by every dear name she could think of and saying what should she do without me! Nor was Richard much better; and as for me, I should have been the worst of the three if I had not severely said to myself, ‘Now Esther, if you do, I’ll never speak to you again!’
时间就这么过去了，直到我不得不考虑回去。当那一刻到来时，这是最糟糕的，因为那时我亲爱的完全崩溃了。她搂住我的脖子，用她能想到的每一个可爱的名字呼唤我，并说如果没有我她该怎么办！理查德也好不了多少。至于我，如果我没有严厉地对自己说：“埃丝特，如果你这样做，我就再也不会和你说话了！”

‘Why, I declare,’ said I, ‘I never saw such a wife. I don’t think she loves her husband at all. Here, Richard, take my child, for goodness’ sake.’ But I held her tight all the while, and could have wept over her I don’t know how long.
“哎呀，我声明，”我说，“我从来没有见过这样的妻子。”我认为她根本不爱她的丈夫。理查德，看在上帝的份上，带上我的孩子吧。”但我一直紧紧地抱着她，我不知道我可以为她哭泣多久。

‘I give this dear young couple notice,’ said I, ‘that I am only going away to come back to-morrow and that I shall be always coming backwards and forwards until Symond’s Inn is tired of the sight of me. So I shall not say good-bye, Richard. For what would be the use of that, you know, when I am coming back so soon!’
“我通知这对亲爱的年轻夫妇，”我说，“我只是离开，明天才回来，而且我将一直来回走动，直到西蒙旅馆厌倦了我的视线。所以我不会说再见，理查德。你知道，我这么快就回来了，那有什么用呢！

I had given my darling to him now, and I meant to go; but I lingered for one more look of the precious face which it seemed to rive my heart to turn from.
我现在已经把我的爱人交给了他，我也打算走了；但我还是想再看一眼那张珍贵的脸，它似乎让我的心不得不转开。

So I said (in a merry, bustling manner) that unless they gave me some encouragement to come back, I was not sure that I could take that liberty, upon which my dear girl looked up, faintly smiling through her tears, and I folded her lovely face between my hands, and gave it one last kiss, and laughed, and ran away.
所以我（以一种快乐、忙碌的方式）说，除非他们给我一些鼓励让我回来，否则我不确定我是否可以采取这种自由，我亲爱的女孩抬起头来，泪水微弱地微笑着，我折叠起来我双手捧着她那张可爱的脸，最后吻了一下，然后笑了，然后跑开了。

And when I got downstairs, oh, how I cried! It almost seemed to me that I had lost my Ada for ever. I was so lonely and so blank without her, and it was so desolate to be going home with no hope of seeing her there, that I could get no comfort for a little while as I walked up and down in a dim corner sobbing and crying.
当我下楼时，哦，我哭了！在我看来，我几乎永远失去了我的艾达。没有她，我是多么孤独，多么茫然，回家却看不到她，心里多么凄凉，我在昏暗的角落里走来走去，抽泣着，一时得不到安慰。 。

I came to myself by and by, after a little scolding, and took a coach home. The poor boy whom I had found at St. Albans had reappeared a short time before and was lying at the point of death; indeed, was then dead, though I did not know it. My guardian had gone out to inquire about him and did not return to dinner. Being quite alone, I cried a little again, though on the whole I don’t think I behaved so very, very ill.
经过一番责骂后，我渐渐清醒过来，坐了一辆马车回家。我在圣奥尔本斯找到的那个可怜的男孩不久前又出现了，而且已经濒临死亡。事实上，他当时已经死了，尽管我并不知道。我的监护人出去打听他的情况，没有回来吃晚饭。由于孤身一人，我又哭了一会儿，不过总的来说，我认为我的行为并没有那么糟糕。

It was only natural that I should not be quite accustomed to the loss of my darling yet. Three or four hours were not a long time after years. But my mind dwelt so much upon the uncongenial scene in which I had left her, and I pictured it as such an overshadowed stony-hearted one, and I so longed to be near her and taking some sort of care of her, that I determined to go back in the evening only to look up at her windows.
很自然的是，我还不太习惯失去我的爱人。时隔多年，三四个小时并不算长的时间。但我的思绪太多地停留在我离开她时的不愉快的场景上，我把它想象成一个黯然失色的铁石心肠的场景，我如此渴望靠近她并照顾她，所以我决定晚上回去只是为了抬头看看她的窗户。

It was foolish, I dare say, but it did not then seem at all so to me, and it does not seem quite so even now. I took Charley into my confidence, and we went out at dusk. It was dark when we came to the new strange home of my dear girl, and there was a light behind the yellow blinds. We walked past cautiously three or four times, looking up, and narrowly missed encountering Mr. Vholes, who came out of his office while we were there and turned his head to look up too before going home. The sight of his lank black figure and the lonesome air of that nook in the dark were favourable to the state of my mind. I thought of the youth and love and beauty of my dear girl, shut up in such an ill-assorted refuge, almost as if it were a cruel place.
我敢说，这是愚蠢的，但当时对我来说根本不是这样，甚至现在看来也不是那么回事。我信任查理，我们在黄昏时出去了。当我们来到我亲爱的女儿陌生的新家时，天已经黑了，黄色的百叶窗后面有一盏灯。我们小心翼翼地走过三四次，抬头仰望，差点就遇到了沃尔斯先生，我们在的时候他从办公室里出来，回家前也转过头抬头看了看。看到他那瘦长的黑色身影，以及黑暗中那个角落的孤独空气，都对我的心境产生了有利的影响。我想起了我亲爱的女儿的青春、爱情和美丽，她被关在这样一个杂乱无章的避难所里，几乎就像是一个残酷的地方。

It was very solitary and very dull, and I did not doubt that I might safely steal upstairs. I left Charley below and went up with a light foot, not distressed by any glare from the feeble oil lanterns on the way. I listened for a few moments, and in the musty rotting silence of the house believed that I could hear the murmur of their young voices. I put my lips to the hearse-like panel of the door as a kiss for my dear and came quietly down again, thinking that one of these days I would confess to the visit.
那里非常孤独，非常沉闷，我毫不怀疑我可以安全地偷上楼。我把查理留在下面，轻轻松松地上了去，路上微弱的油灯发出的刺眼的光芒并没有让我感到不安。我听了一会儿，在房子里发霉腐烂的寂静中，我相信我能听到他们年轻的低语声。我把嘴唇放在像灵车一样的门板上，作为对亲爱的人的一个吻，然后又悄悄地下来，想着有一天我会承认我的来访。

And it really did me good, for though nobody but Charley and I knew anything about it, I somehow felt as if it had diminished the separation between Ada and me and had brought us together again for those moments. I went back, not quite accustomed yet to the change, but all the better for that hovering about my darling.
这确实对我有好处，因为虽然除了查理和我之外没有人知道这件事，但我不知何故感觉好像它减少了艾达和我之间的分离，并在那些时刻让我们再次聚集在一起。我回去了，虽然还不太习惯这种变化，但在我亲爱的身边徘徊就更好了。

My guardian had come home and was standing thoughtfully by the dark window. When I went in, his face cleared and he came to his seat, but he caught the light upon my face as I took mine.
我的监护人回家了，站在黑暗的窗边若有所思。当我进去时，他的脸变得清晰起来，他来到了自己的座位上，但当我拿起我的座位时，他看到了我脸上的光芒。

‘Little woman,’ said he, ‘You have been crying.’
“小女人，”他说，“你一直在哭。”

‘Why, yes, guardian,’ said I, ‘I am afraid I have been, a little. Ada has been in such distress, and is so very sorry, guardian.’
“嗯，是的，监护人，”我说，“恐怕我曾经有过一点。”艾达一直处于如此痛苦的境地，我非常抱歉，监护人。”

I put my arm on the back of his chair, and I saw in his glance that my words and my look at her empty place had prepared him.
我把手臂放在他的椅背上，从他的眼神中我看出我的话和我看着她空荡荡的地方已经让他做好了准备。

‘Is she married, my dear?’
“亲爱的，她结婚了吗？”

I told him all about it and how her first entreaties had referred to his forgiveness.
我告诉了他这一切，以及她的第一次恳求是如何得到他的宽恕的。

‘She has no need of it,’ said he. ‘Heaven bless her and her husband!’ But just as my first impulse had been to pity her, so was his. ‘Poor girl, poor girl! Poor Rick! Poor Ada!’
“她不需要它，”他说。 “愿上帝保佑她和她的丈夫！”但正如我的第一反应是可怜她一样，他也是如此。 ‘可怜的姑娘，可怜的姑娘！可怜的瑞克！可怜的艾达！

Neither of us spoke after that, until he said with a sigh, ‘Well, well, my dear! Bleak House is thinning fast.’
此后我们谁都没有说话，直到他叹了口气说：‘好吧，好吧，亲爱的！ 《荒凉山庄》正在迅速减少。

‘But its mistress remains, guardian.’ Though I was timid about saying it, I ventured because of the sorrowful tone in which he had spoken. ‘She will do all she can to make it happy,’ said I.
“但它的女主人仍然存在，守护者。”虽然我不敢这么说，但由于他说话时的悲伤语气，我还是冒险说出来。 “她会尽一切努力让它幸福，”我说。

‘She will succeed, my love!’
“她会成功的，我的爱人！”

The letter had made no difference between us except that the seat by his side had come to be mine; it made none now. He turned his old bright fatherly look upon me, laid his hand on my hand in his old way, and said again, ‘She will succeed, my dear. Nevertheless, Bleak House is thinning fast, O little woman!’
这封信对我们之间没有任何影响，只是他旁边的座位变成了我的。现在它什么也没有了。他用他那古老而明亮的父亲般的目光看着我，以他一贯的方式把手放在我的手上，再次说道：“她会成功的，亲爱的。”尽管如此，荒凉山庄正在迅速减少，哦，小女人！

I was sorry presently that this was all we said about that. I was rather disappointed. I feared I might not quite have been all I had meant to be since the letter and the answer.
我很抱歉，我们对此就只说了这么多。我相当失望。我担心自从收到这封信和得到答复以来，我可能并没有完全成为我想要的样子。

CHAPTER LII
第十三章


Obstinacy
固执

But one other day had intervened when, early in the morning as we were going to breakfast, Mr. Woodcourt came in haste with the astounding news that a terrible murder had been committed for which Mr. George had been apprehended and was in custody. When he told us that a large reward was offered by Sir Leicester Dedlock for the murderer’s apprehension, I did not in my first consternation understand why; but a few more words explained to me that the murdered person was Sir Leicester’s lawyer, and immediately my mother’s dread of him rushed into my remembrance.
但有一天，我们一大早就要去吃早餐，伍德考特先生匆匆而来，带来了令人震惊的消息：发生了一起可怕的谋杀案，乔治先生因此被捕并被拘留。当他告诉我们，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士悬赏悬赏逮捕凶手时，我一开始惊愕不明白这是为什么；但我又说了几句话，就知道被谋杀的人是莱斯特爵士的律师，我立刻就想起了母亲对他的恐惧。

This unforeseen and violent removal of one whom she had long watched and distrusted and who had long watched and distrusted her, one for whom she could have had few intervals of kindness, always dreading in him a dangerous and secret enemy, appeared so awful that my first thoughts were of her. How appalling to hear of such a death and be able to feel no pity! How dreadful to remember, perhaps, that she had sometimes even wished the old man away who was so swiftly hurried out of life!
这种出乎意料的、暴力的方式将一个她长期注视和不信任的人，一个她长期以来一直注视和不信任她的人，一个她本来可以很少有善意的时间间隔的人，总是害怕他是一个危险和秘密的敌人，显得如此可怕，以至于我的第一个想到的就是她。听到这样的死亡却毫无怜悯之心，这是多么令人震惊啊！也许，想起她有时甚至希望那位如此迅速地从生活中消失的老人走开，这真是太可怕了！

Such crowding reflections, increasing the distress and fear I always felt when the name was mentioned, made me so agitated that I could scarcely hold my place at the table. I was quite unable to follow the conversation until I had had a little time to recover. But when I came to myself and saw how shocked my guardian was and found that they were earnestly speaking of the suspected man and recalling every favourable impression we had formed of him out of the good we had known of him, my interest and my fears were so strongly aroused in his behalf that I was quite set up again.
如此拥挤的思考，增加了我在提到这个名字时总是感到的痛苦和恐惧，让我如此激动，以至于我几乎无法在餐桌上保持自己的位置。我完全无法跟上谈话内容，直到我有一点时间恢复过来。但当我清醒过来，看到我的监护人是多么震惊，发现他们正在认真地谈论那个可疑男子，并回想起我们基于对他的了解而对他形成的每一个好印象时，我的兴趣和恐惧都消失了。我对他的感情如此强烈，以至于我再次陷入了困境。

‘Guardian, you don’t think it possible that he is justly accused?’
“监护人，你认为他不可能受到公正的指控吗？”

‘My dear, I CAN’T think so. This man whom we have seen so openhearted and compassionate, who with the might of a giant has the gentleness of a child, who looks as brave a fellow as ever lived and is so simple and quiet with it, this man justly accused of such a crime? I can’t believe it. It’s not that I don’t or I won’t. I can’t!’
‘亲爱的，我不这么认为。我们所看到的这个人如此坦诚和富有同情心，他拥有巨人的力量，却又拥有孩子般的温柔，他看起来像以前一样勇敢，而且如此简单和安静，这个人被公正地指控为这样的人。犯罪？我简直不敢相信。并不是我不这样做或我不会。我不能！

‘And I can’t,’ said Mr. Woodcourt. ‘Still, whatever we believe or know of him, we had better not forget that some appearances are against him. He bore an animosity towards the deceased gentleman. He has openly mentioned it in many places. He is said to have expressed himself violently towards him, and he certainly did about him, to my knowledge. He admits that he was alone on the scene of the murder within a few minutes of its commission. I sincerely believe him to be as innocent of any participation in it as I am, but these are all reasons for suspicion falling upon him.’
“我不能，”伍德考特先生说。 “尽管如此，无论我们相信或了解他，我们最好不要忘记有些外表对他不利。他对已故的绅士怀有敌意。他在很多地方都公开提到过这一点。据说他对他表达了暴力，据我所知，他确实对他做了暴力。他承认，谋杀案发生后几分钟内，他独自一人出现在现场。我真诚地相信他和我一样无辜参与其中，但这些都是怀疑他的理由。

‘True,’ said my guardian. And he added, turning to me, ‘It would be doing him a very bad service, my dear, to shut our eyes to the truth in any of these respects.’
“是的，”我的监护人说。他转向我补充道：“亲爱的，如果我们对这些方面的真相视而不见，那对他来说是非常糟糕的。”

I felt, of course, that we must admit, not only to ourselves but to others, the full force of the circumstances against him. Yet I knew withal (I could not help saying) that their weight would not induce us to desert him in his need.
当然，我觉得我们不仅必须向自己而且向其他人承认，环境对他不利。然而我知道（我忍不住说）他们的重量不会导致我们在他需要时抛弃他。

‘Heaven forbid!’ returned my guardian. ‘We will stand by him, as he himself stood by the two poor creatures who are gone.’ He meant Mr. Gridley and the boy, to both of whom Mr. George had given shelter.
“天哪！”我的监护人回答道。 “我们会支持他，就像他本人支持这两个死去的可怜人一样。”他指的是格里德利先生和那个男孩，乔治先生曾庇护过他们俩。

Mr. Woodcourt then told us that the trooper’s man had been with him before day, after wandering about the streets all night like a distracted creature. That one of the trooper’s first anxieties was that we should not suppose him guilty. That he had charged his messenger to represent his perfect innocence with every solemn assurance be could send us. That Mr. Woodcourt had only quieted the man by undertaking to come to our house very early in the morning with these representations. He added that he was now upon his way to see the prisoner himself.
伍德考特先生然后告诉我们，那个警察的人在白天之前就和他在一起了，之前他像一个心烦意乱的人一样在街上闲逛了一整夜。这名士兵首先担心的就是我们不应该认定他有罪。他吩咐他的使者向我们发出每一份庄严的保证，以表明他完全清白。伍德考特先生承诺一大早带着这些陈述来到我们家，才让这个人安静下来。他补充说，他现在正在去见囚犯本人的路上。

My guardian said directly he would go too. Now, besides that I liked the retired soldier very much and that he liked me, I had that secret interest in what had happened which was only known to my guardian. I felt as if it came close and near to me. It seemed to become personally important to myself that the truth should be discovered and that no innocent people should be suspected, for suspicion, once run wild, might run wilder.
我的监护人直接说他也去。现在，除此之外，我非常喜欢那个退役士兵，他也喜欢我，我对所发生的事情有一种秘密的兴趣，只有我的监护人知道。我感觉它离我越来越近了。对我个人来说，发现真相、不怀疑任何无辜者似乎变得很重要，因为怀疑一旦猖獗，可能会更加猖獗。

In a word, I felt as if it were my duty and obligation to go with them. My guardian did not seek to dissuade me, and I went.
总之，我觉得和他们一起去是我的责任和义务。我的监护人没有劝阻我，我就去了。

It was a large prison with many courts and passages so like one another and so uniformly paved that I seemed to gain a new comprehension, as I passed along, of the fondness that solitary prisoners, shut up among the same staring walls from year to year, have had—as I have read—for a weed or a stray blade of grass. In an arched room by himself, like a cellar upstairs, with walls so glaringly white that they made the massive iron window-bars and iron-bound door even more profoundly black than they were, we found the trooper standing in a corner. He had been sitting on a bench there and had risen when he heard the locks and bolts turn.
那是一所大型监狱，有许多庭院和通道，彼此相似，铺设得如此均匀，当我经过时，我似乎对年复一年被关在同一堵凝视墙壁中的孤独囚犯的喜爱有了新的理解，正如我所读到的那样，已经找到了一根杂草或一片零散的草叶。在一个拱形房间里，他独自一人，就像楼上的地窖，墙壁洁白得耀眼，使得巨大的铁窗栏和铁门显得更加黑色，我们发现士兵站在一个角落里。他当时正坐在那儿的一张长凳上，听到门锁和插销转动的声音就站了起来。

When he saw us, he came forward a step with his usual heavy tread, and there stopped and made a slight bow. But as I still advanced, putting out my hand to him, he understood us in a moment.
当他看到我们时，他像往常一样沉重地向前迈出了一步，然后停了下来，微微鞠了一躬。但当我继续向前，向他伸出手时，他立刻就明白了我们的意思。

‘This is a load off my mind, I do assure you, miss and gentlemen,’ said he, saluting us with great heartiness and drawing a long breath. ‘And now I don’t so much care how it ends.’
“女士们，先生们，我向你们保证，这让我卸下了沉重的负担。”他说着，满怀热忱地向我们致意，长长地吸了一口气。 “现在我不太关心它如何结束。”

He scarcely seemed to be the prisoner. What with his coolness and his soldierly bearing, he looked far more like the prison guard.
他看上去根本不像是个囚犯。由于他的冷静和军人的举止，他看上去更像是一名狱警。

‘This is even a rougher place than my gallery to receive a lady in,’ said Mr. George, ‘but I know Miss Summerson will make the best of it.’ As he handed me to the bench on which he had been sitting, I sat down, which seemed to give him great satisfaction.
“这里比我的画廊更难接待一位女士，”乔治先生说，“但我知道萨默森小姐会充分利用它。”当他把我递到他一直坐的长凳上时，我坐下来，这似乎让他感到非常满意。

‘I thank you, miss,’ said he.
“我谢谢你，小姐，”他说。

‘Now, George,’ observed my guardian, ‘as we require no new assurances on your part, so I believe we need give you none on ours.’
“现在，乔治，”我的监护人说道，“因为我们不需要你做出新的保证，所以我相信我们不需要给你任何我们的保证。”

‘Not at all, sir. I thank you with all my heart. If I was not innocent of this crime, I couldn’t look at you and keep my secret to myself under the condescension of the present visit. I feel the present visit very much. I am not one of the eloquent sort, but I feel it, Miss Summerson and gentlemen, deeply.’
“一点也不，先生。我全心全意地感谢你。如果我不是无辜的，我就不能看着你，在这次访问的居高临下之下保守我的秘密。这次访问我感触很深。我不是那种善于言辞的人，但萨默森小姐和先生们，我深深地感受到了这一点。

He laid his hand for a moment on his broad chest and bent his bead to us. Although he squared himself again directly, he expressed a great amount of natural emotion by these simple means.
他把手放在宽阔的胸膛上一会儿，然后向我们弯下腰。虽然他再次直接摆正了自己，但通过这些简单的手段，他却表达出了大量自然的情感。

‘First,’ said my guardian, ‘can we do anything for your personal comfort, George?’
“首先，”我的监护人说，“为了您的个人舒适，我们可以做些什么吗，乔治？”

‘For which, sir?’ he inquired, clearing his throat.
“为了什么，先生？”他清了清喉咙问道。

‘For your personal comfort. Is there anything you want that would lessen the hardship of this confinement?’
“为了您个人的舒适。你想要什么东西来减轻这次监禁的痛苦吗？

‘Well, sir,’ replied George, after a little cogitation, ‘I am equally obliged to you, but tobacco being against the rules, I can’t say that there is.’
“好吧，先生，”乔治想了一会儿后回答道，“我同样对你表示感谢，但烟草是违反规定的，我不能说有。”

‘You will think of many little things perhaps, by and by. ‘Whenever you do, George, let us know.’
‘渐渐地，你也许会想到很多小事。 “乔治，无论什么时候，请告诉我们。”

‘Thank you, sir. Howsoever,’ observed Mr. George with one of his sunburnt smiles, ‘a man who has been knocking about the world in a vagabond kind of a way as long as I have gets on well enough in a place like the present, so far as that goes.’
'谢谢你，先生。不管怎样，”乔治先生带着晒伤的微笑说道，“只要我在像现在这样的地方过得足够好，他就一直以一种流浪者的方式在这个世界上徘徊。这些都不在了。'

‘Next, as to your case,’ observed my guardian.
“接下来，关于你的情况，”我的监护人说道。

‘Exactly so, sir,’ returned Mr. George, folding his arms upon his breast with perfect self-possession and a little curiosity.
“正是如此，先生，”乔治先生回答道，他把双臂抱在胸前，表现得十分镇定，还带着一点好奇。

‘How does it stand now?’
“现在怎么样？”

‘Why, sir, it is under remand at present. Bucket gives me to understand that he will probably apply for a series of remands from time to time until the case is more complete. How it is to be made more complete I don’t myself see, but I dare say Bucket will manage it somehow.’
“哎呀，先生，目前还押候审。巴克特让我了解到，他可能会不时申请一系列还押，直到案件更加完整。我自己不明白如何让它变得更加完整，但我敢说巴克特会以某种方式做到这一点。

‘Why, heaven save us, man,’ exclaimed my guardian, surprised into his old oddity and vehemence, ‘you talk of yourself as if you were somebody else!’
“哎呀，老天救救我们吧，伙计，”我的监护人惊呼道，他对自己过去的古怪和激烈感到惊讶，“你说自己就像是别人一样！”

‘No offence, sir,’ said Mr. George. ‘I am very sensible of your kindness. But I don’t see how an innocent man is to make up his mind to this kind of thing without knocking his head against the walls unless he takes it in that point of view.
“无意冒犯，先生，”乔治先生说。 ‘我非常感受到你的好意。但我不明白一个无辜的人如何能够在不碰壁的情况下做出这样的决定，除非他以这种观点来看待。

‘That is true enough to a certain extent,’ returned my guardian, softened. ‘But my good fellow, even an innocent man must take ordinary precautions to defend himself.’
“在某种程度上，这确实是真的。”我的监护人语气软化了。 “但是我的好朋友，即使是一个无辜的人也必须采取普通的预防措施来保护自己。”

‘Certainly, sir. And I have done so. I have stated to the magistrates, ‘Gentlemen, I am as innocent of this charge as yourselves; what has been stated against me in the way of facts is perfectly true; I know no more about it.’ I intend to continue stating that, sir. What more can I do? It’s the truth.’
'当然，先生。我已经这样做了。我已经对法官们说：‘先生们，我和你们一样对这项指控是无辜的；以事实的方式对我提出的指控是完全正确的；我对此一无所知。’我打算继续这样说，先生。我还能做什么？真的。'

‘But the mere truth won’t do,’ rejoined my guardian.
“但光靠事实是不行的，”我的监护人回答道。

‘Won’t it indeed., sir? Rather a bad look-out for me!’ Mr. George good-humouredly observed.
“确实如此吗，先生？ “对我来说真是太糟糕了！”乔治先生幽默地说道。

‘You must have a lawyer,’ pursued my guardian. ‘We must engage a good one for you.’
“你必须有一名律师，”我的监护人追问。 “我们必须为你聘请一位好人。”

‘I ask your pardon, sir,’ said Mr. George with a step backward. ‘I am equally obliged. But I must decidedly beg to be excused from anything of that sort.’
“请您原谅，先生，”乔治先生后退了一步说道。 ‘我同样有义务。但我必须坚决请求原谅我做这类事情。

‘You won’t have a lawyer?’
“你没有律师吗？”

‘No, sir.’ Mr. George shook his head in the most emphatic manner. ‘I thank you all the same, sir, but—no lawyer!’
“不，先生。”乔治先生用最坚决的方式摇摇头。 “我还是谢谢你，先生，但是——不是律师！”

‘Why not?’
'为什么不？'

‘I don’t take kindly to the breed,’ said Mr. George. ‘Gridley didn’t. And—if you’ll excuse my saying so much—I should hardly have thought you did yourself, sir.’
“我对这个品种不太友好，”乔治先生说。 '格里德利没有。而且——请原谅我说了这么多——我简直没想到你自己也这么做了，先生。”

‘That’s equity,’ my guardian explained, a little at a loss; ‘that’s equity, George.’
“这就是公平，”我的监护人解释道，有点不知所措。 “这就是公平，乔治。”

‘Is it, indeed, sir?’ returned the trooper in his off-hand manner. ‘I am not acquainted with those shades of names myself, but in a general way I object to the breed.’
“真的是这样吗，长官？”士兵随口答道。 “我自己并不熟悉这些名字，但总的来说，我反对这个品种。”

Unfolding his arms and changing his position, he stood with one massive hand upon the table and the other on his hip, as complete a picture of a man who was not to be moved from a fixed purpose as ever I saw. It was in vain that we all three talked to him and endeavoured to persuade him; he listened with that gentleness which went so well with his bluff bearing, but was evidently no more shaken by our representations that his place of confinement was.
他张开双臂，改变姿势，一只大手放在桌子上，另一只手放在臀部，这完全是我所见过的一个不肯放弃固定目标的男人的完整写照。我们三个人都跟他谈话并试图说服他，但都是徒劳。他听得很温柔，这与他的直言不讳的态度很相配，但显然他并没有像他的监禁地那样被我们的陈述所动摇。

‘Pray think, once more, Mr. George,’ said I. ‘Have you no wish in reference to your case?’
“请再想一想，乔治先生，”我说，“你对你的案子没有任何愿望吗？”

‘I certainly could wish it to be tried, miss,’ he returned, ‘by court-martial; but that is out of the question, as I am well aware. If you will be so good as to favour me with your attention for a couple of minutes, miss, not more, I’ll endeavour to explain myself as clearly as I can.’
“我当然希望通过军事法庭来审判，小姐，”他回答道。但据我所知，这是不可能的。如果您愿意花几分钟的时间关注我，小姐，不要再多了，我会尽力尽可能清楚地解释自己。

He looked at us all three in turn, shook his head a little as if he were adjusting it in the stock and collar of a tight uniform, and after a moment’s reflection went on.
他依次看着我们三个人，轻轻摇了摇头，仿佛正在调整紧身制服的枪托和领子，沉思了一会儿之后继续说道。

‘You see, miss, I have been handcuffed and taken into custody and brought here. I am a marked and disgraced man, and here I am. My shooting gallery is rummaged, high and low, by Bucket; such property as I have—‘tis small—is turned this way and that till it don’t know itself; and (as aforesaid) here I am! I don’t particular complain of that. Though I am in these present quarters through no immediately preceding fault of mine, I can very well understand that if I hadn’t gone into the vagabond way in my youth, this wouldn’t have happened. It HAS happened. Then comes the question how to meet it”
“你看，小姐，我被戴上手铐并被拘留并带到这里。我是一个被标记和耻辱的人，而我就在这里。我的射击场被巴克特翻遍了；我所拥有的财产——虽然很小——被这样或那样地转动，直到它不认识自己为止； （如上所述）我在这里！我对此并不特别抱怨。虽然我现在的处境并不是因为我之前的过失，但我很清楚，如果我年轻时没有走上流浪之路，就不会发生这样的事情。它已经发生了。那么问题来了，如何应对”

He rubbed his swarthy forehead for a moment with a good-humoured look and said apologetically, ‘I am such a short-winded talker that I must think a bit.’ Having thought a bit, he looked up again and resumed.
他揉了揉黝黑的额头，表情好笑，抱歉道：“我说话太短，必须想一想。”想了想，他又抬起头，继续说道。

‘How to meet it. Now, the unfortunate deceased was himself a lawyer and had a pretty tight hold of me. I don’t wish to rake up his ashes, but he had, what I should call if he was living, a devil of a tight hold of me. I don’t like his trade the better for that. If I had kept clear of his trade, I should have kept outside this place. But that’s not what I mean. Now, suppose I had killed him. Suppose I really had discharged into his body any one of those pistols recently fired off that Bucket has found at my place, and dear me, might have found there any day since it has been my place. What should I have done as soon as I was hard and fast here? Got a lawyer.’
‘如何去迎接它。现在，不幸的死者本身就是一名律师，并且对我的控制非常严格。我不想捡起他的骨灰，但他——如果他还活着，我应该这么称呼——一个紧紧抓住我的魔鬼。我因此更不喜欢他的交易。如果我不参与他的交易，我就应该远离这个地方。但这不是我的意思。现在，假设我杀了他。假设我真的把巴克特在我家发现的那些最近发射的手枪中的任何一支射进了他的身体，亲爱的我，自从那是我的家以来，随时可能会在那里找到。当我在这里硬着头皮的时候，我应该做什么呢？有律师了。

He stopped on hearing some one at the locks and bolts and did not resume until the door had been opened and was shut again. For what purpose opened, I will mention presently.
听到有人敲门锁的声音，他停了下来，直到门被打开又关上才继续。出于什么目的而开设，我稍后会提到。

‘I should have got a lawyer, and he would have said (as I have often read in the newspapers), ‘My client says nothing, my client reserves his defence’: my client this, that, and t’other. Well, ‘tis not the custom of that breed to go straight, according to my opinion, or to think that other men do. Say I am innocent and I get a lawyer. He would be as likely to believe me guilty as not; perhaps more. What would he do, whether or not? Act as if I was— shut my mouth up, tell me not to commit myself, keep circumstances back, chop the evidence small, quibble, and get me off perhaps! But, Miss Summerson, do I care for getting off in that way; or would I rather be hanged in my own way—if you’ll excuse my mentioning anything so disagreeable to a lady?’
“我应该找一位律师，他会说（正如我经常在报纸上读到的那样），‘我的委托人什么也没说，我的委托人保留他的辩护’：我的委托人这样、那样、那样。嗯，根据我的观点，或者认为其他人也这样做，这不是这个品种的习惯。说我是无辜的，我就请律师。他可能认为我有罪，也可能认为我无罪。也许更多。无论是否，他会做什么？表现得好像我是——闭嘴，告诉我不要做出承诺，隐瞒情况，把证据削减，狡辩，也许然后让我离开！但是，萨默森小姐，我愿意这样下车吗？或者我宁愿以我自己的方式被绞死——如果你能原谅我提到任何令一位女士如此不愉快的事情吗？

He had warmed into his subject now, and was under no further necessity to wait a bit.
他现在已经熟悉了自己的主题，不需要再等待了。

‘I would rather be hanged in my own way. And I mean to be! I don’t intend to say,’ looking round upon us with his powerful arms akimbo and his dark eyebrows raised, ‘that I am more partial to being hanged than another man. What I say is, I must come off clear and full or not at all. Therefore, when I hear stated against me what is true, I say it’s true; and when they tell me, ‘whatever you say will be used,’ I tell them I don’t mind that; I mean it to be used. If they can’t make me innocent out of the whole truth, they are not likely to do it out of anything less, or anything else. And if they are, it’s worth nothing to me.’
“我宁愿以我自己的方式被绞死。我也想成为这样的人！我不想说，”他有力的双手叉腰，眉毛扬起，环顾我们，“我比其他人更愿意被绞死。我要说的是，我必须表现得清晰、饱满，否则就根本没有。因此，当我听到对我不利的说法时，我说它是真的；当他们告诉我“无论你说什么都会被使用”时，我告诉他们我不介意；我的意思是要使用它。如果他们不能从全部真相中让我清白，他们就不太可能用更少的东西或其他任何东西来做到这一点。如果是的话，那对我来说毫无价值。

Taking a pace or two over the stone floor, he came back to the table and finished what he had to say.
他在石头地板上走了一两步，回到桌边，讲完了他要说的话。

‘I thank you, miss and gentlemen both, many times for your attention, and many times more for your interest. That’s the plain state of the matter as it points itself out to a mere trooper with a blunt broadsword kind of a mind. I have never done well in life beyond my duty as a soldier, and if the worst comes after all, I shall reap pretty much as I have sown. When I got over the first crash of being seized as a murderer—it don’t take a rover who has knocked about so much as myself so very long to recover from a crash—I worked my way round to what you find me now. As such I shall remain. No relations will be disgraced by me or made unhappy for me, and—and that’s all I’ve got to say.’
“女士们，先生们，我多次感谢你们的关注，更多次感谢你们的兴趣。这就是事情的简单情况，因为它向一个头脑简单的士兵表明了这一点。除了作为一名士兵的职责之外，我一生中从未做过任何好事，如果最坏的情况最终发生，我将收获与我种下的一样多。当我第一次从被当作杀人犯抓获的事故中恢复过来时——一个像我这样颠簸了这么久的漫游者不需要很长时间才能从事故中恢复过来——我努力地找到了你现在找到的我。因此我将留下来。没有任何亲戚会因我而蒙羞或为我感到不高兴，而且——这就是我要说的。

The door had been opened to admit another soldier-looking man of less prepossessing appearance at first sight and a weather-tanned, bright-eyed wholesome woman with a basket, who, from her entrance, had been exceedingly attentive to all Mr. George had said. Mr. George had received them with a familiar nod and a friendly look, but without any more particular greeting in the midst of his address. He now shook them cordially by the hand and said, ‘Miss Summerson and gentlemen, this is an old comrade of mine, Matthew Bagnet. And this is his wife, Mrs. Bagnet.’
门打开了，进来了另一个乍一看不太讨人喜欢的军人模样的男人，还有一个提着篮子、皮肤晒得黝黑、眼睛明亮、健康的女人，从她进来时，她就对乔治先生的一切都非常细心。说。乔治先生以熟悉的点头和友好的眼神接待了他们，但在讲话中没有任何更特别的问候。他现在亲切地与他们握手，说道：“萨默森小姐和先生们，这是我的一位老战友，马修·巴格内特。”这是他的妻子，巴格内特夫人。

Mr. Bagnet made us a stiff military bow, and Mrs. Bagnet dropped us a curtsy.
巴格内特先生向我们行了一个僵硬的军事鞠躬，巴格内特夫人向我们行了屈膝礼。

‘Real good friends of mine, they are,’ sald Mr. George. ‘It was at their house I was taken.’
“他们是我真正的好朋友，”乔治先生说道。 “我是在他们家被带走的。”

‘With a second-hand wiolinceller,’ Mr. Bagnet put in, twitching his head angrily. ‘Of a good tone. For a friend. That money was no object to.’
“用一把二手小提琴，”巴格内特先生插话道，愤怒地扭动着头。 ‘语气很好。为了一个朋友。这笔钱是没有异议的。

‘Mat,’ said Mr. George, ‘you have heard pretty well all I have been saying to this lady and these two gentlemen. I know it meets your approval?’
“马特，”乔治先生说，“我对这位女士和两位先生所说的一切你都听得很清楚了。我知道你同意吗？

Mr. Bagnet, after considering, referred the point to his wife. ‘Old girl,’ said he. ‘Tell him. Whether or not. It meets my approval.’
巴格内特先生考虑之后，将这一点转告给了他的妻子。 “老姑娘，”他说。 '告诉他。无论是否。它符合我的认可。

‘Why, George,’ exclaimed Mrs. Bagnet, who had been unpacking her basket, in which there was a piece of cold pickled pork, a little tea and sugar, and a brown loaf, ‘you ought to know it don’t. You ought to know it’s enough to drive a person wild to hear you. You won’t be got off this way, and you won’t be got off that way—what do you mean by such picking and choosing? It’s stuff and nonsense, George.’
“哎呀，乔治，”巴格尼特太太大声说道，她正在打开篮子，里面有一块冷腌猪肉、一点茶和糖，还有一块棕色面包，“你应该知道不是这样的。”你应该知道，听你说话就足以让一个人发疯。这样也过不去，那样也过不去，什么叫挑挑拣拣呢？这是胡说八道，乔治。

‘Don’t be severe upon me in my misfortunes, Mrs. Bagnet,’ said the trooper lightly.
“巴格内特夫人，请不要在我遭遇不幸时对我严厉，”士兵轻声说道。

‘Oh! Bother your misfortunes,’ cried Mrs. Bagnet, ‘if they don’t make you more reasonable than that comes to. I never was so ashamed in my life to hear a man talk folly as I have been to hear you talk this day to the present company. Lawyers? Why, what but too many cooks should hinder you from having a dozen lawyers if the gentleman recommended them to you”
'哦！巴格内特夫人叫道，“如果你的不幸不能让你比现在更理智，那就去管你的不幸吧。”我这辈子从来没有像今天听到你对现在的公司说话那样感到羞愧，因为听到一个人说蠢话。律师？哎呀，如果这位先生向你推荐了十几个律师，那么太多的厨师就会阻碍你聘请他们。”

‘This is a very sensible woman,’ said my guardian. ‘I hope you will persuade him, Mrs. Bagnet.’
“这是一个非常明智的女人，”我的监护人说。 “我希望你能说服他，巴格内特夫人。”

‘Persuade him, sir?’ she returned. ‘Lord bless you, no. You don’t know George. Now, there!’ Mrs. Bagnet left her basket to point him out with both her bare brown hands. ‘There he stands! As self-willed and as determined a man, in the wrong way, as ever put a human creature under heaven out of patience! You could as soon take up and shoulder an eight and forty pounder by your own strength as turn that man when he has got a thing into his head and fixed it there. Why, don’t I know him!’ cried Mrs. Bagnet. ‘Don’t I know you, George! You don’t mean to set up for a new character with ME after all these years, I hope?’
“说服他吗，先生？”她回答道。 ‘愿上帝保佑你，不。你不了解乔治。现在，就在那里！”巴格内特太太离开篮子，用她那双裸露的棕色双手指着他。 ‘他站在那里！一个任性而坚定的人，以错误的方式，让天下的人类失去了耐心！你可以用自己的力量拿起并扛起一门八四十磅的炮，就像当那个人把一个东西塞进他的脑袋并将其固定在那里时转动他一样。哎呀，我不认识他！”巴格尼特太太喊道。 “我不认识你吗，乔治！我希望你不会是想在这么多年之后和我一起创造一个新角色吧？

Her friendly indignation had an exemplary effect upon her husband, who shook his head at the trooper several times as a silent recommendation to him to yield. Between whiles, Mrs. Bagnet looked at me; and I understood from the play of her eyes that she wished me to do something, though I did not comprehend what.
她友好的愤慨对她的丈夫起到了模范作用，他多次向警察摇摇头，无声地建议他屈服。巴格内特夫人不时地看着我。从她的眼神中我明白她希望我做点什么，尽管我不明白是什么。

‘But I have given up talking to you, old fellow, years and years,’ said Mrs. Bagnet as she blew a little dust off the pickled pork, looking at me again; ‘and when ladies and gentlemen know you as well as I do, they’ll give up talking to you too. If you are not too headstrong to accept of a bit of dinner, here it is.’
“但是我已经放弃和你说话了，老伙计，很多年了。”巴格尼特太太一边说，一边吹掉腌猪肉上的灰尘，再次看着我。 “当女士们先生们像我一样了解你时，他们也会放弃与你交谈。如果你不是太任性而无法接受一点晚餐，那就来吧。

‘I accept it with many thanks,’ returned the trooper.
“我非常感谢地接受它，”士兵回答道。

‘Do you though, indeed?’ said Mrs. Bagnet, continuing to grumble on good-humouredly. ‘I’m sure I’m surprised at that I wonder you don’t starve in your own way also. It would only be like you. Perhaps you’ll set your mind upon THAT next.’ Here she again looked at me, and I now perceived from her glances at the door and at me, by turns, that she wished us to retire and to await her following us outside the prison. Communicating this by similar means to my guardian and Mr. Woodcourt, I rose.
“你确实这么认为吗？”巴格内特太太继续幽默地抱怨着。 “我确信我很惊讶你不会也以自己的方式挨饿。只会像你一样。也许你接下来会考虑这个。”说到这里，她再次看着我，从她轮流扫视门口和扫视我的眼神中，我看出她希望我们退出，并在门外等她跟着我们。监狱。我用类似的方式向我的监护人和伍德考特先生传达了这一点，然后站了起来。

‘We hope you will think better of it, Mr. George,’ said I, ‘and we shall come to see you again, trusting to find you more reasonable.’
“我们希望你能考虑清楚，乔治先生，”我说，“我们会再次来看你，相信会发现你更通情达理。”

‘More grateful, Miss Summerson, you can’t find me,’ he returned.
“更感激的是，萨默森小姐，你找不到我，”他回答道。

‘But more persuadable we can, I hope,’ said I. ‘And let me entreat you to consider that the clearing up of this mystery and the discovery of the real perpetrator of this deed may be of the last importance to others besides yourself.’
“但我希望我们能更容易被说服，”我说，“让我恳请你考虑一下，解开这个谜团并发现这起事件的真正肇事者，对于你以外的其他人来说可能是最重要的。” '

He heard me respectfully but without much heeding these words, which I spoke a little turned from him, already on my way to the door; he was observing (this they afterwards told me) my height and figure, which seemed to catch his attention all at once.
他恭敬地听我说话，但并没有太在意我说的话，我在走向门口的路上稍微转过身去。他正在观察（他们后来告诉我的）我的身高和身材，这似乎一下子引起了他的注意。

‘‘Tis curious,’ said he. ‘And yet I thought so at the time!’
“这很好奇，”他说。 “但我当时也是这么想的！”

My guardian asked him what he meant.
我的监护人问他这是什么意思。

‘Why, sir,’ he answered, ‘when my ill fortune took me to the dead man’s staircase on the night of his murder, I saw a shape so like Miss Summerson’s go by me in the dark that I had half a mind to speak to it.’
“为什么，先生，”他回答道，“在他被谋杀的那天晚上，当我的厄运把我带到死者的楼梯时，我看到一个像萨默森小姐那样的人影在黑暗中从我身边经过，我几乎不想说话。到它。

For an instant I felt such a shudder as I never felt before or since and hope I shall never feel again.
有那么一瞬间，我感到前所未有的颤抖，希望以后再也不会有这种感觉了。

‘It came downstairs as I went up,’ said the trooper, ‘and crossed the moonlighted window with a loose black mantle on; I noticed a deep fringe to it. However, it has nothing to do with the present subject, excepting that Miss Summerson looked so like it at the moment that it came into my head.’
“我上楼的时候，它也下了楼，”士兵说，“披着一件宽松的黑色斗篷，穿过了月光下的窗户；我注意到它有一个很深的边缘。然而，这与现在的主题无关，只是萨默森小姐此刻看起来很像，以至于它出现在我的脑海中。

I cannot separate and define the feelings that arose in me after this; it is enough that the vague duty and obligation I had felt upon me from the first of following the investigation was, without my distinctly daring to ask myself any question, increased, and that I was indignantly sure of there being no possibility of a reason for my being afraid.
我无法区分和定义此后我内心产生的感受；我从调查一开始就感受到的模糊的责任和义务就已经足够了，尽管我并没有明确地敢于问自己任何问题，但我愤怒地确信没有任何理由可以这样做。我害怕。

We three went out of the prison and walked up and down at some short distance from the gate, which was in a retired place. We had not waited long when Mr. and Mrs. Bagnet came out too and quickly joined us.
我们三人出了监狱，在离大门不远的地方走来走去，大门是一个僻静的地方。没等多久，巴格尼特夫妇也出来了，很快就加入了我们。

There was a tear in each of Mrs. Bagnet’s eyes, and her face was flushed and hurried. ‘I didn’t let George see what I thought about it, you know, miss,’ was her first remark when she came up, ‘but he’s in a bad way, poor old fellow!’
巴格内特太太的眼里都含着泪水，她的脸涨得通红，神情匆忙。 “我没有让乔治知道我对此的想法，你知道，小姐，”她走上来时的第一句话是，“但他的情况很糟糕，可怜的老家伙！”

‘Not with care and prudence and good help,’ said my guardian.
我的监护人说：“没有小心、谨慎和良好的帮助。”

‘A gentleman like you ought to know best, sir,’ returned Mrs. Bagnet, hurriedly drying her eyes on the hem of her grey cloak, ‘but I am uneasy for him. He has been so careless and said so much that he never meant. The gentlemen of the juries might not understand him as Lignum and me do. And then such a number of circumstances have happened bad for him, and such a number of people will be brought forward to speak against him, and Bucket is so deep.’
“像您这样的绅士应该最清楚，先生，”巴格内特夫人回答道，她急忙擦干灰色斗篷下摆上的眼睛，“但我为他感到不安。他真是太粗心了，说了那么多根本就不是本意的事情。评审团的先生们可能不像我和 Lignum 那样理解他。然后发生了这么多对他不利的情况，就会有这么多人站出来反对他，而巴克特的根深蒂固。

‘With a second-hand wiolinceller. And said he played the fife. When a boy,’ Mr. Bagnet added with great solemnity.
“有一个二手小提琴手。并说他吹横笛。当我还是个孩子的时候，”巴格内特先生非常严肃地补充道。

‘Now, I tell you, miss,’ said Mrs. Bagnet; ‘and when I say miss, I mean all! Just come into the corner of the wall and I’ll tell you!’
“现在，我告诉你，小姐，”巴格内特太太说。 ‘当我说小姐时，我指的是一切！只要走到墙角，我就告诉你！

Mrs. Bagnet hurried us into a more secluded place and was at first too breathless to proceed, occasioning Mr. Bagnet to say, ‘Old girl! Tell ‘em!’
巴格尼特夫人催促我们到一个更僻静的地方，起初气喘吁吁，无法继续前进，巴格尼特先生说：“老姑娘！”告诉他们！'

‘Why, then, miss,’ the old girl proceeded, untying the strings of her bonnet for more air, ‘you could as soon move Dover Castle as move George on this point unless you had got a new power to move him with. And I have got it!’
“那么，小姐，”老女孩继续说道，解开帽子的带子呼吸更多的空气，“在这一点上，你可以像移动乔治一样移动多佛城堡，除非你有一种新的力量来移动他。我已经得到了！

‘You are a jewel of a woman,’ said my guardian. ‘Go on!’
“你是女人的瑰宝，”我的监护人说。 '继续！'

‘Now, I tell you, miss,’ she proceeded, clapping her hands in her hurry and agitation a dozen times in every sentence, ‘that what he says concerning no relations is all bosh. They don’t know of him, but he does know of them. He has said more to me at odd times than to anybody else, and it warn’t for nothing that he once spoke to my Woolwich about whitening and wrinkling mothers’ heads. For fifty pounds he had seen his mother that day. She’s alive and must be brought here straight!’
“现在，我告诉你，小姐，”她接着说道，每句话都匆忙而激动地拍了十几次手，“他所说的与没有亲戚关系的事情都是胡说八道。他们不认识他，但他认识他们。他在奇怪的时候对我说的比对其他任何人都多，而且他曾经对我的伍尔维奇谈论过美白和皱纹母亲的头，这并不是没有道理的。那天他花了五十英镑才见到了他的母亲。她还活着，必须直接带来这里！”

Instantly Mrs. Bagnet put some pins into her mouth and began pinning up her skirts all round a little higher than the level of her grey cloak, which she accomplished with surpassing dispatch and dexterity.
巴格尼特太太立刻把一些别针放进嘴里，开始把裙子周围别起来，比她的灰色斗篷高一点，她以超乎寻常的敏捷和灵巧完成了这一任务。

‘Lignum,’ said Mrs. Bagnet, ‘you take care of the children, old man, and give me the umbrella! I’m away to Lincolnshire to bring that old lady here.’
“Lignum，”巴格内特太太说，“你照顾好孩子们，老人，把伞给我！”我要去林肯郡把那位老太太带到这里来。

‘But, bless the woman,’ cried my guardian with his hand in his pocket, ‘how is she going? What money has she got?’
“但是，上帝保佑那个女人，”我的监护人把手插在口袋里喊道，“她怎么样了？”她有什么钱？

Mrs. Bagnet made another application to her skirts and brought forth a leathern purse in which she hastily counted over a few shillings and which she then shut up with perfect satisfaction.
巴格尼特太太又在裙子上抹了一下，拿出一个皮钱包，她匆匆数了数，里面有几先令，然后心满意足地把它关上。

‘Never you mind for me, miss. I’m a soldier’s wife and accustomed to travel my own way. Lignum, old boy,’ kissing him, ‘one for yourself, three for the children. Now I’m away into Lincolnshire after George’s mother!’
‘别介意我，小姐。我是一名士兵的妻子，习惯按自己的方式旅行。利格纳姆，老男孩，”吻着他，“一个给你自己，三个给孩子们。现在我要去林肯郡追寻乔治的母亲了！

And she actually set off while we three stood looking at one another lost in amazement. She actually trudged away in her grey cloak at a sturdy pace, and turned the corner, and was gone.
她真的出发了，我们三个站在那里，面面相觑，惊讶不已。她实际上穿着灰色斗篷，迈着稳健的步伐，拐过街角，就不见了。

‘Mr. Bagnet,’ said my guardian. ‘Do you mean to let her go in that way?’
'先生。巴内特，”我的监护人说。 “你打算就这样放她走吗？”

‘Can’t help it,’ he returned. ‘Made her way home once from another quarter of the world. With the same grey cloak. And same umbrella. Whatever the old girl says, do. Do it! Whenever the old girl says, I’LL do it. She does it.’
“没办法，”他回答道。 “她曾经从世界的另一个角落回家过一次。搭配同样的灰色斗篷。还有同一把伞。老姑娘说什么，就做什么。做吧！只要老姑娘说，我就照做。她做到了。

‘Then she is as honest and genuine as she looks,’ rejoined my guardian, ‘and it is impossible to say more for her.’
“那么，她就像她看起来那样诚实和真诚，”我的监护人回答道，“对她来说，没有什么可以说的了。”

‘She’s Colour-Sergeant of the Nonpareil battalion,’ said Mr. Bagnet, looking at us over his shoulder as he went his way also. ‘And there’s not such another. But I never own to it before her. Discipline must be maintained.’
“她是无与伦比营的上士，”巴格内特先生一边说，一边也走过去，回头看着我们。 ‘而且没有这样的另一个。但我从来没有在她面前承认过这一点。必须维持纪律。”

CHAPTER LIII
第十三章


The Track
轨道

Mr. Bucket and his fat forefinger are much in consultation together under existing circumstances. When Mr. Bucket has a matter of this pressing interest under his consideration, the fat forefinger seems to rise, to the dignity of a familiar demon. He puts it to his ears, and it whispers information; he puts it to his lips, and it enjoins him to secrecy; he rubs it over his nose, and it sharpens his scent; he shakes it before a guilty man, and it charms him to his destruction. The Augurs of the Detective Temple invariably predict that when Mr. Bucket and that finger are in much conference, a terrible avenger will be heard of before long.
巴克特先生和他的胖食指在现有情况下经常一起协商。当巴克特先生考虑一件如此紧迫的事情时，他那根肥大的食指似乎就竖了起来，呈现出一种熟悉的恶魔般的尊严。他把它放在耳边，它就会低声传达信息；他把它放到嘴边，它要求他保密。他把它擦在鼻子上，它使他的气味变得更加刺鼻。他在一个有罪的人面前摇动它，它会吸引他走向毁灭。神殿侦探的占卜师们总是预测，当巴克特先生和那个手指进行多次会议时，不久就会听到可怕的复仇者的消息。

Otherwise mildly studious in his observation of human nature, on the whole a benignant philosopher not disposed to be severe upon the follies of mankind, Mr. Bucket pervades a vast number of houses and strolls about an infinity of streets, to outward appearance rather languishing for want of an object. He is in the friendliest condition towards his species and will drink with most of them. He is free with his money, affable in his manners, innocent in his conversation—but through the placid stream of his life there glides an under-current of forefinger.
巴克特先生在对人性的观察上还算勤奋，总的来说，他是一位仁慈的哲学家，不打算严厉批评人类的愚蠢行为，他走遍了无数的房屋，漫步在无数的街道上，从外表上看，他对人类的愚蠢行为感到十分沮丧。想要一个物体。他对他的物种处于最友好的状态，并且会与大多数物种一起喝酒。他用钱自由，举止和蔼可亲，谈吐纯真——但在他平静的生活中，却有一股食指的暗流在流淌。

Time and place cannot bind Mr. Bucket. Like man in the abstract, he is here to-day and gone to-morrow—but, very unlike man indeed, he is here again the next day. This evening he will be casually looking into the iron extinguishers at the door of Sir Leicester Dedlock’s house in town; and to-morrow morning he will be walking on the leads at Chesney Wold, where erst the old man walked whose ghost is propitiated with a hundred guineas. Drawers, desks, pockets, all things belonging to him, Mr. Bucket examines. A few hours afterwards, he and the Roman will be alone together comparing forefingers.
