时间和地点不能束缚巴克特先生。就像抽象的人一样，他今天在这里，明天就离开了——但是，与人非常不同的是，他第二天又在这里。今晚，他将漫不经心地查看镇上莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士家门口的铁制灭火器。明天早上，他将沿着切斯尼沃尔德的路行走，老人曾经走过的地方，他的鬼魂被一百几尼安抚了。抽屉、桌子、口袋，所有属于他的东西，巴克特先生检查了一下。几个小时后，他和罗马人将单独在一起比较食指。

It is likely that these occupations are irreconcilable with home enjoyment, but it is certain that Mr. Bucket at present does not go home. Though in general he highly appreciates the society of Mrs. Bucket—a lady of a natural detective genius, which if it had been improved by professional exercise, might have done great things, but which has paused at the level of a clever amateur—he holds himself aloof from that dear solace. Mrs. Bucket is dependent on their lodger (fortunately an amiable lady in whom she takes an interest) for companionship and conversation.
这些职业很可能与家庭享受是不可调和的，但可以肯定的是，巴克特先生目前不回家。虽然总的来说，他非常欣赏巴克特夫人的交往——一位具有天生侦探天才的女士，如果通过专业锻炼得到提高，可能会做出伟大的事情，但她的水平还停留在聪明的业余爱好者的水平——他他让自己远离那亲爱的安慰。巴克特太太依赖她们的房客（幸运的是，她感兴趣的是一位和蔼可亲的女士）的陪伴和交谈。

A great crowd assembles in Lincoln’s Inn Fields on the day of the funeral. Sir Leicester Dedlock attends the ceremony in person; strictly speaking, there are only three other human followers, that is to say, Lord Doodle, William Buffy, and the debilitated cousin (thrown in as a make-weight), but the amount of inconsolable carriages is immense. The peerage contributes more four-wheeled affliction than has ever been seen in that neighbourhood. Such is the assemblage of armorial bearings on coach panels that the Herald’s College might be supposed to have lost its father and mother at a blow. The Duke of Foodle sends a splendid pile of dust and ashes, with silver wheel-boxes, patent axles, all the last improvements, and three bereaved worms, six feet high, holding on behind, in a bunch of woe. All the state coachmen in London seem plunged into mourning; and if that dead old man of the rusty garb be not beyond a taste in horseflesh (which appears impossible), it must be highly gratified this day.
葬礼当天，一大群人聚集在林肯客栈球场。莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士亲自出席仪式；严格来说，人类追随者只有三个，即杜多勋爵、威廉·巴菲和虚弱的表弟（作为补充体重），但令人伤心的车厢数量却是巨大的。贵族带来的四轮痛苦比该地区以往任何时候都多。车厢面板上的徽章轴承的组合使得先驱学院可能一下子就失去了父亲和母亲。福德尔公爵送来了一堆华丽的灰尘和灰烬，还有银色的轮箱、专利车轴、所有最后的改进，还有三只六英尺高的失去亲人的蠕虫，在一堆悲伤中紧握在后面。伦敦所有的州车夫似乎都陷入了哀悼之中。如果那个穿着生锈衣服的死去的老人没有尝过马肉的味道（这似乎是不可能的），那么今天一定会非常高兴。

Quiet among the undertakers and the equipages and the calves of so many legs all steeped in grief, Mr. Bucket sits concealed in one of the inconsolable carriages and at his ease surveys the crowd through the lattice blinds. He has a keen eye for a crowd—as for what not?—and looking here and there, now from this side of the carriage, now from the other, now up at the house windows, now along the people’s heads, nothing escapes him.
巴克特先生躲在一辆令人伤心的车厢里，在殡仪员、马具和那么多沉浸在悲痛中的小腿之间安静地坐着，透过格子百叶窗悠闲地观察着人群。他对人群有敏锐的洞察力——至于什么不是？——他东张西望，时而从马车的这一侧，时而从另一侧，时而抬头望向房屋的窗户，时而顺着人们的头顶，没有什么能逃过他的眼睛。 。

‘And there you are, my partner, eh?’ says Mr. Bucket to himself, apostrophizing Mrs. Bucket, stationed, by his favour, on the steps of the deceased’s house. ‘And so you are. And so you are! And very well indeed you are looking, Mrs. Bucket!’
“你就在那里，我的搭档，是吗？”巴克特先生自言自语地说，并省略了巴克特太太，巴克特太太在他的恩惠下驻扎在死者房子的台阶上。 ‘你也是。你也是！巴克特太太，你确实在看！

The procession has not started yet, but is waiting for the cause of its assemblage to be brought out. Mr. Bucket, in the foremost emblazoned carriage, uses his two fat forefingers to hold the lattice a hair’s breadth open while he looks.
游行还没有开始，正在等待集合原因的公布。巴克特先生坐在最前面的一辆装饰精美的马车上，他一边看，一边用他的两个粗大的食指将格子撑开一个头发丝的宽度。

And it says a great deal for his attachment, as a husband, that he is still occupied with Mrs. B. ‘There you are, my partner, eh?’ he murmuringly repeats. ‘And our lodger with you. I’m taking notice of you, Mrs. Bucket; I hope you’re all right in your health, my dear!’
作为一个丈夫，他仍然对 B 太太很着迷，这充分说明了他的依恋。“你在这儿，我的伴侣，是吗？”他低声重复道。 “还有我们的房客和你在一起。我注意到你了，巴克特太太；我希望你身体健康，亲爱的！

Not another word does Mr. Bucket say, but sits with most attentive eyes until the sacked depository of noble secrets is brought down— Where are all those secrets now? Does he keep them yet? Did they fly with him on that sudden journey?—and until the procession moves, and Mr. Bucket’s view is changed. After which he composes himself for an easy ride and takes note of the fittings of the carriage in case he should ever find such knowledge useful.
巴克特先生一言不发，只是用最专注的目光坐着，直到被洗劫的高贵秘密的储藏室被拆毁——那些秘密现在在哪里？他还保留着它们吗？他们在那次突然的旅程中和他一起飞行了吗？——直到队伍移动，巴克特先生的观点改变了。之后，他平静下来，准备轻松骑行，并记下马车的配件，以防万一他发现这些知识有用。

Contrast enough between Mr. Tulkinghorn shut up in his dark carriage and Mr. Bucket shut up in HIS. Between the immeasurable track of space beyond the little wound that has thrown the one into the fixed sleep which jolts so heavily over the stones of the streets, and the narrow track of blood which keeps the other in the watchful state expressed in every hair of his head! But it is all one to both; neither is troubled about that.
关在黑暗马车里的图金霍恩先生和关在他的车厢里的巴克特先生形成了鲜明的对比。在小伤口之外的不可估量的空间轨迹之间，小伤口使一个人陷入固定的睡眠，在街道的石头上剧烈摇晃，而狭窄的血迹使另一个人保持警惕状态，表现在他的每一根头发上头！但这对双方来说都是一回事；两人都不为此烦恼。

Mr. Bucket sits out the procession in his own easy manner and glides from the carriage when the opportunity he has settled with himself arrives. He makes for Sir Leicester Dedlock’s, which is at present a sort of home to him, where he comes and goes as he likes at all hours’, where he is always welcome and made much of, where he knows the whole establishment, and walks in an atmosphere of mysterious greatness.
巴克特先生以他自己轻松的方式坐在队伍外面，当他与自己达成一致的机会到来时，他就从马车上滑下来。他前往莱斯特戴德洛克爵士的家，那里目前对他来说有点像家，他随时都可以来去自如，在那里他总是受到欢迎和重视，在那里他了解整个机构，并且散步在一种神秘伟大的气氛中。

No knocking or ringing for Mr. Bucket. He has caused himself to be provided with a key and can pass in at his pleasure. As he is crossing the hall, Mercury informs him, ‘Here’s another letter for you, Mr. Bucket, come by post,’ and gives it him.
巴克特先生不准敲门或按铃。他给自己准备了一把钥匙，可以随心所欲地进去。当他穿过大厅时，墨丘利告诉他：“这是给你的另一封信，巴克特先生，请邮寄过来。”然后交给了​​他。

‘Another one, eh?’ says Mr. Bucket.
“再来一张，嗯？”巴克特先生说。

If Mercury should chance to be possessed by any lingering curiosity as to Mr. Bucket’s letters, that wary person is not the man to gratify it. Mr. Bucket looks at him as if his face were a vista of some miles in length and he were leisurely contemplating the same.
如果水星碰巧对巴克特先生的信产生了任何挥之不去的好奇心，那么那个谨慎的人就不是满足这种好奇心的人。巴克特先生看着他，仿佛他的脸是几英里长的远景，他正在悠闲地沉思着同样的事情。

‘Do you happen to carry a box?’ says Mr. Bucket.
“你碰巧带着一个盒子吗？”巴克特先生说。

Unfortunately Mercury is no snuff-taker.
不幸的是，水星并不是一个贪吃的人。

‘Could you fetch me a pinch from anywheres?’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘Thankee. It don’t matter what it is; I’m not particular as to the kind. Thankee!’
“你能从任何地方给我取一点吗？”巴克特先生说。 “谢谢。”它是什么并不重要；我对那种类型并不特别。谢谢！’

Having leisurely helped himself from a canister borrowed from somebody downstairs for the purpose, and having made a considerable show of tasting it, first with one side of his nose and then with the other, Mr. Bucket, with much deliberation, pronounces it of the right sort and goes on, letter in hand.
巴克特先生悠闲地从楼下某人借来的一个罐子里拿了一杯，并做了相当多的品尝，先用一侧鼻子，然后用另一侧，巴克特先生经过深思熟虑，宣布这是正确分类并继续，手里拿着信。

Now although Mr. Bucket walks upstairs to the little library within the larger one with the face of a man who receives some scores of letters every day, it happens that much correspondence is not incidental to his life. He is no great scribe, rather handling his pen like the pocket-staff he carries about with him always convenient to his grasp, and discourages correspondence with himself in others as being too artless and direct a way of doing delicate business. Further, he often sees damaging letters produced in evidence and has occasion to reflect that it was a green thing to write them. For these reasons he has very little to do with letters, either as sender or receiver. And yet he has received a round half-dozen within the last twenty-four hours.
现在，尽管巴克特先生走上楼，来到大图书馆内的小图书馆，脸上的表情每天都会收到几十封信，但碰巧的是，许多信件并不是他生活中偶然的。他不是一个出色的抄写员，他对待笔的方式就像他随身携带的袖珍工作人员一样，总是方便他抓握，并且不鼓励与他人进行通信，因为这种方式过于天真和直接，是一种处理微妙事务的方式。此外，他经常看到有破坏性的信件作为证据，并有机会反思写这些信件是一件绿色的事情。由于这些原因，无论是作为寄件人还是收件人，他与信件关系不大。然而在过去的二十四小时内他已经收到了六封。

‘And this,’ says Mr. Bucket, spreading it out on the table, ‘is in the same hand, and consists of the same two words.’
“而这个，”巴克特先生一边说，一边把它摊在桌子上，“出自同一个人之手，并且由相同的两个词组成。”

What two words?
哪两个字？

He turns the key in the door, ungirdles his black pocket-book (book of fate to many), lays another letter by it, and reads, boldly written in each, ‘Lady Dedlock.’
他转动门上的钥匙，解开他的黑色皮夹（对很多人来说都是命运之书），在旁边放了另一封信，每封都用粗体字写着“戴德洛克夫人”。

‘Yes, yes,’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘But I could have made the money without this anonymous information.’
“是的，是的，”巴克特先生说。 “但如果没有这些匿名信息，我也能赚到钱。”

Having put the letters in his book of fate and girdled it up again, he unlocks the door just in time to admit his dinner, which is brought upon a goodly tray with a decanter of sherry. Mr. Bucket frequently observes, in friendly circles where there is no restraint, that he likes a toothful of your fine old brown East Inder sherry better than anything you can offer him. Consequently he fills and empties his glass with a smack of his lips and is proceeding with his refreshment when an idea enters his mind.
将信件放入命运之书并重新束紧后，他及时打开门进入晚餐，晚餐盛在一个精美的托盘上，托盘上盛有一瓶雪利酒。巴克特先生经常在没有任何限制的友好圈子里观察到，他更喜欢喝一口你的上好的老棕色东印度雪利酒，胜过你能给他的任何东西。因此，当他用嘴唇咂嘴地倒满和倒空杯子时，当一个想法进入他的脑海时，他正在继续他的茶点。

Mr. Bucket softly opens the door of communication between that room and the next and looks in. The library is deserted, and the fire is sinking low. Mr. Bucket’s eye, after taking a pigeon-flight round the room, alights upon a table where letters are usually put as they arrive. Several letters for Sir Leicester are upon it. Mr. Bucket draws near and examines the directions. ‘No,’ he says, ‘there’s none in that hand. It’s only me as is written to. I can break it to Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, to-morrow.’
巴克特先生轻轻地打开了那个房间和另一个房间之间的通讯门，往里看去。图书馆里空无一人，火势正在慢慢减弱。巴克特先生的目光在房间里飞来飞去，最后落在一张桌子上，信件到达时通常会放在桌子上。上面有几封写给莱斯特爵士的信。巴克特先生走近并检查方向。 “不，”他说，“那只手上什么也没有。”正如所写的那样，只有我一个人。明天我可以向莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，准男爵透露。

With that he returns to finish his dinner with a good appetite, and after a light nap, is summoned into the drawing-room. Sir Leicester has received him there these several evenings past to know whether he has anything to report. The debilitated cousin (much exhausted by the funeral) and Volumnia are in attendance.
说完，他胃口大好地吃完了晚饭，小睡了一会儿后，被叫进了客厅。莱斯特爵士前几天晚上在那里接待了他，询问他是否有什么要报告的。虚弱的表弟（因葬礼而筋疲力尽）和沃伦尼亚出席了会议。

Mr. Bucket makes three distinctly different bows to these three people. A bow of homage to Sir Leicester, a bow of gallantry to Volumnia, and a bow of recognition to the debilitated Cousin, to whom it airily says, ‘You are a swell about town, and you know me, and I know you.’ Having distributed these little specimens of his tact, Mr. Bucket rubs his hands.
巴克特先生向这三个人行了三个截然不同的鞠躬礼。向莱斯特爵士致敬，向沃伦尼亚致敬，向虚弱的堂兄致敬，它轻描淡写地对他说：“你是城里的名人，你认识我，我也认识你。”巴克特先生分发完这些他机智的小样本后，搓了搓手。

‘Have you anything new to communicate, officer?’ inquires Sir Leicester. ‘Do you wish to hold any conversation with me in private?’
“您有什么新消息要传达吗，军官？”莱斯特爵士问道。 “你想和我私下交谈吗？”

‘Why—not tonight, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet.’
“为什么——今晚不行，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵。”

‘Because my time,’ pursues Sir Leicester, ‘is wholly at your disposal with a view to the vindication of the outraged majesty of the law.’
“因为我的时间，”莱斯特爵士继续说道，“完全由您支配，以维护法律的尊严。”

Mr. Bucket coughs and glances at Volumnia, rouged and necklaced, as though he would respectfully observe, ‘I do assure you, you’re a pretty creetur. I’ve seen hundreds worse looking at your time of life, I have indeed.’
巴克特先生咳嗽了一声，看了一眼涂着胭脂、戴着项链的沃伦尼亚，仿佛他会恭敬地说道：“我向你保证，你是个漂亮的怪物。”在你一生中，我见过数百个更糟糕的人，我确实见过。

The fair Volumnia, not quite unconscious perhaps of the humanizing influence of her charms, pauses in the writing of cocked-hat notes and meditatively adjusts the pearl necklace. Mr. Bucket prices that decoration in his mind and thinks it as likely as not that Volumnia is writing poetry.
美丽的沃伦尼娅也许并没有完全意识到她的魅力所带来的人性化影响，她在写三角帽笔记时停下来，若有所思地调整着珍珠项链。巴克特先生在心里对这种装饰进行了估价，并认为沃伦尼亚很可能正在写诗。

‘If I have not,’ pursues Sir Leicester, ‘in the most emphatic manner, adjured you, officer, to exercise your utmost skill in this atrocious case, I particularly desire to take the present opportunity of rectifying any omission I may have made. Let no expense be a consideration. I am prepared to defray all charges. You can incur none in pursuit of the object you have undertaken that I shall hesitate for a moment to bear.’
“如果我没有，”莱斯特爵士继续说道，“以最强烈的方式恳求您，军官，在这起残暴的案件中发挥最大的技巧，我特别希望利用目前的机会纠正我可能犯下的任何疏忽。不要考虑任何费用。我准备支付所有费用。为了追求你所承担的目标，你不会招致任何让我犹豫是否要承担的事情。

Mr. Bucket made Sir Leicester’s bow again as a response to this liberality.
巴克特先生再次向莱斯特爵士鞠躬，作为对这种慷慨的回应。

‘My mind,’ Sir Leicester adds with a generous warmth, ‘has not, as may be easily supposed, recovered its tone since the late diabolical occurrence. It is not likely ever to recover its tone. But it is full of indignation to-night after undergoing the ordeal of consigning to the tomb the remains of a faithful, a zealous, a devoted adherent.’
“我的思想，”莱斯特爵士慷慨地热情地补充道，“正如人们容易想象的那样，自从最近发生的恶魔事件以来，我的思想还没有恢复正常。”它不太可能恢复其基调。但今晚，在经历了将一位忠实、热心、忠诚的信徒的遗体送入坟墓的磨难之后，它充满了愤慨。”

Sir Leicester’s voice trembles and his grey hair stirs upon his head. Tears are in his eyes; the best part of his nature is aroused.
莱斯特爵士的声音在颤抖，他的灰白头发在头上抖动。他的眼里含着泪水；他本性中最好的部分被激发了。

‘I declare,’ he says, ‘I solemnly declare that until this crime is discovered and, in the course of justice, punished, I almost feel as if there were a stain upon my name. A gentleman who has devoted a large portion of his life to me, a gentleman who has devoted the last day of his life to me, a gentleman who has constantly sat at my table and slept under my roof, goes from my house to his own, and is struck down within an hour of his leaving my house. I cannot say but that he may have been followed from my house, watched at my house, even first marked because of his association with my house—which may have suggested his possessing greater wealth and being altogether of greater importance than his own retiring demeanour would have indicated. If I cannot with my means and influence and my position bring all the perpetrators of such a crime to light, I fail in the assertion of my respect for that gentleman’s memory and of my fidelity towards one who was ever faithful to me.’
“我声明，”他说，“我郑重声明，在这一罪行被发现并在正义的过程中受到惩罚之前，我几乎感觉自己的名字受到了玷污。”一个为我奉献了大半辈子的绅士，一个为我奉献了一生最后一天的绅士，一个经常坐在我桌边睡在我屋檐下的绅士，从我家到他家，并在他离开我家后一小时内被击倒。我只能说，他可能从我家被跟踪，在我家被监视，甚至因为他与我家的联系而首先被注意到——这可能表明他拥有更多的财富，并且比他自己的退休行为更重要。已表明。如果我不能凭借我的手段、影响力和我的地位将此类罪行的所有肇事者绳之以法，我就无法表达对那位先生的记忆的尊重，也无法表达对曾经忠实于我的人的忠诚。”

While he makes this protestation with great emotion and earnestness, looking round the room as if he were addressing an assembly, Mr. Bucket glances at him with an observant gravity in which there might be, but for the audacity of the thought, a touch of compassion.
巴克特先生怀着极大的情感和真诚做出了这一声明，他环视房间，仿佛他正在向集会发表讲话，而巴克特先生则用一种敏锐的严肃态度看了他一眼，如果不是这个想法大胆的话，其中可能有一丝同情。

‘The ceremony of to-day,’ continues Sir Leicester, ‘strikingly illustrative of the respect in which my deceased friend’—he lays a stress upon the word, for death levels all distinctions—‘was held by the flower of the land, has, I say, aggravated the shock I have received from this most horrible and audacious crime. If it were my brother who had committed it, I would not spare him.’
“今天的仪式，”莱斯特爵士继续说道，“鲜明地说明了我已故的朋友”——他强调这个词，因为死亡消除了一切区别——“是由这片土地的花朵举行的，我说，这加剧了我对这一最可怕、最大胆犯罪行为的震惊。如果是我哥哥干的，我也不会饶过他。”

Mr. Bucket looks very grave. Volumnia remarks of the deceased that he was the trustiest and dearest person!
巴克特先生看上去很严肃。沃伦尼亚评价死者说，他是最值得信赖和最亲爱的人！

‘You must feel it as a deprivation to you, miss, replies Mr. Bucket soothingly, ‘no doubt. He was calculated to BE a deprivation, I’m sure he was.’
“你一定觉得这对你来说是一种剥夺，小姐，”巴克特先生安慰地回答道，“毫无疑问。”他被认为是一种剥夺，我确信他确实如此。

Volumnia gives Mr. Bucket to understand, in reply, that her sensitive mind is fully made up never to get the better of it as long as she lives, that her nerves are unstrung for ever, and that she has not the least expectation of ever smiling again. Meanwhile she folds up a cocked hat for that redoubtable old general at Bath, descriptive of her melancholy condition.
作为回答，沃伦尼亚让巴克特先生明白，她敏感的头脑已经下定决心，只要她活着，就永远不会好起来，她的神经永远处于紧张状态，她对任何事情都没有任何期望。再次微笑。与此同时，她为巴斯那位令人敬畏的老将军折了一顶三角帽，描述了她忧郁的处境。

‘It gives a start to a delicate female,’ says Mr. Bucket sympathetically, ‘but it’ll wear off.’
“它给娇弱的雌性带来了一个开始，”巴克特先生同情地说，“但它会逐渐消失。”

Volumnia wishes of all things to know what is doing? Whether they are going to convict, or whatever it is, that dreadful soldier? Whether he had any accomplices, or whatever the thing is called in the law? And a great deal more to the like artless purpose.
Volumnia希望万物都知道在做什么？他们是否要对那个可怕的士兵定罪，或者不管是什么？他是否有任何同谋，或者法律上所说的任何东西？还有很多类似的简单目的。

‘Why you see, miss,’ returns Mr. Bucket, bringing the finger into persuasive action—and such is his natural gallantry that he had almost said ‘my dear’—‘it ain’t easy to answer those questions at the present moment. Not at the present moment. I’ve kept myself on this case, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,’ whom Mr. Bucket takes into the conversation in right of his importance, ‘morning, noon, and night. But for a glass or two of sherry, I don’t think I could have had my mind so much upon the stretch as it has been. I COULD answer your questions, miss, but duty forbids it. Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, will very soon be made acquainted with all that has been traced. And I hope that he may find it’—Mr. Bucket again looks grave—‘to his satisfaction.’
“为什么你这么看，小姐，”巴克特先生回答道，用手指做出有说服力的动作——这就是他天生的殷勤，他几乎要说“亲爱的”——“现在回答这些问题并不容易。” 。目前还没有。我一直在关注这个案子，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，男爵，”巴克特先生根据他的重要性将他纳入谈话，“早上、中午和晚上。如果不是喝一两杯雪利酒，我想我不可能像现在这样全神贯注了。我可以回答你的问题，小姐，但职责不允许这样做。莱斯特·戴德洛克男爵爵士很快就会了解所有追踪到的情况。我希望他能找到它’——先生。巴克特再次显得严肃起来——“这让他很满意。”

The debilitated cousin only hopes some fler’ll be executed—zample. Thinks more interest’s wanted—get man hanged presentime—than get man place ten thousand a year. Hasn’t a doubt—zample—far better hang wrong fler than no fler.
虚弱的表弟只希望有人被处决——例如。认为现在需要更多的兴趣——立即绞死一个人——而不是让一个人每年获得一万块钱。毫无疑问——例如——挂错了比没有挂要好得多。

‘YOU know life, you know, sir,’ says Mr. Bucket with a complimentary twinkle of his eye and crook of his finger, ‘and you can confirm what I’ve mentioned to this lady. YOU don’t want to be told that from information I have received I have gone to work. You’re up to what a lady can’t be expected to be up to. Lord! Especially in your elevated station of society, miss,’ says Mr. Bucket, quite reddening at another narrow escape from ‘my dear.’
“你知道生活，你知道，先生，”巴克特先生说道，他的眼睛眨着眼睛，弯曲着手指，“你可以证实我向这位女士提到的事情。”您不想被告知，根据我收到的信息，我已经去上班了。你能做到一位女士无法做到的事情。主！尤其是在你社会地位较高的情况下，小姐。”巴克特先生说道，他又一次险些逃脱了“亲爱的”，他的脸涨得通红。

‘The officer, Volumnia,’ observes Sir Leicester, ‘is faithful to his duty, and perfectly right.’
莱斯特爵士评论说：“这位军官，沃卢尼亚，忠实于他的职责，而且完全正确。”

Mr. Bucket murmurs, ‘Glad to have the honour of your approbation, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet.’
巴克特先生低声说道：“很高兴得到您的认可，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，男爵。”

‘In fact, Volumnia,’ proceeds Sir Leicester, ‘it is not holding up a good model for imitation to ask the officer any such questions as you have put to him. He is the best judge of his own responsibility; he acts upon his responsibility. And it does not become us, who assist in making the laws, to impede or interfere with those who carry them into execution. Or,’ says Sir Leicester somewhat sternly, for Volumnia was going to cut in before he had rounded his sentence, ‘or who vindicate their outraged majesty.’
“事实上，沃伦尼亚，”莱斯特爵士继续说道，“向军官提出你向他提出的任何此类问题，并不能成为一个良好的模仿模式。”他是自己责任的最佳判断者；他履行自己的责任。我们作为协助制定法律的人，不应该去阻碍或干涉那些执行法律的人。或者，”莱斯特爵士有些严厉地说，因为沃伦尼亚正要在他结束话之前插话，“或者谁来维护他们愤怒的陛下。”

Volumnia with all humility explains that she had not merely the plea of curiosity to urge (in common with the giddy youth of her sex in general) but that she is perfectly dying with regret and interest for the darling man whose loss they all deplore.
沃卢姆尼娅谦虚地解释说，她不仅仅是出于好奇（与一般同性中轻浮的年轻人一样），而且她正在带着对失去这个亲爱的男人的遗憾和兴趣而彻底死去，他们都为失去这个男人而感到遗憾。

‘Very well, Volumnia,’ returns Sir Leicester. ‘Then you cannot be too discreet.’
“很好，沃伦尼亚，”莱斯特爵士回答道。 “那你就不能太谨慎了。”

Mr. Bucket takes the opportunity of a pause to be heard again.
巴克特先生利用暂停的机会再次发言。

‘Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I have no objections to telling this lady, with your leave and among ourselves, that I look upon the case as pretty well complete. It is a beautiful case—a beautiful case—and what little is wanting to complete it, I expect to be able to supply in a few hours.’
“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，男爵，在您允许的情况下，我不反对告诉这位女士，我认为这个案子已经完成了。这是一个漂亮的箱子——一个漂亮的箱子——而且我希望能够在几个小时内提供完成它的很少的东西。”

‘I am very glad indeed to hear it,’ says Sir Leicester. ‘Highly creditable to you.’
“我确实很高兴听到这个消息，”莱斯特爵士说道。 “你非常值得信赖。”

‘Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,’ returns Mr. Bucket very seriously, ‘I hope it may at one and the same time do me credit and prove satisfactory to all. When I depict it as a beautiful case, you see, miss,’ Mr. Bucket goes on, glancing gravely at Sir Leicester, ‘I mean from my point of view. As considered from other points of view, such cases will always involve more or less unpleasantness. Very strange things comes to our knowledge in families, miss; bless your heart, what you would think to be phenomenons, quite.’
“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，”巴克特先生非常严肃地回答道，“我希望它能同时为我赢得荣誉，并让所有人都满意。”当我把它描绘成一个美丽的案例时，你看，小姐，”巴克特先生继续说道，严肃地看了莱斯特爵士一眼，“我的意思是从我的角度来看。从其他角度考虑，此类案件总会或多或少地带来不愉快。我们在家庭中发现了非常奇怪的事情，小姐；保佑你的心，你认为这是现象，相当。

Volumnia, with her innocent little scream, supposes so.
沃伦妮娅天真地小声尖叫，她这么认为。

‘Aye, and even in gen-teel families, in high families, in great families,’ says Mr. Bucket, again gravely eyeing Sir Leicester aside. ‘I have had the honour of being employed in high families before, and you have no idea—come, I’ll go so far as to say not even YOU have any idea, sir,’ this to the debilitated cousin, ‘what games goes on!’
“是的，甚至在上流家庭、上流家庭、伟大家庭也是如此，”巴克特先生说，再次严肃地看着一旁的莱斯特爵士。 “我以前曾有幸受雇于名门望族，而你不知道——来吧，我什至可以说，连你也不知道，先生，”这是对虚弱的表弟说的，“什么游戏？”继续！'

The cousin, who has been casting sofa-pillows on his head, in a prostration of boredom yawns, ‘Vayli,’ being the used-up for ‘very likely.’
表弟一直把沙发枕头放在头上，无聊地打着哈欠，“Vayli”是“很可能”的用词。

Sir Leicester, deeming it time to dismiss the officer, here majestically interposes with the words, ‘Very good. Thank you!’ and also with a wave of his hand, implying not only that there is an end of the discourse, but that if high families fall into low habits they must take the consequences. ‘You will not forget, officer,’ he adds with condescension, ‘that I am at your disposal when you please.’
莱斯特爵士认为是时候解雇这名军官了，他在这里庄严地插话道：“很好。”谢谢！”他还挥了挥手，不仅暗示谈话到此结束，而且暗示如果名门望族陷入低俗习惯，他们必须承担后果。 “你不会忘记，长官，”他居高临下地补充道，“只要你愿意，我随时为你服务。”

Mr. Bucket (still grave) inquires if to-morrow morning, now, would suit, in case he should be as for’ard as he expects to be. Sir Leicester replies, ‘All times are alike to me.’ Mr. Bucket makes his three bows and is withdrawing when a forgotten point occurs to him.
巴克特先生（仍然很严肃）询问明天早上是否合适，以防他像他期望的那样前进。莱斯特爵士回答道：“对我来说，任何时候都是一样的。”巴克特先生三鞠躬，正要退出时，突然想起了一个被遗忘的事情。

‘Might I ask, by the by,’ he says in a low voice, cautiously returning, ‘who posted the reward-bill on the staircase.’
“顺便问一下，”他小心​​翼翼地回过头来，低声说道，“谁把悬赏单贴在楼梯上的。”

‘I ordered it to be put up there,’ replies Sir Leicester.
“我命令把它放在那里，”莱斯特爵士回答道。

‘Would it be considered a liberty, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, if I was to ask you why?’
“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，如果我问你为什么，这会被视为一种自由吗？”

‘Not at all. I chose it as a conspicuous part of the house. I think it cannot be too prominently kept before the whole establishment. I wish my people to be impressed with the enormity of the crime, the determination to punish it, and the hopelessness of escape. At the same time, officer, if you in your better knowledge of the subject see any objection—‘
'一点也不。我选择它作为房子的显眼部分。我认为它不能在整个机构面前太显眼。我希望我的人民对罪行的严重性、惩罚罪行的决心以及逃脱的无望印象深刻。同时，警官，如果您对这个问题有更深入的了解，发现有任何反对意见——”

Mr. Bucket sees none now; the bill having been put up, had better not be taken down. Repeating his three bows he withdraws, closing the door on Volumnia’s little scream, which is a preliminary to her remarking that that charmingly horrible person is a perfect Blue Chamber.
巴克特先生现在什么也看不见了。法案既然提出了，最好不要撤掉。重复三鞠躬之后，他退出了，关上了沃伦妮娅小尖叫声的大门，这是她评论那个迷人而可怕的人是一个完美的蓝室的前奏。

In his fondness for society and his adaptability to all grades, Mr. Bucket is presently standing before the hall-fire—bright and warm on the early winter night—admiring Mercury.
巴克特先生热爱社交，对各个年级的适应能力都很强，他现在正站在大厅的火前——初冬的夜晚明亮而温暖——欣赏着墨丘利。

‘Why, you’re six foot two, I suppose?’ says Mr. Bucket.
“我猜你身高六英尺二英寸？”巴克特先生说。

‘Three,’ says Mercury.
“三，”墨丘利说。

‘Are you so much? But then, you see, you’re broad in proportion and don’t look it. You’re not one of the weak-legged ones, you ain’t. Was you ever modelled now?’ Mr. Bucket asks, conveying the expression of an artist into the turn of his eye and head.
‘你就这么厉害吗？但是，你看，你的比例很宽大，但看起来并不如此。你不是腿软的人之一，你不是。 “你现在当过模特吗？”巴克特问道，他的目光和头部的转动传达出艺术家的表情。

Mercury never was modelled.
水星从未被建模。

‘Then you ought to be, you know,’ says Mr. Bucket; ‘and a friend of mine that you’ll hear of one day as a Royal Academy sculptor would stand something handsome to make a drawing of your proportions for the marble. My Lady’s out, ain’t she?’
“那你就应该这样，你知道，”巴克特先生说。 “有一天你会听说我的一位朋友，他是一名皇家学院雕塑家，他会站在一些漂亮的东西上，为你绘制大理石的比例图。夫人出去了，不是吗？

‘Out to dinner.’
“出去吃晚饭。”

‘Goes out pretty well every day, don’t she?’
“她每天都出去得很好，不是吗？”

‘Yes.’
'是的。'

‘Not to be wondered at!’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘Such a fine woman as her, so handsome and so graceful and so elegant, is like a fresh lemon on a dinner-table, ornamental wherever she goes. Was your father in the same way of life as yourself?’
“这并不奇怪！”巴克特先生说。像她这样的好女人，那么英俊，那么优雅，那么优雅，就像餐桌上的新鲜柠檬，走到哪里都是装饰品。你父亲的生活方式和你一样吗？

Answer in the negative.
答案是否定的。

‘Mine was,’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘My father was first a page, then a footman, then a butler, then a steward, then an inn-keeper. Lived universally respected, and died lamented. Said with his last breath that he considered service the most honourable part of his career, and so it was. I’ve a brother in service, AND a brotherin-law. My Lady a good temper?’
“我的是，”巴克特先生说。 “我的父亲最初是一名侍从，然后是一名男仆，然后是一名管家，然后是一名管家，然后是一名旅馆老板。生时受人尊敬，死时受人哀叹。他用最后一口气说，他认为服务是他职业生涯中最光荣的部分，事实也确实如此。我有一个服役的兄弟，还有一个姐夫。夫人脾气好吗？

Mercury replies, ‘As good as you can expect.’
水星回答说：“正如你所期望的那样好。”

‘Ah!’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘A little spoilt? A little capricious? Lord! What can you anticipate when they’re so handsome as that? And we like ‘em all the better for it, don’t we?’
“啊！”巴克特先生说。 ‘有点被宠坏了？有点任性？主！当他们如此英俊时，你能期待什么？我们因此更喜欢他们，不是吗？

Mercury, with his hands in the pockets of his bright peach-blossom small-clothes, stretches his symmetrical silk legs with the air of a man of gallantry and can’t deny it. Come the roll of wheels and a violent ringing at the bell. ‘Talk of the angels,’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘Here she is!’
墨丘利双手插在亮丽的桃花小衣口袋里，伸展着匀称的丝腿，一副侠气十足的样子，让人无法否认。车轮的滚动声和剧烈的铃声响起。 “谈论天使，”巴克特先生说。 '她在这！'

The doors are thrown open, and she passes through the hall. Still very pale, she is dressed in slight mourning and wears two beautiful bracelets. Either their beauty or the beauty of her arms is particularly attractive to Mr. Bucket. He looks at them with an eager eye and rattles something in his pocket—halfpence perhaps.
门打开了，她穿过大厅。她仍然很苍白，穿着浅丧服，戴着两个漂亮的手镯。无论是她们的美丽，还是她手臂的美丽，都对巴克特先生特别有吸引力。他用热切的目光看着他们，并把口袋里的东西弄得格格作响——也许是半便士。

Noticing him at his distance, she turns an inquiring look on the other Mercury who has brought her home.
注意到他在远处，她转而询问地看着另一个带她回家的水星。

‘Mr. Bucket, my Lady.’
'先生。桶，我的女士。

Mr. Bucket makes a leg and comes forward, passing his familiar demon over the region of his mouth.
巴克特先生迈出一条腿，向前走去，将他熟悉的恶魔放在嘴边。

‘Are you waiting to see Sir Leicester?’
“你在等见莱斯特爵士吗？”

‘No, my Lady, I’ve seen him!’
“不，夫人，我见过他！”

‘Have you anything to say to me?’
“你有什么话要对我说吗？”

‘Not just at present, my Lady.’
“不仅仅是现在，夫人。”

‘Have you made any new discoveries?’
“你有什么新发现吗？”

‘A few, my Lady.’
“有一些，夫人。”

This is merely in passing. She scarcely makes a stop, and sweeps upstairs alone. Mr. Bucket, moving towards the staircase-foot, watches her as she goes up the steps the old man came down to his grave, past murderous groups of statuary repeated with their shadowy weapons on the wall, past the printed bill, which she looks at going by, out of view.
这只是顺便说一下。她几乎没有停下来，独自一人上楼。巴克特先生朝楼梯脚走去，看着她走上台阶，老人来到了他的坟墓，经过墙上重复出现的一群凶残的雕像，他们拿着阴暗的武器，经过她看着的印刷账单路过时，看不见。

‘She’s a lovely woman, too, she really is,’ says Mr. Bucket, coming back to Mercury. ‘Don’t look quite healthy though.’
“她也是一个可爱的女人，确实如此，”回到水星的巴克特先生说道。 “不过看起来不太健康。”

Is not quite healthy, Mercury informs him. Suffers much from headaches.
水星告诉他，他不太健康。深受头痛之苦。

Really? That’s a pity! Walking, Mr. Bucket would recommend for that. Well, she tries walking, Mercury rejoins. Walks sometimes for two hours when she has them bad. By night, too.
真的吗？太可惜了！巴克特先生建议步行。好吧，她尝试走路，水星重新加入。当她身体不好时，有时会走两个小时。晚上也是。

‘Are you sure you’re quite so much as six foot three?’ asks Mr. Bucket. ‘Begging your pardon for interrupting you a moment?’
“你确定你身高有六英尺三英寸吗？”巴克特先生问道。 “请原谅打扰您一下？”

Not a doubt about it.
毫无疑问。

‘You’re so well put together that I shouldn’t have thought it. But the household troops, though considered fine men, are built so straggling. Walks by night, does she? When it’s moonlight, though?’
‘你们的配合如此之好，我不应该想到这一点。但家中的军队虽然被认为是优秀的人，但身材却如此散漫。她晚上走路吗？不过，什么时候是月光呢？

Oh, yes. When it’s moonlight! Of course. Oh, of course! Conversational and acquiescent on both sides.
哦是的。当月色明媚的时候！当然。哦，当然！双方对话并默许。

‘I suppose you ain’t in the habit of walking yourself?’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘Not much time for it, I should say?’
“我想你没有自己走路的习惯吧？”巴克特先生说。 “我应该说，时间不多吧？”

Besides which, Mercury don’t like it. Prefers carriage exercise.
除此之外，水星不喜欢它。更喜欢马车运动。

‘To be sure,’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘That makes a difference. Now I think of it,’ says Mr. Bucket, warming his hands and looking pleasantly at the blaze, ‘she went out walking the very night of this business.’
“当然，”巴克特先生说。 ‘这很重要。现在我想起来了，”巴克特先生一边说，一边暖暖的手，愉快地看着火焰，“这件事发生的那天晚上，她就出去散步了。”

‘To be sure she did! I let her into the garden over the way.
‘当然她做到了！我让她顺路进入花园。

‘And left her there. Certainly you did. I saw you doing it.’
'然后把她留在那里。当然你做到了。我看到你这么做了。

‘I didn’t see YOU,’ says Mercury.
“我没有看到你，”墨丘利说。

‘I was rather in a hurry,’ returns Mr. Bucket, ‘for I was going to visit a aunt of mine that lives at Chelsea—next door but two to the old original Bun House—ninety year old the old lady is, a single woman, and got a little property. Yes, I chanced to be passing at the time. Let’s see. What time might it be? It wasn’t ten.’
“我很着急，”巴克特先生回答道，“因为我要去拜访住在切尔西的一位阿姨——就在原来的面包屋隔壁，但只有两层楼——那位老太太已经九十岁了，是一位单身女性，有一点财产。是的，我当时正好路过。让我们来看看。可能是什么时间？还不到十点。”

‘Half-past nine.’
'九点半。'

‘You’re right. So it was. And if I don’t deceive myself, my Lady was muffled in a loose black mantle, with a deep fringe to it?’
'你说得对。确实如此。如果我没有欺骗自己的话，我的女士穿着一件宽松的黑色斗篷，上面有很深的流苏？

‘Of course she was.’
“当然是。”

Of course she was. Mr. Bucket must return to a little work he has to get on with upstairs, but he must shake hands with Mercury in acknowledgment of his agreeable conversation, and will he—this is all he asks—will he, when he has a leisure half-hour, think of bestowing it on that Royal Academy sculptor, for the advantage of both parties?
她当然是。巴克特先生必须回去做他必须在楼上进行的一项小工作，但他必须与墨丘利握手，以感谢他愉快的谈话，而且他会——这就是他所要求的——他会吗，当他有一半闲暇的时候时辰，想不想赠予那位皇家学院雕塑家，对双方都有利？

CHAPTER LIV
第四章


Springing a Mine
挖掘地雷

Refreshed by sleep, Mr. Bucket rises betimes in the morning and prepares for a field-day. Smartened up by the aid of a clean shirt and a wet hairbrush, with which instrument, on occasions of ceremony, he lubricates such thin locks as remain to him after his life of severe study, Mr. Bucket lays in a breakfast of two mutton chops as a foundation to work upon, together with tea, eggs, toast, and marmalade on a corresponding scale. Having much enjoyed these strengthening matters and having held subtle conference with his familiar demon, he confidently instructs Mercury ‘just to mention quietly to Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, that whenever he’s ready for me, I’m ready for him.’ A gracious message being returned that Sir Leicester will expedite his dressing and join Mr. Bucket in the library within ten minutes, Mr. Bucket repairs to that apartment and stands before the fire with his finger on his chin, looking at the blazing coals.
巴克特先生在睡眠中精神焕发，早上准时起床，为一天的野外活动做好准备。借助一件干净的衬衫和一把湿发刷，他在仪式上用这种工具润滑了他经过一生的严格学习后留下的稀疏的头发，巴克特先生吃了两块羊排的早餐，让自己变得聪明起来。作为基础，与相应比例的茶、鸡蛋、吐司和果酱一起使用。在非常享受这些增强力量的过程并与他熟悉的恶魔举行了微妙的会议后，他自信地指示墨丘利“悄悄地向莱斯特·戴德洛克男爵爵士提及，无论何时他为我做好了准备，我也为他做好了准备。”这是一个亲切的信息。得知莱斯特爵士将加快穿衣，并在十分钟内与巴克特先生一起去图书馆，巴克特先生回到那间公寓，手指托着下巴站在火前，看着熊熊燃烧的煤炭。

Thoughtful Mr. Bucket is, as a man may be with weighty work to do, but composed, sure, confident. From the expression of his face he might be a famous whist-player for a large stake—say a hundred guineas certain—with the game in his hand, but with a high reputation involved in his playing his hand out to the last card in a masterly way. Not in the least anxious or disturbed is Mr. Bucket when Sir Leicester appears, but he eyes the baronet aside as he comes slowly to his easy-chair with that observant gravity of yesterday in which there might have been yesterday, but for the audacity of the idea, a touch of compassion.
巴克特先生体贴周到，就像一个有繁重工作要做的人一样，但镇定、肯定、自信。从他脸上的表情来看，他可能是一位著名的惠斯特玩家，赌注很大——比如一百基尼——手里拿着牌，但他在牌局中将手牌打到最后一张牌时享有很高的声誉。高超的方式。当莱斯特爵士出现时，巴克特先生并没有表现出丝毫的焦虑或不安，但当他慢慢地走向他的安乐椅时，他把男爵放在一边，带着昨天的观察力，如果不是因为他的大胆，他可能已经是昨天了。这个想法，一丝同情心。

‘I am sorry to have kept you waiting, officer, but I am rather later than my usual hour this morning. I am not well. The agitation and the indignation from which I have recently suffered have been too much for me. I am subject to—gout’—Sir Leicester was going to say indisposition and would have said it to anybody else, but Mr. Bucket palpably knows all about it—‘and recent circumstances have brought it on.’
“很抱歉让您久等了，警官，但我今天早上比平常的时间晚了很多。”我不好。最近我所遭受的焦躁和愤慨让我难以承受。我患有——痛风”——莱斯特爵士本来想说的是身体不适，也会对其他任何人这么说，但巴克特先生显然知道这一切——“最近的情况导致了这种情况。”

As he takes his seat with some difficulty and with an air of pain, Mr. Bucket draws a little nearer, standing with one of his large hands on the library-table.
当巴克特先生费力地、带着痛苦的神情坐到座位上时，他靠近了一点，用一只大手放在图书馆的桌子上。

‘I am not aware, officer,’ Sir Leicester observes; raising his eyes to his face, ‘whether you wish us to be alone, but that is entirely as you please. If you do, well and good. If not, Miss Dedlock would be interested—‘
“我不知道，长官，”莱斯特爵士说道。他抬起眼睛看着自己的脸，“无论你是否希望我们单独相处，但这完全随你的意。”如果你这样做了，那就太好了。如果没有的话，戴德洛克小姐会感兴趣——”

‘Why, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,’ returns Mr. Bucket with his head persuasively on one side and his forefinger pendant at one ear like an earring, ‘we can’t be too private just at present. You will presently see that we can’t be too private. A lady, under the circumstances, and especially in Miss Dedlock’s elevated station of society, can’t but be agreeable to me, but speaking without a view to myself, I will take the liberty of assuring you that I know we can’t be too private.’
“嘿，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，男爵，”巴克特先生回答道，他的头偏向一侧，食指像耳环一样挂在一只耳朵上，“我们现在不能太私密。”您很快就会发现我们不能太私密。一位女士，在这种情况下，特别是在戴德洛克小姐的社会地位较高的情况下，不能不同意我，但在不考虑自己的情况下说话，我会冒昧地向你保证，我知道我们不能太私人了。

‘That is enough.’
'足够了。'

‘So much so, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,’ Mr. Bucket resumes, ‘that I was on the point of asking your permission to turn the key in the door.’
“正是如此，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，男爵，”巴克特先生继续说道，“我正想请求您允许我转动门上的钥匙。”

‘By all means.’ Mr. Bucket skilfully and softly takes that precaution, stooping on his knee for a moment from mere force of habit so to adjust the key in the lock as that no one shall peep in from the outerside.
“无论如何。”巴克特先生熟练而轻柔地采取了这一预防措施，出于习惯的力量，他在膝盖上弯下身子，调整钥匙在锁中的位置，以免有人从外面偷看。

‘Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I mentioned yesterday evening that I wanted but a very little to complete this case. I have now completed it and collected proof against the person who did this crime.’
“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，男爵，我昨天晚上提到，我想要的只是一点点来完成这个案子。我现在已经完成了这项工作，并收集了针对犯下这起罪行的人的证据。”

‘Against the soldier?’
“针对士兵？”

‘No, Sir Leicester Dedlock; not the soldier.’
“不，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士；不是士兵。

Sir Leicester looks astounded and inquires, ‘Is the man in custody?’
莱斯特爵士看上去很惊讶，问道：“这个人被拘留了吗？”

Mr. Bucket tells him, after a pause, ‘It was a woman.’
巴克特先生停顿了一下后告诉他，“那是一个女人。”

Sir Leicester leans back in his chair, and breathlessly ejaculates, ‘Good heaven!’
莱斯特爵士靠在椅子上，气喘吁吁地说：“天哪！”

‘Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,’ Mr. Bucket begins, standing over him with one hand spread out on the library-table and the forefinger of the other in impressive use, ‘it’s my duty to prepare you for a train of circumstances that may, and I go so far as to say that will, give you a shock. But Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, you are a gentleman, and I know what a gentleman is and what a gentleman is capable of. A gentleman can bear a shock when it must come, boldly and steadily. A gentleman can make up his mind to stand up against almost any blow. Why, take yourself, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet. If there’s a blow to be inflicted on you, you naturally think of your family. You ask yourself, how would all them ancestors of yours, away to Julius Caesar—not to go beyond him at present—have borne that blow; you remember scores of them that would have borne it well; and you bear it well on their accounts, and to maintain the family credit. That’s the way you argue, and that’s the way you act, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet.’
“现在，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，男爵，”巴克特先生站在他身边，一只手摊开在图书馆的桌子上，另一只手的食指使用得令人印象深刻，“我有责任让你为一系列情况做好准备”我什至可以说，这可能会让你感到震惊。但是莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，你是一位绅士，我知道什么是绅士，以及绅士的能力。君子能在必须到来的冲击面前，勇敢而坚定地承受。一位绅士可以下定决心抵抗几乎任何打击。嘿，以你自己为例，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵。如果你受到打击，你自然会想到你的家人。你问自己，你所有的祖先，远赴朱利叶斯·凯撒——目前还没有超越他——如何承受这一打击？你记得有很多人能够很好地忍受这一切；你要好好地记在他们的账上，维护家族的信用。这就是你争论的方式，这就是你行事的方式，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵。

Sir Leicester, leaning back in his chair and grasping the elbows, sits looking at him with a stony face.
莱斯特爵士靠在椅子上，抓住他的胳膊肘，面无表情地看着他。

‘Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock,’ proceeds Mr. Bucket, ‘thus preparing you, let me beg of you not to trouble your mind for a moment as to anything having come to MY knowledge. I know so much about so many characters, high and low, that a piece of information more or less don’t signify a straw. I don’t suppose there’s a move on the board that would surprise ME, and as to this or that move having taken place, why my knowing it is no odds at all, any possible move whatever (provided it’s in a wrong direction) being a probable move according to my experience. Therefore, what I say to you, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, is, don’t you go and let yourself be put out of the way because of my knowing anything of your family affairs.’
“现在，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，”巴克特先生继续说道，“这样你就做好了准备，让我恳求你暂时不要为我所知的任何事情而烦恼。”我对这么多人物的了解如此之多，无论高低，一条信息或多或少都不能代表一根稻草。我不认为董事会上的任何举动会让我感到惊讶，至于已经发生的这个或那个举动，为什么我知道这根本没有可能性，任何可能的举动（只要它是在错误的方向上）都是根据我的经验，这是一个可能的举动。因此，我对你说的是，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，准男爵，你不要因为我对你的家庭事务一无所知而让自己陷入困境。

‘I thank you for your preparation,’ returns Sir Leicester after a silence, without moving hand, foot, or feature, ‘which I hope is not necessary; though I give it credit for being well intended. Be so good as to go on. Also’—Sir Leicester seems to shrink in the shadow of his figure—‘also, to take a seat, if you have no objection.’
“我感谢你的准备，”莱斯特爵士在沉默后回答道，手脚和表情都没有移动，“我希望没有必要；尽管我认为这是出于好意。好好地继续下去吧。还有——莱斯特爵士似乎在他的身影的阴影下缩了缩——“还有，如果你不反对的话，也可以坐下来。”

None at all. Mr. Bucket brings a chair and diminishes his shadow. ‘Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, with this short preface I come to the point. Lady Dedlock—‘
一个都没有。巴克特先生拿来一把椅子，缩小了他的影子。 “现在，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，男爵，通过这篇简短的序言，我进入了正题。德洛克夫人——‘

Sir Leicester raises himself in his seat and stares at him fiercely. Mr. Bucket brings the finger into play as an emollient.
莱斯特爵士从座位上站起来，凶狠地盯着他。巴克特先生将手指用作润肤剂。

‘Lady Dedlock, you see she’s universally admired. That’s what her ladyship is; she’s universally admired,’ says Mr. Bucket.
“戴德洛克女士，你看她受到普遍的钦佩。这就是她的夫人； “她受到普遍的钦佩，”巴克特先生说。

‘I would greatly prefer, officer,’ Sir Leicester returns stiffly, ‘my Lady’s name being entirely omitted from this discussion.’
“我非常希望，长官，”莱斯特爵士生硬地回答道，“这次讨论中完全省略了夫人的名字。”

‘So would I, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, but—it’s impossible.’
“我也愿意，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，但是——这是不可能的。”

‘Impossible?’
'不可能的？'

Mr. Bucket shakes his relentless head.
巴克特先生无情地摇着头。

‘Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, it’s altogether impossible. What I have got to say is about her ladyship. She is the pivot it all turns on.’
“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，这完全不可能。我要说的是关于她的女士。她是一切的枢纽。

‘Officer,’ retorts Sir Leicester with a fiery eye and a quivering lip, ‘you know your duty. Do your duty, but be careful not to overstep it. I would not suffer it. I would not endure it. You bring my Lady’s name into this communication upon your responsibility—upon your responsibility. My Lady’s name is not a name for common persons to trifle with!’
“警官，”莱斯特爵士用火热的眼睛和颤抖的嘴唇反驳道，“你知道你的职责。”尽你的职责，但要注意不要超越它。我不会受苦。我不会忍受它。你将我夫人的名字带入这份通讯中是你的责任——你的责任。小姐的名字，可不是一般人可以玩弄的！”

‘Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I say what I must say, and no more.’
“莱斯特·戴洛克爵士，从男爵，我说的是我必须说的，仅此而已。”

‘I hope it may prove so. Very well. Go on. Go on, sir!’ Glancing at the angry eyes which now avoid him and at the angry figure trembling from head to foot, yet striving to be still, Mr. Bucket feels his way with his forefinger and in a low voice proceeds.
“我希望事实证明如此。很好。继续。继续吧，先生！”巴克特先生扫了一眼那双现在避开他的愤怒的眼睛，又看了一眼那个从头到脚颤抖却竭力保持安静的愤怒身影，用食指摸索着，低声继续说道。

‘Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, it becomes my duty to tell you that the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn long entertained mistrusts and suspicions of Lady Dedlock.’
“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，我有责任告诉您，已故的图尔金霍恩先生长期以来一直对戴德洛克夫人抱有不信任和怀疑。”

‘If he had dared to breathe them to me, sir—which he never did—I would have killed him myself!’ exclaims Sir Leicester, striking his hand upon the table. But in the very heat and fury of the act he stops, fixed by the knowing eyes of Mr. Bucket, whose forefinger is slowly going and who, with mingled confidence and patience, shakes his head.
“如果他敢向我吐出这些东西，先生——他从来没有这样做过——我就会亲手杀了他！”莱斯特爵士一边说，一边用手敲着桌子。但在这场激烈而激烈的行动中，他停了下来，被巴克特先生会意的眼睛注视着，巴克特先生的食指慢慢地移动，充满信心和耐心地摇了摇头。

‘Sir Leicester Dedlock, the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn was deep and close, and what he fully had in his mind in the very beginning I can’t quite take upon myself to say. But I know from his lips that he long ago suspected Lady Dedlock of having discovered, through the sight of some handwriting—in this very house, and when you yourself, Sir Leicester Dedlock, were present—the existence, in great poverty, of a certain person who had been her lover before you courted her and who ought to have been her husband.’ Mr. Bucket stops and deliberately repeats, ‘Ought to have been her husband, not a doubt about it. I know from his lips that when that person soon afterwards died, he suspected Lady Dedlock of visiting his wretched lodging and his wretched grave, alone and in secret. I know from my own inquiries and through my eyes and ears that Lady Dedlock did make such visit in the dress of her own maid, for the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn employed me to reckon up her ladyship—if you’ll excuse my making use of the term we commonly employ—and I reckoned her up, so far, completely. I confronted the maid in the chambers in Lincoln’s Inn Fields with a witness who had been Lady Dedlock’s guide, and there couldn’t be the shadow of a doubt that she had worn the young woman’s dress, unknown to her. Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I did endeavour to pave the way a little towards these unpleasant disclosures yesterday by saying that very strange things happened even in high families sometimes. All this, and more, has happened in your own family, and to and through your own Lady. It’s my belief that the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn followed up these inquiries to the hour of his death and that he and Lady Dedlock even had bad blood between them upon the matter that very night. Now, only you put that to Lady Dedlock, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, and ask her ladyship whether, even after he had left here, she didn’t go down to his chambers with the intention of saying something further to him, dressed in a loose black mantle with a deep fringe to it.’
“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，已故的图尔金霍恩先生是一位深沉而亲近的人，他一开始心里所想的一切我都无法承担自己的责任。但我从他的嘴里知道，他很久以前就怀疑戴德洛克夫人通过看到一些笔迹——就在这所房子里，当你本人，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士在场时——在极度贫困中发现了一个人的存在。巴克特先生停了下来，故意重复道：“毫无疑问，他应该是她的丈夫。”我从他的嘴里得知，当那个人不久之后去世时，他怀疑戴德洛克夫人独自秘密地拜访了他的破烂住所和他破烂的坟墓。我从我自己的询问和我的眼睛和耳朵中得知，戴德洛克夫人确实穿着她自己女仆的衣服来拜访，因为已故的图金霍恩先生雇用我来计算她的夫人身份——请原谅我利用我们常用的术语——到目前为止，我已经完全理解了她。我在林肯客栈菲尔兹的房间里与一名女仆对峙，证人是戴德洛克夫人的向导，毫无疑问，她穿过那位年轻女子的衣服，而她对此并不知情。莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，男爵，我昨天确实尽力为这些令人不快的披露铺平道路，我说过，即使在上流家庭中有时也会发生非常奇怪的事情。所有这一切以及更多的事情都发生在你自己的家庭中，并发生在你自己的女士身上。我相信，已故的图尔金霍恩先生一直到他去世的那一刻都在跟进这些询问，而且当晚他和戴德洛克夫人甚至在这件事上产生了不和。 现在，只有你把这个告诉戴德洛克夫人，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，并询问她的夫人，即使在他离开这里之后，她是否也没有去他的房间，打算对他说进一步的话，穿着一件宽松的黑色斗篷，上面有深流苏。’

Sir Leicester sits like a statue, gazing at the cruel finger that is probing the life-blood of his heart.
莱斯特爵士像一尊雕像一样坐着，凝视着那根残酷的手指，正在探查他心脏的命脉。

‘You put that to her ladyship, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, from me, Inspector Bucket of the Detective. And if her ladyship makes any difficulty about admitting of it, you tell her that it’s no use, that Inspector Bucket knows it and knows that she passed the soldier as you called him (though he’s not in the army now) and knows that she knows she passed him on the staircase. Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, why do I relate all this?’
“你把这句话交给了夫人，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，我，侦探巴克特督察。”如果她的夫人在承认这一点上有任何困难，你告诉她这是没有用的，巴克特督察知道这一点，并且知道她按照你的称呼越过了那个士兵（尽管他现在不在军队中）并且知道她知道她在楼梯上从他身边经过。现在，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，我为什么要讲述这一切？

Sir Leicester, who has covered his face with his hands, uttering a single groan, requests him to pause for a moment. By and by he takes his hands away, and so preserves his dignity and outward calmness, though there is no more colour in his face than in his white hair, that Mr. Bucket is a little awed by him. Something frozen and fixed is upon his manner, over and above its usual shell of haughtiness, and Mr. Bucket soon detects an unusual slowness in his speech, with now and then a curious trouble in beginning, which occasions him to utter inarticulate sounds. With such sounds he now breaks silence, soon, however, controlling himself to say that he does not comprehend why a gentleman so faithful and zealous as the late Mr. Tulkinghorn should have communicated to him nothing of this painful, this distressing, this unlooked-for, this overwhelming, this incredible intelligence.
莱斯特爵士用手捂住脸，发出一声呻吟，要求他暂停一下。渐渐地，他把手拿开，保持了自己的尊严和外表的平静，尽管他的脸上没有比他白发更多的颜色，以至于巴克特先生对他有点敬畏。巴克特先生很快就发现他的讲话异常缓慢，开始时时不时地出现一种奇怪的麻烦，这使他发出不清晰的声音。听到这样的声音，他很快就打破了沉默，然而，他控制自己说，他不明白为什么像已故的图尔金霍恩先生这样忠诚和热心的绅士不应该向他传达这种痛苦，这种令人沮丧，这种不经意的事情——因为，这种压倒性的、令人难以置信的智慧。

‘Again, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,’ returns Mr. Bucket, ‘put it to her ladyship to clear that up. Put it to her ladyship, if you think it right, from Inspector Bucket of the Detective. You’ll find, or I’m much mistaken, that the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn had the intention of communicating the whole to you as soon as he considered it ripe, and further, that he had given her ladyship so to understand. Why, he might have been going to reveal it the very morning when I examined the body! You don’t know what I’m going to say and do five minutes from this present time, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet; and supposing I was to be picked off now, you might wonder why I hadn’t done it, don’t you see?’
“再一次，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，”巴克特先生回答道，“请夫人夫人来解决这个问题。”如果您认为正确的话，请把它从侦探的督察巴克特那里交给她的女士。你会发现，或者我大错特错了，已故的图金霍恩先生打算在他认为时机成熟时立即向你传达整个情况，而且，他还赋予了她夫人身份，以便让她理解。为什么，他可能在我检查尸体的那天早上就透露了这一点！莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，你不知道五分钟后我要说什么、做什么；假设我现在就被选中，你可能会奇怪我为什么不这么做，你明白吗？

True. Sir Leicester, avoiding, with some trouble those obtrusive sounds, says, ‘True.’ At this juncture a considerable noise of voices is heard in the hall. Mr. Bucket, after listening, goes to the library-door, softly unlocks and opens it, and listens again. Then he draws in his head and whispers hurriedly but composedly, ‘Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, this unfortunate family affair has taken air, as I expected it might, the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn being cut down so sudden. The chance to hush it is to let in these people now in a wrangle with your footmen. Would you mind sitting quiet—on the family account—while I reckon ‘em up? And would you just throw in a nod when I seem to ask you for it?’
真的。莱斯特爵士费力地避开了那些刺耳的声音，说道：“是的。”就在这时，大厅里传来一阵喧闹的声音。巴克特先生听完后，走到图书馆门前，轻轻地打开门，又听了一遍。然后他集中注意力，匆忙但镇定地低声说道：“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，这起不幸的家庭事件已经传开，正如我所预料的那样，已故的图金霍恩先生突然被砍倒了。”平息事态的机会就是让这些正在与你的仆人发生争执的人进来。为了家庭的缘故，你介意安静地坐着，让我来算账吗？当我似乎向你提出要求时，你会点头吗？

Sir Leicester indistinctly answers, ‘Officer. The best you can, the best you can!’ and Mr. Bucket, with a nod and a sagacious crook of the forefinger, slips down into the hall, where the voices quickly die away. He is not long in returning; a few paces ahead of Mercury and a brother deity also powdered and in peach-blossomed smalls, who bear between them a chair in which is an incapable old man. Another man and two women come behind. Directing the pitching of the chair in an affable and easy manner, Mr. Bucket dismisses the Mercuries and locks the door again. Sir Leicester looks on at this invasion of the sacred precincts with an icy stare.
莱斯特爵士含糊其辞地回答：“长官。”尽力而为，尽力而为！”巴克特先生点了点头，明智地弯曲了食指，溜进了大厅，声音很快就消失了。不久他就回来了。水星前面几步远的地方还有一位神兄弟，他也涂着粉，穿着桃花小衣，中间放着一把椅子，椅子上坐着一位无能的老人。另一个男人和两个女人跟在后面。巴克特先生以一种和蔼可亲、从容的态度指挥着椅子的倾斜，然后让水星们解散并再次锁上门。莱斯特爵士用冰冷的眼神看着这次对圣域的入侵。

‘Now, perhaps you may know me, ladies and gentlemen,’ says Mr. Bucket in a confidential voice. ‘I am Inspector Bucket of the Detective, I am; and this,’ producing the tip of his convenient little staff from his breast-pocket, ‘is my authority. Now, you wanted to see Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet. Well! You do see him, and mind you, it ain’t every one as is admitted to that honour. Your name, old gentleman, is Smallweed; that’s what your name is; I know it well.’
“现在，女士们先生们，也许你们可能认识我了，”巴克特先生用一种私密的声音说道。 “我是侦探的探长巴克特，我是；而这，”从胸前的口袋里掏出他方便的小手杖的尖端，“就是我的权力。现在，你想见莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵。出色地！你确实看到了他，请注意，并不是每个人都被授予这一荣誉。老先生，您的名字是斯莫威德；这就是你的名字；我很清楚。

‘Well, and you never heard any harm of it!’ cries Mr. Smallweed in a shrill loud voice.
“好吧，你从来没有听说过它有什么危害！”斯莫威德先生大声喊道。

‘You don’t happen to know why they killed the pig, do you?’ retorts Mr. Bucket with a steadfast look, but without loss of temper.
“你不知道他们为什么杀猪，对吗？”巴克特先生反驳道，他表情坚定，但没有发脾气。

‘No!’
'不！'

‘Why, they killed him,’ says Mr. Bucket, ‘on account of his having so much cheek. Don’t YOU get into the same position, because it isn’t worthy of you. You ain’t in the habit of conversing with a deaf person, are you?’
“哎呀，他们杀了他，”巴克特先生说，“因为他厚颜无耻。”你不要陷入同样的​​境地，因为它不值得你。你没有与聋人交谈的习惯，是吗？

‘Yes,’ snarls Mr. Smallweed, ‘my wife’s deaf.’
“是的，”斯莫威德先生咆哮道，“我妻子聋了。”

‘That accounts for your pitching your voice so high. But as she ain’t here; just pitch it an octave or two lower, will you, and I’ll not only be obliged to you, but it’ll do you more credit,’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘This other gentleman is in the preaching line, I think?’
“这就是你把声音调得这么高的原因。”但因为她不在这里； “只要把音调低一两个八度就可以了，我不仅会感激你，而且会给你带来更多的荣誉，”巴克特先生说。 “我想，另一位先生也在传教吗？”

‘Name of Chadband,’ Mr. Smallweed puts in, speaking henceforth in a much lower key.
“查德班德的名字，”斯莫尔威德先生插话道，此后说话的语气要低得多。

‘Once had a friend and brother serjeant of the same name,’ says Mr. Bucket, offering his hand, ‘and consequently feel a liking for it. Mrs. Chadband, no doubt?’
“曾经有一个同名的朋友兼兄弟军士，”巴克特先生伸出手说道，“因此对他产生了喜欢之情。”查德班德夫人，毫无疑问？

‘And Mrs. Snagsby,’ Mr. Smallweed introduces.
“还有斯纳格斯比夫人，”斯莫尔韦德先生介绍道。

‘Husband a law-stationer and a friend of my own,’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘Love him like a brother! Now, what’s up?’
“丈夫是一名法律文员，也是我自己的朋友，”巴克特先生说。 ‘像爱兄弟一样爱他！现在，怎么了？

‘Do you mean what business have we come upon?’ Mr. Smallweed asks, a little dashed by the suddenness of this turn.
“你是说我们遇到了什么事情吗？”斯莫威德先生问道，突然的转变让他有点沮丧。

‘Ah! You know what I mean. Let us hear what it’s all about in presence of Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet. Come.’
'啊！你知道我的意思。让我们听听莱斯特·戴德洛克男爵爵士在场的情况是怎样的。来。'

Mr. Smallweed, beckoning Mr. Chadband, takes a moment’s counsel with him in a whisper. Mr. Chadband, expressing a considerable amount of oil from the pores of his forehead and the palms of his hands, says aloud, ‘Yes. You first!’ and retires to his former place.
斯莫威德先生向查德班德先生招手，低声与他商量了一下。查德班德先生从额头和手掌的毛孔中挤出了大量的油脂，大声说道：“是的。”你先！”然后退到原来的地方。

‘I was the client and friend of Mr. Tulkinghorn,’ pipes Grandfather Smallweed then; ‘I did business with him. I was useful to him, and he was useful to me. Krook, dead and gone, was my brother-in-law. He was own brother to a brimstone magpie—leastways Mrs. Smallweed. I come into Krook’s property. I examined all his papers and all his effects. They was all dug out under my eyes. There was a bundle of letters belonging to a dead and gone lodger as was hid away at the back of a shelf in the side of Lady Jane’s bed—his cat’s bed. He hid all manner of things away, everywheres. Mr. Tulkinghorn wanted ‘em and got ‘em, but I looked ‘em over first. I’m a man of business, and I took a squint at ‘em. They was letters from the lodger’s sweetheart, and she signed Honoria. Dear me, that’s not a common name, Honoria, is it? There’s no lady in this house that signs Honoria is there? Oh, no, I don’t think so! Oh, no, I don’t think so! And not in the same hand, perhaps? Oh, no, I don’t think so!’
“我是图尔金霍恩先生的客户和朋友，”祖父斯莫威德当时说道； “我和他做生意。我对他有用，他对我也有用。克鲁克已经死了，他是我的姐夫。他是一只硫喜鹊的兄弟——至少是斯莫威德夫人。我进入了克鲁克的财产。我检查了他所有的文件和所有的物品。都在我眼皮子底下被挖出来了。简夫人的床——他的猫的床——旁边的架子后面藏着一叠属于已故房客的信件。他把各种各样的东西藏起来，到处都是。图金霍恩先生想要它们并且得到了它们，但我先看了它们。我是个生意人，我斜视着他们。这是房客的情人写来的信，她的署名是霍诺丽娅。天哪，这不是一个常见的名字，霍诺丽亚，是吗？这房子里没有一位女士表明霍诺丽娅在吗？哦，不，我不这么认为！哦，不，我不这么认为！也许不是在同一只手上？哦，不，我不这么认为！

Here Mr. Smallweed, seized with a fit of coughing in the midst of his triumph, breaks off to ejaculate, ‘Oh, dear me! Oh, Lord! I’m shaken all to pieces!’
斯莫威德先生在胜利的过程中突然咳嗽起来，突然脱口而出：“哦，天哪！我的天！我浑身颤抖！

‘Now, when you’re ready,’ says Mr. Bucket after awaiting his recovery, ‘to come to anything that concerns Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, here the gentleman sits, you know.’
“现在，当你准备好时，”巴克特先生在等待康复后说道，“来处理任何与莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士有关的事情，男爵，这位先生坐在这里，你知道。”

‘Haven’t I come to it, Mr. Bucket?’ cries Grandfather Smallweed. ‘Isn’t the gentleman concerned yet? Not with Captain Hawdon, and his ever affectionate Honoria, and their child into the bargain? Come, then, I want to know where those letters are. That concerns me, if it don’t concern Sir Leicester Dedlock. I will know where they are. I won’t have ‘em disappear so quietly. I handed ‘em over to my friend and solicitor, Mr. Tulkinghorn, not to anybody else.’
“我还没想到吗，巴克特先生？”斯莫威德爷爷喊道。 ‘先生还不担心吗？不是和霍顿船长、他永远深情的霍诺丽亚以及他们的孩子一起做交易吗？那么，我想知道那些字母在哪里。如果莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士不关心的话，那我也关心。我会知道他们在哪里。我不会让他们就这样悄无声息地消失。我把它们交给了我的朋友兼律师图尔金霍恩先生，而不是其他任何人。

‘Why, he paid you for them, you know, and handsome too,’ says Mr. Bucket.
“哎呀，他付钱给你买的，你知道，而且还很帅，”巴克特先生说。

‘I don’t care for that. I want to know who’s got ‘em. And I tell you what we want—what we all here want, Mr. Bucket. We want more painstaking and search-making into this murder. We know where the interest and the motive was, and you have not done enough. If George the vagabond dragoon had any hand in it, he was only an accomplice, and was set on. You know what I mean as well as any man.’
‘我不在乎这个。我想知道谁拥有它们。我告诉你我们想要什么——我们所有人都想要什么，巴克特先生。我们希望对这起谋杀案进行更深入的调查。我们知道兴趣和动机在哪里，但你们做得还不够。如果流浪龙骑兵乔治参与其中，他也只是同谋，而且是被人陷害的。你和任何人一样明白我的意思。

‘Now I tell you what,’ says Mr. Bucket, instantaneously altering his manner, coming close to him, and communicating an extraordinary fascination to the forefinger, ‘I am damned if I am a-going to have my case spoilt, or interfered with, or anticipated by so much as half a second of time by any human being in creation. YOU want more painstaking and search-making! YOU do? Do you see this hand, and do you think that I don’t know the right time to stretch it out and put it on the arm that fired that shot?’
“现在我告诉你，”巴克特先生说，他立即改变了态度，靠近了他，用食指表达了一种非凡的魅力，“如果我的案子被破坏或受到干扰，我就该死了。”与任何人类在创造中所预期的半秒时间相同或预期。您需要更多的努力和搜索！你做？你看到这只手了吗？你是否认为我不知道何时伸出它并放在开枪的手臂上？

Such is the dread power of the man, and so terribly evident it is that he makes no idle boast, that Mr. Smallweed begins to apologize. Mr. Bucket, dismissing his sudden anger, checks him.
这就是这个人的可怕力量，而且非常明显，他不会无谓地夸耀，斯莫尔韦德先生开始道歉。巴克特先生平复了突然的愤怒，制止了他。

‘The advice I give you is, don’t you trouble your head about the murder. That’s my affair. You keep half an eye on the newspapers, and I shouldn’t wonder if you was to read something about it before long, if you look sharp. I know my business, and that’s all I’ve got to say to you on that subject. Now about those letters. You want to know who’s got ‘em. I don’t mind telling you. I have got ‘em. Is that the packet?’
“我给你的建议是，不要为这起谋杀案而烦恼。那是我的事。你对报纸半睁着眼睛，如果你看起来很敏锐的话，我不应该怀疑你不久后是否会读到一些有关报纸的内容。我知道我的事，这就是我要对你说的关于这个话题的全部内容。现在谈谈那些信。你想知道谁拥有它们。我不介意告诉你。我有它们。那是包裹吗？

Mr. Smallweed looks, with greedy eyes, at the little bundle Mr. Bucket produces from a mysterious part of his coat, and identifles it as the same.
斯莫威德先生用贪婪的眼睛看着巴克特先生从他外套的神秘部分中取出的小捆，并认出它是一样的。

‘What have you got to say next?’ asks Mr. Bucket. ‘Now, don’t open your mouth too wide, because you don’t look handsome when you do it.’
“接下来你有什么要说的？”巴克特先生问道。 “现在，别把嘴张得太大，因为这样你看起来就不帅了。”

‘I want five hundred pound.’
“我想要五百英镑。”

‘No, you don’t; you mean fifty,’ says Mr. Bucket humorously.
“不，你不知道；” “你是说五十。”巴克特先生幽默地说。

It appears, however, that Mr. Smallweed means five hundred.
然而，斯莫威德先生的意思似乎是“五百”。

‘That is, I am deputed by Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, to consider (without admitting or promising anything) this bit of business,’ says Mr. Bucket—Sir Leicester mechanically bows his head—‘and you ask me to consider a proposal of five hundred pounds. Why, it’s an unreasonable proposal! Two fifty would be bad enough, but better than that. Hadn’t you better say two fifty?’
“也就是说，莱斯特·戴德洛克男爵爵士委托我考虑（不承认或承诺任何事情）这件事，”巴克特先生说道——莱斯特爵士机械地低下头——“而你让我考虑一项提议五百英镑。为什么，这是一个不合理的提议！二五十已经够糟糕的了，但也比那好。你最好说两点五十分吗？

Mr. Smallweed is quite clear that he had better not.
斯莫威德先生很清楚他最好不要这么做。

‘Then,’ says Mr. Bucket, ‘let’s hear Mr. Chadband. Lord! Many a time I’ve heard my old fellow-serjeant of that name; and a moderate man he was in all respects, as ever I come across!’
“那么，”巴克特先生说，“让我们听听查德班德先生的意见。”主！我曾多次听到我的老同事叫这个名字。正如我所见过的那样，他在各方面都是一个温和的人！

Thus invited, Mr. Chadband steps forth, and after a little sleek smiling and a little oil-grinding with the palms of his hands, delivers himself as follows, ‘My friends, we are now—Rachael, my wife, and I—in the mansions of the rich and great. Why are we now in the mansions of the rich and great, my friends? Is it because we are invited? Because we are bidden to feast with them, because we are bidden to rejoice with them, because we are bidden to play the lute with them, because we are bidden to dance with them? No. Then why are we here, my friends? Air we in possession of a sinful secret, and do we require corn, and wine, and oil, or what is much the same thing, money, for the keeping thereof? Probably so, my friends.’
受到邀请，查德班德先生走上前来，在微微微笑并用手掌打磨了一下之后，他说道：“我的朋友们，我们现在——瑞秋、我的妻子和我——在富人和伟人的豪宅。为什么我们现在住在富人和伟人的豪宅里，我的朋友们？是因为我们被邀请了吗？因为我们被命令与他们一起赴宴，因为我们被命令与他们一起欢乐，因为我们被命令与他们一起弹奏琵琶，因为我们被命令与他们一起跳舞？不，那我们为什么在这里呢，我的朋友们？我们拥有罪恶的秘密，我们是否需要谷物、酒和油，或者同样的东西，金钱，来保存这些秘密？可能是这样，我的朋友们。

‘You’re a man of business, you are,’ returns Mr. Bucket, very attentive, ‘and consequently you’re going on to mention what the nature of your secret is. You are right. You couldn’t do better.’
“你是个生意人，确实如此，”巴克特先生非常专心地回答道，“因此你会继续提到你的秘密的本质是什么。”你是对的。你不能做得更好了。

‘Let us then, my brother, in a spirit of love,’ says Mr. Chadband with a cunning eye, ‘proceed unto it. Rachael, my wife, advance!’
“那么，我的兄弟，让我们本着爱的精神，”查德班德先生用狡猾的眼睛说道，“继续前进吧。”瑞秋，我的妻子，前进！

Mrs. Chadband, more than ready, so advances as to jostle her husband into the background and confronts Mr. Bucket with a hard, frowning smile.
查德班德夫人已经做好了充分的准备，她走上前去，把她的丈夫挤到了后面，面对巴克特先生，脸上皱着眉头，脸上露出冷酷的微笑。

‘Since you want to know what we know,’ says she, ‘I’ll tell you. I helped to bring up Miss Hawdon, her ladyship’s daughter. I was in the service of her ladyship’s sister, who was very sensitive to the disgrace her ladyship brought upon her, and gave out, even to her ladyship, that the child was dead—she WAS very nearly so—when she was born. But she’s alive, and I know her.’ With these words, and a laugh, and laying a bitter stress on the word ‘ladyship,’ Mrs. Chadband folds her arms and looks implacably at Mr. Bucket.
“既然你想知道我们所知道的，”她说，“我就告诉你。”我帮助抚养了夫人的女儿霍顿小姐。我为夫人的妹妹服务，她对夫人给她带来的耻辱非常敏感，甚至向夫人透露，孩子出生时就已经死了——她几乎就死了。但她还活着，我认识她。”查德班德太太一边说着这句话，一边大笑着，狠狠地强调了“女士”这个词，然后抱起双臂，一脸不情愿地看着巴克特先生。

‘I suppose now,’ returns that officer, ‘YOU will he expecting a twenty-pound note or a present of about that figure?’
“我想，”那位军官回答道，“您会期待一张二十英镑的钞票还是一份价值大约这个数字的礼物吗？”

Mrs. Chadband merely laughs and contemptuously tells him he can ‘offer’ twenty pence.
查德班德夫人只是笑了笑，轻蔑地告诉他他可以“提供”二十便士。

‘My friend the law-stationer’s good lady, over there,’ says Mr. Bucket, luring Mrs. Snagsby forward with the finger. ‘What may YOUR game be, ma’am?’
“我的朋友，法律站的好女士，就在那边。”巴克特先生一边说，一边用手指引诱斯纳斯比太太向前走。 “女士，您想玩什么游戏？”

Mrs. Snagsby is at first prevented, by tears and lamentations, from stating the nature of her game, but by degrees it confusedly comes to light that she is a woman overwhelmed with injuries and wrongs, whom Mr. Snagsby has habitually deceived, abandoned, and sought to keep in darkness, and whose chief comfort, under her afflictions, has been the sympathy of the late Mr. Tulkinghorn, who showed so much commiseration for her on one occasion of his calling in Cook’s Court in the absence of her perjured husband that she has of late habitually carried to him all her woes. Everybody it appears, the present company excepted, has plotted against Mrs. Snagsby’s peace. There is Mr. Guppy, clerk to Kenge and Carboy, who was at first as open as the sun at noon, but who suddenly shut up as close as midnight, under the influence—no doubt—of Mr. Snagsby’s suborning and tampering. There is Mr. Weevle, friend of Mr. Guppy, who lived mysteriously up a court, owing to the like coherent causes. There was Krook, deceased; there was Nimrod, deceased; and there was Jo, deceased; and they were ‘all in it.’ In what, Mrs. Snagsby does not with particularity express, but she knows that Jo was Mr. Snagsby’s son, ‘as well as if a trumpet had spoken it,’ and she followed Mr. Snagsby when he went on his last visit to the boy, and if he was not his son why did he go? The one occupation of her life has been, for some time back, to follow Mr. Snagsby to and fro, and up and down, and to piece suspicious circumstances together—and every circumstance that has happened has been most suspicious; and in this way she has pursued her object of detecting and confounding her false husband, night and day. Thus did it come to pass that she brought the Chadbands and Mr. Tulkinghorn together, and conferred with Mr. Tulkinghorn on the change in Mr. Guppy, and helped to turn up the circumstances in which the present company are interested, casually, by the wayside, being still and ever on the great high road that is to terminate in Mr. Snagsby’s full exposure and a matrimonial separation. All this, Mrs. Snagsby, as an injured woman, and the friend of Mrs. Chadband, and the follower of Mr. Chadband, and the mourner of the late Mr. Tulkinghorn, is here to certify under the seal of confidence, with every possible confusion and involvement possible and impossible, having no pecuniary motive whatever, no scheme or project but the one mentioned, and bringing here, and taking everywhere, her own dense atmosphere of dust, arising from the ceaseless working of her mill of jealousy.
斯纳斯比夫人起初因泪水和哀叹而无法说出她的游戏的本质，但渐渐地，人们困惑地发现她是一个被伤害和错误压垮的女人，斯纳斯比先生习惯性地欺骗、抛弃她，并试图保持在黑暗中，在她的痛苦中，她的主要安慰是已故图尔金霍恩先生的同情，他有一次在她作伪证的丈夫不在场的情况下拜访库克法院时，对她表现出了极大的同情她最近习惯性地把所有的不幸都倾诉给他。除了现在的公司之外，似乎每个人都在密谋破坏斯纳格斯比夫人的和平。还有肯吉和卡博伊公司的职员古皮先生，他一开始像正午的太阳一样开放，但在接近午夜时突然闭嘴，毫无疑问是受到斯纳斯比先生的收买和篡改的影响。韦夫勒先生是古比先生的朋友，由于类似的连贯原因，他神秘地住在法庭上。克鲁克已经死了。那里有已故的宁录；乔已经死了。他们“都在其中。”斯纳斯比夫人没有具体表达，但她知道乔是斯纳斯比先生的儿子，“就好像喇叭说的一样”，她跟着斯纳斯比先生当他最后一次去看望那个男孩时，如果他不是他的儿子，他为什么要去？一段时间以来，她一生的唯一任务就是跟着斯纳斯比先生来来回回，把可疑的情况拼凑起来——而每一次发生的情况都是最可疑的；就这样，她日日夜夜地追求着查出并迷惑她的假丈夫的目标。因此，她把查德班德夫妇和图金霍恩先生召集在一起，并与查德班德先生商量。 图金霍恩谈了古比先生的变化，并帮助发现了目前公司感兴趣的情况，随意地，在路边，静止不动，永远走在斯纳格斯比先生的全面曝光和终止的伟大道路上。婚姻分居。所有这一切，斯纳格斯比夫人，作为一名受伤的妇女，查德班德夫人的朋友，查德班德先生的追随者，以及已故图尔金霍恩先生的哀悼者，在此以信任的方式证明，可能的混乱和卷入可能和不可能，没有任何金钱动机，除了提到的那个之外没有任何计划或计划，并把她自己的浓密的灰尘带到这里，带到各处，这是她嫉妒工厂不断运转所产生的。

While this exordium is in hand—and it takes some time—Mr. Bucket, who has seen through the transparency of Mrs. Snagsby’s vinegar at a glance, confers with his familiar demon and bestows his shrewd attention on the Chadbands and Mr. Smallweed. Sir Leicester Dedlock remains immovable, with the same icy surface upon him, except that he once or twice looks towards Mr. Bucket, as relying on that officer alone of all mankind.
虽然这篇序言已经在手——而且需要一些时间——先生。巴克特一眼就看穿了斯纳斯比夫人的醋的透明性，他与他熟悉的恶魔商量，并将他精明的注意力集中在查德班德一家和斯莫威德先生身上。莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士仍然一动不动，脸上同样冰冷，只是他有一两次看向巴克特先生，因为他信赖全人类中唯一的那位军官。

‘Very good,’ says Mr. Bucket. ‘Now I understand you, you know, and being deputed by Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, to look into this little matter,’ again Sir Leicester mechanically bows in confirmation of the statement, ‘can give it my fair and full attention. Now I won’t allude to conspiring to extort money or anything of that sort, because we are men and women of the world here, and our object is to make things pleasant. But I tell you what I DO wonder at; I am surprised that you should think of making a noise below in the hall. It was so opposed to your interests. That’s what I look at.’
“非常好，”巴克特先生说。 “现在我理解你了，你知道，由莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士委托调查这件小事，”莱斯特爵士再次机械地鞠躬以确认这一说法，“可以给予我公平和充分的关注。”现在我不会提及密谋勒索金钱或任何类似的事情，因为我们是这里的男人和女人，我们的目标是让事情变得愉快。但我告诉你我真正想知道的是什么；我很惊讶你竟然想在下面的大厅里制造噪音。这太违背你的利益了。这就是我所看到的。

‘We wanted to get in,’ pleads Mr. Smallweed.
“我们想进去，”斯莫威德先生恳求道。

‘Why, of course you wanted to get in,’ Mr. Bucket asserts with cheerfulness; ‘but for a old gentleman at your time of life—what I call truly venerable, mind you!—with his wits sharpened, as I have no doubt they are, by the loss of the use of his limbs, which occasions all his animation to mount up into his head, not to consider that if he don’t keep such a business as the present as close as possible it can’t be worth a mag to him, is so curious! You see your temper got the better of you; that’s where you lost ground,’ says Mr. Bucket in an argumentative and friendly way.
“嘿，你当然想进去，”巴克特先生高兴地断言。 “但是对于你这个年纪的一位老绅士来说——请注意，我称之为真正可敬的人！——他的智慧变得敏锐，我毫不怀疑，由于失去了四肢的使用能力，他所有的活力都消失了他脑子里浮现出这样的想法，而不是考虑到如果他不尽可能地保留这样的事情，那么它对他来说就不值一本杂志，真是太好奇了！你发现你的脾气控制住了你； “这就是你失利的地方。”巴克特先生以一种好辩而友好的方式说道。

‘I only said I wouldn’t go without one of the servants came up to Sir Leicester Dedlock,’ returns Mr. Smallweed.
“我只是说过，如果没有一名仆人来到莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士面前，我就不会去，”斯莫威德先生回答道。

‘That’s it! That’s where your temper got the better of you. Now, you keep it under another time and you’ll make money by it. Shall I ring for them to carry you down?’
'就是这样！这就是你的脾气占了上风的地方。现在，你把它保留在另一个时间，你就会从中赚钱。要我按铃叫他们把你抱下来吗？

‘When are we to hear more of this?’ Mrs. Chadband sternly demands.
“我们什么时候才能听到更多这样的消息？”查德班德夫人严厉地问道。

‘Bless your heart for a true woman! Always curious, your delightful sex is!’ replies Mr. Bucket with gallantry. ‘I shall have the pleasure of giving you a call to-morrow or next day—not forgetting Mr. Smallweed and his proposal of two fifty.’
‘祝福你的心成为一个真正的女人！总是充满好奇，你的性爱令人愉悦！”巴克特先生殷勤地回答道。 “我很高兴明天或后天给你打电话——不要忘记斯莫威德先生和他提出的两点五十的提议。”

‘Five hundred!’ exclaims Mr. Smallweed.
“五百！”斯莫威德先生喊道。

‘All right! Nominally five hundred.’ Mr. Bucket has his hand on the bell-rope. ‘SHALL I wish you good day for the present on the part of myself and the gentleman of the house?’ he asks in an insinuating tone.
'好的！名义上是五百。”巴克特先生把手放在铃绳上。 “我可以代表我自己和家里的绅士祝你今天过得愉快吗？”他用含沙射影的语气问道。

Nobody having the hardihood to object to his doing so, he does it, and the party retire as they came up. Mr. Bucket follows them to the door, and returning, says with an air of serious business, ‘Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, it’s for you to consider whether or not to buy this up. I should recommend, on the whole, it’s being bought up myself; and I think it may be bought pretty cheap. You see, that little pickled cowcumber of a Mrs. Snagsby has been used by all sides of the speculation and has done a deal more harm in bringing odds and ends together than if she had meant it. Mr. Tulkinghorn, deceased, he held all these horses in his hand and could have drove ‘em his own way, I haven’t a doubt; but he was fetched off the box head-foremost, and now they have got their legs over the traces, and are all dragging and pulling their own ways. So it is, and such is life. The cat’s away, and the mice they play; the frost breaks up, and the water runs. Now, with regard to the party to be apprehended.’
没有人有勇气反对他这样做，他就这么做了，然后党就退出了。巴克特先生跟着他们到了门口，回来后一本正经地说：“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，你应该考虑是否买下这个。”我应该建议，总的来说，它是我自己买的；我认为它可能会买得很便宜。你看，斯纳斯比夫人的那个小腌黄瓜已经被各方的猜测所利用，并且在将零碎的东西放在一起时造成的伤害比她故意的要大得多。图金霍恩先生，已故，他手里握着所有这些马，可以按照自己的方式驾驭它们，我毫不怀疑；但他是头朝前被从箱子上拉下来的，现在他们已经把腿踩在了铁轨上，都在拖着自己的路走。如此，人生亦如此。猫走了，老鼠又玩；霜消，水流。现在，关于被逮捕的一方。

Sir Leicester seems to wake, though his eyes have been wide open, and he looks intently at Mr. Bucket as Mr. Bucket refers to his watch.
莱斯特爵士似乎醒了，尽管他的眼睛睁得大大的，当巴克特先生指着他的手表时，他专心地看着巴克特先生。

‘The party to be apprehended is now in this house,’ proceeds Mr. Bucket, putting up his watch with a steady hand and with rising spirits, ‘and I’m about to take her into custody in your presence. Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, don’t you say a word nor yet stir. There’ll be no noise and no disturbance at all. I’ll come back in the course of the evening, if agreeable to you, and endeavour to meet your wishes respecting this unfortunate family matter and the nobbiest way of keeping it quiet. Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, don’t you be nervous on account of the apprehension at present coming off. You shall see the whole case clear, from first to last.’
“要逮捕的人现在就在这所房子里，”巴克特先生继续说道，他的手稳稳地竖起手表，精神抖擞，“我要在你在场的情况下将她拘留。”莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，你先别说话，也别动一下。不会有任何噪音，也不会受到任何干扰。如果您同意的话，我会在晚上回来，并尽力满足您的愿望，尊重这个不幸的家庭问题，并以最高尚的方式保持沉默。现在，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，您不要因为目前的忧虑而紧张。你会清楚地看到整个案子，从头到尾。”

Mr. Bucket rings, goes to the door, briefly whispers Mercury, shuts the door, and stands behind it with his arms folded. After a suspense of a minute or two the door slowly opens and a Frenchwoman enters. Mademoiselle Hortense.
巴克特先生按响了铃声，走到门口，低声对墨丘利说了几句，然后关上门，抱臂站在门后。一两分钟的悬念之后，门缓缓打开，一位法国女人走了进来。霍滕斯小姐。

The moment she is in the room Mr. Bucket claps the door to and puts his back against it. The suddenness of the noise occasions her to turn, and then for the first time she sees Sir Leicester Dedlock in his chair.
她一进房间，巴克特先生就拍响了门，背靠在门上。突然的噪音让她转过身来，然后她第一次看到莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士坐在椅子上。

‘I ask you pardon,’ she mutters hurriedly. ‘They tell me there was no one here.’
“请原谅，”她急忙低声说道。 “他们告诉我这里没人。”

Her step towards the door brings her front to front with Mr. Bucket. Suddenly a spasm shoots across her face and she turns deadly pale.
她朝门口迈出一步，与巴克特先生面对面。突然，她的脸一阵痉挛，脸色变得惨白。

‘This is my lodger, Sir Leicester Dedlock,’ says Mr. Bucket, nodding at her. ‘This foreign young woman has been my lodger for some weeks back.’
“这是我的房客，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，”巴克特先生向她点点头说道。 “几周前，这位外国年轻女子一直是我的房客。”

‘What do Sir Leicester care for that, you think, my angel?’ returns mademoiselle in a jocular strain.
“我的天使，你认为莱斯特爵士关心这个有什么用？”小姐用一种幽默的语调回答道。

‘Why, my angel,’ returns Mr. Bucket, ‘we shall see.’
“噢，我的天使，”巴克特先生回答道，“我们拭目以待吧。”

Mademoiselle Hortense eyes him with a scowl upon her tight face, which gradually changes into a smile of scorn, ‘You are very mysterieuse. Are you drunk?’
霍顿斯小姐紧张地看着他，脸上的表情逐渐变得阴沉，逐渐变成了轻蔑的微笑，“你真是个神秘的人。”你醉了吗？'

‘Tolerable sober, my angel,’ returns Mr. Bucket.
“还算清醒，我的天使，”巴克特先生回答道。

‘I come from arriving at this so detestable house with your wife. Your wife have left me since some minutes. They tell me downstairs that your wife is here. I come here, and your wife is not here. What is the intention of this fool’s play, say then?’ mademoiselle demands, with her arms composedly crossed, but with something in her dark cheek beating like a clock.
“我是和你的妻子一起来到这个如此可憎的房子的。你的妻子几分钟后就离开了我。他们在楼下告诉我你的妻子在这里。我来了，你老婆不在。那么，你说这个傻瓜游戏的目的是什么？”小姐问，她双臂泰然地交叉，但她黝黑的脸颊上有什么东西像时钟一样跳动。

Mr. Bucket merely shakes the finger at her.
巴克特先生只是对她摇了摇手指。

‘Ah, my God, you are an unhappy idiot!’ cries mademoiselle with a toss of her head and a laugh. ‘Leave me to pass downstairs, great pig.’ With a stamp of her foot and a menace.
“啊，我的上帝，你真是个不快乐的白痴！”小姐一边摇头一边笑道。 “让我下楼去吧，大猪。”她跺着脚，威胁道。

‘Now, mademoiselle,’ says Mr. Bucket in a cool determined way, ‘you go and sit down upon that sofy.’
“现在，小姐，”巴克特先生冷静而坚定地说，“你去坐在那张沙发上。”

‘I will not sit down upon nothing,’ she replies with a shower of nods.
“我不会在任何事情上坐下来，”她连连点头回答道。

‘Now, mademoiselle,’ repeats Mr. Bucket, making no demonstration except with the finger, ‘you sit down upon that sofy.’
“现在，小姐，”巴克特先生重复道，除了用手指做任何动作，“你坐在那个沙发上。”

‘Why?’
'为什么？'

‘Because I take you into custody on a charge of murder, and you don’t need to be told it. Now, I want to be polite to one of your sex and a foreigner if I can. If I can’t, I must be rough, and there’s rougher ones outside. What I am to be depends on you. So I recommend you, as a friend, afore another half a blessed moment has passed over your head, to go and sit down upon that sofy.’
“因为我以谋杀罪将你拘留，而你不需要被告知这一点。现在，如果可以的话，我想对一位女性和一位外国人有礼貌。如果我做不到，我一定很粗暴，外面还有更粗暴的。我要成为什么样的人取决于你。所以我建议你，作为朋友，在又一个幸福的时刻从你的脑海中过去之前，去坐在那个沙发上。

Mademoiselle complies, saying in a concentrated voice while that something in her cheek beats fast and hard, ‘You are a devil.’
小姐照办了，脸颊上有什么东西快速有力地跳动着，她用专注的声音说道：“你是个魔鬼。”

‘Now, you see,’ Mr. Bucket proceeds approvingly, ‘you’re comfortable and conducting yourself as I should expect a foreign young woman of your sense to do. So I’ll give you a piece of advice, and it’s this, don’t you talk too much. You’re not expected to say anything here, and you can’t keep too quiet a tongue in your head. In short, the less you PARLAY, the better, you know.’ Mr. Bucket is very complacent over this French explanation.
“现在，你看，”巴克特先生赞许地继续说道，“你很自在，举止也很自在，就像我期望像你这样理智的外国年轻女子会做的事。”所以我给你一个建议，就是这个，你不要说太多。你不应该在这里说任何话，而且你也不能在脑子里保持沉默。简而言之，你知道，赌注越少越好。”巴克特先生对法国人的解释非常满意。

Mademoiselle, with that tigerish expansion of the mouth and her black eyes darting fire upon him, sits upright on the sofa in a rigid state, with her hands clenched—and her feet too, one might suppose—muttering, ‘Oh, you Bucket, you are a devil!’
小姐张大了嘴巴，黑色的眼睛向他射出火光，她笔直地坐在沙发上，双手紧握——人们可能会认为，她的脚也是紧握的——嘟囔道：“哦，你这个桶子，你是个魔鬼！

‘Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,’ says Mr. Bucket, and from this time forth the finger never rests, ‘this young woman, my lodger, was her ladyship’s maid at the time I have mentioned to you; and this young woman, besides being extraordinary vehement and passionate against her ladyship after being discharged—‘
“现在，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，男爵，”巴克特先生说，从这时起，他的手指就再也没有停过，“这个年轻的女人，我的房客，在我向您提到的时候，是她夫人的女仆；她是我的房客。”这位年轻的女士，除了在出院后对她的夫人表现出异常强烈的热情之外——”

‘Lie!’ cries mademoiselle. ‘I discharge myself.’
“撒谎！”小姐喊道。 “我释放自己。”

‘Now, why don’t you take my advice?’ returns Mr. Bucket in an impressive, almost in an imploring, tone. ‘I’m surprised at the indiscreetness you commit. You’ll say something that’ll be used against you, you know. You’re sure to come to it. Never you mind what I say till it’s given in evidence. It is not addressed to you.’
“现在，你为什么不接受我的建议呢？”巴克特先生以一种令人印象深刻、几乎是恳求的语气回答道。 “我对你的轻率行为感到惊讶。你知道，你会说一些会被用来对付你的话。你一定会遇到的。在提供证据之前，你别介意我说的话。这不是写给你的。

‘Discharge, too,’ cries mademoiselle furiously, ‘by her ladyship! Eh, my faith, a pretty ladyship! Why, I r-r-r-ruin my character hy remaining with a ladyship so infame!’
“也罢免吧，”小姐愤怒地喊道，“以夫人名义！”呃，我的信仰，一位漂亮的女士！为什么，我因为和一位如此臭名昭著的女士在一起而毁了我的品格！

‘Upon my soul I wonder at you!’ Mr. Bucket remonstrates. ‘I thought the French were a polite nation, I did, really. Yet to hear a female going on like that before Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet!’
“我发自内心地对你感到好奇！”巴克特先生抗议道。 “我认为法国人是一个有礼貌的国家，我确实如此。但在莱斯特·戴德洛克男爵爵士面前却听到一个女人这样说话！

‘He is a poor abused!’ cries mademoiselle. ‘I spit upon his house, upon his name, upon his imbecility,’ all of which she makes the carpet represent. ‘Oh, that he is a great man! Oh, yes, superb! Oh, heaven! Bah!’
“他是一个可怜的受虐者！”小姐喊道。 “我向他的房子、他的名字、他的愚蠢吐口水”，她让地毯代表了这一切。 ‘噢，但愿他是一个伟大的人！哦，是的，太棒了！哦，天堂！呸！'

‘Well, Sir Leicester Dedlock,’ proceeds Mr. Bucket, ‘this intemperate foreigner also angrily took it into her head that she had established a claim upon Mr. Tulkinghorn, deceased, by attending on the occasion I told you of at his chambers, though she was liberally paid for her time and trouble.’
“好吧，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，”巴克特先生继续说道，“这个放纵的外国人也愤怒地认为，她参加了我告诉过你的在图金霍恩先生的房间里的活动，从而对已故的图尔金霍恩先生提出了索赔，尽管她的时间和麻烦得到了丰厚的报酬。

‘Lie!’ cries mademoiselle. ‘I ref-use his money all togezzer.’
“撒谎！”小姐喊道。 “我拒绝全部使用他的钱。”

‘If you WILL PARLAY, you know,’ says Mr. Bucket parenthetically, ‘you must take the consequences. Now, whether she became my lodger, Sir Leicester Dedlock, with any deliberate intention then of doing this deed and blinding me, I give no opinion on; but she lived in my house in that capacity at the time that she was hovering about the chambers of the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn with a view to a wrangle, and likewise persecuting and half frightening the life out of an unfortunate stationer.’
“你知道，如果你愿意赌注，”巴克特先生插话道，“你就必须承担后果。”现在，无论她成为我的房客，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，当时是否有任何故意做这件事并使我失明的意图，我不发表任何意见；但她当时就住在我家，她在已故的图尔金霍恩先生的房间里徘徊，目的是为了一场争吵，同样地迫害和半威胁一个不幸的文具店员的生命。

‘Lie!’ cries mademoiselle. ‘All lie!’
“撒谎！”小姐喊道。 “全都是谎言！”

‘The murder was commttted, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, and you know under what circumstances. Now, I beg of you to follow me close with your attention for a minute or two. I was sent for, and the case was entrusted to me. I examined the place, and the body, and the papers, and everything. From information I received (from a clerk in the same house) I took George into custody as having been seen hanging about there on the night, and at very nigh the time of the murder, also as having been overheard in high words with the deceased on former occasions—even threatening him, as the witness made out. If you ask me, Sir Leicester Dedlock, whether from the first I believed George to be the murderer, I tell you candidly no, but he might be, notwithstanding, and there was enough against him to make it my duty to take him and get him kept under remand. Now, observe!’
“谋杀是发生的，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，男爵，你知道是在什么情况下发生的。现在，我请求你集中注意力跟随我一两分钟。我被叫来了，这个案子就交给我了。我检查了这个地方、尸体、文件以及一切。根据我收到的信息（来自同一所房子的一名职员），我将乔治拘留，因为有人看到乔治在那儿闲逛，而且是在谋杀发生的非常接近的时候，也有人无意中听到他与死者高声交谈。正如目击者所表明的那样，以前有过几次，甚至威胁过他。如果你问我，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，我是否从一开始就相信乔治是凶手，我坦率地告诉你不，但他可能是，尽管如此，而且有足够多的证据对他不利，使我有责任抓住他并得到他的帮助。他仍被还押。现在，观察！

As Mr. Bucket bends forward in some excitement—for him—and inaugurates what he is going to say with one ghostly beat of his forefinger in the air, Mademoiselle Hortense fixes her black eyes upon him with a dark frown and sets her dry lips closely and firmly together.
当巴克特先生兴奋地向前倾身——为了他——并用食指在空中幽灵般地一击开始他要说的话时，霍顿斯小姐用她的黑眼睛紧紧地皱着眉头，紧紧地盯着他。并牢固地结合在一起。

‘I went home, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, at night and found this young woman having supper with my wife, Mrs. Bucket. She had made a mighty show of being fond of Mrs. Bucket from her first offering herself as our lodger, but that night she made more than ever—in fact, overdid it. Likewise she overdid her respect, and all that, for the lamented memory of the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn. By the living Lord it flashed upon me, as I sat opposite to her at the table and saw her with a knife in her hand, that she had done it!’
“莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士，从男爵，我晚上回家时发现这位年轻女子正在和我的妻子巴克特夫人一起吃晚饭。从她第一次主动提出做我们的房客开始，她就表现出了对巴克特太太的喜爱，但那天晚上她赚得比以往任何时候都多——事实上，做得太过分了。同样，她对已故的图尔金霍恩先生的哀悼也过分尊敬了。当我坐在桌边她对面，看到她手里拿着一把刀时，我突然意识到，她已经做到了！

Mademoiselle is hardly audible in straining through her teeth and lips the words, ‘You are a devil.’
小姐从牙齿和嘴唇中挤出这句话，声音几乎听不见：“你是个魔鬼。”

‘Now where,’ pursues Mr. Bucket, ‘had she been on the night of the murder? She had been to the theayter. (She really was there, I have since found, both before the deed and after it.) I knew I had an artful customer to deal with and that proof would be very difficult; and I laid a trap for her—such a trap as I never laid yet, and such a venture as I never made yet. I worked it out in my mind while I was talking to her at supper. When I went upstairs to bed, our house being small and this young woman’s ears sharp, I stuffed the sheet into Mrs. Bucket’s mouth that she shouldn’t say a word of surprise and told her all about it.
