“现在，贾迪斯先生”——巴克特一直全神贯注地观察着他的表情——“我以一位仁慈的绅士的身份对你说话，而且是在这种不常发生的紧迫情况下。”如果说拖延曾经是危险的，那么现在也是危险的。如果事后你无法原谅自己造成的后果，现在就是时候了。自从戴德洛克夫人失踪以来，已经损失了八到十个小时，我告诉你，每个人至少损失了一百英镑。我受命去找她。我是巴克警督。除了所有让她感到沉重的事情之外，正如她所相信的那样，她还有谋杀的嫌疑。如果我单独跟随她，她可能会因为不了解莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士向我传达的信息而陷入绝望。但如果我和一位年轻女士一起跟随她，回答她对一位年轻女士的温柔描述——我不问任何问题，我只说这些——她会认为我很友善。让我跟上她，能够抓住她，把那位年轻女士放在前面，如果她还活着，我会救她并战胜她。让我单独去找她——这是一件困难的事情——我会尽力而为，但我不会回答什么是最好的。时光飞逝;已经一点钟了。当其中一个击中时，又过去了一个小时，现在它值一千英镑，而不是一百英镑。

This is all true, and the pressing nature of the case cannot be questioned. Mr. Jarndyce begs him to remain there while he speaks to Miss Summerson. Mr. Bucket says he will, but acting on his usual principle, does no such thing, following upstairs instead and keeping his man in sight. So he remains, dodging and lurking about in the gloom of the staircase while they confer. In a very little time Mr. Jarndyce comes down and tells him that Miss Summerson will join him directly and place herself under his protection to accompany him where he pleases. Mr. Bucket, satisfied, expresses high approval and awaits her coming at the door.
这都是事实，案件的紧迫性不容质疑。贾迪斯先生恳求他在与萨默森小姐交谈时留在那儿。巴克特先生说他会的，但按照他一贯的原则，他没有这么做，而是跟着上楼，让他的人在他的视线范围内。于是，当他们交谈时，他留下来，躲闪着，潜伏在阴暗的楼梯里。不久之后，贾迪斯先生下来告诉他，萨默森小姐将直接加入他，并将自己置于他的保护之下，随他去任何他想去的地方。巴克特先生很满意，表示高度认可，并在门口等待她的到来。

There he mounts a high tower in his mind and looks out far and wide. Many solitary figures he perceives creeping through the streets; many solitary figures out on heaths, and roads, and lying under haystacks. But the figure that he seeks is not among them. Other solitaries he perceives, in nooks of bridges, looking over; and in shadowed places down by the river’s level; and a dark, dark, shapeless object drifting with the tide, more solitary than all, clings with a drowning hold on his attention.
他在心中登上了一座高塔，眺望远方。他看到许多孤独的人影在街道上爬行。许多孤独的身影出现在荒野、道路上，以及躺在干草堆下。但他所寻找的人物并不在其中。他在桥的角落里看到了其他孤独的人，在张望；以及河水位以下的阴影处；一个黑暗的、黑暗的、无形的物体随着潮水漂流，比一切都更加孤独，紧紧地抓住了他的注意力。

Where is she? Living or dead, where is she? If, as he folds the handkerchief and carefully puts it up, it were able with an enchanted power to bring before him the place where she found it and the night-landscape near the cottage where it covered the little child, would he descry her there? On the waste where the brick-kilns are burning with a pale blue flare, where the strawroofs of the wretched huts in which the bricks are made are being scattered by the wind, where the clay and water are hard frozen and the mill in which the gaunt blind horse goes round all day looks like an instrument of human torture—traversing this deserted, blighted spot there is a lonely figure with the sad world to itself, pelted by the snow and driven by the wind, and cast out, it would seem, from all companionship. It is the figure of a woman, too; but it is miserably dressed, and no such clothes ever came through the hall and out at the great door of the Dedlock mansion.
她在哪？生还是死，她在哪里？如果，当他折叠手帕并小心地把它放起来时，它能以一种神奇的力量将她发现它的地方和它覆盖着小孩的小屋附近的夜景带到他面前，他会在那里看到她吗？ ？在荒原上，砖窑燃烧着淡蓝色的火光，制砖的破旧小屋的草屋顶被风吹散，粘土和水都结冰了，磨坊里的砖块被风吹散了。瘦弱的盲马终日转来转去，就像是人类的酷刑工具——走过这片荒凉、枯萎的地方，有一个孤独的身影，带着悲伤的世界，被雪击打，被风吹走，似乎被抛弃了。 ，来自一切陪伴。这也是一个女人的形象；但它的穿着很破烂，从来没有这样的衣服穿过大厅，从戴德洛克宅邸的大门出来。

CHAPTER LVII
第四十七章


Esther’s Narrative
以斯帖的叙述

I had gone to bed and fallen asleep when my guardian knocked at the door of my room and begged me to get up directly. On my hurrying to speak to him and learn what had happened, he told me, after a word or two of preparation, that there had been a discovery at Sir Leicester Dedlock’s. That my mother had fled, that a person was now at our door who was empowered to convey to her the fullest assurances of affectionate protection and forgiveness if he could possibly find her, and that I was sought for to accompany him in the hope that my entreaties might prevail upon her if his failed. Something to this general purpose I made out, but I was thrown into such a tumult of alarm, and hurry and distress, that in spite of every effort I could make to subdue my agitation, I did not seem, to myself, fully to recover my right mind until hours had passed.
我已经上床睡觉了，监护人敲了敲我的房门，让我直接起床。当我急忙去跟他谈话并了解发生了什么事时，他经过一两句话的准备后告诉我，莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士有一个发现。我的母亲已经逃走了，现在有一个人就在我们家门口，如果他能找到她，他有权向她表达最充分的深情保护和宽恕，而我被找来陪伴他，希望我的母亲能找到她。如果他的恳求失败的话，她可能会被说服。我想出了一些达到这个总体目的的东西，但我陷入了如此惊慌、匆忙和痛苦的混乱之中，尽管我尽了一切努力来抑制我的激动，但我自己似乎并没有完全恢复过来。直到几个小时过去，我的头脑才清醒。

But I dressed and wrapped up expeditiously without waking Charley or any one and went down to Mr. Bucket, who was the person entrusted with the secret. In taking me to him my guardian told me this, and also explained how it was that he had come to think of me. Mr. Bucket, in a low voice, by the light of my guardian’s candle, read to me in the hall a letter that my mother had left upon her table; and I suppose within ten minutes of my having been aroused I was sitting beside him, rolling swiftly through the streets.
但我很快就穿好衣服，没有吵醒查理或任何人，就下楼去见巴克特先生，他就是被托付这个秘密的人。在带我去见他时，我的监护人告诉了我这一点，并解释了他是如何想到我的。巴克特先生在大厅里借着我监护人的烛光低声给我读了一封我母亲留在桌子上的信。我想在我被唤醒后不到十分钟，我就坐在他旁边，快速地滚过街道。

His manner was very keen, and yet considerate when he explained to me that a great deal might depend on my being able to answer, without confusion, a few questions that he wished to ask me. These were, chiefly, whether I had had much communication with my mother (to whom he only referred as Lady Dedlock), when and where I had spoken with her last, and how she had become possessed of my handkerchief. When I had satisfied him on these points, he asked me particularly to consider—taking time to think—whether within my knowledge there was any one, no matter where, in whom she might be at all likely to confide under circumstances of the last necessity. I could think of no one but my guardian. But by and by I mentioned Mr. Boythorn. He came into my mind as connected with his old chivalrous manner of mentioning my mother’s name and with what my guardian had informed me of his engagement to her sister and his unconscious connexion with her unhappy story.
当他向我解释说，很大程度上取决于我能否毫无困惑地回答他想问我的几个问题时，他的态度非常敏锐，但又很体贴。这些主要是，我是否与我的母亲（他只称她为戴德洛克夫人）进行过多次交流，我最后一次与她交谈的时间和地点，以及她是如何拥有我的手帕的。当我对这些观点感到满意后，他要求我特别考虑——花时间思考——在我的知识范围内，无论在哪里，在最后必要的情况下，她是否有可能向谁吐露心声。 。除了我的监护人之外，我想不到任何人。但渐渐地我提到了博伊索恩先生。他进入我的脑海，是因为他提到我母亲的名字时那种古老的侠义态度，以及我的监护人告诉我的他与她姐姐订婚的消息，以及他与她不幸的故事的无意识联系。

My companion had stopped the driver while we held this conversation, that we might the better hear each other. He now told him to go on again and said to me, after considering within himself for a few moments, that he had made up his mind how to proceed. He was quite willing to tell me what his plan was, but I did not feel clear enough to understand it.
当我们谈话时，我的同伴拦住了司机，以便我们能更好地听到彼此的声音。现在他让他再继续，并对我说，在他自己考虑了一会儿之后，他已经决定如何继续。他很愿意告诉我他的计划是什么，但我感觉还不够清楚，无法理解。

We had not driven very far from our lodgings when we stopped in a by-street at a public-looking place lighted up with gas. Mr. Bucket took me in and sat me in an armchair by a bright fire. It was now past one, as I saw by the clock against the wall. Two police officers, looking in their perfectly neat uniform not at all like people who were up all night, were quietly writing at a desk; and the place seemed very quiet altogether, except for some beating and calling out at distant doors underground, to which nobody paid any attention.
距离住所没开多远，我们停在一条小街上，停在一个点燃了煤气灯的公共场所。巴克特先生带我进去，让我坐在明亮的炉火旁的扶手椅上。我从墙上的时钟上看到，现在已经过了一点了。两名警察，穿着整齐的制服，一点也不像熬夜的人，正在办公桌前安静地写着字。这个地方看起来非常安静，除了地下远处的门上传来一些敲打声和呼喊声，没有人理会。

A third man in uniform, whom Mr. Bucket called and to whom he whispered his instructions, went out; and then the two others advised together while one wrote from Mr. Bucket’s subdued dictation. It was a description of my mother that they were busy with, for Mr. Bucket brought it to me when it was done and read it in a whisper. It was very accurate indeed.
巴克特先生叫来了第三个穿制服的人，他低声向他发出了指示，然后他就出去了。然后另外两人一起提出建议，其中一人根据巴克特先生柔和的口授进行写作。他们正在忙着写我母亲的故事，写完后巴克特先生把它拿给我，并低声读了一遍。确实非常准确。

The second officer, who had attended to it closely, then copied it out and called in another man in uniform (there were several in an outer room), who took it up and went away with it. All this was done with the greatest dispatch and without the waste of a moment; yet nobody was at all hurried. As soon as the paper was sent out upon its travels, the two officers resumed their former quiet work of writing with neatness and care. Mr. Bucket thoughtfully came and warmed the soles of his boots, first one and then the other, at the fire.
二副密切关注着它，然后把它抄下来，叫来另一个穿制服的人（外面的房间里有几个人），他拿起它就走了。所有这一切都以最快的速度完成，没有浪费任何时间。但没有人着急。报纸一发出去，两位军官就又恢复了以前安静的写作工作，工整而细心。巴克特先生若有所思地走过来，在火边暖了他的靴底，先一只，然后另一只。

‘Are you well wrapped up, Miss Summerson?’ he asked me as his eyes met mine. ‘It’s a desperate sharp night for a young lady to be out in.’
“萨默森小姐，你穿得好吗？”当他的目光与我相遇时，他问我。 “对于一位年轻女士来说，这是一个令人绝望的寒冷夜晚。”

I told him I cared for no weather and was warmly clothed.
我告诉他我不在乎天气，而且穿得暖和。

‘It may be a long job,’ he observed; ‘but so that it ends well, never mind, miss.’
“这可能是一项漫长的工作，”他评论道。 “不过为了结局好，没关系，小姐。”

‘I pray to heaven it may end well!’ said I.
“我向上帝祈祷，一切都会有好结果！”我说道。

He nodded comfortingly. ‘You see, whatever you do, don’t you go and fret yourself. You keep yourself cool and equal for anything that may happen, and it’ll be the better for you, the better for me, the better for Lady Dedlock, and the better for Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet.’
他安慰地点点头。 ‘你看，无论你做什么，都不要让自己烦恼。你保持冷静，对可能发生的任何事情保持平等，这对你、对我、对戴德洛克夫人、对莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士、从男爵来说都更好。

He was really very kind and gentle, and as he stood before the fire warming his boots and rubbing his face with his forefinger, I felt a confidence in his sagacity which reassured me. It was not yet a quarter to two when I heard horses’ feet and wheels outside. ‘Now, Miss Summerson,’ said he, ‘we are off, if you please!’
他真的非常善良和温柔，当他站在火前加热靴子并用食指揉搓脸时，我对他的睿智充满了信心，这让我放心了。还不到两点一刻，我听到外面有马蹄声和车轮声。 “现在，萨默森小姐，”他说，“如果您愿意的话，我们就出发吧！”

He gave me his arm, and the two officers courteously bowed me out, and we found at the door a phaeton or barouche with a postilion and post horses. Mr. Bucket handed me in and took his own seat on the box. The man in uniform whom he had sent to fetch this equipage then handed him up a dark lantern at his request, and when he had given a few directions to the driver, we rattled away.
他伸出手臂，两名军官礼貌地把我送出去，我们在门口发现了一辆四轮马车，上面有一辆马车和马匹。巴克特先生把我交给了包厢，并在包厢里坐了下来。他派去取这辆装备的穿制服的人应他的要求递给他一盏黑灯笼，当他给司机指了几个方向后，我们就匆匆离开了。

I was far from sure that I was not in a dream. We rattled with great rapidity through such a labyrinth of streets that I soon lost all idea where we were, except that we had crossed and re-crossed the river, and still seemed to be traversing a low-lying, waterside, dense neighbourhood of narrow thoroughfares chequered by docks and basins, high piles of warehouses, swing-bridges, and masts of ships. At length we stopped at the corner of a little slimy turning, which the wind from the river, rushing up it, did not purify; and I saw my companion, by the light of his lantern, in conference with several men who looked like a mixture of police and sailors. Against the mouldering wall by which they stood, there was a bill, on which I could discern the words, ‘Found Drowned”; and this and an inscription about drags possessed me with the awful suspicion shadowed forth in our visit to that place.
我非常不确定自己是不是在梦中。我们以极快的速度穿过迷宫般的街道，很快我就完全不知道我们在哪里了，只知道我们已经过了一遍又一遍地过河，而且似乎仍在穿过一个低洼、水边、狭窄的密集社区。大道上布满了码头和盆地、高高堆起的仓库、平转桥和船桅。最后，我们停在一个小泥泞的拐角处，河风从河上吹来，并没有净化它。我借着灯笼的光看到我的同伴正在和几个看上去像是警察和水手的人开会。他们站立的那堵腐烂的墙上有一张钞票，我可以辨认出上面写着“被发现淹死了”；这件事和关于变装的铭文让我产生了我们访问那个地方时所笼罩的可怕怀疑。

I had no need to remind myself that I was not there by the indulgence of any feeling of mine to increase the difficulties of the search, or to lessen its hopes, or enhance its delays. I remained quiet, but what I suffered in that dreadful spot I never can forget. And still it was like the horror of a dream. A man yet dark and muddy, in long swollen sodden boots and a hat like them, was called out of a boat and whispered with Mr. Bucket, who went away with him down some slippery steps—as if to look at something secret that he had to show. They came back, wiping their hands upon their coats, after turning over something wet; but thank God it was not what I feared!
我不需要提醒自己，我的存在并不是因为放纵自己的任何感情而增加搜寻的难度，或者减少搜寻的希望，或者增加搜寻的延误。我保持沉默，但我永远无法忘记在那个可怕的地方所遭受的痛苦。但这仍然像一场梦一样的恐怖。一个皮肤黝黑、浑身泥泞的男人，穿着肿胀的湿漉漉的长靴，戴着一顶像他们一样的帽子，被从船上叫了出来，和巴克特先生低声交谈，巴克特先生跟着他走下了一些湿滑的台阶——好像要看看他所知道的秘密。必须展示。他们回来时，把湿漉漉的东西翻过来，然后在外套上擦手。但感谢上帝，这并不是我所担心的！

After some further conference, Mr. Bucket (whom everybody seemed to know and defer to) went in with the others at a door and left me in the carriage, while the driver walked up and down by his horses to warm himself. The tide was coming in, as I judged from the sound it made, and I could hear it break at the end of the alley with a little rush towards me. It never did so—and I thought it did so, hundreds of times, in what can have been at the most a quarter of an hour, and probably was less—but the thought shuddered through me that it would cast my mother at the horses’ feet.
经过一番进一步的会议后，巴克特先生（每个人似乎都认识并尊重他）和其他人一起从门口进去，把我留在马车上，而车夫则骑着马走来走去取暖。从潮水发出的声音判断，潮水即将涌来，我能听到潮水在小巷尽头破裂，有点冲向我。它从来没有这样做过——我以为它这样做了，数百次，最多只用了一刻钟，而且可能更短——但一想到它会把我母亲扔到马背上，我就不寒而栗。 ' 脚。

Mr. Bucket came out again, exhorting the others to be vigilant, darkened his lantern, and once more took his seat. ‘Don’t you be alarmed, Miss Summerson, on account of our coming down here,’ he said, turning to me. ‘I only want to have everything in train and to know that it is in train by looking after it myself. Get on, my lad!’
巴克特先生又出来了，叮嘱其他人要提高警惕，然后关上灯笼，再次坐下。 “萨默森小姐，我们来到这里，您不必担心，”他转向我说道。 “我只想把所有东西都准备好，并通过亲自照看来知道它们都在准备中。”加油，我的小伙子！

We appeared to retrace the way we had come. Not that I had taken note of any particular objects in my perturbed state of mind, but judging from the general character of the streets. We called at another office or station for a minute and crossed the river again. During the whole of this time, and during the whole search, my companion, wrapped up on the box, never relaxed in his vigilance a single moment; but when we crossed the bridge he seemed, if possible, to be more on the alert than before. He stood up to look over the parapet, he alighted and went back after a shadowy female figure that flitted past us, and he gazed into the profound black pit of water with a face that made my heart die within me. The river had a fearful look, so overcast and secret, creeping away so fast between the low flat lines of shore—so heavy with indistinct and awful shapes, both of substance and shadow; so death-like and mysterious. I have seen it many times since then, by sunlight and by moonlight, but never free from the impressions of that journey. In my memory the lights upon the bridge are always burning dim, the cutting wind is eddying round the homeless woman whom we pass, the monotonous wheels are whirling on, and the light of the carriagelamps reflected back looks palely in upon me—a face rising out of the dreaded water.
我们似乎又沿着来时的路走了回去。并不是说我在心烦意乱的状态下注意到了任何特定的物体，而是从街道的总体特征来判断。我们在另一个办公室或车站打了电话一分钟，然后再次过河。在这整个过程中，在整个搜寻过程中，我的同伴裹着箱子，一刻也没有放松警惕。但当我们过桥时，如果可能的话，他似乎比以前更加警惕。他站起身来，往栏杆外看去，他下了车，又跟着一个从我们身边掠过的模糊女人影走回来，他凝视着深​​邃的黑色水坑，那张脸让我的心在我心里死去。这条河看上去很可怕，阴沉而神秘，在低矮平坦的海岸线之间快速地蠕动——充满了模糊而可怕的形状，既有实体，也有阴影；如此死亡般且神秘。从那时起，我在阳光下和月光下多次看到它，但从未摆脱那次旅程的印象。在我的记忆中，桥上的灯光总是暗淡的，刺骨的风在我们经过的无家可归的女人周围旋转，单调的车轮在旋转，车灯反射回来的光苍白地看着我——一张脸升起从可怕的水中出来。

Clattering and clattering through the empty streets, we came at length from the pavement on to dark smooth roads and began to leave the houses behind us. After a while I recognized the familiar way to Saint Albans. At Barnet fresh horses were ready for us, and we changed and went on. It was very cold indeed, and the open country was white with snow, though none was falling then.
我们一路叮叮当当地穿过空荡荡的街道，终于从人行道上走上黑暗平坦的道路，开始把房子抛在身后。过了一会儿，我认出了通往圣奥尔本斯的熟悉道路。在巴尼特，新鲜的马匹已经为我们准备好了，我们换好衣服继续前行。天气确实很冷，空旷的田野被雪覆盖着，尽管当时没有下雪。

‘An old acquaintance of yours, this road, Miss Summerson,’ said Mr. Bucket cheerfully.
“萨默森小姐，这条路是你的老熟人，”巴克特先生高兴地说。

‘Yes,’ I returned. ‘Have you gathered any intelligence?’
“是的，”我回答道。 “你收集到情报了吗？”

‘None that can be quite depended on as yet,’ he answered, ‘but it’s early times as yet.’
“目前还不能完全可靠，”他回答道，“但现在还为时过早。”

He had gone into every late or early public-house where there was a light (they were not a few at that time, the road being then much frequented by drovers) and had got down to talk to the turnpikekeepers. I had heard him ordering drink, and chinking money, and making himself agreeable and merry everywhere; but whenever he took his seat upon the box again, his face resumed its watchful steady look, and he always said to the driver in the same business tone, ‘Get on, my lad!’
他走进每一个迟到或早到的有灯的酒馆（当时这样的酒馆不在少数，当时这条路上有很多牲畜贩子经常光顾），然后坐下来和收费公路管理员交谈。我曾听见他点酒、交钱，到处表现得和蔼可亲、快快乐乐。但每当他再次坐在包厢上时，他的脸上就会恢复警惕、稳定的表情，并且总是用同样的商务语气对司机说：“上车，小伙子！”

With all these stoppages, it was between five and six o’clock and we were yet a few miles short of Saint Albans when he came out of one of these houses and handed me in a cup of tea.
经历了所有这些停顿，时间已经是五点到六点了，距离圣奥尔本斯还有几英里，他从其中一栋房子里出来，递给我一杯茶。

‘Drink it, Miss Summerson, it’ll do you good. You’re beginning to get more yourself now, ain’t you?’
“喝了它，萨默森小姐，这对你有好处。”你现在开始变得更加自我了，不是吗？

I thanked him and said I hoped so.
我感谢他并说我希望如此。

‘You was what you may call stunned at first,’ he returned; ‘and Lord, no wonder! Don’t speak loud, my dear. It’s all right. She’s on ahead.’
“一开始你可能会被惊呆，”他回答道。 ‘主啊，这也不足为奇！别大声说话，亲爱的。没关系。她在前面。

I don’t know what joyful exclamation I made or was going to make, but he put up his finger and I stopped myself.
我不知道我发出或将要发出什么快乐的感叹，但他竖起了手指，我停了下来。

‘Passed through here on foot this evening about eight or nine. I heard of her first at the archway toll, over at Highgate, but couldn’t make quite sure. Traced her all along, on and off. Picked her up at one place, and dropped her at another; but she’s before us now, safe. Take hold of this cup and saucer, ostler. Now, if you wasn’t brought up to the butter trade, look out and see if you can catch half a crown in your t’other hand. One, two, three, and there you are! Now, my lad, try a gallop!’
‘今天晚上八九点左右步行经过这里。我第一次听说她是在海格特的拱门收费站，但不太确定。一直断断续续地追踪着她。在一个地方接她，又在另一个地方放下她；但她现在就在我们面前，安全了。拿着这个杯子和碟子，马夫。现在，如果你没有接触过黄油行业，请留意一下，看看你是否能用另一只手抓住半克朗。一、二、三，你就到了！现在，我的小伙子，尝试一下驰骋吧！

We were soon in Saint Albans and alighted a little before day, when I was just beginning to arrange and comprehend the occurrences of the night and really to believe that they were not a dream. Leaving the carriage at the posting-house and ordering fresh horses to be ready, my companion gave me his arm, and we went towards home.
我们很快就到了圣奥尔本斯，天亮之前就下了车，当时我刚刚开始整理和理解当晚发生的事情，并真正相信它们不是梦。把马车留在邮局，吩咐准备好新马，我的同伴挽着我的胳膊，我们就回家了。

‘As this is your regular abode, Miss Summerson, you see,’ he observed, ‘I should like to know whether you’ve been asked for by any stranger answering the description, or whether Mr. Jarndyce has. I don’t much expect it, but it might be.’
“因为这是你的常住处，萨默森小姐，你看，”他说道，“我想知道是否有任何陌生人向你询问过你的描述，或者贾迪斯先生是否有。我对此不太抱有希望，但也有可能。

As we ascended the hill, he looked about him with a sharp eye—the day was now breaking—and reminded me that I had come down it one night, as I had reason for remembering, with my little servant and poor Jo, whom he called Toughey.
当我们登上山坡时，他用锐利的眼睛环顾四周——现在天已经亮了——并提醒我，有一天晚上，我和我的小仆人和可怜的乔一起下了山，我有理由记得。叫托吉。

I wondered how he knew that.
我想知道他是怎么知道的。

‘When you passed a man upon the road, just yonder, you know,’ said Mr. Bucket.
“当你在路上超越一个人时，就在那边，你知道，”巴克特先生说。

Yes, I remembered that too, very well.
是的，我也记得，记得很清楚。

‘That was me,’ said Mr. Bucket.
“那就是我，”巴克特先生说。

Seeing my surprise, he went on, ‘I drove down in a gig that afternoon to look after that boy. You might have heard my wheels when you came out to look after him yourself, for I was aware of you and your little maid going up when I was walking the horse down. Making an inquiry or two about him in the town, I soon heard what company he was in and was coming among the brick-fields to look for him when I observed you bringing him home here.’
看到我的惊讶，他继续说道：“那天下午我开车去照顾那个男孩。当你亲自出来照顾他的时候，你可能已经听到了我的车轮声，因为当我牵着马下山的时候，我就知道你和你的小女仆正在上楼。我在镇上打听了一两次关于他的事，很快就听说了他在哪家公司，正要到砖地里去找他，这时我看到你把他带回家了。

‘Had he committed any crime?’ I asked.
“他犯了什么罪吗？”我问。

‘None was charged against him,’ said Mr. Bucket, coolly lifting off his hat, ‘but I suppose he wasn’t over-particular. No. What I wanted him for was in connexion with keeping this very matter of Lady Dedlock quiet. He had been making his tongue more free than welcome as to a small accidental service he had been paid for by the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn; and it wouldn’t do, at any sort of price, to have him playing those games. So having warned him out of London, I made an afternoon of it to warn him to keep out of it now he WAS away, and go farther from it, and maintain a bright look-out that I didn’t catch him coming back again.’
“没有人对他提出指控，”巴克特先生冷静地摘下帽子说道，“但我想他并没有过于挑剔。不，我要他的目的是为了让戴德洛克夫人的事情保密。对于已故的图尔金霍恩先生付钱给他的一项小小的意外服务，他一直表现得很自由，而不是受欢迎；不管付出什么代价，让他玩这些游戏都是行不通的。因此，在警告他离开伦敦之后，我花了一个下午的时间来警告他，现在他已经离开了，远离伦敦，并保持警惕，以免我发现他再次回来。 .'

‘Poor creature!’ said I.
“可怜的家伙！”我说道。

‘Poor enough,’ assented Mr. Bucket, ‘and trouble enough, and well enough away from London, or anywhere else. I was regularly turned on my back when I found him taken up by your establishment, I do assure you.
“够穷的，”巴克特先生表示同意，“也够麻烦的，而且远离伦敦或其他地方也够好了。”我向你保证，当我发现他被你的机构占用时，我经常感到不高兴。

I asked him why. ‘Why, my dear?’ said Mr. Bucket. ‘Naturally there was no end to his tongue then. He might as well have been born with a yard and a half of it, and a remnant over.’
我问他为什么。 “为什么，亲爱的？”巴克特先生说。 “当然，那时他的舌头就没有尽头。他可能生来就有一码半的长度，还有剩下的部分。

Although I remember this conversation now, my head was in confusion at the time, and my power of attention hardly did more than enable me to understand that he entered into these particulars to divert me. With the same kind intention, manifestly, he often spoke to me of indifferent things, while his face was busy with the one object that we had in view. He still pursued this subject as we turned in at the garden-gate.
虽然我现在还记得这次谈话，但当时我的头脑很混乱，我的注意力只能让我明白他进入这些细节是为了转移我的注意力。显然，出于同样的善意，他经常对我谈论无关紧要的事情，而他的脸却忙于我们所关注的唯一目标。当我们在花园门口拐进去时，他仍在继续这个话题。

‘Ah!’ said Mr. Bucket. ‘Here we are, and a nice retired place it is. Puts a man in mind of the country house in the Woodpeckertapping, that was known by the smoke which so gracefully curled. They’re early with the kitchen fire, and that denotes good servants. But what you’ve always got to be careful of with servants is who comes to see ‘em; you never know what they’re up to if you don’t know that. And another thing, my dear. Whenever you find a young man behind the kitchen-door, you give that young man in charge on suspicion of being secreted in a dwelling-house with an unlawful purpose.’
“啊！”巴克特先生说。 “我们在这里，这是一个不错的退休之地。让人想起啄木鸟啄木场的乡间别墅，那是因为那优美的袅袅烟雾而闻名。他们很早就生了厨房的火，这表明他们是好仆人。但对待仆人，你始终要小心的是谁来看望他们；如果你不知道，你永远不知道他们在做什么。还有一件事，亲爱的。每当你发现厨房门后面有一个年轻人时，你就会因为涉嫌出于非法目的而被秘密藏在住宅中而让该年轻人负责。

We were now in front of the house; he looked attentively and closely at the gravel for footprints before he raised his eyes to the windows.
我们现在已经到了房子前面。他仔细地、仔细地观察砾石上是否有脚印，然后抬起眼睛看向窗户。

‘Do you generally put that elderly young gentleman in the same room when he’s on a visit here, Miss Summerson?’ he inquired, glancing at Mr. Skimpole’s usual chamber.
“萨默森小姐，当这位年长的年轻绅士来访时，你通常会把他安排在同一个房间里吗？”他问道，扫了一眼斯基姆波尔先生常用的房间。

‘You know Mr. Skimpole!’ said I.
“你认识斯金波尔先生！”我说。

‘What do you call him again?’ returned Mr. Bucket, bending down his ear. ‘Skimpole, is it? I’ve often wondered what his name might be. Skimpole. Not John, I should say, nor yet Jacob?’
“你又叫他什么？”巴克特先生弯下耳朵问道。 “斯金波尔，是吗？我经常想知道他叫什么名字。斯金波尔。我应该说，不是约翰，也不是雅各布？

‘Harold,’ I told him.
“哈罗德，”我告诉他。

‘Harold. Yes. He’s a queer bird is Harold,’ said Mr. Bucket, eyeing me with great expression.
‘哈罗德。是的。 “哈罗德，他真是个奇怪的人。”巴克特先生说道，表情很灿烂地看着我。

‘He is a singular character,’ said I.
“他是一个独特的人物，”我说。

‘No idea of money,’ observed Mr. Bucket. ‘He takes it, though!’
“对钱一无所知，”巴克特先生说。 “不过他接受了！”

I involuntarily returned for answer that I perceived Mr. Bucket knew him.
我不由自主地回过头来寻求答案，因为我发现巴克特先生认识他。

‘Why, now I’ll tell you, Miss Summerson,’ he replied. ‘Your mind will be all the better for not running on one point too continually, and I’ll tell you for a change. It was him as pointed out to me where Toughey was. I made up my mind that night to come to the door and ask for Toughey, if that was all; but willing to try a move or so first, if any such was on the board, I just pitched up a morsel of gravel at that window where I saw a shadow. As soon as Harold opens it and I have had a look at him, thinks I, you’re the man for me. So I smoothed him down a bit about not wanting to disturb the family after they was gone to bed and about its being a thing to be regretted that charitable young ladies should harbour vagrants; and then, when I pretty well understood his ways, I said I should consider a fypunnote well bestowed if I could relieve the premises of Toughey without causing any noise or trouble. Then says he, lifting up his eyebrows in the gayest way, ‘It’s no use menfioning a fypunnote to me, my friend, because I’m a mere child in such matters and have no idea of money.’ Of course I understood what his taking it so easy meant; and being now quite sure he was the man for me, I wrapped the note round a little stone and threw it up to him. Well! He laughs and beams, and looks as innocent as you like, and says, ‘But I don’t know the value of these things. What am I to DO with this?’ ‘Spend it, sir,’ says I. ‘But I shall be taken in,’ he says, ‘they won’t give me the right change, I shall lose it, it’s no use to me.’ Lord, you never saw such a face as he carried it with! Of course he told me where to find Toughey, and I found him.’
“为什么，现在我告诉你，萨默森小姐，”他回答道。 ‘你的头脑不要太持续地在某一点上运转会更好，我会告诉你改变一下。正是他向我指出了图伊所在的位置。那天晚上我决定去门口找托伊，如果仅此而已的话。但如果棋盘上有这样的棋子的话，我愿意先尝试一下，所以我只是在我看到影子的那个窗户上扔了一点砾石。哈罗德一打开门，我看了他一眼，我想，你就是我的理想人选。于是我安抚了他，说不想在家人睡觉后打扰他们，而且慈善的小姐窝藏流浪汉是一件令人遗憾的事情；然后，当我非常了解他的方式时，我说如果我能在不引起任何噪音或麻烦的情况下缓解托伊的房屋，我应该考虑给予fypunnote很好的奖励。然后他用一种最快乐的方式扬起了眉毛，说道：“我的朋友，对我提一句fypunnote是没有用的，因为在这种事情上我只是个孩子，对金钱一无所知。”当然，我明白他的意思。采取如此简单的意思是；现在我确信他就是我的理想人选，于是我把纸条包在一块小石头上，扔给了他。出色地！他笑起来，笑容满面，看起来很天真，然后说：“但我不知道这些东西的价值。”我该怎么处理这个？”“花掉它，先生，”我说。“但我会被骗，”他说，“他们不会给我正确的零钱，我会失去它，这是没有用的主啊，你从来没有见过他这样的脸！当然，他告诉我在哪里可以找到托伊，然后我就找到了他。”

I regarded this as very treacherous on the part of Mr. Skimpole towards my guardian and as passing the usual bounds of his childish innocence.
我认为斯金波尔先生对我的监护人的行为非常奸诈，超出了他孩子气的纯真通常的界限。

‘Bounds, my dear?’ returned Mr. Bucket. ‘Bounds? Now, Miss Summerson, I’ll give you a piece of advice that your husband will find useful when you are happily married and have got a family about you. Whenever a person says to you that they are as innocent as can be in all concerning money, look well after your own money, for they are dead certain to collar it if they can. Whenever a person proclaims to you ‘In worldly matters I’m a child,’ you consider that that person is only a-crying off from being held accountable and that you have got that person’s number, and it’s Number One. Now, I am not a poetical man myself, except in a vocal way when it goes round a company, but I’m a practical one, and that’s my experience. So’s this rule. Fast and loose in one thing, fast and loose in everything. I never knew it fail. No more will you. Nor no one. With which caution to the unwary, my dear, I take the liberty of pulling this here bell, and so go back to our business.’
“界限，亲爱的？”巴克特先生回答道。 ‘界限？现在，萨默森小姐，我给你一条建议，当你婚姻幸福并组建家庭时，你的丈夫会发现这些建议很有用。每当一个人对你说他们在金钱方面是天真无邪的时候，请好好保管好你自己的钱，因为如果可以的话，他们肯定会抓住它。每当有人向你宣称“在世俗问题上我还是个孩子”时，你就会认为那个人只是在哭泣，逃避追究责任，而你已经得到了那个人的号码，而且是第一号。现在，我自己并不是一个富有诗意的人，除非在公司里以一种声音的方式传播，但我是一个务实的人，这就是我的经验。这条规则也是如此。在一件事上快速而宽松，在所有事情上都快速而宽松。我从来不知道它会失败。你不会再这样了。也没有人。亲爱的，出于对粗心者的谨慎，我冒昧地拉响了这里的铃，然后回到我们的正事上来。

I believe it had not been for a moment out of his mind, any more than it had been out of my mind, or out of his face. The whole household were amazed to see me, without any notice, at that time in the morning, and so accompanied; and their surprise was not diminished by my inquiries. No one, however, had been there. It could not be doubted that this was the truth.
我相信他一刻也没有想到这一点，就像我的脑海中或他的脸上从来没有出现过一样。早上的那个时候，全家人都惊讶地看到我，没有任何通知，并陪着我。我的询问并没有减少他们的惊讶。然而，没有人在那里。毫无疑问，这是事实。

‘Then, Miss Summerson,’ said my companion, ‘we can’t be too soon at the cottage where those brickmakers are to be found. Most inquiries there I leave to you, if you’ll be so good as to make ‘em. The naturalest way is the best way, and the naturalest way is your own way.’
“那么，萨默森小姐，”我的同伴说，“我们不能太早到达那些制砖匠所在的小屋。如果你愿意的话，我会把大部分询问留给你。最自然的方式就是最好的方式，最自然的方式就是你自己的方式。

We set off again immediately. On arriving at the cottage, we found it shut up and apparently deserted, but one of the neighbours who knew me and who came out when I was trying to make some one hear informed me that the two women and their husbands now lived together in another house, made of loose rough bricks, which stood on the margin of the piece of ground where the kilns were and where the long rows of bricks were drying. We lost no time in repairing to this place, which was within a few hundred yards; and as the door stood ajar, I pushed it open.
我们立即再次出发。到达小屋后，我们发现它关闭了，显然已经荒废了，但是一位认识我的邻居在我试图让别人听到的时候出来告诉我，这两个女人和他们的丈夫现在一起住在另一间房子里。房子是用松散的粗糙砖砌成的，坐落在窑炉所在的那块土地的边缘，长排的砖块正在那里晾晒。我们不失时机地赶到了这个地方，距离这里只有几百码。当门半开时，我把门推开了。

There were only three of them sitting at breakfast, the child lying asleep on a bed in the corner. It was Jenny, the mother of the dead child, who was absent. The other woman rose on seeing me; and the men, though they were, as usual, sulky and silent, each gave me a morose nod of recognition. A look passed between them when Mr. Bucket followed me in, and I was surprised to see that the woman evidently knew him.
早餐时只有三个人坐在一起，孩子躺在角落的床上睡着了。失踪的是死去孩子的母亲珍妮。另一个女人看到我就站了起来。这些人虽然像往常一样闷闷不乐、沉默不语，但每个人都阴郁地点点头表示认可。当巴克特先生跟着我进去时，他们互相看了一眼，我惊讶地发现那个女人显然认识他。

I had asked leave to enter of course. Liz (the only name by which I knew her) rose to give me her own chair, but I sat down on a stool near the fire, and Mr. Bucket took a corner of the bedstead. Now that I had to speak and was among people with whom I was not familiar, I became conscious of being hurried and giddy. It was very difficult to begin, and I could not help bursting into tears.
当然，我已经请假进入。莉兹（我认识她的唯一名字）起身把她自己的椅子让给我，但我坐在火边的凳子上，巴克特先生占据了床架的一角。现在我必须说话，而且是在一个我不熟悉的人中间，我开始意识到自己的匆忙和头晕。开始的时候非常困难，我忍不住流下了眼泪。

‘Liz,’ said I, ‘I have come a long way in the night and through the snow to inquire after a lady—‘
“莉兹，”我说道，“我冒着大雪，在夜色中走了很长一段路，来探望一位女士——”

‘Who has been here, you know,’ Mr. Bucket struck in, addressing the whole group with a composed propitiatory face; ‘that’s the lady the young lady means. The lady that was here last night, you know.’
“你们知道，谁来过这里。”巴克特先生插话道，脸上带着平静的安抚表情，对大家说道。 ‘这就是那位小姐所说的那位女士。你知道，昨晚在这里的那位女士。

‘And who told YOU as there was anybody here?’ inquired Jenny’s husband, who had made a surly stop in his eating to listen and now measured him with his eye.
“谁告诉你的，因为有人在这里？”珍妮的丈夫问道，他在吃饭时乖乖地停下来听，现在用眼睛打量着他。

‘A person of the name of Michael Jackson, with a blue welveteen waistcoat with a double row of mother of pearl buttons,’ Mr. Bucket immediately answered.
“一个名叫迈克尔·杰克逊的人，穿着一件蓝色的十二绒背心，上面有两排珍珠母纽扣。”巴克特先生立即回答道。

‘He had as good mind his own business, whoever he is,’ growled the man.
“不管他是谁，他都对自己的事很在意，”那人咆哮道。

‘He’s out of employment, I believe,’ said Mr. Bucket apologetically for Michael Jackson, ‘and so gets talking.’
“我相信他失业了，”巴克特先生为迈克尔·杰克逊道歉，“所以才开始谈论。”

The woman had not resumed her chair, but stood faltering with her hand upon its broken back, looking at me. I thought she would have spoken to me privately if she had dared. She was still in this attitude of uncertainty when her husband, who was eating with a lump of bread and fat in one hand and his clasp-knife in the other, struck the handle of his knife violently on the table and told her with an oath to mind HER own business at any rate and sit down.
那个女人没有坐回椅子上，而是摇摇晃晃地站着，把手放在断掉的椅背上，看着我。我想如果她敢的话，她会私下跟我说话。当她还处于这种不确定的态度时，她的丈夫一手拿着一块面包和脂肪，另一只手拿着折叠刀，用刀柄猛烈地敲击着桌子，并发誓地告诉她。无论如何，先别管她自己的事，坐下吧。

‘I should like to have seen Jenny very much,’ said I, ‘for I am sure she would have told me all she could about this lady, whom I am very anxious indeed—you cannot think how anxious—to overtake. Will Jenny be here soon? Where is she?’
“我非常想见到珍妮，”我说，“因为我确信她会告诉我关于这位女士的一切，我确实非常渴望——你无法想象有多渴望——超越她。珍妮很快就会来吗？她在哪？'

The woman had a great desire to answer, but the man, with another oath, openly kicked at her foot with his heavy boot. He left it to Jenny’s husband to say what he chose, and after a dogged silence the latter turned his shaggy head towards me.
女人很想回答，男人却又发誓，用沉重的靴子公然踢她的脚。他让珍妮的丈夫说出他的选择，在一阵顽强的沉默之后，后者把蓬乱的头转向我。

‘I’m not partial to gentlefolks coming into my place, as you’ve heerd me say afore now, I think, miss. I let their places be, and it’s curious they can’t let my place be. There’d be a pretty shine made if I was to go a-wisitin THEM, I think. Howsoever, I don’t so much complain of you as of some others, and I’m agreeable to make you a civil answer, though I give notice that I’m not a-going to be drawed like a badger. Will Jenny be here soon? No she won’t. Where is she? She’s gone up to Lunnun.’
“我不偏爱绅士来到我的地方，正如你之前听到我说的那样，我想，小姐。我让他们占地方，奇怪的是他们却不能让我占地方。我想，如果我去拜访他们，那一定会很光彩夺目。然而，我并没有像其他人那样抱怨你，我很乐意给你一个文明的答复，尽管我注意到我不会像獾一样被吸引。珍妮很快就会来吗？不，她不会。她在哪？她去了伦努。

‘Did she go last night?’ I asked.
“她昨晚去了吗？”我问。

‘Did she go last night? Ah! She went last night,’ he answered with a sulky jerk of his head.
‘她昨晚去了吗？啊!她昨晚就去了。”他闷闷不乐地摇摇头回答道。

‘But was she here when the lady came? And what did the lady say to her? And where is the lady gone? I beg and pray you to be so kind as to tell me,’ said I, ‘for I am in great distress to know.’
“但是那位女士来的时候她在吗？”那那位女士对她说了什么？而这位女士又去哪儿了呢？我恳求并祈祷你能好心告诉我，”我说，“因为知道这一点我感到非常痛苦。”

‘If my master would let me speak, and not say a word of harm—‘ the woman timidly began.
“如果我的主人允许我说话，并且不说一句伤害的话——”女人胆怯地开始说道。

‘Your master,’ said her husband, muttering an imprecation with slow emphasis, ‘will break your neck if you meddle with wot don’t concern you.’
“你的主人，”她的丈夫低声咒骂着，语气缓慢地加重了语气，“如果你多管闲事，他会扭断你的脖子的。”

After another silence, the husband of the absent woman, turning to me again, answered me with his usual grumbling unwillingness.
又一阵沉默后，缺席的女人的丈夫再次转向我，用他一贯的抱怨不情愿的方式回答我。

‘Wos Jenny here when the lady come? Yes, she wos here when the lady come. Wot did the lady say to her? Well, I’ll tell you wot the lady said to her. She said, ‘You remember me as come one time to talk to you about the young lady as had been a-wisiting of you? You remember me as give you somethink handsome for a handkercher wot she had left?’ Ah, she remembered. So we all did. Well, then, wos that young lady up at the house now? No, she warn’t up at the house now. Well, then, lookee here. The lady was upon a journey all alone, strange as we might think it, and could she rest herself where you’re a setten for a hour or so. Yes she could, and so she did. Then she went—it might be at twenty minutes past eleven, and it might be at twenty minutes past twelve; we ain’t got no watches here to know the time by, nor yet clocks. Where did she go? I don’t know where she go’d. She went one way, and Jenny went another; one went right to Lunnun, and t’other went right from it. That’s all about it. Ask this man. He heerd it all, and see it all. He knows.’
“那位女士来的时候，珍妮在吗？”是的，那位女士来时她就在这里。那位女士对她说了什么？好吧，我来告诉你那位女士对她说的话。她说：“你还记得我有一次来和你谈论那位一直在想念你的年轻女士吗？”你还记得我给了你一些漂亮的东西作为她留下的手帕吗？’啊，她想起来了。所以我们都这么做了。那么，那位年轻女士现在在家里吗？不，她现在不在家里。那么，看这里。这位女士独自踏上旅程，虽然我们可能会觉得很奇怪，但她能否在你所在的地方休息一个小时左右。是的，她可以，而且她也这么做了。然后她就走了——可能是十一点二十分，也可能是十二点二十分；我们这里没有可以知道时间的手表，也没有时钟。她去哪儿了？我不知道她去了哪里。她走一条路，珍妮走另一条路。一个直接前往伦农，另一个则直接从那里出发。仅此而已。问这个人。他听到了这一切，也看到了这一切。他知道。'

The other man repeated, ‘That’s all about it.’
另一个人重复道：“仅此而已。”

‘Was the lady crying?’ I inquired.
“那位女士在哭吗？”我问道。

‘Devil a bit,’ returned the first man. ‘Her shoes was the worse, and her clothes was the worse, but she warn’t—not as I see.’
“有点魔鬼，”第一个人回答道。 “她的鞋子更糟糕，她的衣服更糟糕，但她没有——不像我所看到的那样。”

The woman sat with her arms crossed and her eyes upon the ground. Her husband had turned his seat a little so as to face her and kept his hammer-like hand upon the table as if it were in readiness to execute his threat if she disobeyed him.
女人交叉双臂坐着，眼睛看着地面。她的丈夫稍微转动了座位，面向她，并将锤子般的手放在桌子上，仿佛准备好在她不服从他的情况下执行他的威胁。

‘I hope you will not object to my asking your wife,’ said I, ‘how the lady looked.’
“我希望你不会反对我问你的妻子，”我说，“这位女士看起来怎么样。”

‘Come, then!’ he gruffly cried to her. ‘You hear what she says. Cut it short and tell her.’
“那么，来吧！”他粗声粗气地对她喊道。 ‘你听她说的话。话不多说，告诉她。”

‘Bad,’ replied the woman. ‘Pale and exhausted. Very bad.’
“不好。”女人回答道。 ‘脸色苍白，疲惫不堪。很坏。'

‘Did she speak much?’
“她话多吗？”

‘Not much, but her voice was hoarse.’
“不多，但她的声音很沙哑。”

She answered, looking all the while at her husband for leave.
她一边回答，一边一直看着丈夫请假。

‘Was she faint?’ said I. ‘Did she eat or drink here?’
“她晕倒了吗？”我问，“她在这里吃过喝过吗？”

‘Go on!’ said the husband in answer to her look. ‘Tell her and cut it short.’
“继续吧！”丈夫回应她的目光说道。 “告诉她，别再说了。”

‘She had a little water, miss, and Jenny fetched her some bread and tea. But she hardly touched it.’
“她有一点水，小姐，珍妮给她拿了一些面包和茶。但她几乎没碰过它。

‘And when she went from here,’ I was proceeding, when Jenny’s husband impatiently took me up.
“当她离开这里时，”我正说着，珍妮的丈夫不耐烦地把我抱起来。

‘When she went from here, she went right away nor’ard by the high road. Ask on the road if you doubt me, and see if it warn’t so. Now, there’s the end. That’s all about it.’
‘当她离开这里时，她立刻就沿着大路往北走。如果你怀疑我，就在路上问问，看看是否如此。现在，结束了。仅此而已。

I glanced at my companion, and finding that he had already risen and was ready to depart, thanked them for what they had told me, and took my leave. The woman looked full at Mr. Bucket as he went out, and he looked full at her.
我看了一眼我的同伴，发现他已经起身准备离开，我向他们的吩咐道谢后就告辞了。当巴克特先生走出去时，那个女人注视着他，而他也注视着她。

‘Now, Miss Summerson,’ he said to me as we walked quickly away. ‘They’ve got her ladyship’s watch among ‘em. That’s a positive fact.’
“现在，萨默森小姐，”当我们快步走开时，他对我说。 “他们中间有她夫人的手表。”这是一个积极的事实。

‘You saw it?’ I exclaimed.
“你看到了吗？”我惊呼道。

‘Just as good as saw it,’ he returned. ‘Else why should he talk about his ‘twenty minutes past’ and about his having no watch to tell the time by? Twenty minutes! He don’t usually cut his time so fine as that. If he comes to half-hours, it’s as much as HE does. Now, you see, either her ladyship gave him that watch or he took it. I think she gave it him. Now, what should she give it him for? What should she give it him for?’
“和看到的一样好，”他回答道。 “否则他为什么要谈论他的‘过去二十分钟’以及他没有手表来判断时间呢？” 20分钟！他通常不会把时间安排得这么好。如果他能上半小时，那就和他一样多了。现在，你看，要么是她的夫人给了他那块手表，要么是他拿走了它。我想她给了他。现在，她该给他做什么？她应该把它给他做什么？

He repeated this question to himself several times as we hurried on, appearing to balance between a variety of answers that arose in his mind.
当我们匆忙前行时，他对自己重复了这个问题好几次，似乎在他脑海中出现的各种答案之间取得了平衡。

‘If time could be spared,’ said Mr. Bucket, ‘which is the only thing that can’t be spared in this case, I might get it out of that woman; but it’s too doubtful a chance to trust to under present circumstances. They are up to keeping a close eye upon her, and any fool knows that a poor creetur like her, beaten and kicked and scarred and bruised from head to foot, will stand by the husband that ill uses her through thick and thin. There’s something kept back. It’s a pity but what we had seen the other woman.’
“如果可以节省时间，”巴克特先生说，“在这种情况下，这是唯一不能节省的东西，我可能会从那个女人那里得到它;但在目前的情况下，这是一个值得信赖的机会。他们会密切注视着她，任何傻瓜都知道，像她这样一个可怜的怪物，从头到脚被殴打、踢伤、伤痕累累，都会站在那个虐待她的丈夫身边。有一些东西被保留了。很遗憾，我们看到了另一个女人。”

I regretted it exceedingly, for she was very grateful, and I felt sure would have resisted no entreaty of mine.
我非常后悔，因为她非常感激，我确信她不会拒绝我的恳求。

‘It’s possible, Miss Summerson,’ said Mr. Bucket, pondering on it, ‘that her ladyship sent her up to London with some word for you, and it’s possible that her husband got the watch to let her go. It don’t come out altogether so plain as to please me, but it’s on the cards. Now, I don’t take kindly to laying out the money of Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, on these roughs, and I don’t see my way to the usefulness of it at present. No! So far our road, Miss Summerson, is for’ard—straight ahead—and keeping everything quiet!’
“有可能，萨默森小姐，”巴克特先生沉思着说道，“可能是夫人派她去伦敦转告你的，也有可能是她丈夫拿到了表让她走的。”虽然结果并没有让我满意，但这是有可能的。现在，我不乐意把莱斯特·戴德洛克男爵爵士的钱花在这些毛坯上，而且目前我看不出它有什么用处。不！萨默森小姐，到目前为止，我们的路是向前——一直向前——并保持一切安静！

We called at home once more that I might send a hasty note to my guardian, and then we hurried back to where we had left the carriage. The horses were brought out as soon as we were seen coming, and we were on the road again in a few minutes.
我们再次打电话到家里，让我赶紧给我的监护人写个便条，然后我们就匆匆回到了下马车的地方。一看到我们来了，马匹就被牵了出来，几分钟后我们又上路了。

It had set in snowing at daybreak, and it now snowed hard. The air was so thick with the darkness of the day and the density of the fall that we could see but a very little way in any direction. Although it was extremely cold, the snow was but partially frozen, and it churned—with a sound as if it were a beach of small shells —under the hoofs of the horses into mire and water. They sometimes slipped and floundered for a mile together, and we were obliged to come to a standstill to rest them. One horse fell three times in this first stage, and trembled so and was so shaken that the driver had to dismount from his saddle and lead him at last.
天一亮就下雪了，现在雪下得很大。由于白天的黑暗和瀑布的密度，空气变得如此浓重，以至于我们在任何方向都只能看到很小的距离。虽然天气极其寒冷，但雪只部分结冰，在马蹄下翻滚，发出如同沙滩上的小贝壳般的声音，化为泥沼和水中。有时他们会滑倒，一起挣扎一英里，我们不得不停下来让他们休息。第一赛段有一匹马摔了三下，颤抖得厉害，赶车的人最后不得不下马牵着他。

I could eat nothing and could not sleep, and I grew so nervous under those delays and the slow pace at which we travelled that I had an unreasonable desire upon me to get out and walk. Yielding to my companion’s better sense, however, I remained where I was. All this time, kept fresh by a certain enjoyment of the work in which he was engaged, he was up and down at every house we came to, addressing people whom he had never beheld before as old acquaintances, running in to warm himself at every fire he saw, talking and drinking and shaking hands at every bar and tap, friendly with every waggoner, wheelwright, blacksmith, and tolltaker, yet never seeming to lose time, and always mounting to the box again with his watchful, steady face and his business-like ‘Get on, my lad!’
我什么也吃不了，也睡不着，而且在这些延误和缓慢的行进速度下，我变得非常紧张，以至于我有一种不合理的愿望想要出去散步。然而，我屈服于同伴的理智，还是留在了原地。一直以来，他都对自己所从事的工作保持着某种新鲜感，在我们来到的每一所房子里走来走去，把以前从未见过的人当作老熟人，每次都跑进去取暖。他看到火，在每个酒吧和水龙头前聊天、喝酒、握手，与每一个车夫、车匠、铁匠和收费员都很友好，但似乎从不浪费时间，总是以警惕、稳定的表情和他的眼神再次登上包厢。公事公办的“加油，小伙子！”

When we were changing horses the next time, he came from the stable-yard, with the wet snow encrusted upon him and dropping off him—plashing and crashing through it to his wet knees as he had been doing frequently since we left Saint Albans—and spoke to me at the carriage side.
当我们下次换马的时候，他从马厩院子里出来，湿漉漉的雪覆盖在他身上，从他身上掉下来——溅起雪花，砸到他湿漉漉的膝盖上，自从我们离开圣奥尔本斯以来，他经常这样做——在车厢边对我说话。

‘Keep up your spirits. It’s certainly true that she came on here, Miss Summerson. There’s not a doubt of the dress by this time, and the dress has been seen here.’
‘打起精神来。萨默森小姐，她确实来到了这里。这时候，这件衣服已经没有疑问了，而且这件衣服已经在这里被看到了。

‘Still on foot?’ said I.
“还在步行吗？”我说。

‘Still on foot. I think the gentleman you mentioned must be the point she’s aiming at, and yet I don’t like his living down in her own part of the country neither.’
'仍然步行。我想你提到的那位先生一定是她的目标，但我也不喜欢他住在她自己的地区。

‘I know so little,’ said I. ‘There may be some one else nearer here, of whom I never heard.’
“我知道的太少了，”我说，“附近可能还有其他人，但我从未听说过。”

‘That’s true. But whatever you do, don’t you fall a-crying, my dear; and don’t you worry yourself no more than you can help. Get on, my lad!’
'这是真的。但无论你做什么，亲爱的，你都不要哭；你不必担心自己无能为力。加油，我的小伙子！

The sleet fell all that day unceasingly, a thick mist came on early, and it never rose or lightened for a moment. Such roads I had never seen. I sometimes feared we had missed the way and got into the ploughed grounds or the marshes. If I ever thought of the time I had been out, it presented itself as an indefinite period of great duration, and I seemed, in a strange way, never to have been free from the anxiety under which I then laboured.
一整天雨夹雪一直下个不停，早起浓雾，一刻也没有升起或变亮。这样的路我从来没有见过。有时我担心我们迷了路，进入了犁过的土地或沼泽地。如果我回想一下我出去的那段时间，它本身就是一个无限期的漫长时期，而我似乎以一种奇怪的方式从未摆脱过我当时所承受的焦虑。

As we advanced, I began to feel misgivings that my companion lost confidence. He was the same as before with all the roadside people, but he looked graver when he sat by himself on the box. I saw his finger uneasily going across and across his mouth during the whole of one long weary stage. I overheard that he began to ask the drivers of coaches and other vehicles coming towards us what passengers they had seen in other coaches and vehicles that were in advance. Their replies did not encourage him. He always gave me a reassuring beck of his finger and lift of his eyelid as he got upon the box again, but he seemed perplexed now when he said, ‘Get on, my lad!’
随着我们的前进，我开始担心我的同伴失去了信心。他对路边的人还是一如既往，只是当他一个人坐在箱子上时，他的表情更加严肃了。在整个漫长而疲惫的舞台上，我看到他的手指不安地在他的嘴上划过又划过。我无意中听到他开始询问向我们驶来的长途汽车和其他车辆的司机，他们在提前到达的其他长途汽车和车辆上看到了哪些乘客。他们的回答并没有鼓励他。当他再次登上箱子时，他总是向我轻轻一挥手指，抬起眼睑，让我放心，但现在当他说“上车，我的小伙子！”时，他似乎很困惑。

At last, when we were changing, he told me that he had lost the track of the dress so long that he began to be surprised. It was nothing, he said, to lose such a track for one while, and to take it up for another while, and so on; but it had disappeared here in an unaccountable manner, and we had not come upon it since. This corroborated the apprehensions I had formed, when he began to look at direction-posts, and to leave the carriage at cross roads for a quarter of an hour at a time while he explored them. But I was not to be down-hearted, he told me, for it was as likely as not that the next stage might set us right again.
最后，当我们换衣服时，他告诉我，他已经忘记了衣服的踪迹，以至于他开始感到惊讶。他说，暂时失去这样的踪迹，然后又重新拾起它，等等，这并不算什么。但它莫名其妙地消失在这里，从那以后我们就再也没有遇到过它。这证实了我的担忧，当时他开始看方向标，并在他探索十字路口时每次将马车停在十字路口一刻钟。但我不应该灰心丧气，他告诉我，因为下一阶段很可能会让我们再次走上正轨。

The next stage, however, ended as that one ended; we had no new clue. There was a spacious inn here, solitary, but a comfortable substantial building, and as we drove in under a large gateway before I knew it, where a landlady and her pretty daughters came to the carriage-door, entreating me to alight and refresh myself while the horses were making ready, I thought it would be uncharitable to refuse. They took me upstairs to a warm room and left me there.
然而，下一阶段也像上一阶段一样结束了。我们没有新的线索。这里有一家宽敞的客栈，虽然孤零零，但却是一栋舒适而坚固的建筑，当我们从一个大门下驶入时，我不知不觉间，一位女房东和她漂亮的女儿们来到了马车门前，恳求我下车休息一下。当马匹准备就绪时，我认为拒绝是不仁慈的。他们把我带到楼上一个温暖的房间，然后把我留在那里。

It was at the corner of the house, I remember, looking two ways. On one side to a stable-yard open to a by-road, where the ostlers were unharnessing the splashed and tired horses from the muddy carriage, and beyond that to the by-road itself, across which the sign was heavily swinging; on the other side to a wood of dark pine-trees. Their branches were encumbered with snow, and it silently dropped off in wet heaps while I stood at the window. Night was setting in, and its bleakness was enhanced by the contrast of the pictured fire glowing and gleaming in the windowpane. As I looked among the stems of the trees and followed the discoloured marks in the snow where the thaw was sinking into it and undermining it, I thought of the motherly face brightly set off by daughters that had just now welcomed me and of MY mother lying down in such a wood to die.
我记得它在房子的拐角处，朝两个方向看。一侧是马厩院子，通向一条小路，马夫们正在那里从泥泞的马车上卸下浑身湿透、疲惫不堪的马匹，再往前，就是小路本身，路标在小路上沉重地晃动；另一边是一片漆黑的松树林。它们的树枝上沾满了积雪，当我站在窗前时，积雪无声无息地落下，湿漉漉的。夜色即将降临，窗玻璃上闪烁的火光的对比增强了夜色的凄凉。当我在树干间望去，顺着积雪中融化的变色痕迹看去时，我想起了刚刚欢迎我的女儿们衬托出的母亲般的脸庞，也想起了躺在床上的母亲。就死在这样的树林里。

I was frightened when I found them all about me, but I remembered that before I fainted I tried very hard not to do it; and that was some little comfort. They cushioned me up on a large sofa by the fire, and then the comely landlady told me that I must travel no further to-night, but must go to bed. But this put me into such a tremble lest they should detain me there that she soon recalled her words and compromised for a rest of half an hour.
当我发现它们就在我身边时，我很害怕，但我记得在我晕倒之前我非常努力地不这样做；这是一些小小的安慰。他们把我放在火炉旁的一张大沙发上，然后漂亮的女房东告诉我今晚不能再旅行了，但必须去睡觉。但这让我心里忐忑不安，生怕他们把我扣留在那里，她很快就回想起自己的话，妥协了，休息了半个小时。

A good endearing creature she was. She and her three fair girls, all so busy about me. I was to take hot soup and broiled fowl, while Mr. Bucket dried himself and dined elsewhere; but I could not do it when a snug round table was presently spread by the fireside, though I was very unwilling to disappoint them. However, I could take some toast and some hot negus, and as I really enjoyed that refreshment, it made some recompense.
她真是个可爱的人。她和她的三个漂亮女孩，都为我忙碌着。我要喝热汤和烤鸡，而巴克特先生擦干身体去别处吃饭。但当炉边已经摆好了一张舒适的圆桌时，我无法做到这一点，尽管我非常不愿意让他们失望。不过，我可以吃一些吐司和一些热尼古斯，而且因为我真的很喜欢这种茶点，所以它也算是一种补偿。

Punctual to the time, at the half-hour’s end the carriage came rumbling under the gateway, and they took me down, warmed, refreshed, comforted by kindness, and safe (I assured them) not to faint any more. After I had got in and had taken a grateful leave of them all, the youngest daughter—a blooming girl of nineteen, who was to be the first married, they had told me—got upon the carriage step, reached in, and kissed me. I have never seen her, from that hour, but I think of her to this hour as my friend.
半小时后，马车准时地从大门下隆隆驶来，他们把我带下来，我感到温暖、神清气爽、善意安慰，而且安全（我向他们保证）不会再晕倒了。我上车后，满怀感激地与大家告别后，最小的女儿——他们告诉我，她是一个十九岁的花季少女，将是第一个结婚的——走上马车台阶，伸手进来，吻了我。从那时起我就再也没有见过她，但直到现在我仍将她视为我的朋友。

The transparent windows with the fire and light, looking so bright and warm from the cold darkness out of doors, were soon gone, and again we were crushing and churning the loose snow. We went on with toil enough, but the dismal roads were not much worse than they had been, and the stage was only nine miles. My companion smoking on the box—I had thought at the last inn of begging him to do so when I saw him standing at a great fire in a comfortable cloud of tobacco—was as vigilant as ever and as quickly down and up again when we came to any human abode or any human creature. He had lighted his little dark lantern, which seemed to be a favourite with him, for we had lamps to the carriage; and every now and then he turned it upon me to see that I was doing well. There was a folding-window to the carriage-head, but I never closed it, for it seemed like shutting out hope.
透明的窗户上有火和光，在门外寒冷的黑暗中显得如此明亮和温暖，但很快就消失了，我们再次压碎和搅拌松散的雪。我们继续辛苦地前行，但那条阴暗的道路并不比以前糟糕多少，而且舞台只有九英里。我的同伴在盒子上抽烟——在最后一家旅馆里，当我看到他站在篝火旁，烟雾缭绕，我本想求他这么做——他一如既往地保持警惕，当我们离开时，他很快又站了起来。来到任何人类住所或任何人类生物。他点亮了他的小黑灯笼，这似乎是他最喜欢的，因为我们的马车上有灯。他时不时地把注意力转向我，看看我做得很好。车头有一扇折叠窗，但我从未关上它，因为这似乎将希望拒之门外。

We came to the end of the stage, and still the lost trace was not recovered. I looked at him anxiously when we stopped to change, but I knew by his yet graver face as he stood watching the ostlers that he had heard nothing. Almost in an instant afterwards, as I leaned back in my seat, he looked in, with his lighted lantern in his hand, an excited and quite different man.
我们来到了舞台的尽头，但丢失的痕迹仍然没有恢复。当我们停下来换衣服时，我焦急地看着他，但当他站在那里看着马夫们时，我从他更加严肃的表情中知道他什么也没听到。几乎就在那之后的一瞬间，当我向后靠在座位上时，他手里拿着点燃的灯笼，朝里望去，他是一个兴奋的、截然不同的人。

‘What is it?’ said I, starting. ‘Is she here?’
“这是什么？”我吃惊地说。 “她在吗？”

‘No, no. Don’t deceive yourself, my dear. Nobody’s here. But I’ve got it!’
'不，不。不要欺骗自己，亲爱的。没有人在这里。但我明白了！

The crystallized snow was in his eyelashes, in his hair, lying in ridges on his dress. He had to shake it from his face and get his breath before he spoke to me.
结晶的雪落在他的睫毛上、头发上、衣服上，呈脊状分布。在跟我说话之前，他必须先把脸上的灰尘甩掉，平复一下呼吸。

‘Now, Miss Summerson,’ said he, beating his finger on the apron, ‘don’t you be disappointed at what I’m a-going to do. You know me. I’m Inspector Bucket, and you can trust me. We’ve come a long way; never mind. Four horses out there for the next stage up! Quick!’
“现在，萨默森小姐，”他用手指敲着围裙说道，“你不要对我要做的事情感到失望。你了解我。我是巴克特督察，你可以相信我。我们已经走了很长的路；没关系。四匹马即将进入下一阶段！快的！'

There was a commotion in the yard, and a man came running out of the stables to know if he meant up or down.
院子里一阵骚动，一个人从马厩里跑出来，想知道他是要上还是下。

‘Up, I tell you! Up! Ain’t it English? Up!’
‘起来，我告诉你！向上！不是英文吗？向上！'

‘Up?’ said I, astonished. ‘To London! Are we going back?’
“起来？”我惊讶地说。 '去伦敦！我们要回去吗？

‘Miss Summerson,’ he answered, ‘back. Straight back as a die. You know me. Don’t be afraid. I’ll follow the other, by G—‘
“萨默森小姐，”他回答道，“回来了。”像死了一样直接回来。你了解我。不要害怕。我会跟着另一个，G——”

‘The other?’ I repeated. ‘Who?’
“另一个？”我重复道。 'WHO？'

‘You called her Jenny, didn’t you? I’ll follow her. Bring those two pair out here for a crown a man. Wake up, some of you!’
“你叫她珍妮，是吗？我会跟着她。把这两对带出来，作为一个男人的王冠。醒醒吧，你们中的一些人！

‘You will not desert this lady we are in search of; you will not abandon her on such a night and in such a state of mind as I know her to be in!’ said I, in an agony, and grasping his hand.
“你不会抛弃我们正在寻找的这位女士；你不会在这样的夜晚、在这样的心情下抛弃她！我抓住了他的手，痛苦地说。

‘You are right, my dear, I won’t. But I’ll follow the other. Look alive here with them horses. Send a man for’ard in the saddle to the next stage, and let him send another for’ard again, and order four on, up, right through. My darling, don’t you be afraid!’
“你说得对，亲爱的，我不会。”但我会跟随另一个。看看这里的马匹是否充满生机。派一个坐在马鞍上的人到下一个阶段，然后让他再派另一个人，然后命令四个人上，上，一直通过。我亲爱的，别害怕！

These orders and the way in which he ran about the yard urging them caused a general excitement that was scarcely less bewildering to me than the sudden change. But in the height of the confusion, a mounted man galloped away to order the relays, and our horses were put to with great speed.
这些命令以及他在院子里跑来跑去催促这些命令的方式引起了普遍的兴奋，这与突然的变化一样让我感到困惑。但就在最混乱的时候，一个骑马的人疾驰而去，命令接力，我们的马匹很快就被催动了。

‘My dear,’ said Mr. Bucket, jumping to his seat and looking in again, ‘—you’ll excuse me if I’m too familiar—don’t you fret and worry yourself no more than you can help. I say nothing else at present; but you know me, my dear; now, don’t you?’
“亲爱的，”巴克特先生说，跳到座位上，又往里看了一眼，“——如果我太熟悉了，请原谅我——别太着急和担心了。”目前我什么也没说；但亲爱的，你了解我；现在，不是吗？

I endeavoured to say that I knew he was far more capable than I of deciding what we ought to do, but was he sure that this was right? Could I not go forward by myself in search of—I grasped his hand again in my distress and whispered it to him—of my own mother.
我尽力说我知道他比我更有能力决定我们应该做什么，但他确定这是正确的吗？我难道不能独自前去寻找——我痛苦地再次握住他的手，低声对他说——我自己的母亲。

‘My dear,’ he answered, ‘I know, I know, and would I put you wrong, do you think? Inspector Bucket. Now you know me, don’t you?’
“亲爱的，”他回答道，“我知道，我知道，你认为我会误会你吗？督察桶。现在你认识我了，不是吗？

What could I say but yes!
我还能说什么，但是是的！

‘Then you keep up as good a heart as you can, and you rely upon me for standing by you, no less than by Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet. Now, are you right there?’
“那么，你就尽可能保持一颗善良的心，你就相信我会支持你，就像莱斯特·戴洛克爵士从男爵那样。”现在，你在吗？

‘All right, sir!’
“好吧，先生！”

‘Off she goes, then. And get on, my lads!’
‘那么她就走了。继续前进，我的小伙子们！

We were again upon the melancholy road by which we had come, tearing up the miry sleet and thawing snow as if they were torn up by a waterwheel.
我们又回到了原来那条忧郁的路上，泥泞的雨夹雪和融化的雪，就像被水车撕裂一样。

CHAPTER LVIII
第四十八章


A Wintry Day and Night
寒冷的一天一夜

Still impassive, as behoves its breeding, the Dedlock town house carries itself as usual towards the street of dismal grandeur. There are powdered heads from time to time in the little windows of the hall, looking out at the untaxed powder falling all day from the sky; and in the same conservatory there is peach blossom turning itself exotically to the great hall fire from the nipping weather out of doors. It is given out that my Lady has gone down into Lincolnshire, but is expected to return presently.
戴德洛克联排别墅依然冷漠，正如它的诞生所应有的那样，它像往常一样走向悲惨的宏伟街道。大厅的小窗户里不时有扑粉的脑袋，望着窗外终日从天而降的未纳税的粉末；在同一个温室里，桃花在室外寒冷的天气中异国情调地转向大厅的火光。据报道，夫人已前往林肯郡，但预计很快就会返回。

Rumour, busy overmuch, however, will not go down into Lincolnshire. It persists in flitting and chattering about town. It knows that that poor unfortunate man, Sir Leicester, has been sadly used. It hears, my dear child, all sorts of shocking things. It makes the world of five miles round quite merry. Not to know that there is something wrong at the Dedlocks’ is to augur yourself unknown. One of the peachy-cheeked charmers with the skeleton throats is already apprised of all the principal circumstances that will come out before the Lords on Sir Leicester’s application for a bill of divorce.
然而，由于过于忙碌，谣言不会传到林肯郡。它持续在城里飞来飞去、喋喋不休。它知道那个可怜的不幸的人，莱斯特爵士，已经被可悲地利用了。我亲爱的孩子，它听到了各种令人震惊的事情。它使五英里圆的世界变得非常快乐。不知道戴德洛克家出了什么问题就预示着你自己不为人知。一位面颊桃色、喉咙骷髅的魅力人物已经获悉了莱斯特爵士申请离婚法案时将在上议院提出的所有主要情况。

At Blaze and Sparkle’s the jewellers and at Sheen and Gloss’s the mercers, it is and will be for several hours the topic of the age, the feature of the century. The patronesses of those establishments, albeit so loftily inscrutable, being as nicely weighed and measured there as any other article of the stock-intrade, are perfectly understood in this new fashion by the rawest hand behind the counter. ‘Our people, Mr. Jones,’ said Blaze and Sparkle to the hand in question on engaging him, ‘our people, sir, are sheep—mere sheep. Where two or three marked ones go, all the rest follow. Keep those two or three in your eye, Mr. Jones, and you have the flock.’ So, likewise, Sheen and Gloss to THEIR Jones, in reference to knowing where to have the fashionable people and how to bring what they (Sheen and Gloss) choose into fashion. On similar unerring principles, Mr. Sladdery the librarian, and indeed the great farmer of gorgeous sheep, admits this very day, ‘Why yes, sir, there certainly ARE reports concerning Lady Dedlock, very current indeed among my high connexion, sir. You see, my high connexion must talk about something, sir; and it’s only to get a subject into vogue with one or two ladies I could name to make it go down with the whole. Just what I should have done with those ladies, sir, in the case of any novelty you had left to me to bring in, they have done of themselves in this case through knowing Lady Dedlock and being perhaps a little innocently jealous of her too, sir. You’ll find, sir, that this topic will be very popular among my high connexion. If it had been a speculation, sir, it would have brought money. And when I say so, you may trust to my being right, sir, for I have made it my business to study my high connexion and to be able to wind it up like a clock, sir.’
在 Blaze and Sparkle’s 珠宝商和 Sheen and Gloss’s Mercer 中，它现在和将来都会成为几个小时的时代主题、世纪特征。这些场所的女赞助人，尽管如此高深莫测，就像股票交易中的任何其他物品一样，在那里经过了很好的称重和测量，柜台后面最原始的手以这种新方式完全理解了。 “我们的人民，琼斯先生，”布莱兹和斯帕克尔在与他接触时对那只手说道，“我们的人民，先生，都是羊——只是羊。”两到三个标记的去哪里，其余的都跟着去。琼斯先生，把这两三个人放在你的眼睛里，你就有了羊群。”所以，同样，光泽和光泽给他们的琼斯，指的是知道哪里有时尚人士以及如何带来他们的东西（光泽和光泽）光泽）选择融入时尚。基于类似的无误原则，图书管理员斯拉德利先生，事实上也是美丽羊的伟大农民，今天承认，“为什么是的，先生，肯定有关于戴德洛克夫人的报道，在我的高层关系中确实很流行，先生。”你看，我的高级亲戚必须谈论一些事情，先生；这只是为了让一个主题在我能说出名字的一两个女士中流行起来，让它与整体一起流行。先生，如果您留给我带来任何新奇的东西，我应该对那些女士们做些什么，在这种情况下，她们通过认识德洛克夫人并且也许也有点天真地嫉妒她，做了自己的事情，先生。先生，你会发现这个话题在我的高层人士中会很受欢迎。先生，如果这是一次投机，就会带来金钱。 当我这么说时，您可以相信我是对的，先生，因为我把研究我的高级关系作为我的职责，并能够像时钟一样给它上发条，先生。’

Thus rumour thrives in the capital, and will not go down into Lincolnshire. By half-past five, post meridian, Horse Guards’ time, it has even elicited a new remark from the Honourable Mr. Stables, which bids fair to outshine the old one, on which he has so long rested his colloquial reputation. This sparkling sally is to the effect that although he always knew she was the best-groomed woman in the stud, he had no idea she was a bolter. It is immensely received in turf-circles.
因此，谣言在首都盛行，不会传到林肯郡。到了下午五点半，即午后，即皇家骑兵卫队时间，它甚至引起了尊敬的马厩先生的新言论，这显然比他长期以来赖以口语声誉的旧言论更加耀眼。这个闪闪发光的俏皮话的意思是，尽管他一直都知道她是马场里打扮得最好的女人，但他不知道她是一名爆弹手。它在圈子里受到了极大的欢迎。

At feasts and festivals also, in firmaments she has often graced, and among constellations she outshone but yesterday, she is still the prevalent subject. What is it? Who is it? When was it? Where was it? How was it? She is discussed by her dear friends with all the genteelest slang in vogue, with the last new word, the last new manner, the last new drawl, and the perfection of polite indifference. A remarkable feature of the theme is that it is found to be so inspiring that several people come out upon it who never came out before—positively say things! William Buffy carries one of these smartnesses from the place where he dines down to the House, where the Whip for his party hands it about with his snuff-box to keep men together who want to be off, with such effect that the Speaker (who has had it privately insinuated into his own ear under the corner of his wig) cries, ‘Order at the bar!’ three times without making an impression.
在节日和盛宴上，她也经常在苍穹中熠熠生辉，在星座中，她也显得格外耀眼，但昨天，她仍然是普遍的话题。它是什么？是谁？那是什么时候？它在哪里？它怎么样？她亲爱的朋友们用所有流行的最文雅的俚语谈论她，用最后一个新词，最后一个新方式，最后一个新拖慢语气，以及完美的礼貌冷漠。这个主题的一个显着特点是，它是如此鼓舞人心，以至于有几个以前从未出现过的人站出来——积极地说一些事情！威廉·巴菲（William Buffy）将其中一项聪明才智从他用餐的地方带到了众议院，在那里，他所在政党的党鞭用他的鼻烟盒将其传递给想要离开的人，以将那些想要离开的人聚集在一起，其效果是议长（谁他在假发一角下偷偷地把它塞进了自己的耳朵里）喊了三遍“到酒吧点餐！”却没有留下任何印象。

And not the least amazing circumstance connected with her being vaguely the town talk is that people hovering on the confines of Mr. Sladdery’s high connexion, people who know nothing and ever did know nothing about her, think it essential to their reputation to pretend that she is their topic too, and to retail her at secondhand with the last new word and the last new manner, and the last new drawl, and the last new polite indifference, and all the rest of it, all at second-hand but considered equal to new in inferior systems and to fainter stars. If there be any man of letters, art, or science among these little dealers, how noble in him to support the feeble sisters on such majestic crutches!
与她隐隐约约地成为镇上谈论的最令人惊奇的情况是，那些徘徊在斯拉德利先生的高层关系范围内的人们，那些对她一无所知并且曾经一无所知的人，认为假装她对他们的声誉至关重要也是他们的话题，用二手的最后一个新单词和最后一个新的方式，最后一个新的慢吞吞的声音，最后一个新的礼貌的冷漠，以及所有其他的东西，所有这些都是二手的，但被认为是平等的到劣质系统中的新星和较暗的恒星。如果这些小贩中间有一个文学家、艺术家、科学家，他能拄着如此威严的拐杖扶着弱小的姐妹们，那是多么高尚啊！

So goes the wintry day outside the Dedlock mansion. How within it?
戴德洛克宅邸外的冬日就这样过去了。怎么在里面？

Sir Leicester, lying in his bed, can speak a little, though with difficulty and indistinctness. He is enjoined to silence and to rest, and they have given him some opiate to lull his pain, for his old enemy is very hard with him. He is never asleep, though sometimes he seems to fall into a dull waking doze. He caused his bedstead to be moved out nearer to the window when he heard it was such inclement weather, and his head to be so adjusted that he could see the driving snow and sleet. He watches it as it falls, throughout the whole wintry day.
莱斯特爵士躺在床上，能说一点话，虽然很困难，也很模糊。他被命令保持安静并休息，他们给了他一些鸦片来减轻他的痛苦，因为他的老敌人对他非常严厉。他从不睡觉，尽管有时他似乎会陷入昏昏欲睡的状态。当他听说天气如此恶劣时，他把床架移到靠近窗户的地方，并调整了他的头部，以便他可以看到大雪和雨夹雪。整个冬日里，他都看着它落下。

Upon the least noise in the house, which is kept hushed, his hand is at the pencil. The old housekeeper, sitting by him, knows what he would write and whispers, ‘No, he has not come back yet, Sir Leicester. It was late last night when he went. He has been but a little time gone yet.’
屋子里一直安静，只要有一点动静，他的手就会放在铅笔上。坐在他旁边的老管家知道他会写什么，低声说道：“不，他还没回来，莱斯特爵士。”他去的时候已经是深夜了。他已经走了一段时间了。

He withdraws his hand and falls to looking at the sleet and snow again until they seem, by being long looked at, to fall so thick and fast that he is obliged to close his eyes for a minute on the giddy whirl of white flakes and icy blots.
他收回手，再次注视着雨夹雪，直到经过长时间的观察，它们似乎下得又厚又快，以至于他不得不闭上眼睛一分钟，在白色雪花和冰的令人眼花缭乱的旋转中印迹。

He began to look at them as soon as it was light. The day is not yet far spent when he conceives it to be necessary that her rooms should be prepared for her. It is very cold and wet. Let there be good fires. Let them know that she is expected. Please see to it yourself. He writes to this purpose on his slate, and Mrs. Rouncewell with a heavy heart obeys.
天一亮他就开始看着他们。这一天还没有过去，他就觉得有必要为她准备房间了。天气又冷又湿。要有良好的火势。让他们知道她是值得期待的。请你自己看一下。他在石板上写下了这个目的，朗斯韦尔夫人心情沉重地服从了。

‘For I dread, George,’ the old lady says to her son, who waits below to keep her company when she has a little leisure, ‘I dread, my dear, that my Lady will never more set foot within these walls.’
“因为我害怕，乔治，”老太太对她的儿子说，她的儿子在下面等她有一点闲暇的时候陪伴她，“亲爱的，我担心我的夫人再也不会踏进这些墙了。”

‘That’s a bad presentiment, mother.’
“这是一个不好的预感，妈妈。”

‘Nor yet within the walls of Chesney Wold, my dear.’
“亲爱的，还没有在切斯尼沃尔德的围墙内。”

‘That’s worse. But why, mother?’
‘那更糟了。但为什么呢，妈妈？

‘When I saw my Lady yesterday, George, she looked to me—and I may say at me too—as if the step on the Ghost’s Walk had almost walked her down.’
“昨天我见到我的夫人乔治时，她看着我——我也可以这么说——好像幽灵步道上的台阶差点把她带倒了。”

‘Come, come! You alarm yourself with old-story fears, mother.’
'来来！你用老故事的恐惧来警醒自己，妈妈。”

‘No I don’t, my dear. No I don’t. It’s going on for sixty year that I have been in this family, and I never had any fears for it before. But it’s breaking up, my dear; the great old Dedlock family is breaking up.’
“不，我不喜欢，亲爱的。不，我不。我在这个家庭里已经六十年了，以前我从未有过任何恐惧。但亲爱的，它正在分手；伟大的老戴德洛克家族正在分裂。

‘I hope not, mother.’
“我希望不会，妈妈。”

‘I am thankful I have lived long enough to be with Sir Leicester in this illness and trouble, for I know I am not too old nor too useless to be a welcomer sight to him than anybody else in my place would be. But the step on the Ghost’s Walk will walk my Lady down, George; it has been many a day behind her, and now it will pass her and go on.’
“我很庆幸自己能活得足够长，能够在这场疾病和麻烦中与莱斯特爵士在一起，因为我知道我并没有太老，也没有太无用，无法比我这个位置上的任何人更受他欢迎。但是幽灵步道上的台阶会带我的女士下来，乔治；她已经过去很多天了，现在它将超越她并继续下去。

‘Well, mother dear, I say again, I hope not.’
“好吧，亲爱的妈妈，我再说一遍，我希望不会。”

‘Ah, so do I, George,’ the old lady returns, shaking her head and parting her folded hands. ‘But if my fears come true, and he has to know it, who will tell him!’
“啊，我也是，乔治，”老太太回答道，摇摇头，分开双手。 “但如果我的担心成真，而他必须知道这一点，谁会告诉他！”

‘Are these her rooms?’
“这些是她的房间吗？”

‘These are my Lady’s rooms, just as she left them.’
“这些是夫人的房间，就像她离开时一样。”

‘Why, now,’ says the trooper, glancing round him and speaking in a lower voice, ‘I begin to understand how you come to think as you do think, mother. Rooms get an awful look about them when they are fitted up, like these, for one person you are used to see in them, and that person is away under any shadow, let alone being God knows where.’
“哎呀，现在，”士兵环顾四周，低声说道，“我开始明白你是如何想出你现在的想法了，妈妈。当房间布置好后，它们看起来会很糟糕，就像这样，因为你习惯在房间里看到一个人，而那个人不在任何阴影下，更不用说上帝知道在哪里了。

He is not far out. As all partings foreshadow the great final one, so, empty rooms, bereft of a familiar presence, mournfully whisper what your room and what mine must one day be. My Lady’s state has a hollow look, thus gloomy and abandoned; and in the inner apartment, where Mr. Bucket last night made his secret perquisition, the traces of her dresses and her ornaments, even the mirrors accustomed to reflect them when they were a portion of herself, have a desolate and vacant air. Dark and cold as the wintry day is, it is darker and colder in these deserted chambers than in many a hut that will barely exclude the weather; and though the servants heap fires in the grates and set the couches and the chairs within the warm glass screens that let their ruddy light shoot through to the furthest corners, there is a heavy cloud upon the rooms which no light will dispel.
他已经离我们不远了。正如所有的离别都预示着最后的离别，所以，空荡荡的房间，失去了熟悉的存在，悲伤地低语着你的房间和我的房间有一天会是什么样子。夫人的状态看起来空洞、阴暗、被遗弃；在内室里，也就是巴克特先生昨晚秘密探查的地方，她的衣服和装饰品的痕迹，甚至是那些习惯于反射它们的镜子，当它们是她自己的一部分时，都透着一种荒凉和空虚的气氛。尽管冬日又黑又冷，但这些废弃的房间比许多几乎无法排除天气的小屋更黑、更冷。尽管仆人们在壁炉里堆起火，把沙发和椅子放在温暖的玻璃屏风里，让红色的光射到最远的角落，但房间里却有一层厚重的云，没有任何光线可以驱散。

The old housekeeper and her son remain until the preparations are complete, and then she returns upstairs. Volumnia has taken Mrs. Rouncewell’s place in the meantime, though pearl necklaces and rouge pots, however calculated to embellish Bath, are but indifferent comforts to the invalid under present circumstances. Volumnia, not being supposed to know (and indeed not knowing) what is the matter, has found it a ticklish task to offer appropriate observations and consequently has supplied their place with distracting smoothings of the bed-linen, elaborate locomotion on tiptoe, vigilant peeping at her kinsman’s eyes, and one exasperating whisper to herself of, ‘He is asleep.’ In disproof of which superfluous remark Sir Leicester has indignantly written on the slate, ‘I am not.’
老管家和她的儿子留下来，直到准备工作完成，然后她才回到楼上。与此同时，沃伦尼亚取代了朗斯韦尔夫人的位置，尽管珍珠项链和胭脂罐无论多么精心设计来装饰巴斯，在目前的情况下对病人来说都只是无足轻重的安慰。沃伦尼亚不应该知道（实际上也不知道）发生了什么事，却发现提供适当的观察是一项棘手的任务，因此用令人分心的平滑床单、踮起脚尖的复杂动作、警惕的偷看来代替自己的位置。看着她亲戚的眼睛，她恼怒地低声自言自语道：“他睡着了。”为了反驳这一多余的话，莱斯特爵士愤怒地在石板上写下：“我没有。”

Yielding, therefore, the chair at the bedside to the quaint old housekeeper, Volumnia sits at a table a little removed, sympathetically sighing. Sir Leicester watches the sleet and snow and listens for the returning steps that he expects. In the ears of his old servant, looking as if she had stepped out of an old picture-frame to attend a summoned Dedlock to another world, the silence is fraught with echoes of her own words, ‘who will tell him!’
因此，沃伦尼亚将床边的椅子让给了古色古香的老管家，坐在一张稍远的桌子旁，同情地叹了口气。莱斯特爵士注视着雨夹雪，聆听着他期待的归来的脚步声。在他的老仆人耳中，她仿佛从旧相框里走出来，去参加被召唤的戴德洛克到另一个世界，沉默中充满了她自己的话的回响：“谁来告诉他！”

He has been under his valet’s hands this morning to be made presentable and is as well got up as the circumstances will allow. He is propped with pillows, his grey hair is brushed in its usual manner, his linen is arranged to a nicety, and he is wrapped in a responsible dressing-gown. His eye-glass and his watch are ready to his hand. It is necessary—less to his own dignity now perhaps than for her sake—that he should be seen as little disturbed and as much himself as may be. Women will talk, and Volumnia, though a Dedlock, is no exceptional case. He keeps her here, there is little doubt, to prevent her talking somewhere else. He is very ill, but he makes his present stand against distress of mind and body most courageously.
今天早上，他一直在他的贴身男仆的照顾下，让自己变得体面，并在情况允许的情况下起床。他枕着枕头，灰白的头发照常梳理，亚麻布整理得井井有条，身上裹着一件负责任的晨衣。他的眼镜和手表已经准备好了。有必要——现在也许不是为了他自己的尊严，而是为了她——让人们看到他尽可能少受干扰，尽可能展现他自己。女人会说话，沃伦尼亚虽然是戴德洛克人，但也不例外。毫无疑问，他把她留在这里，是为了防止她在别处说话。他病得很重，但他以最勇敢的方式面对身心的痛苦。

The fair Volumnia, being one of those sprightly girls who cannot long continue silent without imminent peril of seizure by the dragon Boredom, soon indicates the approach of that monster with a series of undisguisable yawns. Finding it impossible to suppress those yawns by any other process than conversation, she compliments Mrs. Rouncewell on her son, declaring that he positively is one of the finest figures she ever saw and as soldierly a looking person, she should think, as what’s his name, her favourite Life Guardsman —the man she dotes on, the dearest of creatures—who was killed at Waterloo.
美丽的沃伦尼亚是那些活泼的女孩之一，她不能长时间保持沉默，否则就会面临被无聊之龙抓住的迫在眉睫的危险，她很快就用一系列毫不掩饰的哈欠来表明那个怪物的逼近。她发现除了谈话之外，不可能通过任何其他方式来抑制哈欠，她称赞朗斯韦尔夫人对她儿子的评价，宣称他确实是她见过的最优秀的人物之一，她应该认为，他是一个看起来像军人的人，就像他的儿子一样。名字，她最喜欢的近卫军——她最喜爱的人，最亲爱的生物——他在滑铁卢被杀。

Sir Leicester hears this tribute with so much surprise and stares about him in such a confused way that Mrs. Rouncewell feels it necesary to explain.
莱斯特爵士听到这番致敬，感到非常惊讶，并以一种困惑的方式盯着他，朗斯韦尔夫人觉得有必要解释一下。

‘Miss Dedlock don’t speak of my eldest son, Sir Leicester, but my youngest. I have found him. He has come home.’
“戴德洛克小姐说的不是我的长子莱斯特爵士，而是我最小的儿子。我已经找到他了。他已经回家了。

Sir Leicester breaks silence with a harsh cry. ‘George? Your son George come home, Mrs. Rouncewell?’
莱斯特爵士一声刺耳的叫喊打破了沉默。 '乔治？朗斯韦尔夫人，你的儿子乔治回家了吗？

The old housekeeper wipes her eyes. ‘Thank God. Yes, Sir Leicester.’
老管家擦了擦眼睛。 '感谢上帝。是的，莱斯特爵士。

Does this discovery of some one lost, this return of some one so long gone, come upon him as a strong confirmation of his hopes? Does he think, ‘Shall I not, with the aid I have, recall her safely after this, there being fewer hours in her case than there are years in his?’
某人失踪的发现，以及久别重逢的人的回归，对他来说是否是对他的希望的有力证实？他是否会想：“在我所拥有的帮助下，我是否应该在这之后安全地召回她，因为她的时间比他的时间要少？”

It is of no use entreating him; he is determined to speak now, and he does. In a thick crowd of sounds, but still intelligibly enough to be understood.
恳求他是没有用的；他现在决心要发言，而且他确实这么做了。在一大堆声音中，但仍然清晰易懂。

‘Why did you not tell me, Mrs. Rouncewell?’
“朗斯韦尔夫人，你为什么不告诉我？”

‘It happened only yesterday, Sir Leicester, and I doubted your being well enough to be talked to of such things.’
“这件事就发生在昨天，莱斯特爵士，我怀疑你的身体状况是否足以让别人谈论这样的事情。”

Besides, the giddy Volumnia now remembers with her little scream that nobody was to have known of his being Mrs. Rouncewell’s son and that she was not to have told. But Mrs. Rouncewell protests, with warmth enough to swell the stomacher, that of course she would have told Sir Leicester as soon as he got better.
此外，头晕的沃伦尼亚现在用她的小尖叫声记起了，没有人应该知道他是朗斯韦尔夫人的儿子，而她也不应该告诉。但朗斯韦尔夫人抗议道，她的热情足以让胃胀起来，她当然会在莱斯特爵士康复后立即告诉他。

‘Where is your son George, Mrs. Rouncewell?’ asks Sir Leicester,
“朗斯韦尔夫人，您的儿子乔治在哪里？”莱斯特爵士问道，

Mrs. Rouncewell, not a little alarmed by his disregard of the doctor’s injunctions, replies, in London.
在伦敦，朗斯韦尔夫人对他无视医生的禁令感到非常震惊。

‘Where in London?’
“伦敦哪里？”

Mrs. Rouncewell is constrained to admit that he is in the house.
朗斯韦尔夫人不得不承认他在房子里。

‘Bring him here to my room. Bring him directly.’
‘把他带到我的房间来。直接带他来。

The old lady can do nothing but go in search of him. Sir Leicester, with such power of movement as he has, arranges himself a little to receive him. When he has done so, he looks out again at the falling sleet and snow and listens again for the returning steps. A quantity of straw has been tumbled down in the street to deaden the noises there, and she might be driven to the door perhaps without his hearing wheels.
老太太没有办法，只能去找他。莱斯特爵士的行动力极强，他稍微调整了一下身体，迎接他。当他这样做时，他再次望向正在飘落的雨夹雪，并再次倾听着归来的脚步声。街上已经撒了一些稻草，以减弱那里的噪音，也许他的轮子没有听力，她可能会被赶到门口。

He is lying thus, apparently forgetful of his newer and minor surprise, when the housekeeper returns, accompanied by her trooper son. Mr. George approaches softly to the bedside, makes his bow, squares his chest, and stands, with his face flushed, very heartily ashamed of himself.
当管家带着她的士兵儿子回来时，他就这样躺着，显然忘记了他的新的小惊喜。乔治先生轻轻地走到床边，鞠了一躬，挺胸站着，脸涨得通红，心里非常羞愧。

‘Good heaven, and it is really George Rouncewell!’ exclaims Sir Leicester. ‘Do you remember me, George?’
“天哪，这真是乔治·朗斯韦尔！”莱斯特爵士惊呼道。 “你还记得我吗，乔治？”

The trooper needs to look at him and to separate this sound from that sound before he knows what he has said, but doing this and being a little helped by his mother, he replies, ‘I must have a very bad memory, indeed, Sir Leicester, if I failed to remember you.’
士兵需要看着他，并在他知道自己说了什么之前将这个声音与那个声音分开，但是这样做并在他母亲的帮助下，他回答道：“确实，我的记忆力一定很差，先生。”莱斯特，如果我不记得你的话。

‘When I look at you, George Rouncewell,’ Sir Leicester observes with difficulty, ‘I see something of a boy at Chesney Wold—I remember well—very well.’
“当我看着你时，乔治·朗斯威尔，”莱斯特爵士艰难地说道，“我看到了切斯尼沃尔德的一个男孩——我记得很清楚——非常清楚。”

He looks at the trooper until tears come into his eyes, and then he looks at the sleet and snow again.
他看着士兵，直到泪水涌出眼眶，然后他再次看着雨夹雪。

‘I ask your pardon, Sir Leicester,’ says the trooper, ‘but would you accept of my arms to raise you up? You would lie easier, Sir Leicester, if you would allow me to move you.’
“请您原谅，莱斯特爵士，”士兵说道，“但是您愿意接受我的手臂来扶您起来吗？”莱斯特爵士，如果你允许我移动你的话，你会更容易撒谎。

‘If you please, George Rouncewell; if you will be so good.’
“如果你愿意的话，乔治·朗斯韦尔；如果你能这么好的话。

The trooper takes him in his arms like a child, lightly raises him, and turns him with his face more towards the window. ‘Thank you. You have your mother’s gentleness,’ returns Sir Leicester, ‘and your own strength. Thank you.’
士兵像个孩子一样把他抱在怀里，轻轻地把他抱起来，然后把他的脸转向窗户。 '谢谢。你有你母亲的温柔，”莱斯特爵士答道，“还有你自己的力量。谢谢。'

He signs to him with his hand not to go away. George quietly remains at the bedside, waiting to be spoken to.
他用手示意他不要走开。乔治静静地守在床边，等待与他交谈。

‘Why did you wish for secrecy?’ It takes Sir Leicester some time to ask this.
“你为什么希望保密？”莱斯特爵士花了一些时间才问这个问题。

‘Truly I am not much to boast of, Sir Leicester, and I—I should still, Sir Leicester, if you was not so indisposed—which I hope you will not be long—I should still hope for the favour of being allowed to remain unknown in general. That involves explanations not very hard to be guessed at, not very well timed here, and not very creditable to myself. However opinions may differ on a variety of subjects, I should think it would be universally agreed, Sir Leicester, that I am not much to boast of.’
“说实话，我没什么值得夸耀的，莱斯特爵士，而且我——我仍然应该，莱斯特爵士，如果你不是那么不舒服——我希望你不会太久——我仍然希望得到允许的恩惠。”总体上仍然未知。这涉及到的解释不太难猜，时机不太好，对我自己来说也不太可信。然而，在各种主题上可能会有不同的意见，我认为莱斯特爵士，我应该认为这是普遍同意的，我没什么值得夸耀的。

‘You have been a soldier,’ observes Sir Leicester, ‘and a faithful one.’
“你曾是一名士兵，”莱斯特爵士说道，“而且是一名忠诚的士兵。”

George makes his military how. ‘As far as that goes, Sir Leicester, I have done my duty under discipline, and it was the least I could do.’
乔治如何打造他的军队。 “就目前而言，莱斯特爵士，我已经按照纪律履行了我的职责，这是我至少能做的。”

‘You find me,’ says Sir Leicester, whose eyes are much attracted towards him, ‘far from well, George Rouncewell.’
“你发现我，”莱斯特爵士说道，他的目光被他吸引了，“乔治·朗斯韦尔，情况很糟糕。”

‘I am very sorry both to hear it and to see it, Sir Leicester.’
“我对听到和看到这件事感到非常遗憾，莱斯特爵士。”

‘I am sure you are. No. In addition to my older malady, I have had a sudden and bad attack. Something that deadens,’ making an endeavour to pass one hand down one side, ‘and confuses,’ touching his lips.
'我敢肯定你是。没有。除了我的老毛病之外，我还突发过一次严重的发作。某种东西会变得迟钝，”试图将一只手从一侧滑下来，“并且令人困惑，”触摸他的嘴唇。

George, with a look of assent and sympathy, makes another bow. The different times when they were both young men (the trooper much the younger of the two) and looked at one another down at Chesney Wold arise before them both and soften both.
乔治再次鞠了一躬，脸上露出赞同和同情的表情。当他们都是年轻人（那名士兵是两人中更年轻的）时，在切斯尼沃尔德互相注视的不同时刻出现在他们两人面前，使两人都软化了。

Sir Leicester, evidently with a great determination to say, in his own manner, something that is on his mind before relapsing into silence, tries to raise himself among his pillows a little more. George, observant of the action, takes him in his arms again and places him as he desires to be. ‘Thank you, George. You are another self to me. You have often carried my spare gun at Chesney Wold, George. You are familiar to me in these strange circumstances, very familiar.’ He has put Sir Leicester’s sounder arm over his shoulder in lifting him up, and Sir Leicester is slow in drawing it away again as he says these words.
莱斯特爵士显然下定决心要以自己的方式说出心中的想法，然后又陷入沉默，他试图在枕头上再站起来一点。乔治观察着这个动作，再次把他抱在怀里，把他放在他想要的位置。 “谢谢你，乔治。你对于我来说就是另一个自己。乔治，你经常在切斯尼沃尔德携带我的备用枪。在这些奇怪的环境中，你对我来说很熟悉，非常熟悉。”他把莱斯特爵士的健全手臂搭在肩上，将他举起来，莱斯特爵士一边说着这些话，一边慢慢地把它收回来。

‘I was about to add,’ he presently goes on, ‘I was about to add, respecting this attack, that it was unfortunately simultaneous with a slight misunderstanding between my Lady and myself. I do not mean that there was any difference between us (for there has been none), but that there was a misunderstanding of certain circumstances important only to ourselves, which deprives me, for a little while, of my Lady’s society. She has found it necessary to make a journey—I trust will shortly return. Volumnia, do I make myself intelligible? The words are not quite under my command in the manner of pronouncing them.’
“我正要补充一点，”他随即继续说道，“考虑到这次袭击，我正要补充一点，不幸的是，这同时发生在我和夫人之间的轻微误会。”我并不是说我们之间有任何区别（因为本来就没有），而是对某些只对我们自己重要的情况存在误解，这使我暂时无法与夫人交往。她觉得有必要去一趟——我相信很快就会回来。 Volumnia，我让自己变得容易理解了吗？这些词的发音方式不太受我的指挥。

Volumnia understands him perfectly, and in truth be delivers himself with far greater plainness than could have been supposed possible a minute ago. The effort by which he does so is written in the anxious and labouring expression of his face. Nothing but the strength of his purpose enables him to make it.
沃伦尼亚完全理解他，事实上，他的表达方式比一分钟前想象的要简单得多。他的努力从他脸上焦急而劳累的表情中可见一斑。只有坚定的目标才能让他实现这一目标。

‘Therefore, Volumnia, I desire to say in your presence—and in the presence of my old retainer and friend, Mrs. Rouncewell, whose truth and fidelity no one can question, and in the presence of her son George, who comes back like a familiar recollection of my youth in the home of my ancestors at Chesney Wold—in case I should relapse, in case I should not recover, in case I should lose both my speech and the power of writing, though I hope for better things—‘
“因此，沃伦尼亚，我想当着你的面，当着我的老随从和朋友朗斯韦尔夫人的面，她的真实性和忠诚度无人能质疑，还有她儿子乔治的面，他回来时就像这是我年轻时在切斯尼沃尔德祖先家里的熟悉回忆——万一我旧病复发，万一我不能康复，万一我失去言语和写作的能力，尽管我希望有更好的事情—— '

The old housekeeper weeping silently; Volumnia in the greatest agitation, with the freshest bloom on her cheeks; the trooper with his arms folded and his head a little bent, respectfully attentive.
老管家默默流泪；沃伦尼娅心情极度激动，脸颊上绽放着最新鲜的花朵；士兵双手抱胸，微微低着头，恭敬地专注着。
