‘Therefore I desire to say, and to call you all to witness— beginning, Volumnia, with yourself, most solemnly—that I am on unaltered terms with Lady Dedlock. That I assert no cause whatever of complaint against her. That I have ever had the strongest affection for her, and that I retain it undiminished. Say this to herself, and to every one. If you ever say less than this, you will be guilty of deliberate falsehood to me.’
“因此，我想要说，并请你们所有人见证——首先，沃伦妮娅，您本人，最庄严地——我与戴德洛克夫人的关系没有改变。我断言没有任何理由对她提出投诉。我对她怀有最强烈的感情，而且我一直保持着这种感情，丝毫没有减退。这句话对她自己说，也对每个人说。如果你说的比这个少，你就会犯有故意对我撒谎的罪。

Volumnia tremblingly protests that she will observe his injunctions to the letter.
沃伦尼娅颤抖着抗议，要求她严格遵守他的禁令。

‘My Lady is too high in position, too handsome, too accomplished, too superior in most respects to the best of those by whom she is surrounded, not to have her enemies and traducers, I dare say. Let it be known to them, as I make it known to you, that being of sound mind, memory, and understanding, I revoke no disposition I have made in her favour. I abridge nothing I have ever bestowed upon her. I am on unaltered terms with her, and I recall—having the full power to do it if I were so disposed, as you see—no act I have done for her advantage and happiness.’
“我敢说，我的夫人地位太高，太英俊，太有成就，在许多方面都比她周围最优秀的人优越，她不可能没有敌人和诽谤者。”让他们知道，就像我让你知道的那样，我有健全的头脑、记忆力和理解力，我不会撤销我对她有利的安排。我没有减少我曾经给予她的任何东西。我和她的关系没有改变，而且我记得——如果我愿意的话，我完全有能力这么做，如你所见——我所做的任何事情都不是为了她的利益和幸福。

His formal array of words might have at any other time, as it has often had, something ludicrous in it, but at this time it is serious and affecting. His noble earnestness, his fidelity, his gallant shielding of her, his generous conquest of his own wrong and his own pride for her sake, are simply honourable, manly, and true. Nothing less worthy can be seen through the lustre of such qualities in the commonest mechanic, nothing less worthy can be seen in the best-born gentleman. In such a light both aspire alike, both rise alike, both children of the dust shine equally.
他的正式措辞在其他时候可能会像往常一样含有一些可笑的东西，但此时却是严肃而感人的。他高尚的真诚，他的忠诚，他对她的英勇保护，他慷慨地克服自己的错误，他为了她而感到自豪，这些都是光荣的，有男子气概的，真实的。从最普通的机械师身上的这些品质的光彩来看，没有什么比这更值得的了，在出身最好的绅士身上也没有什么比这更不值得的了。在这样的光芒下，两人都同样渴望，两人同样崛起，尘埃之子同样闪耀。

Overpowered by his exertions, he lays his head back on his pillows and closes his eyes for not more than a minute, when he again resumes his watching of the weather and his attention to the muffled sounds. In the rendering of those little services, and in the manner of their acceptance, the trooper has become installed as necessary to him. Nothing has been said, but it is quite understood. He falls a step or two backward to be out of sight and mounts guard a little behind his mother’s chair.
他被自己的努力压倒了，把头靠在枕头上，闭上眼睛不到一分钟，然后他再次开始观察天气和低沉的声音。在提供这些小服务的过程中，以及在接受这些服务的方式中，士兵已经成为他所需要的人。虽然什么也没说，但也都明白了。他向后退了一两步，以免被人看见，然后在他母亲的椅子后面稍远的地方站了起来。

The day is now beginning to decline. The mist and the sleet into which the snow has all resolved itself are darker, and the blaze begins to tell more vividly upon the room walls and furniture. The gloom augments; the bright gas springs up in the streets; and the pertinacious oil lamps which yet hold their ground there, with their source of life half frozen and half thawed, twinkle gaspingly like fiery fish out of water—as they are. The world, which has been rumbling over the straw and pulling at the bell, ‘to inquire,’ begins to go home, begins to dress, to dine, to discuss its dear friend with all the last new modes, as already mentioned.
现在天色开始下降。雪化成的雾气和雨夹雪变得更暗，房间的墙壁和家具上的火焰开始变得更加生动。阴霾加剧；街道上涌起明亮的气体；顽强的油灯仍然坚守在那里，它们的生命之源半冻半融，喘息着闪烁，就像离开水的火鱼一样。世界，一直在稻草上隆隆作响，拉响门铃，“询问”，开始回家，开始穿衣服，吃饭，用所有最后的新模式讨论它亲爱的朋友，正如已经提到的。

Now does Sir Leicester become worse, restless, uneasy, and in great pain. Volumnia, lighting a candle (with a predestined aptitude for doing something objectionable), is bidden to put it out again, for it is not yet dark enough. Yet it is very dark too, as dark as it will be all night. By and by she tries again. No! Put it out. It is not dark enough yet.
现在莱斯特爵士的情况变得更糟了，焦躁不安，心神不宁，而且非常痛苦。沃伦尼亚点燃了一支蜡烛（注定会做一些令人反感的事情），但被命令再次将其熄灭，因为天还不够黑。但天也很黑，就像整个晚上一样黑。渐渐地，她再次尝试。不！把它拿出来。天还不够黑。

His old housekeeper is the first to understand that he is striving to uphold the fiction with himself that it is not growing late.
他的老管家第一个明白，他正在努力坚持自己的幻想，即天色还不算晚。

‘Dear Sir Leicester, my honoured master,’ she softly whispers, ‘I must, for your own good, and my duty, take the freedom of begging and praying that you will not lie here in the lone darkness watching and waiting and dragging through the time. Let me draw the curtains, and light the candles, and make things more comfortable about you. The church-clocks will strike the hours just the same, Sir Leicester, and the night will pass away just the same. My Lady will come back, just the same.’
“亲爱的莱斯特爵士，我尊敬的主人，”她轻轻地低语道，“为了您的利益和我的职责，我必须拥有乞求和祈祷的自由，让您不会躺在这里，在孤独的黑暗中观看、等待和拖拖拉拉。”时间。让我拉上窗帘，点燃蜡烛，让你感觉更舒服。莱斯特爵士，教堂的钟会照常敲响，夜晚也会照常过去。无论如何，我的女士会回来的。

‘I know it, Mrs. Rouncewell, but I am weak—and he has been so long gone.’
“我知道，朗斯韦尔夫人，但我很虚弱——而且他已经走了这么久了。”

‘Not so very long, Sir Leicester. Not twenty-four hours yet.’
“不会太久，莱斯特爵士。还不到二十四小时。”

‘But that is a long time. Oh, it is a long time!’
‘但那是很长一段时间了。哦，已经很久了！

He says it with a groan that wrings her heart.
他说这话时，发出一阵呻吟，让她心痛不已。

She knows that this is not a period for bringing the rough light upon him; she thinks his tears too sacred to be seen, even by her. Therefore she sits in the darkness for a while without a word, then gently begins to move about, now stirring the fire, now standing at the dark window looking out. Finally he tells her, with recovered self-command, ‘As you say, Mrs. Rouncewell, it is no worse for being confessed. It is getting late, and they are not come. Light the room!’ When it is lighted and the weather shut out, it is only left to him to listen.
她知道现在不是对他进行严厉打击的时期；她认为他的眼泪太神圣了，连她自己都看不到。于是她在黑暗中一言不发地坐了一会儿，然后轻轻地走动起来，时而搅动火，时而站在黑暗的窗前向外看。最后，他恢复了自制力，对她说：“正如你所说，朗斯韦尔夫人，被坦白并没有更糟糕。”天色已晚，他们还没有来。照亮房间！”当房间亮起来并且天气不受影响时，他就只能听。

But they find that however dejected and ill he is, he brightens when a quiet pretence is made of looking at the fires in her rooms and being sure that everything is ready to receive her. Poor pretence as it is, these allusions to her being expected keep up hope within him.
但他们发现，无论他多么沮丧和生病，当他安静地假装看着她房间里的火并确信一切都准备好迎接她时，他就会变得高兴起来。尽管这是一种蹩脚的假装，但这些对她的期待的暗示让他内心充满了希望。

Midnight comes, and with it the same blank. The carriages in the streets are few, and other late sounds in that neighbourhood there are none, unless a man so very nomadically drunk as to stray into the frigid zone goes brawling and bellowing along the pavement. Upon this wintry night it is so still that listening to the intense silence is like looking at intense darkness. If any distant sound be audible in this case, it departs through the gloom like a feeble light in that, and all is heavier than before.
午夜来临，随之而来的是同样的空白。街上的马车很少，附近也没有其他晚间的声音，除非一个人醉得醉醺醺地误入寒冷地带，在人行道上吵架、吼叫。在这个冬夜，万籁俱寂，听着这寂静无声的声音，就如同看到了漆黑的夜色。在这种情况下，如果能听到远处的任何声音，它就会像微弱的光一样穿过黑暗，一切都比以前更沉重。

The corporation of servants are dismissed to bed (not unwilling to go, for they were up all last night), and only Mrs. Rouncewell and George keep watch in Sir Leicester’s room. As the night lags tardily on—or rather when it seems to stop altogether, at between two and three o’clock—they find a restless craving on him to know more about the weather, now he cannot see it. Hence George, patrolling regularly every half-hour to the rooms so carefully looked after, extends his march to the hall-door, looks about him, and brings back the best report he can make of the worst of nights, the sleet still falling and even the stone footways lying ankledeep in icy sludge.
一群仆人都被打发去睡觉了（不是不愿意去，因为他们昨晚一整晚都没睡），只有朗斯韦尔夫人和乔治在莱斯特爵士的房间里看守。随着夜幕慢慢降临——或者更确切地说，当夜色似乎完全停止时，在两点到三点之间——他们发现他焦躁不安地渴望了解更多有关天气的信息，但现在他却看不到了。因此，乔治每半小时定期巡逻一次，前往精心照料的房间，将行军延伸到大厅门口，环顾四周，并带回他所能对最糟糕的夜晚做出的最好的报告，雨夹雪仍在下着，甚至是深埋在冰冷污泥中的石板路。

Volumnia, in her room up a retired landing on the stair-case—the second turning past the end of the carving and gilding, a cousinly room containing a fearful abortion of a portrait of Sir Leicester banished for its crimes, and commanding in the day a solemn yard planted with dried-up shrubs like antediluvian specimens of black tea—is a prey to horrors of many kinds. Not last nor least among them, possibly, is a horror of what may befall her little income in the event, as she expresses it, ‘of anything happening’ to Sir Leicester. Anything, in this sense, meaning one thing only; and that the last thing that can happen to the consciousness of any baronet in the known world.
沃伦尼亚，在她的房间里，在楼梯上一个退休的平台上——经过雕刻和镀金末端的第二个转弯，这是一个堂兄的房间，里面有一幅因犯罪而被放逐的莱斯特爵士的肖像，令人恐惧地流产了，在白天指挥着庄严的院子里种满了干枯的灌木，就像古老的红茶标本一样，是多种恐怖的牺牲品。其中最重要的可能是，她担心如果莱斯特爵士“发生任何事情”，她微薄的收入可能会受到影响。从这个意义上来说，任何事物都只意味着一件事；这是已知世界中任何男爵意识中最不可能发生的事情。

An effect of these horrors is that Volumnia finds she cannot go to bed in her own room or sit by the fire in her own room, but must come forth with her fair head tied up in a profusion of shawl, and her fair form enrobed in drapery, and parade the mansion like a ghost, particularly haunting the rooms, warm and luxurious, prepared for one who still does not return. Solitude under such circumstances being not to be thought of, Volumnia is attended by her maid, who, impressed from her own bed for that purpose, extremely cold, very sleepy, and generally an injured maid as condemned by circumstances to take office with a cousin, when she had resolved to be maid to nothing less than ten thousand a year, has not a sweet expression of countenance.
这些恐怖的影响是，沃伦尼亚发现她不能在自己的房间里睡觉，也不能坐在自己房间的火边，但必须带着她美丽的头绑上大量的披肩，她美丽的身体被裹着窗帘，像幽灵一样在豪宅中游行，特别是在房间里出没，温暖而豪华，为仍然没有回来的人准备。在这种情况下，孤独是不值得考虑的，沃伦尼亚有她的女仆照顾，为此目的，她在自己的床上感到非常寒冷，非常困，而且通常是一个受伤的女仆，因为环境注定要与表弟一起上任当她决定每年做不少于一万人的女仆时，脸上的表情并不甜美。

The periodical visits of the trooper to these rooms, however, in the course of his patrolling is an assurance of protection and company both to mistress and maid, which renders them very acceptable in the small hours of the night. Whenever he is heard advancing, they both make some little decorative preparation to receive him; at other times they divide their watches into short scraps of oblivion and dialogues not wholly free from acerbity, as to whether Miss Dedlock, sitting with her feet upon the fender, was or was not falling into the fire when rescued (to her great displeasure) by her guardian genius the maid.
然而，巡警在巡逻过程中定期访问这些房间是对情妇和女仆​​的保护和陪伴的保证，这使得他们在深夜非常容易接受。每当听到他走过来时，他们都会做一些装饰性的准备来迎接他。其他时候，他们把手表分成简短的遗忘片段和不完全没有尖刻的对话，比如脚放在挡泥板上的戴德洛克小姐在获救时是否掉进了火里（令她非常不高兴）由她的守护天才女仆。

‘How is Sir Leicester now, Mr. George?’ inquires Volumnia, adjusting her cowl over her head.
“莱斯特爵士现在怎么样了，乔治先生？”沃伦妮娅一边问道，一边调整着头上的兜帽。

‘Why, Sir Leicester is much the same, miss. He is very low and ill, and he even wanders a little sometimes.’
“哎呀，莱斯特爵士也差不多，小姐。他的情绪非常低落，而且病得很重，有时甚至会走神。”

‘Has he asked for me?’ inquires Volumnia tenderly.
“他找过我吗？”沃伦尼亚温柔地问道。

‘Why, no, I can’t say he has, miss. Not within my hearing, that is to say.’
“为什么，不，我不能说他有，小姐。也就是说，不在我的听力范围内。

‘This is a truly sad time, Mr. George.’
“这真是一个悲伤的时刻，乔治先生。”

‘It is indeed, miss. Hadn’t you better go to bed?’
‘确实如此，小姐。你不是最好去睡觉吗？

‘You had a deal better go to bed, Miss Dedlock,’ quoth the maid sharply.
“戴德洛克小姐，你最好去睡觉，”女仆尖锐地说。

But Volumnia answers No! No! She may be asked for, she may be wanted at a moment’s notice. She never should forgive herself ‘if anything was to happen’ and she was not on the spot. She declines to enter on the question, mooted by the maid, how the spot comes to be there, and not in her room (which is nearer to Sir Leicester’s), but staunchly declares that on the spot she will remain. Volumnia further makes a merit of not having ‘closed an eye’—as if she had twenty or thirty—though it is hard to reconcile this statement with her having most indisputably opened two within five minutes.
但沃伦尼亚的回答是“不”！不！她可能会被要求，也可能会在接到通知后立即被通缉。 “如果发生任何事情”，她永远不应该原谅自己，而她又不在现场。她拒绝回答女仆提出的问题，即这个地点是如何出现在那里的，而不是在她的房间（离莱斯特爵士的房间更近），但坚定地宣称她将留在原地。沃伦尼娅还进一步指出，她没有“闭上一只眼睛”——就好像她有二十只或三十只眼睛一样——尽管很难将这一说法与她在五分钟内毫无争议地睁开两只眼睛相调和。

But when it comes to four o’clock, and still the same blank, Volumnia’s constancy begins to fail her, or rather it begins to strengthen, for she now considers that it is her duty to be ready for the morrow, when much may be expected of her, that, in fact, howsoever anxious to remain upon the spot, it may be required of her, as an act of self-devotion, to desert the spot. So when the trooper reappears with his, ‘Hadn’t you better go to bed, miss?’ and when the maid protests, more sharply than before, ‘You had a deal better go to bed, Miss Dedlock!’ she meekly rises and says, ‘Do with me what you think best!’
但是到了四点钟，仍然一片空白，沃伦尼娅的坚定不移开始让她失望，或者更确切地说，它开始加强，因为她现在认为她有责任为明天做好准备，因为明天可能会发生很多事情。事实上，无论她多么渴望留在原地，作为一种自我奉献的行为，她都可能需要离开原地。因此，当警察再次出现时，他问道：“小姐，你不应该去睡觉吗？”当女仆抗议得比以前更加尖锐时，“你最好去睡觉，戴德洛克小姐！”她温顺地站起来，说：“对我做你认为最好的事情！”

Mr. George undoubtedly thinks it best to escort her on his arm to the door of her cousinly chamber, and the maid as undoubtedly thinks it best to hustle her into bed with mighty little ceremony. Accordingly, these steps are taken; and now the trooper, in his rounds, has the house to himself.
乔治先生无疑认为最好是挽着她的胳膊护送她到她表弟的房间门口，而女仆无疑也认为最好以隆重的小仪式把她推到床上。因此，采取这些步骤；现在，巡查中的士兵已经拥有了这座房子。

There is no improvement in the weather. From the portico, from the eaves, from the parapet, from every ledge and post and pillar, drips the thawed snow. It has crept, as if for shelter, into the lintels of the great door—under it, into the corners of the windows, into every chink and crevice of retreat, and there wastes and dies. It is falling still; upon the roof, upon the skylight, even through the skylight, and drip, drip, drip, with the regularity of the Ghost’s Walk, on the stone floor below.
天气没有任何好转。从门廊、从屋檐、从护墙、从每一个壁架、柱子和柱子上，都滴着融化的雪。它就像是为了避难所一样，爬进了大门的门楣——门下，爬进了窗角，爬进了每一个退路的缝隙和缝隙，在那里浪费和死亡。它静止不动；在屋顶上，在天窗上，甚至透过天窗，滴，滴，滴，按照幽灵行走的规律，滴在下面的石头地板上。

The trooper, his old recollections awakened by the solitary grandeur of a great house—no novelty to him once at Chesney Wold— goes up the stairs and through the chief rooms, holding up his light at arm’s length. Thinking of his varied fortunes within the last few weeks, and of his rustic boyhood, and of the two periods of his life so strangely brought together across the wide intermediate space; thinking of the murdered man whose image is fresh in his mind; thinking of the lady who has disappeared from these very rooms and the tokens of whose recent presence are all here; thinking of the master of the house upstairs and of the foreboding, ‘Who will tell him!’ he looks here and looks there, and reflects how he MIGHT see something now, which it would tax his boldness to walk up to, lay his hand upon, and prove to be a fancy. But it is all blank, blank as the darkness above and below, while he goes up the great staircase again, blank as the oppressive silence.
士兵的旧回忆被一座宏伟的大房子唤醒了——在切斯尼沃尔德对他来说这并不新鲜——走上楼梯，穿过主要房间，举起手电筒，与他保持一臂距离。想到他在过去几周内的不同命运，想到他质朴的童年，想到他生命中的两个时期如此奇怪地跨越广阔的中间空间聚集在一起；想起那个被谋杀的人，他的形象还历历在目；想起那位从这些房间里消失的女士，以及她最近出现的痕迹都在这里；想到楼上的主人，想到不祥的预感，“谁会告诉他！”他看看这里，看看那里，思考着他现在可能会看到什么东西，这会考验他的勇气，他把手放下了。并被证明是一种幻想。但一切都是空白的，空白的就像上面和下面的黑暗一样，而当他再次走上大楼梯时，空白的就像令人压抑的沉默。

‘All is still in readiness, George Rouncewell?’
“一切都准备好了，乔治·朗斯韦尔？”

‘Quite orderly and right, Sir Leicester.’
“非常有秩序，也很正确，莱斯特爵士。”

‘No word of any kind?’
“没有任何消息吗？”

The trooper shakes his head.
士兵摇摇头。

‘No letter that can possibly have been overlooked?’
“没有一封信可能被忽视吗？”

But he knows there is no such hope as that and lays his head down without looking for an answer.
但他知道没有这样的希望，于是低下了头，没有寻求答案。

Very familiar to him, as he said himself some hours ago, George Rouncewell lifts him into easier positions through the long remainder of the blank wintry night, and equally familiar with his unexpressed wish, extinguishes the light and undraws the curtains at the first late break of day. The day comes like a phantom. Cold, colourless, and vague, it sends a warning streak before it of a deathlike hue, as if it cried out, ‘Look what I am bringing you who watch there! Who will tell him!’
正如几个小时前他自己所说的那样，乔治·朗斯韦尔对他来说非常熟悉，在漫长的冬夜里，乔治·朗斯韦尔把他抬到更容易的位置，同样熟悉他未表达的愿望，在第一次晚间休息时熄灭灯光并拉开窗帘。的一天。这一天像幻影一样来临。冰冷、无色、模糊，它在它面前发出一道死一般的警告，仿佛在呼喊：“看看我给你带来了什么！”谁来告诉他！

CHAPTER LIX
第十九章


Esther’s Narrative
以斯帖的叙述

It was three o’clock in the morning when the houses outside London did at last begin to exclude the country and to close us in with streets. We had made our way along roads in a far worse condition than when we had traversed them by daylight, both the fall and the thaw having lasted ever since; but the energy of my companion never slackened. It had only been, as I thought, of less assistance than the horses in getting us on, and it had often aided them. They had stopped exhausted halfway up hills, they had been driven through streams of turbulent water, they had slipped down and become entangled with the harness; but he and his little lantern had been always ready, and when the mishap was set right, I had never heard any variation in his cool, ‘Get on, my lads!’
凌晨三点钟，伦敦郊外的房屋终于开始将乡村拒之门外，并用街道将我们封闭起来。我们沿着道路前行，路况比我们白天走过时要糟糕得多，从那时起，秋天和解冻就一直持续着。但我同伴的精力却从未减弱。正如我所想，它在让我们上车方面的帮助不如马匹，但它却经常帮助他们。他们在半山腰时筋疲力尽地停下来，他们被赶过汹涌的水流，他们滑倒并被挽具缠住；但他和他的小灯笼一直准备着，当事故得到纠正时，我从未听到他的冷静有任何变化，“加油，我的小伙子们！”

The steadiness and confidence with which he had directed our journey back I could not account for. Never wavering, he never even stopped to make an inquiry until we were within a few miles of London. A very few words, here and there, were then enough for him; and thus we came, at between three and four o’clock in the morning, into Islington.
我无法解释他在带领我们返程时表现出的坚定和自信。他毫不犹豫，甚至从未停下来询问，直到我们到达距离伦敦几英里的地方。对他来说，时不时说几句话就足够了。就这样，我们在凌晨三点到四点之间到达了伊斯灵顿。

I will not dwell on the suspense and anxiety with which I reflected all this time that we were leaving my mother farther and farther behind every minute. I think I had some strong hope that he must be right and could not fail to have a satisfactory object in following this woman, but I tormented myself with questioning it and discussing it during the whole journey. What was to ensue when we found her and what could compensate us for this loss of time were questions also that I could not possibly dismiss; my mind was quite tortured by long dwelling on such reflections when we stopped.
我不会详述我一直以来的悬念和焦虑，因为我们每一分钟都把母亲抛在身后越来越远。我想我有一种强烈的希望，他一定是对的，跟踪这个女人不可能没有一个令人满意的目标，但在整个旅程中我一直在质疑和讨论中折磨着自己。当我们找到她时会发生什么，以及什么可以补偿我们所损失的时间，这些也是我无法忽视的问题；当我们停下来时，我的心因长时间思考这些想法而受到折磨。

We stopped in a high-street where there was a coach-stand. My companion paid our two drivers, who were as completely covered with splashes as if they had been dragged along the roads like the carriage itself, and giving them some brief direction where to take it, lifted me out of it and into a hackney-coach he had chosen from the rest.
我们在一条大街上停了下来，那里有一个马车停靠站。我的同伴付钱给我们的两个司机，他们浑身溅满了水花，就好像他们像马车一样被拖过马路，并给了他们一些简短的指示，然后把我从车里抱起来，上了一辆出租马车。他是从其他人中选择的。

‘Why, my dear!’ he said as he did this. ‘How wet you are!’
“为什么，亲爱的！”他边说边这样做。 “你多湿啊！”

I had not been conscious of it. But the melted snow had found its way into the carriage, and I had got out two or three times when a fallen horse was plunging and had to be got up, and the wet had penetrated my dress. I assured him it was no matter, but the driver, who knew him, would not be dissuaded by me from running down the street to his stable, whence he brought an armful of clean dry straw. They shook it out and strewed it well about me, and I found it warm and comfortable.
我并没有意识到这一点。但融化的雪已经进入了马车，我下了两三次，一匹摔倒的马摔倒了，不得不站起来，湿透了我的衣服。我向他保证没关系，但认识他的司机不会被我劝阻，沿着街道跑到他的马厩，从那里他带来了一抱干净的干稻草。他们把它抖出来，撒在我身上，我觉得温暖又舒服。

‘Now, my dear,’ said Mr. Bucket, with his head in at the window after I was shut up. ‘We’re a-going to mark this person down. It may take a little time, but you don’t mind that. You’re pretty sure that I’ve got a motive. Ain’t you?’
“现在，亲爱的，”我被关起来后，巴克特先生把头探进窗户说道。 “我们要把这个人记下来。这可能需要一点时间，但你不介意。你很确定我有动机。你不是吗？

I little thought what it was, little thought in how short a time I should understand it better, but I assured him that I had confidence in him.
我几乎没有想到那是什么，也没有想到在多短的时间内我应该更好地理解它，但我向他保证我对他有信心。

‘So you may have, my dear,’ he returned. ‘And I tell you what! If you only repose half as much confidence in me as I repose in you after what I’ve experienced of you, that’ll do. Lord! You’re no trouble at all. I never see a young woman in any station of society—and I’ve seen many elevated ones too—conduct herself like you have conducted yourself since you was called out of your bed. You’re a pattern, you know, that’s what you are,’ said Mr. Bucket warmly; ‘you’re a pattern.’
“所以你可能有，亲爱的，”他回答道。 ‘我告诉你什么！在我经历过你之后，如果你对我的信心只有我对你的信心的一半，那就行了。主！你一点也不麻烦。我从来没有见过任何社会阶层的年轻女性——我也见过很多地位较高的女性——表现得像你被叫下床后的表现一样。 “你是一个榜样，你知道，你就是这样。”巴克特先生热情地说。 “你是一个典范。”

I told him I was very glad, as indeed I was, to have been no hindrance to him, and that I hoped I should be none now.
我告诉他，我很高兴，事实上我也确实如此，没有成为他的障碍，我希望我现在不会成为任何障碍。

‘My dear,’ he returned, ‘when a young lady is as mild as she’s game, and as game as she’s mild, that’s all I ask, and more than I expect. She then becomes a queen, and that’s about what you are yourself.’
“亲爱的，”他回答道，“当一位年轻女士既温和又活泼，又活泼又温和时，这就是我所要求的，而且比我期望的还要多。然后她成为女王，这就是你自己。”

With these encouraging words—they really were encouraging to me under those lonely and anxious circumstances—he got upon the box, and we once more drove away. Where we drove I neither knew then nor have ever known since, but we appeared to seek out the narrowest and worst streets in London. Whenever I saw him directing the driver, I was prepared for our descending into a deeper complication of such streets, and we never failed to do so.
他说完这句鼓励的话——在孤独焦虑的情况下对我来说确实是一种鼓励——上了车，我们再次开车离开了。我们当时不知道我们开车去哪里，从那以后我也不知道，但我们似乎在寻找伦敦最狭窄、最糟糕的街道。每当我看到他在指挥司机时，我就做好了进入更复杂的街道的准备，而且我们从来没有失败过。

Sometimes we emerged upon a wider thoroughfare or came to a larger building than the generality, well lighted. Then we stopped at offices like those we had visited when we began our journey, and I saw him in consultation with others. Sometimes he would get down by an archway or at a street corner and mysteriously show the light of his little lantern. This would attract similar lights from various dark quarters, like so many insects, and a fresh consultation would be held. By degrees we appeared to contract our search within narrower and easier limits. Single police-officers on duty could now tell Mr. Bucket what he wanted to know and point to him where to go. At last we stopped for a rather long conversation between him and one of these men, which I supposed to be satisfactory from his manner of nodding from time to time. When it was finished he came to me looking very busy and very attentive.
有时我们会出现在一条更宽阔的大道上，或者来到一栋比一般情况更大、光线充足的建筑物前。然后我们在我们开始旅程时参观过的办公室停下来，我看到他正在与其他人协商。有时他会走到拱门或街角，神秘地展示他的小灯笼的光芒。这会吸引来自各个黑暗角落的类似灯光，就像许多昆虫一样，并且将举行新的磋商。渐渐地，我们似乎将我们的搜索范围缩小到了更窄、更容易的范围内。值班的单身警察现在可以告诉巴克特先生他想知道什么，并指出他该去哪里。最后，我们停下来，他和其中一个人进行了相当长的交谈，从他不时点头的方式来看，我认为这很令人满意。结束后，他来到我身边，看上去很忙碌，也很专心。

‘Now, Miss Summerson, he said to me, ‘you won’t be alarmed whatever comes off, I know. It’s not necessary for me to give you any further caution than to tell you that we have marked this person down and that you may be of use to me before I know it myself. I don’t like to ask such a thing, my dear, but would you walk a little way?’
“现在，萨默森小姐，他对我说，‘我知道，无论发生什么，你都不会感到惊慌。我没有必要给你任何进一步的警告，只是告诉你我们已经标记了这个人，并且在我自己意识到之前你可能对我有用。我不想问这样的问题，亲爱的，但是你能走远一点吗？

Of course I got out directly and took his arm.
我当然是直接下车拉住他的手臂。

‘It ain’t so easy to keep your feet,’ said Mr. Bucket, ‘but take time.’
“保持稳定并不是那么容易，”巴克特先生说，“但是需要时间。”

Although I looked about me confusedly and hurriedly as we crossed the street, I thought I knew the place. ‘Are we in Holborn?’ I asked him.
虽然过马路时我困惑而匆忙地环顾四周，但我想我知道那个地方。 “我们在霍尔本吗？”我问他。

‘Yes,’ said Mr. Bucket. ‘Do you know this turning?’
“是的，”巴克特先生说。 “你知道这个转弯吗？”

‘It looks like Chancery Lane.’
“它看起来像大法官巷。”

‘And was christened so, my dear,’ said Mr. Bucket.
“亲爱的，它就是这么命名的，”巴克特先生说。

We turned down it, and as we went shuffling through the sleet, I heard the clocks strike half-past five. We passed on in silence and as quickly as we could with such a foothold, when some one coming towards us on the narrow pavement, wrapped in a cloak, stopped and stood aside to give me room. In the same moment I heard an exclamation of wonder and my own name from Mr. Woodcourt. I knew his voice very well.
我们拒绝了它，当我们拖着脚步穿过雨夹雪时，我听到时钟敲响了五点半。我们默默地、尽可能快地站稳脚跟，继续前行，这时，狭窄的人行道上，一个裹着斗篷的人向我们走来，停下来，站在一旁给我让出空间。与此同时，我听到伍德考特先生发出一声惊叹和我自己的名字。我很熟悉他的声音。

It was so unexpected and so—I don’t know what to call it, whether pleasant or painful—to come upon it after my feverish wandering journey, and in the midst of the night, that I could not keep back the tears from my eyes. It was like hearing his voice in a strange country.
在我狂热的流浪之旅之后，在半夜里，我不知道该怎么称呼它，是愉快的还是痛苦的，这真是太出乎意料了，我忍不住流下了眼泪。眼睛。就像在一个陌生的国家听到他的声音一样。

‘My dear Miss Summerson, that you should be out at this hour, and in such weather!’
“我亲爱的萨默森小姐，在这样的天气里，你应该在这个时间出去！”

He had heard from my guardian of my having been called away on some uncommon business and said so to dispense with any explanation. I told him that we had but just left a coach and were going—but then I was obliged to look at my companion.
他从我的监护人那里听说我因一些不寻常的事情而被叫走，所以他没有做任何解释。我告诉他我们刚刚离开了一辆教练并且要走了——但随后我不得不看看我的同伴。

‘Why, you see, Mr. Woodcourt’—he had caught the name from me—‘we are a-going at present into the next street. Inspector Bucket.’
“哎呀，你看，伍德考特先生”——他从我嘴里听到了这个名字——“我们现在正要去下一条街。桶督察。”

Mr. Woodcourt, disregarding my remonstrances, had hurriedly taken off his cloak and was putting it about me. ‘That’s a good move, too,’ said Mr. Bucket, assisting, ‘a very good move.’
伍德考特先生不顾我的抗议，急忙脱下斗篷，给我披上。 “这也是一个很好的举措，”巴克特先生帮忙说道，“非常好的举措。”

‘May I go with you?’ said Mr. Woodcourt. I don’t know whether to me or to my companion.
“我可以和你一起去吗？”伍德考特先生说。我不知道是对我自己还是对我的同伴。

‘Why, Lord!’ exclaimed Mr. Bucket, taking the answer on himself. ‘Of course you may.’
“为什么，主啊！”巴克特先生大声说道，他自己也得到了答案。 “当然可以。”

It was all said in a moment, and they took me between them, wrapped in the cloak.
一切都在一瞬间说完，他们把我裹在斗篷里夹在他们中间。

‘I have just left Richard,’ said Mr. Woodcourt. ‘I have been sitting with him since ten o’clock last night.’
“我刚刚离开理查德，”伍德考特先生说。 “从昨晚十点开始我就一直和他坐在一起。”

‘Oh, dear me, he is ill!’
“哦，天哪，他病了！”

‘No, no, believe me; not ill, but not quite well. He was depressed and faint—you know he gets so worried and so worn sometimes—and Ada sent to me of course; and when I came home I found her note and came straight here. Well! Richard revived so much after a little while, and Ada was so happy and so convinced of its being my doing, though God knows I had little enough to do with it, that I remained with him until he had been fast asleep some hours. As fast asleep as she is now, I hope!’
‘不，不，相信我；没病，但不太好。他情绪低落、虚弱——你知道他有时会如此担心、如此疲惫——当然，艾达派给了我；当我回到家时，我发现了她的字条，就直接来到了这里。出色地！过了一会儿，理查德就苏醒了很多，艾达非常高兴，也非常确信这是我做的，尽管上帝知道我与这件事无关，所以我一直陪着他，直到他睡了几个小时。我希望她能像现在一样熟睡！”

His friendly and familiar way of speaking of them, his unaffected devotion to them, the grateful confidence with which I knew he had inspired my darling, and the comfort he was to her; could I separate all this from his promise to me? How thankless I must have been if it had not recalled the words he said to me when he was so moved by the change in my appearance: ‘I will accept him as a trust, and it shall be a sacred one!’
他对他们的友善和熟悉的谈论方式，他对他们不做作的忠诚，我知道他激发了我亲爱的感激的信心，以及他对她的安慰;我能把这一切与他对我的承诺分开吗？如果没有想起他被我外表的变化所感动时对我说的话：“我将接受他作为一种信任，这将是一种神圣的信任！”，我该是多么感激不尽啊！

We now turned into another narrow street. ‘Mr. Woodcourt,’ said Mr. Bucket, who had eyed him closely as we came along, ‘our business takes us to a law-stationer’s here, a certain Mr. Snagsby’s. What, you know him, do you?’ He was so quick that he saw it in an instant.
我们现在拐进了另一条狭窄的街道。 '先生。 “伍德考特，”我们走过时，巴克特先生一直密切地注视着他，说道，“我们的生意把我们带到了这里的一个律师事务所，就是斯纳格斯比先生的律师事务所。什么，你认识他吧？”他动作很快，一瞬间就看出来了。

‘Yes, I know a little of him and have called upon him at this place.’
“是的，我对他有一点了解，并且曾到过这个地方拜访过他。”

‘Indeed, sir?’ said Mr. Bucket. ‘Then you will be so good as to let me leave Miss Summerson with you for a moment while I go and have half a word with him?’
“真的吗，先生？”巴克特先生说。 “那你能不能让我把萨默森小姐留在你身边，我去和他说半句话？”

The last police-officer with whom he had conferred was standing silently behind us. I was not aware of it until he struck in on my saying I heard some one crying.
与他交谈的最后一位警察静静地站在我们身后。直到他插嘴说我听到有人在哭，我才意识到这一点。

‘Don’t be alarmed, miss,’ he returned. ‘It’s Snagsby’s servant.’
“别惊慌，小姐，”他回答道。 “这是斯纳斯比的仆人。”

‘Why, you see,’ said Mr. Bucket, ‘the girl’s subject to fits, and has ‘em bad upon her to-night. A most contrary circumstance it is, for I want certain information out of that girl, and she must be brought to reason somehow.’
“哎呀，你看，”巴克特先生说，“这个女孩很容易抽搐，今晚她的症状很糟糕。”这是一个最相反的情况，因为我想从那个女孩那里得到某些信息，而且必须以某种方式让她明白道理。

‘At all events, they wouldn’t be up yet if it wasn’t for her, Mr. Bucket,’ said the other man. ‘She’s been at it pretty well all night, sir.’
“无论如何，如果没有她，他们还不会起床，巴克特先生，”另一个人说道。 “她整个晚上都表现得很好，先生。”

‘Well, that’s true,’ he returned. ‘My light’s burnt out. Show yours a moment.’
“嗯，确实如此，”他回答道。 ‘我的灯烧坏了。展示一下你的。

All this passed in a whisper a door or two from the house in which I could faintly hear crying and moaning. In the little round of light produced for the purpose, Mr. Bucket went up to the door and knocked. The door was opened after he had knocked twice, and he went in, leaving us standing in the street.
这一切都在离房子一两扇门的地方悄悄过去，我隐约能听到里面的哭声和呻吟声。在为此目的而产生的小圆光中，巴克特先生走到门前敲了敲门。他敲了两下门，门开了，他走了进去，留下我们站在街上。

‘Miss Summerson,’ said Mr. Woodcourt, ‘if without obtruding myself on your confidence I may remain near you, pray let me do so.’
“萨默森小姐，”伍德考特先生说，“如果不妨碍您对我的信任，我可以留在您身边，请让我这样做。”

‘You are truly kind,’ I answered. ‘I need wish to keep no secret of my own from you; if I keep any, it is another’s.’
“你真的很善良，”我回答道。 “我不想对你隐瞒我自己的秘密；如果我保留任何东西，那也是别人的。”

‘I quite understand. Trust me, I will remain near you only so long as I can fully respect it.’
‘我很明白。相信我，只要我完全尊重你，我就会留在你身边。

‘I trust implicitly to you,’ I said. ‘I know and deeply feel how sacredly you keep your promise.
“我绝对信任你，”我说。 “我知道并且深深地感受到你是多么神圣地信守诺言。

After a short time the little round of light shone out again, and Mr. Bucket advanced towards us in it with his earnest face. ‘Please to come in, Miss Summerson,’ he said, ‘and sit down by the fire. Mr. Woodcourt, from information I have received I understand you are a medical man. Would you look to this girl and see if anything can be done to bring her round. She has a letter somewhere that I particularly want. It’s not in her box, and I think it must be about her; but she is so twisted and clenched up that she is difficult to handle without hurting.’
过了一会儿，那道小光又亮了，巴克特先生驾着光向我们走来，一脸诚恳。 “请进来，萨默森小姐，”他说，“坐在火边。”伍德考特先生，根据我收到的信息，我了解到您是一名医生。你能不能看看这个女孩，看看能不能做点什么让她苏醒。她在某个地方有一封我特别想要的信。它不在她的盒子里，我想这一定是关于她的；但她是如此扭曲和紧握，很难在不受伤的情况下处理她。

We all three went into the house together; although it was cold and raw, it smelt close too from being up all night. In the passage behind the door stood a scared, sorrowful-looking little man in a grey coat who seemed to have a naturally polite manner and spoke meekly.
我们三个一起进了屋子。尽管天气又冷又生，但由于整夜未睡，闻起来也很接近。门后的过道里站着一个穿着灰色大衣的小个子男人，神情惊恐悲伤，看上去彬彬有礼，说话也很温顺。

‘Downstairs, if you please, Mr. Bucket,’ said he. ‘The lady will excuse the front kitchen; we use it as our workaday sitting-room. The back is Guster’s bedroom, and in it she’s a-carrying on, poor thing, to a frightful extent!’
“请到楼下吧，巴克特先生，”他说。 “这位女士请原谅前厨房；我们用它作为我们的工作客厅。后面是古斯特的卧室，她在里面胡闹，可怜的东西，到了可怕的程度！

We went downstairs, followed by Mr. Snagsby, as I soon found the little man to be. In the front kitchen, sitting by the fire, was Mrs. Snagsby, with very red eyes and a very severe expression of face.
我们下了楼，斯纳斯比先生跟在后面，我很快就发现了这个小个子男人。斯纳斯比太太坐在前厨房的火边，她的眼睛非常红，脸上的表情非常严肃。

‘My little woman,’ said Mr. Snagsby, entering behind us, ‘to wave— not to put too fine a point upon it, my dear—hostilities for one single moment in the course of this prolonged night, here is Inspector Bucket, Mr. Woodcourt, and a lady.’
“我的小女人，”斯纳斯比先生走进我们身后说道，“在这漫长的夜晚里，挥手——不要过分强调这一点，亲爱的——在这漫长的夜晚中，只有一刻的敌对行动，这是巴克特督察，伍德考特先生和一位女士。

She looked very much astonished, as she had reason for doing, and looked particularly hard at me.
她看起来非常惊讶，这是她有理由这样做的，并且特别用力地看着我。

‘My little woman,’ said Mr. Snagsby, sitting down in the remotest corner by the door, as if he were taking a liberty, ‘it is not unlikely that you may inquire of me why Inspector Bucket, Mr. Woodcourt, and a lady call upon us in Cook’s Court, Cursitor Street, at the present hour. I don’t know. I have not the least idea. If I was to be informed, I should despair of understanding, and I’d rather not be told.’
“我的小女人，”斯纳格斯比先生说，他坐在门边最偏僻的角落里，仿佛是在冒昧，“你可能会问我为什么巴克特督察、伍德考特先生和一个女士现在正在库西托街的库克法院拜访我们。我不知道。我一点也不知道。如果我要被告知，我就会对理解感到绝望，而且我宁愿不被告知。

He appeared so miserable, sitting with his head upon his hand, and I appeared so unwelcome, that I was going to offer an apology when Mr. Bucket took the matter on himself.
他用手托着头坐着，看上去很痛苦，而我则显得很不受欢迎，当巴克特先生亲自处理这件事时，我正要道歉。

‘Now, Mr. Snagsby,’ said he, ‘the best thing you can do is to go along with Mr. Woodcourt to look after your Guster—‘
“现在，斯纳格斯比先生，”他说，“你能做的最好的事情就是和伍德考特先生一起去照顾你的古斯特——”

‘My Guster, Mr. Bucket!’ cried Mr. Snagsby. ‘Go on, sir, go on. I shall be charged with that next.’
“我的古斯特，巴克特先生！”斯纳斯比先生喊道。 ‘继续吧，先生，继续吧。接下来我将受到指控。

‘And to hold the candle,’ pursued Mr. Bucket without correcting himself, ‘or hold her, or make yourself useful in any way you’re asked. Which there’s not a man alive more ready to do, for you’re a man of urbanity and suavity, you know, and you’ve got the sort of heart that can feel for another. Mr. Woodcourt, would you be so good as see to her, and if you can get that letter from her, to let me have it as soon as ever you can?’
“并且要举起蜡烛，”巴克特先生没有纠正自己，继续说道，“或者抱住她，或者以任何你被要求的方式让自己变得有用。”没有一个人比你更愿意这样做，因为你是一个彬彬有礼、温文尔雅的人，你知道，而且你有一颗能够同情他人的心。伍德考特先生，您能帮我照顾一下她吗？如果您能从她那里得到那封信，请尽快让我收到？

As they went out, Mr. Bucket made me sit down in a corner by the fire and take off my wet shoes, which he turned up to dry upon the fender, talking all the time.
当他们出去时，巴克特先生让我坐在火边的一个角落里，脱掉湿鞋，然后把鞋翻到挡泥板上晾干，一直在说话。

‘Don’t you be at all put out, miss, by the want of a hospitable look from Mrs. Snagsby there, because she’s under a mistake altogether. She’ll find that out sooner than will be agreeable to a lady of her generally correct manner of forming her thoughts, because I’m a-going to explain it to her.’ Here, standing on the hearth with his wet hat and shawls in his hand, himself a pile of wet, he turned to Mrs. Snagsby. ‘Now, the first thing that I say to you, as a married woman possessing what you may call charms, you know—‘Believe Me, if All Those Endearing,’ and cetrer—you’re well acquainted with the song, because it’s in vain for you to tell me that you and good society are strangers—charms—attractions, mind you, that ought to give you confidence in yourself—is, that you’ve done it.’
“小姐，你别因为斯纳斯比夫人热情好客的目光而感到沮丧，因为她完全犯了一个错误。她会比一位女士更早地发现这一点，因为她通常会以正确的方式形成自己的想法，因为我要向她解释这一点。”在这里，戴着湿帽子和披肩站在壁炉上他手里拿着一堆湿漉漉的东西，他转向斯纳斯比太太。 “现在，我对你说的第一件事，作为一个拥有你所谓的魅力的已婚女人，你知道——‘相信我，如果所有那些可爱的’等等——你很熟悉这首歌，因为它是你告诉我你和上流社会是陌生人——魅力——吸引力，请注意，这应该让你对自己充满信心——是徒劳的，但你已经做到了。

Mrs. Snagsby looked rather alarmed, relented a little and faltered, what did Mr. Bucket mean.
斯纳斯比夫人看起来相当惊慌，态度稍稍缓和了一些，支吾着，巴克特先生的意思是什么？

‘What does Mr. Bucket mean?’ he repeated, and I saw by his face that all the time he talked he was listening for the discovery of the letter, to my own great agitation, for I knew then how important it must be; ‘I’ll tell you what he means, ma’am. Go and see Othello acted. That’s the tragedy for you.’
“巴克特先生是什么意思？”他重复道，我从他的脸上看出，他说话的所有时间里，他都在倾听这封信的发现，我自己也非常激动，因为我当时就知道这封信一定有多么重要；但是，我知道这封信的重要性。 “我会告诉你他的意思，女士。去看奥赛罗的表演。这就是你的悲剧。

Mrs. Snagsby consciously asked why.
斯纳斯比夫人有意识地问为什么。

‘Why?’ said Mr. Bucket. ‘Because you’ll come to that if you don’t look out. Why, at the very moment while I speak, I know what your mind’s not wholly free from respecting this young lady. But shall I tell you who this young lady is? Now, come, you’re what I call an intellectual woman—with your soul too large for your body, if you come to that, and chafing it—and you know me, and you recollect where you saw me last, and what was talked of in that circle. Don’t you? Yes! Very well. This young lady is that young lady.’
“为什么？”巴克特先生说。 ‘因为如果你不留心的话，你就会陷入这样的境地。为什么，就在我说话的那一刻，我知道你心里还没有完全摆脱对这位年轻女士的尊重。但我要告诉你这位年轻女士是谁吗？现在，来吧，你就是我所说的知识分子女人——你的灵魂对于你的身体来说太大了，如果你到了那一步，并摩擦它——你认识我，你记得最后一次见到我的地方，以及我的经历。那个圈子里议论纷纷。你不是吗？是的！很好。这位年轻女士就是那位年轻女士。

Mrs. Snagsby appeared to understand the reference better than I did at the time.
斯纳格斯比夫人当时似乎比我更能理解这个参考资料。

‘And Toughey—him as you call Jo—was mixed up in the same business, and no other; and the law-writer that you know of was mixed up in the same business, and no other; and your husband, with no more knowledge of it than your great grandfather, was mixed up (by Mr. Tulkinghorn, deceased, his best customer) in the same business, and no other; and the whole bileing of people was mixed up in the same business, and no other. And yet a married woman, possessing your attractions, shuts her eyes (and sparklers too), and goes and runs her delicate-formed head against a wall. Why, I am ashamed of you! (I expected Mr. Woodcourt might have got it by this time.)’
“而托伊——你们称呼他为乔——也卷入了同一件事，除此之外没有别的事；你所认识的那位法律作家也从事同一行业，而不是其他行业。而你的丈夫，对这方面的了解并不比你的曾祖父多，他（已故的图尔金霍恩先生，他最好的客户）也参与了同一行，而不是其他行。人们的所有愤怒都集中在同一件事上，而不是其他事情。然而，一个已婚女人，拥有你的吸引力，闭上眼睛（也闭上眼睛），然后把她精致的头靠在墙上。为什么，我为你感到羞耻！ （我预计伍德考特先生此时可能已经明白了。）

Mrs. Snagsby shook her head and put her handkerchief to her eyes.
斯纳斯比太太摇摇头，用手帕捂住眼睛。

‘Is that all?’ said Mr. Bucket excitedly. ‘No. See what happens. Another person mixed up in that business and no other, a person in a wretched state, comes here to-night and is seen a-speaking to your maid-servant; and between her and your maid-servant there passes a paper that I would give a hundred pound for, down. What do you do? You hide and you watch ‘em, and you pounce upon that maid-servant—knowing what she’s subject to and what a little thing will bring ‘em on—in that surprising manner and with that severity that, by the Lord, she goes off and keeps off, when a life may be hanging upon that girl’s words!’
“就这些了吗？”巴克特先生兴奋地说。 '不。走着瞧吧。另一个人卷入了这件事，而不是其他人，一个处于悲惨状态的人，今晚来到这里，被发现正在和你的女仆说话；她和你的女仆之间夹着一张纸，我愿出一百英镑买下。你做什么工作？你躲起来，看着他们，你扑向那个女仆——知道她会遭受什么，也知道一件小事会给他们带来什么——以那种令人惊讶的方式和严厉的方式，主啊，她走了当那个女孩的话可能会危及生命时，请远离！

He so thoroughly meant what he said now that I involuntarily clasped my hands and felt the room turning away from me. But it stopped. Mr. Woodcourt came in, put a paper into his hand, and went away again.
他现在所说的话是如此的认真，以至于我不由自主地握紧了双手，感觉整个房间都在远离我。但它停了下来。伍德考特先生进来了，把一张纸塞到手里，然后又走了。

‘Now, Mrs, Snagsby, the only amends you can make,’ said Mr. Bucket, rapidly glancing at it, ‘is to let me speak a word to this young lady in private here. And if you know of any help that you can give to that gentleman in the next kitchen there or can think of any one thing that’s likelier than another to bring the girl round, do your swiftest and best!’ In an instant she was gone, and he had shut the door. ‘Now my dear, you’re steady and quite sure of yourself?’
“现在，斯纳格斯比夫人，您唯一能做出的补偿，”巴克特先生迅速扫了一眼，说道，“就是让我私下在这里跟这位年轻女士说句话。”如果你知道可以为隔壁厨房里的那位先生提供任何帮助，或者能想到任何一件事比另一件事更有可能让女孩苏醒，请尽你最大的努力！” 转眼间，她就走了，他已经关上了门。 “亲爱的，你现在已经稳定了，对自己很有信心了吗？”

‘Quite,’ said I.
“确实如此，”我说。

‘Whose writing is that?’
“那是谁写的？”

It was my mother’s. A pencil-writing, on a crushed and torn piece of paper, blotted with wet. Folded roughly like a letter, and directed to me at my guardian’s.
这是我母亲的。一张用铅笔写的字，写在一张被压碎、撕破的纸上，上面沾满了湿气。像一封信一样粗略地折叠起来，指向我的监护人。

‘You know the hand,’ he said, ‘and if you are firm enough to read it to me, do! But be particular to a word.’
“你认识这手牌，”他说，“如果你足够坚定，愿意读给我听，那就读吧！”但要特别注意一个词。

It had been written in portions, at different times. I read what follows:
它是在不同时间分部分写成的。我读了以下内容：

‘I came to the cottage with two objects. First, to see the dear one, if I could, once more—but only to see her—not to speak to her or let her know that I was near. The other object, to elude pursuit and to be lost. Do not blame the mother for her share. The assistance that she rendered me, she rendered on my strongest assurance that it was for the dear one’s good. You remember her dead child. The men’s consent I bought, but her help was freely given.’
“我带着两件东西来到小屋。首先，如果可以的话，再次见到亲爱的人——但只是见她——而不是和她说话或让她知道我就在附近。另一个目的是逃避追捕并迷失方向。不要责怪母亲的份额。她向我提供的帮助，是为了我亲爱的人的利益而提供的。你记得她死去的孩子。我买了男人的同意，但她的帮助是无偿的。

‘‘I came.’ That was written,’ said my companion, ‘when she rested there. It bears out what I made of it. I was right.’
“我来了。”我的同伴说，“当她在那里休息时，上面写着。”它证实了我的想法。我是对的。'

The next was written at another time:
下一篇是在另一个时间写的：

‘I have wandered a long distance, and for many hours, and I know that I must soon die. These streets! I have no purpose but to die. When I left, I had a worse, but I am saved from adding that guilt to the rest. Cold, wet, and fatigue are sufficient causes for my being found dead, but I shall die of others, though I suffer from these. It was right that all that had sustained me should give way at once and that I should die of terror and my conscience.
“我已经流浪了很长一段距离，而且已经走了好几个小时，我知道我很快就会死去。这些街道！我没有任何目的，除了死。当我离开时，我的情况变得更糟，但我免于将这种负罪感添加到其他事情中。寒冷、潮湿和疲劳足以导致我死亡，但我会死于其他人，尽管我患有这些。支撑我的一切都应该立刻消失，我应该死于恐惧和良心，这是正确的。

‘Take courage,’ said Mr. Bucket. ‘There’s only a few words more.’
“鼓起勇气，”巴克特先生说。 “只剩下几句话了。”

Those, too, were written at another time. To all appearance, almost in the dark:
这些也是在另一个时间写的。从表面上看，几乎是在黑暗中：

‘I have done all I could do to be lost. I shall be soon forgotten so, and shall disgrace him least. I have nothing about me by which I can be recognized. This paper I part with now. The place where I shall lie down, if I can get so far, has been often in my mind. Farewell. Forgive.’
‘为了迷失，我已竭尽全力。我很快就会被遗忘，也不会令他蒙羞。我没有任何可以让别人认出我的东西。我现在放弃这篇论文。如果我能走得这么远，我应该躺下的地方常常在我的脑海里。告别。原谅。'

Mr. Bucket, supporting me with his arm, lowered me gently into my chair. ‘Cheer up! Don’t think me hard with you, my dear, but as soon as ever you feel equal to it, get your shoes on and be ready.’
巴克特先生用手臂支撑着我，轻轻地将我放到椅子上。 '开心点！别以为我对你很严厉，亲爱的，但一旦你觉得自己可以承受，就穿上鞋子做好准备。

I did as he required, but I was left there a long time, praying for my unhappy mother. They were all occupied with the poor girl, and I heard Mr. Woodcourt directing them and speaking to her often. At length he came in with Mr. Bucket and said that as it was important to address her gently, he thought it best that I should ask her for whatever information we desired to obtain. There was no doubt that she could now reply to questions if she were soothed and not alarmed. The questions, Mr. Bucket said, were how she came by the letter, what passed between her and the person who gave her the letter, and where the person went. Holding my mind as steadily as I could to these points, I went into the next room with them. Mr. Woodcourt would have remained outside, but at my solicitation went in with us.
我按照他的要求做了，但我被留在那里很长一段时间，为我不幸的母亲祈祷。他们都忙着照顾这个可怜的女孩，我听到伍德考特先生经常指挥他们并与她说话。最后，他和巴克特先生一起进来，说因为温柔地对待她很重要，所以他认为我最好向她询问我们想要获得的任何信息。毫无疑问，如果她得到安抚而不惊慌，她现在可以回答问题了。巴克特说，问题是她是如何收到这封信的，她和给她信的人之间传递了什么，以及这个人去了哪里。我尽可能稳定地思考这些问题，然后和他们一起走进了隔壁的房间。伍德考特先生本来应该留在外面，但在我的恳求下和我们一起进去了。

The poor girl was sitting on the floor where they had laid her down. They stood around her, though at a little distance, that she might have air. She was not pretty and looked weak and poor, but she had a plaintive and a good face, though it was still a little wild. I kneeled on the ground beside her and put her poor head upon my shoulder, whereupon she drew her arm round my neck and burst into tears.
可怜的女孩正坐在他们放她的地板上。他们站在她周围，虽然距离有点远，以便她呼吸空气。她长得并不漂亮，看上去又弱又穷，但她的脸却哀怨又好看，虽然还是有些野性。我跪在她身边的地上，把她可怜的头靠在我的肩上，她用手臂搂住我的脖子，放声大哭。

‘My poor girl,’ said I, laying my face against her forehead, for indeed I was crying too, and trembling, ‘it seems cruel to trouble you now, but more depends on our knowing something about this letter than I could tell you in an hour.’
“我可怜的女孩，”我说，把脸贴在她的额头上，因为我确实也在哭，而且浑身发抖，“现在麻烦你似乎很残忍，但更多的是取决于我们对这封信的了解，而不是我能告诉你的一个小时内。'

She began piteously declaring that she didn’t mean any harm, she didn’t mean any harm, Mrs. Snagsby!
她开始可怜兮兮地宣称她没有任何恶意，她没有任何恶意，斯纳斯比太太！

‘We are all sure of that,’ said I. ‘But pray tell me how you got it.’
“我们都确信这一点，”我说，“但请告诉我你是怎么得到它的。”

‘Yes, dear lady, I will, and tell you true. I’ll tell true, indeed, Mrs. Snagsby.’
“是的，亲爱的女士，我会的，而且实话实说。我实话实说，斯纳斯比夫人。

‘I am sure of that,’ said I. ‘And how was it?’
“我确信这一点，”我说，“怎么样？”

‘I had been out on an errand, dear lady—long after it was dark— quite late; and when I came home, I found a common-looking person, all wet and muddy, looking up at our house. When she saw me coming in at the door, she called me back and said did I live here. And I said yes, and she said she knew only one or two places about here, but had lost her way and couldn’t find them. Oh, what shall I do, what shall I do! They won’t believe me! She didn’t say any harm to me, and I didn’t say any harm to her, indeed, Mrs. Snagsby!’
“亲爱的女士，我出去办事了——天黑很久了——很晚了；当我回到家时，我发现一个长相普通的人，浑身湿透，浑身泥泞，抬头看着我们的房子。当她看到我走进门口时，她给我回了电话，说我住在这里吗？我说是的，她说她只知道这里的一两个地方，但迷路了，找不到它们。唉，我该怎么办，我该怎么办啊！他们不会相信我的！她没有说任何伤害我的话，我也没有说任何伤害她的话，斯纳斯比太太！

It was necessary for her mistress to comfort her—which she did, I must say, with a good deal of contrition—before she could be got beyond this.
她的女主人有必要安慰她——我必须说，她是带着很大的悔悟来安慰她的——然后她才能摆脱这一切。

‘She could not find those places,’ said I.
“她找不到那些地方，”我说。

‘No!’ cried the girl, shaking her head. ‘No! Couldn’t find them. And she was so faint, and lame, and miserable, Oh so wretched, that if you had seen her, Mr. Snagsby, you’d have given her half a crown, I know!’
“不！”女孩摇着头喊道。 '不！找不到他们。她是如此虚弱、跛脚、悲惨，哦，如此可怜，斯纳斯比先生，如果你看到她，你就会给她半个克朗，我知道！

‘Well, Guster, my girl,’ said he, at first not knowing what to say. ‘I hope I should.’
“好吧，古斯特，我的女儿，”他说道，一开始不知道该说什么。 “我希望我应该这么做。”

‘And yet she was so well spoken,’ said the girl, looking at me with wide open eyes, ‘that it made a person’s heart bleed. And so she said to me, did I know the way to the burying ground? And I asked her which burying ground. And she said, the poor burying ground. And so I told her I had been a poor child myself, and it was according to parishes. But she said she meant a poor burying ground not very far from here, where there was an archway, and a step, and an iron gate.’
“但她说得那么好，”女孩睁大眼睛看着我说，“让人心都在流血。”于是她对我说，我知道去墓地的路吗？我问她哪个墓地。她说，可怜的墓地。所以我告诉她我自己也是一个穷孩子，这是根据教区的说法。但她说她指的是离这里不远的一个简陋的墓地，那里有一个拱门、一个台阶和一扇铁门。

As I watched her face and soothed her to go on, I saw that Mr. Bucket received this with a look which I could not separate from one of alarm.
当我看着她的脸并安抚她继续说下去时，我看到巴克特先生用一种我无法从惊慌中分离出来的表情接受了这句话。

‘Oh, dear, dear!’ cried the girl, pressing her hair back with her hands. ‘What shall I do, what shall I do! She meant the burying ground where the man was buried that took the sleeping-stuff—that you came home and told us of, Mr. Snagsby—that frightened me so, Mrs. Snagsby. Oh, I am frightened again. Hold me!’
“噢，天哪，天哪！”女孩大声喊道，用手把头发往后拢。 ‘我该怎么办，我该怎么办！她指的是埋葬那个拿走睡眠用品的人的墓地——你回家告诉我们的，斯纳格斯比先生——这让我很害怕，斯纳格斯比太太。唉，我又害怕了。抱紧我！'

‘You are so much better now,’ sald I. ‘Pray, pray tell me more.’
“你现在好多了，”我说道，“祈祷，祈祷告诉我更多。”

‘Yes I will, yes I will! But don’t be angry with me, that’s a dear lady, because I have been so ill.’
‘是的，我会的，是的，我会的！但别生我的气，那是一位亲爱的女士，因为我病得很厉害。”

Angry with her, poor soul!
生她的气，可怜的灵魂！

‘There! Now I will, now I will. So she said, could I tell her how to find it, and I said yes, and I told her; and she looked at me with eyes like almost as if she was blind, and herself all waving back. And so she took out the letter, and showed it me, and said if she was to put that in the post-office, it would be rubbed out and not minded and never sent; and would I take it from her, and send it, and the messenger would be paid at the house. And so I said yes, if it was no harm, and she said no—no harm. And so I took it from her, and she said she had nothing to give me, and I said I was poor myself and consequently wanted nothing. And so she said God bless you, and went.’
'那里！现在我会了，现在我会了。所以她说，我可以告诉她如何找到它吗？我说可以，然后我告诉了她；她用几乎瞎子般的眼神看着我，同时也向我招手。于是她拿出那封信给我看，并说如果她把它放进邮局，它就会被擦掉，不会在意，也永远不会寄出去；但她却把它扔进了邮局。我会从她那里拿走它并寄出它，而使者将在家里得到报酬。所以我说是的，如果没有伤害的话，她说不——没有伤害。于是我从她手中夺走了它，她说她没有什么可以给我的，我说我自己很穷，因此什么也不想要。所以她说愿上帝保佑你，然后就走了。

‘And did she go—‘
“她有没有去——”

‘Yes,’ cried the girl, anticipating the inquiry. ‘Yes! She went the way I had shown her. Then I came in, and Mrs. Snagsby came behind me from somewhere and laid hold of me, and I was frightened.’
“是的，”女孩喊道，期待着询问。 '是的！她按照我向她展示的方式走了。然后我进来了，斯纳斯比夫人从什么地方来到我身后，抓住了我，我很害怕。

Mr. Woodcourt took her kindly from me. Mr. Bucket wrapped me up, and immediately we were in the street. Mr. Woodcourt hesitated, but I said, ‘Don’t leave me now!’ and Mr. Bucket added, ‘You’ll be better with us, we may want you; don’t lose time!’
伍德考特先生好心地把她从我身边接走。巴克特先生把我包起来，我们立刻就到了街上。伍德考特先生犹豫了，但我说，“现在别离开我！”巴克特先生补充道，“你和我们在一起会更好，我们可能需要你；但我们需要你。”不要浪费时间！

I have the most confused impressions of that walk. I recollect that it was neither night nor day, that morning was dawning but the street-lamps were not yet put out, that the sleet was still falling and that all the ways were deep with it. I recollect a few chilled people passing in the streets. I recollect the wet house-tops, the clogged and bursting gutters and water-spouts, the mounds of blackened ice and snow over which we passed, the narrowness of the courts by which we went. At the same time I remember that the poor girl seemed to be yet telling her story audibly and plainly in my hearing, that I could feel her resting on my arm, that the stained house-fronts put on human shapes and looked at me, that great water-gates seemed to be opening and closing in my head or in the air, and that the unreal things were more substantial than the real.
那次散步给我的印象最混乱。我记得当时不是黑夜，也不是白天，黎明时分，路灯还没有熄灭，雨夹雪还在下，所有的道路都被雨深深地覆盖着。我记得街上有几个冷漠的人经过。我记得潮湿的屋顶，堵塞和爆裂的排水沟和龙卷风，我们经过的黑色冰雪堆，我们走过的狭窄庭院。与此同时，我记得那个可怜的女孩似乎还在我的耳边清晰地讲述着她的故事，我能感觉到她靠在我的手臂上，污迹斑斑的房屋正面变成了人形，看着我，巨大的水门似乎在我的脑海或空中打开和关闭，虚幻的事物比真实的事物更真实。

At last we stood under a dark and miserable covered way, where one lamp was burning over an iron gate and where the morning faintly struggled in. The gate was closed. Beyond it was a burial ground —a dreadful spot in which the night was very slowly stirring, but where I could dimly see heaps of dishonoured graves and stones, hemmed in by filthy houses with a few dull lights in their windows and on whose walls a thick humidity broke out like a disease. On the step at the gate, drenched in the fearful wet of such a place, which oozed and splashed down everywhere, I saw, with a cry of pity and horror, a woman lying—Jenny, the mother of the dead child.
最后，我们站在一条阴暗而破败的小道下，铁门上点着一盏灯，晨曦微弱地袭来。铁门关着。越过它是一个墓地——一个可怕的地方，夜色正在慢慢地搅动，但我隐约可以看到成堆的不光彩的坟墓和石头，周围是肮脏的房子，窗户里有几盏昏暗的灯光，墙壁上有浓浓的湿气像一种疾病一样爆发了。在门口的台阶上，这个地方的可怕的湿气浸透了，到处都是渗水和溅落的地方，我看到，带着怜悯和恐惧的呼喊，躺着一个女人——珍妮，死孩子的母亲。

I ran forward, but they stopped me, and Mr. Woodcourt entreated me with the greatest earnestness, even with tears, before I went up to the figure to listen for an instant to what Mr. Bucket said. I did so, as I thought. I did so, as I am sure.
我向前跑去，但他们拦住了我，伍德考特先生非常诚恳地恳求我，甚至流着泪，然后我走到人物面前，暂时听听巴克特先生说的话。我就这么做了，正如我所想的那样。我确实这样做了。

‘Miss Summerson, you’ll understand me, if you think a moment. They changed clothes at the cottage.’
“萨默森小姐，如果你想一下，你就会明白我的意思。他们在小屋里换了衣服。

They changed clothes at the cottage. I could repeat the words in my mind, and I knew what they meant of themselves, but I attached no meaning to them in any other connexion.
他们在小屋里换了衣服。我可以在心里重复这些话，而且我知道它们本身的含义，但我对它们没有任何其他联系的意义。

‘And one returned,’ said Mr. Bucket, ‘and one went on. And the one that went on only went on a certain way agreed upon to deceive and then turned across country and went home. Think a moment!’
“一只回来了，”巴克特先生说，“一只继续走。”而那个继续前进的人只是沿着同意欺骗的某种方式前进，然后穿越乡村回家了。想一想！’

I could repeat this in my mind too, but I had not the least idea what it meant. I saw before me, lying on the step, the mother of the dead child. She lay there with one arm creeping round a bar of the iron gate and seeming to embrace it. She lay there, who had so lately spoken to my mother. She lay there, a distressed, unsheltered, senseless creature. She who had brought my mother’s letter, who could give me the only clue to where my mother was; she, who was to guide us to rescue and save her whom we had sought so far, who had come to this condition by some means connected with my mother that I could not follow, and might be passing beyond our reach and help at that moment; she lay there, and they stopped me! I saw but did not comprehend the solemn and compassionate look in Mr. Woodcourt’s face. I saw but did not comprehend his touching the other on the breast to keep him back. I saw him stand uncovered in the bitter air, with a reverence for something. But my understanding for all this was gone.
我也可以在心里重复这句话，但我完全不知道这意味着什么。我看到我面前的台阶上躺着死去孩子的母亲。她躺在那里，一只手臂爬过铁门的一根栅栏，似乎正在拥抱它。她躺在那里，最近才和我母亲说过话。她躺在那里，一个痛苦、无家可归、毫无知觉的生物。她带来了我母亲的信，她能给我关于我母亲在哪里的唯一线索；她，引导我们去营救和拯救我们迄今为止一直在寻找的她，她通过某种与我母亲有关的方式来到了这种境地，我无法跟随，并且在那一刻可能超出了我们的能力和帮助;她躺在那里，他们阻止了我！我看到了伍德考特先生脸上严肃而富有同情心的表情，但不明白。我看到但不明白他触碰对方的乳房以阻止他。我看到他赤身裸体地站在寒冷的空气中，带着对某种事物的敬畏。但我对这一切的理解已经消失了。

I even heard it said between them, ‘Shall she go?’
我什至听到他们之间说：“她要走吗？”

‘She had better go. Her hands should be the first to touch her. They have a higher right than ours.’
‘她最好走吧。她的手应该是第一个触摸她的人。他们拥有比我们更高的权利。

I passed on to the gate and stooped down. I lifted the heavy head, put the long dank hair aside, and turned the face. And it was my mother, cold and dead.
我走到门口，弯下腰。我抬起沉重的头，把湿漉漉的长发拨到一边，转过脸去。那是我的母亲，冰冷而死了。

CHAPTER LX
第六章


Perspective
看法

I proceed to other passages of my narrative. From the goodness of all about me I derived such consolation as I can never think of unmoved. I have already said so much of myself, and so much still remains, that I will not dwell upon my sorrow. I had an illness, but it was not a long one; and I would avoid even this mention of it if I could quite keep down the recollection of their sympathy.
我继续讲述我的叙述的其他段落。从我周围一切的善良中，我得到了这样的安慰，我从来没有想过不感动。我已经说了很多关于我自己的事，还有很多话要说，所以我不会再详述我的悲伤。我生了一场病，但病的时间不长；如果我能完全不去回忆起他们的同情的话，我什至会避免提及此事。

I proceed to other passages of my narrative.
我继续讲述我的叙述的其他段落。

During the time of my illness, we were still in London, where Mrs. Woodcourt had come, on my guardian’s invitation, to stay with us. When my guardian thought me well and cheerful enough to talk with him in our old way—though I could have done that sooner if he would have believed me—I resumed my work and my chair beside his. He had appointed the time himself, and we were alone.
我生病期间，我们仍在伦敦，伍德考特夫人应我监护人的邀请来到伦敦和我们住在一起。当我的监护人认为我身体健康，心情愉快，可以用我们以前的方式与他交谈时——尽管如果他相信我的话，我可以早点这样做——我继续工作，把椅子放在他旁边。他自己指定了时间，只有我们两个人。

‘Dame Trot,’ said he, receiving me with a kiss, ‘welcome to the growlery again, my dear. I have a scheme to develop, little woman. I propose to remain here, perhaps for six months, perhaps for a longer time—as it may be. Quite to settle here for a while, in short.’
“特洛特夫人，”他一边吻着我一边说道，“欢迎再次来到咆哮声，亲爱的。我有一个计划要制定，小女人。我建议留在这里，也许是六个月，也许是更长的时间——视情况而定。简而言之，很想在这里定居一段时间。

‘And in the meanwhile leave Bleak House?’ said I.
“同时离开荒凉山庄？”我说道。

‘Aye, my dear? Bleak House,’ he returned, ‘must learn to take care of itself.’
‘是吗，亲爱的？ “荒凉山庄，”他回答道，“必须学会照顾自己。”

I thought his tone sounded sorrowful, but looking at him, I saw his kind face lighted up by its pleasantest smile.
我以为他的语气听起来很悲伤，但看着他，我看到他慈祥的脸上绽放着最愉快的笑容。

‘Bleak House,’ he repeated—and his tone did NOT sound sorrowful, I found—‘must learn to take care of itself. It is a long way from Ada, my dear, and Ada stands much in need of you.’
“荒凉山庄，”他重复道——我发现他的语气听起来并不悲伤——“必须学会照顾自己。”亲爱的，离艾达很远，艾达非常需要你。

‘It’s like you, guardian,’ said I, ‘to have been taking that into consideration for a happy surprise to both of us.’
“就像你一样，监护人，”我说，“你已经考虑到了这一点，为我们俩带来了惊喜。”

‘Not so disinterested either, my dear, if you mean to extol me for that virtue, since if you were generally on the road, you could be seldom with me. And besides, I wish to hear as much and as often of Ada as I can in this condition of estrangement from poor Rick. Not of her alone, but of him too, poor fellow.’
“亲爱的，如果你想赞扬我的美德，那也不是那么无私，因为如果你经常在路上，你就很少能和我在一起。此外，在与可怜的瑞克疏远的情况下，我希望尽可能多、尽可能多地听到艾达的消息。不仅仅是她一个人，还有他，可怜的家伙。

‘Have you seen Mr. Woodcourt, this morning, guardian?’
“监护人，今天早上你见过伍德考特先生吗？”

‘I see Mr. Woodcourt every morning, Dame Durden.’
“我每天早上都会见到伍德考特先生，德登夫人。”

‘Does he still say the same of Richard?’
“他对理查德还这么说吗？”

‘Just the same. He knows of no direct bodily illness that he has; on the contrary, he believes that he has none. Yet he is not easy about him; who CAN be?’
” “就是一样。他不知道自己有任何直接的身体疾病；相反，他认为自己没有。然而他对他并不容易；谁可以是？

My dear girl had been to see us lately every day, some times twice in a day. But we had foreseen, all along, that this would only last until I was quite myself. We knew full well that her fervent heart was as full of affection and gratitude towards her cousin John as it had ever been, and we acquitted Richard of laying any injunctions upon her to stay away; but we knew on the other hand that she felt it a part of her duty to him to be sparing of her visits at our house. My guardian’s delicacy had soon perceived this and had tried to convey to her that he thought she was right.
我亲爱的女儿最近每天都来看我们，有时一天两次。但我们一直都预见到，这种情况只会持续到我恢复正常为止。我们非常清楚，她的热情对她的表弟约翰一如既往地充满了感情和感激之情，我们宣告理查德没有对她施加任何禁止她离开的禁令。但另一方面我们知道，她认为不去我们家拜访是她对他的责任的一部分。我的监护人很快就察觉到了这一点，并试图向她传达他认为她是对的。

‘Dear, unfortunate, mistaken Richard,’ said I. ‘When will he awake from his delusion!’
“亲爱的，不幸的，误会的理查德，”我说，“他什么时候才能从他的妄想中醒来！”

‘He is not in the way to do so now, my dear,’ replied my guardian. ‘The more he suffers, the more averse he will be to me, having made me the principal representative of the great occasion of his suffering.’
“亲爱的，他现在不能这样做，”我的监护人回答道。 “他受的苦越多，他就越厌恶我，因为我让我成为了他受苦的重大事件的主要代表。”

I could not help adding, ‘So unreasonably!’
我忍不住补充道：“太不合理了！”

‘Ah, Dame Trot, Dame Trot,’ returned my guardian, ‘what shall we find reasonable in Jarndyce and Jarndyce! Unreason and injustice at the top, unreason and injustice at the heart and at the bottom, unreason and injustice from beginning to end—if it ever has an end—how should poor Rick, always hovering near it, pluck reason out of it? He no more gathers grapes from thorns or figs from thistles than older men did in old times.’
“啊，特洛特夫人，特洛特夫人，”我的监护人回答道，“我们在贾迪斯和贾迪斯身上能找到什么合理的东西！”上层的不合理和不公正，内心和底层的不合理和不公正，自始至终的不合理和不公正——如果它有终结的话——总是徘徊在它附近的可怜的瑞克该如何从中剔除理性呢？他不再像古代的老年人那样从荆棘中采集葡萄，或从蓟中采集无花果。

His gentleness and consideration for Richard whenever we spoke of him touched me so that I was always silent on this subject very soon.
每当我们谈到理查德时，他的温柔和体贴都让我感动，所以我很快就在这个话题上保持沉默。

‘I suppose the Lord Chancellor, and the Vice Chancellors, and the whole Chancery battery of great guns would be infinitely astonished by such unreason and injustice in one of their suitors,’ pursued my guardian. ‘When those learned gentlemen begin to raise moss-roses from the powder they sow in their wigs, I shall begin to be astonished too!’
“我想大法官、副大法官以及整个大法官法庭的大炮们都会对他们的追求者之一的这种不理智和不公正感到无比惊讶，”我的监护人继续说道。 “当那些博学的绅士开始用他们在假发中撒下的粉末种植苔藓玫瑰时，我也会开始感到惊讶！”

He checked himself in glancing towards the window to look where the wind was and leaned on the back of my chair instead.
他停下来，朝窗户看了一眼，看看风在哪里，然后靠在了我的椅背上。

‘Well, well, little woman! To go on, my dear. This rock we must leave to time, chance, and hopeful circumstance. We must not shipwreck Ada upon it. She cannot afford, and he cannot afford, the remotest chance of another separation from a friend. Therefore I have particularly begged of Woodcourt, and I now particularly beg of you, my dear, not to move this subject with Rick. Let it rest. Next week, next month, next year, sooner or later, he will see me with clearer eyes. I can wait.’
‘好啦好啦，小女人！继续前进，亲爱的。我们必须把这块石头留给时间、机遇和充满希望的环境。我们决不能让艾达沉船在上面。她无法承受，他也无法承受与朋友再次分离的哪怕一丝一毫的可能性。因此，我特别恳求伍德考特，现在我也特别恳求你，亲爱的，不要向里克转移这个话题。让它休息吧。下周，下个月，明年，迟早，他会用更清晰的眼睛看到我。我可以等。'

But I had already discussed it with him, I confessed; and so, I thought, had Mr. Woodcourt.
但我承认，我已经和他讨论过了。我想，伍德考特先生也是如此。

‘So he tells me,’ returned my guardian. ‘Very good. He has made his protest, and Dame Durden has made hers, and there is nothing more to be said about it. Now I come to Mrs. Woodcourt. How do you like her, my dear?’
“他是这么告​​诉我的，”我的监护人回答道。 '非常好。他已经提出了抗议，德登夫人也提出了她的抗议，对此没有什么可说的了。现在我来谈谈伍德考特夫人。你觉得她怎么样，亲爱的？

In answer to this question, which was oddly abrupt, I said I liked her very much and thought she was more agreeable than she used to be.
在回答这个奇怪的唐突问题时，我说我非常喜欢她，并认为她比以前更讨人喜欢了。

‘I think so too,’ said my guardian. ‘Less pedigree? Not so much of Morgan ap—what’s his name?’
“我也这么认为，”我的监护人说。 ‘血统更少？不太像摩根·阿普——他叫什么名字？

That was what I meant, I acknowledged, though he was a very harmless person, even when we had had more of him.
我承认，这就是我的意思，尽管他是一个非常无害的人，即使我们有更多的他。

‘Still, upon the whole, he is as well in his native mountains,’ said my guardian. ‘I agree with you. Then, little woman, can I do better for a time than retain Mrs. Woodcourt here?’
“不过，总的来说，他还是在家乡的山里，”我的监护人说。 '我同意你的看法。那么，小女人，我能暂时把伍德考特夫人留在这里更好吗？

No. And yet—
不。然而——

My guardian looked at me, waiting for what I had to say.
我的监护人看着我，等待我要说的话。

I had nothing to say. At least I had nothing in my mind that I could say. I had an undefined impression that it might have been better if we had had some other inmate, but I could hardly have explained why even to myself. Or, if to myself, certainly not to anybody else.
我无话可说。至少我心里没什么可说的。我有一种不明确的印象，如果我们有其他囚犯可能会更好，但我什至无法向自己解释为什么。或者，如果是对我自己，当然不是对其他人。

‘You see,’ said my guardian, ‘our neighbourhood is in Woodcourt’s way, and he can come here to see her as often as he likes, which is agreeable to them both; and she is familiar to us and fond of you.’
“你看，”我的监护人说，“我们的邻居妨碍了伍德考特，他可以随时来这里看望她，这对他们俩来说都是很高兴的；她对我们来说很熟悉并且喜欢你。

Yes. That was undeniable. I had nothing to say against it. I could not have suggested a better arrangement, but I was not quite easy in my mind. Esther, Esther, why not? Esther, think!
是的。这是不可否认的。我对此无话可说。我无法提出更好的安排，但我心里不太轻松。以斯帖，以斯帖，为什么不呢？以斯帖，想一想！

‘It is a very good plan indeed, dear guardian, and we could not do better.’
“这确实是一个非常好的计划，亲爱的监护人，我们不能做得更好。”

‘Sure, little woman?’
“当然可以，小女人？”

Quite sure. I had had a moment’s time to think, since I had urged that duty on myself, and I was quite sure.
非常肯定。自从我敦促自己承担起这项责任以来，我花了一点时间思考，而且我非常确定。

‘Good,’ said my guardian. ‘It shall be done. Carried unanimously.’
“很好，”我的监护人说。 ‘一定会完成的。一致通过。

‘Carried unanimously,’ I repeated, going on with my work.
“一致通过，”我重复道，继续我的工作。

It was a cover for his book-table that I happened to be ornamenting. It had been laid by on the night preceding my sad journey and never resumed. I showed it to him now, and he admired it highly. After I had explained the pattern to him and all the great effects that were to come out by and by, I thought I would go back to our last theme.
这是我碰巧装饰的他的书桌封面。它在我悲伤旅程的前一天晚上就被搁置了，再也没有恢复过。我现在拿给他看，他非常欣赏。在我向他解释了这个模式以及所有即将出现的伟大效果之后，我想我应该回到我们的上一个主题。

‘You said, dear guardian, when we spoke of Mr. Woodcourt before Ada left us, that you thought he would give a long trial to another country. Have you been advising him since?’
“亲爱的监护人，当我们在艾达离开我们之前谈到伍德考特先生时，您说您认为他会去另一个国家进行长期审判。从那以后你一直在给他提供建议吗？

‘Yes, little woman, pretty often.’
“是的，小女人，经常这样。”

‘Has he decided to do so?’
“他决定这么做了吗？”

‘I rather think not.’
“我宁愿不这么认为。”

‘Some other prospect has opened to him, perhaps?’ said I.
“也许他已经看到了其他的前景？”我说。

‘Why—yes—perhaps,’ returned my guardian, beginning his answer in a very deliberate manner. ‘About half a year hence or so, there is a medical attendant for the poor to be appointed at a certain place in Yorkshire. It is a thriving place, pleasantly situated—streams and streets, town and country, mill and moor—and seems to present an opening for such a man. I mean a man whose hopes and aims may sometimes lie (as most men’s sometimes do, I dare say) above the ordinary level, but to whom the ordinary level will be high enough after all if it should prove to be a way of usefulness and good service leading to no other. All generous spirits are ambitious, I suppose, but the ambition that calmly trusts itself to such a road, instead of spasmodically trying to fly over it, is of the kind I care for. It is Woodcourt’s kind.’
“为什么——是的——也许吧，”我的监护人回答道，他以一种非常从容的方式开始回答。大约半年后，约克郡的某个地方将任命一名穷人医务人员。这是一个繁荣的地方，地理位置宜人——溪流和街道，城镇和乡村，磨坊和沼泽——似乎为这样的人提供了一个机会。我的意思是一个人的希望和目标有时可能高于普通水平（我敢说，大多数人有时会这样做），但如果它被证明是一种有用的方式，那么普通水平毕竟足够高了。良好的服务导致没有其他。我想，所有慷慨的人都是雄心勃勃的，但平静地相信自己走上这条路，而不是断断续续地试图飞越它的雄心，正是我所关心的。这是伍德考特的那种。”

‘And will he get this appointment?’ I asked.
“他会得到这个任命吗？”我问。

‘Why, little woman,’ returned my guardian, smiling, ‘not being an oracle, I cannot confidently say, but I think so. His reputation stands very high; there were people from that part of the country in the shipwreck; and strange to say, I believe the best man has the best chance. You must not suppose it to be a fine endowment. It is a very, very commonplace affair, my dear, an appointment to a great amount of work and a small amount of pay; but better things will gather about it, it may be fairly hoped.’
“为什么，小女人，”我的监护人微笑着回答道，“我不能自信地说，这不是神谕，但我想是的。他的声誉很高；沉船中的人来自该国那个地区；奇怪的是，我相信最好的人有最好的机会。你一定不能认为这是一笔很好的捐赠。亲爱的，这是一件非常非常平常的事情，约定做大量的工作，但报酬却很少。但更好的事情将会聚集在它周围，这可能是相当有希望的。

‘The poor of that place will have reason to bless the choice if it falls on Mr. Woodcourt, guardian.’
“如果这个选择落在监护人伍德考特先生身上，那地方的穷人将有理由祝福这个选择。”

‘You are right, little woman; that I am sure they will.’
‘你是对的，小女人；我相信他们会的。

We said no more about it, nor did he say a word about the future of Bleak House. But it was the first time I had taken my seat at his side in my mourning dress, and that accounted for it, I considered.
我们没有再谈论此事，他也没有提及《荒凉山庄》的未来。但这是我第一次穿着丧服坐在他身边，我想这就是原因。

I now began to visit my dear girl every day in the dull dark corner where she lived. The morning was my usual time, but whenever I found I had an hour or so to spare, I put on my bonnet and bustled off to Chancery Lane. They were both so glad to see me at all hours, and used to brighten up so when they heard me opening the door and coming in (being quite at home, I never knocked), that I had no fear of becoming troublesome just yet.
现在我开始每天去我亲爱的女儿住的那个阴暗的角落看望她。早上是我平常的时间，但每当我发现有一个小时左右的空闲时间时，我就会戴上帽子，匆匆赶往大法官巷。他们总是很高兴见到我，而且常常高兴起来，所以当他们听到我开门进来时（我很自在，从来不敲门），所以我还不用担心会带来麻烦。

On these occasions I frequently found Richard absent. At other times he would be writing or reading papers in the cause at that table of his, so covered with papers, which was never disturbed. Sometimes I would come upon him lingering at the door of Mr. Vholes’s office. Sometimes I would meet him in the neighbourhood lounging about and biting his nails. I often met him wandering in Lincoln’s Inn, near the place where I had first seen him, oh how different, how different!
在这些场合，我经常发现理查德缺席。其他时候，他会在他那张桌子上写或读有关事业的论文，桌子上铺满了文件，从来没有受到打扰。有时我会遇见他在沃尔斯先生的办公室门口徘徊。有时我会在附近遇到他，他正在闲逛，咬着指甲。我经常在林肯律师学院遇见他，就在我第一次见到他的地方附近，哦，多么不同，多么不同！

That the money Ada brought him was melting away with the candles I used to see burning after dark in Mr. Vholes’s office I knew very well. It was not a large amount in the beginning, he had married in debt, and I could not fail to understand, by this time, what was meant by Mr. Vholes’s shoulder being at the wheel—as I still heard it was. My dear made the best of housekeepers and tried hard to save, but I knew that they were getting poorer and poorer every day.
艾达给他带来的钱正随着天黑后在沃尔斯先生办公室里燃烧的蜡烛一起融化，这一点我非常清楚。一开始这笔钱并不多，他是负债累累地结婚的，到了这个时候，我不可能不明白沃尔斯先生的肩膀负责开车是什么意思——就像我仍然听说的那样。亲爱的管家尽力了，努力攒钱，但我知道他们一天天变得越来越穷。

She shone in the miserable corner like a beautiful star. She adorned and graced it so that it became another place. Paler than she had been at home, and a little quieter than I had thought natural when she was yet so cheerful and hopeful, her face was so unshadowed that I half believed she was blinded by her love for Richard to his ruinous career.
她就像一颗美丽的星星，在悲惨的角落里闪闪发光。她装饰它，使它变得优雅，使它成为另一个地方。她比在家里时更苍白，比我想象的更安静，因为她仍然那么快乐和充满希望，她的脸是如此的没有阴影，我几乎相信她被她对理查德的爱蒙蔽了双眼，忽视了他毁灭性的职业生涯。

I went one day to dine with them while I was under this impression. As I turned into Symond’s Inn, I met little Miss Flite coming out. She had been to make a stately call upon the wards in Jarndyce, as she still called them, and had derived the highest gratification from that ceremony. Ada had already told me that she called every Monday at five o’clock, with one little extra white bow in her bonnet, which never appeared there at any other time, and with her largest reticule of documents on her arm.
有一天，我带着这样的印象去和他们一起吃饭。当我拐进西蒙旅馆时，我遇见了小弗利特小姐走了出来。她曾对贾迪斯的病房进行一次庄严的拜访，她仍然这样称呼它们，并从这次仪式中获得了最高的满足。艾达已经告诉我，她每周一五点钟打电话，帽子上别着一个额外的白色蝴蝶结，以前从来没有出现过，胳膊上还挎着最大的文件袋。

‘My dear!’ she began. ‘So delighted! How do you do! So glad to see you. And you are going to visit our interesting Jarndyce wards? TO be sure! Our beauty is at home, my dear, and will be charmed to see you.’
“亲爱的！”她开始说道。 ‘太高兴了！你好吗！很高兴见到你。您打算参观我们有趣的贾迪斯病房吗？为了确定！亲爱的，我们的美丽就在家里，见到你我一定会很高兴。”

‘Then Richard is not come in yet?’ said I. ‘I am glad of that, for I was afraid of being a little late.’
“那么理查德还没进来吗？”我说道，“我很高兴，因为我担心会迟到一点。”

‘No, he is not come in,’ returned Miss Flite. ‘He has had a long day in court. I left him there with Vholes. You don’t like Vholes, I hope? DON’T like Vholes. Dan-gerous man!’
“不，他没有进来。”弗利特小姐回答道。 “他在法庭上度过了漫长的一天。我把他留在了沃勒斯那里。我希望你不喜欢Vholes？不喜欢Vholes。危险的人！

‘I am afraid you see Richard oftener than ever now,’ said I.
“恐怕你现在见到理查德比以前更频繁了，”我说。

‘My dearest,’ returned Miss Flite, ‘daily and hourly. You know what I told you of the attraction on the Chancellor’s table? My dear, next to myself he is the most constant suitor in court. He begins quite to amuse our little party. Ve-ry friendly little party, are we not?’
“我最亲爱的，”弗利特小姐回答道，“每天，每时每刻。”你知道我告诉过你财政大臣餐桌上的吸引力是什么吗？亲爱的，除了我之外，他是法庭上最坚定的追求者。他开始让我们这个小团体感到很有趣。非常友好的小聚会，不是吗？

It was miserable to hear this from her poor mad lips, though it was no surprise.
从她那可怜的疯狂的嘴唇里听到这句话真是令人痛苦，尽管这并不奇怪。

‘In short, my valued friend,’ pursued Miss Flite, advancing her lips to my ear with an air of equal patronage and mystery, ‘I must tell you a secret. I have made him my executor. Nominated, constituted, and appointed him. In my will. Ye-es.’
“简而言之，我尊贵的朋友，”弗利特小姐继续说道，她的嘴唇凑到我耳边，神态既恩赐又神秘，“我必须告诉你一个秘密。我已任命他为我的遗嘱执行人。提名、组建和任命他。在我的意愿中。是的，是的。’

‘Indeed?’ said I.
“真的吗？”我说。

‘Ye-es,’ repeated Miss Flite in her most genteel accents, ‘my executor, administrator, and assign. (Our Chancery phrases, my love.) I have reflected that if I should wear out, he will be able to watch that judgment. Being so very regular in his attendance.’
“是的，是的，”弗利特小姐用她最文雅的口音重复道，“我的遗嘱执行人、管理者和受托人。” （我们的大法官用语，亲爱的。）我已经考虑过，如果我精疲力尽，他将能够观看判决。他的出席非常规律。

It made me sigh to think of him.
一想到他我就叹息。

‘I did at one time mean,’ said Miss Flite, echoing the sigh, ‘to nominate, constitute, and appoint poor Gridley. Also very regular, my charming girl. I assure you, most exemplary! But he wore out, poor man, so I have appointed his successor. Don’t mention it. This is in confidence.’
“我曾经想过，”弗利特小姐说，呼应着叹息，“提名、组成和任命可怜的格里德利。也很规律，我迷人的女孩。我向你保证，堪称典范！但他已经筋疲力尽了，可怜的人，所以我指定了他的继任者。别提了。这是保密的。

She carefully opened her reticule a little way and showed me a folded piece of paper inside as the appointment of which she spoke.
她小心翼翼地把手提袋打开一点，给我看了一张折叠起来的纸，上面写着她所说的约会。

‘Another secret, my dear. I have added to my collection of birds.’
“又一个秘密，亲爱的。我已经添加了我的鸟类收藏。

‘Really, Miss Flite?’ said I, knowing how it pleased her to have her confidence received with an appearance of interest.
“真的吗，弗利特小姐？”我说道，我知道她对自己的信任表现出感兴趣的样子是多么高兴。

She nodded several times, and her face became overcast and gloomy. ‘Two more. I call them the Wards in Jarndyce. They are caged up with all the others. With Hope, Joy, Youth, Peace, Rest, Life, Dust, Ashes, Waste, Want, Ruin, Despair, Madness, Death, Cunning, Folly, Words, Wigs, Rags, Sheepskin, Plunder, Precedent, Jargon, Gammon, and Spinach!’
她连连点头，脸色变得阴沉起来。 ‘还有两个。我称他们为贾迪斯病房。他们和其他人一起被关在笼子里。希望、欢乐、青春、和平、休息、生命、灰尘、灰烬、浪费、匮乏、废墟、绝望、疯狂、死亡、狡猾、愚蠢、言语、假发、破布、羊皮、掠夺、先例、行话、火腿和菠菜！'

The poor soul kissed me with the most troubled look I had ever seen in her and went her way. Her manner of running over the names of her birds, as if she were afraid of hearing them even from her own lips, quite chilled me.
这个可怜的灵魂用我在她身上见过的最痛苦的表情吻了我，然后就走了。她念叨鸟儿名字的方式，就好像她害怕从自己嘴里听到它们一样，这让我感到很冷。

This was not a cheering preparation for my visit, and I could have dispensed with the company of Mr. Vholes, when Richard (who arrived within a minute or two after me) brought him to share our dinner. Although it was a very plain one, Ada and Richard were for some minutes both out of the room together helping to get ready what we were to eat and drink. Mr. Vholes took that opportunity of holding a little conversation in a low voice with me. He came to the window where I was sitting and began upon Symond’s Inn.
这对我的访问来说并不是一个令人愉快的准备，当理查德（他在我之后一两分钟内到达）带他来分享我们的晚餐时，我本可以省掉沃尔斯先生的陪伴。尽管这是一个非常简单的事情，但艾达和理查德都一起走出房间几分钟，帮助准备我们要吃的和喝的。沃尔斯先生借此机会与我低声交谈了一会儿。他来到我坐的窗前，开始朝西蒙德旅馆走去。

‘A dull place, Miss Summerson, for a life that is not an official one,’ said Mr. Vholes, smearing the glass with his black glove to make it clearer for me.
“萨默森小姐，这是一个沉闷的地方，对于非官方的生活来说，”沃尔斯先生说，用他的黑手套在玻璃上涂抹，让我看得更清楚。

‘There is not much to see here,’ said I.
“这里没什么可看的，”我说。

‘Nor to hear, miss,’ returned Mr. Vholes. ‘A little music does occasionally stray in, but we are not musical in the law and soon eject it. I hope Mr. Jarndyce is as well as his friends could wish him?’
“也别听，小姐，”沃尔斯先生回答道。 “偶尔会有一点音乐误入，但我们在法律上不音乐，很快就会将其驱逐出去。我希望贾迪斯先生和他的朋友们一样希望他好吗？

I thanked Mr. Vholes and said he was quite well.
我感谢了沃尔斯先生，并说他很好。

‘I have not the pleasure to be admitted among the number of his friends myself,’ said Mr. Vholes, ‘and I am aware that the gentlemen of our profession are sometimes regarded in such quarters with an unfavourable eye. Our plain course, however, under good report and evil report, and all kinds of prejudice (we are the victims of prejudice), is to have everything openly carried on. How do you find Mr. C. looking, Miss Summerson?’
“我本人并不高兴被接纳为他的朋友之一，”沃尔斯先生说，“而且我知道，我们这个行业的绅士有时会在这些方面受到不利的对待。然而，在善意的报道和恶毒的报道以及各种偏见（我们是偏见的受害者）下，我们的简单做法就是一切都公开进行。萨默森小姐，你觉得 C 先生看起来怎么样？

‘He looks very ill. Dreadfully anxious.’
‘他看起来病得很重。非常焦虑。

‘Just so,’ said Mr. Vholes.
“正是如此，”沃尔斯先生说。

He stood behind me with his long black figure reaching nearly to the ceiling of those low rooms, feeling the pimples on his face as if they were ornaments and speaking inwardly and evenly as though there were not a human passion or emotion in his nature.
他站在我身后，黑色修长的身影几乎伸到了那些低矮房间的天花板，摸着脸上的痘痘，仿佛它们是装饰品，他内心平静地说话，仿佛他的本性中没有人类的激情和情感。

‘Mr. Woodcourt is in attendance upon Mr. C., I believe?’ he resumed.
'先生。我相信伍德考特正在照顾 C. 先生吗？”他继续说道。

‘Mr. Woodcourt is his disinterested friend,’ I answered.
'先生。伍德考特是他无私的朋友，”我回答道。

‘But I mean in professional attendance, medical attendance.’
“但我指的是专业出勤、医疗出勤。”

‘That can do little for an unhappy mind,’ said I.
“对于一个不快乐的人来说，这没什么用处，”我说。

‘Just so,’ said Mr. Vholes.
“正是如此，”沃尔斯先生说。

So slow, so eager, so bloodless and gaunt, I felt as if Richard were wasting away beneath the eyes of this adviser and there were something of the vampire in him.
如此缓慢，如此热切，如此毫无血色和憔悴，我觉得理查德似乎在这位顾问的眼皮子底下日渐消瘦，他身上有某种吸血鬼的味道。

‘Miss Summerson,’ said Mr. Vholes, very slowly rubbing his gloved hands, as if, to his cold sense of touch, they were much the same in black kid or out of it, ‘this was an ill-advised marriage of Mr. C.’s.’
“萨默森小姐，”沃尔斯先生非常缓慢地搓着戴着手套的双手，仿佛在他冰冷的触觉中，无论是黑山羊皮还是非黑山羊皮，它们都一样，“这是先生的一次不明智的婚姻。” 。 CS。'

I begged he would excuse me from discussing it. They had been engaged when they were both very young, I told him (a little indignantly) and when the prospect before them was much fairer and brighter. When Richard had not yielded himself to the unhappy influence which now darkened his life.
我恳求他原谅我不要讨论这个问题。我告诉他（有点愤慨），他们都很年轻的时候就订婚了，当时他们面前的前景更加美好和光明。当理查德还没有屈服于现在使他的生活变得黑暗的不幸影响时。

‘Just so,’ assented Mr. Vholes again. ‘Still, with a view to everything being openly carried on, I will, with your permission, Miss Summerson, observe to you that I consider this a very illadvised marriage indeed. I owe the opinion not only to Mr. C.’s connexions, against whom I should naturally wish to protect myself, but also to my own reputation—dear to myself as a professional man aiming to keep respectable; dear to my three girls at home, for whom I am striving to realize some little independence; dear, I will even say, to my aged father, whom it is my privilege to support.’
“正是如此，”沃尔斯先生再次表示同意。 “尽管如此，为了让一切都公开进行，在您的允许下，萨默森小姐，我会向您指出，我认为这确实是一场非常不明智的婚姻。我的意见不仅是出于 C. 先生的关系，我自然希望保护自己免受他们的侵害，而且也是出于我自己的声誉——作为一个致力于保持受人尊敬的专业人士，我很珍视自己的声誉。亲爱的家里的三个女儿，我正在努力为她们实现一点独立；亲爱的，我什至会对我年迈的父亲说，我很荣幸能够支持他。

‘It would become a very different marriage, a much happier and better marriage, another marriage altogether, Mr. Vholes,’ said I, ‘if Richard were persuaded to turn his back on the fatal pursuit in which you are engaged with him.’
“这将成为一段截然不同的婚姻，一段更幸福、更美好的婚姻，完全是另一段婚姻，沃尔斯先生，”我说，“如果理查德被说服，放弃你与他订婚的致命追求。”

Mr. Vholes, with a noiseless cough—or rather gasp—into one of his black gloves, inclined his head as if he did not wholly dispute even that.
沃尔斯先生戴着一只黑手套，无声地咳嗽——或者更确切地说是喘气——歪着头，仿佛他对此也没有完全反驳。

‘Miss Summerson,’ he said, ‘it may be so; and I freely admit that the young lady who has taken Mr. C.’s name upon herself in so illadvised a manner—you will I am sure not quarrel with me for throwing out that remark again, as a duty I owe to Mr. C.’s connexions—is a highly genteel young lady. Business has prevented me from mixing much with general society in any but a professional character; still I trust I am competent to perceive that she is a highly genteel young lady. As to beauty, I am not a judge of that myself, and I never did give much attention to it from a boy, but I dare say the young lady is equally eligible in that point of view. She is considered so (I have heard) among the clerks in the Inn, and it is a point more in their way than in mine. In reference to Mr. C.’s pursult of his interests—‘
“萨默森小姐，”他说，“可能是这样；我坦率地承认，那位以如此不明智的方式冒用了C.先生的名字的年轻女士——我相信你不会因为我再次抛出这句话而与我争吵，因为我对C.先生负有责任。 C.的关系——是一位非常有教养的年轻女士。商业使我无法以职业身份与一般社会打交道。我仍然相信我有能力看出她是一位非常优雅的年轻女士。至于美貌，我自己并没有这样的判断，我也从来没有对男孩子给予太多关注，但我敢说这位年轻的女士在这个角度上同样有资格。 （我听说）旅馆里的店员们也这么认为她，这对他们来说比对我来说更重要。关于 C. 先生对自己利益的追求——‘

‘Oh! His interests, Mr. Vholes!’
'哦！他的兴趣，沃尔斯先生！

‘Pardon me,’ returned Mr. Vholes, going on in exactly the same inward and dispassionate manner. ‘Mr. C. takes certain interests under certain wills disputed in the suit. It is a term we use. In reference to Mr. C,’s pursuit of his interests, I mentioned to you, Miss Summerson, the first time I had the pleasure of seeing you, in my desire that everything should he openly carried on—I used those words, for I happened afterwards to note them in my diary, which is producible at any time—I mentioned to you that Mr. C. had laid down the principle of watching his own interests, and that when a client of mine laid down a principle which was not of an immoral (that is to say, unlawful) nature, it devolved upon me to carry it out. I HAVE carried it out; I do carry it out. But I will not smooth things over to any connexion of Mr. C.’s on any account. As open as I was to Mr. Jarndyce, I am to you. I regard it in the light of a professional duty to be so, though it can be charged to no one. I openly say, unpalatable as it may be, that I consider Mr. C.’s affairs in a very bad way, that I consider Mr. C. himself in a very bad way, and that I regard this as an exceedingly illadvised marriage. Am I here, sir? Yes, I thank you; I am here, Mr. C., and enjoying the pleasure of some agreeable conversation with Miss Summerson, for which I have to thank you very much, sir!’
“请原谅，”弗霍尔斯先生回答道，语气一模一样，内心平静。 '先生。 C. 根据诉讼中有争议的某些遗嘱取得某些利益。这是我们使用的术语。关于C先生对他的兴趣的追求，我第一次有幸见到你时，我向你提到过，萨默森小姐，我希望他能公开地进行一切——我用这些话，是为了后来我碰巧在我的日记中记下了这些内容，日记可以随时拿出来——我向你提到过，C.先生制定了关注自己利益的原则，当我的一位客户制定了一个原则时，这并非不道德（即非法）性质，而是由我来执行。我已经执行了；我确实执行了。但无论如何，我都不会因为 C. 先生的任何关系而让事情变得顺利。就像我对贾迪斯先生持开放态度一样，我对你也持开放态度。我认为这是出于一种职业责任，尽管这不能归咎于任何人。我公开地说，尽管这可能令人不快，但我对 C. 先生的事务的看法非常糟糕，我对 C. 先生本人的看法也非常糟糕，而且我认为这是一桩极其不明智的婚姻。我在这儿吗，先生？是的，我谢谢你；我在这里，C. 先生，享受着与萨默森小姐愉快交谈的乐趣，为此我非常感谢您，先生！
