He broke off thus in answer to Richard, who addressed him as he came into the room. By this time I too well understood Mr. Vholes’s scrupulous way of saving himself and his respectability not to feel that our worst fears did but keep pace with his client’s progress.
他就这样停下来回答理查德，当他走进房间时，理查德向他打招呼。此时，我已经非常了解沃尔斯先生自救的谨慎方式和他的受人尊敬，因此我不会感到我们最担心的事情确实发生了，而是与他的客户的进步保持同步。

We sat down to dinner, and I had an opportunity of observing Richard, anxiously. I was not disturbed by Mr. Vholes (who took off his gloves to dine), though he sat opposite to me at the small table, for I doubt if, looking up at all, he once removed his eyes from his host’s face. I found Richard thin and languid, slovenly in his dress, abstracted in his manner, forcing his spirits now and then, and at other intervals relapsing into a dull thoughtfulness. About his large bright eyes that used to be so merry there was a wanness and a restlessness that changed them altogether. 1 cannot use the expression that he looked old. There is a ruin of youth which is not like age, and into such a ruin Richard’s youth and youthful beauty had all fallen away.
我们坐下来吃晚饭，我有机会焦急地观察理查德。我并没有被沃尔斯先生（他脱下手套进餐）打扰，尽管他坐在我对面的小桌子上，因为我怀疑他是否曾抬起头，把目光从主人的脸上移开。我发现理查德瘦弱而无精打采，衣着邋遢，举止心不在焉，时不时地强迫自己精神起来，有时又陷入沉闷的沉思。他那双明亮的大眼睛原本是那么快乐，现在却变得苍白和不安，完全改变了它们。 1 不能用“他看上去很老”这样的表达方式。青春的废墟与年龄不同，理查德的青春和青春的美丽都在这样的废墟中消失了。

He ate little and seemed indifferent what it was, showed himself to be much more impatient than he used to be, and was quick even with Ada. I thought at first that his old light-hearted manner was all gone, but it shone out of him sometimes as I had occasionally known little momentary glimpses of my own old face to look out upon me from the glass. His laugh had not quite left him either, but it was like the echo of a joyful sound, and that is always sorrowful.
他吃得很少，似乎对吃什么漠不关心，表现得比以前更加不耐烦，甚至对艾达也反应很快。起初我以为他以前轻松愉快的态度已经消失了，但有时他身上会散发出这种光芒，因为我偶尔会瞥见自己那张苍老的脸从玻璃上看着我。他的笑声也没有完全消失，但它就像欢乐声音的回声，而且总是悲伤的。

Yet he was as glad as ever, in his old affectionate way, to have me there, and we talked of the old times pleasantly. These did not appear to be interesting to Mr. Vholes, though he occasionally made a gasp which I believe was his smile. He rose shortly after dinner and said that with the permission of the ladies he would retire to his office.
然而，他还是像以前一样高兴，以他一贯的深情方式，让我在那里，我们愉快地谈论了过去的时光。沃尔斯先生似乎对这些不感兴趣，尽管他偶尔会喘口气，我相信那是他的微笑。晚饭后不久，他起身说，如果得到女士们的允许，他将回到自己的办公室。

‘Always devoted to business, Vholes!’ cried Richard.
“沃尔斯，永远致力于事业！”理查德喊道。

‘Yes, Mr. C.,’ he returned, ‘the interests of clients are never to be neglected, sir. They are paramount in the thoughts of a professional man like myself, who wishes to preserve a good name among his fellow-practitioners and society at large. My denying myself the pleasure of the present agreeable conversation may not be wholly irrespective of your own interests, Mr. C.’
“是的，C. 先生，”他回答道，“客户的利益永远不能被忽视，先生。对于像我这样的专业人士来说，它们是最重要的，因为我希望在他的同修和整个社会中保持良好的声誉。我拒绝享受当前愉快的谈话可能并不完全不考虑你自己的利益，C 先生。

Richard expressed himself quite sure of that and lighted Mr. Vholes out. On his return he told us, more than once, that Vholes was a good fellow, a safe fellow, a man who did what he pretended to do, a very good fellow indeed! He was so defiant about it that it struck me he had begun to doubt Mr. Vholes.
理查德表示自己对此非常肯定，并让沃尔斯先生不再说话。回来后，他不止一次地告诉我们，沃尔斯是一个好人，一个安全的人，一个做了他假装做的事的人，确实是一个非常好的人！他对此如此挑衅，以至于我突然意识到他已经开始怀疑沃尔斯先生了。

Then he threw himself on the sofa, tired out; and Ada and I put things to rights, for they had no other servant than the woman who attended to the chambers. My dear girl had a cottage piano there and quietly sat down to sing some of Richard’s favourites, the lamp being first removed into the next room, as he complained of its hurting his eyes.
然后他累得瘫倒在沙发上。艾达和我纠正了事情，因为除了看守房间的女人之外，他们没有其他仆人。我亲爱的女孩那里有一架乡村钢琴，她静静地坐下来唱理查德最喜欢的一些歌曲，灯首先被移到隔壁房间，因为他抱怨它伤害了他的眼睛。

I sat between them, at my dear girl’s side, and felt very melancholy listening to her sweet voice. I think Richard did too; I think he darkened the room for that reason. She had been singing some time, rising between whiles to bend over him and speak to him, when Mr. Woodcourt came in. Then he sat down by Richard and half playfully, half earnestly, quite naturally and easily, found out how he felt and where he had been all day. Presently he proposed to accompany him in a short walk on one of the bridges, as it was a moonlight airy night; and Richard readily consenting, they went out together.
我坐在他们中间，在我亲爱的女孩身边，听着她甜美的声音，我感到很忧郁。我想理查德也是如此。我认为他就是因为这个原因才把房间调暗的。当伍德考特先生进来的时候，她已经唱了一段时间了，时不时地站起来弯下腰来和他说话。然后他在理查德身边坐下，一半开玩笑，一半认真，很自然而轻松地了解了他的感受和感受。他一整天都待在那里。不久，他提议陪他在其中一座桥上散步，因为那是一个月光明媚的夜晚。理查德爽快地答应了，他们一起出去了。

They left my dear girl still sitting at the piano and me still sitting beside her. When they were gone out, I drew my arm round her waist. She put her left hand in mine (I was sitting on that side), but kept her right upon the keys, going over and over them without striking any note.
他们留下我亲爱的女儿仍然坐在钢琴前，而我仍然坐在她旁边。当他们出去时，我伸出手臂搂住她的腰。她把左手放在我的手上（我坐在那一边），但把右手放在琴键上，一遍又一遍地敲击着它们，没有敲出任何音符。

‘Esther, my dearest,’ she said, breaking silence, ‘Richard is never so well and I am never so easy about him as when he is with Allan Woodcourt. We have to thank you for that.’
“艾丝特，我最亲爱的，”她打破沉默说道，“理查德从来没有像他和艾伦·伍德考特在一起时那样好过，我对他也从来没有这么轻松过。”我们必须为此感谢你。

I pointed out to my darling how this could scarcely be, because Mr. Woodcourt had come to her cousin John’s house and had known us all there, and because he had always liked Richard, and Richard had always liked him, and—and so forth.
我向我亲爱的指出这怎么可能是这样，因为伍德考特先生来到了她表弟约翰的家，并且在那里认识我们所有人，而且因为他一直喜欢理查德，而理查德也一直喜欢他，等等。

‘All true,’ said Ada, ‘but that he is such a devoted friend to us we owe to you.’
“确实如此，”艾达说，“但他是我们如此忠实的朋友，我们要感谢你。”

I thought it best to let my dear girl have her way and to say no more about it. So I said as much. I said it lightly, because I felt her trembling.
我认为最好让我亲爱的女儿随心所欲，不再多说。所以我就说了这么多。我说得很轻，因为我感觉到她在颤抖。

‘Esther, my dearest, I want to be a good wife, a very, very good wife indeed. You shall teach me.’
“埃丝特，我最亲爱的，我想成为一个好妻子，一个非常非常好的妻子。你来教我。

I teach! I said no more, for I noticed the hand that was fluttering over the keys, and I knew that it was not I who ought to speak, that it was she who had something to say to me.
我教！我没有再说什么，因为我注意到那只手在琴键上颤动，我知道不应该由我说话，而是她有话要对我说。

‘When I married Richard I was not insensible to what was before him. I had been perfectly happy for a long time with you, and I had never known any trouble or anxiety, so loved and cared for, but I understood the danger he was in, dear Esther.’
“当我嫁给理查德时，我对他面前的一切并不是无动于衷。我和你在一起很长一段时间都非常幸福，我从来没有遇到任何麻烦或焦虑，所以被爱和关心，但我理解他所处的危险，亲爱的埃丝特。

‘I know, I know, my darling.’
“我知道，我知道，亲爱的。”

‘When we were married I had some little hope that I might be able to convince him of his mistake, that he might come to regard it in a new way as my husband and not pursue it all the more desperately for my sake—as he does. But if I had not had that hope, I would have married him just the same, Esther. Just the same!’
“当我们结婚时，我有一些小小的希望，希望我能够说服他承认自己的错误，让他能够以一种新的方式将其视为我的丈夫，而不是为了我而更加拼命地追求它——就像他那样做。但如果我没有这个希望，我还是会嫁给他，埃丝特。一样！

In the momentary firmness of the hand that was never still—a firmness inspired by the utterance of these last words, and dying away with them—I saw the confirmation of her earnest tones.
从她那只从未静止过的瞬间坚定的手上——这种坚定是由这最后一句话的说出引起的，并随之消失——我看到了她真诚的语气的确认。

‘You are not to think, my dearest Esther, that I fail to see what you see and fear what you fear. No one can understand him better than I do. The greatest wisdom that ever lived in the world could scarcely know Richard better than my love does.’
“我最亲爱的埃丝特，你不要以为我看不到你所看到的，害怕你所害怕的。没有人比我更能理解他。世界上最伟大的智慧也不可能比我的爱人更了解理查德。

She spoke so modestly and softly and her trembling hand expressed such agitation as it moved to and fro upon the silent notes! My dear, dear girl!
她说话是如此谦虚和轻柔，她颤抖的手在无声的音符上来回移动，表现出如此的激动！我亲爱的、亲爱的女孩！

‘I see him at his worst every day. I watch him in his sleep. I know every change of his face. But when I married Richard I was quite determined, Esther, if heaven would help me, never to show him that I grieved for what he did and so to make him more unhappy. I want him, when he comes home, to find no trouble in my face. I want him, when he looks at me, to see what he loved in me. I married him to do this, and this supports me.’
“我每天都看到他最糟糕的时候。我看着他睡梦中的样子。我知道他脸上的每一个变化。但当我嫁给理查德时，我下定决心，埃丝特，如果上天能帮助我的话，永远不要让他知道我为他的所作所为感到悲伤，从而让他更加不高兴。我希望他回家后不会在我脸上发现任何麻烦。我希望他在看着我的时候，能看到他爱我的地方。我嫁给他就是为了这么做，这支持了我。”

I felt her trembling more. I waited for what was yet to come, and I now thought I began to know what it was.
我感觉到她颤抖得更厉害了。我等待着即将到来的事情，现在我想我开始知道那是什么了。

‘And something else supports me, Esther.’
“还有其他东西在支持我，埃丝特。”

She stopped a minute. Stopped speaking only; her hand was still in motion.
她停了一分钟。只停止说话；她的手还在动。

‘I look forward a little while, and I don’t know what great aid may come to me. When Richard turns his eyes upon me then, there may be something lying on my breast more eloquent than I have been, with greater power than mine to show him his true course and win him back.’
‘我期待了一会儿，但我不知道会有什么伟大的帮助降临到我身上。当理查德把目光转向我时，我胸中可能有某种东西比我以前更有说服力，比我更有力量，可以向他展示他的真实路线并赢得他的支持。

Her hand stopped now. She clasped me in her arms, and I clasped her in mine.
她的手现在停了下来。她将我搂在怀里，我也将她搂在怀里。

‘If that little creature should fail too, Esther, I still look forward. I look forward a long while, through years and years, and think that then, when I am growing old, or when I am dead perhaps, a beautiful woman, his daughter, happily married, may be proud of him and a blessing to him. Or that a generous brave man, as handsome as he used to be, as hopeful, and far more happy, may walk in the sunshine with him, honouring his grey head and saying to himself, ‘I thank God this is my father! Ruined by a fatal inheritance, and restored through me!’’
“如果那个小生物也失败了，埃丝特，我仍然期待着。我期待了很长一段时间，年复一年，并想，当我变老，或者当我死去时，一个美丽的女人，他的女儿，幸福地结婚了，可能会为他感到骄傲，并祝福他。或者，一个慷慨勇敢的人，像以前一样英俊，一样充满希望，更加快乐，可以和他一起走在阳光下，尊重他的白发并对自己说：“我感谢上帝，这是我的父亲！”被致命的传承毁掉，又通过我恢复！”

Oh, my sweet girl, what a heart was that which beat so fast against me!
哦，我可爱的女孩，那颗心脏在我身上跳得如此之快！

‘These hopes uphold me, my dear Esther, and I know they will. Though sometimes even they depart from me before a dread that arises when I look at Richard.’
“这些希望支撑着我，亲爱的埃丝特，我知道它们会的。尽管有时候，当我看到理查德时，我会感到恐惧，甚至他们也会离开我。

I tried to cheer my darling, and asked her what it was. Sobbing and weeping, she replied, ‘That he may not live to see his child.’
我试图让我亲爱的开心起来，并问她那是什么。她抽泣着回答说：“以免他活着见到他的孩子。”

CHAPTER LXI
第十六章


A Discovery
一个发现

The days when I frequented that miserable corner which my dear girl brightened can never fade in my remembrance. I never see it, and I never wish to see it now; I have been there only once since, but in my memory there is a mournful glory shining on the place which will shine for ever.
我经常光顾那个被我亲爱的女孩照亮的悲惨角落的日子永远不会在我的记忆中消失。我从未见过它，现在我也不想见到它；从那以后我只去过那里一次，但在我的记忆中，有一种悲伤的光辉照耀着这个地方，它将永远闪耀。

Not a day passed without my going there, of course. At first I found Mr. Skimpole there, on two or three occasions, idly playing the piano and talking in his usual vivacious strain. Now, besides my very much mistrusting the probability of his being there without making Richard poorer, I felt as if there were something in his careless gaiety too inconsistent with what I knew of the depths of Ada’s life. I clearly perceived, too, that Ada shared my feelings. I therefore resolved, after much thinking of it, to make a private visit to Mr. Skimpole and try delicately to explain myself. My dear girl was the great consideration that made me bold.
当然，我没有一天不去那里。起初，我曾有两三次发现斯金波尔先生在那儿，悠闲地弹着钢琴，用他一贯的活泼语气说话。现在，除了我非常怀疑他在场不会让理查德变得更穷之外，我觉得他漫不经心的快乐中似乎有什么东西与我对艾达生活深处的了解太不一致了。我也清楚地意识到艾达也有同样的感受。因此，经过深思熟虑，我决定私下拜访斯金波尔先生，并尝试巧妙地解释自己的情况。我亲爱的女孩是我的伟大考虑让我变得勇敢。

I set off one morning, accompanied by Charley, for Somers Town. As I approached the house, I was strongly inclined to turn back, for I felt what a desperate attempt it was to make an impression on Mr. Skimpole and how extremely likely it was that he would signally defeat me. However, I thought that being there, I would go through with it. I knocked with a trembling hand at Mr. Skimpole’s door— literally with a hand, for the knocker was gone—and after a long parley gained admission from an Irishwoman, who was in the area when I knocked, breaking up the lid of a water-butt with a poker to light the fire with.
一天早上，我在查理的陪同下出发前往萨默斯镇。当我走近那所房子时，我强烈地想回头，因为我觉得要给斯金波尔先生留下印象是多么绝望的尝试，而且他很可能会明显地击败我。然而，我想，在那里，我会经历这一切。我用颤抖的手敲了敲斯基姆波尔先生的门——实际上是一只手，因为门环不见了——经过长时间的谈判，一位爱尔兰女人承认了，当我敲门时，她就在附近，打破了水箱的盖子。 -用拨火棍点燃火。

Mr. Skimpole, lying on the sofa in his room, playing the flute a little, was enchanted to see me. Now, who should receive me, he asked. Who would I prefer for mistress of the ceremonies? Would I have his Comedy daughter, his Beauty daughter, or his Sentiment daughter? Or would I have all the daughters at once in a perfect nosegay?
斯金波尔先生躺在房间的沙发上，吹着长笛，看到我很着迷。现在，谁应该接待我，他问道。我更喜欢谁作为仪式的女主人？我会拥有他的喜剧女儿，他的美丽女儿，还是他的情感女儿？或者我会让所有的女儿同时拥有完美的花束吗？

I replied, half defeated already, that I wished to speak to himself only if he would give me leave.
我已经半途而废地回答说，只有在他允许我离开的情况下，我才想和自己说话。

‘My dear Miss Summerson, most joyfully! Of course,’ he said, bringing his chair nearer mine and breaking into his fascinating smile, of course it’s not business. Then it’s pleasure!’
“我亲爱的萨默森小姐，非常高兴！当然，”他一边说，一边把椅子拉近我的位置，露出迷人的微笑，当然这不是生意。那么就很高兴了！

I said it certainly was not business that I came upon, but it was not quite a pleasant matter.
我说我遇到的这件事当然不是什么生意，但这并不是一件令人愉快的事情。

‘Then, my dear Miss Summerson,’ said he with the frankest gaiety, ‘don’t allude to it. Why should you allude to anything that is NOT a pleasant matter? I never do. And you are a much pleasanter creature, in every point of view, than I. You are perfectly pleasant; I am imperfectly pleasant; then, if I never allude to an unpleasant matter, how much less should you! So that’s disposed of, and we will talk of something else.’
“那么，我亲爱的萨默森小姐，”他坦率地高兴地说，“不要提及此事。”你为什么要提及任何不愉快的事情呢？我从来没有做。从各个角度来看，你都是一个比我更令人愉快的生物。我是一个不完美的令人愉快的人；那么，如果我从不提及任何不愉快的事情，你更不应该提及！所以这个问题就解决了，我们会讨论别的事情。

Although I was embarrassed, I took courage to intimate that I still wished to pursue the subject.
尽管我很尴尬，但我鼓起勇气表示我仍然希望继续这个话题。

‘I should think it a mistake,’ said Mr. Skimpole with his airy laugh, ‘if I thought Miss Summerson capable of making one. But I don’t!’
“如果我认为萨默森小姐有能力做到这一点，”斯金波尔先生轻快地笑着说，“我应该认为这是一个错误。”但我不！

‘Mr. Skimpole,’ said I, raising my eyes to his, ‘I have so often heard you say that you are unacquainted with the common affairs of life—‘
'先生。斯基姆波尔，”我抬起眼睛看着他，说道，“我经常听到你说你不熟悉生活中的常见事务——”

‘Meaning our three banking-house friends, L, S, and who’s the junior partner? D?’ said Mr. Skimpole, brightly. ‘Not an idea of them!’
“指的是我们的三位银行朋友，L、S，谁是初级合伙人？” D？”斯金波尔先生明亮地说。 “不知道他们的想法！”

‘—That perhaps,’ I went on, ‘you will excuse my boldness on that account. I think you ought most seriously to know that Richard is poorer than he was.’
“——也许，”我继续说，“你会原谅我因此而大胆。”我认为你应该认真地知道理查德比他以前更穷。

‘Dear me!’ said Mr. Skimpole. ‘So am I, they tell me.’
“天啊！”斯金波尔先生说。 “他们告诉我，我也是。”

‘And in very embarrassed circumstances.’
“而且是在非常尴尬的情况下。”

‘Parallel case, exactly!’ said Mr. Skimpole with a delighted countenance.
“完全是平行的情况！”斯金波尔先生一脸高兴地说。

‘This at present naturally causes Ada much secret anxiety, and as I think she is less anxious when no claims are made upon her by visitors, and as Richard has one uneasiness always heavy on his mind, it has occurred to me to take the liberty of saying that—if you would—not—‘
“目前，这自然会让艾达产生很多隐秘的焦虑，而且我认为，当没有访客对她提出要求时，她会不那么焦虑，而且理查德总是有一种不安的感觉沉重地压在他的脑海里，所以我想到要冒昧地冒一下险。”说——如果你愿意的话——不——”

I was coming to the point with great difficulty when he took me by both hands and with a radiant face and in the liveliest way anticipated it.
当我好不容易才说到重点时，他用双手握住了我，脸上容光焕发，以最生动的方式期待着这一切。

‘Not go there? Certainly not, my dear Miss Summerson, most assuredly not. Why SHOULD I go there? When I go anywhere, I go for pleasure. I don’t go anywhere for pain, because I was made for pleasure. Pain comes to ME when it wants me. Now, I have had very little pleasure at our dear Richard’s lately, and your practical sagacity demonstrates why. Our young friends, losing the youthful poetry which was once so captivating in them, begin to think, ‘This is a man who wants pounds.’ So I am; I always want pounds; not for myself, but because tradespeople always want them of me. Next, our young friends begin to think, becoming mercenary, ‘This is the man who HAD pounds, who borrowed them,’ which I did. I always borrow pounds. So our young friends, reduced to prose (which is much to be regretted), degenerate in their power of imparting pleasure to me. Why should I go to see them, therefore? Absurd!’
‘不去那里吗？当然不是，我亲爱的萨默森小姐，绝对不是。我为什么要去那里？当我去任何地方时，我都是为了快乐。我不会为了痛苦而去任何地方，因为我生来就是为了快乐。当痛苦需要我的时候它就会来找我。现在，我最近在我们亲爱的理查德家几乎没有什么乐趣，你的实际智慧证明了原因。我们的年轻朋友们失去了曾经如此迷人的青春诗意，开始思考：“这是一个想要英镑的人。”我也是；我总是想要英镑；不是为了我自己，而是因为商人总是想从我这里得到它们。接下来，我们的年轻朋友开始思考，成为唯利是图的人，“这个人有英镑，是借钱的”，我也这么做了。我总是借英镑。因此，我们的年轻朋友们，沦落为散文（这是非常遗憾的），他们给我带来快乐的能力也退化了。那么我为什么要去见他们呢？荒诞！'

Through the beaming smile with which he regarded me as he reasoned thus, there now broke forth a look of disinterested benevolence quite astonishing.
当他如此推理时，他看着我的笑容中，现在爆发出一种令人惊讶的无私仁慈的神情。

‘Besides,’ he said, pursuing his argument in his tone of lighthearted conviction, ‘if I don’t go anywhere for pain—which would be a perversion of the intention of my being, and a monstrous thing to do—why should I go anywhere to be the cause of pain? If I went to see our young friends in their present ill-regulated state of mind, I should give them pain. The associations with me would be disagreeable. They might say, ‘This is the man who had pounds and who can’t pay pounds,’ which I can’t, of course; nothing could be more out of the question! Then kindness requires that I shouldn’t go near them—and I won’t.’
“此外，”他用轻松而坚定的语气继续论证，“如果我不去任何地方去寻求痛苦——这将是对我存在意图的曲解，也是一件可怕的事情——我为什么要这么做？”去哪里成为疼痛的原因？如果我去看看我们年轻的朋友们目前精神不正常的状态，我应该给他们带来痛苦。和我的交往会很不愉快。他们可能会说，“这个人有英镑，却付不起英镑”，当然，我不能；没有什么比这更不可能的了！然后出于善意，我不应该靠近他们——而且我不会。”

He finished by genially kissing my hand and thanking me. Nothing but Miss Summerson’s fine tact, he said, would have found this out for him.
最后他亲切地吻了我的手并向我表示感谢。他说，只有萨默森小姐的机智才能让他发现这一点。

I was much disconcerted, but I reflected that if the main point were gained, it mattered little how strangely he perverted everything leading to it. I had determined to mention something else, however, and I thought I was not to be put off in that.
我感到非常不安，但我想，如果要点已经达成，那么他如何奇怪地歪曲了导致这一点的一切就无关紧要了。然而，我决定提及其他事情，并且我认为我不能因此而被推迟。

‘Mr. Skimpole,’ said I, ‘I must take the liberty of saying before I conclude my visit that I was much surprised to learn, on the best authority, some little time ago, that you knew with whom that poor boy left Bleak House and that you accepted a present on that occasion. I have not mentioned it to my guardian, for I fear it would hurt him unnecessarily; but I may say to you that I was much surprised.’
'先生。斯金波尔，”我说，“在我结束访问之前，我必须冒昧地说，不久前，我很惊讶地得知，根据最权威的资料，你知道那个可怜的男孩和谁一起离开了荒凉山庄，而且那次你接受了一份礼物。我没有向我的监护人提及此事，因为我担心这会对他造成不必要的伤害；但我可以告诉你，我很惊讶。

‘No? Really surprised, my dear Miss Summerson?’ he returned inquiringly, raising his pleasant eyebrows.
'不？真的很惊讶吗，我亲爱的萨默森小姐？”他询问地回答，扬起他愉快的眉毛。

‘Greatly surprised.’
“非常惊讶。”

He thought about it for a little while with a highly agreeable and whimsical expression of face, then quite gave it up and said in his most engaging manner, ‘You know what a child I am. Why surprised?’
他想了一会儿，脸上露出一种非常和蔼可亲又异想天开的表情，然后完全放弃了，用他最迷人的方式说道：“你知道我是个什么样的孩子。”为什么感到惊讶？

I was reluctant to enter minutely into that question, but as he begged I would, for he was really curious to know, I gave him to understand in the gentlest words I could use that his conduct seemed to involve a disregard of several moral obligations. He was much amused and interested when he heard this and said, ‘No, really?’ with ingenuous simplicity.
我不愿意详细讨论这个问题，但当他恳求我这样做时，因为他真的很想知道，我用我能用的最温和的语言让他明白，他的行为似乎涉及对一些道德义务的无视。当他听到这句话时，他感到非常有趣和感兴趣，并天真地简单地说：“不，真的吗？”

‘You know I don’t intend to be responsible. I never could do it. Responsibility is a thing that has always been above me—or below me,’ said Mr. Skimpole. ‘I don’t even know which; but as I understand the way in which my dear Miss Summerson (always remarkable for her practical good sense and clearness) puts this case, I should imagine it was chiefly a question of money, do you know?’
“你知道我不想承担责任。我从来都做不到。斯金波尔先生说，责任始终是高于我或低于我的事情。 “我什至不知道是哪一个；但据我了解我亲爱的萨默森小姐（总是以她实际的良好判断力和清晰性而著称）提出这个问题的方式，我应该认为这主要是一个金钱问题，你知道吗？

I incautiously gave a qualified assent to this.
我不经意地表示有条件地同意了这一点。

‘Ah! Then you see,’ said Mr. Skimpole, shaking his head, ‘I am hopeless of understanding it.’
'啊！那么你看，”斯金波尔先生摇着头说道，“我无法理解它。”

I suggested, as I rose to go, that it was not right to betray my guardian’s confidence for a bribe.
当我起身离开时，我建议，为了贿赂而背叛监护人的信任是不对的。

‘My dear Miss Summerson,’ he returned with a candid hilarity that was all his own, ‘I can’t be bribed.’
“我亲爱的萨默森小姐，”他带着一种完全属于他自己的坦率的欢笑回答道，“我不能被贿赂。”

‘Not by Mr. Bucket?’ said I.
“不是巴克特先生写的吗？”我说。

‘No,’ said he. ‘Not by anybody. I don’t attach any value to money. I don’t care about it, I don’t know about it, I don’t want it, I don’t keep it—it goes away from me directly. How can I be bribed?’
“不，”他说。 ” “不是任何人。我不重视金钱。我不在乎它，我不知道它，我不想要它，我不保留它——它直接从我身边消失了。我怎么会被贿赂呢？

I showed that I was of a different opinion, though I had not the capacity for arguing the question.
我表明了我的不同意见，尽管我没有能力争论这个问题。

‘On the contrary,’ said Mr. Skimpole, ‘I am exactly the man to be placed in a superior position in such a case as that. I am above the rest of mankind in such a case as that. I can act with philosophy in such a case as that. I am not warped by prejudices, as an Italian baby is by bandages. I am as free as the air. I feel myself as far above suspicion as Caesar’s wife.’
“恰恰相反，”斯金波尔先生说，“在这种情况下，我正是应该被置于更有利位置的人。”在这种情况下，我高于其他人。在这种情况下我可以用哲学来行事。我没有被偏见扭曲，就像意大利婴儿被绷带扭曲一样。我就像空气一样自由。我觉得自己和凯撒的妻子一样不容怀疑。

Anything to equal the lightness of his manner and the playful impartiality with which he seemed to convince himself, as he tossed the matter about like a ball of feathers, was surely never seen in anybody else!
当他像羽毛球一样把事情抛来抛去时，他的举止轻松自如，而且他似乎说服自己的顽皮的公正性，肯定是其他人从未见过的！

‘Observe the case, my dear Miss Summerson. Here is a boy received into the house and put to bed in a state that I strongly object to. The boy being in bed, a man arrives—like the house that Jack built. Here is the man who demands the boy who is received into the house and put to bed in a state that I strongly object to. Here is a bank-note produced by the man who demands the boy who is received into the house and put to bed in a state that I strongly object to. Here is the Skimpole who accepts the bank-note produced by the man who demands the boy who is received into the house and put to bed in a state that I strongly object to. Those are the facts. Very well. Should the Skimpole have refused the note? WHY should the Skimpole have refused the note? Skimpole protests to Bucket, ‘What’s this for? I don’t understand it, it is of no use to me, take it away.’ Bucket still entreats Skimpole to accept it. Are there reasons why Skimpole, not being warped by prejudices, should accept it? Yes. Skimpole perceives them. What are they? Skimpole reasons with himself, this is a tamed lynx, an active police-officer, an intelligent man, a person of a peculiarly directed energy and great subtlety both of conception and execution, who discovers our friends and enemies for us when they run away, recovers our property for us when we are robbed, avenges us comfortably when we are murdered. This active police-officer and intelligent man has acquired, in the exercise of his art, a strong faith in money; he finds it very useful to him, and he makes it very useful to society. Shall I shake that faith in Bucket because I want it myself; shall I deliberately blunt one of Bucket’s weapons; shall I positively paralyse Bucket in his next detective operation? And again. If it is blameable in Skimpole to take the note, it is blameable in Bucket to offer the note—much more blameable in Bucket, because he is the knowing man. Now, Skimpole wishes to think well of Bucket; Skimpole deems it essential, in its little place, to the general cohesion of things, that he SHOULD think well of Bucket. The state expressly asks him to trust to Bucket. And he does. And that’s all he does!’
“观察这个情况，我亲爱的萨默森小姐。这是一个我强烈反对的男孩被带进屋并放在床上的情况。男孩正在床上，一个男人到来了——就像杰克建造的房子一样。这是一个男人，他要求男孩被带进屋，并以我强烈反对的状态放在床上。这是一张由男子出示的钞票，他要求男孩被带进屋，并以我强烈反对的状态放在床上。斯金波尔接受了一个男人出示的钞票，并要求男孩被带进屋，并以我强烈反对的状态放在床上。这些都是事实。很好。斯金波尔应该拒绝这张纸条吗？为什么斯金波尔要拒绝这张纸条？斯金波尔向巴克特抗议，“这是做什么用的？”我不明白，它对我没有用，把它拿走吧。”巴克特仍然恳求斯基姆波尔接受它。斯金波尔没有被偏见所扭曲，有什么理由应该接受它呢？是的。斯金波尔察觉到了它们。这些是什么？斯金波尔自言自语，这是一只被驯服的山猫，一个活跃的警察，一个聪明的人，一个具有独特的定向能量和构思和执行的高度微妙的人，当我们的朋友和敌人逃跑时，他为我们发现他们，当我们被抢劫时，为我们夺回财产；当我们被谋杀时，为我们报仇。这位活跃的警官和聪明人在他的艺术实践中，对金钱产生了坚定的信念。他发现它对他非常有用，他也让它对社会非常有用。我是否应该动摇对 Bucket 的信心，因为我自己也想要它？我应该故意弄钝巴克特的一把武器吗？我应该在巴克特的下一次侦探行动中积极地瘫痪他吗？然后再次。 如果说斯基姆波尔拿纸条是有罪的，那么巴克特提供纸条就应该受到谴责——而巴克特更应该受到谴责，因为他是知情者。现在，斯金波尔希望对巴克特有好感。斯金波尔认为，就事物的总体凝聚力而言，在其微小的地方，他应该好好考虑巴克特。州政府明确要求他信任巴克特。他确实做到了。这就是他所做的一切！’

I had nothing to offer in reply to this exposition and therefore took my leave. Mr. Skimpole, however, who was in excellent spirits, would not hear of my returning home attended only by ‘Little Coavinses,’ and accompanied me himself. He entertained me on the way with a variety of delightful conversation and assured me, at parting, that he should never forget the fine tact with which I had found that out for him about our young friends.
我对这个解释没有什么可提供的，因此就告辞了。然而，斯金波尔先生心情很好，不肯听到我回家时只有“小科文斯”陪伴，他亲自陪我回家。路上他用各种愉快的谈话招待我，并在临别时向我保证，他永远不会忘记我为他发现我们年轻朋友的巧妙机智。

As it so happened that I never saw Mr. Skimpole again, I may at once finish what I know of his history. A coolness arose between him and my guardian, based principally on the foregoing grounds and on his having heartlessly disregarded my guardian’s entreaties (as we afterwards learned from Ada) in reference to Richard. His being heavily in my guardian’s debt had nothing to do with their separation. He died some five years afterwards and left a diary behind him, with letters and other materials towards his life, which was published and which showed him to have been the victim of a combination on the part of mankind against an amiable child. It was considered very pleasant reading, but I never read more of it myself than the sentence on which I chanced to light on opening the book. It was this: ‘Jarndyce, in common with most other men I have known, is the incarnation of selfishness.’
碰巧我再也没有见过斯金波尔先生，所以我可以立即讲完我所知道的关于他的历史。他和我的监护人之间出现了冷淡，主要是基于上述理由，以及他无情地无视我监护人对理查德的恳求（正如我们后来从艾达那里得知的那样）。他欠我监护人的债与他们的分居无关。大约五年后，他去世了，留下了一本日记，其中有信件和其他有关他生活的材料，这些日记被出版，表明他是人类联合起来对付一个可爱的孩子的受害者。这本书被认为是非常令人愉快的读物，但我自己读到的内容最多不过是我打开这本书时偶然看到的那句话。正是这样：“与我所认识的大多数其他男人一样，贾迪斯是自私的化身。”

And now I come to a part of my story touching myself very nearly indeed, and for which I was quite unprepared when the circumstance occurred. Whatever little lingerings may have now and then revived in my mind associated with my poor old face had only revived as belonging to a part of my life that was gone—gone like my infancy or my childhood. I have suppressed none of my many weaknesses on that subject, but have written them as faithfully as my memory has recalled them. And I hope to do, and mean to do, the same down to the last words of these pages, which I see now not so very far before me.
现在，我的故事的一部分确实非常触动我自己，而当情况发生时我对此毫无准备。无论那些与我可怜的老脸相关的小事时不时地在我脑海中浮现，都只是作为属于我生命中已经消失的一部分而复活——就像我的婴儿期或童年一样。我并没有隐瞒自己在这个问题上的许多弱点，而是按照我的记忆所回忆的那样忠实地写下了它们。我希望也打算这样做，直到这几页的最后几个字，我现在就看到这些内容就在我眼前。

The months were gliding away, and my dear girl, sustained by the hopes she had confided in me, was the same beautiful star in the miserable corner. Richard, more worn and haggard, haunted the court day after day, listlessly sat there the whole day long when he knew there was no remote chance of the suit being mentioned, and became one of the stock sights of the place. I wonder whether any of the gentlemen remembered him as he was when he first went there.
几个月过去了，我亲爱的女儿，靠她向我吐露的希望支撑着，成为悲惨角落里那颗美丽的星星。理查德更加疲惫和憔悴，日复一日地出没在法庭上，当他知道诉讼案被提及的可能性微乎其微时，他无精打采地坐了一整天，成为了这个地方的常见景观之一。我不知道是否有先生还记得他第一次去那里时的样子。

So completely was he absorbed in his fixed idea that he used to avow in his cheerful moments that he should never have breathed the fresh air now ‘but for Woodcourt.’ It was only Mr. Woodcourt who could occasionally divert his attention for a few hours at a time and rouse him, even when he sunk into a lethargy of mind and body that alarmed us greatly, and the returns of which became more frequent as the months went on. My dear girl was right in saying that he only pursued his errors the more desperately for her sake. I have no doubt that his desire to retrieve what he had lost was rendered the more intense by his grief for his young wife, and became like the madness of a gamester.
他完全沉浸在自己固定的想法中，以至于他常常在快乐的时刻发誓，“如果不是伍德考特”，他现在根本不应该呼吸新鲜空气。只有伍德考特先生才能偶尔转移他的注意力几个小时。即使他的身心陷入昏睡状态，这也让我们非常震惊，而且随着时间的推移，这种情况的出现变得更加频繁。我亲爱的女孩说得对，他只是为了她而更加拼命地追寻自己的错误。我毫不怀疑，他对年轻妻子的悲伤使他想要找回失去的东西的愿望更加强烈，变得像赌徒一样疯狂。

I was there, as I have mentioned, at all hours. When I was there at night, I generally went home with Charley in a coach; sometimes my guardian would meet me in the neighbourhood, and we would walk home together. One evening he had arranged to meet me at eight o’clock. I could not leave, as I usually did, quite punctually at the time, for I was working for my dear girl and had a few stitches more to do to finish what I was about; but it was within a few minutes of the hour when I bundled up my little work-basket, gave my darling my last kiss for the night, and hurried downstairs. Mr. Woodcourt went with me, as it was dusk.
正如我所提到的，我随时都在那里。当我晚上在那里的时候，我通常会和查理一起乘坐马车回家。有时我的监护人会在附近遇见我，我们会一起走回家。一天晚上，他约好八点钟来见我。我当时无法像往常一样准时离开，因为我正在为我亲爱的女儿工作，还需要缝几针才能完成我的工作；但不到几分钟，我就收拾好我的小工作篮，给了我亲爱的今晚最后一个吻，然后匆匆下了楼。伍德考特先生和我一起去，因为当时是黄昏。

When we came to the usual place of meeting—it was close by, and Mr. Woodcourt had often accompanied me before—my guardian was not there. We waited half an hour, walking up and down, but there were no signs of him. We agreed that he was either prevented from coming or that he had come and gone away, and Mr. Woodcourt proposed to walk home with me.
当我们来到平常见面的地方时——就在附近，伍德考特先生以前也经常陪我——我的监护人不在那里。我们等了半个小时，走来走去，却不见他的踪影。我们一致认为，他要么被阻止来，要么他来了又走了，伍德考特先生提议和我一起走回家。

It was the first walk we had ever taken together, except that very short one to the usual place of meeting. We spoke of Richard and Ada the whole way. I did not thank him in words for what he had done—my appreciation of it had risen above all words then—but I hoped he might not be without some understanding of what I felt so strongly.
这是我们第一次一起散步，除了到通常见面地点的那条路很短。我们一路上都在谈论理查德和艾达。我没有用言语感谢他所做的事情——当时我对他的感激之情已经超过了任何言语——但我希望他不会不理解我如此强烈的感受。

Arriving at home and going upstairs, we found that my guardian was out and that Mrs. Woodcourt was out too. We were in the very same room into which I had brought my blushing girl when her youthful lover, now her so altered husband, was the choice of her young heart, the very same room from which my guardian and I had watched them going away through the sunlight in the fresh bloom of their hope and promise.
到家上楼后，我们发现我的监护人出去了，伍德考特夫人也出去了。我们就在同一个房间里，我把我脸红的女孩带进了同一个房间，当时她年轻的情人，现在是她改变了的丈夫，是她年轻的心的选择，也是我和我的监护人看着他们离开的同一个房间。他们的希望和承诺在阳光下绽放。

We were standing by the opened window looking down into the street when Mr. Woodcourt spoke to me. I learned in a moment that he loved me. I learned in a moment that my scarred face was all unchanged to him. I learned in a moment that what I had thought was pity and compassion was devoted, generous, faithful love. Oh, too late to know it now, too late, too late. That was the first ungrateful thought I had. Too late.
当伍德考特先生对我说话时，我们正站在打开的窗户旁，俯视着街道。在那一刻我知道他爱我。刹那间我发现，我那张伤痕累累的脸对他来说毫无改变。刹那间我明白了，我所认为的怜悯和慈悲其实是忠诚、慷慨、忠实的爱。哦，现在知道已经太晚了，太晚了，太晚了。这是我第一个忘恩负义的想法。为时已晚。

‘When I returned,’ he told me, ‘when I came back, no richer than when I went away, and found you newly risen from a sick bed, yet so inspired by sweet consideration for others and so free from a selfish thought—‘
“当我回来时，”他告诉我，“当我回来时，并不比我离开时更富有，发现你刚从病床上爬起来，却如此受到对他人的甜蜜关怀的启发，如此摆脱了自私的想法—— '

‘Oh, Mr. Woodcourt, forbear, forbear!’ I entreated him. ‘I do not deserve your high praise. I had many selfish thoughts at that time, many!’
“哦，伍德考特先生，忍住，忍住！”我恳求他。 ‘我不值得你的高度赞扬。我当时有很多自私的想法，很多！

‘Heaven knows, beloved of my life,’ said he, ‘that my praise is not a lover’s praise, but the truth. You do not know what all around you see in Esther Summerson, how many hearts she touches and awakens, what sacred admiration and what love she wins.’
“天知道，我一生的挚爱，”他说，“我的赞美不是情人的赞美，而是事实。”你不知道你在埃丝特·萨默森身上看到了什么，她触动和唤醒了多少人的心，她赢得了多少神圣的钦佩和爱。”

‘Oh, Mr. Woodcourt,’ cried I, ‘it is a great thing to win love, it is a great thing to win love! I am proud of it, and honoured by it; and the hearing of it causes me to shed these tears of mingled joy and sorrow—joy that I have won it, sorrow that I have not deserved it better; but I am not free to think of yours.’
“哦，伍德考特先生，”我喊道，“赢得爱情是一件伟大的事情，赢得爱情是一件伟大的事情！我为此感到自豪，并以此为荣；听到这个消息，我流下了喜悦与悲伤交织的泪水——喜悦是我赢得了它，悲伤是我没有得到更好的奖赏。但我不能自由地想你的。

I said it with a stronger heart, for when he praised me thus and when I heard his voice thrill with his belief that what he said was true, I aspired to be more worthy of it. It was not too late for that. Although I closed this unforeseen page in my life to-night, I could be worthier of it all through my life. And it was a comfort to me, and an impulse to me, and I felt a dignity rise up within me that was derived from him when I thought so.
我怀着更坚强的心说这句话，因为当他这样称赞我时，当我听到他的声音因他相信他所说的是真的而激动时，我渴望更配得上它。现在还不算太晚。尽管今晚我结束了生命中这不可预见的一页，但我一生都可以更值得它。这对我来说是一种安慰，对我来说是一种冲动，当我这么想时，我感到一种来自他的尊严在我内心升起。

He broke the silence.
他打破了沉默。

‘I should poorly show the trust that I have in the dear one who will evermore be as dear to me as now’—and the deep earnestness with which he said it at once strengthened me and made me weep— ‘if, after her assurance that she is not free to think of my love, I urged it. Dear Esther, let me only tell you that the fond idea of you which I took abroad was exalted to the heavens when I came home. I have always hoped, in the first hour when I seemed to stand in any ray of good fortune, to tell you this. I have always feared that I should tell it you in vain. My hopes and fears are both fulfilled to-night. I distress you. I have said enough.’
“我不应该表现出我对亲爱的人的信任，他将永远像现在一样对我来说是亲爱的”——他说这句话时所表现出的深深的诚挚立刻使我坚强起来，让我哭泣——“如果在她保证之后“她不能自由地思考我的爱，”我催促道。亲爱的埃丝特，我只能告诉你，当我回到家时，我在国外对你的好感已升上天堂。我一直希望，在我似乎处于幸运之光的第一个小时里，能告诉你这一点。我一直担心我告诉你是徒劳的。我的希望和恐惧今晚都实现了。我心疼你了。我已经说得够多了。

Something seemed to pass into my place that was like the angel he thought me, and I felt so sorrowful for the loss he had sustained! I wished to help him in his trouble, as I had wished to do when he showed that first commiseration for me.
似乎有什么东西进入了我的位置，就像他心目中的天使一样，我为他所遭受的损失感到非常悲伤！我希望帮助他摆脱困境，正如他最初对我表示同情时我所希望的那样。

‘Dear Mr. Woodcourt,’ said I, ‘before we part to-night, something is left for me to say. I never could say it as I wish—I never shall—but—‘
“亲爱的伍德考特先生，”我说，“在我们今晚分手之前，我有件事要说。我永远无法如我所愿地说出来——我永远不会——但是——”

I had to think again of being more deserving of his love and his affliction before I could go on.
在我继续前进之前，我必须再次思考是否更值得他的爱和他的痛苦。

‘—I am deeply sensible of your generosity, and I shall treasure its remembrance to my dying hour. I know full well how changed I am, I know you are not unacquainted with my history, and I know what a noble love that is which is so faithful. What you have said to me could have affected me so much from no other lips, for there are none that could give it such a value to me. It shall not be lost. It shall make me better.’
“——我深深地感受到你的慷慨，我将珍惜它，直到我临死之时。我很清楚我的变化有多大，我知道你对我的历史并不陌生，我知道那是一种多么崇高而忠诚的爱。你对我说的话不可能从其他人嘴里对我产生如此大的影响，因为没有人能给我如此的价值。它不会丢失。它会让我变得更好。

He covered his eyes with his hand and turned away his head. How could I ever be worthy of those tears?
他用手捂住眼睛，转过头去。我怎么配得上那些泪水？

‘If, in the unchanged intercourse we shall have together—in tending Richard and Ada, and I hope in many happier scenes of life —you ever find anything in me which you can honestly think is better than it used to be, believe that it will have sprung up from to-night and that I shall owe it to you. And never believe, dear dear Mr. Woodcourt, never believe that I forget this night or that while my heart beats it can be insensible to the pride and joy of having been beloved by you.’
“如果，在我们在一起不变的交往中——照顾理查德和艾达，我希望在生活中许多更幸福的场景中——你在我身上发现了任何你可以诚实地认为比以前更好的东西，相信它从今晚开始，我将把它归功于你。永远不要相信，亲爱的伍德考特先生，永远不要相信我会忘记这个夜晚，或者当我的心脏跳动时，它会麻木不仁地感受到被你所爱的骄傲和喜悦。

He took my hand and kissed it. He was like himself again, and I felt still more encouraged.
他握住我的手并吻了它。他又恢复了原来的样子，我更加受到鼓舞。

‘I am induced by what you said just now,’ said I, ‘to hope that you have succeeded in your endeavour.’
“我被你刚才的话所吸引，”我说，“希望你的努力能够成功。”

‘I have,’ he answered. ‘With such help from Mr. Jarndyce as you who know him so well can imagine him to have rendered me, I have succeeded.’
“我有，”他回答。 “在贾迪斯先生的帮助下，你们这些非常了解他的人都可以想象他是如何成就了我，我成功了。”

‘Heaven bless him for it,’ said I, giving him my hand; ‘and heaven bless you in all you do!’
“愿上帝保佑他，”我一边说，一边把手伸给他。 “愿上天保佑你所做的一切！”

‘I shall do it better for the wish,’ he answered; ‘it will make me enter on these new duties as on another sacred trust from you.’
“为了这个愿望，我会做得更好。”他回答道。 “这将使我承担起这些新的职责，就像接受您的另一项神圣委托一样。”

‘Ah! Richard!’ I exclaimed involuntarily, ‘What will he do when you are gone!’
'啊！理查德！”我不由自主地喊道，“你走了之后他会做什么！”

‘I am not required to go yet; I would not desert him, dear Miss Summerson, even if I were.’
“我还没有被要求去；亲爱的萨默森小姐，即使我愿意，我也不会抛弃他。

One other thing I felt it needful to touch upon before he left me. I knew that I should not be worthier of the love I could not take if I reserved it.
在他离开我之前，我觉得有必要谈一谈另一件事。我知道如果我保留了我无法接受的爱，我就不会更值得。

‘Mr. Woodcourt,’ said I, ‘you will be glad to know from my lips before I say good night that in the future, which is clear and bright before me, I am most happy, most fortunate, have nothing to regret or desire.’
'先生。 “伍德考特先生，”我说，“在我说晚安之前，你会很高兴从我的嘴里知道，在我面前清晰明亮的未来，我是最幸福的，最幸运的，没有什么可后悔或渴望的。”

It was indeed a glad hearing to him, he replied.
他回答说，这对他来说确实是一个很高兴的事情。

‘From my childhood I have been,’ said I, ‘the object of the untiring goodness of the best of human beings, to whom I am so bound by every tie of attachment, gratitude, and love, that nothing I could do in the compass of a life could express the feelings of a single day.’
我说：“从我的童年起，我就一直是最优秀的人类的不懈善良的对象，我对他们的依恋、感激和爱是如此紧密地联系在一起，以至于我在这个世界上什么也做不了。”生命的罗盘可以表达一天的感受。

‘I share those feelings,’ he returned. ‘You speak of Mr. Jarndyce.’
“我也有同样的感受，”他回答道。 “你说的是贾迪斯先生。”

‘You know his virtues well,’ said I, ‘but few can know the greatness of his character as I know it. All its highest and best qualities have been revealed to me in nothing more brightly than in the shaping out of that future in which I am so happy. And if your highest homage and respect had not been his already—which I know they are—they would have been his, I think, on this assurance and in the feeling it would have awakened in you towards him for my sake.’
“你很了解他的美德，”我说，“但很少有人能像我一样了解他性格的伟大之处。”它的所有最高和最好的品质都在我如此幸福的未来的塑造中更加明亮地向我展示。如果你还没有向他致以最高的敬意和尊重——我知道它们是——我想，基于这种保证和这种感觉，你会为了我而对他产生敬意和尊重。

He fervently replied that indeed indeed they would have been. I gave him my hand again.
他热切地回答说，确实如此。我再次把手伸给他。

‘Good night,’ I said, ‘Good-bye.’
“晚安，”我说，“再见。”

‘The first until we meet to-morrow, the second as a farewell to this theme between us for ever.’
“第一个直到我们明天见面，第二个是我们之间永远告别这个主题。”

‘Yes.’
'是的。'

‘Good night; good-bye.’
'晚安;再见。'

He left me, and I stood at the dark window watching the street. His love, in all its constancy and generosity, had come so suddenly upon me that he had not left me a minute when my fortitude gave way again and the street was blotted out by my rushing tears.
他离开了我，我站在黑暗的窗前看着街道。他的爱，以其坚定不移和慷慨，来得如此突然，以至于他一分钟没有离开我，我的毅力又消失了，街道被我汹涌的泪水淹没了。

But they were not tears of regret and sorrow. No. He had called me the beloved of his life and had said I would be evermore as dear to him as I was then, and I felt as if my heart would not hold the triumph of having heard those words. My first wild thought had died away. It was not too late to hear them, for it was not too late to be animated by them to be good, true, grateful, and contented. How easy my path, how much easier than his!
但它们并不是悔恨和悲伤的眼泪。不。他称我为他生命中的挚爱，并说我将永远像当时一样亲爱的，而我感觉我的心似乎无法承受听到这些话的胜利。我第一个疯狂的想法已经消失了。现在聆听他们的声音还不算太晚，因为被他们激励起来变得善良、真实、感恩和满足还不算太晚。我的路多么容易，比他的容易得多！

CHAPTER LXII
第六十二章


Another Discovery
另一个发现

I had not the courage to see any one that night. I had not even the courage to see myself, for I was afraid that my tears might a little reproach me. I went up to my room in the dark, and prayed in the dark, and lay down in the dark to sleep. I had no need of any light to read my guardian’s letter by, for I knew it by heart. I took it from the place where I kept it, and repeated its contents by its own clear light of integrity and love, and went to sleep with it on my pillow.
那天晚上我没有勇气去见任何人。我连看自己的勇气都没有，因为我害怕我的眼泪会责备我。我在黑暗中回到自己的房间，在黑暗中祈祷，然后在黑暗中躺下睡觉。我不需要任何灯光来阅读我监护人的信，因为我已经熟记在心了。我把它从我放它的地方拿出来，用它自己清晰的正直和爱的光芒重复了它的内容，然后把它放在枕头上睡觉了。

I was up very early in the morning and called Charley to come for a walk. We bought flowers for the breakfast-table, and came back and arranged them, and were as busy as possible. We were so early that I had a good time still for Charley’s lesson before breakfast; Charley (who was not in the least improved in the old defective article of grammar) came through it with great applause; and we were altogether very notable. When my guardian appeared he said, ‘Why, little woman, you look fresher than your flowers!’ And Mrs. Woodcourt repeated and translated a passage from the Mewlinnwillinwodd expressive of my being like a mountain with the sun upon it.
我一大早起床，打电话给查理来散步。我们买了早餐桌上的鲜花，回来后把它们摆好，忙得不可开交。我们来得很早，所以早餐前我仍然很开心地听查理的课。查理（他在旧有缺陷的语法文章中没有丝毫进步）在热烈的掌声中完成了它。我们都是非常引人注目的。当我的监护人出现时，他说：“嘿，小女人，你看起来比你的花还新鲜！”伍德考特夫人重复并翻译了《Mewlinnwillinwodd》中的一段话，表达了我就像一座阳光照耀的山。

This was all so pleasant that I hope it made me still more like the mountain than I had been before. After breakfast I waited my opportunity and peeped about a little until I saw my guardian in his own room—the room of last night—by himself. Then I made an excuse to go in with my housekeeping keys, shutting the door after me.
这一切是如此令人愉快，我希望这能让我比以前更加喜欢这座山。早餐后，我等待机会，四处张望，直到我看到我的监护人独自一人在他自己的房间里——昨晚的房间里。然后我借口拿着家务钥匙进去，关上了门。

‘Well, Dame Durden?’ said my guardian; the post had brought him several letters, and he was writing. ‘You want money?’
“怎么样，德登夫人？”我的监护人说道。邮局给他带来了几封信，他正在写信。 '你想要钱？'

‘No, indeed, I have plenty in hand.’
“不，确实，我手上还有很多。”

‘There never was such a Dame Durden,’ said my guardian, ‘for making money last.’
我的监护人说：“从来没有一位杜登夫人能把钱放在最后。”

He had laid down his pen and leaned back in his chair looking at me. I have often spoken of his bright face, but I thought I had never seen it look so bright and good. There was a high happiness upon it which made me think, ‘He has been doing some great kindness this morning.’
他放下笔，靠在椅子上看着我。我经常说起他那张明亮的脸，但我想我从来没有见过它看起来如此明亮和美好。它充满了高度的幸福感，让我想：“他今天早上做了一些伟大的善事。”

‘There never was,’ said my guardian, musing as he smiled upon me, ‘such a Dame Durden for making money last.’
“从来没有，”我的监护人一边对我微笑，一边若有所思地说，“杜登夫人是最后才赚钱的。”

He had never yet altered his old manner. I loved it and him so much that when I now went up to him and took my usual chair, which was always put at his side—for sometimes I read to him, and sometimes I talked to him, and sometimes I silently worked by him— I hardly liked to disturb it by laying my hand on his breast. But I found I did not disturb it at all.
他从来没有改变过他的旧作风。我非常喜欢它和他，以至于当我走到他面前，坐在我常用的椅子上时，它总是放在他身边——因为有时我读书给他听，有时我和他说话，有时我默默地在他身边工作——我几乎不喜欢把手放在他的胸口上来打扰它。但我发现我根本没有打扰它。

‘Dear guardian,’ said I, ‘I want to speak to you. Have I been remiss in anything?’
“亲爱的监护人，”我说，“我想和你谈谈。”我有什么疏忽吗？

‘Remiss in anything, my dear!’
“做任何事都不能疏忽，亲爱的！”

‘Have I not been what I have meant to be since—I brought the answer to your letter, guardian?’
“自从我给你的信带来回信以来，我难道就没有成为我应该成为的人吗，监护人？”

‘You have been everything I could desire, my love.’
“我的爱人，你就是我所渴望的一切。”

‘I am very glad indeed to hear that,’ I returned. ‘You know, you said to me, was this the mistress of Bleak House. And I said, yes.’
“我确实很高兴听到这个消息，”我回答道。 ‘你知道吗，你对我说，这就是荒凉山庄的女主人。我说，是的。

‘Yes,’ said my guardian, nodding his head. He had put his arm about me as if there were something to protect me from and looked in my face, smiling.
“是的，”我的监护人点点头说道。他用手臂搂住我，仿佛有什么东西可以保护我，并微笑着看着我的脸。

‘Since then,’ said I, ‘we have never spoken on the subject except once.’
“从那时起，”我说，“除了一次之外，我们再也没有谈论过这个话题。”

‘And then I said Bleak House was thinning fast; and so it was, my dear.’
“然后我说《荒凉山庄》正在迅速减少；事情就是这样，亲爱的。”

‘And I said,’ I timidly reminded him, ‘but its mistress remained.’
“我说过，”我胆怯地提醒他，“但它的女主人仍然存在。”

He still held me in the same protecting manner and with the same bright goodness in his face.
他仍然以同样的保护方式抱着我，脸上仍然带着同样明亮的善良。

‘Dear guardian,’ said I, ‘I know how you have felt all that has happened, and how considerate you have been. As so much time has passed, and as you spoke only this morning of my being so well again, perhaps you expect me to renew the subject. Perhaps I ought to do so. I will be the mistress of Bleak House when you please.’
“亲爱的监护人，”我说，“我知道你对所发生的一切有什么感受，也知道你是多么体贴。时间已经过去了，而且你今天早上才谈到我的情况又恢复得这么好，也许你希望我重新讨论这个话题。也许我应该这样做。只要你愿意，我就会成为《荒凉山庄》的女主人。

‘See,’ he returned gaily, ‘what a sympathy there must be between us! I have had nothing else, poor Rick excepted—it’s a large exception—in my mind. When you came in, I was full of it. When shall we give Bleak House its mistress, little woman?’
“瞧，”他高兴地回答道，“我们之间一定有多么同情啊！在我看来，除可怜的瑞克外，我一无所有——这是一个很大的例外。当你进来的时候，我已经充满了它。我们什么时候才能让荒凉山庄成为她的女主人，小女人？

‘When you please.’
“只要你愿意。”

‘Next month?’
'下个月？'

‘Next month, dear guardian.’
“下个月，亲爱的监护人。”

‘The day on which I take the happiest and best step of my life—the day on which I shall be a man more exulting and more enviable than any other man in the world—the day on which I give Bleak House its little mistress—shall be next month then,’ said my guardian.
“在这一天，我迈出了一生中最幸福、最美好的一步，在这一天，我将成为一个比世界上任何其他人都更兴奋、更令人羡慕的人，在这一天，我给《荒凉山庄》一个小女主人——那就下个月吧，”我的监护人说。

I put my arms round his neck and kissed him just as I had done on the day when I brought my answer.
我用双臂搂住他的脖子，亲吻他，就像我带来答案的那一天一样。

A servant came to the door to announce Mr. Bucket, which was quite unnecessary, for Mr. Bucket was already looking in over the servant’s shoulder. ‘Mr. Jarndyce and Miss Summerson,’ said he, rather out of breath, ‘with all apologies for intruding, WILL you allow me to order up a person that’s on the stairs and that objects to being left there in case of becoming the subject of observations in his absence? Thank you. Be so good as chair that there member in this direction, will you?’ said Mr. Bucket, beckoning over the banisters.
一个仆人走到门口通报巴克特先生，这完全没有必要，因为巴克特先生已经越过仆人的肩膀往里看。 '先生。贾迪斯和萨默森小姐，”他气喘吁吁地说，“对于打扰您深表歉意，请允许我命令一个在楼梯上的人，他反对留在那儿，以防成为观察的对象。他的缺席？谢谢。 “当好主席，让这个方向有成员，好吗？”巴克特先生一边说，一边在栏杆上招手。

This singular request produced an old man in a black skull-cap, unable to walk, who was carried up by a couple of bearers and deposited in the room near the door. Mr. Bucket immediately got rid of the bearers, mysteriously shut the door, and bolted it.
这个奇特的要求催生了一位头戴黑色小便帽、无法行走的老人，由几个轿夫抬了出来，放在靠近门的房间里。巴克特先生立即摆脱了轿夫，神秘地关上了门，并上了锁。

‘Now you see, Mr. Jarndyce,’ he then began, putting down his hat and opening his subject with a flourish of his well-remembered finger, ‘you know me, and Miss Summerson knows me. This gentleman likewise knows me, and his name is Smallweed. The discounting line is his line principally, and he’s what you may call a dealer in bills. That’s about what YOU are, you know, ain’t you?’ said Mr. Bucket, stopping a little to address the gentleman in question, who was exceedingly suspicious of him.
“现在你看，贾迪斯先生，”他放下帽子，用他那记忆深刻的手指一挥，开始了他的话题，“你认识我，萨默森小姐也认识我。”这位先生也认识我，他的名字叫斯莫威德。贴现线主要是他的线，他就是你所说的票据经销商。 “这就是你的身份，你知道，不是吗？”巴克特先生稍稍停下来对那位对他非常怀疑的绅士说道。

He seemed about to dispute this designation of himself when he was seized with a violent fit of coughing.
当他突然剧烈咳嗽时，他似乎正要对自己的这一称呼提出异议。

‘Now, moral, you know!’ said Mr. Bucket, improving the accident. ‘Don’t you contradict when there ain’t no occasion, and you won’t be took in that way. Now, Mr. Jarndyce, I address myself to you. I’ve been negotiating with this gentleman on behalf of Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, and one way and another I’ve been in and out and about his premises a deal. His premises are the premises formerly occupied by Krook, marine store dealer—a relation of this gentleman’s that you saw in his life-time if I don’t mistake?’
“现在，道德，你知道！”巴克特先生说道，改善了这次事故。 ‘没有必要的时候不要反驳，这样你就不会被那样对待了。现在，贾迪斯先生，我向您讲话。我一直代表莱斯特·戴德洛克男爵爵士与这位绅士进行谈判，我也曾多次进出过他的住所，就一笔交易达成了协议。他的住所是海事商店经销商克鲁克以前住过的地方——如果我没记错的话，你在生前见过这位先生的亲戚？

My guardian replied, ‘Yes.’
我的监护人回答说：“是的。”

‘Well! You are to understand,’ said Mr. Bucket, ‘that this gentleman he come into Krook’s property, and a good deal of magpie property there was. Vast lots of waste-paper among the rest. Lord bless you, of no use to nobody!’
'出色地！你要明白，”巴克特先生说，“这位先生进入了克鲁克的财产，那里有很多喜鹊的财产。其中还有大量废纸。上帝保佑你，对任何人都没有用！

The cunning of Mr. Bucket’s eye and the masterly manner in which he contrived, without a look or a word against which his watchful auditor could protest, to let us know that he stated the case according to previous agreement and could say much more of Mr. Smallweed if he thought it advisable, deprived us of any merit in quite understanding him. His difficulty was increased by Mr. Smallweed’s being deaf as well as suspicious and watching his face with the closest attention.
巴克特先生狡猾的眼睛和巧妙的方式，没有让他警惕的审计员可以抗议的一个表情或一句话，让我们知道他按照先前的协议陈述了这个情况，并且可以对先生说更多的话。如果斯莫尔威德认为这是明智的，那么我们就没有任何充分了解他的优点了。斯莫尔韦德先生既聋又多疑，而且全神贯注地看着他的脸，这增加了他的困难。

‘Among them odd heaps of old papers, this gentleman, when he comes into the property, naturally begins to rummage, don’t you see?’ said Mr. Bucket.
“在这些奇怪的旧文件堆中，这位先生一进屋，自然就开始翻找，你没看到吗？”巴克特先生说。

‘To which? Say that again,’ cried Mr. Smallweed in a shrill, sharp voice.
‘到哪个？ “再说一遍。”斯莫尔韦德先生用尖锐的声音喊道。

‘To rummage,’ repeated Mr. Bucket. ‘Being a prudent man and accustomed to take care of your own affairs, you begin to rummage among the papers as you have come into; don’t you?’
“翻找，”巴克特先生重复道。 “作为一个谨慎的人，习惯于处理自己的事情，你开始翻阅你所得到的文件；你不是吗？

‘Of course I do,’ cried Mr. Smallweed.
“我当然知道，”斯莫威德先生喊道。

‘Of course you do,’ said Mr. Bucket conversationally, ‘and much to blame you would be if you didn’t. And so you chance to find, you know,’ Mr. Bucket went on, stooping over him with an air of cheerful raillery which Mr. Smallweed by no means reciprocated, ‘and so you chance to find, you know, a paper with the signature of Jarndyce to it. Don’t you?’
“你当然知道，”巴克特先生闲聊地说，“如果你不这样做，你就会受到很大的责备。”所以你有机会找到，你知道，”巴克特先生继续说道，弯下身子，脸上带着一种愉快的嘲讽的神情，斯莫尔韦德先生却没有回应，“所以你有机会找到，你知道，一份带有贾迪斯的签名。你不是吗？

Mr. Smallweed glanced with a troubled eye at us and grudgingly nodded assent.
斯莫威德先生用困惑的眼神看了我们一眼，勉强点头表示同意。

‘And coming to look at that paper at your full leisure and convenience—all in good time, for you’re not curious to read it, and why should you be?—what do you find it to be but a will, you see. That’s the drollery of it,’ said Mr. Bucket with the same lively air of recalling a joke for the enjoyment of Mr. Smallweed, who still had the same crest-fallen appearance of not enjoying it at all; ‘what do you find it to be but a will?’
“在你完全闲暇和方便的时候来看看那篇论文——一切都恰逢其时，因为你并不好奇去读它，你为什么应该好奇呢？——你发现它除了一份遗嘱之外还有什么，你瞧。 “这就是滑稽之处。”巴克特先生说道，语气中带着同样活泼的神情，就像回忆起斯莫威德先生的一个笑话一样，而斯莫威德先生仍然一副垂头丧气的样子，根本不喜欢这个笑话。 “你认为这除了遗嘱之外还有什么？”

‘I don’t know that it’s good as a will or as anything else,’ snarled Mr. Smallweed.
“我不知道它作为遗嘱或其他什么东西好，”斯莫威德先生咆哮道。

Mr. Bucket eyed the old man for a moment—he had slipped and shrunk down in his chair into a mere bundle—as if he were much disposed to pounce upon him; nevertheless, he continued to bend over him with the same agreeable air, keeping the corner of one of his eyes upon us.
”尽管如此，他仍然以同样令人愉快的神情向他俯身，用眼角的余光看着我们。

‘Notwithstanding which,’ said Mr. Bucket, ‘you get a little doubtful and uncomfortable in your mind about it, having a very tender mind of your own.’
“尽管如此，”巴克特先生说，“你的内心还是会感到有点怀疑和不安，因为你自己的内心非常温柔。”

‘Eh? What do you say I have got of my own?’ asked Mr. Smallweed with his hand to his ear.
‘呃？ “你说我自己有什么？”斯莫威德先生用手捂住耳朵问道。

‘A very tender mind.’
“一颗非常温柔的心。”

‘Ho! Well, go on,’ said Mr. Smallweed.
‘嗬！好吧，继续吧，”斯莫威德先生说。

‘And as you’ve heard a good deal mentioned regarding a celebrated Chancery will case of the same name, and as you know what a card Krook was for buying all manner of old pieces of furniter, and books, and papers, and what not, and never liking to part with ‘em, and always a-going to teach himself to read, you begin to think— and you never was more correct in your born days—‘Ecod, if I don’t look about me, I may get into trouble regarding this will.’’
“正如你所听到的，关于一个著名的大法官法庭的同名案件，你也知道，克鲁克是一张什么样的卡片，可以用来购买各种旧家具、书籍、纸张等等。” ，并且永远不想与他们分开，并且总是要自学读书，你开始思考——在你出生的时候你从来没有这么正确过——“Ecod，如果我不看看我自己，我可能会因这份遗嘱而陷入麻烦。”

‘Now, mind how you put it, Bucket,’ cried the old man anxiously with his hand at his ear. ‘Speak up; none of your brimstone tricks. Pick me up; I want to hear better. Oh, Lord, I am shaken to bits!’
“现在，注意你怎么说，巴克特，”老人把手放在耳边焦急地喊道。 ‘说出来；没有你的硫磺伎俩。接我;我想听得更好。哦，主啊，我被震撼了！

Mr. Bucket had certainly picked him up at a dart. However, as soon as he could be heard through Mr. Smallweed’s coughing and his vicious ejaculations of ‘Oh, my bones! Oh, dear! I’ve no breath in my body! I’m worse than the chattering, clattering, brimstone pig at home!’ Mr. Bucket proceeded in the same convivial manner as before.
巴克特先生确实一下子就抓住了他。然而，一听到斯莫威德先生的咳嗽声和恶毒的“哦，我的骨头！”的声音，就听到了他的声音。哦亲爱的！我的身体已经没有气息了！ “我比家里那头喋喋不休、喋喋不休的硫磺猪还糟糕！”巴克特先生继续以和以前一样愉快的方式进行。

‘So, as I happen to be in the habit of coming about your premises, you take me into your confidence, don’t you?’
“所以，由于我碰巧习惯到你的住所，你就信任我了，不是吗？”

I think it would be impossible to make an admission with more ill will and a worse grace than Mr. Smallweed displayed when he admitted this, rendering it perfectly evident that Mr. Bucket was the very last person he would have thought of taking into his confidence if he could by any possibility have kept him out of it.
我认为斯莫威德先生在承认这一点时所表现出的恶意和优雅是不可能的，这充分表明巴克特先生是他最不想信任的人如果他能有任何可能让他远离这件事就好了。

‘And I go into the business with you—very pleasant we are over it; and I confirm you in your well-founded fears that you will get yourself into a most precious line if you don’t come out with that there will,’ said Mr. Bucket emphatically; ‘and accordingly you arrange with me that it shall be delivered up to this present Mr. Jarndyce, on no conditions. If it should prove to be valuable, you trusting yourself to him for your reward; that’s about where it is, ain’t it?’
“我和你一起谈这件事——非常高兴我们已经结束了； “我证实你有充分的理由担心，如果你不这样做，你就会陷入最宝贵的境地，”巴克特先生强调道。 “因此，您与我安排，将其无条件地交给在场的贾迪斯先生。如果它被证明是有价值的，你就相信他会给你回报；这就是它所在的地方，不是吗？

‘That’s what was agreed,’ Mr. Smallweed assented with the same bad grace.
“这就是商定的事，”斯莫威德先生同样不客气地表示同意。

‘In consequence of which,’ said Mr. Bucket, dismissing his agreeable manner all at once and becoming strictly businesslike, ‘you’ve got that will upon your person at the present time, and the only thing that remains for you to do is just to out with it!’
“因此，”巴克特先生说，他立刻抛弃了他那令人愉快的态度，变得严格公事公办，“你现在已经有了这个意愿，唯一剩下你要做的就是只是为了摆脱它！

Having given us one glance out of the watching corner of his eye, and having given his nose one triumphant rub with his forefinger, Mr. Bucket stood with his eyes fastened on his confidential friend and his hand stretched forth ready to take the paper and present it to my guardian. It was not produced without much reluctance and many declarations on the part of Mr. Smallweed that he was a poor industrious man and that he left it to Mr. Jarndyce’s honour not to let him lose by his honesty. Little by little he very slowly took from a breast-pocket a stained, discoloured paper which was much singed upon the outside and a little burnt at the edges, as if it had long ago been thrown upon a fire and hastily snatched off again. Mr. Bucket lost no time in transferring this paper, with the dexterity of a conjuror, from Mr. Smallweed to Mr. Jarndyce. As he gave it to my guardian, he whispered behind his fingers, ‘Hadn’t settled how to make their market of it. Quarrelled and hinted about it. I laid out twenty pound upon it. First the avaricious grandchildren split upon him on account of their objections to his living so unreasonably long, and then they split on one another. Lord! There ain’t one of the family that wouldn’t sell the other for a pound or two, except the old lady—and she’s only out of it because she’s too weak in her mind to drive a bargain.’
巴克特先生用余光看了我们一眼，胜利地用食指揉了揉鼻子，然后站了起来，眼睛紧盯着他的密友，伸出手准备接过纸和礼物。交给我的监护人。斯莫尔韦德先生在制作这本书时非常不情愿，并多次声明他是一个勤劳的穷苦人，为了贾迪斯先生的名誉，他不让他因为自己的诚实而受到损失。他慢慢地从胸前的口袋里掏出一张脏兮兮、褪色的纸，纸的外面已经严重烧焦，边缘也有一点烧焦，就好像它很久以前被扔进火里，又被匆忙地扯下来一样。巴克特先生毫不犹豫地以魔术师般的灵巧把这张纸从斯莫尔韦德先生手中转给了贾迪斯先生。当他把它交给我的监护人时，他在手指后面低声说道：“还没有决定如何利用它进行销售。”吵架了还暗示了。我在上面放了二十英镑。首先，贪婪的孙子们因为反对他过长的寿命而对他产生了分裂，然后他们又互相分裂了。主！除了老太太之外，家里没有一个人不会以一两英镑的价格卖掉另一个人——而她之所以出局，只是因为她的头脑太弱了，无法讨价还价。

‘Mr Bucket,’ said my guardian aloud, ‘whatever the worth of this paper may be to any one, my obligations are great to you; and if it be of any worth, I hold myself bound to see Mr. Smallweed remunerated accordingly.’
“巴克特先生，”我的监护人大声说道，“无论这篇论文对任何人来说有什么价值，我对你的义务都是巨大的；如果它有任何价值，我一定会看到斯莫威德先生得到相应的报酬。

‘Not according to your merits, you know,’ said Mr. Bucket in friendly explanation to Mr. Smallweed. ‘Don’t you be afraid of that. According to its value.’
“你知道，这不是根据你的优点，”巴克特先生友好地向斯莫威德先生解释说。 ‘你不用害怕这个。根据其价值。

‘That is what I mean,’ said my guardian. ‘You may observe, Mr. Bucket, that I abstain from examining this paper myself. The plain truth is, I have forsworn and abjured the whole business these many years, and my soul is sick of it. But Miss Summerson and I will immediately place the paper in the hands of my solicitor in the cause, and its existence shall be made known without delay to all other parties interested.’
“这就是我的意思，”我的监护人说。 “你可能会注意到，巴克特先生，我放弃亲自检查这篇论文。显而易见的事实是，多年来我已经发誓并放弃了整个事业，我的灵魂对此感到厌倦。但萨默森小姐和我会立即将这份文件交给我的律师，并且应立即向所有其他感兴趣的各方通报该文件的存在。”

‘Mr. Jarndyce can’t say fairer than that, you understand,’ observed Mr. Bucket to his fellow-visitor. ‘And it being now made clear to you that nobody’s a-going to be wronged—which must be a great relief to YOUR mind—we may proceed with the ceremony of chairing you home again.’
'先生。贾迪斯说得再公平不过了，你明白，”巴克特先生对他的同伴说。 “现在你已经清楚地知道，没有人会受到冤屈——这对你来说一定是一种很大的安慰——我们可以再次开始主持你回家的仪式。”

He unbolted the door, called in the bearers, wished us good morning, and with a look full of meaning and a crook of his finger at parting went his way.
他打开门，叫来了轿夫，向我们道了早安，然后带着充满意味的神情和临别时的手指弯曲走开了。

We went our way too, which was to Lincoln’s Inn, as quickly as possible. Mr. Kenge was disengaged, and we found him at his table in his dusty room with the inexpressive-looking books and the piles of papers. Chairs having been placed for us by Mr. Guppy, Mr. Kenge expressed the surprise and gratification he felt at the unusual sight of Mr. Jarndyce in his office. He turned over his double eye-glass as he spoke and was more Conversation Kenge than ever.
我们也走自己的路，尽快前往林肯旅馆。肯格先生心不在焉，我们发现他坐在布满灰尘的房间里的桌子旁，桌上放着看起来毫无表情的书和成堆的文件。古比先生为我们摆放了椅子，肯格先生对贾迪斯先生出现在他的办公室里表示惊讶和欣慰。他说话时翻转了双眼眼镜，比以往任何时候都更加谈话肯格。

‘I hope,’ said Mr. Kenge, ‘that the genial influence of Miss Summerson,’ he bowed to me, ‘may have induced Mr. Jarndyce,’ he bowed to him, ‘to forego some little of his animosity towards a cause and towards a court which are—shall I say, which take their place in the stately vista of the pillars of our profession?’
“我希望，”肯吉先生说，“萨默森小姐的友善影响，”他向我鞠了一躬，“可能会促使贾迪斯先生，”他向他鞠了一躬，“放弃了他对某项事业的一些敌意。”以及朝廷，我应该说，他们在我们职业支柱的庄严前景中占有一席之地吗？

‘I am inclined to think,’ returned my guardian, ‘that Miss Summerson has seen too much of the effects of the court and the cause to exert any influence in their favour. Nevertheless, they are a part of the occasion of my being here. Mr. Kenge, before I lay this paper on your desk and have done with it, let me tell you how it has come into my hands.’
“我倾向于认为，”我的监护人回答说，“萨默森小姐已经看到了太多法庭的影响和对他们施加任何有利于他们的影响的原因。然而，它们是我来到这里的一部分。肯格先生，在我把这张纸放在您的桌子上并处理完之前，让我告诉您它是如何到达我手中的。

He did so shortly and distinctly.
他的动作很快而且清晰。

‘It could not, sir,’ said Mr. Kenge, ‘have been stated more plainly and to the purpose if it had been a case at law.’
“先生，”肯吉先生说，“如果这是一个法律案件的话，就不能说得更清楚、更符合目的了。”

‘Did you ever know English law, or equity either, plain and to the purpose?’ said my guardian.
我的监护人说：“你是否了解过英国法律或衡平法？”

‘Oh, fie!’ said Mr. Kenge.
“噢，呸！”肯吉先生说道。

At first he had not seemed to attach much importance to the paper, but when he saw it he appeared more interested, and when he had opened and read a little of it through his eye-glass, he became amazed. ‘Mr. Jarndyce,’ he said, looking off it, ‘you have perused this?’
起初他似乎并不太重视这篇论文，但当他看到它时，他显得更感兴趣，当他打开并通过眼镜阅读其中一点时，他感到惊讶。 '先生。贾迪斯，”他说，把目光移开，“你读过这个吗？”

‘Not I!’ returned my guardian.
“不是我！”我的监护人回答道。

‘But, my dear sir,’ said Mr. Kenge, ‘it is a will of later date than any in the suit. It appears to be all in the testator’s handwriting. It is duly executed and attested. And even if intended to be cancelled, as might possibly be supposed to be denoted by these marks of fire, it is NOT cancelled. Here it is, a perfect instrument!’
“但是，亲爱的先生，”肯格先生说，“这份遗嘱的日期比诉讼中的任何遗嘱都要晚。”似乎全部都是遗嘱人的笔迹。它已正式执行并得到证实。即使打算被取消，正如这些火痕可能应该表明的那样，它也没有被取消。这就是，一个完美的乐器！”

‘Well!’ said my guardian. ‘What is that to me?’
“好吧！”我的监护人说。 “那对我来说是什么？”

‘Mr. Guppy!’ cried Mr. Kenge, raising his voice. ‘I beg your pardon, Mr. Jarndyce.’
'先生。 “孔雀鱼！”​​肯吉先生提高了声音喊道。 “贾迪斯先生，请原谅。”

‘Sir.’
'先生。'

‘Mr. Vholes of Symond’s Inn. My compliments. Jarndyce and Jarndyce. Glad to speak with him.’
'先生。西蒙旅馆的山谷。我的赞美。贾迪斯和贾迪斯。很高兴与他交谈。

Mr. Guppy disappeared.
古比先生失踪了。

‘You ask me what is this to you, Mr. Jarndyce. If you had perused this document, you would have seen that it reduces your interest considerably, though still leaving it a very handsome one, still leaving it a very handsome one,’ said Mr. Kenge, waving his hand persuasively and blandly. ‘You would further have seen that the interests of Mr. Richard Carstone and of Miss Ada Clare, now Mrs. Richard Carstone, are very materially advanced by it.’
“你问我这对你来说是什么，贾迪斯先生。如果你仔细阅读了这份文件，你会发现它大大降低了你的兴趣，尽管它仍然是一个非常漂亮的文件，仍然是一个非常漂亮的文件，”肯格先生说道，他有说服力地、温和地挥舞着他的手。 “你还会进一步看到，理查德·卡斯通先生和艾达·克莱尔小姐（现在的理查德·卡斯通夫人）的利益因此得到了极大的物质提升。”

‘Kenge,’ said my guardian, ‘if all the flourishing wealth that the suit brought into this vile court of Chancery could fall to my two young cousins, I should be well contented. But do you ask ME to believe that any good is to come of Jarndyce and Jarndyce?’
“肯哥，”我的监护人说，“如果这起诉讼给这个卑鄙的大法官法庭带来的所有繁荣财富都能落到我的两个年轻表弟身上，我就心满意足了。但是你让我相信贾迪斯和贾迪斯会带来任何好处吗？

‘Oh, really, Mr. Jarndyce! Prejudice, prejudice. My dear sir, this is a very great country, a very great country. Its system of equity is a very great system, a very great system. Really, really!’
“噢，真的，贾迪斯先生！”偏见，偏见。亲爱的先生，这是一个非常伟大的国家，一个非常伟大的国家。它的股权制度是一个非常伟大的制度，一个非常伟大的制度。真的真的！'

My guardian said no more, and Mr. Vholes arrived. He was modestly impressed by Mr. Kenge’s professional eminence.
我的监护人没有再说什么，沃尔斯先生就到了。肯格先生的专业成就给他留下了深刻的印象。

‘How do you do, Mr. Vholes? Willl you be so good as to take a chair here by me and look over this paper?’
“你好吗，沃尔斯先生？”你能在我旁边坐下来看看这张纸吗？

Mr. Vholes did as he was asked and seemed to read it every word. He was not excited by it, but he was not excited by anything. When he had well examined it, he retired with Mr. Kenge into a window, and shading his mouth with his black glove, spoke to him at some length. I was not surprised to observe Mr. Kenge inclined to dispute what he said before he had said much, for I knew that no two people ever did agree about anything in Jarndyce and Jarndyce. But he seemed to get the better of Mr. Kenge too in a conversation that sounded as if it were almost composed of the words ‘ReceiverGeneral,’ ‘Accountant-General,’ ‘report,’ ‘estate,’ and ‘costs.’ When they had finished, they came back to Mr. Kenge’s table and spoke aloud.
沃尔斯先生按照要求做了，而且似乎每一个字都读过。他并不为此兴奋，但他也不为任何事兴奋。当他仔细检查过之后，他和肯吉先生一起退到窗边，用黑色手套遮住嘴，对他说了一些长话。看到肯格先生在他说得太多之前就倾向于对他所说的话提出异议，我并不感到惊讶，因为我知道，没有两个人在《加迪斯》和《加迪斯》中的任何事情上达成过一致。但他似乎也比肯格先生更胜一筹，谈话听起来几乎都是由“总管”、“总会计师”、“报告”、“遗产”和“费用”等词组成。他们吃完后，回到肯格先生的桌子旁，大声说话。

‘Well! But this is a very remarkable document, Mr. Vholes,’ said Mr. Kenge.
'出色地！但这是一份非常了不起的文件，Vholes 先生，”Kenge 先生说。

Mr. Vholes said, ‘Very much so.’
沃尔斯先生说：“非常如此。”

‘And a very important document, Mr. Vholes,’ said Mr. Kenge.
“这是一份非常重要的文件，沃尔斯先生，”肯格先生说。

Again Mr. Vholes said, ‘Very much so.’
沃尔斯先生再次说道：“非常如此。”

‘And as you say, Mr. Vholes, when the cause is in the paper next term, this document will be an unexpected and interesting feature in it,’ said Mr. Kenge, looking loftily at my guardian.
“正如您所说，沃尔斯先生，当下学期的报纸上刊登这一事业时，这份文件将成为其中一个意想不到的、有趣的特色，”肯格先生说道，他傲慢地看着我的监护人。

Mr. Vholes was gratified, as a smaller practitioner striving to keep respectable, to be confirmed in any opinion of his own by such an authority.
作为一个努力保持受人尊敬的小从业者，沃尔斯先生很高兴自己的任何观点得到这样一位权威的证实。

‘And when,’ asked my guardian, rising after a pause, during which Mr. Kenge had rattled his money and Mr. Vholes had picked his pimples, ‘when is next term?’
“那么，”我的监护人停顿了一下，站起身问道，“下学期是什么时候？”肯格先生在不停地摆弄着钱，沃尔斯先生则在抠痘痘。

‘Next term, Mr. Jarndyce, will be next month,’ said Mr. Kenge. ‘Of course we shall at once proceed to do what is necessary with this document and to collect the necessary evidence concerning it; and of course you will receive our usual notification of the cause being in the paper.’
“贾迪斯先生，下学期将是下个月，”肯吉先生说。 “当然，我们将立即着手处理这份文件，并收集相关的必要证据；当然，您会收到我们通常在报纸上公布的原因通知。

‘To which I shall pay, of course, my usual attention.’
“当然，我会一如既往地关注这一点。”

‘Still bent, my dear sir,’ said Mr. Kenge, showing us through the outer office to the door, ‘still bent, even with your enlarged mind, on echoing a popular prejudice? We are a prosperous community, Mr. Jarndyce, a very prosperous community. We are a great country, Mr. Jarndyce, we are a very great country. This is a great system, Mr. Jarndyce, and would you wish a great country to have a little system? Now, really, really!’
“亲爱的先生，”肯吉先生一边说，一边带我们穿过外面的办公室走到门口，“即使你的心胸宽广，仍然一意孤行，去附和普遍的偏见吗？”我们是一个繁荣的社区，贾迪斯先生，一个非常繁荣的社区。我们是一个伟大的国家，贾迪斯先生，我们是一个非常伟大的国家。这是一个伟大的制度，贾迪斯先生，你希望一个伟大的国家也有一个小制度吗？现在，真的，真的！”

He said this at the stair-head, gently moving his right hand as if it were a silver trowel with which to spread the cement of his words on the structure of the system and consolidate it for a thousand ages.
他在楼梯口说道，右手轻轻地移动，仿佛那是一把银抹子，将他的话的水泥铺在系统的结构上，并将其巩固一千个世纪。

CHAPTER LXIII
第六十章


Steel and Iron
钢铁

George’s Shooting Gallery is to let, and the stock is sold off, and George himself is at Chesney Wold attending on Sir Leicester in his rides and riding very near his bridle-rein because of the uncertain hand with which he guides his horse. But not to-day is George so occupied. He is journeying to-day into the iron country farther north to look about him.
乔治的射击场即将出租，股票已被卖掉，乔治本人正在切斯尼沃尔德观看莱斯特爵士的骑马活动，而且由于他控制马的手不确定，他骑得非常靠近他的缰绳。但乔治今天可没这么忙。今天他正前往更北的铁国去看看他的周围。

As he comes into the iron country farther north, such fresh green woods as those of Chesney Wold are left behind; and coal pits and ashes, high chimneys and red bricks, blighted verdure, scorching fires, and a heavy never-lightening cloud of smoke become the features of the scenery. Among such objects rides the trooper, looking about him and always looking for something he has come to find.
当他进入更北边的铁国时，像切斯尼森林那样新鲜的绿色树林就被抛在了后面。煤坑和灰烬、高高的烟囱和红砖、枯萎的青翠、灼热的火焰和永不消散的浓烟成为风景的特征。士兵骑在这些物体中，环顾四周，总是寻找他要寻找的东西。

At last, on the black canal bridge of a busy town, with a clang of iron in it, and more fires and more smoke than he has seen yet, the trooper, swart with the dust of the coal roads, checks his horse and asks a workman does he know the name of Rouncewell thereabouts.
最后，在一座繁忙城镇的黑色运河桥上，铁块叮当作响，火光和烟雾比他见过的还要多，被煤炭道路的灰尘弄得黝黑的士兵检查了他的马并问道一个工人知道附近的朗斯韦尔的名字吗？

‘Why, master,’ quoth the workman, ‘do I know my own name?’
“为什么，主人，”工人问道，“我知道自己的名字吗？”

‘‘Tis so well known here, is it, comrade?’ asks the trooper.
“这在这里很出名，是吗，同志？”士兵问道。

‘Rouncewell’s? Ah! You’re right.’
“朗斯韦尔的？啊!你说得对。'

‘And where might it be now?’ asks the trooper with a glance before him.
“那现在可能在哪儿呢？”士兵看了一眼前方问道。

‘The bank, the factory, or the house?’ the workman wants to know.
“银行、工厂还是房子？”工人想知道。

‘Hum! Rouncewell’s is so great apparently,’ mutters the trooper, stroking his chin, ‘that I have as good as half a mind to go back again. Why, I don’t know which I want. Should I find Mr. Rouncewell at the factory, do you think?’
'哼！朗斯韦尔的显然太棒了，”士兵摸着下巴嘀咕道，“我几乎想再回去一次了。为什么，我不知道我想要哪个。你觉得我应该去工厂找朗斯韦尔先生吗？

‘Tain’t easy to say where you’d find him—at this time of the day you might find either him or his son there, if he’s in town; but his contracts take him away.’
“很难说你会在哪里找到他——一天中的这个时候，你可能会在那里找到他或他的儿子，如果他在城里；但他的合同把他带走了。”

And which is the factory? Why, he sees those chimneys—the tallest ones! Yes, he sees THEM. Well! Let him keep his eye on those chimneys, going on as straight as ever he can, and presently he’ll see ‘em down a turning on the left, shut in by a great brick wall which forms one side of the street. That’s Rouncewell’s.
工厂是哪个？哎呀，他看到了那些烟囱——最高的！是的，他看到了他们。出色地！让他盯着那些烟囱，尽可能笔直地走，很快他就会在左边的一个转弯处看到它们，被街道一侧的一堵巨大的砖墙封闭起来。那是朗斯韦尔的。

The trooper thanks his informant and rides slowly on, looking about him. He does not turn back, but puts up his horse (and is much disposed to groom him too) at a public-house where some of Rouncewell’s hands are dining, as the ostler tells him. Some of Rouncewell’s hands have just knocked off for dinner-time and seem to be invading the whole town. They are very sinewy and strong, are Rouncewell’s hands—a little sooty too.
士兵感谢了他的线人，然后慢慢地骑着马，环顾四周。他没有回头，而是把他的马停在一家酒馆里（而且也很愿意给它梳理毛发），正如马夫告诉他的那样，朗斯韦尔的一些手正在那里用餐。朗斯韦尔的一些手刚刚在晚餐时间被砍掉，似乎正在入侵整个城镇。朗斯韦尔的双手非常强壮有力——也有点黑黑的。

He comes to a gateway in the brick wall, looks in, and sees a great perplexity of iron lying about in every stage and in a vast variety of shapes—in bars, in wedges, in sheets; in tanks, in boilers, in axles, in wheels, in cogs, in cranks, in rails; twisted and wrenched into eccentric and perverse forms as separate parts of machinery; mountains of it broken up, and rusty in its age; distant furnaces of it glowing and bubbling in its youth; bright fireworks of it showering about under the blows of the steam-hammer; red-hot iron, white-hot iron, cold-black iron; an iron taste, an iron smell, and a Babel of iron sounds.
他来到砖墙上的一个入口处，往里看，发现每一层都有一大堆复杂的铁，形状各异——条形、楔形、片状；在储罐中、在锅炉中、在车轴中、在车轮中、在齿轮中、在曲柄中、在轨道中；作为机械的独立部件，扭曲并扭曲成偏心和反常的形式；山峦破碎，因岁月而生锈；远处的熔炉在年轻时闪闪发光、冒着气泡；明亮的烟花在蒸汽锤的打击下洒落；红热铁、白热铁、冷黑铁；铁的味道，铁的气味，还有铁的声音。

‘This is a place to make a man’s head ache too!’ says the trooper, looking about him for a counting-house. ‘Who comes here? This is very like me before I was set up. This ought to be my nephew, if likenesses run in families. Your servant, sir.’
“这也是一个让人头疼的地方！”士兵一边说，一边环顾四周，寻找账房。 ‘谁来了？这很像我被设置之前的我。如果家族里有相似之处的话，这应该是我的侄子。您的仆人，先生。

‘Yours, sir. Are you looking for any one?’
‘你的，先生。你在找人吗？

‘Excuse me. Young Mr. Rouncewell, I believe?’
'打扰一下。我相信是年轻的朗斯韦尔先生吧？

‘Yes.’
'是的。'

‘I was looking for your father, sir. I wish to have a word with him.’
“我正在寻找你的父亲，先生。我想和他谈谈。

The young man, telling him he is fortunate in his choice of a time, for his father is there, leads the way to the office where he is to be found. ‘Very like me before I was set up—devilish like me!’ thinks the trooper as he follows. They come to a building in the yard with an office on an upper floor. At sight of the gentleman in the office, Mr. George turns very red.
年轻人告诉他，他选择的时间很幸运，因为他的父亲就在那里，并带路前往他所在的办公室。 “很像我被陷害之前的样子——像我一样邪恶！”士兵边走边想。他们来到院子里的一栋大楼，楼上有一间办公室。乔治先生一看到办公室里的那位先生，脸就红了。

‘What name shall I say to my father?’ asks the young man.
“我该给我父亲起什么名字呢？”年轻人问道。

George, full of the idea of iron, in desperation answers ‘Steel,’ and is so presented. He is left alone with the gentleman in the office, who sits at a table with account-books before him and some sheets of paper blotted with hosts of figures and drawings of cunning shapes. It is a bare office, with bare windows, looking on the iron view below. Tumbled together on the table are some pieces of iron, purposely broken to be tested at various periods of their service, in various capacities. There is iron-dust on everything; and the smoke is seen through the windows rolling heavily out of the tall chimneys to mingle with the smoke from a vaporous Babylon of other chimneys.
充满了铁的想法的乔治，绝望地回答“钢”，并被呈现出来。办公室里只剩下他和那位先生，后者坐在一张桌子旁，面前放着账簿和几张纸，上面沾满了大量的数字和形状各异的图画。这是一间光秃秃的办公室，光秃秃的窗户，看着下面的铁窗景色。桌子上堆放着一些铁片，这些铁片被故意打碎，以便在不同的使用时期和不同的性能下进行测试。万物皆有铁尘；透过窗户可以看到浓烟从高大的烟囱里滚滚而出，与其他烟囱冒出的烟雾混合在一起。

‘I am at your service, Mr. Steel,’ says the gentleman when his visitor has taken a rusty chair.
“我随时为您服务，斯蒂尔先生。”当客人坐上一张生锈的椅子时，这位绅士说道。

‘Well, Mr. Rouncewell,’ George replies, leaning forward with his left arm on his knee and his hat in his hand, and very chary of meeting his brother’s eye, ‘I am not without my expectations that in the present visit I may prove to be more free than welcome. I have served as a dragoon in my day, and a comrade of mine that I was once rather partial to was, if I don’t deceive myself, a brother of yours. I believe you had a brother who gave his family some trouble, and ran away, and never did any good but in keeping away?’
“好吧，朗斯韦尔先生，”乔治回答道，身体前倾，左臂放在膝盖上，手里拿着帽子，非常小心地避免与他哥哥的目光对视，“我并非没有期望，在这次访问中，我可能会事实证明，自由比受欢迎更重要。我当年当过龙骑兵，我曾经颇为偏爱的一个战友，如果我不自欺欺人的话，其实是你的兄弟。我相信你有一个兄弟，给他的家人带来了一些麻烦，然后就逃跑了，除了躲避之外，从来没有做过任何好事？

‘Are you quite sure,’ returns the ironmaster in an altered voice, ‘that your name is Steel?’
“你确定你的名字叫钢铁吗？”钢铁大师换了一种声音问道。

The trooper falters and looks at him. His brother starts up, calls him by his name, and grasps him by both hands.
士兵犹豫了一下，看着他。他的兄弟站了起来，叫着他的名字，并用双手抓住了他。

‘You are too quick for me!’ cries the trooper with the tears springing out of his eyes. ‘How do you do, my dear old fellow? I never could have thought you would have been half so glad to see me as all this. How do you do, my dear old fellow, how do you do!’
“你对我来说太快了！”士兵喊道，泪水夺眶而出。 ‘你好吗，我亲爱的老伙计？我从来没想到你见到我会这么高兴。你好吗，我亲爱的老伙计，你好吗！

They shake hands and embrace each other over and over again, the trooper still coupling his ‘How do you do, my dear old fellow!’ with his protestation that he never thought his brother would have been half so glad to see him as all this!
他们一遍又一遍地握手、拥抱，士兵仍然一边说着“你好，我亲爱的老伙计！”一边断言，他从来没有想过他的兄弟见到他会这么高兴。 ！

‘So far from it,’ he declares at the end of a full account of what has preceded his arrival there, ‘I had very little idea of making myself known. I thought if you took by any means forgivingly to my name I might gradually get myself up to the point of writing a letter. But I should not have been surprised, brother, if you had considered it anything but welcome news to hear of me.’
“远非如此，”他在详细叙述了自己到达那里之前的经历后宣称，“我几乎没有想过要让自己出名。”我想，如果你无论如何都能原谅我的名字，我可能会逐渐达到写信的程度。但兄弟，如果你认为听到我的消息只是受欢迎的消息，我不会感到惊讶。

‘We will show you at home what kind of news we think it, George,’ returns his brother. ‘This is a great day at home, and you could not have arrived, you bronzed old soldier, on a better. I make an agreement with my son Watt to-day that on this day twelvemonth he shall marry as pretty and as good a girl as you have seen in all your travels. She goes to Germany to-morrow with one of your nieces for a little polishing up in her education. We make a feast of the event, and you will be made the hero of it.’
“我们会在家里告诉你我们认为这是什么样的新闻，乔治，”他的兄弟回答道。 “这是家里美好的一天，你这个古铜色的老战士，不可能以更好的心情来的。”我今天和我的儿子瓦特达成协议，在十二月的这一天，他将娶一个你在所有旅行中见过的漂亮、善良的女孩。她明天将和你的一个侄女一起去德国，以提高她的教育水平。我们为这次活动举办了一场盛宴，而您将成为其中的英雄。

Mr. George is so entirely overcome at first by this prospect that he resists the proposed honour with great earnestness. Being overborne, however, by his brother and his nephew—concerning whom he renews his protestations that he never could have thought they would have been half so glad to see him—he is taken home to an elegant house in all the arrangements of which there is to be observed a pleasant mixture of the originally simple habits of the father and mother with such as are suited to their altered station and the higher fortunes of their children. Here Mr. George is much dismayed by the graces and accomplishments of his nieces that are and by the beauty of Rosa, his niece that is to be, and by the affectionate salutations of these young ladies, which he receives in a sort of dream. He is sorely taken aback, too, by the dutiful behaviour of his nephew and has a woeful consciousness upon him of being a scapegrace. However, there is great rejoicing and a very hearty company and infinite enjoyment, and Mr. George comes bluff and martial through it all, and his pledge to be present at the marriage and give away the bride is received with universal favour. A whirling head has Mr. George that night when he lies down in the state-bed of his brother’s house to think of all these things and to see the images of his nieces (awful all the evening in their floating muslins) waltzing, after the German manner, over his counterpane.
乔治先生一开始就完全被这个前景所征服，以至于他非常认真地拒绝了这项提议的荣誉。然而，他被他的兄弟和侄子压垮了——关于他们，他重申了他的声明，他从来没有想过他们会这么高兴见到他——他被带回家到一栋优雅的房子，里面的所有安排都在里面。可以看到，父母原本简单的习惯与适合他们改变的地位和孩子更高的命运的习惯令人愉快地混合在一起。在这里，乔治先生对他的侄女们的优雅和成就以及他未来的侄女罗莎的美丽以及这些年轻女士们深情的问候感到非常沮丧，这些年轻女士们在一场梦中受到了欢迎。他也被他侄子的尽职行为吓了一跳，并悲惨地意识到自己是一个可怜人。然而，这里充满了巨大的欢乐、衷心的陪伴和无限的享受，乔治先生在这一切中表现得虚张声势和好战，他承诺出席婚礼并赠送新娘的承诺受到了普遍的欢迎。那天晚上，乔治先生躺在他哥哥家的豪华床上，想着所有这些事情，并看到他的侄女们（整个晚上都穿着漂浮的平纹细布）跳华尔兹的画面，这让乔治先生感到头晕目眩。德国风格，在他的床单上。

The brothers are closeted next morning in the ironmaster’s room, where the elder is proceeding, in his clear sensible way, to show how he thinks he may best dispose of George in his business, when George squeezes his hand and stops him.
第二天早上，兄弟俩被关在铁匠的房间里，长老正以他清晰明智的方式继续进行，以表明他认为如何最好地处理乔治的生意，这时乔治捏住了他的手并阻止了他。

‘Brother, I thank you a million times for your more than brotherly welcome, and a million times more to that for your more than brotherly intentions. But my plans are made. Before I say a word as to them, I wish to consult you upon one family point. How,’ says the trooper, folding his arms and looking with indomitable firmness at his brother, ‘how is my mother to be got to scratch me?’
“兄弟，我感谢你一百万次，感谢你超越兄弟般的欢迎，更感谢你一百万次，感谢你超越兄弟般的意图。但我的计划已经制定了。在我对他们说一句话之前，我想就一个家庭问题向你们咨询一下。 “怎么，”士兵抱起双臂，用不屈不挠的坚定眼神看着他的兄弟，“我妈妈怎么会抓我呢？”

‘I am not sure that I understand you, George,’ replies the ironmaster.
“我不确定我是否理解你，乔治，”钢铁大师回答道。

‘I say, brother, how is my mother to be got to scratch me? She must be got to do it somehow.’
‘我说，兄弟，我妈妈怎么会抓我呢？她必须以某种方式去做。

‘Scratch you out of her will, I think you mean?’
“我想你的意思是把你从她的遗嘱中剔除掉？”

‘Of course I do. In short,’ says the trooper, folding his arms more resolutely yet, ‘I mean—TO—scratch me!’
'我当然是了。简而言之，”士兵更加坚定地抱起双臂说道，“我的意思是——抓——抓我！”

‘My dear George,’ returns his brother, ‘is it so indispensable that you should undergo that process?’
“我亲爱的乔治，”他的兄弟回答道，“这是必不可少的，以至于你应该经历这个过程吗？”

‘Quite! Absolutely! I couldn’t be guilty of the meanness of coming back without it. I should never be safe not to be off again. I have not sneaked home to rob your children, if not yourself, brother, of your rights. I, who forfeited mine long ago! If I am to remain and hold up my head, I must be scratched. Come. You are a man of celebrated penetration and intelligence, and you can tell me how it’s to be brought about.’
'相当！绝对地！我不能因为没有它而回来的卑鄙行为而感到内疚。如果我不再离开，我就永远不会安全。我偷偷溜回家并不是为了剥夺你的孩子们的权利，如果不是你自己的话，兄弟。我，早就失去了我的！如果我要留下来并抬起头，我就必须被抓伤。来。你是一个以洞察力和智慧着称的人，你可以告诉我如何实现这一目标。”

‘I can tell you, George,’ replies the ironmaster deliberately, ‘how it is not to be brought about, which I hope may answer the purpose as well. Look at our mother, think of her, recall her emotion when she recovered you. Do you believe there is a consideration in the world that would induce her to take such a step against her favourite son? Do you believe there is any chance of her consent, to balance against the outrage it would be to her (loving dear old lady!) to propose it? If you do, you are wrong. No, George!
