You must make up your mind to remain UNscratched, I think.’ There is an amused smile on the ironmaster’s face as he watches his brother, who is pondering, deeply disappointed. ‘I think you may manage almost as well as if the thing were done, though.’
“我可以告诉你，乔治，”钢铁大师故意回答道，“如何才能不发生这种情况，我希望这也能达到目的。”看看我们的母亲，想想她，回想一下她找回你时的心情。你相信世界上有什么考虑会让她对她最爱的儿子采取这样的举动吗？你相信她有可能同意，以平衡她（亲爱的亲爱的老太太！） 提出这个建议所带来的愤怒吗？如果你这样做了，那你就错了。不，乔治！我想，你必须下定决心，不被划伤。”当铁匠看着他的兄弟时，他的脸上露出了一丝有趣的微笑，而他的兄弟正在沉思，深感失望。 “不过，我认为如果这件事完成了，你可能会做得很好。”

‘How, brother?’
“怎么样，兄弟？”

‘Being bent upon it, you can dispose by will of anything you have the misfortune to inherit in any way you like, you know.’
“你知道，只要你一心一意，你就可以按照自己的意愿，以任何你喜欢的方式处置你不幸继承的任何东西。”

‘That’s true!’ says the trooper, pondering again. Then he wistfully asks, with his hand on his brother’s, ‘Would you mind mentioning that, brother, to your wife and family?’
“确实如此！”士兵沉思着说道。然后，他把手放在弟弟的手上，若有所思地问道：“兄弟，你介意向你的妻子和家人提及这一点吗？”

‘Not at all.’
'一点也不。'

‘Thank you. You wouldn’t object to say, perhaps, that although an undoubted vagabond, I am a vagabond of the harum-scarum order, and not of the mean sort?’
'谢谢。也许你不会反对说，虽然我是一个毫无疑问的流浪汉，但我是一个鲁莽的流浪汉，而不是卑鄙的流浪汉？

The ironmaster, repressing his amused smile, assents.
铁匠强忍着他的好笑，同意了。

‘Thank you. Thank you. It’s a weight off my mind,’ says the trooper with a heave of his chest as he unfolds his arms and puts a hand on each leg, ‘though I had set my heart on being scratched, too!’
'谢谢。谢谢。这让我的心如释重负，”士兵一边说着，一边展开双臂，将一只手放在每条腿上，“尽管我也很想被抓伤！”

The brothers are very like each other, sitting face to face; but a certain massive simplicity and absence of usage in the ways of the world is all on the trooper’s side.
兄弟俩很像，面对面坐着；但世界上的某种巨大的简单性和缺乏使用性都站在士兵一边。

‘Well,’ he proceeds, throwing off his disappointment, ‘next and last, those plans of mine. You have been so brotherly as to propose to me to fall in here and take my place among the products of your perseverance and sense. I thank you heartily. It’s more than brotherly, as I said before, and I thank you heartily for it,’ shaking him a long time by the hand. ‘But the truth is, brother, I am a—I am a kind of a weed, and it’s too late to plant me in a regular garden.’
“好吧，”他抛开失望继续说道，“接下来也是最后一个，就是我的那些计划。”你们是如此兄弟般地向我提议落入这里，并在你们的毅力和理智的产物中取代我的位置。我衷心感谢你。正如我之前所说，这不仅仅是兄弟情谊，我衷心感谢你，”握着他的手良久。 “但事实是，兄弟，我是——我是一种杂草，现在把我种在普通的花园里已经太晚了。”

‘My dear George,’ returns the elder, concentrating his strong steady brow upon him and smiling confidently, ‘leave that to me, and let me try.’
“我亲爱的乔治，”长老回答道，他的眉毛集中在他身上，自信地微笑着，“把这件事交给我吧，让我试试。”

George shakes his head. ‘You could do it, I have not a doubt, if anybody could; but it’s not to be done. Not to be done, sir! Whereas it so falls out, on the other hand, that I am able to be of some trifle of use to Sir Leicester Dedlock since his illness— brought on by family sorrows—and that he would rather have that help from our mother’s son than from anybody else.’
乔治摇摇头。 “你能做到，我毫不怀疑，如果有人能做到的话；但这不是必须要做的。不可以，先生！另一方面，事实证明，自从莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士因家庭悲伤而生病以来，我能够为他提供一些小帮助，而且他宁愿从我们母亲的儿子那里得到帮助，也不愿从我们母亲的儿子那里得到帮助。其他人。'

‘Well, my dear George,’ returns the other with a very slight shade upon his open face, ‘if you prefer to serve in Sir Leicester Dedlock’s household brigade—‘
“好吧，我亲爱的乔治，”另一个人回答道，他那张开放的脸上带着一丝淡淡的阴影，“如果你愿意在莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士的家庭旅中服役——”

‘There it is, brother,’ cries the trooper, checking him, with his hand upon his knee again; ‘there it is! You don’t take kindly to that idea; I don’t mind it. You are not used to being officered; I am. Everything about you is in perfect order and discipline; everything about me requires to be kept so. We are not accustomed to carry things with the same hand or to look at ‘em from the same point. I don’t say much about my garrison manners because I found myself pretty well at my ease last night, and they wouldn’t be noticed here, I dare say, once and away. But I shall get on best at Chesney Wold, where there’s more room for a weed than there is here; and the dear old lady will be made happy besides. Therefore I accept of Sir Leicester Dedlock’s proposals. When I come over next year to give away the bride, or whenever I come, I shall have the sense to keep the household brigade in ambuscade and not to manoeuvre it on your ground. I thank you heartily again and am proud to think of the Rouncewells as they’ll be founded by you.’
“就是这里，兄弟。”士兵喊道，一边检查他，一边再次把手放在膝盖上。 ‘就是这样！你不喜欢这个想法；我不介意。你不习惯担任军官；我是。你的一切都井然有序、井井有条；关于我的一切都需要保持这样。我们不习惯用同一只手拿东西，也不习惯从同一个角度看东西。我没有过多谈论我的驻军礼仪，因为昨晚我发现自己非常放松，我敢说，他们在这里不会被注意到，一次又一次。但我在切斯尼沃尔德会过得最好，那里比这里更适合杂草生长。而且亲爱的老太太也会很高兴的。因此我接受莱斯特·戴德洛克爵士的建议。当我明年来送新娘的时候，或者无论什么时候我来的时候，我都会明智地让家庭大队埋伏起来，而不是在你的阵地上操纵它。我再次衷心感谢你们，并为朗斯韦尔家族感到自豪，因为他们将由你们创立。

‘You know yourself, George,’ says the elder brother, returning the grip of his hand, ‘and perhaps you know me better than I know myself. Take your way. So that we don’t quite lose one another again, take your way.’
“你了解你自己，乔治，”哥哥说，收回了他的手，“也许你比我更了解我自己。”走你的路吧。这样我们就不会再次失去彼此，走你的路吧。

‘No fear of that!’ returns the trooper. ‘Now, before I turn my horse’s head homewards, brother, I will ask you—if you’ll be so good—to look over a letter for me. I brought it with me to send from these parts, as Chesney Wold might be a painful name just now to the person it’s written to. I am not much accustomed to correspondence myself, and I am particular respecting this present letter because I want it to be both straightforward and delicate.’
“不用担心！”士兵回答道。 “现在，在我调转马头回家之前，兄弟，我想请你——如果你愿意的话——帮我看一封信。我带着它从这些地方寄出，因为切斯尼沃尔德对于收信人来说可能是一个痛苦的名字。我自己不太习惯通信，我特别尊重现在的这封信，因为我希望它既直截了当又精致。

Herewith he hands a letter, closely written in somewhat pale ink but in a neat round hand, to the ironmaster, who reads as follows:
在此，他将一封信交给铁匠，这封信是用淡墨写成的，但字体工整，圆润，铁匠的内容如下：

Miss Esther Summerson,
埃丝特·萨默森女士，

A communication having been made to me by Inspector Bucket of a letter to myself being found among the papers of a certain person, I take the liberty to make known to you that it was but a few lines of instruction from abroad, when, where, and how to deliver an enclosed letter to a young and beautiful lady, then unmarried, in England. I duly observed the same.
巴克特督察向我传达了一封信，说在某个人的文件中发现了一封写给我自己的信，我冒昧地告诉你，这只是来自国外的几行指示，何时何地，以及如何将附上的信寄给英国一位年轻漂亮、尚未结婚的女士。我也确实观察到了同样的情况。

I further take the liberty to make known to you that it was got from me as a proof of handwriting only and that otherwise I would not have given it up, as appearing to be the most harmless in my possession, without being previously shot through the heart.
我进一步冒昧地向您表明，它是我从我这里得到的，仅作为笔迹证明，否则我不会放弃它，因为它似乎是我拥有的最无害的东西，而且之前没有被射穿。心。

I further take the liberty to mention that if I could have supposed a certain unfortunate gentleman to have been in existence, I never could and never would have rested until I had discovered his retreat and shared my last farthing with him, as my duty and my inclination would have equally been. But he was (officially) reported drowned, and assuredly went over the side of a transportship at night in an Irish harbour within a few hours of her arrival from the West Indies, as I have myself heard both from officers and men on board, and know to have been (officially) confirmed.
我进一步冒昧地指出，如果我能假设存在某个不幸的绅士，我永远不会也永远不会休息，直到我发现他的隐居处并与他分享我最后的一分钱，作为我的责任和我的责任。倾向也会同样如此。但据（官方）报道，他溺水身亡，而且确实是在一艘运输船从西印度群岛抵达后的几个小时内，在夜间从爱尔兰港口的一艘运输船的舷侧翻过去的，正如我自己从船上的军官和士兵那里听到的那样，知道已被（正式）确认。

I further take the liberty to state that in my humble quality as one of the rank and file, I am, and shall ever continue to be, your thoroughly devoted and admiring servant and that I esteem the qualities you possess above all others far beyond the limits of the present dispatch.
我还冒昧地声明，作为一名普通士兵，我是并且将永远是您的忠实和钦佩的仆人，并且我尊重您所拥有的品质，远远超出了其他人的品质。当前调度的限制。

I have the honour to be,
我有幸成为，

GEORGE
乔治

‘A little formal,’ observes the elder brother, refolding it with a puzzled face.
“有点正式，”哥哥说，一脸困惑地重新折叠它。

‘But nothing that might not be sent to a pattern young lady?’ asks the younger.
“但是没有什么东西不能送给一位典型的年轻女士吗？”年轻的问道。

‘Nothing at all.’
“什么也没有。”

Therefore it is sealed and deposited for posting among the iron correspondence of the day. This done, Mr. George takes a hearty farewell of the family party and prepares to saddle and mount. His brother, however, unwilling to part with him so soon, proposes to ride with him in a light open carriage to the place where he will bait for the night, and there remain with him until morning, a servant riding for so much of the journey on the thoroughbred old grey from Chesney Wold. The offer, being gladly accepted, is followed by a pleasant ride, a pleasant dinner, and a pleasant breakfast, all in brotherly communion. Then they once more shake hands long and heartily and part, the ironmaster turning his face to the smoke and fires, and the trooper to the green country. Early in the afternoon the subdued sound of his heavy military trot is heard on the turf in the avenue as he rides on with imaginary clank and jingle of accoutrements under the old elm-trees.
因此，它被密封并存放在当时的铁信中邮寄。完成后，乔治先生与家庭聚会热情告别，准备上马。然而，他的兄弟不愿意这么快与他分开，提议与他一起乘坐一辆轻便的敞篷马车前往他将要过夜的地方，并在那里一直陪着他直到早上，一个仆人骑着马车走了这么多的路。骑着来自切斯尼沃尔德的纯种老灰马的旅程。我们很高兴地接受了这个提议，接下来就是愉快的旅程、愉快的晚餐和愉快的早餐，所有这一切都在兄弟般的交流中进行。然后他们再次热烈地握手，然后分开，铁匠将脸转向烟雾和火焰，而士兵则转向绿色的乡村。下午早些时候，他在老榆树下骑着马，带着想象中的叮当声和叮当声，在大道的草坪上听到了他沉重的军事小跑的柔和声音。

CHAPTER LXIV
第十四章


Esther’s Narrative
以斯帖的叙述

Soon after I had that convertion with my guardian, he put a sealed paper in my hand one morning and said, ‘This is for next month, my dear.’ I found in it two hundred pounds.
在我和我的监护人皈依后不久，一天早上，他把一张密封的纸放在我手里，说：“这是下个月的，亲爱的。”我在里面发现了两百英镑。

I now began very quietly to make such preparations as I thought were necessary. Regulating my purchases by my guardian’s taste, which I knew very well of course, I arranged my wardrobe to please him and hoped I should be highly successful. I did it all so quietly because I was not quite free from my old apprehension that Ada would be rather sorry and because my guardian was so quiet himself. I had no doubt that under all the circumstances we should be married in the most private and simple manner. Perhaps I should only have to say to Ada, ‘Would you like to come and see me married to-morrow, my pet?’ Perhaps our wedding might even be as unpretending as her own, and I might not find it necessary to say anything about it until it was over. I thought that if I were to choose, I would like this best.
我现在开始悄悄地做我认为必要的准备工作。我根据监护人的品味来控制我的购买，我当然非常了解这一点，我安排了我的衣柜来取悦他，并希望我能取得巨大的成功。我做这一切的时候都很安静，因为我还没有完全摆脱过去的忧虑，担心艾达会感到抱歉，而且因为我的监护人自己也很安静。我毫不怀疑，在任何情况下，我们都应该以最私密、最简单的方式结婚。也许我只需要对艾达说：“我的宠物，你明天愿意来看我结婚吗？”也许我们的婚礼甚至可以像她自己的婚礼一样朴实无华，我可能觉得没有必要说什么直到结束为止。我想，如果让我选择的话，我最喜欢这个。

The only exception I made was Mrs. Woodcourt. I told her that I was going to be married to my guardian and that we had been engaged some time. She highly approved. She could never do enough for me and was remarkably softened now in comparison with what she had been when we first knew her. There was no trouble she would not have taken to have been of use to me, but I need hardly say that I only allowed her to take as little as gratified her kindness without tasking it.
我唯一的例外是伍德考特夫人。我告诉她我即将与我的监护人结婚，并且我们已经订婚一段时间了。她高度认可。她为我做的永远都不够，与我们第一次认识她时相比，她现在明显软化了。没有什么麻烦她不会认为对我有用，但我几乎不用说，我只允许她接受尽可能少的满足她的善意而不承担任务。

Of course this was not a time to neglect my guardian, and of course it was not a time for neglecting my darling. So I had plenty of occupation, which I was glad of; and as to Charley, she was absolutely not to be seen for needlework. To surround herself with great heaps of it—baskets full and tables full—and do a little, and spend a great deal of time in staring with her round eyes at what there was to do, and persuade herself that she was going to do it, were Charley’s great dignities and delights.
当然，现在不是忽视我的监护人的时候，当然也不是忽视我的宝贝的时候。这样我就有了很多工作，对此我感到很高兴。至于查理，绝对不能让人看到她做针线活。用一大堆东西包围自己——篮子满了，桌子满了——做一点，花大量的时间用她的圆眼睛盯着要做的事情，并说服自己她要做这件事，是查理的伟大尊严和快乐。

Meanwhile, I must say, I could not agree with my guardian on the subject of the will, and I had some sanguine hopes of Jarndyce and Jarndyce. Which of us was right will soon appear, but I certainly did encourage expectations. In Richard, the discovery gave occasion for a burst of business and agitation that buoyed him up for a little time, but he had lost the elasticity even of hope now and seemed to me to retain only its feverish anxieties. From something my guardian said one day when we were talking about this, I understood that my marriage would not take place until after the term-time we had been told to look forward to; and I thought the more, for that, how rejoiced I should be if I could be married when Richard and Ada were a little more prosperous.
与此同时，我必须说，在遗嘱的问题上，我无法同意我的监护人的意见，我对贾迪斯和贾迪斯抱有一些乐观的希望。我们中谁是对的很快就会出现，但我确实鼓励了人们的期望。在理查德身上，这一发现给他带来了一阵生意和激动的机会，让他暂时振奋起来，但现在他甚至失去了希望的弹性，在我看来，只保留了狂热的焦虑。有一天，当我们谈论这件事时，我的监护人说的话让我明白，我的婚姻要等到我们被告知要期待的学期结束后才会举行。我越想越是这样，如果我能在理查德和艾达稍微富裕一点的时候结婚，我该多么高兴啊。

The term was very near indeed when my guardian was called out of town and went down into Yorkshire on Mr. Woodcourt’s business. He had told me beforehand that his presence there would be necessary. I had just come in one night from my dear girl’s and was sitting in the midst of all my new clothes, looking at them all around me and thinking, when a letter from my guardian was brought to me. It asked me to join him in the country and mentioned by what stagecoach my place was taken and at what time in the morning I should have to leave town. It added in a postscript that I would not be many hours from Ada.
当我的监护人被叫出城去约克郡处理伍德考特先生的事务时，这个期限确实已经临近了。他事先告诉我，他的存在是必要的。一天晚上，我刚从我亲爱的女儿那里回来，坐在我所有的新衣服中间，看着我周围的它们，想着，这时我的监护人给我带来了一封信。它要求我去乡下和他会合，并提到我乘坐哪辆驿站马车，以及早上什么时间我必须离开城镇。它在附言中补充说，我离开艾达的时间不会太长。

I expected few things less than a journey at that tinae, but I was ready for it in half an hour and set off as appointed early next morning. I travelled all day, wondering all day what I could be wanted for at such a distance; now I thought it might be for this purpose, and now I thought it might be for that purpose, but I was never, never, never near the truth.
我原本以为在那个蒂纳的旅行没什么比这更糟糕的了，但我在半小时内就做好了准备，并在第二天一早按照约定出发了。我一整天都在旅行，一整天都在想，在这么远的地方，我会被要求做什么。现在我认为它可能是为了这个目的，现在我认为它可能是为了那个目的，但我从来，从来，从来没有接近真相。

It was night when I came to my journey’s end and found my guardian waiting for me. This was a great relief, for towards evening I had begun to fear (the more so as his letter was a very short one) that he might be ill. However, there he was, as well as it was possible to be; and when I saw his genial face again at its brightest and best, I said to myself, he has been doing some other great kindness. Not that it required much penetration to say that, because I knew that his being there at all was an act of kindness.
当我到达旅程的终点​​时，已经是晚上了，我发现我的监护人正在等我。这让我松了口气，因为到了晚上，我开始担心（尤其是因为他的信很短）他可能生病了。然而，他就在那里，而且是有可能的。当我再次看到他那张和蔼可亲的脸庞时，我对自己说，他还做了其他一些伟大的善事。说这句话并不需要太多洞察力，因为我知道他在那里根本就是一种善意的行为。

Supper was ready at the hotel, and when we were alone at table he said, ‘Full of curiosity, no doubt, little woman, to know why I have brought you here?’
旅馆里的晚饭已经准备好了，当我们单独坐在餐桌旁时，他说：“毫无疑问，小女人，充满了好奇，想知道我为什么带你来这里？”

‘Well, guardian,’ said I, ‘without thinking myself a Fatima or you a Blue Beard, I am a little curious about it.’
“好吧，监护人，”我说，“虽然我不认为自己是法蒂玛，也不认为你是蓝胡子，但我对此有点好奇。”

‘Then to ensure your night’s rest, my love,’ he returned gaily, ‘I won’t wait until to-morrow to tell you. I have very much wished to express to Woodcourt, somehow, my sense of his humanity to poor unfortunate Jo, his inestimable services to my young cousins, and his value to us all. When it was decided that he should settle here, it came into my head that I might ask his acceptance of some unpretending and suitable little place to lay his own head in. I therefore caused such a place to be looked out for, and such a place was found on very easy terms, and I have been touching it up for him and making it habitable. However, when I walked over it the day before yesterday and it was reported ready, I found that I was not housekeeper enough to know whether things were all as they ought to be. So I sent off for the best little housekeeper that could possibly be got to come and give me her advice and opinion. And here she is,’ said my guardian, ‘laughing and crying both together!’
“那么，为了确保你晚上休息，亲爱的，”他高兴地回答道，“我不会等到明天才告诉你。”我非常希望以某种方式向伍德考特表达我对他对可怜不幸的乔的人性、他对我年轻表兄弟的不可估量的服务以及他对我们所有人的价值的认识。当决定他要在这里定居时，我突然想到，我可以请他接受一个朴实无华且合适的小地方来安放自己的头。因此，我让人们留意这样一个地方，这样一个地方。这个地方的找到条件非常简单，我一直在为他修饰它并使它适合居住。然而，当我前天走过它，报告已经准备好时，我发现我的管家不够，无法知道事情是否一切顺利。所以我派人去找了最好的小管家，她可能会过来给我建议和意见。 “她就在这里，”我的监护人说，“一边笑一边哭！”

Because he was so dear, so good, so admirable. I tried to tell him what I thought of him, but I could not articulate a word.
因为他是如此可爱，如此优秀，如此令人钦佩。我试图告诉他我对他的看法，但我一个字也说不出来。

‘Tut, tut!’ said my guardian. ‘You make too much of it, little woman. Why, how you sob, Dame Durden, how you sob!’
“啧，啧！”我的监护人说道。 ‘你太过分了，小女人。哎呀，你哭得多么伤心，德登夫人，你哭得多么伤心！”

‘It is with exquisite pleasure, guardian—with a heart full of thanks.’
“这是带着极大的喜悦，守护者——带着一颗充满感激的心。”

‘Well, well,’ said he. ‘I am delighted that you approve. I thought you would. I meant it as a pleasant surprise for the little mistress of Bleak House.’
“好吧，好吧，”他说。 ‘我很高兴你同意。我以为你会的。我的意思是给《荒凉山庄》的小女主人一个惊喜。

I kissed him and dried my eyes. ‘I know now!’ said I. ‘I have seen this in your face a long while.’
我吻了他并擦干了眼睛。 “我现在知道了！”我说，“我在你脸上看到这一点已经很久了。”

‘No; have you really, my dear?’ said he. ‘What a Dame Durden it is to read a face!’
'不;你真的有吗，亲爱的？”他说。 “杜登夫人真是能读懂一张脸啊！”

He was so quaintly cheerful that I could not long be otherwise, and was almost ashamed of having been otherwise at all. When I went to bed, I cried. I am bound to confess that I cried; but I hope it was with pleasure, though I am not quite sure it was with pleasure. I repeated every word of the letter twice over.
他是如此的古怪而快乐，以至于我不可能长久地不高兴，而且几乎为自己的不高兴感到羞愧。当我上床睡觉时，我哭了。我必须承认我哭了；但我希望这是愉快的，尽管我不太确定这是愉快的。我把信中的每一个字都重复了两遍。

A most beautiful summer morning succeeded, and after breakfast we went out arm in arm to see the house of which I was to give my mighty housekeeping opinion. We entered a flower-garden by a gate in a side wall, of which he had the key, and the first thing I saw was that the beds and flowers were all laid out according to the manner of my beds and flowers at home.
一个最美好的夏日早晨到来了，早餐后，我们手挽手出去参观我要对家政提出强烈意见的房子。我们从侧墙的一扇门进入了一个花园，他有钥匙，我首先看到的是花坛和花都是按照我家里的花坛和花的方式布置的。

‘You see, my dear,’ observed my guardian, standing still with a delighted face to watch my looks, ‘knowing there could be no better plan, I borrowed yours.’
“你看，亲爱的，”我的监护人说道，他一动不动地站着，一脸高兴地看着我的样子，“我知道没有更好的计划了，所以我借用了你的计划。”

We went on by a pretty little orchard, where the cherries were nestling among the green leaves and the shadows of the apple-trees were sporting on the grass, to the house itself—a cottage, quite a rustic cottage of doll’s rooms; but such a lovely place, so tranquil and so beautiful, with such a rich and smiling country spread around it; with water sparkling away into the distance, here all overhung with summer-growth, there turning a humming mill; at its nearest point glancing through a meadow by the cheerful town, where cricket-players were assembling in bright groups and a flag was flying from a white tent that rippled in the sweet west wind. And still, as we went through the pretty rooms, out at the little rustic verandah doors, and underneath the tiny wooden colonnades garlanded with woodbine, jasmine, and honey-suckle, I saw in the papering on the walls, in the colours of the furniture, in the arrangement of all the pretty objects, MY little tastes and fancies, MY little methods and inventions which they used to laugh at while they praised them, my odd ways everywhere.
我们继续前行，经过一个漂亮的小果园，那里的樱桃依偎在绿叶之间，苹果树的影子在草地上嬉戏，我们来到了房子本身——一座小屋，一座充满了玩偶房间的质朴小屋；但这是一个多么可爱的地方，多么宁静，多么美丽，周围是一个富饶而微笑的国家。远处的水波闪闪发光，这里长满了夏季的植物，那里转动着嗡嗡作响的磨坊；在最近的地方，可以看到这座令人愉快的小镇旁的一片草地，那里的板球运动员们聚集在一起，色彩鲜艳，白色的帐篷里飘扬着一面旗帜，在甜美的西风中飘扬。尽管如此，当我们穿过漂亮的房间，来到质朴的小阳台门前，在装饰着苦藤、茉莉花和金银花的小木柱廊下面时，我在墙上的墙纸上看到了家具，所有漂亮物品的布置，我的小品味和幻想，我的小方法和发明，他们在称赞它们时常常嘲笑它们，我的奇怪方式无处不在。

I could not say enough in admiration of what was all so beautiful, but one secret doubt arose in my mind when I saw this, I thought, oh, would he be the happier for it! Would it not have been better for his peace that I should not have been so brought before him? Because although I was not what he thought me, still he loved me very dearly, and it might remind him mournfully of what be believed he had lost. I did not wish him to forget me—perhaps he might not have done so, without these aids to his memory—but my way was easier than his, and I could have reconciled myself even to that so that he had been the happier for it.
我对这一切如此美丽的赞叹之情无以言表，但当我看到这一幕时，我心中升起一个秘密的疑问，我想，哦，他会因此而更快乐吗？如果我不被带到他面前，对他的平安不是更好吗？因为虽然我不是他想象的那样，但他仍然非常爱我，这可能会悲伤地提醒他他所失去的东西。我不希望他忘记我——也许他可能不会这样做，如果没有这些记忆辅助工具——但我的方式比他的容易，我什至可以接受这样的安排，这样他会因此而更高兴。

‘And now, little woman,’ said my guardian, whom I had never seen so proud and joyful as in showing me these things and watching my appreciation of them, ‘now, last of all, for the name of this house.’
“现在，小女人，”我的监护人说，我从未见过他如此自豪和快乐地向我展示这些东西并看着我欣赏它们，“现在，最后，为了这座房子的名字。”

‘What is it called, dear guardian?’
“它叫什么名字，亲爱的监护人？”

‘My child,’ said he, ‘come and see,’
“我的孩子，”他说，“过来看看，”

He took me to the porch, which he had hitherto avoided, and said, pausing before we went out, ‘My dear child, don’t you guess the name?’
他把我带到了门廊，这是他迄今为止一直回避的地方，在我们出去之前停下来说道，“我亲爱的孩子，你猜不到这个名字吗？”

‘No!’ said I.
“不！”我说。

We went out of the porch and he showed me written over it, Bleak House.
我们走出门廊，他给我看上面写着“荒凉山庄”。

He led me to a seat among the leaves close by, and sitting down beside me and taking my hand in his, spoke to me thus, ‘My darling girl, in what there has been between us, I have, I hope, been really solicitous for your happiness. When I wrote you the letter to which you brought the answer,’ smiling as he referred to it, ‘I had my own too much in view; but I had yours too. Whether, under different circumstances, I might ever have renewed the old dream I sometimes dreamed when you were very young, of making you my wife one day, I need not ask myself. I did renew it, and I wrote my letter, and you brought your answer. You are following what I say, my child?’
他把我领到附近树叶间的一个座位上，坐在我旁边，握住我的手，对我这样说道：“我亲爱的女孩，在我们之间发生的事情中，我希望，我真的关心您的幸福。当我给你写了一封你带来答复的信时，”他微笑着提到这封信，“我有太多自己的想法;但我也有你的。在不同的情况下，我是否会重温你年轻时有时梦想的旧梦，有一天让你成为我的妻子，我不需要问自己。我确实更新了它，我写了我的信，你带来了你的答复。你听我说的话吗，我的孩子？

I was cold, and I trembled violently, but not a word he uttered was lost. As I sat looking fixedly at him and the sun’s rays descended, softly shining through the leaves upon his bare head, I felt as if the brightness on him must be like the brightness of the angels.
我浑身冰冷，浑身剧烈颤抖，但他却一句话也没漏掉。当我坐在那儿定定地看着他，阳光洒下来，透过树叶，温柔地照在他光秃秃的头上，我觉得他身上的光辉一定像天使的光辉。

‘Hear me, my love, but do not speak. It is for me to speak now. When it was that I began to doubt whether what I had done would really make you happy is no matter. Woodcourt came home, and I soon had no doubt at all.’
‘听我说，亲爱的，但不要说话。现在该由我发言了。当我开始怀疑我所做的事情是否真的能让你幸福的时候，没关系。伍德考特回到家后，我很快就不再怀疑了。

I clasped him round the neck and hung my bead upon his breast and wept. ‘Lie lightly, confidently here, my child,’ said he, pressing me gently to him. ‘I am your guardian and your father now. Rest confidently here.’
我搂住他的脖子，把我的珠子挂在他的胸前哭了起来。 “轻轻地、自信地躺在这里，我的孩子，”他说着，轻轻地将我压向他。 ‘我现在是你的监护人，也是你的父亲。在这里放心地休息。

Soothingly, like the gentle rustling of the leaves; and genially, like the ripening weather; and radiantly and beneficently, like the sunshine, he went on.
舒缓，如树叶轻柔的沙沙声；和蔼可亲，就像成熟的天气；他像阳光一样，容光焕发、仁慈地继续前行。

‘Understand me, my dear girl. I had no doubt of your being contented and happy with me, being so dutiful and so devoted; but I saw with whom you would be happier. That I penetrated his secret when Dame Durden was blind to it is no wonder, for I knew the good that could never change in her better far than she did. Well! I have long been in Allan Woodcourt’s confidence, although he was not, until yesterday, a few hours before you came here, in mine. But I would not have my Esther’s bright example lost; I would not have a jot of my dear girl’s virtues unobserved and unhonoured; I would not have her admitted on sufferance into the line of Morgan ap-Kerrig, no, not for the weight in gold of all the mountains in Wales!’
‘理解我，我亲爱的女孩。我毫不怀疑你对我感到满足和快乐，对我如此尽职尽责，如此忠诚。但我知道你和谁在一起会更快乐。当杜登夫人视而不见时，我却洞悉了他的秘密，这并不奇怪，因为我比她更了解她永远不会改变的优点。出色地！艾伦·伍德考特长期以来一直对我充满信心，尽管直到昨天，也就是你来这里的几个小时前，我才对他充满信心。但我不想失去我的埃丝特的光辉榜样；我不会让我亲爱的女儿的一点点美德不被人注意和不被尊重；我不会让她勉强进入摩根·阿普·克里格的血统，不，不会因为威尔士所有山脉的黄金重量！”

He stopped to kiss me on the forehead, and I sobbed and wept afresh. For I felt as if I could not bear the painful delight of his praise.
他停下来亲吻我的额头，我又抽泣起来。因为我感觉自己似乎无法忍受他的赞美所带来的痛苦的喜悦。

‘Hush, little woman! Don’t cry; this is to be a day of joy. I have looked forward to it,’ he said exultingly, ‘for months on months! A few words more, Dame Trot, and I have said my say. Determined not to throw away one atom of my Esther’s worth, I took Mrs. Woodcourt into a separate confidence. ‘Now, madam,’ said I, ‘I clearly perceive—and indeed I know, to boot—that your son loves my ward. I am further very sure that my ward loves your son, but will sacrifice her love to a sense of duty and affection, and will sacrifice it so completely, so entirely, so religiously, that you should never suspect it though you watched her night and day.’ Then I told her all our story—ours—yours and mine. ‘Now, madam,’ said I, ‘come you, knowing this, and live with us. Come you, and see my child from hour to hour; set what you see against her pedigree, which is this, and this’—for I scorned to mince it—‘and tell me what is the true legitimacy when you shall have quite made up your mind on that subject.’ Why, honour to her old Welsh blood, my dear,’ cried my guardian with enthusiasm, ‘I believe the heart it animates beats no less warmly, no less admiringly, no less lovingly, towards Dame Durden than my own!’
‘嘘，小女人！别哭；这将是一个欢乐的日子。我已经期待了好几个月了，”他兴奋地说，“好几个月了！特罗特夫人，再多说几句话，我已经说了我的话。我决心不放弃我以斯帖的一丁点价值，于是我单独对伍德考特夫人保密。 “现在，夫人，”我说，“我清楚地意识到——事实上我知道——你的儿子爱我的受监护人。我进一步非常确定，我的受监护人爱你的儿子，但会牺牲她的爱来换取责任感和感情，而且会牺牲得如此彻底、如此完全、如此虔诚，以至于你永远不会怀疑这一点，尽管你看着她的夜晚和然后我告诉她我们所有的故事——我们的——你的和我的。 “现在，女士，”我说，“你知道了这一点，就来和我们住在一起吧。”你来吧，时时刻刻看望我的孩子；把你所看到的与她的血统进行比较，就是这个，还有这个”——因为我不屑于拐弯抹角——“当你在这个问题上完全下定决心时，告诉我什么是真正的合法性。”为什么，很荣幸她古老的威尔士血统，亲爱的，”我的监护人热情地喊道，“我相信，它所激发的心，对德登夫人的热情，同样令人钦佩，同样充满爱意，不亚于我自己的心！”

He tenderly raised my head, and as I clung to him, kissed me in his old fatherly way again and again. What a light, now, on the protecting manner I had thought about!
他温柔地抬起我的头，当我紧贴着他时，他以他古老的父亲般的方式一遍又一遍地吻我。现在，我对我所考虑的保护方式有了多大的了解！

‘One more last word. When Allan Woodcourt spoke to you, my dear, he spoke with my knowledge and consent—but I gave him no encouragement, not I, for these surprises were my great reward, and I was too miserly to part with a scrap of it. He was to come and tell me all that passed, and he did. I have no more to say. My dearest, Allan Woodcourt stood beside your father when he lay dead —stood beside your mother. This is Bleak House. This day I give this house its little mistress; and before God, it is the brightest day in all my life!’
‘还有最后一句话。当艾伦·伍德考特对你说话时，亲爱的，他是在我知情和同意的情况下说话的——但我没有给他任何鼓励，因为这些惊喜是我的巨大奖励，而我太吝啬了，无法放弃其中的一小部分。他要来告诉我发生的一切，他做到了。我没有更多可说的了。我最亲爱的，艾伦·伍德考特在你父亲去世时站在他身边——站在你母亲身边。这就是《荒凉山庄》。今天我给这座房子当了小女主人；在上帝面前，这是我一生中最光明的一天！

He rose and raised me with him. We were no longer alone. My husband—I have called him by that name full seven happy years now —stood at my side.
他站起来，把我和他一起抚养长大。我们不再孤单。我的丈夫——我已经用这个名字称呼他整整七年了——站在我身边。

‘Allan,’ said my guardian, ‘take from me a willing gift, the best wife that ever man had. What more can I say for you than that I know you deserve her! Take with her the little home she brings you. You know what she will make it, Allan; you know what she has made its namesake. Let me share its felicity sometimes, and what do I sacrifice? Nothing, nothing.’
“艾伦，”我的监护人说，“请从我这里得到一份心甘情愿的礼物，一个男人拥有的最好的妻子。”除了我知道你配得上她之外，我还能对你说什么呢！带着她给你带来的小家吧。你知道她会做什么，艾伦；你知道她的名字是什么。有时让我分享它的幸福，我要牺牲什么？没事没事。'

He kissed me once again, and now the tears were in his eyes as he said more softly, ‘Esther, my dearest, after so many years, there is a kind of parting in this too. I know that my mistake has caused you some distress. Forgive your old guardian, in restoring him to his old place in your affections; and blot it out of your memory. Allan, take my dear.’
他再次吻了我，眼里含着泪水，他更加轻柔地说：“艾丝特，我最亲爱的，这么多年过去了，这也有一种离别。”我知道我的错误给你带来了一些痛苦。原谅你的老监护人，让他在你的感情中恢复原来的位置；并将其从你的记忆中抹去。艾伦，带上我亲爱的。

He moved away from under the green roof of leaves, and stopping in the sunlight outside and turning cheerfully towards us, said, ‘I shall be found about here somewhere. It’s a west wind, little woman, due west! Let no one thank me any more, for I am going to revert to my bachelor habits, and if anybody disregards this warning, I’ll run away and never come back!’
他从树叶的绿色屋顶下走开，在外面的阳光下停下来，高兴地转向我们，说：“我会在这附近的某个地方被发现。”这是西风，小女人，正西！不要再有人感谢我了，因为我要恢复单身汉的习惯了，如果有人无视这一警告，我就会逃跑，再也不会回来了！

What happiness was ours that day, what joy, what rest, what hope, what gratitude, what bliss! We were to be married before the month was out, but when we were to come and take possession of our own house was to depend on Richard and Ada.
那天我们是多么的幸福，多么的喜悦，多么的休息，多么的希望，多么的感激，多么的幸福！我们本来要在月底之前结婚，但是什么时候我们能拥有自己的房子就得靠理查德和艾达了。

We all three went home together next day. As soon as we arrived in town, Allan went straight to see Richard and to carry our joyful news to him and my darling. Late as it was, I meant to go to her for a few minutes before lying down to sleep, but I went home with my guardian first to make his tea for him and to occupy the old chair by his side, for I did not like to think of its being empty so soon.
第二天我们三个人就一起回家了。我们一到城里，艾伦就直接去见理查德，把我们的喜讯告诉他和我的宝贝。虽然已经很晚了，我本想去找她几分钟，然后躺下睡觉，但我先和我的监护人一起回家，为他泡茶，并占据了他旁边的旧椅子，因为我不喜欢想到它这么快就空了。

When we came home we found that a young man had called three times in the course of that one day to see me and that having been told on the occasion of his third call that I was not expected to return before ten o’clock at night, he had left word that he would call about then. He had left his card three times. Mr. Guppy.
当我们回到家时，我们发现一个年轻人在一天之内给我打了三次电话，而在他第三次打电话时被告知我预计晚上十点之前不会回来。 ，他留下了话，说他届时会打电话询问。他已经三度留下名片了。古比先生。

As I naturally speculated on the object of these visits, and as I always associated something ludicrous with the visitor, it fell out that in laughing about Mr. Guppy I told my guardian of his old proposal and his subsequent retraction. ‘After that,’ said my guardian, ‘we will certainly receive this hero.’ So instructions were given that Mr. Guppy should be shown in when he came again, and they were scarcely given when he did come again.
由于我自然地猜测这些访问的目的，并且由于我总是将一些可笑的事情与来访者联系在一起，所以结果是，在嘲笑孔雀先生时，我告诉了我的监护人他以前的提议以及他随后的撤回。 “在那之后，”我的监护人说，“我们一定会接待这位英雄。”因此，有人指示孔比先生再次来时应带他进来，但当他再次来时，他们几乎没有下达指示。

He was embarrassed when he found my guardian with me, but recovered himself and said, ‘How de do, sir?’
当他发现我的监护人和我在一起时，他感到很尴尬，但他恢复了平静，问道：“怎么样，先生？”

‘How do you do, sir?’ returned my guardian.
“你好吗，先生？”我的监护人回答道。

‘Thank you, sir, I am tolerable,’ returned Mr. Guppy. ‘Will you allow me to introduce my mother, Mrs. Guppy of the Old Street Road, and my particular friend, Mr. Weevle. That is to say, my friend has gone by the name of Weevle, but his name is really and truly Jobling.’
“谢谢您，先生，我可以忍受。”古比先生回答道。 “请允许我介绍一下我的母亲，老街的古比夫人，还有我特别的朋友，威夫勒先生。也就是说，我的朋友的名字是 Weevle，但他的名字确实是 Jobling。

My guardian begged them to be seated, and they all sat down.
我的监护人请他们坐下，他们都坐下了。

‘Tony,’ said Mr. Guppy to his friend after an awkward silence. ‘Will you open the case?’
“托尼，”在一阵尴尬的沉默后，古比先生对他的朋友说道。 “你愿意打开箱子吗？”

‘Do it yourself,’ returned the friend rather tartly.
“你自己做吧，”朋友尖刻地回答道。

‘Well, Mr. Jarndyce, sir,’ Mr. Guppy, after a moment’s consideration, began, to the great diversion of his mother, which she displayed by nudging Mr. Jobling with her elbow and winking at me in a most remarkable manner, ‘I had an idea that I should see Miss Summerson by herself and was not quite prepared for your esteemed presence. But Miss Summerson has mentioned to you, perhaps, that something has passed between us on former occasions?’
“好吧，贾迪斯先生，先生，”顾比先生考虑了一会儿后，开始说道他母亲的极大的消遣，她用肘部碰了碰乔布林先生，并以一种非常引人注目的方式向我眨了眨眼，这表明了这一点， “我有一个想法，我应该单独见见萨默森小姐，但对于尊敬的您的到来我还没有做好准备。但萨默森小姐也许向你提到过，我们之间曾经发生过一些事情？

‘Miss Summerson,’ returned my guardian, smiling, ‘has made a communication to that effect to me.’
“萨默森小姐，”我的监护人微笑着回答道，“已经向我传达了这一点。”

‘That,’ said Mr. Guppy, ‘makes matters easier. Sir, I have come out of my articles at Kenge and Carboy’s, and I believe with satisfaction to all parties. I am now admitted (after undergoing an examination that’s enough to badger a man blue, touching a pack of nonsense that he don’t want to know) on the roll of attorneys and have taken out my certificate, if it would be any satisfaction to you to see it.’
“这样，”古比先生说，“让事情变得更容易了。”先生，我已经在 Kenge 和 Carboy’s 发表了文章，我相信各方都感到满意。我现在已经被录取（经过一次足以让一个人忧郁的考试，接触了一堆他不想知道的废话），并且已经拿出了我的证书，如果你能满意的话。你来看看吧。

‘Thank you, Mr. Guppy,’ returned my guardian. ‘I am quite willing —I believe I use a legal phrase—to admit the certificate.’
“谢谢你，孔雀鱼先生，”我的监护人回答道。 “我非常愿意——我相信我用的是法律用语——承认这个证书。”

Mr. Guppy therefore desisted from taking something out of his pocket and proceeded without it.
因此，古比先生不再从口袋里掏出任何东西，而是继续前行。

I have no capital myself, but my mother has a little property which takes the form of an annuity’—here Mr. Guppy’s mother rolled her head as if she never could sufficiently enjoy the observation, and put her handkerchief to her mouth, and again winked at me—‘and a few pounds for expenses out of pocket in conducting business will never be wanting, free of interest, which is an advantage, you know,’ said Mr. Guppy feelingly.
我自己没有资本，但我母亲有一点财产，以年金的形式出现。”——说到这里，孔雀鱼先生的母亲转了转头，仿佛她永远无法充分享受这种观察，然后把手帕放到嘴边，再次说道。向我眨了眨眼睛——“做生意时自掏腰包的几英镑永远不会缺，而且是免息的，你知道，这是一个优势，”古皮先生感慨地说。

‘Certainly an advantage,’ returned my guardian.
“当然是一个优势，”我的监护人回答道。

‘I HAVE some connexion,’ pursued Mr. Guppy, ‘and it lays in the direction of Walcot Square, Lambeth. I have therefore taken a ‘ouse in that locality, which, in the opinion of my friends, is a hollow bargain (taxes ridiculous, and use of fixtures included in the rent), and intend setting up professionally for myself there forthwith.’
“我有一些联系，”古皮先生继续说道，“它就在兰贝斯沃尔科特广场的方向。”因此，我“在那个地方租了一套房子，在我的朋友看来，这是一笔空洞的交易（税收荒谬，并且使用包含在租金中的固定装置），并打算立即在那里为自己建立职业生涯。”

Here Mr. Guppy’s mother fell into an extraordinary passion of rolling her head and smiling waggishly at anybody who would look at her.
在这里，古比先生的母亲陷入了一种非凡的热情，她对任何看着她的人都摇着头，调皮地微笑。

‘It’s a six-roomer, exclusive of kitchens,’ said Mr. Guppy, ‘and in the opinion of my friends, a commodious tenement. When I mention my friends, I refer principally to my friend Jobling, who I believe has known me,’ Mr. Guppy looked at him with a sentimental air, ‘from boyhood’s hour.’
“这是一间有六间卧室的房子，不包括厨房，”古皮先生说，“在我的朋友们看来，这是一栋宽敞的公寓。”当我提到我的朋友时，我主要指的是我的朋友乔布林，我相信他就认识我了，”古皮先生用一种感伤的神情看着他，“从孩提时代起就认识了。”

Mr. Jobling confirmed this with a sliding movement of his legs.
乔布林先生用双腿的滑动动作证实了这一点。

‘My friend Jobling will render me his assistance in the capacity of clerk and will live in the ‘ouse,’ said Mr. Guppy. ‘My mother will likewise live in the ‘ouse when her present quarter in the Old Street Road shall have ceased and expired; and consequently there will be no want of society. My friend Jobling is naturally aristocratic by taste, and besides being acquainted with the movements of the upper circles, fully backs me in the intentions I am now developing.’
“我的朋友乔布林将以职员的身份为我提供帮助，并将住在‘房子’里，”顾比先生说。 “当我母亲目前在老街的住所停止并到期时，她也将住在这所房子里；”因此就不会有社会的缺乏。我的朋友乔布林天生具有贵族品味，除了熟悉上层圈子的动向外，还完全支持我现在正在发展的意图。

Mr. Jobling said ‘Certainly’ and withdrew a little from the elbow of Mr Guppy’s mother.
乔布林先生说“当然”，然后从古比先生母亲的肘部退了一点。

‘Now, I have no occasion to mention to you, sir, you being in the confidence of Miss Summerson,’ said Mr. Guppy, ‘(mother, I wish you’d be so good as to keep still), that Miss Summerson’s image was formerly imprinted on my ‘eart and that I made her a proposal of marriage.’
“现在，我没有机会向您提及，先生，您是萨默森小姐的秘密，”古皮先生说，“（妈妈，我希望您保持安静），萨默森小姐的这个形象以前就印在我的“心上，我向她求婚了”。

‘That I have heard,’ returned my guardian.
“我听说过，”我的监护人回答道。

‘Circumstances,’ pursued Mr. Guppy, ‘over which I had no control, but quite the contrary, weakened the impression of that image for a time. At which time Miss Summerson’s conduct was highly genteel; I may even add, magnanimous.’
“情况，”顾比先生继续说道，“我无法控制，但恰恰相反，一度削弱了那个形象的印象。当时萨默森小姐的举止非常有教养。我什至可以补充一句，宽宏大量。

My guardian patted me on the shoulder and seemed much amused.
我的监护人拍拍我的肩膀，看上去很有趣。

‘Now, sir,’ said Mr. Guppy, ‘I have got into that state of mind myself that I wish for a reciprocity of magnanimous behaviour. I wish to prove to Miss Summerson that I can rise to a heighth of which perhaps she hardly thought me capable. I find that the image which I did suppose had been eradicated from my ‘eart is NOT eradicated. Its influence over me is still tremenjous, and yielding to it, I am willing to overlook the circumstances over which none of us have had any control and to renew those proposals to Miss Summerson which I had the honour to make at a former period. I beg to lay the ‘ouse in Walcot Square, the business, and myself before Miss Summerson for her acceptance.’
“现在，先生，”顾比先生说，“我自己已经进入了这样的心态，我希望得到一种宽宏大量的行为的回报。我希望向萨默森小姐证明，我可以达到她认为我几乎没有能力达到的高度。我发现我以为已经从我的“心中根除”的形象并没有根除。它对我的影响仍然是巨大的，屈服于它，我愿意忽视我们谁都无法控制的情况，并重申我以前有幸向萨默森小姐提出的那些建议。我请求将“沃尔科特广场的房屋、公司和我自己的情况交给萨默森小姐，以求她的接受。”

‘Very magnanimous indeed, sir,’ observed my guardian.
“确实非常宽宏大量，先生。”我的监护人说道。

‘Well, sir,’ replied Mr. Guppy with candour, ‘my wish is to BE magnanimous. I do not consider that in making this offer to Miss Summerson I am by any means throwing myself away; neither is that the opinion of my friends. Still, there are circumstances which I submit may be taken into account as a set off against any little drawbacks of mine, and so a fair and equitable balance arrived at.’
“好吧，先生，”古比先生坦率地回答，“我的愿望是宽宏大量。”我不认为向萨默森小姐提出这个提议是我自暴自弃。我的朋友们也不是这么认为的。尽管如此，我提交的一些情况可以被考虑作为抵消我的任何小缺点，因此达到了公平公正的平衡。

‘I take upon myself, sir,’ said my guardian, laughing as he rang the bell, ‘to reply to your proposals on behalf of Miss Summerson. She is very sensible of your handsome intentions, and wishes you good evening, and wishes you well.’
“先生，我愿意代表萨默森小姐答复您的建议，”我的监护人按响了门铃，笑着说道。她非常明白你的美好意图，祝你晚安，祝你一切顺利。

‘Oh!’ said Mr. Guppy with a blank look. ‘Is that tantamount, sir, to acceptance, or rejection, or consideration?’
“哦！”孔雀先生一脸茫然地说。 “先生，这是否等于接受、拒绝或考虑？”

‘To decided rejection, if you please,’ returned my guardian.
“请决定拒绝，”我的监护人回答道。

Mr. Guppy looked incredulously at his friend, and at his mother, who suddenly turned very angry, and at the floor, and at the ceiling.
孔雀先生难以置信地看着他的朋友，又看看他的母亲，后者突然变得非常生气，又看看地板，又看看天花板。

‘Indeed?’ said he. ‘Then, Jobling, if you was the friend you represent yourself, I should think you might hand my mother out of the gangway instead of allowing her to remain where she ain’t wanted.’
“真的吗？”他说。 “那么，乔布林，如果你是你所代表的朋友，我想你可能会把我母亲从舷梯上交出来，而不是让她留在她不想要的地方。”

But Mrs. Guppy positively refused to come out of the gangway. She wouldn’t hear of it. ‘Why, get along with you,’ said she to my guardian, ‘what do you mean? Ain’t my son good enough for you? You ought to be ashamed of yourself. Get out with you!’
但古比夫人坚决拒绝从舷梯出来。她不会听到的。 ‘为什么，和你相处，’她对我的监护人说，‘你是什么意思？我儿子配不上你吗？你应该为自己感到羞耻。和你一起出去吧！

‘My good lady,’ returned my guardian, ‘it is hardly reasonable to ask me to get out of my own room.’
“我的好女士，”我的监护人回答道，“让我离开自己的房间是不合理的。”

‘I don’t care for that,’ said Mrs. Guppy. ‘Get out with you. If we ain’t good enough for you, go and procure somebody that is good enough. Go along and find ‘em.’
“我不在乎这个，”古比太太说。 ‘和你一起出去吧。如果我们对你来说不够好，那就去找一个足够好的人。一起去找到“他们”。

I was quite unprepared for the rapid manner in which Mrs. Guppy’s power of jocularity merged into a power of taking the profoundest offence.
我对古比夫人的幽默力量如此之快地融入了最严重冒犯的力量感到非常措手不及。

‘Go along and find somebody that’s good enough for you,’ repeated Mrs. Guppy. ‘Get out!’ Nothing seemed to astonish Mr. Guppy’s mother so much and to make her so very indignant as our not getting out. ‘Why don’t you get out?’ said Mrs. Guppy. ‘What are you stopping here for?’
“去找一个对你来说足够好的人吧，”古比夫人重复道。 “出去！”似乎没有什么比我们不出去更让孔雀先生的母亲感到惊讶和愤怒的了。 “你为什么不出去呢？”古比太太说。 “你在这里停下来做什么？”

‘Mother,’ interposed her son, always getting before her and pushing her back with one shoulder as she sidled at my guardian, ‘WILL you hold your tongue?’
“妈妈，”她的儿子插话道，当她侧身靠近我的监护人时，儿子总是站在她前面，用一只肩膀将她推回去，“你能闭嘴吗？”

‘No, William,’ she returned, ‘I won’t! Not unless he gets out, I won’t!’
“不，威廉，”她回答道，“我不会！”除非他出去，否则我不会！

However, Mr. Guppy and Mr. Jobling together closed on Mr. Guppy’s mother (who began to be quite abusive) and took her, very much against her will, downstairs, her voice rising a stair higher every time her figure got a stair lower, and insisting that we should immediately go and find somebody who was good enough for us, and above all things that we should get out.
然而，古比先生和乔布林先生一起靠近了古比先生的母亲（她开始变得相当粗暴），并非常违背她的意愿，把她带到了楼下，每当她的身形降低一层时，她的声音就会升高一层。 ，并坚持认为我们应该立即去找一个对我们来说足够好的人，最重要的是我们应该放弃的东西。

CHAPTER LXV
第六十五章


Beginning the World
开始世界

The term had commenced, and my guardian found an intimation from Mr. Kenge that the cause would come on in two days. As I had sufficient hopes of the will to be in a flutter about it, Allan and I agreed to go down to the court that morning. Richard was extremely agitated and was so weak and low, though his illness was still of the mind, that my dear girl indeed had sore occasion to be supported. But she looked forward—a very little way now—to the help that was to come to her, and never drooped.
学期已经开始，我的监护人从肯格先生那里得到了暗示，称诉讼将在两天内开始。由于我对这件事抱有足够的希望，所以我和艾伦同意那天早上去法庭。理查德极度焦躁，身体虚弱，情绪低落，尽管他的病仍然困扰着我，我亲爱的女儿确实需要得到支持。但她期待着——现在已经很远了——期待着即将到来的帮助，并且从未懈怠。

It was at Westminster that the cause was to come on. It had come on there, I dare say, a hundred times before, but I could not divest myself of an idea that it MIGHT lead to some result now. We left home directly after breakfast to be at Westminster Hall in good time and walked down there through the lively streets—so happily and strangely it seemed!—together.
这场事业将在威斯敏斯特展开。我敢说，它已经出现过一百次了，但我无法放弃这样的想法：它现在可能会带来一些结果。早餐后，我们立即离开家，赶到了威斯敏斯特大厅，一起穿过热闹的街道——看起来如此幸福而奇怪！——一起。

As we were going along, planning what we should do for Richard and Ada, I heard somebody calling ‘Esther! My dear Esther! Esther!’ And there was Caddy Jellyby, with her head out of the window of a little carriage which she hired now to go about in to her pupils (she had so many), as if she wanted to embrace me at a hundred yards’ distance. I had written her a note to tell her of all that my guardian had done, but had not had a moment to go and see her. Of course we turned back, and the affectionate girl was in that state of rapture, and was so overjoyed to talk about the night when she brought me the flowers, and was so determined to squeeze my face (bonnet and all) between her hands, and go on in a wild manner altogether, calling me all kinds of precious names, and telling Allan I had done I don’t know what for her, that I was just obliged to get into the little carriage and caln her down by letting her say and do exactly what she liked. Allan, standing at the window, was as pleased as Caddy; and I was as pleased as either of them; and I wonder that I got away as I did, rather than that I came off laughing, and red, and anything but tidy, and looking after Caddy, who looked after us out of the coach-window as long as she could see us.
当我们继续计划我们应该为理查德和艾达做些什么时，我听到有人喊“埃丝特！”我亲爱的埃丝特！以斯帖！”还有凯迪·杰利比，她把头伸出一辆小马车的窗外，她现在租了一辆小马车去见她的学生（她有很多学生），好像她想在一百码外拥抱我。距离。我给她写了一张纸条，告诉她我的监护人所做的一切，但没有时间去看她。当然，我们回头了，那个深情的女孩正处于那种狂喜的状态，她非常高兴地谈论她给我送花的那个夜晚，并且决心用双手捏住我的脸（帽子和所有的东西），继续疯狂地叫我各种珍贵的名字，并告诉艾伦我为她做了什么，我不知道为她做了什么，我只是不得不进入小马车并让她平静下来说、做她喜欢做的事。艾伦站在窗前，和凯迪一样高兴。我和他们一样高兴；我想知道我是这样逃走的，而不是我笑着离开，脸红了，一点也不整洁，并照顾着凯蒂，只要她能看到我们，她就会在车窗外照顾我们。

This made us some quarter of an hour late, and when we came to Westminster Hall we found that the day’s business was begun. Worse than that, we found such an unusual crowd in the Court of Chancery that it was full to the door, and we could neither see nor hear what was passing within. It appeared to be something droll, for occasionally there was a laugh and a cry of ‘Silence!’ It appeared to be something interesting, for every one was pushing and striving to get nearer. It appeared to be something that made the professional gentlemen very merry, for there were several young counsellors in wigs and whiskers on the outside of the crowd, and when one of them told the others about it, they put their hands in their pockets, and quite doubled themselves up with laughter, and went stamping about the pavement of the Hall.
这让我们迟到了大约一刻钟，当我们来到威斯敏斯特大厅时，发现当天的工作已经开始了。更糟糕的是，我们在大法官法院发现了如此不寻常的人群，以至于门口都挤满了人，我们既看不到也听不到里面的情况。这似乎是一件滑稽的事情，因为偶尔会有一阵笑声和一声“安静！”的叫喊声，这似乎是一件有趣的事情，因为每个人都在推挤着，努力靠近。这似乎是一件让职业绅士们非常高兴的事情，因为人群外面有几个戴着假发、留着胡须的年轻辅导员，当其中一个告诉其他人这件事时，他们把手插进口袋，然后笑得弯腰，在大厅的人行道上跺着脚。

We asked a gentleman by us if he knew what cause was on. He told us Jarndyce and Jarndyce. We asked him if he knew what was doing in it. He said really, no he did not, nobody ever did, but as well as he could make out, it was over. Over for the day? we asked him. No, he said, over for good.
我们问身边的一位绅士是否知道原因是什么。他告诉我们加迪斯和加迪斯。我们问他是否知道里面在做什么。他说真的，不，他没有这样做，从来没有人这样做过，但据他所知，一切都结束了。这一天结束了吗？我们问他。不，他说，永远结束了。

Over for good!
永远结束了！

When we heard this unaccountable answer, we looked at one another quite lost in amazement. Could it be possible that the will had set things right at last and that Richard and Ada were going to be rich? It seemed too good to be true. Alas it was!
当我们听到这个莫名其妙的答案时，我们面面相觑，惊讶不已。有没有可能遗嘱最终把一切都安排好了，理查德和艾达会变得富有？这似乎好得令人难以置信。唉，原来如此！

Our suspense was short, for a break-up soon took place in the crowd, and the people came streaming out looking flushed and hot and bringing a quantity of bad air with them. Still they were all exceedingly amused and were more like people coming out from a farce or a juggler than from a court of justice. We stood aside, watching for any countenance we knew, and presently great bundles of paper began to be carried out—bundles in bags, bundles too large to be got into any bags, immense masses of papers of all shapes and no shapes, which the bearers staggered under, and threw down for the time being, anyhow, on the Hall pavement, while they went back to bring out more. Even these clerks were laughing. We glanced at the papers, and seeing Jarndyce and Jarndyce everywhere, asked an official-looking person who was standing in the midst of them whether the cause was over. Yes, he said, it was all up with it at last, and burst out laughing too.
我们的悬念很短，因为人群中很快就发生了分手，人们涌了出来，脸色通红，浑身燥热，还带着一股恶气。尽管如此，他们还是都被逗乐了，更像是从一场闹剧或杂技演员中走出来的人，而不是从法庭上走出来的人。我们站在一旁，注视着我们认识的任何人的表情，不久，大捆的纸开始被搬出——装在袋子里的捆，捆得太大而无法装进任何袋子的捆，大量的各种形状和不形状的纸张，搬运工摇摇晃晃地跌倒在地，无论如何，暂时扔在大厅的人行道上，同时他们又回去搬出更多的东西。连这些店员都笑了。我们扫了一眼报纸，到处都是加迪斯和加迪斯，就问站在他们中间的一个官员模样的人，事情是否已经结束了。是的，他说，一切终于结束了，然后也笑了起来。

At this juncture we perceived Mr. Kenge coming out of court with an affable dignity upon him, listening to Mr. Vholes, who was deferential and carried his own bag. Mr. Vholes was the first to see us. ‘Here is Miss Summerson, sir,’ he said. ‘And Mr. Woodcourt.’
就在这个时候，我们看到肯格先生带着和蔼可亲的尊严走出法庭，听着弗霍尔斯先生的讲话，弗霍尔斯先生恭敬地拿着自己的包。 Vholes 先生是第一个见到我们的人。 “这是萨默森小姐，先生，”他说。 “还有伍德考特先生。”

‘Oh, indeed! Yes. Truly!’ said Mr. Kenge, raising his hat to me with polished politeness. ‘How do you do? Glad to see you. Mr. Jarndyce is not here?’
‘噢，确实如此！是的。真的！”肯吉先生礼貌地向我举起帽子说道。 '你好吗？很高兴见到你。贾迪斯先生不在吗？

No. He never came there, I reminded him.
不，我提醒他，他从来没有来过那里。

‘Really,’ returned Mr. Kenge, ‘it is as well that he is NOT here to-day, for his—shall I say, in my good friend’s absence, his indomitable singularity of opinion?—might have been strengthened, perhaps; not reasonably, but might have been strengthened.’
“真的，”肯吉先生回答道，“他今天不在这里也好，因为他的——我应该说，在我的好朋友不在的情况下，他不屈不挠的独特观点吗？——也许会得到加强；但他的观点可能会得到加强。”不合理，但可能会得到加强。

‘Pray what has been done to-day?’ asked Allan.
“请问今天做了什么？”艾伦问道。

‘I beg your pardon?’ said Mr. Kenge with excessive urbanity.
“请原谅？”肯格先生非常客气地说。

‘What has been done to-day?’
“今天做了什么？”

‘What has been done,’ repeated Mr. Kenge. ‘Quite so. Yes. Why, not much has been done; not much. We have been checked—brought up suddenly, I would say—upon the—shall I term it threshold?’
“已经做了什么，”肯格先生重复道。 '这么。是的。哎呀，我们并没有做太多事情。不多。我们已经被检查了——我想说，突然被提起来——在——我可以称之为阈值吗？

‘Is this will considered a genuine document, sir?’ said Allan. ‘Will you tell us that?’
“先生，这遗嘱算是一份真实的文件吗？”艾伦说。 “你能告诉我们吗？”

‘Most certainly, if I could,’ said Mr. Kenge; ‘but we have not gone into that, we have not gone into that.’
“当然，如果我可以的话，”肯吉先生说。 “但我们还没有讨论这个问题，我们还没有讨论这个问题。”

‘We have not gone into that,’ repeated Mr. Vholes as if his low inward voice were an echo.
“我们还没有讨论这个，”沃尔斯先生重复道，仿佛他内心低沉的声音是一种回声。

‘You are to reflect, Mr. Woodcourt,’ observed Mr. Kenge, using his silver trowel persuasively and smoothingly, ‘that this has been a great cause, that this has been a protracted cause, that this has been a complex cause. Jarndyce and Jarndyce has been termed, not inaptly, a monument of Chancery practice.’
“伍德考特先生，你要反思，”肯格先生用他的银抹子很有说服力地、平稳地说道，“这是一个伟大的事业，这是一个长期的事业，这是一个复杂的事业。”詹迪斯和詹迪斯被称为大法官法庭实践的纪念碑，这并非不恰当。

‘And patience has sat upon it a long time,’ said Allan.
“耐心已经等待了很长时间了，”艾伦说。

‘Very well indeed, sir,’ returned Mr. Kenge with a certain condeseending laugh he had. ‘Very well! You are further to reflect, Mr. Woodcourt,’ becoming dignified almost to severity, ‘that on the numerous difficulties, contingencies, masterly fictions, and forms of procedure in this great cause, there has been expended study, ability, eloquence, knowledge, intellect, Mr. Woodcourt, high intellect. For many years, the—a—I would say the flower of the bar, and the—a—I would presume to add, the matured autumnal fruits of the woolsack—have been lavished upon Jarndyce and Jarndyce. If the public have the benefit, and if the country have the adornment, of this great grasp, it must be paid for in money or money’s worth, sir.’
“确实很好，先生。”肯吉先生带着一种居高临下的笑声回答道。 '很好！伍德考特先生，您要进一步反思，“变得庄严得近乎严厉，”在这项伟大事业中的无数困难、偶然事件、精妙的虚构和程序形式中，有大量的研究、能力、口才、知识、智力，伍德考特先生，智力很高。多年来，我想说的是酒吧之花，还有羊毛袋成熟的秋季果实，这些都被大量地奉献给了加迪斯和加迪斯。如果公众能从这种伟大的掌握中受益，如果国家有这种伟大的掌握，那么就必须用金钱或金钱的价值来支付，先生。

‘Mr. Kenge,’ said Allan, appearing enlightened all in a moment. ‘Excuse me, our time presses. Do I understand that the whole estate is found to have been absorbed in costs?’
'先生。肯格，”艾伦说道，瞬间显得恍然大悟。 ‘对不起，我们的时间很紧迫。我是否理解整个遗产已被纳入成本？

‘Hem! I believe so,’ returned Mr. Kenge. ‘Mr. Vholes, what do YOU say?’
‘哼！我相信是这样，”肯吉先生回答道。 '先生。维勒斯，你说什么？

‘I believe so,’ said Mr. Vholes.
“我相信是这样，”沃尔斯先生说。

‘And that thus the suit lapses and melts away?’
“那么诉讼就会失效并消失吗？”

‘Probably,’ returned Mr. Kenge. ‘Mr. Vholes?’
“可能，”肯吉先生回答道。 '先生。沃勒斯？

‘Probably,’ said Mr. Vholes.
“可能吧，”沃尔斯先生说。

‘My dearest life,’ whispered Allan, ‘this will break Richard’s heart!’
“我最亲爱的生命，”艾伦低声说道，“这会让理查德心碎！”

There was such a shock of apprehension in his face, and he knew Richard so perfectly, and I too had seen so much of his gradual decay, that what my dear girl had said to me in the fullness of her foreboding love sounded like a knell in my ears.
他的脸上充满了恐惧，他对理查德如此了解，我也看到了他逐渐衰弱的情况，所以我亲爱的女孩充满不祥之爱对我说的话听起来就像丧钟。在我耳边。

‘In case you should be wanting Mr. C., sir,’ said Mr. Vholes, coming after us, ‘you’ll find him in court. I left him there resting himself a little. Good day, sir; good day, Miss Summerson.’ As he gave me that slowly devouring look of his, while twisting up the strings of his bag before he hastened with it after Mr. Kenge, the benignant shadow of whose conversational presence he seemed afraid to leave, he gave one gasp as if he had swallowed the last morsel of his client, and his black buttoned-up unwholesome figure glided away to the low door at the end of the Hall.
“如果您需要 C. 先生，先生，”沃尔斯先生跟在我们后面说道，“您会在法庭上找到他的。”我让他在那里休息一会儿。美好的一天，先生；美好的一天，萨默森小姐。”当他用他那种慢慢吞噬的眼神看着我时，他一边扭着包的绳子，一边加快脚步追赶肯格先生，他似乎不敢离开肯格先生的亲切的影子，他喘了口气，仿佛吞下了委托人的最后一口食物，他黑色的、扣着纽扣的、不健康的身影滑向大厅尽头的低矮门。

‘My dear love,’ said Allan, ‘leave to me, for a little while, the charge you gave me. Go home with this intelligence and come to Ada’s by and by!’
“我亲爱的，”艾伦说，“暂时把你交给我的任务交给我吧。”带着这个情报回家，一会儿就到艾达那里去！”

I would not let him take me to a coach, but entreated him to go to Richard without a moment’s delay and leave me to do as he wished. Hurrying home, I found my guardian and told him gradually with what news I had returned. ‘Little woman,’ said he, quite unmoved for himself, ‘to have done with the suit on any terms is a greater blessing than I had looked for. But my poor young cousins!’
我不让他带我去马车，但恳求他立刻去找理查德，让我按照他的意愿去做。我赶回家，找到了监护人，慢慢地告诉了他我回来的消息。 “小女人，”他说，自己一点也不为所动，“不管怎样，能穿上这套衣服，这比我所期待的还要大。”但我可怜的年轻表兄弟们！

We talked about them all the morning and discussed what it was possible to do. In the afternoon my guardian walked with me to Symond’s Inn and left me at the door. I went upstairs. When my darling heard my footsteps, she came out into the small passage and threw her arms round my neck, but she composed herself direcfly and said that Richard had asked for me several times. Allan had found him sitting in the corner of the court, she told me, like a stone figure. On being roused, he had broken away and made as if he would have spoken in a fierce voice to the judge. He was stopped by his mouth being full of blood, and Allan had brought him home.
我们整个早上都在谈论它们，并讨论可以做什么。下午，我的监护人陪我走到西蒙旅馆，把我留在门口。我上楼了。当我的宝贝听到我的脚步声时，她走到小过道里，用双臂搂住我的脖子，但她直接镇定下来，说理查德已经找过我好几次了。她告诉我，艾伦发现他坐在球场的角落里，就像一个石像。当他被惊醒时，他挣脱了出来，做出一副要对法官大声说话的样子。他被满嘴的血阻止了，艾伦把他带回家了。

He was lying on a sofa with his eyes closed when I went in. There were restoratives on the table; the room was made as airy as possible, and was darkened, and was very orderly and quiet. Allan stood behind him watching him gravely. His face appeared to me to be quite destitute of colour, and now that I saw him without his seeing me, I fully saw, for the first time, how worn away he was. But he looked handsomer than I had seen him look for many a day.
我进去的时候，他正躺在沙发上，闭着眼睛。桌子上放着补品。房间尽可能通风，光线昏暗，非常有序和安静。艾伦站在他身后，严肃地看着他。在我看来，他的脸色毫无血色，现在我看到了他，而他却没有看到我，我第一次完全看出他是多么憔悴。但他看起来比我很多天见到的他都要英俊。

I sat down by his side in silence. Opening his eyes by and by, he said in a weak voice, but with his old smile, ‘Dame Durden, kiss me, my dear!’
我默默地坐在他身边。渐渐地，他睁开了眼睛，用微弱的声音说道，但脸上带着古老的微笑：“德登夫人，吻我吧，亲爱的！”

It was a great comfort and surprise to me to find him in his low state cheerful and looking forward. He was happier, he said, in our intended marriage than he could find words to tell me. My husband had been a guardian angel to him and Ada, and he blessed us both and wished us all the joy that life could yield us. I almost felt as if my own heart would have broken when I saw him take my husband’s hand and hold it to his breast.
发现他在情绪低落时心情愉快、充满期待，这让我感到极大的安慰和惊喜。他说，他对我们预定的婚姻感到幸福，无法用言语来告诉我。我的丈夫一直是他和艾达的守护天使，他祝福我们俩，并祝愿我们生活能带给我们所有的快乐。当我看到他握住我丈夫的手并将其放在胸前时，我几乎感觉自己的心都要碎了。

We spoke of the future as much as possible, and he said several times that he must be present at our marriage if he could stand upon his feet. Ada would contrive to take him, somehow, he said. ‘Yes, surely, dearest Richard!’ But as my darling answered him thus hopefully, so serene and beautiful, with the help that was to come to her so near—I knew—I knew!
我们尽可能多地谈论未来，他多次说过，如果他能站起来，他就必须出席我们的婚礼。他说，艾达会想方设法带走他。 “是的，当然，亲爱的理查德！”但是当我的宝贝如此满怀希望地、如此平静而美丽地回答他时，在她如此接近的帮助下——我知道——我知道！

It was not good for him to talk too much, and when he was silent, we were silent too. Sitting beside him, I made a pretence of working for my dear, as he had always been used to joke about my being busy. Ada leaned upon his pillow, holding his head upon her arm. He dozed often, and whenever he awoke without seeing him, said first of all, ‘Where is Woodcourt?’
他说话太多不好，当他沉默时，我们也沉默。我坐在他旁边，假装为亲爱的工作，因为他总是开玩笑说我很忙。艾达靠在他的枕头上，把他的头枕在她的手臂上。他经常打瞌睡，每当他醒来看不到他时，他首先会问：“伍德考特在哪里？”

Evening had come on when I lifted up my eyes and saw my guardian standing in the little hall. ‘Who is that, Dame Durden?’ Richard asked me. The door was behind him, but he had observed in my face that some one was there.
当我抬起眼睛，看到我的监护人站在小大厅里时，已经是晚上了。 “德登夫人，那人是谁？”理查德问我。门在他身后，但他从我的脸上看出有人在那里。

I looked to Allan for advice, and as he nodded ‘Yes,’ bent over Richard and told him. My guardian saw what passed, came softly by me in a moment, and laid his hand on Richard’s. ‘Oh, sir,’ said Richard, ‘you are a good man, you are a good man!’ and burst into tears for the first time.
我向艾伦寻求建议，当他点点头说“是”时，我弯下腰告诉他。我的监护人看到了发生的一切，立刻轻轻地从我身边走过，将他的手放在理查德的手上。 “哦，先生，”理查德说，“你是一个好人，你是一个好人！”他第一次哭了起来。

My guardian, the picture of a good man, sat down in my place, keeping his hand on Richard’s.
我的监护人，一个好人的形象，坐在我的位置上，把手放在理查德的手上。

‘My dear Rick,’ said he, ‘the clouds have cleared away, and it is bright now. We can see now. We were all bewildered, Rick, more or less. What matters! And how are you, my dear boy?’
“我亲爱的瑞克，”他说，“乌云已经散去，现在天亮了。”我们现在可以看到了。瑞克，我们或多或少都感到困惑。有什么关系！你好吗，我亲爱的孩子？

‘I am very weak, sir, but I hope I shall be stronger. I have to begin the world.’
“我很虚弱，先生，但我希望我能变得更坚强。我必须开始这个世界。

‘Aye, truly; well said!’ cried my guardian.
是的，确实如此；说得好！”我的监护人喊道。

‘I will not begin it in the old way now,’ said Richard with a sad smile. ‘I have learned a lesson now, sir. It was a hard one, but you shall be assured, indeed, that I have learned it.’
“我现在不会再用以前的方式开始了，”理查德悲伤地微笑着说道。 “我现在已经吸取了教训，先生。这很难，但你可以放心，我确实学会了。”

‘Well, well,’ said my guardian, comforting him; ‘well, well, well, dear boy!’
“好吧，好吧，”我的监护人安慰他说。 “好吧，好吧，好吧，亲爱的孩子！”

‘I was thinking, sir,’ resumed Richard, ‘that there is nothing on earth I should so much like to see as their house—Dame Durden’s and Woodcourt’s house. If I could be removed there when I begin to recover my strength, I feel as if I should get well there sooner than anywhere.’
“我在想，先生，”理查德继续说道，“世界上没有什么比他们的房子——杜登夫人和伍德考特的房子更让我想去看看的了。如果我能在我开始恢复体力时被转移到那里，我觉得我应该比任何地方都更快康复。

‘Why, so have I been thinking too, Rick,’ said my guardian, ‘and our little woman likewise; she and I have been talking of it this very day. I dare say her husband won’t object. What do you think?’
“为什么，我也是这么想的，里克，”我的监护人说，“我们的小女人也是如此；我和她今天一直在谈论这件事。我敢说她丈夫不会反对。你怎么认为？'

Richard smiled and lifted up his arm to touch him as he stood behind the head of the couch.
当理查德站在沙发床头后面时，他微笑着抬起手臂触碰他。

‘I say nothing of Ada,’ said Richard, ‘but I think of her, and have thought of her very much. Look at her! See her here, sir, bending over this pillow when she has so much need to rest upon it herself, my dear love, my poor girl!’
“我没有提到艾达，”理查德说，“但我想起了她，而且非常想念她。看着她！看到她在这里，先生，当她非常需要靠在枕头上休息时，她弯腰在枕头上，我亲爱的爱人，我可怜的女孩！

He clasped her in his arms, and none of us spoke. He gradually released her, and she looked upon us, and looked up to heaven, and moved her lips.
他把她搂在怀里，我们谁都没有说话。他逐渐松开了她，她看着我们，仰望天空，动了动嘴唇。

‘When I get down to Bleak House,’ said Richard, ‘I shall have much to tell you, sir, and you will have much to show me. You will go, won’t you?’
“当我到达荒凉山庄时，”理查德说，“我有很多东西要告诉你，先生，你也会有很多东西要给我看。你会去的，不是吗？

‘Undoubtedly, dear Rick.’
“毫无疑问，亲爱的瑞克。”

‘Thank you; like you, like you,’ said Richard. ‘But it’s all like you. They have been telling me how you planned it and how you remembered all Esther’s familiar tastes and ways. It will be like coming to the old Bleak House again.’
'谢谢;就像你，就像你，”理查德说。 ‘但一切都像你。他们一直告诉我你是如何计划的，以及你如何记住埃斯特所有熟悉的品味和方式。这就像再次来到古老的荒凉山庄一样。

‘And you will come there too, I hope, Rick. I am a solitary man now, you know, and it will be a charity to come to me. A charity to come to me, my love!’ he repeated to Ada as he gently passed his hand over her golden hair and put a lock of it to his lips. (I think he vowed within himself to cherish her if she were left alone.)
“我希望你也会去那里，里克。你知道，我现在是一个孤独的人，能来找我将是一种慈善。 “这是对我的善行，我的爱人！”他对艾达重复道，同时轻轻地用手抚过她金色的头发，把一绺放在唇边。 （我想他心里发誓，如果她独自一人，他会珍惜她。）

‘It was a troubled dream?’ said Richard, clasping both my guardian’s hands eagerly.
“这是一个困扰的梦吗？”理查德急切地握住我监护人的双手说道。

‘Nothing more, Rick; nothing more.’
“仅此而已，瑞克；而已。'

‘And you, being a good man, can pass it as such, and forgive and pity the dreamer, and be lenient and encouraging when he wakes?’
“而你，作为一个好人，可以这样对待它，原谅和怜悯梦者，并在他醒来时宽容和鼓励他吗？”

‘Indeed I can. What am I but another dreamer, Rick?’
‘我确实可以。我不是另一个梦想家吗，瑞克？

‘I will begin the world!’ said Richard with a light in his eyes.
“我将开始这个世界！”理查德眼中闪烁着光芒。

My husband drew a little nearer towards Ada, and I saw him solemnly lift up his hand to warn my guardian.
我的丈夫向艾达靠近了一点，我看到他郑重地举起手来警告我的监护人。

‘When shall I go from this place to that pleasant country where the old times are, where I shall have strength to tell what Ada has been to me, where I shall be able to recall my many faults and blindnesses, where I shall prepare myself to be a guide to my unborn child?’ said Richard. ‘When shall I go?’
“我什么时候才能离开这个地方，去那个令人愉快的国家，那里有旧时光，在那里我将有力量讲述艾达对我的影响，在那里我将能够回忆起我的许多错误和盲目，在那里我将做好准备成为我未出生孩子的向导？”理查德说。 “我什么时候去？”

‘Dear Rick, when you are strong enough,’ returned my guardian.
“亲爱的瑞克，当你足够强大时，”我的监护人回答道。

‘Ada, my darling!’
“艾达，我亲爱的！”

He sought to raise himself a little. Allan raised him so that she could hold him on her bosom, which was what he wanted.
他试图把自己抬高一点。艾伦把他抱起来，这样她就可以把他抱在怀里，这就是他想要的。

‘I have done you many wrongs, my own. I have fallen like a poor stray shadow on your way, I have married you to poverty and trouble, I have scattered your means to the winds. You will forgive me all this, my Ada, before I begin the world?’
‘我对你做了很多错事，我自己的。我像一个可怜的流浪影子一样倒在你的路上，我让你嫁给了贫穷和麻烦，我让你的财产随风飘散。在我开始这个世界之前，我的艾达，你会原谅我这一切吗？

A smile irradiated his face as she bent to kiss him. He slowly laid his face down upon her bosom, drew his arms closer round her neck, and with one parting sob began the world. Not this world, oh, not this! The world that sets this right.
当她弯下腰去吻他时，他的脸上绽放出微笑。他慢慢地将脸埋在她怀里，用双臂搂住她的脖子，伴随着一声临别抽泣，世界开始了。不是这个世界，哦，不是这个！这个世界纠正了这一点。

When all was still, at a late hour, poor crazed Miss Flite came weeping to me and told me she had given her birds their liberty.
当一切都安静下来的时候，已经很晚了，可怜的疯狂的弗利特小姐哭着来到我身边，告诉我她已经给了她的鸟儿自由。

CHAPTER LXVI
第六十六章


Down in Lincolnshire
位于林肯郡

There is a hush upon Chesney Wold in these altered days, as there is upon a portion of the family history. The story goes that Sir Leicester paid some who could have spoken out to hold their peace; but it is a lame story, feebly whispering and creeping about, and any brighter spark of life it shows soon dies away. It is known for certain that the handsome Lady Dedlock lies in the mausoleum in the park, where the trees arch darkly overhead, and the owl is heard at night making the woods ring; but whence she was brought home to be laid among the echoes of that solitary place, or how she died, is all mystery. Some of her old friends, principally to be found among the peachy-cheeked charmers with the skeleton throats, did once occasionally say, as they toyed in a ghastly manner with large fans—like charmers reduced to flirting with grim death, after losing all their other beaux—did once occasionally say, when the world assembled together, that they wondered the ashes of the Dedlocks, entombed in the mausoleum, never rose against the profanation of her company. But the dead-and-gone Dedlocks take it very calmly and have never been known to object.
在这些变化的日子里，切斯尼沃尔德一片寂静，就像家族历史的一部分一样。据说，莱斯特爵士付钱给一些本可以发声的人，让他们保持沉默。但这是一个蹩脚的故事，有气无力地低声细语，悄无声息，它所展现的任何明亮的生命火花很快就会消失。众所周知，英俊的戴德洛克夫人躺在公园的陵墓里，那里的树木在头顶上呈黑暗的拱形，晚上可以听到猫头鹰的叫声，让树林里响起；但她从哪里被带回家，安葬在那个偏僻地方的回声中，或者她是怎么死的，都是个谜。她的一些老朋友，主要是那些长着骷髅喉咙的桃色脸颊的魔术师，偶尔会这样说，因为他们以一种可怕的方式玩弄着大扇子——就像魔术师在失去了所有的能力后，沦落到与可怕的死亡调情一样。其他花花公子——当世界聚集在一起时，他们偶尔会说，他们想知道埋在陵墓中的戴德洛克家族的骨灰，从来没有在她的陪伴下升起。但已经去世的戴德洛克夫妇却非常冷静地对待这件事，而且从来没有反对过。

Up from among the fern in the hollow, and winding by the bridleroad among the trees, comes sometimes to this lonely spot the sound of horses’ hoofs. Then may be seen Sir Leicester—invalided, bent, and almost blind, but of worthy presence yet—riding with a stalwart man beside him, constant to his bridle-rein. When they come to a certain spot before the mausoleum-door, Sir Leicester’s accustomed horse stops of his own accord, and Sir Leicester, pulling off his hat, is still for a few moments before they ride away.
从洼地里的蕨丛中，沿着树林间的马路蜿蜒而上，有时，这个偏僻的地方会传来马蹄声。然后可以看到莱斯特爵士——残疾、弯腰、几乎失明，但仍值得一提——他身边有一个壮实的男人骑马，始终控制着他的缰绳。当他们来到陵墓门前的某个地方时，莱斯特爵士惯常的马自行停下来，莱斯特爵士脱下帽子，静止了一会儿，然后他们就骑马离开了。

War rages yet with the audacious Boythorn, though at uncertain intervals, and now hotly, and now coolly, flickering like an unsteady fire. The truth is said to be that when Sir Leicester came down to Lincolnshire for good, Mr. Boythorn showed a manifest desire to abandon his right of way and do whatever Sir Leicester would, which Sir Leicester, conceiving to be a condescension to his illness or misfortune, took in such high dudgeon, and was so magnificently aggrieved by, that Mr. Boythorn found himself under the necessity of committing a flagrant trespass to restore his neighbour to himself. Similarly, Mr. Boythorn continues to post tremendous placards on the disputed thoroughfare and (with his bird upon his head) to hold forth vehemently against Sir Leicester in the sanctuary of his own home; similarly, also, he defies him as of old in the little church by testifying a bland unconsciousness of his existence. But it is whispered that when he is most ferocious towards his old foe, he is really most considerate, and that Sir Leicester, in the dignity of being implacable, little supposes how much he is humoured. As little does he think how near together he and his antagonist have suffered in the fortunes of two sisters, and his antagonist, who knows it now, is not the man to tell him. So the quarrel goes on to the satisfaction of both.
战争仍在与大胆的博伊索恩进行，尽管间隔时间不确定，时而激烈，时而冷静，像不稳定的火焰一样闪烁。据说，事实是，当莱斯特爵士永远来到林肯郡时，博伊索恩先生表现出明显的愿望，要放弃他的通行权，做莱斯特爵士想做的任何事，莱斯特爵士认为这是对他的疾病或疾病的屈尊俯就。博伊索恩先生发现自己必须公然侵入，才能将邻居归还给自己。同样，博伊索恩先生继续在有争议的大道上张贴巨大的标语牌，并（头上戴着鸟）在自己家的避难所中激烈反对莱斯特爵士；同样，他也像往常一样在小教堂里反抗他，证明他对他的存在表现出一种温和的无意识。但有传言说，当他对老对手最凶猛时，他实际上是最体贴的，莱斯特爵士以不屈不挠的尊严，很少有人想象他有多么幽默。他几乎没有想到，他和他的对手在两姐妹的命运中所遭受的苦难是多么紧密，而他的对手现在知道了，却不是告诉他的人。就这样，争吵一直持续到双方都满意为止。

In one of the lodges of the park—that lodge within sight of the house where, once upon a time, when the waters were out down in Lincolnshire, my Lady used to see the keeper’s child—the stalwart man, the trooper formerly, is housed. Some relics of his old calling hang upon the walls, and these it is the chosen recreation of a little lame man about the stable-yard to keep gleaming bright. A busy little man he always is, in the polishing at harness-house doors, of stirrup-irons, bits, curb-chains, harness bosses, anything in the way of a stable-yard that will take a polish, leading a life of friction. A shaggy little damaged man, withal, not unlike an old dog of some mongrel breed, who has been considerably knocked about. He answers to the name of Phil.
在公园的一间小屋里——那个小屋在房子的视野范围内，很久以前，当林肯郡的水流出来时，我的夫人经常看到看门人的孩子——那个坚定的男人，以前的士兵，正在那里。安置。墙上挂着一些他昔日职业的遗物，这些是马厩院子里一个小瘸子选择的消遣，以保持闪闪发光。他总是一个忙碌的小个子，在马具房的门上抛光马镫铁、马具、锁链、马具凸台，以及任何马厩院子里需要抛光的东西，过着一种摩擦。一个毛茸茸的小受伤男人，而且，与某种杂种品种的老狗没有什么不同，它被严重撞倒了。他回应了菲尔的名字。

A goodly sight it is to see the grand old housekeeper (harder of hearing now) going to church on the arm of her son and to observe— which few do, for the house is scant of company in these times—the relations of both towards Sir Leicester, and his towards them. They have visitors in the high summer weather, when a grey cloak and umbrella, unknown to Chesney Wold at other periods, are seen among the leaves; when two young ladies are occasionally found gambolling in sequestered saw-pits and such nooks of the park; and when the smoke of two pipes wreathes away into the fragrant evening air from the trooper’s door. Then is a fife heard trolling within the lodge on the inspiring topic of the ‘British Grenadiers”; and as the evening closes in, a gruff inflexible voice is heard to say, while two men pace together up and down, ‘But I never own to it before the old girl. Discipline must be maintained.’
看到那位伟大的老管家（现在听力不好了）挽着儿子的胳膊去教堂，并观察——很少有人这样做，因为这个房子里很少有人陪伴——两人之间的关系，这是一个很好的景象。莱斯特爵士和他对他们的态度。在盛夏的天气里，这里会有访客，在树叶间可以看到切斯尼·沃尔德在其他时期不曾见过的灰色斗篷和雨伞；偶尔会发现两位年轻女士在僻静的锯坑和公园的角落里嬉戏；当两根烟斗的烟雾从警官的门口盘旋到芬芳的夜晚空气中时。然后，小屋内响起了长笛声，谈论着“英国掷弹兵”这个鼓舞人心的话题；当夜幕降临时，两个男人一起踱来踱去，听到一个粗鲁、僵硬的声音说：“但我从来没有在老女孩面前承认过这一点。”必须维持纪律。”

The greater part of the house is shut up, and it is a show-house no longer; yet Sir Leicester holds his shrunken state in the long drawing-room for all that, and reposes in his old place before my Lady’s picture. Closed in by night with broad screens, and illumined only in that part, the light of the drawing-room seems gradually contracting and dwindling until it shall be no more. A little more, in truth, and it will be all extinguished for Sir Leicester; and the damp door in the mausoleum which shuts so tight, and looks so obdurate, will have opened and received him.
房子的大部分都被封闭了，它不再是一个样板间；然而，莱斯特爵士却在长长的客厅里保持着萎缩的状态，在夫人的照片前安息在他的老地方。夜晚，客厅被宽大的屏风封闭，只有那部分有光，客厅的光线似乎逐渐收缩、减弱，直至消失。事实上，再多一点，莱斯特爵士的一切就会消失。陵墓里那扇关得那么紧、看起来那么顽固的潮湿的门将会打开并迎接他。

Volumnia, growing with the flight of time pinker as to the red in her face, and yellower as to the white, reads to Sir Leicester in the long evenings and is driven to various artifices to conceal her yawns, of which the chief and most efficacious is the insertion of the pearl necklace between her rosy lips. Long-winded treatises on the Buffy and Boodle question, showing how Buffy is immaculate and Boodle villainous, and how the country is lost by being all Boodle and no Buffy, or saved by being all Buffy and no Boodle (it must be one of the two, and cannot be anything else), are the staple of her reading. Sir Leicester is not particular what it is and does not appear to follow it very closely, further than that he always comes broad awake the moment Volumnia ventures to leave off, and sonorously repeating her last words, begs with some displeasure to know if she finds herself fatigued. However, Volumnia, in the course of her bird-like hopping about and pecking at papers, has alighted on a memorandum concerning herself in the event of ‘anything happening’ to her kinsman, which is handsome compensation for an extensive course of reading and holds even the dragon Boredom at bay.
随着时间的流逝，沃伦尼娅的脸变得越来越粉红，脸色变得越来越黄，在漫长的夜晚给莱斯特爵士读书，并被迫采取各种手段来掩饰她的哈欠，其中最主要也是最有效的是珍珠项链插在她红润的嘴唇之间。关于 Buffy 和 Boodle 问题的长篇大论，展示了 Buffy 是如何完美无缺的，而 Boodle 是邪恶的，以及国家如何因只做 Boodle 而没有 Buffy 而失去，或者如何通过只做 Buffy 而没有 Boodle 而拯救（它一定是其中之一）两个，不能是其他），是她阅读的主要内容。莱斯特爵士并不特别关注它的本质，而且似乎并没有非常密切地关注它，而且，当沃伦尼亚冒险离开时，他总是完全清醒，并大声地重复她的最后一句话，有些不高兴地请求知道她是否发现她自己也累了。然而，沃伦尼娅在她像鸟儿一样跳来跳去、啄食文件的过程中，落下了一份关于她自己的备忘录，以防她的亲戚“发生任何事情”，这是对广泛阅读课程的丰厚补偿，并持有甚至连巨龙的无聊都陷入困境。

The cousins generally are rather shy of Chesney Wold in its dullness, but take to it a little in the shooting season, when guns are heard in the plantations, and a few scattered beaters and keepers wait at the old places of appointment for low-spirited twos and threes of cousins. The debilitated cousin, more debilitated by the dreariness of the place, gets into a fearful state of depression, groaning under penitential sofa-pillows in his gunless hours and protesting that such fernal old jail’s—nough t’sew fler up—frever.
表兄弟们一般都对切斯尼沃尔德的沉闷感到害羞，但在射击季节，当种植园里听到枪声时，一些分散的殴打者和看守人在旧的约会地点等待着情绪低落的人。三三两两的表兄弟姐妹。虚弱的表弟，由于这个地方的沉闷而更加虚弱，陷入了一种可怕的抑郁状态，在他没有枪的时间里，他在忏悔的沙发枕头下呻吟，并抗议说这样的地狱般的老监狱永远不会再出现。

The only great occasions for Volumnia in this changed aspect of the place in Lincolnshire are those occasions, rare and widely separated, when something is to be done for the county or the country in the way of gracing a public ball. Then, indeed, does the tuckered sylph come out in fairy form and proceed with joy under cousinly escort to the exhausted old assembly-room, fourteen heavy miles off, which, during three hundred and sixty-four days and nights of every ordinary year, is a kind of antipodean lumberroom full of old chairs and tables upside down. Then, indeed, does she captivate all hearts by her condescension, by her girlish vivacity, and by her skipping about as in the days when the hideous old general with the mouth too full of teeth had not cut one of them at two guineas each. Then does she twirl and twine, a pastoral nymph of good family, through the mazes of the dance. Then do the swains appear with tea, with lemonade, with sandwiches, with homage. Then is she kind and cruel, stately and unassuming, various, beautifully wilful. Then is there a singular kind of parallel between her and the little glass chandeliers of another age embellishing that assembly-room, which, with their meagre stems, their spare little drops, their disappointing knobs where no drops are, their bare little stalks from which knobs and drops have both departed, and their little feeble prismatic twinkling, all seem Volumnias.
在林肯郡这个地方发生了变化的方面，沃伦尼亚唯一的伟大场合是那些罕见的、相隔很远的场合，即要为县或国家做一些事情，为公共舞会增光添彩。然后，确实，这位衣衫褴褛的仙女以仙女的形式出现，在堂兄弟的护送下，欢欣鼓舞地前往十四英里外的疲惫不堪的旧会议室，在每年的三百六十四个日日夜夜中，是一种澳大利亚的储藏室，里面摆满了倒置的旧椅子和桌子。那么，确实，她以她的居高临下、她少女般的活泼，以及她的蹦蹦跳跳，迷住了所有人的心，就像那个满嘴牙齿的丑恶老将军没有以每两畿尼的价格砍下其中一颗的日子一样。然后，她像一位出身于好家庭的田园仙女一样，旋转着，缠绕着，穿过舞蹈的迷宫。然后，情人们带着茶、柠檬水、三明治和致敬出现。那么她就是善良又残酷，端庄又谦逊，多姿多彩，美丽任性。那么，她和装饰那个会议室的另一个时代的小玻璃枝形吊灯之间有一种奇特的相似之处，这些吊灯的灯杆很细，有多余的小水滴，没有水滴的令人失望的旋钮，有光秃秃的小灯杆，旋钮和水滴都消失了，它们微弱的棱柱形闪烁，看起来全都是沃伦尼亚斯。

For the rest, Lincolnshire life to Volumnia is a vast blank of overgrown house looking out upon trees, sighing, wringing their hands, bowing their heads, and casting their tears upon the windowpanes in monotonous depressions. A labyrinth of grandeur, less the property of an old family of human beings and their ghostly likenesses than of an old family of echoings and thunderings which start out of their hundred graves at every sound and go resounding through the building. A waste of unused passages and staircases in which to drop a comb upon a bedroom floor at night is to send a stealthy footfall on an errand through the house. A place where few people care to go about alone, where a maid screams if an ash drops from the fire, takes to crying at all times and seasons, becomes the victim of a low disorder of the spirits, and gives warning and departs.
对于其他人来说，林肯郡对沃伦尼亚的生活就是一片杂草丛生的大房子，望着窗外的树木，叹息着，绞着双手，低着头，把眼泪洒在窗玻璃上，单调而压抑。一座宏伟的迷宫，与其说是一个古老的人类家族及其幽灵般的肖像的财产，不如说是一个古老的回声和雷鸣家族的财产，每一次声音都从他们的数百个坟墓中发出，并在整个建筑中回响。晚上把梳子扔在卧室地板上，浪费未使用的通道和楼梯，就像在房子里发出悄悄的脚步声。一个很少有人愿意独自走动的地方，那里的女仆如果有灰烬从火中掉下来就会尖叫，在任何时候和任何季节都会哭泣，成为精神低落紊乱的受害者，发出警告并离开。

Thus Chesney Wold. With so much of itself abandoned to darkness and vacancy; with so little change under the summer shining or the wintry lowering; so sombre and motionless always—no flag flying now by day, no rows of lights sparkling by night; with no family to come and go, no visitors to be the souls of pale cold shapes of rooms, no stir of life about it—passion and pride, even to the stranger’s eye, have died away from the place in Lincolnshire and yielded it to dull repose.
因此切斯尼沃尔德。其自身的大部分都被遗弃在黑暗和空虚之中；在夏季的阳光照耀下或在冬季的低垂下变化如此之小；总是那么阴沉、一动不动——现在白天没有旗帜飘扬，夜晚也没有一排排闪烁的灯光；没有家人来来去去，没有来访者成为苍白冰冷的房间的灵魂，周围没有任何生机——即使在陌生人看来，激情和骄傲也已经从林肯郡的这个地方消失了，并屈服于它。沉闷的休息。

CHAPTER LXVII
第十六章


The Close of Esther’s Narrative
以斯帖叙述的结尾

Full seven happy years I have been the mistress of Bleak House. The few words that I have to add to what I have written are soon penned; then I and the unknown friend to whom I write will part for ever. Not without much dear remembrance on my side. Not without some, I hope, on his or hers.
我当《荒凉山庄》的女主人已经整整七年快乐的时光了。我要补充的几句话很快就写下来了；那么我和我写信的那个不知名的朋友将永远分离。我这边也有很多美好的回忆。我希望，他或她的身上并非没有一些。

They gave my darling into my arms, and through many weeks I never left her. The little child who was to have done so much was born before the turf was planted on its father’s grave. It was a boy; and I, my husband, and my guardian gave him his father’s name.
他们把我的爱人投入我的怀抱，几个星期以来我从未离开过她。这个原本要做这么多事情的小孩子在父亲的坟墓上铺上草皮之前就出生了。那是一个男孩；我、我的丈夫和我的监护人给了他父亲的名字。

The help that my dear counted on did come to her, though it came, in the eternal wisdom, for another purpose. Though to bless and restore his mother, not his father, was the errand of this baby, its power was mighty to do it. When I saw the strength of the weak little hand and how its touch could heal my darling’s heart and raised hope within her, I felt a new sense of the goodness and the tenderness of God.
我亲爱的人所指望的帮助确实来到了她的身边，尽管这是出于永恒的智慧，是为了另一个目的。虽然这个婴儿的任务是祝福和恢复他的母亲，而不是他的父亲，但它的力量是强大的。当我看到那只虚弱的小手的力量，以及它的触摸如何治愈我亲爱的心并在她内心燃起希望时，我对上帝的良善和温柔有了新的感觉。

They throve, and by degrees I saw my dear girl pass into my country garden and walk there with her infant in her arms. I was married then. I was the happiest of the happy.
它们茁壮成长，渐渐地，我看到我亲爱的女儿走进了我的乡村花园，怀里抱着她的婴儿走在那里。那时我已经结婚了。我是最幸福的一个。

It was at this time that my guardian joined us and asked Ada when she would come home.
就在这个时候，我的监护人加入了我们，并问艾达什么时候回家。

‘Both houses are your home, my dear,’ said he, ‘but the older Bleak House claims priority. When you and my boy are strong enough to do it, come and take possession of your home.’
“亲爱的，这两栋房子都是你的家，”他说，“但旧的荒凉山庄拥有优先权。当你和我的孩子足够强大时，就来占领你的家吧。

Ada called him ‘her dearest cousin, John.’ But he said, no, it must be guardian now. He was her guardian henceforth, and the boy’s; and he had an old association with the name. So she called him guardian, and has called him guardian ever since. The children know him by no other name. I say the children; I have two little daughters.
艾达称他为“她最亲爱的表弟约翰”。但他说，不，现在必须是监护人。从此以后，他就是她的监护人，也是男孩的监护人。他对这个名字有着由来已久的联想。所以她称他为监护人，并且从那时起就一直称他为监护人。孩子们只知道他的名字。我说的是孩子们；我有两个小女儿。

It is difficult to believe that Charley (round-eyed still, and not at all grammatical) is married to a miller in our neighbourhood; yet so it is; and even now, looking up from my desk as I write early in the morning at my summer window, I see the very mill beginning to go round. I hope the miller will not spoil Charley; but he is very fond of her, and Charley is rather vain of such a match, for he is well to do and was in great request. So far as my small maid is concerned, I might suppose time to have stood for seven years as still as the mill did half an hour ago, since little Emma, Charley’s sister, is exactly what Charley used to be. As to Tom, Charley’s brother, I am really afraid to say what he did at school in ciphering, but I think it was decimals. He is apprenticed to the miller, whatever it was, and is a good bashful fellow, always falling in love with somebody and being ashamed of it.
很难相信查理（仍然睁着圆眼睛，完全不合语法）嫁给了我们附近的一个磨坊主；但事实就是如此；即使是现在，当我清晨在夏日的窗户前写作时，从办公桌上抬起头来，我仍然看到磨坊开始运转。我希望磨坊主不要宠坏查理；但他非常喜欢她，查理对这样的婚姻感到相当自负，因为他做得很好，而且要求很高。就我的小女仆而言，我可能会认为时间已经静止了七年，就像半小时前的磨坊一样，因为查理的妹妹小艾玛和以前的查理一模一样。至于查理的弟弟汤姆，我真的不敢说他在学校学过什么密码，但我认为那是小数。不管是什么，他都是磨坊主的学徒，是个害羞的好家伙，总是爱上某人并为此感到羞耻。

Caddy Jellyby passed her very last holidays with us and was a dearer creature than ever, perpetually dancing in and out of the house with the children as if she had never given a dancing-lesson in her life. Caddy keeps her own little carriage now instead of hiring one, and lives full two miles further westward than Newman Street. She works very hard, her husband (an excellent one) being lame and able to do very little. Still, she is more than contented and does all she has to do with all her heart. Mr. Jellyby spends his evenings at her new house with his head against the wall as he used to do in her old one. I have heard that Mrs. Jellyby was understood to suffer great mortification from her daughter’s ignoble marriage and pursuits, but I hope she got over it in time. She has been disappointed in Borrioboola-Gha, which turned out a failure in consequence of the king of Boorioboola wanting to sell everybody—who survived the climate—for rum, but she has taken up with the rights of women to sit in Parliament, and Caddy tells me it is a mission involving more correspondence than the old one. I had almost forgotten Caddy’s poor little girl. She is not such a mite now, but she is deaf and dumb. I believe there never was a better mother than Caddy, who learns, in her scanty intervals of leisure, innumerable deaf and dumb arts to soften the affliction of her child.
球童杰利比和我们一起度过了她最后的假期，她比以往任何时候都更加可爱，她总是和孩子们一起在房子里进进出出，仿佛她一生中从未上过舞蹈课。凯迪现在拥有自己的小马车，而不是租一辆，她住在比纽曼街更西两英里的地方。她工作非常努力，而她的丈夫（一位优秀的丈夫）却是个瘸子，能做的事情很少。尽管如此，她还是很满足，全心全意地做着自己该做的事。杰利比先生晚上在她的新房子里头靠在墙上，就像他以前在她的旧房子里那样。我听说杰利比夫人因女儿不光彩的婚姻和追求而蒙受了极大的屈辱，但我希望她能及时克服。她对 Borrioboola-Gha 感到失望，因为 Boorioboola 国王想把所有在气候中幸存下来的人卖给朗姆酒，结果失败了，但她已经开始致力于妇女在议会中的权利，并且凯迪告诉我，这是一项比旧任务涉及更多信件的任务。我几乎忘记了凯迪可怜的小女孩。她现在不是什么小东西了，但她又聋又哑。我相信没有比凯蒂更好的母亲了，她在有限的闲暇时间里学会了无数又聋又哑的技巧来减轻孩子的痛苦。
