As if I were never to have done with Caddy, I am reminded here of Peepy and old Mr. Turveydrop. Peepy is in the Custom House, and doing extremely well. Old Mr. Turveydrop, very apoplectic, still exhibits his deportment about town, still enjoys himself in the old manner, is still believed in in the old way. He is constant in his patronage of Peepy and is understood to have bequeathed him a favourite French clock in his dressing-room—which is not his property.
就好像我永远不会和凯蒂告别一样，我在这里想起了皮皮和老特维德罗普先生。皮皮在海关，而且表现得非常好。老特维德罗普先生，非常中风，仍然表现出他在城里的举止，仍然以旧的方式享受自己，仍然以旧的方式被相信。他始终如一地赞助皮比，据了解，他在更衣室里遗赠了他最喜欢的法国钟表，但这不是他的财产。

With the first money we saved at home, we added to our pretty house by throwing out a little growlery expressly for my guardian, which we inaugurated with great splendour the next time he came down to see us. I try to write all this lightly, because my heart is full in drawing to an end, but when I write of him, my tears will have their way.
我们用家里存下的第一笔钱，专门为我的监护人大肆咆哮，为我们的漂亮房子增添了色彩。当他下次来看我们时，我们为它举行了盛大的落成典礼。我试着轻描淡写地写下这一切，因为我的心已经快要结束了，但当我写到他的时候，我的眼泪就会流出来。

I never look at him but I hear our poor dear Richard calling him a good man. To Ada and her pretty boy, he is the fondest father; to me he is what he has ever been, and what name can I give to that? He is my husband’s best and dearest friend, he is our children’s darling, he is the object of our deepest love and veneration. Yet while I feel towards him as if he were a superior being, I am so familiar with him and so easy with him that I almost wonder at myself. I have never lost my old names, nor has he lost his; nor do I ever, when he is with us, sit in any other place than in my old chair at his side, Dame Trot, Dame Durden, Little Woman—all just the same as ever; and I answer, ‘Yes, dear guardian!’ just the same.
我从不看他，但我听到我们可怜的亲爱的理查德称他为好人。对于艾达和她漂亮的男孩来说，他是最慈爱的父亲；对我来说，他就是他曾经的样子，我可以给它起什么名字呢？他是我丈夫最好、最亲爱的朋友，他是我们孩子们的宠儿，他是我们最深爱和尊敬的对象。然而，虽然我觉得他是一个高人一等的人，但我对他是如此熟悉，对他如此轻松，以至于我几乎对自己感到惊讶。我从未失去我的旧名字，他也没有失去他的旧名字；当他和我们在一起时，我也不会坐在他身边的旧椅子上，特洛特夫人、杜登夫人、小妇人——都和以前一样；我还是回答：“是的，亲爱的监护人！”

I have never known the wind to be in the east for a single moment since the day when he took me to the porch to read the name. I remarked to him once that the wind seemed never in the east now, and he said, no, truly; it had finally departed from that quarter on that very day.
自从他带我到门廊念名字那天起，我就从来没有一刻知道风是东风。有一次我对他说，现在风似乎不再是东边了，他说，不，确实如此。它终于在那天离开了那个季度。

I think my darling girl is more beautiful than ever. The sorrow that has been in her face—for it is not there now—seems to have purified even its innocent expression and to have given it a diviner quality. Sometimes when I raise my eyes and see her in the black dress that she still wears, teaching my Richard, I feel—it is difficult to express—as if it were so good to know that she remembers her dear Esther in her prayers.
我觉得我亲爱的女儿比以前更漂亮了。她脸上一直流露出的悲伤——因为现在已经不存在了——似乎甚至净化了她那无辜的表情，并赋予它一种神圣的品质。有时，当我抬起眼睛，看到她仍然穿着黑色连衣裙，教导我的理查德时，我感到——很难表达——仿佛知道她在祈祷中记得她亲爱的以斯帖是多么高兴。

I call him my Richard! But he says that he has two mamas, and I am one.
我称他为我的理查德！但他说他有两个妈妈，而我是其中之一。

We are not rich in the bank, but we have always prospered, and we have quite enough. I never walk out with my husband but I hear the people bless him. I never go into a house of any degree but I hear his praises or see them in grateful eyes. I never lie down at night but I know that in the course of that day he has alleviated pain and soothed some fellow-creature in the time of need. I know that from the beds of those who were past recovery, thanks have often, often gone up, in the last hour, for his patient ministration. Is not this to be rich?
我们的银行并不富有，但我们一直很富裕，而且我们已经足够了。我从来没有和我的丈夫一起出去过，但我听到人们祝福他。我从来没有走进过任何级别的房子，但我听到他的赞美或看到他们感激的眼神。我晚上从不躺下，但我知道在这一天的过程中，他减轻了痛苦，并在需要时安抚了一些同胞。我知道，在过去的一个小时里，那些已经康复的人在病床上常常对他的耐心服务表示感谢。这不是要发财吗？

The people even praise me as the doctor’s wife. The people even like me as I go about, and make so much of me that I am quite abashed. I owe it all to him, my love, my pride! They like me for his sake, as I do everything I do in life for his sake.
人们还称赞我是医生的妻子。当我到处走动时，人们甚至喜欢我，并且对我如此评价，让我感到非常羞愧。我把这一切都归功于他，我的爱，我的骄傲！他们因为他而喜欢我，就像我一生中所做的一切都是为了他。

A night or two ago, after bustling about preparing for my darling and my guardian and little Richard, who are coming to-morrow, I was sitting out in the porch of all places, that dearly memorable porch, when Allan came home. So he said, ‘My precious little woman, what are you doing here?’ And I said, ‘The moon is shining so brightly, Allan, and the night is so delicious, that I have been sitting here thinking.’
一两个晚上前，在忙着为明天要来的我的亲爱的、我的监护人和小理查德做准备之后，当艾伦回家时，我坐在所有地方的门廊上，那个令人难忘的门廊上。于是他说，“我亲爱的小女人，你在这里做什么？”我说，“艾伦，月亮如此明亮，夜晚如此美妙，我一直坐在这里思考。”

‘What have you been thinking about, my dear?’ said Allan then.
“亲爱的，你在想什么？”艾伦问道。

‘How curious you are!’ said I. ‘I am almost ashamed to tell you, but I will. I have been thinking about my old looks—such as they were.’
“你真好奇！”我说，“我几乎不好意思告诉你，但我会的。”我一直在思考我以前的样子——就像它们本来的样子。

‘And what have you been thinking about THEM, my busy bee?’ said Allan.
“我的勤劳的蜜蜂，你一直在想什么？”艾伦说。

‘I have been thinking that I thought it was impossible that you COULD have loved me any better, even if I had retained them.’
“我一直在想，即使我保留了它们，你也不可能更好地爱我。”

‘‘Such as they were’?’ said Allan, laughing.
“就像他们一样？”艾伦笑着说。

‘Such as they were, of course.’
“当然，就像他们本来的样子。”

‘My dear Dame Durden,’ said Allan, drawing my arm through his, ‘do you ever look in the glass?’
“我亲爱的德登夫人，”艾伦拉着我的手臂说道，“你看过镜子吗？”

‘You know I do; you see me do it.’
'你知道我会的;你看我这样做。

‘And don’t you know that you are prettier than you ever were?’
“你难道不知道你比以前更漂亮了吗？”

‘I did not know that; I am not certain that I know it now. But I know that my dearest little pets are very pretty, and that my darling is very beautiful, and that my husband is very handsome, and that my guardian has the brightest and most benevolent face that ever was seen, and that they can very well do without much beauty in me—even supposing—.
'我不知道;我不确定我现在是否知道。但我知道我最亲爱的小宠物很漂亮，我的宝贝很漂亮，我的丈夫很英俊，我的监护人有一张有史以来最明亮、最仁慈的脸，他们可以很好地我身上没有多少美感——即使假设——。
